That's where there has been enough of a sell-off that some stocks are worth buying, and Leydon saidin a radio interview that there are select financials - notably Bank of America and American Express - that are at that point now. loading... title: Financial services stocks have reached 'capitulation'

content: Pre-open moves A strong start took shape before data on new-home sales. Other data showed U.S. economic growth accelerated in the second quarter to the fastest pace in more than a year, while jobless claims fell to their lowest level since early May. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets British Airways detailed a massive fleet purchase that favored Airbus' A380 superjumbo over Boeing for its largest planes. Strong auto, airline and construction sectors boosted Europe. Asian markets rallied anew, with highs set in Hong Kong, Singapore and Sydney. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Banc of America Securities downgraded Seattle-based coffee chain Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02% to sell from neutral, saying the inflection point on slower growth has been reached. Goldman Sachs upgraded Campbell Soup Co. CPB, -0.23% to neutral from sell, saying it believes the stock's current multiple reflects more realistic growth expectations. Bear Stearns upgraded private equity giant KKR Financial KFN to outperform from peer perform, saying the company has the brand name, the access and the liquidity to take advantage of what has become a less competitive environment for investment in its target assets. Standard & Poor's Ratings Services maintained its credit ratings for Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% saying the oil giant's $15 billion stock buyback and $20 billion capital-improvement plan won't affect its credit, given strong commodity prices. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest No. 1 retailer Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% is expanding its year-old $4 prescription drug program as it added 24 new prescriptions costing $4 each to cover treatments for medical problems including glaucoma, the company said. Wal-Mart also added a $9 birth control prescription, which it said will save women as much as $250 annually. Rite Aid Corp. RAD, +0.60% said its fiscal second-quarter loss widened, hurt by an increase in expenses related to the Brooks Eckerd acquisition. Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71% is planning to increase its staff by a third, with most of the expansion coming in Europe, according to a report in the Financial Times newspaper. FL Group, one of American Airlines' shareholders AMR, -4.53% said it wrote to the board of parent company AMR Corp., urging the company to consider strategic alternatives that it said would boost shareholder value. The alternatives include the separation of American Airlines' frequent-flyer loyalty program, AAdvantage, from the main business. British Airways Plc said it's splitting a multibillion order for new long-haul planes between Airbus and Boeing BA, +2.46% though it ended decades of loyalty to the U.S. manufacturer's 747 jumbo with a switch to the Airbus A380 double-decker. Home builder KB Home KBH, +2.60% swung to a fiscal third-quarter loss. Taser International Inc. TASR said three additional product liability lawsuits against the company were dismissed. Rodger Lawson, who in July returned to Fidelity Investments as president, this week launched the largest reorganization in the Boston-based company's history, the Boston Globe reported, citing an internal memo. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Wal-Mart, Rite Aid, Starbucks, Campbell Soup to feature

content: BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- John Buckingham, president of Al Frank Asset Management and editor of the Prudent Speculator newsletter, says investors need to go against the flow and find a reason to be optimistic during market downturns, namely the ability to buy quality stocks at a discount. In a radio interview with Chuck Jaffe, MarketWatch senior columnist, Buckingham discussed the importance of sticking with a discipline, particularly when markets get volatile and scary. Buckingham, whose discipline involves seeking stocks trading for no more than half of their fair value, put buy recommendations on Cypress Semiconductor CY, +2.05% Sanofi Aventis SNY, +0.30% and Pfizer PFE, +0.54% He described Thornburg Mortgage TMA Apple AAPL, +0.78% Medtronic MDT, +2.24% Johnson Controls JCI, +2.77% and US Steel X, +4.92% as holds and made one sell recommendation: Taser International TASR Listen to the highlights of Your Money with Chuck Jaffe. Jaffe's radio show regularly features reviews of stocks and mutual funds suggested by MarketWatch readers; to request a stock or mutual fund for review, send your name, hometown and the ticker symbols that interest you to Chuck Jaffe. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’
title: Stay disciplined to find quality stocks at a discount

In a radio interview, Buckingham discussed the importance of sticking with a discipline, particularly when markets get volatile and scary. loading... content: Crane posts higher profit, raises quarterly dividend (5:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Crane Co. CR, +2.29% on Monday posted a second-quarter profit of $45.7 million, or 75 cents a share, up slightly from $44.5 million, or 71 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding a one-time tax related item, profit would have come in at 84 cents a share. Sales rose to $660.9 million, from $558.2 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had expected earnings of 78 cents a share on sales of $647 million. The company, which makes products for aerospace and other industrial customers, raised its full-year forecast to a range of $2.90 to $3.05 a share from $2.80 to $2.95 a share. Crane, in a separate release ahead of the earnings report, raised its dividend 20% to 18 cents a share. Equifax quarterly profit, revenue rise (5:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Equifax Inc. EFX, -1.03% late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $70.1 million, or 51 cents a share, up slightly from $69.6 million, or 53 cents a share, during the year-ago period. There were 138.6 million shares outstanding during the quarter compared with 130.4 million last year. The Atlanta-based transaction-processor and information management company said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $454.5 million from $387.7 million. Adjusted earnings, which excluded the impact of several litigation-related matters, among other items, were 57 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 56 cents on revenue of $455 million. Reinsurance Group of America quarterly net rises 22% (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Reinsurance Group of America RGA, -0.50% said late Monday that second-quarter net income came in at $77.5 million, or $1.20 a share, up 22% from a year earlier when the life reinsurer made $63.6 million, or $1.01 a share. Operating income, which excludes net realized investment gains and losses, was $84.6 million, or $1.31 a share, the company added. RGA was expected to earn $1.25 a share, according to a Thomson Financial survey of six analysts. Second-quarter net premiums rose 12% to $1.21 billion. Hexcel's quarterly profit falls; revenue up 5.8% (5:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hexcel Corp. HXL, +0.67% late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $8.8 million, or 9 cents a share, down from $17.6 million, or 19 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Income from continuing operations during the quarter came in at 18 cents a share. Revenue for the period ended June 30 rose 5.8% to $289.8 million from $274 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 17 cents on revenue of $295.8 million. The Stamford, Conn.-based structural materials company now expects 2007 sales growth in the high end of is previously forecasted range of 5% to 10%. Pactiv rises 1% on price increases, Prairie Packaging deal (4:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pactiv Corp. PTV said late Monday net income for the second quarter rose to $70 million, or 53 cents a share, from $69 million, or 49 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Earnings from continuing operations totaled 52 cents a share. Sales rose 10% to $828 million, helped by its acquisition of Prairie Packaging. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 48 cents a share and sales of $787 million. The maker of Hefty bags said sales should rise 11% to 13% for the year. It anticipates making 41 cents a share to 45 cents in the third quarter and $1.82 a share to $1.92 for the year, including 2-4 cents from the Prairie Packaging purchase. Analyst forecast Pactiv will make 45 cents in the third quarter and $1.85 for the year. Shares rose 1.9% to $32.07 by the close of normal trading. Texas Instruments reports lower profit, sales (4:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Texas Instruments Inc. TXN, +1.94% late Monday reported a weaker second-quarter profit amid lower demand for its chips used in cell phones and other electronics. TI said net income was $610 million, or 42 cents a share. In last year's same period, the company earned $2.39 billion, or $1.50 a share, which included a favorable tax refund and royalty settlement. Sales fell 7% to $3.42 billion. The results were in line with analysts' forecasts, who estimated TI would earn 42 cents a share on revenue of $3.4 billion. Dallas, Tex.-based TI makes chips used in phones, telecommunications equipment, calculators, and high-definition televisions. Its biggest customer is Nokia Corp., the world's No. 1 phone maker. TI shares, trading around five-year highs, closed at $38.18, up 17 cents. Lincare quarterly profit rises 8% (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Lincare Holdings Inc. LNCR late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $56 million, or 63 cents a share, up 8% from $51.9 million, or 52 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Clearwater, Fla.-based provider of home oxygen equipment and other respiratory therapy services said revenue for the three months ended June 30 rose to $397.1 million from $350.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 62 cents on revenue of $394 million. Lincare also said it added nine new operating centers during the quarter derived from internal development. Plum Creek net income slips 3%; reduces full-year outlook (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Plum Creek Timber Co. PCL, +0.00% said late Monday that it earned $60 million, or 34 cents a share, in the second quarter, down from $62 million, or 34 cents, in the year-ago quarter. Sales at the Seattle-based land and timber company rose nearly 4% to $395 million. The most recent quarter's income included a $2 million gain from selling a mineral asset, bringing profit from continuing operations to 33 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast earnings of 34 cents a share, on average, and sales of $373 million. Plum Creek said it cut the high end of its 2007 earnings outlook by a nickel, to $1.40 to $1.55 a share, based on its performance in the first half and expectations of a "relatively flat housing market" during the second half. Plum Creek shares fell 0.8% to $42.09 by the close of normal trading. Brown & Brown quarterly profit rises 17% (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Brown & Brown. BRO, -0.27% late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $52 million, or 37 cents a share, up 17% from $44.4 million, or 32 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Daytona Beach, Fla.-based insurance company said revenue in the three months ended June 30 rose to $246.6 million from $220.8 million in the comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 32 cents on revenue of $237 million. The results include a pretax gain of $9.8 million from the sale of the remaining shares of the long-term investment in Rock-Tenn Co., the company said. PartnerRe quarterly net income rises 35% (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- PartnerRe Ltd. PRE, -1.92% said late Monday that second-quarter net income came in at $105 million, or $1.66 a share, up 35% from a year earlier when the reinsurer made $77.5 million, or $1.20 a share. Operating earnings, which exclude net after-tax realized investment gains and losses and are calculated after payment of preferred dividends, were $139.2 million, or $2.39 a share. PartnerRe was expected to make $2.49 a share, according to the average estimate of 16 analysts in a Thomson Financial poll. Net premiums written climbed 10% to $898.7 million in the period, PartnerRe also reported. "Pricing declines are being broadly offset by continued favorable loss trends," Chief Executive Patrick Thiele said. "We are more sanguine about the outlook for 2007 premiums than we were at the start of the year." Matrixx Initiatives' quarterly loss narrows (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Matrixx Initiatives, Inc. MTXX, +0.24% late Monday reported a fiscal firs-quarter net loss of $1.06 million, or 11 cents a share, versus a year-ago net loss of $1.89 million, or 19 cents a share. The Phoenix-based healthcare products company said revenue in the quarter ended June 30 rose to $8.57 million from $8.21 million in the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share loss of 10 cents on revenue of $8.87 million. For fiscal 2008, the company still expects revenue to increase 5% to 15% from the previous year and expects net income in a range of $9.3 million to $10.8 million. Netflix profit rises 50%; net subscribers decline (4:24 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Online DVD rental pioneer Netflix Inc. NFLX, +3.35% said its second-quarter profit rose 50% on a gain related to a patent lawsuit settlement, even as net subscribers decreased. Netflix said it earned $25.6 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with a profit of $17 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Excluding the gain, stock compensation expense and other items, Netflix would have earned $23.1 million, or 33 cents a share, in the latest three months. Revenue rose 27% to $303.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a profit of 23 cents a share on revenue of $307.7 million. Netflix ended the quarter with 6.74 million subscribers, compared with 5.17 million subscribers at the end of the second quarter in 2006. However, net subscriber change was a decrease of 55,000, compared to an increase of 303,000 in the same quarter in 2006. Gross subscriber additions totaled 1.03 million, a 4% decline from 1.07 million gross subscriber additions a year earlier. Churn, or the rate of subscriber cancellations, rose to 4.6% from 4.3% a year ago. In accordance with its plan to reduce marketing spending amid increased competition from rival Blockbuster Inc. BBI, +4.00% Netflix cut its forecasts for year-end subscribers and earnings per share. It now sees 2007 subscribers totaling 6.8 million to 7.3 million, down from 7.3 million to 7.8 million. It also anticipates earnings of 62 cents to 76 cents a share, down from its earlier estimate of 76 cents to 83 cents a share. Altera quarterly profit rises 4% as revenue falls (4:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Altera Corp. ALTR, +1.98% late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $80.5 million, or 22 cents a share, up 4% from $77.3 million, or 21 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The San Jose, Calif.-based chipmaker said revenue fell to $319.7 million from $334.1 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 19 cents on revenue of $313 million. Additionally, Altera said it's negotiating a long-term credit facility of up to $750 million and may use some of the proceeds to finance a share buyback. For the third quarter, the company said it expects sequential sales growth of flat to up 3%. American Express' second-quarter profit rises 12% (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% late Monday reported second-quarter net earnings of $1.06 billion, or 88 cents a share, up 12% from $945 million, or 76 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The New York-based financial-services company said consolidated revenue net of interest expense for the three months ended June 30 rose 9% to $7.13 billion from $6.54 billion in the comparable period last year. Return on average equity was 37.5% versus 29.8% a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had forecast, on average, a per-share profit of 86 cents on revenue of $7.49 billion. PetMed Express' shares up as first-quarter profit rises (1:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- PetMed Express Inc. PETS, -1.51% shares rallied in Monday afternoon trade, rising 10% to $15.24. The Pompano Beach, Fla.-based pet pharmacy chain reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings of $6.18 million, or 25 cents a share, up 30% from $4.75 million, or 20 cents a share diluted per share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 16.5% to $59 million from $50.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 22 cents on revenue of $60.6 million. Astec Industries' shares rally as quarterly profit rises (1:48 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Astec Industries Inc.'s ASTE, +1.23% shares surged 18% to $56.42 in Monday afternoon trade after the Chattanooga, Tenn.-based maker of building equipment reported second-quarter net earnings of $18.5 million, or 83 cents a share, up from $12.4 million, or 56 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 18.3% to $226.4 million from $191.3 million in the comparable period last year. "The international demand has steadily increased throughout 2007 which should be indicative of strong international sales for the third and fourth quarter of 2007 compared to 2006," said Don Brock, chairman and chief executive, in a statement. GigaBeam's shares soar on new purchase order (12:40 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- GigaBeam Corp.'s GGBM shares more than doubled in value, adding $3.58 to $6.38 in Monday afternoon trade. After Friday's closing bell, the Durham, N.C.-based company said it has received purchase orders for 24 additional WiFiber links from One Velocity Inc, a wireless telecom provider for the western United States. Tom Online swings to a second-quarter loss (11:18 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Tom Online Inc. TOMO on Monday reported a second-quarter loss attributable to common shareholders of $9.56 million, of 18 cents per American Depositary share, versus earnings of $11.8 million, or 21.8 cents per ADS, in the same period in 2006. Excluding a goodwill impairment charge, Tom Online lost 5.2 cents per ADS in the second quarter of 2007. The Chinese wireless Internet company said revenue in the three months ended June 30 fell 30% to $34.4 million from $49.4 million in the comparable period last year. Tom Online shares fell 30 cents to $13.84 in Monday morning trade. Gentex hits 3-yr high; profit jumps on overseas business (11:04 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Gentex Corp. GNTX, +1.86% shares on Monday hit a new three-year high of $22.19, up almost 6%, after the rearview-mirror maker said second-quarter profit climbed 14% to $31 million thanks to increased overseas business and sales of higher priced products. Earnings per share rose to 22 cents from 18 cents a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were looking for a profit of 21 cents a share. Revenue increased 15% to a record $163.5 million. Netflix shares sink as company cuts prices (10:34 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Netflix Inc. [s; nflx] shares tumbled 12% Monday, dropping to $17.30, after the online movie rental company announced that it is lowering the price of two of its subscription plans. Los Gatos, Calif.-based Netflix said it's cutting its $9.99 monthly plan to $8.99, and its $17.99 monthly plan to $16.99. The $4.99 and $13.99 monthly plans remain unchanged. Netflix is scheduled to report its quarterly results after the market closes on Monday. Taser swings to a profit; shares rally (10:28 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR shares rose 5.7% to $18.12 in Monday morning trade after the maker of Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of stun guns said it swung to a second-quarter net profit of $3.7 million, or 6 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $9.61 million, or 15 cents a share. Taser said revenue increased 59% to $25.9 million from $16.2 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 4 cents on revenue of $21.3 million. Separately, Strength in Merck buoys drug shares (9:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Pharmaceutical shares rose in Monday morning trading, led by strength in drug maker Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% Merck reported an increase in quarterly profit and revenue and raised its forecast for the year, pushing shares up 4.9% in early dealings. Shares of Schering-Plough Corp. SGP, -1.28% climbed 2.5% to $32.27 after it reported robust quarterly results, helped by strength in drugs such as Remicade and Nasonex. The Amex Pharmaceutical Index $DRG was up fractionally at 353.03, while the Amex Biotechnology Index $BTK slipped marginally to 782.94. Baxter sees 'promising' early results in influenza vaccine (9:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Baxter International Inc. BAX, +1.86% on Monday announced "promising" initial study data for its candidate, Vero cell-based seasonal influenza vaccine, which is now undergoing a Phase I/II clinical trial in Europe. The preliminary data indicate that the vaccine-induced strong antibody responses and good tolerability in all study populations. The Phase I/II study data show that Baxter's seasonal candidate vaccine, which was developed using a split virus process, was effective in inducing protective levels of antibodies for all three seasonal virus strains in about 940 subjects divided between the ages of 18-49 and 50 years of age and older. Arch Coal 2nd-quarter EPS 26c vs 48c (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)--Arch Coal Inc. ACI, -0.18% said Monday that its second-quarter net income of $37.5 million, or 26 cents per share, down from $69.6 million, or 48 cents, in the year-earlier period. A Thomson Financial analysts poll had predicted of 27 cents. Arch Coal's revenue for the quarter was $598.7 million, compared with $637.5 million the year before, while operating profit was $53.9 million, down from $99.8 million. The company cited a weak U.S. coal market and higher unit costs from planned volume reductions. It also reduced its estimate for full 2007 earnings, due to high power generator stockpile levels and weak prices. Merck profit rises, boosts year view (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% on Monday said second-quarter profit rose to $1.68 billion or 77 cents a share, from $1.5 billion, or 69 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding restructuring charges, it earned 82 cents a share. Sales rose to $6.11 billion from $5.77 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to earn 72 cents a share on revenue of $5.77 billion, according to Thomson Financial. Merck raised its forecast for the year to a range of $3 to $3.10 a share, excluding restructuring charges, and forecast its reported earnings per share in a range of $2.80 to $2.95 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial expect it to earn $2.94 a share for the year, on average. Wal-Mart plans price cuts on 16,000 items (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% on Monday said it will slash prices on 16,000 items this week, much of the discounted merchandise is back-to-school related. Also this week, Wal-Mart said it was launching an advertising campaign to address the importance of saving money as gas prices remain high during the critical shopping season. Families with school-age children are expected to spend on average $563 this year on back to school, Wal-Mart said, citing BIGresearch. The Bentonville, Ark.-based retailer's new price campaign aims to make a big difference in savings -- 10% to even 50% -- on key back-to-school items. Schering-Plough profit climbs, tops forecast (7:04 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% said its second-quarter profit more than doubled to $517 million, or 34 cents a share, with sales up 13% to $3.18 billion. Excluding charges of $106 million from licensing and from buying the Organon human health business and Intervet animal health business this quarter and last year's restructuring charges, and its profit would've rose to 41 cents a share from 25 cents a share. Including its 50% share in a cholesterol joint venture with Merck, and its sales would've climbed 15% to $3.8 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting earnings of 35 cents a share on revenue of $3.07 billion. Teleflex to acquire Arrow International for $2 billion (6:59 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Teleflex Inc. TFX, +0.74% has agreed to acquire Arrow International Inc. ARRO in a $2 billion transaction, the companies said. Terms call for Limerick, Pa.-based Teleflex to pay $45.50 a share in cash for Arrow, implying a buyout premium of about 20% over the Friday closing price of $37.79 for Arrow's common shares. "We expect the transaction to be meaningfully accretive to Teleflex's earnings by 2009," said Jeffrey Black, chairman and chief executive of Teleflex, a diversified company for which medical technology will become its largest source of revenue and profitability as a result of the deal for Reading, Pa.-based Arrow. It's anticipated that the transaction will close by the fourth quarter and will be dilutive to Teleflex's earnings for 2007. Excluding any financial impact frmo the deal, Teleflex confirmed its full-year target for earnings from continuing operations before restructuring charges and losses in a range of $4.05 to $4.25 a share. Journal Communications 2nd-quarter net off 7.2% (6:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Journal Communications, JRN the Milwaukee media company, reported second-quarter earnings fell 7.2% on 4.3% lower revenue. Earnings fell to $14.2 million from $15.2 million in the year-earlier period. Earnings per share were flat at 21 cents; shares outstanding fell 5.7% to 68.2 million. The latest results included a $1.4 million gain related to the divestitures of its Ohio, New England and Louisiana community-publishing clusters. Earnings from continuing operations were 19 cents against 17 cents. A survey of four analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 20 cents. Revenue fell to $147.5 million from $154 million. The average estimate of three analysts surveyed by Thomson was $161 million. Cal-Maine swings to profit on higher egg prices (6:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Egg producer Cal-Maine Foods Inc. CALM, -4.17% said Monday that it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter net profit of $18.3 million, or 77 cents a share, from a loss of $210,000, or 1 cents a share, a year earlier. Net sales for the period rose 31% to $169.9 million. The group said its results reflected strong egg prices, aided by increased demand from a strong export market. Cal-Maine Foods said feed prices remain high, supported by demand for corn from ethanol producers. It added that strong egg prices have continued into the first quarter of fiscal 2008. Transformers helps power Hasbro's quarterly growth (6:43 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Hasbro Inc. HAS, +0.57% reported second-quarter net earnings $4.8 million, or 3 cents a share, down from $27.1 million, or 7 cents, earned in the same period during 2006. The Pawtucket, R.I.-based toymaker's quarterly revenue totaled $691.4 million, up 31% from the prior year's $527.8 million. Excluding a final mark-to-market expense related to the company's repurchase of warrants held by Lucasfilm Ltd. and Lucas Licensing Ltd., Hasbro said it would have earned 24 cents a share for the latest quarter. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 18 cents a share on revenue of $648 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. Hasbro said its quarterly growth was driven in part by shipments of Transformers and Marvel movie-related products. Quarterly operating margin widened to 8.1% from 3.9% in the year-ago second quarter. Hasbro in May paid $200 million in cash and closed the repurchase of all of the Lucasfilm and Lucas Licensing warrants. Shares of Hasbro lost 15 cents to end Friday's trading at $32.56. Halliburton 2nd-quarter net doubles; operations exceed view (6:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Halliburton Co., HAL, +1.93% the Houston oil-services company, reported second-quarter net income more than doubled, reflecting a special gain, on 20% higher revenue. Earnings reached $1.53 billion, or $1.62 a share, from $591 million, or 55 cents, in the year-earlier period. The latest figure reflects a gain of $933 million from the separation of KBR Inc. Earnings from continuing operations were 63 cents against 47 cents. A survey of analysts by Thomson Financial produced a consensus estimate of 56 cents for the quarter. Revenue reached $3.74 billion from $3.12 billion. Thomson's survey was looking for $3.51 billion. The quarter was driven by increased energy-services business, particularly in the Eastern Hemisphere, Halliburton said in a statement. RPM International posts profit; quarterly sales up 10.6% (6:13 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- RPM International Inc. RPM, +0.55% reported net income of nearly $84 million, or 65 cents a share, for the fourth quarter ended May 31, a reversal from the prior year's net loss of $142 million, or $1.21 a share. Revenue generated by the Medina, Ohio-based supplier of specialty coatings and sealants reached $1 billion from $909.1 million in the final three months of fiscal 2006, reflecting what RPM called "sharp improvements" posted by its industrial segment. Analysts, on average, had been looking for RPM to earn 60 cents a share on revenue of $969 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Financial. The company took a sizable asbestos-related charge against results for the year-earlier fourth quarter. For fiscal 2008, the company said it's projecting growth in both revenue and net income of about 8%. Shares of RPM added 8 cents to end Friday's trading at $24.30. Spread-better IG reports 35% profit rise (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. spread-better IG Group(UK:IGG)said fiscal-year pretax profit rose an in-line 35% to 68.9 million pounds, with revenue up 36% to 122 million pounds. The board has recommended a final dividend of 6.5p per share, making a total distribution for 2007 of 8.5p, an increase of 55%. It said the new fiscal year has "started well" with a new record monthly level of revenue for June. Autonomy quarterly profit climbs 73% (2:43 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. infrastructure software provider Autonomy Corp.(UK:AU)said second-quarter net income rose to $16.5 million, or 8 cents a share, from $9.54 million, or 5 cents a share, with revenue up 20% to $73.2 million. On an adjusted basis, it earned 10 cents a share after winning contracts from Deutsche Bank, Shell, Coca Cola, Fidelity and the governments of the U.S., U.K., Singapore and Greece. Autonomy had previously flagged that the results were ahead of consensus expectations. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr shares rose 5.7% to $18.12 in Monday morning trade after the maker of Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of stun guns said it swung to a second-quarter net profit of $3.7 million, or 6 cents a share, from a year-ago net loss of $9.61 million, or 15 cents a share. Taser said revenue increased 59% to $25.9 million from $16.2 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting, on average, a per-share profit of 4 cents on revenue of $21.3 million. Separately,
title: Taser swings to a profit; shares rally

content: Andrew O'Day says the Fed may have switched its view of what inflation pressure means, and the maker of the Blackberry reminds the market the iPhone doesn't run the bling show yet. loading...
title: Andrew O'Day's Money Markets & More for June 29

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr shares gained almost 5% Tuesday, rising to $12.70. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company said it has received an export purchase order from a foreign international law enforcement agency for 1,375 Taser X26 electronic control devices and related accessories. The order is expected to ship in the second quarter, the company said.
title: Taser reports large purchase order; shares rally

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Three wrongful death product liability cases have been dismissed against Taser International tasr the company said Monday. TASER said it did not pay compensation of any type, other than waiving counterclaims for costs and fees. The company added that it has not lost any product liability lawsuit.
title: Taser says three product liability cases dismissed

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Wednesday an Arizona court granted its motion for summary judgment in a training injury lawsuit. It's the 45th wrongful death or injury lawsuit that has been dismissed or judgment entered in favor of Taser, the company said.
title: Taser marks 45th win in wrongful death or injury lawsuits

content: LOS ANGELES (TechTrader) -- A stock market that looks to be topping at least short-term makes trading on the long side rather nerve-racking, but some stocks with extremely strong technicals should not be overlooked by traders with a longer time horizon. The following are seven stocks setting up for potential intermediate- to longer-term (three- to six-month) moves, and although they may be a bit short-term overbought and the market may be due for a retracement of the recent strong run-up, they're worth monitoring for potential entry points, especially on low-volume pullbacks to support. Taser Looking at the daily chart of Taser TASR going back two years, you can see a large narrowing coil-type pattern has formed. The stock recently has been thrusting back up to test the major declining tops lines and key overhead resistance. Technicals are surging and positively diverging, indicating this stock may want to break out and create a new intermediate- to long-term uptrend. Key overhead resistance at the October high at around 10.20 may be tested next. Beyond that a move above the February-April double-top up near 11.30 - 11.35, which is secondary resistance, on strong volume could get Taser going again. Targets would be the mid-teens intermediate-term and beyond that a move to the low-20s is possible. Short-term support is at 8. IDM Pharma IDM Pharma IDMI is another stock on the move. This junior biotech, which had been in a seven-year down-channel, exploded in early April through its declining tops line and out across the mid-year 2005 and spring 2006 resistance highs around 6.5. The stock then backed off and formed a very distinct pennant pattern, which was followed by another breakout last Friday, although the stock pulled back on Tuesday. The technicals, however, look great, and IDM could reach our initial trading target in the 13 range on an intermediate basis, with our longer-term projection in the 18-19 range. Short-term support is in the 6.5-7 zone. Research Frontiers Research Frontiers REFR, +1.88% also broke out recently, thrusting out of a two-year base pattern on strong volume at the very end of January. The stock followed through in early February and then backed off very bullishly on low volume, holding the 8.25 - 8.5 area. Since then, REFR has stair-stepped its way up to nominal new highs, reaching as high as 12.75 a couple weeks ago before backing off recently to retest the three-month rising bottoms line and the 40-day moving average. It did this on low volume with the technicals holding up very well. Beneath the current levels, there's strong short-term support around the 8.5 - 9 zone, but targets are 14, 17 and 20 short-, intermediate and longer-term. Nymox Pharmaceutical Breakouts of long bases on strong volume are frequent harbingers of continued price appreciation, and Nymox Pharmaceutical NYMX, -4.51% is another recent breakout stock. Earlier this year the stock broke out of a six-year basing pattern when it surged across key overhead resistance at around 5.75. After a secondary surge, the stock reached as high as 7 before backing and filling in a two-month large pennant-type pattern. That pennant was recently taken out with another surge late last week. The stock backed off at its March high and is currently consolidating, but the target at the top of the intermediate up-channel indicates a move to 9 is possible, my initial trading target. Secondary target is around the 13 area, and longer-term target in the high teens. Moving average and price support is around 5. Ceragon Networks Similarly, Ceragon Networks CRNT, +1.51% just last Friday had a strong price-volume surge out of a three-year base pattern, and as a result hit the top of its nine-month rising channel. It could easily back off and consolidate, but there's a very distinct possibility that the early 2004 highs around 8.75 will be tested in the not-too-distant future. That's my initial trading target, followed by a secondary target around 12 and longer-tem target at 18. Short-term support is around the 6 level and beneath that the trendline and moving averages would be between 5.5 and 5.75. Spectrum Control Spectrum Control SPEC, +21.36% built a nice multi-year base pattern from the low in 2001 through the spring of 2006, and although it had a nominal breakout last summer, it then pulled back in the fall and consolidated, testing the bottom of the nine-month rising channel before a January surge took it to more new multi-year highs. Another pullback/retest on low-volume occurred in February and March before a strong price-volume breakaway gap occurred, with a strong follow-through in early April. Since then the stock has been in a very positive bullish-looking consolidation, and I'm expecting support around the 12 - 12.25 area to hold. Should resistance at 14.85 be taken out, the stock should move to our initial trading target around 17. Intermediate target is in the 20 - 20.5 area, and longer-tem target in the mid-20s. Exide Technologies Finally, Exide Technologies XIDE had a long drop from 24.5 down to under 2.5 from the spring of 2004 to the spring of 2006, after which the stock then turned around, moved up, backed off and retested and formed an 18-month base pattern. In early January the stock began a move, followed by a four-day bullish flag pattern that then resulted in a very strong price-volume surge, taking the stock to new multi-year highs. A brief pullback held support and then the stock made higher highs. It's currently consolidating and near its moving average and trendline. XIDE should make it near the 12 range, my initial trading target, if it gets out over the 9.75 area. Secondary target is at 17 and longer-term target in the low 20s. Price support is at 8.25 - 8.5. Harry Boxer is a 35-year veteran technical analyst and author of TheTechTrader.com, a real-time diary of his intraday and intermediate-term trading ideas. He has no holdings in stocks mentioned in this article. (thetechtrader.com) Content found in The Guru's Corner is subject to the terms and conditions found in the Disclaimer and does not represent a recommendation of investment advice. Investors should seek the advice of a qualified investment professional prior to making any investment decisions. title: Seven technically strong stocks to buy on a dip

content: Robbins & Myers quarterly profit jumps; ups fiscal 2007 view (6:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Robbins & Myers Inc. RBN, +0.00% late Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $7.93 million, or 46 cents a share, up from $1.2 million, or 8 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Dayton, Ohio-based industrial-equipment maker posted revenue of $162.5 million vs. $150 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial had estimated second-quarter earnings of 47 cents a share. Robbins & Myers said it attributed the increase in earnings to strong sales growth and improvements in its cost structure. The company also raised its fiscal 2007 forecast on the strength of its backlog and continued favorable outlook. Robbins & Myers said it now expects fiscal 2007 per-share earnings of $2.20 to $2.40, up from its previous range of $2.10 to $2.30. Third-quarter earnings are expected to be from 52 cents to 62 cents a share, the company said. CryoCor: Audit includes 'going concern' qualification (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CryoCor Inc. CRYO, +40.32% late Tuesday said its annual report on Form 10-K included an audit opinion with a "going concern" qualification. A going-concern qualification is a statement from the company's independent registered public accounting firm expressing substantial doubt, based upon current financial resources, whether the company can continue to meet obligations over the next year. The San Diego-based medical device company said in the report that it has sufficient working capital to fund its operations until December 2007 and to pay off its existing debt, and that additional capital would be needed to fund operations into 2008. The company has previously disclosed it's pursuing several financing options. Pacer lowers 2007 earnings outlook; plans job cuts (4:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pacer International Inc. PACR late Tuesday said it now expects 2007 per-share earnings of $1.50 to $1.60, based on lower-than-forecasted revenue growth for the first quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial are currently estimating 2007 earnings of $1.98 a share on revenue of $1.99 billion. The Concord, Calif.-based provider of third-party logistics and freight transportation also said that it has authorized the purchase of up to an additional $100 million of its common shares. Pacer said it plans to consolidate some of its operations, reduce headcount and invest in information technology systems. These and other initiatives could result in restructuring charges and increased expenses during 2007 and lower per-share earnings for the year, the company said. Pacer said it expects to reduce ongoing costs by about $10 million annually through its consolidation efforts. Exfo Electro-Optical quarterly profit rises (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Exfo Electro-Optical Engineering Inc. EXFO, +1.20% (CA:EXF)late Tuesday reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $2.68 million, or 4 cents a share, up 97% from $1.37 million, or 2 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Quebec City-based maker of test and measurement products for the telecommunications industry rose 17.1% to $35.2 million from $30.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 6 cents on revenue of $36 million. Exfo forecast earnings of 3 cents to 6 cents a share on revenue of $36 million to $39 million. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 7 cents on revenue of $39 million. Oxford Industries quarterly profit falls 33% (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oxford Industries Inc. OXM, -1.25% after Tuesday's closing bell reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $9.74 million, or 54 cents a share, down 33% from $14.6 million, or 82 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The Atlanta-based apparel maker said revenue in the quarter ended March 2 fell 3.1% $266.6 million from $275.2 million in comparable period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial were expecting a per-share profit of 57 cents on revenue of $271 million. Oxford expects fiscal fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $1.07 to $1.14 to a share, or $1.00 to $1.07 excluding a gain on the sale of real property. Oxford had previously forecast earnings from continuing operations of $1.17 to $1.25 a share. The company now expects fourth-quarter revenue of $285 million to $295 million, compared with its previous forecast of $295 million to $305 million. Analysts are expecting per-share earnings of $1.21 a share on revenue of $301 million. Fuel Cell Energy rallies as 9 mln share offering debuts (11:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FuelCell Energy Inc. FCEL, +0.58% rallied 9% to $8.44 on Tuesday after the Danbury, Conn. maker of fuel cell power plants for electric power generation to sell 9 million shares. The company plans to use the net proceeds from the offering for market and product development, project financing and general corporate purposes. Iridex swings to a fourth-quarter loss; shares fall (10:52 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Iridex Corp. IRIX, -1.21% shares fell 15% to $7.53 in Tuesday morning trade after the Mountain View, Calif.-based company reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $3.77 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with a net profit of $381,000, or 5 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $9.04 million from $10.4 million last year. Iridex is a provider of laser systems, disposable laser probes and delivery devices to treat eye diseases and skin diseases. Mindspeed lowers second-quarter revenue outlook (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Mindspeed Technologies MSPD Tuesday lowered its revenue outlook for the second quarter, citing weak demand for its high performance analog products, including a customer that's undergoing merger consolidation. The Newport Beach, Calif., maker of semiconductor networking equipment said it now sees sequential revenue growth of about 2% for the second quarter from its first-quarter total of $30.2 million. The company's prior view was for sequential growth of 7% to 13%. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial is for revenue of $33.1 million in the March period. The company said it continues to expect a non-GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles) operating profit of the third quarter due to the "significant strength" of its backlog. The stock closed Monday at $2.15, down 2 cents. Walgreen March same-store sales up 8% (8:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Walgreen Co. WAG on Tuesday said March sales at stores open at least one year rose 8%. For the month, total sales rose 12.8% to $4.61 billion. March pharmacy sales jumped 13.2%, while same-pharmacy sales increased 8.8%. Total prescriptions filled at comparable stores rose 4.4%. Pharmacy sales accounted for 66.6% of total sales for the month. Same-store front-end sales increased 6.5% in March. The drugstore operator said sales for the month weren't significantly impacted by the earlier Easter holiday, but next month it will report sales results for both April and the combined months of March and April. Easter falls on April 8 this year, vs. April 16 last year. Continental load factor climbs, storm impact at $10 mln (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Continental Airlines Inc. CAL, -0.62% said its traffic in March rose 3.4% while its capacity climbed 1.8% compared to March 2006, resulting in a load factor gain of 1.4 points to 82.6%. Load factor is the percentage of seats filled with paying passengers. Continental said late Monday its total passenger revenue per available seat mile, an industry measure of unit revenue, rose between 4.5% and 5.5% in March from a year ago. The Houston-based carrier, the No. 6 domestic carrier in the U.S. in 2006, said winter storms in the Northeast would cost it $10 million in revenue. March 2007 sales at its Web site also grew, by 18%, over March 2006. Taser sees first-quarter sales of $15M; 3 orders delayed (7:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR said Tuesday it expects preliminary sales of about $15 million for the first quarter. The Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker said, however, that three large customer purchase orders it expected in the first quarter were delayed. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for revenue of $19.03 million in the first quarter. Taser now expects these orders to ship in the second quarter. The stock closed Monday at $8.12, up 9 cents. Morgan Stanley added to KBW's list of favorites (7:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Keefe, Bruyette & Woods on Tuesday reiterated its outperform rating on Morgan Stanley MS, +1.98% and added the stock to its KBW Best Ideas List, "owing to considerable upside to existing price target and a total return in excess of 22%," the broker wrote in a note to clients. "We have crystal clear validation of the successful turnaround story in our view that still has legs. The environment, yes, has become more dicey but Morgan Stanley in our view has the global breadth and depth to weather the storm in relatively good shape." Int'l Speedway earnings, revenue decline (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- International Speedway Corp. ISCA, +1.26% said first quarter earnings fell to $35.8 million, or 67 cents a share, from $44.1 million, or 83 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding additional depreciation associated with a building in Daytona Beach, Fla., earnings for the quarter ending Feb. 28 would have been 70 cents a share. Revenue declined 4.5% to $185.2 million from last year's $193.9 million, with motorsports related sales down 5.2%, admissions revenue slipping 0.4% and food, beverage and merchandise revenue falling 12%. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial had been expecting earnings of 75 cents a share revenue of $188.4 million, on average. The Daytona Beach, Fla. motorsports company said it still expects 2007 adjusted earnings of $3.10 to $3.20 a share and revenue of $800 million to $820 million. The stock closed Monday up 15 cents at $51.85. Kitty Hawk swings to profit, remains cautious on 2007 (6:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Freight transportation company Kitty Hawk Inc. KHK said it swung to a fourth-quarter net profit of $8.3 million, or 15 cents a share, from a loss of $4.1 million, or 8 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue for the period rose 87.8% to $86.2 million due largely to work it did for the U.S. Postal Service over the Christmas period as well as the acquisition of Air Container Transport. Kitty Hawk said it is cautious in its outlook for 2007 due to the seasonality of its business and the softness in demand the industry experienced through the later part of 2006, which has continued into the first quarter. The firm said that achieving its 2007 targets will depend on its ability to improve the performance of its air and ground products as well as the trends in fuel prices. Kitty Hawk added it expects capital expenditure for the year to be around $2 million. ICBC 2006 net profit up 31% on fee growth, interest income (5:20 AM ET) HONG KOING (MarketWatch) -- Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd reported Tuesday net profit rose 31% in 2006, bolstered by higher interest income, growth in fee-based businesses and expansion of its retail banking business. The Beijing-headquartered bank reported net income of 49.26 billion yuan ($6.37 billion) for the year, up from 37.56 billion yuan a year earlier. The results announcement is the first since the bank simultaneously listed on the Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges in October 17th. The bank proposed a final dividend of 0.016 yuan a share for 2006, up from 0.014 yuan a share in the previous year. ICBC's Hong Kong-listed shares ended unchanged ahead of the results announcement. The bank also reported deposits rose by 10.7% to 614.56 billion yuan, while its loan book grew 10.4% to 341.62 billion yuan. Resolution profit jumps after acquiring Abbey life unit (2:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. life assurance group Resolution Plc(UK:RSL)said Tuesday that its 2006 net profit jumped to 494.2 million pounds ($969.4 million) from 154.9 million pounds. Net premiums written were 1.48 billion pounds, from 394.4 million pounds in 2005. Growth was largely due to the acquisition of Abbey's life business as well as a strong performance across all the group's existing divisions. Resolution said the internal rate of return on the Abbey business was improved to 18%, ahead of its original target of 16%. The European Embedded Value of the group increased to 4.2 billion pounds from 2.14 billion pounds. Resolution said it will raise its 2006 dividend by 15% to 19.92 pence a share and also proposed a further 38% rise in dividend to 27.50 pence a share in 2007. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stock futures advanced on Tuesday, as some easing of tensions in the Middle East gave investors reason to cheer, with oil prices sliding below $65 a barrel. Later in the session, figures may show the Big Three automakers are still having difficulty selling cars to Americans. S&P 500 futures improved 7.10 points to 1,440.40 and Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 9.50 points to 1,799.50. Dow industrial futures hiked up 46 points to 12,495. U.S. stocks rose on Monday, helped by a flurry of takeover activity, including the $29 billion acquisition of First Data by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts. The Dow industrials rose nearly 28 points, the Nasdaq Composite edged up six-tenths of a point and the S&P 500 added 3.7 points. See Market Snapshot. "The M&A news helped to shrug off the economic fears from the last couple of sessions. However the gains didn't break the index out of the range we have seen over the last couple of weeks, with the upside level (for the Dow) of 12,400 - 12,450 still holding strong," said Geoff Langham, head of trading at CMC Markets. Tuesday's economic schedule is relatively light, with U.S. pending home sales figures due for February. The dollar climbed 0.8% against the yen to 118.60, while the greenback saw limited moves against the euro. Crude-oil futures dropped $1.02 to $64.92 a barrel and gold futures slipped $2.60 to $663.10 an ounce. There were tentative signs that the U.K. and Iran could be close to a deal to free 15 sailors held by Iran after a U.K. boat entered disputed waters. See Futures Movers. U.K. Prime Minister Tony Blair said the next 48 hours will be "fairly critical" toward resolving the dispute, according to an Associated Press report quoting a Scottish radio station. A surge in demand for fuel-friendly compact cars is expected to stand out as a bright spot in what looks to have otherwise been a relatively sluggish March for the major automakers. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% Chrysler DCX and General Motors GM, +2.45% are all likely to see sales decline from last year, while Toyota Motor TM, +0.77% Honda HMC, +0.90% and Nissan NSANY, -0.65% all of Japan, likely will see U.S. sales improve. See full story. Those figures typically are released around 11 a.m. Eastern. Ahead of the release of those figures, Dow member GM shares rose 1.2% to $31.20 in the pre-open while DaimlerChrysler eased 0.7% to $83.41 and Toyota slipped 1.1% to $125.50. Of other companies in the spotlight, the European Commission has charged that Apple AAPL, +0.78% and Warner Music WMG, -2.22% among others, are breaking antitrust rules by limiting access to music downloads by country. See story. Apple shares gained 0.3% to $93.87 in pre-open trading. Google GOOG, +2.71% said it will sell TV ads through a partnership with EchoStar Satellite DISH, +1.20% and Astound Cable, a small Internet provider in Northern California. The trial is Google's initial attempt to adapt its do-it-yourself Internet advertising features, known as AdSense, to making and selling TV ads. Google shares edged up 0.8% to $462.11 in the pre-open and EchoStar ticked up 0.2% to $43.60. Shares of Fremont General FMT, -0.93% slumped 5.2% to $6.18 in pre-open trading after the subprime lender said its auditor, Grant Thornton, resigned. Grant Thornton said that during the audit there were instances where Fremont didn't provide certain requested information on dates previously agreed upon with management, according to a letter it filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Fremont's subprime mortgage lending unit, which accounted for roughly half its business, stopped offering loans earlier this year. Bunge Ltd. BG, +1.20% warned that first-quarter results would be weaker than year-earlier results, and miss expectations. The stock shed 2.8% to $81.38 ahead of the open. International Speedway ISCA, +1.26% reported earnings and revenue that fell from year-earlier levels, and missed expectations. Shares of Taser International TASR fell 6.7% to $7.57 ahead of the open after the stun gun maker said expects first-quarter revenue of $15 million, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson Financial of $19 million, due to order delays from three large customers. The Nikkei 225 rose 1.3% in Tokyo, and the FTSE 100 rose 0.4% in London. title: U.S. stock futures point gains as Middle East tensions ease

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Tuesday it expects preliminary sales of about $15 million for the first quarter. The Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker said, however, that three large customer purchase orders it expected in the first quarter were delayed. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson Financial was for revenue of $19.03 million in the first quarter. Taser now expects these orders to ship in the second quarter. The stock closed Monday at $8.12, up 9 cents.
title: Taser sees first-quarter sales of $15M; 3 orders delayed

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr advanced 5.3% to $8.14 on Wednesday after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker said two wrongful death lawsuits against it were dismissed. The company said the dismissals, which occurred in courts in Mississippi and Ohio, bring the number of such lawsuits filed against and subsequently dismissed to 33. It noted that it hasn't lost any product liability lawsuit. "These dismissals are the result of the insurmountable burden plaintiffs have in proving there was any defect in the Taser device or that the Taser device was a proximate cause of these unfortunate deaths," said Douglas Klint, the company's general counsel. "We are adamant in not settling these wrongful death lawsuits and we will continue our aggressive defense of all litigation filed against Taser International." Volume of 1.25 million shares was above the issue's 10-day average of 728,500.
title: Taser shares get lift after lawsuits against it dismissed

content: LAS VEGAS (MarketWatch) -- If anyone was looking for insight into 2007 consumer electronics trends at the CES Show this week in Las Vegas they would be sorely disappointed since none emerged. All we saw was a lot of junk and a continuation of confused older trends. Many people thought the most interesting news to hit the Show was actually made at the Macworld event in San Francisco, where Apple AAPL, +0.78% rolled out its iPhone and promptly got threatened for trademark violation by Cisco Systems, the owner of the iPhone moniker. Other than that, the only possible trend was one targeting sobriety since, for some unknown reason, a bunch of consumer-oriented breathalyzers appeared at the Las Vegas show. The most controversial item on display was from the Taser International Inc. TASR which showcased a $300 consumer model of a genuine Taser device that shoots out the little prongs to drop an attacker at a distance. Many critics ask whether such a product should even be available to the public. Curiously, a slew of people attending CES were lined up to get blasted by the thing. I assume this was the only thrill anyone could get from this year's show. Journalists who visited openly complained about the lack of interesting products and specifically carped about the "mine is bigger than yours" approach that many of the TV makers were exploiting with various companies showing huge LCD's and plasmas all larger then 100-inches. Claims of the "world's biggest" were everywhere making the place look like a carnival sideshow. Probably the most interesting things were in the various Asian pavilions. There was even some company with a AA-cell battery that you activated with water. I'm looking into it since nobody at the booth could come close to explaining how it worked except for the fact that you put water into it. Many of these booths were unfortunately peopled who couldn't speak a single word of English except the words "yes" and "OK." I suspect a lot of potential business was lost. A few booths had people who thought they could speak English, and that was actually worse since they'd drag you into the booth to practice on you. One company had a universal battery charger that could take any weird battery and through a Rube Goldberg-like mechanism manage to lock onto it, properly adjust the polarity, determine the type of battery and charge it. It's probably too complicated to ever sell well. Again the language barrier was an issue as all I really found out was they had "many patents." Overall the big consumer electronics companies had nothing new to show. Most of the buzz seemed to stem from the LG Electronics booth, where the combination Blue-ray/HD-DVD drive was showcased. With a price point expected to exceed $1,000 it will be a while before the HD trend takes over the DVD business. Most people seem happy to use their HD screens to watch standard DVDs, which are affordable. If anyone's seeking investment advice coming out of this show, I'd look at the gaming companies since the town of Las Vegas itself seems to be once again undergoing a building boom with virtually every property putting up new additions. The most ambitious (and weirdest) is the MGM-Mirage project called City Center [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_City_Center], a 66-acre mini-city right across from the Aladdin hotel. Originally budgeted at $4 billion, the project may now cost as much as $9 billion to complete, according to the locals. City Center will incorporate condos, people movers, its own firehouse and police department as well as stores and hotels. It's being built on the recently imploded Boardwalk Casino. If you drive up the street you find the classic old Stardust Hotel boarded up and targeted for demolition. God knows what they'll put there, but I'm sure it will have to be something spectacular and expensive. There seems to be no end in sight for this growth and the desert is still out there waiting to be filled up with more stuff. \ More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: CES was little more than breathalyzers and bad trade booths

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr on Thursday said it has received three international orders for its X26 devices plus accessories worth more than $2.3 million. The orders are expected to ship in the fourth quarter.
title: Taser gets 3 orders totaling more than $2.3 mln

content: Advancers Adams Respiratory Therapeutics ARXT shares rose 6% after the company was upgraded to outperform from sector perform at RBC Capital Markets. Ameristar Casinos ASCA shares rose 13% after the company increased its third-quarter earnings estimate. The company expects earnings of 35 to 36 cents a share, up from the previous estimate of 27 to 29 cents. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of 29 cents for the company. The higher earnings estimate reflects reductions in estimated depreciation expense, to $24 million from $25 million, and in interest expense, to $12 million from $12.5 million, Ameristar said. Arrow International Inc. ARRO shares gained 5.3% after the company said fourth-quarter net income rose to $17.6 million, or 39 cents a share, from $5.04 million, or 11 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Quarterly revenue rose to $129.2 million from $114.3 million in the prior year. Copart Inc. CPRT, +2.21% shares added 8.8% after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $31.6 million, or 34 cents a share, up 26% from $25 million, or 27 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Quarterly revenue rose to $137.2 million vs. $110.6 million. Shares of Corrections Corp. of America CXW, -0.56% surged 8.1% after Lehman Bros. reiterated its overweight rating on the stock, saying plans for California to outsource inmates to private prisons "is a significant development in the corrections industry." The firm cited the decision by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger to issue an emergency proclamation to California's prison system, where he characterized "severe overcrowding as a threat to health and safety in 29 of the state's 33 prisons." Lehman said it believes California will look to contract out-of-state facilities for a period of three to five years. Cost-U-Less CULS shares added 6.1% after the Bellevue, Wash., off-price retailer said same-store sales rose 6.7% in September. Dobson Communications Corp. DCEL shares leapt 19% after the compay said it added 23,500 net subscribers in the third quarter. For the same period in the prior year, the wireless services provider reported a total reduction of 24,100 subscribers. Dynavax Technologies DVAX, +1.02% shares soared 55% after the company said a study found Tolamba, its experimental allergy treatment, was effective in battling allergies by ragweed. See full story. GenVec Inc. GNVC shares leapt 18% after the company was awarded an HIV vaccine contract from a department of the National Institues of Health worth up to $52 million. Under terms of the contract, a vaccine research arm of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases is being granted a non-exclusive research license for the use of GenVec's gene-based technologies to support clinical development of an HIV vaccine. The Gaithersburg, Md.-based biopharmaceutical company has been collaborating with the research center on HIV vaccine development for several years. GEO Group GEO, +0.24% shares rose 7.2% after the company said it's received a contract to provide continued management and operation of the Aurora ICE Processing Center in Aurora, Colo., from the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency. The company expects the contract, which has an initial term of eight months, to generate about $13.6 million in annualized operating revenue. GEO, which has managed the center since its opening in 1987, said the pact has four one-year renewal option periods. Guess Inc. GES, -0.81% shares gained 7.5% after the company said September sales at stores open at least a year rose 11.3%. Analysts, on average, expected the Los Angeles retailer to post a same-store sales gain of 4.3%, according to Thomson First Call. Total sales for the month ended Sept. 30 increased 16.3% to $67 million from $57.6 million. Hancock Fabrics HKF, +5.77% shares rose 6.5% after the company said its same-store sales rose 3.3% in September. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a decrease of 5% for the month. Total sales for the five weeks ended Sept. 30 slid to $36.9 million from $37.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The Baldwyn, Miss., retailer of fashion and home decorating fabric products said all major merchandise departments saw improvement during the month in relation to recent sales trends. Helen of Troy Ltd. HELE, +3.51% shares jumped 19% after the company reported net earnings of $10.9 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $9.5 million, or 30 cents a share, the year earlier period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call on average were expecting earnings of 28 cents a share. The El Paso, Tex.-distributor of personal care and household consumer products said net sales were $147.2 million in the second quarter, up 12.9% from the year earlier. The company also reiterated earnings forecasts of $1.70 to $1.80 and sales of $600 to $620 million for its fiscal year 2007. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expect the company to post earnings of $1.74 for the year. Investment Technology Group ITG, +0.77% shares gained nearly 7.9% after the company was upgraded to strong buy from outperform at Raymond James. The firm also set a $60 price target. Lightbridge Inc. LTBG shares jumped 14% after the Burlington, Mass.-based company said it plans to exit the telecom decision services business and cut 200 jobs. The company expects to record restructuring and related charges of $6.5 million to $13 million, the cash portion of which is in the range of $3.5 million to $8 million, through the first half of 2007. Lightbridge also reaffirmed its third-quarter revenue forecast of $22.4 million to $24.2 million and said it expects earnings of 3 to 11 cents a share, excluding any restructuring charges. Excluding other items, the company still expected third-quarter earnings of 8 cents to 16 cents a share. The company was also upgraded to outperform at Robert W. Baird. Marriott International Inc. MAR, +1.55% shares added 6.6% after the company reported that its third-quarter earnings declined 5%, but beat Wall Street's profit expectation. See full story. MDS Inc. MDZ, -2.78% (MDS) shares rose 6.9% agreed to sell its Canadian laboratory services business to Borealis Infrastructure Management Inc. for C$1.325 billion. The company expects to realize net proceeds of about C$1.052 billion from the deal, which it anticipates will close by the end of January. MDS said it plans to C$500 million of the proceeds for a one-time share buyback, and that it also plans to discontinue payment of its quarterly dividend. It plans to invest the rest of the proceeds in its life sciences businesses. Pressure BioSciences Inc. PBIO, +0.00% shares soared 15% on heavy volume. On Wednesday, the West Bridgewater, Mass., biotechnology company said it was awarded a phase I small business innovation research grant from the National Institutes of Health. The company plans to use the grant to fund experiments to demonstrate the feasibility of using its patented pressure cycling technology to develop a novel method of extraction of protein biomarkers. Ross Stores Inc. ROST, +2.39% shares gained 7.2% after the company said its September sales at stores open at least a year rose 6%. Analysts, on average, had expected it to post a same-store sales gain of 2.3%, according to Thomson First Call. Total sales for the five weeks ended Sept. 30 rose 12% to $499 million from $446 million. Ross Stores said it expects third-quarter earnings above its estimated range of 24 to 27 cents a share. Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.02% shares added 7.6% after the company said its September sales at stores open at least 13 months rose 6%, ahead of what Wall Street had expected. The company also raised its long-term store opening goal to 40,000 from its prior target of 30,000. See full story. Taser International Inc. TASR shares rose 12% after the company said it received three orders for a total of 2,654 X26 units and related accessories. Taser, which makes devices for use by law enforcement, the military and security companies, said it now expects third-quarter revenue of $18 million. Zumiez Inc. ZUMZ, +0.00% shares added 6.5% after the company said its same-store sales rose 14.9% in September. Analysts had expected a gain of 5.7% for the month. Total net sales for the 5-week period ended Sept. 30 increased 47.3% to $28.7 million. Decliners Able Energy ABLE, +900.00% shares plunged 25% after the company said late in Wednesday's session that it's provided formal notice of plans to voluntarily de-list its securities from the Nasdaq Capital Market to the exchange. The company anticipates its common stock will be eligible for listing on the NASD's over-the-counter bulletin board. Dillard's Inc. DDS, +0.96% shares lost 7.4% after the company said September sales at stores open at least a year were flat compared with the year-ago period. Analysts, on average, expected the Little Rock, Ark., retailer to post a same-store sales increase of 1.7%, according to Thomson First Call. Total sales for the five weeks ended Sept. 30 increased 3%. Diodes Inc. DIOD, +0.00% shares slipped 7.4% after the company said it now expects third-quarter sequential revenue growth will be slightly more than 11.5%. The subminiature devices company said its prior growth view was for 9% to 11%. Frontier Airlines FRNT, +0.00% shares sank 12% after the company said traffic in September rose 11.3% to 616.5 million revenue passenger miles. Load factor, or the percentage of the plane filled with passengers, fell 3.4 percentage points to 67.6%. Capacity rose 17% to 911.6 million available seat miles, the Denver-based carrier said. Frontier also said it now expects second-quarter earnings to fall between a penny and 5 cents a share, excluding the impact of unrealized fuel derivative gains and losses. The airline had previously forecast the earnings to be in line with the first-quarter results of 10 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently estimating second-quarter per-share earnings of 18 cents. Goldleaf Financial Solutions GFSI shares slid 11% after the company said it's priced an offering of 10 million shares of its common stock at $5.50 per share. The Brentwood, Tenn., developer of technology products for the financial services industry said the deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of an additional 1.5 million shares. Haverty Furniture HVT, +3.33% shares dropped 6.6% after the company said September same-store sales 6.4% over year-earlier levels. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting same-store sales growth of 6%, on average. Total sales for the month increased 8% to $72.4 million from last year's $67.1 million. The Atlanta home furnishings retailer said fiscal third-quarter gross margins were below levels seen in the sequential second quarter due to greater-than-anticipated clearance activity. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT shares fell 12% after the company reported a slump in same-store sales for September and said its third quarter profit is apt to be at the low end of its hopes. See full story. Ikanos Communications Inc. IKAN shares plunged 29% after the company cut its third-quarter revenue forecast and issued a fourth-quarter outlook below analysts' view. Shipments have been limited due to product delays and manufacturing constraints. Intermec Inc. IN, +6.11% shares sank 15% after the company said its now sees third-quarter revenue of $192 million to $196 million, compared with its prior view of $230 million to $240 million. The supply chain technology concern said the revised outlook reflects an estimated 20% decrease of System and Solutions revenue, and a 5% decrease of Service revenue, compared with results during the same period in the prior year. Kopin Corp. KOPN, +0.32% shares fell 7.2% after the Taunton, Mass., liquid crystal display maker lowered its outlook for the third quarter. The company now sees revenue of between $14 million and $15 million for the period, below a prior guidance for revenue of $19 million and $20.5 million. The company cited a delay in product shipments due to a design change made to a display module that employs its microdisplay technology. Molson Coors Brewing Co. TAP, -0.11% shares lost 6.5% after the company was downgraded to underperform from peer perform at Bear Stearns. New York & Co. NWY, -0.29% shares dropped 8.6% after the company said September same-store sales rose 2.3% over year earlier levels. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting sales growth of 3.3%, on average. Total sales increased 9.2% to $114.6 million from last year's $104.9 million. The New York women's apparel retailer said it expects fiscal third-quarter earnings to be at the high-end of previously provided forecasts. Oxford Industries Inc. OXM, -1.25% reported first-quarter net earnings of $11 million, or Par Technology Corp. PTC, +1.26% shares sank 19% after the company said it now expects third-quarter earnings of 4 cents to 7 cents a share on revenue of $49 million to $50 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently forecasting third-quarter earnings of 15 cents a share on revenue of $56 million. Siga Technologies Inc. SIGA, -0.65% shares lost 14% after the company said it has terminated its merger agreement with PharmAthene Inc. Tweeter Home Entertainment Group TWTR, +1.97% shares dropped 21% after the company said fourth-quarter sales at stores open at least a year fell 13% for the three months ended Sept. 30. Total revenue from continuing operations in the quarter fell to $162 million, from $188 million in the same period last year. The company expects to report a 2006 operating loss of $13 million to $15 million, narrower than the operating loss of $47 million -- including $16.5 million in restructuring charges -- in the year-ago period.
