title: Thursday's biggest stock gainers and decliners

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr shares rose 11% to $8.48 in Thursday morning trade after the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company said it has received three orders for a total of 2,654 X26 units and related accessories. Taser, which makes devices for use by law enforcement, the military and security companies, said it now expects third-quarter revenue of $18 million.
title: Taser gets orders for 2,654 X26 units, shares rise

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr said its chairman of the board, Phillips Smith, will retire on Oct. 23 after 13 years with the company. The Scottsdale, Ariz. stun gun maker said it named Thomas Smith as its chairman, effective Oct. 23. The company also said it promoted Kathleen Hanrahan to president. The stock closed Tuesday up 12 cents at $7.86.
title: Taser Int'l chairman to retire

content: Advancers Arkansas Best Corp. ABFS shares rose 8.2% Monday after the company reported second-quarter net income rose 37.8% to $32.3 million, or $1.26 a share, as revenue grew 12% to $479.3 million. The company said its profit included a gain of 12 cents a share on the sale of its Clipper Exxpress unit. Revenue was boosted by a 6.4% increase in total weight carried per day in the second quarter. Arkansas Best said tonnage trends in July are at or slightly behind those in the second-quarter. ATI Technologies ATYT shares jumped 19% after the company greed to be acquired by Advanced Micro Devices Inc. AMD, +2.45% for $5.4 billion, a deal that would open a new front in AMD's rivalry with Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% See full story. Cardiome Pharmaceuticals Corp. CRME, +3.11% (COM) shares leapt 36% after the company said it was pleased with the results from a Phase IIa pilot study of RSD1235, a potential therapy for preventing the recurrence of atrial fibrillation. The Vancouver-based company said the safety data for the 300mg dosing group suggests that RSD1235 is well-tolerated, and that the drug demonstrated a clear positive trend toward efficacy. Enrollment and dosing for the second stage of the study, evaluating a 600mg dose, is complete, the company said. Results from this dosing group, as well as the complete study, are expected later in the third quarter. Cardiome plans to initiate a larger Phase IIb clinical study after it analyzes the results. CNH Global N.V. CNH, +26.92% shares added 7.6% after the company said second-quarter net income climbed 29% to $147 million, or 62 cents a share, with revenue up 4% to $3.7 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 63 cents a share on revenue of $3.61 billion. The majority-owned agricultural and construction equipment unit of Fiat SpA said gross margins at equipment operations improved 2.7 percentage points on positive price recovery and increased manufacturing efficiencies in agricultural equipment and positive price recovery, better volume and mix and manufacturing efficiencies in construction equipment. Earnings per share before restructuring should surge to $1.30 to $1.40 a share, from 95 cents last year, while equipment sales are seen rising 2% to 5%. Exco Resources Inc. XCO jumped 18% after the company set plans to acquire Winchester Energy, a unit of Progressive Energy PGN, -0.73% for $1.2 billion in cash. Exco plans to float an initial public offering of units representing limited partner interests of a master limited partnership subsidiary being formed to acquire Winchester Energy Company. The IPO will also include assets of Exco. The assets are located in East Texas and North Louisiana. Exco plans to sell an approximate 50% interest in the partnership and retain 50%. Net proceeds will be used to repay debt incurred in connection with the acquisitions. Hasbro Inc. HAS, +0.57% shares moved up 9.5% after the nation's No.2 toy maker said that second-quarter income declined from a year-ago period that was bolstered by strong sales of "Star Wars" toys, but total revenue easily topped Wall Street's view. See full story. Landry's Restaurants Inc. LNY, -25.00% shares gained 8.4% after the company said it will retain Wachovia Securities and Northpoint Advisors to help evaluate strategic alternatives for its Joe's Crab Shack chain. Landry's added that certain underperforming Joe's Crab restaurants have closed, and that it expects to record a charge of $6 million, or 27 cents a share. See full story. PFF Bancorp Inc.'s PFB, +2.78% shares rose 8.6% after the Pomona, Calif.-based provider of financial services reported first-quarter earnings of $15.4 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with $12.4 million, or 49 cents a share, last year. PFF's quarterly net interest income rose 14% to $46.9 million vs. $41 million. Shares of Philips Electronics NV PHG, +0.79% jumped 6.5% following a report in The Wall Street Journal that three groups of private-equity firms are in the final stage of bidding more than $10 billion for the company's semiconductor division. Polo Ralph Lauren RL, +1.60% shares surged 16% after the designer of apparel, accessories and home furnishings raised its earnings outlook for the fiscal first quarter amid robust customer demand for its products. See full story. Pre-Paid Legal Services PPD shares gained 6.1% after the company said its second-quarter income increased to $12.1 million, or 81 cents a share, from $6.9 million, or 44 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended June 30 advanced to $111.2 million from $105.6 million in last year's second quarter. Membership fees rose to $103.1 million from $97.1 million. The Ada, Okla., provider of legal services said results were helped by lower commissions. Radcom Ltd. RDCM, -0.27% shares added 9.7% after the company reported second-quarter net income doubled on 18% higher revenue. Net reached $208,000, or a penny a share, from $103,000, or a penny a share, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding rose 3.2% to 16.6 million. Revenue reached $5.7 million from $4.8 million. Adjusted earnings were 2 cents against 1 cent. Schering-Plough Inc. SGP, -1.28% shares gained 5.7% after thec company swung to a second-quarter net profit propelled by strong sales of its drugs Vytorin, Nasonex and Remicade that handily beat Wall Street expectations. See full story. Silicon Laboratories SLAB, +2.39% shares jumped 21% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of 18 cents a share, down from 28 cents in the year-earlier period. Adjusted profit was 37 cents in the latest quarter. Revenue rose to $123.5 million from $107.2 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was profit of 33 cents on revenue of $118.7 million. For the third quarter, the Austin, Texas, chip company forecast revenue of $122 million to $127 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is $124.9 million. The company said the board approved the buyback of as much as $100 million of common stock over 12 months. Taser International TASR shares gained 8.2% after Merriman Curhan Ford analyst Eric Wold recommended buying the stock aggressively ahead of its second-quarter results, saying the stun-gun maker's results may exceed expectations. Wold said sales trends are accelerating, wrongful-death suits continue to be dismissed, law-enforcement officers have successfully used Taser products in the field, and significant orders could be announced during the third quarter. Titanium Metals Corp. TIE, -9.16% shares added 7.9% after the company said second-quarter net income for the three months ended June 30 rose 62% to $54.3 million, or 31 cents a share, from $33.6 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Dallas company rose to $300.9 million from $183.7 million. Decliners Astec Industries Inc. ASTE, +1.23% shares fell 22% Monday after the company reported second-quarter net income of $12.4 million, or 56 cents a share, up from $10.2 million, or 49 cents, earned in the same period in 2005. The Chattanooga, Tenn.-based manufacturer of specialized infrastructure equipment also posted quarterly sales of $191.3 million, 12% higher than the prior year's $170.8 million, as international sales accounted for 28% of net sales for the latest period vs. 19.4% a year earlier. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Astec to chalk up earnings of 67 cents a share on revenue of $205 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Chairman and CEO Don Brock cited the impact of "certain negative events occurring at the end of the quarter that were beyond our control." The company's June 30 backlog stood at $121.7 million, up 38.2% from mid-2005. Boston Communications Group BCGI shares plunged 30% after the company said Friday the Securities and Exchange Commission has notified the company of an informal inquiry into certain option grants the company made from 1998 through 2002. Also Friday, the company said it will pay $55.3 million to Freedom Wireless to settle patent litigation against Boston Communications and its carrier customers. China BAK Battery CBAK, +0.00% shares fell 31% after the company issued a weak outlook for the third quarter, saying sales of its steel-case battery cells and aluminum-case battery cells were lower than expected. The company now sees revenue of about $32 million for the third quarter. The current average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $42 million. TGC Industries TGE shares lost 7.1% after the company reported second-quarter net income rose 15% as revenue more than doubled. Net reached $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, from $1.8 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. Shares outstanding rose 20% to 15.7 million. Revenue was $14.9 million against $7.2 million. The revenue jumped stemmed from a rise to seven field crews in operation in the latest period from three crews a year earlier, as well as productivity improvements, TGC said. The quarter was hurt by persistent rain in south Texas and Kansas in May and June, which hampered crews there, TGC said. content: Pre-open moves U.S. shares were poised for modest gains on a flurry of merger-and-acquisition activity and earnings from Merck and others. Crude and gold pulled back on hopes for Mideast diplomacy. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets Techs lifted European markets as Vodafone said growth in its customer base accelerated to 9.5%, but also said star executive Bill Morrow was leaving. Autos cushioned Japan's Nikkei. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Dell Inc DELL was upgraded to buy from hold by Citigroup, which said it expects Dell to raise its prices in the third quarter after earlier, aggressive pricing. Merriman Curhan Ford analyst Eric Wold recommended buying Taser International TASR shares ahead of second-quarter results on the belief the stun-gun maker may exceed expectations. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Hospital operator HCA Inc. HCA, -0.15% said it agreed to be acquired by a group of investors in a deal valued at $51 a share, or $33 billion, including the assumption of about $11.7 billion in debt. The acquiring group includes Bain Capital, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity, and HCA founder Thomas Frist Jr. Advanced Micro Devices Inc. AMD, +2.45% agreed to buy ATI Technologies Inc. ATYT for $5.4 billion, a long-rumored deal that would open a new front in AMD's rivalry with Intel Corp. Canadian firm ATI makes graphics processors and so-called chipsets that support microprocessors, which are the brains of PCs. Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% wrote another chapter in its comeback story, saying second-quarter net income rose to $1.5 billion, or 69 cents a share, from $720.6 million, or 33 cents a share. Excluding restructuring charges it earned 73 cents a share. Sales rose to $5.77 billion from $5.47 billion. The Whitehouse Station, N.J.-based drug maker also raised its 2006 earnings forecast. Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% swung to a second-quarter profit, boosted by strength in Remicade and Nasonex. It posted net income of $259 million, or 16 cents a share. After paying a preferred dividend it earned $237 million. Excluding charges related to its restructuring operations, it earned 25 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose to $2.82 billion from $2.53 billion. Hasbro Inc., HAS, +0.57% the nation's No.2 toy maker, said second-quarter income declined from a year-ago period that was bolstered by strong sales of "Star Wars" toys. Hasbro, whose brands range from Ants in the Pants to Zoombox, said profit fell 8% to $27.1 million from $29.5 million a year ago. Sales for the three months ended July 2 fell 7.8% to $527.8 million. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: HCA, AMD, Merck, Hasbro, Dell in the spotlight

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Merriman Curhan Ford analyst Eric Wold recommended buying Taser International shares tasr aggressively ahead of the company's second-quarter results on the belief the stun gun maker's may exceed expectations. Wold said sales trends are clearly accelerating, wrongful death suits continue to be dismissed, Taser products have been successfully used in the fields by law enforcement officers and that there was potential for significant orders to be announced during the third quarter. Wold estimates revenue for the quarter ending June to be $15.8 million, but said revenue could be in the $16.5 million to $17 million range. The company is slated to report results on Wednesday. The stock closed Friday up 1 cent at $7.40.
title: Merriman says buy Taser ahead of results

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr on Monday said the Securities and Exchange Commission has terminated its investigation into the company and no enforcement action has been recommended. In December 2005, the stun-gun maker said that the SEC's investigation into its disclosures concerning the medical safety of the Taser device and certain accounting and disclosure issues had been completed, and that no enforcement action had been recommended on these matters. However, the SEC also advised the company at that time that it was continuing to investigate issues relating to trading in the company's stock. The SEC investigation has now been terminated in its entirety, Taser said.
title: Taser: SEC terminates investigation, no enforcement action

content: Advancers Big 5 Sporting Goods Corp. BGFV, +0.69% shares ended Friday with an 8.7% gain after the company reported first-quarter earnings fell 7.3%. Per-share profit was 26 cents compared with 28 cents in the year-earlier period. The El Segundo, Calif., retailer posted revenue of $207.2 million vs. $190.1 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 18 cents on revenue of $203 million. The company increased its annual dividend 29% to 36 cents a share from 28 cents. In addition, Big 5 authorized the buyback of as much as $15 million of shares. Shares of Jackson Hewitt Tax Service Inc. JTX rose 8.5% after the company said it prepared 3.66 million tax returns in fiscal 2006, up 10% from the year-earlier period. as average revenues per return rose 14%. As a result, the Parsippany, N.J., company raised its fiscal 2006 per-share earnings forecast to a range of $1.57 to $1.59 from $1.51 to $1.56. It also raised its fiscal 2006 revenue forecast to a range of $273 million to $275 million from $260 million to $265 million. Excluding certain items, the company expects per-share profit of $1.65 to $1.67. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting earnings of $1.57 a share on revenue of $262 million. Mace Security International Inc. MACE, +3.87% stock ended Friday's session higher by 17.8%. The company rejected an unsolicited $36 million offer by a group led by CW No. 1 LLC for its remaining 36 car washes, calling the bid insufficient. Mace, Mount Laurel, N.J., said it plans to talk with CW1 with the goal of obtaining a higher purchase price. Speedus Corp. SPDE, +123.16% shares rocketed higher by 36.8% after the company said the CellularVision Technology & Telecommunications LP unit has filed patent-infringement suits against Verizon Wireless, a joint venture of Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% and Vodafone Group Plc VOD, +0.54% The suits address technologies now used by Verizon Wireless to transmit television to wireless users over cellular networks, and the simultaneous transmission of analog and digital signals within the same bandwidth, Speedus said. The complaints were filed in U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Decliners Agco Corp. AG, +1.50% shares ended Friday down 6.8% after the company was cut to neutral from overweight at J.P. Morgan, which said it expects the stock of the heavy-machinery producer to perform in line with other machinery names. The broker told clients it believes that the U.S. farm-equipment market may be near a cyclical peak and that the European and South American farm-equipment markets won't recover much in the near term. Shares of DRS Technologies Inc. DRS fell 6.6% after the company reported fourth-quarter net income of 79 cents a share, up from 58 cents in the year-earlier period. Revenue at the Parsippany, N.J., military contractor rose 79% to $645.7 million from $361.2 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 75 cents on revenue of $595.2 million. The company forecast first-quarter net income of 49 cents to 51 cents a share, compared with the First Call target of 64 cents a share. For 2007, the company said it expects to earn $3.05 to $3.10 a share, including a 10 cent-to-12-cent impact from the adoption of stock-based compensation accounting. The First Call estimate is $3.13 a share. Expedia Inc. EXPE, +3.85% shares plunged 26.2% after the company reported first-quarter earnings fell to 6 cents a share from 14 cents in the year-earlier period. Adjusted net income was 15 cents a share vs. 27 cents. Revenue at the Bellevue, Wash., online travel-services company rose 1.8% to $493.9 million from $485 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast first-quarter revenue of $544 million. Magnetek Inc. MAG, -2.40% shares slumped 27.6% after the company reported its third-quarter loss from continuing operations widened to 15 cents a share from 7 cents in the year-earlier period. The Chatsworth, Calif., company's revenue rose to $57.2 million from $57 million. The consensus estimate of three analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was a loss of 3 cents a share. Magnetek also said it hired Stephens Inc. to help evaluate fundraising alternatives, including asset sales and securities offerings. Shares of Morgans Hotel Group Co. MHGC gave back 9.2% after the company said it would buy the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino in Las Vegas, along with an adjacent 23-acre chunk of land and other assets, from owner Peter Morton for a total of $770 million in cash. The hotel, built off the Las Vegas Strip in 1995, has 647 guest rooms and 30,000 square feet of casino space. Morgans, the owner of hotel brands including Hudson and Delano, said it expects the deal to close by first-quarter 2007. Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% stock closed 7.5% to the downside. After Thursday's closing bell, the company reported first-quarter net income rose to 23 cents a share from 18 cents in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 17% to $681.8 million. Based in Santa Clara, Calif., Nvidia makes graphics chips used in desktop and laptop computers and video games. Oceaneering International Inc. OII, +3.46% shares moved lower by 5% after the Houston provider of services to companies in marine- and space-related industries said Chief Executive John Huff retired and President T. Jay Collins added the CEO's title. The company also declared a 2-for-1 stock split, payable June 16 to holders of record May 25. After the split, Oceaneering estimates earnings of 48 cents to 53 cents a share for the second quarter and $1.80 to $1.95 for all of 2006. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced consensus pre-split estimates of 97 cents for the quarter and $3.79 for 2006. Taser International Inc. TASR shares fell 6.9% after the company delayed filing its latest quarterly report, citing errors in its calculation of indirect manufacturing expense applied to inventory. The stun-gun maker also said there was a formulaic spreadsheet error in its fourth-quarter calculations. Taser said adjustments were required to correct the cumulative impact in both first-quarter 2006 and in relevant prior periods, which will be disclosed in its first-quarter results. Threshold Pharmaceutical Inc. THLD shares plunged 75.4% after the company said the Food and Drug Administration placed its TH-070 clinical-development program for benign prostatic hyperplasia -- enlarged prostate -- on partial hold. The FDA's action follows abnormalities observed in liver-enzyme levels in six subjects in clinical trials, including three "serious adverse events" at three months of dosing. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr shares were down 7.2% at $9.41 in early trade Friday after the company delayed the filing of its latest quarterly report, citing errors in its calculation of indirect manufacturing expense applied to inventory. The stun-gun maker also said there was a formulaic spreadsheet error in its fourth-quarter calculations. Taser said adjustments were required to correct the cumulative impact both in the first quarter of 2006 and in the relevant prior periods, which will be disclosed in its first-quarter results.
title: Taser delays quarterly filings, discloses expense errors

content: Granite Contruction quarterly loss narrows (8:57 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Granite Construction Inc. GVA late Wednesday reported a first-quarter net loss of $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $8.3 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Watsonville, Calif.-based contracting and construction materials company rose to $496 million from $420.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a loss of 10 cents a share on revenue of $463 million. Forward Industries quarterly income falls (8:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Forward Industries Inc. FORD shares fell more than 40% in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company said second-quarter net income was $63,515, or a penny a share, down from $2.02 million, or 27 cents a share, during the same period last year. Forward said quarterly revenue was $6.46 million, down from $11.2 million last year. Friedman, Billings, Ramsey quarterly income rises (8:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Friedman, Billings, Ramsey Group Inc. FBR Wednesday evening said first-quarter net income $26.6 million, or 16 cents a share, down from $24.4 million, or 14 cents a share, during the same period last year. The investment bank said quarterly revenue was $338.7 million, up from $237.8 million last year. Republic Airways quarterly profit surges 14% (7:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Republic Airways Holdings Inc. RJET late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $16.9 million, or 39 cents a share, up 14% from $14.8 million, or 49 cents a share, last year. There were 42.9 million shares outstanding compared with 30.5 million last year. Revenue at the Indianapolis-based company rose 22.7% to $257.3 million from $209.8 million. Kirby quarterly income rises (7:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Kirby Corp. KEX after Wednesday's closing bell said first-quarter net income was $22.6 million, or 85 cents a share, compared with $13.3 million, or 52 cents a share, during the same period in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for per-share income of 80 cents. The maritime transportation company reported quarterly revenue of $224.9 million, up from $184.4 million last year. Analysts were looking for a result of $218 million. For the second quarter, the company sees per-share income of 85 cents to 90 cents, with analysts looking for 87 cents. FMC quarterly profit rises (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FMC Corp. FMC late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $67.7 million, or $1.71 a share, vs. $64.5 million, or $1.67 a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, earnings came in at $1.74 a share compared with $1.11 a share last year. Revenue rose to $594.1 million from $552.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of $1.40 a share on revenue of $592 million. FMC, a Philadelphia-based chemicals company, forecast second-quarter earnings of $1.40 to $1.50 a share excluding items, and raised its 2006 earnings forecast to $5.35 to $5.55 a share excluding items. Denny's swings to a quarterly profit (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Denny's Corp. DENN after Wednesday's closing bell said first-quarter net income was $712,000, or a penny a share. During the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $1.46 million, or 2 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of a penny. The restaurant operator said quarterly revenue was $248 million, up from $240 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $247 million. Denny's affirmed its view for full-year per-share income of 2 cents to 6 cents, while analysts are looking for a result of 6 cents. Rainmaker Systems swings to quarterly profit (6:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Rainmaker Systems Inc. RMKR were up 8.8% at $5.17 in after-hours trading on Wednesday. Rainmaker reported first-quarter net earnings $820,000, or 6 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, Rainmaker posted a net loss of $2.51 million, or 27 cents a share. Revenue at the Campbell, Calif.-based provider of marketing services rose to $11.1 million from $6.42 million a year ago. Gross margin was 50% vs. 39%. Rainmaker said it now expects its 2006 revenue growth to exceed 30% on an annual basis. CORRECT: Pulte Homes quarterly profit surges 20% (5:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pulte Homes Inc. PHM late Wednesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $262.6 million, or $1.01 a share, up 20% from $218.2 million, or 83 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Bloomfield Hills, Mich.-based company rose 18% to $2.96 billion from $2.52 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a per-share profit of 96 cents. For 2006, the company expects earnings of $6 to $6.25 a share. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of $5.98. (Corrects to reflect that the company earned $1.01 a share.) Cadence Design quarterly income rises (5:55 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cadence Design Systems Inc. CDNS shares rose 1.5% to $18.50 in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company said first-quarter net income was $21.8 million, or 7 cents a share, up from $1.02 million, or breakeven on a per-share basis, during the same period last year. On a pro forma basis, the software company reported per-share income for the quarter of 21 cents, compared with 15 cents last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 20 cents. Cadence said quarterly revenue was $328.2 million, up from $292.5 million. Analysts were looking for revenue of $321 million. For the second quarter, the company sees revenue of $340 million to $350 million, and per-share income of 9 cents to 11 cents, or 21 cents to 23 cents on a pro forma basis. Analysts are looking for quarterly revenue of $341 million, and per-share income of 22 cents. Platinum quarterly net income climbs 5% (5:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Platinum Underwriter Holdings PTP said late Wednesday that first-quarter net income came in at $77 million, or $1.16 a share, up 5% from a year earlier when the Bermuda-based reinsurer earned $73.1 million, or $1.49 a share. Net premiums written dropped 41% to $293.3 million. The combined ratio -- the cost of claims and expenses as a percentage of premiums -- was 85.2% in the first quarter, above the 84.5% ratio of the first quarter of 2005, the company reported. "Net premiums written and earned decreased significantly in our Finite Risk segment and to a lesser extent in our traditional segments reflecting our strategy of underwriting for profitability not market share, and a greater willingness on the part of our clients to retain risk," Chief Executive Michael Price said in a statement. Famous Dave's quarterly earnings rise; revenue up 15% (5:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Famous Dave's of America Inc. DAVE after Wednesday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $742,000, or 7 cents a share, compared with $533,000, or 5 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The results include $371,000, or 2 cents a share, of after-tax expense related to stock-based compensation. Revenue at the Minneapolis-based restaurant chain rose 15% to $27.1 million from $23.5 million. The company said quarterly comparable sales at company-owned restaurants increased 5.6% vs. a year ago. LSI Logic pegs potential sales loss of Apple iPod business (5:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- LSI Logic Corp. LSI said it may lose up to $40 million in sales in the second half of the year from the loss of some business to supply chip components for Apple Computer Inc.'s popular iPod music player. LSI Logic indirectly supplies Apple through its relationship with PortalPlayer Inc. PLAY a big provider of chips for the iPod. Last week, PortalPlayer said Apple AAPL will not use its next-generation chip in some flash-based iPods expected to be released later this year. The news led to a sell off in LSI Logic shares. Netgear quarterly profit rises 26% (5:34 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Netgear Inc. NTGR shares were up 11% to $21.99 in after-hours trading late Wednesday. After the closing bell, the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.87 million, or 29 cents a share, up 26% from $7.9 million, or 24 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, per-share earnings came in at 31 cents a share compared with 25 cents a share last year. Revenue at the Santa Clara, Calif.-based networking products company rose 17% to $127.3 million from $109 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $123 million. Netgear forecast second-quarter revenue of $125 million to $130 million. Analysts are looking for revenue of $123 million. The company also said Chief Financial Officer Jonathan Mather is leaving to pursue other opportunities. CACI International quarterly income rises (5:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- CACI International Inc. CAI after Wednesday's closing bell said third-quarter net income was $21.4 million, or 69 cents a share, compared with a restated result of $20.3 million, or 66 cents a share, during the same period last year. The networking company said quarterly revenue was $435.4 million, up from $414.9 million in the prior year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected revenue of $455 million. For the fourth quarter, CACI sees revenue of $470 million to $490 million, and per-share income of 71 cents to 76 cents. Analysts are looking for revenue of $504 million. Aspen quarterly profit drops as reinsurer cuts cat exposure (5:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aspen Insurance Holdings AHL reported a 12% drop in first-quarter net income late Wednesday after the Bermuda-based reinsurer cut back on the amount of catastrophe risk it underwrote. Net income came in at $61.8 million, or 59 cents a share, versus $70.1 million, or 98 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Operating earnings, which exclude net realized investment gains and losses, were $61.7 million, or 59 cents a share, versus $72.1 million, or $1.01 a share. Net premiums written in the period dropped 29% to $451.9 million, Aspen said. Chief Executive Chris O'Kane said the reinsurer arranged a "major reduction" in its property catastrophe exposures in the quarter -- beyond what the company had originally planned. Catastrophe reinsurance pricing, which didn't improve much at the start of 2006, began to increase considerably as the quarter progressed, he explained. "We are encouraged by this trend and believe it will enable us to replace considerable parts of the business we have rejected with similar exposures at much better prices as the year advances," he added. Hercules triples net profit (5:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Specialty chemicals company Hercules Inc. HPC reported late Wednesday first-quarter net earnings of $14.7 million, or 13 cents a share, up from $4.9 million, or 4 cents, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, operating earnings were $26.4 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $21.1 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier. Sales for the three months ended March 31 totaled $527.3 million, a 5% year-on-year increase from $501.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had predicted the Wilmington, Del. company would earn 21 cents a share on $527 million in revenue. Hercules shares rose 5 cents to close at $14.68 ahead of the report. STATS ChipPAC swings to quarterly profit (5:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of STATS ChipPAC Ltd STTS were up 3.9% at $8.72 in after-hours trading on Wednesday. STATS ChipPAC reported first-quarter net earnings of $12 million, or a penny a share. During the same period a year ago, the company posted a net loss of $27.1 million, or a penny a share. There were 2.16 billion shares outstanding during the quarter vs. 1.95 billion a year ago. The Singapore-based provider of semiconductor test and packaging services recorded net earnings of 6 cents per American Depositary Share. A year ago, the company reported a net loss of 14 cents per ADS. Pro forma earnings were 13 cents per ADS for the quarter. A year ago, the pro forma loss was 5 cents per ADS. Revenue rose to $385.7 million from $234.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast first-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share revenue of $377 million. STATS ChipPAC expects second-quarter earnings of 6 cents to 9 cents per ADS on revenue that's up 4% to 9% sequentially. The company sees second-quarter pro forma earnings of 13 cents to 16 cents per ADS. Skechers quarterly profit surges 62% (5:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Skechers USA Inc. SKX after Wednesday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $16.6 million, or 38 cents a share, up 62% from $10.3 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Manhattan Beach, Calif.-based footwear retailer rose 12.7% to $277.6 million from $246.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 33 cents a share on revenue of $277 million. The Company now expects second-quarter net earnings of 41 cents to 46 cents a share on revenue of $295 million to $305 million. Analysts are looking for earnings of 41 cents a share on revenue of $288 million. Sohu.com quarterly profit rises 5.7%; rev surges 32% (5:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sohu.com Inc. SOHU shares were up 5.6% to $26.78 in after-hours trading late Wednesday. After the closing bell, the China-based online media and search company reported first-quarter net earnings of $6.04 million, or 16 cents a share, up 5.7% from $5.71 million, or 15 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding share-based compensation expenses, the company earned $7.8 million, or 20 cents a share. Revenue rose 32% to $31.3 million from $30.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First call had forecast earnings of 15 cents a share on revenue of $30 million. The company expects second-quarter earnings of 20 cents to 22 cents a share, excluding items, on revenue of $31.5 million to $33.5 million. Analysts are looking for revenue of $32 million. Advanced Energy quarterly income rises (5:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Advanced Energy Industries Inc. AEIS shares rose more than 5% to $16.38 in after-hours trading Wednesday. The chip technology company said first-quarter net income was $12.8 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $734,000, or 2 cents a share, during the same period last year. Advanced Energy said quarterly revenue was $94 million, up from $82.2 million last year. The company added that it sees second-quarter sales of $98 million to $102 million, and per-share income of 27 cents to 29 cents. DTE Energy boost profit 11% (5:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Energy provider DTE Energy Co. DTE reported after Wednesday's closing bell first-quarter net income of $136 million, or 76 cents a share, up 11% from $122 million, or 70 cents, a year ago. Excluding one-time items, operating earnings were $171 million, or 96 cents a share, compared with $154 million, or 88 cents, in the first quarter of 2005. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 rose to $2.64 billion from $2.31 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had predicted the Detroit-based company would earn 85 cents a share on revenue of $2.72 billion. DTE Energy shares fell 0.3% to close at $40.16 ahead of the report. BRE quarterly net drops 74%; funds from operations edge up (5:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- BRE Properties BRE said late Wednesday that first-quarter net income came in at $7.4 million, or 14 cents a share, down 74% from a year earlier, when the real estate investment trust made $28.8 million, or 56 cents a share. Funds from operations, a generally accepted measure of operating performance for REITs, totaled $27.1 million, or 51 cents a share, during the first quarter, up from $26.2 million, or 50 cents a share, a year earlier, BRE reported. Revenue was $78.8 million in the period, versus $70.4 million a year ago, the REIT added. Photon Dynamics swings to a quarterly profit (5:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Photon Dynamics Inc. PHTN shares rose almost 7% to $19.25 in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company reported second-quarter net income of $2.52 million, or 13 cents a share. For the same period last year, the company reported a net loss of $10.3 million, or 61 cents a share. The flat panel display market services supplier said quarterly revenue was $50.3 million, up from $25.3 million last year. For the third quarter, the company sees revenue of $48 million to $50 million, and per-share income of 22 cents to 25 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for revenue of $48 million and per-share income of 20 cents. Zimmer profit climb 18%; sales rise (4:59 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Zimmer Holdings ZMH on Wednesday reported first-quarter net income of $205.6 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $173.6 million, or 70 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Sales for the Warsaw, Indiana-based orthopedic products maker were $860.4 million vs. last year's $828.5 million. Excluding certain charges, the company would have reported earnings of 87 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected, on average, that the company would earn 81 cents a share on sales of $875.1 million. The company reiterating its forecasts for the remainder of the year, expecting earnings of $3.40 a share for fiscal 2006, equal to the First Call forecast. Cirrus quarterly income rises (4:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cirrus Logic Inc. CRUS shares were up 1% at $8.75 in after-hours trading Wednesday. The company said fourth-quarter net income was $15.4 million, or 17 cents a share, compared with $2.54 million, or 3 cents a share, during the same period last year. Cirrus said quarterly revenue was $42.2 million, up from $40.4 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a result of $43 million. For the first quarter, the company sees revenue of $44 million to $48 million, with analysts looking for $48 million. Business Objects shares fall after forecast (4:47 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- U.S.-listed shares of French software firm Business Objects SA BOBJ fell around 6% Wednesday evening as investors digested the company's financial forecast for the current quarter. Business Objects predicted a fiscal second-quarter net profit of 10 cents to 13 cents a share, or 30 cents to 33 cents without items, on revenue of $295 million to $300 million. The average of analysts' estimates called for a profit of 37 cents a share on revenue of $297.9 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. For the entire fiscal year, the maker of software used to analyze and track business data forecast a net profit of between 82 cents and 92 cents a share, or $1.55 to $1.65 a share without items, on revenue of $1.23 billion to $1.25 billion. Estimates, on average, put the company's yearly profit at $1.52 a share on revenue of $1.22 billion. Shares fell $2.24 in evening trade to change hands at $35.40. The stock closed the normal session up fractionally at $37.64. Redback Networks narrows loss as sales rise 69% (4:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Redback Networks Inc. RBAK said late Wednesday its first-quarter loss narrowed to $2.6 million, or 5 cents a share, from $7.1 million, or 13 cents, a year earlier. Excluding stock option expenses, the San Jose, Calif.-based maker of networking equipment said it earned $500,000, or 1 cent a share, compared to a loss of $6 million, or 11 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 69% to $57.9 million, surpassing the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, who expected $52 million. The Houston firm cited record-high average dayrates and rig utilization for the company's entire fleet. The company said its order backlog is at about $5 billion, up from $1 billion last year. Tellabs earnings, revenue rise (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Tellabs TLAB reported first-quarter earnings of $52.4 million, or 11 cents a share, vs. earnings of $700,000, or breakeven on a per share basis in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 14 cents a share. Revenue rose to $514.7 million from last year's $435.6 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 12 cents a share and revenue of $494.7 million, on average. The networking company's stock closed Tuesday up 73 cents at $15.81. Yankee Candle posts in-line quarterly profit, revenue beats (7:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Yankee Candle Company Inc. YCC said Wednesday first-quarter net income rose to $12.5 million, or 30 cents a share compared with $10.8 million, or 23 cents a share a year ago. Excluding a one-time tax benefit, the maker of premium scented candles said earnings came in at 25 cents a share. Sales rose 12% to $133.9 million. Same-store sales for the period rose 1%. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 25 cents a share on sales of $125.5 million. The South Deerfield, Mass. company said it expects second-quarter earnings in the range of 18 cents to 20 cents a share on sales growth of around 6% to 8%. The First Call average estimate is for earnings of 21 cents a share on revenue of $116.3 million. On Tuesday, the stock rose 17 cents to $29.03. Mesa Air net falls, revenue higher (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Mesa Air Group Inc. MESA said Wednesday second-quarter net income fell to $5.3 million, or 14 cents a share, from $10.8 million or 26 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue at the regional air carrier grew 18% to $312.1 million from $263.8 million in the three months ended March 31. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 30 cents a share. CBS posts profit, backs full year view (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CBS Corp. CBS on Wednesday said first-quarter net earnings fell to $226.9 million, or 30 cents a share, from $585 million, or 72 cents a share. Earnings from continuing operations rose to $232 million, or 30 cents a share, from $220 million, or 27 cents a share, a year earlier. Proforma results for 2005 are adjusted for the separation from Viacom Inc. VIA and exclude a net gain on investments. Revenue rose to $3.58 billion from $3.45 billion. Analysts, on average, expected it to post a profit of 28 cents a share on revenue of $3.51 billion, according to Thomson First Call. The media giant said it is on track to deliver low single-digit growth in revenues and mid single-digit growth in operating income and earnings per share for the year. Colgate-Palmolive profit, sales rise (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Colgate-Palmolive Co. CL said Wednesday that first-quarter net income rose to $324.5 million, or 59 cents a share, from $300.1 million, or 53 cents, a year ago. Excluding restructuring charges, earnings would have been 70 cents a share, or 4 cents ahead of analysts' average view. Sales for the three months ended March 31 advanced to $2.87 billion from $2.74 billion in last year's first quarter, and ahead of analysts' view for $2.84 billion in sales. The New York consumer-goods company attributed the results to solid gains in worldwide sales and volume. Moody's net income rises 23% (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Moody's Corp. MCO on Wednesday said first-quarter net income rose 23% to $146.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $118.7 million, or 39 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue advanced to $440.2 million from $390.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 49 cents a share and revenue of $451.8 million. Moody's said it continues to expect 2006 growth in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share in the low double-digit percent range, excluding adjustments related to legacy tax matters and expensing of stock-based compensation. Moody's plans to take 13-15 cents a share this year for stock-based compensation costs. PepsiCo 1Q earns $1.02B vs $912M (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- PepsiCo Inc. PEP Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings of $1.02 billion, or 60 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $912 million, or 53 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $7.21 billion from $6.59 billion in the same period a year earlier. Overall volume rose 7% in the quarter. The company said the latest results include a $50 million pre-tax gain related to the sale of shares in The Pepsi Bottling Group PBG The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 58 cents a share in March period on revenue of $7.03 billion. The Purchase, N.Y., soda maker also reaffirmed its outlook for earnings of at least $2.93 per share in 2006. The stock closed Tuesday at $57.50, up 23 cents. CBiz earnings rise on 10% jump in revenue (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CBiz Inc. CBIZ said Wednesday first-quarter net income rose to $12 million, or 16 cents a share from $8.2 million, or 10 cents a share a year ago. The business services group said income from continuing operations came in at 17 cents a share. Revenue rose 10.3% to $171.1 million, with revenue from newly acquired operations contributing $3.7 million, or 2.4% to revenue growth. Chief executive Steven Gerard said the company remains on track to achieve its goal of a minimum 20% to 25% increase in earnings per share in 206 compared with the 28 cents per share reported for 2005. On Tuesday, the stock closed unchanged at $8.67. Manor Care profit, sales fall (7:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Manor Care Inc. HCR said Wednesday that charges hurt first-quarter net income, as it fell to $25 million, or 30 cents a share, from $40.4 million, or 46 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended March 31 declined to $869.3 million from $879.2 million. Analysts expected the Toledo, Ohio, healthcare provider to post earnings, on average, of 50 cents a share on sales of $862.4 million. First Midwest profit affected by options expensing, dilution (7:04 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- First Midwest Bancorp Inc. FMBI reported first-quarter net income of $25.8 million, or 55 cents a share, little chnaged from $25.2 million, or 55 cents, earned in same period during 2005. Adjusted to exclude costs of expensing stock options, the Itasca, Ill.-based company said earnings would have been 56 cents a share for the latest quarter. Dilution from the issuance of 4.4 million common shares used in the financing of First Midwest's acquisition of Bank Calumet also affected results. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a profit of 57 cents a share. Assets as of March 31 totaled nearly $8.72 billion, up from $6.91 billion a year earlier. Shares of First Midwest eased 5 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $36. Private Business Inc. files $86M offering (7:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Private Business Inc. PBIZ on Wednesday filed to raise up to $86 million in a stock offering. Shares closed at $1.75 on Tuesday. CORRECT: American Tower 1st-period loss narrows, rev up 74% (7:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Tower Corp., AMT the Boston owner, operator and developer of broadcast- and wireless-communications sites in the U.S., Mexico and Brazil, reported a narrower first-quarter loss on 74% higher revenue. The loss narrowed to $2.6 million, or 1 cent a share, from $31.6 million, or 14 cents, in the year-earlier period. Revenue reached $320.4 million from $184.4 million. For the second quarter, American Tower estimates profit from continuing operations of $1 million to $3 million on revenue of $317 million to $322 million. On Tuesday, the company's shares rose 45 cents, or 1.4%, to $33.19. (In fourth sentence, corrects to show profit estimate is from continuing operations and corrects figures in revenue outlook.) Engelhard reports 19% increase in profit (6:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Engelhard Corp. EC said first-quarter net income rose 19% to $69 million, or 55 cents a share, with revenue up 43% to $1.46 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 52 cents a share from the Iselin, N.J.-based chemicals firm that separately rejected a bid from BASF. Potash quarterly profit slips, sales drop 7% (6:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fertilizer company Potash Corp of Saskatchewan Inc POT said first-quarter net income declined to $125.5 million from $131.3 million a year earlier. Earnings per share rose to $1.19 from $1.15, reflecting the value of a reduced share base following the repurchase of 9.5 million shares in 2005. Sales declined 7% to $861 million on lower volumes. Offshore volumes dropped 48% as shipments to China, India and Brazil by Canpotex, the offshore marketing agent for Saskatchewan potash producers, dropped from 1.18 million to 0.13 million tonnes. Potash said it expects second-quarter earnings of $1.25 to $1.50 a share. Harleysville Group's quarterly net growth tops 80% (6:34 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Harleysville Group Inc. HGIC reported first-quarter net income of $21.7 million, or 70 cents a share, up from $12 million, or 39 cents, earned in the same period in 2005. The cumulative effect of an accounting change for share-based payments added 3 cents to per-share net earnings for the latest quarter, and operating earnings amounted to 62 cents a share, the Harleysville, Pa.-based property and casualty insurer said. Quarterly revenue reached $239.5 million from $232.7 million. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 55 cents a share on revenue of $239 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Harleysville Group added 47 cents, or 1.6%, to end Tuesday's trading at $29.85. Monster Worldwide profit more than doubles (6:25 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Online recruitment company Monster Worldwide MNST said first-quarter net income more than doubled to $42.3 million, or 32 cents a share, with revenue up 28% to $292 million. From continuing operations, it earned 29 cents a share, topping Thomson First Call-compiled analyst forecasts of 27 cents a share. Second-quarter earnings from continuing operations are seen between 29 cents and 30 cents a share, with revenue between $293 million and $300 million, and 2006 earnings from continuing operations are seen between $1.25 and $1.29 a share, on revenue between $1.18 billion and $1.22 billion. EnCana swings to quarterly profit, helped by accounting gain (6:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Canadian gas producer EnCana Corp ECA sait it swung to a first-quarter net profit of $1.47 billion, or $1.70 a share. In the same quarter a year ago, the company posted a loss of $45 million, or 5 cents a share. The profit figure benefited from an accounting gain of $830 million. EnCana said gas and liquids sales from continuing operations rose 6% in the quarter to 4.32 cubic feet of gas equivalent. The company lifted its quarterly dividend 33% to 10 cents a share and said it was on track to achieve its 2006 guidance for North American sales' growth of 7%. Regis Corp. updates fourth quarter, issues FY-2007 outlook (6:22 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS said up to $25 million, or 54 cents a share, will be added to the hair-salon operator's profit for the fourth quarter ending June 30 as a result of a fee to be paid by Alberto-Culver ACV over the companies' recently terminated merger pact. Accordingly, Regis pegged its fourth-quarter profit forecast in a range of $1.12 to $1.16 a share, up from 64 cents earned in the same period during fiscal 2005. "Operationally, our fourth-quarter outlook remains unchanged," Regis said. The company also issued projections for fiscal 2007, with earnings pegged in a range of $2.22 to $2.34 a share and consolidated revenue estimated at $2.6 billion. Analysts, on average, are looking for Regis to earn 60 cents a share in the fourth quarter and $2.42 a share for fiscal 2007, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. WellPoint 1st-period net up 20%, revenue up 26% (6:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- WellPoint Inc., WLP the Indianapolis health-benefits provider, reported first-quarter net income rose 20% on 26% higher revenue. Net reached $731.8 million, or $1.09 a share, from $611.7 million, or 98 cents, in the year-earlier period. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate for WellPoint of $1.07. Revenue reached $13.82 billion from $10.94 billion. The company estimates profit of $1.14 a share for the second quarter and $4.63 for the full year. Thomson First Call's estimates: $1.13 and $4.57. WellPoint shares fell 76 cents, or 1.1%, to $70.74 on Tuesday. Regis Corp. posts above-consensus adjusted profit (6:14 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Regis Corp. RGS reported net income of $18.6 million, or 40 cents a share, for the third quarter ended March 31, reversing a year-earlier loss of $16.6 million, or 37 cents a share. The hair-care salon operator's profit for the latest quarter would have been 48 cents a share if a charge associated with its previously announced merger termination with Alberto-Culver ACV is excluded, but Minneapolis-based Regis also said fourth-quarter results will benefit from a merger-termination fee paid by Alberto-Culver. The loss in the year-earlier third quarter reflected a $38.3 million goodwill-impairment charge, Regis said. Third-quarter revenue reached $604 million from $557.3 million, up 8%, but same-store sales eased 0.4%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a profit of 47 cents a share on revenue of $605 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Regis added 25 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $34.96. Ipsco quarterly profit rises, sales jump 18% (6:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Steel mill products maker Ipsco Inc IPS said first-quarter net income rose to $150.7 million, or $3.12 a share, from $154.8 million, or $3.06 per share, a year earlier. Sales jumped 18% to $903 million due to the ongoing strength of the plate, energy, tubular and large diameter pipe markets. Ipsco said it sees second-quarter earnings in the range of $2.60 to $2.80 a share. It added it expects robust demand for steel mill products for all of 2006. Serologicals quarterly net rises, sales slip 2.8% (6:07 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Serologicals Corp SERO a developer of consumable biological products, said first-quarter net income rose to $2.8 million, or 8 cents a a share, from $1.9 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue slipped 2.8% to $55 million, primarily because of the divestiture of certain bioprocessing product lines. Serologicals earlier this week agreed to be acquired by Millipore MIL for about $1.4 billion. Baker Hughes quarterly profit almost doubles (5:51 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil services company Baker Hughes Inc BHI said first-quarter net income almost doubled to $339.2 million, or 99 cents a share, from $179.8 million, or 53 cents a share, in the year earlier quarter. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 79 cents a share. Revenue climbed 26% to $2.06 billion on a strong performance in its drilling and production services units. In 2006, the group said it expects revenue to rise 23% to 25% and sees earnings from continuing operations at $7 to $7.39 a share. Baker Hughes guided to capex of $750 million to $780 million for the year. CORRECT: First American profit falls 12%, revenue climbs 18% (5:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- First American FAF said first-quarter net income slipped 12% to $69.7 million, or 71 cents a share, with revenue up 18% to $2 billion. The Santa Ana, Calif.-based business information provider said it was pleased wtih revenue growth in its title insurance, specialty insurance, property information, and risk mitigation and business solutions segments. But an increase in the loss provision rate for the title insurance operations and continued investments in new business initiatives hurt profits, it said. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 75 cents a share. (Corrects to use net income instead of pretax figure.) Pages Jaunes quarterly sales rise 6.8% (2:34 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pages Jaunes Group, a spinoff of France Telecom FTE (FR:013330)on Wednesday said first-quarter consolidated sales rose 6.8% to 209.4 million euros. Minitel sales dropped 35.5% to 10 3 million euros while Internet sales jumped 20.4% to 63.5 million euros. Imperial Tobacco pretax up 13% as cigarette volumes rise (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Imperial Tobacco ITY (UK:IMT)said first-half pretax profit rose 13% to 547 million pounds after cigarette volumes increased by 9% to 86.3 billion, driven by growth in Asia, Eastern Europe, Africa and the Middle East. It's lifting its interim dividend by 12% to 18.5 pence a share. The company said it grew market in the U.K. and also increased share in Germany despite a challenging market there. Infineon quarterly loss narrows, sales rise 24% (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German semiconductor manufacturer Infineon Technologies AG IFX (DE:623100)on Wednesday said its second-quarter loss narrowed to 26 million euros ($32 million), or 0.03 euros a share, from 114 million euros, or 0.15 euros a share, a year earlier. Infineon swung to an EBIT profit of 28 million euros compared to a loss of 117 million euros in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 24% to 1.99 billion euros on higher sales in the memory products and the automotive, industrial and multimarket segments. In the third quarter, Infineon said it expects EBIT and revenue to decline at its two logic divisions from the second quarter. Infineon reiterated that its memory chip unit will be spun off into a separate entity name Qimonda effective May 1. ABN Amro profit rises 12%, to cut 2,400 IT jobs (2:18 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dutch bank ABN Amro ABN (NL:30110)on Wednesday reported a 12.1% increase in first-quarter net profit to 1 billion euros, on consumer and commercial banking organic growth and the first-time inclusion of Italy's Banca Antonveneta in its results. But loan loss provisions jumped to 331 million from 99 million euros on consumers in Latin America, Asia and Holland. Analysts polled by AFX News were looking for earnings between 967 million and 1.12 billion euros. ABN also announced it would cut 2,400 IT jobs in Holland, the U.S., Brazil and the U.K., while hiring 900 in India. Combined with a new centralized IT function, ABN expects to save an additional 150 million euros by 2008, at a charge of 125 million to 150 million euros. Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc. BUD, +0.28% shares ended Wednesday with a 5.3% gain after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $499.2 million, or 64 cents a share, compared with $500.4 million, or 64 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Revenue at the St. Louis-based maker of Budweiser and other beer brands came in at $3.76 billion vs. $3.56 billion the year before. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been looking for revenue of $3.65 billion for the period ended March 31. See full story. Shares of Bell Microproducts Inc. BELM, +0.66% soared 15.6% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 8 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $4.4 million, or 15 cents a share. Excluding stock option expensing, the San Jose, Calif., maker of chip and storage products earned $2.9 million, or 10 cents a share, in the March quarter. Revenue rose 8% in the latest three months to $866.5 million from $803.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 8 cents a share in the first quarter on revenue of $844.7 million. Looking ahead, Bell Microproducts forecast earnings, excluding stock option expensing, of 7 to 11 cents a share for the second quarter on revenue of between $810 million and $840 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate for the June period is for a profit of 7 cents a share. Shares of DeVry Inc. DV, +2.94% jumped 19.1% after the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., provider of educational services posted sharply higher third-quarter earnings. After Tuesday's closing bell, the company reported a profit of $15.7 million, or 22 cents a share, in the March period, up from a year-ago profit of $10.9 million, 15 cents a share. The latest results included stock option expensing of $800,000. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $220.2 million from $201.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said new undergraduate student enrollments at DeVry University increased 16.4% for the spring semester to 10,359 students. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 23 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $215.8 million. DST Systems Inc. DST, +0.47% stock rallied 12% after the Kansas City provider of information technology and software products and services reported first-quarter adjusted earnings of $51.2 million, or 69 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $48.3 million, or 60 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 68 cents a share in the March period. Revenue totaled $382.7 million for the company, which focuses on customers in the financial services industry, in the three-month period. Encore Wire Corp. WIRE, +1.89% shares added 5.6% after the company reported first-quarter net income of 68 cents a share compared with 4 cents in the year-earlier period. Revenue was $252 million, up from $137.2 million. Fiserv Inc. FISV, +0.81% shares gained 7.8% after the company reported first-quarter profit fell 16% as expenses related to stock options weighed on results. The year-earlier financial performance was boosted by a one-time investment gain. See full story. Shares of General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% surged 8.1% after the automaker was upgraded to neutral from sell at Merrill Lynch on the belief it may leverage its over-funded U.S. pension plan to fund its North America restructuring. The stock, a component of the Dow industrials, was rallying 2.8%, or 59 cents, to $22 in Instinet pre-open trading. Analyst John Murphy said he is seeing evidence that GM was taking the necessary steps to turn the company around, including "shrinking to a defensible position," getting a new labor deal and reinvesting in its products. See full story. Jones Lang LaSalle Inc. JLL, +0.69% soared 10.2% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $4.56 million, or 14 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, Jones Lang LaSalle posted a net loss of $8.58 million, or 27 cents a share. The results include a $1.2 million benefit, or 4 cents a share, from a cumulative effect adjustment for a change in accounting for stock-based compensation. Revenue at the Chicago-based provider of real estate services and money management rose to $337.1 million from $240.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast a first-quarter loss of 20 cents a share on revenue of $276 million. The company said its earnings benefited from improved results in all segments, the acquisition of Spaulding & Slye and particularly strong results in the firm's money management business, LaSalle Investment Management. Shares of Keithley Instruments Inc. KEI, +5.91% rose 8.4% after the Cleveland maker of measurement products reported second-quarter earnings of $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, on sales of $39.7 million. The latest results include stock option expensing of 2 cents a share in the March quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 9 cents a share in the quarter on sales $36.9 million. The company said order levels were at their highest in five years, largely due to demand from semiconductor company customers. Leadis Technology Inc. LDIS stock rallied 11.7% after the company said its first-quarter net loss widened to 10 cents a share from 9 cents in the year-earlier period. The adjusted losses were 8 cents compared with 6 cents. Revenue at the Sunnyvale, Calif., company more than doubled to $24.1 million from $11.6 million. Shares of LifeCell Corp. LIFC surged 14.6% after the Branchburg, N.J., biotechnology company reported first-quarter earnings of $4.1 million, or 12 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $2.1 million, or 7 cents a share. The latest results include stock option expensing of $1.8 million. Revenue rose in the three months ended March 31 to $30.7 million from $19.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 9 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $29.5 million. Looking ahead, LifeCell lifted its forecast for the full year to earnings of 50 to 56 cents a share, including 17 cents a share in stock option expensing. The company sees revenue of $130 million to $138 million in 2006, up from a prior projection of $124 million to $130 million Louisiana-Pacific Corp. LPX, +1.27% stock added 6.1% after the company said its first-quarter net income fell to $83.7 million, or 79 cents a share, compared with $101.7 million, or 91 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 52 cents a share and $621.5 million in sales. Nashville, Tenn., Louisiana-Pacific said sales rose more than 2% to $678.3 million from $661.4 million. Shares of Manitowoc Co. MTW, +3.87% rose 10% after the maker of lifting equipment posted strong first-quarter earnings. After Tuesday's closing bell, the company reported a profit of $29.7 million, or 48 cents a share, in the latest quarter, up from a year-ago profit of $6.5 million, or 11 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, excluding items, the company earned $29.2 million, or 47 cents a share, in the March quarter. Sales rose in the latest three months to $633 million from $510.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 40 cents a share in the quarter. Looking ahead, Manitowoc increased its earnings outlook for the year to $2.15 to $2.25 a share in fiscal 2006, reflecting favorable demand fundamentals, primarily in the global crane market. Meritage Homes Corp. MTH, +1.57% shares ended higher by 7.9% after the company said its first-quarter net income more than tripled from the year-earlier period while revenue rose 54%. See full story. Monaco Coach Corp. MNC, -38.46% stock soared 13.5% after the company said first-quarter net income rose to $8.3 million, or 28 cents a share, from $5.3 million, or 18 cents a share, a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting the company to produce average earnings of 12 cents a share. Sales at the recreational vehicle maker increased 17% to $385.1 million. The company said that it expects the motor home market to remain difficult over the next couple of quarters as consumers are facing higher fuel prices and rising interest rates which could dampen purchases. Second quarter sales are expected in a range of $375 million to $385 million, while 2006 sales are forecast at between $1.45 billion and $1.48 billion. Shares of Monster Worldwide Inc. MNST, +1.72% tacked on 6.9% after the company said first-quarter net income more than doubled to $42.3 million, or 32 cents a share, with revenue up 28% to $292 million. From continuing operations, it earned 29 cents a share, topping Thomson First Call-compiled analyst forecasts of 27 cents a share. Second-quarter earnings from continuing operations are seen between 29 cents and 30 cents a share, with revenue between $293 million and $300 million, and 2006 earnings from continuing operations are seen between $1.25 and $1.29 a share, on revenue between $1.18 billion and $1.22 billion. Shares of M-Systems FLSH rallied 9.1% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $7.1 million, or 17 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $6.1 million, or 16 cents a share. On a pro forma basis, excluding amortization of intangible assets, stock option expensing and a gain from an investment sale, the Israeli flash memory maker said it would have earned $8.7 million, or 21 cents a share, in the latest quarter. Revenue rose 87% in the latest three months to $219.1 million from $117 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 18 cents a share in the March period on revenue of $167.4 million. Office Depot Inc. ODP, +0.94% shares gained 8.7% after the Delray Beach, Fla., office products retailer posted strong quarterly earnings. See full story. RF Micro Devices Inc. RFMD stock closed with a 14% gain after the company reported its fourth-quarter loss narrowed to a penny a share from 34 cents in the year-earlier period. The company reported adjusted per-share profit of 9 cents against a year-earlier adjusted loss of 9 cents. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 6 cents. RF's revenue was $225.9 million, up from $150.4 million. Analysts were looking for $210 million. Sanmina-SCI Corp. SANM, +0.77% shares rocketed higher by 26% after the company reported a fiscal second-quarter loss of $103.4 million, or 20 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $1.06 billion, or $1.99 a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, earnings came in at $30.5 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with $29.3 million, or 6 cents a share, last year. Revenue at the San Jose, Calif.-based electronics manufacturing company fell to $2.67 billion from $2.89 billion last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 6 cents a share on revenue of $2.66 billion. The company forecast fiscal third-quarter earnings of 8 cents to 10 cents, excluding items, on revenue of $2.7 billion to $2.8 billion. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 7 cents on revenue of $2.76 billion. SonicWall Inc. SNWL shares rose 6.4% after the Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of network security products posted a surprise adjusted profit for the first quarter as revenue leapt 25% to $51.9 million. The company reported non-GAAP (generally accepted accounting principles) earnings of $1.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the March period, ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate for a breakeven performance. Looking ahead, SonicWall forecast non-GAAP earnings of 3 to 4 cents a share for second quarter on revenue of between $41 million and $42 million. Shares of Taser International Inc. TASR stock added 5.6% after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun-gun maker posted first-quarter earnings of $692,751, or a penny per share, up from a year-ago loss of $38,915, break even on a per share basis. Net sales swelled to $13.9 million in the three months ended March 31 from $10.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 2 cents a share in the March period on sales of $13.6 million. Tellabs Inc. TLAB shares ran up 8.1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $52.4 million, or 11 cents a share, vs. earnings of $700,000, or breakeven on a per share basis in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 14 cents a share. Revenue rose to $514.7 million from last year's $435.6 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 12 cents a share and revenue of $494.7 million, on average. See full story. TriQuint Semiconductor Inc. TQNT ended up 7.8% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $2.25 million, or 2 cents a share. During the same period a year ago, TriQuint posted a net loss of $7.75 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue at the Hillsboro, Ore.-based company rose to $87.9 million from $67 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast first-quarter revenue of $85 million. Gross margin for the quarter was 30.3% vs. 28.7% in the fourth quarter of 2005, and the book-to-bill ratio was 1.2 to 1. TriQuint expects second-quarter earnings of a penny to 2 cents a share on revenue that's up 8% to 10% sequentially. For 2006, per-share earnings are expected to be 8 cents to 13 cents on revenue that's up 34% to 37% over 2005. Under Armour Inc. UARM shares surged 13.1% after the performance apparel maker reported first-quarter earnings that more than tripled and topped expectations, and raised its 2006 outlook. Earnings rose to $8.7 million, or 18 cents a share, from $2.5 million, or 5 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $87.7 million from last year's $58.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $72 million, on average. Gross margins increased to 50.5% from 44.4%. For 2006, the company now expects revenue growth of 35% to 39% to $380 million to $390 million, vs. analyst projections of $353.5 million. Decliners AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% shares ended Wednesday down 7% after the company reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of 61 cents a share, up from 45 cents in the year-earlier period. The results include a benefit of 6 cents a share from special items. Revenue rose 16% to $15.2 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 54 cents and revenue of $13.85 billion. The pharmaceutical-services company raised its 2006 earnings estimate to $2.06 to $2.21 a share from $1.98 to $2.13, and its revenue growth forecast to 10% to 12% from 7% to 9%. Shares of Ashland Inc. ASH, +1.04% dropped 11% after the Covington, Ky., provider of chemical and transportation products and services reported second-quarter earnings of $49 million, or 67 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $33 million, or 44 cents a share. The latest results include $6 million, or 8 cents a share, in after-tax interest income, and tax benefits of $8 million, or 11 cents a share, from research and development credits and favorable adjustments to tax contingency reserves. Revenue totaled $2.3 billion in the latest three months, up from $2.15 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company noted its year-over-year earnings comparison reflects the transfer of its former 38% interest in a joint venture to its partner Marathon Oil. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 52 cents a share in the March quarter on revenue of $2.34 billion. AVX Corp. AVX, +1.04% shares slumped 12.5% after the company said fourth-quarter net income rose to $27.4 million, or 16 cents a share, from $6.6 million, or 4 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended March 31 increased to $338.4 million from $306 million in last year's fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expect the Myrtle Beach, S.C., maker of electronic components to record earnings, on average, of 14 cents a share. Shares of Cheesecake Factory Inc. CAKE, +0.46% gave back 10.4% after the company reported first-quarter net income of 24 cents a share, level with the year-earlier period. Sales were $306.4 million vs. $268.2 million. Excluding stock option expense, the company would have earned 27 cents a share in the latest period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call on average expected net of 25 cents. C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. CHRW, +2.20% stock fell 8.3% after the company said increased demand and higher rates in its truck-transportation business helped spark a 39% rise in first-quarter profit. See full story. CV Therapeutics Inc. CVTX shares lost 7.6% after the company reported its first-quarter net loss widened to $1.57 a share from $1.31 in the year-earlier period. Revenue for the Palo Alto, Calif., maker of cardiovascular medicines was $5.1 million vs. $5.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call estimated the loss at $1.71 a share. Shares of Doral Financial Corp. DRL, +0.00% tumbled 9.6% after the San Juan, Puerto Rico-based financial services provider suspended dividend payments on its common stock. Doral said its board views the decision as "a prudent capital management decision designed to preserve and strengthen the company's capital." The company also approved dividends on four series of its preferred stock. Evergreen Solar Inc. ESLR shares ended down 6.4% after the company said its first-quarter loss increased to $8.1 million, or 13 cents a share from $3.2 million, or 6 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $11.9 million from $10.5 million. A survey of nine analysts by Thomson First Call forecast a loss of 14 cents a share and revenue of $11.5 million.
