The company continues to expect its consolidated revenue to increase throughout the year, more than doubling from 2005 levels for full-year 2006. Shares of Ingram Micro Inc. IM, +0.23% finished the session lower by 7.1% after the company said its first-quarter profit rose 46% from the year-earlier period as the technology-products wholesaler reported revenue gains across all its major geographic regions. See full story. Keane Inc. KEA shares lost 10.8% after the company said first-quarter net income eased 25.9% to $5.4 million, or 9 cents a share, while revenue rose 4.9% to $243.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting average earnings of 15 cents a share from the business process and information technology company. Keane said that net income fell in part due to severance costs of $1.3 million and a $1.9 million revenue reserve associated with a fixed-price contract. The company estimates that revenues for the second quarter will be in a range of $240 million to $250 million, with earnings per share in a range of 10 to 12 cents. Shares of Lone Star Technologies Inc. LSS, +2.46% slumped 13% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $41.3 million, or $1.33 a share, vs. $38.9 million, or $1.30 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Dallas-based maker of oilfield products rose to $350.9 million from $297.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of $1.54 a share on revenue of $345 million. Shares of Micrel Inc. MCRL plunged 16.8% after the San Jose, Calif., chipmaker forecast sequential revenue growth of 2% to 6% for the second quarter, saying order lead times for its products remains fairly short and that "a relatively high proportion" of its revenue still needs to be booked and shipped. For the first quarter ended March 31, the company posted a profit of $8.7 million, or 10 cents a share, on revenue of $68.2 million. The news prompted downgrades from Citigroup to hold and Deutsche Bank to sell. Moody's Corp. MCO, +1.48% stock fell 12% after the company said first-quarter net income rose 23% to $146.2 million, or 49 cents a share, from $118.7 million, or 39 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue advanced to $440.2 million from $390.5 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 49 cents a share and revenue of $451.8 million. Moody's said it continues to expect 2006 growth in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share in the low double-digit percent range, excluding adjustments related to legacy tax matters and expensing of stock-based compensation. Parametric Technology Corp. PMTC shares gave back 8.1% after the company reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $10.8 million, or 9 cents a share, down from $20.5 million, or 18 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been 20 cents a share. Revenue rose 14% to $200.2 million from last year's $176.1 million, amid an 18% increase in service revenue and 3.6% growth in license revenue. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 22 cents a share and revenue of $198.6 million, on average. Looking ahead, the business software company expects earnings, excluding items, of 20 to 25 cents a share and revenue of $205 million to $210 million. Phoenix Cos. Inc. PNX, -1.57% shares closed down 6.7% after the company said first-quarter net income fell to $1.7 million, or 2 cents a share from $9.4 million, or 9 cents a share in the year-ago period. The Hartford, Conn. insurance firm reported a total segment loss of $6.2 million, or 6 cents a share because of a non-cash charge in its asset management unit. Total segment income last year was $16.8 million, or 16 cents a share. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 22 cents a share. The company said the quarter was "challenging" with its first segment loss since 2002, but the results "are not indicative of the underlying strengths of the business or our prospects for the year." Shares of Pixelworks Inc. PXLW, +3.48% sank 17.6% after the Tualatin, Ore., semiconductor maker reported a loss before items of $7.8 million, or 16 cents a share, for the first quarter, beyond the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of 13 cents a share. Revenue slid 9% in the latest three months to $36.6 million from $40.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The performance missed Wall Street's consensus view for revenue of $37.3 million in the March period. Pixelworks also said it will no longer pursue business in certain digital streaming markets in order to reduce manufacturing overhead costs and operating expenses. The company expects to record restructuring charges of $1.6 million to $3.5 million related to this decision over the course of the second and third quarters. Looking ahead, Pixelworks forecast revenue of $30 million to $33 million for the second quarter with a loss before items of 13 to 19 cents a share. The current average analysts' revenue estimate for the June period is $40.3 million. Shares of PRA International PRAI fell 6.1% after the Reston, Va., provider of clinical research services reported disappointing results for the first quarter. Before the opening bell, the company posted earnings of $6.1 million, or 25 cents a share, for the March period on revenue of $76.6 million. Excluding stock option expensing, the company earned 28 cents a share in the latest quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 32 cents a share in the latest quarter. The company said the performance was below its expectations and it cited timing issues, continued contract delays and the cancellation of a major clinical program. SigmaTel Inc. SGTL shares plummeted 22.6% after the company said it swung to a first-quarter loss of 69 cents a share from earnings of 68 cents in the year-earlier period. The adjusted loss was 61 cents compared with adjusted earnings of 67 cents. Revenue at the Austin, Texas, maker of chips for handheld music players fell to $33 million from $99.3 million. SIRF Technology Holdings Inc. SIRF shares fell 10.8% after the company disappointed investors with its sales outlook following a first-quarter report that was mostly in-line with Wall Street's expectations. See full story. Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc. VRTX, +2.13% shares lost 7.2% after the company posted a wider loss for the first quarter amid mounting costs related to clinical trials for its two leading drug candidates. See full story. Shares of Wellman Inc. WLM, +17.86% tumbled 20.7% after the Shrewsbury, N.J., maker of polyester products swung to a loss in the first quarter due to surging competition from imports because of a raw material cost advantage for Asian companies. The company posted a first-quarter loss of $16 million, or 61 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $11.6 million, or 22 cents a share. Wellman said it estimates it lost 25 million pounds of PET resin volume in the first quarter due to the imports. Shares of Zebra Technologies Corp. ZBRA, +2.38% dropped 12.4% after the Vernon Hills, Ill., printing products company reported first-quarter earnings of $26.1 million, or 37 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $25.8 million, or 36 cents a share. Sales rose in the three months ended April 1 to $175.8 million from $170.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 39 cents a share on revenue of $180.2 million in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, Zebra sees earnings of 34 to 39 cents a share in the second quarter on sales of between $180 million and $190 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 42 cents a share in the June period. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. tasr enjoyed a 4.4% increase to $10.86 on Wednesday after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker posted first-quarter earnings of $692,751, or a penny per share, up from a year-ago loss of $38,915, break even on a per share basis. Net sales swelled to $13.9 million in the three months ended March 31 from $10.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 2 cents a share in the March period on sales of $13.6 million.
title: Taser shares get boost in wake of 1Q earnings report

content: Amedisys quarterly income rises; CFO Browne resigns (8:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Amedisys Inc. AMED, +0.20% on Wednesday said fourth-quarter net income was $7.3 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with $6.14 million, or 39 cents a share, during the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 55 cents. The home health nursing services company said quarterly revenue was $118.9 million, compared with $64.4 million last year. Analysts were looking for quarterly revenue of $118 million. Amedisys affirmed its view of 2006 income ranging from $2.33 to $2.43 cents a share, on revenue of $510 million. Analysts are looking for per-share income of $2.42 on revenue of $516 million. The company added that Gregory Browne, chief financial officer, has resigned to pursue other professional interests. Browne will remain CFO until a replacement is found. Circor quarterly income rises (8:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Circor International Inc. CIR, +2.92% after Wednesday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income was $4.75 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $130,000, or a penny a share, during the same period last year. The provider of valves and fluid control products said quarterly revenue was $120.4 million, compared with $106.8 million last year. Bluefly swings to a quarterly loss (7:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Bluefly Inc. BFLY after Wednesday's closing bell said the fourth-quarter net loss $55,000, or 7 cents a share. During the same period last year, the company reported net income of $7,000, with a net per-share loss of 7 cents. Quarterly revenue was $21.2 million, compared with $14.5 million last year. Knology quarterly loss narrows (7:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Knology Inc. KNOL after Wednesday's closing bell said the fourth-quarter net loss was $14.8 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $18.5 million, or 78 cents a share, during the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of 59 cents. The broadband company said quarterly revenue was $59.9 million, compared with $52.9 million last year. Aaron Rents quarterly profit rises; updates outlook (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Aaron Rents Inc. RNT, +2.20% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $14.6 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $13.8 million, or 27 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Atlanta-based rental services company posted revenue of $296.2 million vs. $242.1 million. Additionally, Aaron Rents forecast first-quarter earnings of 38 cents to 41 cents a share on revenue in excess of $315 million. For 2006, the company expects per-share earnings of $1.45 to $1.55 on revenue in excess of $1.3 billion, excluding revenues of franchisees. The company also sees positive quarterly same-store revenue growth. Quicksilver Resources quarterly income rises (6:47 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Quicksilver Resources Inc. KWK Wednesday evening said fourth-quarter net income was $34.7 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $9.95 million, or 13 cents a share, during the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 44 cents. The oil and gas production company said quarterly revenue was $102.9 million, compared with $52.4 million last year. Analysts had expected revenue of $110 million. GlobalSantaFe swings to profit on strong rig rates (6:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Offshore drilling contractor GlobalSantaFe Corp. GSF, +0.28% reported late Wednesday fourth-quarter net earnings of $180 million, or 73 cents a share, reversing a loss of $7.6 million, or 3 cents a share, a year ago. The latest results include a one-time gain of $23.5 million, or 9 cents a share, from the sale of a drillship. Revenue for the quarter rose to $604 million from $498 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the Houston-based company to report earnings of 56 cents a share on $636 million in revenue. Before the report, GlobalSantaFe shares fell 1% to close at $55.06. General Maritime quarterly earnings fall; ups share buyback (6:33 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- General Maritime Corp. GMR, +1.16% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $104.6 million, or $2.78 a share, compared with $140.5 million, or $3.70 a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the New York-based provider of crude oil transportation services fell to $156.4 million from $233.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of $1.46 a share on revenue of $108 million. Additionally, General Maritime said it has approved an additional $200 million under its share buyback program. The company also declared a quarterly dividend of $2 a share, payable March 17 to shareholders as of March 3. Barrick Gold quarterly profit rises (6:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Barrick Gold Corp. ABX, +0.48% (CA:ABX)after Wednesday's closing bell reported fourth-quarter net earnings were $175 million, or 32 cents a share, compared with $156 million, or 29 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose to $776 million, up from $501 million in the year-ago period. JLG Industries quarterly income rises (6:02 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- JLG Industries Inc. JLG, +1.51% after Wednesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net income of $27.4 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $7.48 million, or 17 cents a share, during the same period last year. The two analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 48 cents. JLG, which produces access equipment, said quarterly revenue was $494.4 million, compared with $353.4 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $442 million. JLG sees full-year revenue growth at the upper end of its prior range of 20% to 25%, with analysts looking for a rate of 24%. The company expects full-year pro forma per-share income of $2.35 to $2.45, up from its prior outlook of $2.15 to $2.25. Analysts are looking for annual per-share income of $2.44. Novatel Wireless quarterly income falls (5:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Novatel Wireless Inc. NVTL after Wednesday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income was $121,000, or breakeven on a per-share basis, compared with $5.17 million, or 17 cents a share, during the same period last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 4 cents. The wireless broadband company said quarterly revenue was $48.7 million, compared with $33.4 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $49 million. Novatel sees first-quarter revenue of $40 million to $42 million, and net pro forma per-share results of breakeven to 3 cents. Analysts are looking for first-quarter revenue of $47 million, and per-share income of 6 cents. Symbol Tech quarterly earnings fall; updates outlook (5:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Symbol Technologies Inc. SBL, +5.07% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $23.9 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $28.5 million, or 11 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Holtsville, N.Y.-based maker of mobile information management systems posted revenue of $438.9 million vs. $450.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 7 cents a share on revenue of $437 million. Symbol said it sees first-quarter earnings of 8 cents to 9 cents a share, excluding the cost of expensing stock options, estimated at a penny a share. The company expects first-quarter revenue to be flat or slightly down from fourth-quarter revenue. Analysts are currently looking for first-quarter earnings of 9 cents a share on revenue of $450 million. Oneok quarterly profit more than doubles (5:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Oneok Inc. OKE, +2.32% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $237.6 million, or $2.30 cents a share, compared with $98.4 million, or 90 cents a share, during the year-ago period. The Tulsa, Okla.-based diversified energy company posted total revenue of $4.7 billion vs. $2.54 billion a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 67 cents a share. Oneok said its fourth-quarter results included the $264.2 million gain on the sale of its Texas gathering and processing assets. The company also recorded a $5.9 million impairment in other income in the fourth quarter on a 50% investment in a gas processing plant in Oklahoma it doesn't operate, and a $2.6 million impairment, recorded in other income, related to its investment in a company-operated gas gathering system partnership that may end early this year. Chiquita Brands swings to quarterly loss (5:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chiquita Brands International Inc. CQB, +31.42% after Wednesday's closing bell said the fourth-quarter net loss was $19 million, or 45 cents a share. During the same period last year, the fruit company reported net income of $25.1 million, or 61 cents a share. Chiquita said the quarterly result includes costs of 55 cents a share from flooding in Honduras, as well as consolidation of fresh-cut fruit facilities in the Midwest. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share loss of a penny. Chiquita said fourth-quarter revenue was $999.1 million, compared with $768.3 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $1.06 billion. Sina quarterly income falls (4:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sina Corp. SINA, +4.55% after Wednesday's closing bell said fourth-quarter net income was $13.8 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $17.4 million, or 30 cents a share, during the same period last year. Pro forma per-share income for the quarter was 21 cents, compared with 31 cents last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected quarterly per-share income of 22 cents. Sina, an online media company providing services in China, reported quarterly revenue of $52 million, compared with $56.9 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $52 million. For the first quarter, Sina expects revenue of $44.5 million to $46.5 million, and pro forma income of $8.5 million to $9.5 million. Analysts are looking for quarterly revenue of $52 million. Express Scripts income jumps 37% (4:35 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93% on Wednesday reported net income of $111 million, or 75 cents a share, a 37% jump over the $81 million, or 53 cents a share, reported a year ago. Reporting after the close, the company said revenue for the St. Louis-based pharmacy distribution firm was $4.6 billion vs. last year's $3.9 billion. Excluding a one-time charge for early debt retirement, the company would have reported earnings of 77 cents a share. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of 75 cents on revenue of $4.5 billion, according to Thomson First Call. The company's shares were up 86 cents to $93.91 at the close. Molina Healthcare quarterly earnings fall; revenue rises 13% (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Molina Healthcare Inc. MOH, +2.64% after the closing bell on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $10.7 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with $16.3 million, or 58 cents a share, during the year-ago period. Revenue at the Long Beach, Calif.-based provider of managed healthcare services rose 13% to $423.2 million from $375.4 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 33 cents a share on revenue of $439 million. Additionally, Molina cited four issues that were adversely affecting medical care costs: increased hospital costs, higher costs from catastrophic cases, increased maternity costs in Michigan and Washington, and greater outpatient costs. Viacom 4Q profit from operations declines (4:27 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) - Viacom Inc. VIA said after the market closed Thursday that, excluding results from the CBS Corp. CBS, -0.94% spinoff it completed in December, its fourth-quarter profit from operations fell to $220 million, or 29 cents a share, from a profit from operations of $378 million, or 45 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The figure in the latest three months includes an unusual severance expense of $23 million and writedowns related to abandoned film projects that totaled $32 million. Excluding these items, Viacom would have earned $282 million, or 37 cents a share, in the latest quarter on a pro forma basis. Revenue rose 9% to $568 million. In 2006, Viacom expects to post revenue that should improve by a double-digit percentage over the 2005 total of $9.61 billion. It also sees a profit from operations in the range of $1.95 to $2 -- excluding unusual charges -- compared with $1.70 per share in 2005. Salesforce.com profit jumps, yet outlook weighs on shares (4:18 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, +3.03% late Wednesday said its fiscal fourth-quarter profit jumped 66% as it signed up a record 48,000 new paying subscribers for its business software delivered via the Internet. The company said its profit for the period ended Jan. 31 rose to $6 million, or 5 cents a share, from $3.6 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 67% to $91.1 million from $54.6 million. Wall Street analysts, on average, expected the San Francisco-based company to earn 5 cents a share on revenue of $91.8 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Salesforce issued a profit outlook for the current fiscal year that fell short of analysts' average estimate, its shares down over 4% in evening trading. RR Donnelley swings to loss on impairment charges (4:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- RR Donnelley & Sons RHD, -2.22% on Wednesday posted a fourth-quarter net loss from continuing operations of $236 million, or $1.09 a share, vs. a profit of $148.8 million, or 66 cents a share, a year ago. Sales came in at $2.4 billion, up from $2.1 billion last year. Excluding impairment and restructuring charges, earnings from continuing operations would have come in at 62 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a profit of 61 cents a share with sales of $2.3 billion. CryoLife shares gain; co. reaffirms 2006 revenue outlook (2:02 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of CryoLife Inc. CRY, +1.26% rose 7% to $4.55 after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $681,000, or 6 cents a share, narrower than a year-ago loss of $2.4 million, or 10 cents a share. The latest results include gains from a change in the value of a derivative related to convertible preferred stock and a favorable adjustment to a product liability accrual. Excluding these items, the company lost $1.8 million, or 10 cents a share, in the December period. Revenue rose 13% in the latest three months to $18 million from $15.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company reaffirmed its revenue outlook for 2006, forecasting tissue processing and product revenue of between $74 million and $77 million. Efunds rallies on strong 4Q earns, outlook (12:22 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Efunds Corp. EFD rose 13% to $25.50 on Wednesday after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $12.7 million, or 27 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $11.3 million, or 22 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 25 cents a share in the December period. Revenue rose 6% in the latest three months to $138 million from $130.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Scottsdale, Ariz., provider of electronic payments technology products and services forecast earnings of $1.26 to $1.36 a share for 2006, excluding stock option expensing. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $1.20 a share for the year. CEC Entertainment shares top NYSE % decliners list (12:05 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of CEC Entertainment CEC, +0.24% fell 12.2% to $33.06 in midday action on Wednesday, topping the percentage decliners list on the New York Stock Exchange. After Tuesday's closing bell, the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $9.9 million, or 28 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $15.6 million, or 41 cents a share. Revenue slipped in the latest three months to $164.1 million from $172.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The profit performance fell short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 35 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Irving, Texas-based restaurant operator sees earnings of 80 to 85 cents a share for the first quarter and $1.94 to $2.02 a share for the year, below Wall Street's current consensus estimates of 93 cents and $2.27 a share, respectively. The company plans to begin expensing stock option compensation starting in the first quarter. CORRECT: Baidu.com quarterly earnings, revenue rise (11:17 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Baidu.com Inc. BIDU, +0.04% after the closing bell on Tuesday reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $3 million, or 9 cents a share. The Chinese Internet search engine posted total revenue of $14.2 million, representing a 29.2% increase from the previous quarter, the company said. Net income excluding share-based compensation expenses was $4.3 million, or 13 cents a share. Baidu.com forecast first-quarter revenue of $15.5 million to $16.1 million. (Corrects first-quarter outlook.) Sempra boosts earnings on growing commodities business (11:00 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Sempra Energy SRE, +0.81% citing strong results from its commodities business, reported Wednesday fourth-quarter net income of $355 million, or $1.38 a share, compared with $346 million, or $1.46, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended Dec. 31 rose to $4 billion from $2.9 billion a year earlier, with higher natural gas prices accounting for most of the increase. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the San Diego-based energy company to hand in per-share earning of $1.25 a share. The company raised its earnings outlook for 2006 to $3.40 to $3.60 a share from $3.20 to $3.40 previously. Sempra stock was up 1.1% in early action at $49.00. Bell Microproducts Q4 adjusted earnings 8c vs 20c (10:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Bell Microproducts Inc. BELM, +0.66% said Wednesday its fourth-quarter loss was $9.4 million, or 31 cents, compared with net income of $5.8 million, or 20 cents, a year earlier. The San Jose, Calif., technology company said that, excluding restructuring costs and one-time charges, earnings for the latest quarter were $2.4 million, or 8 cents a share. The average earnings estimate of five analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 9 cents a share. Revenue for the fourth quarter rose 4% to $842.4 million. Shares of Bell Micro rose 3.1% to $6.20 in early Wednesday trading. Bank stocks lead financial sector's gains (9:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Financial stocks rose Wednesday along with the overall market on tame core consumer price index data. Bank stocks led the way, with a rise of 0.77% by the Philadelphia Bank Index $BKX The Amex Securities Broker Dealer Index $XBD rose 0.5% and the S&P Insurance Index IUX increased 0.5%. Bank of America BAC, +2.04% rose 17 cents to $44.71 after it announced restatements that would result in a $345 million gain. Unit Corp. net income more than doubles (9:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Unit Corp. UNT, +21.08% on Wedneday reported fourth-quarter net income of $84.5 million, or $1.82 a share, compared with $29.9 million, or 65 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $293.1 million from $160 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of $1.61 a share and revenue of $263.45 million. Dayrates and margins on the company's drilling rigs reached record levels and the momentum of the cycle has continued into 2006, the company said. Dresser-Rand to restructure steam turbine business (9:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dresser-Rand Group Inc. DRC, -2.04% said Wednesday it has a plan to integrate its steam turbine business with the steam turbine assets of Tuthill Energy Systems, which it acquired in Sept. 2005. The company expects to save about $15 million a year through the restructuring. This year, the restructuring should save about $10.5 million, which will be offset by about $4.5 million in expenses, and result in a first-quarter non-cash gain of about $12 million. Arrow Electronics tops Wall St. consensus earns view (9:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Arrow Electronics Inc. ARW, +1.70% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $74.4 million, or 60 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $47.7 million, or 40 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $2.96 billion from $2.72 billion in the same period a year earlier. Excluding items, such as restructuring charges and a loss on a debt repurchase, the Melville, N.Y., electronic components company earned $77.4 million, or 63 cents a share, in the December quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 58 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 58 to 61 cents a share in the first quarter on sales of between $3.075 billion and $3.175 billion. The stock closed Tuesday at $35.14, down 30 cents. Speedway Motorsports 4Q profit rises (9:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- Speedway Motorsports TRK, -2.89% said Wednesday its fourth quarter net income rose to $34.2 million, or 77 cents a share from $13.5 million, or 31 cents a share a year ago. Revenue rose to $152.5 million in the latest quarter, from $88.5 million a year ago. TJX Cos. 4Q earns $288.7M vs $165M (8:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- TJX Cos. TJX, +1.08% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $288.7 million, or 60 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $165 million, or 33 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $4.72 billion from $4.33 billion in the same period a year earlier. Excluding gains related to the repatriation of foreign earnings and a correction to a deferred tax liability, the Framingham, Mass., off-price retailer earned 46 cents a share on a pro forma basis in the December period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 44 cents a share in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, TJX sees earnings of 31 to 33 cents a share in the first quarter and $1.42 to $1.46 a share for the full year. This forecast is based on expectations for same-store sales growth of 2% to 3% for both periods. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for earnings of $1.50 a share for the year, and 33 cents a share for the March quarter. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.51, up 6 cents. Bank of America restatements to result in a net gain (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Bank of America BAC, +2.04% said Wednesday that a restatement of its financial statements as far back as 2002 would result in a net gain to the company of $345 million. The changes were made to meet the accounting standard under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards 133 for derivatives transactions. The restatements affect the full year 2002 plus the quarterly and annual periods in 2003, 2004, and 2005. Bank of America said the restatement would increase shareholders equity by $308 million, or less than 1% as of Dec. 31, 2005. Dollar Tree earnings rise (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dollar Tree Stores Inc. DLTR, +1.05% on Wednesday posted earnings of $86.5 million, or 81 cents a share, compared with $83.7 million, or 74 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales for the quarter were $1.08 billion, up 9.3%. The company forecast sales for the first quarter to be in the range of $845 million to $870 million. First quarter same-store sales are expected to be up in the low single digits, with earnings in a range of 29 cents to 31 cents a share. For the full year, Dollar Tree estimates sales will range from $3.85 billion to $3.94 billion, with same-store sales nearly flat to up in the low single digits. The company said it sees earnings for the year in the range of $1.68 to $1.80 a share. Owens Corning income from operations rises (8:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Owens Corning OWENQ reported fourth-quarter income from operations Wednesday of $230 million, including a $74 million credit for asbestos litigation claims related to insurance recoveries, compared with a similar $146 million for the same period a year ago. Sales at Owens Corning rose 15% in the three months ended Dec. 31 to $1.71 billion from $1.48 billion. The company filed a plan of reorganization on Dec. 31 to emerge from Chapter 11. Cox Radio 4Q earns decline on asset write-down charge (8:31 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cox Radio Inc. CXR, +3.28% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5.5 million, or 5 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $18.3 million, or 18 cents a share. The latest results include a non-cash write-down of goodwill of $13.4 million, or 13 cents a share. Revenue slipped 2.1% in the latest three months to $108.9 million from $111.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 18 cents a share in the December period. The stock closed Tuesday at $13.87, up 14 cents. Pinnacle Entertainment 4Q earns $7.5M vs loss $4.8M (8:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pinnacle Entertainment Inc. PNK, +0.57% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $7.5 million, or 17 cents a share, up from a year-ago loss of $4.8 million, or 13 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, the Las Vegas casino operator earned $9.8 million, or 23 cents a share, in the December quarter. Revenue rose 73.2% in the latest three months to $227 million from $131 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 14 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $202.1 million. The stock closed Tuesday at $27.56, down 2.3%. Wabtec profit tops analyst expectations (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Wabtec Corp. WAB, +1.71% reported fourth-quarter net income Wednesday of $16.3 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $9.2 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 32 cents a share. The maker of components for freight cars and railroad locomotives said sales rose in the period by 20% to $270.3 million from $224.4 million. Wabtec also affirmed its earnings outlook of $150 a share in 2006, excluding restructuring expenses. Berry Petroleum posts higher fourth-quarter earnings (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Berry Petroleum Co. BRY, -7.81% on Wednesday posted fourth-quarter earnings of $30.4 million, or $1.35 a share, compared with $25.3 million, or $1.11 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $116.1 million from $80.5 million. Anlaysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of $1.60 a share on revenue of $118.8 million, according to Thomson First Call. Garmin net income rises (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Garmin Ltd. GRMN, +1.24% reported fourth-quarter net income Wednesday of $87.1 million, or 80 cents a share, compared with $47.6 million, or 44 cents a share in the year-ending period in 2004. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 70 cents a share. Sales rose 44% in the 14 weeks ended Dec. 31 to $319.3 million from $220.9 million in the 13 weeks ended Dec. 25, 2004. Garmin, a maker of navigational devices, said it expects 2006 revenue of more than $1.3 billion earnings of $3.19 a share. Entercom fourth quarter profit and revenue fall (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Radio broadcaster Entercom ETM, +1.58% on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter net income of $15.8 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with net income of $19.4 million, or 40 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue declined 6% to $103.7 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected earnings of 34 cents a share on revenue of $103 million. The company said it expects to post first-quarter net revenue of $90 million to $91 million. Analysts predicted revenue of 26 cents a share on revenue of $95 million. Martha Stewart Omnimedia swings to profit (8:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Martha Stewart Omnimedia Inc. MSO, +0.00% on Wednesday posted net income of $2.95 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.33 million, or 15 cents a share. On an operating basis, it posted income of $2.5 million, or 6 cents a share. In the year-ago period it posted an operating loss of $9.5 million, or 14 cents a share. Revenues for the fourth quarter were $84.5 million, up 40%. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of 15 cents a share on revenue of $83 million, according to Thomson First Call. For 2006 it forecast revenue in the range of $270 million to $280 million, and an operating loss in the range of $9 million to $11 million. For the first quarter it expects revenue of about $60 million, and an operating loss in the range of $8.5 million to $9 million. Caraustar to lift prices on paper tube pdts by up to 6% (8:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Caraustar Industries CSAR Wednesday said it plans to raise prices by up to 6% on its paper tube and core product lines, effective March 20. Shares of the Atlanta-based recycled packaging company closed Tuesday at $10.21, down 4.5%. QLT posts widening loss on huge asset impairment charge (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- QLT Inc. QLTI Wednesday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $370.4 million, or $4.04 a share, wider than a year-ago loss of $221.1 million, or $2.64 a share. The latest results include a charge of $410.5 million related to goodwill impairment stemming from its acquisition of Atrix Laboratories. On an adjusted basis, the company earned 11 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Sales slipped in the latest three months to $50.4 million from $53.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Vancouver-based provider of healthcare products forecast sales of $370 million to $400 million in 2006 for its Visudyne treatment for age-related macular degeneration but suspended providing further details of its guidance for the year due to a patent dispute with TAP. The dispute involves the sale of the Eligard prostate cancer treatment product in the U.S. Taser Int'l 4Q earns $92,697 vs $4.7M (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $92,697, or break even on a per share basis, down from a year-ago profit of $4.7 million, or 7 cents a share. Sales fell in the latest three months to $12.6 million from $19.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker closed Tuesday at $10.40. American Woodmark sees 4Q earns ahead of Wall St. view (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Woodmark Corp. AMWD, +3.04% Wednesday posted third-quarter earnings of $6.1 million, or 37 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $7.1 million, or 42 cents a share. Sales rose 4% in the latest three months to $191.1 million from $183.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 26 cents a share in the December period on sales of $188 million. Looking ahead, the Winchester, Va., kitchen cabinet maker forecast earnings of 45 to 50 cents a share for the fourth quarter, ahead of Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 35 cents a share. The stock closed Tuesday at $29.36, up 3.2%. Ritchie Bros. 4Q earns $14.2M vs $11.3M (7:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ritchie Bros. RBA, +0.67% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $14.2 million, or 41 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $11.3 million, or 33 cents a share. Gross auction sales rose in the latest three months to $589.9 million from $549.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 36 cents a share in the December period. The stock closed Tuesday at $47.60, up 27 cents. Harrah's posts fourth-quarter loss (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Harrah's Entertainment Inc. HET, +0.94% on Wednesday posted a net loss of $142.2 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with a profit of $76.9 million, or 68 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Fourth-quarter revenues rose 76.2% to $2.1 billion. IHOP quarterly profit, sales slip (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- IHOP Corp. IHP, -1.15% on Wednesday reported a 4.9% drop in fourth-quarter profit to $10 million, or 53 cents a share, from $10.5 million, or 52 cents, a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 51 cents a share. Earnings per share increased despite the decline in profit because there were fewer shares outstanding in the most recent period. Revenue for the three months ended Dec. 31 fell to $88 million from $94.4 million in last year's fourth quarter. For fiscal 2006, the Glendale, Calif., restaurant operator affirmed its outlook for earnings of $2.25 to $2.35 a share. Analysts' estimate stands at $2.37 a share. Sprint Nextel 4Q earns $197M vs $437M (7:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Sprint Nextel Corp. S, +0.41% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $197 million, or 7 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $437 million, or 29 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, before amortization and certain non-recurring items, the company earned $1.09 billion, or 33 cents a share, in the latest three months. Revenue rose 63% in the December period to $11.3 billion from $6.93 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 34 cents a share in the quarter on revenue of $11.28 billion. The stock closed Tuesday at $24.93, up 25 cents. Landry's Seafood 4Q earns $3.9M vs $13M (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Landry's Seafood Restaurants LNY, -25.00% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $3.9 million, or 18 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $13 million, or 49 cents a share. Excluding items, such as costs related to a refinancing and an income tax benefit, the company posted adjusted earnings of 22 cents a share for the December period. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $328.8 million from $259.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 14 cents a share in the latest quarter on revenue of $297.9 million. Looking ahead, the Houston-based restaurant operator sees earnings of $2.20 a share for fiscal 2006, including stock option expenses and the costs related to changes at its Joe's Crab Shack locations. The stock closed Tuesday at $30.38, down 4 cents. OfficeMax posts fourth-quarter net loss (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% on Wednesday posted a fourth-quarter net loss of $43.1 million, or 62 cents a share, compared with net income of $0.7 million, or 2 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding special items, OfficeMax reported adjusted income of $6 million, or 7 cents a share, compared with an adjusted loss of $18.7 million, or 24 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2004. Sales fell to $2.46 billion from $2.69 billion a year earlier. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of 7 cents a share on revenue of $2.35 billion, according to Thomson First Call. Same-store sales decreased 1% for the fourth quarter. The company expects 2006 total consolidated sales to be flat to slightly up compared to 2005. Henry Schein affirms FY06 earns outlook (7:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Henry Schein Inc. HSIC, +1.42% Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $52.5 million, or 59 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $29.4 million, or 33 cents a share. Sales rose 16.2% in the latest three months to $1.34 billion from $1.16 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 58 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $1.33 billion. Looking ahead, the Melville, N.Y., provider of healthcare products and services affirmed its outlook for earnings of $2.20 to $2.26 a share, excluding stock option expenses, in fiscal 2006. The stock closed Tuesday at $46.73, down 3.8%. Jack In The Box earnings ease less than forecast (7:02 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Fast-food restaurant chain Jack In The Box JBX, -6.28% said first-quarter earnings fell 0.8% to $25.2 million, though earnings per share rose to 70 cents from 68 cents a share on stock buybacks. The quarter included 5 cents a share in stock options expensing and 4 cents in charges from a legal settlement. Revenue rose 11.1% to $819.7 million, or up 5.5% on a same-store basis. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 68 cents on revenue of $779 million, and Jack In The Box said the outperformance was on the sales rise and slightly higher gains on the sales of restaurants to franchisees. For the year, the company expects earnings between $2.57 and $2.60 a share, compared to analyst estimates of $2.52 a share. Pra International 4Q profit jumps, sales slip (6:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Clinical development company PRA International PRAI said fourth-quarter net income jumped 53% to $7.5 million, or 31 cents a share, from $4.9 million, or 22 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue declined 2.3% to $69.5 million due to the delayed execution of three biotech awards and the timing of certain orders. For 2006, PRA predicted it will earn $1.27 to $1.31 a share, including the impact of stock option expense of around 10 cents a share. Orbital Sciences net income drops after income tax change (6:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Orbital Sciences Corp. ORB, +9.85% which develops rockets for military and civil space projects, said fourth-quarter net income was $7.6 million, or 12 cents a share, compared to $166.1 million in the equivalent quarter in 2004. The company said the sharp drop was due to a change in income tax expense and noted adjusted 2004 fourth-quarter income was $5.8 million. Revenue for the quarter rose 13.9% to $199.6 million. Orbital said its communications satellite division performed strongly, but was partially upset by a dip in revenue from the science and defense satellite unit. Orbital said it expects 2006 revenue to be in the range of $760 million to $780 million with earnings in the range of 51 cents to 56 cents a share. Big Lots profit falls; sales up 6% (6:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Big Lots earned $14.7 million, or 13 cents share, in its fourth quarter -- down sharply from the $57.2 million, or 51 cents, of the year ago period, even as sales increased just over 6%. On a continuing operations basis, the Columbus, Ohio-based retailer earned 33 cents a share, down from 50 cents. Revenue came in at $1.39 billion, with same-store sales up 2.5% The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been for Big Lots to earn 43 cents a share on revenue of $1.43 billion. Shares of Big Lots BLI ended the Tuesday session up about 2% at $14.04. European markets open lower after weak Wall Street close (3:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- European markets opened lower Wednesday as well-received corporate news from BASF AG, Heineken and Anglo American was unable to outweigh a weak Wall Street finish. Anglo American AAUK (UK:AAL)climbed 1.1% after increasing the amount of money it will return to shareholders by $500 million. German chemicals giant BASF AG BF (DE:515100)added 0.8% after its 2005 results topped sales forecasts and Heineken(NL:00916)climbed 3.6% in Amsterdam after its 2005 profit soared 18.5% to 761 million euros. Broadly the French CAC 40 index dipped 0.1% at 4,986, the German DAX 30 index was slightly higher at 5,802 and the U.K. FTSE 100 index fell 0.2% at 5,848. Rexam 2005 profit climbs, makes bid for Dutch Airspray NV (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Packaging and drinks can maker Rexam Plc(UK:REX)said Wednesday that 2005 net profit rose 12.1% to 223 million pounds ($389 million) or 40.4 pence a share. Sales for the year rose 5.1% to 3.24 billion pounds. Sales growth was strong in the drinks can division and the company said it is introducing price increases to offset higher materials costs. Rexam said its final dividend will be 10.6 pence, taking the total 2005 dividend to 18.12 pence, up 5% from 2004. Separately the company said it will launch a 146 million euro public offer for Dutch company Airspray NV(NL:33355), which manufactures foam pumps. The offer will be worth 26.75 euros a share, a 17% premium on Tuesday's closing price of 22.85 euros a share. Rexam said the offer will be recommended by Airspray's board and the purchase would enhance earnings immediately. Heineken 2005 profit up 19%, eyes 200M euros in cost cuts (2:39 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Heineken(NL:00916)on Wednesday said annual profit rose 18.5% to 761 million euros, with revenue up 7.3% to 10.8 billion euros and beer volume up 5.3% to 118.6 million hectoliters. Analysts polled by AFX News saw earnings between 715 million and 743 million euros. The Dutch brewer attributed the profit rise to a more positive price and sales mix, with volume in the premium segment rising 4.5%. It's looking to achieve 200 million euros in annual cost savings by 2008, with most of those savings coming next year and in 2008, which includes 65 million euros from its existing cost-savings plan. Net profit on a comparable basis won't rise by more than mid-single digit percentage, it added. Heineken will keep its 2005 dividend unchanged at 0.40 euros a share. BASF net profit jumps 50%, ups dividend (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German chemicals and plastics company BASF AG BF s: de:515100] said Wednesday that its 2005 net profit jumped 50% to 3.01 billion euros ($3.59 billion) or 5.73 euros a share. Sales for the year rose 13.9% to 42.75 billion euros. Analysts had been expecting net profit of 3.06 billion euros and revenue of 41.57 billion euros, according to AFX News. The higher sales were achieved mainly in the company's chemicals and oil and gas units and was helped by price rises across all divisions. BASF said it will hike its 2005 dividend by 17.6% to 2.00 euros a share. BASF said the biggest risks for the company in 2006 come from increased tensions in regional trouble-spots and higher raw materials prices. It added it will continue to buy back shares, but did not specify a value for the buyback. Anglo American ups cash return program, to cut AngloGold stk (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Anglo American AAUK (UK:AAL)on Wednesday said it's increasing the amount it was going to give back to shareholders to $1.5 billion from $1 billion, via a $500 million special dividend plan in 2007, plans to trim its stake in AngloGold Ashanti AU, +0.74% and will list Mondi on the London Stock Exchange in 2006 or 2007. The mining giant reported a 0.6% rise in 2005 profit to $3.52 billion, as a 35.7% rise in adjusted operating profit was offset by year-ago disposal gains. Revenue rose 7.9% to $34.47 billion. Its underlying earnings of $2.58 a share were ahead of analyst predictions of $2.54 on revenue of $31.45 billion. The company will pay a final dividend of 62 cents a share, up 22%, and make a 33 cent a share special dividend payment. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Pre-open moves Stock futures got a lift after data showed that U.S. consumer prices increased a larger-than-expected 0.7% in January, led by higher energy, food and housing costs. The core consumer price index, which excludes food and energy prices, increased 0.2%, as expected. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets European sentiment soured as upbeat corporate news couldn't offset a weak U.S. close on Tuesday. Japan's Nikkei, many other Asian indexes, ended lower. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Bear Stearns upgraded US Airways Group LCC, +0.15% to outperform from peer perform, saying synergies are ahead of schedule. The broker also noted that management indicated revenue per available seat mile growth is accelerating into the first quarter. ThinkEquity Partners downgraded shares of Intel Corp INTC, +5.00% to sell from accumulate, and cut its price target to $16 from $26. The broker believes Intel is building inventories, is losing share -- particularly in servers -- and will likely be negatively impacted by pricing cuts. Intel shares fell 0.8% in the pre-open. Credit Suisse cut car maker DaimlerChrysler DCX to neutral from overweight, citing a disappointing outlook and a lack of detail on restructuring plans. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Harrah's Entertainment Inc. HET, +0.94% posted a net loss of $142.2 million, or 78 cents a share, compared with a profit of $76.9 million, or 68 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Fourth-quarter revenues rose 76.2% to $2.1 billion. Sprint Nextel Corp. S, +0.41% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $197 million, or 7 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $437 million, or 29 cents a share. On an adjusted basis, before amortization and certain non-recurring items, the company earned $1.09 billion, or 33 cents a share, in the latest three months. Revenue rose 63% to $11.3 billion from $6.93 billion a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 34 cents a share on revenue of $11.28 billion. Martha Stewart Omnimedia Inc. MSO, +0.00% swung to profit, posting net income of $2.95 million, or 6 cents a share, compared with a loss of $7.33 million, or 15 cents a share. Revenues for the fourth quarter were $84.5 million, up 40%. For 2006, it forecast revenue in the range of $270 million to $280 million, and an operating loss in the range of $9 million to $11 million. Garmin Ltd. GRMN, +1.24% reported fourth-quarter net income of $87.1 million, or 80 cents a share, compared with $47.6 million, or 44 cents a share, in the year-ending period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 70 cents a share. Garmin, a maker of navigational devices, said it expects 2006 revenue of more than $1.3 billion earnings of $3.19 a share Taser International Inc. TASR reported fourth-quarter earnings of $92,697, or break even on a per-share basis, down from a year-ago profit of $4.7 million, or 7 cents a share. Sales fell in the latest three months to $12.6 million from $19.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle 2 sexy ways to get paid to save This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Intel, US Air, Harrah's, Garmin in the spotlight

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $92,697, or break even on a per share basis, down from a year-ago profit of $4.7 million, or 7 cents a share. Sales fell in the latest three months to $12.6 million from $19.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker closed Tuesday at $10.40.
title: Taser Int'l 4Q earns $92,697 vs $4.7M

content: Advancers 3M Co. MMM, +1.38% increased its quarterly dividend 9.5%, to 46 cents a share from 42 cents. The dividend is payable March 12 to shareholders as of Feb. 24. 3M has also approved an annual share buyback of $2 billion that runs through February of 2007. See full story. American Italian Pasta Co. PLB, +0.58% expects to take a $4.5-5.0 million charge to divest its Eddie's and Mrs. Leeper's pasta brands as part of a strategy of focusing on core businesses. The company will take a further $25 to $29 million impairment charge for the closure of its Kenosha, Wisconsin plant, planned for early April 2006. The company will book a $3.3 million impairment charge in the second quarter on the sale of other non-core assets. It expects a further $32.8 to $37.3 million in charges on the divestments and the plant closure. The company further said it has postponed its annual shareholder meeting normally held in February to complete restatements of previously released financial reports. Amgen Inc. AMGN, +0.01% said it plans to offer $2 billion in convertible senior notes due 2011 and $2 billion in convertible senior notes due 2013. The company expects to use the proceeds from the offering and those from warrant transactions to purchase $3 billion worth of shares of its common stock, some of which may be purchased at the same time as the closing of the notes sale. AMR Corp. AMR, -4.53% said Chief Financial Officer James Beer plans to leave the company to take a CFO position with software company Symantec Corp. SYMC, +0.82% Beer will remain with the company as its CFO through the filing of AMR's annual report, the company said. Arch Capital Group ACGL, -0.24% said fourth-quarter net income fell 6%. See full story. Blair Corp. BL, +0.67% said its board authorized the repurchase of up to 400,000 common shares, or about 10% of the company's shares outstanding. CBIZ Inc. CBIZ reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $3.7 million, or 5 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $3.2 million, or 4 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $132.1 million from $119.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Cleveland-based provider of professional business services forecast revenue growth of 8% to 10% in 2006 with earnings per share from continuing operations projected to increase 20% to 25% from its profit of 28 cents a share in 2005. Charles Schwab Corp SCHW, +2.59% said its clients' trading rose, with daily average revenue trades jumping to 334,000 in January, a 62% increase from year ago levels and 37% better than December 2005's volume. Net new assets brought to the Schwab by new and current clients in January 2006 totaled $9.50 billion, the company said. "Total client assets were a record $1.246 trillion as of month-end January, up 17% from January 2005 and up 4% from December 2005," Schwab said. Coca-Cola Co. KO, +0.25% said Warren Buffett and J. Pedro Reinhard will not run for re-election to the company's board of directors after their terms expire on April 16. Buffett, the chairman and chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% said he was leaving Coke to focus on Berkshire's acquisitions. He added that Berkshire Hathaway will maintain its equity stake in Coke. See full story. Shares of Compass Minerals International Inc. CMP, +2.46% advanced after the Overland Park, Kan., salt producer reported fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations, excluding items, of $33.9 million, or $1.05 a share, on sales of $283.1 million, up 28% year-over-year. The average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 76 cents a share in the December period. Compass said its earnings benefited from heavier than normal snowfall in December, which added revenue of between $35 million and $45 million in the quarter. Deere & Co. DE, +2.53% reported first-quarter net income of $235.9 million, or 99 cents a share, compared with $222.8 million, or 89 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The agricultural equipment maker said its sales rose 7% to $4.2 billion from $3.94 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 83 cents a share and sales of $4.06 billion. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., said equipment sales would rise 3% to 5% in 2006 and be flat to up 2% in the second quarter. Net income in 2006 would be $1.7 billion and $725 million to $759 million in the second quarter. Production levels will fall about 4% in 2006 and 9% for the second quarter. See full story. Shares of DTS Inc. DTSI surged after the Agoura Hills, Calif., developer of digital entertainment technology company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.3 million, or 7 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $192,000, or a penny per share. Last year's results included a charge of $2.5 million, or 14 cents a share, from an inventory write-down. Revenue rose 8% in the latest three months to $17.9 million from $16.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 4 cents a share in the December period. DTS also restated certain prior results to correct an error related to the method used to compute the weighting of warrants and options included in its diluted shares outstanding figure. Genesee & Wyoming Inc. GWR, +0.93% said that fourth-quarter net income rose 50.9% to $10.8 million, or 39 cents a share, while revenue climbed to 29% to $103.3 million. The transport group said that North American revenue rose 29% to $103.3 million, while revenue at its Australian unit rose 1.1% to $86.8 million. The company also said that its board has approved a three-for-two split of class A and class B common stock in the form of a 50% common stock dividend, payable March 14. See full story. Hoku Scientific Inc. HOKU revised its fourth-quarter revenue forecast to $1.4 million. Kapolei, Hawaii-based Hoku said the revision is due to a delay in the demonstration system installation under a fuel cell contract with the U.S. Navy. Hoku was also awarded a new contract by Nissan Motor Co. NSANY, -0.65% Financial terms weren't disclosed. Hoku is developing hydrocarbon-based membranes and membrane electrode assemblies for Nissan's fuel cell cars and trucks. Home Depot's HD, +1.99% purchase of Hughes Supply HUG, -0.17% the Orlando, Fla., distributor of construction, repair and maintenance-related products, cleared the waiting period under U.S. antitrust law, Hughes said. The transaction remains subject to conditions including approval by Hughes Supply's shareholders. Hughes filed a preliminary proxy statement on the deal on Jan. 27. The company said it awaits comments on the statement from the Securities and Exchange Commission and will respond to the agency. Inco Ltd. N the Toronto miner of nickel and copper, reported fourth-quarter earnings rose 4% on 3.4% lower sales. Net income reached US$235 million, or $1.06 a share, from $226 million, or $1.08, in the year-earlier period. Diluted shares outstanding rose 6.2% to 223 million from 210 million. Reflecting special items, fourth-quarter earnings were 76 cents against $1.21. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call produced a consensus estimate of 62 cents. Sales fell to $1.12 billion from $1.16 billion. Thomson First Call's consensus: $1.18 billion. With "strong growth in nickel demand forecast for 2006, and with limited new nickel projects or expansions currently expected to come on stream before at least 2008 ... nickel demand should continue to outpace supply in 2006, which will continue to put upward pressure on prices," Inco said in a statement. Ingersoll-Rand Co. IR, +1.86% reiterated its first-quarter outlook of earnings between 73 cents and 77 cents a share, excluding stock option expense of 2 cents to 3 cents a share. The Bermuda-based diversified industrial company also reiterated its 2006 outlook for per-share earnings of $3.45 to $3.55, excluding stock option expense of 5 cents to 6 cents a share. The company said it plans to increase its 2006 capital expenditures, to a range of $175 million to $200 million, to fund its expansion into key growth markets. Ingersoll-Rand also said it plans to increase its 2006 investments in initiatives to promote long-term growth by $80 million. The investments will be made in new product development to drive long-term revenue growth across all five business sectors, and to expand market opportunities for recently acquired businesses, the company said. IVillage Inc. IVIL reported fourth-quarter earnings of $8.85 million, or 11 cents a share, vs. $2.39 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $30.1 million from $18.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had forecast earnings of 12 cents a share on revenue of $28 million. Jarden Corp. JAH posted fourth-quarter income of $2.5 million, or 4 cents a share, compared to a loss of $3.4 million, or 8 cents a share. On a non-GAAP basis, adjusted net income was $33.8 million or 50 cents a share for the fourth quarter 2005. Jarden, maker of Coleman camping gear, Mr. Coffee coffee makers and Crock-Pots, posted sales for the quarter of $975 million compared to $237 million in the year ago period. Analysts, on average, were expecting it to post a profit of 52 cents a share on revenue of $959.9 million, according to Thomson First Call. The company said it's on track to achieve its three to five year goals outlined at the beginning of 2005. Lincoln National Corp. LNC, +1.46% reported fourth-quarter results that topped analyst expectations. See full story. Masco Corp. MAS, +1.53% said fourth-quarter net income climbed 64.8% to $173 million, or 41 cents a share. Income from continuing operations rose 2.2% to $142 million or 34 cents a share as sales from continuing operations climbed 6% to $3.1 billion. Adjusted earnings excluding impairment charges were 50 cents a share, compared to 54 cents a share in the equivalent quarter in 2004. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 50 cents a share. Masco said its results benefited from a strong construction market, which more than offset rising costs. The company added it expects 2006 earnings from continuing operations to be in the range of $2.35 to $2.45 a share. Shares of NCO Group Inc. NCOG rose after the Horsham, Pa., provider of business process outsourcing services reported fourth-quarter earnings of $7.5 million, or 23 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $12.2 million, or 36 cents a share. The latest results, however, include charges of $5.2 million, or 15 cents a share related to restructuring activities. Revenue leapt 22.4% in the latest three months to $290.3 million from $237.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 11 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $266 million. Looking ahead, NCO sees earnings of $1.52 to $1.72 a share for 2006, and a profit of 17 to 22 cents a share for the first quarter. Both estimates include anticipated restructuring charges of $6.1 million, or 18 cents a share. Shares of Pacific Internet Ltd. PCNTF gained after the Singapore-based Internet access provider posted a fourth-quarter profit of $2.6 million, or 19 cents a share, on revenue of $27.3 million. In the year-ago period, the company earned $2.1 million on revenue of $25.6 million. Pacific Internet attributed the improved results to its concentration on its higher-margin corporate business, stronger take-up of its value-added services, and continuing growth in its broadband business. Palm Inc. PALM, -2.60% declared a 2-for-1 split of its common stock to be effected in the form of a stock dividend. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based mobile computing company said additional shares will be distributed March 14 to shareholders as of Feb. 28. P.H. Glatfelter Co. GLT, +1.43% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $26.9 million, or 61 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $19.3 million, or 44 cents a share. The latest results include gains totaling $22.8 million, or 51 cents a share, related to asset sales and insurance recoveries, and restructuring charges of $1 million, or 2 cents a share. Excluding items, the York, Pa., printing paper producer earned $5.2 million, or 12 cents a share, in the December quarter. Sales rose 2.7% in the latest three months to $143.2 million from $139.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 9 cents a share in the December period. Playboy Enterprises Inc. PLA, +0.00% reported fourth-quarter net income of $4.6 million, or 14 cents a share, down 68% from $14.5 million, or 43 cents a share in the year-ago period, which included a $5.6 million insurance recovery. Revenue rose 2% to $91 million. Licensing segment income rose nearly 90%, but, as anticipated, was more than offset by a $4.1 million decline in publishing group results. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 18 cents a share and revenue of $90.5 million. Excluding a charge of 10 cents for options expense, the media firm expects 2006 earnings of 67-70 cents a share, compared to the Wall Street forecast of 67 cents a share. Qwest Communications Q, +0.00% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $528 million, or 28 cents a share, wider than a year-ago loss of $144 million, or 8 cents a share. Excluding special items, such as restructuring charges and a loss related to debt extinguishment, the company posted a loss of $8 million for the latest quarter, breaking even on a per share basis. Revenue slipped 0.7% in the latest three months to $3.48 billion from $3.5 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 5 cents a share in the December period. See full story. Radyne Corp. RADN said fourth-quarter net income was $4.29 million, or 24 cents a share, compared with $2.98 million, or 18 cents a share, during the year-earlier period. Quarterly revenue was $36.8 million, compared with $16.8 million last year. Shares of RealNetworks RNWK, -4.37% rose after the digital media services company was upgraded to outperform from market perform at Piper Jaffray. Analyst Aaron Kessler also raised his stock price target to $10 from $8.70. Kessler believes the gaming portfolio the company is acquiring is underappreciated and thinks the company will deploy its available cash for acquisitions and share buybacks by the end of first quarter of 2007. He also believes the valuation is attractive relative to its online media peer group. Shares of Taser International TASR gained after the company completed a live demonstration of its extended range elector-muscular projectile, which completes a development program for the Office of Naval Research. The company said the TASER XREP demonstrated similar effects to the TASER X26 device used by law enforcement agencies. In the demonstration, multiple rounds were fired from a shotgun at ranges of up to 30 meters. Travelzoo TZOO, +1.75% plans to buy back as many as 1 million of its shares on the open market. Tribune Co. TRB, -14.29% was upgraded at Banc of America to buy from neutral. United Auto Group UAG, +0.06% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $30.1 million, or 64 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $26.1 million, or 56 cents a share. On a continuing operations basis, the Bloomfield Hills, Mich., automobile seller earned $31.6 million, or 67 cents a share, in the December quarter. The continuing operations performance includes a profit of $5.2 million, or 11 cents a share, from the sale of certain extended service contracts sold at its dealerships over the past five years. Revenue rose 7.5% in the latest three months to $2.46 billion from $2.29 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 54 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings from continuing operations of $2.70 to $2.80 a share for fiscal 2006 and 53 to 57 cents a share for the first quarter. Wall Street's current consensus estimates are for earnings of $2.71 a share and 53 cents a share, respectively. Decliners Advanced Medical Optics EYE, -0.28% reported fourth-quarter net income Tuesday of $2.3 million, or 3 cents a share, compared with $10.1 million or 26 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. The company cited one-time charges for inventory and asset write downs of 37 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 41 cents a share, before items and sales of $264.3 million. Advanced Medical Optics said sales rose 12.5% to $252.8 million from $224.7 million in the year-earlier quarter. The company forecast 2006 revenue of $1.02 billion to $1.04 billion and adjusted earnings of $2.20 to $2.30 a share. Its 2007 revenue would be $1.1 billion to $1.12 billion and adjusted earnings would come to more than $2.65 a share, Advanced Medical Optics said. Blackboard Inc. BBBB said fourth-quarter net income was $23.1 million, or 79 cents a share, compared with $4.73 million, or 17 cents a share, during the same period last year. The company said quarterly cash net income was $23.2 million, or 79 cents a share, compared with $5.61 million, or 20 cents a share, last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share income of 26 cents. The education software provider said quarterly revenue was $35.7 million, compared with $30.1 million last year. Analysts were looking for revenue of $36 million. Bois d'Arc Energy Inc. BDE, +0.00% said fourth-quarter net income was $10.4 million, or 16 cents a share, compared with $7.61 million last year. The energy exploration company went public in May, and did not provide a net income per-share result for the same period last year. Quarterly revenue was $48.8 million, compared with $35.4 million last year. Cendant Corp. CD, +0.00% posted a fourth-quarter profit 50% higher than the same period last year, but offered a reduced outlook for the first quarter. See full story. Cutera Inc. CUTR, +2.97% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $5.81 million, or 41 cents a share, compared with $2.07 million, or 16 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Brisbane, Calif.-based laser technology company posted revenue of $24 million vs. $16.1 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share on revenue of $22 million. EchoStar Communications Corp. DISH, +1.20% said its president and chief operating officer, Michael A. Neuman, resigned. EchoStar in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission didn't detail the reasons for the move. Carl E. Vogel, vice chairman, and Michael T. Dugan, chief technical officer and formerly president and chief operating officer, will take on Neuman's duties, the filing said. See full story. Emerson Radio MSN, +0.69% said its fiscal third-quarter profit declined to $1.40 million, or 5 cents a share, from a profit of $1.91 million, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell 4.8% to $76.5 million on a decrease in sales of Emerson-branded audio products and licensing revenues. Chief Executive Geoffrey Junick said in a statement that the company's Nickelodeon-branded offerings were strong, but that its other audio products experienced "softness of demand" as it transitions to digital formats. Expeditors International of Washington EXPD, +2.73% reported fourth-quarter net income Tuesday of $80.5 million, or 72 cents a share, compared with $43.6 million, or 39 cents a share in the year-earlier period. The quarter included a one-time, 19 cents a share benefit for an accounting change. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 51 cents a share and sales of $1.07 billion. The freight forwarding company said sales in the three months to Dec. 31 rose 18% to $1.1 billion from $934.8 billion. Jakks Pacific Inc. JAKK, +5.00% the Malibu, Calif., designer of toys, writing instruments and other consumer products, reported fourth-quarter net income fell 14% on 10% lower sales. Earnings were $9 million, or 30 cents a share, against $10.5 million, or 35 cents, in the year-earlier period. Excluding the repatriation of $175 million of profit from its overseas subsidiaries, Jakks earned 53 cents a share. Sales declined to $166.3 million from $184.8 million. Reflecting the recent acquisition of Creative Designs International, first-quarter net should range 13 cents to 18 cents on sales of $102 million to $110 million, down from a year earlier, Jakks said, adding that it anticipates "more than making it up" in the rest of the year. For 2006, earnings should reach $2.63 a share from $2.07 in 2005, while sales should more than double to $825 million from $394.8 million, Jakks said. Three analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect 2006 net of $2.07 a share. Lexar Media Inc. LEXR said it expects a fourth-quarter net loss of $17 million to $21 million, or 21 cents to 26 cents a share. During the same period last year, the maker of memory products said its net loss was $63.3 million, or 80 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for per-share income of 4 cents. Lexar said it expects fourth-quarter revenue of $240 million to $245 million, compared with $189 million last year, and an overall gross margin of 6% to 8%. Analysts are looking for revenue of $226 million. Lexar said it will discuss the quarter's results on March 6. Marsh & McLennan MMC, +0.85% the insurance broker and parent of asset manager Putnam, said Tuesday it earned net income of $35 million, or 6 cents a share in the fourth quarter, compared to a loss of $680 million, or $1.29 a share a year ago. Excluding special items and stock option expense, Marsh said its earnings per share in the latest quarter were 28 cents, just shy of the Thomson First Call average estimate of analysts it polled of 31 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter slipped to $2.83 billion from $2.88 billion. Omnicom Group OMC, +0.04% said fourth-quarter net income rose 7% to $252.6 million, or $1.41 a share, as worldwide revenue climbed 5% to $2.94 billion.
