The figures were in-line with forecasts from analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company said growth was particularly strong in the domestic market, where revenue climbed 9% to $1.58 billion. International revenue grew 1% to $1.36 billion. See full story. Shares of Rimage Corp. RIMG dropped after the Minneapolis-based provider of CD and DVD publishing technology said its earnings for the fourth quarter will come in below its prior projections due to higher than anticipated consulting expenses and a slight revenue shortfall. The company now sees earnings of 22 cents a share in the fourth quarter on revenue of about $24 million. The previous forecast was for earnings of 27 to 32 cents a share on revenue of between $24 million to $26 million. Rimage said it spent an additional $800,000 in the quarter on the strategic analysis of its operations by an international consulting group. Sands Regent SNDS said its 10-Q quarterly report for the three months ended Dec. 31 will be delayed pending an internal review by its audit committee. The Reno, Nev., company said its audit panel began a review in response to allegations made by a former employee related the acquisition of the Dayton Casino. The company expects to request a hearing before a Nasdaq Stock Market panel to seek an extension to its listing on the market. School Specialty SCHS, +16.67% reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $22.5 million, or 98 cents a share, wider than a year-ago loss of $11.2 million, or 49 cents a share. Revenue rose slightly in the latest three months to $132.5 million from $128.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 62 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Greenville, Wis., education supplies company sees earnings of $1.25 to $1.35 a share for fiscal 2006 on revenue of between $1.02 billion from $1.03 billion. For fiscal 2007, the company forecast earnings of $2.10 to $2.30 a share, excluding stock option expensing, on revenue of $1.06 billion to $1.1 billion. Stoneridge SRI, +2.07% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $3 million, or 13 cents a share, narrower than a year-ago loss of $114.9 million, or $5.07 a share. The latest results include a valuation allowance that lowered the company's tax benefit and reduced net income by $1.3 million, or 6 cents a share. The year-ago results include a goodwill impairment charge of $183.5 million. Excluding that charge, the company earned $4.8 million, or 21 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales fell 7.2% in the latest three months to $151.7 million from $163.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 10 cents a share in the December period. Looking ahead, the Warren, Ohio-based maker of electrical and electronic components sees earnings of 30 to 40 cents a share for 2006. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 32 cents a share for the year. Suntech Power Holdings Co. STP, +0.87% said fourth-quarter net income was $10.6 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with $11 million, or 12 cents a share, during the year-earlier quarter. The solar energy company said quarterly revenue was $89 million, compared with $37.7 million last year. Looking forward, Suntech sees first-quarter revenue of $75 million to $80 million. Transocean Inc. RIG, +1.43% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $151.6 million, or 45 cents a share, up from a year-ago loss of $73.4 million, or 23 cents a share. The year-ago results include a loss of $27.1 million, or 9 cents a share, from the company's TODCO disposition and a loss of $48.4 million, or 15 cents a share, related to early debt retirement. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $771.2 million from $676.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 48 cents a share in the December period on revenue of $785.5 million. See full story. Warner Music Group WMG, -2.22% said that first-quarter net income nearly doubled to $69 million, or 46 cents a share, from $36 million, or 31 cents a share, a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting the company to post earnings of 40 cents a share. Total revenue eased 4% to $1.04 billion in the quarter, helped by a 176% increase in digital revenue to $69 million. Watsco WSO, +2.77% said fourth-quarter net income more than doubled to $14.1 million, or 50 cents a share, from $6.2 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue rose 35.9% to $416.2 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 32 cents a share on revenue of $387.2 million. Watsco added that operating margin rose 1.9 percentage points to 5.6%. The company said it believes it can expand further, as it still only has a 7% share of the U.S. heating, ventilation and air conditioning market. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Waste Management, and more

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr rallied more than 4% in pre-open trading after the company said it completed a live demonstration of its extended range elector-muscular projectile, which completes a development program for the Office of Naval Research. The company said the TASER XREP demonstrated similar effects to the TASER X26 device used by law enforcement agencies. In the demonstration, multiple rounds were fired from a shotgun at ranges of up to 30 meters. The stock was last up 44 cents, or 4.2%, at $11 in Instinet.
title: Taser up in pre-open after completion of demonstration

content: SAN DIEGO (MarketWatch) -- What could analysts be thinking on AMR, parent of American Airlines? Average analyst estimates for earnings next year are 48 cents per share, or a profit of around $80 million. But based on the guidance AMR AMR, -4.53% gave for fuel costs, inflationary expenses, revenue initiatives and cost savings - the closest the airline gets to giving a forecast -- it appears this year's operating loss could be more than $100 million greater than last year's reported loss. How does that result in a profit? Answer: Unless oil prices collapse, it doesn't, which is why its stock is flying (he said, sarcastically) - a theme, you'll soon discover, of today's sermon. And while we're on irrational stocks: Harley Davidson HDI, -1.78% has, for more years than I can recall, left tire marks on anybody who dared be anything but bullish on its prospects. (Present company included.) But those critical of Harley are a hearty bunch. Among them, hedge fund manager John Succo, writing on Minyanville.com, notes that dealer inventories continued to swell as the resale prices on used bikes continued to fall, "which puts a great deal of pressure on the prices of the new ones," he says. Yet beating estimates, he adds, "caused the earnings surprise guys" to buy, which drove the stock a few points higher. Of course, it doesn't matter how the company beat those numbers, which were puffed up by stock repurchases the company itself says helped earnings per share rise faster than sales - hardly what you'd call a high quality beat. But since when did quality matter? Not in this market -- that's when! Oh, and by the way, delinquencies on the credit side of the company's business are on the rise. One day, with Harley, all of that may actually matter. More market mania: I go out of my way not to write about the overall market. I don't know any more or less than the average guy in the gutter or the average strategist on the street. But one thing I'm good with (if I don't say so myself) is inflection points. I can say, unequivocally, we're at one now. There is always an inflection point, for example, when I start hearing neophyte investors say that they're hanging onto every word I write - and that they are "making money" by shorting stocks merely because they show up in this column with some kind of cautionary statement. That usually means stocks have fallen too quickly, in which case the spring is ready to be sprung on the upside. The other inflection point, which we're at right now, is when stocks I red-flag either here or on TV wind up going higher just because I mention them. At the same time, at this inflection point, bearish sources clam up, I start thinking maybe I ought to throw in the towel and become a coffee barista (how does "Herb's Hut" sound?) and investors start thinking they're geniuses as stocks of companies with questionable fundamentals fly for no apparent reason other than they're going up. But just remember: In the past, whenever this has happened - and I've lived through quite a few episodes-- it has been only a matter of time before the market hits one of those unexpected and unpleasant air pockets that remind people that the reality of potential risks should be respected and that hubris (about how easy it is to make money in some of these stocks) can be horribly humbling. Further signs of ridiculous speculation On Thursday I wrote a piece in my subscription newsletter, Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck, about Novastar NFI, +0.90% I've been writing negatively about the subprime mortgage lender for more than three years. This time I noted how someone smart, who has been publicly bearish, turned temporarily bullish. Within a minute of the alert hitting subscriber mailboxes the stock started to zoom higher. Shortly thereafter, blurbs hit rumor wires that "Herb Greenberg" had turned "positive" on Novastar. No, what Herb Greenberg (otherwise known as I) did was report the conversion of a bear to a short-term bull, how he thinks his prior theory and that of current bears is "flawed" and how the current bears think his argument is equally "flawed." I also pointed out how the short-term bull agrees with the perma-bears that as credit risks take hold, Novastar's stock is headed considerably lower than it is today. (Which is why it remains red-flagged on the RealityCheck watch list.) Sudden thought: A year ago American Italian Pasta PLB, +0.58% was around $26 headed to an April intraday high of close to $30. Today it's closer to $6. A few years ago, Taser TASR was around $31, post a few splits, on its way to a low later in the year of around $5. And remember Movie Gallery MOVI as it peaked mid-year at around $27 after more-than doubling in a matter of months? Today it's under $6. You just might want to keep those three in mind next time you find yourself smug about a stock whose rise appears to be too good to be true. The trouble with parabolic rises is that what goes up fast has a way of falling even faster. All of which is a long-winded way of saying: Fasten those seatbelts and never mind the air sick bags; they'll be of no use. content: Advancers Alkermes Inc. ALKS, -2.14% shares ended Monday's session with a 9.1% gain after the company agreed to partner with Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% on the development and commercialization of inhaled parathyroid hormone for the treatment of osteoporosis. Financial terms weren't disclosed. The companies said the program will utilize Alkermes' pulmonary drug delivery system and Lilly's recombinant PTH Forteo injection. Shares of ATG Inc. ARTG rose 10% after the company agreed to provide its customer response management software for Vodafone's VOD, +0.54% Espana unit. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed. Biolase Technology Inc. BLTI stock tacked on 10.3% after the company forecast revenue of about $19 million for the fourth quarter. The San Clemente, Calif., medical technology company also expects to be cash flow neutral from operations for the quarter. The current average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $17.1 million in the December period. Central European Distribution Corp. CEDC shares added 8.2% after the company forecast earnings of $1.96 to $2.16 a share on sales of between $931 million to $956 million for fiscal 2006. This projection reflects it's completion of various alcohol distribution companies in Poland with combined annualized sales of about $25 million. The company's prior projection was for a profit of $1.94 to $2.14 a share for the year on revenue ranging from $906 million to $931 million. Ceragon Networks Ltd.'s CRNT, +1.51% stock surged 13.5% after the company signed an original equipment manufacturer agreement with Nokia NOK, +0.74% Financial terms weren't disclosed. The deal calls for Ceragon's FibeAir product to be included within Nokia's microwave radio product line. Shares of Emisphere Technologies Inc. EMIS, +8.31% rocketed higher by 24.2% after a U.S. District Court determined that the company properly terminated a licensing deal with Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% The court found that Lilly breached contractural obligations related to licensing and collaboration agreements with Emisphere for oral PTH. The decision will allow Emisphere to enter a licensing deal with Novartis NVS, -0.49% for the use of oral PTH as a treatment for osteoporosis. Focus Media Holdings Ltd. FMCN shares surged 14.6% after the company agreed to pay $94 million in cash and $231 million in newly issued stock to buy Target Media. The China-based display advertising firm expects the deal to close in the first quarter. General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% shares gained 7.7% after the company was upgraded to in line from underperform at Goldman Sachs due to valuation, given Analyst Robert Barry's belief that a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing by the automaker is very unlikely in the near term. Barry thinks GM's long-term fundamentals are still negative, due to revenue and cost pressures related to market share losses and labor costs, but he also believes there are potential catalysts that could improve sentiment and ease bankruptcy fears enough to get the stock to bounce to the mid-$20s during the first half of 2006. "Our views on Chapter 11 reflect GM's high liquid assets and a belief that electing Chapter 11 is not an option, as GM sales would likely plummet post a filing," Barry said. He said likely catalysts include the sale of a stake in its financing arm, GMAC, and avoiding a strike at auto parts supplier Delphi DPHIQ Investment Technology Group ITG, +0.77% stock tacked on 7.5% after the company was upgraded at Sandler O'Neill to buy from hold. Shares of LightPath Technologies Inc. LPTH, +2.33% soared 156% after the company signed a 3-year fiber beam delivery systems supply deal with Ball Corp. BLL, +1.33% Financial terms weren't disclosed. Medarex Inc. MEDX shares added 6.3% after the company said the Food and Drug Administration has granted fast track designation for its Valortim antibody against anthrax infection. Valortim is an investigational fully human antibody created using Medarex's UltiMAb Human Antibody Development System. Rogers Corp. ROG, +1.57% shares ended the session up 11.6% after the company raised its fourth-quarter sales guidance to $97 million, from a previous range of $85 million to $88 million, and also upped earnings per share guidance to between 52 cents and 54 cents, from a previous range of 40 cents to 44 cents a share. The company said the increased guidance is due to its ability to capitalize on its strong market position, which led to an acceleration of sales during the fourth quarter. Taser International Inc. TASR stock rose 8.3% after the company said a training injury lawsuit against it was dismissed by a Circuit Court in Michigan. The Scottsdale, Ariz. stun gun maker said the case represents the eleventh wrongful death or injury lawsuit against it that's either been dismissed or ended with a favorable judgment for Taser in the past 18 months. Tripos Inc. TRPS shares gained 7.6% after the company hired Seven Hills Partners, a financial advisory firm, to explore its strategic alternatives. St. Louis-based Tripos, a provider of drug discovery chemistry and informatics products and services, doesn't plan to make further comments on the process unless there are material developments. Shares of Water Pik Technologies PIK, +24.03% jumped 25.7% after the company agreed to be acquired by The Carlyle Group and Zodiac S.A. (FR:ZCNV) in a $380 million deal. Under the agreement's terms, Water Pik shareholders will receive $27.75 in cash per share. Water Pik, which makes healthcare and pool products, expects the transaction, which is subject to shareholder and regulatory approval, to be complete in late April. Western Digital Corp. WDC, +1.62% stock finished up 6.2% after Deutsche Bank raised its rating on the company to buy from hold and lifted its price target to $24 from $14. The firm cited expectations of market share gains and higher margins. "With the announcement of the Seagate/Maxtor merger, we expect WDC to be a primary beneficiary of share shifts in the industry," Deutsche Bank said. "In addition, we believe healthier industry dynamics resulting from the merger will buffer ASP (average selling price) declines." William Lyon Hones WLS shares closed with an 8.1% gain, among a number of homebuilders that ended the session higher. "Investors got negative on the builder group at the end of 2005, and this looks like a relief rally that the sky isn't falling," said Bill Mack, equity analyst at Standard & Poor's. Toll Bros. TOL, +1.36% shares added 6.2%, while shares of Centex Corp. CTX, +0.48% tacked on 5.8%. XM Satellite Radio Holdings Inc. XMSR stock surged 7.1% after the company was upgraded to buy from hold at Deutsche Bank, and the company's price target was lifted to $33 from $30. "Based on presentations at the company's analyst day, discussions with management, and revisions to our model, we believe XM's stock is a good way to play satellite radio sector growth, based on improved visibility on growth from the OEM auto channel, retail channel growth from new products, and favorable valuation," the broker said. Decliners Emmis Broadcasting Corp. EMMS, -0.65% shares ended Monday 7.3% lower after the company reported net income of $200 million, or $5.30 a share, for the third quarter ended Nov. 30, including $197.5 million, or $5.29 a share, from discontinued operations primarily reflecting results from the company's TV business. Income from continuing operations amounted to 1 cent a share, down from 7 cents for the year-earlier third quarter. Emmis generated adjusted revenue of $100.5 million for the quarter, up 11% from the prior year's $90.2 million. The lower profit from continuing operations stemmed from higher interest costs incurred as a result of borrowings to finance the company's Dutch auction tender completed last June. Analysts were looking for a quarterly loss of 1 cent a share on revenue of $99 million, according to the average of estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Plexus Corp. PLXS, +2.10% slumped 9.4% after Deutsche Bank lowered its rating on the company to sell from hold, citing "slowing momentum and egregious valuation." The firm noted that the stock has risen 49% since it began coverage on Sept. 21 versus 6% appreciation for the S&P 500 index over the same period. Deutsche Bank estimates the downside risk for the shares is roughly three times greater than the upside risk. Santarus Inc. stock gave back SNTS 11% after the company was notified that TAP Pharmaceutical Products Inc. plans to terminated the sublicense agreement between the companies, effective March 7. The agreement related to the North American rights of use of Santarus' immediate-release proton pump inhibitor technology with lansoprazole. These rights now return to Santarus, a San Diego-based specialty drug maker. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr shares gained 8.6% to $8.19 on Monday after the Scottsdale, Ariz. stun gun maker said a training injury lawsuit against it was dismissed by a Circuit Court in Michigan. The company said the case represents the eleventh wrongful death or injury lawsuit against it that's either been dismissed or ended with a favorable judgment for Taser in the past 18 months.
title: Taser shares push higher on lawsuit's dismissal

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. tasr rose almost 5% to $7.55 on Friday after the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns received a favorable verdict in a personal injury lawsuit brought against it. The case involved a former police officer who claimed the company was responsible for injuries sustained in a training exercise with its M26 Advanced Taser product.
title: Taser Int'l shares get lift from favorable jury verdict

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Thursday a jury has returned a verdict in its favor in a personal injury case brought by Samuel Powers. The suit alleged the company was responsible for injuries sustained by a former Maricopa County sheriffs deputy during a training exercise in which he was exposed to a discharge from a Taser product. Taser is based in Scottsdale, Ariz.
title: Taser Int'l gets favorable verdict in personal injury case

content: Advancers ArtheroGenics Inc. AGIX shares ended Thursday's session with a 19.6% gain after the company reached its licensing agreement with AstraZeneca AZN, -0.46% for global development and commercialization of their anti-inflammatory cardiovascular product candidate, AGI-1067. The product is being developed for the treatment of atherosclerosis. The deal calls for AtheroGenics to receive an upfront fee of $50 million, and it provides for development and regulatory milestones of up to $300 million. There's also sales performance-related milestones that could bring AtheroGenics an additional $650 million if reached. Shares of BioCryst Pharmaceuticals BCRX, -0.21% surged 15.6% after the company received verbal approval to begin human studies of intravenous peramivir, its influenza neuraminidase inhibitor, by the Food and Drug Administration. "This communication from the FDA allows us to move forward with our clinical development of injectable formulations of peramivir," said Charles Bugg, the company's chairman and CEO. The company also said it's initiated a phase I/II trial of Fodosine, its leading anti-cancer compound. Global Payments Inc. GPN, +1.31% shares tacked on 6.6% after the company upped its fiscal 2006 earnings and revenue guidance after reporting a 30% rise in second-quarter net income and a 16.5% revenue rise. Second-quarter profit rose to $30.6 million, or 37 cents a share, on revenue of $220 million. The Atlanta, Ga.-based company said it's now looking for fiscal 2006 earnings between $1.41 and $1.47 a share on revenue between $877 million and $892 million. Humana Inc. HUM, +0.48% stock posted a 14.4% rise after the company said it expects enrollment in its Medicare plans to top 1.7 million on Jan. 1, up from a total of about 503,000 as of Sept. 30. The Louisville, Ky., company said it's "encouraged" by the robust response to its new plan offerings, and it reaffirmed its outlook for earnings and Medicare membership in 2006. Shares of Novelis NVL, +0.79% rocketed higher by 17.5% after the company said it plans to find new leadership for its finance group to replace CFO Geoffrey Batt and controller Jo-Ann Longworth. The company said the pair, who will remain until replacements are found, played a valuable role in taking the company public after its spin-off from Alcan AL, +1.43% but it is now looking for individuals with extensive public company experience. Novelis also said it has taken steps to limit its short- and long-term metal price ceiling exposure. High aluminum prices have affected the companies can sheet contracts in North America, triggering a ceiling clause in the contracts. The company said it is eliminating the price ceiling concept from contracts and has revised its hedging policy to minimize its exposure. Omni Energy Services OMNI shares added 13.9% after the company said its seismic drilling backlog has increased recently by 50% to a level now in excess of $40 million. Additionally, the Carencro, La.-based oilfield services provider said it's seeing an increase in the amount of transition zone projects scheduled for 2006, compared with the transition zone projects completed in recent years. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals REGN, +1.74% shares tacked on 6.3% after the company expanded its collaboration with Sanofi-Aventis SNY, +0.30% over the development of the anti-cancer Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor Trap to include Japan. Under the agreement Regeneron will receive an upfront payment of $25 million, milestone payments of up to $40 million and royalties of approximately 35% of annual sales of the VEGF Trap in Japan. SFBC International SFCC shares rose 13.1% after the company said its board has adopted a shareholder rights plan with a 15% trigger. In addition, the Miami-based provider of drug and medical device development services retained Lehman Bros. and UBS Investment Bank to act as joint financial advisors in the exploration of strategic alternatives. Shares of Taser International TASRE ended higher by 5.4% after the company said it has received a letter from the Nasdaq Stock Market indicating the company is no longer subject to possible delisting following the filing of its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30. Tibco Software TIBX shares gained 7.4% after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of $26.6 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with $18.2 million, or 8 cents a share, last year. Earnings on an adjusted basis were $21.8 million, or 10 cents a share. Total revenue rose to $134.4 million from $125.7 million a year ago. Palo Alto, Calif.-based Tibco also said its board approved an 18-month plan to buy back up to $100 million of its common shares. See full story. Shares of Webhire HIRE soared 606.3% after the company agreed to be acquired by Kenexa Corp. KNXA for $34 million. Wayne, Pa.-based Kenexa said it expects the transaction to close in January. Additionally, the company said it sees fiscal 2006 pro forma earnings of 85 to 90 cents a share on revenue of $93 million to $97 million. Decliners Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. BBBY, +1.84% shares ended Thursday's session down 12.1% after the company said third-quarter profit rose 10% to match Wall Street's target but the company's outlook was disappointing. See full story. Shares of Charles & Colvard CTHR, -0.73% plunged 31% after the company forecast sales of $11.3 million to $12.2 million for the fourth quarter, below the current average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call for sales of $12.4 million. The Morrisville, N.C., provider of moissanite for jewelry also said it expects to begin an in-case program for the products with Helzberg diamonds in the first quarter. COMSYS IT Partners CITP stock sank 22.3% after the company priced a public offering of 3 million shares of common stock at $11 a share, or $33 million. The Houston-based information technology company will use about $26.8 million of the net proceeds from the offering to redeem all of its outstanding 15% Series A-1 preferred stock. Duratek DRTK stock gave back 6.1% after the company was downgraded at Wedbush Morgan to hold. Herman Miller Inc. MLHR, +2.40% shares fell 5.5% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $27.9 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with $15.4 million, or 22 cents a share, during the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 40 cents a share. The office furniture systems company reported quarterly revenue of $438.2 million, compared with $368.4 million last year. Analysts had looked for revenue of $442 million. Shares of Hudson Highland Group HHGP finished the session down 28.2% after the company said it expects 2005 EBITDA to range from $27 million to $30 million, down from its prior view of $30 million to $34 million. The cut stems from hiring demand softness in Hudson Australia, New Zealand and North America. Hudson Australia has been hurt by hiring freezes from certain key clients, while Hudson North America experienced softer demand and contract pricing pressure in the IT and accounting and finance practice groups Russell Corp. RML, -11.76% shares lost 7.7% after the company warned that it doesn't expect to meet its previously disclosed financial outlook for fiscal 2005 due to lower than anticipated retail sales and extra expenses related to expediting orders associated with supply orders. The Atlanta-based provider of athletic sporting goods and apparel now sees sales of between $1.425 billion and $1.445 billion in 2005. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for sales of $1.454 billion for the year. Russel also said it plans to take "aggressive action" in early 2006 to improve earnings. Shares of Tuesday Morning TUES, +0.00% slumped 9.5% after the company cut its full-year and fourth-quarter forecast, citing lower traffic levels. Sales for the fourth quarter are expected to be in the range of $330 million to $335 million, with sales for the year in a range of $927 million to $932 million. Same-store sales are expected to be down 4% to 5%. Earnings are forecast at 81 to 84 cents a share for the fourth quarter, and about $1.42 to $1.45 a share for the year, including a 6 cents lease accounting charge. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting 96 cents a share for the fourth quarter and $1.63 a share for the year. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasre said Thursday the inquiry by Arizona Attorney General Terry Goddard into the content of the citizen portion of the electronic control device maker's Web site has ended. Taser said it cooperated fully with the probe and made certain changes to both its site and its consumer product materials in consulation with Goddard.
title: Taser: Ariz Attorney General's inquiry has closed

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASRE on Thursday announced that it has received a letter from the Nasdaq Stock Market indicating the company is no longer subject to possible delisting following the filing of its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended September 30. In trading Wednesday Taser shares rose 68 cents to $6.83.
title: Taser to resume trading on Nasdaq under TASR symbol

content: Advancers Alvarion Ltd. ALVR shares ended Wednesday's session with a 5.4% gain after the company said it's received an initial order worth $7 million from an undisclosed large operator in Latin America that it considers a major customer. The order comes under a new frame agreement with the customer that covers Alvarion's BreezeMax and eMGW products. The company estimates the frame agreement could be worth up to $15 million in total. Shares of Cash Systems Inc. CKN, -3.05% tacked on 5.7% after the company said it expects 2006 earnings, excluding options expenses, to be 18 cents to 22 cents a share. The company is forecasting a 10 cents a share loss for 2005. Cash Systems added it expects to generate $88 million to $92 million revenue in 2006, compared to $62 million to $63 million projected for 2005. The figures are dependent on the acquisition of Indian Gaming Systems closing as expected in January, the company noted. Chaparral Steel Co. CHAP shares jumped 13.7% after the company posted earnings of $34 million, or $1.44 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $21 million, or 92 cents a share. The company said shipments leapt 41% to 548,000 tons for the quarter from a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for Chaparral's results. Christopher & Banks Corp. CBK, +1.90% stock surged 9.2% after the company posted third-quarter earnings of $8.7 million, or 24 cents a share, besting Wall Street's consensus view by a penny. Family Dollar Stores FDO, +7.10% stock added 5.6% after the company said its first-quarter profit fell to $51.4 million, or 32 cents a share, from $54.4 million, or 32 cents, a year ago. Earnings per share remained flat despite the decline in net income because there were fewer shares outstanding in the most recent quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First call were looking for earnings, on average, of 31 cents. Sales for the three months ended Nov. 26, advanced to $1.51 billion from $1.38 billion in last year's first quarter. The Matthews, N.C.-based discount retailer forecast second-quarter earnings of 45 cents to 50 cents a share and full-year earnings at $1.30 to $1.39 a share. Analysts' average estimates stand at 49 cents and $1.34, respectively. FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26% shares finished up 5.3% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $471 million, or $1.53 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $354 million, or $1.15 a share. Revenue rose 10% in the latest three months to $8.09 billion from $7.33 billion in the same period a year earlier. The Memphis, Tenn., package delivery company said it saw a sharp improvement in its operating margins to 9.8% from 8.2% a year ago due to strong customer demand and a disciplined pricing approach. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of $1.40 a share in November quarter on revenue of $8.07 billion. Looking ahead, the company sees third-quarter earnings of $1.15 to $1.30 a share, and a profit before items of $5.60 to $5.85 a share for the full year. The outlook for the full year is an increase from previous expectations Shares of GSI Group Inc. GSIG a supplier of precision motion components, lasers and laser systems, rose 5.7% after the company authorized a stock repurchase program of up to 1.5 million shares. Jabil Circuit JBL, +1.74% shares gained 7.2% after the company posted a profit of $76.9 million, or 37 cents a share, for its fiscal first quarter as revenue rose 31% year-over-year to $2.4 billion. See full story. Shares of Joy Global Inc. JOYG a provider of mining equipment and services, ended higher by 13.6% after the company posted fourth-quarter net income of $56 million, or 45 cents a share, compared with $19 million, or 16 cents a share in the year-ago period. Net sales for the quarter rose 36% to $568 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 45 cents per share, on average. Coal prices in the U.S. remain strong, particularly in the Powder River Basin, Joy Global said, and it expects the non-U.S. coal business will increasingly be driven by the emerging markets of China, Russia and India. The company forecast 2006 total revenue of $2.25 to $2.45 billion, and earnings of $1.85 to $2.15 a share. Maxtor Corp. MXO, +13.04% stock rocketed higher by 53.3% after the company agreed to be acquired by Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% for $1.9 billion in a deal expected to lift earnings by as much as 20% in the first year after completion. Seagate said it will swap 0.37 of its shares, which at Tuesday's close value Maxtor at $7.25 a share, vs. Maxtor's close of $4.52. Seagate said it expects revenue attrition, but sees $300 million in annual operating expenses from greater scale, reduced supply chain costs, and combined R&D efforts. Seagate also reaffirmed December and fiscal 2006 guidance. See full story. Netflix NFLX, +3.35% shares surged 9.1% after Citigroup Investment Research initiated coverage of the online movie rental company with a buy rating and a price target of $39. "We believe its competitive advantage and scale benefits are accentuated as it helps consumers find lesser-known titles," the firm told clients. Citigroup believes it will be very difficult for new and existing competitors to take market share away from Netflix, saying it expects the company to retain 70% of the market for subscription-based services. Playtex Products Inc. PYX, -5.19% stock added 9% after the company was tabbed to replace Southwestern Energy in the S&P SmallCap 600 index. Southwestern Energy SWN, +0.23% shares closed up 5.8% after the company was tabbed to replace PacifiCare in the S&P Midcap 400 index. Shares of Taser International TASRE surged 11.1% after the company said a wrongful death lawsuit against it was dismissed in Texas. In addition, Merriman Curhan Ford initiated coverage of the company with a buy rating. See full story. Tekelec TKLC shares rose 11.1% after the company signed a 3-year extension of a preferred original equipment manufacturing agreement with Alcatel ALA, +0.59% Financial terms weren't disclosed. The deal calls for Alcatel to continue to deploy the Tekelec 8000 Media Gateway as a part of Alcatel's Mobile Next Generation Network product. THQ Inc. THQI shares ended higher by 5.1% after the company said sales of its holiday titles are performing to company expectations and its previous guidance of third quarter ending Dec. 31 net income of around 65 cents a share remains unchanged. Third-quarter net sales are also on track to meet the company's $320 million forecast. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 66 cents a share on net sales of $323 million. The company said it will launch its core titles for the next-generation of games machines next year as the user-base increases. U.S. Express Enterprises XPRSA shares added 11.6% after the company forecast earnings of 43 to 47 cents a share for the fourth quarter, an outlook that's better than previously anticipated due to strong freight demand, improved pricing in its truckload business and somewhat lower net fuel expense. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 28 cents a share in the December period. Decliners Atlantic Liberty Financial Corp. ALFC shares ended the session down 19.7% after the company agreed to be acquired by Flushing Financial Corp. FFIC, -1.46% in a deal valued at approximately $41.9 million. Lake Success, N.Y.-based Flushing Financial said it expects the deal to increase its earnings per share. Atlantic Liberty shareholders will have the choice of receiving $24 a share or 1.43 Flushing Financial shares for every Atlantic Liberty share. Flushing Financial said the deal is subject to aggregate allocation of 65% stock and 35% cash. Shares of Calpine Corp. CPNL fell 13.9% after the company sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy late Tuesday. The San Jose, Calif.-based company, saddled by $17 billion in debt and mounting losses, was trading 8.3% lower at 21 cents a share after dropping as low as 19 cents. The company said it has secured $2 billion in debtor-in-possession financing to begin restructuring and that it will continue to operate its nationwide fleet of 90 power plants. See full story. Cambridge Display Technology OLED, +1.41% stock slumped 9.4% after the company reached deals to sell roughly 2.2 million common shares for $8 each and warrants to purchase an additional 656,250 shares at an exercise price of $12 each in a private placement. The company expects to raise $17.5 million in the deal. Grand Toys International Ltd. GRIN shares gave back 7.6% after the company named Jeff Hsieh Cheng CEO. The Hong Kong company also named Elliot Bier chairman. The changes are part of Grand Toys' pending acquisition of Hua Yang Printing Holdings Co. and Kord Holdings Inc. Intervoice Inc. INTV, -3.06% shares fell 8.4% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $3.6 million, or 9 cents a share, down from last year's equivalent profit of $4.6 million, or 12 cents a share. Shares of TSYS TSS, +1.66% lost 13.9% after the company projected an annualized shortfall of approximately $140 million in revenue from the loss of its Bank of America consumer card portfolio, which is approximately 10.9% of TSYS' projected 2005 revenue, excluding reimbursable items. The company cited Bank of America's shift of its credit card processing away from the Columbus, Ga., company, pending the bank's acquisition of MBNA. TSYS will continue to provide Bank of America with merchant and commercial services. Wavecom WVCM shares slumped 15.2% after the company said it expects revenue for the fourth quarter ending Dec. 31 to come in slightly below its third-quarter total of $38.9 million. The company attributed the shortfall to the rescheduling of orders by a number of customers. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Taser shares rallied Wednesday after the stun-gun maker said a wrongful death suit was dismissed in Texas and a broker initiated coverage of the firm with a buy rating. Taser International TASRE said the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Texas ordered the dismissal of the wrongful death lawsuit filed by Arthur Elsholtz. The move marked the eighth wrongful death or injury lawsuit that has been dismissed against Taser in the past 18 months. Meanwhile, broker Merriman Curhan Ford lauded the Scottsdale company's leading market position. "We believe Taser International has developed the dominant less-than-lethal weapon with a name that has quickly become synonymous with the technology," Merriman Curhan Ford said in a note to clients. "Even so, we estimate Taser has only penetrated 12% of the potential domestic law enforcement market." The broker said it expects Taser shares to approach the $9.20 level over the next 12 months. Taser shares rose 13% to $6.94 on the Nasdaq. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you
title: Taser rallies after suit dismissed, upgrade to buy

content: Advancers Blyth Inc. BTH, +1.01% shares ended Tuesday's session with a 15.1% gain after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $23 million, or 56 cents a share, missing Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 67 cents a share, due to higher freight surcharges, sales shortfall in its Direct Selling business, and lower discretionary consumer spending in its Home Expressions business. The Greenwich, Conn., seller of home fragrance and home decor products also said it plans to repatriate up to $130 million in foreign earnings, and that it expects a ruling from the Internal Revenue Service before the end of the year on the proposed spin-off of its Wholesale business. Looking ahead, Blyth sees earnings of $1.65 to $1.70 a share, excluding the impact of a tax charge related to the repatriation of foreign earnings. Shares of Celanese Corp. CE, +0.47% tacked on 7.7% after the company raised its 2005 earnings-per-share outlook to a range of $2.10 to $2.20, from the previous range of $1.95 to $2.05, citing continued strength of its Ibn Sina joint venture in Saudi Arabia, lower personnel costs, and a lower tax rate. The Dallas-based chemicals company also said it expects 2006 earnings in a range of $2.50 to $2.90. CKE Restaurants Inc. CKR stock rose 7.1% after the company reported third-quarter net earnings of $15.8 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with $13.1 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected the restaurant operator to report per-share earnings of 21 cents. CKE said quarterly revenue was $344.1 million, compared with $348.9 million last year, while the consensus estimate was for $342 million. The restaurant company also said November's same-store sales were up 0.6% from last year, with total revenue reaching $93 million. Diebold Inc. DBD, +7.32% shares gained 5.3% after the company said Chairman and Chief Executive Walden O'Dell resigned for personal reasons, effective immediately. Thomas Swidarski, president and chief operating officer, was named CEO and elected to the board, while John Lauer was named non-executive chairman. In addition, North Canton, Ohio-based Diebold also reaffirmed its fourth-quarter view for earnings of 50 to 60 cents a share. Diodes Inc. DIOD, +0.00% shares surged 12.5% after the company increased its fourth-quarter revenue guidance to 10% to 12% sequential growth from its record third-quarter revenue of $54.2 million. The Westlake Village, Calif.-based company said better-than-expected demand in the Asian and North American consumer electronics markets are fuelling the growth. Shares of Herley Industries HRLY added 7.9% after the company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $4 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $3.6 million, or 24 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 21 cents a share. Revenue rose 25% to $41.9 million from last year's $33.6 million, just shy of analyst projections of $43.3 million. Indevus Pharmaceuticals IDEV, +0.97% shares jumped 17.2% after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $12.6 million, narrower than a year-ago loss of $27.9 million, and acquired the rights to Deltestryl, an injectable testosterone preparation for the treatment for male hypogonadism, from Savient Pharmaceuticals. The company expects the deal to increase its revenue base by about $3.5 million in calendar 2006. Insmed Inc. INSM, +2.22% shares rose 10.1% after the company said the Food and Drug Administration has approved Iplex to treat growth failure in children with severe primary IGF-1 deficiency or with growth hormone gene deletion who have developed neutralizing antibodies to growth hormones. The Richmond, Va.-based biopharmaceutical company said Iplex is entitled to seven years of marketing exclusivity for the treatment of primary IGFD. The news weighed on shares of Tercica TRCA which makes a competing drug. Magellan Health Services MGLN, +0.09% shares added 7.7% after the company agreed to buy National Imaging Associates Inc, a privately held radiology benefits management firm headquartered in Hackensack, N.J., from its owners for a net price of around $122 million in cash. The company also said that, excluding the impact of the NIA acquisition, it expects to generate revenues in a range of $1.61 billion to $1.65 billion, net income in a range of $55 million to $71 million and earnings per share of between $1.42 and $1.84 in 2006. MSGI Security Solutions MSGI shares ended the day higher by 15.7% after the company reached an accord to provide technology products for Turkish OYAK Defense & Security Systems Corp. The company expects the deal to yield between $7 million and $10 million in new revenue next year. Shares of New Frontier Media NOOF gained 5.5% after the company said it plans to buy back up to 2 million shares, or roughly 9% of its outstanding common stock, over the next 30 months. The Boulder, Colo., provider of electronic distribution of adult entertainment materials also said it continues to review strategic options. Palomar Medical Technologies PMTI stock gained 5.9% after a District Court in Massachusetts issued several rulings in the company's favor related to an ongoing patent infringement lawsuit filed against Cutera Inc. CUTR, +2.97% In the lawsuit, Palomar and MGH accuse Cutera's CoolGlide products line of infringing a patent. Rohm and Haas Co. ROH, +0.42% shares rose 6.5% after the company said it plans to cut 400 jobs as part of a restructuring, resulting in pretax charges of $65 million, or 20 cents a share, which will be recorded in the fourth quarter. The Philadelphia-based chemical company said the restructuring initiatives involve the closing or partial shutdown of manufacturing facilities in the United Kingdom and Germany, and will result in annual cost savings of $35 million. The initiatives are expected to result in future charges of $10 million. Rohm and Haas forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 45 to 50 cents a share, including the restructuring charges. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are estimating fourth-quarter earnings of 55 cents a share. Shares of Sabre Holdings Corp. TSG, +4.75% added 6.4% after the company forecast 2006 revenue to rise 15% over last year, toward $3 billion, and for earnings to be ahead of analyst expectations. See full story. Taser International TASRE shares jumped 15% after the company said the Securities and Exchange Commission has completed a previously announced probe into the company's internal disclosures concerning the medical safety of the company's stun gun, and certain accounting and disclosure issues. The SEC will not recommend enforcement proceedings against the company on any of the matters, the Scottsdale, Ariz. company said. The SEC is also probing to investigate issues relating to trading in the company's stock. Taylor Devices TAYD, -0.54% shares ended with a 9.9% gain after the company received an order worth roughly $3.3 million to provide earthquake dampers for use at a bullet train station in Yokohama, Japan. North Tonawanda, N.Y.-based Taylor expects to provide 377 large seismic dampers for the project. Universal Technical Institute UTI, +1.73% shares closed up 12% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $9.2 million, or 32 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $6.7 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue leapt 20.8% in the latest three months to $83.9 million from $69.5 million in the same period a year earlier. The Phoenix-based provider of technical education training services attributed the strong revenue growth to higher average student enrollment and tuition increases. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 28 cents a share in the September period. Looking ahead, the company said it expects an increase of between 19% and 21% in revenue for fiscal 2006. Unova UNA, +1.62% stock surged 15.6% after the company completed the sale of its Landis grinding systems operations to Groupe Fives-Lille, a French engineering group. The consideration included $69 million in cash, a $10 million two-year note, and the assumption of certain liabilities. Wendy's International WEN, +0.75% shares added 7.1% after the company dismissed a shareholder's efforts to drastically overhaul the makeup of the fast-food chain and set the stage for a prolonged public battle. As well, the company said it expects to record $60 million to $70 million in pretax asset gains and $200 million in cash proceeds in the fourth quarter from the sale of 200 Wendy's real estate properties to franchisees and third parties. The fast-food restaurant operator also expects to record pretax charges in the quarter of $23 million to $28 million for the closing of 40 to 45 underperforming Wendy's restaurants. Dublin, Ohio-based Wendy's said it's slowing new restaurant development in 2005 and 2006 and focusing on improving performance of its Wendy's business, but it still expects to re-franchise 250 to 450 Wendy's stores over the next two years. Decliners Best Buy BBY, +2.09% shares ended Tuesday's session down 11.8% after the company reported disappointing results for the third quarter due to overinvestment in certain restructuring activities. See full story. Shares of Cendant Corp. CD, +0.00% lost 10% after the company warned that fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations are expected to be 23 cents a share, at the low end of its prior range of 23 to 26 cents a share, due to "continuing challenges" at its travel distribution services business. Cendant said it's addressing issues at its international online operations. See full story. Cooper Cos. Inc. COO, +1.63% stock gave back 7.5% after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $10.8 million, or 22 cents a share, vs. $29.2 million, or 79 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. Pro forma earnings were 83 cents a share for the quarter. There were 48.1 million shares outstanding during the quarter compared with 36.9 million in the year-ago period. The Pleasanton, Calif.-based medical products company posted revenue of $221.4 million vs. $130.8 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 85 cents a share on revenue of $220 million. CuraGen CRGN shares tumbled 23.6% after the company said its Phase II trial of velafermin, which treats oral mocositis in patients receiving chemotherapy, failed to meet its primary endpoint. While velafermin reduced oral mucositis in come instances, the results were not statistically significant. The company said it would evaluate the results and continue with additional Phase II studies. First BanCorp FBP, +1.35% shares lost 6.9% after the company said it plans to restate its previously reported financial statements to correct its accounting for certain mortgage-related transactions and interest rate swaps. It expects to record a cumulative non-cash loss of about $175 million related to the change in its hedge accounting as of Nov. 30. The mortgage-related changes will reduce the company's reported residential real estate loans going back to 2002, and increase its commercial loans by the same amounts. It will also revise certain disclosures in its statements, and its cash flow from investing activities. FoxHollow Technologies FOXH stock slumped 15.5% after the company said Chief Executive Robert Thomas plans to retire Jan. 1. John Simpson, FoxHollow's founder and chairman, will serve as interim CEO until a successor is named, the Redwood City, Calif.-based medical products company said. Simpson plans to relinquish his role as chairman but will remain on the board. The company also reaffirmed its fourth-quarter revenue outlook of $40 million to $42 million and its full-year 2005 revenue outlook of $126 million to $128 million. Gateway Inc. GTW shares fell 8.2% after fellow personal computer maker Hewlett-Packard gave a revenue forecast for 2006 that could potentially fall below Wall Street's current expectations. In addition, a national class action lawsuit was filed against the company in California District Court by a group of consumers alleging Gateway sold defective plasma televisions Shares of Lightbridge LTBG slumped 15.5% after the company concluded its probe of possible strategic alternatives for its Telecom Decisioning Services unit and decided to continue to operate the business. "Over the last six months, we have been fully engaged in the process of exploring alternatives and opportunities for TDS," said Bob Donahue, the company's president and CEO. "The process has run its course and we believe it is in the best interest of our shareholders to retain the business." Sirius Satellite Radio SIRI, +1.05% shares gave back 6% after the company was downgraded at Banc of America to sell. The company also signed a multiyear agreement with the National Basketball Association that extends the parties' existing broadcast agreement. Star Gas Partners L.P SGU, -0.11% shares slid 13.3% after the company said its fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $46.9 million, from $63.2 million a year ago. The company said that revenue rose 17.8% to $150.7 million, after higher selling prices offset a reduction of home heating oil sales. Home heating oil per gallon margins for the fiscal 2005 fourth quarter rose by 7 cents per gallon, versus the previous year, after the company said it was able to take advantage of opportunities in the commodity market because of its owned storage facilities, the loss of certain low margin price protected customers and a more disciplined approach to product pricing. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading Monday are Hillenbrand Industries Inc. and Apple Computer Inc. Hillenbrand Industries HB is expected to report fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 74 cents a share, according to two analysts polled by Thomson First Call. In addition, Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% said Friday that Apple's AAPL, +0.78% popular iPod music players were among the online retailer's best-selling items so far for the holiday-shopping season. See full story. Watch list Cray Inc. CRAY, +3.24% said that Burton Smith, its co-founder and chief scientist, plans to leave the supercomputer maker to take on an undisclosed position at Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% See full story. Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% is reportedly planning a restructuring that could involve thousands of job reductions as well as plant cutbacks. It would be a major move for Merck's chief executive, who joined the company earlier this year. See full story. Mittal Steel Company NV MT, +4.78% said it has completed its $4.84 billion acquisition of 93.02% of Kryvorizhstal, a Ukrainian carbon-steel producer. Kryvorizhstal had liquid-steel production of 7.7 million tons in 2004 and shipments of 6.7 million tons. It also produced 17.1 million tons of iron ore. Mittal named Narendra Chaudhary as the Ukrainian company's new chief executive. Taser International TASRE disclosed Friday that its stock was in danger of losing its listing on the Nasdaq Stock Market. See full story. The European Commission cleared Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.29% to buy U.S.-based drugmaker Ivax Corp. IVX, +14.29% Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% said Saturday that it expects November sales, which includes the Friday after Thanksgiving, to rise 4.3%. That is within the company's 3% to 5% forecast range. See full story. Crowds flocked to retailers like Best Buy Co Inc. BBY, +2.09% Target Corp. TGT, +0.36% Wal-Mart and Sears Holdings Corp. SHLD, -4.98% heralding the start of the most important shopping season of the year. See full story. XL Capital Ltd. XL, -0.16% said that the previously announced independent, actuary draft report issued in connection with the company's acquisition of Winterthur International from Winterthur Swiss Insurance Co. requires Winterthur Swiss to pay XL $575 million for the net losses and unearned premium balances relating to the acquired business. It's also expected to result in XL recording a fourth-quarter net charge of $830 million, according to the Bermuda-based insurance company. XL added that it's working with ratings agencies and its financial advisers to determine how much capital it will raise and in what form. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins?
