title: Hillenbrand, Merck, Apple and more

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - U.S. stocks closed higher after an abbreviated session Friday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite at fresh 4 1/2-year highs and retailers like Wal-Mart Stores and Best Buy in focus as the Christmas shopping season got underway. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed up 15.53 points at 10,931.62, marking an eight-month high. The day's gains marked the sixth consecutive higher close. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% rose 2.64 points to 1,268.25 and the Nasdaq Composite $COMX advanced 3.03 points to 2,263.01. The Dow rose 1.5% during the holiday-shortened week, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite both racked up 1.6% gains. There were more than 539 million shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, where declining stocks outpaced rising shares by 18 to 12. More than 645 million shares traded in the Nasdaq market, with 14 advancing shares for every 13 declining stocks. The market closed at 1 p.m. Commodities markets were closed, but stocks, foreign exchange, and Treasurys markets were open. There were no scheduled economic reports to lend direction to trading. All eyes were trained on the retail sector because the Friday after Thanksgiving traditionally marks the start of the Christmas shopping season. Investors are eager for data and anecdotal evidence about how much investors are spending because consumers remain one of the engines of the economy. "Everyone is trying to get a handle on retail sales to see how good they are," said Jim Awad of Awad Asset Management. "Money managers would like to keep the rally going. If retail sales look good, money managers will look for the market to have a good close for the year." However, Robert Pavlik, chief investment officer at Oaktree Asset Management, said, "There is increased concern that the market is getter ahead of itself. We've come so far so fast and the market has not had a chance to consolidate. The question for next week is whether we will get a continuation of the rally or a selloff." The dollar was higher, trading up 0.9% at 119.62 yen, as the euro fell 0.09% to $1.1711. See full story. The yen was hurt by disappointing Japanese consumer price data, according to Stuart Scrase, a senior foreign exchange trader with CMC Markets. "Japanese CPI failed to show any inflationary pressures despite the fact that expectations were suggesting otherwise," Scrase said. "Once again this is pushing the Bank of Japan's plans to start tightening monetary policy back somewhat and the return of the dollar to above 119 yen is clearly linked to this news." Treasurys were rallying, sending yields to their lowest level in nearly four weeks. The gains were linked to expectations that the Federal Reserve could end its interest-rate hiking cycle in early 2006. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note last was up 10/32 at 100 18/32 with a yield of 4.430%, See full story. Stocks to watch Shares of iPod maker Apple Computer AAPL, +0.78% closed 3.2% higher at $69.28. The iPod figured prominently in online retailer Amazon's AMZN, +1.11% just-released list of its top-selling holiday items in various categories for the three weeks from Nov. 1 to Nov. 22. Dow industrials component Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% gave up initial gains to close down 8 cents at $50.49 on the first day of the holiday shopping season. Electronic goods retailer Best Buy BBY, +2.09% shot 0.3% higher to $50.63, while Urban Outfitters Inc URBN, +1.59% fell 2.5% to $32.57. Among other retailers, Target Corp. TGT, +0.36% rose 13 cents to $55.23, Kohl's Corp. KSS, +1.47% ended up 13 cents at $49.20 as Sears Holdings Corp. SHLD, -4.98% dropped $2.45 to $118.71. Taser International TASRE fell 13% to $6.48. The stun-gun maker was told by the Nasdaq Stock Market that its shares could be delisted because its third-quarter report is delayed. The company said it will appeal. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks end light post-holiday session with gains

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International slumped Friday after the maker of stun guns disclosed that its stock was in danger of losing its listing on the Nasdaq Stock Market. Taser TASRE fell as much as $1.05, or 14%, to an intraday low of $6.35 before rebounding slightly to trade at $6.42. It was still up 4.4% since the end of October, but has lost 80% since the end of 2004. The Nasdaq informed the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company it's not in compliance with listing standards, citing its failure to file its third-quarter financial statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on time. Taser had disclosed on Nov. 15 that it had filed for an extension in filing its third-quarter financial statements while it analyzed the impact from the restatement of first and second-quarter financial statements. The restatements were a result of incorrect accounting of legal fees and other professional expenses. Taser said it plans to appeal the Nasdaq's decision, and it has requested a hearing before the exchange's listing qualifications panel. Until the Nasdaq issues a final ruling, an "E" will be tacked onto the end of Taser's stock ticker symbol, making it "TASRE." More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau
title: Taser tumbles after receiving delisting warning

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Taser International, Inc. tasr Friday said that, due to a delay in filing a third-quarter Form 10-Q with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, it was informed by the Nasdaq Stock Market that its stock is subject to delisting. The Scottsdale, Ariz. said it plans to appeal the delisting notice. On Wednesday the company's stock rose 4% to $7.40.
title: Taser Intl gets Nasdaq delisting notice due to late 10-Q

content: Hancock Fabrics swings to quarterly loss; suspends dividend (6:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hancock Fabrics Inc. HKF, +5.77% late Tuesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $2.5 million, or 14 cents a share. In the same period last year, the company reported net earnings of $977,000, or 5 cents a share. Revenue at the Baldwyn, Miss.-based retailer fell to $103.9 million from $109.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated a loss of 9 cents a share on revenue of $104 million. Hancock also said it has suspended its quarterly dividend indefinitely. Taser Int'l to restate 1Q, 2Q results, revise 3Q results (6:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR after Tuesday's closing bell said it will restate its first- and second-quarter results to correct its accounting for legal fees and other professional expenses. The correction will shift the expenses among the first three quarters of 2005, with expenses expected to increase in the first quarter and decrease in the second. There will also be a corresponding decrease/increase in net income. As well, Taser expects the restatements will cut its third-quarter expenses to $6.9 million from a previously reported $7 million, sending its net income higher by $60,000 to $300,000. Blue Coat Systems quarterly profit soars (5:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Blue Coat Systems Inc. BCSI after Tuesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $4.16 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $607,000, or 5 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On a pro forma basis, earnings came in at 32 cents a share vs. 9 cents a share last year. Revenue rose to $36.7 million from $21.9 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings of 30 cents a share on revenue of $36.8 million. The Sunnyvale, Calif.-based proxy appliance company forecast third-quarter earnings of 30 cents to 34 cents a share, or 32 cents to 36 cents a share on a pro forma basis. It expects sequential revenue growth of 4% to 7%. National City forecasts $100M-$120M in charges in 4Q (5:13 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- National City Corp. NCC, -0.16% said after the closing bell on Tuesday that it plans to exit the indirect retail auto and motorsports lending business due to low returns and volume challenges. As a result, the Cleveland-based financial services company expects to incur between $100 million and $120 million in charges in the fourth quarter. The charges include $40 million in costs associated with exiting the lending business as well as costs related to the company's implementation of its "Best in Class" program. The program identifies opportunities for long-term, sustainable revenue growth, the company said. Borders 3Q loss widens on remodeling of stores (4:52 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Borders Group Inc. BGP, -4.96% said after the market closed Tuesday that its third-quarter loss widened from that of a year ago on costs associated with the remodeling of 55 stores. The Ann Arbor, Mich.-based book and music retailer said it lost $14 million, or 20 cents a share, compared to its year-ago loss of $1.1 million, or 1 cent a share. The figure in the latest period includes a charge of 2 cents a share related to the remodels. Revenue rose to $841 million from $838.6 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a loss of 18 cents a share on revenue of $829.3 million. In the fourth quarter, Borders expects earnings in the range of $1.60 to $1.80 per share, including charges of 4-5 cents a share. For the year, the company expects to earn $1.28 to $1.47 a share, including charges of 11-12 cents a share. Wachovia sees credit cards adding to, not reducing, earnings (3:26 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Wachovia WB, +3.87% plans to re-enter the credit card market in January but doesn't expect the business to reduce earnings next year due to a $100 million termination fee from MBNA KRB, +13.07% which is merging with Bank of America BAC, +2.04% said Chief Financial Officer Bob Kelly in a presentation at the Merrill Lynch banking conference Tuesday. Previously, Wachovia had a marketing agreement with MBNA. Kelly expects an eventual 20% return from credit cards and said the business should be profitable in 2007. The bank plans to focus on existing customers, which will cut down on marketing and credit costs, Kelly said. TRM Corp. shares plunge; co.'s 3Q earns fall short (2:03 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of TRM Corp. TRMM, +0.00% plummeted almost 42% to $6.98 on Tuesday, putting it atop the Nasdaq percentage decliners list. After Monday's closing bell, the Portland, Ore., provider of consumer ATM and photocopying services posted adjusted earnings of $700,000, or 5 cents a share, on sales of $59.2 million in its fiscal third quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 23 cents a share in the September period on sales of $63.9 million. The company said its operating margins took a hit in the quarter due to unusually high cash losses in its UK ATM operations from theft. It also saw lower copy volumes per unit in its photocopying business. Xerium Tech lowers FY05 financial outlook (1:55 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Xerium Technologies XRM, -2.86% dropped 26.5% to $6.99 on Tuesday after the Westborough, Mass., clothing and roll cover manufacturer lowered its financial outlook for fiscal 2005 due to output issues in its North American clothing business and an inability to increase prices as expected. The company now sees earnings before items of 57 to 62 cents a share for the year, down from a previous projection for a profit of $1.14 to $1.24 a share, excluding costs related to its initial public offering. The current average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of $1.19 a share in 2005. Astea Int'l tops Nasdaq percentage gainers (1:38 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Astea International Inc. ATEA, +4.00% soared almost 43% to $13.08 on Tuesday after the Horsham, Pa., provider of service management software reported third-quarter earnings of $2.7 million, or 91 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $155,000, or a nickel per share. Revenue leapt 106% in the latest three months to $8.2 million from $4 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improvement in its results to the closing of an "unusually large enterprise deal" during the quarter, its acquisition of FieldCentrix, and strength in its international operations, where revenue rose 266%. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate of the company's results. The stock was the top percentage gainer on the Nasdaq exchange. Provident Bank restates full-year 2004, 2005 quarterly earns (12:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Provident Bankshares Corp. PBKS on Tuesday restated its results for the quarters ended March 31, June 30 and Sept 30, following the completion of an accounting review. The Baltimore-based financial services company also restated its earnings for the year ended Dec. 31, 2004. The company restated its third-quarter earnings to 54 cents from its earlier report of 60 cents a share. For the second quarter, Provident restated its earnings to 60 cents from 55 cents a share. The company posted restated earnings of 47 cents for the first quarter, down from 54 cents a share earlier. For the full-year 2004, Provident reported earnings of $2 a share. The company had previously said its earnings were $1.95 a share for the year. World Fuel Services' shares rally on strong 3Q profit growth (12:34 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of World Fuel Services INT, +4.42% rose 10.1% to $36.33 on Tuesday after the Miami-based provider of seller of marine and aviation fuel products posted third-quarter earnings of $10.7 million, or 44 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $5.4 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue leapt in the latest three months to $2.31 billion from $1.57 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 34 cents a share in the September period. Health Management issues fiscal 2006 objectives (12:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCSICO (MarketWatch) -- Health Management Associates Inc. HMA said Tuesday it's targeting revenue of $4 billion to $4.2 billion in fiscal 2006, and per-share earnings results of $1.56 to $1.60. The Naples, Fla.-based hospital operator also targeted between five and seven acquisitions for the year. Mexican Restaurants quarterly earnings plunge; revenue flat (12:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Mexican Restaurants Inc. CASA, +4.94% on Tuesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $31,195, or a penny a share, vs. $583,258, or 16 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The Houston-based operator and franchisor of Mexican restaurants posted revenue of $19.9 million vs. $19.8 million. The company said its results reflect losses related to the disposition of assets associated with remodeling restaurants. Additionally, the company estimated it lost $1 million in revenue due to Hurricane Rita. Centex gives 2007 EPS forecast, reaffirms 2006 EPS view (11:16 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Centex Corp. CTX, +0.48% on Tuesday said it expects to report net earnings from continuing operations for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2007 of $10.75 to $11.25 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for per-share results of $10.72, on average. The homebuilder also reffirmed its 2006 forecast for net earnings from continuing operations of $9.65 to $9.85. Analysts are looking for $9.77 a share in earnings. Centex provided the outlook at its annual investor conference in New York City. Dana: 2004 restatement triggering 2000-2003 restatements (10:45 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dana Corp. DCN, -3.61% said Tuesday that the restatement of its 2004 financial statements will trigger the accounting requirement to restate its financial statements for the years 2002 and 2003 and its financial results for the years 2000 and 2001. The restatements will only affect the timing of reported income, not cumulative net income, the auto parts company said. Dana still expects after-tax net income for all periods to be restated to be reduced by $25 million to $45 million. The company also said it expects to cure the possible violation of covenants under certain indentures by filing its financial statements within the 60-day period provided. Finally, Dana said it's in talks with its bank groups regarding an extension of the covenant waivers for its existing principal bank facility and accounts receivable facility from Nov. 30 to beyond the end of the year, as well as amendments to the bank facility. Analyst says Schwab stock 'has gotten ahead of itself' (10:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Fox-Pitt Kelton analyst David Trone said Schwab's SC.H, +0.00% October trading data was stronger than expected and that he had already expected higher marketing costs for the fourth quarter. However, the company's $10 million charge for severance payments at its U.S. Trust unit marked a new item, he said. "We believe the Schwab story has hit an inflection point as positive catalysts had been exhausted and possible headwinds lurk," Trone said in a note to clients. "The restructuring story has been completed, and now the company faces a period of reinvestment as it transitions to a more offensive strategy. We believe the stock has gotten ahead of itself." Schwab CFO says investments will build momentum (9:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% shares fell 4.7% to $15.24 in early action on Tuesday after the company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of 14 cents a share, below the target of 16 cents a share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. CFO Chris Dodds said in an interview with MarketWatch that the company had already set plans to invest in its business in September. With increased trading results in October, Schwab is seeing "strong" volume that reflects "heightened engagement by investors," Dodds said. The company plans to spend about $60 million on marketing in the fourth quarter, up from $39 million in the previous period. The company's marketing costs and price cuts mark an effort to invest in its business and "build on our real momentum," he said. Sappi rises after quarterly loss is narrower than expected (9:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Depositary shares of Sappi Ltd. SPP, +0.00% rose more than 5% in early trades on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday after the paper company reported a narrower fourth-quarter loss than expected. Sappi said it expects quarter-over-quarter earnings improvement ahead, causing Goldman Sachs analysts to forecast 2006 and 2007 profits of 15 cents and 20 cents a share, respectively. The previous estimates were for losses of 10 cents a share each year in 2006 and 2007. Sappi rose recently to $11.22, up 58 cents. TJX reports lower third-quarter earnings (9:31 AM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- TJX Companies TJX, +1.08% reported lower third-quarter earnings of $171 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $201 million, or 40 cents a share, for the same quarter last year. Revenue for the quarter was $4 billion, versus $3.8 billion last year, with consolidated comparable store sales being flat. A poll of analysts by Thomson First Call estimated the retailer would earn 34 cents a share, on revenue of $4.1 billion. TJX said that it sees fourth-quarter earnings coming in between 41 and 43 cents a share, and fiscal 2006 adjusted earnings between $1.32 and $1.34 a share. Fee elimination, ad campaign to lower Schwab's 4Q earns (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Charles Schwab & Co. SC.H, +0.00% Tuesday forecast fourth-quarter earnings will come in 2 cents below its profit of 16 cents a share in the third quarter ended Sept. 30. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for earnings of 16 cents a share in the December period. The company said it expects a new national advertising campaign and its decision to eliminate certain fees to lower earnings by $40 million on a pre-tax basis in the fourth quarter. It also anticipates pre-tax severance charges totaling $10 million in the December quarter related to staffing reductions at U.S. Trust. As for October, Schwab said new and current clients brought new net assets of $7.6 billion during the month, bringing total client assets to $1.152 trillion at October's end, up 13% from a year ago. The San Francisco-based online broker said client daily average trades totaled 258,900 for October, up 52% from last year and 10% from September. The stock closed Monday at $16 unchanged. DrugMax reports deeper loss as it eyes sale of unit (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- DrugMax Inc. DMAX on Tuesday reported a third-quarter loss of $14.5 million, or 71 cents a share, compared to a loss of $1.8 million, or $2.40 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $51.8 million from $53.4 million. The company said it plans to complete a sale of its wholesale distribution business by December. Shares of Drugmax fell 4 cents to $1.26 on Monday. School Specialty's net income declines 33% (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- School Specialty SCHS, +16.67% which provides learning products to the pre-kindergarten to 12th grade market, reported Tuesday fiscal second-quarter net income of 20.6 million, or 85 cents a share, down from net income of $30.6 million, or $1.30 a share, a year ago. "We expected stronger revenue trends tied to an improved state funding environment for preK-12 education but determined that the higher level of state funding was allocated to other needs," CEO David Vander Zanden said in a statement. Ross Stores sees 4Q earns 44-47c; sets $400M buyback (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ross Stores ROST, +2.39% Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings of $36.3 million, or 25 cents a share, down slightly from a year-ago profit of $37.7 million, or 25 cents a share. Sales rose 20% in the latest three months to $1.24 billion from $1.03 billion in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales increased 9% for the quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 26 cents a share in the October period. Looking ahead, the Pleasanton, Calif., off-price retailer forecast earnings of 44 to 47 cents a share, surrounding Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 45 cents a share. Also, Ross Stores said its board has approved the buyback of up to $400 million worth of its common stock over the next two years and a 20% increase in its quarterly cash dividend to 6 cents a share. For fiscal 2006, Ross sees earnings of $1.60 to $1.70 a share, an outlook that reflects expectations for same-store sales growth of 3% to 4% and profit of 6 to 7 cents a share from an extra week of operations. The stock closed Monday at $26.28, up 2 cents. Vimicro IPO prices below range for Tues. debut (8:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vimicro VIMC on Tuesday priced its initial public offering at $10 a share, below its $11-$13 price range. The fabless designer of multimedia processors for PC cameras and mobile phones raised $87 million by selling 8.7 million shares with underwriter Morgan Stanley for its Nasdaq stock market debut on Tuesday. Fashion retailer Cato's profit more than doubles (8:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Cato Corp. CTR, +2.29% a women's clothing retailer, said Tuesday its net income was $4.1 million, or 13 cents a share, in the third quarter, which compares with net income of $1.8 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year ago period. Comparable store sales rose 4% and total sales rose 9% to $177.8 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected Cato to earn 12 cents a share, on average. Esco Technologies quarterly earnings fall 16% (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Esco Techologies ESE, +1.47% a provider of engineered filtration products, reported net income of $10.2 million, or 39 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter, compared with $12.1 million, or 45 cents a share, reported a year ago. The company expects to earn $1.15 to $1.30 a share in fiscal 2006 -- between 35 cents and 40 cents a share in the first half on sales of $195 million and between 80 cents and 90 cents a share in the second half on sales of $225 million. The company said it would begin to expense stock options in 2006, which is expected to amount to about 3 cents a share per quarter. RBC Bearings swings to a loss (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- RBC Bearings ROLL, +2.15% on Tuesday reported a second-quarter net loss of $2 million or 18 cents a share, compared to net income of $1.7 million, or 8 cents a share in the year-ago period. Sales rose to $65.4 million from $56.4 million. Operating income fell to $5.1 million from $7.4 million. Adjusted operating income rose 39% to $10.4 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 20 cents a share. The company forecast third-quarter operating income of $9.8 million to $10.1 million. Shares of RBC Bearings rose 4 cents to $16.04 on Monday. Illinois Tool Works revenue rises, outlook affirmed (8:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Illinois Tool Works Inc. ITW, +1.82% said Tuesday that revenue grew 9% in the three months that ended Oct. 31, with 5% coming from operations, 3% from acquisitions and 1% from currency translations. The Glenview, Ill.-based toolmaker affirmed its fourth quarter net income forecast of $1.34 to $1.40 a share and its 2005 forecast of $5.12 to $5.18 a share. The shares fell 18 cents Monday to $85.82. ArvinMeritor posts narrower loss (8:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ArvinMeritor Inc. ARM, +3.57% on Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $19 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to a loss of $153 million, or $2.23 a share in the year-ago period. Earnings from continuing operations fell to 17 cents a share from 44 cents a share. Excluding items, operating income was $29 million, or 41 cents a share. Sales rose 6% to $2.1 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 42 cents a share and revenue of $2.15 billion. The company's fiscal year 2006 forecast for light vehicle production is 15.6 million vehicles in North America and 16.4 million vehicles in Western Europe, with 2006 earnings seen at $1.50-$1.70 a share, compared to the analyst forecast of $1.58 a share. Shares rose 60 cents to $17.28 on Monday. J.C. Penney tops Wall St. 3Q earns view; sees in-line 4Q (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- J.C. Penney Co. JCP, -0.98% Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $234 million, or 94 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $148 million, or 50 cents a share. The Plano, Texas-based department store operator attributed the better results to an improved operating performance, lower interest expense, and the positive impact of its ongoing buyback program. Total sales rose 2% in the three months ended Oct. 29 to $4.48 billion from $4.39 billion in the same period a year earlier, while same-store sales increased 2.5%. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 92 cents a share in the October period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnnigs of continuing operations of $1.58 a share for the fourth quarter, in line with Wall Street's current consensus estimate. The stock closed Monday at $53.75, down 1.8%. J.C. Penney tops Wall St. 3Q earns view; sees in-line 4Q (8:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- J.C. Penny Co. JCP, -0.98% Tuesday reported third-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $234 million, or 94 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $148 million, or 50 cents a share. The Plano, Texas-based department store operator attributed the better results to an improved operating performance, lower interest expense, and the positive impact of its ongoing buyback program. Total sales rose 2% in the three months ended Oct. 29 to $4.48 billion from $4.39 billion in the same period a year earlier, while same-store sales increased 2.5%. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 92 cents a share in the October period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of continuing operations of $1.58 a share for the fourth quarter, in line with Wall Street's current consensus estimate. The stock closed Monday at $53.75, down 1.8%. SunPower fattens IPO proceeds by 31% (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- SunPower, a Sunnyvale, Calif. maker of solar energy technology, on Tuesday upped the estimated price range of its upcoming initial public offering to $16-$18 a share, from the earlier level of $12-$14 a share. SunPower kept the size of the deal at 7.7 million shares. Based on the midpoint of its new range, SunPower will raise $131 million, up from earlier proceeds of $100 million. It's the second big price hike of an upcoming IPO this week after InternationalExchange on Monday. Cypress Semiconductor CY, +2.05% owns 100% of SunPower, according to its prospectus. The IPO is expected to debut within the coming week, with plans to trade under the ticker symbol "SPWR." American Eagle profit soars; sets cautious view (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- American Eagle Outfitters Inc. AEOS said Tuesday that third-quarter net income rose to $73.3 million, or 47 cents a share, from $57.9 million, or 38 cents, a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 46 cents a share. Sales for the three months ended Oct. 29 advanced to $577.7 million from $479.6 million in last year's third quarter. Same-store sales, or sales from stores open at least a year, increased 14%, the Warrendale, Pa., specialty apparel retailer said. For the fourth quarter, American Eagle set an earnings target of 73 to 75 cents a share. Analysts' average estimate stands at 76 cents. The company's stock closd Monday at $24.35, down $1.12, or 4.4% AmerisourceBergen doubles dividend, sets 2-for-1 split (7:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% on Tuesday set plans for a 2-for-1 stock split. The Valley Forge, Pa. pharmaceutical services company said it would double its dividend to 5 cents a share from 2.5 cents a share. The new shares will be distributed Dec. 28 to stockholders of record at the close of business on Dec. 13. The company also reiterated its 2006 forecast of $3.95-$4.25 a share in net income, or $1.98-$2.13 a share on a post-split basis. Expectations include a charge of 9 cents a share -- or 4.5 cents a share, post-split -- for equity compensation expense and the anticipation that litigation recovery gains will be offset by facility consolidation and employee severance expense. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of $4.09 a share. AmerisourceBergen Corp. shares fell 24 cents to $76.74 on Monday. Dick's Sporting Goods swings to a third-quarter profit (7:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dick's Sporting Goods Inc. DKS, +2.10% posted Tuesday third-quarter net income of $4.2 million, or 8 cents a share compared to a loss of $2 million, or 4 cents a share. Excluding merger integration and store closing costs, the Pittsburgh, Pa-based retailer would have earned $4.2 million, or 8 cents a share. Sales for the quarter rose 8% to $582.7 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate is for earnings of 7 cents a share on sales of $586.4 million. Same-store sales for the quarter rose 2.9% over year-ago levels. Looking ahead, Dick's Sporting Goods is forecasting fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 95 cents to a $1 per share. Same-store sales are expected to increase 1% to 2%. The First Call average estimate is for quarterly earnings of 96 cents a share. The company re-affirmed its 2005 outlook of earnings between $1.70 and $1.75 a share. The First Call average estimate is for full-year earnings of $1.71 a share. On Monday, the stock fell 54 cents at $30.75. Rock-Tenn adjusted earnings 14 cents vs. 18 cents (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Rock-Tenn Co. RKT said Tuesday that earnings from continuing operations in its fourth quarter were $4.9 million, or 14 cents a share, compared to $6.6 million, or 18 cents, in the same period a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for 27 cents a share. Results were lower due to costs of operations at plants being closed and Sarbanes-Oxley implementation. Net sales were $528.6 million compared to $417.9 million in the fourth quarter of 2004. Shares in the packaging company rose 14 cents Monday to $13.91. Prestige Brands profit off, firm to restate '03-'05 results (7:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Prestige Brands Holdings, Inc. PBH, -1.98% said Tuesday it earned $7.4 million or 15 cents a share in the second fiscal quarter of 2006, compared to net income of $9.9 million or 23 cents a share a year ago. Net sales for the quarter ended September 30, 2005, were $73.3 million, compared to net sales of $80.0 million for the prior year quarter. The company also said it's revising financial reports for the years 2003 through 2005 and has deferred its quarterly filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. BJ's Wholesale net income up 20% (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- BJ's Wholesale Club Inc. BJ on Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $27.8 million, or 41 cents a share, up 20% from $23.2 million, or 33 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue climbed 9.3% to $1.96 billion and same-store sales rose 4.1%. Adjusted net income in the latest quarter was 38 cents a share. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 36 cents a share and revenue of $1.94 billion. The Natick, Mass. retailer forecast 2005 adjusted earnings of $1.85-$1.89 a share as it trimmed the top end of the range from its earlier projection of $1.85-$1.91 a share. Wall Street is expecting earnings of $1.86 a share. BJ's stock closed at $27.82 on Monday. Staples meets earnings estimates; revenue beats (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Staples Inc. SPLS said it earned $238 million, or 32 cents a share, in the third quarter, up from 28 cents a year ago, matching the average forecast of Thomson First Call analysts. The office products retailer said sales grew 11% to $4.25 billion, just above the $4.22 billion forecast of First Call analysts. Same-store sales climbed 3%, while North American retail sales rose 9%. Staples said it now expects to match fourth-quarter analyst estimates, with sales rising about 10%. For 2006, the company expects revenue to grow in the low double digits, and earnings to grow by 15% to 20%, including an adjustment for stock option expense. Shares closed Monday up 11 cents at $23.86. MAIR Holdings swings to 2nd-period loss on Northwest charge (6:46 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- MAIR Holdings Inc., MAIR the Minneapolis parent of Mesaba Airlines, reported that it swung to a second-quarter loss from a year-earlier profit largely because of charges related to the recent bankruptcy filing of Northwest Airlines Inc. NWBBQ Mesaba and Northwest are partners under an airline-service agreement. MAIR's loss was $25.5 million, or $1.24 a share, for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with net income of $4.7 million, or 23 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue rose 0.6% to $114.9 million from $114.2 million. MAIR shares rose 4 cents to $5.11 on Monday. Home Depot raises profit outlook as 3Q earnings gain 16.8% (6:11 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Home Depot Inc. HD, +1.99% reported net income of $1.54 billion, or 72 cents a share, in the third quarter ended Oct. 30, up from $1.32 billion, or 60 cents, earned in the same period a year earlier. Sales rose 10.5%, reaching $20.74 billion, as comparable-store sales advanced 3.6%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for the home-improvement retailer to earn 68 cents a share on revenue of $20.7 billion. Operating margin widened to 11.9%, as the company's average ticket rose to $58.92. In addition, Home Depot revised higher projected growth range for full-year sales to 10% to 12%, up from 9% to 12% previously, and increased its growth target for earnings per share to 17% to 18% from a range of 14% to 17%. Shares of Home Depot, a Dow Jones Industrial Average component, ended Monday at $42.57, up 66 cents, or 1.6%. Burberry profit lower on increased discounts, investments (2:48 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Burberry Group(UK:BRBY), the luxury products group known for its check patterns, said first-half attributable profit fell 3% to 53.1 million pounds, with comparable revenue up 3% and reported sales up 2% to 355 million pounds. Increased end of season sales and investment on its Project Atlas infrastructure redesign program weighed on results, Burberry said. Outgoing CEO Rose Marie Bravo said the group had "cautious optimism" with cold weather arriving and holidays approaching, though it foresees a moderate underlying decline in wholesale sales for the second half of the year. Burberry added that 65% owner Gus(UK:GUS)will give concrete details of its plan to demerge Burberry later this week, and added that COO Brian Blake is resigning for "family reasons." Northern Foods swings to first-half profit (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British food manufacturing and distribution group Northern Foods PLC(UK:NFDS)on Tuesday said it swung to a first-half net profit of 14.4 million pounds ($25 million). In the same period a year ago, the company posted a loss of 7.9 million pounds. Sales from continuing operations rose 2.8% to 700 million pounds. The group also lifted its dividend by 1.5% to 3.40 pence a share. Looking ahead, Northern Foods said it expects the recent period of price deflation to end due to rising input costs, particularly for energy. Diageo says on track for FY view, though first half may lag (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Drinks group Diageo PLC DEO, +0.23% (UK:DGE)said ahead of an investor presentation that it's on track to meet fiscal year to June guidance, though the first-half result may not be as strong. Its comparable operating profit will be similar to a year ago amid higher marketing spend and higher pension costs, as global priority brands Smirnoff, Johnnie Walker and Captain Morgan are growing strongly, though Guinness has seen weakness in Europe. The hurricanes have impacted its performance in the U.S., though Diageo is unsure whether it will make up for the downturn in the second half from restocking. It's confident of a tax rate well below 20% for 2006, though it's still negotiating agreements with tax authorities over brand carrying values. Vodafone first-half profit drops; hikes interim dividend (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British mobile operator Vodafone Group PLC(UK:VOD) VOD, +0.54% on Tuesday hiked its interim dividend by 15% to 2.20 pence a share as it reported first-half net profit down 23.5% to 2.82 billion pounds, or 4.36 pence a share, due to an impairment charge of 500 million pounds. Sales for the period rose 9% to 18.25 billion pounds, topping analysts' expectations, as Vodafone added 10 million new subscribers, bringing its total customer base to 171 million. Looking ahead, the group said it sees fiscal-year sales in the middle of the 6% to 9% range previously indicated. For 2007, Vodafone said it expects strong revenue growth from third-generation enabled data products and a lower rate of mobile revenue growth compared to 2006 due to higher levels of mobile penetration and a greater impact from termination rates. Bid target Skandia third-quarter profit soars (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swedish insurer Skandia(SE:000011309)reported a 69% increase in third-quarter pre-tax profit to SEK398 million ($49 million), with revenue up 16% to SEK4.24 billion. The insurer, subject to a takeover bid from Old Mutual(UK:OML), attributed the rise to a strong inflows and a 41% rise in funds under management, with expense growth limited to 12%. Its operating result by embedded value soared to SEK2.28 billion from SEK655 million, as strong equity markets lifted unit-linked assurance profitability. "Our excellent result performance further strengthens our conviction that Skandia as a standalone company is a very attractive investment proposition for our shareholders, and one that is set to continue to outperform its peers in delivering strong growth in its business results," said CEO Hans-Erik Andersson. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr after Tuesday's closing bell said it will restate its first- and second-quarter results to correct its accounting for legal fees and other professional expenses. The correction will shift the expenses among the first three quarters of 2005, with expenses expected to increase in the first quarter and decrease in the second. There will also be a corresponding decrease/increase in net income. As well, Taser expects the restatements will cut its third-quarter expenses to $6.9 million from a previously reported $7 million, sending its net income higher by $60,000 to $300,000.
title: Taser Int'l to restate 1Q, 2Q results, revise 3Q results

content: CORRECT: Placer Dome quarterly profit falls 77% (9:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Placer Dome Inc. PDG after Wednesday's closing bell reported third-quarter net earnings of $34 million, or 8 cents a share, down 77% from $148 million, or 36 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Vancouver, British Columbia-based mining company rose to $488 million from $453 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated revenue at $505 million. For 2005, the company expects to produce 3.6 million ounces of gold and 370 million pounds of copper. (Corrects that revenue rose from a year ago.) Furniture Brands quarterly earnings sink; revenue falls (8:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Furniture Brand International Inc. FBN late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $9.92 million, or 19 cents a share, vs. $19.4 million, or 36 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The company posted revenue of $557.9 million vs. $574.8 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share on revenue of $558 million. Looking ahead, the company said it sees fourth-quarter revenue off single-digits vs. the year-ago period and earnings of 19 cents to 23 cents a share. Duke Realty qrtrly profit soars; declares $1.05 special div (8:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Duke Realty Corp. DRE late Wednesday's reported third-quarter net earnings of $234.1 million, or $1.48 a share, vs. $46.7 million, or 30 cents a share, last year. Funds from operations were 61 cents a share compared with 62 cents a share a year ago. Revenue from continuing operations totaled $199.9 million, up from $181.2 million last year. The Indianapolis-based company also declared a one-time special dividend of $1.05 a share and said it repurchased $95.2 million of its shares during the quarter. For the fourth quarter, Duke sees FFO per share in a range of 58 cents to 60 cents, which equates to $2.37 to $2.39 a share for 2005. For 2006 the company forecast FFO in a range of $2.32 to $2.45 a share. Lattice Semiconductor quarterly loss widens (7:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lattice Semiconductor Corp. LSCC late Wednesday reported a third-quarter net loss of $7.09 million, or 6 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $6.32 million, or 6 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The pro forma loss was 3 cents a share for the quarter. The Hillsboro, Ore.-based company posted revenue of $53.4 million vs. $57.3 million. Lattice Semiconductor said it expects fourth-quarter revenue to be up 1% to 3% sequentially, and for its gross margin to be flat during the period. AsiaInfo quarterly profit drops; sets 4Q, 2005 view (7:22 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AsiaInfo Inc. ASIA late Wednesday reported third-quarter net earnings of $427,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with $5 million, or 11 cents a share, last year. Revenue was $25.2 million vs. $20 million a year ago. The software maker and services provider expects fourth-quarter revenue of $18 million to $20 million, or a decrease of 13% to 22% from the year-ago period. S&P said the actions follow Sovereign's plan to acquire Independence Community Bank and to sell a stake in its company to Madrid-based Grupo Santander for $2.4 billion. The actions "The ratings actions consider the foothold the acquisition of ICBC provides Sovereign in the desirable New York/New Jersey marketplace," said S&P credit analyst John Bartko in a statement. "The ratings actions also recognize the strain on Sovereign's already aggressive capital profile, as tangible measures are projected to fall immediately following the close of the deal." S&P said while the ICBC deal represents a sizable acquisition for Sovereign and incorporates a degree of integration risk, Sovereign maintains an "enviable record of acquisition integration over the years, which provides some comfort."
