Praxair also projected 2005 earnings, excluding the third-quarter tax charge, of $2.44 to $2.48 a share; Wall Street's average stands at $2.44. Praxair said it's projecting sales and operating-profit growth of 15% to 16% for 2005. Shares of Praxair added 24 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $47.84. PepsiAmericas 3Q profit slips, sales rise (6:11 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Softdrink bottler PepsiAmericas, Inc. PAS said third-quarter net profit fell to $63.7 million, or 47 cents a share, from $64.8 million, or 46 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The results in last year's quarter included a 4 cent-per-share tax gain. Revenue rose 11% to $982.9 million. Looking ahead, PepsiAmericas reiterated its outlook for full-year earnings in the range of $1.39 to $1.42 a share. Smith International 3Q profit, sales rise (5:14 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Smith International, Inc. SII a supplier of products to the oil and gas industry, on Wednesday said third-quarter net income rose 53% to $79.5 million, or 39 cents a share. Excluding one-time items, the company would have earned $77 million, or 38 cents a share. Revenue for the period increased 17% to $1.41 billion. Egg posts 3Q profit, looks forward to Prudential cooperation (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Internet bank Egg PLC(UK:EGG)Wednesday said it swung to a third-quarter profit of 11.1 million pounds. In the same period a year ago, the company posted a loss of 101 million pounds. Net interest income rose 21% to 84.7 million pounds. Operating profit climbed 33% to 17.9 million pounds, a "solid performance", the bank said. Egg also said it looks forward to working more closely with Prudential PLC(UK:PRU), which owns most of its shares. "Clearly, there are exciting opportunities provided by our complementary customer bases, brands and product offerings for the further benefit of both our customers and shareholders," said Egg Chief Executive Paul Gratton. Air Liquide 3Q sales rise, reiterates outlook (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French industrial gas company Air Liquide(FR:012007)on Wednesday said third-quarter sales rose 8.9% to 2.566 billion euros ($4.58 billion), with comparable sales up 5.9%. The company said Asia remains dynamic, with a pick up in Japan, and Europe is led by innovative products and services. Comparable sales for the period rose 8.3% in Asia Pacific to 412 million euros and 3.3% in Europe, to 1.168 million euros. Looking ahead, Air Liquide reiterated its objective of double-digit net income growth in 2005. Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Shares of Acacia Research Corp. CBMX, +0.00% rocketed to end Wednesday's session higher by 62.3% after its CombiMatrix Group unit said it's launched an influenza DNA microarray. The company said the microarray can identify the H5N1 bird flu as well as all other strains of influenza A. In addition, the microarray can provide information on mutations and novel strains of flu not yet seen, Acacia said. Agere Systems AGR, +0.73% shares gained 11.7% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $7 million, or 4 cents a share, vs. a loss of $127 million, or 74 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding items, earnings would have been 21 cents a share. Revenue fell to $416 million from last year's $439 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 10 cents a share and revenue of $433.3 million. The semiconductor maker said it expects fiscal first-quarter adjusted earnings of 3 to 9 cents a share and revenue of $390 million to $410 million, vs. analyst forecasts for earnings of 12 cents a share and revenue of $425.9 million. Separately, the company said its chief executive, John Dickson, will retire. He will be replaced, effective immediately, by Richard Clemmer. In addition, Agere authorized a $200 million stock repurchase program. Anteon International Corp. ANT, +3.36% shares tacked on 5.1% after the company said third-quarter earnings rose 24% to $21 million, or 55 cents a share, versus $16.8 million, or 45 cents a share in the year-ago period. The average of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for 51 cents a share. Revenues grew 17% to $382.1 million and the company said it expects fourth-quarter revenue to come in between $385 million and $400 million. Atmel Corp. ATML stock ended with a 7.1% gain after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $1.1 million, or breakeven on a per-share basis, narrower than its loss of $18 million, or 4 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $418.6 million, up from $413.2 million. Shares of Automatic Data Processing ADP, +1.54% added 5.6% after the company said net income rose $220 million, or 38 cents a share, from $208.2 million, or 35 cents, a year earlier. The Roseland, N.J., company said revenue rose to $2.04 billion from $1.85 million. The average earnings estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 35 cents a share. AVX Corp. AVX, +1.04% shares rose 5% after the firm reported second-quarter earnings of $17 million, or 10 cents a share, down from $18.6 million, or 11 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell $330 million from $325.9 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $323.5 million, on average. Chubb Corp. CB, -1.08% shares closed higher by 6.5% after the company said it's forming a $1.5 billion reinsurer called Harbor Point and will stop underwriting reinsurance after transferring its business to the new Bermuda-based firm. See full story. Shares of Crane Co. CR, +2.29% tacked on 6.1% after the company posted a third-quarter profit and higher sales as its aerospace and fluid-handling businesses strengthened. See full story. F5 Networks Inc. FFIV, +1.40% shares shot higher by 23.5% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $15.7 million, or 39 cents a share, vs. $15.8 million, or 43 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. Pro forma earnings were 47 cents a share for the quarter. The Seattle-based provider of application delivery networking posted revenue of $80.6 million vs. $50.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast fourth-quarter revenue of $77 million. Firstservice Corp. FSRV stock rose 7.7% after the firm reported fiscal second-quarter adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $14.1 million, or 45 cents a share, up from a year-ago equivalent profit of $9.7 million, or 32 cents a share. Revenue jumped 75% in the latest three months to $316.2 million from $180.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 43 cents a share in the September period. Looking ahead, the Toronto-based provider of real estate and security services sees adjusted earnings from continuing operations of $1.08 to $1.16 a share for the year ending in March on revenue of between $1.13 billion and $$1.18 billion. InfoSpace Inc. INSP, -20.00% shares soared 13.5% after the company reported a jump in third-quarter revenue and offered a forecast for the current quarter that blew away analysts' expectations. See full story. Shares of Jones Apparel Group JNY gained 5.2% after the company said third-quarter net income fell to $76.8 million, or 65 cents a share compared to $95.8 million, or 77 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 76 cents a share and the average of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for adjusted earnings of 66 cents a share in the period. Revenue inched ahead to $1.31 billion. Results included the consolidation of the company's Mexican denim manufacturing operations and related expenses. See full story. PerkinElmer PKI, +1.14% stock ended the session higher by 7.6% after the company reported a 33% gain in third-quarter profit that beat forecasts. The company also said it would buy back some of its senior notes. See full story. Ryder System R, +2.28% shares added 9.2% after the company reported net income of $63.3 million, or 98 cents a share, compared with $54.3 million, or 83 cents a share in the third quarter of 2004. Revenue at the fleet management company rose 14% in the three months to Sept. 30 to $1.49 billion from $1.31 billion. The average estimate from analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 93 cents a share and sales of $1.42 billion. Ryder said fourth-quarter earnings would be 89 cents to 94 cents a share and 2005 earnings would be $3.49 to $3.54 a share, up from a previous range of $3.42 to $3.52 a share. See full story. Shares of Select Comfort Corp. SCSS surged 10.8% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $11.4 million, or 30 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $8 million, or 20 cents a share. Sales leapt 22% in the latest three months to $175.8 million from $144.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 27 cents a share in the September period. Looking ahead, the Minneapolis-based bed retailer narrowed its outlook for 2005 to earnings of $1.05 to $1.08 a share from $1 to $1.08 a share, and said it expects to sustain its long-term earnings growth expectations of at least 20% to 25% in 2006. Sento Corp. SNTO stock rocketed higher by 32.3% after the firm reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of $310,061, or 8 cents a share, up from a year-ago loss of $554,889, or 15 cents a share. Excluding a gain related to the partial recovery of a bad debt, the company earned $128,468, or 3 cents a share, in the latest quarter. Revenue surged roughly 60% in the latest three months to $9.9 million from $6.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate of the company's results. Looking ahead, the Salt Lake City provider of customer contact software applications sees sequential growth in the third quarter. Stillwater Mining SWC, +0.39% shares gained 10% after the company was upgraded to overweight by J.P. Morgan. Thoratec Corp. THOR shares tacked on 7% after the company offered an upbeat outlook in the wake of quarterly results that beat analyst expectations. The Pleasanton, Calif. company posted third-quarter net income $3.1 million, or 6 cents a share versus a loss of $398,000, or a penny a share in the year-ago quarter. Excluding exceptional items, the company would have earned $5.5 million, or 11 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose 22% to $48.8 million, driven by a 31% increase in sales of its Ventricular Assist Devices. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 7 cents a share on revenue of $46.7 million. Decliners Agco Corp. AG, +1.50% shares ended the session down 10.7% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $27.8 million, or 31 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $34.8 million, or 36 cents a share. Sales rose slightly to $1.23 billion from $1.22 billion in the third quarter of 2004. The average estimate from analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 33 cents a share and sales of $1.25 billion. Dry weather in North America and poor sales in South America and Western Europe will lower fourth-quarter earnings, Agco said. Shares of AirNet Systems ANS, -4.23% plunged 15.5% after the company entered into a letter of intent to sell the aviation-services company to what it called "a nationally recognized private-equity investment firm." The deal contemplates a going-private transaction valued at $4.55 per AirNet share. The price of AirNet's stock closed Tuesday's trading at $5.15 a share, up 6 cents. The company noted that the buyout price translates into a premium of about 32% over the stock's price as of the start of trading on Jan. 5, when AirNet's board hired Brown Gibbons Lang & Co. to consider strategic alternatives aimed at enhancing shareholder value. The suitor has the exclusive right to negotiate a definitive deal with AirNet until Nov. 30, a deadline that can be extended until no later than Dec. 15 by mutual consent. Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, +1.11% shares closed down 13.9% after the online retailer said third-quarter net income fell 44% as the online retailer paid a large legal settlement and expenses rose faster than sales due in part to a low-priced-delivery promotion. The company also gave a sales outlook for the fourth quarter that disappointed Wall Street. See full story. Shares of Blockbuster BBI, +4.00% sank 15.9% after the company confirmed that it has met with its lender group to talk about modifications to its credit agreement that would give the in-home movie and game entertainment company improved operating flexibility over the term of the original credit agreement. As part of the modifications, Blockbuster said it will work to raise additional capital that will be used for working capital purposes, including cutting debt. Shares of Dixie Group Inc. DXYN, -1.79% shed 7.1% after the company said its third-quarter net income fell to $1.2 million, or 9 cents a share, from $3.5 million, or 29 cents, a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations came to 10 cents a share. On that basis, two analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings, on average, of 19 cents. Sales for the three months ended Sept. 24 increased to $76.7 million form $74.1 million in last year's third quarter. Doral Financial Corp. DRL, +0.00% stock plummeted 20.4% after the company said the Securities and Exchange Commission has issued a formal order of investigation in connection with the company's restatement of its consolidated financial statements. Doral also lowered its quarterly dividend by 55.6% to 8 cents from 18 cents a share. The Puerto Rico-based financial services company said it has received a subpoena from the SEC seeking the production of documents principally regarding the restatement and the terms of certain transactions with local financial institutions. The company said it continues to cooperate with the SEC. Additionally, Doral said it no longer expects to file its amended Form 10-K for the year ended Dec. 31, 2004, by Nov. 10. The delay is principally due to new information regarding Doral's mortgage loan sales to local financial institutions. See full story. Estee Lauder Cos. EL, +2.53% shares fell 7.7% after the company reported first-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $61.8 million, or 28 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $95.7 million, or 41 cents a share. Sales totaled $1.5 billion in the latest three months, slightly higher than $1.49 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 32 cents a share on revenue of $1.54 billion. The New York cosmetics company also said it's accelerating some of its restructuring activities by classifying its Stila brand as a discontinued operation while it seeks a sale of the asset, and streamlining process and organizational changes. See full story. Flextronics International Ltd. FLEX, +0.12% stock slumped 24% after the firm posted a quarterly loss and lowered its financial forecast. See full story. Shares of Gander Mountain Co. GMTN plunged 38.8% after the company said it no longer expects to meet its fiscal 2005 forecast for revenue of at least $850 million, flat same-store sales and pretax income of at least $16 million. The outdoor lifestyle retailer attributed the weak sales to uncertainty about the economy, including the impact of higher energy prices, and the persistently warm weather across much of the country. St. Paul, Minn.-based Gander Mountain said it expects a 9% to 10% decline in same-store sales. GSI Commerce GSIC stock gave back 13.6% after the company postponed the release of its third-quarter operating results as it evaluates certain accounting issues. The King of Prussia, Pa., provider of e-commerce technology said it's found potential discrepancies with certain credits recorded as part of its results in the fourth quarter of 2004, and it's determined that the systemic control over its accounts payable balance has failed. GSI provided a preliminary outlook for the third quarter, forecasting a loss of 10 cents a share, or $4.2 million to $4.5 million, on revenue of between $84 million and $85 million. The company's prior forecast was for a loss of $2.5 million to $3 million in the period. GSI attributed the wider than anticipated loss to cost overruns with partner launches and delays in the actual launch dates. The company expects these same issues to impact its fourth-quarter performance. Lucent Technologies LU shares finished lower by 5.8% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $374 million, or 8 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $1.21 billion, or 23 cents a share. The latest results include gains totaling $127 million, or 2 cents a share, from tax and other items. The year-ago performance included a gain of $1 billion, or 19 cents a share, primarily from an income tax benefit. Sales rose 1% in the latest three months to $2.43 billion from $2.4 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 5 cents a share in the September period on sales of $2.46 billion. See full story. MGM Mirage MGM, +2.70% shares sank 13.6% after the company posted lower quarterly earnings, impacted by the summer's barrage of hurricanes that prompted widespread casino closures. MGM said it earned $93.2 million, or 31 cents a share, in the third quarter vs. $126.8 million, or 45 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue jumped to $1.969 billion from $1.145 billion, mainly reflecting the added gains as a result of the company's acquisition of the Mandalay Resort Group. Stripping out one-time items and discontinued operations, the company said it would have earned 38 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected that figure to be 41 cents a share. See full story. Microtune TUNE, +0.90% stock plummeted 17.9% after the firm said its results for the next two quarters would be hurt by an excess inventory situation. Saying there appears to be "a considerable amount of excess cable modem inventory" at one or more of its customers, the Plano, Texas-based maker of broadband tuning and information delivery products forecast revenue of between $14.5 million and $15 million for the fourth quarter, below the current Wall Street consensus estimate of $17.5 million. Shares of P F Chang's China Bistro PFCB gave back 11.8% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $8.45 million, or 31 cents a share, up 3% from $8.17 million, or 31 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $203 million from $174 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 31 cents a share and revenue of $203.4 million. The restaurant chain cut its fourth-quarter earnings forecast to 33 cents a share from 38 cents a share, below the Wall Street target of 37 cents. The company said CFO Kristina Cashman plans to step down and that it's looking for a replacement. RF Micro Devices RFMD stock fell 7.5% after the company reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $5.9 million, or 3 cents a share. Last year, it lost $6.7 million, or 4 cents a share. On a pro forma basis, the company posted earnings of $8.7 million, or 4 cents a share. Revenue for the period rose to $177 million from $149.1 million a year ago. Shares of Taser International TASR lost 6.3% after the company posted earnings of $270,945, or breakeven on a per-share basis, for the third quarter, down from a year-ago profit of $6.1 million, or 9 cents a share. Sales fell in the latest three months to $11.7 million from $19 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of a penny a share from the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker in the September period on revenue of $13.2 million. Yankee Candle YCC, +0.32% shares ended down 9.9% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $15.4 million, or 35 cents a share, as opposed to $15.8 million, or 33 cents, earned in the same period last year. The retailer's quarterly sales reached $136.5 million from $127.9 million a year earlier, with comparable-store sales off 4% excluding Yankee Candle's mail-order hub. Analysts were looking for earnings of 37 cents a share on revenue of $138 million, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. There were about 8.5% fewer weighted average common shares outstanding in the latest quarter compared to the prior year. Yankee Candle also projected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.04 to $1.07 a share, which would yield a full-year profit of $1.77 to $1.81. Wall Street's looking for earnings of $1.17 and $1.89 a share, respectively. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - U.S. stocks closed lower Wednesday, after an attempt at a rally was thwarted by worries over higher borrowing costs and disappointing earnings from Boeing Co., Amazon and Anheuser-Busch Cos. The Dow Jones Industrials Average DJIA, +1.07% ended down 32.89 points at 10,344.98, after flitting back and forth between positive and negative territory many times. However, Dow components Alcoa AA, +1.22% DuPont DD, +2.74% and American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% locked in solid gains. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% and the Nasdaq Composite $COMPX closed down 5.16 points at 1,191.38 and down 9.40 points at 2,100.05 after unsteady performances. There were more than 1.82 billion shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange, where falling shares outweighed rising stocks by 21 to 10. Volume in the Nasdaq market was over 1.84 billion stocks; decliners outweighed advancing shares by 17 to 11. Trade was uneven with frequent shifts of direction as every attempt at a rally was met with resistance Tuesday. "We are still trying to bottom out, but we need a good catalyst," said Donald Selkin, director of equity research at Joseph Stevens. However, he said investors were kept in a negative frame of mind owing to sharp gains in interest rates -- jumps in both long and short-term bond yields that have followed the White House's nomination of Ben Bernanke to replace Alan Greenspan at the Fed - as well as weak earnings. Barry Hyman, equity market strategist at Ehrenkrantz, King & Nussbaum described Wednesday's market as "trading stock by stock and sector by sector." The stock-price volatility is making investors anxious, but Hyman said he is optimistic that the market is poised for an upswing. Many analysts expect the market to start a rally soon because they think disappointment over third-quarter reports, along with some weak outlooks, have taken too much of a chunk out of stock prices in October. Jeff Kleintop, chief investment strategist at PNC Advisors, said possible catalysts for a late-year market rally include S&P 500 component companies posting double-digit earnings growth for the third quarter and guiding to mid-teens growth for the fourth quarter. Kleintop also noted a large mound of surplus corporate cash "that is fueling a wave of buybacks, dividend increases, and mergers and acquisitions" as a possible catalyst. Bond yields soar, energy prices fall However, all eyes Wednesday were on climbing rates. The Treasury market was under pressure due to investor belief that Ben Bernanke, the White House nominee to replace Alan Greenspan at the Federal Reserve, will continue Greenspan's program of rate increases, Hyman said. See full story. The falling prices pushed the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note to a seven-month high of 4.592%. Earlier price declines lifted yields on 2-year notes to their highest since May 2001. The Energy Department reported that motor gasoline stocks were up 200,000 barrels at 195.9 million barrels in the latest week, below expectations. Crude inventories rose for a third consecutive week and distillate supplies fell 1.6 million barrels to 121.1 million, the department said. Crude futures were higher after the inventories data, but later dropped. They lost nearly 3% to close at $60.66 a barrel. See full story. The dollar recovered from a selloff earlier in the week and last was up 0.8% at 115.83 yen as the euro fell 0.04% to $1.2068. See full story. Gold for December delivery fell from recent highs to close down $1.70 at $473 an ounce. Recent indications of rising inflation have made gold attractive, Hyman said. Copper futures in morning trade tapped a new record, with the December contract rising almost 1% to $1.845 a pound. The contract later closed down 65 cents at $1.818 a pound. See full story. Stocks on the move Dow component Boeing BA, +2.46% closed down 2.7% at $65.10. The aerospace company reported higher third-quarter earnings, but its sales fell 4% due largely to a strike. See full story. Amazon AMZN, +1.11% took a drubbing, falling almost 14% to $39.71. The online retailer's earnings dropped 44% and its fourth-quarter sales forecast was below Wall Street expectations. Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% also in the Dow, shook off early losses and closed up 19 cents at $45.58. The New York Times reported that its executive vice president for benefits suggested in a memo that the retailer hire more part-time workers and discourage unhealthy people from working at its stores in an effort to rein in benefits costs. International Paper IP, +2.00% rose 2.4% to $28.68 after Citigroup upgraded the stock to buy from hold. Stun gun maker Taser International TASR fell about 7.6% to $6.45 after the company posted earnings of $270,945, or breakeven on a per share basis, for the third quarter. Analysts had projected earnings of 1 cent a share. Anheuser-Busch BUD, +0.28% fell 2.2% to $40.80. The brewery company's profit and domestic volume both slumped in the third quarter. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks close lower on worries over rising rates

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr shares fell almost 5% to $6.64 on Wednesday after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker posted earnings of $270,945, or breakeven on a per share basis, for the third quarter, down from a year-ago profit of $6.1 million, or 9 cents a share. Sales fell in the latest three months to $11.7 million from $19 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of a penny a share in the September period on revenue of $13.2 million.
title: Taser shares slump in wake of 3Q earnings report

content: Advancers American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% shares ended Monday higher by 5.1% after the company reported third-quarter net earnings of $1.03 billion, or 82 cents a share, compared with $879 million, or 69 cents a share, a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations before an accounting change came in at 69 cents a share. Revenue rose 11% to $6.07 billion from $5.48 billion a year ago. The period also included a provision of $49 million to cover costs associated with Hurricane Katrina. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of 68 cents a share on revenue of $7.46 billion. The company said third-quarter spending on American Express cards rose 18%, reflecting a double-digit rise in average card-member spending and the addition of 5.7 million cards during the last year. Shares of Ameriprise Financial AMP, +0.67% the advisory group spun off from American Express Co. AXP, +1.16% added 6.7% after the company said third-quarter net profit fell 38% to $125 million, or 50 cents a share, with revenue up 9% to $1.87 billion and adjusted earnings up 11% to $179 million. Adjusted earnings exclude discontinued operations, AMEX Assurance and separation costs. See full story. AMLI Residential Properties Trust AML, +6.52% stock shot up 20% after the firm said it's agreed to be acquired by Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% for about $2.1 billion in cash. AML is a Chicago-based real estate investment trust that manages and acquires multifamily communities in eight major metropolitan markets. The investment bank's Real Estate's Prime Property Fund announced the purchase in an all-cash deal valued at $37.75 a share. The price values the REIT at a premium of 21% to its closing price on Friday of $31.27 a share. See full story. Applica Inc. APN, +2.27% shares rocketed higher by 13.1% after the company said it now expects full-year 2006 net earnings of $7.7 million on sales of $580 million. The company also said it sees gross margins of 30.5% for the year. Arch Coal Inc. ACI, -0.18% stock gained 6.7% after the company said net income almost doubled over what it earned in the third quarter of 2004 on coal prices about 200% higher than they were at the beginning of the year. Arch Coal said its net income was $17.1 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with a profit of $9 million, or 16 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding special items, Arch Coal would have earned $19.9 million, or 31 cents a share. Analysts expected the coal producer to earn about 28 cents a share, according to a Thomson First Call poll. Shares of Arkansas Best Corp. ABFS jumped 13% after the firm said third-quarter net income rose 48% to $40.6 million, or $1.59 a share. Excluding a one-time gain of $9.8 million, or 38 cents a share, related to the sale of three facilities in California, the company would have earned $1.21 a share. Sales for the quarter rose 6.1% to $489.9 million, partly due to a combination of good pricing and consistent cost controls at the company's ABF Freight Systems subsidiary. Astec Industries ASTE, +1.23% shares rose 9.9% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $10 million, or 47 cents a share, up from $731,000, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding items, earnings were 30 cents a share. Sales rose to $149 million from $112 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 33 cents a share and revenue of $156.8 million. Barnes Group B, +1.78% shares gained 6.3% after the company posted third-quarter net profit up 80% to $17.4 million, or 70 cents a share. Earnings from continuing operations came in at 55 cents compared to 40 cents a share a year ago. Sales for the period climbed 11% to $271.5 million. Looking ahead, the distributor of gas springs, dampers and related products raised its 2005 EPS outlook to the range of $2.15 to $2.20. Biovail Corp. VRX, +2.65% stock rose 6.6% after the firm was upgraded at Merrill Lynch to buy from neutral. Shares of Carpenter Technology Corp. CRS, +2.15% surged 9.3% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $40.1 million, or $1.54 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $19.8 million, or 80 cents a share. Sales at the Wyomissing, Pa., specialty alloy company jumped to $346 million for the three-month period from $297.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.26 a share in the September period. Looking ahead, Carpenter sees free cash flow of more than $125 million for fiscal 2006. Ceradyne CRDN stock ended hugher by 8.1% after the company said it won a $47.8 million contract to provide body armor to the U.S. Army's unique missions division. The contract is part of a $461 million indefinite delivery and quantity order received in August 2004. Computer Sciences Corp. CSC, +3.70% stock closed higher by 11.2% after a published report that private-equity firms are actively looking at a buyout of the company, a mainstay of the computer-outsourcing industry with more than $14 billion in annual sales and an $8.4 billion market capitalization. The Wall Street Journal cited people familiar with the matter. Though takeover plans remain in the early stages of development, suitors include Texas Pacific Group, Warburg Pincus and Blackstone Group. Dresser-Rand Group DRC, -2.04% stock tacked on 12% after the firm was upgraded by UBS to buy from neutral ahead of its first quarterly report as a public company due in early November. Ethan Allen Interiors ETH, -1.08% shares rose 8% after the company said first-quarter net income declined to $17.1 million, or 49 cents a share from $18.8 million, or 51 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Excluding a charge, the company would have earned 57 cents a share on net income of $19.7 million. The results beat the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 54 cents a share. Net delivered sales for the period rose 9.1% to $251.3 million. Looking ahead, Chief Executive Farooq Kathwari said that while order trends remain encouraging, written business has slowed from the levels noted in the past three months. J2 Global Communications JCOM, +2.07% stock added 5.7% after the company posted third-quarter earnings before items of $12.5 million, or 49 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $8.1 million, or 32 cents a share. Revenue jumped 36% in the latest three months to $37.7 million from $27.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Including a gain on the sale of an investment, J2 Global earned $18.2 million, or 71 cents a share, in the three month period ended Sept. 30. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 48 cents a share in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, J2 Global sees earnings of 50 to 54 cents a share in the fourth quarter on revenue of between $39 million and $41 million. For fiscal 2006, it forecast earnings and revenue growth of 30%. Shares of On Track Innovations Ltd. OTIV, -2.48% gained 11.9% after the company forecast revenue of $24 million for the first nine months of 2005, an increase of 55% over the same period a year earlier. The Fort Lee, N.J., developer of smart card homeland security technology sees revenue of about $9.5 million for the third quarter, mainly due to growth in demand for its contactless payments products. On Track also said it now expects revenue will reach "low tens of millions of dollars per year starting in 2007" from its deal to produce inlays for travel documents for an undisclosed Asian government. Petmed Express PETS, -1.51% shares rose 11.6% after the firm posted second-quarter earnings of $2.7 million, or 11 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $1.8 million, or 8 cents a share. Sales rose 34% in the latest three months to $38.7 million from $28.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 10 cents a share in the September period. The the Pompano Beach, Fla., provider of pharmacy services for pets noted that it acquired 208,000 new customers in the quarter, up from 155,000 in the same period a year earlier. Pilgrim's Pride Corp. PPC, -1.16% stock tacked on 7% after the company lifted its fourth-quarter earnings outlook to a range of $1.07 to $1.12 a share, from a previous range of 90 cents to $1.00 a share. The company cited better results in both its U.S. and Mexico chicken operations. Plantronics PLT, +5.08% shares added 5.3% after the company was upgraded at Citigroup to hold from sell due to valuation. Rediff.com REDF stock soared 28% after the company reported earnings of $307,000, or 1.2 cents per American Depositary Share, for its fiscal second quarter, up from a year-ago loss of $381,000, or 1.5 cents per ADS. Revenue surged 44% in the latest three months to $4.4 million. The Mumbai, India-based provider of online news and shopping services said its registered users stood at 39.4 million as of Sept. 30, up 18% from the total at that time last year. Regeneration Technologies RTIX, +1.10% shares gained 6.1% after the company reported a loss of $1.6 million, or 6 cents a share, for the third quarter, on revenue of $22.5 million. The Alachua, Fla., maker of medical implant products said the latest results include a charge of 8 cents a share related to its recall of certain tissue products. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of a penny per share on revenue of $22.4 million. Shanda Interactive SNDA stock closed up 5.7% after the company launched a program in which it can buy back up to $50 million worth of its American Depositary Shares. The company said it would fund the program through available cash. At the end of September, there were 71.3 million ADSs outstanding. Shares of Silicon Laboratories SLAB, +2.39% jumped 21.1% after the company posted a third-quarter loss of $745,000, or 1 cent a share, compared with net income of $21 million, or 39 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding charges, the company earned $17.2 million, or 26 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call put earnings at 24 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter ended Oct. 1, rose to $103.9 million from $121 million. The average estimate of analysts had forecast third-quarter revenue at $101.6 million. Syneron Medical Ltd. ELOS shares added 7.3% after the company reported positive results of a study of its VelaSmooth system in the reduction of the appearance of cellulite. The company said the study, which was led by a pair of doctors with the Washington Institute of Dermatologic Laser Surgery, found that 90% of 20 participants "had an overall clinical improvement in the appearance of their cellulite" after treatment with VelaSmooth. Taser International TASR shares jumped 19.4% after the company was upgraded at Jefferies & Co. to buy. The firm said it thinks business from new customers could boost Taser's revenue if the company's able to expand its market share. Shares of Universal Forest Products' UFPI, +1.53% tacked on 6% after the company's board increased its semi-annual dividend 10% to 5.5 cents from 5 cents a share. The dividend is payable Dec. 15 to shareholders of record as of Dec. 1, said the Grand Rapids, Mich.-based wood and wood-alternative products manufacturer. Utah Medical Products' UTMD, -0.25% shares rose 12.5% after a federal district court confirmed the company is operating in compliance with the Food and Drug Administration's quality system regulations. The company said the court disagreed with all of the FDA's allegations and dismissed a lawsuit that sought to shut the company down. Decliners Shares of America Service Group ASGR, +0.00% ended the session down 28.1% after the company said its audit committee is investigating its Secure Pharmacy Plus unit over accruals and reserves and pricing of pharmaceuticals under client contracts. The Brentwood, Tenn., company said 2004 revenue from the Secure Pharmacy unit was $85.9 million. The company said the investigation won't be completed in time to meet the normal schedule of reporting quarterly earnings. The company also said its previous 2005 earnings estimate at between $1.43 and $1.50 a share doesn't reflect the investigation and "therefore should not be relied upon." America Service Group provides prison health-care services. Anadigics ANAD shares shed 9.7% after the company posted a loss of $6.8 million, or 20 cents a share, for the third quarter, narrower than a year-ago loss of $8.3 million, or 25 cents a share. Sales rose in the latest three months to $29.3 million from $25.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 21 cents a share in the quarter on sales of $28.6 million. Looking ahead, the Warren, N.J., supplier of wireless and broadband communications products forecast an improvement of 35% in its loss for the fourth quarter. Cendant Corp. CD, +0.00% stock gave back 6.6% after the company said it plans to split into four separate companies by 2006. Three of the businesses will be spun off to shareholders. See full story. Diagnostic Products Corp. DP shares fell 12.8% after the firm reported third-quarter net income of $17.1 million, or 56 cents a share, up 3.6% from $16.5 million or 55 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 7% to $116.3 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 64 cents a share and revenue of $122 million. First BanCorp FBP, +1.35% shares lost 8% after the company said the Securities and Exchange Commission has issued a formal order of investigation into the company. An informal SEC inquiry into First BanCorp was announced in August. The Santurce, P.R.-based company said the probe appears to relate to, among other things, transactions in which its First Bank unit acquired a substantial number of mortgage loans from other Puerto Rican financial institutions. First BanCorp said it is cooperating with the SEC's investigation. Graco GGG, +2.53% stock fell 9.2% after the company said its third-quarter net income rose 7% to $30.9 million, or 44 cents a share. A year ago, the supplier of fluid control technology earned $28.8 million, or 41 cents a share. Sales rose 19% to $176.9 million after Graco acquired operations. Analysts expected per-share earnings of 50 cents a share, on average. Iomega Corp. IOM, -55.26% shares ended down 5.7% afer the company said Chief Financial Officer Thomas Liguori has resigned, effective Nov. 11. Iomega named Thomas Kampfer as interim CFO. Kampfer served as the company's general counsel from July 2001 until October 2005. Orange 21 Inc. ORNG shares tumbled 9.8% after the company lowered its financial outlook to earnings of 5 to 9 cents a share for 2005 on revenue of between $41.5 million and $42.5 million. The company said it's reduced its expectations for sales in the second half because of a late shipment of orders resulting from delays in manufacturing. The Carlsbad, Calif., sunglass maker also cited late deployment of point of purchase displays, a change in international distributors, and lower than expected sales of its E Eyewear product line. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 16 cents a share for the year on revenue of $43.2 million. Susquehanna Bancshares SUSQ shares lost 5.2% after the company reported third-quarter net earnings of $17.8 million, or 38 cents a share, vs. $18.5 million, or 40 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. Net interest income rose to $60.7 million from $58.4 million the Lititz, Pa.-based financial services company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had forecast third-quarter earnings of 41 cents a share. Shares of United Natural Foods UNFI, +0.59% skidded 10.6% after the firm named Michael Funk chief executive officer, succeeding Steven Townshend, who is retiring. Townshend is also leaving the president position with the Dayville, Conn.-based United Natural, but he will remain chairman until the Dec. 8 annual meeting. Unisys UIS, +2.38% shares plummeted 18.9% following a media report that federal auditors are investigating whether the company over-billed the government. In response, Unisys said it is "not unusual" in complex government contracts to have issues arise over contract obligations. The technology consultant said in a statement it believes most of the issues are being addressed "to the initial satisfaction" of Transportation Security Administration. Shares of Veeco Instruments VECO, +1.19% gave back 6% after the company swung to a third-quarter profit of $1.6 million, or 5 cents a share. In the same period a year ago, Veeco posted a loss of $2.2 million, or 7 cents a share. Excluding items, the company would have earned 14 cents a share, higher than the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for earnings of 12 cents a share. Sales for the period rose 4% to $100.1 million. Bookings for the period, however, rose 6% to $84.6 million, lower than Veeco's forecast of between $95 million and $100 million. Looking ahead, Veeco said it sees fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 3 to 9 cents a share on revenue between $100 million and $105 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate was for a profit of 12 cents a share in the December period. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks closed sharply higher Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and the S&P 500 posting their biggest one-day gains in six months, after strong earnings and the White House's nomination of administration economist Ben Bernanke as the next Federal Reserve chief. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed near its session high, rising 169.78 points to 10,385, locking in its biggest rise since April 21. The average was pulled up by strong earnings results from components Merck and American Express. The S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% also closed near its session high, rising 19.79 points to 1,199.38. while the Nasdaq Composite $COMPX ended at its session high, up 33.62 points at 2,115.83. Market breadth was positive: Advancing stocks outweighed decliners 25 to 7 on the New York Stock Exchange, where more than 1.64 billion stocks traded. On the Nasdaq Stock Market, more than 1.57 billion shares traded, and rising shares outpaced falling stocks 21 to 8. Replacing Greenspan The White House nominated Ben Bernanke, a former Fed governor and chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, as the replacement for Greenspan. See full story. With President George Bush at his side in the White House, Bernanke said Monday that he would seek to continue Greenspan's legacy. Read about Greenspan's legacy. Experts said the economist's nomination is likely to win Senate approval. See full story. Analysts had mixed views about the equities- and bond-market implications of the nomination. See full story. "Bernanke is a strong advocate of inflation targeting, but, as simple and elegant as that sounds, it can prove an unrealistic goal," said Peter Morici, a University of Maryland business professor. "These days, too much of the inflation challenge stems from structural issues beyond the control of the Fed -- for example, hypergrowth in China and the resulting pressures on oil prices, and the mismanagement of energy policy and resulting shortages of refining and natural gas capacity," Morici said. James Park, director of institutional trading at Rodman & Renshaw, said the announcement lifted the market by removing an element of uncertainty. "I would say the news [about a Greenspan replacement] gave the market some incremental gains," said Larry Wachtel, a consultant to Wachovia, noting that shares rallied for two hours before the market received word of the announcement. Wachtel said that the move had been widely expected, following strong hints from officials. See Special Report: New Era at the Fed. Investors are most concerned that the replacement continues Greenspan's policy of transparency and tips the market off in advance to likely rate changes, said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at Jefferies & Co. Stocks, which generally have been under pressure in October due to investor nervousness about economic weakness, inflation and rising interest rates, got a break early Monday from some positive corporate news. December crude futures closed down 31 cents at $60.32 a barrel after Hurricane Wilma struck southwest Florida but largely missed the Gulf of Mexico oil-producing and oil-refining facilities that were hurt by previous hurricanes. See related story. The Treasury market remained jittery after the Bernanke announcement as the Bond Market Association predicted the nominee would maintain the central bank's vigilance on inflation. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note ended down 15/32 at 98 14/32 with a yield TNX, -1.23% of 4.444, compared with its Friday close at 4.38%. See full story. The dollar backed off from recent highs following news that a prominent Chinese economist had called yuan appreciation inevitable over time, adding that changes would likely be gradual, according to analysts whose reports cited the comments. Bullish yuan comments tend to benefit other Asian currencies, particularly the yen. See full story. The dollar last was down 0.4% at 115.44 yen. The euro last was up 0.03% at $1.1983. December gold futures closed lower after a day of volatile action. The contract finished down $2.10 at $467 an ounce. See full story. Stocks in action Stun-gun manufacturer Taser International TASR closed a bit off its highs after gaining as much as 24% intraday. The stock's rating was upgraded to buy by Jefferies & Co., which mentioned Taser's opportunities to expand revenue and market share. See full story. Cendant CD, +0.00% gave up early strong gains to finish almost 7% lower at $18.77. The company said it would split itself into four companies by 2006. The name of the controversial conglomerate is slated to disappear. See full story. Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% closed off its highs, up 2 cents at $21.13. The company's third-quarter results rose above year-earlier levels due to contributions from its turnaround program and strong sales of anti-cholesterol agents. See full story. Dow component Merck MRK, -1.13% also was supported by earnings news. The company reported third-quarter earnings of $1.42 billion, or 65 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $1.33 billion, or 60 cents a share. But sales dipped 2%. See full story. The stock gained 3.1% to close at $27. American Express AXP, +1.16% also a Dow stock, rose 5% to $49.54 after the company reported a sharp year-over-year rise in quarterly earnings to 82 cents a share, excluding a special accounting charged, up from 69 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average analyst estimate was 68 cents a share. The strong results from Schering-Plough and Merck failed to boost the overall sector. The Amex Pharmaceutical Index DRG, +0.38% weakened 1.25% to 306.80. Other Dow components contributing to the Monday rally were Alcoa AA, +1.22% which rose 2.5% to $23.94, and Caterpillar CAT, +1.53% which advanced 2.8% to $50.31. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks close sharply higher; Bernanke news one key

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. surged Monday as Jefferies & Co. raised its rating on the stun-gun maker, citing evidence of a business turnaround, growing market opportunities in the U.S. and the U.K., and an attractive valuation. Analyst Matthew McKay upgraded the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company TASR to buy from hold and lifted his price target by $1 to $7. Taser's stock traded up as much as 23.6% to $6.75 in morning trade . The stock closed up 19.4% at $6.52. McKay's rosier outlook is based on checks with a number of U.S. distributors, which show business has firmed up and may turn around by the end of the year. He said one distributor, which experienced a severe drop-off in its business during the first half of they year, reported receiving a significant increase in orders at the end of the September quarter. "Another distributor highlighted a harder time meeting demand, which we attribute to picked-up demand and leaner inventories after management adjusted inventory levels for the slower business in the first of half of the year," said McKay. Meanwhile, a manufacturer of holsters for Tasers pointed to continued healthy demand during the current quarter. Growth opportunities in the U.K. Expectations that the company will be able to grow its U.K market position also fueled McKay's upgrade of Taser. The analyst learned from talks with members of the Association of Chief Police Officers, a U.K police union, that the Minister of State for Crime, Securities and Communities has agreed to meet with it about potentially expanding the use of of the Taser to all non-firearm officers in the country. If the U.K. government decides to move forward with a trial period for use of the gun's by the country's 100,000 non-firearm officers, McKay says, Taser could be looking at an "$80 million to $100 million revenue opportunity beginning in one to two years." Currently, the U.K. is in the process of rolling out Taser guns to about 10,000 officers who carry firearms. Among other international opportunities, France is considering arming its officers with Taser guns although "appears to be one-to-two years behind the U.K," said McKay. Outlook for U.S. sales In the U.S., the company can tap into a market in which 600,000 sworn law-enforcement officers could be eligible to use the gun, accoding to data supplied by the Department of Homeland Security. "Over the next five years, this market segment should provide over $150 million of revenue from new customers, assuming an average sale price of $750 per Taser and the company can reach 50% market penertration from the current 15%." Cartridge sales, new product launches Cartridge sales for the gun also offer a significant revenue opportunity, said the analyst. Assuming Taser achieves a 50% market share and an average of five cartridges are bought annually per gun, cartridge sales should provide about $27 million of steady annual revenue. "Given that each certified Taser user must shoot a minimum of two cartridges per year for training purposes, we believe five cartridges per year per Taser is reasonable," said McKay. New product introductions offer further reason for optimism, according to the analyst. In particular, the launch of the Taser CAM, a stun-gun that records video once it has been switched to the armed position, could be a significant revenue driver for the company. The company is expected to begin production of this model in the first quarter of 2006. Stun-gun safety Finally, said the analyst, the tone of the debate over the safety of the Taser gun is evolving to the benefit of the company. He said the debate is much more focused on the appropriate situations for using the device rather than the argument over the lethal or non-lethal aspects of the gun. The use of the stun gun has been mired in controversy for a number of years In January, Taser shares plunged after management announced that the company was the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into safety statements related to the gun, and recent sales to a distributor. Read more The American Civil Liberties Union has claimed a number of deaths in the U.S. and Canada can be linked to police use of the gun. Amnesty International, meanwhile, said the use of Tasers should be suspended pending a rigorous, independent investigation into their safety. Since the start of the year, Taser's shares have plunged more than 80% on those safety concerns. Disclosing its interest in the company, Jefferies & Co said it makes a market in shares of the company. Making a market is when a brokerage holds an inventory of stock in a particular company to allow it to fill customer orders quickly. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Taser International's shares surge on Jefferies upgrade

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Jefferies & Co. Monday upgraded Taser International Inc. tasr to a buy rating, concluding that business from new customers could boost the company's revenue if it succeeds in expanding its market share. The research note also cited opportunities in international markets, new products, and markets beyond law enforcement for the company's weapons. In premarket trade the stock rose 61 cents to $6.07.
title: Taser Intl upgraded to buy at Jefferies & Co.; stock up 11%

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stock market futures notched higher Monday, amid weakness in crude-oil prices as Hurricane Wilma nears Florida. Drugmakers were also in focus, as Schering-Plough rallied after reporting results and after Merck exceeded earnings expectations. December S&P 500 futures rose 3.50 points at 1,187.30 and Nasdaq 100 futures were up 3 points at 1,578.5. Dow industrials futures gained 40 points to 10,280. On Friday, the Dow industrials fell 66 points at 10,215, while the S&P 500 rose 1.8 points to 1,179 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 14 points at 2,082, with investors juggling a disappointment from Dow component Caterpillar CAT, +1.53% with better-than-expected results at Internet search engine Google Inc. GOOG, +2.71% On Monday, front-month crude fell back below $60 a barrel as Wilma hit southwestern Florida as a Category 3 hurricane. See full story. December crude was shedding 87 cents to $59.76 in electronic trading. Drug giant Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% surged $1.49, or 7.1%, to $22.60 in Instinet pre-open trading, after reporting earnings that rose to 3 cents a share from last year's 1 cent. Excluding special items, earnings would have been 8 cents a share, topping analyst forecasts of 6 cents. Revenue rose 15% to $2.8 billion. Though not yet active in the pre-open, Merck MRK, -1.13% can be expected to influence trading after the Dow industrials component reported third-quarter earnings of that rose to 65 cents a share from 60 cents a share a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 62 cents a share. Revenue fell to $5.42 billion from $5.54 billion, just shy of the $5.45 billion expected by analysts. Fellow drug maker and Dow component Pfizer PFE, +0.54% which closed at an 8-year low of $21.25 on Friday, ticked up 15 cents to $21.40. Of other companies in focus, Cendant Corp. CD, +0.00% powered up $1.76, or 8.8%, to $21.85 in Instinet pre-open trading after saying early Monday that it will split itself into four companies by 2006, and the name of the controversial diversified company will disappear. The real estate company, which will include brokers Century 21 and Coldwell Banker, will be the biggest unit of the four. See story. Taser International TASR tallied a 14% gain to $6.24 after Jefferies upgraded the stun gun maker to a buy rating, citing a favorable change in the social climate. Silicon Laboratories SLAB, +2.39% shot up $3.05, or 11%, to $29.73 after reporting third-quarter earnings, excluding special items, that rose to 26 cents a share and revenue of $103.9 million, topping analyst forecasts for earnings of 24 cents a share and revenue of $101.6 million. Google GOOG, +2.71% which climbed 12% on Friday, added another $4.30, or 1.3%, to $344.20 in Instinet. Though the economic calendar is barren Monday, consumer confidence and existing home sales data will be released Tuesday, with the eagerly-awaited third-quarter GDP release due for Friday. Economists polled by MarketWatch expect 3.6% growth, compared to 3.3% in the second quarter. The dollar was a touch higher on the euro, at $1.1940, but slightly lower vs. the Japanese yen, at 115.67 yen. Also overseas, the Nikkei 225 ended 0.7% lower, while most European markets advanced. Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano SA STD, -0.33% is in advanced negotiations to take a stake in Philadelphia's Sovereign Bancorp Inc. SOV, +12.26% which will use the proceeds to buy Independence Community Bank Corp. ICBC The Wall Street Journal reported. The same newspaper reported that private-equity firms are actively looking at a buyout of Computer Sciences Corp. CSC, +3.70% Schering AG SHR, +0.18% not affiliated with the U.S. drugmaker, posted better-than-expected third-quarter earnings and revenue and lifted profit guidance on cost-cutting and the performance of its multiple sclerosis and birth control drugs. See story. Focus stocks Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% said it would pay about $2.1 billion in cash to buy AMLI Residential Properties Trust AML, +6.52% a Chicago-based real estate investment trust that manages and acquires multifamily communities in eight major metropolitan markets. The investment bank's Real Estate's Prime Property Fund announced the purchase in an all-cash deal valued at $37.75 a share. The price values the REIT at a premium of 21% to its closing price on Friday of $31.27 a share. Pilgrim's Pride Corp. PPC, -1.16% added that it has raised its fourth quarter earnings guidance to a range of between $1.07 to $1.12 a share, from a previous range of 90 cents to $1.00 a share. The company said it was able to raise the guidance due to better results in both its U.S. and Mexico chicken operations. Kimberly Clark Corp. KMB, +0.61% said Monday that third-quarter net income fell to $325.3 million, or 68 cents a share, from $441.3 million, or 89 cents, a year ago. Excluding charges, earnings would have been 95 cents a share, which matched analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. Sales for the three months ended Sept. 30 rose to $4 billion from $3.78 billion in last year's third quarter, which was ahead of analysts' view for $3.99 billion in sales. For the fourth quarter, the Dallas-based maker of Kleenex tissues, Huggies diapers and other consumer goods forecast earnings before charges of 94 to 96 cents a share because of higher oil costs. Analysts' average estimate stands at 97 cents a share. Broker calls Prudential Equity Group upgraded telecoms operator SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% to neutral weight from underweight, citing valuation, washed out sentiment and the company's recent ability to improve margins and deliver solid fundamentals despite persistent line losses. Merrill Lynch cut State Street Corp. STT, +1.91% to neutral from buy, saying the shares are within 1% of its $55 price target. The broker told clients that the downgrade was purely a valuation call and that momentum remains good. Merrill Lynch cut fashion accessory retailer Coach, Inc. COH, +6.26% to neutral from buy, citing its belief that this holiday season may be more subdued. The broker told clients that the stores today have a lot less color than a year ago when pink was dominant.
