title: Futures notch gains as crude falls, Cendant to break up

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr Thursday said a lawsuit filed against it in Arizona has been dismissed by the state's Superior Court. The company said the complaint alleged liability for a training injury, and the court dismissed the suit on the grounds that it wasn't filed within the statute of limitations. Taser shares closed at $5.58, down 2.1%.
title: Taser Int'l says lawsuit in Arizona was dismissed

content: Advancers Cell Therapeutics' CTIC shares soared to end Tuesday's session higher by 36.8% after the company said a recently completed Phase II trial of Xyotax plus carboplatin in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer demonstrated a statistically significant survival rate among women vs. men. The data was presented at the UBS Global Life Sciences Conference in New York. Cell Therapeutics plans to file a new drug application for Xyotax in the U.S. in 2006, the company said last month. It also plans to file for marketing approval in Europe. Shares of Coley Pharmaceutical Group COLY added 9.2% after the company said it was starting a clinical study of its Actilon drug for the treatment of chronic Hepatitis C. The Phase 1b clinical study will look at the effectiveness of the drug as a stand-alone treatment and as a drug used in combination with other treatments currently available to treat Hepatitis C. Depomed Inc. DEPO shares jumped 8.7% after the Menlo Park, Calif., company named Carl Pelzel chief operating officer and executive vice president. Pelzel joined Depomed in June as a vice president, marketing and commercial development. DGSE Cos. DGSE shares added 5.4% after the Dallas-based seller of watches and jewelry said it's hired Southwest Securities to explore strategic options, including a possible sale of the company. "We believe that our publicly traded securities do not reflect the inherent value of the Company's activities," said William Oyster, the company's president and COO. "The engagement of Southwest Securities will give us an opportunity to professionally examine a range of short-term and long-term possibilities." Exploration Co. TXCO shares rose 9.5% after the company agreed to sell certain interests in its 670,000-acre Maverick Basin block in southwestern Texas for $80 million to EnCana Oil & Gas. Gene Logic GLGC shares gained 10% after the company signed an agreement with Pfizer Inc. PFE to seek new therapeutic indications for several unapproved drug candidates no longer in active development. The drug candidates originated from Pfizer's portfolio. The terms of the agreement provide for success-based milestones per compound and royalties on the commercialization of drugs repositioned through Gene Logic. Icon Plc ICLR shares rose 6.3% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $6.4 million, or 45 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $7.3 million, or 52 cents a share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $85.9 million from $78.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 45 cents a share from the Dublin-based provider of clinical research services in the August quarter. Shares of Monsanto Co. MON ended with a 5.2% gain after the St. Louis-based agricultural technology company issued a press release responding to questions about patents on its Roundup Ready soybean technology in Brazil. The company said it believes "the law is clear" that one of its patents is protected in Brazil until August 2007, and it noted that it's already been granted an injunction that allows it to continue to collect royalties on the technology. Monsanto said the other Roundup patents are valid in Brazil through June 2011. Party City Corp. PCTY shares leapt 37.5% after the company agreed to be acquired by Berkshire Partners LLC and Weston Presidio, for about $360 million, or $17.50 a share. The deal represents a premium of 43% to Party City's Monday closing share price of $12.28. The acquisition of the party goods retail chain is expected to close by the end of 2005 or early 2006. See full story. Siga Technologies' SIGA shares soared 25.9% after the company won a $3.2 million one-year contract from the U.S. army to identify and treat anti-viral diseases, including smallpox. New York-based Siga specializes in using viral and bacterial genomics and computer modeling to create products aimed at treating serious infectious diseases. Todco THE shares surged 11.5% after the Houston provider of contract oil and gas drilling services said that after Hurricane Rita, a visual inspection showed all rigs accounted for. Several rigs appear to have sustained minor damage, but none of them appears likely to be out of service for an extended period. All of Todco's rigs are insured against damage with a total incident deductible of $1 million, the company said. Ultralife Batteries ULBI jumped 16.3% after the company said the Defense Department increased by up to $25 million its order for BA-5372/U batteries. The increase brings the total contract value to up to $45 million. Ultralife has shipped or has orders scheduled for monthly shipments through 2006 totaling more than $20 million. The additional quantities could extend deliveries into 2009. WellChoice WC shares gained 7% after the company agreed to be acquired by WellPoint WLP for a consideration of $77.23 a share, or roughly $6.5 billion in cash and stock. The deal calls for a swap of $38.25 in cash and 0.5191 of a WellPoint share for each WellChoice share. WellPoint expects the deal to be neutral to its 2006 earnings per share, and add to earnings afterwards. The company expects to realize annual synergies of at least $125 million from the deal by 2010. The combined entity will serve more than 33 million members. WellChoice is the parent company of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, the largest health insurer in New York. See full story. Decliners Audiovox Corp. VOXX shares ended the session down 19.2% after the company warned that it won't meet its revenue outlook for the third quarter due to the unexpected decision by a competitor to "drastically" reduce pricing for certain products. Audiovox said this has led to an almost 50% reduction in the pricing for satellite radio plug and play units. The company now expects to report a loss of 16 to 18 cents a share for the third quarter on revenue of roughly $123 million. The company's prior outlook was for revenue of about $135 million in the quarter. Audiovox will also record an inventory markdown of about $3.7 million from the satellite radio situation. Audiovox also expects revenue for the fourth quarter to be negatively affected by the retail price of the satellite radio plug and play units. Capital Title Group CTGI shares slid 5.1% after the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 6.85 million shares of its common stock. The Scottsdale, Ariz., title insurance company plans to offer 5 million of the shares, while certain selling stockholders will offer the remaining 1.85 million shares. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of up to an additional 1,027,500 shares. Corcept Therapeutics CORT shares slumped 10.1% after the Menlo Park, Calif., company moved back its expectations for the reporting of results of one of three Phase III trials it's conducting on the use of its Corlux drug for the treatment of psychotic major depression. The company attributed the delay to a slower than anticipated pace of patient enrollment. It now expects to report the results of the 06 trial in the second half of 2006, instead of the first half, as previously indicated. Shares of DiamondCluster International DTPI tumbled 12.3% after the Chicago-based provider of management consulting services said it plans to reduce its global workforce by about 6% as part of a restructuring. The company expects to close its offices in Munich and Lisbon, downsize its office in Barcelona, and consolidate German operations into a single office in Munich. It won't make job cuts in North America and the United Kingdom. DiamondCluster expects to record charges totaling $11 million to $12 million in the September quarter from the plan. The company believes the restructuring will hurt earnings in the current quarter, and it forecast a loss of 29 to 34 cents a share for the period, including the charge. DiamondCluster projects revenue of between $48 million and $49 million for the period, due to a pullback in spending by core clients in the property and casualty and health insurance sectors. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for revenue of $50.3 million in the September period. ECC Capital Corp. ECR shares fell 7.5% after the company said it will pay a third-quarter cash dividend of 18 cents a share to be paid on Oct. 24 to shareholders of record on Oct. 10. This dividend is 18% lower than the 22 cents a share paid to shareholders in the second quarter. Movie Gallery MOVI shares dropped 13.9% after the company said it's temporarily suspending its quarterly dividend to focus more on cutting debt and other financing needs. The video rental company also attributed the move to the challenging conditions facing the industry. CEO Joe Malugen said he hopes to reinstate the dividend as soon as conditions permit. SBS Technologies SBSE shares lost 6% after the company lowered its sales outlook for the first quarter ending Sept. 30, citing "a combination of supplier problems and customer delays." As revised, the company sees quarterly sales coming in between $32 million and $33 million, as opposed to a range between $35 million and $37 million previously. Taser International TASR shares ended lower by 13.1% after the company said the previously disclosed inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission has now been deemed formal. The Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun company added that the probe has been expanded to include possible unauthorized acquisition of material non-public information by individuals outside of the company in an effort to manipulate the stock price. Taser plans to cooperate fully with the probe. See full story. TriPath Imaging TPTH shares pulled back 12.6% after the company withdrew the pre-market approval supplement it had submitted to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for the FocalPoint GS Imaging System, after it was notified by the FDA that the filing must be amended to include additional data. The company intends to collect additional clinical trial data and has initiated discussions with the FDA regarding these data requirements. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks closed mixed Tuesday after a tame speech by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan helped offset losses caused by disappointment consumer confidence and new home sales figures. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed up 12.58 points at 10,456.21. The top performer on the Dow, Boeing BA, +2.46% registered an almost 3% gain. The Nasdaq Composite $COMPX lost 5.04 points to end at 2,116.42 and the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% gained just 0.03 points for a nearly flat close at 1,215.66. Declining stocks outnumbered rising shares by 18 to 13 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume exceeded 1.49 billion. There were more than 1.63 billion shares traded in the Nasdaq market, where falling shares outpaced winners by 16 to 13. The major averages switched course several times Tuesday, as the market reacted to new data reports and speeches by Federal Reserve officials. Shares rose to their highest levels of the day after Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told the National Association of Business Economics in Chicago that key sectors of business and finance have made the U.S. economy flexible enough to survive a series of shocks including 9/11. See full story. Investors had been worried the Greenspan would express concern about growing inflationary pressures, and drop hints that the Fed may switch to a more aggressive stance on future interest-rate increases. "Greenspan said nothing about monetary policy or the economy," said Peter Boockvar, equity strategist at Miller Tabak. "So it looks like there could be some short-covering by guys who were nervous he would say something hawkish." Boockvar said worries about a more hawkish Fed were triggered earlier in the session when San Francisco Fed President said rising energy prices had put the central bank "on the horns of dilemma." Earlier, stocks saw opening gains fade after the Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index fell to 86.6 in September from 105.5 in August, marking the lowest level since October, 2003. Read full survey. Economists were expecting the index to decline to 94.9, according to a survey conducted by MarketWatch. See Economic Calendar. Separately, the Commerce Department said new home sales slumped 9.9% in August to a seasonally adjusted 1.24 million. See full story. Economists surveyed by MarketWatch were expecting the pace of home sales to cool slightly in August, to 1.34 million units. See Economic Calendar. Oil futures ended lower, as traders struggled to figure out the extent of damage to energy facilities caused by recent hurricanes. The front-month fell 75 cents to $65.07. See full story. Gold futures closed at their lowest level in nearly two weeks on the stronger dollar and weakness in oil prices. The benchmark December contract fell $3.30 to $466.20 an ounce, but off an intraday low of $465.80. See full story. The dollar hit two-month highs against the yen and euro after recent remarks by Kansas City Fed President Thomas Hoenig were seen as sending yet another signal that the Fed intends to keep raising rates. The dollar last was up 1% at 113.45 yen, while the euro fell 0.7% to $1.1994. See full story. Treasurys closed unchanged after mercurial price action that included both gains and losses as the market largely marked time ahead of the Greenspan speech. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note finished the session unchanged at 99-20/32 with a yield TNX, -1.23% of 4.3%. See full story. Stocks on the march Dow component Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% closed up almost 3% at $66.55, extending a prior-session gain of 2.3% as the aerospace giant continued to benefit from news of a tentative agreement with its machinists union that could end a strike by more than 18,000 workers. Taser International Inc. TASR ended almost 13% lower at $6.35 after announcing that a previously disclosed inquiry into the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission has now been deemed formal. See full story. Health insurer WellChoice Inc. WC rose 6.6% to $75.27, after news that fellow insurer WellPoint WLP is buying it for $6.5 billion in cash and stock. WellPoint shares rose 13 cents to $75.22. See full story. Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. PBG, +7.14% gained 3% to $28.46. The company reported third-quarter net income of $205 million, or 82 cents a share, compared to $191 million, or 73 cents a share, a year ago. The results include a 4 cents a share gain from litigation settlement. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 78 cents a share. The company projected record earnings per share for fiscal 2005. Auto parts maker Delphi DPH, -33.33% continued its recent slide, dropping 8% to $2.75. The stock closed almost 14% lower on Monday after being hammered by concerns that it may not be able to avoid a bankruptcy filing. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks close mixed after uneven session

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shares of Taser International slumped Tuesday after the stun-gun maker said a previously disclosed Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry is now formal. The stock closed down 96 cents, or 13%, to $6.35. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company TASR also said the SEC's probe has been expanded to include examination of "the possible unauthorized acquisition of material non-public information" by individuals outside the company in an effort to manipulate the price of Taser stock. The formal designation of the inquiry gives the SEC subpoena power to obtain documents and testimony from all parties it deems relevant. For its part, Taser said it plans to supply the SEC with all materials it requests and continue to fully cooperate with the probe, first disclosed in early January. At that time, Taser said it was compiling information for the SEC related to the safety of its products, and a then-recent order from Davidson's Inc. "We recognize that this has been a difficult process for our employees and shareholders," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a statement. "We continue to make all efforts to assist the SEC in completing their investigation as expeditiously as possible." Smith went on to say he hopes the SEC will look into recent data that indicate the existence of what he termed "a large improper, naked short position in Taser International stock." The stock has been extremely volatile in the past year, running within a range of $33.45 on Dec. 30 to its prior 52-week low of $7.11 set last Friday. In July, the company reported its second-quarter results, posting earnings of $500,000, or a penny a share, on revenue of $13.2 million, down from a year-ago profit of $4.5 million, or 7 cents, earned on revenue of $16.3 million. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid
title: Taser says SEC probe is now formal, has been expanded

content: Pre-open moves U.S. stock markets were set to trade flat to lower before data on consumer confidence and new home sales and a speech by the White House Council of Economic Advisers Chairman Ben Bernake. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets Stocks in Germany and France retreated as crude remained above $65, though that same factor lifted London's FTSE. Shares in Seoul and Sydney touched record highs; Japan's Nikkei ended lower. The dollar reclaimed a two-month high against major counterparts. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action J.P. Morgan shuffled its ratings on oil majors, upgrading Chevron Corp. CVX, +1.73% BP BP, +2.37% and Royal Dutch Shell RDS.A, +1.16% while downgraded Exxon Mobil XOM, +2.47% and France's Total. Bank of America raised its 2005 and 2006 forecast for global handset sales, saying the pace of new subscribers remains strong, particularly in Russia, India and China. The broker sees 2005 sales of 813 million versus 795 million. For 2006, the forecast is 916 million vs. 900 million. Bank of America also lifted its earnings estimates on Nokia NOK, +0.74% and on Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% Prudential Equity Group downgraded Tyson Foods, Inc. TSN, +0.36% to underweight from neutral weight, citing delays related to U.S. beef exports to Japan. Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co. ANF, +2.41% to outperform from neutral, saying expectations have become overly pessimistic. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Health insurer WellPoint is near a $6.5 billion cash-and-stock deal to buy WellChoice, the largest health insurer in New York state, according to a media report. The deal would give WellPoint WLP already the nation's largest health insurer with 28 million members, a foothold in the Northeast, The New York Times reported in its online edition. Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. PBG, +7.14% reported third-quarter net income of $205 million, or 82 cents a share, compared with $191 million, or 73 cents a share, a year ago. The results include a gain of 4 cents a share from a litigation settlement. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 78 cents a share. "Our U.S. business was the primary driver of our operating results in the third quarter," said CEO John Cahill. Taser International Inc. TASR said the previously disclosed inquiry into the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission has now been deemed formal. The Scottsdale, Ariz., stun-gun company added that the probe has been expanded to include possible unauthorized acquisition of material nonpublic information by individuals outside of the company in an effort to manipulate the stock price. DreamWorks SKG has ended talks to be bought by NBC Universal, which is 80% owned by General Electric GE, -1.46% The Wall Street Journal reported, citing DreamWorks principal David Geffen. Price and Steven Spielberg's independence were among the issues that led to the breakdown, the report said. Stride Rite Corp. SRR, +2.25% said third-quarter profit rose to $7.7 million, or 21 cents a share, from $6.2 million, or 16 cents, a year ago. Sales for the three months ended Sept. 2 advanced to $146.2 million from $140.4 million in last year's third quarter. Three analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 17 cents a share on sales of $147.7 million. The Canadian CAW union said it's still in talks with General Motors GM, +2.45% though "a lot of work remains." The union said in a statement that seven subcommittees have wrapped up bargaining, but the local bargaining committees and the remaining subcommittees will be working on outstanding issues including job security. title: WellPoint, DreamWorks, Taser likely to feature

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Uncertain stock markets were looking flat-to-lower Tuesday ahead of data on consumer confidence and new home sales, as well as a speech by the White House Council of Economic Advisers chairman, Ben Bernake. Investors also are eyeing energy prices that are a touch lower and a report of a $6.5 billion deal in the insurance sector. The futures contract for the Dow Jones Industrial Average was off 4 points at 10,483. S&P 500 futures were down 0.2 of a point while Nasdaq 100 futures were down 0.5 of a point. On Monday, markets closed off highs in reaction to mercurial oil prices in the wake of Hurricane Rita. The Dow industrials rose 24 points at 10,443, the S&P 500 rose 0.3 points at 1,215 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 4.6 points at 2,121. Front-month crude-oil futures declined 80 cents at $65.02 a barrel. International stock markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 closing lower and the German DAX down 0.5%, while the FTSE 100 in London rose 0.1%. The dollar reached two-months highs against both the yen and also the euro, with one dollar recently fetching 113.28 yen and a euro worth $1.2019. See story. Remarks by Kansas City Federal Reserve President Thomas Hoenig were seen as yet another signal that the Fed intends to keep raising rates. Analysts polled by MarketWatch are expecting new home sales to fall to 1.34 million from 1.41 million, and consumer confidence to drop to 94.9 in September from 105.6 in August. According to Action Econmics, the expected plunge in consumer confidence is linked to the devastation caused by Hurricane Katrina. On the company front, health insurer WellPoint WLP is near a $6.5 billion cash-and-stock deal to buy WellChoice WC the largest health insurer in New York state, The New York Times reported. See story. DreamWorks SKG has ended talks to be bought by NBC Universal, which is 80% owned by General Electric GE The Wall Street Journal reported Tuesday, citing DreamWorks principal David Geffen. "We pursued it for quite some time, we were unable to come to terms and we're no longer in discussions with them," Geffen told the newspaper. Price and Steven Spielberg's independence were among the issues that led to the breakdown, the report said. Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. PBG reported third-quarter net income of $205 million, or 82 cents a share, compared to $191 million, or 73 cents a share, a year ago. The results include a 4 cents a share gain from litigation settlement. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 78 cents a share. Net revenue rose to $3.2 billion, from $2.9 billion a year ago. Pepsi Bottling said that it now expects to record earnings per share in a range of $1.83 to $1.87 for fiscal 2005, while worldwide adjusted constant territory volume expectations are for growth of 3%. PepsiCo PEP reports earnings on Thursday. In premarket electronic trade, Taser International Inc. TASR was down 8.9% at $6.66 after announcing that a previously disclosed inquiry into the company by the Securities and Exchange Commission has now been deemed formal. The Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun company added that the probe has been expanded to include possible unauthorized acquisition of material non-public information by individuals outside of the company attempting to manipulate the stock price. Broker calls J.P. Morgan shuffled its ratings on oil majors on Tuesday. The broker upgraded Chevron Corp. CVX to overweight from underweight, citing the group's improved outlook following the Unocal acquisition. J.P. Morgan also upgraded BP BP to overweight from neutral, saying the company's high exposure to both U.S. refining and natural gas prices leaves it well placed to benefit from the current commodity strength. The broker upgraded Royal Dutch Shell RDS RDS to overweight from neutral, saying it believes the stock could be a good defense option given the broker's expectation of crude weakness later in the year. In contrast, J.P. Morgan cut Exxon Mobil XOM to neutral from overweight, citing the recent rise in the shares. Total TOT was downgraded to neutral from overweight to reflect a less impressive combination of valuation and potential catalysts in comparison to other stocks. The same broker cut its recommendation on Cypress Semiconductor Corp. CY , ON Semiconductor Corp. ONNN and Fairchild Semiconductor Intl. FCS to neutral from overweight. J.P. Morgan also cut its semiconductor sector stance from bullish to neutral, as it believes that several leading indicators such as utilization rates, gross margins, year-over-year growth rates, EPS estimates and pricing should either peak in the fourth quarter of 2005, or have already peaked. Merrill Lynch cut Boston Scientific Corp. BSX to neutral from buy, citing estimates that the group's share of the U.S. drug eluting stent market will decline to 35% in 2009 from 58% in 2005. The broker told clients that its worst-case scenario implies earnings per share could be down year on year in 2008. Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded apparel retailer Abercrombie & Fitch Co. ANF to outperform from neutral, saying expectations have become overly pessimistic. The broker told clients that while many investors assume the worst, it believes the company's comparison momentum will continue and that over the next several months, several catalysts could change investor sentiment. Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: Uncertain markets pause before data

Taser plans to cooperate fully with the probe. The stock closed Monday at $7.31, up 7 cents.
title: Taser Int'l says SEC probe is now formal, expanded

content: SAN FRANCSISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr after Thursday's closing bell named Grant Thornton LLP as its new accounting firm. The former auditor for Taser International, a Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of non-lethal devices, was Deloitte & Touche LLP.
title: Taser Int'l hires Grant Thornton as new auditor

content: Pre-open moves U.S. stocks looked set for weaker trading as crude turned higher and retailer Best Buy disappointed with earnings. The weakness prevailed as data showed that a record amount of goods and services sold overseas helped narrow the U.S. trade gap in July, despite the record high cost of foreign oil. The narrowing of the trade gap was unexpected. Data also showed that wholesale prices jumped 0.6% in August because of higher energy prices, slightly better than forecast. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets European markets weakened as traders took profit from the oil sector with crude below $64. Japan's Nikkei paused from Monday post-election rally and regional indexes ended mixed. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action EBay EBAY, +0.32% was downgraded to sector performer from sector outperformer at CIBC World Markets on the belief the shares will be stuck in a range given concerns over near-term challenges related to its purchase of Internet-phone startup Skype Technologies. Media company Dow Jones & Co. DJ was cut to reduce from neutral at UBS. The broker said Dow Jones doesn't deserve a premium to sector peers as technology and financial advertising are not poised for a significant recovery. Dow Jones owns MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. See Upgrades/Downgrades: The Internet's most complete source for analyst comment. Breaking news: See Market Pulse for all the latest Nokia NOK, +0.74% the world's top seller of mobile phones, lifted third-quarter earnings and sales guidance due to stronger-than-expected mobile device volumes and a decline in average selling prices that was lower than initially forecast. Shares rose 4% in European trade. Knight-Ridder Inc., KRI, +0.26% the San Jose, Calif., media group, expects third-quarter profit from continuing operations, excluding a tax benefit, to decline 20% while fourth-quarter profit will be higher. The consensus estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are 89 cents for the third quarter and $1.38 for the fourth. Chairman and Chief Executive Tony Ridder called the August results "disappointing." Viacom Inc. VIA, +1.80% VIA and cable giant Comcast Corp. CMCSA, +2.67% CMCSK plan to unveil a wide-ranging joint venture that will create several new cable networks, the New York Post reported. The venture will include several lifestyle channels, video-on-demand and e-commerce. John Sykes, the former head of Viacom's radio division Infinity Broadcasting, is heading up the joint venture, the report said. Time Warner TWX, +0.40% reaffirmed its financial outlook for fiscal 2005 ahead of a company presentation at an investor conference. The New York-based media giant said it continues to expect its growth rate will be in the high single digits for its adjusted operating income before depreciation and amortization in 2005 from its equivalent 2004 total of $9.9 billion. The company said its view reflects both anticipated revenue gains and margin expansion. Taser International, TASR the Scottsdale, Ariz., producer of non-lethal weaponry, said international law-enforcement agencies placed two orders valued at more than $775,000 for its X26 devices and accessories. The orders are expected to ship in the third quarter. Jo-Ann Stores JAS, +1.53% said Brian Carney has resigned as executive vice president and chief financial officer, effective the end of September. And Valerie Gentile Sachs resigned from her executive vice president, general counsel and secretary positions. The company said its finance team will be led during a transition period by Jim Kerr, its controller, and Don Tomoff, its treasurer. EnCana Corp. ECA, +4.56% said it's agreed to sell all of its Ecuador oil and pipeline interests for $1.42 billion. Andes Petroleum Co., a joint venture of Chinese oil companies, will pay Calgary-based EnCana cash under terms of the deal, which is expected to close before the end of 2005. Vivendi Universal V, +2.25% said it'll beat its adjusted net profit target for the year of 1.8 billion euros after seeing first-half adjusted net income climb to 1.16 billion euros from 344 million euros, on rising Universal Music Group profitability, a return to profit at Vivendi Universal Games and increasing telecommunications services earnings.
