title: Nokia, Knight-Ridder, Taser, eBay to draw attention

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International, tasr the Scottsdale, Ariz., producer of non-lethal weaponry, said international law-enforcement agencies placed two orders valued at more than $775,000 for its X26 devices and accessories. The orders are expected to ship in the third quarter. Taser shares fell 25 cents, or 3.1%, to $7.87 on Monday.
title: Taser gets $775K international orders for X26 devices

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr rose 5% to $9.83 on Monday after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker disclosed the results of the six-month study of its devices by the Columbus, Ohio police force, saying the technology helped avert 14 potentially deadly force incidents. The company said 12 of the cases were attempted suicides where Taser's devices were used to prevent death or serious injury.
title: Taser shares rise on study w/ Ohio police force

content: Empresa Brasileira quarterly profit rises 3.5% (7:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. ERJ, +2.20% after Friday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $83 million, or 47 cents per American depositary share, up 3.5% from $80.2 million, or 46 cents per ADS. Analysts polled by Thomson First call had estimated a per-share profit of 41 cents. Revenue at the Brazilian jetmaker fell to $812.4 from $924.3 million last year. Two analysts estimated quarterly revenue of $780.1 million. Beacon Power quarterly loss narrows; rev more than doubles (6:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Beacon Power Corp. BCON after the closing bell on Friday reported a second-quarter net loss of $1.8 million, or 4 cents a share, vs. a loss of $2.3 million, or 5 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. The Wilmington, Mass.-based provider of energy storage and power conversion solutions said revenue more than doubled to $318,304 from $126,484 a year ago. Standard Management quarterly loss widens (5:44 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Standard Management Corp. SMAN, +0.00% after Friday's closing bell reported a second-quarter net loss $5.4 million, or 68 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $2.5 million, or 31 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The company posted a loss from discontinued operations of $800,000, or 10 cents a share, related to the sale of Standard Life Insurance Co. of Indiana in June. Revenue at the Indianapolis-based insurance company rose to $2.5 million from $1.8 million last year. Ark Restaurants quarterly earnings fall 5% (4:58 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ark Restaurants Corp. ARKR, -2.04% after the closing bell on Friday reported third-quarter net earnings fell 5% to $2.8 million, or 80 cents a share, vs. $3 million, or 84 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. The New York-based restaurant and bar operator posted revenue of $32.77 million vs. $32.83 million a year ago. Natural Health Trends' shares surge on narrowed loss (2:53 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Natural Health Trends Corp. BHIP, -2.75% rose almost 6% to $15.10 on Friday after the Dallas direct-selling company reported a loss of $2.2 million, or 32 cents a share, narrower than its year-ago loss of $6.7 million, or $1.24 a share. Sales jumped 182% in the latest three months to $49.9 million from $17.7 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Natural Health attributed the higher sales to significant growth in its Hong Kong-based business. Dell continues to lead tech decliners (2:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dell Inc. DELL shares continued to retreat in late afternoon trading Friday, falling $3.07, or almost 8%, to $36.51 after the No. 1 maker of personal computers gave a third-quarter revenue forecast that didn't please Wall Street. Dell expects to earn between 39 cents to 41 cents a share in the third quarter on sales of $14.1 billion to $14.5 billion. Analysts had previously pegged the company's profit at 41 cents a share on revenue of $14.6 billion. Cosi rallies on improved FY05 loss view; sees earns in FY06 (12:27 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Cosi Inc. COSI leapt 13.5% to $9.08 on Friday after the Deerfield, Ill., restaurant operator lifted its same-store sales outlook for the full year to growth of 7% to 9% from a prior projection for growth of 4% to 5%. The company also forecast a narrower than expected loss for the year to 11 cents a share, narrower than its previous estimate for a loss of 14 to 18 cents a share. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a loss of 20 cents a share for the year. Cosi also said it expects positive earnings before items in fiscal 2006. Jilin Chemical quarterly profit tumbles 77% (12:08 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jilin Chemical Industrial Co. JCC, +0.00% on Friday reported earnings attributable to shareholders of 135 million yuan ($16 million) for the first half of 2005, down 77% from 593.6 million yuan a year ago. Revenue was 18 million yuan, up from 13.7 million yuan last year. The company, based in China, also said that its board has decided not to declare an interim dividend for the first six months ended June 30. In addition, Jilin Chemical said it expects its profit for the first nine months of this year to fall by more than 50% compared with the same period a year ago, citing its view that the increase in the price of crude oil may not be enough to offset the increase in the price of refined oil. First Marblehead shares fall after missing loan forecast (11:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shares of First Marblehead Corp. FMD fell 2.7% to $30.51 on Friday after the provider of outsourcing services for educational lenders topped Wall Street profit expectations for its fourth-quarter results by a nickel but disappointed with its loan volumes. After Thursday's closing bell, Boston-based First Marblehead posted earnings of $43 million, or 65 cents a share, for the June quarter on total service revenue of $120.2 million. The company's private label loan facilitation volume totaled $434 million for the quarter, an increase of 33% from $328 million in the comparable year-ago period. Friedman Billings Ramsey, however, was looking for loan volume of $493 million in the quarter and the firm lowered its price target on the stock to $36 from $40 in the wake of the report. "Despite surprising earnings on the upside, we believe the stock is likely to remain pressured, as investors still lack clarity into volumes for the all-important September quarter," the firm told clients. APA Enterprises quarterly loss widens (11:27 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- APA Enterprises Inc. APAT on Friday reported a first-quarter net loss of $891,006, or 8 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $702,836, or 6 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. The Blaine, Minn.-based fiber-optics maker posted revenue of $3.5 million, down from $3.7 million a year ago. Gross margin for the first quarter was 21%, up 5% from a year ago, the company said. National Interstate names David Michelson COO (11:23 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- National Interstate Corp. NATL, +2.86% said Friday it has named David Michelson to the new position of executive vice president and chief operating officer. Michelson, who began working at the property and casualty insurer in 1999, will oversee the company's business operations. It also named Terry Phillips as senior vice president to oversee the claims and reinsurance operations, among other duties. Movie Gallery shares hammered after posting a loss (10:59 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Movie Gallery Inc. dropped more than 10% Friday morning after the home-video rental company reported a surprise quarterly loss on lower-than-expected revenue. Alabama-based Movie Gallery MOVI said same-store revenue in rural and urban markets dropped 5.5%, more than expected, due to what the company called "the worst box-office slump in more than two decades." At last check, the stock was down $2.02 at $19.35 on volume of 1.8 million shares. AirNet shares top NYSE percentage-gainers list (10:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - AirNet Systems Inc. ANS, -4.23% shares surged 19% to $5.01 in morning trading Friday, making it the top percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange. The move comes after the company reported its second-quarter results after the bell Thursday. For the three months ended June 30, the Columbus, Ohio-based aviation services provider said its earnings rose to $2.1 million, or 20 cents a share. In the comparable year-ago period AirNet lost $100,000, or 1 cent a share. Thomson First Call does not publish an estimate for AirNet's results. Revenue increased 18.4% in the period ending June 30 to $49.9 million from $42.1 million a year earlier. The company noted the strength of its passenger-charter business in the latest quarter, where revenue jumped more than doubled to $8.5 million due to an 82% increase in hours flown and the benefit of additional aircraft. Mossimo shares jump; growth at Target lifts earns (9:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Mossimo Inc. MOSS rose 22.5% to $5.61 in early trades on Friday. The move comes after the Santa Monica, Calif., apparel and footwear design and distribution company reported second-quarter earnings of $2.2 million, or 14 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $1 million, or 6 cents a share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus profit estimate for the company's results. Revenue increased in the latest three months to $9 million from $6.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said its performance in the latest quarter got a lift from the growth of its brand at Target TGT, +0.36% stores, in particular its women's black label and red label, women's shoes, men's wovens and bottoms all performed well. Vina Concha y Toro posts lower quarterly profit (9:31 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Wine producer Vina Concha y Toro VCO, +1.49% on Friday reported second-quarter net earnings of 6.4 million Chilean pesos ($11.1 million) compared with 7.5 million Chilean pesos a year ago. On a per-share basis, earnings were 77 cents per American Depositary Share, down from 80 cents per ADS last year. Revenue was 51.8 million Chilean pesos, up from 47.7 million Chilean pesos in the year-ago period. The company cited, in part, the impact of higher prices for grapes for the lower profit results. FirstBank NW Corp. net income rises 19% (9:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FirstBank NW Corp. FBNW on Friday said first-quarter net income rose 19% to $1.9 million, or 62 cents share, up from $1.6 million, or 52 cents a share, last year. One analyst surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 55 cents a share. Shares closed unchanged at $28.24 on Thursday. CORRECT: Imperial Industries down 24% in pre-market trades (9:00 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Shares of Imperial Industries IPII plunged 24% to $21.85 in pre-market trading on Instinet Friday. The move comes after the Pompano Beach, Fla., building products company reported second-quarter earnings of $1 million, or 40 cents a share, up slightly from a profit of $974,000, or 40 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales in the quarter rose 17.9% to $17.4 million from $14.8 million in the same period a year ago. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's performance. Imperial Industries noted its latest results reflect a tax rate of 35.9%, higher than the rate of 26.5% in last year's equivalent period. (A previous version of this item included incorrect tax rates for the quarterly periods.) Ameritrade average client trades rise in July (8:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Ameritrade Holding Corp. AMTD, +3.49% on Friday reported 144,000 average client trades a day in July, up from 135,000 in the year-ago period. As of July 29, qualified accounts totaled 1.74 million. The company opened 23,000 and closed 14,000 accounts during July, resulting in 3.7 million total accounts. Shares rose 5 cents to $20.17 on Thursday. Knight Capital Group July avg. volume up 15.7% from yr-ago (8:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Knight Capital Group's NITE, +2.00% July average volume was 768,000, up 15.7% from the year-ago figure of 664,000 and up 0.9% from 761,000 in June. Average daily dollar value traded was $7.32 billion, up 0.6% from $7.28 billion in June and up 38.4% from the $5.29 billion in the year-ago period. Shares of Knight Capital rose 12 cents to $7.86 on Thursday. Genworth Financial registers GE stake for sale w/ SEC (8:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Genworth Financial Inc. GNW, +1.07% said early Friday that it's filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to cover any future sales of 243.2 million shares of its common stock currently held by an affiliate of General Electric GE, -1.46% Richmond, Va.-based Genworth said the statement was filed in response to GE's stated plan to reduce its 52% stake in Genworth in an orderly manner over the next two years. Genworth shares rose 1.5% to close at $31.32 on Thursday. Taser says wrongful death suit dismissed (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR on Friday said the Superior Court of the State of Arizona ordered the dismissal with prejudice of Taser International from a wrongful death lawsuit. Dismissal with prejudice by the court prevents the plaintiff from refiling any claim against Taser resulting from the death. "We are very pleased," the company said. Shares fell 16 cents to $8.44 on Thursday. Hansen Natural: No unusual incentives to Dr Pepper/Seven-Up (7:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Hansen Natural Corp., HANS the Corona, Calif., beverage producer, identified a major customer group referred to in its Securities and Exchange Commission Form 10-Q as Dr. Pepper/Seven-Up Bottling Group Inc. Hansen said it has boosted its business with this group substantially as sales of the company's Monster Energy drinks increased and as it allocated more territory to the customer group. Hansen, responding to what it called "unfounded speculation" that may have confused some investors, said it offered no unusual incentives, return rights, or extended credit terms to Dr Pepper/Seven Up. Hansen also said it did not pressure the customer to buy more product than it needed. And it said promotional costs in the quarter were appropriate. Hansen shares fell 75 cents, or 1.7%, on Thursday to $42.62. Cogent Communications loss of 47 cents vs $29.51 loss (7:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Cogent Communications Group Inc. COI, -0.77% said Friday that its loss for the second quarter was $16.1 million, or 47 cents a share. In the same period a year ago Cogent lost $22.2 million, or $29.51 a share. Common shares outstanding in the period were 34,489,085 compared with 753,130 for the year-ago period. The company said service revenue for the period grew 66% to $33.8 million. Cogent shares rose 30 cents on Thursday to $7.41. GTSI Corp. July sales, booking decline (7:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- GTSI Corp. GTSI reported July sales of $45.5 million, down 49% from $89.5 million in the same period a year ago. Bookings fell 9.8% to $72.5 million from last year's $107.5 million, while backlog at month end totaled $156.1 million. Shares of the information technology product company closed Thursday up 11 cents at $7.36. ECC Capital 2Q loss $38.7M vs profit $11.9M (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ECC Capital Corp. ECR, +5.88% Friday reported a second-quarter loss of $38.7 million, or 40 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $11.9 million, or 28 cents a share. On a core basis, excluding the effects of hedging losses taken against income, the company lost $14.4 million, or 15 cents a share, in the June period. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of a penny a share in the latest quarter. The stock closed Thursday at $5.93, up 5.1%. Movie Gallery misses Wall St. earnings view (7:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Movie Gallery Inc. MOVI Friday reported a loss of $12.2 million, or 39 cents a share, for the second quarter, down from a year-ago profit of $10.6 million, or 32 cents a share. Excluding items, the Dothan, Ala., movie rental company earned $4.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the June period. Revenue rose to $504.7 million in the latest three months from $189.6 million in the same period a year earlier with the increase reflecting the company's acquisition of Hollywood Entertainment Corp. in April. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 51 cents a share in the latest quarter on revenue of $528.5 million. The company said its same-store revenue in both rural and urban markets declined more than expected due to what it termed "the worst box-office slump in more than two decades," resulting in a drop of 5.5% for the quarter. The stock closed Thursday at $21.36, up 1.7%. Metretek quarterly net profit, sales rise (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Energy measurement products provider Metretek Technologies, Inc. MEK, +9.09% reported second-quarter net income of $934,000, or 7 cents a share. In the same period a year ago, the company posted net income of $42,000, or a per-share loss of 7 cents. Revenue for the quarter climbed 66% to $14 million. U-Store-It's quarterly same-store revenue up 6.8% (6:14 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- U-Store-It Trust YSI reported second-quarter net income of $2.2 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $33.8 million. Two analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call who follow the real-estate investment trust had expected U-Store-It to earn 7 cents a share on revenue of $35 million, on average. The company went public last October; its predecessor company ran a loss of $1.2 million on revenue of $21.2 million in the 2004 second quarter. Same-store revenue rose 6.8% to $22.7 million, U-Store-It said. The company also chalked up funds from operations of $10.6 million, or 28 cents a share, for the latest quarter. Average occupancy for the 12 months ended June 30 was 84.0%, U-Store-It said. The company acquired 38 facilities over the first half of 2005. Shares of U-Store-It fell 5 cents on Thursday to end trading at $19.90. European shares open mostly higher, BA dips in London (3:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- European shares opened generally higher on Friday, as a positive end to trading in U.S. markets overnight and some well-received corporate earnings in a day of scarce news provided upside. German steelmaker ThyssenKrupp(DE:750000)shares added 1.5% after third-quarter continuing pretax profit beat market expectations and the company outlined guidance for the year. Overall, the German DAX Xetra index added 0.4% to trade at 4,971.05. The FTSE 100 index in the U.K. added 0.2% to trade at 5,367.30, with airline BA BAB, +0.74% (UK:BAB)1.6% lower after strikes forced flight cancellations. French CAC-40 shares were trading 0.2% lower at 4,500.13 amid data which showed GDP slowed to 0.1% in the second quarter of 2005. Julius Baer profit up 15% as assets under management rise (2:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss private bank Julius Baer(ZZ:001208301)on Friday posted a stronger first-half profit rise than expected, up 15% to SFr130 million, after assets under management excluding its custody business rose 11% to SFr151 million. Institutional inflows of SFr9 billion and an investment performance lift of SFr12 billion offset the sale of Private Banking USA, which had assets of SFr5.5 billion. On the down side, higher bonus accruals due to the performance at its U.S. asset management unit helped push operating expenses up 23% to SFr462 million, and trading and sales operating income fell 22% to SFr70 million due to "unpredictable" stock and foreign exchange markets. The bank is looking at a "targeted and swift" expansion in Eastern Europe and Latin America and is looking to launch German private banking operations at the end of 2005. Thales H1 sales rise 3.8%, strong North America growth (2:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Defense contractor Thales(FR:012132)on Monday said first-half sales rose 3.8% to 4.748 billion euros, led by strong growth in France, North America and the aircraft systems division. Sales in France rose 7% to 1.285 billion euros; sales in North America climbed 16% to 415 million euros. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers AirNet Systems ANS, -4.23% jumped 19% after the Columbus, Ohio-based aviation services provider said its earnings rose to $2.1 million, or 20 cents a share, in the second quarter. In the comparable year-ago period AirNet lost $100,000, or 1 cent a share. Thomson First Call does not publish an estimate for AirNet's results. Revenue increased 18.4% in the three-month period ending June 30 to $49.9 million from $42.1 million a year earlier. The company noted the strength of its passenger-charter business in the latest quarter, where revenue jumped more than doubled to $8.5 million due to an 82% increase in hours flown and the benefit of additional aircraft. Shares of Central Parking Corp. C.PC, -0.16% gained 6.5% after the Nashville, Tenn., company said it's started a Dutch auction tender offer to buy up to 4.4 million shares of its common stock for between $14.40 and $16.75 each. The offer expires after the closing bell on Sept. 14. Shares of Cosi Inc. COSI leapt 13.5% after the Deerfield, Ill., restaurant operator lifted its same-store sales outlook for the full year to growth of 7% to 9% from a prior projection for growth of 4% to 5%. The company also forecast a narrower than expected loss for the year to 11 cents a share, narrower than its previous estimate for a loss of 14 to 18 cents a share. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a loss of 20 cents a share for the year. Cosi also said it expects positive earnings before items in fiscal 2006. DreamWorks Animation SKG DWA shares tacked on almost 3% after the company reaffirmed its diminished 2005 earnings forecast and said that it swung to a second-quarter loss amid weaker-than-expected DVD sales of "Shrek 2." See full story. Emulex Corp. ELX, -4.29% shares rallied almost 10% after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $25.3 million, or 28 cents a share. Last year, the storage networking hardware company reported a net loss of $572.9 million, or $6.97 a share. Pro forma per-share profit in the quarter was 30 cents vs. 18 cents a year ago. Revenue rose to $108.2 million from $86.4 million last year. Emulex expects fiscal first-quarter earnings of 16 cents to 18 cents a share, and 26 cents to 28 cents a share on a pro forma basis. It sees fiscal first-quarter revenue of $106 million to $110 million. Isle of Capri Casinos' ISLE shares added 2.6% after the company earned $4 million, or 13 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter, down from $10.6 million, or 35 cents a share, a year ago and 2 cents shy of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue came in at $281.5 million vs. $278.7 million last year. Shares of Knight-Ridder Inc. KRI, +0.26% leapt 4% after the San Jose, Calif., newspaper publisher disclosed plans to buy back 10 million shares of common stock in the next six to nine months. As part of this effort, the company repurchased 5 million shares of its common stock from Goldman Sachs for an upfront payment of about $312 million, or $62.36 a share. Leap Wireless International LEAP shares rose 5.9% after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Last year, the company posted a loss of $18.3 million, or 31 cents a share. Revenue rose to $226.8 million in the latest three months, up from $205.7 million a year ago. The San Diego-based wireless communication services provider raised the top end of its fiscal 2005 revenue forecast to a range of $910 million to $950 million, from $890 million to $950 million. It also raised its 2005 adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization forecast to a range of $265 million and $285 million, from $245 million to $270 million. Metretek Technologies MEK, +9.09% jumped 11.1% after the company reported second-quarter net income of $934,000, or 7 cents a share. In the same period a year ago, the company posted earnings of $42,000, or a per-share loss of 7 cents. Revenue for the quarter climbed 66% to $14 million. Shares of Mossimo Inc. MOSS gained 18% after the Santa Monica, Calif., apparel and footwear design and distribution company reported second-quarter earnings of $2.2 million, or 14 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $1 million, or 6 cents a share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus profit estimate for the company's results. Revenue increased in the latest three months to $9 million from $6.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said its performance in the latest quarter got a lift from the growth of its brand at Target TGT, +0.36% stores, in particular its women's black label and red label, women's shoes, men's wovens and bottoms all performed well. Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% surged 5.7% after the company reported second-quarter net income soared behind stronger sales and tight cost controls. See full story. Shares of Sohu.com SOHU, +4.07% jumped 9% after Charles Zang, the company's chairman and CEO, increased his beneficial stake in the Beijing-based online media company. Zang exercised options to purchase 27,344 shares of the company's stock on August 4 and another 105,625 shares on August 9. Also, Photon Group Ltd., a company where Zhang is a director, bought 50,000 shares on August 4 and 100,000 shares on August 8. These purchases brought Zang's stake to roughly 9.7 million, or 26.7%, including 7.9 million shares benenficially owned by Photon Group Ltd. Shares of Spirent SPM, -2.87% added 6.8% after UBS upgraded the shares to buy from neutral. UBS said the prospect of material contract wins in service assurance and the potential disposal of the networks product business could be significant catalysts over the next 12 months. Taser International TASR shares gained 7.6% after the stun gun maker said the Superior Court of the State of Arizona ordered the dismissal with prejudice of Taser International from a wrongful death lawsuit. Dismissal with prejudice by the court prevents the plaintiff from re-filing any claim against Taser resulting from the death. "We are very pleased," the company said. Telephone & Data Systems TDS, +0.29% shares rose 2.6% after the company received an upgrade to buy from Merrill Lynch. Whirlpool WHR, +1.28% shares tacked on 3.2% following a report that Maytag's MYG, -4.17% board is poised to formally throw its support behind) $21 per share acquisition offer, Reuters said. Friday's report said Maytag's board plans to publicly declare Whirlpool's $1.7 billion bid superior to a competing offer of $1.13 billion from a group led by Ripplewood Holdings unless the Ripplewood group responds with a counter-offer by 2 p.m. ET. Maytag shares edged up less than 1%. Whitehall Jewellers JWL shares rose 6% after the company named Beryl Raff as chief executive officer. Raff will also join the Chicago-based company's board. Lucinda Baier, who had served as interim CEO after the death of Hugh Patinkin earlier this year, will continue to serve as president and chief operating officer. Raff previously was senior vice president and general merchandise manager of fine jewelry at J.C. Penney JCP, -0.98% . Decliners Analog Devices ADI, +1.36% shares fell 3% after the company said its fiscal third-quarter profit sank 28% as revenue slumped on weaker sales of digital-signal processor products to wireless handset customers in Asia. The company earned $121.4 million, or 32 cents a share, down from $169.1 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue fell 19% to $582.4 million from $717.8 million. Analysts expected the company to earn 31 cents a share on revenue of $583.2 million. Looking ahead, Analog Devices forecast fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 32 cents to 34 cents a share, in line with the analyst estimate for earnings of 33 cents a share. Axcan Pharma AXCA shares lost 12.8% after the company reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $4.1 million, or 9 cents a share, a 67% decrease from $12.6 million, or 25 cents a share, last year. Pro forma earnings were $3 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue fell 4.2% to $59.4 million from $62 million a year ago. The company attributed its lower sales to a decline in U.S. wholesaler inventory levels of its products. Cree Inc. CREE, +1.87% shares tumbled 9.5% after the company said its earnings remained flat in its fiscal fourth quarter, despite a 9% gain in revenue over the previous year. Earnings were $21 million, or 27 cents a share, compared to earnings of $21 million, or 28 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenue rose to $98.9 million from $90.9 million last year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $100.6 million. The semiconductor company also forecast earnings and revenue for the first fiscal quarter that are below analysts' estimates. Separately, Cree said its chief financial officer plans to step down. Dell Inc. DELL shares dropped 8.4% after the No. 1 personal computer company posted in-line earnings for the second quarter but gave a weak outlook for the third quarter. See full story. Shares of First Marblehead Corp. FMD fell 2.7% after the provider of outsourcing services for educational lenders topped Wall Street profit expectations for its fourth-quarter results by a nickel but disappointed with its loan volumes. After Thursday's closing bell, Boston-based First Marblehead posted earnings of $43 million, or 65 cents a share, for the June quarter on total service revenue of $120.2 million. The company's private label loan facilitation volume totaled $434 million for the quarter, an increase of 33% from $328 million in the comparable year-ago period. Friedman Billings Ramsey, however, was looking for loan volume of $493 million in the quarter and the firm lowered its price target on the stock to $36 from $40 in the wake of the report. "Despite surprising earnings on the upside, we believe the stock is likely to remain pressured, as investors still lack clarity into volumes for the all-important September quarter," the firm told clients. Hewlett-Packard Co. HPQ, +1.06% shares dipped 1.7% after the company moved to expand its capabilities in large-scale printing technologies by saying it would acquire the assets of Scitex Vision SCIX, +0.24% for $230 million. See full story. Shares of Imperial Industries IPII tumbled 20% after the Pompano Beach, Fla., building products company reported second-quarter earnings of $1 million, or 40 cents a share, up slightly from a profit of $974,000, or 40 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales in the quarter rose 17.9% to $17.4 million from $14.8 million in the same period a year ago. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's performance. Imperial Industries noted its latest results reflect a tax rate of 35.9%, higher than the rate of 26.5% in last year's equivalent period. InfraSource Services IFS, +0.75% shares fell 3.8% after the company said its second-quarter loss narrowed to $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, from $2 million, or 6 cents a share, the prior year. On an adjusted basis, the loss was $0.2 million, down from $3.9 million a year ago. Revenues increased to $231.7 million, compared to $143.3 million last year, after growth in each of the company's electric, natural gas, and telecommunication end markets. Jamdat Mobile Inc. JMDT lost 24% after the wireless video game publisher reported second-quarter revenue that rose 128% from the same period last year, but gave a weaker-than-expected third-quarter forecast. See full story. Jones Apparel JNY shares slid 1.7% after the company was downgraded by Goldman Sachs to underperform from in-line. The firm cited eroding margins at the company due to poor execution and exposure to large department stores. Shares of McDonald's MCD, -1.28% fell 4.3% in late action. The move comes after the Oak Brook, Ill.-based hamburger maker's shares jumped Thursday amid reported speculation that Vornado Realty Trust VNO, -0.33% is interested in the company's vast real-estate holdings. Analysts said it's not likely McDonald's would ever sell its properties. Shares of Midwest Express Holdings MEH, +0.44% tumbled 12/5% after Robert W. Baird lowered its rating on the company to underperform from neutral, saying rising fuel costs are hampering efforts to preserve cash in the airline industry. The firm said it expects Midwest to burn about $10 million of its unrestricted cash balance of $81 million by the end of the year. Baird added that "industry conditions create uncertainty about the sustainability of the premium service business model and the survival of the company. Shares of Movie Gallery MOVI slumped 8.9% after the company reported a loss of $12.2 million, or 39 cents a share, for the second quarter, down from a year-ago profit of $10.6 million, or 32 cents a share. Excluding items, the Dothan, Ala., movie rental company earned $4.3 million, or 13 cents a share, in the June period. Revenue rose to $504.7 million in the latest three months from $189.6 million in the same period a year earlier with the increase reflecting the company's acquisition of Hollywood Entertainment Corp. in April. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 51 cents a share in the latest quarter on revenue of $528.5 million. The company said its same-store revenue in both rural and urban markets declined more than expected due to what it termed "the worst box-office slump in more than two decades," resulting in a drop of 5.5% for the quarter. Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% shares slid 2% after the company said slumping sales of both merchandise and service dragged down its results in the second quarter. The auto parts retailer said Thursday that on a continuing operations basis, it earned just $832,000, or a penny a share, on the period. That is down from $13.5 million and 22 cents a year ago and far below the 11-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue came in at $577.4 million, down nearly 3% while same-store sales fell 2.5%. Red Robin Gourmet Burgers RRGB, -0.51% shares sank 20.5% after Michael Snyder resigned as chairman, chief executive and president amid a travel-expense probe. See full story. Stereotaxis STXS, +0.75% shares fell 10% after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $11.5 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with a loss of $8.4 million, or $5.46 a share, last year. The number of shares used in computing the period's net loss was 27.3 million, compared with 1.5 million a year ago. Revenue rose 57% to $6.1 million from $3.9 million last year. The St. Louis manufacturer of cardiology instrument control systems forecast 2005 revenue of $22 million to $26 million, citing a delay in an expected approval from the Food and Drug Administration of three catheters. Analysts expect revenue of $32 million and a loss of 97 cents a share. Weight Watchers International WTW, +1.51% shares gave back 3% after the company reported second-quarter net earnings of $34.5 million, or 33 cents a share, down 35% from $52.9 million, or 49 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding charges related to its acquisition of the remaining portion of WeightWatchers.com, the company would have reported second-quarter earnings of $60.4 million, or 58 cents a share. Second-quarter revenue rose to $312.6 million from $264.9 million a year ago. The weight loss management company also said it now sees fiscal 2005 earnings of $1.91 to $1.98 a share, excluding transaction-related expenses. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect earnings of $1.93 a share on sales of $1.08 billion. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: Pre-open moves U.S. stocks looked set for a weaker open after disappointing sales at No. 1 computer maker Dell, yet another record-high price for oil and as the U.S. trade deficit widened more than expected by 6.1% in June to $58.8 billion. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets Markets in Europe weakened as crude continued its rally, French GDP came in below expectations and labor strife grounded British Airways flights from London's Heathrow airport. Japan's Nikkei ended flat after GDP growth there disappointed. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Dell Inc. DELL was downgraded to in line from outperform at Goldman Sachs, which said the lack of revenue acceleration and margin expansion makes the PC maker too dependent on stock buybacks to achieve earnings growth. Piper Jaffray lowered its price target for Dell Inc. to $42 from $48, while Lehman Bros. reiterated its overweight rating and recommended investors use any weakness in the stock to add to positions. Goldman Sachs cut Citizens Communications Co. CZN, +8.33% to in line from outperform. The broker said there are more attractive alternatives in the telecom sector, and highlighted Sprint Corp. FON, +5.56% as its top pick. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Crude-oil contracts continued their upward path, blazing a new trail to $66.13 a barrel. Traders noted an unusual occurrence in London's Brent crude-oil market of the September contract trading at a premium to the October contract, indicating market tightness. Crude breached $66 a barrel and gasoline futures neared $2 a gallon Thursday after a lower estimate of non-OPEC supply for the year and continued strong U.S. demand for unleaded gas. Taser International Inc. TASR said the Superior Court of the State of Arizona ordered the dismissal with prejudice of Taser International from a wrongful death lawsuit. Dismissal with prejudice by the court prevents the plaintiff from refiling any claim against Taser resulting from the death. "We are very pleased," the company said. Billionaire investor Carl Icahn and several hedge funds are expected to make their plans public as early as Friday for improving the performance of Time Warner Inc. TWX, +0.40% the Los Angeles Times reported. Wall Street sources told the newspaper that Icahn was preparing to inform the Securities and Exchange Commission in a filing that he had assembled a group of Time Warner shareholders holding more than 5% of the company's stock. In the filing, Icahn is expected to call for Time Warner to expand a stock buyback plan by $10 billion to $20 billion and to radically reduce its costs. Verizon Wireless, the U.S. mobile operator owned by Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% and Vodafone Group VOD, +0.54% had a flaw in its online billing system that could have allowed customers to view account information on other customers, the Washington Post reported on its Web site. Verizon Wireless said the problem appeared to be limited to accounts for some customers in the eastern United States. There is no indication that anyone took advantage of the flaws or that any customer financial information was disclosed, the report added. The glitch has been fixed. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Time Warner, Taser, Verizon in the spotlight

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr on Friday said the Superior Court of the State of Arizona ordered the dismissal with prejudice of Taser International from a wrongful death lawsuit. Dismissal with prejudice by the court prevents the plaintiff from refiling any claim against Taser resulting from the death. "We are very pleased," the company said. Shares fell 16 cents to $8.44 on Thursday.
title: Taser says wrongful death suit dismissed

content: Coming up on MarketWatch Weekend, July 30-31 NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The market for organic products is soaring -- expected to reel in $14.5 billion this year, and spike to $20 billion by 2007. Can supply of a niche product keep up with mainstream demand? Recently an organic milk shortage highlighted the issue. Stacey Delo takes a look at whether supply can keep up with a quickly growing demand. Airline stocks: Ready for takeoff or landing? There's a shiny new American Airlines terminal at New York's JFK airport -- a $1.1 billion investment in the future of the airline. And there's been a recent string of decent earnings from the major carriers, including American AMR, -4.53% Continental CAL, -0.62% and America West AWA, -1.82% But U.S. airlines have lost more than $32 billion dollars over the past five years. And with fuel prices soaring, there's potential for more red-ink. Paul Lin takes a closer look at where the airline industry is headed. Reality Check If you're attracted to the stock of Parlux Fragrances PARL because of its sweet-smelling Paris Hilton perfume ... you might want to know why Herb Greenberg is holding his nose. Defense stocks With acts of terrorism plaguing many parts of the world, U.S. investors are snatching up shares of security technology companies like Taser TASR and L-3 Communications LLL, +2.65% Jean Lee tells us why defense stocks are proving to be the big guns on Wall Street, and also how they can also be risky business. Home assets Have you ever thought of borrowing against your home to invest in the stock market or boost your real estate portfolio? MarketWatch contributor Jennifer Openshaw says there are ways to build wealth by using your home, but it's not for everyone. Find out where to watch the show. View previous show segments. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Can supply of organic products match demand?

content: Tom McIntyre, head of the investment firm McIntyre, Freedman & Flynn, tells Chuck Jaffe that many of today's most popular investment names have reached a point where investors looking to ride the wave could end up buying high and selling low. loading... More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000
title: McIntyre: Avoid popular names

content: Overnite Corp quarterly profit rises 37% (7:06 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Overnite Corp. OVNT after Wednesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $23.1 million, or 82 cents a share, a gain of 37% from $16.8 million, or 60 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Richmond, Va.-based transportation company was $470.6 million, compared with $418.5 million last year. United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, +1.93% agreed to acquire Overnite on May 16 for $1.25 billion. Overnite shareholders will vote on the deal Aug. 4. FormFactor quarterly profit falls 26% (5:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FormFactor Inc. FORM, +1.11% after Wednesday's closing bell reported second-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 12 cents a share, down 26% from $6.8 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the Livermore, Ca.-based maker of semiconductor wafer probe cards was $52.3 million, compared with $43.2 million last year. Owens-Illinois 2Q profit rises 4.4%; rev up 31% (5:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Owens-Illinois Inc. OI, +1.59% Wednesday evening reported second-quarter earnings of $86.2 million, or 53 cents a share, a rise of 4.4% from $82.6 million, or 52 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 31% to $1.85 billion from $1.42 billion a year ago, the glass container and plastics packager said. F5 Networks quarterly profit surges 88% (5:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- F5 Networks Inc. FFIV, +1.40% after Wednesday's closing bell reported third-quarter earnings of $14 million, or 35 cents a share, a gain of 88% from $7.4 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $73.1 million from $44.2 million last year. The Seattle-based company forecast fourth-quarter net earnings of 29 cents to 30 cents a share on revenue of $76 million to $78 million. Excluding a compensation charge, the company sees earnings in the range of 37 cents to 38 cents a share. Global Payments board OKs 2-for-1 stock split (5:23 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Global Payments Inc. GPN, +1.31% said after Wednesday's closing bell that its board approved a 2-for-1 stock split, increasing the outstanding shares to 78 million from 39 million. The electronic transaction processing services provider expects the shares from the split to be distributed on Oct. 28. Molina cuts 2005 view, sees 2Q loss on higher med costs (5:05 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Molina Healthcare MOH, +2.64% after Wednesday's closing bell warned that it expects to report a second-quarter loss of 15 cents to 20 cents a share because of higher medical costs. It also cut its 2005 earnings forecast to a range of 73 cents to 80 cents a share from its previous view of $2.40 to $2.45 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call currently expect the Long Beach, Calif.-based company to report a second-quarter profit of 56 cents a share and a 2005 profit of $2.49 a share. Cirrus Logic swings to quarterly profit (4:46 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Analog and digital chipmaker Cirrus Logic Inc. CRUS, +3.31% after Wednesday's closing bell reported second-quarter net earnings of $26 million, or 30 cents a share. Last year, it reported a loss of $3.4 million, or 4 cents a share. Pro forma earnings for the period were 5 cents a share. Revenue was $52.8 million, down from $59.1 million a year ago. Cirrus Logic expects to take a second-quarter charge of $4 million to $5 million as it exits its digital video product-line facility in Fremont, Calif. The charge will be partially offset by a gain of $1.5 million on the sale of the digital video assets. Cirrus Logic also forecast second-quarter sales of $45 million to $47 million from its core products. AT&T profit improves on cost cuts (4:44 PM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - Long-distance giant AT&T Corp. said Wednesday that second-quarter profit nearly tripled, aided by continued cost reductions and efforts to improve the way the company operates. The famed phone company long known as Ma Bell, which is set to be acquired by SBC Communications Inc., said it earned $307 million, or 38 cents a share. That jumped from net income of $108 million, or 14 cents a share, in the comparable 2004 quarter. Sales fell to $6.76 billion from $7.64 billion. Excluding one-time costs, AT&T T, +0.25% said it would have earned 62 cents a share, exceeding the 53-cent consensus of analysts as surveyed by Thomson First Call. VeriSign net rise 88%, sales up 74% (4:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Verisign Inc. said second-quarter net income rose to $41.3 million, or 15 cents a share, up from $21.9 million, or 9 cents, a year ago. Sales surged 74% to $445 million. Excluding certain items, VeriSign reported earnings of 27 cents a share. VeriSign shares fell more than 5% in late trading after the results were released. Redback Networks quarterly loss narrows (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Redback Networks Inc. RBAK after Wednesday's closing bell reported a second-quarter net loss of $7.2 million, or 13 cents a share, vs. a net loss of $10.7 million, or 20 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue at the San Jose, Calif.-based provider of broadband networking systems was $34.6 million, compared with $32.3 million a year ago. On a pro forma basis the company reported a loss of 5 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been looking for a per-share loss of 8 cents. Qlogic Corp. earnings rise 30% to $41.8 million (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Qlogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% on Wednesday reported a first-quarter profit of $41.8 million, or 45 cents a share, compared to $32.2 million, or 34 cents a share a year ago. Revenue climbed to $158.8 milion from $129.8 million. The maker of storage connectivity technology beat the estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, who forecast a profit of 43 cents a share on $156 million in revenue. Airlines shares end higher as earnings roll in (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% and AMR Corp. AMR, -4.53% both closed higher Wednesday after posting stronger than expected second-quarter results. Ahead of Thursday's financial reports, Alaska Air Group rose 5% to $34.22 and JetBlue Airways JBLU, +0.74% added 2.1% to $22.80. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% which announced a new top finance executive on Wednesday, will also report Thursday; shares rose 1% to $3.91 ahead of the report. Broadly, the Amex Airline Index $XAL rose 2.5% to 53.37 points. Profit climbs 26% at Lam Research (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Lam Research Corp. LRCX, +3.54% the No. 3 U.S. chip tool maker, late Wednesday reported second-quarter net income rose to $66.5 million, or 47 cents a share, up from $52.7 million, or 38 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales climbed over 7% to $353.8 million. The results topped Wall Street's expectations for earnings of 44 cents on revenue of $349 million. Ahead of the report, shares of Lam Research closed at $32.55, up 4.7%. Allstate quarterly profit rises above analyst forecasts (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Allstate Corp. said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income rose 11% to $1.15 billion, or $1.71 per share, from $1.03 billion, or $1.47 a share, a year earlier. Operating income, which excludes one-time items such as realized investment gains and losses, came in at $1.12 billion, or $1.66 per share, up from $1.04 billion, or $1.47 a share, a year ago, the second-largest U.S. property and casualty insurer said. That topped the average estimate of 21 analysts in a Thomson First Call survey, who were expecting operating profit of $1.51 a share. Allstate also lifted its full-year 2005 operating income target to a range of $6 to $6.40 per share and warned that fixed annuity sales may decline temporarily until the interest-rate environment improves. Ryland Group profit up 36% in second quarter (4:26 PM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Ryland Group Inc. RYL said net income in the second quarter was $104.3 million, or $2.10 a share, versus $76.5 million, or $1.51 a share last year. Wall Street analysts had forecast earnings of $1.80 a share. Shares of Ryland Group gained $1.76 to $83.13 on Wednesday. Hub Group profit rises, 2005 outlook affirmed (4:24 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Hub Group Inc. HUBG, +2.45% reported second-quarter net income after the market closed Wednesday of $7.9 million, or 38 cents a share, compared with $4.1 million or 24 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 32 cents a share. Revenue at the freight shipping company grew 6.5% to $371.6 million. Hub also said it was "comfortable" with analysts' estimates of 2005 earnings at $1.35 to $1.45 a share. Shares of Hub Group gained $1.13 Wednesday to $26.22. Oakley profit beats estimates; lifts fiscal view (4:23 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Oakley Inc. OO said late Wednesday that second-quarter profit rose 27% to $20.3 million, or 30 cents a share, from $15 million, or 23 cents, a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast earnings of 26 cents a share. Sales for the period ended June 30 increased 11% to $170.5 million from $153.8 million in last year's second quarter. The better-than expected results led the Foothill Ranch, Calif., maker of sports sunglasses to raise its fiscal 2005 outlook. Earnings are now targeted to grow at the high end of a 25% to 30% range over last year's results, up from the company's previous view for a 15% to 20% gain. Shares in Oakley closed up 25 cents at $16.95. Qualcomm profit up 15% as revenue edges higher (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% on Wednesday after the closing bell posted a fiscal third-quarter net profit $560 million, or 33 cents a share, up 15% from the comparable period a year ago. Not counting one-time items and results from its QSI investment arm, Qualcomm would have earned $465 million, or 28 a share. That surpasses the 25-cent consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 2% to $1.36 billion, excluding QSI. Looking ahead, the San Diego-based company forecast profit from operations of 30 cents a share, matching its existing outlook. Washington Mutual reports 73% jump in net income (4:20 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Washington Mutual on Wednesday said second quarter net income rose 73% to $844 million, or 95 cents a share, up from $489 million, or 55 cents a share, for the same period last year. The Seattle, Wash.-based thrift was expected to earn 83 cents a share, according to survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares of WaMu rose 73 cents to finish at $41.73. Capital One quarterly net rises 30% (4:17 PM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) -- Capital One Financial Corp. COF, +1.64% said after the closing bell Wednesday that quarterly profit was $531.1 million, or $2.03 a share, compared with $407.4 million, or $1.65 a share in the year-ago period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected per-share earnings of $1.75. Shares of Capital One lost 21 cents to close $81.05 on Wednesday. EBay grows second-quarter sales by 40% (4:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- EBay EBAY, +0.32% said late Wednesday that second-quarter revenue rose 40%, as the online marketplace operator saw an acceleration in its U.S. and online payment service. Macromedia profit rises 17.4% on higher revenue (4:16 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Macromedia Inc. MACR, +0.00% on Wednesday said its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 17.4% to $15.2 million, or 19 cents a share, from $13 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the period increased 12.8% to $116.8 million from $103.6 million. Excluding one-time items like charges related to its planned acquisition by Adobe Systems Inc. ADBE, +1.67% Macromedia would have earned $18.1 million, or 22 cents a share. Wall Street analysts, on average, had anticipated a profit of 21 cents a share on revenue of $114.1 million for the period ended June 30, according to a Thomson First Call survey. Torchmark quarterly profit rises in line with forecasts (4:12 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Life insurer Torchmark Corp. said late Wednesday that second-quarter net income rose 13% to $132 million, or $1.25 per share, from $117 million, or $1.04 a share, a year earlier. Operating income, which excludes one-time items such as realized investment gains and losses, came in at $121 million, or $1.14 per share, up from $119 million, or $1.05 a share a year ago, the Birmingham, Ala.-based company said. Fifteen analysts in a Thomson First Call survey expected Torchmark to earn $1.14 per share in the period. Knight Transp. profit rises 31%, matches estimates (4:10 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Knight Transportation Inc. KNX, +1.12% reported second-quarter net income Wednesday after the market closed of $15 million, or 26 cents a share, up from $11.4 million, or 20 cents a share in the year-ago period. The earnings matched analysts' average forecast from Thomson First Call for the trucking company. Revenue rose 25% to $133.9 million. Shares rose $1 Wednesday to $24.60. Tractor Supply second quarter net, sales higher (4:10 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Farm and ranch retailer Tractor Supply Co. TSCO, +5.03% said second quarter net income rose 15.3% to $35.8 million, or to 87 cents a share from 76 cents a share a year ago. Net sales rosed 16.6% to $613.2 million as same-store sales, a measure of sales at operations open at least a year, rose 5.9%. "We are pleased with the results of the spring selling season and are well prepared for the second half," the retailer said. E-Trade net slips (4:05 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Online financial services firm E-trade said Wednesday its second quarter net income slipped a bid from year ago levels due to a charge for discontinued operations and absent a nickels worth of gains it booked last year. The company's net income dipped to $101.6 million, or 27 cents per share compared to $122.9 million or 31 cents a share a year ago. On an operating basis, the company said net income rose to $108.2 million, or 29 cents a share compared to $102.8 million or 26 cents a share. The company's revenue rose to $391.3 million versus $381.5 million last year. The company also raised the low end of its 2005 earnings outlook. The firm said it expects to earn between 96 cents and $1.06 a share for the full year. E-Trade shares Pacific Continental quarterly profit rises 18% (2:42 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Pacific Continental Corp. PCBK on Wednesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $2.3 million, or 26 cents a share, up 18% from $1.9 million, or 22 cents a share, last year. Net interest income rose to $7.3 million from $6 million a year ago. The Medicines Co. slides as quarterly earns miss view (2:35 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of The Medicines Co. MDCO, -0.84% dropped 11.2% to $21.55 after the Parsippany, N.J., medical products provider reported second-quarter earnings of $1.3 million, or 2 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $2.8 million, or 6 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 7 cents a share in the June period. Cognex shares get lift from better than expected earns (2:30 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Cognex Corp. CGNX, +2.40% jumped 13% to $32.71 on Wednesday after the Natick, Mass., maker of machine vision systems for use in manufacturing posted second-quarter earnings of $7.8 million, or 17 cents a share, on revenue of $54.6 million. This performance was better than Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 16 cents a share on revenue of $49.8 million in the June period. Cognex said it saw higher sales to customers in the surface inspection and factory automation markets, strong revenue from its DVT Corp. acquisition, and improved margin in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 19 to 23 cents a share in the third quarter on revenue of between $57 million and $60 million. Align Tech shares off as earns miss Wall St. view (2:24 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Align Technology Inc. ALGN, +2.75% dropped about 11% to $6.25 after the Santa Clara, Calif., company posted second-quarter earnings of $538,000, or a penny a share, on revenue of $53.9 million. In the same period a year earlier, the developer of Invisalign, a method for straightening teeth without wires and brackets, posted earnings of $3.8 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $44.2 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 2 cents a share in the June period. Northern Trust CFO on EPS impact of FSG acquisition (1:33 PM ET) BOSTON (MarketWatch) - Northern Trust Corp.'s acquisition of Baring Asset Management's Financial Services Group, which closed March 31, is expected to reduce earnings per share by about 4 to 6 cents in 2005, the company said Wednesday. Next year, the acquisition will be "accretive by approximately eight cents," Steven Fradkin, Northern Trust's chief financial officer, said during a conference call on second-quarter earnings. CN ups 2005 EPS forecast, OKs new buyback program (12:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Canadian National Railway Co. CN, +2.33% on Wednesday increased its 2005 per-share earnings forecast, saying it now expects to report a profit 20% to 25% higher than C$4.34 a share in 2004. The company had previously forecast a 10% to 15% rise. CN reported second-quarter earnings of C$416 million, or C$1.47 a share, on revenue of C$1.84 billion, compared with C$326 million, or C$1.13 a share, on revenue of C$1.67 billion, last year. The railway also authorized a new share buyback program of 16 million shares, starting July 25 and running through July 24, 2006. GigaMedia tumbles in wake of quarterly earns (12:31 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of GigaMedia Ltd. GIGM, -0.35% dropped 15% to $2.26 on Wednesday after the Taiwan-based provider of broadband and entertainment products and services posted first-quarter earnings of $1 million, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $25.3 million. The performance was better than its year-ago loss of $775,000, or 2 cents a share, but it represents a sequential decline from the company's profit of $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $26.6 million in the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. RiT Tech shares rally on robust quarterly earns (12:04 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of RiT Technologies RITT, +0.00% rose 19.4% to $3.94 Wednesday at midday after the Israeli maker of network infrastructure-related products posted earnings of $511,000, or 3 cents a share, for the second quarter, up from a year-ago loss of $1.1 million, or 12 cents a share. Revenue soared 73% in the June period to $7 million from $4.1 million a year earlier. The company also lifted its outlook for 2005, forecasting 45% year-over-year revenue growth and a profit for the period. Synovus quarterly profit rises 22% (11:58 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Synovus Financial Corp. SNV, +1.18% on Wednesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $128.5 million, or 41 cents a share, a gain of 22% from $105.1 million, or 34 cents a share, a year ago. Net interest income at the Columbus, Ga.-based financial services holding company was $237.1 million compared with $210.5 million last year. Synovus increased its earnings-per-share growth forecast for 2005 to a range of 14% to 17%, from its previous view of 13% to 16%. Epicor shares rise after strong 46% revenue increase (11:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Epicor Software Corp. EPIC, +0.00% shares leapt 19% to $16.03 on Wednesday after the Irvine, Calif., business software company reported second-quarter adjusted earnings of $12.8 million, or 23 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $8 million, or 15 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 22 cents a share in the June period. Revenue jumped 46% in the latest three months to $71 million from $48.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Epicor lifted its outlook for the full year to earnings of 88 to 90 cents a share on revenue of $276 million to $284 million. Action Products 2Q sales slip, reaffirms FY sales view (11:43 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Action Products International Inc. APII, +2.51% on Wednesday reported second-quarter sales of $1.91 million compared with $1.94 million in the same period last year, but said it expects a stronger third quarter as a result of customers' decisions to combine some of their June orders with those of new products arrivals in July and August. The educational toymaker also reaffirmed its forecast for full-year sales growth of more than 10%.
