(Corrects to show that the tax charge is related to $2.7 billion in repatriated funds.) 21st Century Insurance Group net falls (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- 21st Century Insurance Group TW., -0.46% on Wednesday reported second-quarter net income of $20.5 million, or 24 cents a share, compared to $21.4 million, or 25 cents a share for the same period in 2004. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 24 cents a share for the Woodland Hills, Calif. company. "We found better opportunities for growth outside of California," the company said. Net premiums earned rose to $337 million, from $327 million. Shares rose 21 cents to $14.93 on Tuesday. IMS Health quarterly profit beats market expectations (7:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- IMS Health RX, +1.95% a provider of IT services to the pharmaceutical and healthcare sector, said second-quarter net income rose to $93.2 million, or 41 cents a share, from $65.1 million, or 27 cents, beating Thomson First Call broker estimates of 31 cents a share. Revenue rose 14% to $433.3 million, with double-digit revenue gains in the Americas, Europe and Asia Pacific. IMS Health agreed to be bought by Dutch media group VNU NV(NL:038987)in July. Ametek 2Q earnings, sales rise (7:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Ametek, Inc. AME, +1.36% the maker of electronic instruments and electric motors, said second-quarter net income rose 27% to $35.2 million, or 50 cents a share. Sales for the period climbed 16% to $352.1 million driven by strength in the company's aerospace and process businesses as well as contributions from acquisitions. Looking ahead, the company said it expects a low double-digit percentage increase in sales in the third quarter and earnings in the range of 48 cents to 50 cents a share. ChoicePoint Q2 tops estimates by a penny (7:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- ChoicePoint CPS, +1.40% said it earned 40 cents a share in the second quarter, unchanged from the same period a year ago. Excluding a 4 cents charge related to the costs of a fradulent data access case, the provider of I.D. and credential verification services earned 44 cents in the quarter, a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue climbed 15% to $266 million. Looking ahead, the company said it expects revenue to climb 16-19% in 2005, while margins come in the mid 25% to low 26% range. Shares closed Tuesday up 2.2% at $41.06. Martin Marietta Materials hikes quarterly outlook (7:24 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Martin Marietta Materials Inc. MLM, +2.73% said it's raised its second-quarter profit outlook. As revised, the manufacturer of construction products sees earnings in a range of $1.27 to $1.30 a share, higher than Wall Street's consensus of $1.09 as measured by Thomson First Call and 38% to 41% higher than last year's profit of 92 cents a share. The company previously had pegged earnings at 95 cents to $1.10 a share. The revised outlook mainly reflects "strong volume growth, pricing improvement and good costs control," the company said. Shares of Martin Marietta Materials, which is scheduled to report quarterly results on Aug. 1, rose 42 cents to end Tuesday's trading at $69. Journal Communications net eases on broadcast pressure (7:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Milwaukee-based media group Journal Communications JRN, +0.00% posted a 12.9% decline in second quarter net earnings to $18.1 million or to 24 cents a share, down from 25 cents a share a year ago amid pressure on broadcasting earnings. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call projected earnings per share of 23 cents for the June quarter. Revenue from continuing operations rose 1.4% to $194.7 million. Looking ahead, the group said it expects third quarter revenue from $186 million and $191 million and net earnings from $14 million and $16 million. The revenue outlook is line with the average estimate from analysts for the quarter at $190.60 million. Wyeth 2Q profit rises, tops forecast (7:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Pharmaceuticals company Wyeth WYE said second-quarter net income rose to $976.6 million or 72 cents a share, from $827.3 million, or 61 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The results topped the average forecast for earnings of 70 cents a share of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period climbed 12% to $4.7 billion, including the favorable impact of foreign exchange, thanks to strong sales of arthritis drug Embrel and antidepressant Effexor. Looking ahead, Wyeth reaffirmed its 2005 guidance for adjusted earnings in the range of $2.80 to $2.90 a share. United Tech earns, rev. rise above expectations (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- United Technologies UTX, +1.10% reported second-quarter earnings of $971 million, or 95 cents a share, up from $817 million, or 81 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time tax adjustment-related gains and restructuring costs, earnings would have been 86 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 85 cents. Revenue rose to $11.15 billion from last year's $9.62 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts of $10.93 billion. The diversified industrial and technology company expects 2005 earnings to $3 to $3.07 a share, surrounding analyst projections of $3.06. The stock, a component of the Dow industrials, closed Tuesday up 48 cents at $51.85. Altria lifts FY earns forecast by a nickel (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Altria MO, -0.21% Wednesday reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.91 billion, or $1.40 a share, a performance the Dow component said was in line with its expectations. In the same period a year earlier, the company earned $2.61 billion, or $1.26 a share, on the same basis. On a net basis, Altria earned $2.67 billion, or $1.28 a share, in the latest three months. Revenue rose 8.3% in the June quarter to $24.78 billion from $22.89 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.34 a share in the quarter. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings from continuing operations of $5 to $5.10 a share for the full year, 5 cents ahead of its prior projections. The stock closed Tuesday at $65.26, down 1%. Albemarle second-quarter profit beats Street view (7:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Specialty chemicals maker Albemarle Corp. ALB, +3.55% said second-quarter net income rose to $32 million, or 67 cents a share, from $20.8 million, or 49 cents, higher than Thomson First Call estimates of 59 cents a share. Sales rose to $502.8 million from $326.8 million, due in large part to its refinery catalysts business acquisition and "significant pricing improvement" across each of its business segments. JP Morgan swings to a profit (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, +1.82% on Wednesday reported second-quarter net income of $1 billion, or 28 cents a share, compared to a net loss of $500 million, or 27 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding charges, earnings were $2.3 billion, or 66 cents a share, up from $1.8 billion, or 85 cents a share, last year. CEO William B. Harrison Jr. said trading performance for the second quarter was "very weak." A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 64 cents a share. Shares fell 30 cents to $35.21 on Tuesday. Continental reports earns vs. year ago loss, tops ests. (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% reported second-quarter earnings of $100 million, or $1.26 a share, vs. a loss of $28 million, or 43 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding a non-recurring gain related to the contribution of ExpressJet shares to Continental's pension plan, earnings would have been 69 cents a share, exceeding the average estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 19 cents a share. Revenue rose 12% to $2.86 billion from last year's $2.55 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $2.77 billion. Load factor increased 2 percentage points to 79.6% amid an 8.3% rise in traffic and 5.5% growth in capacity. The air carrier's stock closed Tuesday up 62 cents at $15.70. Kodak ups job cut plans, reports loss vs year ago earns (7:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Eastman Kodak EK increased the number of jobs it planned to cut as part of its restructuring to 22,500 to 25,000 from 15,000 due to the faster-than-anticipated decline in consumer film sales. The company expects to reduce its manufacturing infrastructure to $1 billion vs. $2.9 billion in January 2004. The company also increased its estimate of the restructuring-related charges to $2.7 billion to $3 billion from $1.3 billion to $1.7 billion. Separately, Kodak reported a second-quarter loss of $146 million, or 51 cents a share, vs. a profit of $136 million, or 46 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations and other non-recurring items, earnings would have been 53 cents a share. Revenue rose 6% to $3.69 billion from last year's $3.46 billion, as a rise in graphic communications and health group sales offset a decline in digital and film imaging sales. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 80 cents a share and revenue of $3.63 billion, on average. The stock closed Tuesday up 46 cents at $28.74. Comerica's quarterly net rises 13% (6:58 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Comerica Inc. CMA, +1.76% reported second-quarter net income of $217 million, or $1.28 a share, up from $192 million, or $1.10 a share, earned in the year-ago period. The Detroit-based institution's quarterly net interest income rose to $483 million from $448 million, with net interest margin widening to 4.09% from 3.77%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Comerica to earn $1.12 a share for the latest quarter. Shares of Comerica rose $1.10, or 1.9%, to end at $60.07 in Tuesday's action. Pfizer 2nd-period net up 21%, beating consensus (6:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Pfizer Inc., PFE, +0.54% the New York pharmaceutical producer, reported that second-quarter net income rose 21%, beating analyst estimates, as revenue added 1%. Net for the member of the Dow Jones Industrial Average reached $3.46 billion, or 47 cents a share, from $2.86 billion, or 38 cents, in the year-earlier period. After special items, adjusted earnings were 46 cents a share. The consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 44 cents. Revenue rose to $12.43 billion from $12.27 billion. "Nine of Pfizer's top 10 products showed second-quarter growth" year over year, the company said. Pfizer said it made "significant progress" in a multi-year productivity initiative that it expects will save $400 million in 2005 and $4 billion annually by 2008. The company affirmed its 2005 estimate of adjusted earnings of $1.98 a share. First Call estimates $1.98. The company estimates double-digit growth in adjusted earnings for 2006 and "accelerating" double-digit growth in 2007. Pfizer shares rose 13 cents, or 0.5%, to $27.38 on Tuesday. Bank of New York's quarterly net rises 7.3% (6:47 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Bank of New York Co. BK, +1.82% reported second-quarter net income of $398 million, or 52 cents a share, up from $371 million, or 48 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Revenue reached $2.08 billion from the prior year's $1.78 billion, with securities servicing revenue rising by 8%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for Bank of New York to earn 50 cents a share in the latest quarter. Shares of Bank of New York added 16 cents to close at $29.74 on Tuesday. CIT Group 2nd-period net up 25%; return on equity rises (6:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- CIT Group Inc., CIT, -0.06% the New York commercial and consumer finance company, reported second-quarter net income increased 25%. Earnings reached $220.7 million, or $1.03 a share, from $176.6 million, or 82 cents, in the year-earlier quarter. Special items: CIT sold most of its business-aircraft portfolio for a pretax gain of $22 million, and it posted a $25.2 million pretax charge to reflect benefits for 200 employees the company dismissed. Return on tangible equity rose to 16.3% from 13.7%. Return on average earning assets was even at 1.86% for the quarter. For 2005, the company lifted its estimate of earnings growth to more than 20%. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call for 2005 is $4.04 against $3.35 in 2004, indicating an increase of almost 21%. Knight Capital says quarterly net loss narrows (6:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Financial services company Knight Capital Group Inc. NITE, +2.00% said the net loss in the second quarter narrowed to $4.21 million, or 4 cents a share, from $47.86 million, or 42 cents a share. The company recorded 4 cents a share in charges in the quarter due to real estate charges and a writedown of fixed assets, and 51 cents a share in charges for excess real estate capacity and writedowns in the second quarter of last year. Revenue slipped to $114.1 million from $140 million. "Miserable market conditions in April and May impacted profitability in both our equity markets and asset management businesses," it said. Jakks Pacific 2Q profit, sales rise (6:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Toymaker Jakks Pacific, Inc. JAKK, +5.00% said second-quarter net income rose to $11.6 million, or 39 cents a share, from $6 million, or 22 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period increased to $127.1 million from $109.4 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the company said it's comfortable with its 2005 guidance for earnings of $2.28 a share on sales of about $660 million. Orbital Sciences 2Q profit down, sales flat (6:09 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Space systems developer Orbital Sciences Corp. ORB, +9.85% said second-quarter net income fell to $7.6 million, or 12 cents a share, from $11.1 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding one-time items, the company would have posted earnings of 20 cents a share. Revenue for the period came in at $177.7 million compared to $177.4 million a year ago. Akzo Nobel quarterly profit up 22%, affirms '05 outlook (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dutch pharmaceuticals and chemicals group Akzo Nobel NV AKZOY, -1.20% (NL:00913)said net income for the second quarter rose 22% to 182 million euros, less than expectations for a rise to between 187 million and 212 million euros. Revenue from present operations added 6% to 3.35 billion euros, against forecasts of a 3% decline. Excluding one-off items and divestments, operating income declined 9% to 312 million euros, including a 25 million euro charge for the new labor agreement with Dutch unions. "Market conditions in Europe were difficult; Asia continues to be a growth story. Chemicals was impacted by higher energy prices and incidentals," it said. Akzo Nobel reiterated it sees 2005 net income within the range of 2004. Roche lifts operating margin view for pharma division (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Roche Holding RHHDY (ZZ:001203204)said it now believes 2005 operating margin in its pharmaceutical division will rise, after posting a 4% rise in first-half net profit at SFr3.24 billion, with sales rising 14% at SFr16.6 billion. Both profit and sales for the majority owner of Genentech DNA, -1.03% came in ahead of forecast. In pharmaceuticals, operating profit before exceptional items rose 28% to SFr3.6 billion, with sales up 19% to SFr12.7 billion, driven by cancer drugs Avastin and Tarceva, and the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu. In diagnostics, operating profit before exceptional items fell 3% to SFr904 million, hurt by marketing costs for the launch of new products, with sales up 2% to SFr3.97 billion. Gus says Q1 comp sales up at Experian, down at Argos (2:21 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. retailer Gus PLC(UK:GUS)on Wednesday said first-quarter sales at credit agency Experian rose 27% at constant exchange rates from the year-ago quarter. Argos same-store sales declined 4%; Homebase same-store sales for the four months to June 30 slipped 2%. Gus, which also has a 66% stake in Burberry Group PLC(UK:BRBY)said same-store sales at the luxury group rose 9% in the quarter at comparable exchange rates. Gus said that the demerger of its stake in Burberry would take place in December 2005 after Burberry's interim results. In addition, Gus said the retail environment in the U.K. remains "very challenging." More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr reported second-quarter earnings of $509,048, or a penny per share, down from $4.5 million, or 7 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 2 cents a share. Revenue fell to $13.2 million from $16.3 million. The company said expenses had increased significantly, especially for legal services and public education, as it defended its product safety record against what it believed was misleading public information. The stock closed Tuesday down 7 cents at $10.03.
title: Taser Int'l earns decline, miss expectations

content: Pre-open moves Share trading looked set for a stronger start as data showed U.S. consumer prices were unexpectedly flat in June, while retail sales rose 1.7%, above expectations. Strong results from Apple Computer and microchip maker Advanced Micro Devices and a broker upgrade for General Motor also gave a lift. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets Shares on Continental Europe gained as bourses embraced results from AMD and Apple. London shares were also stronger, with the focus on telecoms. Asian indexes ended generally higher. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action Lehman Brothers raised its price target on Internet search engine Google, Inc. GOOG, +2.71% to $350 from $275, saying it expects strong second-quarter earnings. The broker said its upgrade was based on Google's fundamental earnings power over the long term. Lehman Brothers upgraded car maker General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% to equal weight from underweight. It said with strong liquidity, defiantly strong results at GM's financial unit GMAC, and Kirk Kerkorian as a backstop, "the market is primed to buy into a multi-year automotive turnaround story." Lehman Brothers also raised its view on the auto and auto parts sector to neutral from negative. It upgraded Visteon Corp. VC, +2.18% to overweight from underweight. Credit Suisse First Boston raised its price target on mobile-phone maker Motorola, Inc. MSI, +1.29% to $23 from $21, saying it's confident market positioning, cost reductions and ongoing operating efficiencies will drive margin expansion this year. Credit Suisse First Boston cut insurer Prudential Financial, Inc. PRU, +0.63% to neutral from outperform, saying positive elements of the business are already reflected in the valuation See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Taser International Inc. TASR said a U.S. court had granted the company's request for a summary judgment dismissing claims in a wrongful death lawsuit. The lawsuit, Torres vs. City of Madera, et al., accused Taser of product liability, breach of warranty, failure to warn, and negligence. Taser makes makes stun guns. Federal prosecutors and regulators are examining whether Joseph Brandon, chief executive of General Reinsurance Corp., a division of Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% BRK.B, +1.43% played a role in a controversial transaction between General Re and American International Group AIG, -0.18% The Wall Street Journal reported, citing several people with knowledge of the inquiries. Brandon is the highest-ranking executive at General Re to be investigated in the matter and to remain employed at the company, the report said. UnitedHealth Group, UNH, -2.06% the Minneapolis health-care provider, chalked up growth in net earnings of 36% for the second quarter on "strong and accelerating growth across multiple business segments." The company also reaffirmed its profit outlook for the third quarter and the full year. Swiss drugmaker Novartis AG NVS, -0.49% said second-quarter net income rose 9.2% to $1.65 billion, or 70 cents per U.S.-listed share, with sales climbing 11.8% to $7.8 billion. Analysts were expecting earnings per share of 67 cents, according to Thomson First Call data. Marriott International Inc. MAR, +1.55% said second-quarter profit fell 14% to $138 million, or 59 cents a share, from $160 million, or 67 cents, a year ago. Excluding charges and gains, earnings would have been 75 cents a share, short of analysts' average estimate of 77 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% reported second-quarter earnings of $159 million, or 20 cents a share, up from $113 million, or 14 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 18 cents a share. The bottom line was lifted as bets in the commodities markets helped offset higher jet-fuel expenses. Knight Ridder Inc., KRI, +0.26% the San Jose, Calif., newspaper and online-media company, reported second-quarter earnings fell 14% as revenue gained 0.2%. Net income dropped to $74.4 million, or $1 a share, from $86.3 million, or $1.08, in the year-earlier period. The consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call was 99 cents. Tribune Co. TRB, -14.29% reported second-quarter net income of $233.4 million, or 73 cents a share, up from $96.4 million, or 29 cents, earned in the same period in 2004. The media company's quarterly revenue slipped 2.3% to $1.46 billion from nearly $1.5 billion a year ago. Excluding special items, Tribune Co. would have earned 60 cents a share in the latest quarter and 62 cents a year earlier. Analysts, on average, had been looking for a profit of 58 cents a share on revenue of $1.47 billion, according to Thomson First Call. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Google, Southwest, GM, AMD, Apple in market's eye

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR said Thursday the U.S. District Court for Eastern California granted the company's request for a summary judgment dismissing claims in a wrongful death lawsuit. The lawsuit, Torres vs. City of Madera, et al., accused Taser of product liability, breach of warranty, failure to warn, and negligence. Taser makes makes stun guns.
title: Taser says Calif. wrongful death lawsuit dismissed

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- As most media and entertainment stocks tried to break free of the previous session's declines, Pixar Animation Studios skidded 14% Friday after disclosing lower-than-expected DVD sales for "The Incredibles." Pixar gave back $6.99 to close at $43.06. Based on discussions with distribution partner Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93% and information from video resellers, Pixar PIXR has determined that sales of "The Incredibles" will fall about 7% short of its previous projections. See full story. DreamWorks Animation SKG DWA which made a similar announcement about "Shrek 2" home-video sales two months ago, rose 0.7% to $26.37. XM Satellite Radio XMSR said Friday that it added more than 640,000 net subscribers in the second quarter of 2005, bringing its subscriber total to more than 4.4 million. XM shares rose $1.16, or 3.5%, to close at $34.82. See full story. Meanwhile, the main pockets of pre-holiday strength in the media sector could be found in the newspaper and broadcasting groups. Among newspaper publishers, Dow Jones & Co. DJ parent of MarketWatch Inc., the publisher of this report, was up 3.4% at $36.65; Washington Post Co. WPO added 1.7% to $849.30; and Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% picked up 1.1% to $71.89. Investors shrugged off news that Taser International Inc. TASR said it filed a libel lawsuit against Gannett, publisher of USA Today, alleging that the newspaper published a story in early June about one of its less-lethal stun guns that was "grossly incorrect and completely misrepresented the facts." The suit, filed in Arizona state superior court, also alleges Gannett engaged in false light invasion of privacy, injurious falsehood and tortious interference with business relations. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle 2 sexy ways to get paid to save
title: Pixar plummets as media shares close higher

content: Pre-open moves Shares are expected to open stronger after European markets shrugged off concerns about further U.S. rate hikes and Thursday's drop in the Dow, and Japan also secured gains. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global markets Shares on Continental Europe and in London gained, while the Nikkei closed higher after the Bank of Japan's Tankan survey showed improving corporate sentiment. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker action PepsiCo PEP, -0.03% and Pepsi Bottling Group PBG, +7.14% were downgraded to neutral from buy at UBS, saying that it believes the prospects for growth in earnings per share have faded. Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% Chief Executive John Mack has full support of the board and is focused on bringing departed managers back, according to a research note by UBS analyst Glenn Schorr. Schorr also predicted few strategic changes. "We think Discover gets spun, and given that Mack was for the merger, said he would do it again, and believes in diversification, we don't see material dismantling of the rest of Morgan," Schorr said. Chordiant Software CHRD shares surged in premarket trade after JMP Securities upgraded the stock to strong buy vs. market perform and set a $3 price target, equal to 54% upside from current levels. "We understand from sources that we believe to be reliable that Chordiant may have closed a significant deal with a major U.S. bank in the June quarter," said analyst Patrick Walravens. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Pfizer Inc. PFE, +0.54% will stop collaborating with Germany's Altana AG AAA, -12.50% on the Daxas asthma treatment. That follows a study showing that while Daxas significantly improved lung function, it didn't show a statistically significant reduction in the rate of total exacerbations. Altana said that Pfizer is returning all the rights to Daxas, which Altana will continue to develop. Pfizer also said it's discontinuing development of capravirine, a treatment under study for patients with HIV/AIDS. Taser International Inc. TASR said it filed a libel lawsuit against Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% publisher of USA Today, alleging that the newspaper published a story in early June about one of its less-lethal stun guns that was "grossly incorrect and completely misrepresented the facts.". Unitedhealth Group UNH, -2.06% said it's agreed to buy privately held Neighborhood Health Partnership, which mostly serves Miami-Dade County residents, for an undisclosed sum. Children's book publisher Scholastic Inc. SCHL, +0.21% said it's in the final stages of printing and shipping 10.8 million copies of the new Harry Potter book, due to launch on July 16. Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder has lost a vote of confidence - as planned -- in parliament, triggering the possibility of early elections. Schroeder had arranged the vote in the hopes of losing it to hold a national poll this year instead of in 2006. He said he'd advance elections after the loss of a key state vote in May. The Bank of Japan's quarterly tankan survey of business sentiment at large manufacturers showed the first improvement in three quarters. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: PepsiCo, Pfizer, Scholastic expected to highlight

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Friday it filed a libel lawsuit against Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% publisher of USA Today, alleging that the newspaper published a story in early June about one of its less-lethal stun guns that was "grossly incorrect and completely misrepresented the facts." The suit, filed in the Superior Court of the State of Arizona, also alleges Gannet engaged in false light invasion of privacy, injurious falsehood and tortious interference with business relations. Taser, of Scottsdale, Ariz., saw its stock close Thursday at $10.04, down 21 cents. Gannett shares were up 37 cents at $71.13.
title: Taser sues USA Today publisher Gannett for libel

content: (Editor's note: This is a free version of Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck. For more information on how to subscribe to his paid newsletter, click here.) SAN DIEGO (MarketWatch) -- Americans think the press is too critical of America. That's the word from the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press. They were talking about political coverage, but they might as also be referring to business reporting. That's the same message I get more often than you would believe from readers who, for whatever reason, think that questioning the quality of a company's earnings or doubting management is akin to trying to rip apart the very things that make America great. I've thought about it (for a second) and I think they're right. From here on out...it's an all new me. No more negative news. So, when it comes to oil of $60 a barrel, who cares? The higher the price, the higher inflation and the more the economy will get strangled, which means the Fed eventually will stop raising interest rates, which is supposed to be good for stocks! Jarden JAH doing yet another acquisition of an appliance company -- one of the toughest industries I know? No worries. It resets the cost-savings clock, which helps the company continue to churn out that high earnings growth. Don't worry if the earnings we're talking about are low-quality and unsustainable. They're earnings -- and that's all that counts! Apollo Group's APOL, -1.69% growth continuing to slow? Oh, please, it's still an impressive number so the trend is irrelevant. Besides, everybody loves this stock so it must be good. Amazon AMZN, +1.11% is entering the liquidation business to compete with Overstock OSTK, -0.96% ? Isn't that added competition? Nah, it's actually a positive, as one analyst wrote, because it'll expand the market. Several closed end funds, such as the Gabelli Utility Trust GUT, +2.81% and the Cornerstone Strategic Fund CRF, +0.53% which trade at the highest premiums of any closed end fund, paying out dividends that mostly amount to a return of investor money? But that means you pay less taxes! Another person dies after being hit by police with a gun made by Taser TASR ? My sympathies, but think about how many people haven't died. In this new world order: There's no news but good news, which is why a glass half full has just as few calories as a glass half empty. Now...imagine how the world would be if that were your daily dish of news. Don't know about you: I know I'd rather not. With that behind us: Got this email from a guy who wrote: "Great call on Jarden on Mad Money. Stock is up $5.68 today." Indeed it was after Jarden announced it was acquiring a privately held appliance maker. Yet another reader whose life is consumed, no doubt, by the "trade." He must've either avoided buying Jarden or sold it after watching me last week on Jim Cramer's Mad Money on CNBC without doing an ounce of his own research. (I'm still amazed, after all of my years of doing this, how many people want others to tell them what to buy or sell.) As for Jarden, I was throwing up a few of the red flags I had mentioned in my subscription newsletter, Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck. The difference between the two venues: TV is a minute or two; the story, which he no doubt didn't read, was nearly 1,800 words. And I wouldn't change a word of what I wrote - or what I said! And what I wrote, in summary, is that Jarden is an acquisitive hodge-podge of big, boring (but well-known) companies that would be earning little or next to nothing if it weren't for cost savings tied to the acquired companies, which include Sunbeam -- in the past the kiss of death to anybody who has dared touch it. The company says much of the 20% to 25% earnings growth it's expecting over the next few years will come from cost-savings tied to acquired companies. During that time, Jarden has said, it expects to see $75 to $110 million in savings. As a result, I wrote, "The bigger the company gets, the higher the stock goes and the more the guys running it get hooked on a strategy they can't kick: Acquisitions for the sake of acquisitions so nobody will see that, hype or no hype, growth at Jarden is an illusion." I believed it then. I believed it now. Short of the entire company getting acquired, one day this will matter. As for Apollo APOL\ -- to repeat some of what I wrote Tuesday on Minyanville.com, where some of my posts now appear: After Apollo reported fiscal third quarter earnings, I checked in with a long-time Apollo short who noted that after taking into account taxes and a slower share count, the company beat expectations by just 1 cent or less than 1% above consensus, which is the smallest "beat" in more than three years. This was also the second consecutive quarter the company missed on revenues -- likely the result of higher discounting. In all, revenue growth of 24.5% was the slowest in three years. Cash flow fell considerably while earnings were higher (always a red flag) and consolidated enrollment fell for the fourth straight quarter. Who knows (sounding like the broken record I am on so many companies): One day this too may actually matter. On that note, unless we meet sooner: Have a bang-up Fourth. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Don’t ever do this with your credit card Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Enough with the negative news

content: FMC sees FY05 pro forma earns at high end of forecast (7:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- FMC Corp. FMC, +4.73% said Tuesday evening that it has received a new five-year unsecured $850 million credit agreement that replaces a $600 million secured credit agreement it entered into last October. The Philadelphia-based company also called for the redemption of all its 10.25% senior secured notes due 2009 on July 21, for a principal amount of $355 million. The chemical company now expects full-year 2005 earnings before restructuring and other income and charges to be at the higher end its previous outlook of $4.15 to $4.30 a share. H.B. Fuller 2Q profit rises 45%; ups 2005 EPS view (6:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- H.B. Fuller Co. HB after Tuesday's closing bell reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $16.2 million, or 56 cents a share, up 45% from $11.2 million, or 39 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $387.9 million, up from $363.1 million a year ago. The St. Paul, Minn., chemical products company also increased its full-year 2005 earnings forecast to a range of $1.75 to $1.85 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call currently expect 2005 earnings of $1.48 a share on revenue of $1.53 billion. FSI Int'l swings to quarterly loss; rev down 48% (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Chip-manufacturing equipment maker FSI International FSII after Tuesday's closing bell reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $2 million, or 7 cents a share. Last year, it had a profit of $4 million, 13 cents a share. Revenue fell by 48% to $19.1 million from $36.3 million a year ago. FSI forecast a loss of $3.5 million to $4 million in the fourth quarter. CORRECT: Arbinet-Thexchange warns of 2005 results (5:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Arbinet-Thexchange ARBX which runs an Internet marketplace for trading communications capacity, after Tuesday's closing bell warned that revenue and earnings for fiscal year 2005 would come in below its previous forecast. The company cited a shift in traffic mix and a decrease in the average number of minutes for each call transacted on its exchange as reasons for the warning. The New Brunswick, N.J.-based company sees 2005 net earnings of $3 million to $6 million on fee revenue of $46 million to $50 million. It previously forecast 2005 fee revenue of $58 million to $64 million, with net income of $19 million to $23 million, excluding the expensing of stock options. Arbinet-Thexchange also sees second-quarter fee revenue of $11 million to $11.5 million and earnings of $500,000 to $1 million. (Corrects spelling of company name.) Christopher & Banks 1Q profit slips; comp sales up 4% (4:27 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Christopher & Banks Corp. CBK, +1.90% after the closing bell Tuesday reported first-quarter net earnings of $9.3 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with restated earnings of $10 million, or 26 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose to $122.7 million compared with restated earnings of $102.6 million last year. The women's clothing retailer restated results for changes in its lease accounting. Same-store sales for first quarter rose 4%. Christopher & Banks forecast a 6% to 7% increase in same-store sales for month ending June 25. Jabil Circuit quarterly profit rises 48%;backs '05 view (4:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Jabil Circuit Inc. JBL, +1.74% after Tuesday's closing bell reported fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $59.4 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $40.1 million, or 19 cents a share, last year. Its pro forma earnings for the quarter were 33 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.94 billion from $1.63 billion a year ago. The producer of electronic circuit-board assemblies sees fiscal fourth-quarter net earnings of 31 cents to 33 cents a share and core earnings of 35 cents to 37 cents a share on revenue of $2 billion to $2.1 billion. Jabil Circuit also reiterated its 2005 outlook and forecast fiscal first-quarter net earnings of 37 cents to 41 cents a share and core earnings of 40 cents to 44 cents a share on revenue of $2.2 billion to $2.4 billion. Jabil Circuit profit climbs 48% (4:16 PM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Jabil Circuit Inc. JBL, +1.74% a large contract manufacturer of electronic goods, said third-quarter profit climbed 48% on a strong gain in sales. The company said net earnings rose to $59.4 million, or 29 cents a share, from $40.1 million, or 19 cents, a year earlier. Revenue jumped 19% to $1.9 billion. Excluding onetime items, Jabil said "core" profit totaled $68.9 million, or 33 cents a share, matching the consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Jabil predicted "growth momentum to continue," with fourth-quarter core earnings of 35 cents to 37 cents a share and revenue of $2 billion to $2.1 billion. Media General affirms 2Q EPS view, updates FY views (3:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Media General MEG, +4.36% still expects to post second-quarter earnings of 77 cents to 84 cents a share, the company said Tuesday at an industry conference in New York. The company said it will also report an expected gain of 78 cents a share in the quarter from the sale of its 20% interest in the Denver Post. Media General said that its publishing division has increased its revenue growth projection to a 4.5% to 5.5% increase vs. the 4% to 4.5% rise issued earlier this year, while costs in its broadcasting division in 2005 are now seen rising 5% instead of a previously forecast 6%. Newspaper advertising growth is seen up 6% to 7% while publishing expenses are forecast to rise 5.5% to 6%. Revenue in its interactive media division is expected to increase 43%, Media General said. Christopher & Banks up on Q1 report, June comps view (2:21 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Christopher & Banks' CBK, +1.90% shares added 5.3% to $19.86 after the Minneapolis women's clothing retailer posted in-line results for the first quarter and said it expects an increase in same-store sales of between 6% and 7% in June. The company earned $9.3 million, or 26 cents a share, in the three months ended May 28, down slightly from its year-ago profit of $10 million, or 26 cents a share. Sales rose 20% in the quarter to $122.7 million from $102.6 million a year earlier. Same-store sales increased 4% in the period. The company said the first-quarter performance was "softer than expected" but that it was encouraged by the 4% increase in same-store sales and that it's "well-positioned" for the second quarter. Taser gets 4 orders totaling $1M for X26 devices (12:59 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc., TASR a producer of weaponry for law-enforcement, private-security and military markets, said it received four orders valued at a total $1 million for its X26 devices. The Calgary Police Service, Honolulu Police Department, Houston Police Department and a law enforcement agency the company did not identify ordered the equipment. The orders will ship in the second quarter. Taser said that after "a significant disruption" in its business in the first half, "we are now beginning to see a stabilization in revenue. We expect second-quarter 2005 revenue to be slightly higher" than the first-quarter level. The company's shares were recently trading up more than 4%. Meredith affirms 2005 EPS view, issues 2006 outlook (10:22 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Meredith Corp. MDP, +0.84% still expects to post 2005 earnings of $2.50 a share, the media and marketing company said Tuesday at the Mid-Year Media Review in New York City. For the first half of 2006, Des Moines, Iowa-based Meredith forecast per-share earnings growth of 8% to 10%, reflecting the absence of political advertising, while for the second half, the company said it expects growth in the mid-to-high teens. Meredith forecast earnings of $2.80 a share for the full year 2006. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a per-share profit of $2.50 for fiscal 2005 and $2.82 for fiscal 2006. Omnova Solutions tops NYSE % gainers list (9:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Omnova Solutions' OMN, -4.11% shares leapt 65 cents, or 16.1%, to $4.70 in early action on Tuesday, making it the top percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange. After Monday's closing bell, the Fairlawn, Ohio-based provider of specialty chemicals and building products reported a profit of $3.6 million, or 9 cents a share, for the second quarter, up from year-ago earnings of $300,000, or a penny a share. Excluding charges related to restructuring and severance costs, the company earned 11 cents a share in the quarter, 7 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales rose 10.4% in the latest three months to $209.3 million from $189.5 million in the same period a year earlier. Omnova attributed the performance to aggressive cost reductions and improved pricing. Biomet shares slip following Q4 earns outlook (9:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Biomet BMET, +0.00% fell 3.2% to $35.81 in early trades on Tuesday. The new comes after the Warsaw, Ind., maker of medical products said after Monday's closing bell that it expects adjusted earnings of 40 to 42 cents a share for the fourth quarter, below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 44 cents a share in the May period. The company said it expects sales of $503 million in the quarter with earnings of 39 to 41 cents a share. It plans to report its audited results for the quarter on June 30. Commercial Metals profit rises 40% (9:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Commercial Metals Co. CMC, +2.76% reported third-quarter earnings of $71.7 million, or $1.14 a share, compared with $50.9 million, or 84 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Sales rose to $1.73 billion from $1.41 billion. The company said its outlook for the fourth quarter "remains very positive although varied by segment." Shares fell 24 cents Monday to $27.13. Vermont Pure Holdings delays filing (9:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Vermont Pure Holdings, Ltd. VPS on Tuesday said it won't file its quarterly report for the period ended April 30 by the extended due date, June 20, because of accounting corrections related to Yellow Pages advertising. The bottled water distributor reported preliminary second-quarter net income of $205,000, or a penny a share, down from $283,000, or a penny a share, last year. Revenue rose to $14.8 million, from $13.1 million. The company matched the earnings forecast of a penny a share in a survey of one analyst by Thomson First Call. Shares fell 3 cents to $1.84 on Monday. Journal Comm. sees pick-up in ad revs in June (8:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Milwaukee-based newspaper and broadcasting group Journal Communications, Inc. JNR is seeing a "pick up" in advertising revenue in all major categories in June, Elizabeth Brenner, the vice president of the group and publisher of the Journal Sentinel told analysts and investors at the NAA Mid-Year Media Review conference on Tuesday. Advertising growth for the month is in the low single digits and is "better than May," she said. She added that the group isn't receiving pressure from advertisers to lower ad rates as a result of the decline in circulation that the industry is experiencing. She said "there are no early indications, even from some of the auto dealers" that they will seek reductions. The group is expecting its free publication, the MKE, to be profitable this year and to attract new revenue of $2 million. Futuremedia rallies on profitable view for FY06 (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Futuremedia Plc FMDAY jumped 14.6% to 47 cents on volume of 84,527 on Instinet after the U.K. provider of e-learning and managed benefits services forecast a profit of $1.8 million to $2.7 million for fiscal 2006 on revenue of between $37 million and $44 million. The company also said it expects to achieve profitability on a monthly basis as early as October. Futuremedia anticipates its installed base of homes under the U.K.'s Home Computing initiative will increase to 49,000 this year from a total of 28,000 at the end of fiscal 2005. In addition, the company posted a preliminary loss of $7.6 million on revenue of $29.9 million for fiscal 2005. Kroger rallies after beating views, upping estimate (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares in Kroger Co. KR, +1.35% rallied in pre-market trading Tuesday after the company said fiscal first-quarter profit rose to $294.3 million, or 40 cents a share, from $262.8 million, or 35 cents, a year earlier. Sales for the three months advanced to $17.95 billion from $16.9 billion in last year's first quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 35 cents a share on sales of $17.65 billion. The better than expected results led the Cincinnati-based supermarket chain to raise its fiscal 2005 earnings target to at least $1.24 a share, 3 cents ahead of its prior outlook and 1 cent greater than analysts' average view. Shares in Kroger added 6.2%, or $1.10, to $18.79 ahead of the opening bell. Penford profit, sales rise (7:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Penford Corp. PENX said Tuesday fiscal third-quarter net income rose to $2.6 million, or 29 cents a share, from $2.3 million, or 26 cents, a year ago. Sales for the period ended May 31 advanced to $76.1 million from $72.5 million in last year's third quarter. Thomson First Call doesn't publish an average estimate for the Englewood, Colo.-based ingredient supplier. Shares in Penford closed Monday at $15.35, up 39 cents. FactSet Research Sys net income up 33% (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- FactSet Research Systems FDS, +0.49% on Tuesday reported third-quarter net income of $19.6 million, or 39 cents a share, up 33% from $14.7 million, or 30 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose to $79 million from $63.6 million. The latest quarter's earnings figure includes 4 cents a share in tax benefits. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 34 cents a share and revenue of $78.6 million. The Norwalk, Conn. financial information supplier forecasted fourth-quarter revenue of $80-$82 million, in line with the $81 million Wall Street. Shares fell 40 cents to $33.25 on Monday. Valueclick lifts 2005 earnings forecast (7:13 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Valueclick, Inc. VCLK lifted its fiscal 2005 earnings outlook to the range of 38 cents to 40 cents a share on revenue of $222 million to $226 million, compared to an earlier forecast for earnings between 37 cents and 39 cents a share on revenue of $218 million to $223 million. Valueclick said the new guidance was based on its increased optimism about the second half. The online advertising services provider also reaffirmed its forecast for second-quarter earnings of 8 cents a share on sales of $52 million to $53 million, in line with the average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Lennar lifts 2005 earnings outlook, quarterly profit up (6:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Homebuilder Lennar Corp. LEN, +0.31% upped its 2005 outlook for earnings from continuing operations to $7.80 from $7.15 a share, citing strong consumer demand, a solid balance sheet and record backlog. Second-quarter net earnings rose to $243 million, or $1.48 a share, from $201 million, or $1.22 a share, a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations rose 27% to $233.2 million, or $1.42 a share on sales up 25% to $2.9 billion. The results topped the average forecast for earnings of $1.28 a share of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. For 2005, analysts polled by Thomson First Call anticipate earnings of $7.21 a share. The company said the results stemmed from its ability to "continue to capitalize on favorable pricing conditions within various strategic homebuilding markets." Isoft 05 pretax profit more than doubles, Cryne retires (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Isoft Group PLC(UK:IOT), a supplier of software application solutions to the healthcare sector, on Tuesday said 2005 pre-tax profit more than doubled to 44.5 million pounds from 17.5 million pounds a year ago, partly thanks to synergies from the merger with Torex. Sales for the period jumped 75.5% to 242 million pounds. Earnings per share grew to 11.1 pence from 6.66 pence a year earlier. Separately, the group said non-executive Chairman Patrick Cryne would retire by the end of the financial year. Cattles says bad debt levels remain stable (2:30 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. subprime lender Cattles PLC(UK:CTT)said its customers' arrears levels and bad debts remain stable. It said trading conditions have become more challenging during the second quarter, and are expected to remain challenging. "We remain cautious in the selection of our customers and we retain strong control over credit quality and operational efficiencies," it said. Cattles also said demand for the group's direct repayment products is ahead of the corresponding period last year. There has been some concern recently about bad loans after recent interest rate hikes and after rising levels of bad debt at several banks. Alliance & Leicester sees H1 sales broadly flat from 04 (2:26 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester PLC(UK:AL)on Tuesday said it expects first-half revenue for 2005 to be broadly similar to 2004 and its share buyback program to be significantly lower than in 2004. A&L also said is on track to achieve its targeted return on equity of 20% plus or minus 3% in fiscal 2005. In the first quarter, A&L said gross mortgage lending reached 1.5 billion pounds. New business banking accounts rose by 30% compared to the same period in 2004. Net interest margins continued to decline in the quarter, primarily due to lower margins on the personal unsecured and mortgage books, the bank said. Chrysalis: ad market volatile, rev. down 15% in quarter (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Media company Chrysalis Group PLC(UK:CHS)said the advertising market remains volatile and continues to be affected by the slowdown in consumer spending. Chrysalis Radio's revenue for the three months to May 31 fell by 14.5%, and June is expected to be similar. "The advertising market remains short-term with little visibility into July or August," it said. Chrysalis said that results for the year in its book publishing division are likely to be impacted, given the reliance of the unit on consumer spending. title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc., TASR a producer of weaponry for law-enforcement, private-security and military markets, said it received four orders valued at a total $1 million for its X26 devices. The Calgary Police Service, Honolulu Police Department, Houston Police Department and a law enforcement agency the company did not identify ordered the equipment. The orders will ship in the second quarter. Taser said that after "a significant disruption" in its business in the first half, "we are now beginning to see a stabilization in revenue. We expect second-quarter 2005 revenue to be slightly higher" than the first-quarter level. The company's shares were recently trading up more than 4%.
title: Taser gets 4 orders totaling $1M for X26 devices

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stocks ended slightly higher Monday even as a surge in oil prices to a seven-week high took some of the steam out of the market's gains, with Morgan Stanley a standout as the bank's shares climbed on the departure of Chief Executive Philip Purcell. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% ended up 9.93 points at 10, 522.56, but off a morning high of 10,589.16. It was the third straight session of gains for the benchmark index. The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ rose 5.96 points to 2,068.96 after climbing as high as 2,078.26 in early trading. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% was up 2.71 points at 1,200.82 "It's a very slow news day and today's focus is completely on tomorrow's numbers," said Kenneth Tower, chief market strategist at CyberTrader. Among the economic reports of note, May wholesale inflation and retail sales data is due out Tuesday while the May consumer price index comes out on Wednesday. See Economic Preview. "I think those are expected to come out and confirm this idea that we are moving out of the soft patch." Stocks recently pulled back after a slew of data suggested the economic growth had slowed, notably in the month of March. "It's a directionless market," said Ed Peters, chief investment officer at Pan Agora. "People are waiting for more information which typically means the market is very undecided about what is going to be happening." On the broader market for equities, advancers outpaced decliners by 19 to 13 on the New York Stock Exchange, and by a 16 to 14 margin on the Nasdaq. Volume was light with 1.2 billion shares exchanging hands on the Big Board, while 1.4 billion were traded on the Nasdaq. Oil, dollar, gold, bonds Crude-oil futures ended sharply higher ahead of a meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and after reports that tropical storm Arlene left oil and gas production in the Gulf of Mexico largely undamaged. See Futures Movers. The benchmark July contract was up $2.08, or 3.9%, at $55.62 a barrel in New York trading. On the currency markets, the dollar struck a nine-month high against the euro, benefiting from hopes for more U.S. rate increases and a hint from a European Central Bank official that the ECB could cut its rates. The euro was last at $1.2086 vs. the dollar, down 0.3%. See Currencies. Gold futures ended higher, with the August benchmark contract up $1.80 at $431.10 an ounce, as traders who had anticipated further price declines were forced to cover short positions. See Metals Stocks "Gold's ability to resist the sharp rise in the U.S. dollar is causing both a short-covering rally and new fresh long positions to be added," said Peter Grandich, strategist at Grandich Letter. Treasury prices were down, sending yields higher, in a continuation of the losses seen last week after hopes for a softer interest-rate policy were dashed by strong data and bullish remarks by Federal Reserve speakers. In late trade, the yield on the benchmark 10-year note rose to 4.085% from 4.047% late Friday. See Bond Report Stocks in focus Shares of Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% rose as much as 4.4% after the investment bank announced embattled chief executive Philip Purcell was leaving the company. The company said Purcell will leave no later than March 2006, the date of the company's next annual meeting. See full story. In a separate statement, Morgan Stanley warned its fiscal second-quarter earnings would be around 15% to 20% below the year-ago figure of $1.10 a share. Purcell on May 10 laid out dismal numbers that suggested momentum from Morgan Stanley's strong first quarter is diminishing. Global announced mergers are down 28% for the quarter. Equity underwriting is off 21% and high-yield debt underwriting has fallen 38%, Purcell said at the time. The stock ended up 2% at $50.88. A number of banks are reporting quarterly earnings this week including Lehman Bros. LEH Bear Stearns BSC, +1.30% and Goldman Sachs GS, +1.00% See Weekend Edition for a preview of the results. General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% fell as much as 1.7% on reports that it plans further price cuts on some of its passenger cars. The Detroit industry publication Automotive News, citing dealers, reported that the world's biggest automaker is poised to lower the sticker price for some Chevrolet, Pontiac and Saturn models to boost flagging market share. The move follows price cuts announced in February on several midsize sport utility vehicles. The stock ended down 0.2%. Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% slipped two cents to $64.63 as rival Airbus appeared to have won the first round in their battle to outdo each other on new plane order announcements on the first day of the Paris Air Show. On the first day of the prestigious air show, Qatar Airways said it is going to buy up to 60 Airbus A350 planes and at least 20 Boeing 777s. Boeing also announced, however, that European low-fare carrier Ryanair RYAAY, +1.64% has exercised five order options for its next-generation 737 aircraft as part of an order it placed in 2002 and extended this year. Fast-food restaurant chains and, to a lesser extent, beef-processing companies were under pressure after the Department of Agriculture said that a sample from a cow that had been cleared last year as free of BSE -- more popularly known as mad-cow disease -- generated a possible positive under more intensive testing. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% was down 1.4% at $29.11 while Wendy's International Inc. WEN, +0.75% fell 2.3% to $46.78 Wendy's was further pressured by a downgrade from Piper Jaffray. The brokerage said the current valuation reflects a takeover premium, but it sees the probability of a deal as less than likely. Other beef-related stocks weathered the news better, with Outback Steakhouse Inc. OSI, -2.84% up 1.1%, Tyson Foods Inc. TSN, +0.36% rising 0.8% although rival Smithfield Inc. SFD, +2.50% was off 0.1% at $28.03. See full story. Shares of Taser International Inc. TASR shot up 3.5% to $11.22 after the stun-gun maker won a $1.4 million order from the U.S. government to supply the military with devices and related accessories. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% rose 0.6% after it reaffirmed Saturday that it still sees June same-store sales growing in a range of 2% to 4%. Shares of Northwest Airlines NWAC tumbled nearly 12% to $5.58. The move follows an article published in The Wall Street Journal that says the company may need to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection due to higher fuel and labor costs, the burden of its pension obligations and increased competition from discount airlines. The Journal also said that the company's largest individual shareholder and its non-executive chairman, Gary Wilson, has been selling Northwest Airlines stock. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks end higher; CEO exit lifts Morgan Stanley

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Monday it received an order valued at $1.4 million, through its distributor to the U.S. Government General Services Administration, to deliver devices and related accessories to the U.S. military. The Scottsdale, Ariz. provider of non-lethal stun guns said the order will ship in the second quarter. Shares of Taser closed Friday down 1.19% at $10.84.
title: Taser wins $1.4M order from US military

content: Advancers Shares of Armor Holdings AH, +3.65% tacked on 4% after the security and military products maker said that it received a $12.2 million contract to supply armor and other equipment for U.S. Army vehicles. The work will be done this year at the company's Fairfield, Ohio and Phoenix, Ariz. operations. Benihana BNHNA shares rose 4% after the company reported net income of $2.2 million, or 22 cents a share, for the fourth quarter ended March 27, down from $2.9 million, or 31 cents a share, earned in the same period last year. The restaurant operator's revenue rose 8.1%, reaching $54.8 million. Earnings for the latest quarter included impairment charges amounting to $2.7 million, or 16 cents a share. Analysts were looking for quarterly earnings of 26 cents a share on revenue of $55 million. Benihana also said it's looking for earnings of 28 to 30 cents a share, ahead of the Thomson First Call-derived average estimate of 24 cents. Commercial Metals Co. CMC, +2.76% shares gained 2% after the company said its board has authorized the purchase of up to 2 million shares of its common stock. The company also said that it purchased 1,944,610 shares in April and May 2005 at an average price of $26.06 a share. Conexant Systems CNXT, +2.41% leapt 6.8% after the company was upgraded to neutral from underperform at CS First Boston, which cited the belief that the inventory overhang is behind the company, as well as relative valuation. Analyst Michael Masdea also believes the company has growth prospects in both the satellite set-top box and digital subscriber line markets, and thinks the company is close to being profitable. Diamond Offshore Drilling DO, +2.95% shares tacked on 3.2% after the company said it has two signed and five pending term contracts that would yield combined revenue of up to $1.2 billion over their total duration. The work will be performed in the Gulf of Mexico, Brazil and the U.K. sector of the North Sea. Empire Resorts NYNY, +4.23% shares gained 11.5% after the company announced a number of management changes. The company named David Hanlon chief executive officer, Ronald Radcliffe chief financial officer and John Sharpe chairman. Robert Berman, the previous CEO, moves to the vice chairman role. GameStop Corp. GME, -10.81% shares advanced 4.2% after the company said first-quarter net income rose to $10.3 million, or 19 cents a share, from $6.7 million, or 11 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period climbed to $474.7 million from $371.7 million on strong software sales software and a resurgent growth in hardware. Same-store sales grew 12%. The results beat the average forecast for earnings of 17 cents a share of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, the video game retailer said it sees second-quarter net earnings in the range of 14 to 15 cents a share on same-store sales up 5% to 7%. Genentech Inc. DNA, -1.03% tacked on 2.6% after the company said a Phase III study of its investigational drug Lucentis showed that 95% of patients with wet age-related macular degeneration maintained or had improved vision with the investigational drug, meeting its primary efficacy endpoint. See full story. Goldcorp GG, +2.29% shares added 3.4% after Chief Executive Ian Telfer told MarketWatch that he's shopping for acquisitions and his company has $1 billion to spend. "We're very interested in continuing to grow the company, and we've been amassing a cash hoard so we can go shopping in this choppy share-price market for the other gold mining companies," Telfer said in a broadband interview. Isis Pharmaceuticals ISIS shares rallied 15.3% after the company said it would receive a $1 million technology access fee from Pfizer PFE, +0.54% as part of the companies' new multi-year agreement to identify ophthalmic disease treatments. Isis will also receive research funding and potential milestone payments. JDS Uniphase Corp. JDSU gained 5.8% after the company agreed to buy privately-held Acterna Inc. for $760 million. Under the terms of the agreement, JDS will buy Acterna for $450 million in cash and $310 million in stock. The deal is expected to close in the quarter ending Sept. 30, the San Jose, Calif.-based company said. The company said the deal is expected to accelerate its path to profitability. Acterna will immediately add to the company's financial results. See full story. Lifeway Foods LWAY, -0.83% shares soared 43% after the kefir supplier said it has formalized a deal to provide four flavors of its LowFat Kefir product in select Target TGT, +0.36% stores. Kefir is a milk-based beverage that contains ten types of active probiotic cultures, according to Morton Grove, Ill.-based Lifeway. Linktone Ltd. LTON shares added 6.5% after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $3.2 million, or 12 cents per American Depositary Share, up 13% from $2.8 million, or 11 cents per ADS. Revenue rose 61% to $15.1 million from $9.4 million a year ago. Meredith Corp. MDP, +0.84% shares added 5.5% after the company agreed to acquire four magazines from Gruner + Jahr for roughly $350 million. The deal includes the magazines Parents, Child, Fitness and Family Circle. In addition, the transaction includes an option for Gruner + Jahr to sell the assets of business publications Inc. and Fast Company to Meredith by June 30. The company expects the deal to close by the end of June, and for it to add to earnings in fiscal 2006. Monro Muffler Brake MNRO, +2.58% shares tacked on 2.9% after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.8 million, or 19 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $2 million, or 14 cents a share. Excluding a charge related to a change in lease accounting practices, the company earned $2.9 million, or 20 cents a share, in the latest quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 18 cents a share in the March period. Looking ahead, the Rochester, N.Y., provider of automotive repair services forecast earnings of $1.52 to $1.60 a share for fiscal 2006 on sales of between $375 million and $385 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $1.61 a share for the year. For the first quarter, Monro Muffler expects earnings of 52 to 55 cents a share. Shares of Nanogen NGEN rose 3.5% after the San Diego company said it has received patents related to its biomarker discovery and nucleic acid manipulation technologies. The addition of these two patents brings the company's total portfolio of U.S. patents to 128. The company said one patent relates to software designed for amino acid sequencing pattern matching and determining the number of possible sequences consistent with the molecular weight of the amino acid. The other relates to methods using novel synthetic binding units with very high specificity and sensitivity, linked to nucleic acids as primers. Shares of Napster Inc. NAPS, +0.00% added 6.9% after Piper Jaffray reiterated its outperform rating, saying concerns over competition from Yahoo YHOO have pushed valuations to attractive levels. As of Monday's close ($4.07), the stock had dropped 36% since the May 10 close, after which Yahoo announced the launch of a rival music subscription service. "While Napster is gaining subscribers faster than expected, Wall Street is focused on the competitive threat from Yahoo," said Analyst Gene Munster. "At current levels, we believe the downside to shares is limited, given Napster has $3.86 a share in cash and the Napster names is a global brand that, at a minimum, has value to other online properties and/or device manufacturers." PalmSource PSRC shares jumped 12.9% and PalmOne's PLMO, +0.00% stock rose 5.8% after PalmOne renewed its Palm operating system license with PalmSource. The deal calls for PalmSource to receive a minimum royalty payment of $148.5 million under the deal, including $65 million relating the company meeting certain development milestones during 2007 to 2009. PalmSource has also sold its 55% interest in the holding company that owns the Palm brand trademarks to PalmOne for $30 million, to be paid over three and a half years. Parlux Fragrances PARL shares leapt 13.2% after Wedbush Morgan Securities initiated coverage of the stock with a buy rating with a price target of $28. Analyst Rommel Dionisio said he is expecting "significant acceleration" in Parlux's revenues and earnings driven by new product launches including Guess Fragrance and newly added brand licenses including Guess and XOXO. Shares of Scottish Power SPI, +5.69% gained 5.7% after the company agreed to sell Pacificorp, the leading electricity provider in the Northwest U.S., to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% for $5.1 billion in cash, and the assumption of $4.3 billion in debt. See full story. Shopping.com Ltd. SHOP, +2.46% shares added 5.7% after Deutsche Bank upgraded the Web-based retailer to hold from sell, saying that the current multiples reflect the market's concerns regarding traffic, growth prospects, reinvestment vs. margin expansion and competition. The broker told clients that operating margin expansion may be limited in the near term as the company invests in international expansion. "However, we do think that the better area of investment may be brand advertising in the U.S. market," Deutsche Bank concluded. Spherion Corp. SFN, -1.81% shares rose 3% after the company said it plans to repurchase up to 6 million shares, or approximately 10%, of its outstanding common stock. Share repurchases will be made, from time to time, in open-market transactions, in privately negotiated transactions and through employee stock purchase plans. Superconductor Technologies' SCON, -0.81% shares jumped 17.7% after the company said it's received about $4 million in year-to-date orders for its SuperPlex and AmpLink products, as part of a major wireless carrier's 3G (EV-DO) roll-out. Shipments began in March and are scheduled through the second quarter of 2005, the company said. Shares of Syneron Medical Ltd. ELOS gained 5.7% after the company signed an agreement with Miracle Laser for the distribution of its products in China. The company also said it has received regulatory approval for the sale of its medical aesthetic device products in China from the country's State Food and Drug Administration. Taser International TASR shares advanced 6.1% after the company reduced its 2004 net income by $243,000 to $18.9 million, or 30 cents a share due to tax errors connected to certain stock option grants. Pro forma net income was decreased to $10.7 million, or 17 cents a share. The impact to its 2004 payroll tax was about $395,000, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of non-lethal stun guns said. Amended results were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Taser said. Shares of TiVo Inc. TIVO, +0.37% rallied 17.9% after First Albany started research coverage of the digital video recorder maker with a strong buy rating and a $16 stock price target. Analyst Richard Baldry believes the company can become profitable "at will" when it decides to abandon its hardware subsidization strategy. "We believe TiVo's valuation today is reflective of its history of net income losses, but believe investors will shift focus to its fast-growth recurring revenues as it turns profitable and slowly offloads its hardware burden," Baldry said. Shares of W.R. Grace GRA, +0.23% surged 15% along with the stocks of a number of other companies with asbestos liabilities, including Owens Corning OWENQ up 28.9%, Armstrong Holdings ACKHQ rising 22.6%, USG Corp. USG, +0.10% adding more than 9.3%, and McDermott International MDR, +2.18% gaining 11.2%. The move comes as the U.S. Senate moved closer to consideration of an asbestos liability trust fund bill following resignation of its showdown over judicial nominees. See full story. Decliners Applied Biosystems Group ABI, -7.69% shares lost 5.8% after UBS downgraded the company's stock to reduce from neutral, citing lackluster organic revenue growth and increasing competition. The broker told clients it believes that transforming mergers and acquisitions choices may be limited. "Although margins have improved, in our view, ongoing restructuring has been slow and we believe that it will take longer than expected before Applied Biosystems fully turns around," UBS concluded. Applied Signal Technology APSG shares dropped almost 17.4% after the company reported second-quarter net income of $2.3 million, or 20 cents a share, down from a profit of $3.9 million, or 34 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $32.1 million from $36.8 million. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 26 cents a share. Applied Signal also said it would acquire privately held Dynamics Technology Inc. of Torrance, Calif., for $30 million. Shares of CompuCredit Corp. CCRT gave back 5.5% after the financial services company offered $250 million in senior convertible notes. The Atlanta, Ga. company said the notes, due in 2025, are being offered to qualified institutional buyers, and can be converted by holders into cash, or the company's stock during certain periods and subject to certain conditions. Conversion into stock will be at a rate of 23.0309 shares per $1,000 principal amount of notes. At the same time, CompuCredit said it has repurchased around $100 million of its shares. The company said proceeds from the offering will be used to fund acquisitions and/or used for general corporate and working capital purposes. Comstock Homebuilding Cos. CHCI, +0.00% shares fell 5.2% after the company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a secondary public offering of about 3.25 million Class A common stock. Dillard's Inc. DDS, +0.96% shares dropped 8.3% after the company reported first-quarter net income of $38 million, or 46 cents a share, down from a profit of $53.8 million, or 64 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The latest results include a 4 cent a share charge for store closings. Sales for the quarter ended April 30 slipped 3% to $1.8 billion. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 53 cents a share on revenue of $1.9 billion. Same-store sales in the first quarter fell 3%. The department store operator said gross margins were hurt in the latest quarter by increased markdown activity. See full story. Dycom Industries DY, +3.62% shares fell 19.5% after the contracting services provider issued a disappointing profit forecast for the fourth quarter. See full story. Eltek Ltd. ELTK, -2.16% shares sank 23.9% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $192,000, or 4 cents a share. Last year, it posted a loss of $587,000, or 8 cents a share. Revenue was $7.9 million, up from $7 million a year ago. The Israeli maker of printed circuit boards expects second-quarter revenue to decrease compared with the first quarter because of a short-term flattening in demand for production capacity. Eyetech Pharmaceuticals EYET shares plummeted 46% after Merrill Lynch downgraded the stock to neutral from buy. The firm cited Monday's news that Genentech DNA, -1.03% reported positive Phase III data for Lucentis, a treatment for wet age-related macular degeneration. Merrill said the data suggests Lucentis may have better one-year efficacy as compared to Eyetech's competing product Macugen. See full story. General Motors GM, +2.45% shares dipped 2.8% after Fitch Ratings lowered its senior unsecured ratings on the company, GMAC and the majority of its affiliated entities to BB+ from BBB-. Fitch said the move reflects the continuing decline in GM's North American sales of key mid-size and large SUV products, increasing product and price competition in the large pickup market, and the corresponding impact of these two segments on consolidated profitability. The agency also said it believes that declining volumes and profitability, coupled with lack of tangible progress in attacking manufacturing and legacy costs will result in negative cash flow through at least 2006. The rating outlook for GM remains negative. Harold's Stores HLD, -0.19% shares gave back 5.7% after the company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $782,000, or 4 cents a share, vs. $791,000, or 4 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Sales fell 0.8% to a lower-than-anticipated $24 million from last year's $24.2 million, due primarily to an earlier Easter holiday and cooler weather. The upscale specialty retailer said since these sales trends have continued into May, it would take additional clearance markdowns. Hastings Entertainment HAST, +1.30% shares slid 3.8% after the company said first-quarter profit fell to $754,000, or 6 cents a share, from $2 million, or 17 cents, in the year-ago period. Revenue for the period ended April 30 increased $129.1 million from $127 million in last year's first quarter. Thomson First Call doesn't publish an average analyst estimate for the Amarillo, Texas, media retailer. Hastings affirmed its outlook for full-year earnings of 55 to 58 cents a share. The company's stock closed up 13 cents at $5.78 Monday. Hughes Supply Inc. HUG, -0.17% fell 6.2% after the company said profits jumped 14% to a record $34 million in its fiscal first quarter as sales leaped at the wholesale distributor of construction materials and maintenance products. For the fiscal first quarter 2006, Hughes said its net earnings totaled $34 million, or 51 cents a share, compared with $29.8 million, or 48 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended April 30 soared 25% to $1.24 billion from $993 million a year ago. The performance matched expectations of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. See full story. Shares of Journal Communications JRN tumbled 4.9% after Morgan Stanley downgraded the media and communications services provider to equal weight from overweight.
