Analyst Douglas Arthur is concerned about the lack of apparent near-term catalysts to move the stock higher. He also believes it will be difficult for the company to repeat its stellar revenue performance in newspapers and broadcasting in 2005, and is worried about the deteriorating TV market. Shares of Open Solutions OPEN fell 10.9% after the financial software and services company corrected certain statements it made in its first quarter earnings report released on April 27. The company said internal revenue growth in the quarter was 12% and not 19% as previously reported. Also, the value of newly-signed contracts was $22.4 million compared with $22 million reported in the earlier release. Open Solutions said the corrections have no impact on its first quarter results or its second quarter and full-year outlook. SRA International SRX, +7.69% shares lost 1.7% after the company was downgraded to hold from buy at Legg Mason, due solely to valuation. Analyst William Loomis said he was comfortable that the company's business remains on track and award activity is likely to pick up, but noted that the stock price has already exceeded his $69 price target. Toro Co. TTC, +3.29% shares fell 4.8% after the company reported second-quarter net income of $62 million, or $1.33 a share, compared with $52.2 million, or $1 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales rose to $628.4 million from $548 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call forecast, on average, earnings of $1.30 a share. See full story. Vodafone VOD, +0.54% shares fell 5.7% after the mobile phone giant offering a cautious outlook going forward. See full story. Xyratex Ltd. XRTX lost 4.2% after the data storage company was downgraded to neutral from buy at Merrill Lynch, which cited the lack of apparent growth drivers for the company beyond 2006. "We believe that Dot Hill (a competitor) has the leading bid to provide disk enclosures for an unannounced Network Appliance product, expected in the next 9 to 12 months," said Analyst Shelby Seyrafi in a note to clients. "This limits potential incremental revenue opportunities for Xyratex." Seyrafi noted that Xyratex is currently the sole supplier of disk enclosures to Network Appliance. Seyrafi cut his 2006 adjusted earnings estimate to $1.66 a share from $1.78. Youbet.com UBET shares tumbled 13.4% in afternoon action. The move comes in reaction to a new proposal from Sen. John Kyl to bar credit-card issuers, banks and other financial institutions from transmitting money related to online wagering and authorize a wide array of federal and state law-enforcement agencies to go after the offenders. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: Taser cuts 2004 earnings on tax errors (6:50 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. TASR said after Monday's closing bell that as a result of a tax errors connected to certain stock option grants, it has cut its 2004 net income by $243,000 to $18.9 million, or 30 cents a share. Pro forma net income was decreased to $10.7 million, or 17 cents a share. The impact to its 2004 payroll tax was about $395,000, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of non-lethal stun guns said. Amended results were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Taser said. Bioenvision to restate certain prior financial results (6:37 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Bioenvision Inc. BIVN after Monday's closing bell said that it will restate certain prior financial statements, including its annual report on Form 10-KSB for the year ended June 30, 2004 and its quarterly report on Form 10-QSB for the quarter ended March 31, 2004. The restatements are being made in order to revise the tax accounting treatment associated with the acquisition of Pathagon Inc. back in 2002. The New York-based biopharmaceutical company said the restatements will increase Bioenvision's income tax benefit and net assets and will reduce its net loss and per-share net loss for each period. They will not impact the company's income from operations, cash or other assets. Eltek Ltd. swings to quarterly profit (5:59 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Eltek Ltd. ELTK, -2.16% after Monday's closing bell reported first-quarter net earnings of $192,000, or 4 cents a share. Last year, it posted a loss of $587,000, or 8 cents a share. Revenue was $7.9 million, up from $7 million a year ago. The Israeli maker of printed circuit boards expects second-quarter revenue to decrease compared with the first quarter because of a short-term flattening in demand for production capacity. However, it expects revenue to be higher compared with the same period a year ago. Linktone Q1 quarterly profit rises 13% (5:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Linktone Ltd. LTON after the closing bell Monday reported first-quarter net earnings of $3.2 million, or 12 cents per American Depositary Share, up 13% from $2.8 million, or 11 cents per ADS. Revenue rose 61% to $15.1 million from $9.4 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the Shanghai, China-based wireless media provider sees second-quarter net earnings of 13 cents per ADS on revenue of $16 million. It sees pro forma earnings of about 15 cents per ADS. Dycom quarterly profit rises (4:30 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Dycom Industries Inc. DY, +3.62% said after Monday's closing bell that its third-quarter earnings rose to $13.7 million, or 28 cents a share, from $11.2 million, or 23 cents a share, a year ago. Adjusted earnings were $12.6 million, or 26 cents a share. The company said its total contract revenue was $247.7 million vs. $219.6 million a year earlier. The Palm Beach Gardens, Fla.-based company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings of 33 cents to 38 cents a share on revenue of $250 million to $270 million. Hughes Supply boosts profit 14% (4:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) - Wholesale construction materials distributor Hughes Supply, Inc. HUG, -0.17% reported late Monday fiscal first-quarter 2006 net earnings of $34 million, or 51 cents share, up from $29.8 million, or 48 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the three months ended April 30 totaled $1.24 billion, up 25% from $993 million a year earlier. The results matched expectations of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Hughes Supply shares closed just ahead of the report at $27.34, up 15 cents for the day. CORRECT: On Track Innovations slumps after Q1 report (2:36 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of On Track Innovations Ltd. OTIV, -2.48% fell 7.9% to $12.67 after the Fort Lee, N.J., maker of smart card products reported a loss of $1.7 million, or 20 cents a share, for the first quarter, narrower than a year-ago loss of $2 million, or 39 cents a share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $6.5 million from $5.3 million in the same period a year earlier. On Track Innovations said gross profit slipped to $2.2 million in the quarter from $2.3 million in the same period a year earlier as it started a number of contactless payment programs, which had lower margins in their early stages. (An earlier version of this item had an incorrect name for the company and indicated the company's loss widened instead of narrowed.) Kongzhong shares tumble in wake of Q1 report (12:35 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Kongzhong Corp. KONG fell 6.4% to $7.30 after the Beijing-based provider of wireless entertainment and interactive products and services reported first-quarter results that saw margins decrease markedly due to higher expenses related to class-action litigation. The company posted earnings of $5.9 million, or 17 cents a share, in the March period, down from a year-ago equivalent profit of $6.6 million, or 19 cents a share. The latest period included $860,000 in legal expenses, which reduced margins to 35% in the quarter from 44% last year. Revenue, however, rose to $17 million in the three months ended March 31 from $7.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Kongzhong expects revenue of $17 million to $17.5 million for the second quarter, although it expects revenue from wireless application protocol, or WAP, products to decline on a sequential basis. CORRECT: BMC Software backs Q4 financial outlook (12:06 PM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- BMC Software Inc. BMC, -2.86% said it still sees between a loss of a penny and earnings of 3 cents a share in the fiurth quarter on revenue ranging from $388 million to $400 million. On an adjusted basis, excluding special items, the Houston-based company forecast earnings of 8 to 12 cents a share. The average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings before items of 10 cents a share in the March period. BMC software also said it see cash flow of $500 million for fiscal 2005. Looking forward, BMC anticipates fiscal 2006 earnings excluding special items of 86 to 92 cents a share, ahead of Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 81 cents a share. (A previous version of this item incorrectly reported the company's outlook for the fourth quarter.) Correct: Source Interlink sees adj. earns at 10c to 12c (9:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Source Interlink Cos. SORC said Monday it expects first-quarter 2006 earnings of 10 cents to 12 cents a share before items. The company said the results reflected better-than-expected profitability at its Alliance Entertainment as a result of business mix and early benefits from acquisitions. Excluding merger and other expenses, earnings will be 1 cent to 4 cents a share when the company reports results on June 6. Thomson First Call's average analyst estimate is for 7 cents a share before items. Shares of Bonita Springs, Fla.-based distributor of music, movies and magazines rose three cents Friday to $9.41. (Corrects Thomson estimate.) CORRECT: Campbell Soup tops Wall St. earns view (9:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Campbell Soup Co. CPB, -0.23% Monday reported third-quarter earnings of $146 million, or 35 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $142 million, or 34 cents a share. The year-ago results included a gain of $10 million, or 2 cents a share, related to the settlement of a class action lawsuit. Sales rose 4% in the latest three months to $1.74 billion from $1.67 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 33 cents a share in the April period on sales of $1.76 billion. Looking ahead, the Philadelphia-based company confirmed its outlook for earnings growth of 5 to 7% from an adjusted profit of $1.58 a share in 2004. The stock closed Friday at $30.34, down 4 cents. (An earlier version of this item incorrectly stated a gain was included in the latest results.) American Oil & Gas reverses loss (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - American Oil & Gas Inc. AEZ, -4.74% reported net income Monday for the three months ended March 31 of $61,662, or less than a penny a share, reversing a net loss of $161,999, or a penny a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue from its oil and gas operations rose to $686,727 from $67,914. Shares in the Denver company gained 3 cents Friday to $3.14. Continucare profit falls, but revenue rises (8:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Continucare Corp. CNU, -1.37% Monday reported third-quarter net income of $1.47 million, or 3 cents a share, down slightly from $1.51 million, or 3 cents a share, a year before, citing lower income from continuing operations. Revenue rose to $29.8 million from $25.9 million. The company also said a restatement of its results for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2004 and first two quarters of the current fiscal year resulted in an additional $300,000 in net income for the three periods combined. On Friday the Miami health-care company's stock fell 1 cent to $2.40. Langer Inc. swings to gain on Silipos acquisition (8:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Langer, Inc. GAIT on Monday reported first-quarter net income of $1.4 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with a loss of $219,000, or 5 cents a share, last year. The company included a gain of $1.75 million from its acquisition of Silipos in the latest quarter. Sales rose to $10.4 million from $5.8 million. The company is not tracked by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Shares rose 5 cents to $6.79 on Friday. InterDigital issues revenue view; timing of arbitration (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- InterDigital Communications Corp. IDCC, +0.48% on Monday said it expects second-quarter revenue from current licensees and General Dynamics GD, +1.67% to be in the range of $37.2 million to $38.5 million. Work levels related to the agreement with General Dynamics "remain high," the company said. A postponement of a hearing to an expected date in October, from June, will allow InterDigital and Samsung "ample time to consider the potential effect" of their arbitration with Nokia NOK, +0.74% before the International Chamber of Commerce. Shares rose 27 cents to $16.72 on Friday. McData narrows 1Q loss (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McData Corp. MCDT said Monday that its first-quarter net loss narrowed to $2.9 million, or 2 cents a share, from $9.8 million, or 9 cents, in the year-ago period. On an adjusted basis, earnings would have been 3 cents a share, ahead of analysts' average estimate of 2 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue for the period ended April 30 increased to $98.9 million from $97.2 million in last year's first quarter. Analysts were predicting revenue of $99 million. Shares in the Broomfield, Colo.-based data storage company closed Friday at $3.29, down 9 cents. Printronix lifts qtr div 40% to 7c, pay 6/15, rec 6/1 (6:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Printronix Inc., PTNX the Irvine, Calif., manufacturer of integrated enterprise printing solutions, boosted its quarterly dividend 40%, to 7 cents a share from 5 cents. The company will pay the dividend June 15, 2005 to shareholders of record June 1. On Friday, Printronix shares rose a penny to $15.32. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said after Monday's closing bell that as a result of a tax errors connected to certain stock option grants, it has cut its 2004 net income by $243,000 to $18.9 million, or 30 cents a share. Pro forma net income was decreased to $10.7 million, or 17 cents a share. The impact to its 2004 payroll tax was about $395,000, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of non-lethal stun guns said. Amended results were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Taser said.
title: Taser cuts 2004 earnings on tax errors

content: Advancers Shares of Aastrom Biosciences astm, +0.00% rose 15.5% after the company reported positive results of a feasibility clinical trial of its Tissue Repair Cells for the treatment of severe long bone non-union fractures. Aastrom said the trial showed five of six patients receiving its TRC treatments showed bone regeneration at the fracture site as determined by radiographic imaging by six months. See full story. Agilent Technologies' A, +0.75% shares gained 4.3% after the company posted a narrower second-quarter profit, as sales and orders for its scientific instruments and testing equipment fell. In the three months ended April 30, Agilent said net income slid to $95 million, or 19 cents a share, from $104 million, or 21 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 8% to $1.69 billion from $1.83 billion a year earlier. Orders - a key gauge of future sales - dropped 9% to $1.73 billion. Excluding items, the company said earnings from operations fell to $101 million, or 20 cents a share, from $119 million, or 24 cents, a year earlier. That matched the consensus estimate of analysts compiled by Thomson First Call. See full story. Amtech Systems ASYS, +5.63% shares leapt 6.8% after the Tempe, Ariz., maker of technology manufacturing equipment reported second-quarter earnings of $500,000, or 18 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $100,000, or 3 cents a share. Revenue jumped 59% in the latest three months to $8.9 million from $5.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved results to the strength of its chip equipment business, which saw revenue increase about 84% on a year-over-year basis. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for Amtech's results. Big Lots BLI shares jumped 14.2% after the retailer reported fiscal 2005 first-quarter net income of $7.8 million, or 7 cents a share, up from $6.4 million, or 5 cents a share the previous year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson/First Call had been expecting earnings per share of 5 cents, the company said. Sales increased by 7.8% to $1.1 billion, while comparable sales rose 2.4%, after a 5.5% rise in transactions values was part offset by a 3.1% drop in customer transactions. The company expects same-store sales to rise between 1% and 3% range in May, by between 3% and 5% in June and by 4% to 6% in July. See full story. BJ's Wholesale Club BJ shares surged 4.6% after the company reported net income of $18.6 million, or 27 cents a share, for the first quarter ended April 30, up from $16.1 million, or 23 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Earnings for the latest quarter included 2 cents a share from special items. The wholesale-club retailer's overall revenue, including net sales and membership fees, reached $1.81 billion from the prior year's $1.65 billion. Analysts were looking for earnings of 24 cents a share on revenue of nearly $1.8 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. Cato Corp. CTR, +2.29% shares rose 4.1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $18.4 million, or 87 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $16.8 million, or 81 cents a share. Sales rose 5% in the latest three months to $215.1 million from $205.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales were flat. The Charlotte, N.C., women's fashion apparel retailer said the performance was ahead of its own expectations for earnings of 83 to 86 cents a share in the period due to strong gross margins resulting from tight inventory management. Looking ahead, Cato sees earnings of 40 to 42 cents a share for the second quarter and $1.73 to $1.81 a share for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimates are for earnings of 44 cents a share and $1.79 a share for the respective periods. Deere & Co. DE, +2.53% shares added 4.2% after the farm equipment maker earned $604 million, or $2.43 a share, on revenue of $6.62 billion in its second fiscal quarter, up from $477.3 million, or $1.88 a share, on revenue of $5.88 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of $2.13 a share and revenue of $6.05 billion on average. Looking ahead, Deere said it now expects earnings in a range of $450 million to $475 million for the third quarter and $1.55 billion to $1.6 billion for the year. Deere said production levels are expected to be down 7% to 9% in the second half of the year with most of the reduction occurring in the fourth quarter. See full story. Dick's Sporting Goods' DKS, +2.10% shares gained 5.2% after the Pittsburgh-based retailer earned $12.2 million, or 23 cents a share, in the latest quarter, prior to charges related to an acquisition. Revenue rose 57% to $570.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 20 cents a share and revenue of $566.5 million for the period. Home Depot HD, +1.99% shares rallied 4% after the Dow component reported earnings of $1.25 billion, or 57 cents a share, for the first quarter ended May 1, up from $1.1 billion, or 49 cents, earned in the same period a year ago. The Atlanta-based home-improvement retailing giant's quarterly sales rose 8.1%, reaching $18.97 billion, as comparable-store sales increased 2.1%. Wall Street was looking for earnings of 55 cents a share on sales of nearly $19.26 billion in the period, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. In addition, Home Depot restated its full-year forecast calling for sales growth of 9% to 12% and earnings per share growth of 10% to 14%. See full story. Shares of Jamdat Mobile JMDT leapt 12.8% after the company said it acquired a newly developed wireless version of the PC game "DOOM" as part of a multi-year license agreement with id Software. Jamdat will release "DOOM RPG" for mobile phones in connection with the upcoming "DOOM" motion picture release. Jamdat will also publish a second id Software game for wireless. Separately, Jamdat it said its mobile game Tetris reached double platinum status with more than two million downloads on Sprint phones. J.C. Penney Co. JCP, -0.98% added 3.2% after the company said its first-quarter profit soared to $172 million, or 63 cents a share, from $41 million, or 13 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings exceeded analysts' average estimate by 2 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Excluding discontinued operations in last year's first quarter, profit would have grown 46% from $41 million, or 38 cents a share. Sales for the period ended April 30 rose 3.9% to $4.19 billion from $4.03 billion a year ago. For the second quarter, the Plano, Texas-based department-store operator forecast ongoing earnings of 25 to 30 cents a share, including charges of about 2 cents a share. Wall Street's target stands at earnings of 31 cents a share. See full story. LCA-Vision LCAV shares gained 3.7% after the company's board authorized the buyback of up to 1 million of its common shares. As of March 31, the provider of vision correction service had 20.29 million common shares outstanding. Shares of Mad Catz Interactive MCZ, +4.17% leapt 12.7% after the San Diego-based provider of video game accessories signed a licensing agreement with Microsoft. The deal makes Mad Catz the official peripheral licensee for Microsoft's Xbox 360 gaming system in North America and Europe. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Newfield Exploration NFX, +4.31% shares gained 5.3% after receiving an upgrade from Banc of America. Other oil and gas companies were rallying on similar calls, including Forest Oil FST, +0.28% and Cabot Oil & Gas COG, +1.10% Novamerican Steel TONS shares surged 11.6% after Jefferies & Co. initiated coverage of the company with a hold rating and $32-$34 a share price target. "While we view TONS as a high quality company within the steel/metals distribution/processing segment, valuation is the fundamental issue relative to our intermediate term rating on the shares," analyst Bob Schenosky told clients. Staples SPLS shares rose 5% after the Framingham, Mass., office products retailer reported first-quarter net income of $159 million , or 21 cents a share adjusted for an April 15 three-for-two stock split. A year earlier the office supplies seller earned $125 million, or 17 cents a share. The company cited stronger North American sales for the 24% improvement in profit. The Thomson First Call analysts' average estimate was for earnings per share of 20 cents. Revenue rose 13% to $3.9 billion. The company projected that its 2005 revenue will post a rise over year-earlier levels in the low double digits. Vermont Teddy Bear Co. BEAR, +0.27% soared 20.8% after the company agreed to be taken private by an investment group led by Boston-based The Mustang Group. The Shelburne, Vt.-based company said under the terms of the deal that shareholders of its common stock not continuing as investors will receive $6.50 in cash per share upon the closing of the deal. The company expects the transaction to close on or before Sept. 30. It also said President and Chief Executive Elisabeth Robert will be retained. Decliners Avanex Corp. AVNX shares fell 3.6% after the company said plans to sell $35 million worth of its 8% senior secured convertible notes due 2008 in a private placement. The Fremont, Calif., company said the notes are convertible into shares of common stock at a price of $1.21 each. It plans to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including working capital and restructuring activities. Cogent Systems' COGT, -3.85% shares lost 8.9% after the company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of 11 million shares. The company said the offering consists of 4 million primary shares and the remaining of the offering secondary shares from executive officers and stockholders of the company. Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated and J.P. Morgan Securities, Inc. will serve as joint book-running managers for the offering. Collins & Aikman Corp. CKCR shares dropped 6.2% after the company filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, citing "mounting liquidity issues and the need for immediate cash to fund operations." The Troy, Mich., maker of cockpit modules said it has already received a commitment for up to $300 million worth of debtor-in-possession financing from JP Morgan Chase. Community Banks CMTY shares dipped 6.2% after the company was downgraded to neutral from buy at Janney Montgomery Scott due primarily to valuation. Weiss believes the Pennsylvania bank deserves to trade at a premium, given its strong management team and history of delivering consistent results, but feels smaller mid-Atlantic bank stocks already trade at a premium because of merger speculation. Delphi DPH, -33.33% shares tumbled 4.3% after Standard & Poor's Ratings Service lowered its corporate credit rating on the company o B+ from BB and its senior unsecured rating to B- from BB. S&P said all ratings were removed from CreditWatch with negative implications. The outlook is negative. S&P said the move is a result of Delphi's weak earnings and cash flow generation caused by difficult automotive industry conditions, particularly for its largest customer, General Motors GM, +2.45% It also cited Delphi's "high, inflexible cost structure" for the downgrade. DJ Orthopedics DJO shares fell 7% after Lehman Bros. lowered its rating on the stock to equal-weight, citing price. "DJO is currently within roughly $1 of our $30 price target and we are having difficulty justifying a new 12-month target with more than 20% upside," the broker told clients. Exide Technologies XIDE shares plunged 38.3% after the company said it expects to be in violation of its minimum consolidated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization and leverage ratio financial covenants of its $365 million senior credit facility. Exide, which makes lead-acid batteries, estimates that its adjusted EBITDA for fiscal 2005 will be in the range of $100 million to $107 million. Exide said it's working with the administrative agent for its senior credit facility to secure amendments to the covenants. Hershey Co. HSY, +0.72% shares tumbled 2.7% after the company was downgraded to peer perform from outperform at Bear Stearns, due solely to concerns over valuation. The stock closed Monday up 40 cents at $66.65, just below the all-time high of $67.37 reached in intraday trading on May 12. "While fundamentals remain stellar, the shares' powerful run and valuation suggest a priced-to-perfection scenario and a more challenging risk vs. reward proposition going forward," Analyst Terry Bivens said in a note to clients. Shares of Janus Capital Group JNS fell 3% following a surge on Monday following speculation that the Denver-based fund firm would be acquired by rival Franklin Resources BEN, +1.67% Janus has struggled after a bear market for growth stocks and a damaging trading scandal in the firm's mutual funds, but flows have stabilized recently and analysts say the company is well-positioned for a possible growth rally. Jo-Ann Stores JAS, +1.53% shares fell 10.7% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $4.2 million, or 18 cents a share, down 37% from restated earnings of $6.7 million, or 30 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue was $420.7 million, up from restated sales of $404.9 million last year. The fabric retailer restated some past results to correct accounting for lease expenses. See full story. Morningstar MORN, +0.72% shares lost 3.1% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $4 million, or 9 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $4.5 million, or 9 cents a share. Revenue rose 29% in the latest three months to $53.2 million from $41.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. The Chicago-based provider of independent investment research said results from its international operations were slightly below expectations in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, Morningstar lowered its estimate for 2005 walk-in revenue to $124.9 million from a prior projection of $129.5 million. Opnet Technologies OPNT, +0.68% shares fell 2.2% after the company posted a fourth-quarter loss of $651,000, or 3 cents a share. Last year, the company posted earnings of $2 million, or 10 cents a share. Revenue was $17.2 million vs. $16.3 million a year earlier. The Bethesda, Md.-based company forecast a first-quarter loss of 1 to 3 cents a share on revenue of $16.6 million to $17.5 million. Perry Ellis PERY, -1.64% shares tumbled 4.7% after the company said it expects to report first-quarter sales of $225 million with net earnings of $8.5 million to $9 million, or 85 cents to 89 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for earnings of 83 cents a share on sales of $259 million for the period ended April 30. The clothing maker also reaffirmed its fiscal 2006 outlook for a per-share profit of $2.25 to $2.35 and revenue of $890 million to $910 million. Analysts are forecasting full-year earnings of $2.29 a share and sales of $904 million. PRA International PRAI shares sank 4.5% after the Reston, Va., provider of clinical research services filed for a secondary offering of six million shares of its common stock. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of additional 900,000 shares. Saks Inc. SKS, +0.75% slipped 2% after the company said its preliminary first-quarter profit came to $17.1 million, or 12 cents a share, which was 4 cents short of analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. The Birmingham, Ala.-based department-store operator didn't provide year-ago earnings, as it is in the process of restating results for fiscal years 1999 to 2004. Sales for the period ended April 30 increased fractionally to $1.55 billion from $1.54 billion in last year's first quarter, which was just short of analysts' view for $1.56 billion in sales. Same-store sales, or sales generated at stores open at least a year, rose 1.9%. See full story. Steris Corp. STE, +2.37% gave back 11.6% after the company said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings slid 17.5% to $25 million, or 36 cents a share, while revenue rose 7% to $316 million. Increased raw material costs, lower margins in the Life Sciences segment and a higher than expected tax rate of 44.6% in the quarter weighed on results. Analysts had expected an EPS of 42 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Steris sees fiscal year 2006 EPS between $1.37 to $1.42 a share on revenue growth between 7% and 9%, compared to broker forecasts of $1.49/share. Steris also said it will make its first quarterly dividend payment, of 4 cents a share. Summa Industries' SUMX shares lost 10% after the company forecast a weak performance for the third quarter, citing a recent material decline in bookings for sales of its lighting products. The company now expects its results to come in "substantially lower" than its profit of 30 cents a share on sales of $33.2 million in last year's third quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 32 cents a share in the May period. Shares of Tag-It Pacific Inc. TAG, -66.67% dropped 31.1% after the Los Angeles supplier of fashion apparel trim items and other accessories such as zippers moderated its sales growth outlook for 2005. The company said it now expects growth of 25% for the year, down from its prior projection for growth of 40%. Tag-It also reported a first-quarter loss of $1.6 million, or 9 cents a share, for the first quarter, wider than a loss of $582,535, or 4 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Shares of Taser International TASR lost 11.6% after the maker of stun guns disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its 10-Q report for the quarter ended Mar. 31 would be delayed due to the "substantial amount of time and effort required to complete the restatement of its financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2004." Union Bankshares Corp. UBSH, -0.49% fell 2.7% after the company was downgraded to hold from buy at Legg Mason, due primarily to valuation. Willbros Group WG., +1.62% shares plummeted 30.9% after the oil services company forecast a loss of between $5 million to $7 million for the first quarter following an internal probe of the former head of its international business unit. The company also said the probe will lead to restatements of prior years that will reduce net income. Willbros added that it's cooperating with federal investigations. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: Palm Harbor Homes swings to quarterly profit (6:39 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Palm Harbor Homes Inc. PHHM after Tuesday's closing bell said it swing to a fourth-quarter profit of $1.99 milllion, or 9 cents a share, on sales of $147.7 million. In the same quarter a year earlier, the Dallas-based homebuilder lost $3.21 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenue of $129.8 million. "We have streamlined our company-owned retail operations, adjusted our Texas factory capacity, and further adjusted our cost structure to be consistent with current market demand," Chief Executive Larry Keener said in a statement. "As a result of these consolidations, we believe we have the appropriate capacity and the right cost structure to realize our goal of restoring Palm Harbor to profitable operations in fiscal 2006." Digital Recorders swings to quarterly loss (6:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Digital Recorders Inc. TBUS after the closing bell Tuesday reported a loss of $1 million, or 10 cents a share. Last year, it had a profit of $86,000, or 2 cents a share. The Dallas-based communications equipmaker maker said revenue was $10.6 million, down from $12.1 million a year ago. Photronics quarterly profit jumps 77% (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Photronics PLAB, +1.23% after the closing bell Tuesday reported second-quarter net earnings of $10.6 million, or 28 cents a share, up 77% from $6 million, or 17 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose to $112.9 million from $97.2 million last year, said the Brookfield, Conn.-based maker of photomasks used in semiconductor manufacturing. Borders Group Inc. swings to quarterly loss (5:14 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Borders Group Inc. BGP, -4.96% after Tuesday's closing bell reported a first-quarter loss of $5.3 million, or 7 cents a share. Last year, it reported a profit of $2.3 million, or 3 cents a share. Total revenue rose to $853 million compared with $838.1 million in the year-ago period. The books and music retailer forecast second-quarter earnings of 2 cents to 6 cents a share. The projection includes an after-tax charge of about 2 cents a share. Ann Arbor, Mich.-based Borders forecast 2005 consolidated earnings of $1.70 to $1.84 a share, including an after-tax charge of 9 cents to 11 cents a share. Borders also said it expects the July release of the sixth book in the "Harry Potter" to have a positive impact on its second-quarter same-store sales, and expects comparable sales to increase in the low single digits at its Borders superstores. Applied Materials Q3 financial targets below estimates (5:10 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Applied Materials Inc. AMAT, +2.87% late Tuesday said earnings for its third quarter will be 12 cents a share to 14 cents a share, below Wall Street's target. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call now predict earnings of 18 cents a share. In a conference call, Applied Materials said revenue will slip to a range of $1.58 billion to $1.67 billion. Analysts now project revenue of $1.84 billion. Hancock Fabrics Inc swings to quarterly loss (5:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Hancock Fabrics Inc. HKF, +5.77% after Tuesday's closing bell said that it swung to a first-quarter loss of $3.3 million, or 18 cents a share. Last year, the Baldwyn, Miss.-based specialty retailer posted a profit of $816,000, or 4 cents a share. Revenue declined to $97.8 million from $105.1 million a year earlier. Same-store sales fell 6.9% in the quarter. Wilsons The Leather Experts quarterly loss narrows (4:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Wilsons The Leather Experts Inc. WLSN after Tuesday's closing bell reported a first-quarter loss of $3.8 million, or 10 cents a share, compared with a loss of $26.8 million, or $1.30 a share, a year ago. Revenue fell 14% to $84.3 million compared with $97.8 million last year. Same-store sales increased 15.8%, compared with a decrease of 2% in the year-ago period. Its first-quarter same-store sales results did not include sales from stores that were liquidated. Wilson also said that sales for the prior year-to-date period included about $20.8 million in liquidation sales as it transferred inventory to an independent liquidator. Nordstrom net beats by 5 cents, lifts full-year target (4:19 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Nordstrom Inc. JWN, +1.06% said late Tuesday that first-quarter profit shot up 52% to $104.5 million, or 75 cents a share, from $68.7 million, or 48 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Earnings surpassed analysts' average estimate by 5 cents, according to Thomson First Call. Sales for the three months ended April 30 rose 7.7% to $1.65 billion from $1.54 billion in last year's first quarter, and ahead of analysts' view for $1.62 billion in sales. Same-store sales, or sales generated at stores open at least a year, advanced 6.2%, the Seattle-based high-end department-store chain said. Given the better-than-expected results, Nordstrom raised its full-year earnings target to $3.40 to $3.50 a share, up from its prior view for earnings of $3.25 to $3.35 a share. Analysts' average estimate stands at $3.38 a share. Second-quarter profit is seen coming in at 85 cents to 90 cents a share, in line with analysts' outlook for 88 cents a share. Nordstrom's stock closed up $1.69, or 3%, at $57.32. Abercrombie & Fitch sales rise 33% (4:13 PM ET) CHICAGO (MarketWatch) -- Abercrombie & Fitch earned $40.4 million, or 45 cents a share in its first quarter. That is up sharply from the $29.3 million and 30 cents of the year-ago period and 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue hit $546.8 million, up 33%, as same-store sales climbed 19%. Shares of New Albany, Ohio-based Abercrombie {s: ANF] added nearly 1 percent to close at $58.99 Tuesday. Shanda Interactive shares dip after Q1 report (4:12 PM ET) New York (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Shanda Interactive Entertainment Limited SNDA dropped 2.4% to $33.05 even after the largest operator of online games in China posted earnings for the first quarter of 2005 that were more than double the year-earlier figure. The interactive entertainment media company reported quarterly net income of RMB 220.1 million ($26.6 million), an increase of 205.9% compared with the same period last year. Diluted earnings per share were RMB 3.00 ($0.36) for the quarter, up 163.2% on a year-over-year basis. Revenue rose 118.3% to RMB 497 million. Hewlett-Packard earnings up slightly (4:11 PM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - Hewlett-Packard Co. HPQ, +1.06% on Tuesday said second-quarter earnings rose slightly as profit improved in the company's personal computer and corporate-enterprise businesses. Looking ahead, the company indicated that profit from operations in the third quarter would fall short of Wall Street's forecast. In the quarter ended April 30, H-P reported net income of $966 million, or 33 cents a share. Earnings rose slightly from $884 million, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 7% to $21.57 billion from $20.11 billion. Excluding onetime costs, H-P would have earned 37 cents a share. H-P was expected to earn 36 cents a share on sales of $21.4 billion, according to the consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Applied Materials profit slips 18%, orders drop 30% (4:08 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Applied Materials Inc. AMAT, +2.87% reported fiscal second-quarter net income of $305 million, or 18 cents a share, compared with net income of $373 million, or 22 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales fell 8% to $1.86 billion. The results topped Wall Street's estimate of 17 cents a share on sales of $1.8 billion, according to Thomson First Call. New orders fell 30% to $1.55 billion. Santa Clara, Calif.-based Applied Materials is the world's largest maker of chip equipment. Strong chip equip. biz drives Amtech's earns (2:11 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Amtech Systems ASYS, +5.63% shares leapt 5.6% to $4.16 in afternoon trades Tuesday after the Tempe, Ariz., maker of technology manufacturing equipment reported second-quarter earnings of $500,000, or 18 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $100,000, or 3 cents a share. Revenue jumped 59% in the latest three months to $8.9 million from $5.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved results to the strength of its chip equipment business, which saw revenue increase about 84% on a year-over-year basis. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for Amtech's results. Tag-It Pacific shares drop on lower sales growth view (2:05 PM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Tag-It Pacific Inc. TAG, -66.67% plunged 32% to $2.50 after the Los Angeles supplier of fashion apparel trim items and other accessories such as zippers moderated its sales growth outlook for 2005. The company said it now expects growth of 25% for the year, down from its prior projection for growth of 40%. Tag-It also reported a first-quarter loss of $1.6 million, or 9 cents a share, for the first quarter, wider than a loss of $582,535, or 4 cents a share, for the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. H-P shares move up ahead of results (2:04 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Hewlett-Packard Co.'s stock HPQ, +1.06% moved into the plus column Tuesday ahead of its expected second-quarter results. In recent trading, shares gained 8 cents, or 0.4%, to $21.09 ahead of the results, expected after the close. On average, analysts expect the printing and computer giant to post a profit of 36 cents a share on revenue of $21.36 billion, up from 34 cents a share and $20.11 billion a year ago, according to a Thomson First Call survey. United Technologies affirms 2005 EPS $5.90-$6.15 (1:28 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- United Technologies Corp. UTX, +1.10% Chief Executive George David on Tuesday affirmed the company's forecast for 2005 earnings of $5.90 to $6.15 a share on a pre-split basis. David also affirmed UTX's 2005 forecast for cash flow from operations less capital expenditures equal to net income before potential voluntary contributions of $500 million to pension plans. Hartford, Conn.-based United Technologies said David affirmed the outlook at the Electrical Products Group Conference in Florida. Analysts: Symantec filing amendments spark no concerns (12:33 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Symantec Corp.'s SYMC, +0.82% amendments Tuesday to regulatory filings made last year don't appear material nor raise concerns, analysts said. "We have reviewed the amendments and none appear material," Goldman Sachs analyst Sarah Friar said in a note. "We would view this morning's filings as a positive step forward in the filing of the much anticipated proxy [related to the proposed purchase of Veritas Software Corp. VRTS, +0.36% ]," she said. At Prudential Equity Group, analyst Michael Turits agreed, saying in a note his "initial review of the amendments turns up no changes to the financial statements, or anything we believe is material to valuing Symantec stock, or anything we believe would affect the merger process." National R.V. reschedules quarterly results release (12:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- National R.V. Holdings Inc. NVH, +0.00% on Tuesday delayed the release of its financial results for the quarter ended March 31 and postponed its related earnings conference call until tomorrow. The results and the call had originally been scheduled to take place today. Symantec amends past regulatory filings on results (12:22 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (MarketWatch) -- Symantec Corp. SYMC, +0.82% on Tuesday amended regulatory filings made last year on its results. Symantec made the amendments in response to comments by Securities and Exchange Commission staff related to its planned acquisition of Veritas Software Corp. VRTS, +0.36% Among the amendments, Symantec made a previously disclosed reduction of $20 million to its revenue for the quarter ended June 30, 2004, and increased its deferred revenue by the same amount. Taser Intl. to delay 10-Q filing; shares slide (11:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser Intl. Inc. TASR slumped $1.02, or 8.7%, to $10.66 Tuesday after the maker of stun guns disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the filing of its 10-Q report for the quarter ended Mar. 31 would be delayed because of the "substantial amount of time and effort required to complete the restatement of its financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2004." York reaffirms 2005 EPS view of low end of $2.60-$2.90 (10:53 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- York International Corp. YRK, +3.45% on Tuesday said it was still comfortable with its 2005 forecast for earnings at the low end of the $2.60 to $2.90 range. The view was given at an investor conference sponsored by the Electrical Products Group in Florida, York said. Dick's Sporting Goods beats Wall St. target (9:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Dick's Sporting Goods DKS, +2.10% on Tuesday reported a first-quarter net loss of $7.3 million, or 15 cents a share, compared with net income of $10.6 million, in the year-ago period. Without $19.5 million in integration and closing costs related to its Gaylan's acquisition, the Pittsburgh retailer earned $12.2 million, or 23 cents a share. Revenue rose 57% to $570.8 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 20 cents a share and revenue of $566.5 million. The company predicted 2005 adjusted earnings of $1.82-$1.87 a share, ahead of the current Wall Street target of $1.81 a share. Shares of Dick's Sporting Goods rose 99 cents to $34.09 on Monday. Fidelity National plans title insurance spinoff (9:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Fidelity National Financial, Inc. FNF, +0.53% on Tuesday said it'll distribute 17.5% of is title insurance operations to its shareholders. The Jacksonville, Fla. Fortune 500 financial services firm said its board OK'd a public distribution of a minority interest in the business. Shareholders will will receive 0.175 shares of the title insurance firm for each share of stock. The title insurance firm will pay a dividend of $1 a year, payable quarterly. "Separating the businesses that comprise FNF into distinct companies will provide improved transparency for the investment community and a potentially simpler means of valuing the assets of FNF," the company said. Shares traded unchanged at $33.79 on Tuesday. Jabil Circuit reiterates fiscal targets (9:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Jabil Circuit Inc. JBL, +1.74% on Tuesday reiterated its fiscal 2005 earnings and revenue projections due to an "unsubstantiated" news item posted online late Monday. The St. Petersburg, Fla.-based electronics maker continues to forecast earnings of $1.27 to $1.29 a share on revenue of about $7.5 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for earnings, on average, of $1.28 a share on $7.5 billion in revenue. Shares were off 16 cents to $28.92 in pre-market trading. The company's stock closed Monday's regular session at $29.08, up 48 cents. Time Warner mulling spinoff of AOL, Parsons says (9:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Time Warner TWX, +0.40% may spin off America Online as a separate stock if the online service fails in its latest effort to capture more online ads through its free portal, according to an interview with CEO Dick Parsons published in Fortune magazine. Parsons said AOL will offer an online search engine and features that previously had been available only to AOL subscribers. While Parsons said he has no timeline for a decision on an AOL spinoff, he added, "If this doesn't work, then you start to think about AOL much differently. You start to think about AOL in somewhat the same way I think about the cable company--we'd have access to the platform, but it would have its own currency to go out and do acquisitions or other deals. We'd have to find a way to maximize the value for our shareholders." Shares of Time Warner closed unchanged at $16.95 on Monday. Microchip Technology affirms 1Q estimates (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Microchip Technology Inc. MCHP, +0.22% said Tuesday that it affirmed its first-quarter earnings and revenue targets. For the period ending June 30, the Chandler, Ariz.-based semiconductor maker continues to forecast earnings of about 28 cents a share on approximately $218 million in revenue. Both projections match analysts' average estimates, according to Thomson First Call. The company's stock was off 4 cents to $29.29 in pre-market trading. Shares finished Monday's regular session at $29.33, up 25 cents. Strong gross margins lift Cato's quarterly earns (9:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cato Corp. CTR, +2.29% Tuesday reported first-quarter earnings of $18.4 million, or 87 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $16.8 million, or 81 cents a share. Sales rose 5% in the latest three months to $215.1 million from $205.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales were flat. The Charlotte, N.C., women's fashion apparel retailer said the performance was ahead of its own expectations for earnings of 83 to 86 cents a share in the period due to strong gross margins resulting from tight inventory management. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 86 cents a share in the April period. Looking ahead, Cato sees earnings of 40 to 42 cents a share for the second quarter and $1.73 to $1.81 a share for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimates are for earnings of 44 cents a share and $1.79 a share for the respective periods. The stock closed Monday at $26.65, up 2.7%. April revenue up 3.7% at The New York Times (9:01 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The New York Times NYT, +2.77% on Tuesday said April advertising revenue rose 3.7% to $221 million. Total company revenue added 2.7% to $324 million. Shares rose 20 cents to $32.92 on Monday. Morningstar Q1 earns $4M vs $4.5M (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Morningstar Inc. MORN, +0.72% Tuesday reported first-quarter earnings of $4 million, or 9 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $4.5 million, or 9 cents a share. Revenue rose 29% in the latest three months to $53.2 million from $41.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. The Chicago-based provider of independent investment research said results from its international operations were slightly below expectations in the latest quarter. Looking ahead, Morningstar lowered its estimate for 2005 walk-in revenue to $124.9 million from a prior projection of $129.5 million. The stock closed Monday at $21.98, up 2 cents. Deere & Co. EPS rise 29%, top forecasts (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Deere & Co. DE, +2.53% said Tuesday it earned $604 million, or $2.43 a share, on revenue of $6.62 billion in its second fiscal quarter, up from $477.3 million, or $1.88 a share, on revenue of $5.88 billion a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of $2.13 a share and revenue of $6.05 billion on average. Looking ahead, Deere said it now expects earnings in a range of $450 million to $475 million for the third quarter and $1.55 billion to $1.6 billion for the year. The maker of agricultural equipment said production levels are expected to be down 7% to 9% in the second half of the year with most of the reduction occurring in the fourth quarter. The company expects the lower production rates will bring down year-end trade receivable and inventory levels as company factories prepare for the introduction of new products in 2006. Barnes & Noble says it'll beat 2Q forecasts (8:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Barnes & Noble Inc. BKS, +1.02% on Tuesday reported first-quarter net income of $9.9 million, or 14 cents a share, down 13% from $11.4 million, or 17 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose to $1.1 billion from $1.06 billion. Net earnings from continuing operations increased 37% to $9.9 million, or 13 cents a share. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 11 cents a share and revenue of $1.1 billion for the retailer. The company forecasted second-quarter earnings of 19-21 cents a share, ahead of the current estimate of 16 cents a share. The stock rose 98 cents to $35.46 on Monday. TJX blames bad weather for profit miss (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The TJX Companies, Inc. TJX, +1.08% on Tuesday reported first-quarter net income of $149 million, or 30 cents a share, down 11% from $168.1 million, or 32 cents a share, last year. Revenue rose to $3.65 billion from $3.35 billion. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 31 cents a share and sales of $3.67 billion for the Framingham, Mass. discount retailer. The company cited adverse weather for biting into sales, but said it's "encouraged" by how business is going in the second quarter. Shares rose 53 cents to $23.20 on Monday. Summa Industries sees weakness in Q3 results (8:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Summa Industries Inc. SUMX Tuesday forecast a weak performance for the third quarter, citing a recent material decline in bookings for sales of its lighting products. The company now expects its results to come in "substantially lower" than its profit of 30 cents a share on sales of $33.2 million in last year's third quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 32 cents a share in the May period. The stock closed Monday at $8.10, down 9.7%. Saks net falls short by 4 cents a share (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Saks Inc. SKS, +0.75% said Tuesday preliminary first-quarter profit came to $17.1 million, or 12 cents a share, which was 4 cents short of analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. The Birmingham, Ala.-based department-store operator didn't provide year-ago earnings, as it is in the process of restating results for fiscal years 1999 to 2004. Sales for the period ended April 30 increased fractionally to $1.55 billion from $1.54 billion in last year's first quarter, which was just short of analysts' view for $1.56 billion in sales. Same-store sales, or sales generated at stores open at least a year, rose 1.9%. Shares in Saks closed up 8 cents at $16.94 Monday. Winnebago to restate earnings by 5 cents (8:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Winnebago Industries WGO, -0.53% said an error in a formula in an electronic spreadsheet will cause it to lower its second-quarter earnings by 5 cents a share. The Forest City, Iowa firm will restate its results for the period ended Feb. 26. The restatements will not have any impact on the company's cash position or its revenues for the periods affected. Shares rose 66 cents to $30.93 on Monday. Penney's net exceeds view, but cautions on 2Q (8:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- J.C. Penney Co. JCP, -0.98% said Tuesday first-quarter profit soared to $172 million, or 63 cents a share, from $41 million, or 13 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings exceeded analysts' average estimate by 2 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Excluding discontinued operations in last year's first quarter, profit would have grown 46% from $41 million, or 38 cents a share. Sales for the period ended April 30 rose 3.9% to $4.19 billion from $4.03 billion a year ago, and ahead of analysts' view for $4.17 billion in sales. For the second quarter, the Plano, Texas-based department-store operator said ongoing earnings are forecast at 25 cents to 30 cents a share, including charges of about 2 cents a share. Wall Street's target stands at earnings of 31 cents a share. Penney's stock closed up 17 cents at $47.83 Monday. WPCS International wins $7M wireless contract (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - WPCS International WPCS Tuesday said it won a $7 million 18-month contract from an unnamed wireless carrier to upgrade band equipment at 4,700 remote cell sites in 15 states. On Monday the company's stock rose 11 cents to $5.40. Thermo Electron ups earns outlook (7:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Thermo Electron Corp. TMO, +0.26% raised its 2005 earnings estimate to $1.49 to $1.54 a share from $1.42 to $1.47 a share, which would represent an increase of 19 to 23% over 2004. Revenue is now expected to grow 20 to 22% over last year to $2.65 billion to $2.69 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of $1.49 a share and revenue of $2.45 billion, on average. The analytical instruments company's stock closed Monday up 11 cents at $25.96. Thomson: CapEx spending rises 12.9% in 1Q (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Capital expenditures by companies in the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% grew 12.9% in the first quarter, more than double the historic average of 6%, according to a study to be released Tuesday by Thomson Financial TOC, -2.88% The quarter marked the fifth consecutive period of expansion. Information technology firms led the charge, with a 40.7% increase in capital expenditures in the first quarter, followed by materials firms with 24% growth. BJ's Wholesale quarterly net rises 15.5% (7:15 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- BJ's Wholesale Club Inc. BJ reported net income of $18.6 million, or 27 cents a share, for the first quarter ended April 30, up from $16.1 million, or 23 cents, earned in the year-ago period. Earnings for the latest quarter included 2 cents a share from special items. The wholesale-club retailer's overall revenue, including net sales and membership fees, reached $1.81 billion from the prior year's $1.65 billion. Quarterly sales amounted to $1.77 billion, up from $1.61 billion, as comparable-store sales rose 5.8%. Analysts, on average, had been looking for earnings of 24 cents a share on revenue of nearly $1.8 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. The company's operating income dropped to $25 million in the latest quarter from $26.6 million a year earlier. Shares of BJ's Wholesale rose 61 cents, or 2.2%, to end Monday's trading at $28.30. Staples profit rises 24% on North American growth (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Staples Inc. SPLS Tuesday reported first-quarter net income of $159 million , or 21 cents a share adjusted for an April 15 three-for-two stock split. A year earlier the office supplies seller earned $125 million, or 17 cents a share. The company cited stronger North American sales for the 24% improvement in profit. The Thomson First Call analysts' average estimate was for earnings per share of 20 cents. Revenue rose 13% to $3.9 billion. The company projected that its 2005 revenue will post a rise over year-earlier levels in the low double digits. On Monday the Framingham, Mass. company's stock rose 55 cents to $20.54. Zale Corp. earns rise, top expectations (7:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Zale Corp. ZLC, +0.65% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $14.5 million, or 28 cents a share, up from $11.5 million, or 22 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 26 cents a share. Revenue rose 6.7% to $515.6 million from last year's $483.2 million, while same-store sales increased 3.5%. The jewelry retailer's stock closed Monday up $1.27 at $30. Home Depot's quarterly net up 13.6%; outlook affirmed (6:16 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Home Depot HD, +1.99% reported net earnings of $1.25 billion, or 57 cents a share, for the first quarter ended May 1, up from $1.1 billion, or 49 cents, earned in the same period a year ago. The home-improvement retailing giant's quarterly sales rose 8.1%, reaching $18.97 billion, as comparable-store sales increased 2.1%. Wall Street, on average, had been looking for earnings of 55 cents a share on sales of nearly $19.26 billion, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. The company said it set several records during the latest quarter, as the average ticket totaled $58.25, gross margin widened to 33.5% and operating margin came in at 10.5%. The company also said it expects to sell its interest in the underlying real estate of 15 Expo Design Center stores that are to be closed. In addition, Home Depot restated its full-year forecast calling for sales growth of 9% to 12% and earnings per share growth of 10% to 14%. Shares of the Dow Jones Industrial Average component rose $1.08, or 3%, to $37.37 in Monday's dealings. Transgenomic narrows first quarter net loss to $2.9m (6:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Transgenomic Inc. TBIO said its first-quarter net loss decreased to $2.9 million, or 10 cents a share, fro.0m $3.9 million, or 13 cents a share last year. Total revenue dropped to $7.4 million, compared to $8.6 million the previous year, the research tool provider said. The results reflect the positive impact of the company's 2004 reorganisation, it added. EPCOR Utilities to buy TransCanada Power for $529M (6:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- EPCOR Utilities said it's buying TransCanada Power, which owns 11 power generation assets in Canada and the U.S., for $529 million from TransCanada Corp. TRP, +2.63% (CA:TRP). TransCanada expects to realize an after tax gain of approximately $200 million. Big Lots first quarter net profit rises to $7.8m (6:08 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Retailer Big Lots Inc. BLI reported fiscal 2005 first-quarter net income of $7.8 million, or 7 cents a share, up from $6.4 million, or 5 cents a share the previous year. Analysts surveyed by Thomson/First Call had been expecting earnings per share of 5 cents, the company said. Sales increased by 7.8% to $1.1 billion, while comparable sales rose 2.4%, after a 5.5% rise in transactions values was part offset by a 3.1% drop in customer transactions. Comparable store sales are expected to rise by between 1% and 3% range in May, by between 3% and 5% in June and by 4% to 6% in July, Big Lots added. UPDATE: Steris quarterly profit falls, misses forecast (5:19 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Health-care products maker Steris Corp. STE, +2.37% said fiscal fourth-quarter earnings slid 17.5% to $25 million, or 36 cents a share, while revenue rose 7% to $316 million. Increased raw material costs, lower margins in the Life Sciences segment and a higher than expected tax rate of 44.6% in the quarter weighed on results. Analysts had expected an EPS of 42 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Steris sees fiscal year 2006 EPS between $1.37 to $1.42 a share on revenue growth between 7% and 9%, compared to broker forecasts of $1.49/share. Steris also said it will make its first quarterly dividend payment, of 4 cents a share. (Updates to include separate statement from the company on dividend payout.) UK funds Schroders Q1 pretax up, mulls expansion invest (2:45 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. funds manager Schroders PLC(UK:SDR)said first quarter pretax profits rose to 50.4 million pounds from 33.6 million pounds. The year-ago profits were restated to reflect additional IFRS adjustments. "Profitability was strong in the quarter due to higher management fee revenues and good private equity returns," the group said. "We also continue to examine a range of external investment opportunities to broaden and accelerate the strategic development of our business." Funds were up 3.1% at 108.9 billion pounds at the end of March from the start of the year. The group also said Richard Horlick, Head of Investment, has decided to step down. Alan Brown, formerly Group Chief Investment Officer and Vice Chairman of State Street Global Advisors, will join the Board and assume Horlick's responsibilities on July 5. Marconi and Huawei sign mutual reseller agreement (2:41 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Telecommunications equipment provider Marconi Corp. PLC(UK:MONI) MRCIY said it has signed a mutual reseller distribution agreement with Huawei Technologies Co. Ltd., where Huawei will resell Marconi's microwave radio and associated network services for Huawei's wireless network projects and Marconi will resell Huawei's carrier-class data communications products to telecommunications services providers. Marconi said talks between the two companies are continuing over joint product development in several areas. Separately, Marconi said its fourth-quarter operating loss narrowed to 15 million pounds from 26 million pounds, with sales down to 346 million from 394 million pounds. Marconi sees fierce pricing pressure, 06 revenue stable (2:36 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Telecommunications equipment provider Marconi Corp. PLC(UK:MONI) MRCIY said pricing pressure remains "fierce" and this will impact gross margins in the 2006 fiscal year. It expects revenue from BT Group PLC(UK:BT.A) BT, +1.06% its largest customer with 25% of sales, to fall by 50 million pounds in 2006 from the after failing to win a key next-generation contrac, but expects overall 2006 revenue to be similar to that in 2005 on continuing high levels of customer interest and tender activity. Marconi said it expects the total cost of its recently announced restructuring to be 55 million pounds, and sees annual savings of 50 million pounds. Beyond 2006, Marconi sees further chain cost savings of up to 25 million pounds on an annual basis due competitive sourcing plans. Land Securities fiscal 2005 NAV tops expectations (2:31 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Britain's largest listed real estate company Land Securities PLC(UK:LAND)said Tuesday that fiscal 2005 adjusted diluted net asset value a share rose 9.7% to 1,460 pence. Analysts had been expecting the company to report net asset value of 1,443 pence a share, according to Dow Jones. The company said the value of its property portfolio rose by 10.3% to 9.4 billion pounds during the year, after strong growth from retail and London office property. The property company reported a pretax loss of 155.8 million, after taking an exceptional charge of 682.1 million pounds for debt restructuring. Last year pretax profit was 373.1 million pounds. BAA FY profit climbs on property sale, traffic growth (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.K. airport operator BAA PLC(UK:BAA)on Tuesday said pre-tax profit rose 36% to 733 million pounds, after 96 million pounds in exceptional profit from property disposals minus reorganization costs and with revenue up 7.4% to 2.12 billion pounds. Its profit before tax and exceptional items of 637 million pounds was ahead of Daily Telegraph-compiled broker forecasts between 610 million and 620 million pounds. Passenger traffic rose 5.4% in the fourth quarter and 6.3% for the year, and BAA sees London passenger traffic growth slowing to a 3.5% rise in the next year. It's proposing a final dividend of 14.3 pence to lift fiscal year dividend by 6% to 21.2p/share. UK shipbuilder VT Group sales, earns higher; upbeat (2:28 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British defense-related shipbuilder and support services provider VT Group(UK:VTG)said sales in the year ending in March rose 11% to 744 million pounds as pretax profit rose 63% to 42.9 million pounds. Orders at the end of March were up 11% on the same period in 2004 to stand at 2.7 billion pounds. "Shipbuilding has substantial growth opportunities both in the domestic and international markets for at least the next ten years," it said. "We anticipate that the U.K. Support Services defence market will start to flatten after the next four to five years." Yell to buy TransWestern for $1.6B; swings to profit (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Yell Group(UK:YELL), the U.S. and U.K. directories group, said its Yellow Book USA unit has agreed to buy TransWestern Holdings for $1.575 billion from Thomas H. Lee Partners, CIVC Partners, LLC and TransWestern's management. TransWestern is an independent directory publisher with core positions in California and Texas that had 2004 revenue of $358 million. Yell sees annual savings of around $69 million in its third year, and says the deal will be earnings enhancing in its first full financial year after completion. Separately, Yell swung to a fiscal year ending March 31 profit of 94.2 million pounds after year-ago costs from its IPO. Revenue rose 8.3% to 1.29 billion pounds, and profit before exceptional items nearly doubled to 117 million pounds. Enterprise Inns 1H pretax pft up 53%; says trading well (2:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- British pub operator Enterprise Inns PLC(UK:ETI)said Tuesday that first-half adjusted pretax profit rose 53% to 143.6 million pounds, while revenue almost doubled to 453.9 million pounds, from 240.3 million pounds last year. The results reflect the effective integration of the Unique business and investments in quality and profitability, the company said. It also declared a 56% rise in its interim dividend payout to 5.6 pence a share. Enterprise Inns continues to trade well in a challenging and competitive environment, it said. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser Intl. Inc. tasr slumped $1.02, or 8.7%, to $10.66 Tuesday after the maker of stun guns disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the filing of its 10-Q report for the quarter ended Mar. 31 would be delayed because of the "substantial amount of time and effort required to complete the restatement of its financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2004."
title: Taser Intl. to delay 10-Q filing; shares slide

content: Advancers AmerisourceBergen Corp. ABC, +1.29% tacked on 1% after the company said its board has approved the buyback of up to $450 million worth of its outstanding stock. The Valley Forge, Pa., pharmaceutical services company added that it still sees earnings from continuing operations of $3.10 to $3.50 a share for fiscal 2005 on revenue of about $49 billion. For fiscal 2006, the company affirmed its outlook for earnings from continuing operations of $3.60 to $4.40 a share. Blackboard BBBB shares surged 9.8% after the educational software maker reported first-quarter net income of $5.4 million, or 20 cents a share, reversing a loss of $1.8 million, or 33 cents a share, last year. Revenue climbed to $31 million from $25 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 15 cents a share on revenue of $30.6 million. The company expects second-quarter net income of 17-18 cents a share, compared to the target of 17 cents. C&F Financial Corp. CFFI, -0.38% shares rallied 7.7% after the company said plans to repurchase up to 180,000 common shares, or 5.1% of shares outstanding, at $41 each. Dell Inc. DELL shares gained 6.2% after the company said its first-quarter net income rose 28% as the world's No. 1 personal-computer company posted strong sales growth in Europe and Asia and ran its operations more efficiently. Dell earned $934 million, or 37 cents a share, for the three months ended April 29, compared to $731 million, or 28 cents, a year ago. Revenue rose 16% to $13.4 billion from $11.5 billion. Dell's sales and profits were in line with the average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. See full story. Delphi DPH, -33.33% shares leapt 11% after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $409 million, or 74 cents a share, reflecting weaker-than-expected production volumes from some of the auto-parts manufacturer's major North American customers and including restructuring charges of $31 million, or 6 cents a share. Revenue was $6.9 billion, down about 7% from the 2004 first quarter. Delphi earned $122 million, or 22 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Analysts, on average, had been looking for the company to post a loss of 31 cents a share on revenue of $6.78 billion. See full story. DuPont DD, +2.74% shares tacked on 1% after the Dow component received an upgrade to overweight from J.P. Morgan due to expectations for earnings growth of 26% over the next two years. Genta Inc. GNTA jumped 11% after the company said the phase III trial of its Genasense injection treatment for relapsed or refractory chronic lymphocytic leukemia met its primary endpoint of demonstrating a statistically significant increase in the number of patients achieving either a complete response or a nodular partial response. The company said, overall, 17% of patients receiving chemotherapy and the Genasense treatment achieved the response compared to 7% in the chemotherapy only group. Guitar Center GTRC shares added 5.7% after the company forecast second-quarter earnings of 39 to 44 cents a share, including charges of $3.4 million to $3.6 million, or 7 cents a share, on sales of $395.7 million to $406.4 million. The charges are related to its acquisition of Music and Arts Center. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting the company to report second-quarter earnings of 51 cents a share on revenue of $389 million. Looking ahead, the Westlake Village, Calif.-based musical instruments retailer forecast 2005 earnings of $2.59 to $2.74 a share on sales of $1.77 billion to $1.81 billion. Imperial Industries IPII surged 14.5% after the Pompano Beach, Fla., maker of building products posted earnings of $831,000, or 33 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $362,000, or 15 cents a share. Sales jumped 39.2% in the latest three months to $16.6 million from $11.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved results to higher sales volume and greater operating efficiencies. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Jackson Hewitt Tax Service JTX shares gained 8% after the company reported a 5.9% increase in the number tax returns prepared for the year ended April 30. The company raised its 2005 earnings forecast to $1.30 to $1.33 on revenue of $229 million to $232 million. Previously, the company said it expected earnings of $1.15 to $1.19 on revenue of $220 million to $225 million. LTX Corp. LTXX shares jumped 18.8% after the company forecast a fourth-quarter loss of 10 to 12 cents a share, vs. the average analyst loss estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 23 cents a share. Revenue is expected to be $36 million to $38 million, above analyst forecasts of $30.7 million. For the third quarter, the semiconductor test equipment maker said orders rose 25% from the second quarter to $39.1 million. Maytag Corp. MYG advanced 5% after the company 's board approved a 50% cut to its quarterly dividend to 9 cents a share, payable June 15 to shareholders as of June 1. The company said the dividend cut will allow more financial flexibility as it finalizes its plan to restructure manufacturing operations over the course of the year. Maytag now expects to have additional cash available for debt reduction and pension funding, as well as increasing its advertising and research and development expenses in the second half of 2005. Mesa Air Group MESA shares edged 3% higher after the company inked a deal with United Airlines Inc. UALAQ to operate an additional 30 regional jets. The agreement t brings Mesa's total United Express fleet up to 70 aircraft. The 50-seat regional jets will go into service over the next 12 months, the Phoenix-based airline said. Shares of Michaels Stores MIK, -1.40% rose 3.6% after Lehman Bros. upgraded the retailer to overweight from equal weight. Analyst Scott Nesson said the Irving, Texas arts and crafts retailer's new inventory system, which has already yielded sales and margin improvements, should continue to provide "sustainable benefits" over the next several years. Nobel Learning Communities NLCI shares leapt 9% after the West Chester, Pa., education services provider reported third-quarter earnings before items of $930,000, or 10 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $896,000, or 9 cents a share. Revenue from continuing operations increased 5.8% in the latest three months to $43.2 million from $40.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the improved results to its 3.3% tuition boost, an increase in enrollment at comparable pre-elementary schools, improved school labor management, lower interest expense and a reduction in loss from discontinued operations. Northwest Airlines NWAC shares jumped 8% after Lehman Bros. raised its rating on the company to overweight, saying the risk/reward profile on the stock has improved. The firm also lifted its price target on the stock to $9 from $7. Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% shares advanced 9.6% after the Santa Clara, Calif., maker of graphics and media processors reported first-quarter net income of $64.4 million, or 36 cents a share, up from its year-ago profit of $21.3 million, or 12 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue rose 24% in the latest three months to $583.8 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 28 cents a share in the April period.
