Pacific Sunwear of California PSUN shares gained 10.6% after the company said its first-quarter profit rose 18% to $17.6 million, or 23 cents a share, from $15 million, or 19 cents, in the year-earlier period. Earnings matched analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. Sales for the three months ended April 30 climbed 14% to $280 million from $245.5 million in last year's first-quarter. Same-store sales, or sales generated at stores open at least a year, gained 3%, the Anaheim, Calif.-based apparel retailer said. Shares in Taser International Inc. TASR surged 5.6% after the stun-gun maker said a cardiac study found "no significant cardiac dysrhythmias in 24 healthy human subjects immediately following an electrical exposure" from its latest model Taser X26. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% added 2.2% after the jewelry retailer reported first-quarter net income of $40 million, or 27 cents a share, up 9% from $36.8 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 12% to $510 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 24 cents a share and revenue of $493.7 million. Tiffany maintained its $1.45-$1.55 earning a share range for 2005, but cautioned, "earnings could be at the lower end of that range if full year comparable store sales in Japan were to decline by a single-digit percentage." Toro Co. TTC, +3.29% shares leapt 8.5% after the company said it now expects earnings of $1.28 to $1.33 a share for the second quarter, up from its prior projection for a profit of $1.15 to $1.20 a share. The Bloomington, Minn., lawn mower maker anticipates sales will total between $625 million and $630 million for the quarter, reflecting stronger than expected shipments of professional products and contributions from Hayter Ltd. to international sales. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of $1.18 a share in the April period. WCI Communities' WCI, -2.49% shares gained 2% after the company lifted its earnings outlook for 2005 Friday, citing a favorable business outlook and the closing of its agreement to sell a property in Jupiter, Fla. The Bonita Springs, Fla., builder now sees earnings of $3.50 to $3.80 a share, up from its prior projection for a profit of $3.10 to $3.50 a share. The company said the sale generated revenue of $100 million. Decliners All American Semiconductor SEMI, -4.32% shares slid 2.4% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $61,000, or a penny a share, down from a year-ago profit of $891,000, or 22 cents a share. Sales slipped in the latest three months to $94.3 million from $98.2 million in the same period a year ago. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. The Miami electronic components distributor noted business was soft in the quarter but said it doesn't believe this is a long-term trend. American Sciences & Engineering ASEI shares fell 4% after the Billerica, Mass.-based maker of X-ray inspection systems said fiscal fourth-quarter profit rose to $9.3 million, or $1.04 a share, from $1.8 million, or 24 cents, in the year-ago period. Net income benefited from a gain of $5.4 million from the sale of assets. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 increased to $27 million from $24.5 million in last year's fourth quarter. Cherokee International Corp. CHRK shares lost 17% after the Tustin, Calif., power supply products provider reported first-quarter earnings of $600,000, or 3 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $2.2 million, or 20 cents a share, and 3 cents below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales declined 13% in the latest three months to $32 million from $36.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the weak performance to lower than expected demand from certain datacom customers, the impact of transitioning certain programs to consignment hub arrangements, and unexpected sourcing issues with certain vendors. Continucare Corp. CNU, -1.37% dropped 27% after the company said it would restate financial results for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2004 and the first two quarters of fiscal 2005 after an error in an automated software system lead to an overstatement of revenue. For the fiscal year ending June 2004, revenue will be reduced to $101.7 million from $102.5 million. For the six months ending December 2004, revenue will be lowered to $53.1 million from $54.3 million. The provider of outpatient care services said it now expects earnings for the third quarter of fiscal 2005 of 2 cents a share, vs. 3 cents in the same period a year ago, and revenue of $29.3 million vs. last year's $25.9 million. Foamex International FMXI shares gave back 3.5% after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $10.9 million, or 44 cents a share, wider than a year-ago loss of $2.1 million, or 9 cents a share. Sales rose 6% in the latest three months to $332.7 million from $313.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Gross profit margins fell to 8.3% in the quarter from 12.7% a year ago. The Linwood, Pa., maker of polymer foam products said the results were generally in line with its expectations. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Goldman Sachs' GS, +1.00% shares slid 1.8% after Smith Barney lowered its earnings outlook for the company, citing expectations of revenue weakness in the second quarter. The firm made the same call on Lehman Bros. LEH and Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% See full story. Greg Manning Auctions GMAI shares lost 13% after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $8.2 million, or 29 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $6.5 million, or 23 cents a share. Total sales fell in the latest three months to $74.7 million from $82 million in the same period a year earlier. The estimate of a single analyst polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 31 cents a share in the March period. The company attributed the decline in revenue year-over-year to lower inventory sales related to its contract with Afinsa, although profits from this agreement improved. Kohl's Corp. KSS, +1.47% slid 3.4% after the company reported earnings of $124.7 million, or 36 cents a share in the first quarter, ahead of the $103.1 million, or 30 cents a share a year ago. Sales came in at $2.7 billion, up from $2.4 billion while same-store sales grew 3.7 percent. Looking ahead, Kohl's said it continues to target full year EPS of between $2.40 and $2.50, vs. analyst views of $2.45. A.G. Edwards lowered its rating on the company to "hold." See full story. Krispy Kreme Doughnuts' KKD shares fell 4.4% after the company posted a target date for releasing its overdue financial reports on its Web site on Thursday, only to remove the information later. According to a report on Dow Jones Newswires, Krispy Kreme was looking to release its first-quarter numbers on Aug. 30, but that date disappeared without explanation. See full story. The Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% shares dropped 13.7% after the Philadelphia-based automotive parts and services company reported a first-quarter loss from continuing operations of $2.39 million, or 4 cents a share, down from its year-ago equivalent profit of $15.1 million, or 25 cents a share. Revenue slipped to $564.2 million in the latest three month from $566.1 million a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 20 cents a share in the April period. The performance prompted a downgrade from Wachovia to underperform. Procom Technology PRCM shares lost 5% after the company said it's selling certain assets and intellectual property rights related to its disk-based networked data storage appliance business to Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% for $50 million in cash. The company plans to distribute $20 million of the sale proceeds to its shareholders. QAD Inc. QADI shares fell 13% after the Carpinteria, Calif., maker of manufacturing software cut its outlook for both the first quarter and full year, citing lower-than-expected license and services revenues and a charge of 2 cents a share related to facility exit costs. The enterprise applications provider took its first-quarter per-share forecast to a range of 6 cents to 7 cents on sales of $55 million to $56 million from a previous forecast of 12 cents to 16 cents a share in earnings on sales of between $57 million and $60 million. For the year, QAD now sees earnings of 40 cents to 50 cents a share on sales of between $227 million and $240 million. Its prior outlook was for a per-share profit of 50 cents to 70 cents on revenue of $235 million to $250 million. Ramco-Gershenson Properties Trust RPT, -0.96% shares slid 4% after the company received examination reports from Internal Revenue Service that seek to disallow certain deductions and losses taken by the company in its 1996 tax year and to disqualify it as a real estate investment trust for the period running from 1996 through 2004. The company said it disputes the IRS reports and that it plans to file a protest with the Appeals Office of the service. Shares of Sigma Designs SIGM, +0.40% fell 16% after the maker of digital media processors warned of a first quarter loss on a weaker-than-expected revenue performance. The Milpitas, Calif. company said it expects revenue to be in the range of $6 million to $6.5 million, down from $7.8 million in the year-ago period, and also lower on a sequential basis. The current Thomson First Call average estimate is for the company to break even on revenue of $7.99 million. Track Data Corp. TRAC, +0.00% shares gave back 2% after the company said the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission has recommended a civil enforcement proceeding begin related to the Well Notice issued to Barry Hertz, its chairman and CEO, in April. That notice was related to alleged insider trading by Hertz, and wasn't directed to the company or any other member of its management. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stock market futures pointed to a slight bounce-back on Friday, as investors react to the continued decline in commodity prices and a gain in Dell Inc. after the computer maker reported in line results. June S&P 500 futures rose 2.80 points to 1,162.00 and Nasdaq 100 futures were up 6.5 points at 1,464.00. Dow industrials futures tacked on 22 to 10,210, following the 110-point decline in the Dow on Thursday, amid weakness in commodities components Exxon Mobil XOM, +2.47% and Alcoa AA, +1.22% and retail behemoth Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% See Market Snapshot. "Whereas one should have expected equities to rally, they actually sold off. With economic news optimistic and yields moderately lower, it is a strange move, without a doubt," said analysts at KBC Securities. Data showing a rise in import prices had little affect on stock futures. Prices of imports rose 0.8% in April vs. expectations of a 0.5% rise, due to higher oil, metals and chemicals pricing. Excluding the 3.1% rise in imported petroleum prices, import prices increased 0.4%, the largest rise since November. Elsewhere, business inventories rose 0.4% in March, vs. expected growth of about 0.5%. European markets on Friday behaved similarly to U.S. equities, with oil producers Royal Dutch Petroleum RD and Total SA TOT, +2.65% pulling markets lower. See Europe markets. June-dated crude-oil contracts were holding under $49/barrel, while copper contracts declined in early trade Friday, weighing on London-listed miners. See London markets. The dollar continued to post gains against the euro and the yen, with one euro worth a 7-month low of $1.2623 and one dollar at 107.09 yen. Reports suggested that Russia on Friday may pay off $15 billion in debt owed to the "Paris Club" of sovereign countries. See Currencies. Commodities prices appeared to remain mostly under pressure, despite a 13-cent gain in June crude futures to $48.67. The Commodities Research Bureau Index was down 0.45 at a 3-month low 295.57, after falling 4.93 on Thursday. June gold futures fell 30 cents to $421.90. Dell in focus Shares of Dell DELL rallied $1.23, or 3.4%, to $37.84 in Instinet pre-open trading after the computer maker late Thursday posted a 28% rise in first-quarter profit and also matched Wall Street estimates for the second quarter. See full story. UBS upgraded Dell to buy from neutral, saying it believes the company can gain market share through calendar 2006 despite a potential deceleration in the PC market. Graphics chip maker Nvidia Corp. NVDA, +4.63% climbed 8.8% to $24.80 in Instinet after the company reported late Thursday first-quarter earnings and revenue that exceeded expectations. Also in the semiconductor space, LTX Corp. LTXX shot up 15% to $4.55 after the chip testing equipment maker's fourth-quarter loss outlook was narrower than expected, and its revenue forecast was greater. Another early mover was wireless technologies company Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% which fell 60 cents, or 1.7%, to $35.09 in Instinet after RBC Capital Markets downgraded the stock to sector perform from outperform. Analyst Apjit Walia said recent checks indicate that revenue momentum may be slower than expected for the June quarter and also may not be very strong for the September quarter. Elsewhere, Taser International TASR tacked on 55 cents, or 4.9%, to $11.75 in Instinet after the company said a study found "no significant cardiac dysrhythmias in 24 healthy human subjects immediately following an electrical exposure" from its latest model stun gun. Auto parts maker Delphi Corp. DPH, -33.33% reported a first-quarter net loss of $409 million, or 74 cents a share, reflecting weaker-than-expected production volumes from some of the auto-parts manufacturer's major North American customers and including restructuring charges of $31 million, or 6 cents a share. It also warned it would lose more than $350 million for the year as it revised lower its estimates for General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% production in North America by 6% to 8%. Another key broker note came from J.P. Morgan, which upgraded chemicals company E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Co. DD, +2.74% to overweight from neutral, saying it believes the company's earnings are likely to improve 26% over the next two years due to benefits from a positive pricing dynamic, cost cuttings and core volume growth. The broker told clients it expects du Pont to offset its cost pressures in 2005 with higher selling prices. The chemical company is a Dow industrials component. British spirits to doughnut maker Allied Domecq PLC AED, +0.57% said it has received a "highly conditional" potential offer from a consortium led by Constellation Brands, Inc. STZ, +3.37% and Brown-Forman Corp. BF.A, +3.59% Allied Domecq said the offer was subject to considerable due diligence, confirmation of financing and a number of other significant conditions. Allied said it was too early to say whether the proposal would translate into a firm offer. Last month Allied agreed to be acquired by French spirits maker Pernod Ricard SA for $14 billion in cash. British Airways BAB, +0.74% rose in London following a better than expected March quarter where it posted a small profit. The European airline upped its revenue guidance but also upped its fuel cost guidance for the next fiscal year. See BA story. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: Stock futures edge higher as Dell gains, dollar rallies

content: Pre-Open stocks action Stock futures were leaning higher as investors reacted to the continued decline in commodity prices and a gain in Dell Inc. after the computer maker reported in-line results. A Labor Department report showed U.S. import prices rose a larger than expected 0.8% in April. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global Markets Shares in London slipped as investors digested deal developments in the drinks and insurance sectors, while European bourses were pulled lower by oil and metals. Japan's Nikkei posted its fifth straight loss. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker Action Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% fell 3.3% to $34.50 in premarket trade after RBC Capital Markets downgraded the shares to sector perform from outperform. RBC said recent checks indicate that revenue momentum may be slower than expected for the June quarter and also may not be very strong for the September quarter. Analysts at Smith Barney lowered their second-quarter earnings estimates for brokerage firms Goldman Sachs GS, +1.00% Lehman Brothers LEH and Morgan Stanley MWD, +0.78% to below Wall Street consensus, citing weak revenue in several businesses. UBS upgraded computer giant Dell, Inc. DELL to buy from neutral, saying it believes the company can gain market share through calendar 2006 despite a potential deceleration in the PC market. The broker also said it thinks the company's foray into printers will pay dividends long term. Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded the auto sector to market weight from underweight, saying first-quarter results weren't as bad as expected. The broker said DaimlerChrysler AG DCX Volkswagen AG and BMW didn't warn, even when news could have suggested risks were on the downside. CSFB also noted large dividend increases at Renault SA and Michelin SA. J.P. Morgan upgraded chemicals company E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Co. DD, +2.74% to overweight from neutral, saying it believes the company's earnings are likely to improve 26% over the next two years due to benefits from a positive pricing dynamic, cost cuttings and core volume growth. The broker said it expects du Pont to offset its cost pressures in 2005 with higher selling prices. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Delphi Corp. DPH, -33.33% reported a first-quarter net loss of $409 million, reflecting weaker-than-expected production volumes from some of the auto-parts manufacturer's major North American customers. "We expect these pressures to continue for the remainder of the year," said Chairman and CEO J.T. Battenberg. Along these lines, Troy, Mich.-based Delphi revised lower its 2005 estimate for North American vehicle production by General Motors Corp. GM, +2.45% from which Delphi was spun off in 1999. GM remains Delphi's biggest customer. British spirits to doughnut maker Allied Domecq PLC AED, +0.57% said it has received a "highly conditional" potential offer from a consortium led by Constellation Brands, Inc. STZ, +3.37% and Brown-Forman Corp. BF.A, +3.59% Allied Domecq said the offer was subject to considerable due diligence, confirmation of financing and a number of other significant conditions. Allied said it was too early to say whether the proposal would translate into a firm offer. Last month Allied agreed to be acquired by French spirits maker Pernod Ricard SA for $14 billion in cash. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% reported first-quarter net income of $40 million, or 27 cents a share, up 9% from $36.8 million, or 25 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 12% to $510 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 24 cents a share and revenue of $493.7 million. Tiffany maintained its $1.45-$1.55 earning a share range for 2005, but cautioned, "earnings could be at the lower end of that range if full-year comparable store sales in Japan were to decline by a single-digit percentage." Shares in Taser International Inc. TASR rose 95 cents, or 8.5%, to $12.15 in pre-market trading Friday after the stun-gun maker said a cardiac study found "no significant cardiac dysrhythmias in 24 healthy human subjects immediately following an electrical exposure" from its latest model Taser X26. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company's stock closed Thursday's regular session at $11.20, up 54 cents. British Airways PLC BAB, +0.74% upped its revenue guidance for the fiscal year ending March 2006 due to the fuel charges it's imposed, but also said fuel costs will be more than anticipated. BA said it now sees revenue rising 4% to 5%, vs. earlier company forecasts of 3% to 4%, and said fuel costs should rise by 400 million pounds ($745 million) from its March 2005 year vs. earlier forecasts of a 300 million pound rise. Capacity and volume are expected to rise 3%, with fares being flat. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free e-mail service here. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Delphi, Tiffany, Allied Domecq in focus

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares in Taser International Inc. tasr rose 95 cents, or 8.5%, to $12.15 in pre-market trading Friday after the stun-gun maker said a cardiac study found "no significant cardiac dysrhythmias in 24 healthy human subjects immediately following an electrical exposure" from its latest model Taser X26. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company's stock closed Thursday's regular session at $11.20, up 54 cents.
title: Taser up in pre-market on cardiac study

content: Advancers Anheuser-Busch Cos. BUD, +0.28% shares leapt 6.5% after the St. Louis-based beer brewing giant disclosed Berkshire Hathaway BRK.A, +1.04% which is controlled by Warren Buffett, has become a significant shareholder. See full story. Archipelago Holdings' AX shares soared 59.7% after the company and The New York Stock Exchange agreed to merge and form a public company, NYSE Group Inc. See full story. Automatic Data Processing Inc. ADP, +1.54% shares advanced 3.7% after the company reported third-quarter net income of $338.3 million, or 57 cents a share, up from $300.3 million, or 50 cents a share, a year before, noting improvements in all its business segments. Revenue rose to $2.35 billion from $2.12 billion. The Roseland, N.J. processor of data for businesses projected 2005 revenue growth at the high end of the 7% to 9% range. See full story. Avocent Corp. AVCT, +0.00% shares gained 7.2% after the Huntsville, Ala., telecommunications switching products fell short of Wall Street's estimate with its first-quarter results but said sales activity increased later in the quarter and moved closer to more normal levels in recent weeks. Bemis Co. BMS, +1.75% shares rose 2.8% after the Minneapolis maker of packaging materials said first-quarter net income fell to $32.2 million, or 30 cents a share, from $43 million, or 40 cents a share a year earlier. That matched the average analyst forecast from Thomson First Call for earnings of 30 cents a share. Sales rose to $831.9 million from $684 million. Citing raw materials costs, the company cut its 2005 earnings outlook to 42 cents a share, matching its 2004 second quarter, and said 2005 earnings would be slightly ahead of 2004's $1.67 a share figure. See full story. CACI International CAI, +1.97% shares rose 18% after the company said fiscal third-quarter earnings rose 37% to $21.6 million, or 71 cents a share, up from $15.8 million, or 53 cents a share, last year. Sales in the quarter rose 44% to $414.9 million as the defense- and intelligence-related business grew. Analysts had forecast a profit of 69 cents a share with sales of $400 million, according to Thomson First Call. For the fourth quarter, the company now sees revenue in a range of $415 million to $425 million with earnings of 71 cents to 74 cents a share. Analysts had forecast a profit of 72 cents a share for the fourth quarter with revenue of $410 million. See full story. ChoicePoint Inc. CPS, +1.40% shares gained 10.2% after the Alpharetta, Ga., provider of identification and credential verification services reported first-quarter earnings rose 11% to $37 million, or 40 cents a share, from a profit of $33.3 million, or 37 cents a share, a year ago. Cypress Semiconductor Corp. CY, +2.05% surged 15.4% after the chipmaker posted a wider than anticipated loss in the first quarter but said it expects to return to profitability and revenue growth in the second quarter; however, at the worst case it expects to be very close to breakeven. DayStar Technologies Inc. DSTI shares rose 29% after the Halfmoon, N.Y., solar cell developer said it has produced the first solar cells using its Gen-II production methodology. Delta Air Lines' DAL, +1.63% shares gained 5.8% after the airline reported a first-quarter loss of $1.1 billion, or $7.64 a share, vs. a loss of $387 million, or $3.12 a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding items, the loss would have been $4.89 a share, wider than the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $4.76 a share. Revenue rose 3.3% to $3.65 billion, vs. analyst forecasts of $3.68 billion, amid a 3.5% increase in mainline passenger revenue. See full story. Shares of DoubleClick Inc. DCLK rallied 16.5% following a report in the New York Post that the company is near an agreement to be sold to buyout firm Hellman & Friedman in an around $1.2 billion deal. Earthlink Inc. ELNK shares added 12.2% after the company reported a first-quarter profit of $33.3 million, or 22 cents a share, up from a loss of $11.8 million, or 7 cents a share, last year. Net earnings before facility exit costs were $34 million, or 23 cents a share, up from $18.4 million, or 11 cents a share, last year. Revenue fell to $334.7 million from $351.6 million. The Atlanta-based Internet service provider was expected to earn 21 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Forward Industries Inc.'s FORD, +0.00% shares soared 42.5% after the Pompano Beach, Fla., maker of custom carrying cases reported a second-quarter profit of $2 million, or 27 cents per share, up markedly from earnings of $490,000, or 8 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier. Sales jumped 125 percent year-over-year to $11.2 million in the latest three months. Gevity HR Inc. GVHR shares rose 6.3% after the Bradenton, Fla., developer of employee management software products posted earnings of $8.2 million, or 29 cents per share, for the first quarter, in line with Wall Street's consensus view. The company also reiterated its outlook for 2005. Intuit Inc. INTU, +1.42% shares gained 3.2% after the maker of TurboTax said it expects fiscal third-quarter earnings, excluding non-recurring items, of $1.53 to $1.55 a share, which exceeds the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.47 a share, and revenue of $840 million to $845 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $800.6 million. For 2005, the tax and business management software company raised its 2005 adjusted earnings growth estimate to 21 to 24% from 15 to 20% and its revenue growth projection to 11 to 12% from 8 to 9%. Jamdat Mobile Inc. JMDT shares jumped 15.8% after the Los Angeles wireless entertainment products company said it has completed its acquisition of Blue Lava Wireless LLC for about $137 million, giving it the worldwide rights for a wireless version of Tetris. The company also sees revenue of about $15 million for the first quarter, ahead of its prior projection of $14.1 million. JetBlue Airways Corp.'s JBLU, +0.74% shares advanced 3.9% after the low-cost air carrier said it earned $7 million, or 6 cents a share, on operating revenue of $374 million, down from earnings of $15.2 million, or 14 cents a share, on operating revenue of $289 million last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 3 cents a share on revenue of $366 million, for the quarter, on average. See full story. Mobility Electronics Inc.'s MOBE shares rose 4.6% after the company said its iGo EverywherePower 3500 Series power adapter product will be sold by Apple Computer AAPL, +0.78% for use with the iPod portable digital music player in the second quarter. MoneyGram International Inc. MGI, +1.53% shares added 5.2% after the Minneapolis provider of global payment services lifted its earnings outlook for the full year to $1.11 to $1.15 per share. Its prior projection was for a profit of 93 cents to $1.03 per share in 2005. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% shares rose 6.7% after the Schaumburg, Ill., handset maker said its first-quarter net income increased to $692 million, or 28 cents a share, from $609 million, or 25 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 10% in the latest three months to $8.2 billion. See full story. Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% shares rose 6.6% after the Finnish mobile phone giant said its profit in the first quarter rose 18% to 863 million euros or 19 euro cents a share, well above the average estimate at 15 euro cents a share. Net sales were also above forecasts at 7.4 billion euros. Nokia's second quarter outlook was considered upbeat, with the group setting expectations for net sales to rise to 7.9 billion euros to 8.2 billion euros, up from 6.5 billion euros in the second quarter of 2004. Nokia said it sees earnings per share in a range of 15 euro cents to 18 euro cents vs. 15 euro cents in the year-ago period. See full story. North Fork Bancorp Inc. NFB rose 4.6% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $259 million, or 55 cents a share, up from $102.5 million, or 45 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Mortgage loan originations were $10 billion, up from last year's $8.2 billion. Northwest Airlines Corp. NWAC shares gained 9.4% after the company reported wider first-quarter losses, but J.P. Morgan analysts wrote that the stock was getting a lift from a belief the airline may be helped by possible pension reform. See full story. Oakley Inc. OO shares added 13.4% after the sunglass maker said first-quarter profit soared 74% to $7.4 million, or 11 cents a share, from $4.2 million, or 6 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 7 cents a share. Sales for the three months ended March 31 rose 10% to $141.8 million from $128.6 million a year ago. OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% advanced 3.4% after the company said it earned $2.6 million, or 2 cents, a share on sales of $2.3 billion down sharply from the $59.1 million, or 61 cents a share, on sales of $3.5 billion reported a year earlier. Excluding items, the retailer of office products earned $19.7 million, or 20 cents a share, in the March period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 21 cents a share on sales of $2.4 billion. Perini Corp. PCR, +0.00% leapt 9.7% after the Framingham, Mass., provider of construction services said it has received $954 million worth of new contracts in the first quarter, adding about $694 million to its backlog revenue amount. PMC-Sierra Inc. PMCS shares rallied 6.9% after the networking semiconductor company posted better than expected earnings for the first quarter. The company cited improving trends in Asia, growth in storage-related products, and a recovery in enterprise networking, wireless infrastructure, routing and laser printing. See full story. Power Integrations Inc. POWI, +2.55% shares leapt 12.5% after the San Jose, Calif., chip maker reported first-quarter earnings of $4.7 million, or 15 cents per share, a performance the company said was ahead of its expectations. The latest results included a gain of a penny per share from the recognition of previously deferred revenue. Wall Street's consensus estimate for the March period was for a profit of 12 cents per share. Pozen Inc. POZN, -1.89% shares soared 67.9% after the company said Trexima, a migraine treatment drug that it's co-developing with GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% reached statistical significance for all regulatory endpoints in two phase III trials. Pozen added that, after holding meetings with the Food and Drug Administration, it now believes no additional trials will be necessary for submission of the new drug application for Trexima. It expects to submit the NDA in the third quarter. Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, +1.30% shares rose 4.5% in midday action. Late Wednesday, the wireless communications technology company cut its forecast for the fiscal year because of declining growth in handset sales, offsetting a small gain in second-quarter profit. Qualcomm said 2005 revenue is now projected to range from $5.5 billion to $5.7 billion, down from prior guidance of $5.8 billion to $6.3 billion. Profit from operations is expected to range from $1.10 to $1.14 a share, below the company's previous target of $1.16 to $1.20. See full story. Rohm and Haas Co. ROH, +0.42% shares surged 4.6% after the Philadelphia specialty materials company reported first-quarter net income of $159 million, or 70 cents a share, up 39% to $114 million, or 51 cents a share, last year. The company was expected to earn 64 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 10% to $2.02 billion. The company also forecasted 2005 earnings in the $2.65 to $2.90 a share range, compared to $2.65 a share expected by Wall Street. Schering-Plough Corp. SGP, -1.28% shares gained 3.8% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $105 million, or 7 cents per share, up from a year-ago loss of $73 million, or a nickel per share. The latest results include charges of $27 million, or 2 cents per share, primarily related to employee termination costs. Sales jumped 21% in the latest three months to $2.4 billion from $1.96 billion in the same period a year ago. The Kenilworth, N.J., drug company attributed the improved results to the higher sales and higher equity income from its cholesterol joint venture with Merck MRK, -1.13% The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of a penny per share on sales of $2.17 billion in the March period. See full story. Taser International Inc. TASR shares leapt 24.7% after the stun gun maker said it received two orders for its X26 devices worth more than $619,000 in total from law enforcement agencies in the U.K. Tenneco Automotive Inc. TEN, +2.91% shares added 11% after the company reported first-quarter net income of $7 million, or 16 cents a share. A year ago, the company took a loss of $2 million, or 5 cents a share. Tenneco cited slight improvements in its original equipment business and a stronger aftermarket. Revenue rose slightly to $1.1 billion from $1.03 billion. The Lake Forest, Ill. company said its profit improved despite tough market conditions and sharply higher steel prices. Time Warner Inc. TWX, +0.40% shares rose 3.5% and Comcast Corp. CMCSK shares gained 2.3% after the companies agreed to jointly purchase of the assets of Adelphia Communications Corp. ADELQ for $12.7 billion in cash, plus a 16% stake in Time Warner Cable. See full story. Transkaryotic Therapies Inc. TKTX shares jumped 15.7% after the company agreed to be acquired by Shire Pharmaceuticals SHPGY for $1.6 billion. The deal is expected to close in the third quarter, pending customary closing conditions, and regulatory and shareholder approval. The company also said that it has entered into a license deal with Shire for its Dynepo products. Transkaryotic said that the license agreement will take effect only if the acquisition falls through. See full story. Unifi Inc. UFI, -0.33% shares rose 8.7% after the Greensboro, N.C., yarn producer posted a loss from continuing operations of $1.8 million, or 4 cents per share, for the third quarter, narrower than its year-ago equivalent loss of $33.6 million, or 65 cents per share. United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, +1.93% shares surged 4.9% after the package delivery giant reported first-quarter earnings of $882 million, or 78 cents a share, on revenue of $9.89 billion, up from a year-ago profit of $759 million, or 67 cents a share, on revenue of $8.92 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 73 cents a share, on revenue of $9.72 billion. The company noted that a change to its management bonus program had a positive impact of 4.5 cents a share on first quarter earnings and that it expects comparable benefits for the rest of the year. See full story. Valassis Communications Inc. VCI, +0.00% shares added 5.5% after the Livonia, Mich., marketing services company said first-quarter earnings increased 15% to $28.2 million, or 55 cents a share, from $24.6 million, or 47 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings, on average, of 53 cents a share. Revenue for the three months ended March 31 rose 18% to $279.3 million from $237.4 million a year ago. VeriSign Inc. VRSN, +1.86% shares jumped 13.6% after the Mountain View, Calif., provider of Web infrastructure technology and services posted earnings before items of $95 million, or 25 cents per share, for the first quarter, besting Wall Street's consensus estimate by 4 cents. The news prompted an upgrade from JP Morgan. See full story. Wabash National Corp. WNC, +2.97% shares leapt 14.7% after the Lafayette, Ind., maker of truck trailers posted a profit of $18.5 million, or 52 cents per share, for the first quarter, up from earnings of $6.9 million, or 23 cents per share, in the same period a year earlier, and 9 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. The company said gross margins swelled to 13.4% in the period from 10.4% a year ago due to a favorable customer and product mix and in-line increases in raw material costs. Sales rose to $256.1 million in the period from $221.6 million a year ago. West Pharmaceutical Services Inc. WST, +2.07% gained 15% after the Lionville, Pa., maker of syringes said it expects earnings for the full year in the upper end of its range for a profit of $1.37 to $1.47 a share. Whirlpool Corp. WHR, +1.28% rallied 8.7% after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $86 million, or $1.26 a share, down from $101 million, or $1.43 a share, earned in the 2004 period. The appliance manufacturer cited "significantly higher" costs for raw materials and oil, offset in part by price increases. Quarterly sales rose 6.7%, totaling $3.21 billion, with North American revenue rising 4.5%. Analysts' average profit and sales estimates, as compiled by Thomson First Call, stood at $1.11 a share and $3.12 billion, respectively. See full story. Decliners 1-800-Flowers.com FLWS, -0.42% shares fell 5% after the company reported a fiscal third-quarter loss of $2 million, or 3 cents per share, down from a year-ago profit of $1.9 million, or 3 cents per share. Revenue rose 17.1% in the latest three months to $157 million from $134.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The Westbury, N.Y., flower and gift seller said it significantly increased its marketing and selling efforts during the latest quarter. The average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for breakeven results in the quarter. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 5 to 7 cents per share in the fourth quarter Agilysys Inc. AGYS, +1.02% shares dropped 18.9% after the Cleveland computer technology distributor lowered its earnings outlook for fiscal 2005 to reflect weakening sales volume, and lower than expected supplier incentives. The company now sees earnings of 70 to 74 cents per share for the year, well below its prior projection for a profit of 90 to 93 cents per share. Applica Inc. APN, +2.27% shares sank 32% after the company said it expects to post a first-quarter loss of $22 million to $23 million, larger than its prior estimates. The maker and distributor of small household appliances cited an inventory write-down due to lower-than-expected demand, increased product warranty returns and related expenses, and additional losses in its Mexico manufacturing operations as reasons for the loss forecast. Shares of BearingPoint Inc. BE, +0.49% plummeted 32% after the consulting firm said late Wednesday that it planned to privately sell $250 million worth of convertible debt. The company said it would use the proceeds from the sale to replace or collateralize letters of credit and to support surety bonds. J.P. Morgan followed by downgrading the stock to neutral from overweight, saying the offering suggests the company's situation appeared to be worse than expected. Briggs & Stratton Corp. BGG, +0.47% shares lost 4.8% after the Milwaukee engine products maker reported third-quarter net income of $80.6 million or $1.56 a share, up from a year-ago profit of $71.3 million or $1.44 a diluted share, last year, but a penny below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company also forecasted 2005 earnings of $2.76 to $2.85 a share, below Wall Street's consensus estimate of $3.14 a share. Deckers Outdoor Corp. DECK, -0.22% shares dropped 25.2% after the Goleta, Calif., footwear maker forecast earnings of 28 to 30 cents per share in the second quarter, well below Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 43 cents per share in the March period. The company cited unseasonable weather and lower expectations from its international business for the weak outlook. Enzon Pharmaceuticals Inc. ENZN, +0.00% shares lost 14.8% after the company said its chief financial officer, Kenneth Zuerblis, has resigned for personal reasons. The drugmaker said Zuerblis will remain as a consultant while the company searches for a replacement. See full story. Epicor Software Corp. EPIC, +0.00% shares tumbled 5% after the Irvine, Calif., company was downgraded by Needham to "buy" after its quarterly results came in a penny below Wall Street's consensus estimate. Hub Group Inc. HUBG, +2.45% shares dropped 6.9% after the Downers Grove, Ill., provider of freight transportation management services bested earnings expectations for its first-quarter results but fell short on its revenue total. See full story. Omnicell Inc. OMCL, +2.60% shares lost 11.5% after the Mountain View, Calif., maker of medical patient safety products forecast a pro forma loss of 10 to 12 cents per share for the first quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 3 cents per share in the March period. Outback Steakhouse Inc. OSI, -2.84% shares dipped 2.3% after the Tampa, Fla.-based restaurant operator reported first-quarter net income of $51 million, or 66 cents a share, up from $47.8 million, or 61 cents, earned in the same period last year. The restaurant chain's total revenue reached $895.1 million from $793.7 million in the 2004 first quarter, up 12.8%. According to Thomson First Call, analysts had been looking for earnings of 67 cents a share on revenue of $930 million. Redback Networks Inc. RBAK shares fell 6.1% after the San Jose, Calif., maker of broadband networking systems maker posted an in-line loss before items for the first quarter. See full story. SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% shares tumbled 5.9% after the company, whish is commonly known as Sallie Mae, reported its first-quarter net income slipped 23% from year-ago levels. The educational lender company posted first quarter net income of $223 million, or 49 cents a share, compared to $291 million, or 61 cents a share a year ago. See full story. Spirent Plc SPM, -2.87% shares were off 18.8% after the U.K.-based telecommunications equipment testing company said its operating profits for the first half will be significantly worse than expected due to a delay in capital spending on leased lines and digital-subscriber-line businesses. Shares of Yum Brands Inc. YUM, +1.04% fell 4.3% after the parent company of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell restaurants posted a first-quarter profit of $161 million, or 53 cents a share on sales of $2.05 billion. This performance beat Wall Street's consensus view by a penny but the company said its sales at Pizza Hut locations in China would continue to be hurt by an issue with a seasoning supplier. See full story. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said Tuesday it earned $168,000 on revenue of $10.2 million in the first quarter. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of stun guns said profitability was impacted negatively by increased legal, insurance and professional fees as well as lower than expected gross margins resulting from the revenue decline. "As we noted in our first quarter earnings estimate on April 1, 2005, we experienced a significant disruption in the flow of new business in the first quarter," said Taser CEO Rick Smith. The company also announced that subsequent to the issuance of its audited financial statements for 2004 an error was found that resulted from the company's calculation of the future tax benefit to be received from employee's sale of stock received from the exercise of options and other tax effects of option exercises. Taser said correction of the error will result in an as yet undetermined increase in deferred tax assts, accrued expenses and additional paid-in capital and won't have a significant effect on results of operations or cash flows.
title: Taser results hurt by lower margins; finds '04 error

content: Devcon Int'l files for 15-day 10-K filing extension (6:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Devcon International Corp. DEVC, +0.00% after Friday's closing bell said that it has filed for a 15-day extension to file its 2004 Form 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Deerfield Beach, Fla.-based company said its 10-K will report an $11 million increase in interest and other income. Devcon also expects its consolidated operating loss will be cut by $5 million, largely as a result of an increase in revenue and corresponding gross margin in its construction division. For the three months ended Dec. 31, Devcon expects its operating loss will be about $2 to $3 million wider than the same period a year earlier. AMI Semi reduces debt, sees 1.5c increase to Q2 EPS (3:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- AMI Semiconductor Inc., a unit of AMIS Holdings AMIS said Friday that it has purchased 100% of the total outstanding principal amount of its 10-3/4% senior subordinated notes and has completed the refinancing of its senior secured credit facilities. The refinancing will add to second-quarter earnings of about 1.5 cents a share and about 5 cents a share for the remainder of 2005, the Pocatello, Idaho-based firm said. CORRECT: Ipix Corp swings to Q4 loss (3:16 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Ipix Corp. IPIX, -4.59% Thursday night said it swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $4.8 million, or 22 cents a share. Last year, the company made $529,000, or a penny share. The Vienna, Va.-based company said its revenue rose to $909,000 from $499,000 a year earlier. (This corrects an earlier item that incorrectly stated that the company swung to a profit in the quarter. Corresponding numbers have also been corrected.) Century Casinos sees 2004 EPS 36c (3:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Century Casinos Inc. CNTY, -0.13% has filed for a 15-day extension to file its 2004 10-K with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said Friday. The Colorado Springs, Colo.-based casino company forecast earnings for the full-year period ended Dec. 31 of 36 cents a share compared with a 24-cent per-share profit the year before. The increase is primarily due to a recovery of receivables in the its South African subsidiary that were written off in 2002, and a lower effective income tax rate for its international operations, Century Casinos said in a statement. Cornell closes $10M Correctional Systems purchase (12:45 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cornell Companies Inc. CRN, +0.33% said Friday that its has completed its $10 million acquisition of Correctional Systems Inc. CRXS The deal is expected to generate annual revenue of about $16 million and immediately add to the Houston-based company's 2005 earnings. Specialists lost $38M in 2004 vs. $3M profit in 2003 (11:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Specialists on the New York Stock Exchange reported a $38 million loss for 2004, down from a $3 million profit for 2003, according to year-end results issued by the Big Board late Thursday. Revenues fell 8.7 percent to $902 million. Shares of two stand-alone specialists were mixed: Van der Moolen VDM fell 10 cents to $7.24. LaBranche shares fell 1.8 percent to $9.13. Specialists lost $38M in 2004 vs. $3M profit in 2003 (11:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Specialists on the New York Stock Exchange reported a $38 million loss for 2004, down from a $3 million profit for 2003, according to year-end results issued by the Big Board late Thursday. Revenues fell 8.7 percent to $902 million. Shares of two stand-alone specialists were mixed: Van der Moolen VDM fell 10 cents to $7.24. LaBranche shares fell 1.8 percent to $9.13. Exelis, Bayer CropScience, GenOptera amend agreement (9:58 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Exelixis Inc. EXEL, -0.94% said Friday that the company, Bayer CropScience and GenOptera LLC have mutually agreed to end the research phase of the insecticide collaboration they have had in place since 2000. GenOptera is a joint venture established by Exelixis and Bayer CropScience to facilitate the development of new insecticides. Under the terms of the amended collaboration, the obligations of Bayer CropScience to fund further research cease and Exelixis will have no further obligations to perform research for GenOptera. As a result of the amendment, Exelixis expects to recognize $21.1 million in revenue in 2005, which consists of a termination payment by Bayer CropScience and the accelerated recognition of deferred revenue. Massey Energy to recognize $46M gain from Big Elk sale (9:52 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Massey Energy Co. MEE, +1.42% said Friday that it has completed the sale of its ownership interest in the property known as Big Elk Mining Co., to a privately held coal company for $52 million in cash and non-interest bearing notes, plus the assumption of $10 million in debt. Terms of the sale included an initial payment of $22 million in cash and $30 million payable over a two-and-a-half year period beginning in January of 2006. Massey Energy said it expects to recognize a pre-tax gain of approximately $46 million on the sale, $28 to $32 million of which is expected to be recorded in the first quarter of 2005. Cardinal Health: 2005 EPS may be 10c less than forecast (9:28 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Cardinal Health CAH, +0.94% said Friday that its 2005 earnings per share could come in about 10 cents less than it previously forecast due to short-term earnings. The volatility is being driven primarily by vendor margin volatility in its pharmaceutical distribution business and a lag in the installation of committed contracts for its Pyxis products, Cardinal Health said in a company statement. On Feb. 4, the provider of products and services supporting the health care industry forecast earnings per share for fiscal 2005 to be $3.20 to $3.40, excluding special items and non-recurring charges. Cardinal Health continues to its expect 2006 EPS to grow at a rate considerably above its long-term growth goal of mid-teens or better, excluding special items and non-recurring charges. The updated outlook was made by Chairman and CEO Robert Walter at an investor presentation. Red Hat shares reverse course and head higher after Q4 (8:48 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Red Hat RHAT reversed course and headed 3.6 percent higher on in pre-market action Friday in a volatile reaction to its fourth-quarter earnings. Robert Baird upped its rating on Red Had to "outperform" from "neutral" and said booking trends "remained solid" for the company. Outlook for the first quarter called for revenue of $61-$62 million and earnings per share of 5 cents, compared to consensus expectations of $61 million and 5 cents, Robert Baird noted. Shares advanced 39 cents to $11.30, after falling as low as $10.52 in evening action, down 3.6 percent from its Thursday close of $10.91. Best Buy sees Q1 and fiscal 2006 EPS below Street view (8:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% said Friday it sees fiscal first quarter earnings of 27 to 32 cents a share from continuing operations and fiscal 2006 earnings earnings of $2.95 to $3.10 a share, including stock-based compensation expense of 5 cents a share in the quarter and 17 cents a share in the year. The average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson First Call were for earnings of 38 cents a share for the quarter and $3.31 for the year, excluding the expense. The electronics retailer said it sees first quarter same-store sales up in the low single-digits and 2006 same-store sales up 4% to 5%. Best Buy shares fell 2.8% to $52.50 in premarket trading. National RV delays 10-K to assess financial controls (8:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - National R.V. Holdings NVH, +0.00% Friday said it delayed its filing of its Form 10-K, citing its "need to finalize its required review procedures and enable management to finalize its assessment of internal control over financial reporting as of Dec. 31, 2004." The Perris, Calif. motor homes manufacturer said it will restate its results for 2000, 2001 and 2002. The company also will restate for the third quarter of 2004 and revise its data for the recent fourth quarter. The company estimated the changes will reduce its third-quarter net income by 2 cents a share. On Thursday the company's stock fell 1 cent to $10.16. Best Buy Q4 profit, sales rise (8:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% said Friday fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 22 percent to $572 million, or $1.69 a share, from $469 million, or $1.40 a share, in the same period a year earlier. Earnings from continuing operations came to $1.55 a share, which matched analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue for the three months ended Feb. 26 increased 9.2 percent to $9.23 billion from $8.45 billion in the prior-year period, also matching analysts' view. The nation's largest consumer electronics retailer saw its shares fall 20 cents to $53.81 in pre-market trading. Nat'l Instruments warns of Q1 results shortfall (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- National Instruments NATI, +2.68% warned that first-quarter earnings would be 12 cents a share, below prior projections of 16 to 20 cents a share, due primarily to reduced orders for large systems and instrument control sales. Revenue is expected to rise 4 percent over year-earlier levels to $130 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $136.6 million. The virtual instrumentation technology company's stock closed Thursday down 17 cents at $27.05. Service Corp. 4Q earns fall, restates first 3Q of 2004 (8:17 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Service Corporation International SCI, +0.45% said fourth-quarter net income fell to $25.9 million, or 8 cents a share, from $30.4 million, or 10 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Excluding exceptional items the cemetery operator would have reported earnings of 7 cents a share compared to 12 cents a share a year ago. Service Corporation also restated financial results for the first three quarters of 2004 due to non-cash adjustments made as a result of ongoing projects to verify trust assets and backlog records. Looking ahead, the company said it sees 2005 net income from continuing operations in the range of 32 cents to 37 cents a share. DaimlerChrysler exec: Too costly to close down Smart (8:01 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- On a conference call with investors, Eckhard Cordes, head of the Mercedes Car Group, said the group is committed to developing the Smart concept and that closing down the whole Smart "system", which was an option, was considered too costly. Regarding the Smart Forfour, with which the automaker cooperates with Mitsubishi Motors, he said: "The costs to stop selling the Smart Forfour are so high that it doesn't make any sense... It's a good car. It will reach breakeven. It's cash positive, so it makes no sense to stop this." The executives confirmed that the job cuts related to the Smart reorganization in DaimlerChrysler DCX (DE:710000)are seen at around 700. Humphrey Hospitality lifts div 20% to 6 cents a share (7:15 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Humphrey Hospitality Trust, Inc. HUMP said it has raised it dividend by 20% to 6 cents a share. The dividend payment will be distributed on May 2 to shareholders of record as of April 15. Delta and Pine Land Q2 earns 48c vs 24c (7:12 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Delta and Pine Land Co. DLP said it earned $19.2 million, or 48 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $9.4 million, or 24 cents a share, a year ago. The Scott, Miss. breeder and producer of cotton planting seed said revenue climbed to $119.9 million from $89.2 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 47 cents a share on revenue of $117.8 million. Shares ended Thursday up 1.5 percent at $27. PSS World Medical lifts 2005 earns estimate to 60c/shre (7:11 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch)-- PSS World Medical, Inc. PSSI, +2.15% lifted its 2005 earnings estimate to 60 cents a share, up from a previous forecast of a range of 57 cents to 59 cents a share. The company, which distributes medical products to physicians and elder care providers, said the forecast includes an exceptional tax gain of 9 cents a share. Taser Int'l Q1 rev. to miss expectations (7:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International TASR said it expects first-quarter revenue of $10 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $13.6 million. The stun gun maker attributes the expected sales shortfall to disruption in the flow of new business resulting from "significant adverse publicity" regarding the risks from the use of its products. The company said it has launched an education campaign to address these issues. The stock closed Thursday down 44 cents at $12. Digimarc delays filing Form 10-K to complete review (5:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Digital security firm Digimarc Corp. DMRCE said its 2004 Form 10-K and third-quarter Form 10-Q will be delayed beyond March 31 in order to complete its review of its draft filings. The company expects to file the forms "within a few business days." Progenics offer shares at $15.25/share (5:12 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Progenics Pharmaceuticals Inc. PGNX, +1.22% said it will offer 2 million shares to the public at $15.25 a share. Proceeds to the company are expected to be around $29.3 million, Progenics said. DaimlerChrysler focus on Smart Fortwo, end Smart SUV (1:53 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German-American automaker DaimlerChrysler DCX (DE:710000)plans to end production of the Smart Roadster at the end of this year and said the Smart SUV project will be discontinued as part of its reorganization of the ailing business in the Mercedes division. The group is aiming at a breakeven position for Smart in 2007 and said it plans to continue cooperation with Mitsubishi Motors on the Smart Forfour, although noted "measures will be taken" to improve profitability. It said "the new product concept calls for the intensified development of the successor to the Smart Fortwo, including fulfilling the requirements for the U.S. market." The group's Supervisory Board will make a decision at the end of April on the concept. Icap sees fiscal 2005 profit at high end of forecasts (1:50 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- ICAP(UK:IAP), the interdealer in derivatives, foreign exchange and fixed income, said Friday that it sees fiscal pretax 2005 profit before exceptional items and goodwill amortization at the top end of current market expectations ranging between 172 million pounds and 175 million pounds. The company said performance of its electronic broking businesses has continued to be particularly strong. DaimlerChrysler to reorganize Smart unit, costs $1.5bln (1:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- German-American automaker DaimlerChrysler DCX (DE:710000)expects restructuring costs of up to 1.2 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in 2005 as it reorganizes the ailing Smart car business in the Mercedes division. The automaker said the costs will impact its earnings outlook for 2005. "Excluding the exceptional charge from Smart, DaimlerChrysler, after a weaker first and second quarter, still expects a slightly higher operating profit for full year 2005 compared to 2004," it said. The group foresees "significant workforce reductions." It also said plans include "write-downs on plant and equipment, the settlement of obligations to third parties,and other value adjustments." More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Movers in Friday's regular session including Xybernaut Corp., Red Hat Inc. and Transmeta Corp. stayed active late following a volatile day for the stock market, while Isonics Corp. shares gained after announcing an acquisition. The Nasdaq-100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks evening action of the technology-heavy index's leading shares, dipped 0.15 points to 1469.2. Xybernaut Corp. XYBR shares lost 1 cent, or 4%, to 23 cents in solid trading on Inet after getting crushed by nearly 43% in the regular session. The company said late Thursday that it would delay for a second time filing its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission because of a continuing internal investigation. See full story. Transmeta Corp. TMTA shares tacked on extra 4% to $1.04 after gaining nearly 8% to $1.00 on Friday afternoon. Late Thursday it announced new leadership, job cuts and a multiyear deal with Sony Corp. SNE, +0.54% See full story. Isonics ISON, -99.00% shares picked up nearly 7% to $2.62 after it said it has signed a letter of intent to acquire the Institut fur Umwelttechnologien-Berlin for about $1.4 million in cash and stock. The Golden, Colo.-based company already has a 6% stake in the German-based advanced technology company. Red Hat RHAT shares gained 2 more cents late, trading up to $12.18 after moving up more than 11% to $12.16 in the regular session. On Thursday, the software maker reported after the bell that its earnings that more than doubled, meeting analysts' estimates. The company also expanded its stock buyback program. See full story. Taser International Inc. TASR shares gained 2 cents to $10.43 late Friday after losing more than 13% during the regular session. The company said Thursday that it expects first-quarter revenue of $10 million, which is below the average analysts' estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $13.6 million. See full story. Cognos Inc. COGN shares picked up 3 cents late to $43.12 after gaining nearly 3% during the regular session, after it had reported increased license sales and growth in million-dollar contracts. See full story. General Dynamics GD, +1.67% shares were flat at $107.85 after it said it acquired Maya Viz Ltd., a privately held and collaboration technologies company, based in Pittsburgh, Pa. Falls Church, Va.-based General Dynamics did not disclose terms of the agreement. Precis Inc. PCIS shares were flat after it said it has requested a filing extension with the Securities and Exchange Commission for its 2004 Form 10-K. The Grand Prairie, Texas-based company said it experienced unanticipated delays in completing its 2004 financial statements. Penn Virginia Resource Partners PVR, -1.14% shares were also flat at $1.69 after it said it has purchased the lease rights to about 36 million tons of undeveloped coal reserves and royalty interests in 73 producing oil and natural gas wells for $9.3 million. Qwest Communications International Inc. Q, +0.00% shares were flat after it said in a statement that the recent series of bids and counterbids for MCI Inc. MCIP has become an auction in all but name. Qwest said it expects MCI's board to make a decision by April 5. MCI shares gained 4 cents to $25.33 Friday night. Comcast Corp. CMCSA, +2.67% and Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% said that they have consummated their two previously announced joint ventures. Motorola shares ticked up 2 cents to $14.91 after the bell. The Immune Response Corp. IMNR shares lost 3 cents to $.79 after its said that its independent auditor, Levitz, Zacks & Ciceric, included a "going concern" line in its 2004 Form 10-K. Navarre Corp. NAVR shares gained less than 1 percent to $7.65 after it said has amended the March 14 agreement to purchase the remaining 20% interest of its subsidiary Encore Software Inc. This deal was entered into between Navarre and Michael Bell, Encore's president and chief executive officer. As a result of this transaction, Navarre now owns 100% of Encore. Wyeth WYE shares gained 2 cents to $41.71 after it said a Philadelphia jury has split its verdict in the Pondimin diet drug trial. The company said that in the cases of Patricia Conlon, the jury found in favor of the company. The jury, however, found in favor of the three remaining plaintiffs: Evon Perez, Cynthia Hutchinson and Vicki Morrill. The plaintiffs alleged heart-valve injury from the use of Pondimin, a diet drug once marketed by Wyeth, the company said. Sonus Pharmaceuticals Inc. SNUS shares gained 1 cent to $2.57 after it said it has filed a $50 million shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In afternoon trading, the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed down 99.46 points to 10.404.30 points, which the Nasdaq $COMPQ was down 14.42 points to 1,984.81. title: Transmeta, Xybernaut, Isonics active late

content: Advancers Bakers Footwear Group Inc. BKRS plans to accelerate store openings in 2005 to 35 to 40 stores from its previous target of from 25 to 30 stores. Bakers will also accelerate its store remodelings. The St. Louis-based company also said that it has raised $8.8 million through a private placement. The stock rose 2% Cognos Inc. COGN said increased license sales and growth in million-dollar contracts helped it post an 3% gain in fourth-quarter profits. Cognos shares gained 2.8%. See full story. Cymer Inc. CYMI was upgraded to overweight from neutral at J.P. Morgan, where the broker expressed increased confidence that the second quarter would represent the beginning of the next cycle from a revenue perspective. The shares rose 1%. See The Ratings Game. Fortune Brands Inc. FO, -1.47% to outperform from neutral at CS First Boston, which cited accelerating demand in the home products segment, better than expected sales growth in spirits and wine and an attractive valuation. Analyst Ivy Zelman told clients in a note that demand in the kitchen and bath area increased in the double-digit range in March. Additionally, the analyst raised her price target on the Lincolnshire, Ill. consumer goods conglomerate to $90 from $87. The stock added 2%. Humphrey Hospitality Trust, Inc. HUMP said it has raised it dividend by 20% to 6 cents a share. The dividend payment will be distributed on May 2 to shareholders of record Apr. 15. Shares gained 1%. UBS upgraded railroad Kansas City Southern KSU, +2.10% to buy from neutral, citing more bullish margin forecasts. The broker told clients that KSC Railroad posted a record margin in the fourth quarter and carries strong momentum and a new coal contract into 2005. Shares climbed 3%. JMP Securities upped infrastructure software provider Novell, Inc. NOVL to market perform from underperform, citing improving sales productivity and a re-emergence of growth in Linux and identity management solutions. The broker told clients that although the April quarter will likely reflect the company's continued transitional sales process and new product rollouts, it believes it can likely achieve the broker's estimates and show tangible momentum during the next several months. Shares added 2%. MCI Inc. MCIP said it would re-engage with Qwest Communications International Q, +0.00% to review Qwest's new $8.9 billion bid to acquire the company. MCI confirmed that it has received a waiver from Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% enabling it to engage in discussions with Qwest at any time until the date of the MCI shareholder vote on the proposed Verizon transaction. That date has not yet been set. Verizon has bid $7.6 billion for Qwest. Qwest shares fell 1% while MCI gained 1% and Verizon lost almost 1%. See full story. PalmSource PSRC said it swung to a third-quarter loss and sales fell short of expectations, however, adjusted earnings were in line with the 4 cents a share analysts had expected. The stock added 8%. See full story. PSS World Medical, Inc. PSSI, +2.15% lifted its 2005 earnings estimate to 60 cents a share, up from a previous forecast of a range of 57 cents to 59 cents a share. The company, which distributes medical products to physicians and elder care providers, said the forecast includes an exceptional tax gain of 9 cents a share. Shares rose 7%. Red Hat Inc. RHAT reported earnings that more than doubled, meeting analysts' estimates. The company also expanded its stock buyback program. Shares moved up 11%. See full story. Technology Flavors & Fragrances Inc. TFF, +0.00% agreed to be acquired by FFG Industries Inc. for $1.55 a share in cash. The deal is contingent upon 90% of Technology Flavors & Fragrances shareholders tendering their stock into an offer. Shares spiked 20%. Transmeta Corp. TMTA announced new leadership, job cuts and a multiyear deal with Sony Corp SNE, +0.54% The stock gained 7%. See full story. Decliners Authorities are taking a deeper look at accounting at American International Group Inc. AIG, -0.18% -- going beyond transactions that AIG already has admitted were improper -- to examine actions the company may have taken to polish performance measures closely watched by insurance-industry investors, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter. Now regulators also are scouring deals to determine whether AIG improperly capped its underwriting "loss ratio," which reflects the percentage of each premium dollar that an insurer pays in claims, the people familiar with the matter say. Regulators also want to know if any transactions were used to artificially bolster AIG's surplus capital, the Journal reported. AIG shares fell 8%. See full story. Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $572 million, or $1.69 a share while earnings from continuing operations came to $1.55 a share, which matched analysts' average estimate, according to Thomson First Call. Revenue increased 9.2 percent to $9.23 billion, also matching analysts' view. But the nation's largest consumer electronics retailer said it sees fiscal first quarter earnings of 27 to 32 cents a share from continuing operations and fiscal 2006 earnings of $2.95 to $3.10 a share, including stock-based compensation expense of 5 cents a share in the quarter and 17 cents a share in the year. Analysts were expecting earnings of 38 cents a share for the quarter and $3.31 for the year, excluding the expense. The stock dropped 6%. See full story. Central Freight Lines CENF said late Thursday it filed its 2004 Form 10-K, which included adjustments of previously reported results, with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The stock slid 16%. See full story. Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% said it will press ahead after its pilots and mechanics ratified new contracts while flight attendants, its biggest group of organized workers, rejected the deal. Shares lost 3%. See full story. Corillian Corp. CORI, +2.78% is buying online banking, bill payment and credit card solutions provider InteliData Technologies Corp. INTD, +0.00% in a cash-and-stock deal. Corillion fell 5% while InteliData surged 28%. See full story. The Federal Bureau of Investigation expanded a probe of Delphi Corp. DPH, -33.33% by looking into accounting practices at the Troy, Mich., auto-parts producer, the Detroit News reported. The probe began last summer, the paper said. The accounting inquiry comes after Delphi said that it overstated its income because of bookkeeping errors, the paper reported. The FBI told the paper that it is coordinating the inquiry with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Department of Justice and U.S. postal inspectors. Delphi shares lost 3%. IGate Corp. IGTE said it was unable to file its 2004 Form 10-K by Friday's extended deadline as additional time was needed to complete the previously disclosed review of accounts receivable balances and the assessment of the effectiveness of its internal control over financial reporting. IGate said material weakness exists and it expects to disclose in the Form 10-K that its internal control over financial reporting was not effective as of Dec. 31, 2004 and that its auditor will issue a related adverse opinion. IGate concluded that its receivables were overstated by $800,000, and an adjustment was recorded to reflect this change, but it doesn't expect the impact of any adjustment to require the restatement of any of its previous financial statements. Due to the failure to file, iGate is no longer in Nasdaq listing compliance. The stock fell 2%. Intraware Inc. ITRA reported it swung to a fourth-quarter loss of $374,000, or a penny a share. Last year, it posted a profit of $19,000, or breakeven. Revenue was $2.9 million vs. $3 million. It expects a first-quarter loss of a penny a share. For 2006, it expects revenue of $2.5 million to $2.8 million. The shares slid 18%. National Instruments NATI, +2.68% warned that first-quarter earnings would be 12 cents a share, below prior projections of 16 to 20 cents a share, due primarily to reduced orders for large systems and instrument control sales. Revenue is expected to rise 4 percent over year-earlier levels to $130 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $136.6 million. The stock slumped 8%. National R.V. Holdings NVH, +0.00% it delayed filing its Form 10-K, citing its "need to finalize its required review procedures and enable management to finalize its assessment of internal control over financial reporting as of Dec. 31, 2004." The Perris, Calif. motor homes manufacturer said it will restate its results for 2000, 2001 and 2002. It also will restate results for the third quarter of 2004 and revise its data for the recent fourth quarter. The company estimated the changes will reduce its third-quarter net income by 2 cents a share. The stock fell 9%. Red Robin Gourmet Burgers Inc. RRGBE said it received a Nasdaq delisting notice because it did not file is 2004 Form 10-K in a timely manner. Its ticket will be changed to "RRGBE" on Friday. It said it previously said it would be late filing the form. The stock lost 2%. Taser International TASR said it expects first-quarter revenue of $10 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $13.6 million. The stun gun maker attributes the expected sales shortfall to disruption in the flow of new business resulting from "significant adverse publicity" regarding the risks from the use of its products. The company said it has launched an education campaign to address these issues. The stock fell 13%. J.P. Morgan cut Viisage Technology, Inc. VISG to underweight from neutral. The broker told clients it dropped its rating on the provider of security products for governments and businesses on the slower-than-expected deployment of a coordinated government ID system and international biometrics-enabled passport programs. Shares shed 12%.
