title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Stun gun maker Taser International Inc. said Friday bad publicity over the risk of the company's signature weapons will reduce first-quarter sales below Wall Street's expectations. Taser projected first-quarter revenue of about $10 million. Rick Smith, the Scottsdale, Ariz., company's chief executive, said "significant adverse publicity" has led to "a temporary disruption in our sales pipeline." As a result, "we decided not to issue financial guidance because of the lack of visibility on our business in light of this controversy." The average analysts' estimate compiled by Thomson First Call is for sales of $13.6 million and income of 3 cents per share. The stock fell 13 percent to $10.42 in trading Friday. Taser TASR cited recent studies that it said support the view that its hand-held devices, while not risk free, reduce the chances of death. Smith said Taser had formed a team of "experts" to defend the company "against the myriad of erroneous and misleading information in the public domain" and launched a publicity campaign that includes a users conference in April. Morgan Keegan analyst Brian Ruttenbur cut his 2005 revenue estimate for Taser to $10.1 million and his earnings estimate to breakeven on a per-share basis. Sales to new customers could be weaker, but existing Taser customers will continue to use the products, Ruttenbur predicted. He reiterated an "underperform" rating and withdrew sales and earnings estimates for 2006. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Taser blames publicity for sales 'disruption'

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- U.S. stock futures lifted early Friday after weaker-than-expected U.S. jobs growth in March sent welcome signals to the market about the probable pace of interest rate hikes. The U.S. economy added only 110,000 jobs in March, the Labor Department. This was well short of Wall Street expectations. Economists had forecast payrolls to grow by about 221,000 in March. The data weakened the dollar and bond yields also fell. The yield on the benchmark 10-year note was last at 4.41 percent, down from 4.49 percent ahead of the data. The Dow industrials futures were up 40 points at 10,560 after the data. The Nasdaq futures were up 7.50 points. Continental European and British stocks were higher amid a rally in the mining and oil company stocks with crude oil prices staying well above a $55 a barrel. The Nikkei rebounded overnight as investors focused on better figures in the forward-looking part of the Bank of Japan's closely watched tankan survey. The index ended up 0.5%, or 54.68 points at 11,723.63. See Europe Markets and see Asian Markets Focus stocks Biogen Idec Inc BIIB, +0.74% said in a Friday filing with the SEC that investors should no longer rely upon the financial guidance that the company announced February 7 as a result of the voluntary suspension of sales of its Tysabri drug. Shares eased 1.4 percent in opening action on the Archipelago exchange to $34. Tysabri partner Elan Corp. ELN, +0.00% was up 4.4 percent at $3.36 after the shares dropped in half on Thursday. Best Buy Co. BBY, +2.09% shares 2.8% to $52.50 in premarket trading after the electronics retailer's outlook for earnings and as it said it sees first quarter same-store sales up in the low single-digits. Authorities are taking a deeper look at accounting at American International Group Inc. AIG, -0.18% -- going beyond transactions that AIG already has admitted were improper -- to examine actions the company may have taken to polish performance measures closely watched by insurance-industry investors, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the matter. DaimlerChrysler DCX said it was abandoning two models in its loss-making Smart car business in a restructuring that will lead to job cuts and charges of up to 1.2 billion euros ($1.56 billion). The automaker's shares (710000) in the home Frankfurt market were last down 0.9% at 34.21 euros. See story The Federal Bureau of Investigation expanded a probe of Delphi Corp. DPH, -33.33% by looking into accounting practices at the Troy, Mich., auto-parts producer, the Detroit News reported. The probe began last summer, the paper said. Taser International TASR dropped 12 percent in the speculative pre-open trade to $10.56 after it said it expects first-quarter revenue of $10 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $13.6 million. The stun gun maker attributes the expected sales shortfall to disruption in the flow of new business resulting from "significant adverse publicity" regarding the risks from the use of its products. Plains Exploration & Production PXP, +3.72% said it will sell 275 active wells to XTO Energy XTO, -0.46% for $350 million. PXP has also executed a series of contracts that will eliminate all existing 2006 oil price swaps and collars. The elimination will cost around $295 million. The company has also acquired $45.00 NYMEX put options on approximately 40,000 barrels of oil per day in 2006. Shares of ICAP (IAP) , the British interdealer in derivatives, foreign exchange and fixed income, rallied 2.8 percent on an upbeat earnings outlook. It said performance of its electronic broking businesses has continued to be particularly strong and is gaining market share. The board of U.K. asset manager Singer & Friedlander Group (SFL) confirmed it's in the early stages of talks with Kaupthing Bank which "may or may not" lead to an offer for the whole of the company's issued share capital. Shares in Singer & Friedlander rose about 14% in early afternoon trading in London. Broker calls UBS upped chip equipment manufacturer Cymer, Inc. CYMI to overweight from neutral, citing increased confidence that the second quarter will represent the beginning of the next cycle from a revenue perspective. In addition, the broker told clients that key catalysts are better execution and predictability. Deutsche Bank cut consulting firm Affiliated Computer Services ACS, +8.70% to hold from buy, citing valuation. The broker told clients that while a pick up in consulting activity should bode well for Accenture ACN, +4.13% when it reports results on April 7, ACS's core business "continues to experience headwinds as it anniversaries tough comps and integrates Mellon HR." The broker raised its rating on Accenture to buy from hold. Fortune Brands Inc. FO, -1.47% was upgraded to "outperform" from "neutral" at CSFB Americas, citing accelerating demand in the home products segment, better than expected sales growth in spirits and wine and an attractive valuation. title: Weak jobs data lifts stock futures, yields down

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr said it expects first-quarter revenue of $10 million, which is below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $13.6 million. The stun gun maker attributes the expected sales shortfall to disruption in the flow of new business resulting from "significant adverse publicity" regarding the risks from the use of its products. The company said it has launched an education campaign to address these issues. The stock closed Thursday down 44 cents at $12.
title: Taser Int'l Q1 rev. to miss expectations

content: Advancers Advanced Magnetics' AVM, -1.50% shares rose more than 7 percent after the company received an approvable letter from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for Combidex, a molecular imaging agent to be used in the diagnosis of cancer. Aladdin Knowledge Systems ALDN shares surged more than 8 percent after the company said it's priced 2 million shares at $21.45 per share. The company expects to raise $39.2 million from the sale after deducting the underwriting discount and estimated offering expenses. Charles & Colvard Ltd. CTHR, -0.73% shares added more than 6 percent after the supplier of the jewel moissanite increased its sales outlook for the first quarter. The Morrisville, N.C.-based company now sees sales of $10.4 million to $10.9 million in the period. Its prior projection was for sales of $8.9 million to $9.7 million in the quarter. Chattem CHTT shares advanced more than 13 percent after the company posted a first-quarter profit of $8.7 million, or 42 cents a share. Adjusted earnings, excluding certain charges associated with its litigation settlements, were $10.5 million, or 51 cents a share. Last year, the Chattanooga, Tenn.-based manufacturer of branded consumer products posted a loss of $712,000, or 4 cents a share. Revenue rose to $71.5 million from $60.9 million a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 42 cents per share on revenue of $67.3 million. Darden Restaurants DRI, +1.03% shares surged more than 9 percent after the Orlando, Fla., restaurant operator posted a 20 percent increase in third-quarter earnings and offered a strong outlook for fiscal 2005. See full story. FMC Corp. FMC, +4.73% rallied more than 12 percent after the company said it expects first-quarter earnings before items to significantly exceed 71 cents per share, which is the top end of analysts' current estimates. The Philadelphia chemicals company attributed the outlook to a better than expected performance in all of its businesses, although its agricultural products unit did particularly well due to favorable market conditions in Brazil. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 67 cents per share in the March period. GoAmerica GOAM shares added more than 14 percent after the company said it has launched i711.com, an Internet relay service designed to connect deaf or hard of hearing consumers with hearing callers. Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Co. GAP, +2.27% leapt more than 22 percent after Lehman Bros. raised its rating on the company to "overweight," saying it expects the retailer to take steps to enhance shareholder value over the next 12-to-18 months. Lexar Media LEXR shares soared more than 99 percent after a jury has awarded the flash memory company $380 million in damages after finding Toshiba Corp. (6502) and Toshiba America Electronic Components Inc. TOSBF, -1.49% liable for breach of fiduciary duty and theft of trade secrets in the development of certain technology. See full story. NetSol Technologies NTWK, -2.13% gained more than 4 percent after the company restated results for fiscal 2004 and for the first-half of fiscal 2005. The fiscal 2004 restatement reduced the company's net loss to $2.5 million, or 32 cents a share, compared to a previously stated net loss of $3 million, or 38 cents a share. First-half fiscal 2005 accounts have been restated to show a net income of $294,024, or 3 cents a share, compared to a previous $78,692, or 1 cent a share, net income. NuCO2 Inc. NUCO shares added 8 percent after the company said it plans to sell 4.4 million common shares at $24.17 each. The supplier of carbon dioxide for fountain beverages said the sale will net the company around $35.6 million, which it will use to buy back debt. Pathmark Stores PTMK jumped more than 32 percent after the company said it will receive a $150 million investment from Yucaipa Cos. LLC, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm whose founder and managing partner is Ronald W. Burkle. The Carteret, N.J., supermarket operator will use the proceeds from the deal to upgrade its store base and open additional stores. Yucaipa also signed a five-year management agreement with Pathmark. Shares of Taser International TASR rallied more than 15 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker said its X26 conducted energy device has received approval from the United Kingdom's Home Office for use by authorized officers in England and Wales. Wild Oats Markets OATS gained more than 14 percent after Burkle disclosed in a federal filing that he has acquired a 9.2 percent stake in the company. See full story. Decliners Shares of Adaptec ADPT fell more than 6 percent. The move comes after the Milpitas, Calif., storage technology company lowered its financial outlook for the fourth quarter due to a shortage of enterprise disk drives. The company now expects revenue for the period to come in 9 to 13 percent below its prior projection for a range of $127 million to $131 million. The company said that demand from its original equipment manufacturing and channel customers for small computer system interface products was hurt by the shortage of drives, and that it expects the shortage to continue into the first quarter. Center Financial Corp. CLF, +5.30% shares fell more than 10 percent after the company named Patrick Hartman chief financial officer and said it has identified a "material weakness" in its internal controls related to its implementation of certain accounting principles. The Los Angeles-based holding company for Center Bank said it plans to hire additional internal accounting staff to correct the deficiency. Duratek DRTK shares dropped almost 4 percent after the company said it was unsuccessful in its efforts to win a large closure contract for a site in Idaho from the Department of Energy. Edgar Online EDGR fell more than 12 percent after the company restated its fourth-quarter and fiscal 2004 results by cutting its net income for both periods by $200,000, or a penny a share. The company now says its fourth-quarter earnings were $197,000, or a penny a share. For 2004, the company now says its loss was $2.2 million, or 11 cents a share. Guilford Pharmaceuticals' GLFD shares dropped more than 33 percent after the Baltimore drug developer said it has voluntarily suspended enrollment in ongoing trials of Aquavan, a proposed sedative. The company said a recent phase III trial of Aquavan with patients undergoing colonoscopy procedures met its primary endpoint of successful sedation with a success rate of 96 percent but it found that a lower dose than was used in the trial "would be more appropriate" to meet the characteristics of procedural sedation. Guilford plans to meet with the Food and Drug Administration in the next several weeks to determine a clinical trial plan. It added that these activities may "modestly extend" the timeline for its filing of a new drug application for Aquavan. Harmony Gold HMY, -0.42% shares pulled back more than 7 percent after the company confirmed in a Form 6-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that roughly 21,000 of its employees went on strike in South Africa Wednesday. The company expects its operating profit will be reduced by 1 million rand per working day with the missing production pegged at 5,000 ounces per day. Journal Register Co. JRC lost more than 3 percent after the media company said it expects to report first-quarter earnings in the range of 17 to 19 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate is for earnings of 23 cents a share. The newspaper publishing group said its forecast reflects advertising revenue growth which has been "somewhat softer" than the company had anticipated. It also includes a 2 to 3 cent per share earnings dilution related to its Michigan cluster and Sarbanes-Oxley compliance expenses of around $2.5 to $3 million. Icos Corp. ICOS shares slipped nearly 2 percent after the company said a phase II study of its IC485 molecule as a treatment for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease failed to meet its primary endpoint. LJ International JADE, -2.86% shares dropped more than 13 percent after the jewelry seller forecast earnings of $375,000, or 3 cents per share, for the first quarter, below its year-ago profit of $421,000, or 4 cents per share. Metalink Ltd. MTLK, -4.00% shares gave back more than 4 percent after the company warned that first-quarter revenues would come in below its prior forecast. CEO Tzvika Shukhman said the lowered expectations are due to a few Asian orders for chipsets which have been delayed. Shukhman said he is unable to provide a more definitive revenue estimate for the quarter, with a full week of business still remaining. The Israeli maker of broadband products also said Chief Financial Officer Ofer Lavie is leaving the company and will be replaced by Yuval Ruhama, whose title will be vice-president of finance. Natural Health Trends Corp. BHIP, -2.75% slid more than 14 percent after the direct selling company posted a loss of $802,000, or 12 cents per share, in the fourth quarter, down from its profit of $1.1 million, or 19 cents per share, in the period. The company attributed the decrease in net income to higher commissions paid to distributors and an increase in selling, general and administrative expenses. Richardson Electronics Ltd. RELL, +2.86% shares fell more than 4 percent after the company swung to a third-quarter loss of $2.1 million, or 12 cents a share. Results for the quarter include $2.9 million in after-tax charges. Last year, the company posted a profit of $1 million, or 7 cents a share. See full story. Sourcecorp SRCPE shares sank more than 3 percent after the company swung to a third-quarter loss of $677,000, or 4 cents a share. Last year, the company earned $2.3 million, or 14 cents a share. The company also restated results for 2001-2003 and the first six months of 2004 because of a revenue recognition error made by one of its operating subsidiaries. Sourcecorp said the restatement resulted in the expensing of earn-out overpayments during the periods of payment. See full story. Synovis Life Technologies SYNO lost more than 6 percent after the company said that Connie Magnuson has resigned as chief financial officer, effective April 12, in order to pursue personal interests. The St. Paul medical device company named Brett Reynolds, who has served as director of finance and accounting since 2003, to the CFO position. Wet Seal WTSLA shares fell more than 3 percent after the company postponed the release of its fourth-quarter and 2004 results until April 12. The Foothill Ranch, Fla.-based retailer was scheduled to report Thursday. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares in Taser International Inc. rose more than 15 percent Thursday after the company said the U.K Home Office approved use of its model X26 stun gun. Taser TASR based in Scottsdale, Ariz., saw its stock add $1.82 to finish at $13.90. Shares traded as high as $14.20 earlier in the session. The approval allows authorized law enforcement officers in England and Wales to carry the company's latest model stun guns. content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr rallied more than 11 percent to $13.47 after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker said its X26 conducted energy device has received approval from the United Kingdom's Home Office for use by authorized officers in England and Wales. Volume of 16.3 million was nearly double the issue's daily average.
title: Taser Int'l shares surge on U.K. Home Office approval

content: Corrects percent decline in Sirius stock SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Attacking the bearer of bad news is a human custom with a rich history. In practice, it's an often brutal one, as the fate of killjoys from John the Baptist to Sir Thomas More attests. Business journalists don't cover life and death issues and aren't martyr candidates, so relaying unflattering facts about public companies doesn't carry the deadly consequences of telling a king he shouldn't have married his wife. But while having your inbox filled with irate emails isn't in the same league as losing your head, it is a reminder that investors who fall in love with a stock and then are confronted with bad news about it often choose to savage the messenger, rather than evaluate his message. I was reminded of this last month after writing an analysis which argued that Qwest Communications International Q, +0.00% judging by its relative financial health, is a weaker suitor for MCI MCIP than Verizon Communications. VZ, -0.37% As evidence, I cited Qwest's heavy debt load -- a fact I'd gleaned directly from its most recent regulatory filing -- and its puny revenue compared to Verizon's. Because the story broke no new ground, I was surprised to get passionate emails from readers (whom I assumed were Qwest shareholders) asking why I had it in for the company. The questions ranged from the cordial "why can't you give Qwest a break?" to the ironically humorous "do you own MCI stock?" The latter one is ironic because as someone who's signed the Dow Jones & Co. employee code of ethics, I'm prohibited from owning the stocks of any companies I write about. That complaint called to mind the dozens of responses I'd received in December from investors in SIRI, +1.05% Sirius Satellite Radio. They were enraged, even though I merely relayed the opinion of some analysts who thought the shares' rapid rise in the wake of Howard Stern's signing had gone too far. One reader accused me of owning shares of XM Satellite Radio XMSR Sirius' biggest rival. Notice a pattern here? The shoot-the-messenger reaction seems to be strongest among investors who own stock in companies with reputations for being an upstart brand. Besides Sirius, other examples include Taser International TASR and Krispy Kreme Doughnuts KKD Taser, after all, is out to revolutionize how law enforcement subdues suspects. Sirius, meanwhile, plans to poke a finger in the eye of big corporate radio firms like ClearChannel Communications. Krispy Kreme, like its products, apparently appeals to those in open rebellion against the low-carb craze. "Tell me I can't eat myself into obesity, will you? Take that!" investors seemed to be saying, as they loaded up on Krispy Kreme shares early last year. Investors' passion for these stocks is understandable. Americans love an underdog, after all. The problem is that passion is no help when you own shares of a company whose run is over. Sirius shares are down more than 40 percent since early December, while Taser shares have plummeted more than 60 percent in three months and Krispy Kreme is down more than 70 percent since last April. Yet a portion of shareholders in those companies still believe that Herb Greenberg, who writes a column for MarketWatch, is somehow responsible for their losses. Greenberg fought a running battle for months with Krispy Kreme shareholders who were convinced that it was he - and not the company's unsustainable growth - that put the bruising on their portfolios. Given the stock drop, it's no surprise that Krispy Kreme's chief executive stepped down in January. What is surprising -- given the corporate scandals at Enron, WorldCom, Tyco and Adelphia, among others -- is that investors still cling to statements made by company executives as if they were gospel, even while attacking the bearers of bad news. What investors forget is that corporate officers have a responsibility to NOT say anything negative about their company and, except in very rare cases, always accentuate the positive. Think about it. Among the thousands of public company executives out there, who among them gets paid to say bad things about the firms they run? It may be springtime, but investors would do well to remember that when it comes to their portfolios, falling in love can be an expensive mistake. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: Love and money don't mix

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr gained more than 5 percent to $13.02 in pre-market action after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker unveiled its XP35 air cartridge product with an extended maximum range of 35 feet. Volume on Instinet reached 151,351.
title: Taser shares get lift from new product launch

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International tasr slid more than 2 percent in afternoon action Monday. Before the opening bell, the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns said Bernard Kerik, a former police commissioner of New York City, would resign from its board effective April 1. The company said Kerik was leaving in order to focus on his consulting business. Taser named Judy Martz, a former governor of Montana, to replace Kerik.
title: Taser shares tumble; Kerik to leave board April 1

content: Advancers Allos Therapeutics ALTH leapt more than 16 percent after the company said an affiliate of Warburg Pincus has agreed to buy $50 million of the cancer drug developer's exchangeable preferred stock at a purchase price of $22.10 per common share. Proceeds will be used to fund efforts to develop lead candidate Efaproxyn, currently in Phase III studies, among other research and development activities. Allos said it may also sell, by March 8, $10 million of exchangeable preferred stock to some institutional investors already owning equity in the company. Altair Nanotechnologies ALTI jumped more than 11 percent after the company received a European patent for a process for making microporous structures that can be used as catalyst supports, or as electrode materials, in connection with titanium metal production and other processes. AstraZeneca AZN, -0.46% shares gained more than 3 percent after the Food and Drug Administration overnight a new label stating for the company's Crestor drug that states the risk of getting a muscle weakness disease from taking the cholesterol drug is the same as it is for other statins. See full story. Baker Hughes BHI, +4.27% rose more than 3 percent after A.G. Edwards raised its rating on the stock to "buy" from "hold" citing an improving risk/reward profile. Bebe Stores Inc. BEBE, -7.76% shares tacked on more than 12 percent after the company said same-store sales rose 25.3 percent in February. The company also said it is currently determining if corrections to previous financial statements are needed with its auditors over lease accounting practices. Blue Coat Systems BCSI gained more than 11 percent after Wedbush Morgan raised its rating on the stock to "buy." Boeing BA, +2.46% shares tacked on more than 3 percent in afternoon action, reaching their highest level in more than three years. The move came as Banc of America told clients margins at the Dow component's commercial airline segment could "materially" exceed targets of 5.5 percent. See full story. Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp. BCF, -1.96% added more than 1 percent after the company said comparable store sales improved 7.9 percent in February, with fiscal third quarter sales from continuing operations up 13.9 percent to $969.5 million. Cache Inc. CACH, +200.00% surged more than 2 percent after the company reported a 3 percent increase in February comparable store sales over year-ago levels. Total sales for the four-week period increased $2.2 million, or 12 percent, to $20.7 million compared to 2004. Carrizo Oil & Gas CRZO, +2.76% shares rose more than 6 percent after the company said it's replaced 569 percent of 2004 production as a result of reserve additions made in its Barnett Shale operating area in north Texas and along the Gulf Coast. Year-end proved reserves amounted to 109.3 million billion cubic feet equivalent, up 55 percent from the end of 2003, the energy company said. Cato Corp. CTR, +2.29% gained more than 3 percent after the provider of value-priced women's fashion apparel, said February same-store sales rose 7 percent. Total sales for the period climbed 13 percent to $64.6 million. The company also said it would review its lease accounting. Charming Shoppes' CHRS, -1.34% advanced more than 9 percent after the company said February same-store sales rose 1 percent over the same period a year ago, as 6 percent growth at its Lane Bryant stores and a 2 percent increase at its Catherines stores offset a 4 percent decline at its Fashion Bug stores. Total sales grew 3 percent to $168.2 million. The women's apparel retailer's stock closed Wednesday down 2 cents at $7.73. Shares of Christopher & Banks Corp. CBK, +1.90% added more than 2 percent after the company said it expects fiscal quarter earnings to range from 28 cents to 30 cents a share against 27 cents a share in the same quarter last year. Three analysts polled by Thomson/First Call project earnings at an average 31 cents a share for the May-ending quarter. For the fiscal fourth quarter, the retailer expects earnings to range from 10 cents to 12 cents a share, in line with its prior outlook. Coach COH, +6.26% shares rose more than 3 percent after the company said spring season results were trending above plan and that it now expects earnings for the second half of its fiscal year will be at least 85 cents a share on sales of at least $800 million compared to earnings of 64 cents a share a year earlier. The revised forecast is above the company's prior guidance for earnings of at least 83 cents a share and the 84 cents average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% added more than 5 percent after the company raised its first-quarter earnings forecast to 66 to 69 cents a share from 59 to 61 cents and its 2005 estimate to $2.66 to $2.72 a share from $2.62 to $2.68 due to stronger-than-expected February sales results. Same-store sales for the month grew 9.2 percent over year-earlier levels, with pharmacy sales increasing 11 percent and front-end sales rising 6.4 percent. Total sales rose 36 percent to $2.89 billion, boosted by the acquisition of Eckerd drugstores. Shares of DayStar Technologies DSTI gained more than 11 percent after the maker of silicon-free solar cells on specialty metal foils, introduced LightFoil for high specific power applications. The company said the product can be used for military and homeland security applications and was designed specifically for high altitude airships; winged, unmanned aerial vehicles; and orbital applications for next generation satellite craft. Drugstore.com DSCM added more than 30 percent after the company sold 10 million shares of its common stock to a private investment partnership for $26 million. E Com Ventures ECMV shares advanced more than 1 percent after the company February same-store sales at its Perfumania Marketing unit rose 5.3 percent. Total retail sales climbed 2.9 percent to $13.9 million. Express Scripts ESRX, -0.93% rallied more than 9 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter income rose 13 percent, and offered a forecast for the first quarter that was above expectations. See full story. Jos. A Bank Clothiers JOSB added more than 6 percent after the men's apparel retailer said same-store sales rose 3.1 percent in February compared to the year-ago period, thanks partly to good early results from its spring collection. Total sales jumped 19.2 percent to $28.6 million from a year a Kohl's Corp. KSS, +1.47% gained more than 4 percent after the company said February same-store sales rose 6.1 percent over year-earlier levels. Total sales increased 20 percent to $712.7 million from last year's $592.2 million. At the end of February, the discount department store chain operated 637 stores vs. 542 stores last year. Longs Drug Stores' LDG, -22.86% shares rose nearly 13 percent after the Walnut Creek, Calif., drug store retailer reported its fourth-quarter results, posting a profit of $17.7 million, or 47 cents per share, for the period, 10 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Looking head, the company forecast earnings of $1.27 to $1.35 per share for fiscal 2006. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of $1.20 per share for the year. McCormick & Schmick's Seafood Restaurants' MSSR shares gained more than 5 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter operating income of $5.4 million, up from $479,000 a year ago. Revenue for the quarter is estimated to be $64.9 million, compared with $54 million in 2003. The Portland, Ore.-based restaurant chain forecast first-quarter revenue of $60 million to $61 million, with same-store sales up 2 percent to 3 percent. Shares of Michaels Stores Inc. MIK, -1.40% rose more than 6 percent after the arts and crafts retailer reported fourth-quarter earnings of $111.2 million, or 80 cents a share, vs. $94.6 million or 68 cents a share, a year ago. See full story. Napster NAPS, +0.00% shares rallied more than 6 percent after the company raised its fiscal fourth-quarter revenue guidance to $15 million, from a prior projection of $14 million. "We are raising our guidance based on robust growth in our subscription service," said Chris Gorog, chairman and CEO of the digital music provider. See full story. Peabody Energy Corp. BTU, +0.05% gained more than 1 percent after the company's board authorized a two-for-one stock split on its 65 million shares of common stock. The coal producer said shareholders of record as of March 16 will receive one additional share of stock for each share owned. The shares will be distributed in the form of a stock dividend on March 30. Shares of Peerless Systems PRLS jumped more than 32 percent after the company signed a memorandum of understanding to provide engineering services and high-performance imaging technologies for use in an upcoming line of printers from Kyocera Mita Corp. Peerless will receive $24 million from Kyocera Mita in quarterly payment of $2 million each for the next three years. PRG-Schultz International PRGX, +0.00% shares added more than 4 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss that narrowed to $75.7 million, or $1.23 a share, from $168.1 million, or $2.73 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Revenue for the period declined slightly to $93.7 million from $95.9 million. Looking ahead, the audit services company said it expects revenue to rise in the mid-single digits in 2005 and anticipates "substantial" earnings improvement due to growth in international operations and in new claims categories in the U.S. In addition, the company said it continues to consider a possible sale. Pride International PDE surged more than 3 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $17.4 million, or 12 cents a share vs. a loss of $36.1 million, or 27 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding discontinued operations and non-recurring items, such as a gain on the sale of assets and charges for asset writedowns, earnings would have been 7 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 3 cents a share. Revenue rose 13 percent to $448.1 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of $423.5 million. Ross Stores ROST, +2.39% shares added more than 4 percent after the company said its same-store sales rose 6 percent in February. Total sales for the four weeks ended Feb. 26 jumped 17 percent to $311 million from $266 million in the same period a year earlier. In addition, the Pleasanton, Calif., off-price retailer said it plans to adjust its method of accounting for operating leases. The company expects the adjustment to reduce earnings by a total of 9 cents per share for 2004 and prior years. Sanmina-SCI SANM, +0.77% jumped more than 12 percent after Wells Fargo raised its rating on the stock to "buy." Senomyx SNMX, +0.21% shares advanced more than 10 percent after its savory enhancers S807 and S336 have been determined to be Generally Recognized As Safe by the Food and Drug Administration. The Talbots Inc. TLB, -5.71% leapt more than 8 percent after the company said its same-store sales rose 8.1 percent in February. Total sales for the period shot up 13 percent to $95 million, buoyed by strength in regular-price selling of its early spring merchandise. Looking ahead, the apparel chain said it expects first quarter earnings in the range of 59 to 63 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate is for 62 cents a share. Taser International TASR soared more than 5 percent after the stun gun maker said a lawsuit against it has been dismissed. See full story. Techne Corp. TECH, +2.45% rose more than 7 percent after Baird upgraded the stock to "outperform." Shares of Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% surged nearly 13 percent following a report in the Wall Street Journal that ChevronTexaco Corp. CVX, +1.73% , the nation's second biggest oil company is considering making a offer for the company. See full story. Decliners Advanced Magnetics' AVM, -1.50% shares plummeted more than 65 percent after a Food and Drug Administration panel voted not to recommend approval of a broad indication for Combidex, the company's investigational functional molecular imaging agent. The panel said there was insufficient data to support the indication for the use of Combidex to differentiate metastatic from non-metastatic lymph nodes across all cancer types. The news also hit Cytogen CYTO which hold the U.S. marketing rights to Combidex. Cytogen shares dropped 51 percent. Albany Molecular Research AMRI shares lost more than 18 percent after the company said it expects earnings of 10 to 12 cents per share for the first quarter, below Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 15 cents per share in the period. Best Buy BBY, +2.09% slumped more than 2 percent after the company reported same-store sales rose 2.8 percent in the fourth quarter. Total sales for the three months ended Feb. 26 increased 9 percent to $9.2 billion. Looking ahead, the Minneapolis consumer electronics retailer said it expects earnings for the period to be at the low end or slightly below a range of $1.56 to $1.66 per share due to a more promotional environment and an increase in inventory markdowns. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of $1.60 per share in the February period. Best Buy added that it's reviewing its lease accounting practices. See full story. Cablevision CVC, -0.36% shares fell more than 5 percent after the company said in a regulatory filing that Chairman Charles Dolan has removed three members of the company's board of directors, replacing them with John Malone, Frank Biondi Jr., Leonard Tow and Rand Araskog. One of the vacancies on the board was created by a death. Chico's FAS CHS, +0.33% shares slid more than 3 percent after the company reported a 28.5 percent jump in fourth-quarter earnings but the performance still fell short of analysts' consensus expectations. See full story. EGL EAGL, +0.00% shares lost more than 20 percent after the Houston shipping logistics services reported fourth-quarter 2004 net income of $12.9 million, or 26 cents a share, up from net income of $9.1 million, or 19 cents a share, a year ago. The 2004 results included a net charge of 7 cents a share for deferred tax charges, mainly in the United Kingdom and Canada, and expenses of 3 cents a share relating to Sarbanes-Oxley compliance. EGL projected 2005 gross revenue growth of between 15 percent and 20 percent and raised its guidance for earnings per share to between $1.27 and $1.37. First quarter earnings per share are anticipated in a range of 23 cents to 26 cents a share, the company added. Shares of First Horizon Pharmaceutical Corp. FHRX tumbled more than 6 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter profits dipped significantly, largely on higher expenses from a build-out of its sales force. See full story. Fleetwood Enterprises FLE, +0.00% dropped almost 12 percent after the company said its third-quarter loss widened to $54.7 million, or 99 cents a share, from $10.2 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter, due to severe seasonality impact. The maker of recreational vehicles said sales declined 6 percent to $564.9 million. Looking ahead, the company said it no longer believes it will be profitable in the fourth quarter. Gottschalks GOT, +0.00% shares slid almost 1 percent after the company said February same-store sales fell 0.6 percent from year-earlier levels soft apparel sales resulting from rainy weather in California offset improvement in home division sales. Total sales declined 0.6 percent to $42.8 million from last year's $43.1 million. Graphic Packaging GPK, +0.79% shares lost more than 6 percent after the Marietta, Ga., paperboard packaging maker posted a preliminary fourth-quarter loss of $35.1 million, or 18 cents per share, wider than its year-ago loss of $14 million, or 7 cents per share. The company continues to work on its review of internal reporting controls and it expects to file its Form 10-K for the year by March 16. Knightsbridge Tankers VLCCF tumbled more than 1 percent after J.P. Morgan began coverage of the company with an "underweight" rating. Shares of Micron Technology MU, +1.26% dipped almost 3 percent after Merrill Lynch cut its 2005 earnings estimate for the company to 45 cents a share from 78 cents due to weak memory pricing, which is expected to last through late summer. Analyst Joe Osha also cut his 2006 earnings forecast to 66 cents a share from 77 cents. He said double data rate memory pricing plunged towards the end of February, amid particular weakness in Asia, as a result of sluggish PC sales. "The recent sharp decline in pricing most likely will not be able to be offset by normal cost reduction," Osha said. Nuveen Investments JNC lost more than 4 percent after the company said its Symphony Asset Management unit was advised in January 2005 the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating performance fees paid by an unaffiliated family of mutual funds. In an annual report filed with regulators on Wednesday, the company said the SEC is probing whether Symphony, which was a sub-adviser to the unaffiliated fund family, overcharged the funds through performance fees, and whether Symphony should repay $2.8 million in fees and $1 million in interest. Nuveen said it is reviewing the case and "intends to seek to resolve the matter in an appropriate manner upon the completion of its investigation of the facts and applicable law." PetsMart Inc. PETM fell nearly 3 percent after the company said it overcame a slower-than-expected holiday selling season to post a 20 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings. See full story. Pier 1 Imports PIR, +2.88% pulled back almost 1 percent after the company said it anticipates fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 25 to 27 cents a share, citing weak sales and merchandise margins. The home furnishings retailer posted same-store sales down 15.3 percent in February. Seabulk International SBLK, +3.29% shares fell more than 10 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter 2004 net income of $10.7 million, or 45 cents a share, including a gain of $1.7 million from the sale of offshore vessels. Last year, the marine support and transportation services provider reported a loss of $7.3 million, or 32 cents a share, including charges of $1.2 million related to vessal writedowns. Fourth-quarter revenue increased to $93.2 million, from $79.9 million a year ago. SPX Corp. SPW, -4.73% shares lost more than 8 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $110.8 million, or $1.50 per share, compared to net income of $102.6 million, or $1.19 per share last year. Revenue rose to $1.19 billion, from $1.1 billion. The latest quarter includes non-cash impairment charges of $175.3 million, or $2.24 per share, relating to write-downs of the carrying values of certain of the company's businesses. The company said the results were "disappointing" and that the charges related to "poor operating performance" in three of its businesses. The company was expected to earn 83 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Teleglobe International Holdings Ltd. TLGB lost more than 13 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $9.2 million, or 23 cents per share, compared with a loss of $11 million, or 28 cents per share, last year. Revenue rose to $280.2 million from $276.8 million. The company is not tracked by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Viisage Technology VISG shares sank more than 17 percent after the facial recognition technology provider reported a fourth-quarter loss of 11 cents a share on revenue of $19 million. It was expected to report a loss of 9 cents a share on revenue of $18.1 million. For the coming quarter, it forecast revenue of $15 million and $17 million. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Shares in Taser International Inc. surged more than 5 percent Thursday after the stun gun maker said a lawsuit against it was dismissed. Taser's TASR stock added 72 cents, or 5.3 percent, to finish at $14.22, after hitting a high of $15.44 earlier in the session. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser said before the markets opened that a lawsuit filed in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2004 was dismissed without prejudice. The suit alleged that the claimant, Nick Kerchoff, was injured when he volunteered to experience a Taser discharge during a Taser device demonstration. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: Taser jumps on lawsuit dismissal

content: Pre-Open stocks action U.S. stock futures were firm. Markets are looking to retailers' sales, fresh data on semiconductor sales and Fed chief Alan Greenspan later in the day. U.S. initial jobless claims fell 1,000 to 310,000 in the latest week, the Labor Department said, which was in line with expectations. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global Markets London shares rise on relief over AstraZeneca drug Crestor. On the Continent, chip stocks were hit, but banking shares gained. Stocks in Japan posted gains on optimism about the economy. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker Action J.P. Morgan trimmed its first-quarter revenue estimates on chipmaker Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% by $100 million to $9.2 billion, saying the PC food chain appears to have been hurt in the first quarter by shortages of Intel's new Alviso chipset and low-end Celeron chips. The broker says the problem should be fixed by April. Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded shares of AstraZeneca AZN, -0.46% to "neutral" from "underperform" after the Food and Drug Administration overnight approved a new label stating the risk of getting a muscle weakness disease from taking cholesterol drug Crestor is the same as it is for other statins. "The updated position of the FDA is the best the company could have hoped for - and reduces U.S. regulatory risk substantially," the broker said. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% said same-store sales rose 4.1 percent in February. Total sales for the four weeks ended Feb. 25 jumped 10.9 percent to $22.37 billion from $20.16 billion in the same period a year earlier. The world's largest retailer said it expects U.S. same-store sales for the March period to be similar or better than February. ChevronTexaco Corp. CVX, +1.73% is considering a bid for Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% the Wall Street Journal said Thursday, citing unidentified people familiar with the matter. The consideration of a bid for Unocal, the ninth-largest U.S. oil and natural gas producer, is in its early stages, the report said. China National Offshore Oil Corp., a large state-owned company, expressed interest in Unocal early this year. Other U.S. oil companies are also believed to have intensified their interest in a bid for Unocal after news of Cnooc's interest surfaced, the report said. Federated Department Stores FD said same-store sales rose 1.8 percent in February. Total sales increased 1.6 percent in the four weeks ended Feb. 26 to $1.09 billion from $1.07 billion in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Cincinnati-based operator of Macy's and other department stores forecast an increase of about 2.5 percent in March same-store sales followed by a "relatively flat" performance in April. The company disclosed plans to acquire May Department Stores MAY, +0.00% earlier this week. The stock closed Wednesday at $61.52, up 54 cents. Del Monte Foods DLM reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $48.5 million, or 23 cents a share, down from $53.5 million, or 25 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding costs for the integration of acquired businesses, earnings would have been 24 cents a share, matching the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 6.2 percent to $861.3 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of $849.9 million, amid higher volumes from new products and increased marketing and pricing. For its fourth-quarter, the food distributor expects earnings excluding special items of 30 to 35 cents a share, surrounding analyst projections of 31 cents. Revenue is expected to decline 4 to 6 percent from last year's $915.9 million due primarily to the absence of a 53rd week. The stock closed Wednesday up 14 cents at $10.82. The Semiconductors Industry Association said worldwide microchip sales eased 0.5 percent from December to $18.3 billion in January, which it said was an encouraging sign as January is historically one of the weakest months of the year. It said the excess inventories that slowed growth in the second half of 2004 have been largely depleted. Shares of Taser International TASR climbed 5.6 percent to $14.26 in premarket trade Thursday on news a lawsuit against the maker of stun guns was dismissed without prejudice. The lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Michigan in June 2004, had alleged that the claimant, Nick Kerchoff, was injured when he volunteered to experience a Taser discharge during a Taser device demonstration. J.C. Penney Company, Inc. JCP, -0.98% said February same-store sales increased 6.1 percent. Sales of spring apparel and seasonal products exceeded expectations. For March, the company expects comparable department store sales to be up low-to-mid single digits. Sales expectations reflect the shift of Easter into this year's March period. In last year's March period, comparable department store sales increased 11.4 percent. Shares of the Plano, Texas retailer fell 31 cents to $45.09 on Wednesday. NYFIX Inc. NYFX said it has determined that it incorrectly accounted for certain stock option grants, and would therefore need to restate financial statements for 2002 and 2003, and is evaluating whether it will need to restate results for the nine months ending September 2004. After a review prompted by an inquiry by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, the provider of trading workstations believes compensation expenses primarily for 1999 to 2003 were "materially understated." The company said it also overstated the net loss for the nine months ending September 2003. NYFIX believes the restatements will result in "material weaknesses" under the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002. The stock closed Wednesday down 8 cents at $4.50. Fannie Mae FNM, -11.67% could be forced to recognize additional losses from its derivatives portfolio of as much as $2.8 billion because of new accounting concerns raised by its chief regulator, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources. Fannie Mae last week that its regulator had identified new accounting problems at the government-sponsored mortgage company, including issues with the way it records certain loan transactions. Bain Capital and Game Plan International proposed to pay as much as $3.5 billion for the National Hockey League, the Toronto Star reported. The Boston firms were invited to make the bid by NHL Commissioner Gary Bettman and presented the proposal to league owners on Tuesday, sources told the paper. No talks between the firms and the league are currently set, the paper said. Because of a labor dispute, the NHL recently became the first major North American pro sports league to cancel its season. title: Taser Intl. climbs on lawsuit dismissal

content: Advancers Beacon Roofing BECN, +0.38% rose more than 2 percent after the company said its first-quarter net income shot up to $8.7 million, or 32 cents per share, from $3.1 million, or 17 cents per share, noting that the year-earlier quarter was pressured by unusual charges. The Peabody, Mass. roofing products seller's quarterly revenue strengthened to $199.2 million from $168.6 million. Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% shares advanced nearly 2 percent after the company said that its clients' daily average revenue trades (DARTS) were 186,000 January, down 14 percent from January 2004 and down 1 percent from December 2004. The company also said for February to date, trading levels are comparable to January statistics. The firm said it brought in net new assets of $4 billion in January, while total client assets at the end of January were $1.07 trillion, up 8 percent from January 2004 and down 1 percent from December 2004. Citadel Security Software CDSS shares leapt more than 9 percent after the Dallas company agreed to provide its Hercules automated vulnerability management application to Raytheon RTN, +2.26% Discovery Laboratories' DSCO shares surged more than 10 percent after the company said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has issued it an approvable letter for Surfaxin, a drug used for the prevention of respiratory distress in infants. The approvable letter is an official notification that the FDA is prepared to approve the Surfaxin New Drug Application and contains conditions that the applicant must meet prior to obtaining final U.S. marketing approval. Shares of DPL Inc. DPL, -3.00% gained almost 8 percent after the company agreed to sell its interests in 46 private equity funds to AlpInvest/Lexington for $850 million. The sale and transfer of each private equity investment is subject to the approval of the general partner or other applicable manager of each investment and other customary closing conditions. Duke Energy DUK, +0.06% tacked on about 2 percent after the company received an upgrade to "buy" from Smith Barney. Encysive Pharmaceuticals' ENCY shares rose more than 12 percent after the company said a Phase III trial to test the safety of Thelin in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension met its primary endpoint. "We are now focused on filing a New Drug Application... with the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in April 2005 to seek marketing authorization. This NDA submission will be closely followed by marketing applications in Europe and other territories," the company said. Friedman Industries' FRD, +0.86% shares leapt more than 2 percent after the company restated second-quarter earnings to 29 cents a share, up 4 cents from its original report, as it corrected the accounting for liabilities for materials it received in September. Gateway GTW tacked on more than 2 percent after the PC maker received an upgrade to "buy" from First Albany. Global Signal GSL, +6.80% shares gained more than 4 percent the company received an exclusive deal to exclusively lease the rights to Sprint's FON, +5.56% more than 6,600 towers for about $1.2 billion in cash. Global Signal will also be able to sublease space on the towers and will have the option to purchase them at the end of the 32-year lease for about $2.3 billion. Sprint will sublease space on the towers from Global Signal for at least 10 years at an initial rate of $1,400 per month per tower. See full story. Shares of IRSA Inversiones y Representaciones Sociedad Anonima IRS, +2.12% leapt more than 8 percent in midday action. After Friday's closing bell, the Argentina-based real estate company posted earnings for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 that were well ahead of its year-ago performance. JDS Uniphase JDSU rose almost 4 percent after the San Jose, Calif., producer of products and subsystems for fiber optic communications said Chief Financial Officer Ron Foster stepped down. He is being replaced temporarily by controller David Vellequette. Shares of Kendle International (KNDL) soared more than 35 percent after the Cincinnati provider of clinical research services reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.1 million, or 16 cents a share, up from $513,000, or 4 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Net service revenue was $48 million versus $40 million a year earlier. Income from operations for the quarter was $3.8 million, up from $2.1 million in 2003. Mair Holdings' MAIR shares added about 1 percent after the company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $1.5 million, or 7 cents a share, up from $700,000, or 3 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 12 cents a share, on average. Revenue increased 0.2 percent to $115.5 million. The air carrier said poor weather at its hub operations hurt its aircraft operations and ground handling business. Meadow Valley Corp. MVCO shares gained more than 16 percent after the Phoenix construction materials company and contractor said it's filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of its Ready Mix unit, which provides ready-mix concrete products. The company plans to sell 1 million shares of Ready Mix common stock at $12 each. See full story. Monarch Casino & Resort MCRI, +0.52% shares rose more than 6 percent after Merriman Curhan Ford initiated coverage of the company with a "buy" rating. Monster Worldwide MNST, +1.72% surged more than 2 percent after the company agreed to acquire French online recruiter Emailjob.com for $26 million from trade show organizer Reed Expositions France, a subsidiary of Reed Elsevier. Monster also received an upgrade to "outperform" from CSFB on valuation. Network Appliance NTAP, +3.73% gained more than 4 percent after the company received an upgrade to "outperform" from Friedman Billings Ramsey. See full story. New Century Financial NEW, +0.00% rose more than 1 percent after the Irvine, Calif. non-prime mortgage lender increased its outlook for its 2005 dividend to $6.50 per share, up from an earlier forecast of $6.20 per share or more. Pacer International PACR shares advanced almost 5 percent after the company received an upgrade from Bear Stearns. Redback Networks' RBAK shares rallied more than 5 percent after the company received an upgrade to "sector outperform" from CIBC World Markets. Retalix Ltd. RTLX shares climbed more than 5 percent after its joint-venture partner Fujitsu announced the launch of the U-Scan Shopper, a wireless, cart-mounted computer which provides shoppers with store information and allows them scan products as they shop. The cart also has a self-checkout function. Retalix and Fujitsu cooperate in the joint venture StoreNext Retail Technologies, which offers retail technology to independent grocers and regional supermarket chains. Smithfield Foods' SFD, +2.50% shares jumped more than 6 percent after the company said it expects fiscal third-quarter earnings of 86 to 87 cents a share, up from 38 cents a share in the same period a year ago and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 61 cents a share. The processed meats distributor is scheduled to reveal full results on March 1, with analysts expecting revenue of $2.89 billion, on average. Shares of Taser International TASR surged more than 7 percent after the maker of stun guns announced it received new orders worth a total of $675,000. See full story. Transaction Systems' TSAI shares gained more than 9 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after hedge fund Jana Partners, which owns roughly 5 percent of the company, send a highly critical letter to management urging expansion of its buyback program and consideration of strategic options. See full story. TriZetto Group TZIX shares added more than 7 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of 13 cents a share, topping Wall Street's consensus view by 2 cents. For the first quarter, the Newport Beach, Calif, producer of healthcare technology and services forecast between a breakeven performance and a profit of 5 cents per share. W.R. Berkley BER, +0.00% tacked on more than 6 percent after the insurance provider reported fourth-quarter earnings of $116 million, or $1.31 a share, up from $93 million, or $1.07 a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, earnings would have been $1.29 a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.25. Net premiums increased 15 percent to $1.1 billion. Exide Technologies' XIDE shares jumped almost 14 percent after the Lawrenceville, N.J.-based battery maker said its sales jumped 11.5 percent to $727.9 million in the third quarter as it did a better job of offsetting the impact of higher lead costs with price increases. Decliners Shares of American International Group AIG, -0.18% fell nearly 3 percent after the company received subpoenas from the New York Attorney General and the Securities and Exchange Commission, "relating to investigations of non-traditional insurance products and certain assumed reinsurance transactions and AIG's accounting for such transactions." The company said the subpoenas came subsequent to its earnings conference call on Feb. 9. AIG said it will cooperate in responding to the subpoenas. See full story. Ark Restaurants' ARKR, -2.04% shares dropped almost 9 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $1.2 million, or 34 cents per share, up from $556,000, or 17 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $27 million, compared with $25 million in 2003. The New York-based restaurant and bar operator said that same-store sales rose 8.3 percent in the first quarter. Armor Holdings' AH, +3.65% shares lost more than 5 percent after Goldman Sachs lowered its rating on the company to "underperform," saying earnings have peaked. The firm said the Jacksonville, Fla., vehicle armor and security products maker's fourth-quarter results came in 3 cents shy of its estimate with margins dropping beyond expectations. Audiovox VOXX, -1.98% shares fell more than 6 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter sales dropped to $149.5 million from $190.3 million, amid a year-over-year 21.4 percent decrease in video and DVD sales, although other electronics products sold well. The company's net income vaulted nearly ten times to $66.3 million, or $3.02 per share, from $7.3 million, or 33 cents per share, boosted by a special gain from an asset sale. On an adjusted basis, the company took a quarterly loss of 10 cents per share, against year-earlier net income of 26 cents. Brunswick Corp. BC, +1.71% lost more than 3 percent after the Lake Forest, Ill., engine maker was downgraded to "sector perform" by RBC Capital Markets. See full story. Chiron CHIR dipped almost 1 percent after the company said late Friday that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has formalized its inquiry into whether the Emeryville, Calif., biopharmaceutical firm violated securities laws. Chiron said it is continuing to cooperate with the SEC. Shares of EPlus Inc. PLUS, +1.70% dropped more than 15 percent after the company said it plans to restate its financial results for the three and six-month periods ended September 30 2004, which will lead to a cut in its earnings for the two periods of 5 cents a share respectively. The enterprise software group said the restatement was necessary to correct an error related to the recording of a lease transaction in its leasing unit. The company also said it would receive $37 million from Ariba ARBA as part of a settlement of a patent infringement dispute. Magal Security Systems Ltd. MAGS, -6.18% shares fell more than 7 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $442,000, or 5 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $663,000, or 6 cents per share. Revenue fell 3.9 percent in the latest three months to $17 million from $17.7 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Israel-based maker of computerized security systems said it expects its performance in 2005 to shoe "significant improvement" over 2004. Shares of MCI Inc. MCIP tumbled more than 3 percent after the company confirmed an agreement to be acquired by Verizon Communications VZ, -0.37% in a deal with a total value of $6.746 billion, including a special dividend to be paid by MCI to shareholders. Verizon's actual payout works out to about $5.3 billion -- $4.8 billion in equity and $488 million in cash. On a per-share basis, the deal values MCI at $20.75 per share, meaning no premium is being paid over Friday's closing price. Verizon shares fell about 1 percent. Qwest Q, +0.00% which was in the bidding for MCI, saw its stock fall 4 percent. See full story. NVE Corp. NVEC, +6.83% shares fell more than 8 percent in midday action. The move comes after Cypress Semiconductor CY, +2.05% announced plans to divest its magnetoresistive random access memory, or MRAM, business. Cypress had used NVE's technology in its MRAM samples. OfficeMax OMXS30, +1.54% shares lost more than 5 percent after Christopher Milliken resigned as CEO, president and director. Executive director George Harad will serve as interim CEO until the board finds a replacement. Additionally, the company said it will release financial results on March 14, when it expects to report operating income from its office products business of $125 million to $135 million for fiscal 2004. OfficeMax delayed reporting earnings due to an internal investigation into a $3.3 million accounting fraud. See full story. Specialty Laboratories' SP, -1.11% shares gave back more than 3 percent after the company said its chief executive officer, Douglas Harrington, M.D., is leaving to pursue other scientific and business ventures and to spend more time with his family. Harrington will remain with the company until March 29, after which chief financial officer Kevin Sayer will act as the company's senior officer until a successor is found. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International's shares added more than 11 percent at one point in Monday trading after the company announced new orders for its Taser-brand stun guns. Taser's TASR stock shot up $1.03 cents, or 7.6 percent, to finish at $14.51, after trading as high as $15.15 earlier in the session. The move higher in shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of so-called "non-lethal" weapons helped offset last week's weakness, ignited by the Chicago Police Department's decision to hold off distributing additional Tasers to its officers following a death and heart attack thought related to their use. Detailing its latest supply deals, Taser said the El Paso, Texas, police department ordered another 124 of its stun guns, the Pima, Ariz., sheriff's department wants an additional 140 devices, and an unnamed agency placed a follow-on order for an undisclosed number of Tasers. Overseas, Singapore's national police force put in a first-time order for 126 Tasers, the company said. The orders received came to $675,000 and are expected to ship in the first quarter of 2005, said Taser. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition
title: Taser's shares gain on new orders

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Shares of Taser International, Inc. tasr rose 5 percent at $14.20 with some 9000 shares traded. The shares moved after the maker of stun guns announced it received new orders totaling $675,000.
title: Taser Int'l shares up 5% amid new orders

content: SAN FRANCISCO (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr on Friday said that it is disputing Associated Press and CBS News reports about how the company's stun guns caused heart damage in pigs during an Air Force study. "The study did not find ventricular fibrillation or heart damage," Taser said in a statement. The study's results were presented in November, Taser said.
title: Taser disputes AP, CBS reports about stun gun tests
