Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 12 to 20 cents per share in the first quarter, and a profit of 95 cents to $1.05 per share for the full year. The stock closed Monday at $14.36, down 4.4 percent. Level 3 Comms posts narrower-than-expected loss Q4 loss (8:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Level 3 Communications LVLT posted Tuesday a fourth quarter net loss of $77 million, or 11 cents a share compared with $171 million, or 25 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. The Internet networking group said fourth quarter revenue edged up to $1.06 billion from $988 million. Revenue from its key communication division came in at $482 million ahead of the company's own forecast of $455 to $482 million due to better-than-expected sales of its Internet telephony services. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for a loss of 20 cents a share on revenue of $1 billion. Looking ahead, the Broomfield, Colo. company said it expects communications revenue in the first quarter of around $400 million to $420 million. Shares of Level 3 Communications fell 3.9 percent, to $2.99 in trading Monday. NovaStar Financial Q4 net falls (8:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- NovaStar Financial, Inc. NFI, +0.90% a residential lender and mortgage real estate investment trust, said Tuesday it earned 22.8 million, or 85 cents per share in the fourth quarter, compared to $35.2 million, or $1.45 per share a year ago. NovaStar shares fell 18 cents and closed at $41.95 on Monday. McDonald's January same-store sales up 5.2% (8:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- McDonald's MCD, -1.28% reported same-store sales for the restaurants increased 5.2 percent worldwide in January. The company said global systemwide sales for its restaurants rose 8.3 percent for the month. The Dow component said same-store sales jumped 4.1 percent in the U.S., a performance that reflects "the vitality of our menu, service and marketing initiatives along with our strategic focus on delivering an exceptional customer experience." Shares of the Oak Brook, Ill., hamburger seller closed Monday at $32.78, up 21 cents. Perot Q4 earnings almost triple; revs up 18% (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Perot Systems PER, +2.70% said it earned $27.1 million, or 22 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, almost triple the $9.9 million, or 8 cents a share, earned in the year earlier period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 19 cents a share. Revenue climbed 18 percent to $466 million, against a First Call estimate of $466.9 million. Looking ahead, the Plano, Tx. IT company said it expects earnings of 21 to 24 cents, on revenue of $465 to $480 million. First Call is forecasting earnings of 20 cents a share on revenue of $479 million. Shares closed Monday up 1 percent at $15.00. DJ Orthopedics Q4 adj profits top Street view (7:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- DJ Orthopedics Inc. DJO posted Tuesday fourth quarter net income of $5.3 million, or 24 cents a share compared with $4.1 million, or 21 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Excluding restructuring charges of $2.6 million related to the integration of its Regentek division, net income was $6.9 million, or 31 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter shot up 24.7 percent to $68.1 million, buoyed by the contribution from its newly-acquired Regentek business. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 27 cents a share on revenue of $66.9 million. Looking ahead, the San Diego company is forecasting 2005 earnings in the range of $1.20 to $1.25 per share before the impact of stock option expensing, which will be required from the second half of 2005.222 Revenues are expected to come in between $273 million and $275 million. The current First Call average estimate is for full-year earnings of $1.22 a share on revenue of $270 million. Shares of DJ Orthopedics ended unchanged at $24.10 in trading Monday. Advanced Medical Q4 net income, sales rise (7:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Advanced Medical AVO, +0.00% Wednesday said its fourth-quarter net income was $10.1 million, or 26 cents per share, against $9.7 million, or 28 cents per share, a year earlier. The Santa Ana, Calif. ophthalmic surgical and eye care products manufacturer's quarterly sales shot up to $224.6 million from $166.9 million. On Tuesday the company's stock fell 25 cents to $44.01. Keystone Automotive Q3 EPS 25 c vs 29 c (7:52 AM ET) NE WYORK (MarketWatch) -- Keystone Automotive KEYS, +2.26% said Tuesday its net income for the fiscal third quarter was $4.0 million, or 25 cents per share on revenue of $136.6 million compared with $4.5 million, or $0.29 per share on of $126.3 million a year ago. Keystone shares closed Monday off 7 cents at $23.52 Eclipsys Q4 shares loss lessens to 6c vs 46 c (7:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Eclipsys Corp ECLP said Tuesday it lost $2.9 million, or 6 cents per share in the fourth quarter on revenue of $87.2 million, compared to a loss of $6.7 million, or 46 cents per share on revenue of $66.6 million a year ago. The loss of 6 cents per share matched the average analyst estimate as compiled by Thomson First Call. Eclipsys closed off 35 cents Monday, at $18.32.shares Phoenix Cos. Q4 net surges past Street view (7:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- The Phoenix Companies, Inc. PNX, -1.57% posted Tuesday fourth quarter net income of $42.9 million, or 43 cents a share compared with $28.9 million, or 29 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 19 cents a share. Looking ahead, the insurance group said it is targeting double-digit percentage growth in total life insurance sales for 2005 and positive net flows in asset management and variable annuities. Shares of The Phoenix Companies climbed 0.8 percent, to $12.95 in trading Monday. Alcan swings to Q4 loss (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Alcan Inc. AL, +1.43% said Tuesday it lost $538 million, or $1.46 a share, in its fourth quarter on revenue of $6.5 billion. A year earlier, the Canadian aluminum producer(CA:AL)had earned $96 million, or 30 cents a share, on revenue of $3.6 billion. Operating earnings, which exclude foreign currency translation and other items, were 30 cents a share for the current quarter, down from 37 cents a share in 2003. Reflecting non-cash impairment charges of $346 million, the loss from continuing operations for the fourth quarter was $1.44 a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 52 cents a share, on average, for the quarter. Looking ahead, the company said it expects to face headwinds from higher input costs in the near-term but that fundamentals for primary aluminum and key end markets remain positive. Kimco Realty Q4 funds from operations match Street view (7:29 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch)-- Kimco Realty Corp. KIM, -0.89% posted Tuesday fourth quarter net income of $75.8 million, or 64 cents a share compared with $84.1 million, or 72 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Revenues for the quarter dipped to $124.7 million from $125 million. Funds from operations, a common measure of profitability for real estate investment trusts, rose to $103.6 million, or 90 cents a share from $96.3 million,, or 85 cents a share a year-ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for funds for operations to come in at 90 cents a share. Looking ahead, the New Hyde Park, N.Y. company reiterated its forecast of funds from operations in 2005 in the range of $3.77 to $3.83 per share. The current First Call average estimate is for earnings of $3.82 a share. Kimco Realty shares ended down 0.9 percent, at $54.88 in trading Monday. Johnson Outdoors swings to a Q1 loss (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - Johnson Outdoors JOUT, -0.86% Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $1 million, or 12 cents per share, compared to year-earlier net income of $200,000, or 2 cents per share, pressured by losses in its watercraft and diving businesses. The Racine, Wis. maker of outdoor sports equipment had quarterly revenue of $75 million, up from $62.9 million a year earlier. On Monday the company's stock closed unchanged at $20.15. Taser Int'l Q4 earns, rev. rise, but miss expectations (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International TASR reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 8 cents a share, up from $2.8 million, or 5 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $19.25 million, up 79 percent from last year's $10.78 million, but below analyst forecasts of $20.3 million. Shares of the maker of non-lethal law enforcement devices closed Monday up 47 cents at $17.16. Church & Dwight adj Q4 net handily tops Street view (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Church & Dwight CHD, +2.27% posted Tuesday fourth quarter net income of $11.9 million, or 18 cents a share compared to $15.9 million, or 25 cents in the same quarter in 2003. Excluding a one-off refinancing charge of $14.9 million, the maker of the Arm & Hammer range of household products would have earned 33 cents a share. Sales for the quarter climbed to $405 million from $286 million, buoyed by a $135.6 million contribution from its recently-acquired Armkel and oral care businesses. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 27 cents a share on sales of $395 million. Looking ahead, the Princeton, N.J. company said it is forecasting 2005 earnings of at least $1.70 per share, which compares with a current First Call average estimate of $1.73 a share. Church & Dwight shares rose 0.8 percent, to $36. Earthlink Q4 earnings top forecasts, sales fall (7:16 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Internet service provider Earthlink ELNK said fourth-quarter profits rose to $35.6 million, or 23 cents a share, from $10.7 million, or 7 cents a share, while revenue eased 3 percent to $338 million. Brokers expected a first-quarter EPS of 22 cents, Thomson First Call said. Earthlink said it benefited from greater operational efficiencies and lower telecommunications costs. Net income is expected to be in a $106 million to $146 million range for 2005 vs. $111 million in 2004, and Earthlink expects net profits in a range of $28 million to $33 million in the first quarter. Engelhard sees '05 EPS below analyst forecasts (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Engelhard Corp. EC, +3.54% said Tuesday it earned $58.1 million, or 47 cents a share, on sales of $1.02 billion in its fourth quarter compared with $63.7 million, or 50 cents a share, on sales of $1.04 billion a year earlier. Fourth quarter results included a net pre-tax charge of $5.3 million, or 3 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of 48 cents a share on average for the quarter. Looking ahead, the company said it expects 2005 earnings of $1.90 to $2.00 a share and said it believes it is well-positioned to achieve double-digit earnings growth before 2005. The average First Call estimate for 2005 was for earnings of $2.02 a share. Cubic Q1 earns decline, miss expectations (7:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Cubic Corp. CUB, +0.63% reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 20 cents a share, down from $7.5 million, or 28 cents a share, due primarily to increased investment in product development. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 31 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 11 percent to $190 million from last year's $171 million, amid a 17 percent rise in defense sales. The stock closed Monday up 17 cents at $22.86. Vitran transport Q4 sees 2005 earns $1.23-1.35/share (6:56 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Toronto-based transport and logistics group Vitran Corp. VVN said it expects 2005 earns from $1.23 to $1.35 a share. The group posted net income of $4.4 million, or 34 cents a share in the fourth quarter, up from 29 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 13 percent to $96.5 million. Net income in the 2004 fourth quarter was positively impacted by a one-time tax benefit reflecting the recognition of a loss carry-forward of around $700,000, it said. Bunge posts lower Q4 results; 2005 seen 'more typical' (6:55 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Bunge Ltd. BG, +1.20% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $105 million, or 89 cents per share, as opposed to $100 million, or 94 cents, earned in the final three months of 2003. The agribusiness and food company had about 11 percent more shares outstanding in the latest quarter. Bunge's quarterly sales slipped 2 percent to $6.212 billion, as volumes eased 1 percent from the prior year to 26.8 million metric tons. Excluding special items, Bunge's earnings would have been $1.00 and $1.55 per share in the 2004 and 2003 fourth quarters, respectively. Wall Street, on average, had been looking for earnings of 82 cents and revenue of $6.825 billion for the latest quarter, according to estimates compiled by Thomson First Call. This year "promises strong growth and a return to more typical market conditions," said CEO Alberto Weisser. Assuming stable currencies and normal harvests, Bunge is projecting 2005 earnings of $3.82 to $3.98 per share; analysts' average target is $3.95. Shares of Bunge added 81 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $57.35 in Monday's trading. Myriad Genetics posts $10M loss on higher Q2 revenue (6:53 AM ET) WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) -- Myriad Genetics Inc. MYGN, -0.40% reported a loss of $10.05 million, or 33 cents per share, in the second quarter ended Dec. 31, as opposed to a loss $9.85 million, or 36 cents, recorded in the same period in fiscal 2004. There were about 11 percent more shares outstanding in the latest quarter. The biotechnology company's quarterly revenue reached $19.64 million from the prior year's 14.15 million. Predictive medicine revenue totaled $17.54 million. Analysts' average estimates were for a loss of 34 cents per share on revenue of $17 million, according to data compiled by Thomson First Call. Phase I enrollments for Myriad's MPC-6827 and MPC-2130 cancer drug candidates are moving ahead as scheduled, the company said. Shares of Myriad Genetics dropped 61 cents, or 2.4 percent, to end at $24.86 in Monday's dealings. Marriott Int'l tops Q4 forecasts on better RevPAR (6:49 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Marriott International MAR, +1.55% posted a fourth-quarter earnings rise ahead of company and broker forecasts as RevPAR was stronger than anticipated. Marriott's fourth quarter profit rose to $189 million, or 79 cents a share, from $169 million, or 69 cents a share, as revenue rose to $3.14 billion from $2.86 billion. Analysts had been expecting an EPS of 75 cents on sales of $3.1 billion, according to Thomson First Call. For 2005, Marriott sees an EPS before options expensing of $2.73 to $2.83, vs. a broker forecast of $2.84, and a 52 cent to 54 cent EPS for the first quarter vs. a broker view of 59 cents a share. New bedding will result in a $40 million to $45 million pre-tax one-time hit in 2005, with most of the charge in the second quarter, it said. Building Materials Q4 net $1.34/share vs. 43c year-ago (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Building Materials Holding Corp. BMHC said fourth quarter net income rose to $19.0 million or $1.34 per share, up from 43 cents a share in fourth quarter of 2003. Sales rose 28 percent to $539.3 million. "Looking ahead, we remain steadfast in our plan to increase our market share through acquisitions and the expansion of our construction services business," it said. Toll Brothers reiterates FY, tops on Q1 sales (5:23 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Luxury home builder Toll Brothers TOL, +1.36% reiterated it's on track for over 40 percent growth in fiscal 2005 net profit after first quarter ending Jan. 31 contracts rose 60 percent to $1.44 billion, or 2,173 homes, a new company record. Revenue rose 68 percent to $989 million, and its backlog of $4.89 billion, or 7,292 homes, is up 66 percent; both are company records. Analysts had been expecting first-quarter revenue of $940.5 million, according to Thomson First Call. General Growth Q4 net falls, FFO tops forecast (4:10 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- General Growth Properties GGP, -0.44% said fourth quarter earnings eased to $93.6 million, or 41 cents a share, from $99.4 million, or 46 cents a share, while revenue soared to $671 million from $382.7 million. Funds from operations per share rose to 90 cents from 75 cents and was ahead of broker forecasts of 87 cents, according to a Thomson First Call poll. For 2005, it sees an FFO of $3.13 a share vs. broker estimates of $3.11. Renault 04 net up 43% to 3.5b euros, sees 05 sales up (2:44 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- French carmaker Renault(FR:013190)posted a 43 percent rise in net income for 2004 to 3.5 billion euros as revenue rose 8.4 percent to 40.7 billion euros. Renault said it attained a 4.1 percent market share in 2004 with a 4.2 percent rise in cars to 2.5 million. Looking ahead, Renault said it expects the auto market in Europe "to remain stable" and to "grow slightly" in other countries, with the exception of Turkey. "Overall, in a sluggish market and an environment impacted by the rise in raw material prices, Renault intends to continue to grow its global sales and report a Group operating margin - under IFRS - higher than 4 percent of revenues." BP Q4 dividend, proforma profits climb 26% (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Oil major BP BP, +2.37% (UK:BP)said Tuesday that it was lifting its fourth-quarter dividend in dollar-terms by 26 percent to 8.5 cents a share after posting a 26 percent rise in proforma net income to $3.64 billion, with $1.12 billion in charges. BP said the increased dividend level is sustainable even if oil falls to $20/barrel and said it sees giving around $23 billion to shareholders in 2005 and 2006 through buybacks and dividends. BP said its stategy is unchanged and on track, that 2005 output should be between 4.1 million and 4.2 million barrels of oil equivalent per day after a fourth-quarter 4 percent rise to 4.09 million boed, and said its combined reserve ratio calculated using SEC accounting was at 89 percent. Oil prices are likely to have a support level of around $30 a barrel for at least the medium term, it added. Eircom swings to Dec. quarter profit, aims 500,000 DSL (2:24 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Telecoms carrier Eircom(UK:EIR)said operating profit ahead of restructuring costs rose to 63 million euros in the December quarter from 7 million euros in the year-ago period. The carrier swung to a profit of 17 million euros as revenue held flat at 401 million euros, it said. The carrier said it's targeting 500,000 DSL broadband customers by December 2007, up from 117,000 currently. UBS Q4 profits top forecast, trading revenue climbs (2:20 AM ET) LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Swiss banking giant UBS UBS, +0.40% said Tuesday that fourth-quarter net income improved to SFr2.02 billion ($1.65 billion) from SFr1.8 billion a year ago, as a 7 percent rise in operating income outstripped a 4 percent gain in operating expenses. Analysts polled by AFX News had forecast a fourth quarter net between SFr1.65 billion and SFr1.89 billion. Equity trading revenue rose 25 percent in the quarter, fixed income trading revenue rose 10 percent and foreign exchange revenue improved 13 percent, which UBS attributed to improved market activity levels following the U.S. elections. UBS said it's upping its 2004 dividend by 15 percent to SFr3/share, and it plans a SFr5 billion share buyback after a SFr3.5 billion share buyback plan in 2004. For 2005, it said it will have to contend with unpredictable financial markets but said 2004 showed its wealth and asset management business can provide "growth momentum and earnings quality" in fluctuating trading conditions. Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers The Advisory Board Co. ABCO gained more than 21 percent after the Washington, D.C., provider of research for the health care industry posted strong third-quarter earnings and provided a bullish outlook. See full story. AeroFlex ARXX shares leapt almost 14 percent after the Plainview, N.Y., automated testing technology company posted pro forma earnings for the second quarter that matched Wall Street's consensus estimate and forecast a sequential sales increase for the third quarter. Analogic Corp. ALOG, +1.75% shares added more than 4 percent after the company said it was informed by the Nasdaq that it is now in compliance with the exchange's listing qualifications. ATI Technologies' ATYT shares advanced more than 2 percent after the Markham, Ontario, producer of 3D graphics and digital media silicon products agreed to pay as much as $14 million for Terayon Communication Systems Inc.'s TERN, -3.85% cable modem silicon intellectual property. Shares of The Brink's Co. BCO, +0.92% tacked on more than 3 percent after the company posted fourth-quarter net income of $32.1 million, or 57 cents a share compared with a net loss of $25 million, or 47 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Earnings from continuing operations came in at 55 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter climbed 17 percent, to $1.3 billion, buoyed by across-the-board gains across all its businesses. The Richmond, Va. company said the weaker dollar contributed three percentage points of the increase in revenues. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 63 cents a share on revenue of $1.25 billion. Shares of Building Materials Holding Corp. BMHC gained more than 14 percent after the San Francisco provider of building products posted fourth-quarter earnings rose to $19.0 million or $1.34 per share, on sales of $539.3 million. The performance was well ahead of a year-ago profit of $5.8 million, or 43 cents per share. Business Objects BOBJ surged more than 12 percent after the San Jose, Calif., provider of business intelligence software turned in a fourth-quarter profit, reversing a year-ago loss as it saw its software-license revenue leap 38 percent. See full story. Carrington Laboratories' CARN shares gained more than 2 percent after the company said revenue for 2004 would be slightly above its previous forecast. The Irving, Texas, biopharmaceutical company said that it expects net operating income to be breakeven, due to a nearly 40 percent increase in funding for its DelSite Biotechnologies unit Shares of Corixa Corp CRXA rose more than 2 percent after GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% said it received European regulatory approval for a hepatitis B vaccine that contains Corixa's MPL compound. The vaccine, called Fendrix, is designed to prevent hepatitis B in patients with insufficient kidney function. Cutera Inc. CUTR, +2.97% shares rose more than 20 percent after the Brisbane, Calif.-based medical laser device and skin-treatment systems reported strong fourth-quarter results. See full story. DJ Orthopedics' DJO shares added more than 5 percent after the San Diego medical device maker posted fourth-quarter adjusted earnings that topped Wall Street's consensus estimate with a solid contribution from its newly-acquired Regentek business. Ebay EBAY, +0.32% gained more than 3 percent after the online auctioneer disclosed that its $415 million acquisition of Rent.com will be an all-cash deal, not the mostly stock deal originally announced in December, according to a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Elbit Medical Imaging EMITF, +1.82% shares leapt more than 18 percent after the company confirmed that it's mulling a possible initial public offering of its InSightec Image Guided Treatment Ltd. operations. Shares of Extended Systems XTNDE soared more than 34 percent after the Boise, Idaho company lifted its outlook for the third quarter, saying it has closed a significant prepaid licensing transaction for its mobile device solutions products. The company now expects earnings of 11 to 16 cents per share for the period on revenue of between $10.5 million and $11.5 million. The company's previous outlook for the quarter was for between a breakeven performance and earnings of 6 cents per share on revenue of $8.5 million to $9.5 million. Goldcorp Inc. GG, +2.29% rose almost1 percent after its board recommended that shareholders reject Glamis Gold Ltd.'s GLG, +0.00% amended take-over offer and reiterated its recommendation that they vote in favor of Wheaton River Minerals Ltd.'s WHT offer. The Toronto-based mining company also declared a special cash dividend of 50 cents per share to be paid to shareholders of record as of Feb. 16, contingent upon satisfaction of Wheaton River's bid conditions Grant Prideco GRP, -1.24% added more than 2 percent after the Houston developer of oil drilling technology was upgraded to "neutral" by Credit Suisse First Boston. Liberty Corp. LC, -0.28% shares gained more than 8 percent after the company declared a $4 a share special cash dividend, to be paid on April 4 to shareholders of record as of March 15. The Greenville, S.C.-based media company also said that it is extending the deadline for its stock repurchase program to Feb. 28. Metal Storm Ltd. MTSX shares rose more than 8 percent named David Smith chief executive officer. The appointment is effective Feb. 14. Smith was previously the president and CEO of SenSyTech Inc. The Arlington, Va.-based defense contractor also announced the retirement of Mike O'Dwyer and J. Dennis Heipt from the board of directors. Nam Tai Electronics' NTE, +2.94% shares rallied more than 7 percent, surging for a second straight session after the Hong Kong-based provider of electronic manufacturing services posted strong fourth-quarter results and gave a positive outlook. Nathan's Famous' NATH, +4.23% shares surge more than 7 percent after the Westbury, N.Y., hotdog seller reported third-quarter net income per share doubled on 16 percent higher revenue. NetSol Technologies' NTWK, -2.13% shares gained more than 9 percent after the Calabasas, Calif., provider of information technology services and software reported second-quarter earnings of $27,956, or breakeven on a per share basis, up from its year-ago loss of $566,175, or 8 cents per share. The latest results include a charge of 4 cents per share related to the exercise of warrants. Sales jumped 125 percent in the latest three months to $2.7 million from $1.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Net2Phone NTOP shares rose more than 8 percent after the company agreed to jointly offer an integrated Voice over Internet Protocol service with Hughes Network Systems to Directwave customers in Europe and the Middle East. Palatin Technologies' PTN, +3.81% shares added more than 6 percent after the company and King Pharmaceuticals KG, +4.65% said their Phase 2A clinical study of the PT-141 drug for pre-menopausal women diagnosed with female sexual dysfunction showed an increase in sexual desire and genital arousal. Perot Systems' PER, +2.70% shares advanced almost 3 percent after the company earned $27.1 million, or 22 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, almost triple the $9.9 million, or 8 cents a share, earned in the year-ago period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 19 cents a share. Revenue climbed 18 percent to $466 million, against a First Call estimate of $466.9 million. Looking ahead, the Plano, Tex., information technology services company said it expects earnings of 21 to 24 cents, on revenue of $465 to $480 million. First Call is forecasting earnings of 20 cents a share on revenue of $479 million. Pfizer PFE, +0.54% shares added more than 2 percent amid news of strong results for a cancer drug, and speculation that the Dow component may announce a restructuring plan. See full story. The Phoenix Companies' shares PNX, -1.57% gained more than 4 percent after the company posted fourth-quarter net income of $42.9 million, or 43 cents a share compared with $28.9 million, or 29 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 19 cents a share. Looking ahead, the insurance group said it is targeting double-digit percentage growth in total life insurance sales for 2005 and positive net flows in asset management and variable annuities. Playtex Products' PYX, -5.19% shares rose more than 3 percent after the company said it would record charges of $17 million to $19 million in 2005 for consolidating its divisions and realigning sales, marketing and manufacturing operations. About $11 million of the charges will come in the fourth quarter, and Playtex will also take an additional $17 million in the final three months of 2004 for writing down the value of its Baby Magic and Binaca trademarks, blaming, respectively, "the impact of increased competition and reduced brand focus." Primeda PRM, -0.79% shares rose more than 12 percent following a New York Times report that it plans to sell Web site About.com. Presstek PRST, +0.00% shares added more than 10 percent after the company forecast fourth-quarter revenue to be in excess of $53 million. The Hudson, N.H.-based digital imaging company said that it expects to report its highest quarterly revenue ever in the fourth quarter. Redback Networks' RBAK shares rose more than 4 percent after the company inked a deal to sell its gear to BellSouth BLS, +0.00% Roper Industries' ROP, +1.52% shares gained more than 4 percent after the Duluth, Ga., industrial products company narrowed its prediction for adjusted earnings in 2004 to $2.67 to $2.69 per share from a previous outlook of $2.58 to $2.70 per share. The estimates exclude about $7 million to $8 million in charges for acquisitions. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call is for earnings of $2.67 per share. ScanSoft SSFT, -5.41% rallied more than 6 percent after the company said that its first-quarter earnings more than doubled to $3.1 million, or 3 cents a share, from $1.3 million, or a penny a share, a year ago. Pro forma earnings were $9.1 million, or 8 cents a share. Revenue for the Peabody, Mass.-based software company was $60.6 million vs. $46.9 million a year earlier. Toll Brothers' TOL, +1.36% shares added more than 4 percent after the company reiterated that it's on track for over 40 percent growth in fiscal 2005 net profit after first quarter ending Jan. 31 contracts rose 60 percent to $1.44 billion, or 2,173 homes, a new company record. Revenue rose 68 percent to $989 million, and its backlog of $4.89 billion, or 7,292 homes, is up 66 percent; both are company records. Analysts had been expecting first-quarter revenue of $940.5 million, according to Thomson First Call. Tripath Technology TRPH shares rose more than 11 percent after the company said it would provide its class-T amplifier products for use in Virgin Electronics Boomtube EX portable speaker system. TriQuint Semiconductor TQNT shares gained more than 9 percent after the company reported a narrower than expected loss for the fourth quarter. VF Corp. VFC, +0.61% shares added more than 7 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $125.3 million, or $1.10 a share, compared with $105.6 million, or 96 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were $1.56 billion, up from $1.39 billion last year. The Greensboro, N.C.-based apparel maker forecast 2005 earnings to increase 6 percent to 8 percent and earnings per share to rise at least 8 percent. It also expects sales to increase 6 percent to 8 percent and earnings to rise about 8 percent in the first quarter. See full story. The Wet Seal WTSLA rose more than 10 percent after the company said it's a target of an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry. The retailer said it intends to cooperate. The SEC generally concerns the company's 2004 second quarter earnings results during the period of August 5 through August 19, 2004. It said the SEC requested documents, if any, relating to the sale of the company's stock by La Senza Corp. and certain of its units in 2004. Decliners Alcan AL, +1.43% shares dipped almost 3 percent after the company lost $538 million, or $1.46 a share, in its fourth quarter on revenue of $6.5 billion. A year earlier, the Canadian aluminum producer (AL) had earned $96 million, or 30 cents a share, on revenue of $3.6 billion. Arch Coal ACI, -0.18% shares lost roughly 3 percent after the St. Louis coal producer forecast earnings of $1.50 and $2 per share in 2005, below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of $2.26 per share. Shares of Ariba ARBA slid more than 17 percent after a Virginia court found the enterprise software group guilty of infringing three U.S. patents held by ePlus INc. Aribal said it plans to appeal the verdict. EPlus is claiming royalty damages of $76 million to $98 million. However, based on the jury's finding that Aribal willfully infringed the patents, the trial judge has the discretion to raise any award by up to three times the jury's award of damages. Ariba said it will be updating its customer software to avoid the infringement. Bunge Ltd. BG, +1.20% shares fell more than 2 percent in midday action. Before the opening bell, the White Plains, N.Y., producer of fertilizers and various food products reported fourth-quarter earnings of $105 million, or 89 cents per share, higher than a year-ago profit of $100 million, or 94 cents per share. Looking ahead, however, the company sees a profit of $3.82 to $3.98 per share for 2005. Wall Street's consensus estimate is for earnings of $3.95 per share in the period. Bunge said it expects its earnings to be split over the year with 30 percent of profits coming in the first half and 70 percent coming in the second half. Chesapeake Corp. CSK, -8.86% lost more than 3 percent after the company was downgraded to "sell" from "hold" by Smith Barney. Cubic Corp. CUB, +0.63% dropped more than 8 percent after the San Diego-based maker of combat training systems reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 20 cents a share, down from a year-ago profit of $7.5 million, or 28 cents a share, due to increased investment in product development. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 31 cents a share, on average, in the period. Cyberonics CYBX shares lost more than 4 percent after the Houston medical devices manufacturer reported a third-quarter loss of $800,000, or 3 cents per share, compared with net earnings of $1.6 million, or 6 cents per share, a year before. The company said results were eroded by the fact that its U.S. sales organization spent more than two weeks away from normal duties to take time out for training. Cybertronics also said its fourth-quarter results will be impacted by the costs of launching a new depression treatment. Earthlink ELNK shares tumbled more than 9 percent after the Atlanta-based provider of Internet access services posted fourth-quarter results that beat Wall Street's profit forecast but fell short of the consensus revenue estimate. The company also reported a sharp decline in the number of its premium dial-up subscribers. Eclipsys Corp. ECLP shares lost more than 11 percent after the Boca Raton, Fla., healthcare information management software company posted an in-line loss for the fourth quarter. Electronic Data Systems' EDS shares lost almost 6 percent after the Plano, Texas-based IT services company disappointed Wall Street with its new contract signings figures and outlook. See full story. Shares of Flowserve Corp. FLS, +3.69% sank more than 6 percent after the Dallas fluid motion and control products and services company confirmed it will restate four years' worth of financial statements, resulting in a total reduction of $20 million in net income. The company also said CEO C. Scott Greer plans to step down, effective June 30. See full story. Golden Telecom GLDN, -0.50% shares slid more than 2 percent after the company lowered its 2004 operating income outlook to $94 million from a range of $105 million to $110 million. The Moscow-based telecommunications and Internet services company cited increased costs and unanticipated expenses for the lower forecast. Golden Telecom said that its revenue estimate remains unchanged. Griffon Corp. GFF, +0.83% fell more than 9 percent after the company said fiscal first-quarter profit was $10.5 million, or 34 cents a share, down 20 percent from $13.1 million, or 41 cents a share, last year. Sales were $340.2 million, up from $338.5 million a year ago, said the Jericho, N.Y.-based provider of products ranging from garage doors, plastic films for diapers, and information and communications systems. Human Genome Sciences' HGSI shares slumped more than 5 percent after the Rockville, Md., biotechnology company reported a widened fourth-quarter loss, due largely to a drop in revenue. S&P lowered its equity rating on the company to "hold." See full story. Iridex IRIX, -1.21% shares sank more than 13 percent after the company delayed the release of its fourth-quarter and year-end results to Feb. 15 from Feb. 8, saying its management and audit firm need additional time to finalize the year-end audit. Level 3 Communications' LVLT shares tumbled more than 11 percent after the company forecast lower sales for its main communications business in 2005. See full story. Maxim Pharmaceuticals' MAXM shares fell more than 19 percent after the company said it would cut 12 to 39 jobs as part of its realignment plan. The San Diego-based company said that most of the jobs are related to its Ceplene development program, which is winding down. Maxim also said that it is realigning its corporate objectives based on preliminary data from its Phase II trials for Ceplene. These objectives include the hiring of an investment back to explore strategic opportunities and seeking a marketing partner for its products. Mcafee Inc. MFE, +0.60% shares gave back more than 8 percent in reaction to news that Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% had purchased rival Sybari Software, an anti-virus security products company. The news also weighed on Symantec SYMC, +0.82% which fell more than 6 percent. See full story. MGP Ingredients' MGPI, +1.70% shares lost more than 9 percent after the company posted second-quarter net income of $1.35 million, or 8 cents per share, down from $1.83 million, or 12 cents per share, pressured in part by diminished demand for low-carbohydrate products. Quarterly sales of the Atchison, Kan. company, which produces wheat-based food ingredients, strengthened 3 percent to $61.2 million. Myriad Genetics' MYGN, -0.40% shares fell more than 4 percent after the company reported a loss of $10.1 million, or 33 cents per share, in the second quarter ended Dec. 31, as opposed to a loss $9.9 million, or 36 cents, recorded in the same period in fiscal 2004. There were about 11 percent more shares outstanding in the latest quarter. The biotechnology company's quarterly revenue reached $19.64 million from the prior year's 14.15 million. Predictive medicine revenue totaled $17.54 million. Analysts' average estimates were for a loss of 34 cents per share on revenue of $17 million, according to data compiled by Thomson First Call. Nike NKE, +1.53% shares lost more than 2 percent after the company was downgraded to "neutral" by Merrill Lynch. NovaStar Financial NFI, +0.90% shares gave back almost 7 percent after the residential lender and mortgage real estate investment trust fell short Wall Street's consensus estimate for its fourth-quarter results. See full story. NPS Pharmaceuticals' NPSP dipped more than 2 percent after the company said it need extra time to prepare the new drug application for its Preos drug, a proposed treatment for osteoporosis. OSI Pharmaceuticals' OSIP shares fell more than 1 percent after the company reported a loss of $48.4 million, or $1.02 a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31, wider than a year-ago loss of $40.1 million, or $1.03 a share for the like period a year ago. Excluding items, the loss was 98 cents a share, higher than the 71-cent estimate from analysts. Protein Design Labs' PDLI, +0.34% shares fell more than 9 percent after the company said it plans to raise roughly $250 million through the sale of seven-year notes that convert into common stock. Shares of Sina Corp. SINA, +4.55% shares lost more than 10 percent after the company said fourth-quarter income almost doubled, but its first-quarter forecast fell short of analyst estimates. See full story. SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% fell more than 5 percent after the company downgraded by Friedman Billings Ramasey to "market perform." Stoneridge Inc. SRI, +2.07% slid more than 4 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $114.9 million, or $5.07 per share, including a non-cash impairment charge of $183.5 million. Sales rose 8 percent in the latest three months to $163.4 million from $151.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Excluding the charge, the Warren, Ohio, maker of electrical and electronic components for cars and trucks earned $4.8 million, or 21 cents per share, for the quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 16 cents per share in the December period. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 12 to 20 cents per share in the first quarter, and a profit of 95 cents to $1.05 per share for the full year. Taser International TASR shares dropped more than 11 percent after the stun gun maker reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 8 cents a share, up from $2.8 million, or 5 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $19.25 million, up 79 percent from last year's $10.78 million, but below analyst forecasts of $20.3 million. See full story. UniSource Energy UNS, +1.06% shares gave back more than 7 percent after the company posted a steep drop in fourth-quarter profit, with earnings of $1.6 million, or 5 cents a share, vs. $27.3 million, or 79 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue came in at $273.5 million compared with $280.2 million in the same period last year. The Tucson, Ariz.-based utility holding company said it expects to report a per-share profit of $1.50 to $1.75 in 2005. Viisage Technology VISG shares lost more than 18 percent after the Billerica, Mass.-based digital security and identification systems supplier warned of a wider than expected loss for 2004. See full story. W.R. Grace GRA, +0.23% shares fell more than 8 percent after the Justice Department charged the company and 7 high-ranking employees knew and hid the fact that a Montana mine emitted cancer-causing asbestos particles. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) - U.S. stocks closed higher Tuesday, bolstered by a rally in semiconductor shares and in stock of Pfizer Inc. after the drug company reported positive results from testing on a cancer drug. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed up 8.87 points, or 0.1 percent, at 10,724.63, while the Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ edged up 4.65 points, or 0.2 percent, to 2,086.68 and the S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% eked out a gain of 0.58 points to 1,202.30. Advancers led decliners by a nine to seven margin on the New York Stock Exchange and 16 to 15 on the Nasdaq. Big Board volume topped 1.41 billion shares, while more than 1.93 billion shares moved on the Nasdaq. Analysts said markets were seeing a clear shift in momentum after a terrible January. "February certainly seems to have got some of the bulls back into the game," said Art Hogan, chief market strategist at Jefferies & Co. The gains were offset by caution ahead of earnings after the close from Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% The networking giant reported that net income in its fiscal second-quarter almost doubled, as revenue rose to $6.06 billion, which was just shy of analyst estimates. See full story. Cisco's shares were little changed ahead of the results, but fell as much about 2 percent in late trading in the first hour after the company's earnings report. Meanwhile, semiconductor stocks rallied as analysts said they saw inventory concerns fading. "We believe the inventory risk at semiconductor suppliers was significantly reduced in Q4, as inventory decreased by 11 days and $626 million at the 25 suppliers we track," SG Cowen told clients. The broker recommended investors buy Analog Devices ADI, +1.36% Altera ALTR, +1.98% Intel INTC, +5.00% Linear Technology LLTC Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% and Xilinx XLNX, +1.25% ahead of improving fundamentals. Traders also indicated that the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, +2.24% which was up 2.2 percent, has broken a technical resistance level. "They are buying semiconductors like crazy," said Tom Schrader, head of listed trading at Legg Mason. Listen to the interview. Intel, the world's largest chipmaker and a Dow component, climbed 2.2 percent. Pfizer was the Dow's other big winner, while American Express AXP, +1.16% General Motors GM, +2.45% and Procter & Gamble PG, +0.56% were among the decliners. Pfizer PFE, +0.54% lifted 2.6 percent after reporting positive results of a Phase III study of a cancer drug designed to treat Gleevec, or resistant gastrointestinal stromal tumor. The pharmaceutical giant said the drug demonstrated efficacy and safety seven months ahead of schedule, and that an independent panel of experts has recommended stopping the trial and giving the drug to patients who were receiving the placebo. See full story. Separately, Lehman Brothers told clients Tuesday it believed Pfizer was readying a restructuring of its sales and marketing teams. Checking other markets, the dollar jumped 0.9 percent against the Japanese yen to 105.73 yen and up 0.1 percent against the euro at $1.2770. See full story. Treasurys were mixed as the bond market digested the first leg of a trio of government note auctions to be held this week. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note finished up 3/32 at 101 22/32 to leave the yield virtually unchanged at 4.06 percent. See Bond Report. In the energy pits, March crude futures closed up 12 cents at $45.40 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. See Futures Movers. April gold futures recovered from an intraday drop of more than $3 an ounce to close down just 10 cents at $414.20 an ounce in New York. See Metals Stocks. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% slipped 1.1 percent after J.P. Morgan lowered revenue and earnings projections, citing competitive and secular pressures as risks to enterprise margins. The broker expects $83.74 billion in revenue in fiscal 2005 and earnings of $1.46 a share, down from a prior revenue estimate at $83.98 billion and earnings of $1.49 a share. "As we enter the seasonally weaker part of the year, we believe that increasing competitive pressure from Dell DELL and IBM IBM, +0.60% could make it difficult for H-P to continue its enterprise profit recovery," J.P. Morgan said. Fellow tech blue-chip Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% added 0.3 percent after announcing plans to buy antivirus security provider Sybari Software. The news sent shares of other antivirus companies into a tailspin, with McAfee MFE, +0.60% sliding 8.2 percent and Symantec SYMC, +0.82% dropping 6.4 percent. See full story. Among the latest to report earnings, Level 3 Communications LVLT posted a narrower-than-expected loss while Business Objects BOBJ Church & Dwight CHD, +2.27% Marriott International MAR, +1.55% Perot Systems PER, +2.70% and UBS UBS, +0.40% all bested expectations. Biogen Idec BIIB, +0.74% Electronic Data Systems EDS Human Genome Sciences HGSI and Taser International TASR however, all came up short of Wall Street forecasts. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks close higher as Pfizer, chip stocks rally

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International Inc. said Tuesday fourth-quarter profit soared 77 percent on sales growth of 79 percent, but investors punished its stock as the results failed to meet expectations. Shares of Taser TASR plunged 11.3 percent, or $1.95, to finish at $15.21, after falling as low as $14.10 earlier in the session. The Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of so-called less-lethal weapons, used primarily by law enforcement agencies, said net income swelled to $5 million, or 8 cents a share, from $2.8 million, or 5 cents, earned in the fourth quarter of 2003. Quarterly sales rose to $19.2 million from $10.8 million. Three analysts polled by Thomson First who follow Taser had been looking for earnings, on average, of 10 cents a share on $20.2 million in sales. Morgan Keegan analyst Brian Ruttenbur downgraded Taser to "underperform," based on the company's earnings miss and his expectation for a slowdown in profit and sales growth in 2005. "While we see a certain degree of short-term uncertainty, we remain optimistic about our long-term business prospects," said Chief Executive Rick Smith. "We continue to receive affirmation of the life-saving value of our products from our existing customers," he added. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau
title: Taser's profit falls short, shares plunge

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Homeland security stocks were mostly lower early Tuesday, led by Taser tasr and Viisage Technology visg Taser slumped 10 percent after fourth-quarter earnings missed estimates, while Viisage lost 17.7 percent after a profit warning late Monday. Stephens Inc. cut its rating on the stock to "underweight" on the news. Elsewhere in the sector, Digital Recorders tbus lost 1.4 percent, Mace fell 0.9 percent, and Identix idnx lost 0.6 percent.
title: Homeland security stocks dip; Taser, Viisage disappoint

content: LONDON (MarketWatch) -- Dealers were looking for a flat open in New York markets Tuesday, expecting the quarterly update and outlook from networking bellwether Cisco Systems after the close to set a more definitive tone. Still the U.S. stock futures were holding off lows, with the Dow industrials futures up 8 points at 10,708 at 8 a.m. Eastern. The Nasdaq and S&P futures were flat. The tech stocks are an expected focus following solid recent gains as well as the chipmaker updates at the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers conference this week in San Francisco. The tech sector looks "a bit toppish at the moment on the Nasdaq," said Geoff Langham, Head of Trading with CMC Group in London. Cisco CSCO, +2.95% was up 0.7 percent after 8 a.m. at $18.30. Cisco is expected to report a 20 percent surge in fiscal second-quarter profit. See story Outside of equities, the dollar built on recent gains as the markets look for deficit-cutting in the U.S. The dollar bid was most apparent in the yen, as the greenback surged 0.9 percent to 105.84 yen. The euro eased to $1.2735 and the British pound was held to $1.85. Crude oil was lower, bolstering the U.S. stock futures. The benchmark New York crude contract was last at $45 a barrel. Focus stocks Investment banker stocks should draw some notice after UBS UBS, +0.40% posted a 12 percent surge in fourth quarter profit, driven by banner investment banking results. UBS executives, marking something of a turn for the big European companies, said deal-making and growth are a priority over buying back shares. See story Lehman Brothers overnight, citing industry contacts, said it expects pharmaceuticals maker Pfizer PFE, +0.54% is restructuring its sales and marketing teams. "We understand that at least some sales and marketing teams will be meeting today with senior management," the broker said. "We believe that were Pfizer to reduce its headcount globally, the U.S. reduction in particular would have a beneficial effect on the global pharmaceutical sector as others would follow suit." Pfizer, a Dow industrials component, was marked at $25.01 in Frankfurt, indicating a gain from its $24.91 close on Monday. Luxury home builder Toll Brothers TOL, +1.36% reiterated it's on track for over 40 percent growth in fiscal 2005 net profit after first quarter ending Jan. 31 contracts rose 60 percent to $1.44 billion, or 2,173 homes, a new company record. Marriott International MAR, +1.55% sees 2005 earnings per share before options expensing of $2.73 to $2.83, vs. a broker forecast of $2.84, and a 52 cent to 54 cent EPS for the first quarter vs. a broker view of 59 cents a share. Stun gun maker Taser International TASR often a volatile pre-open stock, dropped close to 19 percent to $14 after reporting fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 8 cents a share, up from 5 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 10 cents a share. The stock was the top by volume and trades on the Archipelago exchange early Tuesday. British gaming group Wembley (WMY) said it expects to sell its Lincoln Park track operation in Rhode Island as well as Colorado to BLB Investors in a deal that will net Wembley $339 million. The sale is conditional on a revenue-sharing pact. BLB said it plans to invest $560 million, including $125 million in infrastructure improvements to buy Lincoln Park. The average weekly VLT revenue during 2004 was $5.8 million, up from $5.1 million in 2003. Wembley shares rose 7.6 percent in London. Oil major BP BP, +2.37% that it was lifting its fourth-quarter dividend in dollar-terms by 26 percent to 8.5 cents a share after posting a 26 percent rise in proforma net income to $3.64 billion, with $1.12 billion in charges. Overnight movers included Sina Corp. SINA, +4.55% which dropped 21 percent to $21.60 amid a disappointing outlook. Business Objects BOBJ rose 12 percent to $26.28 after growth in license revenue. Electronic Data Systems EDS fell 6.4 percent to $19.98 after a quarterly disappointment. BiogenIDEC BIIB, +0.74% was up 1.6 percent at $67.25 after its quarter late Monday. Bear Stearns upgraded the stock Tuesday to "outperform" from "peer perform, citing the outlook for sales of its multiple sclerosis treatment Tysabri. Broker calls Merrill Lynch overnight downgraded Nike, Inc. NKE, +1.53% to "neutral" from "buy," telling clients the February earnings per share outlook at 97 cents "looks high to us." The broker added it expects Nike will be "be negatively impacted by the S&P's transition to a free float index, half of which takes place on March 18. Nike is the fifth biggest weight loser in market cap, at over $1.2 billion, representing about 15 days to trade." J.P. Morgan overnight lowered its revenue and earnings projections for Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% , citing competitive and secular pressures risks to enterprise margins. The broker expects $83.74 billion in revenue in fiscal 2005 and earnings per share of $1.46, down from a prior revenue estimate at $83.98 billion and earnings of $1.49 a share. "As we enter the seasonally weaker part of the year, we believe that increasing competitive pressure from Dell DELL and IBM IBM, +0.60% could make it difficult for HP to continue its enterprise profit recovery," the broker said. QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% was upgraded to "outperform" from "neutral" by CS First Boston on the belief that fundamentals are improving in the company's three major business segments, which could lead to upside to estimates through. SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% was downgraded to "market perform" from "outperform" by Friedman Billings Ramsey citing concerns that the White House's budget proposal would put pressure on student loan spreads and reduce returns on equity in the near term. Temporary staffing group Adecco ADO, +0.00% was upgraded to "overweight" by Morgan Stanley, with its price target hiked to SFr74 from SFr61, with the broker citing its low valuation compared to peers. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: US futures steady as oil retreats, Nike downgraded

content: Pre-Open stocks action Dealers looked for a modestly bullish U.S. open as crude oil extended its decline, the dollar gained and analysts weighed in on Pfizer, Sallie Mae, QLogic and Nike. See indications for full pre-open coverage. Global Markets Shares in London and on the Continent edged higher on the dollar and crude, as well as earnings from BP and Swiss banking giant UBS. Japan's Nikkei ended down as tech shares were sold, with much of Asia celebrating the lunar New Year. See Global Markets page for Europe, U.K. and Asia markets. Broker Action SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% was downgraded to "market perform" from "outperform" by Friedman Billings Ramsey, which cited concerns the White House's budget proposal would put pressure on student loan spreads and reduce returns on equity in the near term. SLM, or Sallie Mae, is a student loan services company. "Although higher loan limits, longer repayment terms and variable consolidation loans would be strong positives, the benefits would take years to flow to the bottom line," analyst Matt Snowling said. "Until then, the company would face compressing margins as a result of reduced government subsidies and new fees." J.P. Morgan lowered its revenue and earnings projections for Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% citing competitive and secular pressure risks to enterprise margins. The broker expects $83.74 billion in revenue in fiscal 2005 and earnings per share of $1.46, down from a prior revenue estimate at $83.98 billion and earnings of $1.49 a share. Merrill Lynch downgraded Nike Inc. NKE, +1.53% to "neutral" from "buy," telling clients the February earnings-per-share outlook at 97 cents "looks high to us." The broker said it expects Nike will be "be negatively impacted by the S&P's transition to a free-float index, half of which takes place on March 18." QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% was upgraded to "outperform" from "neutral" by CSFB on the belief that fundamentals are improving in the company's three major business segments. Analyst Andy McCullough raised his stock price target to $48 from $40, his 2006 earnings estimate to $1.97 a share from $1.94 and his revenue forecast to $667 million from $656 million. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments. Breaking news - See market pulse for breaking news About.com, the Primedia-owned property that offers a network of about 475 Web sites on a range of topics, is up for sale, according to a New York Times report. Five prospective buyers -- identified as Google GOOG, +2.71% Yahoo YHOO Ask Jeeves ASKJ New York Times Co. NYT, +2.77% and the America Online unit of Time Warner TWX, +0.40% -- are expected to submit final bids later Tuesday, with the expected asking price pegged at $350 million to $500 million, the newspaper reported. It cited executives close to the auction. Primedia, which paid $690 million for About.com in October 2000, is controlled by buyout firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% agreed to pay Chairman Craig Barrett a base salary of $610,000 for 2005, the Santa Clara, Calif., chipmaker disclosed in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Barrett also has a target of $700,000 of additional compensation under the company's incentive plan for officers. Intel will recommend that he receive a grant of options on 250,000 shares, which vest in 25 percent annual increments beginning a year from the date of grant. Barrett is also part of the company's semiannual cash award program and he will participate in Intel's retirement programs. Intel INTC, +5.00% agreed to pay its new president and chief executive, Paul Otellini, a base salary of $550,000, rising to $650,000 on June 1 when he officially becomes CEO. Otellini also has a target of $750,000 additional compensation under the company's incentive plan for officers. Otellini received options on 400,000 Intel shares, which vest in 25 percent annual increments starting four years from the date of the grant, Feb. 2, 2005. Intel will also recommend that Otellini receive a grant of options on 500,000 shares as part of the company's annual option-grant program. These vest in 25 percent annual increments beginning a year from the date of grant. Otellini is also part of the company's semiannual cash award program, a calculation based on pay, and he will participate in Intel's retirement programs. Marriott International MAR, +1.55% posted a fourth-quarter earnings rise ahead of company and broker forecasts. Marriott's fourth-quarter profit rose to $189 million, or 79 cents a share, from $169 million, or 69 cents a share, as revenue rose to $3.14 billion from $2.86 billion. Analysts had been expecting an EPS of 75 cents on sales of $3.1 billion, according to Thomson First Call. For 2005, Marriott sees an EPS before options expensing of $2.73 to $2.83, vs. a broker forecast of $2.84, and a 52 cent to 54 cent EPS for the first quarter vs. a broker view of 59 cents a share. New bedding will result in a $40 million to $45 million pre-tax one-time hit in 2005, with most of the charge in the second quarter, it said Oil major BP BP, +2.37% said it was lifting its fourth-quarter dividend in dollar terms by 26 percent to 8.5 cents a share after posting a 26 percent rise in pro forma net income to $3.64 billion, with $1.12 billion in charges. BP said the increased dividend level is sustainable even if oil falls to $20 a barrel and said it sees giving around $23 billion to shareholders in 2005 and 2006 through buybacks and dividends. BP said its strategy is unchanged and on track, that 2005 output should be between 4.1 million and 4.2 million barrels of oil equivalent per day after a fourth-quarter 4 percent rise to 4.09 million boed, and said its combined reserve ratio calculated using SEC accounting was at 89 percent. Oil prices are likely to have a support level of around $30 a barrel for at least the medium term, it added. Swiss banking giant UBS UBS, +0.40% said fourth-quarter net income improved to SFr2.02 billion ($1.65 billion) from SFr1.8 billion a year ago, as a 7 percent rise in operating income outstripped a 4 percent gain in operating expenses. Analysts polled by AFX News had forecast fourth-quarter net between SFr1.65 billion and SFr1.89 billion.UBS upped its 2004 dividend by 15 percent and detailed a share buyback plan. It anticipated unpredictable financial markets in 2005, but said 2004 showed its wealth and asset management business can provide "growth momentum and earnings quality" in fluctuating trading conditions. Retailer The Wet Seal WTSLA said the company is a target of an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry. The retailer said it intends to cooperate. The SEC probe generally concerns the company's 2004 second-quarter earnings results during the period of Aug. 5 through Aug. 19, 2004. It said the SEC requested documents, if any, relating to the sale of the company's stock by La Senza Corp. and certain of its affiliates during 2004. Taser International TASR reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 8 cents a share, up from $2.8 million, or 5 cents a share, in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $19.25 million, up 79 percent from last year's $10.78 million, but below analyst forecasts of $20.3 million. Shares of the maker of non-lethal law enforcement devices closed Monday up 47 cents at $17.16. Internet service provider Earthlink ELNK said fourth-quarter profits rose to $35.6 million, or 23 cents a share, from $10.7 million, or 7 cents a share, while revenue eased 3 percent to $338 million. Brokers expected a first-quarter EPS of 22 cents, Thomson First Call said. Earthlink said it benefited from greater operational efficiencies and lower telecommunications costs. Net income is expected to be in a range of $106 million to $146 million for 2005 vs. $111 million in 2004, and Earthlink expects net profits in a range of $28 million to $33 million in the first quarter. U.S. retail chains kicked off February on a strong note, with same-store sales rising 2.2 percent in the week ended Feb. 5 compared with the prior week, according to data compiled by the International Council of Shopping Centers and UBS. On a year-over-year basis, last week's sales rose 3.0 percent. Discounters in particular saw a rebound in sales as consumers geared up for the Super Bowl. title: QLogic, Nike, Taser, Marriott, BP in focus

content: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) -- Taser International tasr reported fourth-quarter earnings of $5 million, or 8 cents a share, up from $2.8 million, or 5 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 10 cents a share. Revenue was $19.25 million, up 79 percent from last year's $10.78 million, but below analyst forecasts of $20.3 million. Shares of the maker of non-lethal law enforcement devices closed Monday up 47 cents at $17.16.
title: Taser Int'l Q4 earns, rev. rise, but miss expectations

content: Advancers Amphenol Corp. APH, +1.51% shares gained more than 5 percent after the company said fourth-quarter earnings rose 38 percent to $45.6 million, or 51 cents a share, with sales climbing 18 percent to $403.9 million. Analysts had forecast earnings of 49 cents per share, according to Thomson First Call. The Wallingford, Conn.-based connector maker also said it'll make its first quarterly dividend payment, of 3 cents a share, payable to shareholders of record on March 15. Shares of AVI Biopharma Inc. AVII soared more than 102 percent after the company was issued one patent and granted a notice of allowance on another, covering the use of antisense to modulate stem-cell maturation. The stock was the top percentage gainer on the Nasdaq in early action. Check Point Software Technologies CHKP, +0.30% shares gained nearly 5 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter income rose as sales climbed 24 percent on strong demand for its security-related software. See full story. Shares of Distributed Energy Systems Corp. DESC, +1.49% rose more than 19 percent after the Connecticut company reported strong revenues and orders in the fourth quarter. Entremed Inc. ENMD shares advanced more than 11 percent after the Rockville, Md., company disclosed the findings of a recently published preclinical report on the use of its lead drug candidate. The company said the study showed Panzem, or 2-methoxyestradiol, alone or in combination with paclitaxel significantly inhibited tumor growth in a preclinical xenograft model. Shares of Hub Group Inc. HUBG, +2.45% rose nearly 10 percent following an upgrade by Raymond James to "strong buy" with an earnings estimate for 2005 of $2.45 to $2.60 per share. Raymond James said strong sales trends will continue at the freight carrier as volumes of intermodal shipping-trailers that are carried by both trucks and trains remain high on traffic eastward from West Coast ports. Kana Software KANA shares gained more than 4 percent after the company reported preliminary fourth-quarter revenue at $13.5 million, which the company said was at the high end of its own estimates and would include about $4.6 million in license revenue. Mobility Electronics Inc. MOBE shares rose nearly 7 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based provider of mobile electronic power supply products formed a multiyear joint venture with Energizer Holdings Inc. ENR, +12.35% Energizer will also market and distribute Energizer branded versions of a number of Mobility's current universal power adapters for consumer electronic devices on a worldwide basis. Financial terms were not disclosed. Overstock.com OSTK, -0.96% shares rose nearly 2 percent after the company announced a surge in auction listings on Overstock.com Auctions. The jump in listings follows news that eBay Inc. EBAY, +0.32% plans to increase its fees by 52 percent; the number of listings on Overstock.com increased 50 percent in the five days since eBay's announcement. The online retailer said it plans to reduce its listing fees by an additional 52 percent from Feb. 18 through March 18. Pepsi Bottling Group PBG, +7.14% shares gained more than 2 percent after the company was upgraded by UBS to "buy" from "neutral." The firm said that despite near-term cost pressures, it believes its earnings-per-share estimates can be achieved "due to solid innovation from PepsiCo, Inc. and easier sales (bad weather in 2004) and cost comparisons in the second half of 2005." Rhodia RHA, -50.00% shares added more than 5 percent after the French specialty chemicals company said it expects to report fiscal 2004 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization and before restructuring costs "slightly above" its previously issued guidance of 420 million euros ($548 million) to 425 million euros. Shares of Scitex Corp. SCIX, +0.24% rose more than 7 percent after the Israeli inkjet digital printing products company said it continues to explore strategic alternatives related to its assets. The company said these alternatives include a possible initial public offering and possible dispositions or acquisitions. Sigma-Aldrich Corp. SIAL shares gained nearly 2 percent after the company said it signed an agreement to purchase the JRH Biosciences unit of CSL Ltd. for $370 million in cash. The company also reaffirmed its 2004 earnings estimate of $3.30 to $3.35 a share. For 2005, earnings are expected to be $3.45 to $3.55 a share. Shares of Triarc Cos. TRY, +2.00% rose more than 13 percent after the New York company confirmed Wednesday that it is in negotiations to combine its Arby's restaurant business with RTM Restaurant Group, which operates about 774 Arby's restaurants in the United States. If the deal is consummated, it is expected that Triarc would be the majority owner of the combined entity. Wegener Corp. WGNR, -0.62% shares gained nearly 8 percent after the company said that it has received an order from Nielsen Media Research for the development, manufacture and sale of its Nielsen Audio Encoder. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but the company said that it expects the order to add to its 2005 and 2006 revenue. Shares of York International YRK, +3.45% gained almost 5 percent after Banc of America Securities launched research coverage of the maker of heating, ventilation and air conditioning equipment with a "buy" rating, saying the potential upside to earnings and operating margin expectations are substantial. Analyst Don MacDougall set a 12-month stock-price target of $45. Decliners Shares of Alvarion Ltd. ALVR, +0.00% lost more than 13 percent after Merriman Curhan Ford downgraded the company to "neutral" from "buy" due to concerns over the timing of revenue generation. Analyst Kevin Dede said he has yet to see evidence that broadband wireless deployments in China will increase to a meaningful level and the he is still skeptical that the company's key customer in Latin America will continue to increase its fixed wireless deployments at the current pace. Shares of CellStar Corp. CLST fell more than 20 percent after Southwest Securities analyst Raymond Carpenter raised concerns over potential accounts receivable and inventory adjustments as worries about the company's China business increase. ChipMos Technology IMOS, +0.00% shares skidded more than 9 percent after the company said it sees 2005 revenue of $520 million to $550 million. Analysts expect earnings of $580 million. It said December revenue was $41.4 million vs. $29.6 million. Collectors Universe CLCT, +0.51% shares lost more than 6 percent after the company said it filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed offering of 3 million shares of its common stock. The company said it will offer about 1.9 million shares and selling stockholders will offer about 1.09 million shares. The company will grant its underwriters an option to purchase up to an additional 450,000 shares for over-allotment purposes. Doral Financial Corp. DRL, +0.00% shares fell more than 11 percent despite reporting better-than-expected profit of $150.5 million, or $1.22 a share, for the fourth quarter. Shares of Embarcadero Technologies Inc. EMBTE fell more than 13 percent. Late Tuesday, the company said that as a result of restating its first-quarter results, revenue for the first quarter declined $181,000. For the second quarter, revenue decreased $366,000. Income for the first quarter decreased $130,000, or 1 cent a share, and its second-quarter net loss increased $326,000, or 1 cent a share. The company said it expects investigation-related costs of about $2.1 million for the quarter ending Dec. 31, 2004, and $2.3 million for the quarter ending March 31, 2005. The company said it is now in compliance with Nasdaq. The company also reported delayed third-quarter earnings of $753,000, or 3 cents a share, compared with $1.5 million, or 5 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter was $14 million vs. $13.2 million a year ago. GlowPoint Inc. GLOW, -3.28% shares slid more than 6 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter revenue of $4.3 million. Analysts expect revenue of $5 million. It also said its customers under contract increased 20 percent since 2003. It also forecast 2004 revenue of $16 million, in line with analysts' estimates. Shares of Lucent Technologies LU sank more than 7 percent Wednesday as weakness in the traditional networking market stunted the company's first-quarter sales. See full story. Maytag MYG shares lost more than 10 percent after the company said it plans to stop selling its appliances at Best Buy. The company also announced the departure of two executive vice presidents, William Beer and Thomas Briatico. Motorola Inc. MSI, +1.29% shares fell more than 7 percent in morning trading. The company said Tuesday its quarterly profit jumped more than 50 percent, bolstered by strong demand for its wireless phones. However, Piper Jaffray lowered its rating on the stock to "market perform" in the wake of the results, citing lower margin estimates. See full story. Pervasive Software Inc. PVSW shares slumped more than 8 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $547,000, or 2 cents a share, vs. $902,000, or 4 cents a share, last year. Pro forma earnings were 4 cents a share. Revenue was $11.6 million vs. $11.5 million. Analysts expected earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $12 million. For the third quarter, it forecast revenue of $11.5 million to $12.5 million and earnings of 2 cents to 4 cents a share. Plantronics PLT, +5.08% shares fell nearly 8 percent after the communications headset maker forecast a sequential drop in revenue for the fourth quarter after reporting third-quarter profits that were 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. Rambus Inc. RMBS, +0.67% shares tumbled nearly 16 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter income fell amid higher litigation costs. See full story. Southwest Airlines' LUV, +1.83% shares were off more than 4 percent after the company posted a 15 percent drop in earnings for the fourth quarter due to competitive pressures, higher fuel costs, and an industry-wide seat glut. See full story. Taser International TASR shares lost more than 11 percent after three new lawsuits were filed against the company alleging either securities fraud or misleading statements from its directors. The suits, filed in an Arizona court, allege that the company misled investors and regulators on the safety of its stun guns. Taser shares have lost 40 percent of their value since January 6, when the company disclosed an informal SEC probe of its safety statements and a deal with one of its distributors. Teradyne TER, +1.96% shares tumbled nearly 6 percent after the chip-equipment maker issued a disappointing outlook for the first quarter. See full story. Texas Roadhouse TXRH, +0.50% shares fell more than 5 percent after the company was downgraded by Banc of America Securities to "neutral" from "buy," due purely for valuation reasons. Total System Services' TSS, +1.66% shares lost more than 3 percent after the company reported results that were in line for the fourth quarter. Track Data TRAC, +0.00% shares sank more than 8 percent after the company said its board has authorized a one-for-five reverse stock split. Its chairman and CEO controls more than 50 percent of the company's outstanding common stock and will consent to the reverse stock split, Track Data said. Shares of Trustmark Corp. TRMK, +0.10% fell more than 8 percent after the Jackson, Miss., financial services provider reported a 5.3 percent year-over-year decline in earnings for the fourth quarter following Tuesday's closing bell. The company earned $28.8 million, or 50 cents a share, in the December period, down from its profit of $30.5 million, or 52 cents a share, a year ago, and a penny below Wall Street's consensus view. The results prompted J.P. Morgan Chase to lowered its rating on the company's stock to "neutral" from "overweight" due to sluggish loan growth in the quarter and expectations Trustmark won't see business pick up until late in 2005. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares fell 10 percent Wednesday after three new lawsuits were filed against the company alleging either securities fraud or misleading statements from its directors. The suits were filed late Tuesday or early Wednesday in an Arizona court, alleging that the company mislead investors and regulators on the safety of their core "stun guns." Taser shares have lost 40 percent of their value since January 6, when the company disclosed an informal SEC probe of its safety statements and of a deal with one of its distributors. Shares were last quoted down 9.5 percent at $17.89.
title: Taser loses another 10% as 3 new lawsuits emerge
