The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for revenue of $14.04 million. The company received orders for about $6.5 million in licenses, representing the highest quarterly license booking level achieved by the company in more than two years. Radioshack RSH, -0.07% shares added more than 5 percent after the Fort Worth, Texas consumer electronics retailer reported a 7 percent increase in its fourth-quarter sales. See full story. Sports Authority TSA, +3.32% gained almost 10 percent in afternoon action. The company cut its fourth-quarter earnings forecast to a range of 90 to 95 cents a share, down from its previous view of $1.08 a share, on Wednesday but there are expectations that heavy snowfall could help its sales of ski equipment in January. See full story. SteelCloud Inc. SCLD shares rose almost 28 percent after the Dulles, Va., network security company swung to a profit in the fourth quarter. SteelCloud posted earnings of $475,107 for the three months ended Oct. 31, up from its year-ago equivalent loss of $1.1 million. The company said the performance was "better than planned" due to a significant increase in new orders. Synnex Corp. SNX, +3.46% shares rose more than 4 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings rose 77 percent to $15.3 million, or 50 cents a share, from $8.6 million, or 35 cents a share, a year ago. Taser International Inc. TASR shares soared nearly 22 percent after reports from a medical journal and the Pentagon asserted the company's stun gun devices are safe. See full story. ARNA, -0.28% shares gave up more than 4 percent after the company said it will publicly offer 6 million shares of its common stock following an effective registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Belo Corp. BLC, +0.00% shares lost more than 3 percent after the company was downgraded to "neutral" from "buy" at Fulcrum Global Partners on the belief that near-term earnings pressures will limit the stock's near-term performance. Healthaxis HAXS shares tumbled more than 13 percent in afternoon action, pulling back after a plus 40 percent gain on Wednesday when it received a contract from CBCA Inc. Shares of InterDigital Communications IDCC, +0.48% lost more than 11 percent after the company disclosed in a Form 8-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it's facing a complaint from Nokia NOK, +0.74% in U.S. District Court related to the ongoing arbitration between the companies. "We think margins could be depressed through early 2006, due to higher depreciation expenses via plant consolidations," Mills said. "This pushes out our expectations for material margin expansion and a rebound in earnings growth." title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International shares shot up more than 22 percent in Thursday trading after reports from a medical journal and the Pentagon asserted the company's stun guns are safe. Taser's TASR stock added $3.79 to finish at $20.80. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of "less-lethal" weapons said a cardiac safety study published in the Pacing and Clinical Electrophysiology Journal found that Tasers had an "extraordinarily wide safety margin" for causing heart fibrillations. Dr. Richard Luceri, a cardiologist and member of Taser's medical advisory board, said in a statement the company's stun guns have a greater margin of safety than most cardiac drugs approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Meanwhile, the Department of Defense said a study conducted by the Air Force Research Laboratory found that Tasers do not have a "significant risk of unintended severe effects." However, the ACLU and Amnesty International said the studies still cast doubts on Taser's safety claims and urged local police departments to re-evaluate their use or purchase of the weapons based on safety concerns. The ACLU said 89 deaths in the U.S. and Canada have been linked to police use of Tasers. Amnesty International said the use of Tasers should be suspended pending a rigorous, independent investigation into their safety. "The deaths have generally involved people whose hearts are already at greater risk of fatal ventricular fibrillation because they've ingested drugs or alcohol, are in severe mental distress, or are very pumped with adrenaline," said John Crew, an ACLU lawyer and police practices expert. "The question is -- and always has been -- how Taser shocks interact with these other 'at risk' factors in these deaths. That's why we need more study." The PACE journal and Pentagon reports followed Wednesday's endorsement of Tasers by a Miami-Dade County panel of county commissioners. The grand jury "strongly recommended" the use of Tasers by police in their "confrontations and dangerous encounters with mentally ill subjects." Taser's stock lost almost half its value between Jan. 6 and Tuesday's close, following a series of disclosures that rattled investors. Among the issues battering Taser's shares was its Jan. 6 statement that it was cooperating with an informal Securities and Exchange Commission probe into its safety statements and a sale to a distributor. Additionally, on Tuesday the company warned that it may see some delays in orders in the first half of fiscal 2005, as customers test and evaluate potential rivals' products. One would-be rival, Stinger Systems Inc. STIY which trades on the pink sheets, has seen its shares move in inverse proportion to Taser's. That company's stock plunged 35 percent Wednesday to close at $30, while Taser's shares added 21 percent to $17.01 after the Miami grand jury's endorsement. Stinger's stock lost more than 18 percent to $24.50 Thursday. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000
title: Taser shares shoot up on safety reports

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. tasr rose almost 9 percent to $18.52 in pre-market action on Instinet. The move comes after the company issued a press release about a recent study to be published in the Pacing and Clinical Electrophysiology Journal of electrical neuromuscular incapacitation technology similar to that used in its stun gun devices. The company said the study found the risk of inducing ventricular fibrillation with such technology was "extremely low."
title: Taser Intl surges in pre-market action

content: SAN DIEGO (CBS.MW) -- When dealing with Taser it appears even the company's top execs don't necessarily know all the details about things they're commenting on. In a follow-up to my column from Tuesday, which pointed to a possible conflict of interest between Taser and a former officer in the Minneapolis police department, USA Today Wednesday pointed out that Taser paid stock options to four "active" police officers who are part of its training board. The paper says it received the information from Taser president Tom Smith. Funny, because in his interview with me earlier this week Smith said options were only paid to employees, "down to production workers." Why the change of heart? In a brief interview Wednesday Smith says he was driving during the original interview and didn't have all information at hand. (So why guess?) As it turns out, in its 10-K Taser TASR says options were also paid to consultants. How many consultants? In addition to the four active officers, Smith says, they went to a patent attorney and a medical adviser as well as "three others" on the training board. One, he says, was a retired cop. Who are the others? According to the company's 10-K, the training board includes another active police officer and a "representative from the commercial airline industry." Did they get options as well? And what airline does the airline employee work for? In an e-mail response to those questions, Smith said, "Due to privacy requirements and regulation FD, we cannot provide any information beyond what is contained in our public statements and is consistent with what I provided to you this morning." Thursday thwack Medicine for Medicis: Medicis Pharmaceutical MRX which has plenty of fans on Wall Street for its knack of always meeting or beating earnings estimates, went on the yellow-flag list of my subscription newsletter, Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck, on Nov. 8 when its stock was $39. (And, for now, there it will stay!) The concern at the time was the drug company's dispute with BioMarin Pharmaceutical BMRN, +1.82% which claimed Medicis overcharged BioMarin for the rights and option to buy Orapred, a pediatric asthma drug. After the deal closed, BioMarin found the Orapred sales (and therefore sales price) had been artificially pumped up by a distribution channel that was stuffed with more inventory than BioMarin imagined. BioMarin sued Medicis, which is best known for wrinkle-corrector Restalyn. The suit was then dropped and the two settled the dispute out of court. They finally reached an agreement this week, reducing the licensing payments on Orapred starting "after" July; Medicis also reduced the price it will charge BioMarin to buy all of Orapred, and it agreed to lend up to $25 million to BioMarin, via a convertible note. All of this is a long-winded way to say: It appears Medicis did indeed try to make the Orapred market look stronger than it really is. Orapred's stock, which had tumbled to around $32 before the deal was announced, lifted slightly on the news and now trades at around $34. My original source, a money manger who is short Medicis, continues to be bearish. "Now I think the headwind for them next year is virtually impossible to overcome, short of an acquisition," he says. Not only is there brewing competition for Restalyn, but the company will now get incrementally less licensing revenue from BioMarin. (Note the price paid by BioMarin doesn't get rolled back until July, which would appear to be convenient timing for Medicis from the meeting or beating estimates vantage point.) Medicis will also have to come up with an encore to fill BioMarin's licensing revenue, which was already scheduled to fall sharply next year. As I mentioned in RealityCheck, in the wake of the BioMarin fiasco you can bet that future buyers of anything from Medicis are likely to take a closer look at what they're really getting. Final point: My year-end report card's "incomplete" on NovaStar NFI, +0.90% didn't go over well (surprise, surprise) with the NovaStar noisemakers, which have bombarded me with e-mails pointing out "how much money people would've lost" if they had followed my "recommendation" to short NovaStar two years ago. The only problem with that comment: this column does not make recommendations; it points out risks or situations that are otherwise overlooked. It's then up to readers to decide whether to sell the stock (if they own it), avoid it (if they're considering owning it), ignore what I've written or, if they're so inclined, make a negative bet on a company. (For the record: I think shorting, by the average investor, is like playing with fire. Too many risks and nuances.) As for NovaStar, I wouldn't change a word in any item I've written regarding the company. The beat, as they say, goes on. Editor's note: The most recent edition of the Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck is available by e-mail. For more information or to subscribe, click here. Get an alert every time Herb's free column is published. title: Who else got options from Taser?

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Shares of Apple Computer jumped in evening trading Wednesday after it reported quarterly financial results that far surpassed analyst expectations and boosted its earnings and revenue targets for the coming quarter. The Nasdaq 100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks the evening action of the technology heavy index's leading shares, rose 6.38 points to 1,572.16. Apple AAPL, +0.78% rose 12 percent to 73.49 after it reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of 70 cents per share on sales of $3.49 billion. It was expected earn 49 cents per share on sales of $3.19 billion. It also said it expected second-quarter earnings of 40 cents per share on sales of $2.9 billion, above current expectations. See full story. Apple was by far the most heavily traded stock after the bell, with more than six times the volume of the next most heavily traded share, which was Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% The results dissipated some disappointment at the number of iPods it sold last quarter. The company said it shipped 4.6 million of the music players in the period. Some analysts expected Apple to ship 5 million. See full story. Earlier, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed up 61.56 points at 10,617.78, while the technology heavy Nasdaq Composite Index rose 12.91 points to close at 2,092.53. See full story. The Street.com Inc. TSCM jumped 20 percent to $4.89 after it said I had hired investment bank Allen & Co. to advise the company on "alternatives for enhancing stockholder value." It gave no details. Intel was up 0.4 percent to $23.25 as investors remained interested a day after it reported better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings and revenue. Electric stun gun maker Taser International TASR which added about 20 percent in the regular session, fell 3.4 percent to $16.44 after the bell. The stock gained during the day on word of a Miami grand jury's endorsement of its stun guns. See full story. title: Apple climbs in evening after results beat expectations

content: Advancers Action Products International APII, +2.51% shares rose more than 4 percent after the Orlando, Fla., toy maker reported sales of $488,700 for December, a jump of 154.7 percent from its year-ago equivalent total. The company said it was looking for a gain of 85 percent for the month. Action Products said sales totaled $3 million for the fourth quarter and $9.1 million for the full year. Boston Beer Co. SAM, -0.11% shares rose more than 13 percent after the company was upgraded to "buy" from "hold" by Deutsche Bank due to evidence that fourth-quarter volumes are tracking ahead of expectations amid underlying strength in retail demand. Closure Medical Corp. CLSR shares added nearly 13 percent after the company forecast 2005 revenue of $46 million to $50 million. Analysts currently expect revenue of $45 million, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of Conolog Corp. CNLG advanced more than 14 percent after the company said it received a blanket contract from the U.S. military for communications security equipment. As part of the contract, the company will immediately deliver $200,000 worth of amplifiers and frequency signal selectors. Digital Video Systems Inc. DVID shares rallied more than 19 percent after the company received a letter from the Nasdaq allowing its stock to continue trading on the Nasdaq SmallCap Market, on a couple of conditions. The company is in the process of providing the paperwork for its reverse stock split. The company's shares must show a closing bid price of at least $1 per share by Feb. 23 and a minimum $1 per share closing bid price for 10 consecutive trading days thereafter, the company said. Shares of Forbes Medi-Tech Inc. FMTI advanced more than 5 percent after the Canada-based biopharmaceutical company forecast revenue of C$21 million to C$22 million for fiscal 2005. The company's previous projection was for revenue of C$16.5 million. The company cited strong sales of company's Reducol and Phyto-S Sterols in November and December. Genzyme Corp. GENZ shares rose nearly 5 percent after the biotech company said fourth-quarter revenue rose 23 percent following completion of two mergers, FDA approval of its drug Clolar, and the purchase of U.S. sales and marketing rights for painkiller Synvisc. See full story. Shares of Kansas City Southern KSU, +2.10% tacked on nearly 3 percent after the company received an upgrade to "overweight" from "underweight" from Lehman Bros. HCA Inc. HCA, -0.15% shares advanced nearly 11 percent after the Nashville, Tenn., health-care insurance company raised its outlook to earnings of 68 to 72 cents per share for the fourth quarter Wednesday from its prior projection for a profit of 52 to 57 cents per share. The news sparked jumps in Triad Hospitals TRI, +0.31% and Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% See full story. Healthaxis HAXS shares added more than 53 percent after the Irving, Texas, provider of business claims and administration software received a contract from CBCA Inc., a private provider of benefits management services. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% shares rose nearly 3 percent after the company said late Tuesday fourth-quarter income dipped slightly, even as earnings per share topped analyst forecasts and revenue rose 9.8 percent on better-than-expected sales of its computer chips. See full story. Shares of LifePoint Hospitals LPNT, -1.67% surged more than 9 percent after Raymond James upgraded the hospital operator due to a more constructive outlook for the company's acquisition of Province Healthcare, improving valuation and a favorable view of rural market fundamentals. Myriad Genetics MYGN, -0.40% shares gained more than 13 percent after the company initiated the Phase III human clinical trial of its Flurizan drug for patients with Alzheimer's disease. The trial will be conducted in 750 patients at 100 centers in the United States and will determine if the drug alters the course of cognitive decline and behavioral change in patients with Alzheimer's. Neoforma Inc. NEOF shares surged more than 16 percent after the company said it hired Merrill Lynch & Co. to help explore strategic alternatives, including a possible sale or merger. See full story. On Track Innovations Ltd. OTIV, -2.48% shares surged more than 11 percent after the Fort Lee, N.J.-based smart-card software provider's subsidiary OTI America Inc. received an award that designates it to provide electronic passports for the U.S. government. The company expects one or several companies will ultimately be selected to produce the passports. Rockwell Collins COL, -0.33% shares gained more than 6 percent after the company raised its sales and earnings forecast for fiscal 2005, citing enhanced operating efficiencies, particularly in its commercial systems business. Sinovac Biotech SVA, +3.11% shares jumped more than 5 percent after the company said it won marketing and sales approval from China for its hepatitis A & B vaccine Bilive. Sinovac said GlaxoSmithKline's GSK, -0.79% Twinrix vaccine is not available in China and that the rival drug sells for a much higher price than Bilive in countries where both are available. It is projecting high sales growth rates similar to Hepatitis A drug Healive. Synergy Brands SYBR, +0.00% shares rose more than 14 percent after the company forecast 2004 revenue of $56 million, up 37 percent from $41 million in revenue a year ago. The company cited growth in its business-to-business and online operations. Taser International's TASR shares soared more than 20 percent in afternoon trading. A Miami grand jury has strongly backed the expanded use of the company's "stun guns" in crisis situations involving the mentally ill, the Associated Press reported Wednesday. The jury found that Taser's weapons are a safe alternative to guns, going so far as to assert, "we believe Tasers save lives," in its report. The jury's recommendation comes just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission launched an informal probe of the company's safety reports. The SEC is also investigating a deal with a distributor. The company's shares had fallen sharply after the company disclosed the SEC probe. Ultimate Electronics Inc. ULTEE shares surged nearly 30 percent after the company said it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and arranged for financing with Wells Fargo Retail Finance and Mark Wattles Enterprises, which will also buy shares of the company. Websense Inc. WBSN shares advanced more than 11 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter revenue of $32 million, higher than its previous outlook of $30 million to $31 million. See full story. Decliners BindView Corp. BVEW shares tumbled more than 19 percent after the Houston provider of policy compliance software lowered its revenue outlook for the fourth quarter. See full story. Dendreon DNDN shares skidded more than 8 percent after the company was downgraded by Piper Jaffray to "market perform" from "outperform," following the announcement that the company's prostate cancer drug Provenge had missed the primary endpoint of time-to-progression. See full story. Shares of Canada's EXFO Electro-Optical Engineering EXFO, +1.20% fell almost 7 percent after the company's fiscal first-quarter results missed Wall Street's consensus forecast. The maker of test and measurement equipment for the telecommunications industry posted a pro forma loss of $814,000, or a penny per share, on sales of $21.6 million in the quarter. Analysts had expected the company to earn a penny per share on average, according to Thomson First Call. The company said its results were hurt by the sharp increase in the Canadian dollar vs. the U.S. dollar. ISTA Pharmaceuticals ISTA shares fell more than 7 percent after the company disclosed plans to sell 4.5 million shares of its common stock and grant an option to underwriters to purchase a further 675,000 shares. King Pharmaceuticals KG, +4.65% lost more than 6 percent after the CEO of Mylan Laboratories MYL, +1.65% said the company is "unlikely" to close on its merger with King under the current terms of a proposed transaction. Millennium Pharmaceuticals MLNM shares slipped nearly 5 percent after the company was downgraded by Lehman Brothers to "underweight" from "equal-weight" and cut its 12-month price target on the stock to $8. NCR Corp. NCR, +2.04% shares lost more than 3 percent after the company was downgraded by Merrill Lynch to "neutral" from "buy," saying it expects upside in the fourth quarter and suggesting investors use strength to move to an equal weight position. Net.com NWK shares sank more than 12 percent after the company said it swung to a 12 cent loss per share in the third quarter to Dec. 24, partly on a charge for restructuring. In the previous year, the company had earnings of 4 cents per share. Revenue decreased 12 percent year to $29.7 million. OfficeMax Inc. OMXS30, +1.54% shares gave up more than 4 percent after the company said it was postponing the release of fourth-quarter results until it concludes a previously-announced internal investigation. The office supplies retailer also said its chief financial officer, Brian Anderson, has resigned after two months in the role. See full story. Pozen Inc. POZN, -1.89% shares slid more than 1 percent after the company said its board of directors has approved the adoption of a stockholder rights plan, or a poison pill, by issuing preferred stock. The Chapel Hill, N.C., pharmaceutical company said the rights plan is "designed to enable all Pozen stockholders to realize the full long-term value of their investment and to provide for fair and equal treatment ... in the event that an unsolicited attempt is made." Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, +3.03% shares fell more than 8 percent after the company said its paid subscriber base reached 214,000 in 2004. It also said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings of 1 cent to 2 cents a share, on revenue of $51 million to $52 million. Shares of United Parcel Service UPS, +1.93% gave up more than 7 percent after the parcel delivery company issued a profit-warning for the fourth quarter. The warning prompted Credit Suisse First Boston to downgrade the stock to "neutral" from "outperform". The stock was trading at $80.10 in pre-market activity, down 3.8 percent from $83.30 at Tuesday 's close. See full story. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International shares shot up more than 20 percent Wednesday, rebounding partly from a massive recent sell off and boosted by a Miami grand jury's endorsement of its stun guns. Taser's TASR stock added $2.91 to close at $17.01. That advance partially offset a 49 percent drop in the stock since Jan. 6, when the less-than-lethal weapons manufacturer disclosed it was cooperating with an informal Securities and Exchange Commission probe into its safety statements and a sale to a distributor. Compounding its problems, the Scottsdale, Ariz. company's shares fell another 30 percent Tuesday, after it warned it may see some delays in orders in the first half of fiscal 2005, as potential customers test and evaluate rivals' products. But the stock reversed course Wednesday, following media reports that a Miami-Dade grand jury "strongly recommended" the use of Tasers by police in their "confrontations and dangerous encounters with mentally ill subjects." The panel said Tasers are a safe alternative to traditional handguns, despite the reports of deaths and safety issues that have bedeviled Taser's shares for months. On November 8, the company's stock jumped 16 percent after its stun guns were cleared for use aboard planes by the U.S. Transportation Security Administration, but that was offset by a New York Times article later in the month reporting an unreleased government study that reportedly found the company's stun guns to be dangerous in certain circumstances. On Nov. 30 Amnesty International called on law enforcement agencies to suspend use of Tasers pending an independent investigation of safety issues. title: Taser shares rebound, boosted by grand jury endorsement

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- A Miami grand jury has strongly backed the expanded use of Taser International's tasr "stun guns" in crisis situations involving the mentally ill, the Associated Press reported Wednesday. The jury found that Taser's weapons are a safe alternative to guns, going so far as to assert, "we believe Tasers save lives," in its report. The jury's recommendation comes just days after the Securities and Exchange Commission launched an informal probe of the company's safety reports, following a series of alleged deaths of stun gun targets. The SEC is also investigating a deal with a distributor. Taser shares were last trading up 20.6 percent at $17 in hefty volume of 42.7 million shares. The shares have lost about 40 percent of their value since the company disclosed the SEC probe.
title: Miami grand jury backs Taser use - AP

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Shares of semiconductor leader Intel Corp. rose in evening trading Tuesday after its fourth-quarter earnings and revenue exceeded expectations. The Nasdaq 100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks the evening trading of the technology heavy index's leading shares, rose 1.74 points to 1,555.14. Intel INTC, +5.00% rose 3 percent to $23.22 after it reported net income of 33 cents per share on revenue of $9.60 billion. The company was expected to earn 31 cents per share on revenue of $9.42 billion. Intel said it expected to report first-quarter revenue between $8.8 billion and $9.4 billion. See full story. The better-than-expected results lifted some sector stocks after the bell. Applied Materials AMAT, +2.87% rose 3.2 percent to $16.67 and KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, +2.29% climbed 4.8 percent to $44.45. Intel's report followed results-related warnings on Monday by chip industry rivals Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% and STMicroelectronics N.V. STM, +0.63% (012970)(055085). AMD warned that its revenue in the quarter would not grow as much as previously expected, while STMicro said its gross margins would fall short of expectations. Meanwhile, Germany's Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% (623101) said it was canceling the sale of a unit. See full story. After the bell, AMD rose 1.3 percent to $15.05, partly recouping its 26 percent loss in the regular session. Earlier, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 10,556.22, down 64.81 points on the day, while the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 17.42 points to 2,079.62. See full story. Electric stun gun maker Taser International TASR whose stock fell 30 percent in the regular session after the company said it might see some delays in orders in the first half of the year, fell 2.1 percent to $13.80 after the bell. See full story. United Parcel Service UPS, +1.93% fell 2.9 percent to $80.90 after it said it expected to report a smaller fourth-quarter profit than it had previously expected, citing higher operating costs and slow growth in the company's domestic package volumes. For the fourth quarter, UPS said it expected a profit of 84 cents to 87 cents a share. On an adjusted basis and excluding any tax benefit, the company said it now forecasts a per-share profit of 75 cents to 76 cents a share. Analysts, according to Thomson First Call, forecast a profit of 85 cents a share. UPS also backed its 2005 outlook, which calls for earnings to rise 13 percent to 17 percent over 2004's levels. See full story. title: Intel up in evening after results beat expectations

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International Inc.'s stock plunged nearly 30 percent Tuesday after the company said it may see some delays in orders in the first half of fiscal 2005, as potential customers test and evaluate rivals' products. Taser TASR shares closed down $5.95 to $14.10. The Scottsdale, Ariz. stun-gun maker made the disclosure in an open letter to shareholders and customers -- which the company normally only publishes in conjunction with it annual report -- intended to ease investors' concerns amid an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the safety of its less-than-lethal weapons and the timing of a sale to a distributor. Since its disclosure of the informal SEC inquiry, Taser shares have plummeted 49 percent from its closing Jan. 6, including a drop Monday of 11.8 percent. After the markets closed Jan. 6, Taser said it was cooperating with the informal SEC inquiry into its safety statements, as well as a sale to distributor Davidson Inc. The sale raised the eyebrows of at least one analyst, Gradient Analytics' Rob Miceli, given that it came just 11 days before the end of the quarter, possibly allowing the company to meet its fourth-quarter and full-year revenue forecasts. Potential Taser competitors include Stinger Systems STIY shares of which advanced more than 9 percent to $46 in Tuesday pink-sheets trading; and Law Enforcement Associates LENF which shed more than 25 percent to $8.10, after trading as high as $12.64 earlier in the session. Morgan Keegan told clients in a note Tuesday that although it's maintaining its "market perform" rating on the stock and likes its long-term prospects, it has concerns regarding the SEC inquiry, as well as rivals' product offerings. "We are also concerned that potential competition may slow down Taser sales to the law enforcement community in the first half of 2005," said the broker in a note. "We see some competition coming into the company's market in the next few of months. We believe that despite these new entrants, Taser will continue to penetrate domestic and international markets." Insider sales defended In addition, Taser disclosed insider sales, in which Phil Smith, who retired as chairman Dec. 31, sold most of the Taser stock he owned. The company said Smith sold the shares as part of his transition to retirement. Meanwhile, co-founders Tom Smith and Rick Smith sold about 22 percent of their respective Taser share holdings in the fourth quarter. "We still retain a significant majority of our personal assets," Tom Smith and Rick Smith said in the letter. "Hence, we feel that the rumors about us 'bailing out' are not fair, nor accurate." Executives at Taser International have profited well from the company's sharp stock swings over the past year, despite controversial news reports about the company's main product. According to insider trading data from Thomson Financial, executives and board members at Taser sold more than $125 million of shares during 2004. In the previous year, insider sales totaled about $17.3 million, according to Thomson data. The bulk of those sales came in November, as Taser shares crossed into record territory above $30, on a split-adjusted basis. Insiders sold off $61.6 million of shares during the month. Members of the company's founding family have made the most profitable insider transactions this year. Chairman Phillips Smith and sons Patrick and Thomas -- who serve as the company's CEO and president, respectively -- sold about $105 million of shares in 2004. A portion of those shares were acquired through the exercise of options. The stock made sharp swings in both directions last year as news of new contracts was offset by reports questioning the safety of the company's products. On November 8, Taser shares jumped 16 percent after its stun guns were cleared for use aboard planes by the U.S. Transportation Security Administration. That gain was offset by a New York Times article later in the month reporting an unreleased government study that reportedly found the company's stun guns to be dangerous in certain circumstances.
title: Taser's stock craters; warns of  potential order delays

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Stocks tumbled Tuesday as disappointing numbers from Alcoa and several warnings in the technology sector sparked concerns about fourth-quarter profits as reporting season began. "We went into this earnings season following a very benign preannouncement season so people started to believe that my company didn't pre-announce and therefore everything should be fine," said Peter Boockvar, equity strategist at Miller Tabak. That changed, he said, with Alcoa's weaker-than-expected report and preannouncements from Advanced Micro Devices and STMicroelectronics. "[They] woke people up to the fact that just because you don't pre-announce doesn't mean that you're not going to have anything negative to say," Boockvar said. The tech warnings, especially, unnerved investors who were waiting to hear what Intel Corp. would reveal when it reported after the closing bell. (After the bell, Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% posted a slight drop in fourth-quarter earnings to 33 cents despite a 13 percent gain in revenue to $9.6 billion. The recent quarter included a tax benefit of 3 cents per share. Analysts were expecting earnings of 31 per share on revenue of $9.4 billion. Intel shares lost 1.5 percent ahead of the report.) The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% closed down 64.81 points, or 0.6 percent, at 10,556.22 while the Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ skidded 17.42 points, or 0.8 percent, to 2,079.62 and the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% shed 7.26 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,182.99. Decliners led advancers 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange and 11 to 5 on the Nasdaq. Big Board volume was about 1.48 billion shares while some 2.22 billion shares traded on the Nasdaq. Within the Dow, only 3M MMM, +1.38% and United Technologies UTX, +1.10% managed gains. 3M climbed 0.9 percent after Deutsche Bank raised its stock price target to $95 from $90 and said it expects the maker of Post-it notes and Scotch tape to post earnings that at least meet and possibly beat expectations when it reports Jan. 18. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% was the Dow's biggest decliner, sliding 3.7 percent after Morgan Stanley slammed the computer hardware maker with a downgrade. The broker cut its recommendation to "underweight," saying competition from Dell Inc. DELL and continued signs of supply chain inefficiencies increase the chance for near-term business execution missteps. But the focus was really on earnings as Alcoa kicked off the reporting season with a weaker-than-expected report. "One of the big worries about 2005 is how earnings are going to do," said Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A.G. Edwards. "The news is scary when a company [Alcoa], despite product prices being up, has lower earnings due to higher energy costs and interest rate costs," he added. Whether Wall Street takes Alcoa's report as a company specific issue or a universal problem will be determined by the mood of investors, he said. "If investors remain in a glass-is-half-full attitude, then they will assume it's company specific, but if investors decide to get grouchy, they're going to go into a mood of the glass is half empty and they're going to worry overall." Right now, he noted, the mood is basically optimistic, though it has deteriorated a bit because of the poor market start this year. Shares of the aluminum giant AA, +1.22% stumbled 2.7 percent after it said fourth-quarter profit fell 8 percent, despite higher prices for its aluminum, because of the cost of selling assets, decreased production at its Quebec smelter and higher materials costs. Its report of fourth-quarter earnings of 39 cents a share from continuing operations, excluding one-time items, was 2 cents shy of analysts' forecasts. See full story. Advanced Micro AMD, +2.45% meanwhile, said it expected fourth-quarter sales to be "up slightly" from the $1.24 billion it posted in the previous quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected AMD to post sales of $1.35 billion, on average, for the quarter. See full story. At least four brokers downgraded the stock, which plunged 26 percent. Strategists were concerned about the disappointing start to earnings season but weren't ready to write off the remainder of the reporting period. "I wouldn't want to base a new down market or another negative trend developing on the backs of Alcoa or AMD," said Barry Hyman, equity market strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum. As the season progresses, Hyman thinks markets may start to see some counterbalance to these early-stage earnings. "Even though there may be some downside in the near term, I think once we get deeper into the earnings season ... a lot of the concern as to earnings growth and GDP growth for 2005 will dissipate and the market will right itself and start another uptrend," he added. European-based chipmaker ST Microelectronics STM, +0.63% meanwhile, also warned that fourth-quarter margins would fall short of forecasts. Its shares fell 4.3 percent. See full story. More caution in the tech sector came from Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% which said it now expects to post a loss of 7 to 10 cents a share rather than its prior forecast for profit of 27 cents to 31 cents a share. Unisys shares fell 6 percent. See full story. Nortel Networks NT rose 4.2 percent after issuing its much anticipated audited financial statements for 2003. The telecommunications equipment maker said its restatements are complete. See full story. Elsewhere, Taser International's TASR shares plunged nearly 30 percent after the company said it may see some delays in orders in the first half of fiscal 2005 as potential customers test and evaluate rivals' products. Read more. In the biotechnology space, Genentech DNA, -1.03% fell 6.9 percent after it reported a 63 percent rise in fourth-quarter profit and forecast 25 percent earnings growth for 2005. The results were short of analyst estimates. See full story. Banc of America, meanwhile, downgraded three names in the biotechnology sector, saying higher valuations warrant more stock selection. The broker cut its ratings on MedImmune MEDI, -1.36% Chiron Corp. CHIR and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals REGN, +1.74% Checking other markets, the dollar was down 0.2 percent against the euro, which rose to $1.3111, and down 0.9 percent against the yen at 103.33 yen. See Currencies. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note closed up 7/32 to 100 1/32 to yield 4.25 percent. See Bond Report. Crude futures climbed rose to a three-week high. February crude rose 35 cents to close at $45.68 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange while the February gold contract climbed $2.70 to finish at $422.40 an ounce. See Futures Movers. title: U.S. stocks end lower on sluggish start to Q4 earnings

content: Advancers Books-A-Million Inc. BAMM shares advanced more than 3 percent after the company forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 54 cents to 58 cents a share, up from its previous outlook of 49 cents to 51 cents a share. The company said it increased earnings because of insurance recoveries from hurricane damage in the southeast U.S. Buffalo Wild Wings Inc. BWLD shares gained more than 5 percent after the company said it now expects earnings of 25 cents to 28 cents a share, against its previous forecast of 17 cents to 19 cents. Analysts expect earnings of 21 cents. Ceco Environmental Corp. CECE, -3.05% shares added more than 4 percent after the company said it had won two new orders totaling $3.4 million to install thermal oxidizers at ethanol manufacturing facilities located in the U.S. Midwest. The New York company said each order is worth $1.7 million. Datalink Corp. DTLK shares climbed more than 17 percent after the company said fourth-quarter earnings and revenue would be better than forecast on an improved business mix, although it also sees an unprofitable first quarter on a previously announced charge, rising expenses and Sarbanes-Oxley compliance. Datalink says it'll return to profitability in the second quarter of 2005. Intellisync Corp. SYNC, +3.23% shares surged nearly 11 percent after the company said it now expects second-quarter revenue to exceed its previous forecast of $13 million. Navarre Corp. NAVR shares climbed nearly 5 percent after the company said it plans to buy FUNimation Productions Ltd. and FUNimation Store Ltd. for $101 million in cash and stock. Nortel NT shares rose more than 4 percent after the company restated results. The telecommunications equipment company posted a net loss of $25.7 billion for 2001 and $2.99 billion for 2002 on revenue of $18.9 billion and $11 billion respectively. For 2002, Nortel said earnings excluding charges were $446 million, or 10 cents a share; earnings from continuing operations were $262 million, or 6 cents a share; and earnings from discontinued operations were $184 million, or 4 cents a share. Revenue for 2003 was $10.19 billion. Shares of QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% jumped more than 7 percent after the storage products maker said it expects sales in the fiscal third quarter to rise at least 10 percent from the second quarter, ahead of its expectation. It now sees net revenues of $148 million to $150 million against its previously expected range of $136 million to $143 million. It expects net income per share for the third quarter of 44 cents to 46 cents vs. the previously forecast 36 cents to 39 cents. Rockwell Automation Inc. ROK, -0.29% shares added nearly 13 percent after the company forecast first-quarter earnings of 65 cents a share and revenue of $1.19 billion. See full story. Select Comfort SCSS shares jumped more than 10 percent after the company was upgraded to "outperform" from "market perform" by Piper Jaffray. SpectraLink Corp. SLNK shares advanced more than 22 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter earnings of 20 cents a share on sales of $27.5 million. For 2004, it forecast earnings of 56 cents a share on revenue of $90 million. Decliners Advanced Micro Devices' AMD, +2.45% shares plunged more than 26 percent. The company's rating was cut by Piper Jaffray to "underperform" and its price target was lowered to $15. The downgrade came after AMD late Monday cautioned that sales for the quarter ended Dec. 26 "are expected to be up slightly" from the $1.24 billion it posted in the previous quarter, but that revenue may fall below Wall Street expectations. Analysts expect AMD to post sales of $1.35 billion, on average, based on a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. American Superconductor Corp. AMSC, +7.98% shares slid than 6 percent after the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell four million shares. The underwriters have an option to purchase an additional 600,000 shares to cover over-allotments, if any. Apple Computer AAPL, +0.78% shares fell more than 6 percent in afternoon trading on weakness in the technology sector. The company introduced a new $499 computer, and a smaller version of its popular iPod music device as well. See related story. Dendreon Corp. DNDN shares tumbled more than 26 percent after the company said its prostate cancer trial for Provenge failed its primary endpoint. Dendreon said it plans to complete the final pre-specified, three-year survival analysis of the study in the second half of 2005. See related story. Encore Capital Group ECPG, +0.67% shares slid nearly 3 percent after the company said Tuesday that it has lost a bid with a portfolio seller to renew a forward flow purchase contract for 2005. Genentech DNA, -1.03% shares fell more than 6 percent in afternoon trading. The biotechnology giant reported a 63 percent rise in fourth quarter profit, but its financial results still fell short of analyst estimates. See full story. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% shares skidded almost 4 percent after the company was downgraded to "underweight" from "equal weight" by Morgan Stanley. Competition from Dell DELL in the company's largest profit pools and continued signs of supply chain inefficiencies increases the chance for near-term business execution missteps, Morgan Stanley said. Analyst Rebecca Runkle also cut her stock price target to $18 from $20. In addition, Runkle believes H-P is most at risk from the introduction of a sub-$500 Mac from Apple Computer. LAN Airlines LFL, +16.29% shares fell nearly 5 percent said that December passenger traffic increased 14.8 percent over last year while capacity rose 17.8 percent. Load factor at the Latin American airline fell 1.8 percentage points to 69.9 percent. MGI Pharma Inc. MOGN shares lost more than 11 percent after the company said it expects 2005 revenue of $285 million. It also said it expects 2004 U.S. sales of its Aloxi Injection to range $155 million to $160 million. Regeneron Pharmaceuticals REGN, +1.74% shares slumped more than 11 percent after Banc of America Securities downgraded the stock to "sell" from "neutral." Sypris Solutions, Inc. SYPR, -0.61% shares sank more than 16 percent after the company slashed its fourth-quarter outlook, saying it now expects a loss in the range of 7 cents to 10 cents per share versus an earlier forecast calling for earnings of 17 cents to 20 cents per share. The company expects revenue for the period between $121 million and $123 million, in line with prior guidance. Taser International TASR slumped more than 29 percent after the company said it may see some delays in orders in the first half of fiscal 2005, as potential customers test and evaluate rivals' products. Taser also disclosed in a letter to shareholders that Phil Smith, who retired as chairman on Dec. 31, sold most of the Taser stock he owned. In addition, co-founders Tom Smith and Rick Smith sold about 22 percent of their respective Taser holdings in the fourth quarter. Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% shares fell more than 6 percent after the company lowered its fourth-quarter outlook Tuesday, saying it now expects to post a loss of seven to 10 cents a share for the fourth quarter compared with a prior forecast of profit of 27 cents to 31 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 28 cents a share. Unisys said it expects revenues for the quarter to fall 7 percent to between $1.52 billion and $1.53 billion. title: Highlights of stocks moving Tuesday

content: Editor's note: Corrects typographical error in 14th paragraph. SAN DIEGO (CBS.MW) -- Taser's stock has been stunned in recent days by news the SEC was probing the safety of its products and a recent order from a distributor. In a letter to shareholders Tuesday morning, the company said the inquiry "may not be resolved quickly." While regulators are at it, they might as well see if the company is properly disclosing its relationship with customers. In late December, Minneapolis television station WCCO reported the Minneapolis police launched an internal investigation of its stun gun point man who was also paid by Taser TASR to train users outside of the department. The report included an on-camera interview with Deputy Chief Tom Dolan, who said the officer, Ron Bellendier, didn't have permission to work for Taser. He said Bellendier was the department's chief Taser trainer and was responsible for monitoring Taser use within the department. He was also believed to have influence over recommending how many guns should be purchased by the department. In response to my questions, a police department spokeswoman sent a copy of Bellendier's employment history, which shows he resigned on Christmas Day, three days after the report aired. One week later, the 16-year Minneapolis police veteran was hired by Taser as a regional manager in charge of the Midwest. Bellendier's dual role in charge of Taser training for the Minneapolis police department and as a Taser "master instructor," paid by Taser, is "sure cozy -- uncomfortably so," John Gavin of SEC Insight wrote Monday in a report to clients detailing the WCCO report. Like many local TV reports, the WCCO piece was ignored by other media; Gavin, who lives in Minneapolis, only heard about it after mentioning Taser to someone who had seen it. In its last annual 10-K filed with the SEC, Taser said that it had certified more than 11,500 "law enforcement training officers" as Taser instructors. Of those, 263 are certified by Taser as "master instructors" who train "other law enforcement and corrections agency trainers, not just end-users within these organizations." The company says master instructors are paid for each session they conduct. "These training sessions have led directly to the sale of Tasers to a number of police departments," according to the 10-K. Taser President Tom Smith told me the master instructors are paid a cash consulting fee and do their training when they're not on duty for their regular job -- much like police officer who moonlight as bouncers "at a local nightclub." Isn't it a conflict for an active police officer whose department uses Taser guns to also be employed by Taser? "That's between the officer and that department," Smith says. A department spokeswoman says the investigation ended when Bellendier left the department because there can be no outcome for a non-employee. However, sources say the department is continuing to look deeper into whether Bellendier, who had a flexible schedule, did work for Taser while on the department's clock. A bigger question: In the law enforcement industry, was Bellendier the rule or the exception? Meanwhile, one of the knocks on Taser from Gradient Analytics was that the company recorded an unusually large sale to a distributor at the end of its fourth quarter. Such big end-of the-quarter shipments often suggests a company has stuffed its distribution channel by convincing customers to take more product than they really need to help boost revenues. Enter Tuesday's letter to shareholders: Taser said it may see "delays" in orders growth during the fist half of 2005 as customers "test and evaluate potential new entrants." Since when has competition ever been an issue? For what it's worth, stuffing also tends to steal sales from future quarters. Short Positions Pump and dump: Several weeks ago a self-proclaimed investment newsletter editor jumped on the Novastar NFI, +0.90% bandwagon with a lengthy report extolling the virtues of the subprime mortgage lender. A good portion of the report was spent trying to discredit yours truly, but the bottom line was that Novastar is a good investment. (Sounded like a recommendation, which was borne out by the fine print: The newsletter editor owns a small Novastar stake.) Then came his second report over the weekend, with more Greenberg grousing and the likelihood that Novastar's stock is likely to soar in the wake of a short squeeze prompted by Regulation SHO, a new government regulation designed to crack down on illegal so-called naked shorting. Then, at the bottom of the report, the newsletter editor repeats that he owns a small position in Novastar but then quickly added he is "NOT recommending the issue." So he owns it but doesn't recommend it. Talk about mixed messages! Speaking of Regulation SHO: In recent days there has been tremendous buzz over possible short squeezes of stocks that are on the NYSE and Nasdaq threshold lists. This is a list of stocks where there appears to be more stock that has been sold short than there are shares. The list includes Novastar, Taser and Krispy Kreme KKD Now there's a solid reason to own stocks. Works until it doesn't. Taser, which rose 12 percent in the final days of last year, is down more 53 percent from its year-end highs. Krispy Kreme is down 23 percent over the same period but considerably more from all-time highs. Their swift declines should serve as a reminder of what can happen, Regulation SHO or no Regulation SHO, if it turns out the performances of puffed-up companies aren't all they're cracked up to be. Sign up for Herb Greenberg's Reality Check. Get an alert every time Herb's free column is published. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: Taser's cozy relationship with customers

content: Pre-Open stocks action U.S. stock futures were holding lower as declines for the chip-related stocks after a disappointing sales outlook from U.S. chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% pulled on market sentiment. The stock dropped 14 percent on the Archipelago ECN to to $17.25 on a volume of 261,000 shares by 8:15 a.m. Eastern. Rival Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% was down 1 percent; the semiconductor sector 'Holdr' stock SMH, +2.05% was down 1.8 percent. Elsewhere on the earnings front, Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% lowered its fourth quarter outlook and retailer Williams-Sonoma WSM, +1.77% lowered its outlook for fourth quarter revenue. See Indications for full pre-open coverage. Global Markets European benchmark indices were on the decline, reflecting the euro's 0.3 percent gain on the dollar. Tokyo's Nikkei ended at a six-month high overnight amid broad-based gains. Deutsche Bank upgraded Rockwell Automation ROK, -0.29% to 'buy' from 'hold' Tuesday as the maker of motors and controls forecast first-quarter earnings of 65 cents per share, well above the average analyst estimate of 48 cents per share Baird upgraded wireless carrier Alltel AT, -2.33% to "outperform" from "neutral", citing the prospects for greater growth from the pro forma wireless-centric entity and the increasing likelihood of a spin-off of the local business. The storage products maker said overnight it expects sales in the fiscal third quarter to rise at least 10 percent on the second quarter, ahead of its expectation. Restated results for 2001 and 2002 revealed by Nortel Networks NT indicated the troubled telecommunications equipment company posted a net loss of $25.7 billion in 2001 and $2.99 billion in 2002 on respective revenue of $18.9 billion and $11 billion. Taser International TASR disclosed in a letter to shareholders that Phil Smith, who retired as chairman on Dec. 31, sold most of the Taser stock he owned. In addition, co-founders Tom Smith and Rick Smith sold about 22 percent of their respective Taser share holdings in the fourth quarter. "We still retain a significant majority of our personal assets," Tom Smith and Rick Smith said in the letter. "Hence, we feel that the rumors about us 'bailing out' are not fair, nor accurate." Infineon said it's terminated its agreement with Finisar FNSR, +4.84% where the California company would've bought Infineon's fiber optics for 110 million shares valued at $206 million, due to delays related to the filing of the proxy statement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that pushed closing to no earlier than end of March 2005.
