title: AMD, Intel, Hewlett-Packard, Nortel and more

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) - U.S. stock futures were holding lower early Tuesday as declines for the chip-related stocks after a disappointing sales outlook from U.S. chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices pulled on market sentiment. A weak start to the December quarter earnings season also weighed. Dow industrials component Alcoa AA, +1.22% stumbled in overnight trade after posting a profits decline after the close Monday. AA shares were down 1.5 percent at $30.01. The Dow futures were down 26 points at 10,602 at 8 a.m. Eastern. The Nasdaq 100 futures were down 4 points at 1,564. The The Nasdaq 100s tracker QQQ, +1.83% was down 0.4 percent and the semiconductor sector 'Holdr' stock SMH, +2.05% was down 1.65 percent at $30.90 in the speculative pre-open. European benchmark indices were on the decline, reflecting the euro's 0.4 percent gain on the dollar. Yet Tokyo's Nikkei ended at a six-month high overnight amid broad-based gains. Chips view At least two broker downgrades surfaced for AMD AMD, +2.45% overnight after the chipmaker's update indicated sales in December-ending quarter are likely to miss growth expectations. The stock dropped over 12 percent in the pre-open at $17.60. Citing AMD's expectation for a quarter-on-quarter decline in its flash business, PiperJaffray said it suspected "difficult pricing from Intel is the primary culprit." Flash accounts for around 50 percent of sales for AMD and around 10 percent at Intel, the broker said. "As such, Intel can push the flash button and put a crimp in AMD's cash flow generation." The AMD view, as well as profit margin caution from European chipmaker STMicroelectronics STM, +0.63% overnight, weighed on the sector in Europe. German DRAM maker Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% and electronics group Philips PHG, +0.79% were each down over 1 percent. AMD rival Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% - whose quarterly update after the close is expected to set a more definitive tone for the tech sector - dropped 1.2 percent in the speculative early trade to $22.60. Focus stocks Nortel Networks NT rose 3.6 percent to $3.46 after detailing its revised 2001-03 losses. The telecoms equipment maker said its restatements are complete. Unisys Corp. UIS, +2.38% lowered its fourth quarter outlook Tuesday, saying it now expects to post a loss in the range of seven to ten cents a share in the fourth quarter compared with a prior forecast of a profit between 27 cents to 31 cents a share. The information technology services group said around 8 cents per share of its earnings shortfall was linked to its decision to recognize revenue from a contract on a month-to-month basis rather than in the entire fourth quarter. Retailer Williams-Sonoma WSM, +1.77% said reiterated its earnings outlook ranges for fourth quarter and 2004 earnings, but lowered its outlook for fourth quarter revenue after net sales in the 8 weeks to Dec. 26 rose 7.3 percent to $775.9 million. The growth was below its expectations, the retailer said. Taser International TASR disclosed that co-founders Tom Smith and Rick Smith sold about 22 percent of their respective Taser share holdings in the fourth quarter. "We still retain a significant majority of our personal assets," Tom Smith and Rick Smith said in the letter. "Hence, we feel that the rumors about us 'bailing out' are not fair, nor accurate." Shares dropped 4.5 percent to $19.15. Boeing Co. BA, +2.46% could come in focus. Peter Mandelson, the EU trade commissioner, plans to make a statement on the Airbus/Boeing state subsidies dispute at around 8:30 a.m. Eastern. Nokia NOK, +0.74% plans to cut a "few hundred" jobs in its multimedia business, mainly in research and development jobs in Germany and Finland as part of a broader plan to get R&D expenditure down to 9 percent-to-10 percent of sales by the end of 2006. See more Vivendi Universal Games V, +2.25% plans to cut 89 jobs in France, French newspaper Les Echos reported, according to AFX News. The move comes just six months after Vivendi's decision to cut around 350 jobs in the U.S. at its loss-making North American games unit and 29 in France, the report added. Infineon said it's terminated its agreement with Finisar FNSR, +4.84% where the California company would've bought Infineon's fiber optics for 110 million shares valued at $206 million, due to delays related to the filing of the proxy statement with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that pushed closing to no earlier than end of March 2005. Infineon said the significant delay and high uncertainty of closing are expected to result in deterioration of its Fiber Optics business and in potential harm to its customers, so Infineon is assessing legal options via an arbitration hearing in Germany. Buckeye Technologies BKI, +0.86% announced plans to shutter a cotton linter pulp plant in Glueckstadt, Germany in the fourth quarter of this year with the lose of 100 jobs. "We can no longer economically justify operating this high fixed cost facility which has seen its economic position deteriorate considerably from the large rise in the euro over the past two years," it said. Shares of QLogic Corp. QLGC, +0.12% rose 4.5 percent in pre-open trading at $35.29. The storage products maker said overnight it expects sales in the fiscal third quarter to rise at least 10 percent on the second quarter, ahead of its expectation. Genentech DNA, -1.03% overnight reported a 63 percent rise in fourth-quarter profit Monday and vowed 25 percent earnings growth for 2005, but its shares fell in after-hours trading as its financial results still fell short of analyst estimates. Broker calls Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% was downgraded to "underweight" from "equal weight" by Morgan Stanley as competition from Dell DELL in the company's largest profit pools and continued signs of supply chain inefficiencies increases the chance for near-term business execution missteps. Deutsche Bank upgraded Rockwell Automation ROK, -0.29% to 'buy' from 'hold' Tuesday as the maker of motors and controls forecast first-quarter earnings of 65 cents per share, well above the average analyst estimate of 48 cents per share Baird upgraded wireless carrier Alltel AT, -2.33% to "outperform" from "neutral", citing the prospects for greater growth from the pro forma wireless-centric entity and the increasing likelihood of a spin-off of the local business. On Monday Alltel announced an agreement to buy Western Wireless for roughly $39 per share. The broker also noted that Alltel could still be an attractive acquisition target. Merrill Lynch upgraded German bank HVB (802200) to "buy" from "neutral," saying it sees a "probability-weighted upside" in the company of around 30 percent. "If everything goes wonderfully right (which is unlikely), this could even be over 80 percent," the broker said. Merrill noted that after many years of restructuring, HVB is "getting close to the end of its problems" and that the new management team in Germany could greatly improve performance of this key business. Deutsche Bank upgraded insurer Swiss Re (001233237) to "buy" from "hold", saying it believes "the larger, global insurers and reinsurers are likely to outperform in 2005." The broker said that Swiss Re "has strong non-life earnings power, has delivered strong messages on its ability to manage the cycle, and should see a marked recovery in its life business this year." J.P. Morgan upgraded U.K. miner Rio Tinto RIO, +2.65% to "overweight" from "neutral," saying it expects earnings to grow to $3.7 billion in 2007, thanks mainly to volume growth rather than commodity prices. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: AMD downgrades, sales view weigh on tech stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said some orders may be delayed during the first half of 2005 as agencies test and evaluate potential new entrants. The stun gun maker said it was confident in the safety evaluations already performed, and believes it can maintain its market leadership through an expanded research and development team. The stock closed Monday down 12 percent at $20.05.
title: Taser's 2005 orders may be delayed due to testing

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr disclosed in a letter to shareholders that Phil Smith, who retired as chairman on Dec. 31, sold most of the Taser stock he owned. In addition, co-founders Tom Smith and Rick Smith sold about 22 percent of their respective Taser share holdings in the fourth quarter. "We still retain a significant majority of our personal assets," Tom Smith and Rick Smith said in the letter. "Hence, we feel that the rumors about us 'bailing out' are not fair, nor accurate." The stock closed Monday down 12 percent at $20.05 due to concerns over an informal probe into the company by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.
title: Taser discloses insider sales

content: Advancers American Pharmaceuticals Partners Inc. APPX shares soared more than 28 percent after the company and its majority owner American Bioscience Inc. said the Food and Drug Administration has approved their drug Abraxane for injectable suspension in metastatic breast cancer. See full story. Animas Corp. PUMP, +2.32% shares advanced more than 11 percent after the company increased its revenue outlook for the fourth quarter to about $19.5 million due to continued strong sales of its IR 1200 pump. The company also said it sees results before items for the December period in line with its previous outlook for between a breakeven performance and a profit of $1 million. The West Chester, Pa. maker of insulin infusion pumps also said it has received 510(k) clearance for the marketing of its IR 1250 pump from the Food and Drug Administration. Shares of Benthos, Inc BTHS climbed 5 percent in afternoon trading Monday after winning a $1 million order for its GeoPoint Seismic Hydrophones from an undisclosed buyer. A GeoPoint hydrophone is an underwater microphone used by geophysicists to locate oil and gas deposits beneath the ocean floor. Delivery of the hydrophones has already begun, the company said, and will continue into the second quarter of fiscal 2005. Blue Square-Israel BSI, +2.04% shares gained more than 6 percent after the company said it's in talks to acquire a 50 percent stake in Israel-based retail chain Hamachsam Hamerkazi Kfar Hashaashuim Ltd. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Captiva Software Corp. CPTV added almost 17 percent after the San Diego developer of input management applications lifted its financial outlook due to stronger than anticipated market demand. The company forecast pro forma earnings of 17 to 19 cents per share on revenue of between $19.8 million and $20.2 million for the fourth quarter. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 16 cents per share in the December period. Shares of CDI Corp. CDI, +0.00% surged more than 6 percent to after C.L. King upgraded the Philadelphia-based staffing and outsourcing software provider to "strong buy" from "neutral." The firm cited the fact its new management, which has been in place for about three years, has had a positive effect on the company, and valuation. Additionally, "a rebound in capital spending has had a noticeable and favorable effect on the company," the firm told clients. Shares of Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% gained more than 4 percent after the Warren, N.J., biopharmaceutical maker forecast earnings before items of 9 cents per share for the fourth quarter, in line with Wall Street's consensus estimate. The company sees earnings of 55 cents per share for fiscal 2005. Concord Communications CCRD, +6.75% shares jumped nearly 4 percent after the company said it's agreed to buy privately-held Aprisma Management Technologies from Gores Technology Group for $93 million in cash. Concord said the deal for Aprisma, which was profitable on revenue of $43 million in 2004, should be accretive in 2005. Concord separately said it expects to lose between four and five cents per share in the fourth quarter on revenue between $28.3 million and $28.9 million. dj Orthopedics DJO rose more than 13 percent after the company forecast revenue of about $68 million for the fourth quarter, and $256 million for the full year 2004. "Our domestic rehabilitation businesses had a strong year, growing at over five percent, which remains faster than market rates of growth," said Les Cross, president and CEO of the San Diego, Calif., medical device maker. "Additionally, our international segment delivered solid double-digit growth driven by our focus on expanding our direct selling strategy in key international markets and the launch of new products." The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $65.4 million in the December period, and $253.3 million for the full year. Dyax Corp. DYAX, +0.26% shares gained more than 9 percent after the company reported positive interim results from its Phase II clinical trial of DX-88, its treatment for hereditary angioedema, a rare inherited condition characterized by episodes of acute swelling of the extremities, the abdominal tract, the genitalia and the larynx. The Cambridge, Mass. company plans to launch a Phase III trial of DX-88 during the first half of 2005. It's developing the angioedema treatment in a joint venture with Genzyme Corp. GENZ Shares of Ennis Inc. EBF, -1.01% rose more than 3 percent after the company posted fiscal third-quarter earnings of $6.1 million, or 35 cents a share, on Friday, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $4.5 million, or 27 cents a share, last year. The maker of business documents and promotional products said sales were $91.8 million, up from $66.4 million a year ago. Fox Entertainment Group FOX, +2.45% shares surged more than 9 percent after News Corp NWS, +1.90% NWSA, +2.40% said it's offering 1.9 of its A-class shares for each of the remaining shares in the company which represents a 7.4 percent premium to the Jan. 7 close of Fox. News Corp. currently owns approximately 82.1 percent of the equity and 97.0 percent of the voting power of Fox. The move helps Rupert Murdoch consolidate his media empire. See full story. Genaera Corp. GENR shares surged more than 1 percent after the company reported positive results from a phase II clinical trial of squalamine for the treatment of choroidal neovascularization associated with age-related macular degeneration. The company said the trial demonstrated said all six patients in the trial had preserved or improved vision at week three, week five, and after two months. InfoUSA IUSA, +1.50% shares rose nearly 10 percent after the company said it expects to beat its earlier revenue and earnings outlook for 2004. In July, the business and consumer data-collection company forecast 2004 revenue of $335 million to $345 million and earnings of 28 cents to 32 cents a share. InfoUSA also said that it expects to meet or exceed analyst estimates for 2005. Two analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 66 cents a share on revenue of $398 million for 2005. Jones Apparel Group Inc. JNY shares gained more than 2 percent after the company was upgraded to "buy" from "neutral" at Banc of America Securities. In addition, analyst Robert Ohmes raised his target price to $44 from $38. The analyst told clients in a note the rating revision was due partly to the potential for greater rebounds in the company's moderate apparel, better apparel and footwear businesses in 2005. Hollywood Entertainment HLYW shares tacked on more than 6 percent after the Movie Gallery MOVI said it would buy the company for $13.25 a share in cash, which represents a 1.5 percent premium over Friday's closing price of $13.05. The bid also represents a 15 percent premium Blockbuster Inc's BBI, +4.00% bid for the company. See full story. Shares of Lexicon Genetics LEXG, +12.33% rose more than 4 percent after the company confirmed revenue forecasts for 2004 and 2005. The Woodlands, Tex-based drug maker said Friday after the close it expects full-year revenues "just shy" of $60 million for 2004 and of $73.7 million for 2005. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for 2004 revenue of $58.5 million and 2005 revenue of $73.7 million. Mac-Gray Corp TUC, +3.97% shares added more than 4 percent after the company said it bought the laundry facilities operations of privately-held Web Service Company in a $110 million all-cash deal. Cambridge, Mass.-based Mac-Gray said the deal would boost its annual revenue by $67 million and boost earnings within the first full quarter of operations. Monarch Casino & Resort Inc. MCRI, +0.52% shares jumped more than 12 percent after the Reno, Nev.-based resort operator said it expects to report record results for its fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Dec. 31. For the fourth quarter, net revenues are expected to be approximately $31 million versus $28.3 million during the same period a year earlier. Based on these preliminary results, the company expects its fourth-quarter earnings to be about 36 cents versus 19 cents per share for the same period a year earlier. For the calendar year ended Dec. 31, revenues are expected to be $129 million, compared to $116 million the previous year. Nabi Pharmaceuticals NABI shares rose more than 2 percent after the company reported encouraging results from its Phase I/II clinical trial of its Altastaph vaccine to treat adult in-hospital patients with persistent Staphylococcus aureus bloodstream infections. In the trial, patients given altastaph were discharged on average after nine days in hospital compared with an average of 14 days in the placebo group. U.S-listed shares of Nam Tai Electronics Inc NTE, +2.94% soared 9 percent in afternoon trading Monday, buoyed by fourth quarter sales which exceeded both company and analyst estimates. The Canadian maker of telecommunications and consumer electronic products saw quarterly sales jump around 40 percent to over $150 million, beating the top end of its forecast range of $135 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for sales of $131.6 million, based on two analyst reports. Nam Tai attributed its outperformance to strong sales of FPC sub-assemblies, CMOS sensor modules for mobile phones and liquid crystal display modules. The company releases its fourth quarter results after the market closes on February 4. Pilgrim's Pride Corp. PPC, -1.16% shares climbed nearly 11 percent after the company raised its earnings forecast for the first quarter to the range of 68 to 73 cents per share versus a previous forecast of 50 to 60 cents per share. The poultry producer said the revised guidance was due primarily to lower feed ingredient costs and stronger results in the company's prepared foods division than previously forecasted for the quarter. See full story. SupportSoft SPRT, -0.36% rose more than 11 percent after the company received an upgrade to "buy" from Smith Barney. Warnaco Group WRNC rose more than 2 percent after Banc of America initiated coverage of the company with a "buy" rating and a price target of $26. See full story. William Lyon Homes' WLS shares gained more than 9 percent after the company disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that, on Jan. 7, its CEO William Lyon acquired an additional 655,569 shares of its common stock, increasing his more than 50 percent stake in the company. Decliners American Retirement Corp. ACR, -3.60% shares sank more than 11 percent after the company said Monday that it will sell 4 million shares under an effective shelf registration statement. The company said it plans to use proceeds from the sale to repay debt, make acquisitions and expand and develop communities. Cosine Communications Inc. COSN shares sank more than 5 percent after Tut Systems TUTS said it agreed to purchased the company in a stock-for-stock deal worth about $24.1 million. The deal is expected to close by March 31. Tut also reaffirmed its fourth-quarter revenue forecast of $7 million and issued a fiscal 2004 revenue forecast of $25 million. Creative Computer Applications CAP, -33.33% shares fell nearly 11 percent after the company, a provider of clinical information Systems, said it has signed a letter of intent to merge with privately held StorCOMM. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Shares of Deckers Outdoor Corp. DECK, -0.22% lost more than 6 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after the company said expects to exceed the high end of its outlook for earnings of 47 to 51 cents per share on sales of between $55 million and $61 million for the fourth quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 51 cents per share in the period on revenue of $61.9 million. Shares of FLYi FLYI parent of low-fare carrier Independence Air, slipped nearly 11 percent after the company said Monday it is preparing company-wide staff cuts as part of its broader plan to sidestep bankruptcy. Company spokesman Rick DeLisi declined to say how many jobs would likely be eliminated. The move also comes as the airline plans to eliminate about 25 percent of its daily flights starting Feb. 1. Independence Air needs to make an $83 million aircraft lease payment by Jan. 15 to avoid defaulting, a move that could throw the company into bankruptcy. The Greenbrier Cos. GBX, +0.20% slipped almost 2 percent after the Lake Oswego, Ore., maker of railroad freight cars said fiscal first quarter ending Nov. 30 earnings rose to $5.4 million, or 35 cents a diluted share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 39 cents per share in the period. Shares of Intersections Inc. INTX, -6.32% slumped 15 percent after the company said in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission that an amended pricing agreement with Capital One COF, +1.64% is expected to reduce fourth-quarter earnings by a penny a share and also lower 2005 results. The provider of identity theft protection and credit management services believes an amended agreement to market new products and services will begin offsetting the lowered pricing agreement some time in 2005. Meanwhile, Analyst Brad Eichler at Stephens Inc. downgraded the company to "equal weight" from "overweight." Mobility Electronics MOBE shares tumbled more than 10 percent after the company said it expects to report fourth-quarter revenue of $20.6 million, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $23.3 million. The company said production of new products and programs began too late in the quarter to have a material impact on results. See full story. Novoste NOVT, +2.66% shares slumped nearly 12 percent after the company said that during a review of strategic alternatives it discovered that a change in ownership took place in September 2003. As a result, about two-thirds of its net operating loss carry-forwards will expire unused. RF Micro Devices' RFMD shares fell more than 3 percent after J.P. Morgan downgraded the maker of integrated circuits for wireless applications to "neutral" from "overweight" due to a lack of catalysts during the upcoming seasonally weak period for handsets. Taser International TASR shares lost another 11 percent of their value Monday, extending their prior session's losses on concern about an informal SEC probe of the company's safety statements and sales to a distributor. See full story. Torch Offshore Inc. TORC, -9.28% shares fell nearly 4 percent after the company said that it, along with certain affiliates, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to facilitate a restructuring of its debt. Additionally, Torch has received a commitment for $6.9 million in new debtor-in-possession financing from Regions Bank and Export Development Canada UAP Holding Corp. UAPH shares lost more than 2 percent after the company reported a fiscal third-quarter net loss of $30.9 million, or 65 cents a share, wider than the year-earlier loss of $18.5 million. Excluding items, the loss was 55 cents a share. Revenue fell 9.1 percent to $267.2 million from $293.8 million as lower sales of cotton defoliation products led to a decline in crop protection chemical sales. Ultimate Electronics, Inc. ULTEE shares gave up more 9 percent after the company said same-store sales in December dropped 18 percent; total sales also dropped 18 percent to $85.7 million from the prior year period. November sales dropped 8 percent to $69.2 million. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: HIghlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares lost another 8 percent of their value Monday, extending their prior session's losses on concern about an informal SEC probe of the company's safety statements and sales to a distributor. The share lost as much as 23 percent Friday before closing down about 18 percent. Shares were last trading at $20.92, down $1.85, or 8.1 percent.
title: Taser extends losses on concerns about SEC probe

content: Shares of Volterra Semiconductor Corp. VLTR could be on the move Monday. Late Friday, the company said it's in discussions with the underwriters of its initial public offering regarding the potential early release of about 18 million shares of its common stock from lock-up. Volterra expects the lock-up restriction, which is currently scheduled to expire on Jan. 24, to now expire after the market closes on Jan. 14. Novoste Corp. NOVT, +2.66% saw its shares fall 14 percent in after-hours trading Friday. The company said that during a review of strategic alternatives it discovered that a change in ownership took place in September 2003. As a result, about two-thirds of its net operating loss carryforwards will expire unused. The company said its future use of carryforwards is limited to $1.8 million a year, with a total of about $36 million. Novoste, which sells vascular brachytherapy products, said the ownership change had no impact on its net income or loss per share for the fiscal year 2003 or for the third quarter in 2004. Also after Friday's bell, Tut Systems TUTS said Friday it agreed to purchased Cosine Communications Inc. COSN in a stock-for-stock deal worth about $24.1 million. The deal is expected to close by March 31. Tut also reaffirmed its fourth-quarter revenue forecast of $7 million and issued a fiscal 2004 revenue forecast of $25 million. InfoUSA IUSA, +1.50% said it expects to beat its earlier revenue and earnings outlook for 2004. In July, the business and consumer data-collection company forecast 2004 revenue of $335 million to $345 million and earnings of 28 cents to 32 cents a share. InfoUSA also said that it expects to meet or exceed analyst estimates for 2005. Two analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 66 cents a share on revenue of $398 million for 2005. Torch Offshore Inc. TORC, -9.28% said that it, along with certain affiliates, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to facilitate a restructuring of its debt. Additionally, Torch has received a commitment for $6.9 million in new debtor-in-possession financing from Regions Bank and Export Development Canada. The banks have also agreed to provide a discretionary facility of up to $2 million for bonding and letters of credit, the company said. Omnicare Inc. OCR, +0.00% said that it has extended its tender offer for all of outstanding NeighborCare Inc. NCRX common stock, for $30 a share in cash. The offer, which had been scheduled to expire today, has been extended until Feb. 4. American Pharmaceuticals Partners Inc. APPX and American Bioscience Inc. said the Food and Drug Administration has approved their drug Abraxane for injectable suspension in metastatic breast cancer. The approval marks a new class of "protein-bound particle" drugs, the companies said. Adolph Coors Co. RKY said that fourth-quarter U.S. sales volume to wholesalers rose 4.2 percent. It said wholesaler sales to retail increased 0.8 percent. The company said for 2004, U.S. sales volume to retail fell 0.8 percent, with sales to retail decreasing 0.2 percent compared with 2003. Coors said it issued the fourth-quarter sales figures in response to reports that U.S. beer sales industrywide declined for the final three months of the year. Eaton Corp. ETN, +1.09% said it won legal proceedings against ZF Friedrichshafen AG, Arvin Meritor Inc. ARM, +3.57% and ZF Meritor. The judge said that automated truck transmissions manufactured and marketed by the three companies infringed an Eaton patent and are unlawfully being imported into the United States, according to Eaton. American Capital Strategies Inc. ACAS said it's invested $30 million in Rocky Shoes and Boots Inc. RCKY, +6.19% to support its purchase of EJ Footwear. American Capital said its investment is in the form of a senior-term B loan Vornado Realty Trust VNO, -0.33% said Friday that it's been repaid $275 million of loans secured by partnership interests in the General Motors Building, located in Chicago. Vornado said it also received a prepayment penalty of $4.5 million and $1.2 million of unamortized fees, which will be included in income in the first quarter. New Century Financial Corp. NEW, +0.00% said late Friday that its December loan production rose 43 percent over the same period last year. For the year, production increased 54 percent. Callaway Golf ELY, +0.62% will buy four U.S. patents from Perfect Putter, resolving a patent dispute over certain putter designs. The lawsuit will subsequently be dismissed by the parties with no admission of any wrongdoing, Callaway said. It was filed in November 2002 by Perfect Putter and its owners. Ennis Inc. EBF, -1.01% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $6.1 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $4.5 million, or 27 cents a share, last year. The maker of business documents and promotional products said sales were $91.8 million, up from $66.4 million a year ago. MicroStrategy Inc. MSTR, +1.01% said it won a lawsuit against Business Objects BOBJ that had alleged MicroStrategy infringed on Business Objects' patent concerning a relational database access system employing what were termed "semantically dynamic objects." Friday's advancers Accenture Ltd. ACN, +4.13% shares rose more than 4 percent after the company said late Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 13 percent from a year ago to $196 million, or 32 cents a share, a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. See full story. Albany Molecular Research AMRI shares added more than 3 percent after the company inked a two-year agreement with Alcon Research to develop opthalmic drugs. Blyth Inc.'s BTH, +1.01% ) stock jumped more than 10 percent in Friday trading after the company raised its fiscal 2005 earnings estimate to $2.13 to $2.18 a share. Its previous outlook was for earnings of $2.05 to $2.15 a share, while the Thomson First Call-derived estimate was for earnings of $2.07 a share. The Greenwich, Conn.-based direct marketer said the earnings revision was based on strong results from it European operations. Cavco Industries Inc. CVCO, +1.40% shares rose more than 3 percent after the company authorized a two-for-one stock split in the form of a dividend payable on Jan. 31 to shareholders as of Jan. 18. Collins & Aikman CKC shares added more than 6 percent in afternoon action. In an SEC filing after Thursday's closing bell, the company disclosed stock purchases by David Stockman, its chairman and CEO, and certain funds controlled by Heartland Industrial Associates, of which Stockman is the managing partner. The company said Stockman purchased 7,500 shares with his own funds and that the Heartland funds purchased 70,000 shares. Constellation Brands Inc. STZ, +3.37% shares added nearly 6 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings rose 17 percent to $96.9 million, or 83 cents a share. See full story. Darden Restaurants DRI, +1.03% shares jumped nearly 4 percent after the company said December same-restaurant sales at its Olive Garden and Red Lobster chains were up 14 percent. DoubleClick DCLK shares climbed more than 8 percent after the company said results for its fourth quarter and the year would outpace prior expectations on stronger-than-expected performance. Shares of ID Biomedical Corp. IDBE rose more than 6 percent after the Vancouver-based company said it has received clearance for its investigational new drug application to begin immediate clinical testing of its Fluviral influenza vaccine in the United States from the Food and Drug Administration. The company (IDB) plans to ship product to the United States and begin enrolling patients by the end of the month. Shares of Isco International Inc. ISO, +6.94% gained more than 22 percent after the Elk Grove Village, Ill., maker of radio-frequency processing chips named John Thode president and CEO. Thode most recently served as a vice president with Motorola, where he worked for 25 years. Isco also said it expects revenue of $650,000 for the fourth quarter, and that it has purchase orders worth more than $2.5 million scheduled for shipment in the first quarter. Shares of Lazare Kaplan LKI climbed nearly 5 percent after the diamond retailer reported an 11 times increase in its second-quarter earnings. Lazare posted net income of $1.1 million, or 12 cents per share, up from $110,000, or a penny per share, last year. The company's results are not tracked by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net sales rose 78 percent to $93 million. Lesco Inc. LSCO shares jumped nearly 6 percent after the company said it expects a loss of 42 to 48 cents a share on revenue ranging from $560 million to $563 million for 2004. On a pro forma basis, it expects earnings of 50 to 53 cents a share, up from the previous estimate of 40 to 50 cents a share. Lightpath Technologies LPTH, +2.33% shares advanced more than 3 percent after the company said it expects sales of roughly $3.3 million for the second quarter, a 75 increase from its year-ago equivalent total of $1.9 million. The company said its sales backlog was "reduced somewhat" in the quarter to about $3 million as of Dec. 31 due to the holiday season and weakness in communication market orders. Shares of NMT Medical Inc. NMTI added more than 16 percent after the Boston-based company said it's started enrolling patients in Europe in a clinical study of its MIST system for the treatment of migraine headaches. The company said the study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of its proprietary STARFlex implant technology. NMY also noted that the recruitment has progressed "more quickly than originally anticipated" so it expects enrollment to be completed in the third quarter, one quarter ahead of schedule. It expects to begin a U.S. migraine study in the second half of the year. Parlux Fragrances Inc. PARL shares gained more than 8 percent after the company said Friday that it has purchased the exclusive worldwide marketing and licensing rights for the XOXO fragrance brand from Victory International. The XOXO fragrances will launch during the February Valentine's Day weekend at U.S. department stores. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. RF Industries Ltd. RFIL, +4.55% shares surged nearly 10 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter net income rose 45 percent to $437,000, or 12 cents a diluted share, from $301,000, or nine cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter, which ended Oct. 31, increased 10 percent to $3.3 million from $3.04 million. ScanSource Inc. SCSC, +0.28% shares climbed more than 7 percent after the company said it expects sales of $363 million to $371 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31, up from its year-ago equivalent total of $289 million. Shaw Group Inc. SGR, +0.00% shares surged nearly 7 percent after the company reported first-quarter net income of $10 million, or 16 cents a diluted share, versus last year's net loss of $49.6 million, or $1.07 a share. The company recorded income from continuing operations of $10.8 million, or 17 cents a share, against the Thomson First Call-derived estimate for earnings of 14 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter expanded 28 percent to $828.1 million from $646.9 million in the prior-year period. Higher sales and lower costs were responsible for the improved results, the company said. Shire Pharmaceuticals SHPGY (SHP) shares gained more than 5 percent after the U.K. company was upgraded to "overweight" by J.P. Morgan Chase. SimpleTech STEC, +2.14% shares rose more than 13 percent after the Santa Ana, Calif., memory company forecast earnings of 6 cents per share for the fourth quarter on revenue of between $77 million and $77.5 million, a projection that matches its prior indications. This profit view is in line with Wall Street's current consensus estimate, and the revenue projection exceeds the average analysts' outlook of $74.6 million. SYS Technologies SYS, -2.30% shares added nearly 5 percent after the company said it paid $2.6 million in cash and stock for privately held Antin Engineering of San Diego. Revenue for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2004 were $4 million with a current annual run rate of $7 million, SYS said. Talx Corp. TALX shares rose nearly 13 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings "comfortably" above its previous forecast of 26 cents to 28 cents a share. It also said it expects revenue slightly above its forecast of $37 million to $39 million. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% shares added nearly 4 percent after the company said it expects net earnings to grow 10 to 12 percent in 2005. The jewelry retailer also reaffirmed its full-year 2004 earnings forecasts after posting December same-store sales growth of 6 percent from the year-earlier period. The company said it's on track to achieve its previous forecast for 2004 earnings of $1.43 to $1.48 a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for 2004 earnings of $1.44 a share. Shares of Tripath Technology Inc. TRPH soared more than 15 percent after the company said its TCD6001 and TPS4100 digital amplifier products would be used in Panasonic's automotive in-dash audio head unit systems. The rally builds on a surge during Thursday's session after the company inked a deal for the use of its products in liquid crystal display televisions made by Sharp. The stock rose 38 cents, or 23.5 percent, to $2 in afternoon trades, a gain of roughly 70 percent from Wednesday's close at $1.33 Vastera VAST, +1.61% shares soared 50 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% for $129 million, or $3 a share. in cash. The consideration values shares of Vastera, whose technology automates trading processes, at a 50 percent premium to Thursday's close. See full story. Video Display Corp. VIDE, -6.67% shares leapt more than 7 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings of 10 to 11 cents a share with revenue coming in more than 15 percent above its year-ago total of $18.1 million. The current average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $21 million WD-40 Co. WDFC, -0.04% shares gained more than 4 percent after the company said first-quarter net income rose 28.4 percent to $5.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from $4.4 million, or 26 cents a share, a year ago. Sales for the quarter were $60.7 million vs. $52.5 million a year earlier. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting first-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share, on average. The company, whose main product is its namesake all-purpose lubricant, also said it still expects its 2005 net income to increase 5.5 percent to $27 million, or $1.62 a share. Westaff Inc. WSTF shares skyrocketed more than 31 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 15 cents a share. Last year, it lost $600,000, or 4 cents a share. Revenue was $205.6 million, up from $178.9 million. Shares of WSI Industries WSCI, +1.03% gained more than 17 percent after the Minneapolis maker of high-precision avionics and aerospace products posted first-quarter earnings of $26,000, or a penny per share, down from its year-ago profit of $56,000, or 2 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company. Sales jumped 38 percent in the latest three months to $3.9 million from $2.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said the latest results include $168,000 in relocation and facility operation costs. Zi Corp. ZICA shares rose more than 7 percent after the software company said it named Richard Tingle to its board, effective immediately. Tingle, who is a senior partner at Tingle Merrett, replaces Rod Love. Friday's decliners Shares of Bright Horizons Family Solutions BFAM, +2.08% lost nearly 6 percent after SunTrust Robinson Humphrey downgraded the childcare center operator to "reduce" from "neutral." Brocade Communications Systems' BRCD shares fell more than 7 percent after the company said plans to restate its financial statements for fiscal years 2002 and 2003, in order to record additional stock-based compensation expense as a result of an internal review. The company also said it plans to delay the filing of its fiscal 2004 Form 10-K that is due on Jan. 13. See full story. Depomed Inc. DEPO, +0.00% shares slumped more than 11 percent after the company said it's agreed to sell up to 5 million common shares for $4.50 each to institutional investors. The Menlo Park, Calif., pharmaceutical company anticipates gross proceeds of roughly $22.7 million from the sale. Electronics Boutique Holdings Corp. ELBO shares skidded more than 3 percent after the company's January quarter earnings per share estimate was cut by Piper Jaffray to $1.55 a share from its prior projection for earnings at $1.72 a share. "Holiday video game sales are expected to fall short of expectations," the broker told clients. FormFactor Inc. FORM, +1.11% shares slid nearly 4 percent after the company said it now expects to report revenue of $46.1 million, down from its previous forecast of $50 million to $53 million. See full story. Game Stop Corp. GME, -10.81% shares sank more than 7 percent after the company lowered its fourth-quarter earnings forecast, citing hardware supply shortages. Schering SHR, +0.18% stock fell more than 5 percent as the German drug firm said it had received an "approvable" letter from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration calling for more data on the company's breast cancer drug Bonefos. Analysts said that the impact of the anti-cancer drug's delayed marketing on Schering's stock depends on the kind of data the FDA is requesting. Schering could likely not produce more clinical data supporting the drug before 2007, which would be disastrous for the company, they said. Taser International TASR shares sank more than 17 percent after the stun gun maker said it's the subject of an informal probe by the Securities and Exchange Commission. See full story. Shares of TiVo Inc. TIVO, +0.37% were off almost 14 percent in afternoon action. The move follows news that DirecTV Group DTV, +0.36% plans to begin offering its own branded digital video recorder to its subscribers later this year. DirecTV shares rose almost 2 percent to $16.28. See full story. UTStarcom Inc. UTSI, +2.71% shares plunged more than 19 percent after the company said problems with its China operations hurt its fourth-quarter results. See full story. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Novoste, InfoUSA, Volterra, Cosine, Coors and more

content: The new year began this week and ... ahem, did you hear that, Nasdaq? 2005 has begun. Please, someone, alert the Nasdaq. Whether investors were, as the cliché has it, taking 2004's profits or were anxious about market prospects, and whether they subscribe to the belief that a year's opening days hold disproportionate significance or they don't, the week was a challenging one for stock investors. The charitably somnambulant Nasdaq dropped five straight decisions, and the big-time Dow industrials did just slightly better, rising only Thursday. In aggregate, though, it could've been worse. The Nasdaq COMP, +1.64% paced an across-the-board retrenchment, slumping 4 percent from New Year's Eve through this Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, +1.38% forfeited 2.1 percent and the Dow INDU, -0.10% slipped 1.6 percent. It was, however, a good week for the U.S. dollar, which closed Friday at a six-week high against the rival euro. See full story. Stay tuned to MarketWatch this weekend. Our weekly television show on CBS stations includes a look at the latest gadgets being unveiled at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. Also: Learn about MGM Mirage's efforts to diversify, and find out what gives in the latest round of airfare jockeying. Our online cover story examines which companies are stepping up to aid disaster victims on the Indian Ocean's rim. Tim Rostan, assistant managing editor Doughnut maker digs a deeper hole Shares of Krispy Kreme Doughnuts KKD had a sticky time of it after the company faced embarrassing allegations about faked orders in a legal filing said it would restate its results for fiscal 2004 to reflect errors related to its acquisitions of certain former franchise locations. See full story and commentary by Herb Greenberg. Apple speculation, enthusiasm equally high The annual game of Guess What Apple's Bringing to Macworld is in full swing ahead of Chief Executive Steve Jobs' AAPL, +0.78% keynote address to a crowd of thousands at the conference next week. See full story. Lucent offspring Avaya growing up Life isn't quite so tough anymore for 4-year-old Avaya. The Lucent LU spinoff back in the black. Sales of its Net-phone-oriented products are rising. And its stock AV., -0.38% is showing more than a little appreciation. So what's it been doing right? See full story. Tokyo banking team-up and you Non-Japanese investors can be forgiven for thinking the latest mega-bank-merger saga enfolding there doesn't concern them. In the short term, they're right. But Detroit's automakers were similarly complacent just a few decades ago. See full story. Taser investors jolted Taser International's extraordinarily volatile and headline-grabbing stock TASR slumped as much as 23 percent at one point in Friday trading, following the company's disclosure that it's cooperating with an informal U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its safety statements and its recent sales to a distributor. See full story. Asbestos plagues insurer's financials Insurance giant Ace Ltd. ACE, +3.23% said late Wednesday that it would take an after-tax charge of $298 million, or $1.05 per share, in its fourth fiscal quarter to bolster its asbestos, environmental and related financial reserves. See full story. Retail's escalator pulls both ways As more data are sorted, retail chains' holiday sales are indeed looking like the proverbial mixed bag. J.C. Penney and American Eagle were as eager to boast of their monthly receipts as the likes of Cost Plus and Pier 1 were to put the month of December and its disappointing results behind them. The industry behemoth Wal-Mart, meanwhile, said the week after Christmas had salvaged its month. See full story. Delta drowns out sector rivals So attention-grabbing was Delta's DAL, +1.63% announcement of a radically new fare structure that it cast into darkest shadows even the world's No. 1 carrier AMR, -4.53% AMR's Wednesday news that traffic increased more than 6 percent in December. See full story. President stumps against 'tilted' medical liability law You'd think it would take some masterful politicking to arrange an open-arms welcome for an elected official who, with his allies, had labeled the destination a hellhole. And perhaps that's just what we witnessed this week as, in a speech in Illinois' Madison County, across the Mississippi from St. Louis, President Bush implored Congress to pass legislation that would put a cap of $250,000 on noneconomic damages in medical malpractice cases, charging that "frivolous lawsuits" were driving good doctors from their practices, leaving patients to scramble for adequate health care and pushing up medical costs for all Americans. See full story. Tuition inflation stirs Congress With college costs running as high as $40,000 a year, House and Senate education committees have put tuition control on their to-do lists. Or perhaps they've thumb-typed them into their BlackBerry devices, to-do lists as such being well past passé around the quadrangle. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock
title: The week's top news and analysis, Jan. 3-7

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of directories company DAG Media jumped in evening trading Friday after it said it wanted to sell its classified directories business, while Taser International rebounded from earlier losses that stemmed from word regulators were investigating the stun gun maker. The Nasdaq 100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks the evening trading of the technology heavy index's leading shares, rose 2.02 points to 1,566.83. DAG Media DAGM rose 19 percent to $4.15 after it said it was looking to sell its classified directories business, which includes the Jewish Israeli Yellow Pages and the Master or Kosher Guide. It said the complexity and margins of the business make compliance with new regulatory requirements prohibitive. The company also declared a 10-cent dividend to shareholders of record on March 21, June 20, Sept. 20 and Dec. 20. The dividend will pay on April 5, July 5, Oct. 5, and Jan. 5, respectively. DAG Media also said it would seek to buy a new business that would be bigger and potentially more profitable. It gave no details. See full story. Electric stun gun maker Taser International TASR rose 1.4 percent to $23.03, partly reversing deep regular session losses that were triggered by the company's announcement it was cooperating in an informal Securities and Exchange Commission probe into its safety statements and its recent sales to a distributor. See full story. Drugmaker Biopure BPUR rose 1 cent to 62 cents in the evening session after rising 7.2 percent in the regular session. The stock was active ahead of the closing of its offering to sell 22 million shares of its stock to raise capital. Most of the rest of the action after the bell was in technology bellwethers like Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% Microsoft Corp. MSFT, +2.10% and Oracle Corp. ORCL, +1.71% which often trade heavily after hours because they have such a wide base of shareholders. Earlier, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 18.92 points to close at 10,603.96, while the Nasdaq Composite Index finished the day 1.39 points lower at 2,088.61. See full story. title: DAG Media jumps after hours on directories sale plan

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of two companies preparing to launch products to rival Taser International's electric "stun guns" rallied Friday, after Taser said the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission had launched an informal probe of its safety statements and sales to a distributor. Neither Taser rival trades on a major U.S. exchange. Bulletin Board-traded shares of Law Enforcement Associates LENF rallied as much as 52 percent before settling back to close at $7.72, up more than 34 percent. Volume was heavy at 4.6 million shares traded, about 16 times the stock's average full-day volume. Stinger Systems STIY which trades on the pink sheets and is therefore not subject to reporting requirements, rose 16 percent in volume of 358,000 shares traded, or about five times its average daily turnover. Taser, meanwhile, fell almost 18 percent to $22.72. Investors jarred Law Enforcement Associates and Stinger Systems surged after Taser disclosed the informal regulatory inquiry of its weapon, which is widely used by U.S. law-enforcement agencies and the military. Questions about the weapon's safety -- and studies used to support safety claims -- were raised last fall, when The New York Times reported that a U.S. Air Force laboratory study had concluded the weapons could be dangerous, and in November, after police in Florida used the device on children. Taser TASR had claimed tests showed the weapon was safe to use even against children. The company has consistently defended its weapon, which is designed to shoot a bolt of temporarily disabling electricity into a person to enable law-enforcement officials to subdue them. See full story. Law Enforcement Associates, based in Youngsville, N.C., is preparing to launch a rival less-lethal weapon in March, according to the company's president, Paul Feldman. Feldman said the new LEA gun has demonstrated greater capacities for distance and accuracy than Taser's gun. "It will be significantly less expensive than other products, so it'll be really competitive," he said. LEA specializes in video and surveillance eq uipment for law-enforcement agencies and has annual sales of about $6 million. The company decided to expand into the less-lethal-weapon market after purchasing patents from James McNulty, former vice president of operations and engineering at Tasertron, acquired by Taser in 2002. Charlotte, N.C.-based Stinger Systems, which also purchased patents from McNulty, is preparing to release its own less-lethal weapon, called Stinger 4 Dart, in the next 30 days. Chief Executive Robert Gruder said early marketing has generated strong interest from the law-enforcement community. Morgan Keegan analyst Brian Ruttenbur is expecting the weapon to offer serious competition to Laser's stun gun, he said. The Stinger uses four darts, while the Taser weapon uses just two. "When you shoot with the Taser, you have to have both probes go in to create the shock effect," Ruttenbur told CBS MarketWatch. "With Stinger, you only need two of the four probes to go in -- and it's selling at $600 a unit against the $1,000 Taser charges for its gun." Hear more from Ruttenbur. Addressing concerns CEO Gruder said the Stinger is also equipped with a video camera, with four-hour recording capability, for day or night use. "It's very important for accountability with the police and also organizations like Amnesty International," he said. Amnesty has been critical of the findings of some of the safety studies carried out on Taser's weapons. The Stinger has attracted a great deal of criticism from one quarter: Taser International. In December, Taser filed a lawsuit against Stinger Systems, accusing it of false advertising and unlawful patent marking. Among the long list of allegations in the suit, Taser claims that Stinger Systems' new device is not even at the prototype stage and that videos on its Web site demonstrating its use are faked. Gruder rejected all the charges in a press release issued Tuesday. "They're basically calling all the law-enforcement officers who've tested our gun a bunch of liars, which is incredible," he said. Stinger is planning to vigorously defend itself and is mulling a countersuit, he said. Stinger Systems was created in September with the acquisition of Electronic Defense Systems and its merger into a shell company, Gruder said. On Jan. 1, the company announced a $10 million private placement, with two institutional investors. Those investors received warrants for a further $7.5 million worth of stock. The CEO was unable to provide any details of the company's financials ahead of a filing with the SEC due next week. title: Taser rivals rally on news of SEC probe

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - U.S. stocks ended lower Friday as the market kicked off 2005 with a weekly loss on fears a solid December employment report and Federal Reserve concerns about inflation may lead to a pick-up in the pace of future interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% ended down 18.92 points, at 10,603.96, notching up a weekly decline of 1.6 percent. Within the blue-chip benchmark, Alcoa Inc. AA, +1.22% climbed 1 percent as investors bought into the stock ahead of its fourth-quarter earnings report due out on Monday. Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% scheduled to report quarterly results next Tuesday, gained 1.5 percent. The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ drifted lower into the close, to end down 1.39 points, at 2,088.61. The tech-rich index tumbled nearly 4 percent on the week. Strength in semiconductor SOX, +2.24% and Internet stocks $GIN helped put a floor underneath the Nasdaq. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% dipped 1.70 points, to 1,186.19. The broad gauge fell 2.1 percent on the week. Historical trends offer investors little in the way of guidance as to the future behavior of a market which kicks off a year on a down note, as this one did. Of the 20 down First Five Days since 1950, 10 were followed by full-year gains and 10 by full-year losses, according to the Stock Trader's Almanac. And in six of the last 13 post-election years, full-year losses averaged 11.1 percent. Friday's employment report left investors pondering the pace and size of U.S. interest rate hikes. "The problem is that we're getting job growth that is good, but not great," said Peter Boockvar, equity strategist at Miller Tabak. "But it's good enough to continue inflation pressures building and the Fed still raising interest rates." He added: "There was some hope with the rally this morning that maybe we would bounce from the weakness this week, but the lack of any follow-through scared the bulls and brought out immediate selling." Other market strategists took a more positive view of the employment data. "Today's jobs report, when you look at all the moving parts, was pretty much in line with expectations, "said Michael Sheldon, chief market strategist at Spencer Clarke. 'Should be supportive' "If anything, it should be mildly supportive for the stock market because it takes some of the pressure off the [Federal Reserve] to raise rates aggressively over the next three to six months," Sheldon said. However, a combination of end-of-week profit taking and a little bit of uncertainty caused by the Fed's rising concern about inflation "put a bit of a dampener on things," Sheldon added. U.S. nonfarm payrolls grew by a seasonally adjusted 157,000 in December, while the unemployment rate held steady at 5.4 percent, the Labor Department said. The average estimate of economists polled by CBS MarketWatch had been for a gain of 178,000 new jobs, but revisions to previous months put the December data near this mark. See full story. Bonds, dollar, gold, oil Meanwhile, benchmark U.S. Treasury notes ended little changed after the jobs data, which did little to alter expectations for a continued pace of modest rate increases engineered by the Fed, analysts said. The price of the 10-year Treasury note ended down 2/32 at 99 26/32. In the currencies market, the dollar reversed course against the euro and pared losses against the Japanese yen in mid-morning trading. The greenback's move higher was initiated in part by a repeat of a strong-dollar preference by U.S. Treasury Secretary John Snow and the triggering of sell orders that waited at the six-week euro-dollar lows reached earlier this week, traders said. See currency report Gold ended lower to log a one-week loss of over 4 percent with metals traders' assessment of the jobs report leaning toward the likelihood of near-term gains in the dollar. Strength in the greenback lowers the attractiveness of the precious metal as an investment. February gold closed at $419.50 an ounce, down $2.10 for the session, and down $18.90 for the week. In energy futures, the February crude-oil contract briefly topped $46 a barrel amid growing signs that key oil producers are prepared to stave off any steep prices declines by trimming output even further. Crude for February delivery ended down 13 cents at $45.43, but up almost $2 for the week. See full story. Turning back to the broader market for equities, there were 18 decliners for every 13 advancers on the New York Stock Exchange, whiles losers outpaced winners by an 18 to 11 score on the Nasdaq. Volume was around 1.5 billion for the Big Board, and 2.2 billion on the Nasdaq. Stocks in focus Taser International Inc. TASR whose electric "stun" guns have come under mounting criticism in recent months, said early Friday that it's cooperating in an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its safety statements and sales to a distributor. The inquiry was disclosed by the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of the weapon, which enjoys wide use by U.S. law-enforcement agencies. Taser shares tumbled more than 18 percent. See full story. Also in the news, Sprint Corp. FON, +5.56% and Virgin Group are considering selling a stake in their U.S. wireless joint venture, Virgin Mobile USA, via an initial public offering, according to a Wall Street Journal report. Shares of Sprint, which recently announced plans to merge with Nextel Communications NXTL ended down 0.9 percent, at $24.30. Broker action First Albany overnight raised its earnings estimate for Apple Computer Inc. AAPL, +0.78% for the fiscal first quarter ended in December to 50 cents a share from its prior projection of 47 cents. Apple is expected to issue an update on its prospects for the quarter next Wednesday and has steered analysts toward earnings from 39 cents to 42 cents a share. "Expectations are running high, as we think investors may be anticipating 4.5-5.0 million iPods and at least 50 cents earnings per share. Nevertheless, we expect consensus estimates for FY05 to take another step function upward, which should enable further appreciation," the broker told clients. Apple's shares soared 7.3 percent, climbing to $69.25. In other broker action, Morgan Stanley upgraded ratings on FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26% and United Parcel Service UPS, +1.93% to "overweight" from "equal weight," as the brokerage rebalanced its portfolio of transportation stocks. UPS shares climbed as high $84.88, before paring gains to trade down 0.2 percent, at $83.50. FedEx shares followed a similar pattern, climbing to an intraday high of $97.49, before falling back to trade down 0.3 percent at $94.91. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: U.S. stocks end lower; open the year with weekly loss

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International shares slumped as much as 23 percent at one point in Friday trading, following the company's disclosure that it's cooperating with an informal U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into its safety statements and its recent sales to a distributor. Shares of Taser TASR which makes electric stun guns, closed down $4.90, or 17.7 percent, to $22.72, having earlier touched a low of $21.29. Almost 36 million shares changed hands, more than twice the company's average daily turnover. The inquiry was disclosed late Thursday by the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of the devices, which are widely used by U.S. law enforcement and military agencies. Morgan Keegan Equity Research told clients in a note that it's concerned about the probe, although it's sticking with a "market perform" rating on the stock. "We are certain that the company will share all safety studies that are currently available," said analyst Brian Ruttenbur. "However, the available data has been determined, for example by Amnesty International, to be insufficient to make a conclusive decision on the product safety in all circumstances including children, (the) elderly, and individuals with specific health conditions." Questions about the weapon's safety -- and studies used to support safety claims -- were raised last fall, when the New York Times reported that a U.S. Air Force laboratory study concluded the weapons could be dangerous, and in November, after police in Florida used the device on children. On Nov. 30, Amnesty International called for a nationwide ban on the use of Taser devices until more independent testing proved the safety of the weapons. The company's primary weapon is designed to deliver a bolt of temporarily disabling electricity into a person, allowing law enforcement officers or soldiers to subdue him. "Our public statements about the safety of Taser devices are consistent with those of medical experts we have consulted, or in the case of the Department of Defense, were reviewed and approved prior to release by the very agencies that have commissioned the research," said Taser CEO Rick Smith in a press release. Taser has claimed tests showed the weapon was safe to use on children. Taser's expansion into a consumer version of its devices has also served to heighten safety concerns. The company said the SEC was looking into a recent order received from distributor Davidson's Inc. for 1,000 consumer stun guns. The order, which Taser said was for less than $1 million, was disclosed by the company on Dec. 20, just 11 days before the end of its fiscal fourth quarter. "The Davidson order was entered into very late in the month, and Taser does make safety claims about its guns," said Source Capital Group analyst Joe Blankenship, "but I doubt that anything negative will come from it." Rivals ready for launch Adding to its challenges, the company will soon face increased competition from two new entrants, Stinger Systems STIY and Law Enforcement Associates LENF which are both preparing to introduce products. See full story. Morgan Keegan is expecting Stinger Systems' new four-dart, "less-lethal weapon," which is gun-powder based, to offer competition to the Taser stun gun. "We remain concerned that competition to Taser may rise in the first half of 2005 and potentially slow down Taser sales in the period," said Ruttenbur. The analyst is also skeptical that Taser can reach its own forecast of 100 percent revenue growth in the next several years. Ruttenbur forecasts growth of 30 to 40 percent. "We maintain that we like the long-term prospects for Taser International and other conduct energy weapons but believe shares of Taser are fairly priced at current levels," he said. Taser's difficulties, however, were good news for its rivals' stocks. Stinger Systems shares advanced more than 16 percent to finish at $33.75, while Law Enforcement Associates added nearly 38 percent to $7.71.
