title: Taser shares tumble on news of SEC inquiry

content: Advancers Accenture Ltd. ACN, +4.13% shares rose more than 4 percent after the company said late Thursday that first-quarter profit rose 13 percent from a year ago to $196 million, or 32 cents a share, a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. See full story. Albany Molecular Research AMRI shares added more than 3 percent after the company inked a two-year agreement with Alcon Research to develop opthalmic drugs. Blyth Inc.'s BTH, +1.01% ) stock jumped more than 10 percent in Friday trading after the company raised its fiscal 2005 earnings estimate to $2.13 to $2.18 a share. Its previous outlook was for earnings of $2.05 to $2.15 a share, while the Thomson First Call-derived estimate was for earnings of $2.07 a share. The Greenwich, Conn.-based direct marketer said the earnings revision was based on strong results from it European operations. Cavco Industries Inc. CVCO, +1.40% shares rose more than 3 percent after the company authorized a two-for-one stock split in the form of a dividend payable on Jan. 31 to shareholders as of Jan. 18. Collins & Aikman CKC shares added more than 6 percent in afternoon action. In an SEC filing after Thursday's closing bell, the company disclosed stock purchases by David Stockman, its chairman and CEO, and certain funds controlled by Heartland Industrial Associates, of which Stockman is the managing partner. The company said Stockman purchased 7,500 shares with his own funds and that the Heartland funds purchased 70,000 shares. Constellation Brands Inc. STZ, +3.37% shares added nearly 6 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings rose 17 percent to $96.9 million, or 83 cents a share. See full story. Darden Restaurants DRI, +1.03% shares jumped nearly 4 percent after the company said December same-restaurant sales at its Olive Garden and Red Lobster chains were up 14 percent. DoubleClick DCLK shares climbed more than 8 percent after the company said results for its fourth quarter and the year would outpace prior expectations on stronger-than-expected performance. Shares of ID Biomedical Corp. IDBE rose more than 6 percent after the Vancouver-based company said it has received clearance for its investigational new drug application to begin immediate clinical testing of its Fluviral influenza vaccine in the United States from the Food and Drug Administration. The company (IDB) plans to ship product to the United States and begin enrolling patients by the end of the month. Shares of Isco International Inc. ISO, +6.94% gained more than 22 percent after the Elk Grove Village, Ill., maker of radio-frequency processing chips named John Thode president and CEO. Thode most recently served as a vice president with Motorola, where he worked for 25 years. Isco also said it expects revenue of $650,000 for the fourth quarter, and that it has purchase orders worth more than $2.5 million scheduled for shipment in the first quarter. Shares of Lazare Kaplan LKI climbed nearly 5 percent after the diamond retailer reported an 11 times increase in its second-quarter earnings. Lazare posted net income of $1.1 million, or 12 cents per share, up from $110,000, or a penny per share, last year. The company's results are not tracked by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net sales rose 78 percent to $93 million. Lesco Inc. LSCO shares jumped nearly 6 percent after the company said it expects a loss of 42 to 48 cents a share on revenue ranging from $560 million to $563 million for 2004. On a pro forma basis, it expects earnings of 50 to 53 cents a share, up from the previous estimate of 40 to 50 cents a share. Lightpath Technologies LPTH, +2.33% shares advanced more than 3 percent after the company said it expects sales of roughly $3.3 million for the second quarter, a 75 increase from its year-ago equivalent total of $1.9 million. The company said its sales backlog was "reduced somewhat" in the quarter to about $3 million as of Dec. 31 due to the holiday season and weakness in communication market orders. Shares of NMT Medical Inc. NMTI added more than 16 percent after the Boston-based company said it's started enrolling patients in Europe in a clinical study of its MIST system for the treatment of migraine headaches. The company said the study is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of its proprietary STARFlex implant technology. NMY also noted that the recruitment has progressed "more quickly than originally anticipated" so it expects enrollment to be completed in the third quarter, one quarter ahead of schedule. It expects to begin a U.S. migraine study in the second half of the year. Parlux Fragrances Inc. PARL shares gained more than 8 percent after the company said Friday that it has purchased the exclusive worldwide marketing and licensing rights for the XOXO fragrance brand from Victory International. The XOXO fragrances will launch during the February Valentine's Day weekend at U.S. department stores. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. RF Industries Ltd. RFIL, +4.55% shares surged nearly 10 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter net income rose 45 percent to $437,000, or 12 cents a diluted share, from $301,000, or nine cents a share, a year earlier. Sales for the quarter, which ended Oct. 31, increased 10 percent to $3.3 million from $3.04 million. ScanSource Inc. SCSC, +0.28% shares climbed more than 7 percent after the company said it expects sales of $363 million to $371 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31, up from its year-ago equivalent total of $289 million. Shaw Group Inc. SGR, +0.00% shares surged nearly 7 percent after the company reported first-quarter net income of $10 million, or 16 cents a diluted share, versus last year's net loss of $49.6 million, or $1.07 a share. The company recorded income from continuing operations of $10.8 million, or 17 cents a share, against the Thomson First Call-derived estimate for earnings of 14 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter expanded 28 percent to $828.1 million from $646.9 million in the prior-year period. Higher sales and lower costs were responsible for the improved results, the company said. Shire Pharmaceuticals SHPGY (SHP) shares gained more than 5 percent after the U.K. company was upgraded to "overweight" by J.P. Morgan Chase. SimpleTech STEC, +2.14% shares rose more than 13 percent after the Santa Ana, Calif., memory company forecast earnings of 6 cents per share for the fourth quarter on revenue of between $77 million and $77.5 million, a projection that matches its prior indications. This profit view is in line with Wall Street's current consensus estimate, and the revenue projection exceeds the average analysts' outlook of $74.6 million. SYS Technologies SYS, -2.30% shares added nearly 5 percent after the company said it paid $2.6 million in cash and stock for privately held Antin Engineering of San Diego. Revenue for the nine months ended Sept. 30, 2004 were $4 million with a current annual run rate of $7 million, SYS said. Talx Corp. TALX shares rose nearly 13 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings "comfortably" above its previous forecast of 26 cents to 28 cents a share. It also said it expects revenue slightly above its forecast of $37 million to $39 million. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% shares added nearly 4 percent after the company said it expects net earnings to grow 10 to 12 percent in 2005. The jewelry retailer also reaffirmed its full-year 2004 earnings forecasts after posting December same-store sales growth of 6 percent from the year-earlier period. The company said it's on track to achieve its previous forecast for 2004 earnings of $1.43 to $1.48 a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for 2004 earnings of $1.44 a share. Shares of Tripath Technology Inc. TRPH soared more than 15 percent after the company said its TCD6001 and TPS4100 digital amplifier products would be used in Panasonic's automotive in-dash audio head unit systems. The rally builds on a surge during Thursday's session after the company inked a deal for the use of its products in liquid crystal display televisions made by Sharp. The stock rose 38 cents, or 23.5 percent, to $2 in afternoon trades, a gain of roughly 70 percent from Wednesday's close at $1.33 Vastera VAST, +1.61% shares soared 50 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% for $129 million, or $3 a share. in cash. The consideration values shares of Vastera, whose technology automates trading processes, at a 50 percent premium to Thursday's close. See full story. Video Display Corp. VIDE, -6.67% shares leapt more than 7 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings of 10 to 11 cents a share with revenue coming in more than 15 percent above its year-ago total of $18.1 million. The current average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $21 million WD-40 Co. WDFC, -0.04% shares gained more than 4 percent after the company said first-quarter net income rose 28.4 percent to $5.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from $4.4 million, or 26 cents a share, a year ago. Sales for the quarter were $60.7 million vs. $52.5 million a year earlier. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting first-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share, on average. The company, whose main product is its namesake all-purpose lubricant, also said it still expects its 2005 net income to increase 5.5 percent to $27 million, or $1.62 a share. Westaff Inc. WSTF shares skyrocketed more than 31 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 15 cents a share. Last year, it lost $600,000, or 4 cents a share. Revenue was $205.6 million, up from $178.9 million. Shares of WSI Industries WSCI, +1.03% gained more than 17 percent after the Minneapolis maker of high-precision avionics and aerospace products posted first-quarter earnings of $26,000, or a penny per share, down from its year-ago profit of $56,000, or 2 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company. Sales jumped 38 percent in the latest three months to $3.9 million from $2.8 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said the latest results include $168,000 in relocation and facility operation costs. Zi Corp. ZICA shares rose more than 7 percent after the software company said it named Richard Tingle to its board, effective immediately. Tingle, who is a senior partner at Tingle Merrett, replaces Rod Love. Decliners Shares of Bright Horizons Family Solutions BFAM, +2.08% lost nearly 6 percent after SunTrust Robinson Humphrey downgraded the childcare center operator to "reduce" from "neutral." Brocade Communications Systems' BRCD shares fell more than 7 percent after the company said plans to restate its financial statements for fiscal years 2002 and 2003, in order to record additional stock-based compensation expense as a result of an internal review. The company also said it plans to delay the filing of its fiscal 2004 Form 10-K that is due on Jan. 13. See full story. Depomed Inc. DEPO, +0.00% shares slumped more than 11 percent after the company said it's agreed to sell up to 5 million common shares for $4.50 each to institutional investors. The Menlo Park, Calif., pharmaceutical company anticipates gross proceeds of roughly $22.7 million from the sale. Electronics Boutique Holdings Corp. ELBO shares skidded more than 3 percent after the company's January quarter earnings per share estimate was cut by Piper Jaffray to $1.55 a share from its prior projection for earnings at $1.72 a share. "Holiday video game sales are expected to fall short of expectations," the broker told clients. FormFactor Inc. FORM, +1.11% shares slid nearly 4 percent after the company said it now expects to report revenue of $46.1 million, down from its previous forecast of $50 million to $53 million. See full story. Game Stop Corp. GME, -10.81% shares sank more than 7 percent after the company lowered its fourth-quarter earnings forecast, citing hardware supply shortages. Schering SHR, +0.18% stock fell more than 5 percent as the German drug firm said it had received an "approvable" letter from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration calling for more data on the company's breast cancer drug Bonefos. Analysts said that the impact of the anti-cancer drug's delayed marketing on Schering's stock depends on the kind of data the FDA is requesting. Schering could likely not produce more clinical data supporting the drug before 2007, which would be disastrous for the company, they said. Taser International TASR shares sank more than 17 percent after the stun gun maker said it's the subject of an informal probe by the Securities and Exchange Commission. See full story. Shares of TiVo Inc. TIVO, +0.37% were off almost 14 percent in afternoon action. The move follows news that DirecTV Group DTV, +0.36% plans to begin offering its own branded digital video recorder to its subscribers later this year. DirecTV shares rose almost 2 percent to $16.28. See full story. UTStarcom Inc. UTSI, +2.71% shares plunged more than 19 percent after the company said problems with its China operations hurt its fourth-quarter results. See full story. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) - U.S. stock futures rose as the market digested the U.S. jobs growth in December - the 157,000 nonfarm jobs growth was seen below expectations, but not strong enough to trigger inflation concerns. The Dow industrials futures surged 24 points at 10,645 in volatile trade after the report. In December, the U.S. unemployment rate remained steady at 5.4 percent, the Labor Department said. With upward revisions of 34,000 to previous months, payroll growth was close to expectations of 178,000. For all of 2004, 2.231 million jobs were added, the best since 1999. European markets were showing moderate gains, led by the FTSE 100 in the U.K. amid gains in the energy stocks. Focus stocks Pfizer shares PFE, +0.54% were marked at $26.80 in German trading of U.S. shares, up from a close at $26.29. London dealers cited a report in the Wall Street Journal Friday that the drugmaker's progress in developing a voice test to diagnose Parkinson's. Pfizer has no plans to market the speech test but may explore licensing the technology to other companies, the report said. Taser International TASR whose electric "stun" guns have come under criticism in recent months, said overnight it's cooperating in an informal Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry of its safety statements and sales to a distributor. Shares dropped 11 percent to $24.58 on the Archipelago ECN with over 70,000 shares traded. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% expects net earnings to grow 10 to 12 percent in 2005, while sales grow 8 to 10 percent. The jewelry retailer also reaffirmed its full-year 2004 earnings forecasts after posting December same-store sales growth of 6 percent from the year-earlier period. J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% said it would buy trade processes management automator Vastera VAST, +1.61% for $129 million, or $3 a share in cash. The deal values Vastera shares at a 50 percent premium to Thursday's closing price of $2. VAST spiked to $2.95 in the pre-open trade. ImmunoGen Inc. IMGN, -2.05% a Cambridge, Mass., producer of treatments for cancer, said Christopher U. Missling, chief financial officer, vice president of finance, and treasurer, left the company to pursue other interests. Sprint Corp. FON, +5.56% and Virgin Group are considering selling a stake in their U.S. wireless joint venture, Virgin Mobile USA, in an initial public offering, according to a report in the Wall Street Journal. Shares in U.K.-based speaker specialist NXT Sound (NTX) surged more than 44 percent to 65 pence after Japanese mobile phone leader NTT DoCoMo DCM, +0.87% said it was releasing a cell phone whose screen acts as a speaker, developed using NXT's technology. Cap Gemini (012533), the French IT group, was stung 3.7 percent in Paris by a credit rating downgrade by Standard & Poor's to BBB- from BB+. The firm reacted to the move, saying it expresses its "strong disagreement with this opinion. Overnight, shares of DoubleClick DCLK rose 6.9 percent to $7.91 after it said it expected its fourth-quarter results would be stronger than forecast, citing revenue from the company's ad management, e-mail and Performics businesses. Brocade Communications Systems BRCD fell 5.9 percent to $6.51 after it said it planned to restate its financial results for fiscal years 2002 and 2003, in order to record additional stock-based compensation expense as a result of an internal review. The company also said it plans to delay the filing of its fiscal 2004 Form 10-K that is due on Jan. 13. See full story. Broker calls Broker Piper Jaffray overnight cut its January quarter earnings per share estimate on Electronics Boutique Holdings Corp. ELBO to $1.55 a share from its prior projection for earnings at $1.72 a share. "Holiday video game sales are expected to fall short of expectations," the broker told clients. "Same store sales are likely at low single-digit levels hit hard by severe shortages of hardware from Sony SNE, +0.54% Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% and Nintendo. On top of missed software sales tied to the missed hardware sales, store traffic was negatively impacted and software sales will be challenged." First Albany overnight raised its earnings estimate for Apple Computer, Inc. AAPL, +0.78% fiscal first December quarter to 50 cents a share from its prior projection for earnings at 47 cents a share. Apple is expected to update on its quarter next Wednesday and has guided for earnings from 39 cents to 42 cents a share. "Expectations are running high, as we think investors may be anticipating 4.5-5.0 million iPods and at least 50 cents earnings per share. Nevertheless, we expect consensus estimates for FY05 to take another step function upward, which should enable further appreciation," the broker told clients. Siemens SI was upgraded to "outperform" from "in-line" by Goldman Sachs, based on its high exposure to long-cycle industries and emerging markets as well as potential upside from corporate catalysts such as asset sales and increased returns to shareholders. Syngenta SYT, +3.29% shares were 2.7 percent stronger in Swiss trade after Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded the seed group to "outperform" from "neutral." Against a negative backdrop for the European chemicals sector, "Syngenta is, we believe, in a very strong position to benefit from the positive drivers that we foresee in the coming 2-3 years in the seeds and agrochemicals markets," the broker said. content: Corrects chart data for Taser International. BOSTON (CBS.MW) -- In defining "stupid" for average investors, I sometimes personify the word, and show myself as "lacking normal intelligence and reason." Thankfully, that didn't happen often in 2004. While the most patently ridiculous investment scenarios have supporters -- most sending me nasty letters promising I'd rue the day I highlighted their favorite stock or fund -- there's no denying that 2004 witnessed an abundance of bad investment ideas, the kinds of things that look attractive on the surface but which prove that beauty is only skin deep. As such, it is with pleasure (rather than great discomfort) that I review the best and worst picks for Stupid Investment of the Week in 2004. Stupid Investment of the Week highlights the problems that make specific securities, plans or products less than ideal for the average investor, in the hope that spotlighting one bad issue will make others easier to find. The words "average investor" are crucial in deciding where and why I point the finger. Stock jockeys, day traders, investors with advanced technical timing models or an insider's knowledge are far from average, though they represent the bulk of people who send me hate mail. Savvy investors can make money using investments and strategies that don't work for the average guy. There also plenty of occasions when a pick falls into the category of "good company, bad stock," which means that -- despite good promise and potential -- current conditions suggest the issue is in a dangerous place. Profits alone can't make an investment "smart for the average consumer." The ride a security provides is critical. Studies show that average investors tend to bail out when losses move into the 20 percent range, so a security that takes a dive after gaining some acclaim is a lousy choice, even if it rebounds to reach new highs. The average investor sees only the downturn, and is gone when the rebound comes. As the arbiter of stupid, there are many issues on which my feelings will never change. The "Freedom Tower Silver Dollar" (Read Sept. 24 column) would be a putrid investment even if the National Collectors Mint were not prohibited by court order from selling any more of them. Likewise, the "burial expense plan" from Physicians Life Insurance Co.(Read Feb. 27 column.) will never become a good idea, and the massive number of complaints piling up against the computer-financing deal from Blue Hippo Funding(Read Nov. 12 column) simply prove how bad that situation is. Half of the 15 individual stocks chosen for Stupid Investment of the Week will finish the year at least 25 percent below the price they were at when named a poor choice. The smallest, most speculative issues were the worst, with eDollars. (Read March 19 column), losing 97 percent of its value and Computerized Thermal Imaging (Read March 26 column) disappearing entirely. Another small issue, Maui General Stores(Read Aug. 20 column.) is off roughly 80 percent, but also represented one of my failings. Maui General was dragged into the "vice mail" scam, where fake "wrong-number" voice messages were left in the hope that investors would think they had been blessed with a hot insider tip. I needed to make the Maui pick sooner. I knew the company was in the soup, and the trading patterns showed it was moving because of the scam, but I held the story an extra week to make sure the minute details were correct. Several readers noted that if my column had moved sooner -- before the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission notified the public of the fraud (the agency did not name the stocks involved), I would have saved them some heartache. They were reckless to follow the silly voice-mail tip, but my job is helping investors protect themselves and I failed to provide the earliest possible warning. One of the more controversial picks of the year was Taser International, which was Stupid Investment of the Week in early April (Read April 9 column.), about a week before it hit a peak and dropped into a pit that would shave about 50 percent off the price before a rebound. It took seven months to regain the high; while long-term holders have come out ahead on Taser, the average person buying near the peak probably would not have stuck around long enough to profit. The big miss among stocks this year was Tesoro Petroleum, (Read June 11 column.), which refines, markets and distributes oil and gas products. The company was coming off a 222 percent gain in 2003 and was up another 50 percent in 2004 when I wrote about it. I said the gains were not sustainable, particularly if oil prices started to fall. Well, oil prices declined, but TSO didn't; it's up another 40 percent since my column appeared, and while my premise of avoiding the hot name in a cyclical business has merit, I feel silly for reading the tea leaves so badly here. On the mutual fund side, ProFunds Ultra Wireless Investors(Read June 25 column.) was the leading fund at the year's halfway point, which put it on the outs with me. The fund still gets just a one-star rating from Morningstar and gets Lipper's worst grades for total return, consistent return and preservation of capital, but there is no denying that the market conditions that propelled it to the top did not dissipate as quickly as I expected. One bit of solace: last year, the midway leader was Apex Mid-Cap Growth(Read July 11, 2003 column.) and it, too, maintained performance long enough for me to eat some crow. This year, however, Apex Mid-Cap is back down near the bottom of the barrel. My call wasn't bad, so much as it was early, and I think the same will happen with ProFunds Ultra Wireless. Another bad call on funds came late in 2003, when I singled out the Vice Fund, a gimmick issue that buys "sin stocks," and where top management was in some regulatory trouble. At least for 2004, the gimmick worked and the regulatory issues made no difference; the fund is up nearly 20 percent this year, putting it near the top of its asset category. I still hate the premise, but I can't deny I might have been too cynical about the fund's performance potential. It won't stop me from being cynical and judgmental in 2005, because there is a lot of stupidity left to uncover. But it will serve as a reminder that I need to avoid falling into stupid traps, too. I'll try to do better in 2005. content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Morgan Keegan analyst Brian Ruttenbur said Taser International tasr might face competition in the law enforcement market in the next couple of months. Ruttenbur believes Stinger Systems' stiy new 4-dart less lethal weapon, which has a shooting range of up to 31 feet vs. Taser's current range of 25 feet, will be available for sale in the end of January or early February. He said about 1,200 police agencies were evaluating the Stinger weapons. Ruttenbur also expects competition from Law Enforcement Associates lenf which makes surveillance and intelligence gathering products. Taser was last trading up 75 cents, or 2.7 percent, to $28.78 after the company said a contract extension with the U.S. Marine Corps and the Office of Naval Research could be worth at least $515,000.
title: Taser may face competition in couple months: analyst

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said Wednesday morning that it has received a contract extension with the U.S. Marine Corps and the Office of Naval Research that will be worth at least $515,000. The work involves the development of a longer range shoulder-fired projectile that will work in a similar way to the company's other weapons.
title: Taser gets Navy research contract extension

content: Last week shares of Pfizer got dinged when results of a study linked its arthritis drug Celebrex to heart problems -- but that hasn't fazed the newsletter gurus, who are still quite bullish on the stock, says Mark Hulbert. Now that 2004 is coming to a close, which newsletters performed the best? The top spot goes to Fredhager.com, remarkably up over 150 percent, says Peter Brimelow, who notes most newsletters in this year's top ten are value-oriented. Michael Ashbaugh's charts show the markets are extended in the near-term, but on a longer-term basis, they're anything but. Leapfrog's shares fell when the company recently withdrew estimates, though Herb Greenberg says the writing was on the wall. And Robert Powell talks about the growing popularity of life-cycle funds. In The Guru's corner, Yiannis G. Mostrous of Wall Street Winners warns against investor euphoria, which is again becoming one of the main drivers of the financial markets. In newsletter news, some investment letters might not be as independent as you might think. Samantha Soga, Newsletters Assistant Subscribe now: Investment Newsletter Insights THE GURU'S CORNER www.guruscorner.com Wall Street Winners Euphoria is once again becoming a main market driver. -- Yiannis G. Mostrous NEWSLETTERS & RESEARCH www.hulbertdigest.com Wiser about Pfizer? Before the Celebrex news, Pfizer PFE, +0.54% was the most popular stock among newsletters. It still is. -- Mark Hulbert Subscribe: Hulbert Interactive Discover the stock and mutual fund advisory letters with the most successful track records in both up and down markets since 1990: Hulbert Financial Digest 2005 Newsletter Honor Roll Top newsletters of 2004 It's noticeable that many of the investment letters in this year's top 10 are value oriented. -- Peter Brimelow Subscribe: The Hulbert Financial Digest Froggy bottom Leapfrog LF shares knocked down after withdrawing estimates -- but the handwriting was on the wall.-- Herb Greenberg Subscribe: Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck Pick your cycle Retirement savers are flocking to life-cycle funds, where stock and bond allocations are preset. -- Robert Powell Subscribe: Retirement Weekly Favoring further gains The markets are extended near-term, but longer-term, they're anything but. Stocks on the MikeWatch: Taser International TASR Nanophase Technologies NANX, -0.22% InterActive Corp. IACI, +0.00% Quest Communications Q, +0.00% Wright Medical Group WMGI, +1.33% Infosys Technologies INFY, +0.90% and Radisys RSYS, -0.76% -- Michael Ashbaugh Subscribe: The Technical Indicator The ties that bind In recent years, many investors have begun to question the ties that Wall Street analysts have to the stocks that they tout. As such, investment newsletters, considered free of such entanglements, have drawn greater attention. In the "it pays to read the small print" department," it appears that some newsletters may not be so independent. Stock Prospector and Equities Special Situations are two such publications that freely admit in legal disclaimers to having received fees from companies that have been recommended in their newsletters. Eric Dany, who edits Stock Prospector and Mutual Fund Prospector, currently holds 27,500 shares of Turner Valley Oil & Gas TVOG, -9.74% in his Stock Prospector model portfolio. Dany began running this disclaimer in this year's April issue: "Eric Dany received a payment of $20,000 in cash and additional subscription revenue for a publicly distributed special advertising issue of the Stock Prospector intended to create investor awareness of Turner Valley Oil and Gas and generate subscriptions to the Stock Prospector." Dany initiated coverage of Turner Valley in November 2003, purchasing 17,500 shares for his model portfolio, according to the Hulbert Financial Digest. An additional 10,000 shares joined the portfolio toward the end of October when the stock was trading near its 52-week low. While Turner Valley's share price is still down roughly 45 percent from its price when Dany initiated coverage in 2003, it has rebounded sharply from the 52-week low. Give Dany credit, he's not shy about noting this stock's volatility, and maintains that this is an extremely speculative buy. The HFD began tracking Eric Dany's Stock Prospector at the beginning of 2000. Since that time, it's lost 5.9 percent annually through the end of November, vs. a 2.2 yearly loss for the Wilshire 5000 SVH, +5.63% Over the 13 months since Dany added Turner Valley to his portfolio, however, the Stock Prospector is off a cumulative 11 percent annually, vs. a 15.1 percent gain for the Wilshire. Similarly, Equities Special Situations has acknowledged a financial relationship with at least seven of its current 12 buy recommendations. Many of these relationships derive from a fee paid by these companies to do presentations at investment conferences hosted by parent publication Equities Magazine. From Equities Special Situations comes this caveat emptor: "Readers should be aware that (this company) paid $7,500 to present its strategy at (one of our conferences). We have tried to be objective, but may have failed. You readers must decide for yourself." Other relationships stem from companies purchasing 500 or 1000 copies of the issue of Equities Special Situations in which they were featured, presumably for promotional purposes. The newsletter always discloses the number of copies that each company purchased, as well as the price at which they were purchased. In addition, each issue of the newsletter includes the additional boilerplate disclaimer in even smaller print: "Some companies written up may be advertisers in our sister publication, paid sponsors at one of our corporate conferences or may buy reprints. However, our buy, sell or hold decisions will never be based on such events but on what we believe is best for our readers." The HFD has been tracking Equities Special Situations since the beginning of 1987. Equities Special Situations has returned 8.9 percent annualized through the end of November, vs. 11.5 percent annualized for the Wilshire 5000 over the same period. -- Ari Charney Subscribe: HFD Newsletter Performance Profiles More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Don’t ever do this with your credit card S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Pfizer murmur, Leapfrog stumble and 2004’s top letters

content: This is a free edition of The Technical Indicator. To receive the daily edition, which includes technical analysis and stock picks every morning, please subscribe. It's now available at a monthly rate. Learn more and subscribe. CINCINNATI (CBS.MW) -- Tuesday's pre-market bias was higher following stronger-than-expected quarterly results from Morgan Stanley and Bear Stearns. Early buy interest follows a mixed session for U.S. stocks Monday. The Dow rose 11 points, the Nasdaq lost 7 points, and the S&P 500 edged higher by less than a point. This first chart above is an hourly chart of the S&P 500. It serves as a detailed view of the past two weeks. Since finding support two weeks ago at 1,174, the index has rallied as much as 31 points, or 2.6 percent, before consolidating its gains over the past two sessions. Yet also note that for two consecutive sessions, the S&P has found support almost precisely at 1,194. That 1,194 support closely matches the top of a former range, and the support point designated here last week at 1,195. The near-term story on the Dow mirrors that on the S&P. Since lifting two weeks ago from support around 10,425, the Dow has run as much as 314 points, or 3.0 percent. Yet while the Dow has consolidated its gains over the past several sessions, it has maintained a posture above near-term support around 10,640. That 10,640 support closely matches the top of a former range -- the Dec. 3 high came in at 10,643. On a near-term basis, the Nasdaq remains the weakest of the three major averages. Last week, the index topped out for all practical purposes almost precisely at 2,164. Recall that level also matched the Dec. 3 high. Since then, the Nasdaq has trended steadily lower, though it has observed the designated technical levels. On further weakness, the next obvious support point holds at the mid-November highs around 2,110 to 2,112. The Nasdaq's daily chart widens the view on its recent rally. Again, the recent pullback has done little to alter the longer-term uptrend. The Dow is arguably the best positioned index. After staging that sharp rally in early November, the Dow consolidated its gains for five to six weeks, before extending its gains last week. Again, Friday's support around 10,640 is a rough match with the breakout point from that previously tight trading range - the Dec. 3 high came in at 10,643. So from a technical standpoint, the Dow's price action is consistent with an ongoing longer-term uptrend. The daily view on the S&P 500 also remains bullish. Remember the S&P closed the previous week - two Friday's ago -- precisely on 1,188.00. That set the stage for last week's break to three-year highs. The bigger picture Over the past two months, the major averages have spiked to notable new highs. The Dow has cleared a nine-month downtrend, the S&P 500 has made three-year highs, and the Nasdaq has made three-year highs. And to get to those new highs, the markets have staged massive near-term rallies. From the October lows -- where the Dow touched its 2004 low -- each index has carved out the following two-month return: The Dow Industrials has rallied 1,031 points, or 10.6 percent. The S&P 500 has gained 118 points, or 10.8 percent. The Nasdaq has added 272 points, or 13.8 percent. So on the one hand, the markets have staged these massive near-term rallies, making it difficult to be aggressively bullish. Still, it's worth placing longer-term perspective on this rally. Taking the S&P 500 and using January 4, 2002 as a reference point -- almost three years ago -- the S&P 500 at Monday's close was all of 18 points, or 1.5 percent, higher. That means the index has turned in a minuscule three-year return of just 1.5 percent. Yet taking this comparison one step further, note the S&P topped out on January 4, 2002 at 1,176. That's almost an exact match with the recent lift from support, illustrated on the S&P's hourly chart above, at 1,174. So in essence, this recent one-week lift from 1,174 almost precisely matches the net gain on the S&P 500 over the past three years. Again, the frame of reference is the important issue. While the markets are indeed extended near-term -- making it tough to add aggressively following this two-month run of 10 percent -- on a longer-term basis, they're anything but extended at current levels. Tuesday's watch list The charts below identify several names worth watching from a technical perspective. These are intended as radar screen names - sectors or stocks that appear well positioned for a potential move in the specified direction over the near term. For the original comments on the stocks below, check out The Technical Indicator Library. Index Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Gold & Silver Index XAU 98.76 96.0 100 Over the past three weeks, the Gold & Silver Index has broken decisively lower, and even at current levels, isn't exactly attracting buyers. Note that last week the XAU violated the 100 level and has since observed that area as resistance. The group's outlook now favors further downside until it at least reasserts a stance back above its 50-day moving average. Yet the real point illustrated above isn't so much the adverse outlook for gold as it is the bullish near-term outlook for the U.S. dollar. As a very general rule, when interest rates rise it attracts foreign investors to buy U.S. bonds. That requires them to purchase U.S. dollars, which in turn increases the value of the dollar. When the U.S. dollar goes up, gold goes down. Also note that strength in the U.S. dollar dilutes the drop in crude oil prices, making the recent slump in crude more sustainable. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Taser International TASR $28.34 $26.75 $29.00 Stun gun maker Taser International TASR is well positioned technically to rise. In early November, it broke higher on strong volume confirming its longer-term uptrend. Since then, it has consolidated on lighter volume, finding support almost exactly at the breakout point around the July and September highs. Monday, it challenged one-month highs on strong volume, suggesting it may be positioned to resume its longer-term uptrend. The bullish near-term outlook would be placed in question on a close under its one-week low around $26.75. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Nanophase Technologies NANX $7.92 $7.50 $8.40 Nanophase Technologies NANX, -0.22% is another name positioned to rise. Last week, it broke decisively above its 200-day moving average, making five-month highs in the process. Since then, it has maintained those highs behind a sustained increase in volume. That means despite its recent extension, there are still buyers at prevailing levels. Its bullish near-term outlook should remain intact barring a close under very recent support at $7.50. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance InterActiveCorp IACI $25.88 $23.70 $26.85 Profiled in The Technical Indicator on Dec. 10, InterActiveCorp IACI, +0.00% remains technically well positioned. It will open higher Tuesday after the company announced plans to spin off Expedia as a separate public entity. The rally should place InterActiveCorp above its 200-day moving average, currently at $26.85. That 200-day moving average sets the longer-term trend, and assuming it can sustain Tuesday's breakout, the longer-term term outlook will be higher. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Qwest Communications Q $4.23 $4.00 $4.30 Qwest Communications Q, +0.00% is another name positioned to rise. Since breaking out in early December, it has consolidated its gains on lighter volume, finding support around the breakout point of $4.00. Also note the bullish 50-day/200-day moving average crossover signals the intermediate-term uptrend has overtaken the longer-term trend. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Wright Medical Group WMGI $29.65 $28.30 $30.22 Initially profiled Dec. 9, Wright Medical Group WMGI, +1.33% remains technically well positioned. Recall its initial rally occurred on strong volume, after the company reaffirmed its fourth quarter outlook. Yet from a technical standpoint, that early December rally also resolved a bullish inverse head-and-shoulders pattern. The left shoulder is defined by the August low, the head by the October low, and the right shoulder by the November low. The neckline is defined by the September high at $28.34 and the November high of $28.30. Its bullish near-term outlook should be intact barring a close back under that neckline. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Infosys Technologies INFY $71.58 $65.30 New High Profiled Nov. 30, Infosys Technologies INFY, +0.90% has since edged two points higher, and remains well positioned. Last week, it rallied on above average volume, after recently finding support just above its 50-day moving average. Then Monday, Infosys edged to four-year highs, also on increased volume. From current levels, initial support around $65.30 approximates the December low. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance RadiSys RSYS $17.60 $16.80 $18.60 RadiSys RSYS, -0.76% is another name positioned to rise. In early December, it spiked above its 200-day moving average on strong volume. Since then, it has consolidated its gains, favoring the high end of its range on lighter relative volume. Also note the early December rally resolved a four-month ascending triangle, a bullish formation suggesting the shares are attracting buyers at progressively higher prices. Still well positioned The table below includes selected names recently profiled in The Technical Indicator that remain well positioned. For the original comments on the stocks below, check out The Technical Indicator Library. content: SAN DIEGO (CBS.MW) -- So many stories, so little time. Gas pains: With Cheniere Energy's stock trading below $50 briefly last Thursday, I wondered whether investors who bought 5 million shares of the company's stock the night before at $60 would want their money back. It seemed like an appropriate question, considering that in the same press release announcing the deal's pricing Cheniere also announced that ChevronTexaco had decided not to invest in the company's Sabine Pass liquid gas project. Fast forward to Monday: After the market's close Cheniere LNG, +2.20% announced it had signed a long-awaited, 20-year deal with ChevronTexaco CVX, +1.73% to provide Cheniere with 700 million cubic feet per day of liquefied natural gas at Sabine Pass. (In English: This is gas that Cheniere will take in liquid from ChevronTexaco, convert to gaseous gas, and then return to ChevronTexaco.) As a result, investors who held their stock were back in the money based on after-market trading. And according to fans, those who bought are likely to be richly rewarded down the road -- assuming everything goes the way they're hoping. If the stock's so attractive, why would Chevron back out of its investment? Cheniere hasn't said -- and the company never returned my call from last week. But those who talk to Cheniere say word from inside is that ChevronTexaco actually wanted a bigger piece of the project and Cheniere didn't want to risk losing commercial control to a minority investor. Besides, with $300 million from the stock offering, Cheniere no longer needed ChevronTexaco's cash. Still, the announcement of negotiations with ChevronTexaco allowed investors to extrapolate a value of $80 per share for all of Cheniere. Bulls believe that value should increase at 15 percent a year as Cheniere gets closer to generating cash flow from its three key projects, including Sabine, which should all be on line within the next five years. (No wonder the nasty-grams were flowing in on this one, even though all I really did was point out what had happened -- and how bizarre it all was.) Speaking of nasty-grams: The Hostile React-O-Meter was spinning outta control, outta control, I tell ya, after my Friday night column on OmniVision OVTI, +1.49% which makes image-sensor chips used in cell phones. We're talking religious slurs and everything in between. Pretty par for the course. (Never ceases to amaze me how many people are reading this column for the first time -- and some, I'm sure, the last!-- even after nearly 17 years and three employers.) The column in question merely pointed out what the company itself disclosed in its 10-Q: That it's the focus of an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission. But emotions run high among investors, and that's understandable. The company itself issued a press release Monday regarding the inquiry, saying absolutely nothing. (Actually, to paraphrase, it said it can't comment beyond what it has already disclosed.) Meanwhile, OmniVision also disclose in the quarterly filing that the company's gross margin had been inflated by $3.5 million by the sale of products for which reserves had been taken. That's another way of saying the company sold chips that it previously wrote off. Why would a company sell previously written off products in an increasingly competitive industry in which products are becoming rapidly obsolete? Shouldn't they be turned into sand? Good question, and it's one I would've asked CFO Peter Leigh had he returned my call. On Dec. 2 I reported that he said gross margins were higher, in part, because a smaller reserve was taken, in turn leading to a lower cost of goods. That's what happens, I guess, if you sell inventory that no longer has any cost. That's also one way of not having to having to reverse a reserve. Moving on... Over-the-top on Overstock.com: An analyst from Lehman Brothers, which was the lead investment banker on Overstock's OSTK, -0.96% recent stock offering, initiated coverage on the retailer with a target price of $90. But reading the report is yet another throwback to 1999. The analyst explains there's really no good way to value the company other than using the discounted cash flow method, which uses projections of revenue and EBITDA growth out to 2009. (As if that's really possible, but I digress...) If you didn't know better you'd think you were reading a report by Goldman Sachs from April 2000 on the brilliant potential B2B e-Commerce star Internet Capital Group, then $90 a share -- now $9 a share. Video volley: Investors ignored news last week that according to retail data, Take-Two's TTWO, +0.33% latest version of Grand Theft Auto didn't sell as many copies in November as had been expected. More not-so-great news: Electronic Arts ERTS Monday announced it had signed an exclusive video game licensing deal with the NFL. To quote my pal Jeff Macke, who writes for Minyanville.com: "Take-Two is once again, effectively, a one horse show... No financials were announced, but no matter what ERTS paid, the deal looks like a Joe-Theisman's-leg type of blow to Take-Two." Take-Two, of course, is like a cat when it comes to lives, so time will tell whether it lands on its feet this time. Finally -- Doughnut holes: Krispy Kreme's KKD third-quarter 10-Q was delayed as the company tried to work through some accounting issues related to a franchisee... Blast from the past: In my recent "Have investors learned nothing?" column I mentioned a company in Ohio that issued a press release years ago denouncing a story that was about to appear in Business Week. (I used it as a reference point in mentioning Taser TASR which did something similar a week ago regarding an upcoming Miami Herald story.) I forgot the name. It's Cincinnati Microwave, which ran into financial problems. Its stock -- or what's left of it -- trades on the pink sheets... TV time: I'll be on CBS MarketWatch Weekend this weekend and PBS's Wall Street Week with Fortune. Check your local listings. Editor's note: The most recent edition of the subscription-only Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck is available by e-mail. Highlights include: Will Trinity Industries' investors get railroaded? Why red flags still fly over Toro More on Medicis, OmniVision, Interstate Bakeries and others For more information or to subscribe to Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck, click here. Sign up for an alert whenever Herb's free column is published. title: Gas pains gone at Cheniere?

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International Inc. tasr said an independent study conducted by Florida Gulf University found that the company's technology "reduced deadly force litigation at the Orange County Sheriff's Office in Florida and caused fewer injuries versus traditional use of force tools." The stock closed Friday at $27.03, up 3.1 percent.
title: Taser: independent study says tech caused less injuries

content: SAN DIEGO (CBS.MW) -- There was a lesson I learned long ago. It was in the mid-1990s. I would write almost daily in my column, which then appeared on the front page of the San Francisco Chronicle, about a now-defunct company called Media Vision. At the time, it was one of the hottest in Silicon Valley. I've told this story here in one form or another several times in the past. But it warrants telling yet again today with the way stocks like Travelzoo TZOO, +1.75% Overstock.com OSTK, -0.96% Taser TASR and even OmniVision OVTI, +1.49% have been acting. After its stock had jumped 22 percent in the wake of my latest critical stab at the company, Media Vision's then-CEO, Paul Jain, called me and crowed, "That confirms that this is a high-quality story." It was that comment that made me realize just how often the movement of stocks is totally unrelated to the business. Rising stocks often mean nothing more than, well, stocks are rising. Jain, whose company was the focus of short sellers, took it one step further in the same story when he said, "The shorts have to understand that they'll be burned by me." They were -- until several months later, when the company reported a big disappointment, causing Media Vision's stock to crater. Several years later, Jain went to prison after it was discovered the company was booking revenue on products when the parts for some of those very products counted as sold were still on a slow boat from China. (I'm not kidding.) It's a story that often resonates in my head, and it's one reason that today, more than 10 years later, I still take what many CEOs say with little more than a grain of salt -- especially those who are keen on bragging about how well they're doing and talk along the lines of how they're going to "burn" the shorts and critics. Don't get me wrong: There are some plenty of really good CEOs out there who go about their business and live or die by their numbers -- not their stock prices. If the numbers bear out, the stock prices go higher. It's human nature to want stocks to rise, but too often they rise merely because of nothing more than unsustainable momentum. Unfortunately, that momentum lulls investors and even company executives into thinking they're smart, when they're really just parading around the chairs while the music is playing. That's why, when I used to work at TheStreet.com TSCM I would often write that it was important to read Jim Cramer because he would tell you what was going on at the "lunatic fringe" of the market. There's nobody who understands that world better than Jim, who just last week wrote of Taser and another company: "They have made fortunes for people, no mean task, and they have enough hope to do it again. I salute them and their ilk rather than thumb my nose at them. That's for old-timers who have forgotten that the process is not an academic one; it is one about making money." Damn the fundamentals. But Jim's right, and that fringe started having a big influence on the market in direct correlation to the growth of the Internet and popularity of business TV, both of which helped speed the flow of information. But it's all really a game, and in the end, as we all know -- and as companies like Krispy Kreme KKD and Netflix NFLX, +3.35% remind us -- it works until it doesn't. You can justify all kinds of valuations using all kinds of wacky metrics as long as stocks are going higher. It's funny how some of those methods of valuation look so silly after the fact. Is it different this time? No -- just as it wasn't during the bubble. When the music stops you still need to find a chair. It's remarkable so many investors still haven't learned that lesson. What's happening, after all, is so 1999. Except that instead of Amazon, we have Overstock. Meanwhile, back on OmniVision: Quite of bit of reader response to last week's item here on the maker of camera chips, which are better known as image sensors. It was enough to get the Hostile React-o-Meter spinning, but by no means out of control. Many of the responses were along the lines that one reason investors have been bidding up OmniVision's stock is because it's cheap on a cash flow basis. (Since when are chip companies valued their cash flow? Ah, that's right, as I mentioned earlier, you use whatever metrics work. Besides, as we all know, cash flow isn't always what it appears.) Others pointed to the company's cash generation last quarter, which on the surface looks impressive. But cash generation can always look good if you defer payments to suppliers or engage in other maneuverings. Notice that "other" current liabilities rose by $16 million. (You have to wonder what the "other" means.) Meanwhile, there were readers who said I should be careful about questioning OmniVision, because it's the leader in its industry. Well, I realize that, but in tech, especially chips, today's leader is likely to be tomorrow's laggard. Success in technology breeds competition, which for OmniVision is coming from the likes of Micron Technology MU, +1.26% Micron made that clear at a recent investment conference. "The major players in that market today is OmniVision, who is, I think, generally considered to be the No. 1 player in the mobile space," Micron investor relations chief Kip Bedard said. "We have moved into what we think is probably No. 2, and we're probably about a 25 percent market share player there. There's about 32 different CMOS image sensor companies. The ones that tend to get mentioned next are ST Micro STM, +0.63% and Agilent A, +0.75% The ones that I think are coming on the horizon you have to keep your eye on would be Toshiba TOSBF, -1.49% Samsung SSNGY, +0.00% and probably even Sony SNE, +0.54% here at some point. So I think the landscape probably changes pretty dramatically over the next couple of years." If not sooner. Taser Talk: Over the weekend Taser issued a press release damning a Miami Herald story before it was published. No idea how Taser knew what the Herald would write, but it reminds me of an Ohio smoke alarm company that did a similar thing years ago after being interviewed by Business Week. I forget the name of the company, because it no longer exists. Finally, sly as a fox: Was on Fox News Channel's Cavuto on Business over the weekend going head-to-head with Neil Cavuto. (Don't even ask where I got the tie.) He was wondering why the media is always so negative regarding positive economic news. Neil is without a doubt the best of the bunch among business commentators -- even if you don't always agree with his politics or his angle. On this topic not only did I disagree, I told him that if anything, the press isn't negative enough. And can you believe it? He called me a perma-bear! (Who, me?) Neil also wondered how anybody can be so glass-half-empty when they live in San Diego. Well, I muttered something like, "It's been cold here lately." (By the way, I'm not a perma-bear but a perma-skeptic -- big difference.) For more information or to subscribe to Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck, click here. Sign up for an alert whenever Herb's free column is published. title: Have investors learned nothing?

content: Editor's note: Corrects typographical error in first paragraph. SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taser International and researchers are debating safety of the company's stun guns for use on children after Miami police zapped two children last month, according to a published report Sunday. The company said its products are safe to use on children and the outcry unwarranted, according to a story Sunday on the Miami Herald's Web site. But researchers, doctors and Underwriters Laboratories, a nonprofit organization that provides product-safety testing and certification, have raised questions about the gun and have called for more study of their safety, particularly on the young, the Herald reported. Taser TASR claims its weapons deliver a shock within a safe range for children as young as 2 years old. But, a researcher at UL told the Herald that tests on the stun guns were not designed with children in mind. "I don't know that I had ever envisioned the use of this thing on small children," Wayne McDaniel, a University of Missouri-Columbia electrical engineer in charge of the Taser studies, told the Herald. "I don't think anyone has ever tried to draw any inferences as far as use in children...The design of this device is for bad guys." The debate over the products' safety on children began last month after police in Miami-Dade County, Fla. used the stun guns to subdue a 6-year-old boy and a 12-year-old girl. The report also says that Taser products haven't been tested by UL, despite indications in Taser-company literature that suggest otherwise. Taser said in a statement Saturday that the Herald report "mischaracterizes" the basis for its safety claims. Taser's statement comes within weeks of a New York Times article about unpublished results of U.S. Air Force Research Laboratory tests. The article said the stun guns could be dangerous and that more tests were needed to evaluate risks. See full story. Taser, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said Saturday that its confidence in its technology is based on "a body of overwhelming evidence that Tasers are generally safe and effective -- not on any one guideline or standard." Taser said it has published safety charts that compare its stun guns' output to standards published by Underwriters Laboratories, a nonprofit organization that provides product-safety testing and certification. "Much of the early development of Taser devices utilized electrical safety standards published by Underwriter Laboratories and other agencies," said Steve Tuttle, Taser's vice president of communications, in a statement. "Taser International has never claimed that UL has tested or approved Taser devices, although we invite and welcome them to test our products." Taser said one safety chart in question was developed by government research contractor Jaycor Inc., now a unit of Titan Corp. TTN from funding by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and the National Institute of Justice. The company said the study shows that Tasers have a "significant margin" of safety compared to published standards. On its Web site, Taser has links to studies, including a UL report on electrified fences that could deliver shocks to humans. It also links to the Jaycor study that mentions UL standards for the threshold of electrically injuring people. The company also cited recent independent reports from the Canadian government, the U.S. Department and Defense and the United Kingdom, which it said indicated that the devices are among the lowest-risk alternatives available to law enforcement agencies. The company said the results of additional testing on its devices will be published in a medical journal in January 2005, but did not name the journal. Amnesty International last month added its voice to a growing number of complaints about stun guns, saying more than 70 people have died during the past three years in the United States and Canada after they were jolted by the guns. Taser defended itself against the claims on Nov. 30, sending shares about 9 percent higher that day. See full story. Taser shares rose 47 cents Friday to $28.22. title: Taser's safety on kids questioned

content: The earnings lull continues this week. On Monday, truck and engine maker Navistar International NAV, +7.43% reports. Tuesday grocery chain Kroger Co. KR, +1.35% AutoZone Inc. AZO, +1.80% is up Wednesday. Thursday will see telecom networker Ciena Corp. CIEN, +2.29% retailer Costco Wholesale COST, +2.63% and chipmaker National Semiconductor NSM, -0.28% Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% a microchip maker, had its senior unsecured debt rating raised to "B" from "B-" with a stable outlook late Friday by Fitch, which cited improvements in the AMD product line and intermediate term liquidity. AirNet Communications ANCC which makes wireless network software, said late Friday that its board approved a 1-for-10 reverse stock split. The record date of the split is Wednesday and it's effective on Thursday. AirNet said it will have 9.6 million shares outstanding after the split. American Tower AMT, +0.72% which operates broadcast and communication towers, had its debt rating upgraded late Friday by Moody's, which noted improved free cash flow. Arch Capital Group Ltd. ACGL, -0.24% an insurance conglomerate, said late Friday that its Arch Insurance Group received a subpoena Thursday from New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer requesting information concerning its underwriting for lawyer professional malpractice coverage. Arch said it intends to cooperate with the request. ATA Airlines, a subsidiary of ATA Holdings Corp. ATAHQ said late Friday that traffic fell 6 percent in November. The load factor for the month rose seven percentage points to 70.5 percent. Capacity fell 15.3 percent. Callaway Golf ELY, +0.62% a maker of golf clubs and golf balls, could see prospects rise after its stock has taken a beating, says Barron's. A forecast of 2 percent higher golf equipment sales by an industry group plus rising numbers of golfers leads Barron's to say there are "reasons for hope" of a rising stock price. A new line of irons could boost sales, as well, and takeover rumors add potential premiums to the present $11.86 price. Celgene Corp. CELG, +0.90% and Pharmion Corp. PHRM said after the bell Friday that they have signed a three-year extension agreement to collaborate on the development, marketing and licensing of Celgene's Thalomid drug. The pact will result in Celgene receiving $88 million. Pharmion will also receive licensing rights to develop and market the drug in three additional locations in Asia: Hong Kong, Korea and Taiwan. Community Health Systems CYH, -3.65% which operates acute-care hospitals, said late Friday that it is privately placing $250 million of bonds, with proceeds aimed at paying down a revolving line of credit. Constellation Brands STZ, +3.37% which makes and sells wine and spirits, said late Friday that it has purchased a 40 percent interest in Ruffino S.r.l., an Italian fine wine company. The Folonari family, owners of Ruffino since 1913, will retain the majority interest in the Tuscany-based company. Terms were not disclosed Equity One Inc. EQY a real estate investment trust, said late Friday that its board approved a 3.6 percent quarterly dividend increase to 29 cents a share. The dividend is payable on Dec. 31 to shareholders as of Dec. 16. Fairfax Financial Holdings FFH, +1.58% an insurance holding company, said late Friday that it is selling $200 million of 7 3/4 percent note, with proceeds aimed at retiring $112 million of debt and a 45.7 million euro note due in 2007. Fairfax said the move is part of a debt elimination plan, including a stock sale, that cut $409.7 million of debt since the start of the year. Federal Signal Corp. FSS, +1.33% which makes firefighting equipment, said late Friday that it has sold Technical Tooling Inc., a Tool Group company, to Sandvik Hard Materials. Net proceeds from the sale are $6 million. Federal said it will realize a small gain on the transaction. FedEx FDX, +2.26% the package shipper, had its short-term debt rating reaffirmed late Friday by Moody's with the outlook raised to "stable" from "negative." But the rating agency said it was putting certain trust certificates, secured by airplanes, on review for possible downgrade. Moody's said it is concerned about the value of older aircraft. Fleetwood Enterprises FLE, +0.00% a recreational vehicle maker, reported second-quarter earnings late Friday of $8.1 million, or 14 cents a share. A year earlier, it posted income of $3.8 million, or 10 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter rose to $712.7 million, from $647.7 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had estimated earnings of 16 cents a share and revenue of $713 million. Forest City Enterprises FCE.A, +0.25% a real estate developer, said late Friday that it has sold five apartment complexes for $25 million. It said its after-tax gain from the sale is $9 million. General Electric's GE, -1.46% aircraft engine unit won a $162.3 million Army aviation contract for maintenance and repair of GE's T700 engines, the Defense Department said late Friday. The work will be finished by Dec. 31, according to the Pentagon. Hilb, Rogal & Hobbs's HRH, +0.00% the seventh largest insurance broker, had its "BB" counterparty credit rating cut to "negative" from "stable" late Friday by Standard & Poor's. The rating agency said New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's investigation into contingent commissions in the insurance industry will put pressure on the company's finances. Idacorp IDA, +0.75% the holding company for Idaho Power Co., saw its debt rating downgraded late Friday by Moody's, affecting about $1.1 billion in debt securities. Among the factors cited, Moody's said a rate increase was not as large as requested and drought conditions could raise the cost of hydroelectric power. Jos. A. Bank Clothiers JOSB a men's clothing retailer, is seen posting third-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share on Monday. Monsanto MON, -0.05% the agricultural product manufacturer, appears to be overcoming resistance to its genetically modified seeds, according to the Barron's cover story. Genetically modified products made up $2.3 billion of Monsanto's $5.5 billion in fiscal 2004 sales, Barron's notes, and contributed the most to profits. Wider acceptance for the products is likely to boost those numbers. Also benefiting would be Swiss company Syngenta SYT, +3.29% says Barron's. Parker Hannifin Corp. PH, +1.71% which makes hydraulic products, said late Friday that its November orders for its North American industrials businesses increased 11 percent from last year. In the climate and industrial controls business, November order rates fell 18 percent, while orders at Parker Aerospace were 24 percent higher compared with last year. Pinnacle Entertainment PNK, +0.57% a casino operator, said late Friday that it completed the offering of $100 million in 8.25 percent notes due 2012. Proceeds will be used to retire 9.25 percent notes. Ramco-Gershenson Properties Trust RPT, -0.96% a real estate investment trust, said late Friday that it agreed to buy two Michigan shopping centers with an aggregate value of $128 million. The transaction is expected to close during the first quarter of 2005. Taser International TASR the maker of stun devices used by law enforcers, said Saturday that it has never cited Underwriter's Laboratories as a tester of its products. It said the Miami Herald would be reporting on the issue. Taser said its products were based on electrical safety studies published by UL, and said it welcomes the researcher to test its stunners. See full story. Terra Industries TRA, +6.67% which makes nitrogen products, said late Friday that it had lost an appeal in Arizona of an earlier $10.1 million judgment. The case relates to a 1997 contract to purchase another business. Terra said it is reviewing whether to further appeal. It took a charge in 2002 for the original lawsuit loss. Timken Latrobe Steel, a division of Timken Co. TKR, +0.44% said late Friday that it will increase prices 5 to 10 percent Monday on its aerospace alloys and some stainless steel grades. United Airlines UALAQ said late Friday that traffic rose 3.6 percent in November. The load factor for the month rose 0.4 percentage points to 76.1 percent. Capacity rose 2.9 percent. Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% the large oil and gas company, said late Friday that its board authorized a share buyback of up to $465 million. Up to $265 million will be used to call the remaining outstanding Unocal 6.25 percent trust convertible preferred securities. The remainder would be for buying back common stock. Walt Disney Co.'s DIS, +1.93% most prominent dissident shareholders, Roy Disney and Stanley Gold, don't plan to present an alternate slate of directors at the annual meeting next year, the men said in a letter to the company's board, announced late Friday. Gold and Disney said their decision is based on the board's move to announce a replacement as chief executive for Michael Eisner in June. Eisner is due to step down when his contract expires in 2006. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Monday's stocks to watch: NAV, KR

Ramco-Gershenson Properties Trust RPT, -0.96% a real estate investment trust, said late Friday that it agreed to buy two Michigan shopping centers with an aggregate value of $128 million. The transaction is expected to close during the first quarter of 2005. Taser International TASR the maker of stun devices used by law enforcers, said Saturday that it has never cited Underwriter's Laboratories as a tester of its products. It said the Miami Herald would be reporting on the issue. Taser said its products were based on electrical safety studies published by UL, and said it welcomes the researcher to test its stunners. See full story. Terra Industries TRA, +6.67% which makes nitrogen products, said late Friday that it had lost an appeal in Arizona of an earlier $10.1 million judgment. The case relates to a 1997 contract to purchase another business. Terra said it is reviewing whether to further appeal. It took a charge in 2002 for the original lawsuit loss. Timken Latrobe Steel, a division of Timken Co. TKR, +0.44% said late Friday that it will increase prices 5 to 10 percent Monday on its aerospace alloys and some stainless steel grades. United Airlines UALAQ said late Friday that traffic rose 3.6 percent in November. The load factor for the month rose 0.4 percentage points to 76.1 percent. Capacity rose 2.9 percent. Unocal Corp. UCL, +0.00% the large oil and gas company, said late Friday that its board authorized a share buyback of up to $465 million. Up to $265 million will be used to call the remaining outstanding Unocal 6.25 percent trust convertible preferred securities. The remainder would be for buying back common stock. Walt Disney Co.'s DIS, +1.93% most prominent dissident shareholders, Roy Disney and Stanley Gold, don't plan to present an alternate slate of directors at the annual meeting next year, the two men said in a letter to the company's board, announced late Friday. Gold and Disney said their decision is based on the board's move to announce a replacement as chief executive for Michael Eisner in June. Eisner is due to step down when his contract expires in 2006. See full story.
