title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: Advancers Accredited Home Lenders Holdings LEND shares gained nearly 15 percent Tuesday after the company said it expects 2005 earnings of $6.90 per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $6.56 per share. Chairman and Chief Executive Officer James Konrath added he believes the company can increase its earnings per share at an average rate of 15 percent per year for the next three to five years. Shares of CoTherix Inc. CTRX advanced more than 21 percent in afternoon action, breaching the $7 level. The San Francisco-based biopharmaceutical developer held its initial public offering on Oct. 15, selling 5 million common shares at $6 each. CIBC World Markets and Piper Jaffray initiated coverage of the company with "sector performer" and "outperform" ratings, respectively. Eon Communications Corp. EONC shares rallied more than 39 percent after the Atlanta-based provider of communications software said its eQueue Multi-Media Contact Center applications has received Defense Switched Network certification from the Defense Department. The company explained that eQueue is now cleared to connect to the agency's primary voice communications network. Shares of Firearms Training Systems Inc. FATS jumped more than 19 percent after it received a contract worth an estimated $1.7 million from the U.S. government to provide law-enforcement training systems to the Baghdad Police Academy. The Atlanta-based designer of virtual arms training systems said the contract calls for the provision of systems with multi-user configurations and judgmental scenarios for Iraqi security forces. FranklinCovey FC, -2.00% shares advanced more than 11 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter net loss narrowed to $4.2 million, or 21 cents a share, on lower costs, while revenue fell to $60.4 million as a result of store closures and fewer sales of handheld devices. Global ePoint Inc. GEPT soared more than 32 percent to $3.13 in afternoon action. After Monday's closing bell, the City of Industry, Calif.-based developer of homeland-security technology said it's optimistic about prospects for continued growth in 2005. Shares of I-Flow Corp. IFLO gained more than 3 percent after the company signed a national agreement for its InfuSystem oncology therapy delivery product with Aetna AET, -0.25% Financial terms weren't disclosed. Shares of Loudeye Corp. LOUD soared nearly 17 percent after the company said it was selected to provide content, encoding, watermarking and delivery services to support the launch of Music Choice's on-demand music video service for cable-television systems. Metal Storm Ltd. MTSX shares added more than 3 percent after the company said that its third-quarter loss widened to $1.8 million with revenue growing sharply to $1.1 million. The company also said it has about $13 million in cash and equivalents. Micromuse MUSE shares jumped more than 5 percent after the company said NTT Communications, a unit of Japan's NTT NTT, +2.02% had chosen its suite of products to provide a strategic infrastructure backbone. PacificNet Inc. PACT, +1.11% shares surged more than 18 percent on heavy volume, trading lately at $11.75, after the company said it has signed an agreement to become a distributor of China Netcom's CN, +2.33% mobile-phone products, prepaid calling cards and wireless and Internet services in the Chinese province of Shandong. Pfizer PFE, +0.54% shares gained nearly 2 percent after the company reaffirmed its 2004 net earnings outlook of $12 billion to $12.2 billion, or $1.58 to $1.60 a share. The pharmaceutical giant also said it still sees pro forma earnings of $16.1 billion to $16.3 billion, or $2.12 to $2.14 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of $2.13 a share. Shares of Red Hat RHAT shares leapt nearly 8 percent following an upgrade on the from Prudential Equity Group, which raised its rating on the Linux software company's stock to "overweight" from "neutral." Smithfield Foods SFD, +2.50% shares rose nearly 5 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $58.4 million, or 52 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit from continuing operations of $31.9 million, or 29 cents per share. Sales grew by 32 percent, propelled by strong pricing for live hogs. Stage Stores STGS gained nearly 4 percent after the company was selected to join the S&P SmallCap 600 index, replacing Information Holdings IHI, +1.55% which is being acquired by Thomson TOC, -2.88% Taser International Inc. TASR shares climbed nearly 8 percent after the company defended the safety of its stun-gun technology early Tuesday, taking issue with a report issued by Amnesty International that it said "refuses to accept independent and comprehensive reports concerning the safety and effectiveness of the Taser system." It was also the first trading session since the company's latest two-for-one stock split. Shares of Ultimate Electronics ULTE shares soared more than 33 percent to $3.02 after the Thornton, Colo.-based retailer of home-entertainment and consumer-electronics products signed supply agreements with eight U.S. construction companies. Financial terms weren't disclosed. See full story. United Natural Foods UNFI, +0.59% shares surged more than 9 percent after the company reported fiscal first-quarter earnings of $9.9 million, or 24 cents a share, up from $6.6 million, or 16 cents a share, excluding special items, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose 25 percent to $477.5 million from last year's $381.4 million, as growing demand for natural and organic products more than offset the negative impact of hurricanes in Florida and rising fuel prices. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 23 cents a share and revenue of $463.1 million, on average. Shares of Viisage Technology VISG rallied more than 8 percent after the company said it was selected to provide its face-recognition technology to Pakistan's passport and national identification program. Pakistan's ID program is one of the largest face-recognition projects to date with more than 40 million images. YM BioSciences Inc. YMI, +5.48% shares rose more than 4 percent after the company said its EGF receptor monoclonal antibody TheraCIM hR3 has been granted orphan-drug status for the treatment of brain cancer by the Food and Drug Administration. Decliners Allergan AGN, +1.59% shares traded off nearly 5 percent after the company said late Monday that it's working with state and federal health authorities to investigate reports that a couple who were hospitalized with botulism poisoning over the weekend received Botox injections at one of its facilities in Florida. American Equity Investment Life Holding Co. AEL, -0.07% lost nearly 7 percent after the company said it plans to raise $125 million through the sale of 20-year convertible notes. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of an additional $50 million worth of notes. Ameritrade Holdings AMTD, +3.49% shares slipped more than 2 percent after the company was initiated by Banc of America Securities with a "sell" rating. The firm told clients it's likely the online broker's share price will be constrained by falling commissions. Shares of Cray Inc. CRAY, +3.24% slid more than 15 percent after C.E. Unterberg Towbin lowered its 2005 earnings forecast for the company by a penny, to 9 cents per share, in reaction to the supercomputer maker's announced plans for a $60 million convertible debt offering. The firm said it thinks the offering reflects higher anticipated working-capital needs due to a shift in product mix. Elan ELN, +0.00% saw its U.S.-listed shares fell more than 3 percent after the company was downgraded by Deutsche Bank to "hold" from "buy." The broker cited potential risks related to Tysabri launch execution, adding that future Tysabri-related clinical data "could keep a ceiling on Elan shares given the stock's current premium valuation and lack of diversified revenue base at this point in time." FormFactor FORM, +1.11% shares sank more 4 percent after the company was downgraded by Piper Jaffray to "market perform" from "outperform" due to a lack of near-term catalysts. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT shares slumped more than 13 percent after the retailer lowered its fourth-quarter profit outlook to between 37 cents and 43 cents a share, down from its prior estimate of 49 cents to 52 cents. Same-store sales fell 8 percent in November. It said it expects same-store sales for the fourth quarter to fall from the year-ago period. Kintera Inc. KNTA shares skidded more than 10 percent after the company said institutional investors have agreed to buy 2.5 million common shares in a private placement priced at $7 each. Proceeds will be used for general corporate purposes, including funding the software provider's pending acquisition of American Fundware Inc. Qiao Xing Universal Telephone Inc. XING shares declined nearly 18 percent after the company said income from operations rose to $8.4 million for the first nine months of 2004, exceeding its total equivalent profit of $400,000 for the whole of 2003. Sales for the first nine months of 2004 totaled $199.7 million, compared to $222 million for all of 2004. The company also forecast a year-over-year sales increase of 30 percent for 2004. Syneron Medical Ltd. ELOS shares plunged more than 27 percent after the company was downgraded to "sector underperformer" from "sector outperformer" by CIBC World Markets, which cited concerns over the delay of the U.S. approval of its cellulite treating device and over valuation. The company said late Monday that it was asked by the Food and Drug Administration to resubmit its VelaSmooth application for pre-market approval, which CIBC believes might delay approval by a year. Winn-Dixie WIN, -2.08% shares lost more than 9 percent after the company was pulled from the S&P 500 index and replaced by Freescale Semiconductor FSL, -0.26% Winn-Dixie was selected because its market capitalization of $580 million was the last among the companies listed in the benchmark index. Freescale's shares rose more than 1 percent. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stocks ended lower Tuesday, but posted their best monthly gain for the year after a hitch-free presidential election sparked a broad-based rally in the market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average $INDU ended down 47.88 points, at 10,428.02. The benchmark index climbed 4 percent in November, but is still posting a loss on the year. Among the notable movers on the Dow, Wal-Mart WMT fell 2 percent and Home Depot HD dropped 2.8 percent on fears holiday sales may not live up to expectations. Intel INTC tumbled nearly 3 percent on investor jitters ahead of its midquarter trading update on Thursday. In a note to clients, Merrill Lynch said the chipmaker will likely stick with the midpoint of its previous financial targets. Pfizer Inc PFE was the biggest percentage gainer on the Dow, rising 1.6 percent after reiterating its 2004 earnings outlook, and offering a 2005 forecast within the current range of analyst estimates. The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ fell 10.06 points, to 2,096.81. The tech-rich index soared 6.2 percent on the month. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 Index $SPX fell 4.75 points, to 1,173.82, with the broad gauge putting in a 3.9 percent gain on the month. List of concerns weigh on sentiment Tuesday's action saw investors grappling with a series of conflicting economic reports, prompting investors to consolidate some of those gains made over the last month. A retreat in oil prices offered some comfort, but the weakness of the dollar raised fears the Federal Reserve may have to raise interest rates to contain inflation and keep dollar-denominated assets attractive to foreign investors. "The market is taking a little breather here while it digests a lot of this information, but it's not falling out of bed," said Edgar Peters, chief investment officer at Pan Agora. "I think it will come back again." Peters minimized the importance of an unexpected drop in the Conference Board's closely watched consumer confidence report. "Consumer confidence falling is probably tied to higher energy prices and it's not completely clear that is going to result in lower Christmas sales." The Conference Board reported U.S. consumers became more cautious in November. Its consumer confidence index fell to 90.5 points in November from a revised 92.9 in October. Economists had forecast the confidence index to rise to 95.7 in November Over at Miller Tabak, equity strategist Peter Boockvar was somewhat more cautious. "It's worrisome in the context of a holiday season. This is the wrong time of the year to see faltering consumer confidence." On the current weakness in bonds, Peters of Pan Agora said it could be seen as a positive factor for stocks. "Part of the rise in bond prices may be due to the fact that people are going to be selling their bonds and buying some stocks with them in the coming days," said Peters. Bonds came off lows as the mixed bag of economic reports lowered the odds of a pickup in the scope and size of future interest rate increases. The benchmark 10-year note ended down 9/32 at 99 4/32. Its yield rose to 4.36 percent from 4.32 percent Monday. See full story. Elsewhere, retailers were dealt a double blow as the weaker-than-expected consumer confidence reading followed on the heels of a survey appearing to point to a softer-than-expected start to the holiday shopping season. Citing consumers holding out for bargains and a drop-off in Saturday's customer traffic, U.S. retail chains' same-store sales fell 1.5 percent in the week ended Nov. 27 compared with the previous week, according to data from the International Council of Shopping Centers compiled with UBS. The S&P Retail Index $RLX which tracks the sector, fell nearly 2 percent. However, solid consumer spending was one factor in this morning's upward revision to U.S gross domestic product growth for the third quarter. The economy grew at a 3.9 percent annual rate in the quarter, slightly faster than the 3.7 percent estimated a month ago, the Commerce Department reported. The figure was in line with economist expectations. The Commerce Department said higher exports, business investments and consumer spending drove the revision. See full story. On a more upbeat note, business activity expanded more than expected in the Chicago region this month. The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index stood at 65.2 percent compared to forecasts for 62.8 percent. Readings over 50 percent denote expansion. Growth did cool somewhat from a 17-year high 68.5 percent in October. See full story. The report helped stocks bounce off lows sparked by disappointing consumer confidence data. See full story. Oil, dollar, gold Crude-oil futures fell back under $50 a barrel in nervous trading ahead of this week's updates on U.S. petroleum supplies. Nervous traders -- "running around like chickens with their heads cut off" -- are trying to decide which direction to go ahead of the U.S. inventory numbers due out Wednesday, according to Kevin Kerr, president of Kerr Trading International. Earlier, oil climbed to an intraday high of $50.40 after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries indicated it will "either lower production quotas or vow to roll back production to current quotas," said Phil Flynn, a senior analyst at Alaron Trading. "It appears the falling dollar has OPEC wanting the price of oil to go higher as compensation," he said. OPEC is set to meet on Dec. 10 in Cairo. The benchmark January contract ended at a one-week low, down 63 cents at $49.13 a barrel, and down 4.9 percent on the month. See full story. High energy prices are taking their toll on economic growth, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. The OECD lowered its 2005 economic growth forecasts for the U.S, Japan and the eurozone, saying the surge in oil prices has "depressed real incomes as well as confidence in the OECD countries." Read more The dollar hit a record low against the euro after the weaker-than-expected consumer confidence data. The dollar was down 0.1 percent with 1 euro at $1.3255, but was at $1.3335 in intraday trading. The buck recovered from early weakness against the yen, to trade up 0.2 percent, at 103.08. December gold fell $2.40 to close at $451.30 an ounce in New York, and February gold lost $2.60 to end at $453.20. But prices for the contracts still logged gains of around $22 for the month amid weakness in the U.S. dollar. Turning back to the broader market for equities, decliners outpaced advancers 19 to 13 on the New York Stock Exchange, and by a 17 to 14 count on the Nasdaq. Volume was 1.5 billion on the Big Board, and 1.8 billion on the Nasdaq. Stocks in focus Shares of Taser International Inc. TASR jumped as much as 9 percent after the company refuted criticism from human rights group Amnesty International that its stun gun is unsafe. Amnesty International said the company should suspend the sale of the gun, which it says has killed more than 70 people over the past three years. As its name implies, the gun is only supposed to stun an assailant. But Taser said several independent reviews have confirmed the gun has one of the safest use-of-force options open to the police. The company's stock was also getting a boost on the first day of trading after a 2-for-1 stock split. See full story. Meat processor Smithfield Foods SFD posted in-line second-quarter profit as sales jumped 32 percent from the same period a year ago. The company said its solid quarterly performance was the result of a 36 percent jump in live hog market prices, strong results from its turkey operations and a better performance from its international processing business. Shares in Smithfield Foods rose 4.1 percent to $29.05. Bank of New York BK is in talks with federal prosecutors to avert a possible criminal indictment on charges it failed to report suspicious activity at one of its branches, according to a published report. See full story. The bank's shares ended 0.2 percent lower. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: U.S. stocks end lower; month's gain is best this year

content: WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International Inc. rose Tuesday as the company issued a sharp response to criticism from human rights group Amnesty International. The stock TASR gained almost 9 percent to $27.73. It was the first day of trading after a 2-for-1 stock split, originally announced Nov. 4. The split was Taser's third of the year. Amnesty International questions the growing use of the company's stun gun technology by law enforcement officers. The group said more than 70 people have died during the past three years in the U.S. and Canada after being jolted by the devices. The comments are the latest in what's been a growing chorus of criticism of stun guns. Taser, of Scottsdale, Ariz., defended its technology as non-lethal, saying Amnesty "refuses to accept independent and comprehensive reports" on the safety of the devises. Though promoted as a safer alternative for subduing people considered dangerous, Tasers are routinely used against people who don't pose a serious threat, Amnesty International said. "They are frequently used in situations where use of firearms, or even batons, would never be justified." Amnesty said its analysis indicates "most of those who died were unarmed men who, while displaying disturbed or combative behavior, did not appear to present a serious threat to themselves or to the lives and safety of others." In some cases, the use of Tasers "has amounted to torture or cruel, inhuman and degradating treatment," Amnesty International said. It has requested that Taser use be suspended pending an independent inquiry into the effects, and that all officers be trained to use them only as a last resort. In response, Taser said Amnesty International is "out of step with law enforcement worldwide." "Amnesty has repeatedly called for independent testing while ignoring the mounting independent, comprehensive reports showing Taser technology is safe and effective," said CEO Rick Smith. Citing several independent reviews conducted recently in the U.S. and the U.K., Smith said they "clearly indicate that the Taser technology, while not risk-free, is among the safest use-of-force options our law-enforcement officers have." More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Don’t ever do this with your credit card This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition
title: Taser shares up despite Amnesty Intl criticism

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International Inc. tasr defended the safety of its stun gun technology early Tuesday, taking issue with a report issued by Amnesty International that it said "refuses to accept independent and comprehensive reports concerning the safety and effectiveness of the TASER system." The company added that: "Amnesty has repeatedly called for independent testing while ignoring the mounting independent comprehensive reports showing TASER technology is safe and effective." Taser noted that its technology has been independently reviewed by the United States Department of Defense Human Effects Center of Excellence, the United Kingdom's Defence Scientific Advisory Council, and a number of other governments, including Australia and Canada. The stock closed Monday at $50.92, up 8.3 percent.
title: Taser defends tech's safety against Amnesty Intl report

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stocks are likely to struggle to make gains early this week as investors wait to take their cue from a midquarter update by chip-making titan Intel Corp. on Thursday and the November jobs data due on Friday. Investors, who have watched equity markets rally by about 8 percent over the last month, were also likely to be concerned by high energy prices and a weakening dollar, strategists said. "It will come down to the payroll number," said Peter Boockvar, an equity strategist at Miller Tabak. "A good number started this rally and we'll see if there is any follow-through." October's jobs data, released early this month, showed the U.S. economy added 337,000 jobs last month, many more than expected. The big increase in payrolls followed months of disappointingly low job gains and investors will be looking to see whether October was a fluke or the start of a period of sustained growth. Analysts polled by CBS MarketWatch expect, on average, that the jobs report will show payrolls swelled by 201,000 in November. Analysts expect the unemployment rate will drop to 5.4 percent from 5.5 percent. Intel's INTC, +5.00% report was another factor likely to draw scrutiny for indications of how technology spending may develop for the rest of the year. The prospects for Intel, one of the most important tech bellwethers, helps set the tone for investors across the technology sector. The semiconductor sector has been struggling with sluggish demand, rising inventories and pressure on profit margins for months, and investors appear to have low expectations for Intel's report, said Michael Sheldon, chief market strategist for Spencer Clarke. "Going into the midquarter update, the bar has been set on the low side and investors aren't expecting a lot of good news," Sheldon said. "So if Intel were to say positive things about demand, margins and inventories, that could boost sentiment." Paul Mendelsohn, chief investment strategist for Windham Financial Services, said he agreed. "A lot of investors, large institutional investors, are sitting out there with at least a market weight in that sector, so you need some good news to push to the next stage of the rally," he said. On Friday, the major U.S. equity averages finished mixed with Wall Street trading desks sparsely manned for the shortened session after the Thanksgiving holiday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which has risen 5.3 percent since the start of the month, ended Friday at 10,522.23, a gain of almost 2 points for the day; for the week, the blue-chip gauge added 0.6 percent.. The Nasdaq Composite Index ended less than a point lower at 2,101.97 on Friday, but putting it up 1.5 percent on the week. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index, which has risen 4.4 percent since the start of the month, closed up slightly at 1,182.65 on Friday, a rise of more than 12 points and 1 percent for the week. With the third-quarter earnings season mostly on the books, profit growth is likely to come in at about 17 percent, according to data from Thomson First Call. Thomson said 488 of the S&P 500's companies have reported and that 62 percent have posted results above analyst expectations, 16 percent in line and 22 percent below forecasts, a typical quarter. Earnings preannouncement season has yet to start in earnest but First Call data show the negative-to-positive preannouncement ratio at 1.8 percent, above the 1.6 ratio at the point of the previous quarter but below the long-term 2.0 average. Data currently suggest a fourth-quarter earnings growth rate of 15 percent, Thomson First Call data show. Dollar, oil in focus Other than economic data and Intel's report, investors will be preoccupied with the level of the dollar and the price of oil, strategists said. The dollar has been trading near all-time lows against the euro and the yen, which helps corporate profits in the short term and can lift the stock market, but also imports inflation and can undermine the economy in the longer term, they said. While many expect the dollar to continue to drop in the near term, they said the manner of its decline could turn out to be important. "The major question is whether the dollar decline will be orderly or whether it will turn into a rout," Sheldon said. "If the decline is orderly, that could be positive for equities, but if it turns into a rout, it could be a major destabilizing effect for U.S. markets." Oil meanwhile stayed under $50 a barrel in the past week, and strategists said continued moderation would help the markets move higher. A slew of data Other than payrolls, investors this week will have to contend with several important economic reports, which will be closely watched for clues about economic performance as the year nears its end. "Next week we really get all of November's economic data and that is really going to set the tone of the market," Mendelsohn said. On Tuesday, investors will get a second reading of third-quarter gross domestic product, which analysts expect to be revised up slightly to 3.8 percent from the 3.7 percent earlier reading. Tuesday also brings the November Chicago Purchasing Management index, which is expected to have dropped to 62.4 percent from 68.5 percent in October. On Wednesday, the Institute of Supply Management will release its index for November, which is expected to have fallen to 56.5 percent from 56.8 percent. Data on October personal income and consumer spending is also due on Wednesday, with analysts forecasting a 0.5 percent rise in income after September's 0.2 percent gain. Spending for the month is expected to have risen by 0.4 percent after a 0.6 percent rise in September. Wednesday also brings data on October construction spending, which is expected to have risen by 0.7 percent after staying flat in September. Vehicle sales data is also due Wednesday. Thursday brings a government report on factory orders for October, which are expected to have risen by 0.4 percent after September's 0.4 percent decline. See Economic Preview. A trickle of earnings Only four S&P 500 companies are scheduled to report their earnings this week. On Wednesday Comverse Technology CMVT is expected to report a third-quarter profit of 7 cents per share on sales of $239 million, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Retailer Dollar General DG, +0.66% also reporting on Wednesday, is expected to post a third-quarter profit of 25 cents per share on revenue of $1.88 billion. On Thursday food and drug retailer Albertson's Inc ABS, +1.81% is expected to post earnings of 33 cents per share on sales of $10.13 billion. Pall Corp. PLL, -6.21% which makes industrial filters, is expected to report a fiscal first-quarter profit of 21 cents per share on revenue of $399 million. Friday's trading The major U.S. stock indexes finished the Friday session not far from where they started, with the lackluster benchmark moves belying strength in the broader market. "It's the small-cap stocks that are doing well. The big capitalization issues, which are really the darlings of the institutions, are a bit sluggish here," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. "I think the institutional players are completely absent; it's really retail demand here." Wall Street trading desks were sparsely manned in the post-holiday, abbreviated trading session that ended at 1 p.m. Eastern time. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% finished the day up 1.92 points at 10,522.23. The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ slipped 0.57 point to 2,101.97. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% added 0.89 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,182.65. Breadth was positive Friday, with Big Board winners outnumbering losers by a margin of nine to six, while on the Nasdaq advancers led decliners by 17 to 12. Underscoring the thin trading tone, volume was a paltry 501 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange and 668 million on the Nasdaq. Intel INTC, +5.00% down 1.7 percent, was the biggest decliner on the Dow, after the Semiconductor Industry Association said consumer electronics sales in the fourth quarter are expected to be about even with those of this year's third quarter, as high energy prices are holding back discretionary spending. Alcoa AA, +1.22% Altria Group MO, -0.21% Merck MRK, -1.13% and Pfizer PFE, +0.54% led blue-chip advancers. Also Friday, the dollar continued to fall to record levels vs. the euro, reaching as low as $1.3328 in overnight trading. Weighing on the greenback were reports that China's central bank had cut its U.S. Treasury holdings, due to concerns over the eroding value of the dollar. The dollar pared its pullback to 0.2 percent against the euro, changing hands at $1.3289, after a member of the monetary policy committee under the Chinese central bank said his remarks at a Shanghai seminar had been misinterpreted in a local newspaper article, a Xinhua Financial Network report said. Meanwhile, U.S. Treasurys fell on the speculation that the recently plummeting dollar might prompt foreign central banks to cut their investments in U.S. securities. "If that's true [reports of Chinese sales], you can see a further rise in interest rates, which would tend to disconcert equity buyers," said Metz. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note was down 10/32 at 100 3/32 to yield 4.24 percent in late trade. See Bond Report. Against the yen, the dollar hit an overnight low of 102.12, the lowest level seen in nearly five years, but recovered and was last up 0.1 percent at 102.58. See Currencies. "The market is not paying much attention to that [the weak dollar] for the moment, simply because of the fact that oil prices are not really getting out of hand," said Peter Cardillo, chief market analyst and strategist at S.W. Bach. Instead, he added, the market is focusing on what's expected to be a good holiday shopping season. Upbeat on retail outlook "Consumer feeling somewhat better than they have been over the past several months, the elections out of the way, a brighter job market and a strong stock market [are], I think, setting us up for a strong selling season," said Cardillo. Retail stocks were under the microscope on so-called "Black Friday" -- the official launch of the holiday shopping season. See related story. Trading among the retailers was mixed: Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% Home Depot HD, +1.99% Circuit City CC, +5.43% Best Buy BBY, +2.09% and Lowe's LOW, +2.18% were among those moving lower, while Sears S, +0.41% J.C. Penney JCP, -0.98% Costco COST, +2.63% and Saks SKS, +0.75% posted gains, among others. See Retail Stocks. Steel stocks were a bright spot, rallying on news that Japanese automaker Nissan Motor NSANY, -0.65% will have to cut production due to a shortage of steel materials. See Market Focus. Steelmakers were the beneficiaries. U.S. Steel X, +4.92% rose 7 percent, with Steel Dynamics STLD, +3.56% up 5 percent, Nucor NUE, +2.98% gaining nearly 6 percent, International Steel Group ISG, +0.27% rising 4.1 percent and AK Steel AKS, +5.84% rallying 14 percent. Elsewhere, Taser International TASR slid 7 percent after a New York Times report said that the laboratory that conducted research for the maker of stun guns disagreed with Taser's claims that the devices were safe. See full story. US Airways UAIRQ popped 23 percent, moving back above $1, as the stock was buoyed by news that the bankrupt carrier had struck leasing, financing and maintenance deals with two General Electric GE, -1.46% units that will provide $140 million in interim liquidity. title: U.S. stocks seen struggling for gains

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- The major U.S. stock indexes finished the Friday session not far from where they started, with the lackluster benchmark moves belying strength in the broader market. "It's the small-cap stocks that are doing well. The big capitalization issues, which are really the darlings of the institutions, are a bit sluggish here," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Co. "I think the institutional players are completely absent; it's really retail demand here." Wall Street trading desks were sparsely manned in the post-holiday, abbreviated trading session that ended at 1 p.m. Eastern time. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% finished the day up 1.92 points at 10,522.23. For the week, the blue-chip gauge added 0.6 percent. The Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ slipped 0.57 point to 2,101.97, putting it up 1.5 percent on the week. The S&P 500 Index SPX, +1.38% added 0.89 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,182.65. For the week, the S&P was 1.1 percent higher. Breadth was positive Friday, with Big Board winners outnumbering losers by a margin of nine to six, while on the Nasdaq advancers led decliners by 17 to 12. Underscoring the thin trading tone, volume was a paltry 501 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange and 668 million on the Nasdaq. Intel INTC, +5.00% down 1.7 percent, was the biggest decliner on the Dow, after the Semiconductor Industry Association said consumer electronics sales in the fourth quarter are expected to be about even with those of this year's third quarter, as high energy prices are holding back discretionary spending. Alcoa AA, +1.22% Altria Group MO, -0.21% Merck MRK, -1.13% and Pfizer PFE, +0.54% led blue-chip advancers. Also Friday, the dollar continued to fall to record levels vs. the euro, reaching as low as $1.3328 in overnight trading. Weighing on the greenback were reports that China's central bank had cut its U.S. Treasury holdings, due to concerns over the eroding value of the dollar. The dollar pared its pullback to 0.2 percent against the euro, changing hands at $1.3289, after a member of the monetary policy committee under the Chinese central bank said his remarks at a Shanghai seminar had been misinterpreted in a local newspaper article, a Xinhua Financial Network report said. Meanwhile, U.S. Treasurys fell on the speculation that the recently plummeting dollar might prompt foreign central banks to cut their investments in U.S. securities. "If that's true [reports of Chinese sales], you can see a further rise in interest rates, which would tend to disconcert equity buyers," said Metz. The benchmark 10-year Treasury note was down 10/32 at 100 3/32 to yield 4.24 percent in late trade. See Bond Report. Against the yen, the dollar hit an overnight low of 102.12, the lowest level seen in nearly five years, but recovered and was last up 0.1 percent at 102.58. See Currencies. "The market is not paying much attention to that [the weak dollar] for the moment, simply because of the fact that oil prices are not really getting out of hand," said Peter Cardillo, chief market analyst and strategist at S.W. Bach. Instead, he added, the market is focusing on what's expected to be a good holiday shopping season. Upbeat on retail outlook "Consumer feeling somewhat better than they have been over the past several months, the elections out of the way, a brighter job market and a strong stock market [are], I think, setting us up for a strong selling season," said Cardillo. Retail stocks were under the microscope on so-called "Black Friday" -- the official launch of the holiday shopping season. See related story. Trading among the retailers was mixed: Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% Home Depot HD, +1.99% Circuit City CC, +5.43% Best Buy BBY, +2.09% and Lowe's LOW, +2.18% were among those moving lower, while Sears S, +0.41% J.C. Penney JCP, -0.98% Costco COST, +2.63% and Saks SKS, +0.75% posted gains, among others. See Retail Stocks. Steel stocks were a bright spot, rallying on news that Japanese automaker Nissan Motor NSANY, -0.65% will have to cut production due to a shortage of steel materials. See Market Focus. Steelmakers were the beneficiaries. U.S. Steel X, +4.92% rose 7 percent, with Steel Dynamics STLD, +3.56% up 5 percent, Nucor NUE, +2.98% gaining nearly 6 percent, International Steel Group ISG, +0.27% rising 4.1 percent and AK Steel AKS, +5.84% rallying 14 percent. Elsewhere, Taser International TASR slid 7 percent after a New York Times report said that the laboratory that conducted research for the maker of stun guns disagreed with Taser's claims that the devices were safe. See full story. US Airways UAIRQ popped 23 percent, moving back above $1, as the stock was buoyed by news that the bankrupt carrier had struck leasing, financing and maintenance deals with two General Electric GE, -1.46% units that will provide $140 million in interim liquidity. title: U.S. stocks end mixed in thin post-holiday trading

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Intel and Taser International were among the companies whose shares were active following Friday's shortened holiday trading session. Shares of Intel INTC, +5.00% ticked higher in late trade. The world's largest chipmaker closed down 1.7 percent after the Semiconductor Industry Association said consumer electronics sales in the fourth-quarter are expected to be about even with those of the third quarter as high energy prices hold back discretionary spending. See full story. Intel stock was last changing hands for $23.25, up 4 cents. But shares of Taser TASR continued to lose ground on the heels of a New York Times report that raised new safety concerns about the stun-gun maker's main product line. See full story. Taser shares, which closed down $3.51, or 6.9 percent, at $47, fell to $46.75 after hours. In news released after Friday's closing bell, a subsidiary of Electronic Data Systems Corp. EDS has received a 10-year technology contract from the government of British Columbia, according to the province's revenue ministry. The contract's potential value is C$572 million. EDS Advanced Solutions will begin working in December to coordinate more than 40 revenue systems for the government. Shares of EDS ended the regular session down 4 cents at $22.06. They did not trade after the bell. The Nasdaq-100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks late trade in the technology sector, was down 0.23 points, or 0.01 percent. title: Intel, Taser Int'l move in after-hours trade

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of stun-gun maker Taser International tumbled Friday, hit by a New York Times report that raised new safety concerns about the company's main product line. Taser TASR shares ended down $3.51, or 7 percent, to $47 in Friday's abbreviated post-Thanksgiving Day session. The article in the New York Times, citing unpublished results of Air Force Research Laboratory tests, adds to a growing body of complaints over the use and safety of Taser's stun guns. According to the paper, the Air Force said at a symposium last week that Taser stun guns may be dangerous and require further testing. The Air Force's comments fly in the face of a recent federal study that called Taser's products "generally safe and effective." Company executives could not be reached for comment. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser markets its guns as nonlethal self-protection devices, with law enforcement agencies and security companies making up its biggest customer base. According to the company, its products send a nonlethal jolt of electricity to subdue the target body. But there has been a rash of complaints in recent months blaming Taser stun guns for accidental injuries, raising the specter of debilitating lawsuits. Taser shares have shed about 13 percent of their value in just the past two weeks. title: Taser stock slumps amid published safety concerns

content: Advancers Shares of AngioDynamics Inc. ANGO, +2.19% gained more than 10 percent after the Queensbury, N.Y.-based developer of medical products for vascular disease said its VenaCure endovenous laser ablation procedure was now covered by Anthem Inc. for the treatments of varicose veins. Calvary Bancorp CAVB shares added more than 10 percent after the company's board approved a nearly 17 percent increase in its quarterly dividend and declared a one-time cash dividend of $1.50 per share. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia MSO, +0.00% surged 13 percent, enough to make it the biggest percentage gainer on the NYSE. The stock reached a near 4-year high in intraday trading. Sprint Corp.'s FON, +5.56% shares rose almost 2 percent after its stock price target was raised by UBS to $27 from $24. The move was based on the belief that the company will focus on returning cash to shareholders, by way of a dividend increase and/or a stock buyback, once it reaches its net debt level target of $13 billion. United Therapeutics' UTHR, +1.68% stock leapt more than 10 percent after the company's hypertension drug Remodulin received approval for a second indication from the Food and Drug Administration. U.S. Steel X, +4.92% was among the steel stocks gaining ground Friday following news that Japanese auto maker Nissan plans to cut production due to a steel supply shortage, fueling hopes that metals prices in North America may be able to remain at their current elevated levels for some time. Other stocks getting a lift included AK Steel AKS, +5.84% Nucor NUE, +2.98% Steel Dynamics STLD, +3.56% Allegheny Technologies ATI, +3.91% and International Steel Group ISG, +0.27% See full story. Decliners BindView Corp. BVEW shares slipped more than 5 percent after the company said that it has received a delisting notice from the Nasdaq and an 'E' will be added to its ticker, effective Friday. BindView failed to file its third-quarter financial report with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, because it said it has been investigating revenue recognition practices in its Latin American operations. Bindview plans to request a hearing with the Nasdaq panel. Delcath Systems DCTH, -9.45% fell more than 14 percent after the Stamford, Conn., company said it had completed a $2 million private placement of common stock and warrants. Genta Inc. GNTA shares plunged more than 20 percent after the company said a phase III trial of its Genasense injection treatment for patients with advanced multiple myeloma failed to meet its primary endpoint. The trial was set up to evaluate whether adding Genasense to standard therapy would increase the time to development of progressive disease in patients who had previously received extensive therapy. See full story. Lexar Media Inc. LEXR shares fell almost 3 percent after the company filed a $200 million shelf registration with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and will use proceeds for general corporate purposes. Nastech Pharmaceuticals NSTK shares fell more than 3 percent after it announced that it plans to offer 4.25 million shares under an effective shelf registration. Shares of Taser International Inc. TASR slid almost 5 percent after a New York Times article published Friday stoked fears about the safety of the company's stun gun products. The article said a government study, whose full results have yet to be released, found the guns could be dangerous and that more data was needed to evaluate the risks of their use. Taser, however, said last month that the study found its guns were safe. See full story. content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. tasr sank more than 6 percent to $47.43 in early trades after a New York Times article published Friday stoked fears about the safety of the company's stun gun products. The article said a government study, whose full results have yet to be released, found the guns could be dangerous and that more data was needed to evaluate the risks of their use. Taser, however, said last month that the study found its guns were safe.
title: Taser shares tumble on NYT article

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stock futures ticked higher early Friday, but gains were tentative given overnight weakness in overseas bourses and concerns over the continued slide in the dollar to record lows. Volume was very light, however, and was expected to remain well below average throughout the shortened session as a dearth of corporate and economic news provided little incentive for the skeleton crews manning Wall Street trading desks to get involved on the day after the Thanksgiving holiday. The U.S. stock markets were scheduled to close at 1:00 p.m. ET. December S&P 500 futures tacked on 1.20 to 1,183.10 and the Nasdaq 100 futures gained 4.00 to 1,586.50. The "Diamonds" DIA, +1.31% a tracking stock for the Dow Jones Industrials Average, was up 6 cents at $105.09 in Instinet pre-open trading. Among stocks seeing early activity, Intel INTC, +5.00% erased earlier gains to inch a nickel lower to $23.56 in Instinet. The Semiconductor Industry Association said worldwide chip sales in October increased 22 percent over the same period a year ago to $18.8 billion, and rose 1.5 percent from September. Consumer electronics sales in the fourth-quarter are expected to be about even with those of the sequential third quarter, the SIA said, as high energy prices hold back discretionary spending. Within the chip equipment makers, Applied Materials AMAT, +2.87% was up 7 cents at $17.03 and KLA-Tencor KLAC, +2.29% was unchanged at $45.98 in Instinet. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% climbed 22 cents, or 3.2 percent, to $7.20 in Instinet after the air carrier said late Wednesday that it had signed agreements with aircraft lessors and lenders under which it expects to receive $57 million in concessions a year from 2005 to 2009. In exchange, Delta issued 4.4 million common shares. Online retailers appeared set to post gains on what is typically the busiest shopping day of the year. Amazon AMZN, +1.11% added 23 cents to $38.98 and Overstock.com OSTK, -0.96% gained 90 cents to $63.25. Home improvement retailer and Dow component Home Depot HD, +1.99% edged up 3 cents to $43.46. Taser International TASR shed $2.86, or 5.7 percent, to $47.65. A report in the New York Times reported that while the company said results of a government study showed that its electrical guns were safe, the laboratory that conducted the research now says that the guns could be dangerous and that more data was needed to evaluate the risks. Elsewhere, Google GOOG, +2.71% gained 64 cents to $175.40, Sirius Satellite SIRI, +1.05% shed 2 cents to $6.23 and Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% edged up 7 cents to $19.28. Steel stocks were poised to garner some early interest as the sector enjoyed strong gains in Asia on concerns that regional demand might outstrip supply. U.S. Steel X, +4.92% was $1.29, or 2.7 percent better, at $49.24 in light volume. Japan's Nissan Motor NSANY, -0.65% said overnight that it would suspend operations at three of its four domestic factories for a total of five days over the next two weeks due to the steel shortage. Read more. Elsewhere, SuperValu SVU, -1.42% was downgraded to "neutral" from "buy" by UBS, and Sprint Corp. FON, +5.56% had its stock price target raised to $27 from $24 by UBS. The dollar continued to fall to record levels vs. the euro, reaching $1.3328 in overnight trading. Weighing on the buck were reports that the Chinese central bank had cut its U.S. Treasury holdings due to concerns over the eroding value of the dollar. The dollar bounced slightly from its lows, and was last trading up 0.2 percent against the euro at $1.3243, after a member of the monetary policy committee under the Chinese central bank said his remarks at a Shanghai seminar had been misinterpreted in a local newspaper report, a Xinhua Financial Network report said. See Currencies. Against the yen, the dollar hit an overnight low of 102.12, the lowest level seen in nearly 5 years, but was last up 0.5 percent at 102.96. The major stock indexes in London and Europe gave back some of the healthy gains seen on Thursday. Among notable decliners were Shell Trading and Transport SC, +1.62% in London and Royal Dutch RD in Europe, which slipped after warning that the release of 2004 financials might have to be delayed. title: U.S. stock futures lean to the upside

content: Advancers ArvinMeritor ARM, +3.57% shares gained more than 7 percent Monday after the Troy, Mich.-based maker of motor vehicle parts reported a fourth-quarter profit before items of $37 million, or 54 cents per share, 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Dawson Geophysical DWSN, +5.15% shares gained more than 21 percent after the Midland, Texas-based provider of seismic data reported fourth-quarter earnings of 72 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of 10 cents a share. The latest results include a gain of 28 cents a share related to a deferred-income tax benefit. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 39 cents a share in the September period. Shares of DPL DPL, -3.00% advanced 6 percent after Lehman Brothers raised its rating on the Dayton, Ohio-based energy company to "overweight" from "equal weight," and raised its price target to $30 from $22. Empire Resorts NYNY, +4.23% shares vaulted more than 22 percent after the company agreed to acquire the Concord and Grossinger's resort hotels and golf courses from Concord Associates and an affiliate for 18 million Empire shares and the assumption of debt. Independence Air FLYI shares soared more than 53 percent after the company amended its purchase agreement with Airbus for the delivery of aircraft. The struggling low-fare carrier said the deal assists "in the company's efforts to address its liquidity requirements," according to a regulatory filing. Independence Air last week defaulted on a $8.7 million payment to Airbus. The airline still must reduce or defer a separate $83 million aircraft payment due in January or face the possibility of bankruptcy. Shares of Instinet Group INGP gained more than 12 percent after the electronic broker-dealer received an upgrade from Merrill Lynch to "buy" from "neutral." The firm, which set a $6 price target on the stock, said Instinet "is a play on higher volumes and we are heading into the seasonal strong period, which we expect to be a favorable near-term catalyst and drive valuation." LMI Aerospace LMIA shares skyrocketed 198 percent after the St. Louis maker of aluminum and alloy components for aerospace and technology usage reported third-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 14 cents per share, up significantly from its year-ago loss of $644,000 or 8 cents a share in the same period a year earlier. Sales rose in the latest three months to $23 million from $17.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of MarketWatch MKTW rose 8 percent, after Deutsche Bank newspaper analyst Paul Ginocchio wrote in a note to clients that the $520 million acquisition of the company by Dow Jones DJ "looks relatively attractive based on MarketWatch's position in financial news, its recent growth rate and compared to other recent deals." MarketWatch is the publisher of this report. Micromuse MUSE gained 21 percent after the San Francisco provider of business software reported pro forma earnings of $5.4 million, or 7 cents per share, for the fourth quarter, 6 cents ahead of the average estimate of 10 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Shares of Pixar Animation Studios PIXR jumped more than 5 percent on the news that the company's animated film "The Incredibles" remained at the top of the box-office chart for the second week in a row, despite the debut of another animated feature, "The Polar Express," by Warner Bros. Red Hat RHAT shares surged more than 13 percent after the company's stock was upped by First Albany to buy from neutral and set a $15 price target. Regal-Beloit RBC, +4.86% shares gained 10 percent after the company said it's agreed to pay $379 million for GE Consumer & Industrial's motors and capacitors business. With this product line, the General Electric GE, -1.46% unit serves the heating, ventilation, air-conditioning and refrigeration markets. SuperGen SUPG shares jumped more than 9 percent after the company received approval of its abbreviated new drug application for its Paclitaxel injection in a number of dosages from the Food and Drug Administration. SuperGen said the injection is the identical to Taxol, a cancer treatment produced by Bristol-Myers Squibb BMY, +1.09% Synergy Brands' SYBR, +0.00% shares soared more than 42 percent after the Melville, N.Y.-based seller of premium cigars and other consumer products narrowed its loss for the third quarter amid a 34 percent year-over-year increase in revenue. The company posted a loss of $170,230, or 8 cents per share, an improvement over its year-ago loss of $627,923 or 34 cents a share. Shares of Taser International TASR rose 6 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based provider of advanced nonlethal devices said its stun-gun technology was approved for trials by the South Korean National Police Agency. The Korean National Police Agency has decided to evaluate the Taser X26 device for general duty officers, following successful trials as a new nonlethal device. The initial order of 100 X26 devices ships in the current quarter Tower Group TWGP shares advanced almost 2 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 43 cents per share, up from $2 million or 36 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $26.5 million, compared with $20.5 million in 2003. Tower Semiconductor TSEM, +1.09% shares climbed more than 5 percent after the company said it plans to cut 170 jobs, or 12 percent of its employees, in an effort to produce annual savings of $20 million in 2005. The Israeli chip group said it was responding to recent financial results and an industry-wide inventory correction and slowdown. It reiterated its goal of reaching positive earnings before excluding items by the second half of 2005. Shares of Tripos TRPS soared more than 20 percent after the St. Louis-based provider of drug discovery technology announced a multimillion-dollar, multiyear extension of its global software license agreement with Pfizer PFE, +0.54% Tripos' discovery software is used to manage, analyze and share biological and chemical information. Further financial details were not disclosed. Shares of William Lyon Homes WLS rose more than 22 percent after the Newport Beach, Calif.-based home builder increased its buyback program to 3 million common shares. The company's previous authorization was for the repurchase of up to 20 percent of its outstanding stock, or roughly 2 million shares. As part of the increased authorization, the company bought back 1.3 million shares. Decliners AFC Enterprises AFCE shares slid 5 percent Monday after the company, which owns the Popeye's and Church's chicken restaurant franchises, said after the bell Friday that it swung to a third-quarter loss of $1.9 million, or 7 cents per share, from a profit of $3.8 million or 13 cents a share in the year-ago period. AFC attributed the loss to discontinued operations of $5.4 million related to the sale of the Cinnabon retail business. Shares of Astea International ATEA, +4.00% tumbled more than 14 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after the Horsham, Pa.-based service management software provider reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $155,000, or 5 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent loss of $1.5 million or 54 cents a share. Revenue rose to $4 million, up from its year-ago equivalent of $2.8 million for the third quarter. Shares of EGL EAGL, +0.00% lost more than 7 percent after J.P. Morgan lowered its assessment of the stock to "neutral" from "overweight" due to valuation. The firm said that the shares have appreciated more than 100 percent since late March, and added that it believes the turnaround in the Houston-based shipping company's business has already been priced into the stock. Shares of Kinross Gold KGC, +1.80% fell more than 5 percent after the Toronto gold and silver mining and processing company revised its third-quarter results to a loss of $133.6 million from earnings of $9.4 million. The change reflects a $143 million reduction of goodwill tied to its Paracatu mine in Brazil. Shares of Marisa Christina MRSA, +0.00% dropped more than 24 percent after the New York-based women's clothing maker reported a third-quarter loss of $5.8 million, or 79 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $1.1 million or 15 cents a share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Northeast Utilities NU, -7.41% shares sank 10 percent after the company lowered its outlook for 2005 to earnings of $1.10 to $1.25 per share from its previous forecast for a profit of $1.35 to $1.45 per share. For 2004, the Berlin, Conn.-based utility company still expects earnings of $1.25 to $1.35 a share. The company cited anticipated weakness in its New England wholesale business for the lower outlook. Overstock.com OSTK, -0.96% shares fell 5 percent after the company said it plans to raise about $75 million in gross proceeds by privately placing senior convertible notes. The company said it expects to use the net proceeds from the offer for working capital requirements and general corporate purposes. Via Net.Works VNWI shares dropped more than 5 percent after the company, which provides business Internet services, said late Friday that it narrowed its third-quarter loss to $4.6 million, or 8 cents per share, from $7.6 million or 13 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter was $18.2 million vs. $10.7 million a year earlier. The company said it continues to expect that it will generate positive cash flow from operations by mid-2005. Fourth-quarter revenue is expected to be between $24 million and $26 million. content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International Inc. tasr rose almost 5 percent to $60.17 after the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based provider of advanced non-lethal devices said its stun-gun technology was approved for trials by the South Korean National Police Agency. The Korean National Police Agency has decided to evaluate the TASER X26 device for general duty officers following successful trials as a new non-lethal device. The initial order of 100 TASER X26 devices ships in the current quarter.
title: Taser jumps on South Korean trial

content: Just two weeks into November and insider-purchasing levels are 71 percent of October's total. Exercises for the week ended Nov. 12, were 124 percent of October's total and sales were 113 percent, according to research from Thomson Financial. Although sellers outpaced acquirers more than 3-to-1 by Thomson's calculations, it is early in the month and sales are only 1.8 times greater than the amount exercised. Among high-level insider trades, one of the largest deals came from Phillips Smith, chairman of Taser International TASR who sold more than 1 million shares Nov. 9 and Nov. 10 at a market value of $53.6 million, according to a filing from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Don Blankenship, chief executive of Massey Energy Co. MEE, +1.42% sold 895,670 shares acquired through the exercise of options Nov. 10 and Nov. 11 at a market value of more than $25.7 million. This is the largest sale the company has seen. Forest Laboratories FRX, -1.85% saw CEO Howard Solomon sell 675,000 shares valued at $29.3 million. This is the largest sale the New York developer of pharmaceutical drugs has seen since Solomon sold 1.3 million shares in February. James Crane, the chief executive of EGL EAGL, +0.00% made the largest sale the Houston transportation services company has seen in nearly three years, selling 600,000 shares of company stock on Tuesday, Nov. 9 at a market value of $19.8 million. For insider purchases and sales for the week ending Nov. 12, some of the top individual buyers included Kevin McGrath of Digital Angel DOC, +0.97% Kerry Killinger of Washington Mutual WM, +1.13% William Knight of Bruker Biosciences Corp. BRKR, +0.88% and Grover Wrenn at Strategtic Diagnostics SDIX Nearly 15.4 million shares were sold on the high-level insider level at a market value of nearly $580 million for the week ending Nov. 12, up from the nearly 14.4 million shares at a market value of more than $380.3 million the previous week. title: Insider activity up in November

content: Advancers Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% shares climbed almost 8 percent Thursday after the company received an upgrade from Merrill Lynch to "buy" from "neutral." "We believe that AMD is in the midst of a microprocessor product cycle that should allow the company to continue expanding profit margin and gaining market share against Intel for at least another year," Merrill told clients. Blockbuster BBI, +4.00% shares advanced more than 11 percent after the company confirmed it's interested in acquiring Hollywood Entertainment HLYW for $11.50 per share in cash, or roughly $1 billion. Shares of Hollywood Entertainment rose almost 11 percent. See full story. GenCorp GY shares soared more than 23 percent after the company received a cash offer by Steel Partners II to be bought for $17 per share, a premium of 20 percent over its Wednesday closing price of $14.15 a share. The deal would value the Sacramento, Calif.-based defense contractor and real estate firm at about $772 million. See full story. Shares of biotechnology firm Genelabs Technologies GNLB surged more than 7 percent after the company said it had received a $750,000 milestone payment from GlaxoSmithKline GSK, -0.79% for a hepatitis E vaccine that Glaxo has been developing using Genelabs' vaccine technology. Genelabs has licensed its technology to Glaxo to develop and commercialize hepatitis E vaccines. Shares of Innodata Isogen INOD, +6.47% advanced more than 10 percent after the New York content technology company reported third-quarter earnings of $3.1 million, or 13 cents per share, more than doubling its year-ago earnings of $1.5 million or 6 cents a share. Revenue jumped 42 percent in the latest three months to $15.9 million, from $11.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Intel INTC, +5.00% shares gained more than 1 percent after the company said it has named Paul Otellini chief executive, replacing Craig Barrett, effective at the chip giant's annual meeting on May 18. Otellini currently serves as president and chief operating officer. Barrett, for his part, will succeed Andrew Grove as chairman of the board. Grove will serve as a senior adviser to the board and senior management. See full story. Shares of Kent Financial Services KENT, -0.14% soared almost 41 percent after the Bedminster, N.J.-based financial services company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $739,000, or 26 cents per share, up from a loss of $204,000 or 6 cents a share for the same period a year ago. Results for the three months ended Sept. 30 include a pretax gain of $845,000 from the sale of property. Thomson First Call does not publish an earnings estimate for the company. Revenue rose to $972,000 from $351,000 in the same period a year ago. Shares of Kmart KMRT gained more than 3 percent after the company topped the $100 mark Thursday -- 18 months after emerging from Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Kmart shares peaked at $100.85 before easing to $100.35, up $1.26. Much of the gain in Kmart shares has been attributed to the unlocked value of the company's real estate. Shares of Provide Commerce PRVD rose almost 31 percent after the San Diego-based provider of e-commerce services for perishable goods reported a first-quarter pro forma loss of $189,000, or 2 cents per share, narrower than Wall Street's consensus estimate for a loss of 7 cents a share. Rand Capital RAND, +2.28% shares vaulted more than 96 percent in morning action. In regulatory filings for the third quarter late Wednesday, the company said it believes its cash and cash equivalents of $1.1 million as of Sept. 30, as well as its anticipated SIBC leverage drawdowns and interest and dividend payments on its portfolio investments, will provide the liquidity necessary to fund operations for the next 12 months. Rayovac ROV, +0.00% shares gained more than 12 percent after the company posted a 41 percent rise in fourth-quarter earnings and a 50 percent jump in sales, helped by its purchase of Remington Products, improved battery sales and favorable foreign exchange rates, as well as restructuring and cost improvement initiatives. See full story. Shares of Taser International TASR rose more than 5 percent after the weapons maker said it debuted a new XP air cartridge with 25-foot maximum range. US LEC CLEC shares surged almost 6 percent after the company agreed to acquire the assets of StarNet, a privately held dial-up Internet access provider that has filed for bankruptcy protection in Illinois. US LEC expects the deal to increase earnings almost immediately with the addition of almost 400 new customers and more than $7 million in annual revenue. Whole Foods Market WFMI shares advanced more than 9 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter profit rose 27 percent to $30.2 million, or 46 cents per share, from $23.8 million or 38 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $927.3 million vs. $750.7 million a year earlier. It affirmed 2005 sales growth figures in the range of 15 percent to 20 percent and said same-store sales should increase 8 percent to 10 percent from the year-ago period. See full story. Decliners Air Methods AIRM shares slid almost 8 percent Thursday after the company said third-quarter net income fell 46.1 percent to $1.5 million, or 13 cents per share, compared to prior-year net income of $2.7 million or 27 cents a share. Amedisys AMED, +0.20% shares lost almost 6 percent in afternoon action. The move comes after Legg Mason lowered its rating on the Baton Rouge, La.-based provider of home health-nursing services to "hold" from "buy," citing valuation. Shares of ArthroCare ARTC gave back more than 5 percent after UBS downgraded the medical devices maker to "neutral" from "buy" on valuation grounds. Catapult Communications CATT shares slumped more than 7 percent after the company said its Chief Executive and President Richard Karp and director Nancy Karp are selling 950,000 company shares in an underwriting offering for a shelf registration statement that was previously filed with regulators. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% shares lost almost 1 percent after the company adjusted its long-term growth targets, forecasting volume growth of 3 percent to 4 percent and operating income growth of 6 percent to 8 percent. Coke said the long-term growth targets don't apply to 2005 and that its outlook for the rest of 2004 remains the same. The soft drink giant also forecasted weakness in key markets of North America, the Philippines and Germany in 2005. See full story. Covad Communications COVD shares gave up more than 5 percent after the company said Chief Financial Officer Mark Richman resigned to pursue other career interests. Susan Crawford, head of planning and priorities management, replaced him as acting finance officer. Richman will stay with Covad until Nov. 24 to help with the transition, according to the company. Shares of Ctrip.com International CTRP, +0.97% slipped almost 7 percent to $45.38 after the consolidator of hotel accommodations and airline tickets in China reported a weak outlook for the fourth quarter. The company said while the fourth quarter will be weaker than the third quarter due to seasonality, it is forecasting a similar level of net revenues. Ctrip estimates its net revenues for the fourth quarter of 2004 at 90.2 million yuan to 91 million yuan ($10.9 million to $11 million). Cyberonics CYBX shares sank almost 5 percent after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $2 million, or 8 cents per share, vs. the year-ago earnings of $4 million or 15 cents a share. Revenue for the quarter was $25.4 million, compared with $29.3 million in 2003. See full story. Shares of FuelCell Energy FCEL, +0.58% slumped more than 12 percent after the Danbury, Conn.-based fuel-cell power plant manufacturer said late Wednesday it plans to sell $75 million of series B preferred stock. Shares of Geron GERN, +0.47% fell almost 4 percent in morning trade after the company agreed to sell 6.5 million shares of its common stock to institutional investors at $6.10 a share. The company expects the offering to yield gross proceeds of $40 million. Shares of Global Sources GSOL tumbled more than 17 percent after the New York-based business-to-business media company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $3 million, or 10 cents per share, up from $2 million or 7 cents a share for the same period a year ago. Revenue rose slightly to $23.6 million in the latest three months, up from $22.9 million for the same period a year ago. The company said it wasn't satisfied with "modest" top-line growth, which it attributed to weaker than expected revenue from its print and online businesses. Green Mountain Coffee GMCR shares lost nearly 1 percent after the Waterbury, Vt.-based coffee merchant offered a disappointing outlook for the first quarter, forecasting a profit of 32 cents to 37 cents per share. Wall Street's consensus estimate is for earnings of 41 cents a share in the December quarter. Shares of Integrated Electrical Services IES, +0.00% slid more than 43 percent after the company said current weak conditions in the surety industry are adversely impacting its ability to secure surety bonding consistent with historical terms. The company added that it plans to limit its use of bonds on projects that don't meet certain financial criteria. It has secured $60 million in bonds in the past 90 days but the terms have become "increasingly unattractive." See full story. Shares of NBTY NTY, +0.00% sank more than 6 percent after Adams Harkness downgraded its rating on the Bohemia, N.Y.-based nutritional supplement manufacturer to "market perform" from "buy" and lowered its price target to $27 from $29. Nortel Networks NT tumbled almost 6 percent after the company said that it will again delay its quarterly results, citing revenue accounting problems. The company also said its shares could be suspended and eventually delisted by the New York Stock Exchange if its annual report is not filed by Dec. 15. Canadian regulators also could suspend trading because of the delays, according to Nortel. See full story. PeopleSoft PSFT, +0.00% shares slipped almost 2 percent after the company spurned Oracle's $24 a share takeover offer worth $8.8 billion. PeopleSoft also forecast fourth-quarter pro forma earnings of 20 cents to 22 cents a share. Analysts expect a profit of 20 cents a share and sales of $724 million. Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum downgraded the stock to "underperform" vs. "market perform" on the news. See full story. Shares of Pep Boys PBY, -2.02% tumbled almost 8 percent after the automotive retailer reported third-quarter earnings that, on a per-share basis, were half of what analysts expected. Plato Learning TUTR shares sank almost 9 percent after the company said Chief Financial Officer Greg Melsen resigned to accept a similar position at a life sciences company. Larry Betterley was named finance officer. Plato also forecast fourth-quarter revenue of about $41 million to $43 million and cut its 2004 revenue forecast to $140 million to $142 million from its previous forecast of $143 million to $147 million. See full story. Prime Realty Group PGE, +0.00% shares dropped 7 percent after the company said its plan to be purchased by Prime/Mansur Investment Partners was terminated because Prime/Mansur failed to obtain a financing commitment. Shares of Pure World PURW sank more than 17 percent after the Bedminster, N.J.-based manufacturer of botanical products reported a third-quarter loss that widened from a year ago as weak margins offset higher sales. The company added that $7 million of its total sales of $10.9 million in the latest quarter were of a single product to a single customer, and it offered no assurance that sales of this product will continue or that business with this customer will be significant in the future. Tiffany & Co. TIF, -0.38% shares fell more than 5 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $20.8 million, or 14 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $28 million or 19 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 19 cents a share in the September period. The company said it saw weaker than expected sales in Japan and through its direct marketing channel in the quarter, and that higher precious metal and diamond costs hurt gross margins. See full story. VCampus VCMP, +222.58% shares plunged more than 28 percent after the company said its loss widened to $1.77 million, or 24 cents per share, from a loss of $718,000 or 16 cents a share in the year-ago period. Revenue dropped to $917,000 from $1.4 million. V.I. Technologies VITX shares lost more than 13 percent after the company said it received notification from Nasdaq that it is in jeopardy of being delisted for falling below the minimum $10 million shareholder equity threshold. It must submit a compliance plan by Nov. 19. WebMethods WEBM shares declined more than 8 percent after the company said it delayed filing of its fiscal second-quarter financials while it completes an internal investigation involving an international subsidiary. Washington Group International WGII shares fell more than 2 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $12.3 million, or 45 cents per share, compared with $12.8 million or 51 cents a share a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $715 million, up from $588 million in 2003.
