title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International tasr rose 6 percent to $58.01 in pre-market trade Thursday after the weapons maker said it debuted a new XP air cartridge with 25-foot maximum range. The Scottsdale, Ariz. company said the XP air cartridge is "able to achieve distances of up to 25 feet while maintaining a truer flight trajectory by maximizing probe stability."
title: Taser up 6% premarket after product news

content: Mark Hulbert continues to find himself at odds with loyal VIX followers. At the urging of readers, he reviewed the S&P 500-to-VIX ratio used by many market timers -- but his results still make him a skeptic. Gold's steady move higher over the last several months doesn't seem to have made much of an impression on the gold bugs tracked by the Hulbert Financial Digest, reports Peter Brimelow, citing the Hulbert Gold Newsletter Sentiment Indicator. But Michael Ashbaugh says there's good reason to be bullish on stocks for the long term. Last week, Herb Greenberg had the scoop on Sears when he was the first to report on Vornado Realty Trust's investment in the retailer. Now it appears that Vornado may have more of an interest in the land under the stores than the stores themselves. And with 76 million baby boomers marching toward retirement, Robert Powell examines stocks poised to benefit from the graying population. In The Guru's Corner, DRIP Investor's Charles Carlson talks about how new investors can avoid high broker fees by buying stocks through dividend reinvestment plans and now that the election's a memory, Jack Rothstein of Wealthcast names four tech picks poised to benefit post-election. In newsletter news, Steiner Leisure sails steadily and Louis Navellier's MPT Review gets a makeover. Samantha Soga, Newsletter Assistant Subscribe: Investment Newsletter Insights THE GURU'S CORNER www.guruscorner.com DRIP Investor For investors who may be long on investment "want to" but short on start-up cash, it's possible to buy stocks on the "installment plan" using dividend reinvestment plans. -- Charles Carlson Wealthcast Technology is without a doubt the place to be right now. --Jack Rothstein NEWSLETTERS & RESEARCH www.hulbertdigest.com Hope springs eternal Can the VIX be resurrected as a contrarian stock market timing indicator? -- Mark Hulbert Subscribe: Hulbert Interactive Gold's critical level Gold trends higher since May but fails to attract much enthusiasm. --Peter Brimelow Subscribe: The Hulbert Financial Digest What Vornado has in store Rarely a passive investor, Vornado Realty Trust's stake in Sears is hardly just a simple investment. -- Herb Greenberg Subscribe: Herb Greenberg's RealityCheck Long-term bullish With the massive 10-day rally, the markets are near-term extended but long-term bullish. Stocks on the MikeWatch: Smith International SII, +0.97% Cooper Cameron CAM, -1.67% Schlumberger SLB, +2.48% Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% Southwest Airlines LUV, +1.83% Alaska Air Group ALK, +0.63% Novell NOVL Nextel Partners NXTP Taser International TASR Talbots TLB, -5.71% and CMGI CMGI Subscribe: The Technical Indicator Gray and green Some stocks could benefit from the aging population. -- Robert Powell Subscribe: Retirement Weekly No day at the spa Steiner Leisure STNR enticed two newsletter editors by exceeding analysts' earnings expectations for 10 consecutive quarters -- but that doesn't mean they don't have some caveats. Steiner, which operates spas on 114 cruise ships for major cruise operators, as well as land-based spas at 64 resorts, upheld this impressive record despite dour third-quarter cruise ship earnings following four Florida hurricanes. Upside, which initiated coverage of Steiner in June, noted in an August upgrade report that Steiner's growth prospects could be impacted by cruise operators opting to supplant Steiner with their own in-house spa services. "One potential fly in the ointment is increased competition from cruise operators," said editor Richard Moroney. "Late last year, select ships of Princess Cruises began offering their own in-house spa service," Moroney noted. Similarly, Motley Fool Rule Breakers' contributor Rick Munarriz, who initiated coverage in November, also cited concerns: "The (economic) moat is a concern because there is nothing to keep a land-based rival- or the cruise companies themselves- from trying to replace Steiner at sea," Munarriz observed. But Steiner may have been able to stave off its first real competition. In a Rule Breakers update last week, editor David Gardner mentioned Steiner's response to a rumor that the manager of Princess Cruises' in-house spa services had resigned. "Without confirming the report, Steiner said its Princess spas were outperforming the in-house Princess spa services, and that Steiner would be eager to jump in if Princess pulls the plug on its in-house efforts," Gardner said. On the Motley Fool message boards, Munarriz speculated that "If all this plays out that way (which is probably more theory and conjecture at this point) you have a public example of a company that tried to go in-house, but is not happy with the results. That should scare away others from trying," said Munarriz. That could allow Steiner's investors to shift their concerns back to the long-term fundamentals of the cruise ship industry. Steiner's symbiotic relationship with cruise ship operators means that, as Munarriz describes it, "A half-empty sailing will translate into a half-empty appointment book at the spa." --Ari Charney Order: HFD Newsletter Performance Profiles R.I.P. for MPT banner After 25 years, the MPT Review gets a new name and format. MPT was an acronym for Modern Portfolio Theory. Editor Louis Navellier feels that the title "Emerging Growth" better reflects the newsletter's new focus. Starting in January, Navellier will drop the current 12 model portfolios -- which new customers "found confusing" -- in favor of one large buy list, similar to the format of his sister publication, the Blue Chip Growth Letter. Navellier said his overall goal was to make the strategy easier to implement. He also confessed that commission costs have fallen so dramatically, that it is less important to have different model portfolios for different portfolio sizes. Additionally, the newsletter will begin electronic delivery of weekly hotlines and flash alerts as well as an earnings calendar on its Web site. Currently, MPT offers portfolios for conservative, moderate and aggressive investors with portfolio sizes ranging from $50,000 to over $4 million. The composite average of these current model portfolios, in combination with some discontinued ones, has garnered Navellier a fifth-place position out of fifty newsletters the Hulbert Financial Digest has tracked over that last fifteen, achieving returns of 14.7 percent annually. -- Jimmy Sterns More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: Longer-term view remains bullish

content: Advancers Arch Wireless AWIN shares surged almost 17 percent after the company said late Friday that a Justice Department staff review recommended approving the company's merger with Metrocell Holdings MTOH Boeing BA, +2.46% shares gained almost 2 percent after the company was ordered Friday to pay $3.6 million in damages and compensatory costs by a jury in Georgia, according to the Atlanta Journal-Constitution. See full story. China Yuchai International Ltd. CYD, +1.49% shares jumped more than 20 percent Monday after the company reported third-quarter earnings rose. Conseco Inc. CNO, -0.87% saw its shares advance more than 7 percent after the company reported third-quarter net income of $57.9 million, or 36 cents per share. Dimon DMN, +2.17% shares added more than 2 percent after the company announced an agreement to buy Standard Commercial Corp. STW, +0.00% in a deal valued at $670 million, or $18.66 per share. Standard Commercial's shares added more than 8 percent. See full story. eBay EBAY, +0.32% shares climbed more than 4 percent in morning trading. J.P. Morgan set $130 as a 12-month price target on the Internet auctioneer's stock, indicating a view that the eBay could be poised to rise as much as 30 percent. Elan ELN, +0.00% rose more than 4 percent and Biogen Idec BIIB, +0.74% lost nearly 1 percent after the companies reported encouraging one-year data from a Phase III multiple sclerosis trial of Antegren. Two-year results will be available in the first half of 2005. The drug was previously designated by the Food and Drug Administration for priority review. See full story. FedEx Corp. FDX, +2.26% gained more than 1 percent after the package shipping giant said late Friday that it will raise its shipping rates 2.6 percent for 2005. Limited Brands LTD, +0.52% shares gained almost 5 percent after the company said it expects adjusted earnings of 10 cents a share for the third quarter ended Oct. 31, higher than previously forecast. The company also raised the range on its "Dutch Auction" self-tender offer. See story. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% shares added almost 1 percent after the company said global comparable sales rose 6.1 percent in October, with system-wide sales for the company's namesake restaurants gaining by 9.5 percent. The company said its U.S. business was "robust" for the month. Medarex Inc. MEDX shares surged more than 8 percent after the company said it would receive $50 million from Bristol-Myers Squibb as part of a drug-development and commercialization agreement. It could get up to $205 million if all regulatory milestones are met, and up to $275 million in sales-related milestones. See full story. Novell NOVL shares gained more than 9 percent after the software company said Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% would pay $536 million to settle an antitrust lawsuit involving the NetWare software program. See full story. Pilgrim's Pride Corp. PPC, -1.16% shares jumped more than 14 percent after the company said Monday fourth-quarter net income rose to $72.3 million, or $1.09 per share, including a $23.8 million, 22 cents per share charge for a meat recall. Net income in the same quarter a year ago was $25.1 million, or 61 cents per share. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 83 cents per share. Sales at the Pittsburg, Texas-based poultry producer rose to $1.36 billion from $683.7 million a year ago. See full story. Shares of Qiao Xing Universal Telephone XING advanced more than 9 percent in New York trading Monday after the company said that revenue from fixed-wireless product sales "could be as high as $50 million for the next 12 months." Shares of Taser International TASR rose more than 16 percent after it said the Transportation Security Administration approved an international airline's application for the onboard use of conducted energy weapons by specially trained personnel on flights to and from the U.S. Unico American Corp. UNAM, -3.64% shares gained more than 4 percent on Monday after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $1.4 million, or 26 cents per share. Last year the company posted a loss of $734,000, or 13 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter was $15.5 million, compared with $13 million in 2003. Yahoo YHOO shares rose more than 2 percent after J.P. Morgan Securities assigned a 12-month price target of $50, indicating potential upside of 37 percent. Decliners Shares of AirNet Systems ANS, -4.23% an air cargo carrier, plunged 23 percent after the company said late Friday it will take a third-quarter noncash charge of $47 million, or $3.07 a share. Comstock Resources, Inc. CRK, +4.28% shares dropped more than 7 percent after the company posted third-quarter net income of $12.3 million, or 34 cents a share, compared with $12.9 million, or 36 cents a share. The Frisco, Texas company said sales jumped 38 percent to $78.4 million. Credence Systems CMOS shares fell more than 3 percent after the company named David Ranhoff president and chief operating officer, to the additional position of chief executive officer, effective Jan. 1. Shares of Horizon Offshore HOFF, +2.11% dropped more than 59 percent. Volume was already at more than 7.7 million. Late Friday, the company unveiled details of recapitalization plans that will result in a substantial number of shares of its common stock being issued at a "significant discount" to the stock's recent trading price. GenCorp GY shares lost more than 1 percent after the aerospace manufacturer had its credit rating downgraded by Moody's, affecting about $704 million in debt securities. Guilford Pharmaceuticals Inc. GLFD shares gave up almost 4 percent after the company reported a third-quarter loss of $14.5 million, or 33 cents per share, compared with its loss of $13.3 million, or 46 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $17.3 million, up from $5.4 million in 2003. Mediacom Communications Corp. MCCC shares lost 6 percent after the company, citing cable-TV disruptions caused by Hurricane Ivan in three southeastern states, posted a third-quarter net loss of $12.8 million, or 11 cents per share, a reversal from the prior year's profit of $1.9 million, or 2 cents per share. Analysts had been expecting a quarterly profit. Merisel MSEL shares lost almost 2 percent after the software licensing distributor and reseller late Friday reported it swung to a third-quarter loss $1.1 million, or 15 cents a share. Last year, it earned $683,000, or 9 cents a share. News Corp. NWSWI shares gave up more than 3 percent after the company adopted a "poison pill" shareholder rights plan in a move designed to fortify itself against a potential hostile takeover. See full story. Paxson Communications PAX, +0.57% slipped more than 7 percent after the company said Monday that it will postpone releasing its third-quarter results due out after the bell because the media company needs more time for noncash accounting issues. Shares of Pfizer PFE, +0.54% skidded nearly 2 percent after the company said in a Friday regulatory filing that New York Attorney General Elliott Spitzer has requested "documents and information concerning clinical trials of certain of our pharmaceutical products for indications other than those approved by the FDA and concerning possible promotion of those products for such indications." See full story. Shares of Pixar Animation Studios Inc. PIXR slid more than 6 percent on the heels of the record box-office debut of the company's latest feature "The Incredibles." The film grossed $70.7 million on its opening weekend, coming in just above the $70.3 million debut of its last film, the box-office smash "Finding Nemo." Several analysts noted that the opening was actually on the low side of expectations, and the company was downgraded by Deutsche Bank on concerns about valuation. See full story. Quigley Corp. QGLY shares lost more than 6 percent to in afternoon action. Late Friday, the Doylestown, Pa., company said it has received a faxed complaint indicating a group of consumers have filed a lawsuit against it. Staples SPLS shares slipped more than 3 percent after the company's rating was cut Monday to "in-line" from "outperform" by Goldman Sachs, which lifted its view on the specialty hardline sector to "cautious" from "neutral." Symbol Technologies SBL, +5.07% shares gave up more than 7 percent after the company said it has delayed filing its form 10-Q for the third quarter by two weeks after finding certain inventory discrepancies. The Holtsville, N.Y.-based information technology company said that it's reviewing the discrepancies and that it may need to amend one or both of its previously filed quarterly reports for the year to reflect overstated sales. The company revised its year-to-date financials to reflect the expected changes, reducing earnings for the nine months ended Sept. 30 by 2 cents, to 22 cents per share, with sales revised lower by $13.3 million, to $1.28 billion. United PanAm Financial UPFC shares sank almost 5 percent after the sub-prime lender specializing in auto loans said it will restate financial results for 2001, 2002, 2003 and later quarters after discovering that its computer-based accounting system erroneously calculated accrued interest on certain accounts since 1998. A number of disclaimers said the company's earnings releases should not be relied upon and that any restatements are subject to further audits. See full story. Young Broadcasting YBTVA shares dropped more than 6 percent after the company said its third-quarter net loss widened to $12.11 million, or 61 cents a share, from $12.01 million, or 61 cents a share, with revenue growing to $53.6 million from $50 million. title: Highlights of rising and falling U.S. stocks

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Homeland security-related stocks made a strong showing Monday following news of a government approval for use of Taser's stun gun products on U.S. aircraft. Before the opening, The Scottsdale, Ariz., company said that a "major international airline" received approval for onboard use of Taser products from the Transportation Security Administration of the Department of Homeland Security. Taser International Inc. TASR closed up $7.63, or 16.4 percent, at $56.12 in heavy volume of 37 million shares traded. Taser President Tom Smith said the approval is the first to allow trained personnel to have access to Taser technology on commercial flights in the U.S. The stun guns are already in use on certain flights outside the U.S. "We've been working with the transportation ministry since 2001 to get this approval," Smith told CBS Marketwatch. The company expects the first weapons to be deployed by the end of the year. Listen to Smith interview. The news inspired buying across the sector. Shares of Mace Security International MACE, +3.87% a Mt. Laurel, N.J., maker of electronic surveillance and personal defense products, gained 10.3 percent to $5.35, while Synergx Systems' SYNX stock advanced 7.3 percent to $3.37. Based in Syosset, N.Y., Synergx makes data communication products with fire alarm and life safety applications. Other movers in the group included: Ipix IPIX, -4.59% which finished up 9.5 percent, Digital Recorders TBUS adding 12.3 percent, and Magal Security Systems MAGS, -6.18% increasing 4.3 percent. Taser's announcement comes just days after it announced plans to split its stock 2 for 1, its third such move in the past year. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: Security stocks take cue from rally in Taser

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser Intl. tasr rose 5.7 percent to $49.15 in pre-market trade Monday after it said the Transportation Security Administration of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security approved a major international airline's application for the onboard use of Taser brand conducted energy weapons by specially trained personnel on flights to and from the United States.
title: Taser jumps on approval of devices for use on aircraft

content: Free Preview For full access, Log in or Subscribe Now and get 4 weeks free! CINCINNATI (CBS.MW) -- The pre-market bias is sharply higher Friday behind a stronger-than-expected October employment report. Nonfarm payrolls increased by 337,000 in October, nearly double the consensus estimate. At the same time, payroll gains for August and September were revised higher by 115,000. Early buy interest follows yet another session of massive gains Thursday. The Dow Industrials rose 177 points, the Nasdaq gained 19 points, and the S&P 500 added 18.5 points. title: Markets sharply higher on strong jobs data

content: Advancers Abercrombie & Fitch ANF, +2.41% shares climbed more than 7 percent after the New Albany, Ohio-based casual apparel retailer for young men and women said October same-store sales rose 11 percent. Alcan Inc. AL, +1.43% shares rose more than 4 percent after the Canadian metals and packaging giant posted a strong jump in its third-quarter earnings as pricing and volumes improved. See full story. Shares of Altria Group MO, -0.21% jumped more than 8 percent in afternoon trading after the food and tobacco giant's chief executive said its 2004 earnings would come in at the high end of its previous expectations -- and that the company is looking at splitting up. See full story. AnnTaylor Stores ANN, +0.16% shares added almost 5 percent after the company said the strength of the Ann Taylor Loft division carried a 6.7 percent increase in October's same-store sales, but couldn't hold the third quarter's earnings forecast. See full story. Bebe Stores' BEBE, -7.76% shares advanced more than 13 percent after the company said same-store sales rose 30.6 percent in October. Calpine C.PN, +0.59% shares tacked on more than 13 percent after the utility company reported earnings before items of 20 cents per share, topping Wall Street's consensus estimate and said it sees signs of improvement on the horizon. See full story. Shares of Caremark Rx CMX, -9.09% gained more than 8 percent after the pharmaceutical services company boosted its 2004 outlook following a better-than-expected third quarter report. Catalina Marketing POS, +0.10% shares added more than 8 percent after the company said second-quarter earnings rose to $20.3 million, or 39 cents per diluted share, beating analyst predictions of 25 cents according to a Thomson First Call poll. Shares of Charming Shoppes Inc. CHRS, -1.34% surged more than 11 percent after the Bensalem, Pa.-based women's plus-size apparel retailer said October same-store sales rose 6 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended Oct. 30 increased 8 percent to $169.7 million from $157.6 million in the same period a year ago. Christopher & Banks Corp. CBK, +1.90% shares added more than 14 percent after the company said Thursday its October same-store sales rose 7 percent versus a year ago. Clean Harbors CLHB surged more than 12 percent after the company's earnings before items for the third quarter beat Wall Street's consensus estimate by a dime. CVS Corp. CVS, -0.80% shares added more than 5 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $184.6 million, or 44 cents a share, down from $187.8 million, or 46 cents a share in the same period a year ago, as higher integration costs related to the Eckerd acquisition offset strong margins, but were above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 41 cents a share. Denny's Corp. DNYY shares rose more than 10 percent after the restaurant operator said same-store sales at its company-owned namesake locations rose 7 percent. DHB Industries DHB jumped more than 12 percent after the company received a $24.6 million contract to provide its body armor products to the U.S. Mission forces in Iraq. EGL Inc. EAGL, +0.00% shares rose almost 6 percent after the freight company said third quarter net income tripled to $17.5 million, or 36 cents per share, from $5.6 million, or 12 cents per share, in the third quarter of 2003. The average analyst estimate from Thomson First Call was for earnings of 28 cents per share. Gap Inc. GPS, +0.97% advanced more than 9 percent after the San Francisco casual apparel retailer said it expects earnings of 27 to 28 cents per share for the third quarter after same-store sales rose 3 percent in October. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 26 cents per share in the period. The company also announced a $250 million buyback plan. See full story. Griffon Corp. GFF, +0.83% shares rose more than 4 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $18.9 million, or 61 cents per sheare, up from $18.9 million, or 50 cents per share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $369.7 million, compared with $362.6 million in 2003. Griffon also announced that it has increased its share buyback program by 1 million shares, bringing the total repurchase authorization amount to 1.9 million. Hornbeck Offshore Services Inc. HOS, +2.11% shares gained more than 7 percent after the company posted strong third-quarter earnings and revised its 2004 profit outlook sharply higher, to a range of 52 to 57 cents per share. Insightful Corp. IFUL shares soared more than 28 percent after the company late Monday reported third-quarter earnings of $609,000 or 5 cents per share. Last year, the company posted a loss of $990,000 or 9 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter was $4.8 million, compared with $4 million in 2003. The company forecast fourth-quarter revenue to be flat to slightly above last year's reported revenue. J. Jill Group JILL, +2.31% shares advanced more than 9 percent after the women's apparel retailer narrowed its third-quarter loss and bested Wall Street's consensus estimate. J.C. Penney Co. JCP, -0.98% shares added more than 8 percent after the company raised its fiscal third-quarter earnings to 47 to 49 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 41 cents a share, due to strong sales and gross margin trends and a profitable contribution from its catalog/Internet division. Keithley Instruments' KEI, +5.91% shares rallied almost 9 percent after the Cleveland measurement technology company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $4.5 million, or 27 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $800,000, or 5 cents per share, and better than Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 19 cents per share. The company noted that orders saw a healthy 49 percent increase from last year to $40.5 million. MarketWatch MKTW shares leapt more than 10 percent after Viacom Inc. (VIA: news, chart, profile) disclosed Thursday that it expects to make a bid the company in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Viacom is already a significant shareholder in MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. Marshall Edwards' mshl, +0.00% shares gained more than 18 percent after the company said its investigational anti-cancer drug, phenoxodiol, was granted "fast track" status by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for use in recurrent ovarian cancer. "Fast track" status means the drug is eligible for accelerated marketing approval programs. Northwest Airlines NWAC shares advanced more than 6 percent in afternoon trading . The company said Thursday that traffic rose 8.4 percent in October. Load factor increased 1.8 points to 80.3 percent in the month. Payless ShoeSource PSS shares rose more than 8 percent after the company said October same-store sales rose 6.1 percent. Total sales for month increased 5.6 percent to $219.1 million from $207.5 million in the same period a year earlier. PDI Inc. PDII shares rallied more than 7 percent after the company posted a 31 percent rise in third-quarter earnings and increased its 2004 per-share forecast. The Saddle River, N.J.-based health-care sales and marketing firm said it made $5.5 million, or 37 cents a share, vs. $4.2 million, or 29 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. Penn National Gaming PENN, +1.55% gained more than 26 percent on news the company has agreed to acquire Argosy Gaming Co. AGY, -2.78% for $2.2 billion, including $805 million in debt. Penn National said the deal will immediately add to its earnings. The deal values Argosy shares, which surged 11 percent in midday action, at $47 each. See full story. Rockwell Automation (ROK: news, chart, profile) shares jumped more than 7 percent after the company reported fourth-quarter net income of $148 million, or 78 cents per share, more than double the year-ago figure of $67.6 million, or 35 cents per share, on a sharp rise in sales. The company expects earnings of $2.15 to $2.25 per share in 2005 and first-quarter earnings of 48 cents per share vs. forecasts of $2.10 and 41 cents per share respectively in Thomson First Call surveys. See full story. Sears, Roebuck S, +0.41% shares added more than 5 percent after the department store operator reported a domestic same-store sales increase of 1.9 percent in October, vs. the slight decline expected by analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Semitool Inc. SMTL shares leapt more than 13 percent after the Kalispell, Mont., supplier of chip capital equipment swung to a profit in the fourth quarter. Smith & Nephew plc SNN, -0.78% shares surged more than 10 percent after the medical technology company posted a rise in third-quarter earnings and gave a strong outlook for the fourth quarter. Swift Energy SFY, -0.17% shares climbed more than 5 percent after the Houston company posted earnings before items of $18.5 million, or 65 cents per share, for the third quarter. Wall Street's consensus estimate was for a profit of 57 cents per share. Shares of The Talbots TLB, -5.71% advanced more than 9 percent after the Hingham, Mass., classic apparel retailer said it expects its third-quarter earnings to be at the high end of its previously announced range of 45 to 50 cents per share. Taser International TASR shares surged more than 13 percent after the company said Thursday it will split its stock 2-for-1. The company said it would pay a 100 percent stock dividend on or about Nov. 29 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 15. Taser said after the split the number of shares should be about 59.3 million from 29.6 million. TJX Cos. TJX, +1.08% gained more than 3 percent after the Framingham, Mass., off-price retailer said that, due to its strong October performance, it sees third-quarter earnings "solidly in line" with its prior projections for a profit of 39 to 42 cents per share. TRW Automotive Holdings Corp. TRW, -3.33% rose more than 4 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $13 million, or 13 cents per share, a penny ahead of the average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 12 cents per share in the September period. Looking ahead, TRW sees earnings of 8 to 13 cents per share on sales of $11.8 billion for 2004. This view reflects its third-quarter performance and expectations that for a charge of $115 million related to a seller note transaction. Wal-Mart Stores Inc. WMT, +1.37% shares gained almost 4 percent after the company said fiscal third-quarter earnings would be at the high-end of its previously forecasted range of 52 to 54 cents a share, vs. the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 52 cents a share, as better-than-expected gross margins helped offset sales that were below the original forecasts. See full story. Decliners Andrx ADRX shares plunged almost 16 percent after the company said that its third-quarter earnings were flat with last year's and far short of what had been expected. See full story. Shares of aQuantive Inc. AQNT sank more than 3 percent after the Seattle-based digital marketing services and technology company lowered its fourth-quarter outlook. Shares of Asyst Technologies ASYT sank more than 28 percent after the company said it would delay the filing of its fiscal second-quarter results with securities regulators. Shares of Audiocodes Ltd. AUDC, +2.14% fell more than 8 percent in afternoon trading. The company priced a private offering of $100 million worth of its 2 percent senior convertible notes due 2024 with an initial conversion price of $18.71 per ordinary share. The company granted initial purchasers of the notes a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional $25 million in notes. Biovail Corporation VRX, +2.65% lost more than 7 percent after the company posted third-quarter net income of $49.6 million, or 31 cents a share, short of Thomson First Call's average analysts' estimate for earnings of 37 cents a share. Business Objects BOBJ shares tumbled almost 17 percent after the company forecast fourth-quarter and 2004 results below Wall Street expectations. See full story. Shares of Columbia Laboratories Inc. CBRX slid more than 12 percent after the Livingston, H.J.-based pharmaceutical company reported a third quarter loss of $5.9 million, or 14 cents per share, wider than its loss of $4.2 million, or 11 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 12 cents per share. Shares of CryoLife Inc. CRY, +1.26% skidded more than 13 percent to $6.12 after the Atlanta-based medical products company reported a third-quarter loss of $6 million, or 26 cents per share, wider than its year-ago equivalent loss of $4.7 million, or 24 cents per share. Digene DIGE shares plummeted almost 25 percent after the company swung to a first-quarter loss and issued a second-quarter sales forecast and a 2005 earnings and sales forecast that fell short of Wall Street's expectations. See full story. Ditech Communications DITC shares lost more than 25 percent after the company said that it expects to see second-quarter revenues below Wall Street's consensus estimate. Frontier Oil FTO, +1.91% shares slumped more than 2 percent after the company's third-quarter earnings of $23.8 million, or 87 cents a share, missed Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 91 cents per share. Greg Manning Auctions GMAI shares fell more than 12 percent in midday action. The moves comes despite the auction house company's report of fiscal first-quarter earnings of $5.1 million, or 18 percent a share, an increase from $2.5 million, or 14 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above prior earnings projections of $4.2 million to $4.6 million. Guess? Inc. GES, -0.81% shares lost more than 9 percent after the company said same-store sales rose 6.2 percent in October and total sales for the five-week period ended Oct. 30 rose 12.3 percent to $45.5 million. CIBC said the performance was strong but it reflected decelerating trends at retail and that promotional activity was somewhat higher than the firm expected. The Gymboree Corp. GYMB shares fell more than 3 percent after the company lowered its third-quarter outlook as it reported a 3 percent rise in same-store sales in October. Hot Topic Inc. HOTT shares fell almost 4 percent after the company cut third-quarter profit outlook. The retailer said it expects a profit of 27 cents a share, citing weaker-than-expected October sales. October same-store sales fell 3.8 percent. Impax Laboratories IPXL, +0.00% shares sank almost 23 percent after the company said it is postponing the release of its third-quarter financial results until Nov. 9 while it works on a restatement of its results. Shares of JoS A. Bank Clothiers JOSB slumped more than 13 percent after the retailer of men's clothing said same-store sales fell 7.1 percent in October. "While sales were soft in October, they have been firming up in the first few days of November and appear to be returning to our positive trend," CEO Robert N. Wildrick said in a press release. Jupitermedia JUPM shares dropped more than 14 percent in afternoon action. The move comes despite a stronger than expected earnings report from the company after Wednesday's closing bell. Magic Software MGIC, +4.29% shares fell more than 14 percent after the company posted lower year-over-year earnings, "last minute decision-making delays on the part of some customers" for the decline. PXRE Group Ltd. SPXT, +1.38% tumbled nearly 5 percent after the company disclosed plans for a public offering of $100 million worth of common stock. 85 percent of the shares are to be sold by the company while certain holders will sell the other 15 percent. The deal includes an over-allotment option to sell an additional 15 percent of the number of shares being sold in the offering. Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% shares fell almost 5 percent after the San Diego-based wireless technology company said fourth-quarter sales fell sequentially as it shipped fewer high-end chips for wireless phones. The company also issued an earnings forecast that fell short of Wall Street projections. See full story. Retail Ventures RVI shares slid almost 8 percent after the company forecast a loss for the third-quarter of 3 to 5 cents a share versus the previous outlook for earnings of 11 to 15 cents. Shares of Ryerson Tull Inc. RT lost more than 10 percent after the Chicago metals processor said it plans to sell $125 million worth of convertible senior notes in a private placement. The deal includes an over-allotment option for the sale of an additional $25 million worth of notes. Sharper Image SHRP shares slid more than 10 percent after the high-end gadget retailer forecast a loss of 19 to 23 cents a share for the third quarter, citing a decreased realized gross margin rate and slightly lower than anticipated sales. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a loss of 10 cents a share for the quarter, on average. Shoe Pavilion SHOE, +1.69% lost more than 3 percent after the company reported a profit of $24,000, breaking even on a per share basis, as the reversal of a tax reserve carried it into the black despite a sales drop of 4.2 percent. Same-store sales fell 6.3 percent in the quarter amid an advertising cut-back. Tesoro Petroleum Corp. TSO, +0.00% shares slid more than 4 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings that fell short of the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Ultimate Electronics ULTE shares gave up almost 8 percent after the company's fiscal third-quarter revenue fell short of the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Same-store sales for the quarter ending October fell 8 percent, due primarily to weak traffic and execution at the beginning of the quarter. Varian Inc. VARI shares sank almost 6 percent after the company said fourth-quarter net earnings rose 34 percent but gave an outlook for first quarter and 2005 earnings below Wall Street estimates. See full story. Shares of Vision-Sciences Inc. VSCI tumbled more than 14 percent after the Natick, Mass.-based medical products company reported a second-quarter loss of $930,000, or 3 cents per share, wider than its loss of $840,000 million, or 3 cents per share in the same period a year ago. Sales for the second quarter fell to $2 million from $2.1 million in same period a year ago. Wet Seal Inc. WTSLA shares tumbled more than 9 percent after the company said it is in financing talks with S.A.C. Capital Management and is considering issuing a combination of convertible notes and warrants. The company also said same-store sales fell 15.5 percent in October. World Airways' WLDA, -1.64% shares fell more than 10 percent after the company fell short of Wall Street's consensus estimate for its third-quarter results. The company said it would pay a 100 percent stock dividend on or about Nov. 29 to shareholders of record as of Nov. 15. Taser said after the split the number of shares should be about 59.3 million from 29.6 million.
title: Taser International to split stock 2-for-1

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Homeland security stocks were mostly higher Tuesday on the belief that sector fundamentals will remain positive whatever the outcome of the presidential election. The sector shrugged off a near 6 percent tumble in security systems maker Compudyne, which reported late Monday a wider-than-expected third-quarter loss. "No matter which party controls the White House, we see the federal government focusing concentration on further securing aviation, securing ports, borders and mass transit, protecting infrastructure and strengthening identification and tracking of individuals," said Morgan Keegan analyst Brian Ruttenbur. Among Ruttenbur's highest, or "outperform" rated stocks, American Science and Engineering ASEI tacked on 7.4 percent to $39.88, Lasercard LCRD headed 2.3 percent higher to $9.20, OSI Systems OSIS, +2.61% rallied 3.7 percent to $18.79, First Advantage FADV lost 0.3 percent to $16.75 and Verint Systems VRNT, +13.90% fell 0.7 percent to $38.62. Among biometric technology companies, or those that provide individual identification and authentication systems and services, Identix IDNX shot up 5.9 percent to $7.70. Lehman Brothers analyst Jeffrey Kessler upgraded the industry leader's stock to "outperform" from "equal weight" on the belief that the biometrics industry "may finally be ready for 'prime time' in 2005." "U.S. government-awards flow on biometrics over the next 24 months will convince investors that biometrics is a growth business," Kessler said. "Biometrics is a $1 billion industry and is expected to grow to a multi-billion dollar industry in 3 to 5 years." Also in the biometrics business, Viisage Technology VISG fell 0.2 percent to $7.26 and Cogent Inc. COGT, -3.85% added 2.4 percent to $19.55. Meanwhile, Compudyne Corp. CDCY dropped 5 percent to $6.75, and hit a 20-month low of $6.13 in intraday trading. The company reported late Monday a third-quarter loss of $1.9 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with earnings of $982,000, or 12 cents a share a year ago, and much wider than the average analysts' estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of a loss of 5 cents a share. Friedman Billings Ramsey reiterated its "underperform" rating as the company's attack-protection division was unlikely to turn a profit soon and as quality problems continue to prompt expensive repairs. Among other more active security stocks, Taser International TASR rose 0.6 percent to $41.81, RAE Systems RAE, +8.70% was moving up 2 percent to $7.37 and Armor Holdings AH, +3.65% slipped 0.8 percent to $36.50. "Our overall outlook on the homeland security sector is positive," Ruttenbur said. "We believe the federal funding for homeland security initiatives will continue at a strong level, and we see more programs implemented." More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: Homeland security stocks trade broadly higher

content: LOS ANGELES (CBSMW) -- When investors follow the crowd, they rarely have positive results. When we started this a column a year ago, it wasn't with the intention of studying investor behavior or to come up with any sort of new and improved trading methodology. It's still not. See current Stock of the month. But in our efforts to take an extra look at big volume movers each month, and offer some alternative stock recommendations -- presented by a panel of independent investment letter editors -- we came up with some surprising results. Following the herd After 12 months, if investors traded the stock of the month on the day each column was published -- buying when the herd was buying and shunning when the herd was selling -- they would have lost 3 percent, based on the closing price on Nov. 3, 2003 through the closing price on Nov. 1, 2004. The herd guessed wrong seven out of 12 months. Investors using the stock of the month as a contrary indicator -- shunning when the herd was buying and buying when the herd was selling -- would have garnered a 9 percent gain. That's a 2.3 percent improvement over the Standard & Poor's 500 Index SPX, +1.38% during the same period and 12 percent better than the herd. If investors had followed the consensus opinion of the newsletter writers invited to comment on the heavy movers -- buying on a majority opinion of Buy or Hold and shunning when the majority opinion was to avoid the stock -- returns would have been 11 percent, or 14 percent better than the herd. Our panel missed six out of 12 months. Going with the gurus The real shocker, however, was the performance results of the recommended stocks by our panel. Each month, we featured three experts offering one alternative stock pick. Some of these stocks were recommended for short-term trading, while others were suggested as long-term holds. Had investors traded these three-stock portfolios in each of the past 12 months, they would have nearly doubled their money -- earning a hefty 94.9 percent. Such trading wouldn't have been for the faint of heart, however. These portfolios lost four out of 12 months. The worst month, April 2004, saw a decline of 45.4 percent. The best month, May 2004, leapt 65.5 percent. Those months also saw the best and worst single stock performance, with Sina SINA, +4.55% shooting up 38.3 percent in May and Conexant CNXT, +2.41% receding 30.6 percent in April. No one would recommend using this column to actively trade the stocks mentioned each month. Simply, 12 data points are hardly proof of a reliable methodology. Not to mention that the writers on our panel didn't make their recommendations with a one-month trading window in mind. But there are two conclusions that we believe investors can safely draw from this. First, going with the crowd rarely takes you where you want to go. Second, stocks recommended by our panel of advisers are probably worth a second look. Stocks and picks of the month: Nov. 3, 2003 through Nov. 1, 2004 (Click on company to read original story) Date Stock Herd Panel 1-Mo New Pick 11/3 Intel INTC, +5.00% Buy Buy 0.0 % 1.9% 12/1 Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% Sell Buy 8.9 % 5.7% 1/5 Wal-Mart WMT, +1.37% Sell Shun 4.9% 15.9% 2/2 GE GE, -1.46% Buy Buy -2.5% 37.6% 3/1 Cisco CSCO, +2.95% Sell Buy 0.9% -13.7% 4/1 Intel INTC, +5.00% Sell Buy -4.9% -45.4% 5/3 Taser TASR Sell Shun -9.9% 65.5% 6/1 Citigroup C, -1.11% Sell Buy -1.6% 8.5% 7/1 Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% Buy Buy -0.4% -8.9% 8/2 EBay EBAY, +0.32% Sell Buy 10.7% -18.8% 9/1 Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% Buy Buy 7.9% 44.7% 10/4 Pfizer PFE, +0.54% Buy Buy -8.0% 1.9% Track the performance and consensus recommendations of nearly 180 investment newsletters, only in Hulbert Interactive. title: Stock-of-the-month column shows surprising results

content: Waste Industries Q3 earnings beats Wall Street (11:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Waste Industries WWIN said late Tuesday that third-quarter earnings were $3.4 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $3.1 million, or 23 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $75.2 million vs. $70.8 million a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for third-quarter earnings of 24 cents a share. Medicines Co expects 2004 sales $139M-$145M (9:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- The Medicines Co. MDCO said late Tuesday it expects 2004 sales of $139 million to $145 million, rather than the forecast of $139 million to $141 million issued on the company's third-quarter conference call earlier in the day. The adjustment stems from the recognition of European revenue in the third quarter, which was calculated at a contracted initial price. The Medicines Co. said it may adjust those sales in the fourth quarter based on the end user price. SL Green Q3 FFO, EPS rise (8:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- SL Green Realty Corp. SLG said late Tuesday that its third-quarter net income rose to $20.3 million, or 49 cents a share, from $19.4 million, or 59 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Funds from operations rose to $40.7 million, or 94 cents a share, from $33.9 million, or 87 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting funds from operations of 95 cents a share. Matria Healthcare Q3 earns rise on 20% sales increase (7:56 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Matria Healthcare MATR posted higher third-quarter earnings late Tuesday, as sales rose 20 percent. The Marietta, Ga.-based provider of disease management services and products said it made $3.3 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $2.4 million, or 23 cents a share, last year. Revenue came in at $76 million vs. $63.1 million. Matria said it expects earnings from continuing operations to come in betweeen 34 cents and 36 cents a share in the fourth quarter, on sales ranging from $74 million to $78 million. The earnings forecast excludes an accounting change for the treatment of contingently convertible debt securities. Analysts are looking for a per-share profit of 35 cents for the period. Teradyne swings to Q3 profit, sees Q4 below targets (7:03 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Teradyne Inc. TER said late Tuesday that it swung to a profit in the third quarter, as sales rose despite a drop in customer orders. The semiconductor equipment maker said it made $41.1 million, or 21 cents a share, on sales of $457.8 million. Last year, Teradyne posted a loss of $53.5 million, or 28 cents a share, on sales of $329.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Teradyne said it expects to report earnings per share of breakeven to 4 cents a share on revenue between $360 million and $380 million in the fourth quarter. Analysts are looking for earnings of 16 cents a share on revenue of $427 million, according to Thomson First Call. Palm Harbor Q2 loss 10c vs 2c (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Palm Harbor Homes Inc. PHHM said late Tuesday that its second-quarter net loss was $2.2 million, or 10 cents per share, vs $515,000, or 2 cents a share, a year ago. Net sales totaled $150.5 million compared with $148.5 million. The marketer and builder of manufactured homes said net sales were weaker than expected due to hurricane activity on the East Coast. Churchill Downs swings to Q3 loss on charges (7:01 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Churchill Downs Inc. CHDN late Tuesday said it had a third-quarter loss of $3.8 million, or 29 cents a share, including impairment charges at its Ellis Park racetrack totaling $6.2 million, or 34 cents a share. In the year-ago period, the horse racing venue operator reported a profit of $7.9 million, or 59 cents a share. Revenue fell 1.4 percent to $122.2 million. CoStar Q3 posts higher earnings on new customer orders (6:20 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- CoStar Group CSGP said Tuesday after the bell that third-quarter earnings were $2.4 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $281,000, or 2 cents a share, a year earlier. The real estate services company said third-quarter pro forma earnings were $4 million, or 21 cents a share, vs. $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was $28.6 million vs. $24.1 million a year earlier.
