Pharmaceutical sales were down 9 percent due to lower volumes at Organon and Diosynth and currencies. It said Organon is facing a major decline in Remeron sales due to generic competition. Looking ahead, it said: "We are facing steeply increasing raw material and energy prices and there are increasing uncertainties due to softening macroeconomic conditions." It did not expect to be able to match last year's "very strong" fourth quarter. It says it expects it now expects net income for the year, excluding nonrecurring items, will be around 2003 level. Sainsbury lowers dividend, sees 2H pre-tax flat on 1H (2:22 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. supermarkets group J. Sainsbury(UK:SBRY)expects underlying pre-tax profit for the first half year from between 125 million to 135 million pounds, and it sees the second half year not "significantly different from the first half" as it pursues a "sales led profit recovery." The group also sees a decline in its dividend for the year to 7.8 pence a share in order to invest 135 million pounds into the business. Same-store sales, or sales at stores open at least a year, rose 1.8 percent in the 16 weeks to Oct. 9. Same-store sales showed a 1.1 percent decline excluding petrol sales. Total sales grew 4.4 percent. "We have continued to invest in the customer offer, particularly pricing, and as a result in-store deflation in the quarter was 1.1 percent," the group said. First-half profit was impacted by margin investment, it said. Reuters Q3 sales down 13%, sees Q4 sub down 3% (2:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Reuters Group(UK:RTR) RTRSY the FTSE 100 news and financial data provider, expects underlying revenue from subscriptions - its core business - to drop by close to 5.5 percent for the year. Reuters said third quarter revenue dropped 13 percent on an actual basis to 570 million pounds. Revenue was down 5 percent on an underlying basis reflecting currency movements while recurring revenue - or subscriptions - dropped 4.4 percent to 528 million pounds. The decline in recurring revenue topped Reuters own forecast for a 5 percent decline. Reuter's full year outlook for a sales decline implies a 3 percent decline in core revenue for the fourth quarter. "Reuters made good progress towards recovery this quarter. Despite uncertain market conditions, gross sales outpaced cancellations during the quarter for the first time since the first quarter of 2001," the company said. Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Dutch pharmaceutical giant Akzo Nobel AKZOY saw shares rise almost 4 percent after the company said net income for the third quarter rose 20 percent, excluding nonrecurring items worth 213 million euros. Total net income amounted to 521 million euros, due to a onetime gain of 308 million euros. Pharmaceutical sales were down 9 percent due to lower volumes at Organon and Diosynth and currencies. It said Organon is facing a major decline in Remeron sales due to generic competition. Ameritrade Holding AMTD shares surged more than 5 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $57.2 million, or 14 cents per share, up from $55.1 million or 13 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analysts' estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 11 cents a share. Revenue fell 5 percent to $186.8 million, as a 24 percent decline in commissions and clearing fees offset a 57 percent rise in interest revenue. Analysts expected revenue of $187.5 million. Looking ahead, the discount brokerage expects to earn 72 cents to 89 cents a share in fiscal 2005, above analysts' projections of 70 cents. See full story. CheckFree's CKFR shares rose 10 percent after the electronic payments processor overnight topped expectations with its fiscal first-quarter results. Legg Mason analysts said, however, that they would wait for a pullback in the stock before becoming more aggressive. See full story. CTG CTG shares jumped more than 10 percent after the computer services provider reported third-quarter earnings of $604,000, or 4 cents a share, compared with $340,000 or 2 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Sales were $57.9 million, down from $59.6 million a year earlier. It forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 2 cents to 4 cents a share and revenue from continuing operations of $57.5 million to $59.5 million. CTS CTS shares climbed 5 percent after the company said its third-quarter net income fell to $3.92 million, or 11 cents a share, from $6.07 million or 17 cents a share a year ago. The designer and manufacturer of electronic components said sales rose to $129 million from $108.5 million. Analysts were expecting a profit of 10 cents a share on revenue of $123 million. Decode Genetics DCGN shares advanced more than 11 percent after the drug developer said a Phase II trial of a compound aimed at preventing heart attacks met its primary goals. The Iceland biotech company said the trial of its DG031 compound is the first clinical study based on the isolation of a disease gene in a common ailment. Ethan Allen Interiors ETH shares surged more than 9 percent after the furniture chain said it earned $18.9 million, or 51 cents a share, in its fiscal first quarter, against 50 cents in the same quarter a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was 50 cents a share. Sales rose 3.4 percent to $230.2 million from $222.8 million; the First Call survey estimate was for sales of $228 million. Same-store sales rose 4.9 percent from a year earlier. The company said it is confident it can increase sales at least 5 percent and lift earnings at least 8 percent in fiscal 2005, in line with, or above, consensus estimates. Identification card maker Fargo Electronics FRGO added 12 percent after third-quarter earnings fell to $2.3 million, or 18 cents per share, compared with $2.5 million or 19 cents a share a year ago. The results beat the average analysts' forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 15 cents a share. Sales rose to $19.6 million from $17 million a year ago. Fargo said it sees fourth-quarter earnings in the range of 14 cents to 18 cents a share, and full-year profit of 57 cents to 61 cents a share. IBM IBM shares rose 4 percent a day after the computer leader reported a third-quarter profit from continuing operations of $1.8 billion, or $1.06 a share, on revenue of $23.4 billion. See full story. JDA Software JDAS shares rallied more than 7 percent a day after it reported third-quarter results and listed major retailers, including Sears, that signed contracts in the quarter. See full story. Jefferies Group JEF surged almost 10 percent after the company said its third quarter net income rose 57 percent to $32.3 million, or 51 cents per share, compared with $20.5 million or 35 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Investment banking revenue, which rose 72 percent from a year ago, helped drive the strong results. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had, on average, expected the company to earn 44 cents per shares. Level 3 Communications LVLT jumped more than 4 percent in morning trading after it announced contracts on voice-over-Internet services. Metal Storm MTSX shares skyrocketed more than 36 percent after the electronic weapon developer said it is partnering with Lockheed Martin LMT to study and develop a torpedo defense system. Terms weren't disclosed. A prototype is expected after four months of design and testing. Millennium Cell MCEL shares jumped more than 10 percent after the fuel-cell developer received a notice from Nasdaq stating that it was not in compliance with requirements for further listing on the exchange. Millennium said it is considering whether to maintain its listing on the Nasdaq or transfer to the Nasdaq SmallCap Market. Robert Mondavi MOND shares soared more than 30 percent Tuesday after the winemaker said it has received an unsolicited acquisition bid. See full story. Overstock.com OSTK shares jumped more than 11 percent to after the company was upgraded by Avondale Partners to "market outperform" from "market perform." The brokerage cited positive feedback about the company's auction website services. Parker Hannafin PH shares jumped more than 8 percent Tuesday after the precision technology manufacturer reported first-quarter net income of $132.8 million, or $1.11 per share, compared with net income of $56.7 million or 48 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call estimate was 83 cents. Quarterly revenue was $1.95 billion, up from about $1.59 billion a year earlier and contrasting with a First Call estimate of $1.813 billion. See related story. Pilgrim's Pride PPC shares rose more than 4 percent after the company raised its fourth-quarter earnings forecast to $1.02 to $1.07 a share, including an insurance settlement of $23.8 million, or 22 cents a share. Excluding the insurance recovery, the provider of poultry products sees earnings of 80 cents to 85 cents a share, up from its previous estimate of 70 cents to 80 cents a share. Raven Industries RAVN shares added more than 7 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter earnings and sales to "greatly surpass" last year's earnings of 21 cents a share on revenue of $36.1 million. The company didn't forecast specific earnings and sales targets. The industrial manufacturer cites $8 million in plastic sheet sales for hurricane-affected areas as a reason for its outlook. Reuters Group RTRSY shares advanced almost 6 percent after the FTSE 100 news and financial data provider said it expects underlying revenue from subscriptions -- its core business -- to drop by close to 5.5 percent for the year. Reuters said third-quarter revenue dropped 13 percent on an actual basis to 570 million pounds. Security Capital SCC gained more than 5 percent after the holding company said that it has received an upwardly revised bid of $10.60 a share from Brian Fitzgerald and CP Acquisition. The pervious offer had been $9.65 a share. Shares of Stanley Works SWK jumped more than 9 percent with the company's better than expected third-quarter report leading a rally in toolmakers Station Casinos STN shares rose more than 5 percent after the casino operator said it's anticipating revenue growth of 10 percent to 12 percent in Las Vegas in the fourth quarter and earnings 48 cents to 52 cents a share. Third-quarter earnings, adjusted for nonrecurring items, rose 31 percent to 46 cents a share and net revenues rose 11 percent to $242.9 million. The board raised the quarterly dividend 20 percent to 21 cents a share. Taser International TASR shares added more than 5 percent after the weapons maker reported net income of $6.1 million, or 21 cents per share, compared with $1.08 million or 6 cents per share in the same period in 2003. A Thomson First Call survey of analysts produced an average estimate of 15 cents per share. Sales rose to $18.9 million in the quarter from $6.1 million in the third quarter of 2003. Texas Instruments TXN shares rose almost 7 percent early Tuesday after the chipmaker overnight posted a 26 percent third-quarter profit as customer demand improved late in the quarter. See full story. Decliners Ace ACE shares fell more than 6 percent after the Wall Street Journal reported that two top executives at the insurer knew about a bid-rigging scheme that's now at the center of New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's investigation of the industry. In an e-mail on Nov. 3, 2003, Geoffrey Gregory, president of Ace's casualty risk unit, warned Ace USA's president and chief executive, Susan Rivera, that the way bids were being arranged "could potentially be construed as simply creating the appearance of competition," the report said, adding that the firm and the two executives declined to comment. AK Steel AKS shares lost more than 9 percent after the company said that it will be adding a $149 per ton surcharge to its November flat-rolled carbon steel shipments. The price is an 8 percent decrease from October's $157 per ton surcharge. The surcharge on its electrical steel products will be $250 per ton, down from October's surcharge of $295 per ton. Aon AOC shares fell more than 9 percent after the Wall Street Journal reported that New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer is investigating whether the broker steered business to insurers in return for those firms using Aon as a broker for their own reinsurance packages. The largest reinsurance broker said Friday that to the best of its knowledge, its employees have not engaged in bid rigging. Boston Scientific BSX shares lost 7 percent after the medical device maker reported third-quarter net income, excluding special charges, of $404 million or 47 cents per share, compared with a net income of $137 million or 16 cents a share for the third quarter 2003. Revenue was $1.482 billion. Boston Scientific beat the estimate of 46 cents a share by analysts polled by Thomson First Call. See full story. Commercial Metals CMC shares lost more than 10 percent after the Irving, Texas-based steelmaker reported earnings of $47.4 million, or $1.56 per share, compared with $10.7 million or 38 cents a share a year earlier. Thomson First Call projected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.73 a share. The company said the recent quarter included a higher than anticipated expenses of $38.9 million, or 83 cents per share, compared with expenses of $1.3 million or 3 cents a share a year earlier. Net sales were $1.5 billion vs. $805 million a year earlier; the First Call estimate was $1.5 million. The company expects first-quarter earnings, including expense dilution, of $1.70 to $1.90 a share. Constellation Brands STZ shares slipped more than 8 percent after the wine and liquor seller said it offered to buy table wines brand Robert Mondavi MOND in a cash deal valued at $1.3 billion, including $333 million of Mondavi net debt. Terms set a 37 percent premium for the Class A Mondavi shares as of Oct. 11. Constellation offered $53 a share for Class A shareholders and $61.75 a share in cash for Mondavi's Class B shareholders. See full story. Continental Airlines CAL shares lost 6 percent. The carrier said it expects a "significant loss for 2004, and unless the current environment improves, expects to record a significant loss in 2005 as well." Continental posted a $16 million net loss, or 24 cents per share, in the third quarter, reflecting a charge to retire leased aircraft. It booked a $15 million mark-to-market gain relating to its Orbitz holdings. See full story. Shares of Ford Motor F shed more than 3 percent early Tuesday after the second-largest U.S. automaker once again relied heavily on its financial unit to offset widening losses in its automotive business in the third quarter. See full story. Gentex GNTX shares sank more than 6 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $25.2 million, or 32 cents per share, down from $25.7 million or 33 cents a share a year ago. Sales for the quarter were $120 million, compared with $113 million in 2003. Shares of Flyi FLYI parent of new low-fare carrier Independence Air, plunged more than 28 percent in midday trading Tuesday following a Wall Street downgrade. UBS lowered the company to "reduce" from "neutral," pointing out that the airline's business plan has not met targets. UBS warned that Independence Air could slide into Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in January when a large aircraft-rent payment comes due Shares of InTest INTT tumbled 46 percent after the maker of semiconductor testing equipment warned that third-quarter earnings would fall short of expectations. The company now expects earnings of 10 to 12 cents per share, below prior projections of 22 to 28 cents a share. Revenue is expected to about $19.5 million, vs. prior forecasts of $19 million to $21 million. ." See full story. Isonics ISON shares tumbled more than 21 percent after the technology developer said the market's reaction to various announcements made by the company over the past week was "unanticipated." Also, Isonics told regulators late Monday that three holders were converting 3,000 preferred shares to about 273,000 shares of Isonics common shares. Shares of LeapFrog Enterprises LF plummeted more than 34 percent after the educational toymaker said Monday that it expects to report lower earnings and sales for the third quarter of 2004. See full story. Maverick Tube MVK shares slipped more than 5 percent after the steel tube manufacturer reported third-quarter earnings of $68.5 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $8.7 million or 21 cents a share a year ago. Maverick reported sales of $400.7 million, up from $226.8 million last year. Maverick Tube also said Chief Executive Gregg Eisenberg retired Friday. It named director C. Robert Bunch as acting president and chief executive. Eisenberg will remain as chairman in a nonexecutive capacity until Dec. 31 and will be a consultant for a year after he resigns as chairman. Olympic Steel ZEUS shares lost more than 9 percent after the company reported third-quarter net income of $18.6 million, or $1.80 per share, compared with a net loss of $115,000 or a penny per share a year earlier. The Thomson First Call prediction was for earnings of $1.75 a share. Net sales rose to $244.1 million from $115.9 million. The company cited the strong global steel environment. Packaging Corporation of America PKG shares slid 7 percent. The company said it swung to a third-quarter profit of $26 million, or 24 cents per share. Last year, it lost $32 million or 31 cents a share. Sales rose 12.2 percent to $499 million. Analysts were expecting a profit of 25 cents a share on revenue of $509.7 million. The maker of container board and corrugated packaging products forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share. Radio Shack RSH fell more than 3 percent after the electronics retailer reported third-quarter net income of $69.7 million or 43 cents per share, compared with $57.1 million or 34 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call analysts' consensus was for third-quarter earnings of 39 cents a share. Third-quarter 2004 same-store sales were up 5 percent, compared with the prior year. Quarterly revenue was $1.1 billion, up slightly from $1.06 billion a year before; the First Call projection was for $1.09 billion. See full story. Republic Airways Holdings RJET shares slipped more than 5 percent after the company reported a third-quarter profit of $10 million, or 39 cents per share, compared with a profit of $3.1 million or 15 cents a share in the year-ago period. In the quarter, passenger traffic rose 24.3 percent as capacity increased 18.6 percent. Indianapolis-based Republic is the holding company for Chautauqua Airlines, which flies regional flights for American Airlines, Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and US Airways. Shares of Republic fell 5 cents to $9.66 in midday trading. Sprint FON shares slipped more than 3 percent. The company said it was raising its 2004 outlook on a stronger operating performance after the telecom operator posted adjusted third-quarter earnings ahead of analysts' estimates. The Overland Park, Kansas-based company posted a net loss of $1.32 per share, which includes a $1.53 a share loss associated with its decision to end its long distance operations. See full story. UnumProvident UNM sank almost 10 percent after the company said that it is reviewing its broker compensation policies in light of a recent probe launched by the New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer. The company added that it will not enter into any new compensation agreements until the review is complete to ensure that there is no possible conflict of interest between brokers and clients. UnumProvident said it has received subpoenas from the government on the matter and is fully cooperating with its investigation. See related story. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: AK Steel, Overstock.com, Reuters, Sprint, more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser tasr shares Tuesday tacked on $1.99 to trade at $40 after the company reported reported net income Tuesday of $6.1 million, or 21 cents per share; The Thomson First Call analyts consensus projection was for earnings per share of 15 cents. A year earlier the stun gun seller had net income of $1.08 million, or 6 cents per share.
title: Taser jumps at opening after Q3 earns report

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser International tasr reported net income Tuesday of $6.1 million, or 21 cents per share, compared to $1.08 million, or 6 cents per share in the same period in 2003. A Thomson First Call survey of analysts produced a consensus estimate of 15 cents per share. Sales rose to $18.9 million in the quarter from $6.1 million in the third quarter of 2003. Shares of the stun gun maker rose 6 percent in pre-open trading on Instinet to $40.49 Monday.
title: Taser Q3 earnings at 21c per share, above estimates

content: Stocks to watch Acusphere ACUS, +0.00% a drug developer, said late Friday that its shareholders approved the private placement of about 574,000 shares and warrants to buy about 115,000 more shares. The sale would raise $21.5 million and raise shares outstanding by about 5 percent if the warrants are exercised. AIG AIG, -0.18% was upgraded by Legg Mason to "buy" from "hold." Altria Group's MO, -0.21% Kraft Foods KFT is mulling the sale of its Altoids mints and Life Savers businesses, the Wall Street Journal reported. UBS UBS, +0.40% was tapped as an advisor for a possible sale. The businesses are seen raising more than $1 billion for Kraft; acquirers could include Hershey Foods HSY, +0.72% or Cadbury Schweppes CSG, -8.88% the report said, citing analysts. The possible sale was earlier reported in The Deal. Alvarion ALVR, +0.00% which makes wireless network connections, said Saturday that it reached new terms for its acquisition of Interwave Communications IWAV with a $40.5 million revised price. See full story. American Pharmaceutical Partners Inc. APPX said Monday the Food and Drug Administration approved its Abbreviated New Drug Application for Carboplatin for injection, the generic equivalent of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.'s Paraplatin. Carboplatin is used for initial treatment of advanced ovarian cancer. American Amgen AMGN, +0.01% the world's biggest biotechnology firm, said late Friday that a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled in its favor in a patent infringement lawsuit against Transkaryotic Therapies TKTX and Aventis Pharmaceuticals AVE, +0.00% U.S. District Judge William Young found that two Amgen patents for the production of erythropoietin were infringed upon by the defendants. Apex Silver Mines SIL, +2.06% which owns an open-pit zinc and silver mine in Bolivia, said late Friday it sold 4 percent convertible notes for net proceeds of $96.5 million. The notes are convertible at a share price of $28.62. Apex shares closed Friday at $19.10. Arch Coal ACI, -0.18% the nation's second-largest coal producer, according to Hoover's, had its ratings lowered late Friday by Moody's, affecting about $1.2 billion in debt securities. High capital expenditures are expected to cut free cash flow over the next four years, Moody's said, with the possible reversal of the present record coal prices. Despite those prices, says Moody's, Arch has a number of locked-in contracts that cut its potential earnings. Avista AVA, -0.64% an energy producer and marketer, said that it agreed to buy the half of the Coyote Springs 2 power station in Boardman, Ore., that it doesn't own. It will pay $62.5 million to Mirant MIRKQ with the sale expected to close by the end of the year or in early 2005. The natural gas-powered plant has a peak output of 280 megawatts of electricity. Barnes Group B, +1.78% saw its third-quarter profit miss Wall Street's estimate, coming in at $9.2 million, or 39 cents per share as opposed to the prior year's $9 million, or 38 cents. Sales rose nearly 10 percent, reaching $243.9 million from $222.2 million. Analysts, on average, had been expecting earnings of 42 cents per share on revenue of $239 million, according to Thomson First Call. BearingPoint Inc. BE, +0.49% was downgraded by Jefferies & Co. to "underperform" from "hold." Bear Stearns & Co. BSC, +1.30% which has one of Wall Street's top bond operations, said federal regulators are investigating its municipal bond business and focusing on the Chicago office. See full story. British Airways BAB, +0.74% Deutsche Lufthansa and eight other airlines, have protested to the European Commission the restructuring of partly Italian government-owned Alitalia appeared to be planned "to violate or circumvent EC state aid rules," the Financial Times said Monday, quoting a letter to the EC. Alitalia was "aggressively expanding capacity" which was "all the more astonishing" for a company that was suffering from severe overcapacity and was asking for rescue aid, the airlines complained, according to the report. Blockbuster BBI, +4.00% said it's cutting the price of its online DVD rental subscription service by $2.50 to $17.49 a month, effective Oct. 25. The company also said that, as part of new consumer incentives, the two free in-store rental coupons that online subscribers receive each month can be used for game rentals as well as movie rentals Boston Properties BXP, -0.15% was downgraded to "market perform" from "outperform" by Friedman Billings Ramsey due primarily to valuation. Meanwhile, Analyst David Loeb raised his stock price target to $54.50 from $50. Loeb thinks the company has the potential to create value through development in the Washington, DC area more than any other real estate investment trust he covers, but he feels the stock is fully valued at current levels. Bristol-Myers Squibb BMY, +1.09% one of the top drug developers, is among six sector stocks that Barron's says appear undervalued as recent news developments led to sell-offs. Price-to-earnings ratios are in the low teens and well below the S&P 500 valuation for four of the companies, with Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% an exception, though its shares are still down 20 percent this year. The other big drug makers mentioned are Merck MRK, -1.13% Pfizer PFE, +0.54% Schering-Plough SGP, -1.28% and Wyeth WYE Ceridian Corp. CEN, +2.17% said it will restate its financial results for the period from 1999 through the first quarter of 2004. The cumulative adjustment to the company's results is expected to cut earnings before taxes by $60.2 million. The company said it expects to report third-quarter earnings of 12 cents to 13 cents a share and fourth-quarter earnings between 25 cents and 29 cents a share. CheckFree CKFR an electronic payments middleman, is seen reporting earnings of 26 cents a share for its fiscal first quarter on Monday. Security software maker Check Point Software Technologies CHKP, +0.30% posted a 22 percent rise in third quarter revenue to $129.3 million. Net income rose to $66.8 million, or up 18 percent to $69.1 million, excluding net acquisition related charges. Per share, earnings rose to 26 cents or 27 cents ahead of the charge. Analysts polled by Thomson/First Call projected earnings per share of 25 cents for the quarter and sales of $128.32 million. Churchill Downs CHDN, +0.83% the horseracing track operator, said late Friday that it completed several acquisitions in New Orleans for a total of $57.5 million. The company paid $47 million for Fair Grounds Race Course and five off-track betting sites. It paid $10.5 million of Finish Line Management Corp. and Video Services Inc., which added five more off-track betting sites and 700 video poker machines at nine sites. Crossroads Systems CRDS which makes network equipment and software, said it has named Richard Sorenson as chief financial officer on a three-month, interim basis. In September, the company said Andrea Wenholz resigned as CFO to pursue other opportunities. Dutch biotech Crucell CRXL said it has licensed technology to Merial, a joint venture between Merck & Co. MRK, -1.13% and Sanofi-Aventis SNY, +0.30% unit Aventis, to develop and commercialize veterinary vaccines for foot-and-mouth disease. Crucell will receive an upfront payment, milestone payments, annual maintenance fees, and royalties on sales of vaccines, but financial terms weren't disclosed Auto parts maker Delphi Corp. DPH, -33.33% said its third quarter loss narrowed to $114 million from $353 million a year ago, or to 20 cents a share. Excluding restructuring charges, Delphi saw a pro forma loss of 12 cents - in line, it said, with the average analyst forecast and an Oct. 5 update Downey Financial DSL, +0.45% said net income for the third quarter fell 16.2 percent to $24.5 million, or 88 cents a share, due an increase in operating expenses and an "unfavorable" loan charge. Operating expense rose 10.9 percent due primarily to an increase in salaries and costs due to pending litigation. EBusiness services company Emerging Enterprise Solutions EESI, +0.00% said it has completed talks to consolidate AMCSI into EESI. EESI anticipates revenues over the next twelve months of $22.5 million. The consolidation will add the Independent Corporate Offices to EESI's assets as well as three other AMCSI companies: web development business Windango, health and wellness company Elite Ceuticals and telemarketing group Telemedia. Endocardial Solutions ECSI a medical products manufacturer, late Friday said it has been sued for alleged patent infringement by Biosense Webster, a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson JNJ, +0.55% Biosense Webster, which filed the suit in federal court in Los Angeles, claims that Endocardial Solutions' EnSite mapping and navigation system infringe upon certain of its patents. E-Trade Financial ET, +2.49% a discount brokerage, is expected to report Monday a profit of 18 cents a share for its third quarter. ExxonMobil XOM, +2.47% the oil giant, said Friday that it will take a third-quarter after-tax charge of $550 million as a result of the U.S. Supreme Court's decision to review part of the Allapattah case. The class action lawsuit was originally filed in Florida by a group of Exxon gas station dealers who claimed that the company did not provide them an offset for credit-card processing fees as Exxon had agreed to. The company said it "firmly believed it had provided dealers the offset as agreed." First Niagara Financial Group Inc. FNFG said it earned third quarter net income of $13.3 million, or 17 cents per share compared to $9.3 million, or 14 cents for the same period of 2003. The results surpassed the average analyst estimate of 16 cents per share compiled by Thomson Financial. First State Bancorporation FSNM posted third quarter net income of $4.1 million, or 53 cents a share compared with $4 million, or 53 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 47 cents a share on revenues of $20.9 million. Net interest income for the quarter rose to $17.5 million from $15.6 million while non-interest income edged up to $3.8 million from $3.7 million in the year ago period. Forest Laboratories FRX, -1.85% a drugmaker, is expected on Monday to post a profit of 76 cents a share for its fiscal second quarter. Hasbro Inc. HAS, +0.57% posted third-quarter net earnings of $88.7 million, or 45 cents per share, up from $68.5 million, or 38 cents, earned in the same period last year. Revenue slipped to $947.3 million from $971.1 million. CEO Alfred Verrecchia called the results "disappointing." According to Thomson First Call, analysts' average forecast had been for earnings of 51 cents on revenue of $992 million. HealthExtras HLEX a drug benefit manager, said late Friday that it has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a public offering of up to 5 million shares. The company is offering 3.5 million shares, with the remaining 1.5 million being offered by certain existing shareholders. Health & Nutrition Systems International HNNS which makes weight-management products, said late Friday that it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. It said TeeZee Inc., run by its former CEO, Christopher Tisi, will offer to acquire assets and assume debt for about $2.3 million. Dutch insurer ING Group ING, +0.06% said Scottish Re is taking over the obligations of its individual life reinsurance business in the U.S. ING made the decision to exit the U.S. business line after a review and a study of the mortality assumptions at the unit. ING expects a loss of 500 million euro on the transaction, including the ceding commission of EUR 450 million ($560 million) that it expects to pay Scottish Re. Intel INTC, +5.00% the computer chip king, is not likely to repeat its dominance in the cell-phone chip wars, says Barron's. Handset makers have diverse sources for the various functions that chips enable and Intel ranks behind such names as Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% STMicroelectronics STM, +0.63% and Philips Electronics PHG, +0.79% Barron's says. Intelligroup ITIGE which provides computer services, late Friday named Madhu Poomalil as chief financial officer. Poomalil, previously the CFO of Intelligroup's India unit, replaces David Distel. JDA Software JDAS said it signed a licensing pact with Sears, Roebuck and Co. S, +0.41% under with the retailer will use JDA solutions to manage its inventory. J.P. Morgan Securities upped its rating on Kinross Gold Corp. KGC, +1.80% to neutral from underweight. "This decision is based on the stock's improved relative value after its 34 percent fall relative to the XAU gold index since Feburary 2003." Kinder Morgan Energy Partners KMP, +0.63% said it has agreed to buy nine refined petroleum products terminals from Charter Terminal Company for about $75 million in cash and assumed liabilities. Including this transaction, Kinder Morgan has invested nearly $145 million to purchase 23 refined products terminals in the Southeast in the past 10 months. Lexmark International LXK which makes computer printers, is expected to reporting a 98 cents-a-share profit for its third quarter on Monday. Lone Star Technologies LSS, +2.46% which makes specialty metal products, reported third-quarter earnings late Friday of $26.8 million, or 91 cents a share. Analysts reporting to Thomson First Call were expecting, on average, 95 cents a share. Last year, it lost $17.1 million, or 60 cents a share. Lone Star said sales were $272.2 million, up from $132 million a year ago. ManTech International MANT, +2.44% was upgraded to "buy" from "neutral" by First Albany on the belief that the staffing and cost problems at its security services subsidiary, which performs personnel security investigations for the federal government, will be resolved within the next 6 months. Analyst Randall Scherago feels that will allow margins to expand and earnings to grow. He initiated a $24 stock price target. Mattel, Inc. MAT, +0.38% reported third-quarter earnings of $255.9 million, or 61 cents a share vs. $270 million, or 61 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 60 cents a share. Revenue fell 2 percent to $1.67 billion, missing analyst forecasts of $1.76 billion. Mattel Brands sales fell 9 percent, amid a 13 percent decline in Barbie sales, while Fisher-Price sales increased 7 percent and American Girl sales rose 9 percent. Medtronic MDT, +2.24% a medical products maker, said late Friday its Medtronic Sofamor Danek unit plans to appeal a permanent injunction that prevents it from manufacturing and selling certain multi-axial screws used in some spinal implants. The Minneapolis-based company also said an improved color-coded screw will be fully phased in the market before the injunction takes effect on Jan. 3. Ryan Beck analysts raised their rating on Mellon Financial Corp MEL, +0.58% to "outperform" from "market perform", saying the recent decline in its share price, particularly following a recent weak earnings report from rival State Street [s; stt], makes the shares attractive. "We believe Mellon will also have a challenging quarter, and expect that the Street has discounted this event at current price levels. Our price target of $30 reflects our matrix valuation methodology," the analysts said in their report Monday. Mercury General MCY, +1.37% a property and casualty insurer, said late Friday that it expects to take a third-quarter loss of $24 million related to recent Florida hurricanes. The company said the after-tax effect of the loss is estimated to be $16 million, or 29 cents per share. Nash Finch NAFC a wholesale foods distributor, said late Friday it will refinance its existing senior secured credit facility maturing in 2005. The company said it will use the proceeds to redeem by the end of the year $165 million in its outstanding 8.5 percent senior subordinated notes due 2008 and to prepay outstanding balances under the existing credit facility. The company said full redemption of the notes would result in charges of about $2.5 million for unamortized finance costs and original issuance discount. News Corp. NWS, +1.90% the media group controlled by Rupert Murdoch and presently based in Australia, said late Friday that its board decided to delay an internal restructuring that was to have taken place immediately following reincorporation in the United States. See full story. Odyssey HealthCare ODSY said the Department of Justice has launched a probe of the company under the False Claims Act, and is reviewing payment claims dating from Jan 1, 2000 to the present time. The company said it is cooperating with the probe. The company made the revelation as it announced that CEO David Gasmire is leaving the company, to be replaced by chairman Richard Burnham. "In light of the operational challenges we have experienced, all parties agreed that it was best to take quick action to put us back on a steady track," Burnham said in a statement. The company also warned that third-quarter earnings will come in at about 24 cents a share, 3 cents below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, due to weak admissions and increased competion. For the full year, the company expects earnings of 94 to 96 cents a share, below a prior outlook of $1.03 to $1.05. PalmOne PLMO, +0.00% was upgraded by JP Morgan to overweight from neutral. Pegasus Solutions PEGS a hotel reservations technology provider, said it has signed a multi-year contract extension to provide "commission processing and electronic distribution services" with Hyatt Hotels & Resorts through to June 2007. Penford Corp. PENX reported a fourth quarter net loss of $500,000, or 6 cents a share compared with a profit of $1.8 million, or 21 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. The maker of ingredient systems for food and industrial applications said sales for the quarter rose 5 percent to $72.3 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for a profit of 4 cents a share on sales of $64.5 million. Drugmaker Pfizer PFE, +0.54% is expected later to announce plans to fund a clinical trial of arthritis drug Celebrex for use to prevent heart attacks and strokes, the Wall Street Journal reported. If the study finds an increase in heart trouble, the results "could force swift backpedaling on a drug that is on track to achieve $3 billion in sales this year," according to the report. Shares of PPL Corp. PPL, +0.43% were downgraded to "market perform" from "outperform" in a valuation call by Wachovia Securities PrivateBancorp PVTB on reported third-quarter net income of $7.1 million, or 34 cents per share, up from $5.1 million, or 27 cents per share last year. The Chicago-based lender was expected to earn 31 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Pulte Homes PHM, +1.41% a home builder, is among four stocks Alan Abelson's column in Barron's mentions as possible short sales. Citing trader Doug Kass, a hedge fund partner at Seabreeze Partners who is described as holding short positions on the stocks, Remec Inc. REMC said Monday it sold its components business, a maker of high frequency parts for commercial, military and space applications, to Spectrum Control Inc. SPEC, +21.36% R.J. Reynolds, a division of Reynolds American RAI said it won an antitrust case brought in a federal court in Illinois by retailer Cigarettes Cheaper. Benicia, Calif.-based Cigarettes Cheaper had accused the tobacco company of denying it access to promotions and discount offers. SanDisk Corp. SNDK which makes flash memory devices, said late Friday it will redeem all its outstanding 4.5 percent convertible subordinated notes due 2006, a total of $150 million. The debt is to be redeemed on Nov. 18, though holders can convert to shares at a price of $9.39 a share. SanDisk closed Friday at $20.43. . Shares SAP SAP, +1.13% a German software maker, gained 0.40 percent to 127.05 euros in early trading after JP Morgan said it believes the group closed more deals in the third quarter than previously expected. JP Morgan said it had originally identified 10 large deals to close in the third quarter, but noted its "final channel checks indicated another 2 large deals were likely to have closed in the U.S. with possibly another deal just below the 5 million euros threshold in Europe." Select Medical Corp. SEM, -3.09% said it was being acquired by private equity firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe for $2.3 billion including debt, or $18 a share in cash. The deal values the hospital operator's stock at a 27 percent premium to Friday's closing price of $14.22. Following completion of the deal, which is expected in the first quarter of 2005, the company will continued to be run by its current management and remain headquartered in Mechanicsburg, Penn. Siemens SI said it expects at least 600 million mobile phones to be sold in 2004 globally, and it sees 10 percent growth in total global mobile phone sales in 2005, according to AFX News. "We have always been able to achieve 10 percent growth," said Lother Pauly, head of the Siemens fixed line and mobile unit, at a conference in Munich. He also reportedly said he was happy with Siemens' own business for the Christmas period, which is expected to be in line with the same period last year. SI International SINT, +0.00% and Booz Allen Hamilton were among several companies awarded a $610 million engineering, advisory and support services contract for Peterson Air Force Base in Colorado, the Defense Dept. said. SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% the student loan financier known as Sallie Mae, said late Friday it completed the purchase of Southwest Student Services Corp. from Helios Education Foundation for $500 million, a deal first announced Aug. 5. Southwest has a portfolio of $4.8 billion, which will boost Sallie Mae's total loan holdings to about $100 billion. Spectrum Control SPEC, +21.36% which makes electronic control systems, said late Friday that it bought a microwave communications division of Remec REMC for $8 million, with other payments dependent on orders received by the unit in the next six months. SRA International, Inc. SRX, +7.69% said it won a five-year, $47 million contract to provide information technology services to the Drug Enforcement Administration. Shares fell 68 cents to $51.30 on Friday. Starwood Hotels & Resorts HOT, -0.41% said it had reached a settlement with Caesar Park Hotels and Resorts. It said no money was exchanged in relation to an "outstanding lawsuit filed in New York State Court relating to Starwood's management practices at seven Caesar Park owned (Westin hotel) properties." It said its long-term management contracts with the seven Westin hotels mentioned in the suit will remain intact. Steel Dynamics STLD, +3.56% which makes flat rolled steel, is seen reporting earnings of $1.96 a share on Monday for its third quarter. Sensient Technologies SXT, +1.61% posted third quarter net income of $21.6 million, or 46 cents a share, compared with $20.7 million, or 44 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. Excluding a tax benefit, the maker of colors, flavors and fragrances posted earnings of 42 cents a share. Sales rose 3.9 percent to $256.8 million from $247.3 million. Taubman Centers TCO, -1.52% a realty management company, said late Friday it will stop running nine General Motors pension trust centers as of Nov. 1. Taubman said the agreement waives a required 90-day cancellation notice and that it will receive a $600,000 termination payment. Taubman will incur a related one-time $6 million charge in the fourth quarter, as previously announced. It expects a $4 million loss in net income in 2005 due to the contract loss. Taser International Inc. TASR said a Defense Dept. study concluded that technology used in the company's M26 and X26 weapons "is generally effective without significant risk of unintended results Tecnomatix Technologies Ltd. TCNO said it would implement its eMPower solutions at Severstal. Terms weren't disclosed. The system will enable Severstal, Russia's largest steelmaker, to more efficiently visualize, simulate and forecast facility operations, converter production and resource scheduling, Tecnomatix said. St. Paul-based 3M MMM, +1.38% reported third-quarter net income of $775 million, or 97 cents per share, up from $663 million, or 83 cents a year earlier. The Thomson First Call analysts consensus was for quarterly earnings per share of 98 cents. The diversified industrials company projected 2004 adjusted net income per share in the $3.68 to $3.69 range and said its annual sales should rise 7 percent from 2003 levels TXU TXU a Texas energy producer, is one of six S&P 500 stocks that could provide earnings surprises in the coming week. Also flagged by a database comparison of analyst estimates were Parker Hannifin PH, +1.71% Sprint FON, +5.56% Visteon VC, +2.18% Chiron CHIR and Ameren AEE, +1.23% See full story. United Airlines UALAQ the second-largest U.S. airline, is seeking additional cost cuts from its work force in the face of rising fuel prices, but the union representing the airline's pilots says it has no plans to yield further concessions. See full story. VaxGen VXGN a drug developer, said late Friday that the U.S. government has delayed awarding a contract for providing 75 million doses of anthrax vaccine until Nov. 5. VaxGen said it has extended its bid for the vaccine and it expects to be the only company negotiating for the contract. VaxGen also said it expects to complete its financial restatements for 2001 through 2003 and for the first three quarters of 2004 by mid-November. It said when it files the reports it plans to reapply for listing on the Nasdaq National Market. Vital Signs VITL, +0.00% which makes medical products, said late Friday that it expects 2005 earnings from continuing operations of $2.10 to $2.15 a share. That's up about 20 percent from the company's 2004 earnings. One analyst reporting to Thomson First Call was expecting 2005 EPS of $1.95. The company cited increased sales in its anesthesia and respiratory divisions. Visx, Inc. EYE, -0.28% was downgraded to "neutral" from "buy" at First Albany, citing concern over "good but not great" product survey results, deteriorating consumer sentiment data, difficult comparisons and increasing competition. Analyst Jason Mills cut his stock price target to $23 from $29, lowered his 2004 earnings estimate to 79 cents a share from 81 cents and his 2005 forecast to 98 cents a share from $1.01. Wachovia WB, +3.87% and SouthTrust SOT.R, +0.49% said late Friday that the Federal Reserve Board has approved their merger application. The companies said they will hold meetings on Oct. 28 for shareholders to vote on the deal. The banking firms said they expect to close the transaction on or about Nov. 1. In June, Wachovia said it was buying SouthTrust in a stock-for-stock deal valued at $14.3 billion. Whiting Petroleum WLL, +3.08% an oil and natural gas exploration firm, said that its third-quarter net income rose to $14.3 million, or 70 cents a share, from $8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a profit of 67 cents a share. Revenue rose 59 percent to $67.3 million. The company cited higher crude oil and natural gas prices for the increases in revenue and earnings W.W. Grainger, Inc. GWW, +1.73% reported third-quarter earnings of $67.7 million, or 74 cents a share, up from $56.8 million, or 62 cents a share, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 71 cents a share. Revenue rose 8 percent to $1.3 billion from last year's $1.2 billion, vs. analyst forecasts of $1.29 billion, boosted by 9 percent growth in its branch-based distribution business and a 20 percent increase in its Mexico business. The supplier of facilities maintenance products raised its 2004 earnings estimate to $2.80 to $2.90 a share from $2.65 to $2.85. title: Forest Labs, 3M, more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser International Inc. tasr said Monday a Defense Dept. study concluded that technology used in the company's M26 and X26 weapons "is generally effective without significant risk of unintended results." Shares of the stun gun maker rose three percent on Instinet to $38.90 in pre-open trading Monday.
title: Taser says Defense Dept. study shows weapons are safe

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW)-Taser International tasr Tuesday said it received an order for 360 Taser X26 weapons through Aardvark Tactical intended for the U.S. Army National Guard. The purchase value is over $440,000. The stock, which Monday closed down $2.75 at $37.89, is up 57 cents, or 1.5 percent, to $38.46 before the bell Tuesday.
title: Taser wins order for X26 weapons for U.S. Army

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Herman Miller fell in evening trading Wednesday after the office furniture maker reported mixed quarterly results and gave a tempered outlook, while Taser International added to earlier gains that stemmed from news British police could use its stun guns. The Nasdaq 100 After Hours Indicator, which tracks the evening trading of the technology-heavy index's leading shares, rose 0.48 points to close at 1,415.78. Earlier the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% fell 86.80 points to close at 10,231.36, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index $COMPQ dropped 18.88 points to 1,896.52. See full story. Herman Miller MLHR, +2.40% fell 3.5 percent to $23.18 after it reported a fiscal first-quarter profit of 20 cents per share on sales of $357 million. It had been expected to earn 20 cents per share on revenue of $366 million, according to analysts. It also gave a profit outlook for the second quarter that was weaker than current analyst expectations, forecasting earnings of 19 to 24 cents compared to an average forecast of 25 cents per share. Taser International TASR which rose 22 percent in the regular session, ended evening trading up 0.1 percent at $43.15 in active trading. The shares rose in the day session after British authorities said some police could use Taser's stun guns. See full story. Shares in Lawson Software LWSN dropped 9.5 percent to $5.55 after the company said it expects its fiscal first-quarter earnings to come in below the current estimates of analysts. It blamed lower business activity, slower customer decision making and contract deferrals. For the quarter, Lawson said it expects to post a loss of 1 cent to 2 cents per share on revenue of $82 million. Excluding one-time items, Lawson anticipated its per-share results would range from breakeven to earnings of 1 cent per share. On average, analysts currently anticipate earnings of 3 cents a share on sales of $92.3 million, according to a Thomson First Call survey. See full story. Applied Micro Circuits AMCC fell 1.2 percent to $3.25 after it said its chief executive would retire on August 25, 2005. Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% fell 0.1 percent to $47.40 after a broker lowered its view of the stock, citing a run-up in the shares and tough year-ago financial comparisons for the next 12 months. The share closed 4.3 percent lower in the regular session. Nara Bancorp NARA fell 1.3 percent to $19.25 after it said its accountants had resigned. Nara said there were no disagreements over financial matters. Shares closed the daytime session with a 7.2 percent loss. Most other trades in the evening session were in shares whose wide shareholder bases often produce active evening sessions. These include Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% Intel INTC, +5.00% Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% and Oracle ORCL, +1.71% Oracle was the most active share in the session as investor interest was even more pronounced than usual one day after it reported earnings that beat analyst expectations. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Herman Miller drops, Taser edges higher after the bell

content: Advancers American Medical Security AMZ, +1.49% skyrocketed more than 37 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by PacifiCare Health Systems PHS, -44.75% for roughly $532.2 million in cash and debt. Shares of PacifiCare, which also lifted its earnings outlook for 2005 to reflect expectations that the acquisition would add to earnings, gained almost 4 percent. See full story. Best Buy BBY, +2.09% shares jumped almost 5 percent after the Minneapolis consumer electronics retailer posted second-quarter results than edged Wall Street's consensus estimate by a penny. Looking ahead, it sees earnings of 41 to 47 cents per share in the third quarter and $2.80 to $2.93 per share for the full year. Wall Street's current consensus estimates are for earnings of 44 cents and $2.90 per share, respectively. See full story. Cedara Software CDSW shares rose almost 5 percent after the company agreed to acquire privately held radiology-software company eMed Technologies for $48 million in cash. Cedara said the deal will close in about 30 days and will pay for eMed through cash reserves and bank financing Cyberonics' CYBX shares leapt more than 14 percent after Advanced Neuromodulation Systems ANSI said it is prepared to buy Cyberonics for $22 a share in cash and stock. Cyberonics said it is not interested in a merger or business combination. Gottschalks GOT, +0.00% shares soared almost 23 percent after the company said it expects 2005 earnings to be 65 to 70 cents a share, and sees earnings growing by about 50 percent a year through 2006. There were no estimates available from Thomson First Call. The regional department store chain said same-store sales should increase 2 to 3 percent through 2006, while total sales should rise more than 3 percent a year. The company plans to open 2 new stores in both 2005 and 2006. Capital expenditures are projected to be $12 million to $13 million a year through 2006. Shares of Taser TASR rose almost 22 percent as the stun gun maker said it launched the Taser X26C Citizen Defense System, which private citizens can buy directly from the company's website at a retail price of $999. The company also said its Taser M26 product has been approved for use in England and Wales. Decliners Shares of Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% gave back more than 4 percent after KeyBanc Capital lowered its rating on the publishing software maker to "hold" from "buy" before the opening bell, citing valuation. The firm noted that the stock has gained 28 percent since the beginning of the year, and said it's currently trading above its peer group. KeyBanc also said Adobe is facing tough year-ago comparisons for the next 12 months. "We expects ADBE's shares to trade within a tight range over the near- to mid-term," the firm told clients. Shares of Alfacell ACEL tumbled more than 24 percent after the company disclosed a licensing agreement with the National Institutes of Health. The deal calls for Alfacell to evaluate a specific monoclonal antibody developed by a doctor at the NIH's National Cancer Institute branch. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Alfacell gets the right to develop commercial applications for the antibody, including those derived from its combination with Onconase, the company's treatment for malignant mesothelioma that's currently in phase III trials. Callaway Golf ELY, +0.62% shares slumped more than 16 percent after the company warned it doesn't expect to meet its third-quarter loss estimate of 37 cents a share to 42 cents a share on sales of $150 million to $160 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call were expecting a loss of 37 cents a share on sales of $165.4 million. The Carlsbad, Calif.-based maker of golf clubs and equipment cited a re-evaluation of the timing of new product launches, as well the status of currently available products. There are "several unknowns" that make it "inappropriate to set short term expectations," said recently appointed CEO William Baker, in a statement. Callaway also suspended its 2004 forecast of a profit of 15 cents a share to 25 cents a share on sales of $975 million to $990 million. See full story. Shares of Celestica CLS, +0.68% shares tumbled almost 14 percent after the electronics manufacturing-services provider cut its third-quarter revenue and earnings forecast. See full story. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% shares slid about 4 percent after the company warned that earnings for the second half of 2004 will fall short of current expectations due to weak volumes in North American and Germany and unseasonably cool and rainy weather in Northern Europe. The beverage behemoth expects earnings, excluding an impairment charge, of 46 to 48 cents a share in the third quarter, vs. the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 54 cents a share. Combined with the fourth quarter, earnings are expected to be 88 to 92 cents a share, vs. analyst forecasts of 99 cents. Global unit case volume is expected to be flat to up 1 percent in the third quarter, with "challenging conditions" continuing into the fourth. The stock, a Dow component, closed Tuesday up 7 cents at $42.87. See full story. Concord Camera LENS, +11.79% shares fell almost 7 percent after the company said it cannot file its fiscal 2004 annual report on time due to delays caused by the recent departure of its chief financial officer and the effects of Hurricane Frances, and would therefore seek an extension. The camera maker also said that it expects fiscal 2004 operating results to be significantly lower than 2003 results, although net sales are expected to be higher. . Copart CPRT, +2.21% shares slumped more than 6 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of 23 cents per share on revenue of $100 million, beating analyst expectations of 20 cents per share on revenue of $98 million. Its shares rose 5.1 percent in late trading after the announcement. Shares of Flamemaster FAME, +0.00% dropped almost 13 percent after the company disclosed that its board has authorized a 1-for-10 reverse split of its common stock, payable October 26 to shareholders of record on October 5. The Sun Valley, Calif., chemicals maker also said it plans to file to deregister its shares on the October 5 record date for the split, citing the prohibitive costs of maintaining odd lots of its shares for smaller investors and meeting the reporting requirements of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "The savings the Company will realize from these actions are expected to exceed the cost of reduced liquidity resulting from the Company's shares no longer being eligible to trade on Nasdaq," Flamemaster said in a statement. The company plans to pass the savings along to shareholders in the form of an increased quarterly dividend in the future and the buyback of up to 35,000 split adjusted shares over the next three years, a figure that represents about 50 percent of its float. See full story. Nara Bancorp NARA shares fell more than 7 percent after the company said its accountant Deloitte & Touche has resigned, effective immediately. The company said there were no disagreements over financial matters. Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% shares slumped almost 6 percent after the company received a downgrade from UBS. US Airways' UAIRQ shares plunged almost 26 percent after the company said it will be delisted from the Nasdaq as of market open on Sept. 22, the carrier said. The company's ticker has already been changed to "UAIRQ". US Airways, which declared bankruptcy for the second time in a year on Sunday, said its shares could still be traded on the "over-the-counter" market once they are delisted from Nasdaq. Shares of Xilinx XLNX, +1.25% fell more than 5 percent after the programmable-chip maker cut its fiscal second-quarter revenue outlook. See full story. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Adobe, Best Buy, Taser, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International leapt more than 20 percent Wednesday after news that British authorities will allow about 6,000 police officers to carry the company's weapons. A company statement quoted Homeland Secretary David Blunkett as saying police chiefs can permit officers to use Taser M26 guns in situations where firearms authority already exists. Police in Britain traditionally have not carried guns. "Five police forces have been trialing the use of Taser since April 2003 on a strictly limited basis," Blunkett said. Taser didn't say how much money it expects to earn as a result of the approval. Taser stock TASR TASR closed up $7.36 at $42.70 on volume of nearly 40 million shares. However, Joe Blankenship, an analyst who covers Taser for the Source Capital Group, said that sales of stun guns for about 6,000 officers likely would generate about $6 million to $7 million in revenue. If the United Kingdom eventually approves the stun guns to be used by a wider group of police officers, as Taser predicts, the company would receive "a very significant piece of business," Blankenship added. Taser tacked on gains in premarket activity Wednesday after it unveiled a new Taser X26C, which private citizens can buy directly from the company's Web site. The weapon's retail price is $999. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: Taser gains after British police allow stun gun use

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said Wednesday that the police forces in England and Wales have been authorized to use the company's Taser M26. Five UK police forces have been using the non-lethal weapon on a limited basis since April 2003. Shares of the company were halted in late morning trading on the Nasdaq. They last traded at $38.03, up $2.68, up 7.6 percent. (Corrects percentage rise)
title: Correct: UK police forces OKd to use Taser M26

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW)--Shares of Taser tasr moved higher in pre-market trade Wednesday after the stun gun maker announced the Taser X26C Citizen Defense System which private citizens can buy directly from the company's website. The retail price is $999. The technology is similar to that Taser sells to police departments but includes safeguards to ensure responsible usage, according to the company. The stock, which Tuesday rose $1.96 to $35.35, is up 1.3 percent to $35.82 on volume of 112,656 shares in premarket trade.
title: Taser unveils product for private citizens

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International's stock ended sharply higher Tuesday after the stun-gun producer announced new orders totaling more than $1 million from three U.S. police departments. Shares of Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser TASR closed up $2.01 at $35.38. The stock tends to rally on announcements of orders in the range of $1 million or more. The orders placed for the company's X26 conducted energy weapons are from police departments in Louisville, Ky., as well as Long Beach, Calif., and Miami. These departments have respective employment rolls of 1,246, 900 and 3,000 officers. Taser's board declared a three-for-one stock split early this year, followed by a two-for-one split declared in April. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock
title: Taser stock higher on word of additional X26 orders

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW)--Weapons seller Taser International tasr Tuesday said it received three orders totaling over $1 million for Taxer X26 conducted energy weapons. The orders were from police departments in Louisville, Ky., Long Beach, Ca., and Miami. The stock, which Monday closed up 53 cents at $33.39, in premarket Tuesday trade is up $2.60, or 7.8 percent, to $35.99 on volume of 44,677 shares.
title: Taser wins 3 order valued at over $1M

content: Advancers Shares of Apollo Group APOL, -1.69% climbed more than 8 percent after the provider of adult education classes said revenue for its first quarter and for 2005 would come in above analysts' expectations. See full story. Shares of Cardiac Science DFIB, +0.00% surged more than 8 percent after the Irvine, Calif., company was named sole provider of automated public access defibrillators for the Department of Health in England. It has received a related order for its Powerheart G3 products worth roughly $3 million. Shares of Coldwater Creek CWTR rose more than 10 percent after the Sandpoint, Idaho-based company retailer reported second-quarter earnings of $3.4 million, or 8 cents per share, up from its loss of $1.4 million or 4 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for breakeven results in the quarter. Sales for the second quarter rose 15.1 percent to $111.2 million from $96.7 million in the same period a year earlier. The women's apparel retailer attributed the improved results to continued strong customer response to its merchandise and said it saw strong full price selling for its spring and summer assortments. FNB Bankshares FBSH jumped more than 62 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by First National Lincoln FNLC, +0.11% for $47.9 million. Under the terms of the agreement, each outstanding share of FNB Bankshares is expected to be converted into FNLC stock valued at $42. The exchange ratio will vary depending on the share price of FNLC common stock prior to closing, but shareholders will receive not less than 1.91, nor more than 2.47, shares of FNLC for each share of FNB Bankshares. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2005. First National Lincoln shares rose almost 4 percent. . Lowrance Electronics LEIX rallied more than 12 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $2 million, or 51 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent of $1.2 million or 31 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 47 cents per share in the fourth quarter. Sales for the fourth quarter rose 17 percent to $27.1 million up from $23.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The Tulsa, Okla.-based digital mapping technology company attributed the improved results to its rapid product development pace and a 25 percent increase in research and development spending. Pre-Paid Legal Services PPD leapt more than 3 percent after the company said it started a self-tender offer for up to one million shares of its common stock, which represents approximately 6 percent of its outstanding shares. The offer will be in the form of a "modified Dutch auction tender. Pre-Paid Legal Services stockholders will be given the opportunity to sell part or all of their shares to the company for not less than $22.50 per share and not more than $26 per share. The offer will expire at 5 p.m. ET on Sept. 28. Shares of StockerYale STKR, -3.57% advanced more than 21 percent after the Salem, N.H.-based provider of photonics-based products named Richard Lindsay chief financial officer. Lindsay most recently served as CFO for Boston Beer Co. SAM, -0.11% and director of international business development. Taser TASR gained more than 4 percent after the company received follow-on purchase orders of $1 million for additional stun guns from police departments in El Paso, Texas, San Jose, Calif., Hillsborough County, Fla., and Knoxville, Tenn. Winton Financial WFI shares soared more than 31 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by WesBanco WSBC, -0.77% for $102.5 million cash and stock. See full story. Shares of Zygo ZIGO which distributes optical systems and metrology components for semiconductor and defense industry, rose more than 5 percent after its fiscal fourth-quarter results beat analyst expectations and it announced the sale of a property in Massachusetts. See full story. Decliners Advanced Micro Devices AMD, +2.45% fell more than 3 percent after Banc of America lowered its rating on the stock to "neutral" from "buy," citing expectations of pricing pressure in 2005. AO Smith AOS, +1.71% lost more than 9 percent after Robert Baird cut the stock to "neutral' versus "outperform" and said its earnings forecasts are in jeopardy. "We believe AO Smith's manufacturing improvements are still behind schedule and margins could be squeezed further after a recent round of steel surcharges," said analyst Michael Schneider. The analyst cut his 2004 earnings forecast to $1.75 vs. $1.85 and lowered his price target to $30 vs. $38. Shares were last trading down 9.5 percent at $23.74. Biosite BSTE gave back more than 4 percent after the company was downgraded by Suntrust Robinson Humphrey to "reduce" from "neutral" due to valuation concerns following the stock's recent run-up. The firm, which noted Biosite is up 69 percent for the year, said it believes the risk/reward scenario for the shares is now unfavorable in light of concerns about the current competitive landscape and the eventual commercial viability of the company's stroke product. Suntrust added that it's "unaware of any meaningful near-term catalysts that would drive the stock in the short-term." Boston Beer SAM, -0.11% fell more than 14 percent after the company said its expenses will increase in the last four months of this year due to new TV ad campaigns for its Samuel Adams Boston Lager and Sam Adams Light. Prudential dropped its rating on the stock to "neutral." See full story. Cirrus Logic CRUS, +3.31% slid more than 4 percent after the company said it was lowering its outlook for the second quarter and is cutting its work force by 7 percent, or 55 workers, to reduce expenses. See full story. Credence Systems' CMOS shares lost more than 6 percent after posting lower than expected third-quarter results. See full story. Cyberonics' CYBX shares fell more than 7 percent after the company said it's examining its options over an anti-depression drug after it received a not-approvable letter from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The company also raised its forecast for its fiscal second quarter saying it now expects to lose 14 cents a share. See full story. Fred's Inc. FRED, +4.91% dropped more than 11 percent after the Memphis, Tenn., off-price retailer reported second-quarter earnings of $3.1 million, or 8 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $4.4 million, or 11 cents per share, and a penny short of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The release of the quarterly numbers surprisingly came shortly after the company had said it wouldn't disclose the results until after Thursday's closing bell. Fred's said it saw disappointing sales in both June and July with weakness predominant in its apparel and home furnishings categories. In addition, the company said results were hurt by a shift in sales mix, increased markdowns, and higher transportation expenses. Kirkland's KIRK, +0.52% sank more than 19 percent after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $4.3 million, or 14 cents per share, matching the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Kirkland's, of Jackson, Tenn., reported net income of $1.27 million, or 4 cents per share, in the second quarter of 2003. Net sales rose 7.3 percent to $84.7 million in the recent quarter, even as same-store sales dropped 3.4 percent. Kirkland's also said it would post third quarter losses of 10 to 15 cents per share but a fiscal 2004 gain of 45 cents to 55 cents per share. First Call estimated the retailer would earn 6 cents per share in the third quarter and 79 cents for the year. Krispy Kreme Doughnuts KKD fell more than 10 percent after the company said second quarter ending Aug. 1 adjusted earnings fell to 12 cents per share from 22 cents in the year ago quarter, with revenue up 11.4 percent to $117.5 million. Analysts had expected 22 cents per share in adjusted earnings, according to First Call. It added that system-wide sales, including sales of company and franchise stores, increased 14.8 percent. It lowered its system-wide sales outlook for 2005 from approximately 20 percent to 25 percent to a new target of 15 percent. Six factory stores and three doughnut-and-coffee shops closed during the quarter. See full story. Shares of Omni Energy Services OMNI dropped more than 19 percent after the Carenco, La., geophysical services provider posted a second-quarter loss of $1.2 million, or 11 cents per share, for the second quarter. Excluding items such as interest and accounting charges, the company said it earned $2.2 million in the period. Omni explained that its revenue from seismic drilling for the quarter came in roughly $2 million below expectations due to abnormal weather conditions. In the same period a year earlier, the company earned $1.5 million, or 18 cents per share. Opsware OPSW shares fell more than 4 percent after the company said its loss in the second quarter narrowed as revenue more than doubled. See full story. Shares of Starbucks SBUX, -0.02% tumbled nearly 6 percent after the Seattle-based coffee specialist said its August sales rose 8 percent, well below expectations for a double-digit increase. The company said total sales came in 24.4 percent higher at $418 million for the period compared to $336 million a year ago. Ultimate Electronics ULTE dropped more than 22 percent after the company posted a second-quarter loss of $16.2 million, or $1.09 per share, wider than the loss of $1.8 million, or 12 cents, tallied in the year-ago period. The results "were below our expectations," said Dave Workman, president and CEO. The retailer's sales eased to $152.9 million for the three months ended July 31 from $154.2 million a year earlier, as comparable-store sales dropped 9 percent and gross margin narrowed to 32.7 percent from 33.9 percent. Analysts had been looking for sales of $155 million, according to a Thomson First Cal survey. The latest quarter's loss included a non-cash reversal of an income tax credit of $6.9 million. Shares of Zoran ZRAN dropped more than 8 percent after Needham cut the rating of the Sunnyvale, Calif.-based digital software provider to "hold" from "buy," citing increasing concerns about the overall health of the DVD player, DVD recorder and digital camera markets. The firm also cited the recent run-up in the stock and said it thinks competition is increasing. "With the shares up over 27 percent since the company's July 27 report of second quarter results, we encourage investors to take profits and move to sidelines," Needham told clients. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: AO Smith, Baxter Intl, EDS, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser tasr said it received follow-on purchase orders of $1 million for additional stun guns from police departments in El Paso, Texas, San Jose, Calif., Hillsborough County, Fla., and Knoxville, Tenn. Shares rose 48 cents to $27.10 on Wednesday.
title: Taser receives $1M worth of police department orders

content: Advancers Shares of Arbitron ARB, +0.00% which measures ratings for the radio industry, rallied more than 9 percent after the company raised its forecasts for the third quarter and 2004 after reaching a multi-year deal to provide its services to radio giant Infinity Broadcasting, which is owned by Viacom VIA Viacom is a significant shareholder in MarketWatch, the publisher of this report. Big Lots BLI tacked on 2 percent after the company posted a second-quarter loss of $7.3 million, or 6 cents per share, as opposed to a year-ago net loss of $8 million, or 7 cents. On an adjusted basis, the retailer had a year-earlier loss of 1 cent per share. Analysts had, on average, been looking for Big Lots to report a loss of 7 cents per share in the latest quarter ended July 31. The company's quarterly sales came in at $995 million, up from the prior year's $949.3 million but shy of the Thomson First Call-derived average forecast of $1.015 billion. Comparable-store sales inched up 0.2 percent. The company noted that "sales and customer traffic slowed abruptly during June and July." Shares of Biophan BIPH, +0.00% jumped 42 percent after the company said its TE-Bio unit has inked an agreement for joint development of nanoengineered thermoelectric materials with implantable medical devices with NASA. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed. Borders Group BGP, -4.96% leapt 4 percent after the company reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter profit, but revenue fell short of the analyst estimates. See full story. Shares of Brooks Automation BRKS, +1.92% rose more than 9 percent after the Chelmsford, Mass. chip equipment manufacturer was upgraded by Banc of America to "neutral" from "sell". The firm attributed the move to the current valuation, noting that the stock has surpassed its 12-month price target of $12.60. B of A, however, said it believes the current price reflects a "slowing industry environment" and left its price target intact. The firm thinks that the company's factory automation business remains the "wild card" for the company and it "suspects any wins here will contribute more to topline versus bottom given the intense competitive pricing environment." Brookstone BKST advanced 9 percent after the company reported that fiscal second quarter losses narrowed to $465,000 or 2 cents per share, compared to its year-ago equivalent loss of $2.3 million or 12 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 3 cents. Same-store sales for the 13 week period climbed 13.3 percent while total sales for the second quarter rose 22 percent to $98.3 million compared to the $80.5 million for same period a year ago. Looking ahead, the Nashua, N.H.-based specialty retail company sees a loss of between 33 and 36 cents per share for the third quarter, wider than Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a loss of 31 cents.
