Brookstone also lifted its outlook for the year to earnings of $1.10 to $1.12 per share from its prior projection for a profit of $1.07 to $1.10. CACI International CAI, +1.97% rose 2 percent after the company received a five-year, $126 million contract to support the U.S. Navy's maintenance processes and information systems. CACI said it would perform the work at Naval Sea Systems Command sites in Norfolk, Va., and Washington, D.C. Shares of ChipMOS IMOS, +0.00% leapt more than 21 percent after the company posted a profit of $19 million, or 32 cents per share, up markedly from its year-ago profit of $3 million, or 5 cents per share. Revenue soared 86 percent in the latest three months to $128 million from $69 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't provide a consensus estimate for the results of Taiwan-based provider of chips and chip-related services but the company itself said the performance was above its expectations. Delta Airlines DAL, +1.63% rose more than 13 percent following a report that the company is talking with pilots about exchanging an equity stake for certain benefits. See full story. Shares of Gander Mountain Co. GMTN rose 10 percent after the Minneapolis outdoor lifestyles products retailer posted a second-quarter loss of $3.7 million, or 26 cents per share, on sales of $128.1 million. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 7 cents per share on sales of $127.2 million. Looking ahead, the company, which completed its initial public offering in late April, said it expects sales of between $675 million and $700 million for fiscal 2004, surrounding Wall Street's current consensus estimate of $686.9 million. Hurco HURC, +2.02% shares surged 18 percent after the industrial technology company reported a sharp rise in third-quarter earnings, driven by strong sales of computerized machine tools. Indianapolis-based Hurco said it earned $1.6 million, or 25 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $331,000, or 6 cents, a year ago. Sales climbed 19 percent to $23.7 million, boosted by foreign exchange developments. "Order intake in the United States and Asia continues to be strong while order rates in Europe improved considerably in the third quarter," CEO Michael Doar said in a statement. Shares of Impac Medical Systems IMPC, -99.99% rose more than 8 percent after the company's independent auditor Deloitte & Touche resigned due to a disagreement regarding the timing of the recognition of certain revenues. The company said the disagreement arose during a review of its fiscal third-quarter results, and that it was unable to complete this review due to the resignation. As a result, Impac delayed filing its Form 10-Q for the June quarter. Impac, however, provided preliminary third-quarter results, saying sales increased 21.3 percent to $18.7 million and that operating income fell 31.2 percent to $2 million. The company noted that if it's unable to find an independent auditor by August 23 it may receive a notice from Nasdaq that its stock is subject to delisting. The news prompted Piper Jaffray to downgrade the stock to "underperform." Shares of Network Appliance NTAP, +3.73% rose 14 percent after the storage-technology company said its first-quarter profit rose 73 percent. See full story. Shares of Niku NIKU, +1.28% gained 29 percent after the company topped second-quarter earnings estimates, bolstered by demand for its IT- management and governance product. The company said late Tuesday it earned 11 cents a share in the quarter on revenue of $15.4 million, above consensus estimates of 7 cents and $14.6 million. "Niku had a strong quarter during a time when many software firms faced weaker demand," said Needham analyst Richard Davis. Niku's IT-MG platform "seems to be moving up the budget priority stack at many Global 2000 companies, he said. "The evidence is in another very good quarter as sales cycles inched down, revenues jumped 53% and EPS increased 11-fold," he said. "We believe that NIKU, which trades at a cash adjusted P/E on 2005E of 16 times, will prove to be a very good investment over the intermediate and long-term." Shares of Photronics PLAB, +1.23% added 9 percent after the company beat analyst forecasts for its third quarter. Photronics makes photomasks, a tool used to make semiconductors similar to the way that negatives are used to make photographs. See full story. Shares of Sontra Medical SONT, +183.33% soared more than 50 percent after the company received a 510(k) marketing clearance for its SonoPrep ultrasonic skin premeation device from the Food and Drug Administration. The clearance covers the SonoPrep device and procedure tray for use with topical lidocaine. Sontra anticipates a September launch of the product for this indication, which accelerates the anesthetic effects of lidocaine. Shares of Spanish Broadcasting Systems SBSA, +0.00% rose 12 percent after the company agreed to sell its Southern California radio stations, KZAB-FM and KZBA-FM, to Styles Media Group for $120 million. The Coconut Grove, Fla.-based company, the largest Hispanic-controlled radio broadcasting company in the U.S., said the sale is subject to Federal Communications Commission approval. It expects the deal to close in the fourth quarter. Standard Microsystems SMSC gained almost 6 percent after the company lowered its second-quarter revenue forecast due to a "general slowdown in orders" across all of its businesses. See full story. Talbot's TLB, -5.71% tacked on more than 2 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $19.4 million, or 34 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $18.5 million, or 32 cents per share. The latest results include a previously disclosed income tax benefit of $3.4 million, or 6 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 34 cents per share. Total sales rose 5 percent in the latest three months to $409.4 million from $389.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales increased 0.3 percent in the quarter. Looking ahead, the Hingham, Mass., apparel retailer said it's on track to open a net of 49 stores in the second half and that it continues to target 10 percent growth in earnings per share for the period. Taser International TASR added more than 4 percent after the company received five orders for its non-lethal weapons worth a total of $741,000. The Scottsdale, Ariz., energy weapon provider said the orders came from five law-enforcement agencies --the Milwaukee County Sheriff's Department, the Douglas County Sheriff's office in Colorado, and the Martin County, Orange County and Palm Beach County sheriff's office in Florida. A total of 770 Taser units were ordered. Decliners Dillard's DDS, +0.96% slid more than 7 percent after the company said its loss for the second quarter was $26 million, or 31 cents per share, narrower than a loss of $50.4 million or 60 cents per share last year. The year ago period included charges totaling 25 cents per share for asset impairment and interest expense. Analysts polled by Thomson First call, on average, had expected the company to lose 16 cents per share in the quarter. Dillard's second quarter sales fell to $1.67 billion versus $1.72 billion a year ago. The company also said same-store sales for the second quarter fell 3 percent. Engineered Support EASI fell 6 percent after SunTrust Robinson Humphrey cut 2005 estimates. Analyst Chris Donaghey said two programs he had expected to significantly boost growth in 2005 -- the $300 million Rapidly Installed Fluid Transfer System and the $200 million Minuteman missile silo environmental control unit upgrade -- are now more likely to hit in 2006. The analyst cut his organic growth estimate for the support systems division to 3 percent from 10 percent. At the same time, he raised his estimate for the support service business to 15 percent from 10 percent, creating a net revenue estimate of $920 million against $939 million. "That said, we view the near-term probability of EASI making a sizable acquisition as high,and we would expect to raise our estimates as a result," he said. Gentex GNTX, +1.86% tumbled more than 6 percent after the supplier of parts to auto manufacturers raised its quarterly cash dividend Wednesday by two cents to 17 cents per share but warned that third quarter shipments would be lower as major car makers increased shutdown times to reduce inventory. Gentex, of Zeeland, Mich., said North American light vehicle production declined 11 percent in July, more than expected, and said it would consequently reduce its auto-dimming mirror unit shipment growth estimate to 10 percent from 15 percent in the quarter. Shares of Hancock Fabrics HKF, +5.77% fell more than 4 percent after the Tupelo, Miss., fabric retailer and wholesaler posted a second-quarter loss of $2.7 million, or 15 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $1.6 million, or 9 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 4 cents per share in the July quarter. Sales sank 6.6 percent in the latest three months to $89.8 million from $96.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales dropped 6.7 percent in the quarter. The company said its business was hurt by a weak spring/summer merchandise position. Shares of KongZHong KONG slumped more than 16 percent after the company was hit with a sanction by China Mobile Communications Corp. The company said the sanction suspends approval of its new products until the end of the year. According to the company, China Mobile said the sanction is the result of its finding that one of KongzHong's interactive voice response services contained inappropriate content in early June. The sanction also suspends approval of the company's applications to operate in new platforms until June 30. KongZhong noted that interactive voice response services accounted for less than 2 percent of its revenue in the second quarter, and said it doesn't believe the sanction will have a material adverse impact on its results in the near future. Nanometrics NANO, +1.17% fell more than 4 percent after the company delayed the filing of its Form 10-Q for the quarter ended July 3 due to the planned resignation of Deloitte & Touche as its independent auditor. The company said Deloitte informed it of plans to resign on June 18 with the resignation to be effective upon completion of its review of Nanometrics' financial statements for the second quarter. The company said its transition to a new accounting firm caused it to be unable to finalize its financials within the prescribed period. Nanometrics expects to file the document within five days. Synovis Life Technologies SYNO dropped more than 6 percent after the company said its third quarter net income fell to $187,000, or 2 cents per share, versus $1.5 million, 14 cents per share a year ago. Third-quarter consolidated net revenue was $15.1 million compared to $15.3 million in the same period last year. According to analysts polled by Thomson First Call, the company was expected to earn 8 cents per share. The company also withdrew its previous earnings outlook for the year and won't provide an outlook for the fourth quarter. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Engineered Support, Delta Airlines, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr received five orders for its non-lethal weapons worth a total of $741,000. The Scottsdale, Ariz., energy weapon provider said the orders came from five law-enforcement agencies --the Milwaukee County Sheriff's Department, the Douglas County Sheriff's office in Colorado, and the Martin County, Orange County and Palm Beach County sheriff's office in Florida. A total of 770 Taser units were ordered. Shares of Taser closed Tuesday up 44 cents at $26.34.
title: Taser receives orders worth $741,000

content: Advancers Shares of Alkermes ALKS, -2.14% rallied more than 8 percent after the drugmaker said Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% has decided to proceed with a "significant investment" to develop an inhaled formulation of insulin. Financial details were not disclosed. The development will include new clinical trials and manufacturing activities for the inhaler system and the production facility. Shares of AmeriCredit ACF, +0.00% jumped more than 15 percent after the auto financing company beat Wall Street's quarterly earnings outlook and raised its forecast for 2005. See full story. Arena Pharmaceuticals ARNA, -0.28% added more than 6 percent after the company received a $3 million milestone payment from Merck MRK, -1.13% The payment was related to assay development under their cardiovascular collaboration. BMC Software BMC, -2.86% gained almost 3 percent after the company revised its previously-reported fiscal first-quarter net earnings sharply lower after an analysis of its tax accrual. See full story. Church & Dwight CHD, +2.27% advanced more than 3 percent after the company said it earned $19.6 million, or 45 cents a share, in the second quarter, down from $24.6 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. The figure includes pretax accounting charges of $12.1 million, or 17 cents a share, stemming from the acquisition of the remaining 50 percent stake in Armkel, which closed on May 28. Excluding those charges, the maker of personal care products earned 62 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 44 cents a share. Sales climbed to $340.8 million from $256.3 million. The company raised its 2004 earnings outlook to $2.10 to $2.12 a share, up from a prior $2.07 to $2.10 a share. Taking a planned 3-for-2 stock split into account, the outlook is for earnings of $1.40-1.41 a share. D &K Healthcare Resources DKHR surged almost 3 percent after the company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings of $3.2 million, or 22 cents per share, down from $4.2 million, or 29 cents, in the year earlier period. The latest results include a 10-cent special item related to a legal settlement. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 22 cents. The St. Louis-based drug distributor's revenue in the fourth quarter rose 35 percent to $718 million, driven partly by the acquisition of Walsh HealthCare in December 2003. Looking ahead, D&K expects fiscal 2005 earnings per share in a range of 65 to 80 cents. Wall Street consensus forecasts earnings of 77 cents. EchoStar Communications DISH, +1.20% rose more than 8 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $85 million, or 18 cents a share, down from 27 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose 26 percent to $1.78 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 22 cents a share and revenue of $1.67 billion, on average. The satellite TV company added 340,000 subscribers during the quarter, and now has about 10.13 million subscribers as of the end of June. Separately, the company increased its stock buyback program by $1 billion. Shares of Esco Technologies ESE, +1.47% rallied more than 12 percent after the St. Louis provider of engineered filtration products posted strong third-quarter results and lifted its outlook for the full year. The company posted operating earnings of $11.2 million, or 84 cents per share, in the third quarter, well ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 67 cents per share. Sales jumped 19 percent in the latest three months to $107.9 million. The company said it saw "significantly higher shipments" of its automatic meter reading equipment to electric utility customers during the quarter, and that its results reflect the success of its restructuring program. Looking ahead, Esco forecast operating earnings of $2.80 to $2.85 per share for the full year, ahead of its previous projection for a profit of $2.80 to $2.85 per share. Earlier in the session, the stock reached a 52-week high of $56 Fossil FOSL, +2.09% jumped more than 8 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $15.8 million, or 21 cents a share, up from 14 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 17 cents a share. Revenue rose 29 percent to $206.1 million, topping analyst forecasts of $190 million, boosted by strong sales of Michele brand watches and of Fossil jewelry and watches abroad. Same-store sales of company-owned retail stores rose 12 percent. The fashion accessories seller said it expects third-quarter earnings of 30 cents a share, in line with analyst forecasts, and 2004 earnings of $1.21 to $1.24 a share, which is above analyst projections. Hospira HSP, +0.18% jumped more than 7 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $135.9 million, or 80 cents per share, compared with $67.5 million, or 43 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Lake Forest, Ill. hospital products maker said revenue climbed to $667.4 million, up 2.8 percent. Excluding items, second-quarter EPS were 56 cents. The company was expected to earn 38 cents per share, according to a survey of one analyst by Thomson First Call. infoUSA IUSA, +1.50% shares added more than 3 percent after the company said it has prepaid $5 million in its principal debt under its credit facility and re-affirmed its fiscal 2005 outlook. See full story. Shares of Ionics ION, +2.17% gained more than 9 percent after the Watertown, Mass., provider of water purification and wastewater treatment products and services posted breakeven results before items on a continuing operations basis in the second quarter. In the same period a year earlier, the company posted an equivalent loss of $2 million, or 11 cents per share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $125.8 million from $83.6 million in the same period a year earlier. La-Z-Boy LZB, -2.76% rose more than 4 percent, bouncing off a 52-week low, after reporting a fiscal first-quarter loss and unveiling plans to close four facilities and lay off about 645 workers. See full story. Lions Gate Entertainment LGF gained more than 5 percent after the company said that it expects more than $700 million in revenue in fiscal 2005, partially due to the proceeds from the Michael Moore documentary hit "Fahrenheit 9/11." See full story. May Department Stores' MAY, +0.00% stock rose more than 6 percent after the St. Louis department store retailer reported second-quarter earnings of $101 million, or 33 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $110 million, or 39 cents per share. The latest results include store divestiture costs of $15 million, or 3 cents per share, so on an operating basis the company earned 36 cents per share, a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales slipped 1.5 percent in the latest three months to $2.96 billion from $3 billion in the same period a year earlier. Same-store sales fell 2.2 percent in the quarter. The company said it saw good sales in a number of merchandise categories but that its overall sales performance missed internal expectations. Shares of Merge Technology MRGE, +0.56% leapt more than 9 percent from an upgrade to "buy" from "hold" by WR Hambrecht, which cited "excellent" industry fundamentals and an "attractive" valuation. Shares of the provider of integration software and hardware to healthcare organizations were last up $1.18 at $14.27. That still allowed for a gain of 40 percent to Analyst Sean Wieland's 12-month price target to $20. "We believe shares of Merge are undervalued relative to the peer group, especially when factoring in our estimated 47 percent earnings growth rate in 2005," Wieland said in a note to clients. Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% gained more than 5 percent after the company said that it plans to buy back up to $300 million worth of common stock. Shares of Pulitzer PTZ surged more than 6 percent after Banc of America raised its rating of the company to "neutral" from "sell." The firm attributed the move to valuation with the stock trading below its target price of $45. BofA believes "significant further downside is limited," but it thinks the stock will trade "in a narrow range until the ad environment improves." Analyst John Janedis added that the St. Louis market is the "the key" for the media company, given that 71 percent of its revenue comes from the city and surrounding area. Shanda Interactive Entertainment SNDA rose more than 9 percent after the Chinese online games operator reported a sharp increase in second-quarter earnings. Shanghai-based Shanda said earnings rose 67.2 percent to $17 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter, as revenue climbed 108.8 percent to $36.5 million. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for earnings of 15 cents a share. Shares of Sola International SOL, +1.95% leapt more than 14 percent after the San Diego eyeglass lense maker reported first-quarter adjusted earnings of $10.5 million, or 32 cents per share, a penny ahead of the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The company said it saw "excellent sales growth" in all of its key product categories, and that sales of new products are expanding at a faster rate than sales being lost on older designs and coatings. Overall, sales increased 7.3 percent in the latest three months to $165.2 million from $154 million. Looking ahead, Sola reaffirmed its outlook for earnings of between $48 million and $50 million in fiscal 2005. Shares of Sonic Solutions SNIC rose more than 13 percent after the company agreed to acquire Roxio's ROXI consumer software business for $80 million. The deal calls for Sonic to swap $70 million in cash and $10 million worth of its common stock for the business, which includes Roxio's CD and DVD recording, authoring, photo and video editing application products. Sonic expects the deal to close in the fourth quarter of calendar 2004. Roxio shares tacked on less than a penny in afternoon action. The move is part of a change in strategy for Roxio, which plans to concentrate on the digital music market and change its name to Napster. Taser TASR soared more than 8 percent after the company received orders for non-lethal weapons totaling more than $724,000. The orders came from four law enforcement agencies: Glendale Police Department in Arizona, Fremont Police Department in California, Pinellas County Sheriff's Office in Florida and an unnamed agency. The three named agencies ordered 541 Taser units and accessories. Taser, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., expects to ship the order in the third quarter. Shares of Transmeta TMTA surged more than 12 percent after Schwab SoundView upgraded the chipmaker to "neutral" from "underperform," citing valuation. Analyst Hans Mosesmann says downside risk is limited, given that the stock had already fallen 38 percent, as of Monday's close, since the company reported "disappointing" quarterly results on July 22. He reiterated his $1 stock price target, and said he was still "comfortable" with his third-quarter forecasts for a loss of 12 cents a share and revenue of $8 million. Shares of Urologix ULGX, +0.00% leapt more than 19 percent after the Minneapolis medical products maker reported fourth-quarter earnings of $837,000, or 6 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $3.7 million, or 27 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 4 cents per share in the June quarter. Revenue rose 35 percent in the latest three months to $7 million from $5.17 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 20 to 26 cents per share on revenue of between $30 million and $32 million in fiscal 2005. ValueClick VCLK jumped more than 10 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter net income of 6 cents a share, in line with its previous estimate, and lifted its revenue guidance for the quarter and year. The affirmed estimate includes amortization of intangible assets tied to completion of its purchase of Pricerunner. ValueClick said it closed that transaction for $29 million plus as much as $6 million more if Pricerunner meets performance milestones. ValueClick, a Westlake Village, California, provider of interactive media and technology services, now expects third-quarter revenue of $37 million to $39 million, up from prior guidance of $36 million to $37 million. For 2004 ValueClick projects revenue at $150 million to $154 million, compared with prior guidance of $147 million to $150 million. Decliners Andrx ADRX plummeted more than 16 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of 9 cents a share on sales of $290.6 million. Analysts had been expecting earnings of 33 cents a share on sales of $303 million. Bally Total Fitness Holding BFT, -0.54% fell more than 7 percent after the company said it would postpone the release of its second-quarter earnings release and the filing of its 10-Q with securities regulators because of an investigation of "certain accounting issues." See full story. Cal-Maine Foods CALM, -4.17% tumbled more than 3 percent after the company said it sees a greater supply of eggs in the year ahead, but maintained that consumer demand for eggs "will remain strong in the near-term." The outlook from the Jackson, Miss. food producer came as it moves into fiscal 2005. "Given the highly cyclical nature of egg pricing, the company would maintain its policy of not forecasting future earnings results," said Cal-Maine. "The strongest seasons for egg demand are prior to the Thanksgiving, Christmas, and Easter holidays, while the months between Easter and Labor Day are generally a period of lower demand." Cephalon CEPH dropped more than 9 percent after the company and merger partner Cima Labs CIMA secured clearance for their combination from the Federal Trade Commission. Under a consent agreement with the FTC, Cephalon has agreed to grant a license to its ACTIQ cancer pain product to Barr Labs BRL, -30.00% Cephalon expects to close the deal in the next few days, and it lifted its outlook for the remainder of the year to reflect Cima's addition. Shares of Dobson Communications DCEL plunged more than 55 percent after the company lowered its performance expectations for 2004. See full story. Shares of Ecollege.com ECLG dropped almost 19 percent after the Denver-based provider of post-secondary education information services offered a disappointing outlook for the third quarter. For the second quarter, Ecollege.com reported a preliminary profit of $654,000, or 3 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $275,000, or 2 cents per share. Excluding non-cash charges of $1.6 million related to stock-based compensation, the company earned $2.2 million, or 10 cents per share, in the June period. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 9 cents per share. Looking ahead, the company sees adjusted earnings of $2 million to $2.3 million, or 9 to 10 cents per share, for the third quarter, below Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 13 cents per share in the period. Kmart KMRT shares fell more than 3 percent after the company revised lower the number of stores it would sell to Home Depot HD, +1.99% given that certain closing conditions were not satisfied. The discount retailer now expects to sell no less than 13 stores for $173 million in cash, and up to 19 stores for $288.5 million in cash. Kmart was also granted an option to raise the minimum number of stores to sell to 15 for $214 million. On June 4, Kmart said it would sell up to 24 stores for up to $365 million. NDCHealth NDC shares plunged more than 25 percent after the company said it swung to a fiscal fourth-quarter loss on a charge related to an investment and lower sales of its physician software and information management products. PTEK PTEK shares slumped more than 23 percent after Morgan Keegan cut the stock to "market perform" vs. "market outperform" and said that the disclosure in an SEC filing that IBM is mulling the use of new technologies such as VoIP could negatively impact revenues at PTEK's teleconferencing division. "Although the risk of IBM as a large customer has always been part of Premiere Conferencing's business, this is the first time that PTEK has mentioned in a public filing that we are aware of that IBM is actively exloring the use of new technologies," analyst Tavis McCourt told clients in a note. McCourt said he still expects near-term results to be strong, with any revenue impact likely to come in the second half of 2005 and beyond. Shares of Orthodontic Centers of America OCA, +0.55% lost more than 13 percent after the Metairie, La., provider of business services for orthodontists reported second-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or a nickel per share, down from its year-ago pro forma profit of $4 million, or 8 cents per share. Patient revenue fell in the latest three months to $104.3 million from $111 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of Sina.com SINA, +4.55% fell more than 11 percent after the China-based Internet services firm revealed in a filing late Monday that its interactive voice response (IVR) service with China Mobile CHL, +0.22% had been temporarily suspended due to violations of certain policies "The company is not certain that its IVR service with China Mobile can be restored in the near future," Sina said in a 10-Q filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. The company said revenue and earnings for the current and future quarters could be "negatively impacted" if the IVR service with China Mobile is not restored soon, of if China Mobile chooses to impose monetary penalties. The company said business had accounted for 4 percent of total second-quarter revenue and 7 percent of mobile revenue Six Flags PKS, +26.12% dropped more than 13 percent after the company said that a hoped-for July turnaround failed to materialize as it experienced a second-quarter slump in attendance and revenue. See full story. Shares of Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts DJT, +2.05% lost more than 6 percent after the company said it has reached a deal with DLJ Merchant Banking to recapitalize the company and filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. See full story. 4Kids Entertainment KDE fell more than 14 percent after the New York provider of children's entertainment products reported second-quarter earnings of $2 million, or 14 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $3.6 million, or 26 cents per share. The average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 30 cents per share in the June quarter. Revenue fell in the latest three months to $22.1 million from $23.4 million in the same period a year earlier. 4Kids explained that it experienced less favorable margins in the second quarter. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Merge Tech, Sina.com, 4Kids, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser tasr received orders for non-lethal weapons totaling more than $724,000. The orders came from four law enforcement agencies: Glendale Police Department in Arizona, Fremont Police Department in California, Pinellas County Sheriff's Office in Florida and an unnamed agency. The three named agencies ordered 541 Taser units and accessories. Taser, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., expects to ship the order in the third quarter. Shares of Taser closed Monday down 22 cents at $26.63.
title: Taser receives orders totaling $724,000

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taser shares tumbled nearly 15 percent Monday ahead of a CBS News' scheduled airing of a video that the network said shows a fatality involving the company's much-hyped stun gun. An "Eye on America" segment will be shown during the evening newscast, which airs at 6:30 p.m. in New York, and will focus on an official report about a prisoner who died after being shot with a Taser gun, according to CBS. Taser's fall was just the latest blow to the stock TASR which has seen its value drop by nearly one-half in the past month amid safety questions. Shares of Taser closed down $4.29 at $25.23. In April, the stock set an all-time high of $64.14. Discuss Taser. Last week, the stock shed nearly 20 percent after newspaper reports called into question Taser's claims of its "less-lethal" weapon's safety. The Taser stun gun, typically used in police work, is the company's flagship product. See full story. Just a week ago, news releases from the company referred to its stun guns as "advanced, non-lethal" weapons. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company sought to refute the reports. It said that to correct "all the misleading information would require a manuscript longer that the article itself." Taser says that police avoided serious injuries or death in at least 5,000 incidents by using the stun gun instead of a conventional firearm. Analyst Brian Ruttenbur of Morgan Keegan maintained his "market perform" rating on the volatile stock, cautioning that these concerns could linger. "This has been building for awhile and it will remain an issue with the press," he said. "As we hear more and more about deaths related to Taser, there's going to be an outcry for independent health research into what's really causing this." Lost in the fallout triggered by the stories, Taser delivered earnings Tuesday that came in above the average Wall Street forecast, as revenue rose fourfold to $16.3 million. "The numbers they reported weren't bad; the decline is all based on the concerns of a rising death rate," Ruttenbur added. Taser reported that by the end of June, 930 law enforcement agencies had purchased Taser stun guns, with another 5,400 departments currently testing them in the U.S. and Canada. CBS parent Viacom is a significant investor in MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000
title: Taser falls as death count concerns mount

content: Advancers Agilysys' AGYS shares rose more than 18 percent in early trades after the Cleveland-based computer technology provider swung to a profit in the first quarter and lifted its outlook for the remainder of the year. The company earned $3.9 million, or 14 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30, up from its year-ago equivalent loss of $1.5 million, or 5 cents per share. Sales jumped 38 percent in the quarter to $386.7 million from $279.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 12 cents per share in the quarter. Agilysys cited aggressive marketing and an improving information technology spending environment for its strong performance. Looking ahead, the company now sees earnings of 83 to 93 cents per share in fiscal 2005 with sales growth of 20 to 25 percent from its fiscal 2004 total of $1.4 billion. American Express AXP shares added more than 2 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $876 million, or 68 cents a share, up from 59 cents share in the same period a year ago, and a penny a share above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 14 percent to $7.26 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $6.91 billion, amid 14 percent growth from its travel-related services business, 18 percent growth at its financial advisors business and 2 percent growth at its banking unit. See full story. Anadigics ANAD gained more than 12 percent after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $11.7 million, or 36 cents a share, narrower than the 45 cents a share it lost in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, such as workforce reduction and facility closure charges, the loss was 33 cents a share, vs. the average analyst loss estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 37 cents. Revenue rose 26 percent to $22.7 million, boosted by a 35 percent increase in broadband revenue. Looking ahead, the wireless chip maker expects losses for the sequential third quarter to narrow by 7 to 8 cents a share and revenue to grow 6 to 12 percent, vs. current analyst forecasts of losses narrowing by 7 cents and revenue growth of 11 percent. Shares of AT&T T rose more than 3 percent following a report that the company may be an acquisition target. Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Co., a private buyout firm, has issued a denial of the report, which appeared in Newsweek. Bel Fuse BELFA advanced more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $7.1 million, or 62 cents per share, up from $2.8 million, or 25 cents per share, last year. The latest results included a $2.4 million gain from a lawsuit settlement and a $1 million fixed-asset write-down. The net effect boosted after-tax earnings by 12 cents per share. The average analyst estimate for the same period as polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 46 cents per share. Revenue for the period ending June 30 rose 8 percent to $48.4 million, reflecting sales gains in all of the company's product lines. BellSouth BLS advanced more than 2 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $939 million, or 51 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $908 million, or 49 cents per share. On a normalized basis, including the contribution of BellSouth's 40 percent stake in Cingular, the company earned $938 million, or 51 cents per share, on revenue of $6.7 billion. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 50 cents per share on revenue of $6.65 billion in the June period. See full story. Boise Cascade BCC shares rose more than 5 percent after the company said it was selling its paper, forest product and timberland assets for $3.7 billion to affiliates of Boise Cascade LLC, which is a new company formed by private equity investment firm Madison Dearborn Partners. The deal completes Boise's plan, announced in July 2003, to transform to a distribution company from a manufacturing based company. When the deal is completed, expected to be in mid-November 2004, the company will change its name to OfficeMax, and will trade on the NYSE under the ticker "OMX." Boston Scientific BSX surged more than 5 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $313 million, or 36 cents per share, up from earnings of $114 million, or 13 cents per share, a year ago. Excluding charges, the Natick, Mass., medical device provider earned $377 million, or 44 cents per share. The average analyst estimate for the same period as polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 45 cents per share. The company's revenue in the period ended June 30 rose 71 percent to $1.46 billion, partly due to the growing use of drug-coated stents. Shares of Capitol Federal Financial CFFN gained more than 5 percent after the company's Capitol Federal Savings Bank unit refinanced $2.4 billion worth of its fixed-rate borrowings. The company said the transaction reduces its cost on the debt by 2.35 percent per share. It expects the deal to result in an initial annual savings of $47.5 million through the lower interest expense. Shares of Cardiac Science DFIB jumped more than 9 percent after the Irvine, Calif., medical device maker said it continues to see "strong demand" for its Powerheart line of automatic public access defibrillators and related training services from corporations in the U.S. Specifically, the company said it shipped more than 2,400 of these products to U.S. corporate customers in the second quarter with the majority of these customers purchasing training and program management services. Cardiac Science attributed the orders to expanded investment in direct marketing programs. Shares of Carpenter Technology CRS rose more than 7 percent after J.P. Morgan upgraded the company to "overweight" from "neutral." The firm believes the Wyomissing, Pa., metal provider is positioned to benefit from an uptick in the aerospace industry and its cost-cutting initiatives. Cognizant Technology Solutions CTSH leapt more than 13 percent after the company said it earned $23.8 million, or 17 cents per share, in the second-quarter, up from $13.5 million, or 11 cents, a year-ago and besting the 15 cents a share average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue for the quarter was $138.7 million, above both the $87.4 million posted last year and the $129.8 million First Call estimate. Looking ahead, the IT services provider said it expects third-quarter earnings per share of 17 cents on revenue of at least $150 million and earnings of 66 cents a share on revenue of at least $565 million for all of 2004. First Call forecasts are for earnings of 16 cents a share and revenue of $140.9 million for the third-quarter and earnings of 61 cents on revenue of $543.4 for 2004, on average. Coventry Health Care CVH added more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $84 million, or 93 cents a share, up from 70 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 87 cents a share. Revenue rose 19 percent to $1.3 billion, amid a 19 percent increase in managed care premiums and 31 percent growth in management services. Looking ahead, the health plan services company expects earnings of 93 to 95 cents a share in the third quarter, above analyst forecasts of 92 cents, and earnings of $3.60 to $3.65 for 2004, vs. analyst projections of $3.56. Humana HUM advanced more than 6 percent after the company posted second-quarter earnings of $80.6 million, or 50 cents per share, up from the prior year's $69.3 million, or 43 cents, as revenue reached $3.43 billion from $3.03 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting 39 cents earned on $3.36 billion for the latest quarter. The health benefits provider also raised its forecast for the full year. For the third quarter, Humana expects earnings of 43 to 44 cents per share, including special expenses totaling two cents. For all of 2004, earnings are projected at $1.63 to $1.67 per share. Shares of InfoSpace INSP rose more than 5 percent after First Albany upgraded the company based on an upbeat outlook for its Moviso mobile business unit. Analyst Jason Avilio lifted his rating on the Internet and wireless services group to "buy" from "neutral" saying the recent sell-off in the company's stock combined with strong industry demand for data services make the company an attractive investment. Avilio added that revenues should also benefit from an expanded relationship with Verizon VZ and its acquisition of Atlas Mobile, a mobile games company. Shares of International Game Technology IGT rose more than 5 percent after brokerage CIBC World Markets upgraded the company, saying the recent sell-off in the stock offers an attractive entry point for investors. Analyst William Schmitt upped his rating on the slot machine to video game maker to "sector outperform" from "sector perform," saying the company and the industry's fundamentals remain solid longer-term despites difficult near-term unit sales comparisons, which sparked the pullback on the stock. Schmitt added that management's recent unit sales outlook appears "conservative." International Paper IP tacked on more than 2 percent after the Dow component reported second-quarter earnings of $193 million, or 40 cents a share, more than double the 19 cents a share it earned in the same period a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations, and excluding non-recurring items, earnings were 41 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 38 cents a share. Revenue rose 6.6 percent to $6.5 billion, just shy of the $6.6 billion expected by analysts, as an improvement in economic conditions in North America, Eastern Europe and South America was partially offset by "less robust" growth in Western Europe. Meanwhile, volumes and average sales prices increased while interest expenses decreased. For the third quarter, the paper company expects weakness in wood products earnings and higher transportation and chemical costs and continued high energy costs to offset strong paper and packaging demand. See full story. Jarden JAH rose more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $16 million, or 57 cents a share, compared with $10 million, or 45 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Sales for the quarter jumped 52 percent to $199 million from $130.8 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 55 cents a share on sales of $189.2 million. King Pharmaceuticals KG soared more than 30 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Mylan Labs MYL in a stock deal valued at $4 billion. Under terms of the agreement, each King share will be exchanged for 0.9 Mylan shares. Based on Friday's closing prices, the deal values King shares at $16.66 each, or a 61 percent premium. See full story. Share of ManTech MANT gained more than 13 percent after it won a four-year U.S. government contract with a potential value of $50 million to $100 million a year. Under the terms of the contract, the U.S Office of Personnel Management has selected ManTech, as one of main contractors to conduct security clearance background investigations for a number of federal agencies including the Department of Homeland Security, Department of Defense and the Department of Energy. Microsoft MSFT shares gained almost 2 percent after a positive Barron's cover story. See full story. Shares of Oakley OO rose more than 4 percent after founder and CEO Jim Jannard said he plans to buy up to 2 million shares of the company, subject to market conditions. On July 13, shares of the eyewear group tumbled 7.5 percent after it warned that a slowdown in second quarter sales could bring full-year profits in at the bottom of previous forecasts. "Although our recently announced second quarter earnings were lower than our initial expectations, consumer response to our newest 2004 sunglass introductions has been strong and forced our in-house manufacturing operations and third-party vendors to scramble to respond to demand," said Jannard. In a separate statement, the company also announced it plans to open a flagship "O" store located in the Covent Garden area of London. RealNetworks RNWK shares climbed more than 4 percent after the digital media software- and services-provider announced the launch of its Harmony technology, aimed at allowing consumers download music to all the new music devices, including Apple's iPod. The company also said it added 100,000 subscribers to its digital music services in the second quarter, bringing its total subscriber base to more than 550,000. Shares of Smithway Motor Express SMXC rose almost 21 percent after the Fort Dodge, Iowa-based truckload carrier posted first-quarter earnings of $665,000, or 13 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $458,000, or 9 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Revenue rose 10.5 percent in the latest three months to $46.7 million from $42.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said average revenue per seated tractor rose 16.6 percent in the quarter. Smithway added it remains in compliance with all loan covenants as of June 30, and that it expects to remain in compliance throughout the year. Standard Motor Products SMP advanced more than 6 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $6.7 million, or 35 cents a share up from its profit of $3.9 million, or 31 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago. Earnings from continuing operations were $7.5 million or 38 cents a share. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 33 cents a share. Sales for the quarter jumped to $235 million from $166.1 million, boosted by its acquisition of Dana Corporation's engine management division (DEM). Gross margins for the period ticked up to 26.5 percent from $26.4 percent in the third quarter of 2003, and up from 24.9 percent in the first quarter of this year. The company said it still expects its acquisition of DEM to generate incremental profits throughout 2004 and $40-$45 million in ongoing operating income. Additionally, the company said it has approved a quarterly dividend of 9 cents a share, payable on September 1 to stockholders of record on August 13 2004. Shares of Tellabs TLAB gained more than 3 percent after Merrill Lynch upgraded the telecom equipment maker, citing expectations of rising demand for its products from cellphone operators. Analyst Tal Liani lifted the company's rating to "buy" and established a one-year price target of $10.60. Liani said telecom operators' capital expenditure budgets are poised to increase in the second half of 2004 and 2005 as they upgrade networks to support 3G or third generation technology services. Veeco Instruments VECO added more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $1.58 million, or 5 cents a share, vs. a loss of 4 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time items, such as restructuring charges and accounting adjustments, earnings were 15 cents a share, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 13 cents a share. Revenue rose 40 percent to $102.88 million, above analyst forecasts of $99 million, amid strength in its process equipment and metrology product lines. Looking ahead, chip equipment maker expects adjusted earnings of 15 to 18 cents a share on revenue of $105 million to $110 million in the third quarter, vs. analyst forecasts of 21 cents and $105.9 million. For the fourth quarter sees earnings of 29 to 34 cents a share on revenue of $115 million to $125 million, vs. analyst projections of 30 cents and $114.7 million. Decliners Alcoa AA shares slipped almost 2 percent after the company said it would eliminate 400 jobs at an aluminum smelter in Wenatchee, Wash., after union leadership for the facility rejected proposals on a labor contract without a membership vote. The company expects to record a pre-tax charge of $20 million in the third quarter from the move. Alcoa said the plant has been idled since July 2001, and that it has told the affected employees that their last day of work will be on or about Oct. 1. Alcoa's stock fell 1.4 percent to $30.21 in afternoon trades. Alderwoods Group AWGI shares fell more than 10 percent after the company missed second-quarter earnings estimates, due to a disappointing performance at its funeral services business. Cincinnati, Oh.-based Alderwoods said it lost $6.5 million, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with earnings of $6.9 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding special items, the company earned 7 cents a share against a loss of 5 cents a year ago. One analyst polled by Thomson First Call was looking for earnings of 11 cents a share. Revenue edged back to $164.1 million vs. $166.5 million. Andrew Corp ANDW fell more than 22 percent after the company offered a fourth-quarter outlook below Wall Street's consensus estimate. See full story. Shares of Anthem ATH and WellPoint Health Networks WLP both dropped following news that the two health-maintenance organizations face a challenge to their $16 billion merger from California's insurance commissioner. See full story. Beckman Coulter BEC fell more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $58.3 million, or 88 cents a share, up from 82 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 89 cents a share. Profit margin rose slightly to 48 percent, but was partially offset by an "unfavorable geographic sales mix" and the build up of service and support infrastructure in clinical diagnostics. Revenue rose 8.3 percent to $597.3 million, just shy of the $602.2 million expected by analysts. The maker of biomedical testing equipment expects earnings of 69 to 74 cents a share in the third quarter, surrounding analyst forecasts of 73 cents. Separately, the company raised its quarterly dividend by 2 cents, or 18 percent, to 13 cents a share, payable Sept. 2 to shareholders of record on Aug. 13. Shares of Bluegreen Corp. BXG fell more than 10 percent after the Boca Raton, Fla., developer and seller of vacation ownership resorts reported second-quarter earnings of $9.1 million, or 31 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $6.2 million, or 23 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Sales rose in the latest three months to $128.3 million from $86 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of BSquare BSQR which makes software that meshes with Microsoft's MSFT Windows CE operating system for mobile devices, gave back more than 6 percent after the company said it will stop making hardware products. BSquare said some of its clients felt it was competing with their products. Some workers were dismissed and the company will take a $3.3 million charge in its fiscal second quarter, with the dropped division's $370,000 in revenue and $1.2 million in losses included under discontinued operations. Check Point Software CHKP sank more than 10 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $63.3 million, or 24 cents a share, vs. $60.2 million, or 24 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding the impact of the amortization of assets, earnings were 25 cents a share, matching the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 20 percent to $126.9 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $126.4 million, amid a 24 percent increase in license revenue and 19 percent growth in subscription revenue. See full story. Clark Consulting CLK lost more than 4 percent after the company said it learned of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of possible insider trading by Robert Gallivan, an independent sales contractor. Gallivan, who was not a Clark employee, ended his affiliation with the company. See full story. Consol Energy CNX dipped more than 3 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $26.2 million, or 29 cents per share, compared with $10.6 million, or 13 cents per share in the same period a year ago. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting income of 22 cents per share. Revenue for the second quarter for the Pittsburgh coal and gas producer was $674.6 million, up from $556.5 million in the second quarter of 2003. Consol said its quarterly income was "lifted by the combination of higher production volumes for coal and gas and by the tide of rising coal and gas prices." Digitas DTAS shares lost more than 9 percent after Janney Montgomery Scott downgraded the stock on concerns its revenue will be impacted by AT&T's decision to pull out of the long-distance consumer markets. Digitas generates $30 million in annual revenue from AT&T, equal to about 13 percent of its total revenue, half of which is in the consumer long-distance and local markets. "While the potential impact is not entirely clear, it is quite possible half to three quarters of Digitas' revenue from AT&T could be at risk," said analyst Mayank Tandon, who cut the stock to "hold" vs. "buy." Shares were last trading down 10.3 percent at $6.42. Volume of 1.3 million shares was almost twice the share's daily volume. Shares of Fog Cutter Capital Group FCCG tumbled more than 3 percent after the developer of real estate and restaurant properties said late Friday that Ernst & Young is resigning as its auditor. There were no disagreements on accounting or procedures, the company said. Gaiam GAIA sank more than 14 percent after the company, which makes lifestyle products such as solar energy panels and yoga tapes, warned of lower second-quarter results late Friday, citing weakness in its domestic sales. See full story. U.S.-listed shares of Ilog ILOG fell more than 12 percent after the enterprise software and services group posted fiscal fourth quarter results that came in below analyst expectations. The Paris-based company reported net income of a penny a share, unchanged from the year-ago period. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 5 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter edged up to $26.3 million from $23.5 million, but below First Call estimates of $29 million. Ilog said the 14 percent rise in U.S. sales was below its own expectations, while Asia sales fell 18 percent compared with the fourth quarter. Looking ahead, the company said it is forecasting first quarter earnings in a range of a loss of 8 cents per share to a profit of 8 cents a share on revenue expected to come in between $24 million to $27 million. The First Call average estimate is for earnings of 2 cents a share. Shares of ImClone Systems IMCL fell more than 10 percent after Smith Barney downgraded the biotech firm to "hold" from "buy" on the belief the net royalty obligations could be more than four times what it currently expected. Analyst Yaron Werber also lowered the stock price target to $72 from $90, the 2005 earnings estimate to $2.60 a share from $2.75 and the 2006 estimate to $2.30 a share from $2.70. Werber now believes the company may be obligated to pay 6.5 percent of Erbitux sales to other parties for the use of intellectual property, vs. prior expectations of 1.5 percent. "We believe that Wall Street estimates are not accounting for these royalty obligations since ImClone has not publicly commented on the specifics of these payments," Werber said in a note to clients. The stock was last trading down $4.18 at $61.86, and hit a three-month low of $61.48 in intraday trading. Landry's Restaurants LNY lost more than 5 percent after the company said it earned net income of $21.8 million, or 77 cents per share in the second quarter, to $16.9 million, or 60 cents per share last year. Revenues for the three months ended June 30, 2004, totaled $317.6 million, as compared to $299.9 million a year earlier. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call, on average, expected the company to earn 77 cents per share in the period. Same store sales for the company's restaurants were up approximately 1.1 percent for the quarter. Mylan Labs MYL shares fell more than 13 percent after the company agreed to acquire King Pharmaceuticals KG for about $4 billion in stock, and posted in-line results for the first-quarter. See full story. Omnicare OCR tumbled more than 25 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings that missed expectations, due to pricing pressures and weaker margins resulting from a shift in payor mix to Medicaid, and lowered its outlook for 2004. Earnings for the quarter were $60.5 million, or 58 cents a share, up from 44 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 63 cents a share. Revenue rose 20 percent to $1.01 billion. The pharmaceutical care company lowered its 2004 earnings forecast to $2.35 to $2.45 a share, below analyst projections of $2.60. The news also weighed on shares of NeighborCare NCRX which Omnicare is seeking to acquire through a cash tender offer that expires on July 30. NeighborCare's stock lost more than 11 percent. See full story. Shares of Pep Boys PBY dropped about 4 percent after Whitaker Securities analyst Cid Wilson lowered the earnings-per-share projections by 2 cents to 37 cents noting that Pep Boys' sales in installed parts have slowed, leading to a decline in service margins as well. Wilson also slashed the 12-month price target to $33 from $40. Petmed Express PETS shares lost more than 28 percent after the Pompano Beach, Fla., seller of medications for pets reported first-quarter earnings of $1.8 million, or 8 cents per share, missing the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 11 cents per share. Sales rose 16 percent in the latest three months to $35.3 million from $30.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it was "pleased" with its performance in the quarter, noting that reorder sales jumped 60 percent to $19.9 million. See full story. Pilgrim's Pride PPC gave back more than 4 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $9.8 million, or 15 cents per share, on sales of $1.4 billion. The latest results include charges related to restructuring and other items totaling $39.6 million, or 60 cents per share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 55 cents per share in the June period. In the same period a year earlier, the Pittsburg, Texas-based poultry company earned $17.4 million, or 42 cents per share, on sales of $651.9 million. The increased sales reflect the company's acquisition of ConAgra Foods' chicken business, positive industry and consumption trends, and improved efficiencies. Quanta Services' PWR shares slid more than 3 percent after the company cut its forecast for the second quarter late Friday, citing the "continued suppressed state of the electric utility industry." See full story. Shares of Taser TASR dropped more than 13 percent ahead of a "CBS Evening News" report the network said would air Monday showing a fatal accident involving one of Taser's stun guns. Tyson Foods TSN fell more than 4 percent after the company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings that topped expectations, but indicated that 2004 results would fall short. Earnings were $161 million, or 45 cents a share, up from 23 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 36 cents a share, as improved pricing helped offset higher raw material costs and limited access to export markets. Revenue rose 4.8 percent to $6.6 billion, as increases in chicken, pork and prepared foods sales outweighed declines in beef and other product sales. The meat processor expects fiscal 2004 earnings of $1.20 to $1.30 a share, below analyst forecasts of $1.41. Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: AmEx, Intl Game Tech, Pep Boys, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser tasr tumbled $3.82, or 13 percent, to $25.69 in afternoon trading ahead of a "CBS Evening News" report the network said would air Monday showing a fatal accident involving one of Taser's stun guns. Last Tuesday, the company's stock took a battering after the Arizona Republic and New York Times both questioned the safety of its stun guns. CBS parent Viacom is a significant investor in MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report.
title: Taser slumps 13 % on report of fatal accident

content: TI posts jump in second-quarter earnings (4:37 PM ET) DALLAS (CBS.MW) - Texas Instruments, one of the world's largest chipmakers, said late Tuesday earnings rose due to growth in semiconductor revenue. Dallas-based TI TXN, +1.94% said it earned $441 million, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $3.24 billion, vs. net income of $121 million, or 7 cents a share, on revenue of $2.34 billion, a year ago. Analysts expected TI to report earnings of 25 cents a share and sales of $3.2 billion, on average, according to Thomson First Call. TI, which makes chips used in cell phones and personal computers, as well as industrial and digital consumer products, said orders rose 41 percent year-over-year on strength in demand for semiconductors. Shares closed at $21.76, up 83 cents, or 4 percent, ahead of the announcement. Sanmina-SCI swings to quarterly profit (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sanmina-SCI SANM, +0.77% swung to a quarterly profit of $11.4 million, or 2 cents a share, from a loss of $12.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in the same period last year. Revenue rose 15.9 percent to $3.07 billion. Looking ahead, Sanmina-SCI said it faces a $100 million charge as it restructures its operations in North America and Western Europe to focus on higher growth markets in Asia, Latin America, and Eastern Europe. The San Jose, Calif.-based electronics manufacturing services reaffirmed its fiscal fourth quarter outlook of sales in the range of $3.1 billion to $3.3 billion and pro forma earnings per share of 8 cents to 10 cents, before charges. Microsoft sets $32 billion one-time dividend payment (4:17 PM ET) LOS ANGELES (CBS.MW) -- Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% said Tuesday its board approved a one-time dividend payout of $3 a share, worth a total of $32 billion, and a quarterly dividend of 8 cents per share. The board also approved a plan to buy back up to $30 billion of the company's shares over the next four years. Microsoft shares closed higher by 1.3 percent at $28.32 ahead of the news. Motorola posts net loss, but sales remain strong (4:16 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - Motorola MSI, +1.29% on Tuesday posted a second-quarter loss, but sales remained strong. After U.S. markets closed, the technology giant reported a loss of $203 million, or 9 cents a share. That compared to a profit of $119 million, or 5 cents, in the same quarter a year earlier. Revenue, meanwhile, jumped 41 percent to $8.7 billion from $6.2 billion a year ago, building on the first-quarter sales of $8.6 billion. Excluding one-time items, Motorola earned $845 million from operations in the latest quarter. The company did not provide a corresponding per-share figure. Motorola was expected to earn 18 cents, according to the consensus of analysts compiled by Thomson First Call. Sun Micro posts $795 million Q4 profit (4:07 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% on Tuesday reported a fourth-quarter net profit of $795 million, or 24 cents a share, on revenue of $3.11 billion. Sun said its results included $1.6 billion in other income and $350 million in income related to its recent settlement of its lawsuit against Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% Sun did not give a profit figure excluding one-time charges. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecasted a loss, excluding charges, of 4 cents a share on $2.89 billion in revenue. Greenspan sees economy improving from June 'soft patch' (3:40 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- The economy did hit a "soft-patch" in June, but the economy seems to be improving in July, said Federal Reserve board chairman Alan Greenspan. The relatively small 112,00 increase in June nonfarm payroll data was not an indication of significant economic weakness, he said. "If that were the case, I think we would have seen it in a marked pickup in initial claims...which of course we have not," he said. Other third quarter economic indicators suggest that employment is continuing to expand, and "while there has been weakness in June...July seems somewhat better." "We are going through a soft patch," he said. But auto sales for July "shows a very significant snap back" after falling last month he said. "Our anecdotal data on new orders arriving during the month of July show that the system is holding up, there is no evidence of any cumulative weakness here," Greenspan said. House passes bill to dilute stock-options rule (2:59 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- House lawmakers on Tuesday overwhelmingly passed a bill to weaken a new accounting rule aimed at reining in the use of corporate stock options. The bill, approved in a 313-111 vote, now heads to the U.S. Senate, where its prospects are less certain. Supporters of options say they spur job growth and innovation, while critics argue that options enable companies to inflate profits. Options are granted at a discount to workers and executives as an incentive to work harder. If a company stock reaches a certain price, employees can sell their options for a profit. Yet in the wake of a series of corporate accounting scandals, securities regulators want to curb the use of options. Cdn. Natl. Railway rises after better-than-forecast Q2 (2:55 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Canadian National Railway(CA:CNR)blew past analyst expectations for the second-quarter, posting earnings of C$1.13 per share for the period, well ahead of the 98 cents a share Canadian average estimate on First Call and the 84 Canadian cents posted in the 2003 quarter. Revenue for the period was C$1.665 billion, up from C$1.463 billion a year-ago. U.S.-listed shares of the railroad CNI, +2.18% were up $2.14, or 5 percent, to $44.76, after touching a new 52-week high of $44.82 intraday. Ambassadors Group gets lift from Q2 report (2:54 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Ambassadors Group EPAX rose more than 14 percent to $26.04 in late action. After Monday's closing bell, the Spokane, Wash., travel services provider reported second-quarter earnings of $13.1 million, or $1.26 per share, up from its year-ago profit of $9 million, or 90 cents per share. Revenue rose 42 percent in the latest three months to $25.9 million from $18.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Gentex falls penny short in Q2 (1:19 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Gentex GNTX, +1.86% shares lost more than 6 percent to $33.23 after the Zeeland, Mich., company reported second-quarter earnings of $29 million, or 37 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $26.1 million, or 34 cents per share. Sales rose 11 percent in the latest three months to $129.6 million from $116.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, however, was for earnings of 38 cents per share in June period on sales of $133.1 million. The company manufactures rearview mirrors and commercial fire protection products. Matria gets lift from Q2 outlook; dismissal of lawsuit (12:25 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Matria Healthcare MATR, -2.33% surged more than 7 percent to $25.07 after the company said its second-quarter results would top the high end of its outlook for a profit before items of 21 cents per share and that a class action lawsuit against it has been dismissed. Matria also disclosed two new contracts - one with an undisclosed state government and one for the U.S. employees of a company listed on the London Stock Exchange. The current average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 19 cents per share in the June period. Matria plans to issue its second-quarter report after Thursday's closing bell. Mellon Q2 net rises (12:17 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Pittsburgh-based Mellon Financial MEL, +0.58% said Tuesday rising fees from its investment management business helped boost second quarter results past year ago levels. The company earned net income from continuing operations of $176 million or 42 cents per share in the second quarter of 2004, compared to net income from continuing operations of $173 million, or 40 cents per share in the second quarter of 2003, and $244 million, or 57 cents per share, in the first quarter of 2004. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to earn 44 cents from continuing operations. The results from the second quarter of 2004 included a $24 million pre-tax charge related to vacating 10 leased locations in London and moving into Mellon's new European Headquarters. This charge reduced the Corporation's earnings per share by approximately 4 cents. Mellon shares rose 3.2 percent to $28.16. Note redemption hurts Pogo's Q2 (11:48 AM ET) DALLAS (CBS.MW) -- Pogo Producing Co. PPP, -13.04% said its decision to redeem notes in the second quarter impacted net income. The company posted second-quarter earnings of $65.2 million, or $1.02 per share, on revenue of $326.9 million vs. income of $79.7 million, or $1.29 per share, on revenue of $297.1 million in the second quarter of 2003. Shares fell $1.33 to $44.67. Zhone Technologies falls after Q2 misses estimates (11:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Zhone Technologies ZHNE shares fell sharply Tuesday after the communications software company reported a wider-than-expected second-quarter loss. Oakland, Calif.-based Zhone said it lost 10 cents a share in the period, against a loss of 95 cents a year ago. The average estimate of Thomson First Call analysts was for a loss of 4 cents a share. Revenue edged up to $21 million from $20.5 million, below the $22.7 million market consensus. Shares were last trading down 15.7 percent at $2.69. Manufactured Home sees 2005 FFO above 2004 forecasts (11:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Manufactured Home Communities MHC, -1.14% said it expects 2005 funds from operations (FFO) of $2.20 to $2.25 a share, which is above its previously provided 2004 FFO forecast of $1.85 to $1.90 a share. The company expects property performance to continue to grow along with historical trends. The stock was last trading up 37 cents, or 1.1 percent, at $33.41. Earlier, the real estate managment firm reported second-quarter FFO of 45 cents a share, down from 60 cents a share in the same period a year ago. DSP Group shares hit by lowered forecast (11:23 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- DSP Group DSPG, +2.16% shares shed more than 13 percent to to $19.15 in late morning action after the semiconductor company lowered its revenue forecast for the second half late Monday. During a conference call, DSP Group Chairman and Chief Executive Eliyahu Ayalon said the weaker outlook reflects a product launch delay and indications from distributors of soft demand. The company now sees revenue of between $46 million and $50 million in the third quarter, and $35 million to $40 million in the fourth quarter. DSP also reported second-quarter net income of about $9.4 million, or 30 cents per share, up from $5.5 million, or 19 cents per share, a year earlier. Excluding items, DSP posted a pro forma profit of $9.1 million, or 29 cents per share, 3 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Aladdin surges following Q2 earnings report (11:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Aladdin Knowledge Systems ALDN gained more than 12 percent to $17.42 after the digital security technology company reported second-quarter earnings of $2.1 million, or 16 cents per share, well ahead of its year-ago profit of $563,000, or a nickel per share. The company said its results topped its previously disclosed outlook. Revenue jumped 27 percent in the latest three months to $16.5 million from $13 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Aladdin sees earnings of 14 to 17 cents per share on revenue of between $16.1 million and $16.7 million in the third quarter. Itron downgraded after missing Wall St. view for Q2 (11:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Itron ITRI, +2.65% fell more than 10 percent to $19.62 in mid-morning action. The stock was hit with a downgrade by RBC Capital Markets to "sector perform" from "outperform" following its quarterly report. After Monday's closing bell, the Spokane, Wash., developer of energy and water technology posted pro forma earnings of $2.1 million, or 10 cents per share, for the second quarter, well below its year-ago equivalent profit of $6.1 million, or 28 cents per share. The average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 16 cents per share in the June period. Looking ahead, Itron sees pro forma earnings of 70 to 75 cents per share in the second half on revenue of between $265 million and $270 million. The company said it's "not pleased" with its results in the first half, adding that the utility industry continues to be in the "doldrums" and that lower handheld meter reading revenue in the second quarter offset higher shipments of its automatic meter reading hardware. Golden West Financial Q2 earnings rise 16% (10:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Golden West Financial GDW posted second-quarter earnings of $2.04 versus $1.76 in the second quarter of 2003. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call were expecting earnings of $2 a share, on average. Loan originations in the quarter reached $12.4 billion up from $8 billion a year-ago. The company's primary spread -- the difference between what it earns on its loans and other assets and what it pays for savings and borrowings -- declined to 2.86 percent from 2.98 percent a year earlier as market interest rates started moving up in anticipation of the Federal Reserve rate hike in June. General and administrative expenses rose 17 percent from the second quarter of 2003, Golden West said. Golden West shares fell $1.17, or 1.1 percent, to $104.75. Everest Re falls as Q2 disappoints (10:25 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Everest Re RE, -0.58% shares slumped Tuesday after the company beat second-quarter earnings estimates but disappointed with its underlying results. Analyst William Wilt at Morgan Stanley said the quality of earnings was weak "and we think a beat was largely expected." Everest reported second-quarter earnings of $4.64 a share, up from $1.99 a share a year ago and a full 41 cents a head of consensus. But the beat came mainly from "other income" which totalled 43 cents a share. "Underwriting results, while good historically, are likely to disappoint investors hoping for a breakthrough quarter," said Wilt. Shares were last trading down 8.2 percent at $74.31. Benthos surges on Q3 report (10:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Benthos Inc. BTHS rocketed $2.90, or 48 percent, to $8.98 after the maker of oceanographic products for underwater tasks posted third-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share on sales of $5.7 million versus earnings of 2 cents a share on sales of $4.4 million a year ago. "We have seen another quarter of increased sales for our Undersea Systems Division and our TapTone Package Inspection Systems Division has shown strong evidence of recovery after two quarters of disappointing sales performance," the company's president and CEO Ronald Marsiglio said in a press release. Tenneco Automotive pops after Street beating Q2 (10:05 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Tenneco Automotive TEN, +2.91% soared $1.50, or 12 percent, to $13.85 after posting second-quarter adjusted earnings of 70 cents a share, topping both the year ago report of 58 cents and the 54 cents a share average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Including various one-time items, the maker of emission control products said it earned 69 cents a share in the period. Quarterly revenues of $1.14 billion, versus $998 million a year ago were the "highest ever," the company said. Ceridian falls after postponing Q2 report (10:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Ceridian CEN, +2.17% dropped more than 10 percent to $18.21 after the Minneapolis provider of payment processing and other outsourced human resources services postponed the release of its second-quarter results as it reviews the capitalization and expensing of certain costs in its U.S. Human Resources Solutions business. The release was scheduled for Tuesday. The company said the review is the result of concerns raised internally, and that it could have an impact on its financials for the second quarter, previously reported results, and its outlook.
