Consol Energy ups Q2 earns view, shares turn positive (10:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Consol Energy CNX, +1.38% raised second-quarter earnings expectations, due primarily to higher energy prices and lower health care costs for retirees. The coal miner now expects earnings of 25 cents a share, up from prior projections of 15 to 20 cents a share. The stock was last up 19 cents at $38.20, erasing earlier losses of 50 cents. Separately, the company said June coal production increased 6.3 percent over year-earlier levels to 5.1 million tons. Cognex tumbles following in-line Q2 report (9:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Cognex CGNX, +2.40% dropped more than 13 percent to $28.54 after the Natick, Mass., maker of machine vision systems reported second-quarter earnings of $10.9 million, or 23 cents per share, in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of 24 to 26 cents per share for the third quarter on revenue of between $55 million and $58 million, ahead of Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 23 cents per share on revenue of $56.3 million. The company noted that it saw a 7 percent decline in bookings on a sequential basis, a development it attributed to "an exceptionally high level of business" for its chip and electronics capital equipment customers in the first quarter "as they ramped up their production in response to demands they were seeing for their products." US Bancorp Q2 results top Wall St. view by 1c (9:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- US Bancorp Del USB, +0.86% reported second-quarter earnings of $1.04 billion, or 54 cents per share, up from $919.9 million, or 48 cents per share, a year ago. The average analyst estimate for the same period as polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 53 cents per share. CEO Jerry Grundhofer said the second quarter saw "very strong growth" in fee-based products and services and a lower provision for credit losses. The quarter included $171.7 million in losses on the sale of securities. The Minneapolis-based financial company also reported that mortgage rates rose, lowering refinancing activities and resulting in lower prepayments. Schwab reports net income of $113 million, misses est. (9:07 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Charles Schwab Corp. SC.H, +0.00% reported net income of $113 million, or 8 cents a share on Tuesday. The results were down 10 percent from the $126 million earned in the same period last year and fell short of the 9 cent analyst average estimate as measured by Thomson First Call. The San Francisco-based retail brokerage also said chief executive David Pottruck has been ousted by the board of directors. Founder and chairman Charles Schwab was named CEO. Schwab's after-tax profit margin fell to 10.2 percent from 12.3 percent from the same period last year. Shares of Schwab closed down 10 cents, or 1.2 percent, on Monday to $8.30. Avery Dennison tops Q2 forecasts, ups outlook (9:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Avery Dennison AVY, +2.11% said it earned 68 cents a share in the second quarter compared with 78 cents a year ago. Excluding one-time items, however, the maker of pressure sensitive and self-adhesive products earned 78 cents a share in the current quarter besting the 73 cents a share average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Net sales for the quarter were $1.3 billion, up from about $1.2 billion a year ago. Avery Dennison also lifted the lower end of its earnings expecations for all of 2004 by 10 cents a share to a range of $2.90 to $3.10, before charges, reflecting the benefit of a reduced tax rate and the better-than-expected second-quarter numbers. The improved outlook brings the company in line with the range forecast by analysts. For the second-half, the company is forecasting earnings in the range of $1.45 to $1.65 per share, with a range of $0.72 to $0.77 per share for the third-quarter. First Call indicates a range of 74 cents to 80 cents for the third quarter and 75 to 87 cents for the fourth quarter. AK Steel Q2 earns, rev. exceed forecasts (8:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - AK Steel AKS, +5.84% reported second-quarter net income of $92.7 million, or 85 cents a share, vs. a loss of 72 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding a non-recurring items, such as gains from the sale of assets and a tax benefit associated with discontinued operations, earnings were 19 cents a share, topping the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 16 cents a share. Revenue rose 34 percent to $1.31 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts of $1.28 billion, as higher global steel demand led to a 12 percent increase in shipments to 1.57 million tons. Looking ahead, the steelmaker expects higher selling prices and lower maintenance costs to lead to improved profitability during the second half of 2004. The stock was trading up 55 cents, or 7.6 percent, at $7.75 in Tuesday's pre-open. Freeport-McMoRan reports Q2 loss vs. year ago profit (8:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Freeport-McMoRan FCX, +4.90% reported a second-quarter net loss of $53 million, or 30 cents a share, vs. earnings of 37 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Results included costs of 20 cents a share related to a maintenance turnaround at a wholly-owned Spanish smelting unit. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting a loss of 21 cents a share. The gold and copper miner said results were also hurt by lower ore grades and reduced mill throughput. Revenue fell 20 percent to $486.3 million. The stock closed Monday down 66 cents at $35.34. Wells Fargo 2Q net income up 11%; shy of estimates (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wells Fargo WFC, +1.81% on Tuesday reported second quarter net income of $1.71 billion, or $1 a share, up 11 percent from $1.51 billion earned the same period in 2004. The results, however, fell short of the average analyst estimate of $1.04 as measured by Thomson First Call. Wells reported revenue of $7.4 billion for the quarter, up 7 percent from the same period in 2003. Revenues matched the estimate by analysts. The San Francisco-based bank reported investment gains that added a penny a share for the most recent period, compared to 5 cents a share in the first quarter of 2004. Wells shares closed up 54 cents to $58.45 on Monday. Arkansas Best rallies in pre-market on strong Q2 report (8:21 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Arkansas Best Corp. ABFS gained almost 10 percent to $34.50 in pre-market action on Instinet after the Fort Smith, Ark., trucking company posted a strong year-over-year increase in second-quarter earnings. The company earned $19.3 million, or 76 cents per share, for the three-month period, up from its profit of $15.2 million, or 60 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding items, the company earned 82 cents per share in the June quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 48 cents per share in the period. Revenue jumped in the latest three months to $424.5 million from $384.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Forest Labs Q2 earns, rev. rise, exceed expectations (8:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Forest Laboratories FRX, -1.85% reported second-quarter net income of $229.9 million, or 60 cents a share, up from 48 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 57 cents a share. Net sales rose 29 percent to $782.4 million, above analyst forecasts of $753.5 million, amid increased prescription volume for its Lexapro antidepressant. Also, higher average selling prices of Celexa offset lower prescription volume. For fiscal 2005, the drugmaker adjusted its earnings projection to $2.40 to $2.50 a share from $2.35 to $2.50. Separately, the company set a 20 million share stock repurchase program, which represents 5.3 percent of the weighted average number of diluted shares outstanding at the end of June. The stock rallied $2, or 3.8 percent, to $54.50 in Tuesday's pre-open. Safeco Q2 net more than doubles (8:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Insurer Safeco SAFC said Tuesday that its careful underwriting practices and low catastrophe payouts helped lift more than double its second quarter earnings versus year ago levels. The company reported net income of$247.5 million, or $1.77 per share, compared to $111.9 million, or $0.81 per share a year ago. Safeco said the results reflected the company's "solid underwriting" and the fact that "weather-related catastrophe losses were relatively light for the second quarter." Johnson Controls Q3 earns rise, match expectations (8:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Johnson Controls JCI, +2.77% reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $222.3 million, or $1.15 a share, up from $1 a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 14 percent to $6.79 billion, exceeding analyst forecasts of $6.54 billion, with automotive sales increasing 16 percent and controls sales growing 7 percent. The automotive components maker's stock closed Monday up 36 cents at $53.80. Pulitzer Q2 earns rise, top expectations (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Pulitzer PTZ reported second-quarter net income of $11.8 million, or 54 cents a share, up from 53 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding a non-recurring litigation settlement expense, earnings were 58 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 57 cents. Total operating revenue rose 5.5 percent to $113.1 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $112.1 million, as strength in classified advertising and in retail pre-print revenue boosted overall advertising revenue 6.5 percent. The newspaper publisher's stock closed Monday down 74 cents at $45.59. South Financial Q2 earns, rev. top forecasts (7:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - The South Financial Group TSFG reported second-quarter net income of $30 million, or 49 cents a share, up from 48 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 48 cents a share. Total revenue rose 18 percent to $106.4 million, topping analyst forecasts of $105.1 million, as strong loan growth and higher average investment securities outstanding helped lift net interest income by 21 percent. Non-interest income rose 8 percent. The financial services firm's stock closed Monday down 16 cents at $28.94. Correct: CDW tops Q2 estimate by 1c, sales up 29% (7:41 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- CDW CDWC said it earned $58.3 million, or 67 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $43.6 million, or 51 cents a share, a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 66 cents a share. The Vernon Hills, Ill. technology company said sales climbed 29 percent to $1.383 billion. Average daily sales were $21.6 million in the quarter, up from $16.8 million a year ago. Shares ended Monday down 53 cents at $58.61. (This replaces an earlier item that reported revenue growth incorrectly.) Ameritrade Q3 earns match, rev. falls shy of forecasts (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Ameritrade AMTD, +3.49% reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $62.3 million, or 15 cents a share, up from 12 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Total revenue rose 15 percent to $222.7 million, below analyst forecasts of $231.8 million, with commissions and clearing fees increasing 5.6 percent. The discount broker reaffirmed its fiscal fourth-quarter and 2004 earnings forecasts. The stock closed Monday down 32 cents at $9.39. Allegheny Technologies posts quarterly profit (7:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Allegheny Technologies ATI, +3.91% reported second quarter net income of $26.6 million, or 31 cents per share, on sales of $646.5 million, that included special one-time gains and that beat an average analyst loss estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for 37 cents a share. The results ncluded a net special gain of $40.4 million, or 48 cents per share, in connection new labor agreement and the acquisition of the J&L Specialty Steel and a $34 million, or 40 cents per share loss, for retirement benefits. In the second quarter 2003, ATI reported a net loss of $26 million, or 32 cents per share on sales of $489.9 million. Shares of Allegheny closed Monday 63 cents to $18.38 Greenpoint Financial adj Q2 net tops Street estimates (7:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- GreenPoint Financial GPT, -0.87% posted second quarter net income from continuing operations of $123 million, or $1.03 per share compared with $129.8 million, or $1.03 a share in the same quarter in 2003. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 96 cents a share. Net interest income for the quarter was $178.8 million against $167.9 million in the year-ago period. The bank's net interest margin for the period declined to 3.10 percent from 3.30 percent in the first quarter, which it attributed to accelerated premium amortization in the mortgage loans held-for-investment and securities portfolios. Non-interest income for the quarter meanwhile dipped to $160 million from $164 million a year ago. The company is currently in the process of being acquired by North Fork Bancorp. Shares of Greenpoint Financial were up 1.3 percent at $41.72 at the close of trading Monday. ChoicePoint Reports Inline Q2 EPS (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - ChoicePoint CPS, +1.40% a provider of identification and credential verification services, announced second-quarter earnings per share of 40 cents, in line with the First Call consensus estimate, and up sharply from 23 cents per share a year earlier. The company's revenues in the second quarter rose 16% from year-earlier levels to $231.4 million; ChoicePoint forecast that its 2004 revenues will increase by 15% to 19% over 2003 levels. On Monday the stock closed at $41.56 per share, up 26 cents on the session. EMC posts in-line Q2 profit (7:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- EMC Corp. EMC, +9.92% reported second-quarter earnings of $193 million, or 8 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $82 million, or 4 cents per share. Revenue jumped 33 percent in the latest three months to $1.97 billion from $1.48 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 8 cents per share in the June period on revenue of $1.97 billion. The Hopkington, Mass., storage technology company attributed the results to "strong execution" of its information lifecycle management strategy. EMC said it's "squarely on track" to reach a goal for mid-teens operating margins by the end of the year. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 8 to 9 cents per share on revenue of around $2 billion in the third quarter. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 9 cents per share in the September quarter. "I continue to believe the overall market environment for storage and information management technology is rich with opportunity yet challenging, as customers continue to demand more from IT providers," said Joe Tucci, EMC's president and CEO, in a press release. The stock closed Monday at $10.36, up 11 cents. Manpower Q2 net tops Street estimates by 4 cents (7:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Manpower MAN, +2.35% posted second quarter net income of $53.1 million, or 56 cents a share compared with $29.1 million, or 37 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Revenues for the quarter jumped 20 percent to $3.6 billion from $3 billion, helped by favorable foreign exchange rate factors. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 52 cents a share on revenues of $3.5 billion. Looking ahead, the recruitment company said it expects to earn in the range of 63 to 67 cents a share in the third quarter, which includes an estimated positive currency impact of 4 cents. The First Call average estimate is for earnings of 67 cents a share. Shares of Manpower were down 0.7 percent at $44.50 at the close of trading Monday. Ford tops Q2 expectations, boosts '04 outlook (7:14 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% posted second quarter earnings from continuing operations of 61 cents a share, excluding special items, well above the 50 cents a share average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Net income for the automaker totalled $1.2 billion, or 57 cents a share, while revenues came in at $42.8 billion. Ford noted that worldwide automotive sales for the second quarter rose to $36.7 billion from $34.1 billion in the same period last year while worldwide vehicle-unit sales in the quarter were 1.748 million up from 1.718 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the Dearborn, Mich.-based company said it expects third quarter earnings ranging from breakeven to 5 cents a share and boosted its full year outlook by 15 cents to a range of $1.80 to $1.90 a share, all from continuing operations and excluding special items. Ford noted that special items consisting primarily of the restructuring of its Ballard Power BLDP, +1.43% investment and a European reorganization are currently estimated to reduce full-year earnings by 8 cents a share. AutoNation Q2 earns match, Q3 to miss estimates (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - AutoNation AN, +2.03% reported second-quarter net income from continuing operations of $96 million, or 35 cents a share, down from 37 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Including discontinued operations, earnings were 34 cents a share. The auto retailer attributed the decline in earnings to due to "significant" declines in sales of Ford and General Motors products and a decline in gross margins as low volumes combined with high inventories. Total revenue rose 0.3 percent to $4.99 billion, as growth in revenue from its parts and services and financing and insurance business helped offset slight declines in new and used vehicle sales. Looking ahead, the company expects third-quarter earnings of 36 to 38 cents a share, below analyst forecasts of 40 cents, and 2004 earnings of $1.35 to $1.40 a share, vs. analyst projections of $1.39. The stock closed Monday down 11 cents at $15.47. Altria Group's Q2 adjusted EPS at $1.27; 2004 affirmed (7:13 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Altria Group MO, -0.21% reported a second-quarter profit of $2.6 billion, or $1.27 per share, up from $2.44 billion, or $1.20, earned in the same period last year. The latest quarter's profit included a 13-cent restructuring charge related to Altria's Kraft Foods KFT unit. A lower effective tax rate contributed 15 cents to the quarter's earnings, and favorable currency exchange rates accounted for another 5 cents, Altria said. According to Thomson First Call, analysts who follow the tobacco giant had been expecting an average profit of $1.28 per share. Revenue rose 10.5 percent, reaching $23.01 billion from $20.83 billion. Altria said its quarterly share of the U.S. tobacco market rose to 49.8 percent from the prior year's 48.5 percent. The company also affirmed that it anticipates generating full-year earnings of $4.50 to $4.60 per share. Shares of the Dow Jones Industrial Average component added 16 cents to end Monday's trading at $48.83. RadioShack tops Q2 earns forecast, 2004 to also beat (7:04 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - RadioShack RSH, -0.07% reported second-quarter net income of $68.3 million, or 42 cents a share, up from 34 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 39 cents a share. Revenue rose 3 percent to $1.05 billion, in line with analyst forecasts, boosted by strong wireless communications and computer department sales. Same-store sales increased 3 percent. Looking ahead, the consumer electronics retailer expects earnings of 38 to 40 cents a share in the third quarter, vs. analyst estimates of 37 cents, and 2004 earnings of $2.07 to $2.09 a share, vs. analyst projections of $2.02. The stock closed Monday up 4 cents at $27.08. UAE airlines plans to buy 24 Airbus jets (6:40 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Etihad Airways, the national airline of the United Arab Emirates, has signed a memorandum of understanding to buy 24 Airbus jets, including four of the European aircraft maker's A380 superjumbo jets, Airbus said. Other jets include four ultra-long range A340-500s, four A340-600s and twelve A330-200s. Etihad said it had been in "intensive discussions" with both Boeing BA, +2.46% and Airbus for over a year and that the airline had considered a whole range of aircraft types. Airbus is 80 percent owned by French-based EADS(FR:005730)and 20 percent owned by BAE Systems(UK:BA)of Britain. The list price for the order is seen over $4 billion. ExpressJet Q2 tops estimates by a penny, revs up 16% (6:39 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- ExpressJet Holdings XJT said it earned $29.7 million, or 55 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 10 percent from $27.1 million, or 42 cents a share, a year ago, buoyed by continued cost cutting. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 54 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $370.8 million from $320.3 million. The regional airline said its load factor rose 3 points to 73.2 percent, while capacity grew 26 percent to 2.6 billion available seat miles. Revenue passenger miles rose 31 percent. Shares ended Monday up 1.9 percent at $10.68. Orbital Sci. tops Q2 earns, revenue expectations (6:34 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Orbital Sciences ORB, +9.85% reported second-quarter net income of $11.1 million, or 17 cents a share, vs. a loss of 10 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, such as debt extinguishment costs, earnings were 18 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 15 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose 12 percent to $177.7 million, exceeding analyst forecasts of $165 million, amid strength in its satellite and related space systems and launch vehicles businesses. The stock closed Monday down 4 cents at $12.98. Continental Air in Q2 loss; charge, yields, fuel weigh (6:28 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% cautioned efforts to return to profits "were overwhelmed by the continuing soft domestic yields, a record high cost of fuel, and a $265 million burden of taxes and fees paid to the government over the last three months." The airline posted a $17 million loss, or 26 cents a share, for the second quarter. Excluding a $19 million charge related to an aircraft lease retirement, the airline saw profit of $2 million. The airline said analysts had forecast a loss of 9 cents a share for the second quarter. Second quarter passenger revenue rose 15.1 percent to $2.3 billion from the same quarter a year ago. "Due to intense competition with low cost carriers, mainline yields continue to be weak, decreasing 1.6 percent year-over-year," he said. Health Mgmt. Q3 earns match, rev. just shy of estimates (6:15 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Health Management Associates HMA reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $89.3 million, or 36 cents a share, up from 30 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Net patient revenue rose 26 percent to $817.3 million, just shy of analyst forecasts of $820.8 million, as a 1.2 percent increase in same-hospital admissions and a 3.5 percent improvement in revenue per admission, helped offset a rise in uninsured and under-insured patient admissions. Overall admissions grew 22 percent. The hospital operator's stock closed Monday down 35 cents at $21.70. Taser says Q2 revenue higher, new orders up (5:46 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Stun gun maker Taser International TASR said sales in the second quarter rose four-fold to $16.3 million. Net income rose to $4.5 million or 14 cents a share, up from $347,059 or 2 cents a share in the same quarter of 2003. Four analysts polled by Thomson/First Call had forecast earnings per share of 13 cents for the June quarter and sales of $14.6 million. New orders received in the quarter rose to $16.7 million, a record, it said. Taser also said had understated its estimate of a future tax reduction related to employee stock sales. The corrected tax benefit is $8.9 million; its March estimate was for a $2.1 million benefit. Taser said there was no impact from the tax estimate change on its net income results. Swiss reinsurer Converium plunges 29% on Q2 warning (3:51 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Reinsurer Converium CHR, +1.97% [s:ch:001299771] plunged 29 percent in Swiss trade after it warned second quarter results will miss expectations due to higher U.S. casualty loss emergence, relating to underwriting years 1997 to 2001. Reserves will be bolstered by up to $400 million. It has initiated additional reviews of the U.S. casualty business in order to examine the adequacy of prior years' provisions. Other reinsurers, such as Munich Re(DE:843002)and Swiss Re(ZZ:001233237)also fell on the news. Christian Dior 1H op. profit up 30% as Q2 sales up 26% (2:35 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Christian Dior Coture(FR:013040), the French luxury retailer that owns nearly half of LVMH Moet Hennessy(FR:012101), on Tuesday said second quarter sales rose 26 percent to 138 million euros, or 28 percent at constant rates, leading to first half operating profits of over 30 percent. Asian and U.S. sales led the growth, but European sales also increased, it said. It said the success of its womenswear collections by John Galliano and the Dior Homme line by Hedi Slimane lifted results. Chip's Infineon swings to loss, antitrust costs balloon (2:32 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- German memory chipmaker Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% swung to a loss in its fiscal June quarter of 56 million euro as it raised a charge it's taking against profits related to U.S. and European antitrust investigations into the DRAM industry as well as potential civil claims by 184 million euro to 212 million euro. Infineon said it's been approached by "certain of its major customers seeking compensation for damages arising out of Infineon's alleged anticompetitive behavior." The German chipmaker posted a 116 million euro loss in the year ago quarter and profit of 39 million euro in the previous quarter. Revenue rose 14 percent sequentially to 1.9 billion euro and surged 30 percent on the year. "The worldwide semiconductor market has gained considerable momentum during the last three months," said Max Dietrich Kley, acting CEO of Infineon Technologies AG. It said the revenue growth was "achieved mainly through higher prices for products of the Memory Products segment, as well as higher demand for products of the Secure Mobile Solutions segment." U.K. lender Northern Rock: Year on track, mkt share up (2:17 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. mortgage lender Northern Rock(UK:NRK), a FTSE 100 stock, said Tuesday said it expected to meet the consensus forecasts for earnings in 2004. "The house purchase market should continue to slow but remortgage activity will remain buoyant," the lender said. "We are in good shape to continue to deliver strong operational and financial results going forward and remain comfortable with the average of consensus forecasts for 2004, assuming that the current LIBOR/Bank Base Rate differential does not widen further." U.K. interest rates have been inching higher since October last year as monetary officials, in part, seek to curb rising consumer debt levels amid surging home prices. In the six months to June 30, Northern Rock said it had record residential net lending of 4.4 billion pounds, an increase of 14.9 percent. Its estimated share of U.K. net mortgage lending rose to 8.4 percent from 7.8 percent in the 2003 full year. Pre tax profits, on a comparable basis, rose 14.1 percent to 200.3 million pounds. Shire: U.S. OK on Fosrenol delayed (2:09 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Shire Pharmaceuticals Group [s uk:shp] SHPGY the British drugs maker, said its expected U.S. approval for Fosrenol has been delayed as the Food and Drug Administration indicated a 90 day extension to its review period to complete evaluation of new data. "No concerns are raised in this letter about clinical safety or efficacy," Shire said in a statement to the London Stock Exchange. The extension moved the final action date and anticipated approval to October 26 from June 26. Shire expects no change to its 2004 launch timing and said it's proceeding with all pre-launch activities. Novartis set for 'markedly higher' earnings in 2004 (2:02 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Swiss pharmaceuticals maker Novartis NVS, -0.49% Monday said it expects "high-single-digit to low-double-digit" sales growth in local currencies for the full year. Sales in the first half of the year rose 9 percent in local currencies to $13.6 billion. The group adding that "barring any unforeseen events, Novartis expects to report markedly higher operating and net income in 2004." Correct: Novartis 1H sales rise 14% (1:51 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Swiss pharmaceuticals maker Novartis NVS, -0.49% Tuesday said sales in the first half of the year rose 14 percent in dollar terms to $13.6 billion. Sales rose 9 percent in local currencies. Pharmaceuticals sales rose 17 percent. Second quarter sales rose 12 percent to $7 billion. Net income rose 19 percent to $2.8 billion in the first half; earnings per share rose 21 percent to $1.16. Second quarter earnings per share rose 19 percent to 63 cents. Daniel Vasella, chairman and chief executive said in a brief statement he was "pleased that we have gained market share... All key projects of our rich pipeline are progressing on schedule." Novartis said pharma sales were driven by primary care brands Diovan, Lotrel, Lamisil and Trileptal as well as specialty medicine products Gleevec/Glivec, Zometa, Femara and Visudyne. Operating margins rose 0.6 percentage points" due to excellent business performance and effective resource allocation." (Corrects to reflect 14 percent rise in sales in the first half of the year) More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser fell for the second day, losing more than 14 percent, as a big jump in sales and profit couldn't offset published charges that the company's "non-lethal" stun guns may be anything but. Taser TASR finished off $5.28, or 14.5 percent, at $31.04 Tuesday, adding to a $1.33 decline on the previous session. Two newspapers took aim at the company's safety claims over the weekend. The Arizona Republic GCI, +0.50% reported that there were five deaths for which medical examiners could not rule out Taser's stun guns as the cause - and said that the company's claims that its product is not lethal are based on autopsy reports it never possessed. In addition, The New York Times NYT, +2.77% noted that the British government could not approve Taser's stun guns for general police use after a study could not prove their safety. The company responded to the New York Times report by saying the failure to mention a single life-saving incident indicates the reporter "set out to write a negative article and succeeded." "(To) correct all the misleading information would require a manuscript longer that the article itself," the company said. Taser claims there have been at least 5,000 incidents where police use of its product, rather than a conventional firearm, has saved lives or avoided serious injury. The stories - and Taser's attempts to refute them - overshadowed the company's rollout of robust second-quarter numbers early Tuesday. Before the bell, it said sales in the period rose fourfold to $16.3 million while earnings were up to $4.5 million or 14 cents a share from $347,059 or 2 cents a share in the same quarter of 2003. The average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call been for earnings per share of 13 cents on sales of $14.6 million. New orders received in the quarter rose to $16.7 million, a record, and Taser also said had understated its estimate of a future tax reduction related to employee stock sales. The corrected tax benefit is $8.9 million; its March estimate was for a $2.1 million benefit. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser said there was no impact from the tax estimate change on its bottom line results. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Don’t ever do this with your credit card BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’
title: Taser pummeled again on product safety concerns

content: Advancers Shares of ADE Corp. ADEX gained almost 5 percent after the company said it has received a "large multi-million dollar" order for its wafer geometry systems products from an undisclosed silicon wafer supplier. ADE, which is based in Westwood, Mass., said the deal includes multiple WaferSightwafer flatness and NanoMapper nanotopography systems for qualification and certification of critical wafer geometry parameters. Adolph Coors RKY rose more than 4 percent after the company and Canada's Molson (MOLA) confirmed they have discussed a possible merger. The talks involved Molson Chairman Eric Molson and Coors CEO Leo Kiely, as well as other executives. "An announcement could be made in the near future," the companies said in a statement. See full story. Shares of Aladdin Knowledge Systems ALDN gained more than 12 percent after the digital security technology company reported second-quarter earnings of $2.1 million, or 16 cents per share, well ahead of its year-ago profit of $563,000, or a nickel per share. The company said its results topped its previously disclosed outlook. Revenue jumped 27 percent in the latest three months to $16.5 million from $13 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Aladdin sees earnings of 14 to 17 cents per share on revenue of between $16.1 million and $16.7 million in the third quarter. Shares of Ambassadors Group EPAX rose more than 14 percent after the Spokane, Wash., travel services provider reported second-quarter earnings of $13.1 million, or $1.26 per share, up from its year-ago profit of $9 million, or 90 cents per share. Revenue rose 42 percent in the latest three months to $25.9 million from $18.2 million in the same period a year earlier. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. AMC Entertainment AEN shares surged more than 22 percent following a report that J.P Morgan Partners is preparing to buy the company in a deal valued at about $1.4 billion. The private equity unit of J.P. Morgan is planning to buy the second-largest movie theater chain in the U.S. for $19 to $20 a share, the daily New York Post reported, citing sources familiar with the situation. Final terms of the deal are still being discussed, the paper said. Ameritrade AMTD, +3.49% gained almost 6 percent after the company reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $62.3 million, or 15 cents a share, up from 12 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and in line with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Total revenue rose 15 percent to $222.7 million, below analyst forecasts of $231.8 million, with commissions and clearing fees increasing 5.6 percent. The discount broker reaffirmed its fiscal fourth-quarter and 2004 earnings forecasts. Shares of Arkansas Best ABFS gained almost 7 percent after the Fort Smith, Ark., trucking company posted a strong year-over-year increase in second-quarter earnings. The company earned $19.3 million, or 76 cents per share, for the three-month period, up from its profit of $15.2 million, or 60 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding items, the company earned 82 cents per share in the June quarter. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 48 cents per share in the period. Revenue jumped in the latest three months to $424.5 million from $384.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of Benthos BTHS rose more than 57 percent after the maker of oceanographic products for underwater tasks posted third-quarter earnings of 31 cents a share on sales of $5.7 million versus earnings of 2 cents a share on sales of $4.4 million a year ago. "We have seen another quarter of increased sales for our Undersea Systems Division and our TapTone Package Inspection Systems Division has shown strong evidence of recovery after two quarters of disappointing sales performance," the company's president and CEO Ronald Marsiglio said in a press release. See full story. Shares of Bio-Reference Labs BRLI gained more than 14 percent on the heels of an upgrade from Jefferies & Co. Analyst David Francis boosted his recommendation on the provider of clinical laboratory services to "buy" from "hold" and his price target to $16.50 from $15 in anticipation of "strong" fiscal third quarter results. "With the company's core lab business performing as expected, the prison business picking up new clients, the esoteric business growing at a healthy clip, and a small acquisition adding to the numbers, we see nothing but good things happening at BRLI," Francis wrote in a research note. Francis noted that the stock price has declined nearly 50 percent since he downgraded the shares eight months ago, creating a new opportunity for investors. "With the substantial pullback in valuation, we once again view BRLI as a value priced growth stock," Francis said. CDW CDWC shares added almost 5 percent after the company said it earned $58.3 million, or 67 cents a share, in the second quarter, up from $43.6 million, or 51 cents a share, a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 66 cents a share. The Vernon Hills, Ill., technology company said sales climbed 29 percent to $1.383 billion. Average daily sales were $21.6 million in the quarter, up from $16.8 million a year ago. Cendant CD, +0.00% gained almost 4 percent after the company said it's in talks about selling its mortgage business for between $5.75 billion and $7 billion with an undisclosed party. The company's board also approved a 29 percent increase in its quarterly dividend. See full story. Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% advanced more than 3 percent after CEO David Pottruck resigned under pressure. He was replaced by the company's namesake and founder, Charles Schwab. See full story.The company also posted second-quarter results that came in a penny short of Wall Street's consensus estimate. See full story. Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% tacked on more than 3 percent after the company cautioned efforts to return to profits "were overwhelmed by the continuing soft domestic yields, a record high cost of fuel, and a $265 million burden of taxes and fees paid to the government over the last three months." The airline posted a $17 million loss, or 26 cents a share, for the second quarter. Excluding a $19 million charge related to an aircraft lease retirement, the airline saw profit of $2 million. The airline said analysts had forecast a loss of 9 cents a share for the second quarter. Second-quarter passenger revenue rose 15.1 percent to $2.3 billion from the same quarter a year ago. "Due to intense competition with low cost carriers, mainline yields continue to be weak, decreasing 1.6 percent year-over-year," he said. Corning GLW, +1.94% leapt more than 8 percent after the company reported net earnings for the quarter to June 30 rose to $108 million, or 7 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $22 million, or 2 cents a share, Corning said. The company's net earnings included net after-tax charges of $61 million, or 4 cents a share. Sales for the period rose to $971 million, up 29 percent from $752 million a year ago. Excluding items, earnings came in at $169 million, or 11 cents a share, to top estimates. See full story. CyberSource CYBS surged more than 15 percent in afternoon trades, getting a boost from a William Blair & Co. upgrade. Analyst Franco Turrinelli called the recent sell-off in the stock, which followed the company's release of second quarter results last week, "unwarranted" and raised his rating on the business services company to "outperform" from "market perform." He believes the sell-off was driven by disappointment that the company didn't maintain its recent record of "significant outperformance" relative to expectations and that guidance wasn't raised more significantly following the results. Dobson Communications DCEL jumped almost 10 percent after the company said net subscriber additions for the second-quarter totaled 7,200 vs. a reduction of 5,400 in the sequential first quarter. Customer churn fell 0.2 percentage points to 1.7 percent. Average revenue per unit (ARPU) increased 3.2 percent from the prior quarter to $40. Dun & Bradstreet DNB, -0.71% shares rose more than 5 percent after the company reported its second-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, partly thanks to overseas expansion. The company reported net income of $39.5 million, or 54 cents a share, in the period. Revenue climbed 5 percent to $349.9 million, including the positive effect of currency fluctuations. See full story. EMC EMC, +9.92% shares advanced more than 3 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $193 million, or 8 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $82 million, or 4 cents per share. Revenue jumped 33 percent in the latest three months to $1.97 billion from $1.48 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 8 cents per share in the June period on revenue of $1.97 billion. The Hopkington, Mass., storage technology company attributed the results to "strong execution" of its information lifecycle management strategy. EMC said it's "squarely on track" to reach a goal for mid-teens operating margins by the end of the year. Looking ahead, the company sees earnings of 8 to 9 cents per share on revenue of around $2 billion in the third quarter. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 9 cents per share in the September quarter. ExpressJet Holdings XJT rose more than 2 percent after the company said it earned $29.7 million, or 55 cents a share, in the second quarter, up 10 percent from $27.1 million, or 42 cents a share, a year ago, buoyed by continued cost cutting. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 54 cents a share. Revenue climbed to $370.8 million from $320.3 million. The regional airline said its load factor rose 3 points to 73.2 percent, while capacity grew 26 percent to 2.6 billion available seat miles. Revenue passenger miles rose 31 percent. Federated Department Stores FD tacked on more than 2 percent after the company increased its stock buyback program by $750 million. Including the remaining portion of a previous repurchase program, the department store chain is now authorized to buy back up to $1.3 billion worth of its common stock. Shares of ID Biomedical IDBE rose more than 19 percent after the company reported positive results from a field efficacy study of its FluNsure influenza vaccine. The study found that one dose of the vaccine was "slightly more efficacious" with 67 percent efficacy than two doses but that efficacy with both dosages was "statistically significant" relative to the placebo. Going forward, ID Biomedical plans to focus development efforts on a single dose product. Shares of Matria Healthcare MATR, -2.33% surged more than 7 percent after the company said its second-quarter results would top the high end of its outlook for a profit before items of 21 cents per share and that a class action lawsuit against it has been dismissed. Matria also disclosed two new contracts - one with an undisclosed state government and one for the U.S. employees of a company listed on the London Stock Exchange. The current average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 19 cents per share in the June period. Matria plans to issue its second-quarter report after Thursday's closing bell. QRS QRSI advanced more than 6 percent after the company received unsolicited buyout bids from two different parties, with both topping a prior bid from JDA Software JDAS Avling Partners and GTCR Golder Rauner bid $6.75 a share in cash for the outstanding shares of QRS and an unnamed investment fund said it would pay between $6.50 and $7 a share for the retail trading technology company's outstanding shares, subject to completion of due diligence. On June 17, JDA bid roughly $100 million in stock, which, based on Monday's close, valued QRS shares at $6.12 each. RadioShack RSH, -0.07% jumped more than 8 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $68.3 million, or 42 cents a share, up from 34 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 39 cents a share. Revenue rose 3 percent to $1.05 billion, in line with analyst forecasts, boosted by strong wireless communications and computer department sales. Same-store sales increased 3 percent. Looking ahead, the consumer electronics retailer expects earnings of 38 to 40 cents a share in the third quarter, vs. analyst estimates of 37 cents, and 2004 earnings of $2.07 to $2.09 a share, vs. analyst projections of $2.02. Safeco SAFC added more than 3 percent after the company said its careful underwriting practices and low catastrophe payouts helped lift more than double its second quarter earnings versus year ago levels. The company reported net income of$247.5 million, or $1.77 per share, compared to $111.9 million, or $0.81 per share a year ago. Safeco said the results reflected the company's "solid underwriting" and the fact that "weather-related catastrophe losses were relatively light for the second quarter." Sonus Networks SONSE leapt more said it would restate financial results for fiscal 2001, 2002 and the first three quarters of 2003 after an internal review. It also said its audit committee had completed its review of the company. The stock also received an upgrade from Pacific Growth Equities. Tenneco Automotive TEN, +2.91% jumped more than 13 percent after the company posted second-quarter adjusted earnings of 70 cents a share, topping both the year ago report of 58 cents and the 54 cents a share average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Including various one-time items, the maker of emission control products said it earned 69 cents a share in the period. Quarterly revenues of $1.14 billion, versus $998 million a year ago were the "highest ever," the company said. Decliners Shares of Allegheny Technologies ATI, +3.91% slipped more than 2 percent after the company reported second quarter net income of $26.6 million, or 31 cents per share, on sales of $646.5 million, that included special one-time gains and that beat an average analyst loss estimate compiled by Thomson First Call for 37 cents a share. The results included a gain of $40.4 million, or 48 cents per share, in connection new labor agreement and the acquisition of the J&L Specialty Steel and a $34 million, or 40 cents per share loss, for retirement benefits. In the second quarter 2003, ATI reported a net loss of $26 million, or 32 cents per share on sales of $489.9 million. Allstate ALL, +0.20% fell more than 2 percent after the company said a new computer based underwriting system and lower catastrophe losses helped second-quarter profit jump 76 percent, topping analysts forecasts. The No. 2 U.S. auto insurer reported net income of $1.03 billion, or $1.47 per share, in the second quarter, up from $588 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. See full story. Avery Dennison AVY, +2.11% tumbled almost 3 percent after the company said it earned 68 cents a share in the second quarter compared with 78 cents a year ago. Excluding one-time items, however, the maker of pressure sensitive and self-adhesive products earned 78 cents a share in the current quarter besting the 73 cents a share average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sales for the quarter were $1.3 billion, up from about $1.2 billion a year ago. Avery Dennison also lifted the lower end of its earnings expectations for all of 2004 by 10 cents a share to a range of $2.90 to $3.10, before charges, reflecting the benefit of a reduced tax rate and the better-than-expected second-quarter numbers. The improved outlook brings the company in line with Wall Street's consensus. Shares of Ceridian CEN, +2.17% slid more than 10 percent after the Minneapolis provider of payment processing and other outsourced human resources services postponed the release of its second-quarter results as it reviews the capitalization and expensing of certain costs in its U.S. Human Resources Solutions business. The release was scheduled for Tuesday. The company said the review is the result of concerns raised internally, and that it could have an impact on its financials for the second quarter, previously reported results, and its outlook. Shares of Cognex CGNX, +2.40% lost more than 13 percent after the Natick, Mass., maker of machine vision systems reported second-quarter earnings of $10.9 million, or 23 cents per share, in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of 24 to 26 cents per share for the third quarter on revenue of between $55 million and $58 million, ahead of Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 23 cents per share on revenue of $56.3 million. The company noted that it saw a 7 percent decline in bookings on a sequential basis, a development it attributed to "an exceptionally high level of business" for its chip and electronics capital equipment customers in the first quarter "as they ramped up their production in response to demands they were seeing for their products." Stanford Financial lowered its rating on the stock to "hold" following the report, saying the shares will remain unattractive until there's a rebound in the chip sector. Converium CHR, +1.97% shares plummeted almost 50 percent after the Swiss reinsurer said its second-quarter results would miss expectations due to the emergence of higher than anticipated casualty losses in the U.S. See full story. Shares of Delta Airlines DAL, +1.63% sank more than 8 percent after the company was hit with a downgrade by J.P. Morgan to "neutral." The firm said it thinks the chances of the airline filing for bankruptcy protection are 50/50. Everest Re RE, -0.58% lost more than 7 percent after the company beat second-quarter earnings estimates but disappointed with its underlying results. Analyst William Wilt at Morgan Stanley said the quality of earnings was weak "and we think a beat was largely expected." Everest reported second-quarter earnings of $4.64 a share, up from $1.99 a share a year ago and a full 41 cents a head of consensus. But the beat came mainly from "other income" which totaled 43 cents a share. "Underwriting results, while good historically, are likely to disappoint investors hoping for a breakthrough quarter," said Wilt. Flextronics International FLEX, +0.12% slumped almost 7 percent after the Singapore-based chip maker reported fiscal first quarter earnings before items that met Wall Street's consensus estimate but came in just shy on revenue. See full story. Ford Motor Co. F, +2.03% gave back more than 4 percent after the company posted second quarter earnings from continuing operations of 61 cents a share, excluding special items, well above the 50 cents a share average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Net income for the automaker totaled $1.2 billion, or 57 cents a share, while revenues came in at $42.8 billion. Ford noted that worldwide automotive sales for the second quarter rose to $36.7 billion from $34.1 billion in the same period last year while worldwide vehicle-unit sales in the quarter were 1.748 million up from 1.718 million a year ago. Looking ahead, the Dearborn, Mich.-based company said it expects third quarter earnings ranging from breakeven to 5 cents a share and boosted its full year outlook by 15 cents to a range of $1.80 to $1.90 a share, all from continuing operations and excluding special items. Ford noted that special items consisting primarily of the restructuring of its Ballard Power BLDP, +1.43% investment and a European reorganization are currently estimated to reduce full-year earnings by 8 cents a share. Forest Laboratories FRX, -1.85% forfeited more than 4 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $229.9 million, or 60 cents a share, up from 48 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 57 cents a share. Net sales rose 29 percent to $782.4 million, above analyst forecasts of $753.5 million, amid increased prescription volume for its Lexapro antidepressant. Also, higher average selling prices of Celexa offset lower prescription volume. For fiscal 2005, the drug maker adjusted its earnings projection to $2.40 to $2.50 a share from $2.35 to $2.50. Separately, the company set a 20 million share stock repurchase program, which represents 5.3 percent of the weighted average number of diluted shares outstanding at the end of June. Freeport-McMoRan FCX, +4.90% surrendered almost 5 percent after the company reported a second-quarter net loss of $53 million, or 30 cents a share, vs. earnings of 37 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Results included costs of 20 cents a share related to a maintenance turnaround at a wholly-owned Spanish smelting unit. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting a loss of 21 cents a share. The gold and copper miner said results were also hurt by lower ore grades and reduced mill throughput. Revenue fell 20 percent to $486.3 million. Gentex GNTX, +1.86% fell more than 6 percent after the Zeeland, Mich., company reported second-quarter earnings of $29 million, or 37 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $26.1 million, or 34 cents per share. Sales rose 11 percent in the latest three months to $129.6 million from $116.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call, however, was for earnings of 38 cents per share in June period on sales of $133.1 million. The company manufactures rearview mirrors and commercial fire protection products. Innovex INVX shares lost more than 11 percent after the company posted a widening loss for the third quarter. See full story. Shares of Itron ITRI, +2.65% fell more than 10 percent in afternoon action. The stock was hit with a downgrade by RBC Capital Markets to "sector perform" from "outperform" following its quarterly report. After Monday's closing bell, the Spokane, Wash., developer of energy and water technology posted pro forma earnings of $2.1 million, or 10 cents per share, for the second quarter, well below its year-ago equivalent profit of $6.1 million, or 28 cents per share. The average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 16 cents per share in the June period. Looking ahead, Itron sees pro forma earnings of 70 to 75 cents per share in the second half on revenue of between $265 million and $270 million. The company said it's "not pleased" with its results in the first half, adding that the utility industry continues to be in the "doldrums" and that lower handheld meter reading revenue in the second quarter offset higher shipments of its automatic meter reading hardware. Orthofix OFIX, +1.03% sank more than 14 percent after the company warned that its second quarter financial results would be lower than analysts anticipated because of lower reimbursements, weaker gross margins and soft sales. The Huntersville, N.C.-based orthopedic products company said it expected sales of $70.8 million, below prior Wall Street expectations of $73 million to $73.8 million. Orthofix forecast earnings of 49 cents to 51 cents a share, compared to an earlier analyst estimate of 59 cents to 62 cents. Despite the warning, the company does expect to post a 37 percent increase in sales. See full story. The South Financial Group TSFG fell more than 3 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $30 million, or 49 cents a share, up from 48 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 48 cents a share. Total revenue rose 18 percent to $106.4 million, topping analyst forecasts of $105.1 million, as strong loan growth and higher average investment securities outstanding helped lift net interest income by 21 percent. Taser International TASR fell more than 11 percent after the company said sales in the second quarter rose four-fold to $16.3 million. Net income rose to $4.5 million, or 14 cents a share, up from $347,059 or 2 cents a share in the same quarter of 2003. Four analysts polled by Thomson/First Call had forecast earnings per share of 13 cents for the June quarter and sales of $14.6 million. New orders received in the quarter rose to $16.7 million, a record, it said. Taser also said had understated its estimate of a future tax reduction related to employee stock sales. The corrected tax benefit is $8.9 million; its March estimate was for a $2.1 million benefit. Taser said there was no impact from the tax estimate change on its net income results. XTO Energy XTO, -0.46% fell more than 5 percent after the company adjusted its production and operational guidance for the rest of 2004, citing company projections for output and expenses, as well as the fact that an acquisition of properties from Chevron Texaco CVX, +1.73% will take place up to 10 days later than originally scheduled. The company also reported quarterly earnings of $99.1 million, or 41 cents per share, a sharp increase over earnings of $57.3 million, or 25 cents per share a year earlier. Zhone Technologies ZHNE shares lost almost 16 percent after the communications software company reported a wider-than-expected second-quarter loss. Oakland, Calif.-based Zhone said it lost 10 cents a share in the period, against a loss of 95 cents a year ago. The average estimate of Thomson First Call analysts was for a loss of 4 cents a share. Revenue edged up to $21 million from $20.5 million, below the $22.7 million market consensus. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: ADE, Cendant, Gentex, and more

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Stun gun maker Taser International tasr said sales in the second quarter rose four-fold to $16.3 million. Net income rose to $4.5 million or 14 cents a share, up from $347,059 or 2 cents a share in the same quarter of 2003. Four analysts polled by Thomson/First Call had forecast earnings per share of 13 cents for the June quarter and sales of $14.6 million. New orders received in the quarter rose to $16.7 million, a record, it said. Taser also said had understated its estimate of a future tax reduction related to employee stock sales. The corrected tax benefit is $8.9 million; its March estimate was for a $2.1 million benefit. Taser said there was no impact from the tax estimate change on its net income results.
title: Taser says Q2 revenue higher, new orders up

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Among the stocks likely to see active trading on Tuesday is cigarette and consumer products company Altria Group MO, -0.21% Altria is seen posting a second-quarter profit of $1.28 per share according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Continental Airlines CAL, -0.62% is expected to report a second-quarter loss of 9 cents a share. Ford F, +2.03% is expected to report second quarter profit of 50 cents a share. Chip maker Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% of Germany is expected to report fiscal third-quarter earnings of 11 euro cents a share. Motorola MSI, +1.29% is expected to report earnings of 18 cents a share for the second quarter. Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% is seen posting a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of 4 cents a share. Taser International TASR reporting in the wake of questions raised in published reports about its products, is expected to post earnings of 13 cents a share for the second quarter. Teradyne TER, +1.96% is expected to report second-quarter profit of 37 cents a share. Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% is seen posting profit of 25 cents a share. Well Fargo WFC, +1.81% is expected to report earnings of $1.04 per share. Allstate ALL, +0.20% said a new computer based underwriting system and lower catastrophe losses helped second-quarter profit jump 76 percent, topping analysts forecasts. The No. 2 U.S. auto insurer reported net income of $1.03 billion, or $1.47 per share, in the second quarter, up from $588 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. See full story. The share closed up $1.42 to $47.62, a gain of 3.1 percent. Fiber-optic cable maker Corning GLW, +1.94% reported net earnings for the quarter to June 30 rose to $108 million, or 7 cents a share, from a year-earlier loss of $22 million, or 2 cents a share, Corning said. The company's net earnings included net after-tax charges of $61 million, or 4 cents a share. Sales for the period rose to $971 million, up 29 percent from $752 million a year earlier. Excluding the one-time items, earnings came in at $169 million, or 11 cents a share, to top estimates. See full story. The stock, which climbed in after-hours trading, ended the regular session at $11.27, down 44 cents or 3.76 percent. Flextronics International FLEX, +0.12% reported fiscal first quarter earnings of $74 million or 13 cents a shares on $3.88 billion in sales compared with a loss of $289.7 million or 56 cents a share on $3.1 billion in sales. The company predicted earnings of 15 to 18 cents a share excluding charges for the current quarter. See full story. The company's shares fell in after-hours trading. They ended the regular session at $14.06, down 4 cents or 0.3 percent. Sonus Networks SONSE said it would restate financial results for fiscal 2001, 2002 and the first three quarters of 2003 after an internal review. It also said its audit committee had completed its review of the company. The share rose in after hours trading. It closed the regular session up 7.9 percent at $4.10. A federal grand jury is investigating Halliburton's HAL, +1.93% operations in Iran, the company disclosed in a regulatory filing on Monday. Halliburton said it has received a grand jury subpoena for documents from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Texas, which is based in Houston. Houston-based Halliburton's business unit KBR, the engineering and construction arm of the company, already is under scrutiny for its work in Iraq. See full story. The company's shares closed 0.8 percent lower at $31.26. Brewers Adolph Coors RKY and Canada's Molson (MOLA)(MOLB) acknowledged Monday after the bell they have discussed a possible merger. The talks involved Molson Chairman Eric Molson and Coors CEO Leo Kiely, as well as other executives. "An announcement could be made in the near future," the companies said in a statement. See full story. Coors stock closed at $75.56, up $2.54 or 3.5 percent. Orthopedic product maker Orthofix OFIX, +1.03% warned that its second quarter financial results would be lower than analysts anticipated because of lower reimbursements, weaker gross margins and soft sales. The Huntersville, N.C.-based orthopedic-products company said it expected sales of $70.8 million, below prior Wall Street expectations of $73 million to $73.8 million. Orthofix forecast earnings of 49 cents to 51 cents a share, compared to an earlier analyst estimate of 59 cents to 62 cents. Despite the warning, the company does expect to post a 37 percent increase in sales. See full story. Shares closed 2 cents lower at $38.98. Business information provider Dun & Bradstreet reported its second-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, partly thanks to overseas expansion. The company reported net income of $39.5 million, or 54 cents a share, in the period. Revenue climbed 5 percent to $349.9 million, including the positive effect of currency fluctuations. See full story. The shares closed 1.51 percent higher at $52.60. Sporting goods company Russell RML, -11.76% said it would pay $30 million cash for Huffy Sports, the basketball backboard business of Huffy Corp. HUF, +0.00% Russell also will take on certain liabilities, the companies said. Russell said the acquisition will subtract 4 cents to 5 cents a share from earnings in the second half of this year. However, that will be offset by Russell's recent sale of its investment in Marmot Mountain, which is expected to add as much as 8 cents to earnings. See full story. Russell stock closed at $17.99, down 5 cents; Huffy ended unchanged at $1.03. Johnson Controls JCI, +2.77% said it will buy Grupo Imsa's half of the companies' Mexican and South American car battery business for $525 million. The acquisition is expected to boost Johnson Controls' revenue by $250 million and to add to 2005 earnings. The deal, which includes the assumption of debt, initially will be funded with short-term debt, the Milwaukee-based company said. See full story. Johnson Controls, which makes batteries for automakers like Ford, Honda and DaimlerChrysler, will unveil its third-quarter results on Tuesday. Analysts are expecting a profit of $1.15 a share on just over $6.5 billion in sales, on average, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of Johnson Controls rose 36 cents to close at $53.80. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Altria, Ford, Sun, Texas Instruments

content: Advancers Shares of Applied Industrial Technologies AIT, +1.96% added almost 4 percent after the Cleveland industrial and fluid power products maker forecast fourth-quarter earnings of 52 to 62 cents per share on sales of between $404 million and $406 million, up from its prior outlook for a profit of 45 to 50 cents per share in the period. For the year, Applied Industrial sees earnings of $1.57 to $1.67 per share, ahead of the current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of $1.46 per share. Asbury Automotive Group ABG, +2.97% gained almost 3 percent after the company withdrew plans for a secondary offering of its common stock due to market conditions. The auto retailer had said in January that certain selling shareholders would sell 7.1 million shares, and grant the underwriters options to buy up to an additional 1.5 million shares of stock. The company would not have received any proceeds from the sale. Black & Decker BDK shares rose more than 14 percent after the company reported second quarter net income from continuing operations of $121.8 million, or $1.50 a share compared with $75.7 million, or 98 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Sales for the quarter jumped 19 percent to $1.3 billion from $1.1 billion. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of $1.26 per share on sales of $1.3 billion. Looking ahead, the toolmaker is forecasting third quarter earnings from continuing operations in the range of $1.25 to $1.30 per share on sales growth in the 'low-to-mid-single digit" range, excluding foreign currency factors and acquisitions. The First Call average estimate for the third quarter is for earnings of $1.28 per share. Shares of Compugen CGEN, +11.25% surged more than 18 percent after the company disclosed a research achievement in its work on genetics. The company said has identified additional RNA editing sites in the human transcriptome. Compugen asserted the research increases the number of known adenosine to inosine editing sites to more than 10,000 from about 100. Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% rose more than 4 percent after the company reported a second-quarter loss of $1.96 billion, or $15.79 loss per share, compared with a profit of $184 million, or $1.40 a share, in the year-ago period. The latest quarter includes two previously announced non-cash charges totaling $1.65 billion. Revenue rose 13.3 percent to $3.96 billion, while operating expenses increased 27.3 percent to $4.2 billion. Delta said it ended the quarter with $2 billion in unrestricted cash. Looking ahead, Delta said fuel costs are expected to be approximately $680 million higher for 2004 than 2003. Electronic Data Systems EDS added more than 2 percent after the company signed a $1.1 billion, 8-and-a-half year outsourcing pact with Bank of America BAC, +2.04% to integrate the communications infrastructure for the recently acquired FleetBoston Financial into BofA's voice and data network. First City Bank FBK, +0.22% rose more than 19 percent after the New Britain, Conn., bank holding company agreed to be acquired by Webster Financial WBS, +1.34% for $33 million, or $27 per share. The purchase price represents a premium of 22 percent over First City's $22.05 closing price on Friday. Forest Laboratories FRX, -1.85% tacked more than 2 percent after Morgan Stanley upgraded the drug maker to "overweight" from "equal weight," citing valuation and expectations that investor sentiment will improve in the second half of the year. Analyst Marc Goodman raised his fiscal 2005 earnings forecast to $2.58 a share from $2.56 and his 2006 projection to $2.82 from $2.74, but kept his price target at $70. Magic Software Enterprises MGIC, +4.29% rose more than 6 percent on news of deal for its iBOLT Portal software with Vodafone Netherlands, a unit of Vodafone Group plc VOD, +0.54% The company said its iBOLT Portal will be used to enhance a service management platform and to provide real time information and services to internal support and operations personnel. Mattel MAT, +0.38% surged nearly 6 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $23.5 million, or 6 cents a share, up from a nickel a share in the same period a year ago, and a penny a share above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Net sales rose 5 percent to $804 million, vs. analyst forecasts of $800.9 million, as 37 percent growth in Hot Wheels sales and 12 percent increases in Fisher Price and American Girl brand products helped offset a 13 percent drop in Barbie sales. Shares of M-Systems FLSH gained more than 2 percent after posting second-quarter earnings of $5.4 million, or 14 cents a share, 2 cents above the 12 cents a share average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenues for the quarter came in at $86.1 million, also topping the $69.5 million expected by analysts. The Kfar Saba, Israel-based maker of flash data storage systems also boosted expectations for the rest of the year. The company said it now expects third quarter earnings per share of at least 14 cents a share on revenues of at least $86 million. The average First Call forecast for the third-quarter was for earnings of 13 cents a share on revenues of $74.7 million. For the full year, M-Systems lifted its outlook to earnings "at or above" 55 cents a share from 45 cents and revenues of at least $325 million from $275 million. NitroMed NTMD soared more than 121 percent after the company halted the Phase III trial of its lead drug for the development of heart failure in African Americans, BiDil, due to the "significant" survival benefit seen. Both the Data Safety and Monitoring Board and the steering committee unanimously recommended the decision to halt the trial early, given that the results of the study were "so compelling." See full story. Novavax NVAX, +2.44% advanced more than 6 percent after the company said it would pay King Pharmaceuticals KG, +4.65% $22 million in cash and issue 3.78 million shares of common stock as part of their agreement to end a co-promotion agreement and to reacquire all rights to menopausal hot flash treatment Estrasorb. Novavax said it would also receive $8 million in cash from King. When the deal is done, King will own about 10 percent of the total Novavax shares outstanding. Separately, Novavax said it sold $35 million worth of convertible debt and issued 952,381 shares of stock at a price of $5.25 each to private investors. Shares of PalmOne PLMO, +0.00% rose almost 7 percent to following news that its Treo 600 smartphone is now available to Verizon Wireless customers. Verizon VZ, -0.37% said it's the "only carrier" able to offer an integrated e-mail service using the Treo 600 and Intellisync's SYNC, +3.23% Wireless Sync mobile communications technology to bounce e-mails sent to a customer's PC to their handheld device. Pentair PNR, +0.35% tacked on almost 2 percent after the company agreed to sell its tools business for $775 million to Black & Decker BDK The deal is expected to close by the end of the year. The company will use the proceeds from the sale to pay down debt associated with the WICOR Industries purchase. Shares of QRS QRSI rallied more than 25 percent after the Richmond, Calif., retailing technology provider said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it's received an acquisition offer from private equity firms Avling Partners and GTCR Golder Rauner LLC. The proposal calls for a swap of $6.75 in cash for each QRS share. Shares of Sensient Technologies SXT, +1.61% leapt more than 8 percent after the company posted second-quarter earnings of 39 cents a share, 3 cents better than the 36 cents a share average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. "We reported strong cash flow again this quarter, and we are strengthening our balance sheet. We expect continued improvement in the second half," Kenneth P. Manning, chairman, president and CEO said in a press release. Looking ahead, the company is forecasting earnings of 46 cents a share for the third-quarter and $1.65 for all of 2004. The First Call forecast was for earnings of 42 cents a share for the third-quarter and $1.55 for the year. Sonus Networks SONSE rose more than 12 percent after Smith Barney boosted its recommendation on the shares to "buy" from "hold" ahead of a company update scheduled for after the closing bell. Analyst Alex Henderson believes the filing of restatements from 2001 to 2003, as well as the first half of 2004, are imminent and could even happen Monday. "We continue to believe this is primarily a revenue recognition timing issue and do not expect any major shocks from the restatements," Henderson told clients. Even if the filings don't happen Monday, Henderson thinks the company is far enough along the restatemet process that the Nasdaq would grant another short-term extension if needed. SS&C Technologies SSNC, +4.07% gained almost 10 percent following an upgrade from J.P. Morgan ahead of its second-quarter report to be released after the closing bell. Analyst Adam Holt raised his rating on shares of the financial software company to "overweight" from "neutral," saying he believes his fiscal 2004 forecasts for earnings of 75 cents and revenue of $91 million are conservative. He sees an opportunity to accumulate the stock following a sell-off he thinks was more likely driven by investor capitulation than declining fundamentals. Steel Technologies STTX, +0.00% rose more than 2 percent after the steel processing company posted third quarter net income of $10.5 million, or 81 cents a share compared with $1 million, or 10 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Sales for the quarter jumped 79 percent to $232 million from $129.6 million. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 79 cents a share on sales of $225 million. Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% gained more than 7 percent in afternoon action. Sanford Bernstein had a bullish outlook for Sun Microsystems' second-quarter revenues, telling clients several positive indicators suggest the company may have a "very good" revenue quarter. Analyst Toni Sacconaghi said channel checks revealed consistently strong sentiment about overall sales levels and the quarter finishing well. Swift Transportation SWFT jumped more than 10 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $34.6 million, or 43 cents per share, compared to $19.2 million, or 23 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Phoenix-based trucking firm said revenue rose 18 percent to $691 million, including the business from acquired firm Merit Distribution. Excluding fuel surcharge revenue, revenue would have grown 15.8 percent. Adjusted earnings were 40 cents per share, compared with 24 cents. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted earnings of 27 cents per share. Ultra Clean Holdings UCTT, +5.77% surged more than 9 percent after the company said it expects second-quarter net income of $3.1 million, or 18 cents per share, compared with a net loss of $200,000, or 2 cents per share last year. The company was expected to earn 17 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares of Verticalnet VERT added more than 14 percent after the company completed an acquisition of B2eMarkets, a private software firm, and lifted its financial outlook for the second quarter. The company said it issued 5.1 million common shares and delivered a promissory note of $5.9 million in the deal. The note accrues interest at 8 percent per year with half the principal due in July of 2007 and the remainder due in July of 2008. For the second quarter, Verticalnet now sees a loss of 5 to 7 cents per share on revenue of between $6.2 million and $6.5 million. Its previous outlook was for a loss of 6 to 8 cents per share on revenue of $5.6 million to $5.8 million. The company expects the acquisition to improve its revenue mix and add to cash flow within the next two to three quarters. Decliners Avanex AVNX shares lost more than 6 percent after the company said late Friday it filed with SEC to offer up to $100 million of securities. Avanex also filed so holders Alcatel, Corning and others can sell about 5.7 million shares. Those holders will still have restrictions on the sale of their holdings, acquired when the companies sold optical network holdings to Avanex. Shares of Biolase Technology BLTI sank more than 28 percent after the San Clemente, Calif., medical technology provider offered a financial outlook for the second quarter that's below Wall Street's consensus view. The company now sees second-quarter earnings roughly flat with its first-quarter profit of 3 cents per share.
