The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 6 cents per share in the June quarter. The company said Monday that its board has approved the buyback of up to 1.25 million common shares. Also, Oppenheimer has dropped its rating on Biolase to "neutral." Shares of Blue Coat Systems BCSI dropped more than 10 percent after the Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of Internet monitoring hardware agreed to acquire Cerberian, a private provider of URL filtering software, for $17.5 million in stock. Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40% lost more than 3 percent after the company suspended its financial outlook after announcing a recall of its drug-coated stents. Shares Boston Scientific manufactures the Taxus Express2 with Canadian biomedical firm Angiotech Pharmaceuticals ANPI whose shares fell more than 7 percent. See recall story. Shares of Empire Resorts NYNY, +4.23% lost more than 14 percent in afternoon action. Late Friday, the gaming company priced an offering of $65 million of 5 1/2 percent senior notes that convert to common stock. Empire plans to use the proceeds of the sale to purchase 232 acres of land in Monticello, N.Y., pay down debt, complete renovations at its horsetrack, fund development costs at its Cayuga Catskill Resort and for general corporate purposes. Inspire Pharmaceuticals ISPH, +4.46% slipped almost 2 percent after the company said it plans to offer 6 million shares of common stock to the public. The company will also grant the underwriters of the offering options to buy up to an additional 900,000 shares to cover over-allotments. Legg Mason LM, +2.44% tumbled almost 6 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $86.4 million, or $1.14 per share, compared with $58.4 million, or 83 cents per share in the year-ago period. Net revenue was $538.9 million, up 29 percent. The Baltimore brokerage firm missed by nine cents its earnings target of $1.23 per share. The company cited "difficult" comparisons in its capital markets business, which saw pre-tax profits fall 18 percent. "Hopefully these markets will stabilize enough to allow a more normal transaction volume to resume," the company said. Lexmark International LXK, +0.00% slid more than 6 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $136.6 million, or $1.02 per share, compared with $101.7 million, or 77 cents per share in the year-ago period. The Lexington, Ky. Printer maker beat the forecast of 97 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The company forecasted third-quarter net income of 90 cents to $1 per share. ManTech MANT, +2.44% lost more than 24 percent after the company said that changing government policies are hitting its MSM personnel security investigation business and will lead it to post a second-quarter loss. Fairfax, Va.-based ManTech, which provides technology for national security programs to various government departments, said it can no longer confirm the second-quarter and 2004 revenue and earnings outlooks provided in May. At that time, the company forecast second-quarter revenue of $197 to $201 million, and earnings of 13 to 15 cents a share. The company is planning to report second-quarter results by August 9. 3M MMM, +1.38% pulled back more than 5 percent after the Dow component and Post-it notes and Scotch tape maker reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings and raised its 2004 outlook, but indicated that third-quarter results would fall short of expectations. See full story. Netflix NFLX, +3.35% shares tumbled after Thomas Weisel cut the stock to "peer perform" vs. "outperform," on concerns about a potentially more competitive pricing strategy at rival Blockbuster. "According to its just launched beta site, Blockbuster appears more aggressive in pricing its beta online service ($19.99/month) than we expected, which rates uncertainty and could slow Netflix's growth somewhat," said analyst Gordon Hodge. The analyst is lowering his 2005 earnings outlook to $1.00 from $1.30. Shares of Sify Ltd. SIFY, +3.00% fell more than 20 percent after the India-based Internet and e-commerce services provider posted a loss of $1.2 million, or 3 cents per share, for the second quarter on sales of $16.9 million. The performance represented a sequential decline for the company, which earned $510,000, or a penny per share, on sales of $17.9 million in the three-month period ended March 31. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for Sify. Similar companies trading lower included Chinadotcom CHINA, +0.00% Rediff.com REDF and Sohu.com SOHU, +4.07% St. Mary Land & Exploration SM, +3.32% dipped more than 5 percent after the company updated its production outlook for 2004, reducing production estimates from its energy ventures. St. Mary cited delays in production and "underperformance" in some oil fields causing the company to eliminate 4 billion cubic feet of gas equivalent of production from its previous outlook. See full story. Shares of Taser International TASR slid more than 6 percent following newspaper reports over the weekend that the company's stun guns may be linked to five deaths. The Arizona Republic reported that there were five deaths that medical examiners could not rule out Taser's stun guns as the cause of death, and that the company's claims that its guns are not lethal are based on autopsy reports the company never possessed. The New York Times also noted that the British government could not approve Taser's stun guns for general police use after a study could not prove the weapons' safety. The company responded to the New York Times report by saying the failure to mention a life-saving incident indicates the report was intended to be negative. Taser said that to correct each piece of misleading information "would require a manuscript longer than the article itself." Shares of Vastera VAST, +1.61% tumbled more than 9 percent after JMP Securities downgraded its rating to "market underperform" from "market perform." The move comes after last week's announcement that Visteon Corp. VC, +2.18% would not renew its contract with Vastera, a trade management software company, when it expires Jan. 1, 2005. Shares of The Wet Seal WTSLA dropped more than 16 percent, lputting the stock on pace for a fifth straight negative session. On Friday, La Senza Corp., a Montreal-based apparel retailer, said its board has approved the sale of its holdings in The Wet Seal, which totaled 3.1 million shares. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Don’t ever do this with your credit card Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Sun Microsystems, Vastera, and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International tasr slumped 4.4 percent in pre-open trading following newspaper reports over the weekend that the company's stun guns may be linked to five deaths. The Arizona Republic reported that there were five deaths that medical examiners could not rule out Taser's stun guns as the cause of death, and that the company's claims that its guns are not lethal are based on autopsy reports the company never possessed. The New York Times also noted that the British government could not approve Taser's stun guns for general police use after a study could not prove the weapons' safety. The company responded to the New York Times report by saying the failure to mention a life-saving incident indicates the report was intended to be negative. Taser said that to correct each piece of misleading information "would require a manuscript longer than the article itself." The stock was last trading down $1.79 at $38.45.
title: Taser Int'l slumps on newspaper report, co. responds

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser tasr rose 5 percent to $42 on Instinet after the Scottsdale, Ariz., non-lethal weapon provider said it received orders worth a total of $837,000 from three metropolitan police departments. The three departments -- Chattanooga, Tenn., Lubbock, Tex., and Las Vegas -- ordered a total of 911 Taser X26 weapons and accessories. All orders are expected to ship in the third quarter.
title: Taser receives $837,000 order

content: LOS ANGELES (CBS.MW) - Shares of US Airways UAIR could be a focus in Monday's trading session after the company said it could break even in the second quarter, according to an Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Friday. Allegheny Energy AYE an electric and natural gas distributor, said late Friday it named James Kauffman as chief information officer. American Financial Realty Trust AFR, +4.19% said late Friday it completed its sale of $300 million in 4.375 percent convertible senior notes due 2024. The Jenkintown, Pa.-based real estate trust, also said it granted one of the initial purchasers an option to purchase over the next 45 days up to an additional $85 million of convertible senior notes. De Beers, the world's largest diamond producer, has agreed to plead guilty to criminal price fixing, the New York Times reported on Friday. The paper quoted a court official and a lawyer involved in the case in a move that will end a decade long-case and smooth the way for De Beers to return to U.S. markets after an absence of nearly half a century. De Beers is 45 percent owned by Anglo American AAUK Argosy AGY, -2.78% which owns and operates riverboat casinos and hotels, said late Friday it started its exchange offer for 7 percent senior subordinated notes due 2014. The exchange offer expires on at 5:00 p.m. EST on Aug. 6. Boyd Bros. BOYD a trucking company that primarily transports steel and building materials, said late Friday it increased its purchase price offer in its merger plan with BBT Acquisition. The Clayton, Ala.-based company increased its purchase price offer to $9.18 a share from $7 a share payable to stockholders other than BBT and Boyd family members who own BBT stock. Boyd also extended the merger's termination date to Sept. 15. Boyds Collection FOB which makes gifts and collectibles, said late Friday it signed a letter of intent with Branson, Mo. to develop its fourth Boyds Bear Country store. Boyds expects the store to open in the fourth quarter of 2005. Cleveland-Cliffs CLF, +5.30% which produces iron ore pellets, said late Friday it was "disappointed" that the United Steelworkers of America called a strike at Wabush Mines in Canada. The strike began July 5 and the company said it idled Wabush Mines' mining and concentrating facilities in Labrador, Newfoundland. The company said the strike, along with another one at a facility in Quebec, is costing it $500,000 a week in pre-tax earnings. Cleveland-Cliffs urged the union to resume negotiations. Credit Suisse First Boston's chief financial officer, Barbara Yastine, is resigning, according to a published report. Yastine is leaving just days before CSFB's new CEO Brady Dougan is to name a new management team, according to a Bloomberg news report. Yastine is a member of Credit Suisse Group's CSR, +0.00% executive board and Credit Suisse First Boston's highest-ranking woman. A source tells Bloomberg Yastine plans to stay until a replacement is named next month. Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% is expected to report earnings of 9 cents a share for its second quarter. (AAL). Cintas CTAS, +0.91% which designs and rents corporate uniforms, will weigh in with earnings on Monday. It is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 41 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Helen of Troy HELE, +3.51% which makes and distributes a range of hair care products, is seen posting a per-share profit of 45 cents for its first quarter. IBM IBM, +0.60% is expected this week to introduce an e-mail server designed for medium-sized businesses. The server will be called IBM Lotus Domino Messaging Express. See full story. Instinet Group INGP said late Friday that the Inet ECN's daily U.S. equity share volume in June averaged 451 million shares, or 13 percent of the U.S. equity market. See full story. Barron's Online on Saturday said Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% could see significant gains because of expected increased orders for its FA-22 fighter jet, which is in final Air Force testing before the first combat squadron takes delivery late next year. See full story. McDonald's Corp. MCD, -1.28% is facing a lawsuit by BanTransFat.com, which alleges the company has not upheld its promises to remove trans-fatty acids from cooking oil. BTF says it is not seeking monetary compensation, but wants McDonald's to change to the new cooking oil and take "effective steps to inform its customers about its failure to make the change." See full story. MCI MCIA has sued former boss Bernie Ebbers in an effort to recoup more than $300 million that the company lent him before it was engulfed in a massive accounting scandal. See full story. M.D.C. Holdings MDC, +0.47% whose subsidiaries build and sell homes, is expected to say it made $1.98 a share during its second quarter. M&T Bank MTB, +2.09% a bank holding company based in Buffalo, N.Y., is expected to report earnings of $1.45 per share for its second quarter. Chip-equipment company Novellus Systems NVLS is seen reporting a second-quarter profit of 26 cents a share. Peabody Energy BTU, +0.05% a St. Louis-based coal provider, said late Friday it expects to meet or surpass the second-quarter earnings forecasts it issued in April. See full story. PriceSmart PSMT, +0.78% which runs shopping warehouse clubs in central America, the Caribbean and Asia, said late Friday June same-store sales increased 2.2 percent from last year. June net sales increased 0.6 percent to $46.7 million from $46.4 million last year. Semco Energy SEN, -15.00% which provides natural gas and related services, late Friday named Michael Palmeri as chief financial officer and treasurer effective July 20. Palmeri replaces John Schneider who retires at the end of the month. Stanley Furniture STLY, +0.03% which designs and makes wood furniture, is expected to post a second-quarter profit of 68 cents a share. SunTrust STI, +2.22% a financial services firm based in Atlanta, is seen reporting a second-quarter profit of $1.26 a share. Taser International TASR which provides non-lethal weapons for security and defense uses, said late Friday the U.S. Court of Appeals upheld a previous ruling finding that some of its products did not infringe on a patent held by James McNulty. Troy Group TROY which provides electronic payment and checking printing systems, said late Friday its chief financial officer, Jim Klingler, is resigning on July 23 to work for another company. See full story. TXU Corp. TXU on Friday said it was offended by the false allegations: made by rival Texas Commercial Energy. TXU said the recent suit Texas Commercial filed in U.S. District Court -- alleging that TXU manipulated prices -- was dismissed by the trial court. TXU also stated that the Public Utilities Commission conducted an investigation and found no evidence of wrongdoing. Walt Disney Co.'s DIS, +1.93% Disneyland Big Thunder Mountain Railroad ride has been closed indefinitely by California safety officials following a Thursday accident in which three people were hurt, the Associated Press reported Friday. The incident occurred 10 months after a man was killed on the ride. Wilsons The Leather Experts, WLSN which operates retail stores selling leather items, said late Friday that it repurchased and cancelled $22 million 11 1/4 percent senior notes due August 15. The Minneapolis-based company said the repurchase reduces the total amount of the notes to $8.6 million outstanding. Wisconsin Energy WEC, +0.67% said late Friday it commenced with a modified Dutch auction tender offer for up to $100 million of its 5.5 percent senior notes due Dec. 1, 2008. It is also offering up to $150 million 6.50 percent senior notes due April 1, 2011 and up to $50 million of its 6.20 percent senior notes due April 1, 2033. The offer is conditioned upon the closing of the sale of its WICOR Industries manufacturing unit, which is currently expected to occur on or about July 31. Yukos YUKOY is facing a U.S. lawsuit, which alleges securities fraud. The suit has been filed on behalf of investors in Yukos by Connecticut-based Schatz & Nobel, which claims the company created a complex network of shell companies to evade taxes. See full story. Meanwhile, the Russian government is taking care not to disrupt the group's crude production as it seeks to recoup payment of a $3.4 billion tax bill, according to a report in the New York Times. The CEO of US Airways said the beleaguered airline may break even in the second quarter, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bruce Lakefield, the airline's president and chief executive, said the full-year outlook is "clouded," and cautioned that the company must get its costs in line in order to stay in compliance with its federal loan guarantee. See full story. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Yukos, IBM, Disney, US Airways

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Monday's session is Cintas CTAS, +0.91% which designs and rents corporate uniforms. It is expected to report fourth-quarter earnings of 41 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Walt Disney Co.'s DIS, +1.93% Disneyland Big Thunder Mountain Railroad ride has been closed indefinitely by California safety officials following a Thursday accident in which three people were hurt, the Associated Press reported Friday. Cleveland-Cliffs CLF, +5.30% which produces iron ore pellets, said late Friday that it was "disappointed" that the United Steelworkers of America called a strike at Wabush Mines in Canada. The strike was initiated July 5 and the company said it idled Wabush Mines' mining and concentrating facilities in Labrador, Newfoundland. The company said the strike action, along with another one at a facility in Quebec, is costing the company $500,000 a week in pre-tax earnings. Cleveland-Cliffs urged the labor union to return to the negotiation table. Credit Suisse First Boston's chief financial officer, Barbara Yastine, is resigning, according to a published report. Yastine is leaving just days before CSFB's new CEO Brady Dougan is to name a new management team, according to a Bloomberg news report. Yastine is a member of Credit Suisse Group's CSR, +0.00% executive board and Credit Suisse First Boston's highest-ranking woman. A source tells Bloomberg Yastine plans to stay with the company until a replacement is named next month. Instinet Group INGP said late Friday that the Inet ECN's daily U.S. equity share volume in June averaged 451 million shares, or 13 percent of the U.S. equity market. See full story. MCI MCIA has sued former boss Bernie Ebbers in an effort to recoup more than $300 million that the company lent him before it was engulfed in a massive accounting scandal. See full story. Peabody Energy BTU, +0.05% a St. Louis-based coal provider, said late Friday it expects to meet or surpass the second-quarter earnings forecasts it issued in April. See full story. PriceSmart PSMT, +0.78% which runs shopping warehouse clubs in central America, the Caribbean and Asia, said late Friday June same-store sales increased 2.2 percent from last year. June net sales increased 0.6 percent to $46.7 million from $46.4 million last year. Semco Energy SEN, -15.00% which provides natural gas and related services, late Friday named Michael Palmeri as chief financial officer and treasurer effective July 20. Palmeri replaces John Schneider who retires at the end of the month. Taser International TASR which provides non-lethal weapons for security and defense uses, said late Friday the U.S. Court of Appeals upheld a previous court ruling finding that some of its products did not infringe on a patent held by plaintiff James McNulty. Troy Group TROY which provides electronic payment and checking printing systems, said late Friday its chief financial officer, Jim Klingler, is resigning on July 23 to work for another company. See full story. The CEO of US Airways UAIR said the beleaguered airline may break even in the second quarter, according to a filing Friday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Bruce Lakefield, the airline's president and chief executive, said the full-year outlook is "clouded," and cautioned that the company must get its costs in line in order to stay in compliance with its federal loan guarantee. See full story. Wilsons The Leather Experts, WLSN which operates retail stores selling leather items, said late Friday that it repurchased and cancelled $22 million 11 1/4 percent senior notes due August 15. The Minneapolis-based company said the repurchase reduces the total amount of the notes to $8.6 million outstanding. Wisconsin Energy WEC, +0.67% said late Friday it commenced with a modified Dutch auction tender offer for up to $100 million of its 5.5 percent senior notes due Dec. 1, 2008. It is also offering up to $150 million 6.50 percent senior notes due April 1, 2011 and up to $50 million of its 6.20 percent senior notes due April 1, 2033. The offer is conditioned upon the closing of the sale of the its WICOR Industries manufacturing unit, which is currently expected to occur on or about July 31. title: SCH, NVLS, UAIR, MCIA, BTU

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Taser International got a boost Friday after a lawsuit against the maker of stun guns and other self-defense products was dismissed. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company's stock rose 60 cents to close at $44.30. Earlier, Taser TASR announced that a court in Florida dismissed with prejudice a case brought against the company relating to the death of a man who had one of the company's stun guns used on him while he was in police custody. According to Taser, the medical examiner's report concluded that the man's death was unrelated to use of the Taser stun gun. Because the case was dismissed with prejudice, the plaintiffs are prohibited from filing suit again. Last spring, CBS News reported on fatalities among people who had been stunned. The company vehemently denied that its products were to blame. See story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots
title: Taser's shares rise after lawsuit is dismissed

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stock futures lost ground Friday in a kneejerk reaction to the latest employment report showing the U.S. economy created fewer jobs than economists had anticipated. Nonfarm payrolls rose by 112,000 in June less than half the 244,000 expected by Wall Street economists surveyed by CBS MarketWatch. Employment fell by 11,000 in the manufacturing sector after four months of growth. The unemployment rate remained at 5.6 percent as expected. The rate has been at 5.6 percent for five of the past six months. Dow industrials were last down 5 points at 10,295, S&P futures fell 1.20 points to 1,125 and Nasdaq 100 futures were down 2.50 points at 1,491.50. International markets were not providing support, as the Nikkei fell sharply while bourses in Europe and the U.K. edged lower. Pharmaceutical benefits manager Caremark CMX, -9.09% may weaken after the State of Washington filed administrative subpoenas for civil consumer protection statutes on business practice concerns, the company said. Additional administrative subpoenas will be filed by 18 additional states, Caremark said. Meanwhile, chip stocks could be in focus after the Semiconductor Industry Association said worldwide sales of semiconductors rose to $17.32 billion in May, a sequential increase of 2.1 percent from April and a 36.9 percent increase from May 2003. That's the highest level since December 2000, and the SIA said demand for chips used in wireless communication were especially strong. Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% edged up 21 cents to $23.75, while shares of Intel edged up a penny to $27.03 in pre-market trading. Also in the chip sector, one small deal was announced Friday, as German chip equipment maker Aixtron said it was buying U.S. rival Genus GGNS for 117.7 million euros ($143.2 million) in an all-share deal, valuing Genus shares at $3.61. Genus closed Thursday at $3.40 per share, down two cents. In other tech news, Apple Computer shares fell 6.5 percent to $30.18 pre-market after the company said it was delaying its new iMac computer until September, missing the important back-to-school shopping season. Elsewhere in the computer hardware sector, shares of Maxtor MXO, +13.04% tumbled 11.9 percent to $5.70 ahead of the bell after it said an aggressive pricing environment and lower-than-expected unit shipments had forced it to lower its second quarter forecasts. Shares of Nortel Networks NT fell 10 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $4.72 in pre-market trading after CIBC World Markets downgraded the Canadian telecommunications equipment maker to "sector performer" in a valuation call. Analyst Steve Kamman told clients the stock has reached his $5 price target and although he expects 2004 results to be strong, he recommends a "wait-and-see" approach until mid-August when the company is expected to report full restated results for 2001-2004. Taser International TASR shares gained ground in pre-market trading after it said a court in Florida dismissed a lawsuit alleging the company's Taser M26 stun gun was responsible for the death of Vincent Del'Ostia. The lawsuit alleged that Del'Ostia's death was caused when the City of Hollywood police used the weapon to help in their arrest of the man. In dismissing the suit, the court based its decision on a medical examiner's report which showed Del'Ostia had illegal drugs in his system, concluding that his death was unrelated to the use of the Taser gun. Shares of Taser were up 5 percent at $45.85 in pre-market trading Friday. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: U.S. stock futures slide on weak job data

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares gained ground Friday in pre-market trading after it said a court in Florida dismissed a lawsuit alleging the company's Taser M26 stun gun was responsible for the death of Vincent Del'Ostia. The lawsuit alleged that Del'Ostia's death was caused when the City of Hollywood police used the weapon to help in their arrest of the man. Taser said the U.S District Court for the Southern District of Floriday dismissed the suit with prejudice. Dismissal with prejudice prohibits any re-filing of the litigation. In dismissing the suit, the court based its decision on a medical examiner's report which showed Del'Ostia had illegal drugs in his system, concluding that his death was unrelated to the use of the Taser gun. Shares of Taser were up 5 percent at $45.85 in pre-market trading Friday.
title: Taser gains pre-market on lawsuit dismissal

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Taser shares, which have been hopping in the last week, had another big gain Wednesday after the company announced a $1.8 million contract with the U.S. military. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company's stock jumped $3.47, or 9 percent, to close at $43.23. Taser TASR which makes stun guns and accessories, did not specify which of its products were included in the contract, other than to say it was for "Taser conducted energy weapons and accessories." The company also did not specify how the military would use the weapons, although it did say they had been used by the U.S. in Afghanistan and Iraq. On Monday, Taser's stock rose on the news that the company had been added into the Russell 3,000 Index and from a large stun gun order from the Dayton, Ohio police department. See full story. Earlier on Friday, the stock leapt 20 percent after an analyst said one of the company's consumer stun guns may soon be picked up by an unnamed national retailer. See full story. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title: Taser up on new contract with U.S. military

content: Advancers Electro Scientific Industries ESIO, +3.42% soared more than 18 percent Wednesday after it posted a profit and said it almost quadrupled its sales during its fiscal fourth quarter. The maker of lasers used to manufacture semiconductors said it experienced strong demand in the period. See full story. For the quarter ended May 29, Electro Scientific earned $16.2 million, or 54 cents a share, on sales of $81.8 million. During the same period last year, Electro Scientific lost $20.8 million, or 75 cents a share, on sales of $22.5 million. Emmis Communications EMMS, -0.65% tacked on more than 8 percent after it reported better-than-expected fiscal first quarter results. The net loss was $75.8 million, or $1.36 a share, vs. a profit of a penny a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding losses related to the retirement of debt, the company earned 12 cents a share, ahead of the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 7 cents a share. Revenue rose 10 percent to $161 million, ahead of analyst forecasts of $158.2 million, with adjusted TV revenue rose 13 percent, radio revenue increased 6 percent and publishing revenue grew 2 percent. Kmart KMRT rallied more than 5 percent after it said it would sell up to 54 stores to Sears, Roebuck S, +0.41% for up to $621 million in cash. The discount general merchandise retailer also said that it increased its current stock buyback program to $100 million. The company said the exact number of stores to be sold to Sears will be determined within 75 days. Sears slipped 1.3 percent. Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide QTWW climbed more than 22 percent after reporting late Tuesday narrower losses and higher revenue for the fourth quarter. The hydrogen fuel-cell specialist lost $2 million, or 6 cents per share, a narrower loss than the $3.9 million or 17 cents a share last year. Analysts had expected a per-share loss of 8 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. See full story. Research In Motion RIMM ran up 15 percent after reporting late Tuesday fiscal first-quarter earnings that solidly beat Wall Street's estimates and raised its second-quarter forecast above analysts' expectations. See full story. The Scotts Company SMG, +1.25% gained more than 6 percent after it said it is forecasting third-quarter net income to grow 8 to 10 percent from the same period a year ago, with sales expected to be slightly ahead of its revised full-year outlook. The Marysville, Ohio-based company also raised its 2004 sales outlook, saying it now expects sales to grow by 7 to 8 percent against a prior estimate of 6 to 7 percent. Sonus Networks SONSE said that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has intensified its probe into the firm's delayed financial statements last year, but the stock rose almost 15 percent. See full story. The Sportsman's Guide SGDE powered up nearly 14 percent after it raised late Tuesday its 2004 revenue and earnings forecast following its $30 million cash acquisition of The Golf Warehouse, an online and catalog golf equipment retailer. See full story. The company also upped its 2004 revenue forecast by 10 percent to 12 percent from prior expectations of $205 million to $210 million. By that measure, sales for the year are seen coming in between $225.5 million and $235.2 million. Taser International TASR shot up nearly 9 percent after saying it won a $1.8 million contract from the U.S. military for its non-lethal conducted energy weapons. The company expects to begin shipping the stun guns in the third quarter. U.S.-listed shares of Trinity Biotech TRIB, -0.39% gained almost 12 percent after the U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved a waiver opening up the possibility for its HIV testing kit to be used by almost 200,000 test sites in the U.S. The waiver under the Clinical Laboratory Improvements Amendments of 1998 (CLIA) allows its Uni-Gold Recombigen HIV test to be used in detecting HIV-1 antibodies in venous whole blood samples. Decliners Autozone shares AZO, +1.80% fell more than 9 percent after it said late Tuesday same-store sales have fallen 1 percent so far in the fiscal fourth quarter. Retail sales quarter-to-date have fallen 3 percent. The auto parts retailer's fourth quarter ends Aug. 28. Lexar Media LEXR fell almost 17 percent after saying late Tuesday it expects to post a loss in the second quarter on lower-than-anticipated revenue. See full story. Maxwell Technologies MXWL, +1.37% dropped nearly 14 percent after it warned overnight that sales of its ultracapacitors, which are components used in digital cameras, will drop 20 percent to 30 percent during its second quarter. See full story. Medical devices maker Thoratec THOR plunged almost 26 percent following its warning late Tuesday that second-quarter results would likely to fall below Wall Street's expectations due partly to expected problems with Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements. See full story. WSI Industries WSCI, +1.03% took a more than 22 percent dive after the high-precision parts maker reported a decline in third-quarter earnings from the year earlier. Minneapolis-based WSI said late Tuesday it earned $61,000, or 2 cents a share in the quarter, down from $146,000, or 6 cents a share a year ago. Sales edged up to $3.15 million from $3.05 million. Shares fell 78 cents to close at $2.75. title: Kmart, AutoZone, Taser Int'l and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - U.S. stock futures pointed to opening gains Wednesday, but activity was muted ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates. A quarter percentage point increase in overnight rates is already completely discounted by the financial markets, but if there is any drama remaining, it is about what the Fed will say in its statement, which is due out about 2:15 p.m. ET. In addition, a report on manufacturing activity in the Chicago area will be released at 10:00 a.m. ET. September S&P 500 futures rose 1.40 to 1,137.20 and Nasdaq 100 futures gained 3.00 to 1,510.50. Overseas bourses were also barely budged, with Tokyo's Nikkei Average closing down 0.02 percent, Germany's DAX Xetra 30 adding 0.2 percent and London's FTSE 100 slipping 0.1 percent. The dollar was mixed ahead of the key rate decision, falling 0.6 percent vs. the euro to $1.2150 following strong manufacturing confidence data in France and strong growth in German plant machinery orders. Against the yen, the buck rose 0.6 percent to 108.85 as Japanese factory output growth was below expectations. Within commodities, August crude futures ticked up 13 cents to $35.79 and August gold advanced $1.80 to $394.60. Among stocks seeing early activity, Research in Motion RIMM rallied $6.22, or 10 percent, to $65.60 in pre-open trading after the maker of handheld wireless devices reported late Tuesday better-than-expected fiscal first quarter results. The company also raised its outlook for the second quarter. See full story. Kmart KMRT climbed $4.28, or 6.3 percent, to $72.50 after saying it would sell up to 54 stores to Sears, Roebuck S, +0.41% for a maximum of $621 million. The discount retailer also said it would increase its stock repurchase program to $100 million. Taser International TASR shot up $5.33, or 13 percent, to $45.09 after it said it won a $1.8 million contract from the U.S. military for its non-lethal conducted energy weapons. The company expects to begin shipping the stun guns in the third quarter. General Mills GIS, +1.60% edged up 8 cents to $46.20 after reporting fiscal fourth-quarter adjusted earnings that topped Wall Street forecasts. The company said higher commodity costs will impact fiscal 2005 results, but earnings excluding special items should top forecasts. See full story. Elsewhere, Lexar Media LEXR fell $1.41, or 18 percent, to $6.60 after the digital media company warned late Tuesday that it would report a second-quarter loss due to lower-than-anticipated revenue. See full story. RBC Capital followed by downgrading the stock. Teva Pharmaceuticals TEVA, +0.29% shed 47 cents to $67.30 after the generic drugmaker said it plans to appeal a court decision that patent covering Pfizer's PFE, +0.54% Accupril, a treatment of high blood pressure, was valid. Teva said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had already granted final approval for Teva's generic equivalent, Quinapril. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: U.S. stock futures point to opening gains ahead of Fed

content: Wednesday's stocks to watch SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Kmart KMRT said it would sell up to 54 stores to Sears, Roebuck S, +0.41% for up to $621 million in cash. The discount general merchandise retailer also said that it increased its current stock buyback program to $100 million. The company said the exact number of stores to be sold to Sears will be determined within 75 days. Research In Motion late Tuesday solidly beat Wall Street's first-quarter estimates and raised its second-quarter forecast above analysts' expectations after Tuesday's closing bell. The Waterloo, Ontario, Canada company, reported earnings of $55 million, or 28 cents per share, for the quarter ended May 29. See full story. That marks a sharp turnaround from last year's first quarter, when Research In Motion posted a loss of $8.2 million, or 5 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter was up 158 percent from $104.5 million last year to $269.6 million in the recent quarter. Analysts were expecting revenues of $263.9 million. Excluding charges for a litigation provision, Research In Motion said earnings were $70.6 million, or 36 cents per share, beating the First Call estimates of 32 cents per share. Taser International TASR said it won a $1.8 million contract from the U.S. military for its non-lethal conducted energy weapons. The company expects to begin shipping the stun guns in the third quarter. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% announced that it settled a Massachusetts class-action lawsuit by agreeing to offer consumers vouchers worth $34 million in total that can be used to purchase various computer software and products. See full story. Monsanto MON, -0.05% reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $252 million, or 93 cents a share, up from 66 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding special items, such as restructuring charges and benefits from discontinued operations, earnings were 88 cents a share, exceeding the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 85 cents a share. Sales rose 14 percent to $1.7 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $1.53 billion, amid strength in sales of Roundup and continued growth in sales in its seeds and genomics business. Shares of the provider of agricultural products closed Tuesday up 92 cents at $37.20. Bank One ONE, -0.46% agreed to pay $90 million to resolve allegations over trading abuses in its mutual-fund unit, becoming the last of four firms originally implicated in the fund industry scandal to settle with state and federal regulators. See full story. Overland Storage OVRL warned that fiscal fourth-quarter revenue would fall short of prior expectations due to lower-than-expected original equipment manufacturer sales. The provider of data protection products now expects revenue of $54 million, vs. prior projections of $60 million. For fiscal 2004, the company expects revenue to rise 21 percent over year-earlier levels to $237 million, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $242.6 million. The stock closed Tuesday down 31 cents at $13.21. Quantum Fuel Systems Technologies Worldwide QTWW reported narrow losses and higher revenue for the fourth quarter. The hydrogen fuel-cell specialist lost $2 million, or 6 cents per share, a narrower loss than the $3.9 million or 17 cents a share last year. Analysts had expected a per-share loss of 8 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. See full story. The Scotts Company SMG, +1.25% said it is forecasting third quarter net income to grow 8 to 10 percent from the same period a year ago, with sales expected to be slightly ahead of its revised full-year outlook. For fiscal 2004, the maker of garden equipment said it is forecasting adjusted net income to grow 13 to 16 percent over last year's 2003 adjusted net income of $114.7 million, or $3.57 per share. Scotts said its outlook is based on a continued solid performance of its North American business. The Marysville, Ohio-based company also raised its 2004 sales outlook, saying it now expects sales to grow by 7 to 8 percent against a prior estimate of 6 to 7 percent. Sonus Networks SONSE said that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has intensified its probe into the firm's delayed financial statements last year. See full story. In February, Sonus notified the SEC of an independent investigation following the delay in reporting its financial results for the fourth quarter in 2003. Teva Pharmaceuticals t TEVA, +0.29% said it plans to appeal a court decision that patent covering Pfizer's PFE, +0.54% Accupril, a treatment of high blood pressure, was valid. Teva said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration had already granted final approval for Teva's generic equivalent, Quinapril. The drug had been awarded 180 days marketing exclusivity starting on the earlier date of a final court decision or first commercial launch. Separately, Teva reaffirmed its 2004 financial forecasts. The stock closed Tuesday up 60 cents at $67.77. AVI Biopharma AVII said it terminated its license agreement with Medtronic MDT, +2.24% for the development of AVI's Resten-NG for stent and catheter delivery for the treatment of cardiovascular disease. As a result, AVI said it regains exclusive rights to develop Resten-NG for all cardiovascular applications. The stock closed Tuesday up 6 cents at $2.42. Electro Scientific Industries ESIO, +3.42% posted a profit and almost quadrupled its sales during its fiscal fourth quarter as the maker of lasers used to manufacture semiconductors said it experienced strong demand. See full story. For the quarter ended May 29, Electro Scientific earned $16.2 million, or 54 cents a share, on sales of $81.8 million. During the same period last year, Electro Scientific lost $20.8 million, or 75 cents a share, on sales of $22.5 million. Maxwell Technologies MXWL, +1.37% warned that sales of its ultracapacitors, which are components used in digital cameras, will drop 20 percent to 30 percent during its second quarter. See full story. Medical devices maker Thoratec THOR warned that its second-quarter results are likely to fall below Wall Street's expectations due partly to expected problems with Medicare and Medicaid reimbursements. See full story. Ahead of the news, Thoratec closed up 37 cents, or 3 percent, at $14.42. Shares were halted in after-hours trading. Rayonier RYN, -0.28% raised its second-quarter earnings forecast beyond Wall Street expectations citing improved performance fiber production costs and strong lumber prices. When it reported first-quarter results in April, the company said it expected second-quarter earnings to be "reasonably close" to its 2003 pro-forma second quarter per-share profit of 65 cents. See full story. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call currently expect Rayonier to report earnings of 64 cents a share for the quarter. Lexar Media LEXR said it expects to post a loss in the second quarter on lower-than-anticipated revenue. See full story. The Fremont, Calif.-based digital media company said it expects to report a second-quarter net loss of $17 million to $19 million, compared to net income of $7 million a year ago. Autozone AZO, +1.80% said fourth-quarter same-store sales to date have fallen 1 percent and retail sales to date have fallen 3 percent. The auto parts retailer's fourth quarter ends Aug. 28. The Sportsman's Guide SGDE raised its 2004 revenue and earnings forecast following its $30 million cash acquisition of The Golf Warehouse, an online and catalog golf equipment retailer. See full story. The Sportsman's Guide, a South St. Paul, Minn.-based catalog and online retailer, said the deal would immediately add to earnings and raised its 2004 per-share profit forecast by 8 cents to 10 cents a share to a range of $1.36 to $1.40. The company also upped its 2004 revenue forecast by 10 percent to 12 percent from prior expectations of $205 million to $210 million. By that measure, sales for the year are seen coming in between $225.5 million and $235.2 million. Three analysts polled by Thomson First Call currently expect the company to report full-year earnings per share of $1.31 on sales of $206 million. Shares of The Sportsman's Guide fell 36 cents, or 1.7 percent, to close at $20.55 ahead of the announcement. They rose 5.8 percent to change hands for $21.75 after the bell. title: Kmart, Research in Motion, Taser Int'l and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser International tasr said it won a $1.8 million contract from the U.S. military for its non-lethal conducted energy weapons. The stock surged $4.25, or 11 percent, to $44.01 in Instinet pre-open trading. The company expects to begin shipping the stun guns in the third quarter.
title: Taser shares jump on U.S. military contract win

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Banks dominated evening trading action on Monday with Washington Mutual dropping as much as 12 percent after the mortgage lender cut its forecast. New York Community Bancorp was just about as active, but its shares managed to move north Notable tech issues were holding steady following a mostly negative regular session. The tech-heavy Nasdaq-100 After Hours Indicator, which serves as a barometer for evening trading action, slipped nominally to 1,493. Earlier, stocks reversed course to finish in negative territory after an initial push that was triggered by the earlier-than-expected handover of authority in Iraq. A positive reading in U.S. consumer spending also helped the morning charge. The Nasdaq Composite $COMPQ closed down 6 points at 2,020 while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% shed 15 points to end at 10,357. See Market Snapshot. Busy banks Shares of Washington Mutual WM, +1.13% were halted in late trading after the bank cut its 2004 profit forecast, citing the impact of higher, long-term interest rates on its home-lending business. Shares dropped sharply upon resumption of trading, and last moved down $4.11, or nearly 10 percent, to $37.20. See full story. Separately, New York Community Bancorp shares NYB rallied more than 6 percent on word that Citigroup C, -1.11% has emerged as the frontrunner to buy New York Community Bancorp in a deal valued at close to $6 billion, according to people familiar with the situation. Evening movers Taser TASR remained one of the most-active issues after the close, losing 70 cents from their close at $42.94. The stock soared almost 19 percent on Friday after reports that Taser guns might be picked up by a retail chain this summer. See full story. Elsewhere, Microsoft shares MSFT, +2.10% entered the late session in the red after a weekend decision by the European Commission to put on hold far-reaching antitrust measures against the software giant until a judge can rule on the company's request to suspend the sanctions. See full story. At last check, the stock was very little changed at $28.24. Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% was the only technology issue that saw more evening trading action than Microsoft, dropping 2 cents on Instinet to $4.33. Later this week Looking ahead to Tuesday, investors will set their sights on first-quarter results from Research in Motion RIMM The Blackberry handheld device maker is expected to post earnings of 32 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call, vs. a loss of a penny a share the year before. General Mills GIS, +1.60% will report its numbers on Wednesday along with Monsanto MON, -0.05% while ConAgra CAG, +1.54% prepares to unveil its results on Thursday. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Washington Mutual slumps; NY Community Bancorp rallies

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International -- a new entrant to the Russell 3,000 index -- ended Monday with a modest gain but not before racking up another attention-grabbing intraday gain. The stock rose as high as $48.49 intraday, before closing up 85 cents at $42.94, after the company's stock was added to the Russell index of the 3,000 most actively traded U.S. equities. In addition, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company TASR received a large follow-on stun-gun order from police in Dayton, Ohio. The latest Dayton order is for 265 of the company's X26 stun guns and accessories, said Taser. Earlier this year, Dayton police ordered 40 X26 units, while another 40 of the stun guns were ordered by the Dayton Airport Police Department. Taser estimates that the total value of the new order is $436,000. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Taser rises on Russell inclusion, Dayton stun-gun order

content: Monday stocks to watch Actuate ACTU which makes business software, could see profits rise strongly if sales move near $150 million, says Barron's. Thomson First Call's revenue estimate is for $111 million in 2004 and $120 million in 2005. Ray Conley of Palo Alto Investors, which holds 7 percent of Actuate's shares, tells Barron's that higher sales will drop to the bottom line because of economies of scale. American Capital Strategies ACAS a buyout fund, said late Friday that it raised its stake in Synodys, a maker of radiation detection equipment. With its latest $72 million injection via debt securities and preferred equities, American Capital said it holds about 80 percent of Synodys. Apple Computer AAPL, +0.78% was upgraded by Piper Jaffray analyst Gene Munster to "outperform" from "market perform." He lifted his price target by $8 to $40. Munster said Apple shares could rise further over the next 12 to 24 months as it capitalizes on its anchor position in digital convergence, which in turn will drive sales for its Mac products. Archer Daniels Midland ADM, +1.33% the agriculture giant, had about $7 billion of debt securities placed on review for possible downgrade by Moody's. The move was motivated, said Moody's, by a June 17 ADM agreement to settle a price-fixing suit for $400 million in cash. The rating agency said it will be watching how ADM handles debt protection amid a more challenging situation for its commodity dealings. Arel Communications and Software ARLC which makes video conferencing systems, will see about 661,000 shares purchased by Clayton Mathile at $4.75 apiece. Mathile said about 8 million shares had been tendered in response to his offer. He will own about 33 percent of the company after completing the purchase. Shares closed Friday at $2.41. Avalon Holdings AWX, -1.52% a waste-disposal company, said late Friday that it agreed to sell its transportation operations of DartAmerica to privately held BMC International for $4.4 million, plus possible adjustments based on its balance sheet. As a result of the sale, Avalon said it will take a second-quarter charge between $2.5 million and $3 million. Beverly Enterprises BEV, +4.55% a health-care service provider, said late Friday that it has closed the sale of $215 million in 7 7/8 percent senior subordinated notes due 2014 for proceeds of $211 million. Together with cash on hand, Beverly will use the proceeds to buy back its 9 5/8 percent senior notes due 2009. CoActive Marketing Group CMKG which provides sales services to packaged-goods manufacturers, said late Friday that it will file for an extension on its 10-K form, seeking a new deadline of July 14. The company also lowered its outlook, saying it expects to report a net loss of about $2.6 million for the fiscal year ended March 31. That will include a charge of about $2.2 million. CoActive said it would have reported a net loss of about $417,000 because of sales that didn't close in the fourth quarter, largely as a result of the grocery strike earlier this year in Southern California. The company said the Securities and Exchange Commission and its auditors determined that contract revenue should be recognized only when all services on a contract are completed. Previously, CoActive said, revenue was recognized in stages as certain tasks were completed. See full story. CellGenesys CEGE which is developing anti-cancer therapies, said Saturday that a Phase II clinical trial of pancreatic cancer patients found a correlation between survival and use of its GVAX vaccine. The company said a second Phase II trial for GVAX is enrolling patients with operable pancreatic cancer. That trial will include surgery and radiation. CP Ships TEU a container shipping firm that spun off from Canadian Pacific, has strong prospects if international trade increases and fuel prices continue a recent trend lower, says Barron's. A freight rate increase boosted revenue last year and the company's chairman and CEO both tell Barron's that another hike could come this year. Crown Castle CCI, -1.15% said it will sell its U.K. subsidiary to National Grid Transco PLC for $2.04 billion in cash. The company updated its 2004 and 2005 revenue outlook to reflect the sale of its U.K. business. The wireless network and technologies company expects 2004 revenue of $524 million to $528 million and 2005 revenue of $565 million to $575 million. Crown Castle said it plans to use $1.3 billion of the sale proceeds to pay down debt. The stock closed Friday down 15 cents at $16.08. Crystallex International KRY, +10.34% a gold mining and exploration company, said late Friday that it agreed to acquire the stock of El Callao Mining that it doesn't already hold by giving Toronto-listed El Callao shareholders 0.01818 of a Crystallex share for each of their shares. Approval of shareholders and a Canadian court are required. Edelbrock EDEL a maker of auto parts, said late Friday that its chairman and CEO, O. Victor Edelbrock, is paying $16.75 a share to take the company private. The acquisition via another company owned by the chairman offers a 13 percent premium to the Friday closing price of $14.81. The purchase is subject to securing financing, though a statement said $53 million has been committed by two banks for acquiring the 48.9 percent of shares not controlled by the chairman. Empire Financial Holding EFH, -0.33% a retail stock brokerage, said late Friday that Kevin Gagne has resigned as chairman and CEO. He is under investigation by the SEC over trading of mutual fund shares of clients. Ennis EBF, -1.01% which makes business forms and labels, announced two acquisition agreements late Friday worth $260 million that it said will help it diversify operations. See full story. Garmin GRMN, +1.24% an aviation electronics manufacturer, said late Friday that the Federal Aviation Administration had certified its G1000 all-glass cockpit for Diamond Aircraft's DA40 airplane. The G1000 system integrates flight data onto a single large- display. Genesis Energy GEL, +3.14% which buys and ships oil, said late Friday that it will pay $3 million to settle an oil-spill case with the Justice Department, Environmental Protection Agency and state of Mississippi. Genesis said it took charges in 2002 and 2003 that will account for the payment, related to a December 1999 accident. Genesis said it spend $20 million to clean up the spill, an amount covered by insurance. Goodyear Tire & Rubber GT, +0.83% said it plans to sell $150 million worth of convertible debt. The tire maker will also offer the initial buyers options to buy up to an additional $50 million worth of convertible notes. The company intends to use the proceeds from the sale for general corporate purposes, including the temporary repayment of a revolving credit facility. The stock closed Friday unchanged at $9.85. Grey Global GREY an ad service provider, said late Friday that it hired Goldman Sachs to explore strategic options, including a possible sale, according to published reports. See full story. Halliburton HAL, +1.93% the oilfield services giant, won a $24 million Texas jury verdict late Friday against Smith International SII, +0.97% for patent infringement on a drill bit. Smith said it did not expect the ruling would have any impact on its sales and vowed to appeal the result. Heinz HNZ the foodmaker of "57 varieties" fame, is well positioned for a global economic recovery, according to Barron's cover story. The ketchup manufacturer, known for its link via marriage to Democratic presidential candidate John Kerry, has been aggressively cutting costs and does 60 percent of its business overseas. Barron's says an international pickup in ketchup could flow to the bottom line via currency exchange. Wall Street has been sour on Heinz because of repeated asset write-downs, and the stock carries a 16 price-to-earnings multiple, Barron's says, below such packaged food rivals as Hershey Foods' 23 and Kellogg's 19. Debt reduction and computerized inventory control are helping Heinz's profit picture, says Barron's, and the company's variety of products is down 36 percent from two years ago. The ultimate stock price enhancer could be a takeover, which Barron's says could add about $11 to Heinz's $37.69 Friday close. International Steel Group ISG, +0.27% a steelmaking company put together by investor Wilbur Ross, said late Friday that a Thursday breakdown at a furnace of its factory in Riverdale, Ill., damaged a cooling tower but expects operations to resume within 14 days. ISG said orders will be handled by its other factories and that no effect on second-quarter earnings is expected. Metris MXT, +0.50% a bank card issuer, said late Friday that its receivables division lined up an additional $300 million in financing for a total of $1.2 billion. Micro Therapeutics MTIX, +0.20% which makes medical products, said late Friday that it raised $21 million from the sale of exchangeable notes. Micro Therapeutics expects shareholder approval for exchange of the notes into common stock in the third quarter. The notes, which pay an annual interest rate of 7 percent and mature on June 25, 2005, would be exchanged for 6.85 million shares of common stock at $3.10 each. Micro Therapeutics stock ended Friday's session at $4.94, up30.7 percent. Mine Safety Appliances MSA, +1.49% which makes products for mines, said late Friday that it priced a secondary share offering from its pension plan at $29 apiece for about 2.6 million shares, with an overallotment of about 400,000 shares. In announcing the offering in April, the company said the shares would be sold to diversify the pension plan's assets. Novell NOVL said it plans to privately sell $450 million worth of convertible debt. The software maker said it would grant the initial buyers of the debt, which will be convertible into common stock, options to buy up to an additional $90 million worth of debt. The company intends to use about $125 million of the proceeds to buy back common stock, and the rest of the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions. The stock closed Friday up 3 cents at $8.79. Omnicare OCR, +0.00% is extending its tender offer for the outstanding shares of smaller rival NeighborCare NCRX the pharmaceutical services company said late Friday. See full story. Orbital Sciences ORB, +9.85% a satellite manufacturer, had its debt rating raised late Friday by Moody's, which cited improvements over the past year in cash flow and operating results. The rating affects about $135 million in debt securities. Reebok International RBK a sporting goods manufacturer, said late Friday that it made a tender offer with two subsidiaries to acquire up to $125 million of 11 1/4 percent notes as a way to retire the high-yield debt. The tender amount will be set July 13 based on certain terms related to a Treasury note due April 30, 2006. Tenders by July 12 will also gain a $20 consent fee for each $1,000 principal amount. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco RJR, +0.00% the second biggest U.S. cigarette maker, said late Friday that a judge granted the right to appeal a ruling that allowed the federal government to sue the industry for $280 billion. See full story. Southern Union SUG, +0.00% which operates utilities and distributes natural gas, had its debt rating affirmed late Friday by Moody's with a negative outlook on about $2.2 million of debt securities. Moody's said the company's cash flow is weak compared to its industrial sector, adding that Southern Union carries a relatively high debt balance. Taser TASR said it received a follow-on order for 265 stun guns and accessories valued at $436,000 from the Dayton Police Department. The order adds to the 40 units the DPD ordered earlier in the year. The company separately said its stock was added to the Russell 3000 index after Friday's close. The stock was last trading up $2.69 at $44.78 TBA Entertainment TBA, +7.61% which produces company meetings and events, said late Friday that its shareholders approved a merger with a company controlled by Irving Azoff, Robert Geddes and JHW Greentree Capital. Holders of TBA common stock will receive about 68 cents per share. The acquisition is to be completed Monday, TBA said. Titan TTN a defense contractor, saw its $1.66 billion merger agreement with defense contractor Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% fall apart Saturday. Lockheed said Titan triggered a termination by failing to resolve bribery allegations by a Friday deadline. See full story. Unitrin UTR, +0.00% which sells insurance through various subsidiaries, had its debt rating placed on review for possible downgrade by Moody's late Friday. The rating agency said it was concerned by the shifting of capital from United Insurance to Trinity Universal Insurance -- a cut in United's capital of three-quarters between the end of 2000 and the end of 2003. Moody's said there has been a decline in revenue and operating profit at United. Conversely, Moody's upheld the debt ratings for Trinity. Vans VANS a clothing designer and retailer, said late Friday that it settled a class-action suit over its acquisition by apparel maker VF Corp. VFC, +0.61% Subject to court approval, more details will be disclosed and a deal breakup fee will be reduced. The acquisition and merger is expected to close Wednesday, Vans said. See full story. Vectren VVC, +0.46% a utility holding company in Indiana, said late Friday that a division renewed a $350 million, five-year credit revolver, replacing a $346 million facility. Ventiv Health VTIV said won two new drug sales contracts totaling 400 sales representatives. Separately, the company said Watson Pharmaceuticals WPI, +0.00% terminated its contract sales agreement. The provider of contract pharmaceutical sales said it was "comfortable" with 2004 performance expectations. Under one of the contracts, Ventiv will add 150 representatives in the second half of the year, and 50 additional representatives at the end of 2004, for a current client. For the second contract, Ventiv will build a sales force of 200 representatives to be deployed in the fourth quarter for a new client. Ventiv shares closed Friday down 14 cents at $17.07. Webco Industries WEB, +1.12% which makes stainless steel tubes, said late Friday that its board approved a 1-for-10 reverse stock split, subject to shareholder approval. If that OK is given, there would be fewer than 300 shares and the company would no longer be listed on the American Stock Exchange or file reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Webco said. Wal-Mart Stores WMT, +1.37% is looking for sales in stores open a year or longer to have risen by 2 percent to 4 percent for June, down from the retailing giant's prior growth forecast of 4 percent to 6 percent. Wal-Mart, on its weekly recorded sales update, said weather was to blame for the weaker same-store sales growth. In addition, Father's Day sales were disappointing, coming in flat with last year. Shares of the Dow Jones Industrial Average component dropped 64 cents to end Friday's action at $52.51. Watson Pharmaceuticals WPI, +0.00% indicated that second-quarter earnings and revenue would fall short of expectations, due to lower-than-anticipated demand and product pricing, as well as product launch delays, of its oral contraceptive products. The drugmaker now expects to earn 39 to 41 cents a share on revenue of $400 million, vs. the average analysts estimates compiled by Thomson First Call of earnings of 51 cents a share and revenue of $414.4 million. For 2004, Watson projects earnings of $1.85 to $1.90 a share, below analyst forecasts of $2.14, and revenue of $1.6 billion, below analyst projections of $1.7 billion. The stock closed Friday down 46 cents at $32.29. Ventiv Health shares lost 14 cents to $17.07. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’
title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International tasr ran up 6.4 percent in pre-open trading after the company said it received a follow-on order for 265 stun guns and accessories valued at $436,000 from the Dayton Police Department. The order adds to the 40 units the DPD ordered earlier in the year. The company separately said its stock was added to the Russell 3000 index after Friday's close. The stock was last trading up $2.69 at $44.78.
title: Taser rallies on follow-on order from Dayton Police

Sonic SONC, -0.04% reports its restaurant earnings Monday, Research in Motion RIMM steps up with Blackberry numbers Tuesday, General Mills' GIS, +1.60% food numbers and Monsanto MON, -0.05% agriculture results arrive Wednesday, with ConAgra CAG, +1.54% packaged food on Thursday's menu.
