title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: Corrects title of Nextel Partners' COO SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Titan shares edged higher in after-hours trade Friday following a 20 percent stock plunge on doubts over its merger with Lockheed Martin. Meanwhile, shares of Taser stayed busy on speculation the firm's stun guns may be sold in retail stores this summer. Shares of Taser International TASR soared to close up almost 19 percent. Analyst Brian Ruttenbur at Morgan Keegan, in a new report to clients, wrote that the consumer version of the X26 Taser gun -- which the company already said it will produce -- might be picked up by national retail chain this summer. See full story. After the bell, the stock rose to 1.3 percent to trade for $42.63. Shares of Titan TTN inched up in evening dealings. The San Diego-based the defense electronics has been unable to strike a plea agreement with the Justice Department that would resolve a bribery investigation. Reaching an agreement by Friday is a key condition to closing its $1.6 billion merger with Lockheed LMT, +0.78% See full story. At last check, shares of Titan were changing hands for $14.60, up 7 cents. Lockheed Martin shares, which finished the regular session down 14 cents at $51.97, were unchanged in very thin evening trade. Topping the volume leaders list on Inet were shares of General Electric GE, -1.46% InVision INVN, -2.64% Technologies approved a takeover by GE earlier in the day. GE shares were last trading for $32.64, up 1.4 percent, while shares of InVision rose 7 cents from their closing price, to $49.86. CoActive Marketing Group CMKG said after the closing bell that it expects fourth-quarter and full-year losses, and would also ask for an extension to file its 10-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. See full story. CoActive shares tumbled 17 percent to $2.10 in late trade. And shares of Nextel Partners NXTP slipped 2 cents to $16.70 after the bell. The company said COO Perry Satterlee will step down in mid-July to work for start-up venture Clearwire. Next week A smattering of earnings are due out next week, starting with Research in Motion's RIMM first-quarter results on Tuesday. The maker of the Blackberry handheld is expected to post earnings of 32 cents a share for the period, according to Thomson First Call, vs. a loss of a penny a share the year before. Research in Motion stock ended Friday down 34 cents at $60.69. General Mills GIS, +1.60% will report fourth-quarter numbers on Wednesday, for which the packaged-foods maker is expected to show a per-share profit of 72 cent vs. 64 cents in the same period last year. General Mills shares lost 1.5 percent to close at $45.50. Also Wednesday, Monsanto MON, -0.05% is seen posting earnings of 82 cents a share for the third quarter vs. 67 cents a share the year before. And on Thursday, ConAgra CAG, +1.54% is due out with fourth-quarter results, for which it is expected to report earnings of 42 cent a share, unchanged from the year before. Monsanto shares finished Friday at $35.48, up 25 cents, while ConAgra shares lost 32 cents to end at $27.11. The Nasdaq-100 After Hours Indicator, a barometer of late trade in the technology sector, was down 1.61 points, or 0.11 percent. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Titan, Taser shares move afer the bell

content: Advancers Advanced Magnetics AVM, -1.50% jumped more than 41 percent after receiving a favorable response from the Food and Drug Administration on additional details the company provided about its Combinex imaging agent. According to Advanced Magnetics, the FDA said that the additional data looks "encouraging" to provide a complete response to an approvable letter issued earlier on Combinex, which is designed to aid in the noninvasive diagnosis of metastatic lymph nodes. Aeroflex ARXX gained almost 8 percent after the company said it plans to divest its shock and vibration-control device manufacturing business and seek a strategic buyer. The Plainview, N.Y.-based maker of automated testing and microelectronics products said the operation, which is based in Bloomingdale, N.J., had sales of $11.4 million for the nine months ended March 31. Aeroflex plans to classify the business as a discontinued operation until it's sold, and it expects the eventual divestiture to result in a gain. Shares of Air T AIRT, -0.78% soared more than 43 percent after the Maiden, N.C.-based small-aircraft air cargo operator reported a strong turnaround. For fiscal 2004, Air T earned $1.7 million, or 64 cents per share, up from a loss of $1.2 million or 45 cents per share in fiscal 2003. The 2004 earnings include a charge of $426,000, or 16 cents per share, from discontinued operations. Revenue increased to $13.1 million, or 31 percent compared with the prior fiscal year. Chief Executive Walter Clark said the turnaround was due to the company's "focus on air freight and specialized equipment manufacture." Atari ATAR, +0.00% shares rallied 10 percent after the entertainment software provider said it has shipped 2.5 million units worldwide of DRIV3R, the latest version of its popular three-dimensional driving video game. The company added that consumer demand for the game has been "extremely strong" since its retail launch on June 21 in the United States and June 22 in Europe and Australia. "Our worldwide shipment is right in line with our plan for DRIV3R," said Bruno Bonnell, Atari's chairman and chief executive, in a press release. "The global fan base is as robust and passionate as ever, as indicated by retail reaction in the U.S., the U.K., Germany, France and other key territories." Clinical Data CLDA soared more than 40 percent after the Newton, Mass.-based provider of health-care consulting services reported fourth-quarter earnings of $1.4 million, or 33 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $50,000 or 3 cents per share. Revenue jumped 258 percent in the three months ended March 31 to $15.7 million, from $4.4 million in the same period a year earlier. (Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results.) Clinical Data attributed the strong performance to favorable contributions from domestic acquisitions, increasing contributions from its existing international business and the positive impact of tax loss carry-forwards. Shares of Corinthian Colleges COCO, -0.93% added almost 5 percent. After Thursday's closing bell, the education services provider issued a statement about the Education Department's December 2003 program review of its Bryman campus in Santa Ana, Calif. The company's stock lost roughly 10 percent Thursday following a newspaper report on the review. The company said the department found that the school hadn't "properly verified information in students' financial aid applications and resolved inconsistencies and discrepancies in the available information pertinent to the applications." This determination caused the company to be placed on reimbursement, meaning it has to advance a student's tuition and then apply to the federal government to get the monies. Corinthian said it believes the delay caused by being placed on reimbursement, roughly 45 days, has had an "immaterial" impact on its financial performance, resulting in an increase in accounts receivable of between $750,000 and $1 million. The company also said it received the Education Department's written report on June 21 and that it plans to respond regarding corrective actions within 45 days. Crucell CRXL rose 5 percent after the Dutch biotechnology company announced the discovery of an antibody that protects against SARS virus infection. The results of research show that a human monoclonal antibody, discovered with the use of Crucell's MAbstract technology, protects ferrets from SARS. EverTrust Financial EVRT, -9.09% shares soared 27 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by KeyCorp KEY, +1.45% for $195 million. The price amounts to a 41 percent premium to EverTrust's $138 million market cap as of Thursday's close. The purchase is expected to close in the fourth quarter. Cleveland-based KeyBank said EverTrust's commercial real estate business "represents a particularly strategic fit." Lawson Software LWSN gained more than 6 percent after the company beat Wall Street estimates for its fiscal fourth quarter, as earnings climbed on the back of a 10 percent gain in sales. See full story. Nanogen NGEN rallied more than 8 percent after the San Diego biotechnology firm announced it was issued a patent for "Methods and Apparatus for Detecting Variants Utilizing Base Stacking." The patent is a continuation of patents issued to Nanogen covering methods and devices that detect varying lengths of genetic variants. It expands Nanogen's intellectual property portfolio to 59 patents issued within the United States. Oneida ONEI rose almost 49 percent after the Oneida, N.Y.-based meal settings provider reached an agreement in principle with lenders to restructure its debt and secure $30 million in new credit. As the company previously announced, this agreement automatically extends the waiver of compliance with financial covenants, as well as the waiver of certain payments that have become due, through Aug. 16. The agreement also allows a conversion of $30 million of bank debt into 62 percent of Oneida's common stock. The remaining debt will be restructured into a "Tranche A loan" of $125 million with a 3-year maturity and a "Tranche B loan" of $80 million with a 3 1/2-year maturity. Silicon Image SIMG gained more than 19 percent after the company lifted its revenue outlook for the second quarter, and said it expects sequential revenue growth of 5 percent to 10 percent for the third quarter. In addition, the digital media chipmaker announced that David Lee, its founder, chairman and chief executive, is leading a search committee to identify a successor in the chief executive role. Lee would then serve as chairman. Shares of Taser International TASR surged nearly 19 percent. Morgan Keegan issued a research note on the maker of nonlethal stun weapons early Friday, saying it appears a consumer version of the company's X26 Taser product will be available this summer, as expected. The firm, which maintained its "market perform" rating on the stock, added that it has heard rumors that a national retailer will be selling the weapon to individuals, but that Taser's management was unable to confirm this report. "However, it is our opinion that this development could benefit shares of TASR more than the material impact to the company itself," Morgan told clients. Tektronix TEK, -16.67% gained more than 9 percent after the company reported a surge in fiscal fourth-quarter sales and earnings on strong orders for new products. The Beaverton, Ore.-based test and measurement company said its net income for the fourth quarter was $26.1 million, or 30 cents per share, up from $2.9 million or 3 cents per share in the same period a year ago. See full story. Varian Semiconductor VSEA rose almost 5 percent after it said it filed a patent infringement suit against Japan's Nissin Ion Equipment. The suit alleges the Japanese company's medium-current ion implanter infringes on Varian patents. The Gloucester, Mass.-based company is asking a Texas court to issue an injunction and order Nissin to pay damages. Varian is also looking into other instances of alleged infringement in Europe, Varian President Ernest Godshalk said in a statement. Decliners AaiPharma AAIIE shares lost more than 5 percent after the company posted a wider loss for the third quarter and filed amended financial statements for the first three quarters of the year, bringing it up to date with its reporting requirements and allowing its stock to continue to be listed on the Nasdaq. See full story. Arbitron ARB, +0.00% fell more than 7 percent after the company lowered its 2004 financial outlook, citing Infinity Broadcasting's decision not to renew its contract with the ratings service. Arbitron said it expects its 2004 revenue to be about $12 million lower than its earlier expectations. See full story. ATS Medical ATSI lost almost 13 percent after the company agreed to sell $13.1 million worth of its common stock. The deal is expected to close on June 28. Dana DCN, -3.61% fell nearly 5 percent after Prudential downgraded the Toledo, Ohio-based vehicle product and system provider's stock to "underweight" from "neutral." "Backlog concerns cloud prospects for growth in 2005 and 2006," wrote analyst Michael Bruynesteyn. His target price is $15. Emulex ELX, -4.29% fell more than 5 percent after RBC Capital Markets downgraded the stock to "sector perform" from "outperform." The firm cited concerns that Emulex's results for the June quarter rested too heavily on the contribution of Dow component Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% "We believe trends at HP are tepid, suggesting a back-end loaded close," said analyst Thomas Curlin. Emulex's second half was also in question as Curlin said he saw few catalysts at HP for this period, and that Emulex "does not appear to be well-positioned" for early participation in small and midsize enterprise programs at Dell DELL and IBM IBM, +0.60% RBC lowered its price target on the stock to $19 from $25. O'Charley's CHUX fell more than 6 percent after the company said it expects to report second-quarter net earnings at the low end of its current forecast of 22 cents to 25 cents per share. Same-store sales for the quarter will also come in at the low end of its forecast range of a 2 percent to 4 percent increase for its O'Charley's restaurant chain, as well as in the 1 percent to 3 percent rise for its Ninety Nine restaurant and pub brand. Chief Executive Gregory Burns said the company's conservative outlook is due to a "slower pace of sales growth in May and early June than in the fiscal first quarter and the first few weeks of the second fiscal quarter." O'Charley's profits are also under pressure from rising food costs, notably an increase in chicken prices. Paychex PAYX, +1.63% lost nearly 8 percent after the company missed Wall Street estimates for its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings, reporting a 14 percent decline in net income after taking a legal charge, while sales for the period rose by the same percentage. See full story. Shares of Pemstar PMTR fell more than 12 percent after the company's auditor, Ernst & Young, resigned. The Rochester, Minn.-based engineering services firm said there were no disagreements between it and Ernst & Young "on any matter of accounting principles or practices, financial disclosure or audit procedures." Pemstar is looking for a new auditor. Reynolds & Reynolds REY, +0.95% plummeted almost 24 percent after the company said that it expects lower third- and fourth-quarter profits, citing sluggish sales of its software for auto dealers. "Overall order rates were less than anticipated and we have not achieved critical mass on our newer solutions," said Chief Executive Lloyd Waterhouse in a statement. See full story. Santarus SNTS lost nearly 7 percent after the San Diego pharmaceutical firm announced a follow-on offering of 6 million shares. The deal includes an overallotment option for the sale of an additional 900,000 shares. Sola International SOL, +1.95% fell almost 8 percent after the San Diego eyeglass lens provider reported earnings that missed Wall Street forecasts. Sola reported fourth-quarter earnings of $4.6 million, or 14 cents per share, down from earnings of $8 million or 32 cents per share a year ago. Excluding restructuring charges, the company earned $14.4 million in the fourth quarter, or about 44 cents per share. The average analysts' estimate for the same period as polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 51 cents per share. Chief Executive Jeremy Bishop said earnings were negatively impacted by a "higher than expected" increase in the tax rate to 42.8 percent from 30 percent. Looking ahead, the company expects fiscal 2005 first-quarter adjusted earnings of $10 million. Tetra Tech TTEK, +1.24% slumped nearly 13 percent after the company lowered its earnings outlook for the third and fourth quarters of 2004, saying it will consolidate some of its wired communications and civil infrastructure businesses and take a related pretax charge in both periods. See full story. Titan TTN shares dropped more than 20 percent after merger partner Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% said it would not extend a deadline by which Titan must resolve a federal criminal bribery investigation. "Titan asked us to amend the agreement again to authorize another extension," said Lockheed spokesman Tom Jurkowsky. "We declined to do so. We weren't under any obligation." See full story. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Aeroflex, Atari, Clinical Data, Oneida, more

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International jumped Friday amid speculation the company may soon sell stun guns through a national retailer. The stock climbed $6.67, or 19 percent, to close at $42.09. Taser TASR sells the vast majority of its stun guns to law enforcement agencies in the United States and Canada, according to analyst Brian Ruttenbur at Morgan Keegan. But Ruttenbur, in a new report to clients, wrote that the consumer version of the X26 Taser gun -- which the company already said it will produce -- might be picked up by national retail chain this summer. He did not name the chain. Representatives at Taser's headquarters in Scottsdale, Ariz., did not immediately return a call for comment. Ruttenbur said he is raising his second-quarter estimates, expecting Taser to earn 15 cents a share on revenue of $15.6 million, up from his previous view of 13 cents a share on revenue of $14.4 million. Consumer sales now account for less than 10 percent of Taser's current revenue, according to the analyst. Looking ahead to 2005, he said he expects continued growth, and raised his earnings forecast to 77 cents a share on revenue of $84.6 million, compared with his earlier forecast of 73 cents a share, on revenue of $84.4 million. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Don’t ever do this with your credit card
title: Taser shares jump amid talk of retail-store sales

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International tasr surged more than 5 percent to $37.02 in pre-market action on Instinet. Morgan Keegan issued a research note on the maker of non-lethal stun weapons early Friday, saying it appears a consumer version of the company's X26 Taser product will be available this summer, as expected. The firm, which maintained its "market perform" rating on the stock, added that it has heard rumors that a national retailer will be carrying the weapon to sell to individuals but that Taser's management was unable to confirm this report. "However, it is our opinion that this development could benefit shares of TASR more than the material impact to the company itself," Morgan told clients.
title: Morgan Keegan: consumer Taser product on schedule

content: Priceline.com raises profit goal for second quarter (5:18 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Priceline.com PCLN late Monday raised its second-quarter earnings and sales targets, citing "strong business momentum." The company now expects to earn 29 to 32 cents in the second quarter, excluding certain items, up from a previous estimate of 25 and 30 cents a share. The range does not include the effects of non-cash, acquisition-related amortization expense associated with the company's acquisition of a majority of Travelweb.com, stock-based compensation and option payroll tax expense. Analysts expect Priceline.com to earn 28 cents. PalmOne turns Q4 profit of $13M (4:15 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- PalmOne Inc. PLMO, +0.00% said Monday net income for the fourth quarter was $13.3 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $15 million, or 51 cents a share, in the year ago period. The firm said revenue grew 23 percent to $267.3 million vs. $217.1 million a year ago. The company said demand for its handheld and smartphone products remained strong through the quarter. "We ended fiscal year 2004 with very good results across virtually every key financial metric," said Todd Bradley, PalmOne chief executive. Shares of the company's common stock gained $1.18, closing at $21.53. Taser boosts 2004 revenue outlook (7:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International TASR lifted its revenue outlook for 2004, saying it now expects growth of 150 percent. The Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of non-lethal weapons previously forecast growth of 100 percent from its 2003 total of $24.5 million. The company described its higher outlook as "particularly significant" because "none of the orders that we had expected from International and Military sources during the first half of our year have yet materialized." The stock jumped in pre-market, rising to $28.65 on Instinet from its finish Friday at $25.77. Penford reports Q3 earnings of 26c per share (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Penford PENX reported third-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 26 cents per share, compared to $1.8 million, or 21 cents per share, a year ago. The third-quarter results include a $400,000 charge worth about 5 cents per share related to severance expenses in Australia. The single analyst polled by Thomson First Call forecast third-quarter earnings of 27 cents per share. The Denver-based food and industry ingredient system provider said sales rose 10 percent in the period ending May 31 to $72.5 million. Shares of Penford closed Friday up 16 cents at $17.31. Revlon cuts 2004 financial outlook (7:24 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Revlon REV, +0.98% reduced its financial outlook for 2004, citing slower than anticipated growth in its key mass market categories in the U.S. The company now expects operating income of $90 million for the year with top-line growth of roughly 3 percent. It had been forecasting operating income of $100 million with sales growth of 8 to 9 percent in the period. "We went into 2004 expecting a more robust U.S. color cosmetics category than current trends would suggest," said Jack Stahl, the company's president and CEO, in a press release. "We are acting responsibly by revising our spending plans to more appropriately reflect our current top-line trends and expectations and by accelerating productivity savings ahead of schedule." New York-based Revlon also detailed a number of refinancing transactions, including a cash tender offer for $363 million in senior notes. The stock closed Friday at $3.41, down 2 cents. Lloyds TSB: On track, loans offset debt securities (2:33 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Lloyd TSB(UK:LLOY) LYG, +0.00% the FTSE 100 banking group, said Monday it remains "well positioned" to meet expectations for improved growth in the second half of 2004. Risk-weighted assets at March 31 totalled 119.3 billion pounds, an increase of 1 percent during the quarter "as growth in customer loans and advances, particularly in mortgages, was partly offset by a reduction in debt securities," the bank said. Net interest margin for the first three months of 2004 was 2.97 percent compared with a Group net interest margin, on a continuing operations basis, of 2.92 percent in the first half of 2003, and 3.03 percent in the second half of 2003. In retail banking, Lloyds noted "some slowdown in the demand for consumer credit." The retail bank grew market share in its core markets "particularly in mortgage and credit card lending, albeit with some expected margin erosion." More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Advancers Advanta ADVNB rose more than 8 percent after the company said it would receive $63.8 million in cash from Bank of America BAC, +2.04% as part of a settlement of all outstanding litigation with FleetBoston, which was bought by BofA. Advanta will also have about $18 million worth of unused tax deductions. The payment will be made following an Internal Revenue Service review of the settlement agreement. Advanta expects the settlement to increase its book value by $2.45 a share. American Utilicraft AMUC, +0.00% shares added more than 14 percent after the air cargo developer said late Friday that its shareholders approved a 2-for-1 stock split, effective after June 28. Also, all preferred shares will be converted to common stock, increasing the amount of authorized shares to 200 million from 17.6 million. Central European Distribution Corp CEDC jumped more than 6 percent after the Poland-based beer, wine and spirits importer raised its 2004 outlook. The company now expects 2004 earnings in a range of $1.28 to $1.33, compared to its previous forecast of $1.26 to $1.31. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call was for 2004 earnings of $1.28 per share. Central European raised its forecasts after the company bought an alcohol distributor in southern Poland for $2 million. Chelsea Property Group CPG, +3.03% rose almost 12 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Simon Property Group SPG, -1.00% for a total of about $66 per share in cash and stock. Simon said the deal is worth about $3.5 billion, and that it will also assume Chelsea's existing debt and preferred stock, which totaled about $1.4 billion at the end of March. See full story. Duane Reade DRD, -0.73% advanced more than 5 percent after the drug store retailer amended its merger agreement with a buyout group led by private equity firm Oak Hill Capital. The amendment, among other things, lowers the offering price to $16.50 from $17.00. The amendment also allows Duane Reade to solicit competing proposals and extend the termination date to Aug. 18. Microtune TUNE, +0.90% shares climbed more than 11 percent after CE Unterberg started coverage of the stock with a "buy" rating and $6.50 target price. "Markets for Silicon tuners is in a secular growth phase benefiting from multiple powerful trends driven by technological and regulatory changes that begin today and extend over the next several years," analyst Kalpesh Kapadia told clients in a note. Microtune is the only company to patent a single-chip broadband tuner using a dual conversion approach, the analyst said. The company's revenues are currently growing at a double-digit rate each quarter, while margins are being lifted by a shift to higher-margin products, he said. Nortel Networks' NT shares added more than 2 percent and Cisco Systems' CSCO, +2.95% stock tacked on about 1 percent as the pair of top network equipment manufacturers fueled speculation of a partnership after late Friday by confirming their chief executives had met in Toronto. See full story. Shares of Nve Corp. NVEC, +6.83% rose more than 32 percent after the Eden Prarie, Minn. nanotechnology firm said it received a patent for a type of MRAM--magnetic random access memory. The patent, "Current Switched Magnetoresistive Memory Cell," concerns spin-momentum magnetic memory cells. "This patent significantly strengthens our MRAM intellectual property portfolio," said James Daughton, founder and chief technology officer. "Spin momentum technology should help MRAM reach its potential as a dense, mainstream memory technology." OraSure Technologies OSUR, +0.60% rose more than 3 percent to $7.84 after the Bethlehem, Pa., medical technology provider received a worldwide non-exclusive sublicense of patents related to the HIV-2 virus from Bio-Rad Laboratories BIO, +0.99% The company said the license allows it to sell a rapid test for both HIV-1 and HIV-2 using its OraQuick technology platform. Bio-Rad's stock slid 1 percent. Oxford Industries OXM, -1.25% surged more than 20 percent after the company agreed to acquire London-based Ben Sherman for $146 million and said its fourth-quarter results will be "stronger than expected." The Atlanta-based apparel company expects the deal to add approximately $150 million in revenues and 20 to 25 cents per share in earnings in fiscal year 2005. To finance the acquisition of sportswear maker Ben Sherman, Oxford is using cash and funds secured under a new senior revolving credit facility. The deal is expected to close in late July. Paradigm Genetics' PDGM advanced more than 7 percent after the company received a fast-track contract worth up to $742,000 from the National Institutes of Health for research related to liver toxicity. The deal calls for Paradigm to work to discover biochemicals in urine, serum, and liver tissue that predict the early onset of drug-induced liver injury. Saflink SFLK surged almost 9 percent after the Bellevue, Wash. software security firm said it received an order from the U.S. Office of the Secretary of Defense Comptroller's Office. The contract calls for security software, hardware, and services for more than 250 users as part of an initial deployment. Financial details were not disclosed. SouthTrust SOT.R, +0.49% surged 14 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Wachovia WB, +3.87% for $14.3 billion in stock. See full story. Taser International TASR jumped 18 percent after the company lifted its revenue outlook for 2004, saying it now expects growth of 150 percent. The Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of non-lethal weapons previously forecast growth of 100 percent from its 2003 total of $24.5 million. The company described its higher outlook as "particularly significant" because "none of the orders that we had expected from International and Military sources during the first half of our year have yet materialized." See full story. Walgreen WAG added almost 3 percent after the company posted fiscal third-quarter net earnings of $344.6 million, or 33 cents a share compared with $296.1 million, or 29 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Sales in the quarter rose 15 percent to $9.6 billion vs. $8.3 billion. The Thomson First Call average estimate was for earnings of 32 cents a share on sales of $9.6 billion. The drugstore chain said same-store sales rose 10.4 percent in the quarter. See full story. Decliners Ciber CBR, +5.48% slipped almost 5 percent after the company filed a shelf equity registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to 10 million common shares. The Greenwood Village, Colo. technology consultant said it plans to use the funds for "general corporate purposes, including acquisitions." Cray CRAY, +3.24% slid more than 6 percent after SG Cowen said it lowered estimates for the Seattle-based super-computer company "big-time" and that it "still harbors concerns" about sales of Cray's XD-1 product line and a looming product transition in 2006. SG Cowen now expects Cray to lose 10 cents per share in 2004, down from its prior expectation for a profit of a nickle per share. For 2005, the firm thinks earnings of 25 cents per share "is about the best an investor can count on." SG Cowen further cautioned that "it's hard for us to visualize significant upside relative to the market" in Cray's stock, which currently trades at a 70 percent premium to the S&P 500's price-to-earnings multiple. Escalon Med Corp ESMC, +3.45% fell more than 6 percent after the Wayne, Pa. laboratory equipment provider extended its offer to acquire London-based Drew Scientific Group until July 2. Escalon extended the offer because the threshold level of acceptances of Drew Scientific shareholders has not been achieved to date as required in the exchange offer agreement. Guilford Pharmaceuticals GLFD gave back more than 8 percent after the company announced plans to sell up to 10 million shares of common stock. The company also expects to grant the underwriters of the offering an option to buy up to an additional 1.5 million shares to cover over-allotments. Hanger Orthopedic Group HGR, +1.50% dropped almost 20 percent after the medical services provider said late Friday it received a Justice Department subpoena about alleged billing improprieties by one of its clinicians and also disclosed that the Securities and Exchange Commission has requested information about the allegations. See full story. Ipix IPIX, -4.59% fell more than 8 percent in afternoon action. The Oak Ridge, Tenn., developer of video surveillance technology said in a Form 8-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission late Friday it has dismissed PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as its independent auditor and hired Armanino McKenna LLP as a replacement. The company noted that its consolidated financial statements for the past two years contained no adverse opinion or disclaimer of opinion. LabOne LABS lost more than 8 percent after the company announced plans to sell $90 million worth of convertible debt to qualified institutional buyers. The debt sold will be convertible into a combination of cash and common stock. The provider of diagnostic services also plans to grant the initial buyers options to buy up to an additional $13.5 million worth of debt. LabOne will use the proceeds to reduce borrowings. Magnum Hunter Resources MHR, -11.90% fell almost 5 percent after the company said it would buy $243 million worth of oil and gas properties in New Mexico from EnCana ECA, +4.56% subsidiary Tom Brown. In addition to the 458 wells it is purchasing, Magnum will buy about 44,000 acres of undeveloped mineral interests. The company will fund the purchases through the sale of 15 million shares of common stock and through borrowings from its credit facility. N-Viro International NVIC, -12.50% shares slid almost 10 percent after the wastewater sludge treatment company said late Friday its board approved a price change in its security unit to participate in an equity investment agreement. The price changes to $1.25 per security unit, which comprises one common share and one warrant exercisable at $1.85 a share. Paychex PAYX, +1.63% slipped more than 2 percent after the Rochester, N.Y. human resource company announced its subsidiary had been fined $6.4 million in a court decision. A Los Angeles Superior Court jury determined that the company's Rapid Payroll unit breached a payroll software license agreement with Payroll Partnership and two related entities. Rapid Payroll intends to bring post-trial motions challenging the jury award and, if necessary, to appeal. Paychex said that despite a potential increase in the litigation reserve associated with the penalty, company results are expected to be in line with the company's outlook. Revlon REV, +0.98% sank almost 12 percent after the company lowered its financial outlook for 2004, citing slower than anticipated growth in its key mass market categories in the U.S. The company now expects operating income of $90 million for the year with top-line growth of roughly 3 percent. It had been forecasting operating income of $100 million with sales growth of 8 to 9 percent in the period. "We went into 2004 expecting a more robust U.S. color cosmetics category than current trends would suggest," said Jack Stahl, the company's president and CEO, in a press release. "We are acting responsibly by revising our spending plans to more appropriately reflect our current top-line trends and expectations and by accelerating productivity savings ahead of schedule." New York-based Revlon also detailed a number of refinancing transactions, including a cash tender offer for $363 million in senior notes. Shares of Titan Pharmaceuticals TTP, +1.71% dropped more than 18 percent after the San Francisco drug developer announced that it discovered "significant safety issues" in a clinical trial. The issues arose in a Phase IIb trial of Pivanex, a lung cancer treatment, when it was administered in combination with docetaxel. The safety issues were raised by an interim safety analysis by an independent data monitoring committee. Titan has discontinued treatment with the combination regimen for the remaining patients on study. Titan also plans to withhold further treatment and enrollment in the open label Phase IIa studies in chronic lymphocytic leukemia and melanoma until further analysis of the data from the Phase IIb study is available. Wachovia WB, +3.87% lost more than 3 percent after the company said it would buy regional banker SouthTrust SOT.R, +0.49% in a stock deal valued at $14.3 billion. Under terms of the deal, each SouthTrust share will be exchanged for 0.89 Wachovia shares. Based on Friday's closing prices, the deal values SouthTrust shares at $41.83 each, a 20 percent premium. Wachovia expects the deal to add to cash earnings within 2 years, to add to operating earnings within 2 1/2-years, and to save $255 million a year following a 15-month integration period. Wachovia also said it $1.7 billion in excess capital following completion of the deal, which it intends to use to buy back stock. SouthTrust shares gained more than 12 percent. See full story. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Don’t ever do this with your credit card 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Ipix, Escalon, more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International surged Monday after the company lifted its revenue outlook for 2004, saying it now expects growth of 150 percent. The stock TASR jumped $3.44, or 13.3 percent, to $29.22. Volume of 10.1 million was good for fifth on the Nasdaq's most active chart. The Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of non-lethal weapons previously forecast growth of 100 percent from its 2003 total of $24.5 million. The company described its higher outlook as "particularly significant" because "none of the orders that we had expected from International and Military sources during the first half of our year have yet materialized." The current estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for revenue of $58.4 million for the year. "We are excited to see the US law enforcement business continue at such high levels especially in such a difficult budget environment and we expect to report our financial results for the second quarter and the first half of 2004 just before the open of the market on July 20, 2004," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a press release. title: Taser surges on higher 2004 revenue outlook

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) - U.S. stocks futures were holding higher early Monday, indicating a solid start amid a scattering of multi-billion deals, including Wachovia's agreement to buy SouthTrust for $14.3 billion. SouthTrust SOT.R, +0.49% surged $3.18, or 9.1 percent in pre-open dealings to $37.98. Based on Friday's closing prices, the Wachovia WB, +3.87% deal values SouthTrust shares at $41.83 each, or a 20 percent premium. Wachovia was last down $3, or 6.4 percent, at $44 in Instinet pre-open trading. September S&P futures were up 2.40 at 1,136.40 and the Nasdaq 100 futures added 6.50 to 1,474.50. Futures came off their highs after reports surfaced that three British vessels had been seized, and eight British sailors were arrested, after entering Iranian waters. Solid overnight gains in Japan bolstered the futures; European stock markets were also seeing moderate gains. The Nikkei Average ended up 218 points, or 1.9 percent. Germany's DAX-30 led the Continental markets, up 0.5 percent in the mid-morning as Deutsche Post looks to have got its Postbank division IPO off the ground, albeit at a lower price. M&A Deal talk was seen to be still supporting shares of telecoms equipment maker Nortel Networks NT in Germany. The stock surged some 8 percent late Friday to $4.81 on talk of a Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% partnership after confirmation that their chief executives had met in Toronto. See full story. NT was last up 23 cents, or 5.2 percent, at $4.67 in the pre-open. Cisco was 19 cents better at $23.61. The stock ended at $4.44 in regular session Friday trading. Magnum Hunter Resources MHR, -11.90% said it would buy $243 million worth of oil and gas properties in New Mexico from EnCana ECA, +4.56% subsidiary Tom Brown. In addition to the 458 wells it is purchasing, Magnum will buy about 44,000 acres of undeveloped mineral interests In London, gas group Centrica (CNA) rose 2.7 percent after confirming it was in talks to sell the Automobile Association, a car breakdown and insurance group. The unit could fetch 1.5 billion pounds ($2.7 billion). Insurer Royal & Sun Alliance RSA, -0.25% added 4.3 percent after it announced it's in talks to sell its U.K. life insurance operations, calling the discussions "early stage". The Financial Times Saturday reported a group of investors led by Resolution Life Group offered 900 million pounds ($1.6 billion) for the business. RSA said Monday that "the amounts referred to in the press are purely speculative." Citigroup C, -1.11% will reduce its 21 percent stake in Japan's third-largest brokerage Nikko Cordial to about 12 percent, the two companies said in a statement. See more Japanese telecommunications company KDDI KDDIF, +1.22% said Monday it will sell 90 percent of its wireless phone service provider DDI Pocket for 220 billion yen ($2.03 billion) to a consortium led by the U.S.' Carlyle Group and Japan's Kyocera KYO, +1.01% The new company will be 60-percent owned by private equity firm Carlyle. See story Focus stocks Shares of Taser International TASR surged $3.43, or 13 percent, to $29.20 after the stun gun maker raised its 2004 revenue outlook. The company now expects growth of 150 percent, up from prior forecasts of 100 percent growth. Revlon REV, +0.98% reduced its financial outlook for 2004, citing slower than anticipated growth in its key mass market categories in the U.S. The company now expects operating income of $90 million for the year with top-line growth of roughly 3 percent. Broker calls Citing flash memory and market share trends, J.P. Morgan Securities raised its second quarter revenue projection for Intel Corp. INTC, +5.00% to $8.2 billion, or at the upper end of Intel's own guidance. The stock tacked on 26 cents to $27.90 in Instinet. "Despite the recent mixed bag of data points on the PC industry, we believe Intel's CPU business has begun to improve as a result of market share gains combined with the release of the new Grantsdale chipset and Prescott line of microprocessors," the broker told clients. "We also believe Intel continues to experience upside due to share gains in flash memory as a result of its aggressive pricing, particularly at Nokia NOK, +0.74% " J.P. Morgan lifted its calendar 2004 revenue estimate to $34.7 billion from $34.6 billion and said it now sees earnings per share of $1.23 for the year from its earlier projection at $1.22. It left its 2005 estimates unchanged $37.6 billion in revenue and earnings per share of $1.31, citing its expectation of "risks to Intel's margins due to excess company inventory and the upcoming semiconductor downturn Contract electronics manufacturers found some support from Goldman Sachs after the sector was hit last week after a disappointing update from Jabil Circuit JBL, +1.74% The EMS stocks saw some recovery on Friday, but Goldman believe Flextronics FLEX, +0.12% "remains oversold and compelling." Results from Solectron SLR, +1.69% also last week "affirm that minor inventory corrections relate to JBL-specific programs with its largest customers," Goldman said. "For Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% high margin, high-end products with SLR appear healthy, which is more important than minor inventory correction of low-end products with JBL." title: U.S. futures higher, Wachovia deal in focus

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr lifted its revenue outlook for 2004, saying it now expects growth of 150 percent. The Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of non-lethal weapons previously forecast growth of 100 percent from its 2003 total of $24.5 million. The company described its higher outlook as "particularly significant" because "none of the orders that we had expected from International and Military sources during the first half of our year have yet materialized." The stock jumped in pre-market, rising to $28.65 on Instinet from its finish Friday at $25.77.
title: Taser boosts 2004 revenue outlook

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- It's a terror play. Fundamentals are ripe. Ride the momentum. Bloated pig. Undiscovered gem. Run while you can. Short, long, pump, dump, etc. Sound familiar? If you've clicked your way across stock message boards in the past few months, it certainly should. But this isn't Taser TASR or Magal MAGS, -6.18% It's not Mace Security MACE, +3.87% or Digital Recorders TBUS either. To some extent, the same kind of banter could be found for any one of those stocks, but the past few weeks clearly have belonged to Ipix IPIX, -4.59% A fixture on the Nasdaq's most-active list lately, the video surveillance technology company has been the favored topic for stock jockeys all over the Web. And judging by the gaudy number of posts -- Ipix had, by far, the busiest message board on Yahoo Monday -- the stock is poised to remain in focus for a while. Shares have more than doubled in the past month, with the big kicker coming when Ipix announced last week that its systems were used at the meeting of finance ministers from the world's eight largest economies. See full story. The company also said it was asked to meet with organizers of the 2004 Summer Olympics in Athens, Greece, following the G-8 summit. See full story. From there, the bulls began their charge. CostaRicaDreamer mentioned another potential catalyst: "'60 Minutes' over the weekend highlighted security problems at U.S. chemical plants -- a potential market for Ipix's products." There was yet another boost from Koy316: "This is the only stock that will double this month. Transfer of power back to the Iraqis is going to be chaos. There's going to be big demand for security." So what does that mean for the stock price? StckPckr7o offered up his lofty prediction: "Easy near 3-bagger here. Will take out recent high and run to mid-$30s to $40.What a stock! Buy all you can afford and get rich." Not rosy enough for you? Take a look at GoRedSox2004's post: "Being Long on IPIX now feels like an options holder the day before the debut of a very powerful IPO. The future points north for IPIX and then to the outer hemisphere toward the moon and beyond." The bull contagion just kept spreading. Take SorianoIsMVP: "Once they come, the run today will look like nothing as will the Taser run. The potential here is tremendous and now is the time to get in on the cheap. I don't know about you, but all the signs point to buying at these levels and holding. I want my million dollars!!" The bears, however, certainly didn't stand idly by while the bulls had all the fun. We'll end this message board romp with a sarcastic kernel courtesy of BillWalton4444: "Listen to this board closely. It's love. It's truth. Oh! The visionaries! Sit with bated breath and inhale the wisdom. (Don't mind the spelling.) Bank your children's future on it. Buy! Buy! Buy! Buy! (Just don't look at their last earnings reports. ... Don't worry! Be happy!)" Do you believe the hype or are you more inclined to side with Bill and the rest of the bashers? Share your thoughts in CBS MarketWatch's "IPIX" discussion. Visit the message boards. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Message boards turn focus to Ipix amid terror fears

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- The hardware sector led technology stocks slightly higher in early Thursday trading, ahead of a sparse earnings schedule after the bell that includes a report from storage-networking equipment maker McData. Hewlett-Packard HPQ, +1.06% shares continued to rise two days after the Dow component reported better-than-expected quarterly sales, and it remained one of the most active issues on the New York Stock Exchange. High-flying Taser TASR shares fell more than 4 percent to $28.50 in the early going, after a story on Bloomberg.com reported that a survey of the 10 largest local police departments revealed that only three -- Houston, Los Angeles and Miami -- plan to make Taser stun guns available to all members of their forces. At that, Houston has yet to find funding. The company's shares have rallied on expectations that police forces will widely deploy the weapons as gun alternatives. Chipmaker Intel's INTC, +5.00% shares rose about 1.5 percent to $27.48 as one of the Nasdaq's most active stocks. The gain comes a day after its shareholders voted in favor of expensing option grants to employees. The proposal passed with 54 percent in favor of the measure. It is nonbinding, and does not require Intel's board to act, although it must consider the change. In other Intel news, the company's shareholders learned Thursday that a $500 million patent infringement suit was filed by All Computers. The suit alleges that Intel's sales of Pentium processors and other products violate an All Computers patent on regulating high-speed input signals. The company said it contacted Intel about a license but was ignored. Other computer-makers posted gains in the early going, with Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% rising about 2 percent to $3.88, Dell Computer DELL up nearly 1 percent to $34.32 and IBM IBM, +0.60% climbing about a half-percent to $87.50 after it announced an expanded alliance with software-maker Siebel Systems SEBL McData MCDT shares rose 2 cents to $4.57 ahead of its report. Brocade, one of its main rivals, saw its shares rise 8 percent to $5.52 early Thursday after the company beat analyst expectations with help from cost cuts, and posted a slight sales increase from the previous quarter. Brocade also raised its fiscal 2004 earnings target. Ciena CIEN, +2.29% provided one of the sector's low lights, with its shares tumbling 12 percent to $3.43, after the company posted only a slightly narrower fiscal second-quarter loss, compared with the same quarter a year earlier, missing analyst expectations. Looking ahead, Ciena said it expects third-quarter revenue will increase as much as 30 percent from the second quarter. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: Hardware stocks lead tech gains

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International tasr gained 4.4 percent in pre-market after the company disclosed its receipt of four orders for its conducted energy weapons worth a total of more than $1.2 million. Three of the orders were from police departments in Florida, while the fourth was from a department in North Carolina. The stock last changed hands on the Instinet ECN at $30.58, up $1.30 from its close at $29.28.
title: Taser gains on news of 4 orders worth total of $1.2M

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International tasr rallied 97 cents, or 3.8 percent, to $26.74 after Morgan Keegan said it was encouraged by the company's "strong" April performance. Analyst Brian Ruttenbur believes the stun gun maker took in $5 million in revenue during the month, which is up from both February and March levels. He also thinks the company will increase production and inventory over the next few quarters in order to have product available for immediate shipping.
title: Taser rallies amid positive analyst comments

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Google might want to consider $2.718 or $27.18 as a good starting point for its price per share. That was a suggestion made by a reader of this column, who just like 200-plus other readers responded to the question: What's your Google bid? The obscure number is a humorous take on what Google plans to raise: $2,718,281,828, an amount recognized as a mathematically irrational number. See Net stocks: What's your Google bid? Some readers came up with per-share prices, which are meaningless without a share count. But they were humorous responses, nonetheless. From 10 cents to $230 a share, it seems Google's valuation is certainly ... uncertain. Indeed, given the negative tone across the technology sector in the last several weeks, valuations are unsettled. The good news is that technology valuation premiums are down from 100 percent. The bad news is that they're still expensive at levels of 50 percent, when historically they trade at a premium of 30 percent, according to a Merrill Lynch note Friday. This raises the question: Does Google deserve a premium valuation to the Net leaders, like Yahoo and eBay, which have been public since 1996 and 1998, respectively. Yahoo YHOO trades at 82 times this year's consensus earnings estimate of 65 cents and 60 times the '05 profit estimate. EBay EBAY, +0.32% trades at 69 times this year's consensus profit estimate and 52 times next year's. These two leading Internet companies have set the bar and the multiples that could be applied to Google, giving the five-year-old search engine valuations that rival its rivals. One analyst came up with a valuation between $29 billion and $39 billion. About 40 percent of readers said they'd short Google at that price. Then there were about 10 percent of those who wouldn't dare short such a potential rocket ship of a stock. They wouldn't dare step in front of the mad crowds trampling on one another for a piece of the Google tulip. A number of readers also wrote that they'd stay away from Google and that a valuation below $10 billion was reasonable. But one reader said he may be crazy, but he'd be interested at $25 billion. Here are a few responses: Jim Gitney: Just like Taser TASR Ask Jeeves ASKJ and a few others, these stocks and their investors are in for one hell of a surprise.  Marketing stocks nowadays is like selling a new flavor of Coca Cola.  Michael Jackson (read investment pundits) or whoever struts their stuff in front of a national audience getting [people] like me to part with a few dollars to buy it.  Then we all will get buyer's remorse, or worse yet, be forced into it when the institutions start selling the stock at the end of some near term quarter. Shelley Taylor: It is insanity fueled by those children (now defined as under 37) who think they rule the world. The problem is that they haven't had any experience in any other market. They're still seeing the world in the rose-colored glasses of the 90s, which have become even more cloudy with age. Well, it just creates good shorting opportunities for us grown-ups. At 47, I remember the market of 1974-1982. All these "kids" are missing is a bit of experience. Multiples of 1000 (give or take 500) are simply fantasy, game-boy kind of adventures. Andrew Zucker: Short it. Even at $25 billion, it's a short. Their true/new competitors have not shown their face in a big way to the public yet. I have read of a few... Healthy pressure on Google to grow will apply downward pressure on their partners like Ask Jeeves -- and ultimately cause survival threatening shifts in business strategies for all of Googles partners. Jim Budney: Seriously, I think that the Google IPO is over-hyped. Yes, in the long run, I have no doubt that the stock will perform close to what eBay has done. What we can probably all assume is that the small investors will be completely out of it, even with a Dutch auction, as huge institutional investors will just outbid everybody and set a high price for the stock. Some of my colleagues and I will just sit back and watch as the price will drop most likely for the first week and a half or so. After, I would probably start looking at buying it. What do you think about all this? James Kim: No way [regarding short Google shares], assuming it's overvalued. Just because something is overvalued now doesn't mean it couldn't continue to be overvalued for quite some time -- that's something we learned the hard way a few years ago. But being overvalued does mean that you shouldn't buy for the long-term... Ellen Chang: It is too risky either way. I will not touch Google until the dust settles... John Bresee: I don't know what Google is worth, but I know that dollar for dollar it's worth more than its competitors because it's effective. The funny thing is everyone talks about how Yahoo is the place where large companies will spend their branding dollars, and that's true, up until the time that they realize that branding campaigns have conversion rates as well. There's nothing about cost per click that is inherently unfriendly to branding, it's just not the norm. The days of the black clad Madison Avenue advertising executive who focuses on "synergies" are coming to an end. In their place will be a new wave of spread sheet driven ad execs who communicate true performance to their clients. Any company that sells advertising in a non performance oriented model will take an old fashioned beat down. Why, as a smart executive, would you spend a single dime on non performance oriented marketing before you had maximized all truly measurable performance oriented media? It makes no sense. And, slowly people are figuring it out. Rafe Resenders: My analysts prepared an analysis on Google, assuming a $25 Billion equity capitalization. Just some food for thought on the issue: Given that Google maintains its margins around 40 percent, it will need to achieve approximately 40 percent annual sales growth through 2008 to justify that valuation. If margins drop [to] Yahoo levels of approximately 28 percent it will need to achieve 59 percent annual sales growth. Such growth is obviously not impossible, but certainly not the stuff legends are made of by investing in those expectation levels Sean Kimberly: Given the metrics, you would be an idiot to buy Google at $35 billion. But given the emotion, momentum and psychology behind Google, you may be equally idiotic to short the stock. I think the best way to play Google is to avoid it all together. As it will probably be too expensive to realistically buy, but carries too much positive energy to short. If I was forced to either own it or short it, and couldn't avoid Google, I would buy it and own it as long as momentum and exuberance was pushing it higher, but would set a trailing stop loss at 10 percent and get out with any weakness. Who knows, you might get a pretty hefty bounce out of the gate and make some money. David: The earlier rumored valuations of $20 billion to $25 billion were laughable. $35 billion is something from "Fantasy Island." At $35 billion, I wouldn't short it, because I think John Q. Public has a short memory and will still go gaga over the Googster, but if I had money to burn, I'd bet on something more certain -- like Smarty Jones winning the Triple Crown, or the next Woody Allen movie outgrossing "Titanic." Vinay Patel: I would like a piece of the Google action and would be interested in investing during the IPO. From the hype that has been brought upon this company's IPO is looking like the price will be high. However the starting price will not reflect the company's true value. Eventually things will balance out. The challenge will be to not get burned during the action. I was wondering how Canadians can get in on the auction? The underwriters do not allow us to open accounts with them. John Cranston: The way I see it, there will be another "hot" search engine 2 years from now. First it was Yahoo.  Then it was Alta Vista.  Now it's Google.  Tomorrow it will be someone else, maybe Microsoft's MSFT, +2.10% MSN like you suggested.  No, I wouldn't buy Google for $35 billion. Jeffrey O: The point, of course, is that Google is worth more like $500M than $35 billion. Don't get me wrong. I use it nearly every day, along with Yahoo! and InfoSpace's INSP, -20.00% DogPile and Ask Jeeves (which, unfortunately, now uses Google). But I can't remember the last time I saw any improvement in how it works. The news article option is nice, but it doesn't display the URLs and dates of the articles. The usenet interface is out-right barbaric. The last improvement was when they added lists of group-names to make navigation a little less cumbersome. But I much prefer my old news-reader, NewsWatcher, and its successor, Thoth, which allow me to scan across a list of topics a hundred at a time, or search group names. Security on net transactions is intentionally low. If they really want me to jump on their e-commerce band-wagon they'd better start by increasing strength of encryption by at least a couple orders of magnitude. So, Froogle's out. Jim: As a contrarian, I was thrilled to read your insightful piece on Google at +10 times P/S. Working on Wall Street, I have seen every IPO scam. They take advantage of greed and ego (ex. ownership of Google at IPO prices) and then leave the investor holding the bag (look at China Life's chart the last 3 months). We call it "IPO Roadkill." Poor naive speculators (can't call them investors) that fall for this one. Bill Harts: I don't understand your theory about institutions being forced to buy other IPOs to get a piece of Google.  As I read the S-1 it appears that anyone will be able to "get" shares -- retail as well as institutional -- so long as they are willing to pay up. Because of this dynamic, I think Google will be a short on Day 1 no matter what.  The auction process will attract thousands of unsophisticated investors with access to, and influence on the pricing.  The offering price will be driven up by people thinking that this will be a traditional IPO flipping opportunity, and it won't be. Chris Sumbs: I'd likely buy into the position until it reached ridiculous overvaluation in the range of 35-40 billion.  Then, sell everything and go short the same amount I originally bought in for.  In addition, I would sell 6 mo. put options while I was riding it up and buy 6 mo. puts while riding it down.  Of course I would double dip, it would be dumb not to.  I've seen this work with great effectiveness; the only problem is determining when the company is overvalued due to the vast uncertainty of the internet behemoth's future revenue and EPS. At any rate, I'd be skeptical with the founders and major investors dumping shares when this thing IPOs, it seems like an easy way to get some major cash out of this company.  And obviously, if you want to get out of a position, you have to find someone to buy it! IPO!!!!! FindWhat talks Google FindWhat's FWHT CEO, Craig Pisaris-Henderson visited San Francisco this week to present at the Thomas Weisel Partners and JP Morgan Internet and technology conferences. He stopped by the CBS MarketWatch offices as well. Watch interview with Pisaris-Henderson. Besides touching on the company's push into the pay-per-call offering to merchants, which will be launched in the third quarter, Pisaris-Henderson had this to say about Google's IPO: "It's a huge lift," said Pisaris-Henderson. "When Google does something, the world watches. It brings that much more awareness from the advertising perspective." Bambi Francisco and Trish Regan team up for a financial fitness reality TV segment. Watch this weekend on CBS. title: Readers respond with their Google bids

content: (Corrects analyst sales forecast in fifth paragraph) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Stun-gun maker Taser reported Wednesday it had received two new orders totaling $500,000 from police departments, sending shares higher early only to give up their gains by the closing bell. After climbing as high as $34.03 in the session, shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company TASR closed at $31.78, down 2 cents. "It is exciting to gain a deployment of Taser technology by another large police department," said Tom Smith, Taser chief executive officer, in a press release. The company said it had orders from the Toledo police in Ohio and Harris County Sheriff's Office in Houston, the nation's fourth largest city. The orders -- each about $250,000 -- were for the latest X26 gun, which is 60 percent smaller and lighter than the flagship gun, the M26. Compared to the company's first-quarter, average order of about $3,000, "these are obviously very large," Smith said in an interview Wednesday afternoon. "The new orders are indicative of ongoing acceptance of Taser by police," rather than a major sales breakthrough, said Joe Blankenship, vice-president of research for Source Capital Group. Blankenship, who upgraded his rating Tuesday on Taser from "hold" to "buy," is forecasting $14.5 million in sales for the current quarter. Blankenship said the latest announcement was probably put out to combat an article in the latest Barron's that suggested the stun-gun market was nearing saturation among large police departments. Smith said the Barron's article was off base. "We have a bunch of orders, 15 or 20, this size out there that we are working on as we speak," Smith said, but declined to specify an agency or state Taser is negotiating with. The company has had to deal with recent media reports, including one by CBS News last month, that dozens of people have died while in police custody after they were shocked with Taser guns. (CBS is owned by Viacom, a significant investor in the publisher of this report.) Taser officials and police have said the deaths were a result of the suspects fighting with police or using drugs, not the guns' electrical shock. Taser stun guns use propelled wires spiked with clinging barbs to deliver a disabling shock. "In every single case the medical examiner has attributed the direct cause of death in the autopsy reports to causes other than the Taser device," Smith said in a press release, following what he called speculation by the media. Blankenship said he understood Smith's frustration, but added, "Anything, including an independent study, that would more conclusively demonstrate that these weapons are not having a lethal effect, would be helpful." Smith acknowledged there is at least one study, a Department of Defense review, under way. He didn't know when it would be complete or if the results would be made public. "Originally, (the results) were supposed to be released to the military in March," Smith said. title: Taser gets $500,000 in new orders (Correct)

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Taser International tasr said it won two orders for conducted energy weapons and accessories valued at over $500,000. The first order is from the Harris County sheriff's office in Houston, TX and the second is from the Toledo police department in Ohio. The stock closed Tuesday up 52 cents at $31.80.
title: Taser wins 2 orders valued at over $500,000

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- In Fedspeak, the open market committee all but told the world yesterday to expect an interest rate hike ahead of the presidential election in November, a move that should excite, not scare technology investors. "When the Fed raises rates, tech stocks usually do OK," says David Briggs, chief equities trader at Federated Investors in Pittsburgh. "When rates are going up, the economy is getting better, and the drivers of the economy usually benefit." To test Briggs' theory, I took a look this week at changes in the daily effective Fed funds rate dating back to the early years of Alan Greenspan's first term as Fed chief. I shouldn't be surprised that Briggs is right. Technology stocks moved higher in a 12-month period at the start of four of the five past rate-tightening cycles under Greenspan, dating back to 1988. The only time they didn't rise was when the daily effective funds rate began rose from a nadir in August 1987 -- the same month Greenspan took office. Supposedly, stocks don't do well when interest rate rise. Higher rates tend to slow down economic growth and increase the cost of doing business for all companies. Higher rates also tend to push the possibility of dividend payouts farther into the future, which spells trouble for investors who buy stocks based on their discounted stream of cash flows and dividends. In addition, there's a fear among some on Wall Street that rising rates could trigger the insolvency of one or more overleveraged financial institutions -- something that has happened during other rate-tightening cycles. If that happens, it could lead to an expensive financial bailout and another costly hit to shareholder confidence that could send tech stocks tumbling. "Wall Street is concerned that there are hedge funds out there that are addicted to tremendous short-term borrowing, that rising rates will trigger a financial burnout, and that there could be a spillover effect with counter-party risks spread among several firms," says Janes T. Swanson, chief investment strategist for MFS Investment Management, who oversees $142 billion in assets. Yet most economists say most investor fears about rates are overblown. For example, if Wall Street is really concerned about the meltdown of a financial firm or two, that risk is likely factored in to current stock prices. One reason tech stocks may do well in periods of rising rates is that most publicly traded technology companies have no debt. They don't' have to anything to finance with the higher rates. And while their customers certainly finance equipment, a few quarter-point increases won't be enough to put the brakes on demand for computers, chips, software and networking gear. Meanwhile, there are signs in the gross domestic product figures and in corporate earnings reports that spending in the corporate sector is finally starting to improve -- one more reason the Fed feels comfortable in raising rates. Briggs says some stocks are overvalued, such as high-flying stun-gun maker and media darling Taser TASR which trades at more than 60 times earnings. Yet he says there are a few good ones that are worth their price. His firm recently bought up more of chip equipment-maker Applied Materials' AMAT, +2.87% shares, and he says he likes LAM Research LRCX, +3.54% Value plays are out there, too. Nokia NOK, +0.74% which owns about a third of the worldwide cell phone market, is starting to draw the attention of several large hedge fund managers. Even though the company reported a lackluster first-quarter in which it lost market share and guided below analyst expectations for the first quarter, a turnaround is possible later this year, as the company rolls out new flip phones, recently a more popular option than the candy-bar-size phone designs. Nokia sure seems cheap. It's still generating cash, trades at about 14 times 2005 earnings estimates, is down 38 percent from its March peak, has about $2.50 a share in cash on the book. Plus, it has a 2.5 percent dividend yield, points out Al Davis, analyst with McAdams Wright Ragen, so shareholders get paid even if a turnaround takes a while. Technology shareholders should quit fretting and remember why there's pressure to raise rates. It's because things are looking up. Rising demand for credit reflects an expanding economy and increased purchases of technology goods and services. A small hike or two is in order, considering that the key funds rate remains at a 46-year low. That's hardly enough to derail the economy or the technology stock market.
