title: Rate hike won't cripple tech stocks

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stock futures set hopes for a bounce-back on Monday on hopes that the technology sector will reverse a recent slide. A reading on the manufacturing sector in April will highlight Monday's economic releases, as investors gauge the pace of industrial sector expansion. June S&P futures rose 2.50 to 1,108.60 and Nasdaq 100 futures tacked on 5.50 to 1,408.50. The technology burdened Nasdaq 100 Index $NDX had lost 96 points, or 6.4 percent amid a five session losing streak. Among some high-tech heavyweights seeing early action, Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% added 7 cents to $26.20, Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% gained 23 cents to $21.14 and Intel INTC, +5.00% was 17 cents better at $25.90. Markets were already positioning themselves ahead of Federal Reserve's interest rate policy meeting Tuesday (read more) and the closely-watched payrolls report coming on Friday. Chip stocks may move as the Semiconductors Industry Association said the three-month-rolling average sales for March increased 32.3 percent to $16.3 billion. Applied Materials AMAT, +2.87% added 13 cents to $18.40, Novellus Systems NVLS rose 18 cents to $29.12 and ASML ASML, +2.07% was up 34 cents at $15.91. Memory chip maker Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% rose 2.3 percent in Frankfurt. Meanwhile, KLA-Tencor KLAC, +2.29% slipped 40 cents to $41.30 after the company said late Friday that its president, Gary Dickerson, resigned to take a personal leave of absence. J.P. Morgan said the SIA results were better than expected and hiked its 2004 semiconductor sales forecast from a 22 percent rise year-on-year to a 27 percent gain, though it remains neutral on the semiconductor sector. Merrill Lynch added that the first quarter started off slightly below seasonal trend but ended strongly. "The seasonal strength in the first quarter underpins our forecast that the industry may grow as much as 30-33 percent in 2004. We plan to revisit that shortly," the broker said. Also in technology, publishing software firm Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% shot up $1.99, or 4.8 percent, to $43.49 after the company said it expected to exceed prior fiscal second-quarter financial targets due to greater-than-anticipated revenue for its Creative Suite and CS products and its Acrobat product line. Among other stocks on the move, stun gun maker Taser International TASR fell 95 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $31.40. The company responded Monday to a report in Barron's over the weekend which questioned the stock's valuation by saying a forward price-to-earnings ratio of more than 50 is appropriate for a rapidly growing company. Elsewhere, Pfizer PFE, +0.54% edged ticked up 18 cents to $35.94 after Chairman Hank McKinnell told the Financial Times that the drug giant will acquire more biotechnology companies to fill out its pipeline amid having several drugs nearing patent expirations. German and French stocks were shedding early losses, with volumes thin amid U.K. and Tokyo markets being shut for holidays. More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh Related Topics Futures Commodities Markets Commodity Futures Trading Commission
title: U.S. stocks set to gain amid tech strength

content: Pre-Open Stocks action Hopes for chip stock gains pushed futures higher on Monday as encouraging Semiconductors Industry Association data set expectations for a halt to the five-day tech slide. Investors were also positioning portfolios ahead of an interest rate decision from the FOMC and jobs data later in the week. See Indications for full pre-open action Global Markets European stocks narrowed morning losses on the back of tech stock hopes, with memory chip maker Infineon Technologies IFX, -8.16% advancing 2.3 percent. But volumes were thin due to holidays in London and Tokyo. See European Markets Broker action Dow Chemical DOW, -0.77% was upgraded by UBS to "buy" from "neutral" and its price target upped to $47 from $42, on hopes for ethylene demand. See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments Breaking News - See Market Pulse for breaking news Adobe Systems ADBE, +1.67% said it expects to exceed its previously disclosed targets for the second quarter due to greater than anticipated revenue for its Creative Suite and CS products and its Acrobat product line. The San Jose, Calif., publishing software firm now sees earnings of 39 to 44 cents per share on revenue of between $390 million and $410 million for the quarter. It had been looking for a profit of 33 to 39 cents per share on revenue of between $365 million and $385 million in the period. ImClone Systems IMCL, +6.11% said it plans to sell $400 million worth of convertible senior notes due 2024. The New York-based biotechnology firm plans to use the proceeds of the offering for working capital and general corporate purposes. The interest and conversion terms of the notes have yet to be determined. The stock closed Friday at $66.88, down 2.6 percent. El Paso EP, +0.00% said "certain employees used aggressive and at times unsupportable methods to book proved reserves," after the company launched an independent audit. The audit came after El Paso announced on Feb. 17 that its proved oil and natural gas reserves were being revised lower by approximately 1.8 trillion cubic feet of natural gas equivalent. Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% said it won an $888 million, 6-year contract from the U.S. Air Force to develop and integrate the Multi-Platform Radar Technology Insertion Program (MP-RTIP), which helps track and identify stationary and moving vehicles and cruise missiles. InterActiveCorp IACI, +0.00% reported first-quarter net income of $38 million, or 5 cents a share, vs. a loss of 23 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding special items, earnings rose to 18 cents a share from 16 cents a share, and exceeded the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call of 16 cents. Revenue rose 23 percent to $1.5 billion, topping analyst expectations of $1.44 billion, boosted by 41 percent growth in its travel business, 11 percent growth in electronic retailing and a 282 percent rise in local and media services. The interactive commerce company reaffirmed its 2004 operating income outlook. Taser International TASR on Monday said a forward price-to-earnings ratio of more than 50 is appropriate for a rapidly growing company, in response to a critical article in influential magazine Barron's that said the stock is not worth $22, yet alone its Friday close of $32.35. In an open letter to Barron's, the company said it had significant room to grow. Shares in the volatile Taser have been hit 45 percent since publishing first quarter results on April 20 and having its top institutional shareholder sell out its remaining share. A U.S. District Court has ruled in favor of Mykrolis MYK, -7.30% in its patent suit against Pall Corp. PLL, -6.21% and has ordered Pall to stop making and selling its PhotoKleen EZD-2 filter assembly products. The court ruling relates to Mykrolis' claims that Pall infringed on its patents covering chip making technology . Mykrolis shares closed Friday up 12 cents at $14.55 and Pall rose 28 cents to $23.78. Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free email service here. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets N.Y. Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Chip stocks, Northrop Grumman, Dow Chemical

content: LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr on Monday said a forward price-to-earnings ratio of more than 50 is appropriate for a rapidly growing company, in response to a critical article in influential magazine Barron's that said the stock is not worth $22, yet alone its Friday close of $32.35. "Our forward looking growth prospects greatly benefit from the fact that almost 25 percent of agencies have initiated a TASER program, yet only 6.2 percent of individual police and corrections officers have a TASER conducted energy weapon today. Further, our market penetration with the new TASER X26 is at less than 2 percent of the individual officer market in the United States... I think most people would agree this leaves us significant room to grow," said CEO Rick Smith and President Tom Smith in an open letter. Shares in the volatile Taser have been hit 45 percent since publishing first quarter results on April 20 and having its top institutional shareholder sell out its remaining share.
title: Stun gun maker Taser decries Barron's criticism

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- With the market awaiting Friday's jobs report, earnings take a back saddle. Churchill Downs CHDN, +0.83% fresh off Saturday's Kentucky Derby, reports on Tuesday, as do Hecla Mining HL, +1.94% Spider-Man licenser Marvel Enterprises MVL, +1.31% defense giant Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% Qwest Communications Q, +0.00% grocer Safeway SWY, +1.82% and conglomerate Tyco International TYC, +74.50% Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia closes the week's number Friday. More energy companies will also report. See Earnings Outlook. On Sunday, Anheuser-Busch BUD, +0.28% said it bought a one-third stake in Harbin Brewery Group, the fourth biggest beer maker in China. The American firm already owns a 10 percent interest in Tsingtao, the leading Chinese brewer. Late Friday, Amgen AMGN, +0.01% and Wyeth Pharmaceuticals, a unit of drugmaker Wyeth WYE said their Enbrel medicine had been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for treatment of psoriasis, a skin disease that afflicts about 4.5 million people in the U.S. The companies said it is the fifth disease for which Enbrel has received approval. Biopure BPUR a drugmaker, said late Friday that four more of its officials received Wells notices of possible civil charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission.. Nonexecutive Chairman Charles Sanders, former board member J. Richard Crout, Chief Technology Officer and board member Carl Rausch, and Jane Kober, the firm's general counsel, received notices. The FDA served the company, its then-CEO, Thomas Moore, and a senior vice president with similar notices in late December. Moore resigned weeks later. Bloomingdale's, the department store chain held by Federated Department Stores FD said late Friday that it reached a tentative accord with a retail clerks union at its flagship store in New York. CNA Financial CNA, -0.96% an insurance holding company, said late Friday that it completed the $700 million sale of a life insurance and annuity division to privately held Swiss Re. CNF CNF, -39.53% a transportation and shipping company, said late Friday that it will redeem about $129 million of a subsidiary's convertible debentures. The division, CNF Trust I, will then redeem all 2.5 million of convertible securities known as TECONs as of May 28. The TECONs can be converted to CNF shares at $40 per security until that date; CNF shares closed Friday at $36.56. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% the soft-drink giant, is close to choosing a new chief executive, board member Warren Buffett told Reuters on Saturday at the annual meeting of his company, Berkshire Hathaway. Coke's Chairman and Chief Executive Donald Daft is retiring and the extended search for a replacement has raised concerns, especially since Gillette's top executive turned down the post recently. Donaldson DCI, +3.07% a maker of filtration systems, said late Friday that it sold its factory in Stow, Ohio, to privately held Fall Filtration Technology. Terms were not disclosed, though Donaldson said the plant had annual revenue of about $5 million. Donaldson said there would be no material change in its quarterly or 2004 results. EchoStar DISH, +1.20% the No. 2 satellite television company, said early Saturday that it reached an agreement to carry the Turner Broadcasting cable TV channels such as CNN, Turner Classic Movies and the Cartoon Network. Turner is owned by Time Warner TWX, +0.40% In an earlier hardball contract dispute with Viacom, EchoStar dropped that company's channels, including CBS affiliates, before reaching an accord. (Viacom is a significant shareholder in the publisher of this report.) Empire District Electric Co. EDE, -1.33% a Missouri utility, said late Friday that it filed for a rate increase that would bring in $38 million more a year if approved. Essex KEYW, -0.13% which makes defense products, said late Friday that it completed the acquisition of Computer Science Innovations, a computer engineering company with $7.5 million in annual revenue. Other terms were not disclosed. Fleetwood Enterprises FLE, +0.00% a maker of recreational vehicles, said late Friday that virtually all convertible preferred securities involved in a $150 million call were converted to common stock. About 14.5 million shares were issued. Fleetwood said that in previous earnings statements the underlying shares of the affected convertible securities were included in diluted EPS calculations. GTech Holdings GTK, +2.17% a maker of lottery equipment, said late Friday that it had a contract in Mexico revoked after a losing bidder complained. Separately, the company said late Friday that it completed its $150 million cash purchase of Spielo Manufacturing, which makes video lottery terminals. A $35 million maximum of performance benchmarks are also part of the purchase, with the first standard achieved, followed by a $7 million payment. GTech said it expects the acquisition to add $90 million to $100 million in revenue and 1 to 2 cents per share in earnings for the first year. Starting in the second quarter of 2005, GTech forecast $70 million to $75 million of revenue. Hain Celestial HAIN, +0.69% which makes health foods and snacks, said late Friday that it will miss its fiscal third-quarter target for operating income by $5 million to $7 million. Higher shipping costs and commodity prices were blamed. Hain also said it will raise its U.S. prices by 4 percent to 5 percent starting in July. Hain also said it has a new credit agreement, increasing its credit line by $60 million. Hanmi Financial HAFC, +0.16% a holding company for Hanmi Bank, said late Friday that it completed its $164.5 million purchase of Pacific Union Bank, creating what it called the largest Korean American community bank in the U.S. with assets exceeding $3 billion. Liberte Investors LBI, +0.00% a former mortgage lender, said late Friday that it completed a $50 million rights offering that sold shares to existing holders. The company said it completed the purchase of USAuto Holdings and will change its name to First Acceptance Corporation and its ticker symbol will become "FAC" FAC, -2.67% effective Monday. Louisiana-Pacific LPX, +1.27% a lumber and paper manufacturer, said late Friday that a Minnesota court ruling after it released first-quarter results will result in an accounting revision that trims 3 cents a share from previously reported first-quarter results. Northwest Bancorp's NWSB parent firm, a Pennsylvania bank group, said late Friday that it completed the purchase of Skibo Financial SKBO for $17 in cash per share. Onyx Acceptance ONYX an auto loan financer, said late Friday that its board approved a buyback of up to $5 million of its common stock. Provident Bankshares PBKS a Maryland-based bank holding company, said late Friday that it completed its acquisition of Southern Financial Bank SFFB paying 1.0875 of its shares and $11.125 in cash for each Southern share. Raytheon RTN, +2.26% a major defense contractor, said late Friday that it won a $232.7 million U.S. Navy contract for 368 missiles that defend against anti-ship missiles. RELM Wireless RELM, +0.00% which makes two-way radios, said late Friday that its stock price triggered a condition of warrants that were issued in a March 2002 offering. The nearly 3 million warrants will be redeemed for 10 cents apiece on May 31, though holders can exercise them at $1.05 a share until then; shares closed Friday at $2.60. Research Frontiers REFR, +1.88% a developer of glass and plastic processes, said late Friday that it will write off $209,000 of its investment in SPD, a South Korean division of Hankuk Glass Industries. The company had already taken a $615,200 charge for the rest of its stake in the glass company. Road ARDI which develops mobile phone technologies, said late Friday that its chief financial officer, Tom Hoster, has left to join a private company that is planning an IPO. He will be replaced by Carol Rice-Murphy, presently Road's controller, until a new CFO can be hired. Samsonite SAMC the luggage maker, said late Friday that it is offering to purchase about $322 million of its 10 3/4 notes due in 2008. The price would be $1,022.33 per $1,000 of principal, with a May 13 expiration for the offer. To receive enough tenders to pass an indentured threshold, the company will pay an extra $20 per $1,000 of principal until the minimum level is reached. Samsonite said it intends to finance the repurchase using proceeds of a $325 million private note placement. SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% the regional phone company that's a Dow component, said late Friday that its chief financial officer, Randall Stephenson, will move up to chief operating officer. Rick Lindner, the CFO at wireless company Cingular, which is 60 percent-owned by SBC, will replace Stephenson. Sonic SONC, -0.04% which runs a chain of fast-food restaurants, said late Friday that its board approved a 3-for-2 stock split for holders as of May 10. The extra share will be paid in the form of a dividend on May 21. Shares will rise from about 39.7 million to 59.6 million, Sonic said. Taser TASR the stun-gun manufacturer, takes another shot from Barron's Sizing Up Small Caps column. Shares have fallen back recently after a fivefold rise since the start of the year. The column follows up on its previous criticism in February, questioning sales potential in the U.S. and overseas, and noting a stratospheric multiple to earnings, both trailing and forward looking. Shares closed at $32.35 Friday, yet the column says it doubts they are worth $22. Tenneco Automotive TEN, +2.91% which designs and makes auto parts, said late Friday that it made a tender offer for $500 million of 11 5/8 percent notes due 2009. The offer expires on May 27, with tenders by that date receiving $1,095.50 per $1,000 of principal. Notes tendered after that date will receive $30 less. Tenneco said the tender offer is part of a plan announced April 16 to cut its interest expense. Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts DJT, +2.05% nominally run by media personality Donald Trump, reported a widening first-quarter net loss late Friday. The company, which faces pressure to restructure its debt or be seized, said its loss was $48.8 million, or $1.63 a share, vs. a loss of $24 million, or $1.09, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue fell from $293.7 million to $290.7 million. Excluding items, income from operations rose slightly to $27.8 million from $27.3 million in the 2003 period. Trump, which had been on the earnings calendar for a Monday report, disclosed in early April that its auditor, Ernst & Young, expressed doubts about the company's ability to continue as a going concern unless it completes a proposed $400 million recapitalization deal with Credit Suisse First Boston. See full story. Universal Technical Institute UTI, +1.73% a vocational school, said late Friday that it completed a secondary offering by selling shareholders of about 6.3 million shares, including an overallotment. The company did not gain any proceeds of the sale. Vodafone Group VOD, +0.54% the wireless phone company based in the United Kingdom, should have several healthy years ahead, says Barron's. A bid for AT&T Wireless soured some investors on the company, and its Japanese division performed poorly in 2003. Yet Barron's says there are expectations for a raised dividend and stock buybacks when the company reports on results May 25. Shares could gain 20 to 40 percent over the next two years, in Barron's estimation. Zale ZLC, +0.65% the jewelry retailer, has its chain pulled by Alan Abelson's column in Barron's. Passing along short-seller Doug Kass' observations, Abelson notes that Amazon.com is starting to sell jewelry at the low end and that Kass has bet Zale's stock will ultimately drop. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Amgen, Wyeth, Hain Celestial

Tenneco Automotive TEN, +2.91% which designs and makes auto parts, said late Friday that it made a tender offer for $500 million of 11 5/8 percent notes due 2009. The offer expires on May 27, with tenders by that date receiving $1,095.50 per $1,000 of principal. Notes tendered after that date will receive $30 less. Tenneco said the tender offer is part of a plan announced April 16 to cut its interest expense. Trump Hotels & Casino Resorts DJT, +2.05% nominally run by media personality Donald Trump, reported a widening first-quarter net loss late Friday. The company, which faces pressure to restructure its debt or be seized, said its loss was $48.8 million, or $1.63 a share, vs. a loss of $24 million, or $1.09, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue fell from $293.7 million to $290.7 million. Excluding items, income from operations rose slightly to $27.8 million from $27.3 million in the 2003 period. Trump, which had been on the earnings calendar for a Monday report, disclosed in early April that its auditor, Ernst & Young, expressed doubts about the company's ability to continue as a going concern unless it completes a proposed $400 million recapitalization deal with Credit Suisse First Boston. See full story. Universal Technical Institute UTI, +1.73% a vocational school, said late Friday that it completed a secondary offering by selling shareholders of about 6.3 million shares, including an overallotment. The company did not gain any proceeds of the sale. Vodafone Group VOD, +0.54% the wireless phone company based in the United Kingdom, should have several healthy years ahead, says Barron's. A bid for AT&T Wireless soured some investors on the company, and its Japanese division performed poorly in 2003. Yet Barron's says there are expectations for a raised dividend and stock buybacks when the company reports on results May 25. Shares could gain 20 to 40 percent over the next two years, in Barron's estimation. Zale ZLC, +0.65% the jewelry retailer, has its chain pulled by Alan Abelson's column in Barron's. Passing along short-seller Doug Kass' observations, Abelson notes that Amazon.com is starting to sell jewelry at the low end and that Kass has bet Zale's stock will ultimately drop. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trade in Friday's session is Anadarko Petroleum APC, +2.56% The oil and gas producer is expected to report earnings of $1.42 a share for the first quarter, according to analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Agricultural products company Archer Daniels Midland ADM, +1.33% is seen posting a fiscal third-quarter profit of 27 cents a share. Biogen Idec BIIB, +0.74% which develops cancer therapies, is expected to report earnings of 34 cents a share for the first quarter. Insurer Cigna CI, -0.34% is expected to post a first-quarter per-share profit of $1.84. First-quarter numbers at ChevronTexaco CVX, +1.73% are seen showing earnings of $2.02 a share. CV Therapeutics CVTX is expected to report a first-quarter loss of $1.25 a share. Fiscal third-quarter results are due out from Procter & Gamble PG, +0.56% in which the consumer products company is seen reporting a profit of $1.08 a share. Washington Post Co. WPO is expected to report earnings of $5.91 a share for the first quarter. Winn-Dixie Stores WIN, -2.08% is seen posting a fiscal third-quarter loss of 9 cents a share. Personal-computer and consumer-electronics company Gateway GTW reported a first-quarter net loss late Thursday that narrowed from a year earlier and said it intends to cut about 1,500 more jobs by the end of the year. Poway, Calif.-based Gateway lost $166 million or 49 cents a share, on $868 million in revenue, compared to $200 million, or 62 cents a share, on $844 million in revenue in the same quarter a year earlier. See full story. In after-hours trading, Gateway shares were unchanged at $15.31 after giving up 14 cents in the regular market session. Business Objects BOBJ a maker of business intelligence software used to mine corporate data, missed analysts' earnings expectations and scaled back its second-quarter income target. Business Objects, based in San Jose, Calif., and Paris, posted first-quarter net income of $3.26 million, or 4 cents a share, down 63 percent from $8.81 million in the same quarter last year. See full story. Business Objects shares fell $2.33 to $26.25 in after-hours trading. The stock had risen $1.17 to close at $28.58, ahead of the announcement. Foundry Networks FDRY posted first-quarter results and a second-quarter forecast below analyst' expectations. The networking equipment maker said it made $19.9 million, or 14 cents a share, on sales of $104 million in the first quarter. That compared with earnings $13.4 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $91.1 million the year before. See full story. Foundry shares lost 6.8 percent to end the regular session at $14.15 ahead of the announcement. The stock fell to $10.15 after the bell, down $4. Electronic Arts ERTS boosted fourth-quarter earnings nearly tenfold, as the company said that it benefited from a lower effective tax rate and raised its fiscal fourth-quarter sales 29 percent. The Redwood City, Calif.-based maker of video games posted net income of $90 million, or 29 cents a share, up from $9.2 million, or 3 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was $598 million, up 29 percent from $463 million a year earlier. See full story. Electronic Arts shares rose 70 cents in after-hours trading to $50.65, up from its closing price of $49.95 a share. Shares fell 86 cents in regular-session Nasdaq trading, ahead of the announcement. LookSmart LOOK, -1.02% swung to a loss for the first quarter but managed to beat analyst estimates. LookSmart reported a net loss of $7.1 million, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter ended March 31. A year ago, the company reported net income of $1.1 million, or a penny a share. Revenue for the San Francisco-based Web search company was $27.6 million vs. $29.4 million for the year-ago period. See full story. The company's shares closed Thursday at $2.44, up 8 cents. The NASDAQ Stock Market NDAQ, +3.27% said that its first quarter income available to shareholders was flat despite strong trading volume in January and lower operating costs. Net income applicable to common shareholders was $1.8 million or 2 cents per share in the first quarter of 2004 versus $1.9 million, or 2 cents per share a year ago. First quarter revenue fell 21 percent to $128.4 million from $162.4 million a year ago. Drug distributor McKesson MCK, +0.15% said that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter rose 20 percent from a year earlier but warned that its fiscal 2005 outlook is being negatively impacted by litigation and other factors. San Francisco-based McKesson said its profit was $214.2 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $179 million, or 61 cents, in the year-ago period. The 73-cent figure topped by 8 cents the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 21 percent to $17.94 million, versus the average forecast of $12.3 million. See full story. The stock closed at $30.09, down 15 cents, ahead of the news. Technology-products distributor Ingram Micro IM, +0.23% said first-quarter profits tripled from a year ago due to increased demand for information-technology equipment. Ingram Micro posted net income of $37.6 million, or 24 cents a share, compared to $10.1 million, or 7 cents a share a year ago. Excluding one-time charges, the company earned $23.2 million, or 15 cents a share. Revenue increased to $6.28 billion from $5.47 billion during the same period a year ago. See full story. MCI MCIAV the telecom company formerly known as WorldCom, reduced its financial forecast, citing weak prices and stiff competition within the industry. MCI disclosed that 2004 revenue will be near the low end of its prior target -- $21 billion to $22 billion. And while the company said it still expects to generate profits in the second half of 2004, MCI will report a net loss for the full year. See full story. Huffy HUF, +0.00% said it has hired Lazard Freres & Co. for advice on financing and strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company or product segments within it. The sporting goods company also warned it would not return to profitability until 2005, citing higher-than-expected restructuring and reorganization costs. Huffy said it has reached an agreement in principle with its lenders' agent for increased liquidity and a modification of its loan covenants to allow for a possible sale of the company or its segments. Finally, Huffy said it was considering reducing the carrying value of certain intangible assets and deferred tax assets, which would negatively impact its first-quarter earnings per share. Huffy stock closed up 2 cents at $2.45 ahead of the announcement. Cablevision Systems CVC, -0.36% announced a new structure for the spin-off of its satellite, programming and movie theater businesses. Under the terms the cable operator has now outlined, Rainbow Media Enterprises will be comprised of three divisions: Rainbow DBS, the satellite entity; Rainbow Programming, which includes AMC, the Independent Film Channel and other networks; and Rainbow Movies, which includes the movie theaters. Cablevision Chairman Charles Dolan will also take on the role of Rainbow Media Enterprises chairman after the spin-off, while Thomas Dolan has been named chief executive of Rainbow Enterprises. Cablevision shares fell 11 cents to close at $21.88 ahead of the news. Riggs National RIGS, +0.57% said that it is exiting or selling most of the international banking business that triggered a U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission probe of possible violations of post-Sept. 11 money-laundering laws. See full story. Shares of Riggs ended Thursday's session up 4.8 percent at $16.05 ahead of the announcement. Restructuring costs prompted Eastman Chemical EMN, +1.34% to report a loss for its first-quarter. The Kingsport, Tenn., maker of chemicals, fibers and plastics said it lost $6 million, or 7 cents per share. A year ago, it earned $21 million, or 27 cents per share. See full story. Ahead of the news Thursday, the stock closed at $42.26, down 45 cents. International Rectifier IRF, +125.00% announced sharply higher fiscal third-quarter earnings that topped analysts' forecasts due to strong demand for analog microchips. For the quarter ended on March 31, International Rectifier reported net income of $26.7 million, or 39 cents a share, and sales of $275.4 million. During the same quarter last year, the chipmaker earned $7.5 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $214.4 million. See full story. Its shares were not active in late trading Thursday after ending the regular session down 5.2 percent to $39.94. So far this year, shares are down almost 20 percent. InterMune ITMN pulled its 2004 revenue forecast and its revenue forecast for its drug Actimmune, citing "changing market dynamics." The biopharmaceutical company said the patient referral rate in the first quarter came in significantly lower than expected, though average duration of therapy was higher than expected. InterMune said it was too early to determine the net effect of those two factors and as a result, was removing the 2004 Actimmune forecast of $130 million to $155 million provided in late January, as well as the total revenue forecast of $150 million to $180 million. The company expects to provide guidance when it reports second-quarter results. InterMune shares fell to $15 after the bell, down $3.01. Varian Semiconductor Equipment VSEA boosted its fiscal second-quarter financial results and predicted growth for the third quarter as demand for its chip-manufacturing equipment remains strong. For the quarter ended Apr. 2, Varian reported net income of $14 million, or 38 cents a share, and sales of $127.3 million. During the same quarter last year, Varian earned $5.5 million, or 16 cents a share, on revenue of $111.2 million. See full story. Investors knocked Varian's shares down 6 percent in late trading to $32.25. This drop followed a 6.1 percent plunge in the regular session to $34.38. American Power Conversion APCC posted a first-quarter profit that missed analysts' expectations. The maker of power protection systems said it made $34.7 million, or 17 cents a share, on sales of $351.8 million vs. $30 million, or 15 cents a share, on sales of $309 million the year before. Analysts' average per-share forecast was for 19 cents a share on sales of $352.9 million, according to Thomson First Call. Shares of American Power fell to $20.85 after the bell, down $2.34. Alliance Capital Management Holding AC, +3.74% reported higher first-quarter earnings, but the mutual fund giant continued to lose shareholder assets. New York-based Alliance said first-quarter net income rose 57 percent to 58 cents per unit from 37 cents in the year-ago period, while net income rose to $168 million from $109 million. See full story. Alliance announced results after the closing bell. In trading Thursday, shares lost 64 cents to $33.96. Ford Motor F, +2.03% said it has settled with attorneys for two sisters who died during a 2002 rollover accident involving their 1999 Ford F-150 pickup truck, according to lawyers for victims' families. The terms of the settlement were not released. The plaintiffs alleged that the truck's door latches were defective and opened during the accident, contributing to the death of the sisters. Genesis Microchip GNSS said it swung to a fourth-quarter loss and issued a first-quarter revenue forecast below analyst expectations. The display image processors supplier reported a loss of $1.9 million, or 6 cents a share, on sales of $54.9 million, vs. a profit of $1 million, or 3 cents a share, on sales of $54.8 million. The company said it expects to post sales of $52 million to $56 million for the first-quarter period vs. analysts' average forecast of $58 million, according to Thomson First Call. Genesis Microchip also said it expects gross profit margins to be 38 percent to 40 percent. Genesis Microchip shares fell to $14.85 after the bell, down $2.31. Intersections INTX, -6.32% priced its initial public offering of 6.25 million shares at $17 each late Thursday, for proceeds of $106.25 million. The Chantilly, Va.-based provider of identity theft protection priced the IPO at the high end of its $15-$17 range. Intersections is offering 3 million shares and a selling stockholder, which is a subsidiary of Equifax (EFX), is offering an additional 3.25 million shares. Underwriter Deutsche Banc Alex Brown led the deal. Shares of Intersections, whose clients include credit and charge card issuing financial institutions, are due to start trading Friday on Nasdaq. Guess GES, -0.81% swung to a profit of $756,000, or 2 cents a share, from a loss of $5.7 million, or 13 cents a share, a year ago. Sales of the apparel and accessories maker climbed 9.9 percent to $139.6 million with retail stores ringing up $99.5 million, a 19 percent jump over last year's $83.7 million. Sales at stores open longer than a year vaulted 12.8 percent. The results were better than the average 4 cents a share loss projected by analysts reporting to Thomson First Call. Shares of Guess ended the session at $15.93, falling 91 cents, or 5.4 percent ahead of the release. Finisar FNSR, +4.84% agreed to buy Infineon Technologies' IFX, -8.16% fiber optics unit for $263 million in Finisar stock. The deal will provide Infineon, a maker of memory chips, with a 38 percent equity stake in Finisar, a maker of fiber optic subsystems and network test systems. Thursday's advancers Aldila's ALDA, +233.33% shares rose almost 45 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 46 cents per share, up from a loss of $169,000, or 3 cents a share, last year. Sales rose 51 percent to $15.3 million in the March period from $10.2 million last year. In a report filed Wednesday after the market closed, the Poway, Calif.-based manufacturer of sporting goods attributed the strong sales increase to "overwhelming acceptance" of its flagship NV brand wood shafts for golf clubs, which offset a "relatively slow" performance by its hockey products business. CenturyTel CTL, +1.36% shares gained nearly 8 percent after the company said it earned $83.3 million, or 58 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $80.7 million, or 56 cents, a year earlier. That beat the 53-cent consensus estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue climbed 2.7 percent to $593.7 million, in line with expectations. Looking ahead, CenturyTel predicted second-quarter revenue of $590 to $605 million and earnings per share of 52 cents to 56 cents. For the full year, earnings per share are expected to range from $2.20 to $2.35, an increase of 15 cents over the company's prior estimate. CenturyTel cited stronger sales, lower costs and fewer shares outstanding for the higher forecast. Cepheid CPHD shares lost more than 22 percent after the company said that the U.S. Postal Service has issued a press release saying that further deployment of Cepheid's Biohazard Detection System product is being temporarily delayed. The delay comes after a number of sorting lines began to see an increase in the number of tests coming up as non-determinant. "It is not unexpected that a new program may run into unique issues during initial deployment," Cepheid CEO John Bishop said in a statement. "What is important is to maintain an objective and scientifically valid analysis of issues as they arise in order to minimize or eliminate further issues as deployment proceeds." The company said it's working with Northrop Grumman and the postal service to address the issue. Coca-Cola Enterprises' CCE, +0.56% shares added almost 7 percent after UBS raised its rating on the stock to "buy" from "neutral" following a strong quarterly financial report. The firm also raised its earnings estimate of 2004 to $1.70 per share from $1.46 per share, and lifted its price target for the stock to $32 from $26. Gillette G, +1.27% shares rose nearly 6 percent after the company said it earned $376 million, or 37 cents a share, in the first quarter, up 43 percent from $263 million, or 25 cents a share, a year ago, boosted by strong sales, favorable currency developments and cost cuts. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 29 cents a share. Sales grew 13 percent to $2.24 billion from $1.97 billion and were strongest in Latin America, Russia, Turkey and Eastern Europe. The maker of razors and shaving products, oral care products and Duracell batteries, said it expects continued growth in the second quarter, driven by its M3Power premium wet shaving system and new oral care products. Gillette also unveiled a CEO succession plan. Shares of Immune Response IMNR soared almost 24 percent after the company reported "strong" phase I/II study results for NeuroVax, its investigation T-cell receptor peptide vaccine. The company said the vaccine "produced a peptide-specific immune response in 94 percent of the patients treated" in the multiple sclerosis trial. Immune Response plans to continue research to determine if the response to NeuroVax correlates with "a clinically relevant impact on disease progression." InfoSpace INSP, -20.00% shares slumped more than 13 percent after the Bellevue, Wash., Web search services firm posted first-quarter earnings from continuing operations of $5.4 million, or 15 cents per share, missing Wall Street's consensus view by a penny. See full story. Kroll KROL shares rose almost 7 percent after the company posted first quarter net income of $14.7 million, or 35 cents a share compared with $11.3 million, or 28 cents a share in the first quarter of 2003. Sales jumped nearly 60 percent to $165.3 million from $103.5 million. The Thomson First Call mean estimate was for earnings of 30 cents a share. The global risk consulting company lifted its 2004 financial outlook, saying it now expects to earn in the range of $1.54 to $1.58 a share versus a previous forecast of $1.49 to $1.53 a share. Macromedia MACR, +0.00% shares added more than 13 percent after the company said that it doubled net income from a year earlier on higher sales of its online media publishing products. The San Francisco-based software company posted fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $14.7 million, or 20 cents a share, up from $6.9 million, or 11 cents a share, in the same period last year. See full story. MIM Corporation MIMS advanced more than 6 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $2.2 million, or 10 cents per share, compared to $3.4 million, or 15 cents per share, last year. The average analyst estimate as polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 10 cents per share in the March period. Revenue fell in the latest three months to $148.1 million from $162.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The company noted that the year-ago results included revenue from its TennCare PBM services contract with Tennessee, which ended on July 1, and its distribution of the Synagis product, which ceased in the third quarter. OneSource Information ONES shares rose nearly 7 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by infoUSA IUSA, +1.50% for $8.85 per share in cash. The all-cash tender offer represents a premium of approximately 7 percent to the $8.25 closing price of OneSource common stock on Wednesday. In light of this agreement, OneSource has terminated plans to merge with ValueAct Capital Partners, a private investment firm, and certain of its affiliates in a deal announced in early February that valued the stock at $8.40 per share. ValueAct Capital and Martin Kahn, OneSource's chairman and interim CEO, have agreed to tender their shares to the infoUSA offer. ValueAct Capital and its affiliates currently hold a 32 percent interest in OneSource. Patterson-UTI Energy PTEN, +1.86% shares gained almost 5 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $20.7 million, or 25 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $6.6 million, or 8 cents per share, and a penny short of the average estimate of 21 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped 32 percent in the latest three months to $218.8 million from $165.2 million in the same period a year earlier. In addition, the company said its board has declared a two-for-one stock split, and initiated a quarterly cash dividend of 4 cents per share. The Snyder, Texas-based provider of contract oil drilling services said it had an average of 197 rigs operating in the quarter, a utilization level that it was "especially pleased" to achieve despite "unusually inclement weather." Revlon REV, +0.98% shares leapt almost 5 percent after the company posted a first quarter net loss of $58.2 million, or 63 cents a share compared with a loss of $48.7 million, or 91 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Earnings for the current quarter included a loss of around $33 million linked to debt paydown. Sales rose 6 percent to $308 million from $292 million, buoyed by strength in its overseas markets, notably Asia and Latin America. The Thomson First Call mean estimate was for a quarterly loss of 63 cents a share on revenue of $301.8 million. Taser International TASR shares bounced almost 11 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker responded to what it called "premature, unfounded, speculation in the media" about deaths of people in police custody following the use of its products. "In every single case the medical examiner has attributed the direct cause of death in the autopsy reports to causes other than the Taser device," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a press release. "In over a decade of use, our products have not been listed as a direct cause of death by any independent medical examiner or coroner." The company called the reports "disconcerting" but said its customers understand the safety record of the technology. Shares of Titan International TWI, +1.61% leapt nearly 17 percent after the Quincy, Ill., wheel systems firm reported first-quarter earnings of $5.3 million, or 25 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $5.9 million, or 28 cents per share. Thomson First Call doesn't publish a consensus estimate for the company's results. Titan attributed the strong results to manufacturing efficiencies following its facility consolidations last year, and improvement in its agricultural and light construction markets. Shares of UAL Corp. UALAQ rose more than 6 percent after the parent of United Airlines reported a narrower first-quarter net loss of $459 million, or $4.17 a share, compared with a loss of $1.3 billion, or $14.16 a share, in the same period last year. Revenue rose 17 percent to $3.7 billion. Average fuel prices rose 4 percent to 107.4 cents per gallon, the Chicago-based airline operator said. Shares of United, which hopes to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy, last traded up 6 cents to $1.36. Thursday's decliners Aetna AET, -0.25% shares slid almost 5 percent after the insurance provider affirmed its target for full-year operating earnings of $6.60 to $6.75 per share after a "strong" first quarter. Analysts, on average, are projecting earnings per share at $6.81, according to Thomson/First Call. First-quarter operating earnings, excluding favorable reserve development, rose 31 percent to $1.75 per share, 3 cents ahead of the Thomson/First Call estimate. The insurer said profits growth "primarily reflects growth in revenues in part from increased medical membership, solid underwriting results, and reduced operating expenses." Advanced Fibre Communications AFCI shares fell almost 13 percent after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $2.7 million, or 3 cents per share, down from a profit of $8.3 million, or 10 cents per share, last year. Excluding acquisition-related items, the company posted a core profit of $8.5 million, or 9 cents per share, for the March quarter, a penny higher with the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. The Petaluma, Calif.-based broadband equipment maker said revenue increased in the first quarter to $92.8 million from $80.5 million last year. However, this performance fell short of Wall Street's consensus estimate for revenue of $96.5 million in the latest period. Looking ahead, the company said it's "encouraged by the improving tone of business" despite a slow start to the year. Andrew Corp. ANDW dropped nearly 10 percent after the company reported fiscal second-quarter income of $10.2 million, or 6 cents per share, compared to a loss of $3.4 million, or 3 cents per share, last year. The Orland Park, Ill.-based communications services firm had charges of 4 cents per share in amortization costs and 1 cent per share in pre-tax restructuring charges in the latest quarter. The average analyst estimate for the second quarter as polled by Thomson First Call was 11 cents per share. Sales increased 122 percent in the latest three months to $447 million from $201.3 million last year. Looking ahead, Andrew sees third-quarter profits of 6 to 9 cents per share, which includes charges of about 5 cents per share. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 12 cents a share. Bally Total Fitness BFT, -0.54% lost almost 17 percent after the company said that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating its restatement of 2003 results and that John F. Dwyer has resigned, effective immediately, as chief financial officer and a member of the board. Chicago-based Bally said it is cooperating in the SEC investigation, which it said centers on the timing of recognition of prepaid dues. Bally said William G. Fanelli has been promoted from senior vice president of finance to interim CFO and will be considered for permanent appointment. BMC Software BMC, -2.86% tumbled more than 7 percent after the company agreed to acquire Marimba MRBA for $8.25 per share in cash in a deal valued at $239 million. BMC said that adjusting for Marimba's cash balance at March 31, the price is about $187 million. BMC expects the deal to close in the second quarter and to boost earnings in its first year. Separately, BMC reported fourth-quarter earnings of $36.9 million, or 16 cents a share, up from $20.6 million, or 9 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding special items, earnings stood at 18 cents a share against 17 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 23 cents a share. Marimba shares soared more than 66 percent. Cirrus Logic CRUS, +3.31% gave back more than 22 percent after the company said that it swung to a profit in its fiscal fourth quarter, boosted by strong demand for its mixed signal components. The microchip maker said it made $10.3 million, or 12 cents a share, vs. a loss of $152.8 million, or $1.82 a share, the year before. Sales slipped to $50.2 million from $52.1 million. Cirrus said it expects to post first-quarter sales of $56 million to $59 million vs. analysts' average forecast of $54 million, according to Thomson First Call. Gross margins are expected to be 51 percent to 53 percent. Compex Technologies' CMPX shares lost almost 27 percent after the company warned that third-quarter earnings will come in below its outlook due to weaker-than-expected consumer product sales in Europe and the U.S. The company said it will miss its forecast of earnings of 10 to 12 cents a share on revenue of $21 to $22 million. "Expenses associated with the production and advertising of consumer product launches, much of which occurred in late March, also contributed to the earnings shortfall," chief executive Dan Gladney said in a statement. In February, Compex, which makes electrical nerve and muscle stimulation produces used for pain management and rehabilitation, said it would cut spending to protect its earnings if sales fell below expectations. But the company has now decided to support its consumer goods sales, which will hit earnings for the rest of 2004. Cray CRAY, +3.24% sank more than 9 percent after the company reported a first-quarter loss of $3.8 million, or a nickel per share, reversing its year-ago profit of $1.2 million, or 2 cents per share. The Seattle supercomputer maker said gross margins fell to 30.4 percent in the latest quarter from 42.1 percent a year ago due to an unfavorable product mix as it shipped fewer than anticipated Cray X1 systems and shipped some lower-margin cluster systems. The company added that results were hurt by government procurement delays, and a general slowdown in the defense market. The average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 2 cents per share in the March quarter. JDS Uniphase JDSU shares plummeted almost 16 percent after the San Jose, Calif., fiber optics products firm posted a third-quarter loss before items of $6.7 million, breaking even on a per share basis, a performance that beat Wall Street's consensus view by a penny, but offered a fourth-quarter revenue outlook that left the door open for a disappointment to the current average analysts' view. Wachovia dropped its rating on the stock to "market perform," saying it sees signs that the company's optical business is slowing. See full story. Level 3 Communications LVLT fell nearly 11 percent after the company said it lost $147 million, or 22 cents a share, in the first quarter, wider than the $121 million, or 18 cents a share, lost the year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 30 cents a share. Revenue edged back to $899 million from $988 million a year ago. Level 3 said it has finalized the terms of a reduction in ports and pricing changes with AOL, one of its biggest managed modem clients. The company announced AOL's plan to scale back its purchases in the fourth quarter. From the third quarter, it expects to reduce ports provided to AOL by a third. Including that effect, but excluding revenue from the acquisition of ICG's managed modem business, the company said it's sticking with earnings outlook for 2004. Liz Claiborne LIZ tumbled more than 5 percent after the company said it earned $69 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from $64 million, or 59 cents a share, a year ago. The figure matched the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales climbed 2.5 percent to $1.103 billion, bolstered by improving consumer confidence. The company said it still expects earnings of $2.70 to $2.77 for 2004 on sales growth of 6-to-8 percent. For the second quarter, it's expecting earnings of 41 to 43 cents a share and sales growth of 3 to 5 percent. The First Call average estimate is for second-quarter earnings of 44 cents and 2004 earnings of $2.78. LSI Logic LSI, -0.35% dropped more than 10 percent after the company issued sales targets for the second quarter below what most analysts expected. LSI posted net income of $9 million, or 2 cents a share, and sales of $452 million. During the same quarter last year, LSI lost $122.4 million, or 33 cents a share, on sales of $372.8 million. See full story. Nortel Networks' NT shares fell almost 5 percent as Merrill Lynch lowered its rating on the stock to "neutral" vs. "buy" after the company on Wednesday fired its chief executive and chief finance officer and said it will restate past earnings. Analyst Pat Chiefalo said the news "has created substantial uncertainty around our historical and forecast financial estimates for the company." The firings also raise concern that there may be more bad news to come from the company's internal look at its accounting and an SEC probe. ON Semiconductor's ONNN shares fell nearly 17 percent after the Phoenix chip maker fell short of Wall Street's consensus estimate in the first quarter. The company posted a loss of $51.8 million, or 23 cents per share, in the March period, slightly narrower than its loss of $52.7 million, or 30 cents per share, in the equivalent year-ago period. The latest results included charges totaling $13.1 million, or 6 cents per share, from restructuring and asset impairment, and a loss of $33 million, or 14 cents per share, from debt prepayment. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for breakeven results in the quarter. Looking ahead, ON Semiconductor forecast sequential revenue growth of 6 to 7 percent in the second quarter from its first-quarter total of $308.2 million. Needham & Co., however, raised its assessment of the stock to "buy" from "hold," citing valuation and its belief that an upturn in the chip market bodes well for the company's immediate term growth prospects. The firm set a price target of $8 for the stock, which hit a 52-week high of $9.05 on March 8. Shares of Openwave OPWV tumbled almost 17 percent after the company said its fourth-quarter results could come in as much as a dime below Wall Street's current consensus estimate. The Redwood City, Calif.-based provider of products and services to the communications industry forecast between a loss of up to 14 cents per share and a profit of a penny for its fiscal fourth quarter with revenue running from $69 million to $79 million. The current average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a loss of 4 cents per share on revenue of about $74 million for the June period. Openwave also reported its third-quarter results, coming in with a loss of $5.7 million, or 9 cents per share, beating the analysts' consensus loss view by 3 cents. Taro Pharmaceutical TARO, +0.09% shares dropped more than 27 percent after the company said earnings fell 21 percent in the first quarter from a year ago, hit by the costs of developing new products. Taro said it earned $11.1 million, or 37 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $14 million, or 47 cents a share, a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 53 cents a share. Sales rose 22 percent to $84.1 million. Shares of Time Warner Telecom TWTC fell more than 32 percent after the Littleton, Colo., networking firm missed Wall Street's consensus loss estimate for the first quarter as it experienced a high level of service disconnections in the period. The company posted a loss $38.8 million, or 34 cents per share, in the March quarter on revenue of $161.6 million, falling short of the average estimate for a loss of 27 cents per share. Time Warner Telecom said the loss in the latest quarter was hurt by $8.9 million in deferred loan costs and related fees. Shares of Viasys Healthcare VAS, -0.58% dropped more than 15 percent after the Conshohocken, Pa., medical technology firm reported first-quarter earnings of $2.7 million, or 9 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $4.9 million, or 19 cents per share. Excluding charges from litigation involving its commercialization of nitric oxide, the company earned 12 cents per share in the March period, falling well short of the average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 21 cents per share. The company attributed the earnings weakness to "lower than anticipated sales of several products, margin shortfalls and somewhat higher expenses." Watson Pharmaceuticals' WPI, +0.00% shares lost almost 14 percent after the company posted in-line earnings for the first quarter but fell short of Wall Street's revenue expectations for the period due to an unfavorable sales mix, a supply problem for one product, and customer resistance to a price increase on another product. Watson also offered a second-quarter outlook that at its low end misses the current average analysts' view. In a press release after Wednesday's closing bell, the Corona, Calif., specialty pharmaceutical firm posted first-quarter earnings of $46.7 million, or 42 cents per share, including a charge of $9 million, or 8 cents per share, from a debt repurchase. Revenue of $409.7 million for the three months ended March 31 was 22 percent above its equivalent year-ago total, but slightly below the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call for revenue of $412.9 million. Watson said gross margins fell to 52 percent in the quarter from 56 percent a year ago as sales of less profitable generics represented a higher percentage of total revenue. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Friday: CVX, FDRY, GTW, CI, PG

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares bounced about 3.5 percent to $70.82 in early action. After Wednesday's closing bell, the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker responded to what it called "premature, unfounded, speculation in the media" about deaths of people in police custody following the use of its products. "In every single case the medical examiner has attributed the direct cause of death in the autopsy reports to causes other than the Taser device," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a press release. "In over a decade of use, our products have not been listed as a direct cause of death by any independent medical examiner or coroner." The company called the reports "disconcerting" but said its customers understand the safety record of the technology.
title: Taser bounces; co. defends safety of technology

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser tasr shares lost more than 10 percent Wednesday amid negative media reports about the health risks attached to the company's stun guns. The reports come after CBS News reported in early April that some 40 people have died while in police custody after the Taser product was used on them. Shares were last trading down 11.8 percent at $68.95. A total of 7.4 million shares had changed hands in the session so far.
title: Taser slumps on negative media reports

content: Even in the grip of earnings season, Corporate America proved able to turn its attention this week to larger matters when Jim Cantalupo, McDonald's highly regarded CEO, died suddenly while hosting what had been meant to be a high-spirited company jamboree in Florida. McDonald's MCD, -1.28% passed a crucial test by naming a successor within hours of Cantalupo's death, and then came the stream of tributes. The company itself took out full-page newspaper ads depicting Ronald McDonald shedding a tear. In Chicago, the company's hometown, Coca-Cola responded a day later with a full-page remembrance. And Dominick's, a grocery chain owned by Safeway, joined in the outpouring of sympathy for Cantalupo. Investors showed their confidence in the company, whose stock, a component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, weathered Cantalupo's death with little change. The broader market, after seesawing in response to quarterly earnings reports and rising concerns about potential rate hikes, ended the week higher by the barest of margins but it was enough to send the major U.S. indexes into positive territory year to date. The Dow INDU, -0.10% ended the week barely 0.1 percent higher, while the Nasdaq Composite $COMPQ percent rose 2.7 percent and the S&P 500 Index added 0.5 percent. Stay tuned to CBS MarketWatch this weekend. Online, we'll be featuring a report on a new trend: more small investors being tempted by the promise of quick profits in currency trading. You can also check out our weekly television program on CBS stations, featuring a report on the volatility in shares of Taser TASR the stun-gun maker. Tim Rostan, assistant managing editor McDonald's chief dies at 60 Jim Cantalupo, chairman and chief executive of McDonald's who led the company through a dramatic turnaround, died suddenly Monday of an apparent heart attack. McDonald's moved immediately to name as his successor Chief Operating Officer Charlie Bell, a longtime company man. Analysts said they expected the company to make a smooth transition under Bell's leadership. See full story. EBay shows earnings muscle Shares of online auction behemoth eBay EBAY, +0.32% were bid 10 percent higher to a new all-time high Thursday after it reported a doubling of first-quarter earnings. See full story. Greenspan hints at sweet-spot economy About 24 hours after giving Wall Street a start by saying that deflation was no longer a concern among U.S. central bankers, Alan Greenspan testified Wednesday that inflationary pressures are not yet building, despite signs that the U.S. economy is gathering strength. See full story. Motorola wows Wall Street "Wow just about says it all," said a Piper Jaffray analyst in response to Motorola's latest quarterly report, which was widely characterized as a blowout. Shares of the long-struggling technology giant MSI, +1.29% were treated to a one-day gain of 20 percent. See full story. Microsoft tops targets, voices optimism Microsoft posted weaker earnings, mostly due to massive write-offs, although strong PC sales and strength in most divisions drove revenue growth of 17 percent, helping the software maker beat Wall Street's earnings targets. Shares of Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% surged on the news. See full story. Sony seen bidding on MGM; Time Warner mulls offer Sony SNE, +0.54% reportedly is in talks to buy Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer MGM, +2.70% Word of the negotiations reportedly spurred Time Warner TWX, +0.40% to consider making its own bid MGM, a combination that would combine the Warner Bros. studio with MGM's vast film holdings. See full story. Kumar forced out at Computer Associates Computer Associates' Sanjay Kumar has stepped down under pressure as chief executive and chairman amid a federal probe and after a guilty plea to securities fraud and obstruction charges by three former company CA, +1.25% executives. See full story. Ex-WorldCom is out of bankruptcy While its erstwhile chief executive awaits trial, MCI, the company formerly known as WorldCom, has cleared its slate, exiting bankruptcy status early this week. See full story. The two faces of Janus Mark Whitson stepped down as chief of Janus JNS the fund company being investigated for possible trading abuses. People familiar with the matter note that it's hardly a coincidence that Whiston was gone before the case could be closed. Whether his demise was explicitly demanded by regulators is all but inconsequential. See commentary by Chuck Jaffe. Flu fighters Following a flu season that hit 45 states and killed 142 children in widespread U.S. outbreaks, attention is shifting to combating the illness in advance rather than after the fact. See Personal Finance report. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000
title: The week's top news and commentary, April 19-23

content: Taser's chairman says sales are still hot. But investors think the stun gun maker is missing the mark. John Wordock reports. loading... More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage BlackRock fund manager sees this as the market’s ‘sweet spot’ Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Taser Shoots for More Growth But Stock Stumbles

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of stun-gun maker Taser maintained their volatility Wednesday, recovering from an early slide of 16 percent to close near breakeven. Shares TASR closed at $83.75, down 64 cents, or 0.8 percent, markedly above an intraday low of $70.65. The recovery followed a session in which investors cashed in on the shares' recent rally, precipitating the biggest single-day decline in the stock's history. Tuesday's 29 percent plunge came after Taser reported better-than-expected earnings, but added fewer new customers compared with previous quarters. See full story. New orders for February and March, which averaged $4.1 million, were also down 16 percent from $4.9 million in January. "Put all of these factors together and it just brought them down to earth," said Joe Blankenship, vice president of research for Source Capital Group. "I think the abandonment was fairly complete on Tuesday," added Blankenship, who changed his rating from "hold" to "buy" Wednesday. On Tuesday, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company beat Wall Street expectations, reporting $3.5 million, or 24 cents a share, in net income, compared with $229,000, or 3 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Wall Street analysts, on average, had expected a penny a share in profit. Taser raked in $13 million in sales during the period, compared with $3.4 million a year before. "The company's stock split, effective on April 29, 2004, and expected growth in Great Britain will likely buoy sales in the near-term," said Brian Ruttenbur, security analyst for Morgan, Keegan & Company. Looking further ahead, Ruttenbur said an independent health study of the risks to (Taser) victims is needed to reassure investors of the product's safety. Some 40 people have died while in police custody after they were shot with Taser's electrified fishhooks, CBS News reported earlier this month. Company officials and police defended the so-called nonlethal weapon, saying those who died fought police or were on drugs at the time they were taken into custody, the report claims. Overall, Ruttenbur said he sees Taser's growth slowing somewhat. "It's difficult to continue to grow at this hyper-growth rate for a sustained period of time," Ruttenbur said. Before Tuesday's sudden drop, Taser's stock had skyrocketed 332 percent since the beginning of the year, climbing from $27 on Jan. 1 to close at $118 on Monday after touching a 52-week high of $128.30 that session. As recently as last Oct. 1, the stock was trading under $10. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh
title: Taser recovers after plunge

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International tasr continued their volatility Wednesday, dropping almost $7, another 8 percent, to $77.50. The decline comes after the stock's drop of $34.31, or roughly 30 percent, on Monday following its first-quarter earnings report and a management shift at the chief financial officer position. Shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker closed Monday at $118.70 after running to a 52-week high of $128.30 on an intraday basis. As recently as Oct. 1, the stock was trading under $10.
title: Taser shares extend slide

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Wednesday's session is Altera ALTR, +1.98% The microchip maker is expected to report a first-quarter profit of 13 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. American Airlines parent AMR AMR, -4.53% is seen posting a loss of $1.04 a share for the first quarter. First-quarter numbers at Capital One Financial COF, +1.64% are expected to come in at a per-share profit of $1.53. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% is seen reporting earnings of 43 cents a share for the first quarter. Colgate-Palmolive's CL, +1.24% first quarter is expected to show a profit of 59 cents a share. Auto parts maker Dana DCN, -3.61% is expected to report first-quarter earnings of 40 cents a share. Eastman Kodak EK is seen posting a profit of 17 cents a share for the first quarter. First-quarter results for EBay EBAY, +0.32% are seen coming in at a per-share profit of 26 cents. Ford Motor's F, +2.03% first quarter is expected to show earnings per share of 44 cents. General Dynamics GD, +1.67% is expected to report a first-quarter profit of $1.19 a share. Honeywell International HON, +0.87% is anticipated to post a per-share profit of 30 cents for the first quarter. J.P Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% is seen reporting first-quarter earnings of 87 cents a share. Northwest Airlines NWAC is expected to post a loss for the first quarter, of $2.64 a share. First-quarter results for Sears, Roebuck & Co. S, +0.41% are expected to come in at a loss of 10 cents a share. United Technologies UTX, +1.10% is expected to post earnings of $1.12 a share for the first quarter. Boosted by sizzling wireless-phone sales, Motorola's MSI, +1.29% revenue exceeded forecasts by almost $2 billion. What's more, its resurgence is expected to extend into the current quarter, as Motorola sharply raised its financial forecast. First-quarter profit jumped to $609 million, or 25 cents a share, from $169 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Sales surged 42 percent to $8.6 billion -- well above the $6.8 billion goal forecast by the company and Wall Street analysts. Excluding onetime items, Motorola earned about 19 cents. That easily beat the 7-cent average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. See full story. Motorola shares powered higher 21.8 percent by to change hands for $19.75 after the bell. Ask Jeeves ASKJ reported first-quarter profit growth on sales that rose 73 percent, mirroring substantial growth in searches on its Web sites. The company, based in Emeryville, Calif., said it earned $13.4 million, or 23 cents per share, in the first quarter, compared with a profit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, Ask Jeeves earned $13.5 million, or 23 cents per share, compared with a profit of $3.5 million, or 7 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. The search company also increased quarterly sales by 73 percent to $39.2 million. See full story. Shares of Ask Jeeves rose 3.6 percent to change hands for $38.24 in evening dealings. Silicon Graphics SGI, +3.17% said that it lost $4.09 million, or 2 cents per share, in its third quarter. In the same period last year, SGI lost $34.9 million, or 17 cents a share. SGI also said quarterly sales rose 6 percent to $230 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected SGI to break even on revenue of $230 million. Shares of SGI fell 20 cents, or 7 percent, to $2.64 in after-hours action. StorageTek STK, +1.48% met analyst expectations with stronger sales of services and storage equipment leading to a 42 percent boost in net income and an 11-percent increase in cash from operating activities. The maker of storage equipment reported first-quarter net income of $23.3 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $16.5 million, or 15 cents in the same period a year earlier, meeting analyst expectations. Revenue rose to $515 million, up 7 percent from $480 million. Analysts expected sales of $516 million, on average, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. See full story. StorageTek shares rose 48 cents to $27.69 in regular-session trading, ahead of the announcement. Zion's Bancorp ZION, +1.07% said loan and deposit growth climbed, and credit costs fell, driving earnings to record levels. The Utah-based banking company said its net income for the first quarter was $99.7 million, or $1.10 per share, compared to $87.7 million, or 97 cents per share a year ago. Property/casualty insurance giant Allstate ALL, +0.20% said its first quarter net income rose as written premiums and premium income climbed and catastrophic losses fell. The company earned $949 million, or $1.34 per share versus $665 million, or 94 cents per share a year ago. Electronic financial services firm CheckFree CKFR said it swung to profit in its fiscal third quarter. The company earned, on a GAAP basis, $7.7 million, or 9 cents per share in the latest quarter, compared to a loss of $7.8 million, or 9 cents per share a year ago. The company said underlying earnings - those excluding certain costs, were $26.5 million, or 29 cents per share, compared to $20.5 million, or 23 cents per share a year ago. According to Thomson First Call, analysts expected the company to earn 28 cents per share, on an underlying basis. The company also said it expects fourth quarter earnings of 6 cents to 10 cents per share on a GAAP basis, and 28 cents to 30 cents on an underlying basis. For the full year, the firm expects to earn 5 cents to 9 cents per share on a GAAP basis and $1.04 to $1.06 on an underlying basis. Both the fourth quarter and full year estimates are with Wall Street's expected range. Electronics contract manufacturer Sanmina-SCI SANM, +0.77% reported a second-quarter net loss of $43.9 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. a loss of $31.8 million, or 6 cents, last year. Revenue was $2.9 billion vs. $2.4 billion a year ago. Sanmina exceeded analyst estimates of 4 cents a share in operating income by a penny a share. Sanmina shares rose 6 percent to trade at $10.80 after the bell. Chipmaker Applied Micro Circuits AMCC neared profitability in its fiscal fourth quarter, almost completely reversing a $229 million loss during the same period last year, as sales more than doubled to $47.4 million. Applied Micro Circuits lost $2.1 million, or 1 cent a share, on revenue of $47.4 million. During the same quarter last year, the company lost $229.1 million, or 76 cents a share, on sales of $20.1 million. See full story. Shares of the San Diego-based company rose 4 percent to $5.52 in the late-trading session. In more upheaval at Walt Disney Co. DIS, +1.93% two top executives at the company's troubled ABC network have left their posts, a third has seen his duties cut and the network is undergoing a massive overhaul. See full story. Disney shares lost 16 cents to $24.80 at the close Tuesday. They were up 20 cents in light trading after hours to $25. The fallout over a reporter's lies has apparently cost his editor her job as USA Today announced late Tuesday that Karen Jurgenson has retired -- effective immediately. Jurgenson, 55, steps down three months after the resignation of the paper's Jack Kelley, who was exposed for plagiarism and fabrication in January. In an e-mail to staffers, Craig Moon -- publisher of the Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% flagship -- said that Jurgenson "has been meticulous in every detail since becoming editor. ... She will be missed." See full story. Shares of Gannett closed down almost 2 percent to $88.49 Tuesday. The Food and Drug Administration approved Merck's MRK, -1.13% Proscar prostate drug in combination with another therapy late Tuesday. The agency cleared Proscar tablets to be used with the Whitehouse Station, N.J.-based company's alpha-blocker Cardura drug to treat men with benign enlargement of the prostate, Merck said. See full story. Ahead of the news, shares of Merck closed down 73 cents at $46.21. C.R. Bard BCR said that its first-quarter profit rose 53 percent over the same quarter last year on improved sales of its health-care products. Murray Hill, N.J.-based C.R. Bard said net income rose to $71.9 million, or $1.35 a share, from $46.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding items, C.R. Bard's profit from operations was $63.3 million, or $1.19 a share, in the latest quarter, surpassing the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by 16 cents. Sales rose to $393.8 million from $335.9 million, topping the average analyst estimate of $380.8 million. See full story. The shares rose $1.45 to close at $100.25 ahead of the announcement. Teradyne TER, +1.96% topped its financial targets for the first quarter on strong earnings and sales improvements as demand increased for its test and measurement equipment. The Boston-based company reported net income of $40.2 million, or 20 cents a share, and sales of $430.6 million for the quarter ended on April 4. During the same quarter last year, the company reported a loss $76.5 million, or 41 cents a share, on sales of $334.6 million. See full story. Shares of Teradyne ended the regular session down 3.6 percent at $22.24 ahead of the announcement. Discount brokerage giant Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% said first quarter net income rose from year -ago levels as customers continued to actively trade stocks and generate commissions.
