The company earned $161 million, or 12 cents per share, vs. $71 million, or 5 cents per share, in the same period a year ago. The earnings per share results were a penny ahead of Wall Street analyst estimates, as compiled by Thomson First Call. Schwab also raised its quarterly dividend 43 percent, to 2 cents per share. See full story. Schwab shares closed off 3.2 percent at $10.51 Tuesday. Seagate Technology STX, +2.87% reported that its net income fell during its third quarter and the disc drive maker said its products face price pressure in coming months. Seagate said net income for the quarter ended April 2 was $159 million, or 32 cents a share, a drop of 8.6 percent from the $174 million, or 37 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue for the disk drive maker was $1.4 billion vs. the $1.6 billion reported in the 2003 quarter. See full story. Seagate shares were off 27 cents, or 1.8 percent, to $14.52 at the close Tuesday. Milder weather and cost-cutting in the face of higher commodity prices helped boost Cheesecake Factory's CAKE, +0.46% first-quarter profits by better than 30 percent. Cheesecake Factory said that it earned $16.7 million, or 32 cents per share, on the period. That is up sharply from $12.6 million and 25 cents a year ago and dead-on the 32-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenues for the Calabasas Hills, Calif.-based restaurant operator came in at $220.5 million, up from $173 million, and ahead of a Street view of $216 million. Same-store sales were up a healthy 6.1 percent. See full story. Shares of Cheesecake Factory closed down 3.4 percent at $44.93. Millipore Corp. MIL, -3.92% said that its first-quarter profit rose 21 percent compared with the same period a year earlier on higher sales of its biotechnology products. Billerica, Mass.-based Millipore said it earned $27.2 million, or 55 cents a share, in the quarter, compared to $21.4 million, or 44 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 51 cents a share. Net sales rose to $222 million from $187.5 million, topping the average First Call forecast of $213 million. See full story. The shares fell $1.19 to close at $53.55 ahead of the news. Homebuilder Centex Corp. CTX, +0.48% said net income for the fourth-quarter was $300.1 million, or $2.05 a share, well ahead of Wall Street estimates and last year's figures. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected $1.74 a share, on average. The firm earned $1.56 a share during the same period a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was up 18 percent to $3.2 billion. For the full year, the firm posted $10 billion in revenue. Net income for 2004 was $827.7 million, or $6 a share, the company said Tuesday. Shares fell 97 cents to close at $47.18 before the earnings release. Convergys CVG, +1.48% reported a 7 percent drop in first-quarter earnings Tuesday, beating analyst expectations, although the company says it expects second-quarter results below Wall Street's current targets. The provider of billing software and services posted net income of $32.5 million, or 22 cents a share, down from $34.9 million, or 22 cents, in the first quarter of 2003. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected Convergys to earn 21 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose about 2 percent to $573.9 million, up from $560.4 million a year earlier. See full story. Shares fell 34 cents to close at $15.71 in regular-session trading on the New York Stock Exchange, ahead of the announcement. Career Education Corp. CECO, +0.84% said that its first-quarter profit more than doubled on an 83-percent rise in the number of new students, including a tripling in fulltime enrollment at its online division. The post-secondary-education provider also issued a second-quarter and full-year forecast above Wall Street's expectations. Career Education said it made $41.8 million, or 40 cents a share, on sales of $402.8 million in the first quarter vs. $19.2 million, or 20 cents, on sales of $245.5 million the year before. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected a per-share profit of 32 cents on sales of $381 million. See full story. Shares rose to $66.02 in late trade, a gain of 5.6 percent. Internet Security Systems ISSX reported first-quarter earnings that fell short of analysts' expectations. The computer security company said it made $5.2 million, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $67.1 million vs. $5.4 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $26.3 million. Pro forma earnings came in at 13 cents a share, flat from the same period a year earlier and a penny less than the 14-cent per-share average forecast of analysts polled by First Call. Revenue, however, was higher than analysts' expectations of $66 million. ISS said it expects to report second-quarter earnings of 12 cents to 16 cents a share on sales of $66 million to $70 million. Analysts are forecasting 15 cents a share on sales of $68 million. For the year, ISS expects to make 58 cents to 66 cents a share on sales of $280 million vs. analysts' forecast of 63 cents a share on sales of $280 million. ISS shares fell 8.4 percent to $16.30 after hours. SigmaTel SGTL said it swung to a first-quarter profit and issued a second-quarter forecast above analysts' expectations. The semiconductor designer said it made $6.9 million, or 18 cents a share, on sales of $31.5 million vs. a loss of $8.8 million, or $1.50 a share, on sales of $12.9 million. SigmaTel said it expects to make 22 cents to 24 cents a share in the second quarter on sales between $34 million and $36 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting a per-share profit of 17 cents a share on sales of $34 million. SigmaTel shares rose to $26.25 after the bell, a gain of 5.2 percent. Owens-Illinois OI, +1.59% said its first-quarter profit increased on larger unit shipments and increased prices. The container and packaging firm, based in Toledo, Ohio, said net income was $49 million, or 29 cents a share, versus $34.4 million, or 20 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The company said manufacturing performance also fed the earnings increase. Net sales for the quarter were $1.54 billion compared with first quarter 2003 net sales of $1.38 billion. Shares closed at $13.89, down 7 cents. Gander Mountain GMTN priced its initial public offering of 5.725 million shares at $16 late Tuesday for proceeds of $91.6 million. The outdoor gear retailer raised the numbers of shares in its offering from 5 million and priced its IPO at the high end of its expected $14 to $16 range. Underwriters Banc of America, William Blair & Co. and Piper Jaffray led the deal. Shares of Minneapolis-based Gander Mountain, which operates 66 stores that sell hunting and sporting equipment, are due to start trading on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "GMTN" on Wednesday. ProCentury PROS, +0.00% priced its initial public offering of 8.9 million shares late Tuesday at $10.50 a share for proceeds of $93.45 million. The pricing came in at the low end of the expected 410 to $12 range. Of the total shares, 8 million will be sold by the issuer and 900,000 by shareholders. Friedman Billings Ramsey led the deal's underwriting, along with AG Edwards and Raymond James. The Westerville, Ohio-based property and casualty insurer is slated to begin trading on the Nasdaq Wednesday under the ticker "PROS." The Federal Trade Commission said late Tuesday that it cleared the proposed merger of NBC and Vivendi Universal Entertainment V, +2.25% The companies intend to complete the merger in the next few weeks. Shares of Vivendi ended Tuesday's regular session down 3.6 percent at $25.17. Shares of NBC's parent, General Electric GE, -1.46% shed 2 percent to end at $30.47. Tuesday's advancers AirNet Communications' ANCC shares soared almost 46 percent after the Melbourne, Fla., maker of wireless base stations and other communications equipment said it expects first-quarter revenue to come in at the high end of its previously disclosed outlook. The company now sees revenue of more than $3.6 million for the quarter, roughly doubling its $1.8 million total in the same period a year earlier. Its range is for revenue of $3 million to $4 million in the quarter. America West Airlines AWA, -1.82% rose nearly 6 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $1.2 million, or 2 cents per share, reversing a year-ago loss of $62 million, or $1.84 per share. Excluding a gain following a revision of estimated costs from certain sale-leaseback transactions, the company earned $600,000, or a penny per share, trouncing Wall Street's consensus estimate for a loss of 42 cents per share. Revenue rose 10.2 percent in the latest three months to $576.4 million. Looking ahead, the Phoenix-based firm said it expects to be profitable for the full year despite continued high fuel prices. Check Point Software CHKP, +0.30% gained almost 8 percent after the company said first-quarter net income was $41.9 million, or 16 cents per share, compared with $60.1 million, or 24 cents per share in the year-ago period. Excluding items, net income was $65 million, or 25 cents per share, compared with $60.1 million, or 24 cents per share last year. The Redwood City, Calif. maker of security software said revenue rose to $116.1 million, up from $104.8 million. The company beat the forecast of 23 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Coach COH, +6.26% shares advanced nearly 5 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $58.3 million, or 30 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $31.9 million, or 17 cents per share, and 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales jumped 42 percent in the latest three months to $313.1 million from $220.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The New York fashion accessory firm attributed the strong earnings to the robust sales growth and operating margin improvement. Looking ahead, Coach sees earnings of at least $1.32 per share for 2004 on sales of more than $1.3 billion. This forecast is above Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of $1.25 per share for the year. Cray CRAY, +3.24% shares leapt almost 10 percent after the company disclosed an order for one of its Cray X1 supercomputer system for the U.S. Army Space and Missile Defense Command. Financial terms of the deal, which came through Madison Research Corp., weren't disclosed. Diebold DBD, +7.32% shares gained 6 percent after the company reported in-line first-quarter earnings as revenue climbed 21.5 percent from a year ago. The North Canton, Ohio-based maker of ATMs and voting machines earned $29.2 million, or 40 cents a share, up 12.6 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $498.3 million from $410.2 million. The company forecast second-quarter revenue growth of 13 to 16 percent and earnings of 58 to 62 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 61 cents a share. For 2004, Diebold is forecasting 8 to 12 percent revenue growth and earnings of $2.58 to $2.66. The First Call average is for 2004 earnings of $2.63. Exponent EXPO, +0.51% shares rose almost 5 percent after the provider of engineering and scientific consulting services topped first-quarter earnings estimates by a full 7 cents. Exponent reported earnings of 43 cents a share, up from 32 cents a year ago, as revenue climbed 11 percent to $38.8 million from $34.8 million. The company said first-quarter growth has left it optimistic for 2004. Hughes Supply HUG, -0.17% shares rallied 8 percent after the company raised its first-quarter profit and revenue outlook due to increased commercial construction and higher commodity prices. The Orlando, Fla.-based firm said revenue should be in the range of $965 million to $975 million and earnings per share between 88 cents to 93 cents. A federal tax credit will reduce the first quarter's tax rate from 39 percent to 35 percent, contributing about 6 cents to earnings, Hughes said. Earnings will be released on May 25. J2 Global Communications JCOM, +2.07% rose nearly 15 percent after the company posted a higher first-quarter profit late Monday. The messaging and communications-services provider said it made $6.4 million, or 25 cents a share, vs. $5 million, or 20 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. J2's per-share earnings before taxes came in at 40 cents vs. 21 cents. Revenue rose to $22.9 million from $15.2 million. J2 said it expects to report a second-quarter profit before taxes of 42 to 44 cents a share on sales ranging from $25 million to $25.4 million. Shares of Kent Financial KENT, -0.14% gained almost 48 percent after the Bedminster, N.J. bank set plans for a 2-for-1 stock split. The record date will be April 30, with distribution set for May 3. The company also reduced its previously authorized buyback of common shares to 200,000 post-split shares. Lincare Holdings LNCR shares climbed 9 percent after the provider of oxygen and other respiratory therapy services reported a 26 percent rise in first-quarter earnings. Pixelworks' PXLW, +3.48% shares rose nearly 10 percent after the company posted first-quarter results that beat analysts' expectations. The chip company said it made $6.6 million, or 14 cents a share, on sales of $45.3 million, vs. $248,000, or a penny a share, on sales of $32 million the year before. Pro forma per-share earnings came in at 14 cents a share vs. 5 cents a share. Analysts had been looking for a 9-cent per-share profit on sales of $42 million. Pixelworks said it expects to report a second-quarter pro forma profit of 11 to 13 cents a share on sales in the range of $47 million to $49 million, vs. analysts' average forecast of 10 cents a share on sales of $45 million. Shares of Stocker & Yale STKR, -3.57% surged almost 10 percent Tuesday. The move builds on Monday's extraordinary gain of more than 150 percent. That jump followed news that the company had received a contract to supply specialized lasers for BAE Systems for use in a countermeasure system to protect aircraft from infrared-guided missiles. Tempur-Pedic International TPX, +1.37% shares rose more than 8 percent after the company received an upgrade from Goldman Sachs. The firm went to "outperform" on the stock from "in-line," citing an attractive valuation and a bright outlook for the Lexington, Ky., mattress maker. The company is scheduled to report its first-quarter results after the closing bell on Thursday. Tuesday's decliners Ameritrade AMTD, +3.49% shares fell more than 8 percent after the company reported second-quarter earnings of $81 million, or 19 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $9.6 million, or 2 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 67 percent to $246.9 million in the latest three months from $147.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The Omaha, Neb., online brokerage services firm said its qualified accounts, which have a net liquidation value of at least $2,000 and generate 90 percent of the company's revenue, rose to 1.7 million at the end of March from 1.2 million at the end of September, just after the close of its merger with Datek. Looking ahead, Ameritrade sees earnings of 59 to 79 cents per share for fiscal 2004, surrounding Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 73 cents per share on the year. Shares of Charlotte Russe Holdings CHIC sank nearly 7 percent after the San Diego young women's apparel retailer said it plans to sell 3 million common shares at $17.60 each. The stock to be included in the public offering is held by certain affiliates of Saunders Karp & Megrue, and following the close of the sale, SKM will own about 33 percent of Charlotte Russe's outstanding stock. Digital Recorders TBUS shares fell more than 28 percent Tuesday, trading lower with other security-related stocks, after the company said it "preliminarily" expects to post a profit for the first quarter on revenue of $12.1 million. The maker of mass-transit-related surveillance equipment had revenue of $10.9 million and a loss of $211,466 a year ago. The company said it expects a profit for 2004, excluding any non-cash charges related to financing activities. Federal Signal FSS, +1.33% shares slumped almost 6 percent after the company missed first-quarter earnings estimates due to weak production at U.S. Fire Rescue plants and higher one-time costs. The maker of rescue vehicles and other safety products reported first-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share, below the 14 cents earned a year ago and the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call of 17 cents a share. Sales fell 5 percent to $277 million. Chief executive Robert Welding said the company doesn't expect improvement in municipal and government clients in 2004. Gentex GNTX, +1.86% shares sank more than 8 percent after the Zeeland, Mich., maker of rearview mirror and commercial fire protection products posted first-quarter earnings of $29.8 million, or 38 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $25.9 million, or 34 cents per share, but a penny short of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Revenue rose 12 percent in the latest three months to $129.3 million from $115.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for revenue of $131.1 million in the quarter. JDA Software JDAS dropped almost 9 percent after the company beat first-quarter analyst expectations with license software sales that more than doubled in the Americas and Europe. The maker of retailing software posted a net loss of $437,000, or 2 cents a share. The company lost $2.2 million, or 8 cents, in the first quarter of 2003. Excluding one-time items, JDA Software said it earned $3 million, or 7 cents a share. By that measure, analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected the company to post earnings of 5 cents a share, on average. See full story. Lucent Technologies LU lost more than 10 percent after the company reported fiscal second-quarter profit of $68 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. a loss of $553 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding items, such as charges related to the revaluation of warrants and certain income tax benefits, earnings were 3 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 2 cents a share, on average. Sales rose 9 percent to $2.19 billion, just ahead of analyst forecasts of $2.16 billion. The telecommunications equipment maker said it expects to report a profit for fiscal 2004, with annual revenue to increasing in the "low single digits" percentage range. Shares of NDCHealth NDC gave back almost 10 percent after the company revised its sales outlook for fiscal 2004 to reflect a shift in strategy towards a "solutions-based approach," pressure on discretionary spending by U.S. pharmaceutical makers, and the possibility of a near-term reduction in sales by its physician business unit. The Atlanta-based provider of health information products now sees sales of between $460 million and $466 million for the full year, below the current average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call for sales of $473.3 million. NDCHealth also reported third-quarter results after Monday's closing bell, posting earnings of $9.3 million, or 26 cents per share, on revenue of $116.1 million. Netopia NTPA plummeted nearly 37 percent after the company said it lost $1.6 million, or 7 cents a share, in its fiscal second quarter. Excluding items, the Emeryville, Calif.-based Internet equipment firm lost 5 cents a share, compared with the 5-cent profit expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Sales grew 14 percent to $21.9 million, versus the $28 million analysts expected. See full story. NovaStar Financial NFI, +0.90% shares fell almost 19 percent after the company disclosed late Monday that it's the subject of an informal probe by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The Kansas City, Mo., residential mortgage firm said the probe is looking at certain business practices following an article published in The Wall Street Journal on April 12 that reported the company had compliance issues with certain state licensing agencies. "Receiving this notice was not surprising in the aftermath of a widely circulated newspaper story," said Lanny Davis, outside counsel for NovaStar. The company plans to cooperate fully with the SEC. See full story. Taser International TASR dropped almost 29 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $3.6 million, or 24 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $229,018, or 3 cents per share, and 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. The per share figures do not reflect the 2-for-1 stock split scheduled to take effect on April 29. Sales jumped 286 percent in the latest three months to $13.1 million from $3.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Also, late Monday, the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker named Daniel Behrendt chief financial officer. Behrendt most recently served as CFO of Imperial Home Decor. Behrendt replaces Kathleen Hanrahan in the CFO role. Hanrahan will continue to serve as chief operating officer. See full story. TriZetto Group TZIX lost more than 13 percent after the company lowered its forecast for first-quarter results. TriZetto now expects to lose 8 to 10 cents a share, after previously expecting to break even. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage 2 sexy ways to get paid to save What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Wednesday:  AMR, MOT, KO, F, HON

content: Teradyne Q1 earns 20c, sales $430.6 mln (6:38 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Teradyne TER, +1.96% reported first-quarter net income of $40.2 million, or 20 cents a share, and sales of $430.6 million. Teradyne previously predicted it would earn between 10 and 18 cents a sahre with sales between $400 million and $430 million. For the second quarter, the maker of test equipment expects to earn between 32 and 38 cents a share with sales between $500 million and $525 million. SigmaTel shares gain on Q1 results, Q2 forecast (5:51 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- SigmaTel SGTL shares rose more than 5 percent in late trade Tuesday after the company said it swung to a first-quarter profit and issued a second-quarter forecast above analysts' expectations. The semiconductor designer said it made $6.9 million, or 18 cents a share, on sales of $31.5 million vs. a loss of $8.8 million, or $1.50 a share, on sales of $12.9 million. SigmaTel said it expects to make 22 cents to 24 cents a share in the second quarter on sales between $34 million and $36 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are forecasting a per-share profit of 17 cents a share on sales of $34 million. SigmaTel shares rose to $26.25 after the bell, a gain of $1.30. Convergys beats Q1 expectation (5:49 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Convergys CVG, +1.48% on Tuesday reported a 7-percent drop in first-quarter earnings, beating analyst expectations. The provider of billing software and services posted net income of $32.5 million, or 22 cents a share, down from $34.9 million, or 22 cents, in the first quarter of 2003. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had expected Convergys to earn 21 cents a share, on average. Revenue rose about 2 percent to $573.9 million, up from $560.4 million a year earlier. Convergys shares rose 4 cents to $15.75 in after-hours trading. ISS shares tumble 10% after Q1 profits miss targets (5:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Internet Security Systems ISSX shares lost more than 10 percent in late trade Tuesday after the company's first-quarter earnings fell short of analysts' expectations. The computer security company said it made $5.2 million, or 10 cents a share, on sales of $67.1 million vs. $5.4 million, or 11 cents a share, on sales of $26.3 million. Pro forma earnings came in at 13 cents a share, flat from the same period a year earlier and a penny les than the 14-cent per-share average forecast of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue, however, was higher than analysts' expectations of $66 million. ISS said it expects to report second-quarter earnings of 12 cents to 16 cents a share on sales of $66 million to $70 million. Analysts are forecasting 15 cents a share on sales of $68 million. For the year, ISS expects to make 58 cents to 66 cents a share on sales of $280 million vs. analysts' forecast of 63 cents a share on sales of $280 million. ISS shares fell to $15.94 after hours, down $1.85. Owens-Illinois posts Q1 profit increase (5:25 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW)-- Owens-Illinois said Tuesday first-quarter profit increased on larger unit shipments and increased prices. The container and packaging firm, of Toledo, Ohio, said net income was $49 million, or 29 cents a share, versus $34.4 million, or 20 cents a share, during the same period a year ago. The company said manufacturing performance also fed the earnings increase. Net sales for the quarter were $1.54 billion compared with first quarter 2003 net sales of $1.38 billion. Shares closed at $13.89, down 7 cents. Schwab Q1 net rises, firm boosts dividend (4:43 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Discount brokerage giant Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% said first quarter net income rose versus year -ago levels as customers continued to actively trade stocks and generate commissions. The company earned $161 million, or 12 cents per share versus $71 million, or 5 cents per share a year ago. The earnings per share results were a penny ahead of Wall Street analyst estimates, as compiled by Thomson First Call. Schwab also raised its quarterly dividend 43 percent, to 2 cents per share. Schwab shares closed off 3.2 percent at $10.51 Tuesday. Centex Q4 earnings jump 29% (4:42 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW)-- Home builder Centex Corp. CTX, +0.48% said net income for the fourth-quarter was $300.1 million, or $2.05 a share, well ahead of Wall Street estimates and last year's figures. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call expected $1.74 a share, on average. The firm earned $1.56 a share during the same period a year ago. Revenue for the quarter was up 18 percent to $3.2 billion. For the full year, the firm posted $10 billion in revenue. Net income for 2004 was $827.7 million, or $6 a share, the company said Tuesday. Shares fell 97 cents to close at $47.18 before the earnings release. Career Education stock up on Q1 nos.; Q2, FY forecast (4:35 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Career Education Corporation CECO, +0.84% reported late Tuesday first-quarter results and issued a second-quarter and full-year forecast above Wall Street's expectations. The post-secondary education provider said it made $41.8 million, or 40 cents a share, on sales of $402.8 million in the first quarter vs. $19.2 million, or 20 cents a share, on sales of $245.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been looking for a per-share profit of 32 cents on sales of $381 million. Career Education said it expects to make a profit of 33 cents a share on sales of $405 million to $410 million in the second quarter vs. analysts' average forecast of 29 cents a share on sales of $377 million. For the year, the company is forecasting a per-share profit of $1.75 on sales of $1.675 billion to $1.7 billion compared with analysts' forecast of $1.61 a share on sales of $1.63 billion. Career Education shares rose to $66.15 in after-hours trade, up 5.8 percent. Silicon Graphics falls shy of Q3 goals, shares down (4:32 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO -- Silicon Graphics SGI, +3.17% said late Tuesday that it lost $4.09 million, or 2 cents per share, in its third quarter. In the same period last year, SGI lost $34.9 million, or 17 cents a share. SGI also said quarterly sales rose 6 percent to $230 million. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected SGI to break even on revenue of $230 million. Shares of SGI fell 20 cents, or 7 percent, to $2.64 in after-hours action. Cheesecake Factory profits rise 32 percent (4:27 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW)-- The Cheesecake Factory earned $16.7 million, or 32 cents per share, in its first quarter, up sharply from $12.6 million or 25 cents per share. The earnings, announced after the bell Tuesday, were right on the 32-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenues for the Calabasas Hills, Calif.-based restaurant operator came in at $220.5 million, up from $173 million and ahead of a Street view of $216 million. Shares of Cheesecake Factory CAKE, +0.46% closed the regular New York session down 3.4 percent at $44.93. Ask Jeeves tops Q1 revenue and EPS goals (4:25 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Ask Jeeves ASKJ said late Tuesday that it earned $13.4 million, or 23 cents per share, in the first quarter, compared with a profit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents, in the year-ago period. Excluding certain items, Ask Jeeves earned $13.5 million, or 23 cents per share, compared with a profit of $3.5 million, or 7 cents per share, a year ago. The search company also grew quarterly sales by 73 percent to $39.2 million. Analysts expected Ask Jeeves to earn 18 cents on revenue of $37 million. Shares of Ask Jeeves fell 45 cents to $26.45 in after-hours action. Zion's Q1 net rises (4:25 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) Zion's Bancorp ZION, +1.07% said Tuesday loan and deposit growth climbed, and credit costs fell, driving earnings to record levels. The Utah-based banking company said its net income for the first quarter was $99.7 million, or $1.10 per share, compared to $87.7 million, or 97 cents per share a year ago. Allstate Q1 net rises, catastrophe payouts fall (4:22 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Property/casualty insurance giant Allstate ALL, +0.20% said Tuesday its first quarter net income rose as written premiums and premium income climbed and catastrophe losses fell. The company earned $949 million, or $1.34 per share versus $665 million, or 94 cents per share a year ago. Millipore Q1 profit jumps 21 percent, tops forecasts (4:21 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Millipore Corp. MIL, -3.92% said after the market closed Tuesday that its first-quarter profit rose 21 percent from that of a year earlier on higher sales of its biotechnology products. Billerica, Mass.-based Millipore said it earned $27.2 million, or 55 cents a share in the quarter, compared to $21.4 million, or 44 cents a share, in the year-ago period. On average, analysts polled by Thomson First Call were looking for a profit of 51 cents a share. Net sales rose to $222 million from $187.5 million, topping the average First Call forecast of $213 million. The shares fell $1.19 to close at $53.55 ahead of the news. StorageTek meets Q1 expectation (4:17 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- StorageTek STK, +1.48% on Tuesday reported first-quarter net income of $23.3 million, or 21 cents a share, up from $16.5 million, or 15 cents in the same period a year earlier, meeting analyst expectations. The computer storage-equipment maker posted revenue of $515 million, up from $480 million. Analysts had been expecting sales of $516 million, on average, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. StorageTek shares rose 48 cents to $27.69 in regular-session trading, ahead of the announcement. CheckFree Q3 swings to profit (4:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Electronic financial services firm CheckFree Corp CKFR said Tuesday it swung to profit in its fiscal third quarter. The company earned, on a GAAP basis, $7.7 million, or 9 cents per share in the latest quarter, compared to a loss of $7.8 million, or 9 cents per share a year ago. The company said underlying earnings - those excluding certain costs, were $26.5 million, or 29 cents per share, compared to $20.5 million, or 23 cents per share a year ago. According to Thomson First Call, analysts expected the company to earn 28 cents per share, on an underlying basis. The company also said it expects fourth quarter earnings of 6 cents to 10 cents per share on a GAAP basis, and 28 cents to 30 cents on an underlying basis. For the full year, the firm expects to earn 5 cents to 9 cents per share on a GAAP basis and $1.04 to $1.06 on an underlying basis. Both the fourth quarter and full year estimates are with Wall Street's expected range. C.R. Bard Q1 profit soars 53 percent, tops estimates (4:15 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- C.R. Bard Inc. BCR said after the market closed Tuesday that its first-quarter profit rose 53 percent over the same quarter last year on improved sales of its health care products, plus one-time items. Murray Hill, N.J.-based C.R. Bard said net income rose to $71.9 million, or $1.35 a share, from $46.9 million, or 89 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding items, C.R. Bard's profit from operations was $63.3 million, or $1.19 a share, in the latest quarter, surpassing the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by 16 cents. Sales rose to $393.8 million from $335.9 million, topping the average analyst estimate of $380.8 million. The shares rose $1.45 to close at $100.25 ahead of the announcement. Motorola profit surges on wireless phone sales (4:13 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - Bolstered by sizzling sale of wireless phones, Motorola MSI, +1.29% on Tuesday said first-quarter profit jumped to $609 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $169 million, or 7 cents, a year earlier. Sales surged 42 percent to $8.6 billion - almost $2 billion more than Wall Street expected. Excluding onetime items, Motorola earned about 19 cents a share. That easily beat the 7-cent consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, Motorola forecast second-quarter sales of between $8.2 billion and $8.6 billion and profit of 14 cents to 18 cents a share, well above the 9-cent Wall Street target. Applied Micro Circuits Q4 loss 1c, sales $47.4 mln (4:11 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Applied Micro Circuits AMCC reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss of $2.1 million, or a penny a share, on sales of $47.4 million. During the same quarter last year, the chipmaker lost $229.1 million, or 76 cents a share, on revenue of $20.1 million. Excluding charges, Applied Micro Circuits broke even compared with an average expectation by analysts that it would lose a penny a share on sales of $44.9 million, on average, according to Thomson First Call. Motorola rises ahead of Q1 report (2:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Motorola MSI, +1.29% shares edged 3 cents higher to $16.73 in afternoon trading. The telecommunications equipment maker is scheduled to report its first-quarter results after the closing bell. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are looking for a profit of 7 cents per share on revenue of $6.75 billion in March period. Powerwave shares jump more than 11 percent (1:03 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Powerwave Technologies PWAV shares have reversed their initial trend following the company's release of weaker than expected first-quarter results. The stock had dropped about 5 percent following the company's report after Monday's closing bell, but it's now up more than 11 percent to $8.21, pushing into the top ten on the Nasdaq's percentage gainers list. Powerwave lost $3.3 million, or 5 cents per share, on revenue of $63.2 million in the three months ended April 4. The revenue performance just landed within the company's forecasted range of $63 million to $75 million, but it was below Wall Street's consensus estimate of about $69 million. The company added that it expects its acquisition of LGP Allgon Holding to close within the next month, and that it remains "extremely positive" about its longer term outlook for increasing demand in the wireless communications infrastructure industry. Exponent gains after estimate-beating Q1 (12:58 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Engineering and scientific consulting firm Exponent EXPO, +0.51% shares rose Tuesday after the company topped first-quarter earnings estimates by a full 7 cents. Exponent reported earnings of 43 cents a share, up from 32 cents a year ago, as revenue climbed 11 percent to $38.8 million from $34.8 million. The company said first-quarter growth has left it optimistic for 2004. Shares were last up 6 percent at $25.45. Gentex misses Wall St. view by penny in Q1 (12:15 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Gentex GNTX, +1.86% shares sank almost 4 percent to $44.42 after the Zeeland, Mich., maker of rearview mirror and commercial fire protection products posted first-quarter earnings of $29.8 million, or 38 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $25.9 million, or 34 cents per share, but a penny short of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Revenue rose 12 percent in the latest three months to $129.3 million from $115.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for revenue of $131.1 million in the quarter. Digital Recorders slumps after Q1 outlook (11:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Digital Recorders TBUS shares fell sharply Tuesday, trading lower with other security-related stocks, after the company said it "preliminarily" expects to post a profit for the first quarter on revenue of $12.1 million. The maker of mass-transit-related surveillance equipment had revenue of $10.9 million and a loss of $211,466 a year ago. The company said it expects a profit for 2004, excluding any non-cash charges related to financing activities. Shares were last trading down 23.9 percent at $10.86. Digital Recorders has seen its stock soar this year along with the rest of the sector on speculation it will benefit from terror fears. Ipix shares were down 25 percent at $9.47. Diebold gains on Q1, outlook (11:36 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Diebold DBD, +7.32% shares gained Tuesday after the company reported in-line first-quarter earnings as revenue climbed 21.5 percent from a year ago. The North Canton, Ohio-based maker of ATMs and voting machines earned $29.2 million, or 40 cents a share, up 12.6 percent from a year ago. Revenue climbed to $498.3 million from $410.2 million. The company forecast second-quarter revenue growth of 13 to 16 percent and earnings of 58 to 62 cents a share. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 61 cents a share. For 2004, Diebold is forecasting 8 to 12 percent revenue growth and earnings of $2.58 to $2.66. The First Call average is for 2004 earnings of $2.63. Shares were last up 6.8 percent at $50.41. Itron gets lift from outlook for the full year (11:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Itron ITRI, +2.65% shares rose more than 11 percent to $20.60 in mid-morning action. The move comes after the Spokane, Wash., developer of energy and water delivery technology products reported first-quarter pro forma earnings of $2 million, or 9 cents per share, missing Wall Street's consensus view by a penny. Revenue fell in the latest three months to $65.6 million from $74.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The company, however, attributed the year-over-year decline in revenue to order push-outs by several large customers, and said that it's beginning to see order activity increase. "Our bookings and backlog were both up this quarter and we continue to look for a good second half performance in 2004," said LeRoy Nosbaum, the company's chairman and CEO, in a statement. Looking ahead, Itron forecast pro forma earnings of $1.25 to $1.30 per share, excluding the impact of its SEM acquisition, for the year. This outlook is above the current average estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of $1.20 per share in 2004. NDCHealth shaves 2004 sales outlook (10:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of NDCHealth NDC tumbled more than 13 percent to $21.85 after the company revised its sales outlook for fiscal 2004 to reflect a shift in strategy towards a "solutions-based approach," pressure on discretionary spending by U.S. pharmaceutical makers, and the possibility of a near-term reduction in sales by its physician business unit. The Atlanta-based provider of health information products now sees sales of between $460 million and $466 million for the full year, below the current average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call for sales of $473.3 million. NDCHealth also reported third-quarter results after Monday's closing bell, posting earnings of $9.3 million, or 26 cents per share, on revenue of $116.1 million. Federal Signal slumps after missing Q1 estimates (10:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Federal Signal FSS, +1.33% shares slumped Tuesday after the company missed first-quarter earnings estimates due to weak production at U.S. Fire Rescue plants and higher one-time costs. The maker of rescue vehicles and other safety products reported first-quarter earnings of 5 cents a share, below the 14 cents earned a year ago and the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call of 17 cents a share. Sales fell 5 percent to $277 million. Chief executive Robert Welding said the company doesn't expect improvement in municipal and government clients in 2004. Shares were last down 6.6 percent at $18.86. Check Point beats Q1 earnings target (10:42 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Check Point Software Technologies CHKP, +0.30% on Tuesday posted first-quarter net income that fell 30 percent from the same period last year due mostly to $23 million in acquisition-related costs, although the company beat analysts' targets and said it expects second-quarter results to be in line with Wall Street expectations. The Israel-based maker of security software posted net income of $41.9 million, or 17 cents a share, down from $60.1 million, or 24 cents a share, in the same period last year. Excluding the charge, the company said it earned $65 million, or 25 cents a share, beating analyst expectations by 2 cents a share. Sales were $116.1 million, up 11 percent from $104.8 million. License revenue rose 8 percent to $63 million. The company says it expects to post earnings of 23 to 25 cents in the second quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting 24 cents a share, on average. GM expects interest rates to rise in '04, '05 (10:05 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- General Motors GM, +2.45% told investors Tuesday that it expects interest rates to rise later this year and again in 2005 as the U.S. economy improves. In 2005, however, CFO John Devine said during a conference call with investors that GMAC, the company's finance and lending arm, will be sensitive to rising interest rates, which will have a negative impact on earnings. Rising lending rates also will affect the cheap financing currently used to aggressively market vehicles in the U.S. GM stock rallied on the company's first-quarter results and shares were last up 5.2 percent to $48.55. Trend Micro boosts Q1 earnings (10:03 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Trend Micro TMIC on Tuesday posted first-quarter earnings that rose 81 percent, with help from strong sales growth in Europe, the U.S. and Japan. The Tokyo-based antivirus-software maker's net income was 3.1 billion yen, or about $29 million, up 81 percent from 1.74 billion yen in the same period last year. Revenue rose 25 percent to 13.6 million yen. The company says it expects second quarter net income of 2.7 billion yen, on sales of $13.5 billion yen. U.S.-traded shares of Trend Micro fell 47 cents to $41.60 after the announcement. Cingular adds 554,000 net subscribers (9:45 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Cingular Wireless, the venture between BellSouth BLS, +0.00% and SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% said on Tuesday that it added a net 554,000 customers in the first quarter, improving revenue 8.4 percent to $3.9 billion. Operating income, however, fell to $559 million from $716 million in the year-ago period, though it did rise from $329 million in the prior quarter. Average monthly revenue per user dropped 2.2 percent to $47.95, while churn fell to 2.7 percent from 2.8 percent in the fourth quarter. Cingular is in the process of acquiring AT&T Wireless, potentially allowing the combined entity to surpass Verizon as the largest U.S. wireless phone company. Safeco first quarter profit rises (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Safeco reported Tuesday first quarter net income of $236.2 million, or $1.69 a share compared to $90 million or 65 cents a share for the same time period last year. The results outpaced analyst estimates from Thomson First Call which had expected 84 cents a share. Income from continuing operations was $185.6 million, up from $79.5 million. In March, Safeco SAFC announced plans to sell its life and investments business for a total of $1.44 billion to separate investor groups. America West posts surprise Q1 profit (9:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- America West Airlines AWA, -1.82% reported first-quarter earnings of $1.2 million, or 2 cents per share, reversing a year-ago loss of $62 million, or $1.84 per share. Excluding a gain following a revision of estimated costs from certain sale-leaseback transactions, the company earned $600,000, or a penny per share, trouncing Wall Street's consensus estimate for a loss of 42 cents per share. Revenue rose 10.2 percent in the latest three months to $576.4 million. Looking ahead, the Phoenix-based firm said it expects to be profitable for the full year despite continued high fuel prices. The stock closed Monday at $9.34, up 3.2 percent. M&T Bancorp Q1 net rises (8:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Buffalo, N.Y.-based M&T Bancorp said its first quarter net income rose. The company said it earned $159.5 million or $1.30 per share in the first quarter, compared to $116.5 million, or $1.23 per share a year ago. The latest quarter's results include the operations of AllFirst Financial, acquired last year. The per share results are based on calculations including 26.7 million more average shares outstanding than year ago levels. Those shares were issued at the time of the AllFirst acquisition. Check Point Software beats Wall Street target (8:56 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Check Point Software CHKP, +0.30% said first-quarter net income was $41.9 million, or 16 cents per share, compared with $60.1 million, or 24 cents per share in the year-ago period. Excluding in-process research and development costs, net income was $65 million, or 25 cents per share, compared with $60.1 million, or 24 cents per share last year. The Redwood City, Calif. maker of security software said revenue rose to $116.1 million, up from $104.8 million. The company beat the forecast of 23 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Shares rose 56 cents to $21.94 on Monday. Northern Trust Q1 profit rises (8:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Northern Trust Corp. said Tuesday that first quarter net income rose 35 percent to $127.5 million or 57 cents a share, up from $94.7 million or 42 cents a share for the same time period last year. The results beat average analyst estimates of 55 cents from Thomson First Call. Revenues from continuing operations rose 14 percent to $578.2 million. Chicago-based Northern Trust NTRS, +1.98% said record trust fees, which jumped 17 percent to $327.9 million, drove the gains. First Tennessee Q1 net rises (8:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- First Tennessee National FTN, +0.67% said Tuesday that its first quarter earnings remained mostly flat with year-ago levels as a changing economy led to a rebalancing of earnings in if various businesses. The company earned $119.3 million, or 92 cents per share compared to $119 million or 91 cents per share a year ago. The latest results were 4 cents per share ahead of the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Golden West beats estimate, 1Q net rises 16% to $300M (8:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Golden West Financial on Tuesday reported a 16 percent rise in first quarter net income to $300 million, or $1.93 a share, up from $260 and $1.67 respectively the same period last year. The Oakland, Calif.-based bank beat the average analyst estimate as measured by Thomson First Call by 1 cent. The company GDW cited a rise in mortgage originations, to $9.4 billion from $6.9 billion the same period last year, as a main factor in the increased profits. Interest income rose to $939 million from $877 from the same period last year. Brinker comes in 2c ahead in Q3 (8:42 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Brinker International EAT, +0.03% reported third-quarter earnings of $738,000, or a penny per share, on revenue of $931.9 million. Excluding a number of charges, the restaurant operator earned $53.7 million, or 55 cents per share, in the March period, beating Wall Street's consensus estimate by 2 cents. Looking ahead, the operator of Chili's, Macaroni Grill, and On The Border restaurants among others said it expects to record a charge of between $5 million and $6 million in the fourth quarter related to existing lease obligations related to closing several restaurants. For the fourth quarter, Brinker expects earnings of 66 to 67 cents per share, including the impact of the charge. The stock closed Monday at $38.58, up 1.7 percent. Mellon fee revenue, assets under manage higher (8:26 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Mellon Corp. MEL, +0.58% income from continuing operations rose to $244 million or 57 cents per share vs. $166 million, or 38 cents per share, before a charge in the year-ago period. The financial services group said fee revenue rose 17 percent excluding a gain from the sale of its Shinsei Bank investment. Assets under management rose to a record level of $679 billion at March 31, 2004 from $657 billion at Dec. 31, 2003. Wells Fargo 1Q net income up 15 percent to $1.8 billion (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wells Fargo on Tuesday said net income rose 15 percent to $1.8 billion or $1.03 a share, up from $1.5 billion and 88 cents respectively, the same period last year. The results beat the average analyst estimate of 98 cents for San Francisco-based Wells WFC, +1.81% as measured by Thomson First Call. The bank said revenue for the quarter rose to $7.1 billion, up 7 percent from the same period last year. Deposits grew 8 percent to $213 billion. Non-performing assets, or defaulted loans, fell 30 percent to 0.61 percent of the bank's portfolio. Bank One Q1 earns rise, exceed expectations (8:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Bank One ONE, -0.46% reported first-quarter net income of $1.2 billion, or $1.09 a share, up from 71 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding the impact of special items, earnings were 87 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 81 cents a share, on average. Retail earnings rose 22 percent, commercial banking earnings grew 93 percent, card services earnings increased 29 percent and investment management earnings rose 82 percent. Total revenue rose 16 percent to $4.61 billion, amid an 11 percent increase in net interest income and 21 percent growth in non-interest income. The financial services firm's stock closed Monday down 12 cents at $51.56. Forest Q4 net down as R&D, marketing costs rise (8:19 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Forest Labs FRX, -1.85% pharmaceuticals group, said fiscal fourth quarter net income dropped 20 percent to $145.5 million as expenses due to product launches and R&D spending rose. Net sales rose 17 percent to $725 million. Per share, earnings declined 38 cents from 48 cents a year ago. Forest sees earnings per share for the fiscal year ending March 31, 2005 in the range of $2.35 to $2.50 a share. AK Steel narrows Q1 loss on operating basis (8:17 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- AK Steel AKS, +5.84% reported first-quarter earnings of $165.4 million, or $1.52 per share, reversing a year-ago loss of $40.8 million, or 38 cents per share. The latest results include a gain of $174.9 million, or $1.61 per share related to the sale of Douglas Dynamics LLC. On a continuing operations basis, the Middletown, Ohio firm lost $16.4 million, or 15 cents per share, narrower than the average estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of 43 cents per share in the period. Sales rose in the latest three months to $1.13 billion from $985.3 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said it saw sharply increased steel demand in the quarter, which led to higher shipment volumes and higher realized prices. Looking ahead, AK Steel sees "modestly improved operating results" in the second quarter from its first-quarter performance. The stock closed Monday at $6.26, up 17 cents. Boston Scientific's Q1 EPS a penny ahead; sales up 34% (8:11 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40% reported first-quarter enarings of 23 cents per share on sales of $1.082 billion, up from an adjusted profit of 14 cents earned on sales of $807 million in the year-ago period. Excluding the effects of currency, the medical-products manufacturer's sales increased 27 percent from the 2003 quarter. The latest quarter's profit came in a penny ahead of Wall Street's consensus forecast. Boston Scientific's quarterly operating income reached $264 million, up from an adjusted $175 million in the year-ago quarter. The company also said net U.S. sales of its Taxus stent system totaled $93 million in the first 13 selling days of the second quarter, as opposed to $98 million for the entire first quarter. Shares of Boston Scientific loses 20 cents to end Monday's trading at $43.40. GM trounces Wall St. view for Q1; lifts FY forecast (8:09 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- General Motors GM, +2.45% reported first-quarter earnings of $1.3 billion, or $2.25 per share, up from its year-ago profit of $1 billion, or $1.84 per share. Revenue rose 3.1 percent in the latest three months to $47.8 billion from $47.1 billion in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of 14 analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of $1.79 per share in the March period. The company said its latest results reflect "continued progress" and that it still has more work to do in order to improve profitability "as we face a challenging competitive environment, continuing high health-care costs, and the effects of an artificially weakened Japanese yen." Looking ahead, the world's largest auto maker lifted its outlook for the full year to earnings of around $7 per share, up from its previous target of between $6 and $6.50 per share. For the second quarter, it sees earnings of $2 to $2.25 per share, excluding items. Wall Street's current consensus estimates for these periods are for earnings of $6.30 per share, and $1.88 per share, respectively. Shares of the Detroit-based Dow component closed Monday at $46.15, down 2 cents. 7-Eleven Q1 net 4c vs. 5c: Reiterates 2004 outlook (7:53 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- 7-Eleven SE, +3.11% posted first quarter net income of $4.8 million, or 4 cents a share compared with $5 million, or 5 cents a share in the same quarter in 2003. Revenues climbed 10.7 percent to $2.8 billion against $2.5 billion. 7-Eleven attributed the growth in revenues to a 6.1 percent rise in U.S. same-store merchandise sales, with sales of fresh food, hot and cold beverages, beer and cigarettes putting in a strong contribution. Core earnings, which exclude non-operating items and strips out foreign currency factors, were $13.4 million, or 12 cents a share compared with $.4.9 million, or 5 cents a share in the year-ago quarter. The Thomson First Call mean estimate was for earnings of 8 cents a share. Looking ahead, the convenience store chain said the sale of its headquarters building and the continued improvement in same-store merchandise sales and gasoline sales reinforces the company's confidence that it will meet core earnings estimate for 2004 of a profit of 86 cents to 90 cents per share. 7-Eleven shares were up 5 cents at $17.30 at the close of trading Monday. Black & Decker Q1 EPS top forecasts, 2004 to also beat (7:51 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - Black & Decker BDK reported first-quarter net earnings from continuing operations of $74.3 million, or 93 cents a share, up from 55 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and a penny a share above the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 16 percent to $1.09 billion, just ahead of analyst forecasts of $1.07 billion, boosted by acquisitions and favorable foreign currency translation. Looking ahead, the toolmaker expects to earn $1.20 to $1.25 in the second quarter and $4.70 to $4.85 for the year, exceeding current analyst projections of $1.13 and $4.69 a share, respectively. The stock closed Monday unchanged at $60.20. Tenneco Automotive revenue rises (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Tenneco Automotive TEN, +2.91% reported a first-quarter loss of $2 million, or 5 cents per share, compared with net income of $1 million, or 2 cents per sahre. Adjusted first-quarter net income was $6 million, or 15 cents per share, up from a penny per share. The Lake Forest, Ill. company was expected to earn 5 cents per share, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Revenue was $1.03 billion, up from $921 million. Shares rose 22 cents to $13.12 on Monday. EarthLink Q1 results exceed expectations (7:39 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) - EarthLink ELNK reported a first-quarter net loss of $11.8 million, or 7 cents a share, vs. a loss of 43 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, such as facility exit costs, the Internet access provider earned 11 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 7 cents. Total revenue declined 0.6 percent to $351.56 million, but exceeded analyst forecasts of $350.01 million, as a 26 percent increase in broadband access revenue and 53 percent growth in advertising revenue helped offset a 10 percent decline in narrowband access revenue and a 1.7 percent dip in Web hosting revenue. Looking ahead, the company now expects revenue of $350 million to $355 million in the second quarter, which surrounds current analyst projections of $353.8 million, and to add 300,000 to 550,000 total paying subscribers in 2004. The stock closed Monday unchanged at $9.09. Ameritrade edges Wall St. view for Q2 by penny (7:38 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ameritrade AMTD, +3.49% reported second-quarter earnings of $81 million, or 19 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $9.6 million, or 2 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 67 percent to $246.9 million in the latest three months from $147.6 million in the same period a year earlier. The Omaha, Neb., online brokerage services firm said its qualified accounts, which have a net liquidation value of at least $2,000 and generate 90 percent of the company's revenue, rose to 1.7 million at the end of March from 1.2 million at the end of September, just after the close of its merger with Datek. Looking ahead, Ameritrade sees earnings of 59 to 79 cents per share for fiscal 2004, surrounding Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 73 cents per share on the year. The stock closed Monday at $15.08, down 4 cents. Taser beats in Q1 by 2c; names Behrendt CFO (7:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International TASR reported first-quarter earnings of $3.6 million, or 24 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $229,018, or 3 cents per share, and 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. The per share figures do not reflect the 2-for-1 stock split scheduled to take effect on April 29. Sales jumped 286 percent in the latest three months to $13.1 million from $3.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Also, late Monday, the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker named Daniel Behrendt chief financial officer. Behrendt most recently served as CFO of Imperial Home Decor. Behrendt replaces Kathleen Hanrahan in the CFO role. Hanrahan will continue to serve as chief operating officer. The stock closed Monday at $118.70, up 4 percent, but it fell to $111 in pre-market action. Ingersoll-Rand beats EPS target, raises Q2 outlook (7:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Ingersoll-Rand IR, +1.86% reported first-quarter net income of $179.5 million, or $1.02 per share, up from $153.2 million, or 90 cents per share in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $2.29 billion, up from $2.12 billion. The company beat the forecast of 87 cents per share in a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. The Hamilton, Bermuda-based conglomerate raised its second-quarter outlook to $1.20-$1.30 per share, ahead of the current Wall Street view of $1.05. The company cited strength in most of its units. Shares fell 68 cents to $72 on Monday. Lucent reports Q2 profits that top expectations (7:22 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Lucent Technologies LU reported fiscal second-quarter profit of $68 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. a loss of $553 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding non-recurring items, such as charges related to the revaluation of warrants and certain income tax benefits, earnings were 3 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 2 cents a share, on average. Sales fell 9 percent year-over-year to $2.19 billion, but exceeded Wall Street's forecast of $2.16 billion. The telecommunications equipment maker said it expects to report a profit for fiscal 2004, with annual revenue to increasing in the "low single digits" percentage range. The stock closed Monday up 12 cents at $4.33. Coach tops in Q3 by 3c; boosts FY earnings outlook (7:19 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Coach COH, +6.26% reported third-quarter earnings of $58.3 million, or 30 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $31.9 million, or 17 cents per share, and 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales jumped 42 percent in the latest three months to $313.1 million from $220.4 million in the same period a year earlier. The New York fashion accessory firm attributed the strong earnings to the robust sales growth and operating margin improvement. Looking ahead, Coach sees earnings of at least $1.32 per share for 2004 on sales of more than $1.3 billion. This forecast is above Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of $1.25 per share for the year. The stock closed Monday at $39.50, down 35 cents. RadioShack Q1 tops expectations (7:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- RadioShack RSH, -0.07% posted first quarter earnings of 41 cents a share vs. 33 cents in the year-ago period and 3 cents better than the 38 cents a share average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. First quarter 2004 comparable store sales were up 3 percent compared to the prior year while total sales came in at $1.093 billion compared to $1.070 billion the previous year. Looking ahead, the electronics retailer said it expects second quarter earnings of 38 to 40 cents a share and full year earnings of $1.99 to $2.04. Current First Call estimates are for second quarter earnings of 38 cents and 2004 earnings of $1.98, on average. RadioShack closed up 19 cents at $32.13 Monday. Altria's Q1 profit flat w/ year-ago, revs jump 12.7% (7:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Altria MO, -0.21% reported first-quarter earnings of $2.19 billion, or $1.07 per share, flat with its year-ago profit. The latest results reflect the impact of restructuring charges totaling 9 cents per share. Revenue increased 12.7 percent in the latest three months to $21.8 billion from $19.4 billion in the same period a year earlier. Altria said favorable foreign currency translation added an estimated $1.3 billion to its revenue in the quarter. The average estimate of 11 analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a clean profit of $1.13 per share in the March period. Wall Street's consensus estimate was for revenue of $20.5 billion in the quarter. The Dow component described its performance in the quarter as "solid" with "very strong" results for its domestic tobacco business, and in-line results from its Kraft business. The company also re-affirmed its expectations for earnings of $4.57 to $4.67 per share for 2004. This outlook includes anticipated restructuring charges of 23 cents per share. The stock closed Monday at $56.45, up 55 cents. Regis Q3 earns rise above Wall Street expectations (7:10 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Regis RGS, -0.98% reported fiscal third-quarter earnings of $25.6 million, or 55 cents a share, up from 46 cents a share in the same period a year ago, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 53 cents a share. Total revenue rose 14 percent to $481 million, while same-store sales increased 2.8 percent. The hair salon operator said strong retail product and service sales, coupled with a lower tax rate, helped drive results above expectations. Looking ahead, the company now expects to earn 57 to 59 cents a share in its fourth quarter, $2.27 to $2.29 a share in fiscal 2004 and $2.43 to $2.47 in fiscal 2005, vs. analyst projections of 59 cents, $2.27 and $2.58, respectively. The stock closed Monday up 55 cents at $45.10. Ethan Allen Q1 earns rise, but falls shy of estimates (6:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Ethan Allen ETH, -1.08% reported first-quarter net income of $23.4 million, or 61 cents a share, up from 30 cents a share in the same period a year ago, but a penny a share shy of the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Net sales rose 8.9 percent to $244.6 million, above analyst forecasts of $239.5 million, amid a 13 percent increase in retail division sales and 2.9 percent growth in wholesale sales. Gross margin fell 1 percentage point to 48.8 percent. The furniture seller's stock closed Monday up 49 cents at $42.19. Health Management Associates hits Q2 profit consensus (6:56 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Health Management Associates HMA posted earnings of 37 cents a share for the second quarter ended March 31, up from 31 cents earned in the fiscal 2003 quarter. The latest quarter's profit matched the analyst consensus as compiled by Reuters Research. The hospital operator's revenue reached $833.9 million, up 29 percent from $646.5 million in the year-ago quarter. Same-hospital revenue growth came in at 7.0 percent, while total admissions rose 24.4 percent, the company said. Pricing improved, helping boost net revenue per admission. Health Management's shares dropped 35 cents to end Monday's action at $21.36. Mattel Q1 net drops, U.S. sales down (6:51 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Toy maker Mattel MAT, +0.38% said first quarter net income dropped 73 percent to $9 million, or 2 cents per share. Net sales rose 5 percent to $780.9 million, reflecting the currency benefit. First quarter gross U.S. sales decreased 1 percent, it said. Worldwide gross sales for the Mattel Brands were $532.1 million, reflecting an 11 percent decline in domestic sales offset by a 13 percent increase in international sales, driven by currency exchange rates. Pfizer's Q1 EPS of 52c beats Street consensus by penny (6:48 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Pfizer PFE, +0.54% reported a first-quarter profit of 52 cents on an adjusted basis, or one cent ahead of the Wall Street consensus as compiled by Reuters Research. Net earnings amounted to 30 cents in the latest quarter. The drugmaker, recently made part of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, said quarterly revenue came in at $12.487 billion, up 47 percent in a reflection of Pfizer's Pharmacia acquisition. Norvasc accounted for $1.141 billion in sales, up 16 percent. The company's latest quarter also was marked by the completion of its Esperion Therapeutics acquisition. Pfizer affirmed its 2004 growth targets calling for adjusted earnings of $2.13 per share and revenue of about $54 billion. Shares of Pfizer ended Monday at $37.58, off 4 cents. Station Casinos tops Q1 earns, rev. expectations (6:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Station Casinos STN, +1.65% reported a first-quarter net loss of $29.8 million, or 48 cents a share, vs. a profit of 21 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding non-recurring items, such as the early retirement of debt, earnings were 51 cents a share, exceeding the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 46 cents. Revenue rose 20 percent to $239 million, ahead of analyst forecasts of $232.7 million, while same-store revenue increased 11 percent. Looking ahead, the casino operator expects to earn 45 to 49 cents a share in the second quarter and $1.81 to $1.96 for 2004, vs. analyst projections of 45 cents and $1.80, respectively. The stock closed Monday up $1.28 at $47.27. Eurotunnel Q1op. rev. down 5%, car traffic drops (2:47 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Eurotunnel(UK:ETL), the Channel tunnel operator, said operating revenue declined 5 percent to 125.6 million pounds in the first quarter, as shuttle revenue dropped 8 percent in constant currencies, due to lower truck yields. Eurostar passengers traffic rose 19 percent on the year to 1.6 million. French rebel shareholders earlier this month ousted the Eurotunnel board. Car traffic dropped 13 percent. The new French directors are seeking to renegotiate the group's debts. Akzo Nobel Q1 falls on restructuring, drug settlement (2:29 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Dutch pharma and chemical group Akzo Nobel AKZOY, -1.20% (NL:00913)on Tuesday said first quarter net income eased 4.3 percent to 133 million euros, hit by 43 million euro in costs relating to restructuring at its Organon production site in New Jersey and a settlement in the Remeron court case with generic drug manufacturers. Sales declined 5 percent in the quarter, with a 2 percent improvement in revenue offset by a 5 percent hit on foreign exchange costs and 2 percent hit on divestments. It reiterated 2004 net income, excluding nonrecurring items, will be below 2003 levels. Tesco Feb., year sales surge 18.7% to $60.7 bln (2:19 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Tesco(UK:TSCO), the leading supermarkets group in the U.K., said sales for the year to the end of February rose 18.7 percent to 33.6 billion pound ($60.7 billion) as pre-tax profit rose 17.6 percent to 1.6 billion pounds. Sales at U.K. stores open at least a year rose L6.7 percent over the year-ago period. The dividend for the year will rise 10.3 percent to 6.84 pence a share, Tesco said. "We have seen a step change in non-food with an increase in market share," the retailer said.
