title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Taser enjoyed another record quarter for business, earnings and cash. So says chairman Phil Smith. He tells CBS MarketWatch's John Wordock all U.S. police departments will have his stun guns within 5 years. He also shrugs off Taser's extremely high P-E ratio. loading...
title: Taser Chairman: 'We Continue to Achieve New Heights'

content: SAN DIEGO (CBS.MW) -- I've gone out of my way to avoid writing anything about titillating Taser because I really haven't had anything anybody else didn't have. The stun gun maker's stock, by most rational accounts, was ridiculously overvalued dozens of points ago. That was well before its stock climbed to its current market value of nearly $1.5 billion for a company whose sales this year, based on the most recent quarter, are tracking to be $52 million. Now, however, Taser TASR itself is starting to signal the chinks in its growth story. In its earnings release today, for example, the company said it added 92 police departments to its "growing list" of customers. Yet that number, the company said, is lower than previous quarters. Also worth noting: Quarterly sales per employee were also off, tumbling to $61,013 from $71,394 at the end of December. The trend, as it appears, is increasingly not Taser's friend. The stock got juiced in early February after the company announced "record orders." But orders for February and March, on average were $4.1 million, sharply below January's $4.9 million, touted in an early February press release. And, considering the orders in the first quarter of $13.1 million were equal to sales, it now appears that backlog has stopped growing, as well. Finally, don't be fooled by the company's brag about cash generation. One of the biggest contributors to that cash, no doubt, is tied to employee options that were exercised as the stock spiraled higher -- hardly something that can be counted on in the future. (Especially if the stock falls.) In the end, like so many mania stocks, Taser could be making stun gun or olive pitters. It's all about the stock. And while it's down around 14 percent Tuesday on what appeared to be better-than-expected earnings, keep in mind it's merely back to where it was a week ago. More from MarketWatch Uber for Bikes Could Save Your Commute More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue 2 sexy ways to get paid to save
title: Taser report signals growth worries

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr reported first-quarter earnings of $3.6 million, or 24 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $229,018, or 3 cents per share, and 2 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus view. The per share figures do not reflect the 2-for-1 stock split scheduled to take effect on April 29. Sales jumped 286 percent in the latest three months to $13.1 million from $3.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Also, late Monday, the Scottsdale, Ariz., stun gun maker named Daniel Behrendt chief financial officer. Behrendt most recently served as CFO of Imperial Home Decor. Behrendt replaces Kathleen Hanrahan in the CFO role. Hanrahan will continue to serve as chief operating officer. The stock closed Monday at $118.70, up 4 percent, but it fell to $111 in pre-market action.
title: Taser beats in Q1 by 2c; names Behrendt CFO

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Monday's session is 3M MMM, +1.38% The maker of products including Scotch tape and Post-it Notes is expected to report a first-quarter profit of 87 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Travel and real estate company Cendant's CD, +0.00% first quarter is expected to show earnings of 41 cents a share. Drug giant Eli Lilly's LLY, +0.47% first quarter is expected to come in at a per-share profit of 66 cents. Fannie Mae FNM, -11.67% is expected to post earnings of $1.91 share for the first quarter. Toys and games maker Hasbro HAS, +0.57% is seen posting a per-share profit of 3 cents for the first quarter. First-quarter numbers at Kraft Foods KFT are expected to show earnings of 43 cents a share. Printing and imaging company Lexmark International's LXK, +0.00% first quarter is expected to show a profit of 87 cents a share. Wachovia WB, +3.87% is expected to report earnings of 90 cents a share for the first quarter. First-quarter results for Washington Mutual WM, +1.13% are expected to show a profit of $1.04 a share. The Pentagon said Lockheed Martin LMT, +0.78% and Northrop Grumman NOC, +1.28% won a $220 million contract tied to a space-based radar system for the U.S. military. Each company initially will receive about $30 million worth of work. The work is to wind up by April 2006. Shares of Lockheed Martin, which added 22 cents for a 4 p.m. close of $47, were unchanged in light after-hours trade. Northrop Grumman shares, which rose 48 cents to end at $100.75, were also unchanged in very thin evening dealings. The Securities and Exchange Commission's enforcement division is recommending civil charges against natural-gas distributor Nicor GAS, -3.85% over allegations regarding a performance-based rate plan that critics say led to overcharges for customers. The company said in a press release that the SEC's enforcement group is making the recommendation to the full commission, alleging violations of seven SEC codes. See full story. Nicor shares closed up 22 cents Friday. In after-hours trading, shares dropped 91 cents, or 2.8 percent, to $33.16 in very light trade. Medtronic MDT, +2.24% said it voluntarily recalled two implantable defibrillator models because they may take too long to emit a charge to the heart. The recall involves the Micro Jewel II Model 7223Cx and the GEM DR Model 7271, both of which were mainly implanted in 1997 and 1998, the company said. See full story. Ahead of the news, shares closed up 1.13 at $51.14. They fell to $49.25 in late trade. BearingPoint BE, +0.49% said it lost more than expected in the fourth quarter as Europe's weak economy forced the business consultancy to write down the value of European practices it acquired last year. The McLean, Va.-based company said it lost $126.6 million, or 65 cents a share, in its second fiscal quarter, on revenues of $811.5 million. Excluding the write-down, it earned about $700,000, or less than a cent a share. BearingPoint earned $16 million on sales of $808 million in the second fiscal quarter of 2003. See full story. Shares were unchanged in after-hours trading. They fell 8 cents to $10.51 ahead of the announcement. Alloy ALOY said that it was delaying the filing of its annual 10-K filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, citing additional audit procedures associated with its acquisition of Delia Corp. back in September. The marketing services and retail company said it will file its 10-K by April 30. Shares of Alloy, which closed up a penny at $5.01 ahead of the announcement, slipped to $4.98 in after-hours trade. Volume was thin. Enesco Group ENC, -2.44% said that president and CEO Dan DalleMolle was admitted to a hospital earlier this week with a serious medical condition stemming from complications from a recent surgery. Chief Financial Officer Tom Bradley and Jeff Smith, a senior vice president, will be in charge of daily operations at the maker of gifts and collectibles, effective immediately. They will report to company Chairman Anne-Lee Verville. Shares of Enesco ended Friday's session up 4.8 percent at $13.92 ahead of the announcement. Friday's advancers CyberSource CYBS shares surged more than 39 percent after the company reported a first-quarter profit, confounding expectations of a loss. The Mountain View, Calif.-based company said it earned $0.6 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter, against a loss of $2.1 million, or 6 cents a share a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 4 cents. Revenue rose to $8.5 million, above the company's outlook of $7.3 million. Lone Star Technologies LSS, +2.46% surged almost 20 percent after the Dallas-based maker of steel, oilfield casing and tubing products reported first-quarter earnings of $8 million, or 28 cents per share, on revenue of $179.8 million. These results trounced Wall Street's consensus estimate for a loss of 15 cents per share in the period on revenue of $144.7 million. The company attributed the strong results to its focus on the completion of its cost reduction program, benefits from the current improvement of the general economy, and price increases for all of its products that mitigated the impact of higher natural gas and steel costs. See full story. Lubrizol LZ tacked on 5 percent after the company agreed to acquire privately held Noveon for $1.84 billion. See full story. Shares of Prana Biotechnology Ltd. PRAN, +4.41% soared almost 42 percent after the company said PBT-1, its proposed Alzheimer's disease drug treatment, showed continued promise in an extended phase II clinical trial. The company said the trial showed that use of PBT-1 for 18 months "markedly slowed" the decline in cognitive function related to the disease compared to the predicted level of decline available. Shares of Taser TASR rose more than 14 percent amid positive news reports out of the United Kingdom and ahead of next week's first-quarter earnings release. The results of a one-year test at five U.K. police departments are expected to be released by month's end. A North Wales police spokeswoman was quoted as saying officers -- who don't carry guns -- will be able to continue using Tasers. "They're clearly moving toward deployment," Taser Chairman Phil Smith said. Analysts reporting to Thomson First Call see Taser reporting a profit of 22 cents a share, on average. That's a whopping 633 percent ahead of last year's results. In the last three months, Taser shares have vaulted 169 percent. See full story. Shares of Tegal Group TGAL advanced nearly 10 percent, getting a lift from its addition to Merrill Lynch's Nanotech index. VCampus VCMP, +222.58% soared almost 54 percent after the company began offering online courses to assist in preparation for online security certification testing. The courses will focus on the Certified Information Systems Security Professional exam offered by The International Information Systems Security Certification Consortium. Ventana Medical Systems VMSI, +0.11% gained more than 15 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $2.6 million, or 15 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $1.4 million, or 9 cents per share. Revenue jumped in the latest three months to $31 million from $23.2 million in the same period a year earlier. The average estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a profit of 7 cents per share in the period, on average. The company said gross margin rose to 73.5 percent in the quarter from 71 percent in the same period a year earlier, reflecting an on-going shift in revenue mix to consumables, volume-based manufacturing efficiencies and pricing. Looking ahead, Ventana boosted its outlook for 2004 to earnings of $1.10 to $1.13 per share on revenue of between $156 million and $159 million. The company previously forecast a profit of $1.05 to $1.10 per share for the year on revenue ranging from $154.6 million to $157.1 million. W.W. Grainger GWW, +1.73% advanced more than 7 percent after the company reported first-quarter net earnings of $62.6 million, or 69 cents a share, up from 57 cents a share in the year-earlier period, above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 58 cents a share, helped by improved gross margins, lower expenses and a reduced tax rate. Sales rose 8 percent to $1.2 billion, matching analyst expectations. The provider of facilities maintenance services raised its 2004 earnings forecast to $2.60 to $2.80 a share from $2.45 to $2.70. Friday's decliners Advanced Energy AEIS, +2.54% shares fell almost 26 percent after the company said it expects second-quarter sales growth of 2 to 10 percent, signaling a leveling off in orders from its main clients. The chip equipment company gave the outlook as it reported first-quarter earnings of 21 cents a share, 3 cents above Wall Street estimates. Shares of Aspect Communications ASPT, +20.00% slid almost 10 percent after the San Jose, Calif., provider of customer contact center services reported first-quarter earnings of $13.4 million, or 17 cents per share, topping Wall Street's consensus estimate by 3 cents. However, first-quarter revenue of $91.5 million was below the average view of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call for revenue of $92.6 million. The company also forecast a sequential revenue increase of 3 to 5 percent for the second quarter, and said it expects to record a charge of about $23 million in the second quarter related to conversion of preferred stock to common stock. DoubleClick DCLK shares lost nearly 25 percent after the company met Wall Street expectations for its quarterly results but disappointed with its outlook. The company earned $7.7 million, or 5 cents per share, in the first quarter, compared with $906,000, or a penny per share, in the same period a year ago. Revenue rose to $68 million in the latest three months from $60 million a year ago. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for earnings of 5 cents a share on revenue of $70 million in the March period. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of 2 to 5 cents per share on revenue of between $70 million and $74 million in the second quarter. Wall Street's consensus estimate was for a profit of 6 cents per share in the June period. See full story. Shares of iPix IPIX, -4.59% slumped more than 32 percent after the surveillance camera maker reported first-quarter losses. The company said late-Thursday that it lost $3.6 million, or 41 cents a share on revenue of $700,000. IPIX did not provide a comparison with year-earlier results, given that prior periods reflected revenue from its commercial agreement with EBay EBAY, +0.32% See full story. Shares of Kopin KOPN, +0.32% lost more than 17 percent after the Taunton, Mass., microdisplay firm missed Wall Street's loss estimate for the first quarter. The company attributed the results to lower initial yields related to transition of its legacy monochrome microdisplays to its new color filter CyberDisplay products and additional marketing and technical support activities as customer uptake of the new displays was faster than expected. Kopin lost $3.4 million, or 5 cents per share, on revenue of $22.4 million in the March quarter. The average estimate of three analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of a penny per share. Looking ahead, the company forecast sequential revenue growth of 5 percent for the second quarter. The performance prompted a downgrade of the stock to 'market perform' from Adams, Harkness and Hill. Lexar Media LEXR fell nearly 33 percent after the company missed Wall Street targets for its first quarter. The digital film maker posted first-quarter earnings of 11 cents a share, up from 6 cents a year earlier due to an increase in global demand and strong new product launches. Wall Street forecast a profit of 12 cents a share. Revenue grew more than 200 percent from a year ago to $164.7 million. See full story. Netflix NFLX, +3.35% sank nearly 12 percent after the company said that its first-quarter loss exceeded that of a year earlier on increased marketing expenses related to the acquisition of new customers. The company also announced that it will raise the price of its standard subscription to $21.95 from $19.95 on June 15. The Los Gatos, Calif., firm lost $5.8 million, or 11 cents a share, compared to its loss of $2.4 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding items, the loss from operations was $1.4 million, or 3 cents a share, in the latest period, in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped to $100.4 million from $55.2 million, topping the average First Call forecast of $99.5 million. See full story. Shares of Nokia Corp. NOK, +0.74% gave 9 percent after the Finnish mobile phone giant said it expects earnings to decline in the second quarter. See full story. PMC-Sierra PMCS shares fell almost 6 percent despite news that the company swung to a first-quarter profit from a loss in the year-ago period on stronger demand for its semiconductor products. The Silicon Valley-based firm said its profit was $16.8 million, or 9 cents a share, vs. a loss of $11.5 million, or 7 cents a share, in the same quarter last year. Excluding items, PMC-Sierra's profit from operations was $10.8 million, or 6 cents a share, topping the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by 2 cents. Revenue rose to $78.7 million from $55.4 million, ahead of analysts' estimate of $78.4 million. See full story. Wilsons The Leather Experts WLSN plummeted more than 33 percent after the company said the filing of its annual report to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission will be late given that negotiations to amend its revolving credit facility had not been completed by April 15. The company believes that it may be able to file the report by April 30. The credit facility has been amended to waive certain default covenants related to EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) and extend the refinancing deadline. The leather goods and apparel seller said it also planned to issue 3,500 shares of convertible preferred stock for $10,000 a share. content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser were trading sharply higher Friday, touching an all-time high of $115.11, ahead of the stun-gun maker's scheduled first-quarter earnings release next week. Taser TASR gave back some of the stock's gains to finish the session up $14.10, or 14.1 percent, at $114.10 on volume of nearly 19 million shares. Separately, Taser is expected at the end of the month to learn the results from a one-year test of its guns by five British police departments. A North Wales police spokeswoman was quoted as saying officers -- who don't carry guns -- will be able to continue using Tasers. "They're clearly moving toward deployment," Taser Chairman Phil Smith said. Taser is expected to post a profit of 22 cents a share, according to a Thomson First Call survey of analysts. In the last three months, Taser shares have vaulted 169 percent. title: Taser shares strike new high

content: There's no such thing as a free lunch -- or dinner or cocktails for that matter. Maybe free snacks won't come with a future price, though. All sorts of pitches and come-ons are used to lure investors to financial seminars. Most are legitimate if perhaps one-sided. Some are outright scams. All can be dangerous to your economic health if you go into them with the wrong attitude. It often makes sense to get a little free advice, and maybe some cake and coffee to go with it, from financial gurus or financial-services companies. What you need to avoid, though, is jumping at the product pitches that invariably accompany that "free" advice, especially if the products are a poor fit with your long-term strategy. Our lead story offers cautions for those tempted by investment-seminar pitches, which seem to be coming with more frequency as stock fortunes pick up. Read it, plus find out how sector exchange-traded funds can round out your portfolio and see if playing Japan's Nikkei now is a good idea, on Monday's Personal Finance pages. If you do get an invitation to a glitzy presentation, best to leave the cash, checkbook and charge cards at home. That way, you can eat with impunity. Steve Kerch, personal finance editor Food for thought: 4 cautions on investment seminars Don't let the steak-and-lobster dinner fool you. You're probably better off without the "free" stuff advertised by the investment seminars, especially the ones that rely on the kind of marketing ploys that have lured people to time-share spiels for years. See Weekend Investor How U.S. sector ETFs fit into portfolio puzzle Although some pundits dismiss concentrated sector funds as harmful speculative tools whose only purpose is to humble performance-chasing investors, some financial advisers are adopting sector ETFs for conservative asset allocation strategies, some of which involve tax swaps. See ETF Investing Approaching the Nikkei's recovery with caution Japanese stocks have fooled investors numerous times during almost 15 years of a bear market, rallying sharply only to stumble as hopes for economic recovery faltered. This time, the turnaround might be real. See Global Investor Lumber price hikes haven't slowed building The recent spike in lumber prices is part of a broader pattern of increases for a building material essential to residential construction. But the hikes have yet to put much of a crimp in either homebuilding or remodeling. See full story Faith-based mutual funds can't match wages of sin By their works shall ye know them? As the Christian world celebrates its holiest week of the year, faith-based investors have plenty to rejoice about - though perhaps not as much as those who bought into the tools of the man downstairs. See Mutual Understanding Better disclosure will help investors pick funds "OK, genius, what could a fund company do that would fix the disclosure problem and help people pick better mutual funds?" I love questions like that one from a fund executive in response to my April 4 column, wherein I suggested that reforming the fund industry will not make picking funds any easier. See Chuck Jaffe Stupid Investment of the Week Some investors will overlook all the danger signs and take the plunge. That's why Taser International TASR is today's pick for Stupid Investment of the Week. See Chuck Jaffe Georgia counties become population magnets Georgia is apparently on the minds of a lot more Americans, as the state boasts five of nation's 10 fastest-growing counties. See Real Estate Regulators asking for more from Fannie and Freddie The overseers of mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are asking for more out of the two government-sponsored agencies, both in the way of corporate governance and in their commitment to affordable housing. See Resident Authority Finding fun in a menacing market Is the market back to square one? Warranting "extreme caution"? It may be time to sidestep. See Peter Brimelow Manager Barry likes EResearch, Alliance Gaming, SafeNet There are niche investors, and then there's Thomas Barry. The veteran manager of the Bjurman, Barry Micro-Cap Growth fund BMCFX buys the smallest of the small-caps -- stocks that are often underfollowed and misunderstood. See The Stock Pickers Time to review tax-deduction schemes of all stripes Perhaps you've noticed that the last three letters in "theirs" are I, R, and S. It's the most taxing time of the year. Just don't get carried away -- or scammed -- when doing your income taxes. See Bill Mann Making the most of miscellaneous deductions Every tax season, frantic filers search for ways to reduce the checks they must write to Uncle Sam. A proven tax strategy is deducting as much as possible. But sometimes, technically deductible expenses are wasted because they don't meet other Internal Revenue Service rules. This is often the case for most of the miscellaneous deductions found on Schedule A. See Daily Tax Tip Home is where personal finance literacy should begin A healthy majority of high school seniors failed a recent test of their knowledge of personal financial issues, a reminder that young people need to be taught more about money. In most cases, parents should take the opportunity to do so. title: Personal Finance Daily -- April 12

content: BOSTON (CBS.MW) -- For the average investor, jumping into the middle of a fray between day-traders, momentum players and short sellers is a bad idea. Put that problem together with extremely high valuations, the potential for share dilution, a wave of insider selling and the potential for scream-inducing downside volatility and you've got an investment that might even frighten away some folks who consider themselves savvy, above-average investors. But when those characteristics show up in the hottest stock Wall Street has seen in years, some investors overlook the danger signs and take the plunge. That's why Taser International TASR is today's pick for Stupid Investment of the Week. Taser, which makes non-lethal weapons for law enforcement (think stun gun), has blown investors away over the past year, a time when it is up more than 6,000 percent. You read that right: Taser is up about 7,000 percent in 18 months, up 6,200 percent over the past 12 months and up nearly 250 percent this year alone. The stock has moved in that time from about $1.50 to roughly $100, and management just announced plans for its second stock split - a two-for-one deal - payable later this month. That split will be highly attractive to some investors, as it will make Taser "more affordable" by cutting the price in half. Increased affordability, however, is not necessarily a reason to buy. Stupid Investment of the Week is designed to highlight the characteristics and traits that make an investment less than ideal for the average consumer, in the hope that pointing out such flaws in one security will make them easier to find in another. While obviously not a buy recommendation, neither is Stupid Investment of the Week intended as an automatic sell signal, as there may be times when unloading a troubled investment merely compounds the problem. Any long-term Taser investor, for example, is facing an enormous capital gains tax bill (a nice problem to have, but one that should not be ignored). It's equally important to recognize that Stupid Investment of the Week recognizes an investment at a certain point in time. While no one should minimize the circumstances that lead to a 6,000 percent gain in a year, neither should anyone think that Taser's prospects at $100 per share are the same as its potential $50 or more ago. That price appreciation makes past investors look brilliant, but it's a siren song for newcomers. "For any stock to have this kind of a meteoric rise, there's a great story to fuel the enthusiasm," explains Ken Tower, chief market strategist for CyberTrader, which is owned by Charles Schwab. "The problem is that when you grow at such a rapid pace, it is almost impossible to construct a scenario where you continue to grow at the same rate and justify the enormous p/e ratio you've got. "The worry for average investors is what happens when a stock that has gone crazy on the upside winds up having any bad news. The downside risks are tremendous." That's the problem with Taser, rather than the company's business model or fundamentals. Taser is a "story stock," one with an outstanding tale to tell. The company's products are increasingly the talk of the law-enforcement world because they give officers the chance to end an altercation while reducing the need to use lethal force. Heightened security and safety concerns give the products a huge potential market. Throughout the stock market bubble of the 1990s, story stocks went through a cycle of popping on the story, then crashing on bad news and lousy fundamentals. Taser doesn't have bad fundamentals. While its earnings aren't enormous, they are real. So, too, is the company's sales growth. And the 12-week backlog in orders. The one negative that some investors have been hanging on the stock is what could happen if it loses any wrongful death lawsuits. A CBS Evening News story this week suggested that Taser products may have played a role in some 40 law enforcement deaths, but company officials disputed the claim. More importantly, the market immediately discounted the news, a good sign that lawsuits alone aren't likely to exhaust the fuel in this rocket. Look at the financials and listen to the story and you could make a good case for owning the stock. Just not for the average investor at this price, nor at the one it will have when it splits at the end of the month. And not when you look at who is fueling the continued movement. Taser's price/earnings ratio over the past year is about 300, and it's forward-looking p/e ratio for the next year is about 70. The price-to-book ratio is about 45, a level so high that many analysts say they've never seen a company carrying that number do well in the future. Call me a pessimist, but I see numbers like that and I see a stock priced at a level where expectations have become unreasonable. "The company may well have a bright future, but it will take so many years for the earnings to pan out based on today's price that you will have to hold it forever and things will have to pan out perfectly," says Mark Sellers, editor of the Morningstar Stock Investor newsletter. "It can't be undervalued at this price, and it will need to increase revenues and earnings at an almost triple-digit rate just to make the current stock price remotely reasonable." Other factors working against Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser as an addition to the average investor's portfolio include the high turnover of outstanding shares and the heavy short position. Insiders are selling shares, although you can hardly blame them for locking in their huge profits (of course, had they thought the company was worth $100 per share, they might not have come public at about $3 per share in 2001). "It's a trader stock right now, where you are stuck between the momentum guys and the shorts and the day-traders," says Robert V. Green, editor at Briefing.com. "By definition, that's not the where an average investor wants to be. "If the company has any kind of slip-up and the momentum crowd decides it's no longer the place to be, it's looking at a 50 percent drop overnight, and it's the average guy hoping this thing would keep going who gets stuck with it then." Shares of Taser added $1.76, or 1.8 percent, to close Thursday at $99.80. Editor's note: Chuck Jaffe does not own this stock and is not short in Taser. Jaffe will be one of the featured speakers on the first-ever CBS MarketWatch investment cruise, Oct. 24-31 in the Western Caribbean. title: Stupid Investment of the Week

content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Taser shares powered ahead to all-time highs again Wednesday, a day after the company announced its second stock split in as many months and rebutted a report that its stun guns were lethal. After vaulting more than 21 percent Tuesday, Taser TASR shares set a new peak of $100.30 Wednesday, up nearly 9 percent. At the session's close, shares were higher by $5.79 at $98.04. In the last year, Taser shares have catapulted a stunning 6,200 percent as the company has stepped up marketing efforts and sales to police departments throughout the U.S. In midday trading Wednesday, more than 14.8 million shares had changed hands -- more than double its daily average volume. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of what it calls "advanced less-lethal weapons" is splitting its stock 2-for-1 on or about April 29 to shareholders of record April 15. It was just Feb. 11 that the company held a 3-for-1 stock split as a move to trim the stock's price. The huge jumps in stock prices come after the company spent most of the first two years as a publicly held company in a $1 to $2 range. Wednesday's rally also comes after a two-part "CBS Evening News" series questioning just how nonlethal the stun guns are. The reports said 40 people have died in police custody after being stunned with the Taser guns. The weapons transmit electrical pulses through high-voltage insulated wires. A coroner told CBS that in the death cases he's seen there was an "underlying problem" that the jolt could have aggravated. The shock might, for example, impair breathing, which could lead to death. The company insists that those stunned generally already were fighting with police, delirious or on drugs. "There may be a small group of people that once it's used, may develop difficulties that may result in death," forensic pathologist Dr. Michael Anderson said on Tuesday night's report. On the Taser Web site, the company lists all 40 people who have died and the circumstances and causes surrounding their deaths. "In all of those cases where autopsy reports are available the medical examiners have not listed the Taser as the cause of death in even one instance," Chief Executive Rick Smith said in a statement. "If the Taser had not been used, all 40 of those people would still be dead today," Smith said. "In every single case, these people would have died anyway." Families, however, told CBS News that there was no way to be certain of that. And CBS News also reported Tuesday that at least one victim's autopsy report listed "cause of death" as "electrical shock," according to the program. CBS parent Viacom is a substantial shareholder in MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report. From an earnings viewpoint, analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expect Taser to generate earnings of 22 cents a share on average in the fiscal first quarter, a 633 percent leap over the year-ago profit. title: Taser rebuts report on deaths; stock at new high

content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Investors bolted to shares of Taser in late-day trading Tuesday after the stun-gun maker said it would split shares for the second time in less than two years. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company also responded to a "CBS Evening News" report aired Monday that stated 40 people have died after being stunned with Taser guns. Taser TASR shares surged immediately after the company announced its 2-for-1 stock split. The stock raced to a 52-week peak of $94.84 -- up 21 percent, or $16.35. The day's trading volume more than doubled to nearly 15 million. The company said the stock split would be payable on or about April 29 to shareholders of record on April 15. Taser shareholders are to receive one share of common stock for every share already held. The number of outstanding shares is expected to jump to 28.3 million. Responding to Monday night's TV report, Taser confirmed that approximately 40 people have died while in police custody after being stunned, but it added that, "in all of those cases where autopsy reports are available the medical examiners have not listed the Taser as the cause of death in even one instance. "We are always saddened with loss of a loved one for the grieving families, but all of the medical testing we have done and the tens of thousands of uses of Taser conducted energy weapons by police have clearly established the medical safety of this product," Chief Executive Rick Smith said in a statement. On the CBS news program, Smith had said that the Taser gun was not to blame because most of the victims were fighting with police, delirious or on drugs. "If the Taser had not been used, all 40 of those people would still be dead today," says Smith. "In every single case, these people would have died anyway." Families, however, told CBS News that there was no way to be certain of that. The network will air Part 2 of the series Tuesday evening. CBS parent Viacom is a substantial shareholder in MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report. title: Taser shares jump on stock-split news

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr declared a 2-for-1 stock split to be carried out on or near April 29. Shareholders of record April 15 are to receive one share for every share owned. In a statement, Taser also said it is "very concerned" about statements reported by CBS News this week that there have been Taser-related fatalaties. "While there have been approximately 40 people who have died while in police custody after a Taser energy weapon was used to restrain them, in all of those cases where autopsy reports are available the medical examiners have not listed the Taser as the cause of death in even one instance," read the statement. Shares were last up 7.8 percent at $84.58.
title: Taser in 2-for-1 stock split, comments on deaths report

content: This is a special edition of The Technical Indicator, a daily CBS MarketWatch service. For a more detailed account of the markets on a day-to-day basis -- in addition to 100 trading ideas per month -- please subscribe to The Technical Indicator. CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- U.S. stocks opened lower Tuesday after Nokia NOK, +0.74% cautioned its first quarter earnings would come in at the lower end of its forecast range. The negative early bias suggests that while the bullish uptrend that started almost two weeks ago remains intact, it may be due for a pause. This first chart above is a five-minute chart of the Nasdaq that illustrates the past two sessions -- Friday and Monday. The most obvious take-away above ties to the strength of the Nasdaq's near-term uptrend. Note that even on this narrow two-day time frame, the index has experienced limited intraday pullbacks. A separate point ties to the well-defined technical levels over the past two sessions. From current levels, the Nasdaq faces initial support around 2,064 followed by an additional floor at 2,055. This second chart is an hourly chart of the Nasdaq that widens the view to the prior 10 sessions. Recall that exactly two weeks ago the stage appeared set for a near-term bounce. The Nasdaq had pulled back to its 200-day moving average which, at the time, matched well with the November and December lows. As the chart above illustrates, the index not only experienced a corrective bounce, it has also undertaken a sizeable nine-session run. From bottom to top, the Nasdaq has run 182 points, or 9.6 percent. The Dow industrial average has a similar look to the Nasdaq above. Since breaking higher nine sessions ago, the Dow has trended well from its 20-period moving average. Note that each pullback to that near-term trending average has been regarded as a buying opportunity. Over the past nine sessions, the Dow has added 551 points or 5.5 percent. The near-term picture on the S&P 500 matches closely with the other two indices. Again, the index has trended closely above its 20-period moving average for eight consecutive sessions. Yet unlike the Dow and the Nasdaq, the S&P remains within striking distance of its 52-week high. At Monday's close, the index held just 13 points from its one-year peak. This next chart is a daily chart of the S&P 500 that widens the view to the past six months. With Monday's 8-point gain, the S&P continued to place distance above its 50-day moving average. Like the S&P 500, the Dow also placed distance above its 50-day moving average Monday. Note the Dow is currently approaching its first "real" resistance since the rally started nine sessions ago. The Nasdaq followed Friday's technically significant break above its 50-day moving average with another solid gain Monday. It posted a light volume gain of 22 points Monday, or 1.1 percent. The bigger picture At this point, the Nasdaq faces two competing interests. The overbought near-term condition engendered by the recent rally, versus the favorable technical backdrop created by Friday's employment report. The near-term question is whether the index can extend itself on this nine session, 182-point run and still proceed to take out 2,091 without a period of consolidation. Yet to be clear, both the near-term and the longer-term outlook remain bullish. The major averages have each reclaimed their 50-day simple moving averages. At the same time, the S&P 500 is within striking distance of a 52-week high. So as suggested Monday, the corrective bounce that started two weeks ago has begun to look more sustainable. The "watch out" would be for a strong volume reversal over the next several sessions that takes the indices back below their 50-day moving averages. Absent that kind of sell pressure, both the near-term and longer-term picture favors additional gains, and traders will want to favor long positions on pullbacks to support. Tuesday's watch list The charts below identify several names worth watching from a technical perspective. These are intended as radar screen names -- sectors or stocks that appear well positioned for a potential move in the specified direction over the near term. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance SanDisk SNDK $31.73 $30.62 $31.62 SanDisk SNDK looks well positioned to rise. Over the past two sessions, it has cleared its five-month downtrend (illustrated in green) and its 200-day moving average. At Monday's close, it had also edged just above resistance at $31.62, which approximates the bottom of the gap created in mid-January. The near-term outlook should favor additional upside barring a break back below its 200-day moving average at $30.62. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Taser International TASR $78.60 $77.80 $83.77 The chart above is an hourly chart of Taser International TASR that goes back 10 sessions. Taser was initially profiled March 19 and revisited March 30. Yet following a nine-session 40-percent gain, we grew more cautious on the near-term outlook Thursday. Monday, it was the Nasdaq's leading point loser. The overall technical story is essentially the same. While its relative strength still makes it a risky short candidate, the recent 40-percent run followed by last week's strong volume sell-off make for an unfavorable risk/reward picture over the near-term. content: Coffee, tea or Hulbert? This week, Mark Hulbert asks the question, is a recovery for long-suffering airline stocks in the air? Michael Burke of Investors Intelligence seems to thinks so and Mark takes a look at two of the stocks that caught Burke's eye. Peter Brimelow reviews the newsletters, finding a number of "grumps" who are feeling a little bearish these days. Indeed, Michael Ashbaugh wonders if Monday's gains are sustainable, spying some near-term resistance in the charts. In The Guru's Corner, David Fry of the ETF Digest gives us a first quarter roundup on exchange-traded funds and Elliott Gue of Wall Street Winners takes a look at silver. In newsletter news, China stocks look hot, an old indicator finds new life and an ardent mutual fund critic becomes a fan. Craig Tolliver, Newsletters Editor ctolliver@marketwatch.com Subscribe now: Investment Newsletter Insights THE GURU'S CORNER www.guruscorner.com ETF Digest ETF investors during the first quarter filled their portfolios with a mixed bag of market sectors and specialties. -- David Fry Wall Street Winners Part precious metal and part industrial commodity, silver never seems to get the attention it deserves from investors. -- Elliott H. Gue NEWSLETTERS & RESEARCH www.hulbertdigest.com Taking off? For the first time in a long time, an investment adviser with a good record has something positive to say about an airline stock. -- Mark Hulbert Subscribe: Hulbert Interactive Corrective bounce The indices face well-defined near-term resistance, but see notable broader levels of interest as well. Stocks on the MikeWatch: TASER International TASR Oncolytics Biotech ONCY Netflix NFLX, +3.35% Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% Gevity HR GVHR and New Century Financial NCEN, -40.00% -- Mike Ashbaugh Subscribe: The Technical Indicator How about mid-cap? The conventional wisdom says market leadership should be shifting from small caps to large-cap. -- Peter Brimelow Forced hands On April 1, hundreds of thousands of Americans will take IRA distributions for the first time -- like it or not. -- Robert Powell Subscribe: Retirement Weekly Ordering Chinese China is fast becoming one of the major economic forces of the 21st century. As the U.S. comes out of a three-year recession, China's economy has been roaring at a rate of more than 7 percent annually over the same period. Not surprisingly, a growing number of investment newsletters are shifting their focus into Chinese companies or recommending Chinese stocks. Signaling their enthusiasm for Chinese stocks, editors Carlton and Timothy Lutts have changed the name of the Cabot Sector Inspector investment letter to Cabot's China Investor. Initially launched as the Cabot Internet Stock Letter, the pair previously changed the name when they went to a multi-sector approach. "We think the investment potential in China is huge! We think it holds even more potential than the Internet sector held six years ago," argued the Lutts. As China has become one of the biggest consumers of natural resources in the world, more and more newsletter gurus are also recommending Chinese energy, oil, minerals, and natural gas companies. Louis Navellier of Blue Chip Growth Letter already has three Chinese natural gas and mineral stocks in his portfolio and planning to add more citing the enormous growth potential in the natural resources sector in China. BI Research, Profitable Investing, Oxford Club -- are also recommending Chinese companies. Most notable among the Chinese stocks recommended recently by newsletter editors are PetroChina PTR, -0.14% Huaneng Power International HNP, +0.90% Aluminum Corporation of China ACH, +3.57% Continental Minerals KMKCF and China Petroleum & Chemical SNP, +3.22% -- M. Bobby Syed Order: HFD Newsletter Performance Profiles Listening to specialists The market's recent downturn inspired InvesTech Research Market Analyst to dust off a classic technical indicator to support its still bullish sentiment: The Specialist Short Sales Ratio. This ratio compares NYSE specialists' short sales to the total short sales of all other NYSE participants. It first received widespread exposure among the investing public because of a chapter devoted to it in Norman Fosback's (who now edits Fosback's Fund Forecaster) landmark 1976 book Stock Market Logic. With more than 440 specialists on the NYSE trading floor, the indicator still holds some allure for investors who believe that they have an informational edge. The specialist trades against the prevailing trend of a stock, acting as counterparty whenever there is an excess of buyers or sellers, thus maintaining liquidity and reining in pricing volatility. The specialist must possess the trading savvy to perform this public service while also making money for his firm. To support this dual role, the specialist enjoys access to the Display Book, an electronic workstation, which continuously tracks all limit orders and incoming market orders. Unfortunately, it has become increasingly difficult to measure specialists' short selling behavior in a meaningful way relative to the investing public. In recent years, the total public short sales statistic has been significantly diluted by the short selling volume resulting from two structural shifts in the investing world: the rapid increase in hedge funds and the explosion of convertible debt issuance. To address the massive increase in public short selling, InvesTech, has recalibrated the indicator. In reviewing data from 1976 through 2004, the publication reset the bullish threshold to fall between 36 percent and 38 percent, lower than Fosback's original threshold of 45 percent. During a market decline, a reading under 35 percent indicates that specialists maintain a bullish outlook -- and with the indicator currently reading 28 percent, it's now at the lowest level in its 50-year history, according to InvesTech. "Readings under 35 percent have shown a 98 percent probability of higher stock prices 12 months down the road," the newsletter noted. The Hulbert Financial Digest began monitoring InvesTech since January 1984. Since then, InvesTech has returned 6.8 percent annually through the end of February, vs. 12.5 percent for the Wilshire 5000 TMW, +0.00% -- Ari Charney Sibling rivalry InvesTech's sister publication, InvesTech Research Mutual Fund Advisor, is making some changes to its current format, promising a stronger focus on portfolio strategy and security analysis. Along with the model portfolio, which includes both funds and stocks, the publication will start running an alternative, all mutual fund portfolio that applies the same strategy. The publication also plans to offer more detailed information on individual portfolio positions and defensive hedges. InvesTech Research Mutual Fund newsletter achieved an annualized return of 9.4 percent since the beginning of 1986, when the Hulbert Financial Digest began tracking the publication. This compares to a 12 percent annual gain by the Wilshire 5000 Index over the same period. -- Jimmy Sterns Fool-ish funds The Motley Fool recently launched Motley Fool Champion Funds, a move that must have Motley Fool Stock Advisor subscribers scratching their heads. Founding editors David and Tom Gardner recently issued an "Urgent Investing Bulletin," numbering more than 20 pages, entitled The Case Against Mutual Funds, where the brothers Gardner warn against buying nearly all mutual funds. The new mutual fund letter is edited by former Morningstar analyst Shannon Zimmerman and marks the Fool's first foray into mutual fund investing. Each issue features two new fund picks that have passed Zimmerman's rigorous screens, which include broad, risk controlled diversification, a manager with a historical record of beating the S&P and no-load funds whose expense ratios either justify their performance or compare favorably to the mutual fund universe. In grading funds, Zimmerman also applies what he calls the "X factor," which looks at the quality of the fund family, 12b-1 fees and risk level of the portfolio's investments. In addition, there will be a fund given the dubious title of "dud of the month" which Zimmerman insists you shouldn't touch with the proverbial ten-foot pole. -- John Kimble More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Chinese takeout and Fool-ish funds

content: EDITOR'S NOTE: This is a free edition of The Technical Indicator, a daily newsletter from CBS MarketWatch. For a more detailed account of the markets on a day-to-day basis -- in addition to 100 trading ideas per month -- please subscribe to The Technical Indicator. CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- The pre-market bias is lower Tuesday behind modest losses in European and Asian markets. Early sell pressure follows yet another session of considerable gains Monday. On a percentage basis, the Nasdaq led Monday's rally rising 32 points, or 1.6 percent. At the same time, the Dow added 116 points, or 1.1 percent, while the S&P 500 gained 14.4 points, marking a single-day rally of 1.3 percent. Yet despite Monday's sizeable gains, the broader technical question remains essentially the same. Does this three-day rally mark a resumption of the previous bull trend, or is it merely a corrective bounce following the Nasdaq's massive two-month 11.8 percent pullback? The Nasdaq's hourly chart above illustrates the magnitude of its recent rally. In a matter of just four sessions, the index has lifted a full 100 points, or 5.3 percent. Note the three sessions of tight consolidation beginning last Monday had the index well positioned to rise. Not surprisingly, the near-term picture on the S&P 500 is similar to the Nasdaq. Nonetheless, there is one notable difference between the two indices. Despite Monday's rally, the S&P 500 failed to break outside its two-week range. In fact, it topped just shy of resistance at 1,126 which matches an area of interest going back to March 18. The Dow Industrials has a similar look to the S&P 500. While the Dow did edge to a new two-week high Monday it ended the session at 10,329 - an almost exact match with its former high at 10,328. Note the resistance on both the S&P 500 and the Dow were specifically singled out in the March 22 review. Widening the view So on a near-term basis, the Nasdaq continues to exhibit relative strength. It's the only of the three major indices to break outside its two-week range. By way of comparison, the Dow and the S&P 500 have lifted to observe resistance, but have yet to take out those two-week highs. Yet while the indices contend with well-defined near-term resistance, they face notable broader levels of interest as well. The three charts below are daily charts of the major averages that each go back six months. The real story from a technical perspective ties to the 20-day exponential moving average (EMA). Based on the current picture, the Dow's 20-day moving average rests at 10,287. So Thursday's close at 10,329 placed it just 42 points above this near-term trending average. The daily chart on the S&P 500 illustrates a picture similar to the Dow. Monday's close at 1,122 placed the S&P just 4 points above its 20-day moving average. The Nasdaq was the only major average to place noticeable distance above its 20-day EMA. Monday's close at 1,992 came in roughly 21 points, or 1.1 percent, above that near-term trending average. Nonetheless, the Nasdaq has yet to clear its two-month downtrend illustrated in green. Note that each test of that two-month downtrend has been preceded by an "encouraging" break above the 20-day moving average. The bigger picture So we still face this question of how to interpret Monday's rally. The direct answer is the near-term bias remains higher. Yet as the chart above illustrates, it's still early to get overly bullish regarding the intermediate-term outlook. In a broader sense, the Nasdaq experienced a three-day test of its 200-day simple moving average (SMA) last week. It then found the support you would conventionally expect, and lifted to test that two-month downtrend (illustrated in green) over just four sessions. So while the nature of the price movement has not been unexpected, the recent rally has occurred quickly. At any rate, the strong move lower has occurred, and the corrective bounce has occurred. Over the next several sessions, watch for whether the major averages begin to trend under their 20-day exponential moving averages, or establish a sustainable posture above them. To reiterate a point from last week, even if the indices would reclaim their 20-day moving averages it would only mark a first step to improving the broader outlook. The markets will need to clear their more distant 50-day moving averages before the current bounce might be taken more seriously. Tuesday's Watch List The charts below identify several names worth watching from a technical perspective. These are intended as radar screen names - sectors or stocks that appear well positioned for a potential move in the specified direction over the near term. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance TASER International TASR $74.29 $67.75 New High Initially profiled in The Technical Indicator March 19, Taser International TASR has returned 19 percent in just seven sessions. Monday it was the Nasdaq's third-leading point gainer, carving out a single-day gain of 7.7 percent. The near-term outlook should favor additional gains barring a break below support around $67.75 which matches the February high. title: Is this bounce sustainable?

content: Free Preview For full access, Log in or Subscribe Now and get 4 weeks free! CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- The pre-market bias is lower Tuesday behind modest losses in European and Asian markets. Early sell pressure follows yet another session of considerable gains Monday. On a percentage basis, the Nasdaq led Monday's rally rising 32 points, or 1.6 percent. At the same time, the Dow added 116 points, or 1.1 percent, while the S&P 500 gained 14.4 points, marking a single-day rally of 1.3 percent. Yet despite Monday's sizeable gains, the broader technical question remains essentially the same. Does this three-day rally mark a resumption of the previous bull trend, or is it merely a corrective bounce following the Nasdaq's massive two-month 11.8 percent pullback? title: Is this bounce sustainable?

content: Some folks seek out stocks that have fallen on hard times. They don't have to look much further than Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, whose infamous namesake's highly publicized problems have dealt a crushing blow to the stock. Mark Hulbert highlights one newsletter that's currently holding the stock -- and may be looking to buy more. Meanwhile, we bring you two technicians with slightly different views of the market. Our own Mike Ashbaugh suspects that the Nasdaq may have found a near-term bottom while The Sovereign Strategist's Mark M. Rostenko fears that we've reached a market top. Peter Brimelow is also on hand with a current look at gold and Robert Powell reports on elder migration to escape estate taxes. Craig Tolliver, Newsletters Editor ctolliver@marketwatch.com Subscribe now: Investment Newsletter Insights Living dangerously It takes courage to buy a stock like Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia. -- Mark Hulbert Subscribe: Hulbert Interactive Gauging the depths Indexes' proximity to key levels has created a favorable near-term risk-versus-reward scenario. Stocks on the MikeWatch: MicroStrategy MSTR, +1.01% Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% General Electric GE, -1.46% TASER International TASR Eon Labs ELAB, +0.00% and Oncolytics Biotech ONCY -- Mike Ashbaugh Subscribe: The Technical Indicator Golden bulls Gold still has one big investment letter fan. -- Peter Brimelow The Sovereign Strategist After a spectacular rise in the S&P 500, signs of a major market top are rapidly falling into place. -- Mark M. Rostenko The new immigrants Mores seniors fleeing to warm-weather states to escape the chill of estate taxes. -- Robert Powell Subscribe: Retirement Weekly Correction overdue The recent pullback came as no surprise to newsletter gurus watching the market's steady, yearlong advance. As of Monday, the Standard & Poor's 500 SPX, +1.38% is up 39 percent and the Nasdaq $COMPQ is 52 percent higher since March 12, 2003 -- the beginning of the current market rally. The market seldom moves forward for such a long period of time without a major correction of at least 10 percent to 15 percent. So, after a year of mostly higher prices, the stock market is finally showing signs of strain. Since its January 26 peak, the Nasdaq's declined about 11 percent but considering the rise since last year's March lows, the investment advisors believe the pullback is not excessive. Most top performing newsletter editors agree that although the current market selling has yet to run its course, this pullback is only a correction within the confines of an ongoing bull market. Eric Dany, editor Stock Prospector is expecting the economy to remain strong and continue to strengthen over the balance of the year. Profitable Investing's editor Richard Band mentioned in his recent commentary, "All my key indicators suggest that we've only seen a minor pullback within a major bull market. Once the bottom is complete (probably within the next week or two), we'll be streaming toward new recovery highs on all broad market indexes." Select Investor is cautiously speculating, "There are no signs that a period of strong growth is on the way, but all indications are that we can expect continued slow, steady improvement in the economy. This may be enough to support a modest rally in March." As the U.S. market continues its correction and politicians debate the prospects for the U.S. economy, it's comforting to note that the newsletter industry still has such a positive outlook for the remainder of the year. -- M. Bobby Syed Order: HFD Newsletter Performance Profiles Hats off Biotech investors should take note: Dr. Mark McClellan, who led sweeping reforms as head of the Food and Drug Administration, has just been named to oversee Medicare. Medical Technology Stock Letter (MTSL) summarizes McClellan's year-and-a-half tenure at the FDA as having been marked by key reforms such as streamlining the drug development and approval process, in particular, and reorganizing the massive bureaucracy in general. This led to accelerated review periods for priority treatments, such as new drug therapeutics for cancer, and a steady stream of new drug approvals. Prior to McClellan's appointment as FDA commissioner, the FDA was suffering from a bureaucratic malaise. MTSL describes the FDA during that period as "a ship that was on the wrong course." Under an interim appointee, the FDA had declined to approve a record number of drug treatments and had significantly extended the review periods of a number of other drugs. This led to a great deal of anxiety both among drug companies and their investors. While MTSL retains some skepticism that the FDA will continue in its new direction, it believes that "it should be a significantly easier task to keep the FDA on course than it was to turn the FDA around." Now, of course, McClellan has the chance to leave his intellectual imprint upon the other lumbering behemoth of American medicine, the Medicare administration. This one appointee's reforms could have implications for the pharmaceutical and biotechnology sectors for years to come. "Longer-term, Dr. McClellan may have a larger impact on healthcare as Medicare provides a bigger stage for his philosophies," comments MTSL, "One of these is near and dear to the hearts of biotech investors -- the economic benefits of innovation." The Hulbert Financial Digest has tracked the Medical Technology Stock Letter since the beginning of 1985. Since then, MTSL has achieved a 13.2 percent annualized gain through the end of February, vs. 13 percent annually for the Wilshire 5000 TMW, +0.00% -- Ari Charney More from MarketWatch How Russian Trolls Collected Americans' Personal Information More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue
title: Tough times, sweet buys

content: EDITOR'S NOTE: This is a free edition of The Technical Indicator, a daily newsletter from CBS MarketWatch. For a more detailed account of the markets on a day-to-day basis -- in addition to 100 trading ideas per month -- please subscribe to The Technical Indicator. CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Stocks posted a positive open Tuesday behind modest gains in European markets. The positive bias follows a volatile session Monday that ended with sizeable losses. The Dow dropped 122 points, while the S&P 500 posted a 14-point single day loss. That left the Nasdaq as the session's big percentage loser sliding nearly 31 points on the day. By the end of the session, the major U.S. averages had each touched new three-month lows. This first chart is a 15-minute chart of the Nasdaq that illustrates the past five sessions. The most obvious take away on this time frame is the recent price action has been erratic. Note that three of the Nasdaq's past four opens have resulted in a gap on the chart. Monday, the index gapped lower by 11 points off the open only to fall another 31 points intraday. Nonetheless, the index found support just under 1,900 before lifting to close at 1,909. This second chart is an hourly chart of the Nasdaq that widens the view to the prior 10 sessions. Recall that exactly one week ago -- in the Tuesday review -- the stage appeared set for a corrective bounce. The index had posted consecutive closes under its 20-day Bollinger bands generating a near-term oversold condition. As the chart above illustrates, the index did indeed experience a corrective bounce last Wednesday. It then pulled back to fill the gap Thursday lifting from support just under 1,950. So through Thursday, the Nasdaq's "corrective bounce" scenario remained comfortably intact. Nonetheless, Friday the index closed on its session low setting the stage for pronounced weakness Monday. In retrospect, last week's lift was indeed reflexive, lacking the conviction to trigger a sustainable uptrend. Note that Monday's biggest technical development occurred on the daily time frame. The Nasdaq edged within 11 points of its 200-day simple moving average (SMA) before lifting modestly to close at 1,909. That major moving average (illustrated in blue) sets the longer-term trend, and a sustained break lower could mark the beginning of a pronounced downtrend. Nonetheless, over the near-term the proximity of that 200-day moving average has created a favorable risk/reward scenario. Because you would normally expect that 200-day SMA to hold on the first test, the downside on new long positions should be capped. This means the aggressive trader will want to favor long positions with the notion of setting a strict stop at that 200-day moving average of 1,887. Just to be clear, the Nasdaq would need to reestablish a posture back above its 50-day simple moving average (SMA) at 2,044 for the current bounce -- assuming it even materializes -- to alter the intermediate-term consolidative tone. So pending the Nasdaq's response to its 50-day moving average, the current technical outlook could be characterized as a bullish near-term bias within the context of a broader downtrend. Tuesday's watch list The charts below identify several names worth watching from a technical perspective. These are intended as radar screen names -- sectors or stocks that appear well positioned for a potential move in the specified direction over the near term. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance MicroStrategy MSTR $47.60 $45.50 $49.46 Profiled as a short candidate in The Technical Indicator Monday, MicroStrategy MSTR, +1.01% was the Nasdaq's fourth leading point loser. The move occurred on nearly three times average volume. Despite Monday's 6.6 percent loss, MicroStrategy will remain vulnerable to further downside barring a break above its 200-day moving average at $49.46. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Microsoft MSFT $24.50 $23.60 $25.00 Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% has led both the Nasdaq's and the Dow's recent slide moving to a 10-month low Monday. Last week, it broke support at $25.00 and has since extended its losses on increased volume. Continue to look for sell pressure as the shares retest $25.00 from underneath. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance General Electric GE $29.41 $28.00 $30.27 Profiled in The Technical Indicator on March 10, General Electric GE, -1.46% still looks prone to further downside. Monday, the shares violated their 200-day moving average on twice normal volume. Initial support at $28.00 matches the October low. Note that its recent downturn has been driven by an extended surge in volume. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance TASER International TASR $62.45 $58.00 $64.00 Originally profiled in The Technical Indicator on Friday March 19, Taser International TASR remains well situated to break higher. Monday it was the Nasdaq's fourth leading point gainer. Note the shares have trended closely from their 20-day moving average. Each pullback to that near-term moving average has been regarded as a buying opportunity. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Eon Labs ELAB $60.96 $57.55 $63.19 Eon Labs ELAB, +0.00% approached all-time highs Monday despite considerable broad market weakness. The move followed a successful test of its 50-day moving average and occurred on strong volume. The near-term outlook would improve further on a break above resistance at the February high of $63.19. Company Symbol Mon Close Support Resistance Oncolytics Biotech ONCY $5.18 $5.00 $5.45 Oncolytics Biotech ONCY is another name well positioned to rise. The shares approached 52-week highs Monday after carving out a sizeable five-month base. Initial support around $5.00 represents the breakout point. Still well positioned The table below includes selected names recently profiled in The Technical Indicator that remain well positioned. For the full list, please subscribe to The Technical Indicator. content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) - Shares of Taser International fell Tuesday following an early bounce on the maker of stun guns' report of an enormous rise in fourth-quarter earnings -- and a 2004 profit forecast well above Wall Street's wildest hopes. Taser hit a $52 week high of $154.06 but ran out juice and closed down almost 6 percent at $127.34. Still, the company -- which expects about $49 million in revenues this year -- ended the day with a market cap of $408 million. Before the bell, Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser posted earnings of $2.8 million, or 56 cents a share, for the fourth quarter. That is up from $67,498 and 2 cents a share a year ago, handily over the average estimate (of two) analysts polled by Reuters Research. It's also a tad higher than the company's total sales for the last three months of 2002. Sales better than tripled to $10.8 million, also higher than the Street view. Looking ahead, Taser TASR said it expects sales to come in at $49 million this year, double the 2003 number. The company's eponymous products are used by some law enforcement agencies to subdue citizens at non-contact range without resorting to the use of a firearm. Tasers use compressed nitrogen to fire probes -- connected by wire to a handheld unit -- that shock the target with high-voltage electrical impulses. An atmosphere of heightened security and growing public concern over fatal shootings by police officers has helped the company grow at an exponential rate. "Since the introduction of our weapons to the law enforcement community in late 1999, we have seen our penetration climb from zero to 24 percent of U.S. policing agencies," said CEO Rick Smith in the earnings release. Yet, the company has "only penetrated 5.2 percent of the available market of individual officers ...leaving significant room for continued growth in the domestic markets in the years ahead." Taser is also rolling out a scaled-down version -- the X26 Personal Defense System -- targeted at the civilian market this summer. The product is currently legal to possess in all but a handful of U.S. states. The company's stock has appreciated dramatically over the last year, climbing from a low of under four bucks in Feb. of 2003. title: Taser roars on earnings jump, forecast

content: Sohu's net income jumps sixfold to $11.6 million in Q4 (10:15 PM ET) TOKYO (CBS.MW) -- Chinese Internet company Sohu SOHU, +4.07% on Tuesday reported its net income jumped sixfold in the fourth quarter on the back of a rebound in online advertising. It earned $11.6 million, or 28 cents per shares, in the fourth quarter from $1.9 million, or 5 cents per share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 133 percent from previous-year levels to $24.6 million. Sohu attributed the results to an expanding corporate online advertising base and a large paying consumer base. For the first quarter, Sohu expects net income of $11.2-$11.9 million on sales of $25.6-$26.6 million. Vulcan Materials' Q4 net profit climbs (corrected) (6:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Vulcan Materials reported a 57 percent rise in its fourth-quarter profit late Monday as strength in its construction materials and chemical businesses lifted revenue by 13 percent. polled by Thomson First Call. Sales for the fourth quarter climbed to $657.6 million, compared with $581.3 million a year ago. Analysts expected revenue of $601.5 million, on average. Shares closed at $47.67, down 3 The Birmingham, Ala.-based company VMC, +2.58% said it made $57.3 million, or 56 cents a share. A year ago, it earned $36.6 million, or 36 cents a share. From continuing operations, Vulcan earned $61 million, or 59 cents a share -- in line with the average per-share profit estimate of analysts cents a share, ahead of the announcement. (Corrects percentage gain in profit.) Taser beats Wall Street's Q4 forecast, ups 2004 revs (5:24 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International TASR gained more than 12 percent in after-hours trading Monday after the stun-gun maker reported fourth-quarter earnings and a 2004 forecast that blew past Wall Street's expectations. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser posted earnings of $2.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. $67,498, or 2 cents a share, the year before. Sales rose to $10.8 million from $2.8 million. Two analysts polled by Reuters Research had been looking for a profit of 31 cents a share on sales of $6.4 million. For 2004, Taser said it expects sales to come in at $49 million, double that of 2003's $24.5 million. Analysts are currently looking for sales of $30.1 million for 2004. Taser's shares added $16.48 in late trade, to $151.50. Principal Financial 4Q net income $203 mil., down 5% (5:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Principal Financial PFG, +2.54% said Monday that fourth quarter net income fell 5 percent to $203 million, or 63 cents a share, from the same period the previous year. The Des Moines, Iowa-based life insurer said operating earnings were 46 cents a share, compared to 53 cents the same period of 2002. Analysts at Thomson First call were expecting 32 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter were $2.48 billion up from $2.27 billion the previous year. Aflac reports 4Q net income of $73 mil., Parmalat chg. (4:50 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Aflac AFL, +0.48% on Monday reported fourth quarter net income fell to $73 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $186 million, or 35 cents a share, the same period last year. On an operating basis, the company said net income was $262 million, or 50 cents a share, up 19 percent from a year ago. The Thomson First Call average by the 20 brokers following the Columbus, Ga.-based insurer was 50 cents. The company took a pre-tax loss of $257 million on its investment in Parmalat. Aflac reported revenues of $2.8 billion, up 7 percent. Atari Q3 earnings drop from year ago (4:41 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Atari ATAR, +0.00% on Monday reported fiscal third-quarter earnings that fell 24 percent, as sales of games for Microsoft's Xbox, Nintendo GameCube and PC platforms slipped from the same period a year earlier. The maker of video games reported net income for its third quarter, ended December 31, of $23.0 million, or 19 cents a share, down 24 percent from $30.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the same period last year. Following a profit warning last week, analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been expecting Atari to earn 18 cents a share, on average. Revenue fell to $190.6 million, down from $210.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Atari shares fell 12 cents to close at $3.26 in regular-session Nasdaq trading, ahead of the announcement. Pitney Bowes matches Q4 earns targets (4:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Pitney Bowes PBI, -0.73% said late Monday that it met company and analyst expectations with a fourth-quarter profit, excluding charges, of 66 cents a share. On a net basis, the company posted a profit of of 61 cents a share, versus 8 cents a year ago. Revenue jumped to $1.22 billion. Analysts polled by Reuters Research had expected sales of $1.19 billion. Shares of the office document services company ended the regular session up 25 cents at $40.83. On Semiconductor Q4 loss 21c, sales $279m (4:36 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- On Semiconductor ONNN reported a fourth-quarter net loss of 21 cents a share on sales of $279 million. During the same quarter last year, the chipmaker lost 24 cents a share on sales of $268.5 million. On Semi's fourth-quarter sales are consistent with preliminary figures announced last week. J2 Global Communcations Q4 earnings: $17.6 million (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- J2 Communications JCOM, +2.07% posted a fourth-quarter net profit of $17.6 million, or 69 cents a share, on revenue of $20.5 million. Excluding taxes, the company earned $8.6 million, or 34 cents a share to top the 31-cents-a-share estimate from analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. Revenue fell just shy of analysts' $20.6 million forecast. Going forward, the messaging and communications-services provider said it expects to post 2004 pro forma earnings of $1.65 to $1.75 a share on revenue between $100 million and $105 million. Tyco gains ahead of Q1 report due Tues. morning (2:34 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Tyco International TYC, +74.50% shares rose 1.5 percent to $27.16 in afternoon trades. The Bermuda-based diversified industrial firm is scheduled to report its first-quarter results ahead of Tuesday's opening bell. The mean estimate of 12 analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for earnings of 32 cents per share in the December period. Wall Street's average analysts' view is for revenue of $9.26 billion in the quarter from the company, whose businesses include fire and security services, engineered products, healthcare operations, and electronics. ICU Medical slumps in wake of Q4 results (12:33 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- ICU Medical ICUI, +2.02% shares dropped more than 11 percent to $33.14 in midday action. Before the opening bell, the San Clemente, Calif., maker of safe medical connectors and intravenuous systems reported fourth-quarter earnings of $7.2 million, or 48 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $5.9 million, or 38 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the mean estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped 23 percent in the latest three months to $29.8 million from $24.1 million in the same period a year earlier. But the performance was a tad below Wall Street's consensus estimate for revenue of $29.9 million. Wendy's shares fall amid lowered long-term growth rate (12:30 PM ET) CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Wendy's tumbled more than 5 percent Monday after the restaurant chain lowered its forecast long-term growth rate to a range of 11 to 13 percent from a previous outlook of 12 to 15 percent. CEO Jack Schuessler told analysts at a New York meeting that the forecast offered investors a more "predictable, consistent and credible" expectation from the company. He said, too, that by the end of 2012, the company's Canadian-based Tim Horton's chain would be bigger than the Wendy's brand. The company also doubled its annual dividend to 48 cents a share and said it raised its share-repurchase authorization by $200 million to $366 million. Wendy's WEN, +0.75% shares were down $1.93 at $37.80. Weak margins, bookings trip Mitek Systems in Q1 (11:51 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Mitek Systems' MITK, +2.07% shares lost more than 25 percent to $1.75 after the Poway, Calif., developer of fraud protection and automated check imaging applications reported a loss for the first quarter as gross margins declined due to an unfavorable product mix, and bookings came in below expectations. The company lost $1.1 million, or 10 cents per share, in the December period, on sales of $1.7 million, down from a year-ago profit of $61,000, or a penny per share, on sales of $3 million. Mitek said it hasn't seen increased spending by its core base of regional and community banks, but it remains confident that the passage of Check 21 legislation, which gives the digital image of a check the same legal standing as the original paper check, will be a catalyst for sales growth. Playtex slumps 25 % after warning on earnings (11:26 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Playtex Products PYX, -5.19% slumped $2.03, or 24.8 percent to $6.16 Monday after it said higher-than-expected restructuring charges will hit 2003 and 2004 earnings. After the bell Friday, the personal care and consumer products company said it is targeting full-year 2003 net income of 30 cents a share, well below the Thomson First Call mean estimate of 39 cents a share. The forecast includes a 5 cent per share charge for restructurings and a 2 cent per share charge, related mainly to legal costs.
