Previous company guidance was for a 2 to 3 cent per share restructuring charge for 2003. The company said it also expects additional restructuring charges of $4 million in 2004. The company is now now forecasting full-year 2004 earnings of 30 to 33 cents a share, compared with a First Call mean estimate of 51 cents a share. Playtex said its 2004 earnings estimate includes a 9 cent per share charge linked to the cost of a recently announced refinancing, and a non-cash write-off of 7 cents per share. Hughes Supply sees Q4, FY04 results at top of outlook (10:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Hughes Supply HUG, -0.17% said it expects results for the fourth quarter and fiscal 2004 to come in at the high end of its previously disclosed ranges. The Orlando, Fla., wholesale distributor of construction and repair products noted that this forecast still doesn't reflect six weeks of results from Century Maintenance Supply, which it acquired on Dec. 19. The company's prior outlook was for earnings of $7.3 million to $8.2 million, or 31 to 35 cents per share, in the fourth quarter on revenue ranging from $740 million to $755 million, and for earnings of $55.6 million to $56.5 million, or $2.38 to $2.42 per share, on revenue of $3.2 billion in fiscal 2004. Hughes' shares dipped 1 percent to $48.94 in morning trades. U.S. Jan. ISM shows continued factory growth (10:09 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Factory activity in the United States stayed at a high level in January, the Institute for Supply Management reported Monday. The ISM index rose to 63.6 percent in January from 63.4 percent in December. This is the third month in a row, the index has been above 60. The increase was in line with the consensus of estimates collected by CBS Marketwatch. The number was below the market consensus of 64. New orders slowed in January, the ISM said. New orders fell to 71.1 in January from 73.1 in December. Prices rose to 75.5 in January, the highest level since March 2000. The employment index fell slightly to 52.9 in January from 53.5 in December, but remained above 50 for the third straight month. Lionbridge gets lift from Q4 results; outlook (9:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Lionbridge Technologies' LIOX shares gained more than 7 percent to $8.38 after the Waltham, Mass., information technology testing and globalization services posted fourth-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 2 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $1.3 million, or 4 cents per share. Excluding restructuring expenses of $565,000, the company earned $1.7 million, or 3 cents per share, in the latest three months, in line with the mean estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $36.9 million in the quarter from $30 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Lionbridge forecast adjusted earnings of $2 million to $3.5 million on revenue of between $37 million and $38.5 million for the first quarter, and reiterated its outlook for a profit of $15 million to $19 million on revenue ranging from $160 million to $170 million in fiscal 2004. Incyte jumps on Suntrust upgrade to 'overweight' (9:43 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Incyte Pharmaceuticals' INCY, -1.92% shares rallied more than 9 percent to $9.75 in morning action, pulling back slightly after reaching a 52-week high of $10.24 earlier in the session. The stock was upgraded to "overweight" from "equal-weight" by Suntrust Robinson Humphrey. The Wilmington, Del., drug firm is scheduled to report its financial results for 2003 and to provide an outlook for 2004 after Monday's closing bell. In a note to clients, Suntrust said it believes the potential restructuring of Incyte's database business, and upcoming clinical progress will provide catalysts for the stock. Agilysys Q3 earns 31c vs 7c (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Software company Agilysys AGYS, +1.02% said it earned $8.7 million, or 31 cents a share, in the third quarter, up from $1.9 million, or 7 cents a share, a year ago, buoyed by improving margins and cost cutting. The figure was at the top end of the company's forecast range of 29-31 cents. Sales climbed 22 percent to $459.4 million. The company said it now expects 2004 earnings of 22-24 cents a share. Sales are expected to grow 16 to 18 percent from the $1.2 billion posted in 2003, while margins are expected to growth to be between 12.2 and 12.5 percent of sales. Shares ended Friday down 8 cents at $13.10. Temple-Inland doubles Wall St. view for Q4 (8:49 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Temple-Inland TIN, +0.00% reported a fourth-quarter loss of $39 million, or 71 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $19 million, or 36 cents per share. Excluding items, however, the Austin, Texas-based maker of packaging and building products earned 40 cents per share in the latest quarter, 20 cents ahead of the mean estimate of 7 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose slightly in the latest three months to $1.17 billion from $1.15 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company said its cost-cutting initiatives are expected to result in "reduced personnel requirements" and the consolidation of box plants with savings of $60 million to be realized in the next 18 to 24 months. The stock closed Friday at $59.05, up 2 percent. Crompton Q4 revenue rises 17 percent (8:40 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Crompton Corp. CK, +2.55% reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $12.8 million, or 11 cents per share, vs. net income of $2.4 million, or 2 cents per share in the year-ago period. The most recent loss includes pre-tax charges of $5.5 million for facility closures, severance and related costs and $6.3 million for antitrust legal and related costs. Fourth-quarter sales rose 17 percent to $561 million. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call forecasted a loss of 2 cents per share and revenue of $553 million. Shares of the Middlebury, Conn. maker of polymers rose 25 cents to $7.20 on Friday. Paccar exceeds Q4 earns expectations (8:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Paccar PCAR, +2.59% reported fourth-quarter net earnings of $159.1 million, or $1.35 a share, vs. earnings of $1.05 a share in the year-earlier period, and above the average analyst estimate of $1.25 a share, according to Reuters Research. Net sales rose 15 percent to $2.08 billion, topping analyst forecasts of $2.03 billion. The truck maker said low costs and broad product ranges helped it gain profitable market share. The stock closed Friday down 33 cents at $78.67. Gannett Q4 EPS $.1.31, matching First Call Consensus (8:33 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Gannett Co. GCI, +0.50% reported fourth quarter net income, on a GAAP basis, of $358 million, or $1.31 per share against $347 million, or $1.29 a share in the same period a year ago, in-line with the average consensus of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The media group and owner of USA Today said revenues for the quarter rose 6 percent to $1.82 billion vs. $1.73 billion a year earlier. Gannett CEO Douglas H. McCorkindale said fourth quarter results were helped by a favorable currency exchange rate and a decline in interest expenses. In a separate statement, the company said that pro forma operating revenues for December were 5 percent above the same period last year. Shares of Gannett ended down 95 cents, or 1.11 percent at $85.99 at the close of trading Friday. Moog beats by a penny in Q1; affirms '04 outlook (8:30 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Moog MOG.A, +2.02% reported first-quarter earnings of $12.7 million, or 72 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $9.8 million, or 64 cents per share, a penny ahead of the mean estimate of seven analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales rose 26 percent to $226 million in the latest three months from $180 million in the same period a year earlier. The East Aurora, N.Y., maker of precision control components and systems for military, aerospace, and aviation applications attributed the revenue increase to its acquisition of Northrop-Grumman's Poly-Scientific unit. Looking ahead, Moog affirmed its outlook for earnings of $3.10 to $3.30 per share in fiscal 2004 on sales of between $920 million and $940 million. The stock finished Friday at $52.48, down 2.5 percent. Boston Scientific Q4 earns, rev. top forecasts (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40% reported fourth-quarter net income of $137 million, or 16 cents a share, up from 12 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding one-time items, earnings were 17 cents a share, topping the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 16 cents. Net sales rose 15 percent to $939 million, topping analyst forecasts of $901.9 million, amid strength in international sales of drug eluting stents and favorable foreign currency translation. The medical equipment maker's stock closed Friday up 83 cents at $40.79. International Paper comes in a nickel ahead in Q4 (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- International Paper IP, +2.00% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $48 million, or 10 cents per share, reversing a year-ago loss of $130 million, or 27 cents per share. Excluding items, the Stamford, Conn., paper products firm earned $110 million, or 23 cents per share, in the latest quarter. This performance was a nickel ahead of the mean estimate of 14 analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 18 cents per share. The latest results included a $61 million charge related to restructuring, $26 million in net losses on sales and impairments of businesses, a $15 million credit for reversal of restructuring and realignment reserves, and a $13 million decrease in its income tax provision related to a favorable settlement with Australian tax authorities. Sales rose to $6.5 billion in the latest three months from $6.3 billion in the same period a year earlier. Shares of the Dow component closed Friday at $42.27, up 1.5 percent. BearingPoint to beat Q2 revenue target (8:16 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- BearingPoint BE, +0.49% on Monday reiterated its second-quarter profit target of 4-6 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter will exceed the top end of the previously provided guidance range of $730 million to $760 million, the company said. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call is forecasting earnings of 7 cents per share and revenue of $741 million. The McLean, Va. company said it changed its fiscal year end from June 30 to December 31. Shares of BearingPoint fell 63 cents fell to $9.60 on Friday. ScanSoft ups Q4 earns, revenue outlook (8:06 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - ScanSoft SSFT, -5.41% raised its fourth quarter earnings and revenue forecasts citing strength in its SpeechWorks and imaging products and new partnerships in the auto and mobile device speech markets. The company now expects to earn 4 to 6 cents a share on revenue of $45 million to $47 million, vs. prior projections of 3 to 5 cents and $42 million to $44 million, respectively. The company said it would report full results on Feb. 26. The stock closed Friday up 7 cents at $5.10. Time Warner Telecom narrows Q4 loss to $21.3M (8:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Time Warner Telecom TWTC reported a fourth-quarter loss of $21.3 million, or 19 cents per share, narrower than its year-ago loss of $243.7 million, or $2.12 per share. The mean estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 24 cents per share in the December period, on average. Revenue slid in the latest three months to $169.4 million from $175.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the drop in revenue to a decrease in inter-carrier compensation, lower revenue from WorldCom, and a slump in business from carriers and Internet service providers. Included in the latest revenue figure is $9.2 million related to the sale of a claim related to WorldCom's rejection of certain contracts. The stock closed Friday at $10.92, up 23 cents. Take-Two lowers 2004 outlook, details restatements (8:00 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Take-Two Interactive Software TTWO, +0.33% lowered its outlook for its first quarter and fiscal 2004. It also detailed the moderate impact to revenue and profit in fiscal 2003 and 2002 as a result of a restatement. Take-Two on Friday said it would change how it records reserves for price concessions. It added it's conducting a further review into certain transactions involving sales of products to retailers in fiscal 2000 and the first three quarters of fiscal 2001. As for the fiscal first quarter ending in January, TTWO said it now expects $385 million in net sales and 70 net income per share vs. its earlier forecast of $412 million in net sales and $1.10 in net income per share. TTWO said it cut its outlook because of an unanticipated weakness in the Company's North American publishing business during the holiday season and extending into January, with continued disappointing sales of Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne. It also cited a shift of Mafia for Xbox and the majority of the European shipments of Mafia for PlayStation from the first fiscal quarter to the second fiscal quarter as well as the impact of the change in the company's methodology for recording price concession reserves; bad debt expense incurred as a result of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of KB Toys; and expenses related to the cancellation of two products in development. "We are disappointed that our fiscal 2004 results will not meet our prior expectations," the company said. "However, we remain confident in the long-term performance of our business, and in particular, the release of the next installment of the Grand Theft Auto franchise in our fourth quarter." Taser to beat '03 EPS target; slams Barron's article (7:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International TASR said its current product backlog stands at $7.4 million, as the maker of stun guns also criticized a weekend article in Barron's. Later on Monday, the Scottsdale, Ariz. company plans to release 2003 earnings of at least $1 per share, a level required under terms of a redemption of public warrants, the company said. Wall Street had been expecting 2003 earnings of 78 cents for the year, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Taser said its market penetration in the U.S. is less than 6 percent, in contrast to a weekend Barron's article, which said the company may be reaching market saturation. Taser said Barron's never called for comment on the article, which concluded that the stock may be too pricey. Shares of Taser rose $3.64 to $133.53 on Friday. Apogee warns of Q4 loss, fiscal 2004 earns shortfall (7:58 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Apogee Enterprises APOG, +0.74% warned that fiscal fourth-quarter and 2004 results would fall short of profit expectations, due primarily to project delays and adjustments to project flow. The maker of glass products now expects to lose 8 to 11 cents a share, including one-time charges of 2 to 3 cents a share, in the quarter ending February, vs. prior projections for a profit, excluding items, of 3 to 6 cents a share. For fiscal 2004, the company now expects earnings of 19 to 22 cents a share, vs. previous forecasts of $33 cents a share. The company said it did not see any decline in its backlog. The stock closed Friday down 6 cents at $11.73. Andrew Corp. Q1 earns decline, while sales rise (7:47 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Andrew Corp. ANDW reported fiscal first-quarter net income of $3.8 million, or 2 cents a share, down from 6 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Excluding special items, such as the amortization of assets and losses on asset sales, earnings were 8 cents a share. Net sales for the quarter ending December rose 61 percent to $410.8 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $406 million, on average. The company said cost cutting and increased sales helped offset gross margin declines. The communications equipment supplier's stock closed Friday up 39 cents at $17.14. U.S. Dataworks tumbles in wake of widening Q3 loss (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Shares of U.S. Dataworks UDW, +3.77% plummeted in pre-market action after the Houston-based provider of payment processing software posted a year-over-year decline in revenue and a widening loss for the third quarter. After Friday's closing bell, the company reported a loss of $1.2 million, or 5 cents per share, on revenue of $416,000 for the latest three months. In the same period a year earlier, U.S. Dataworks lost $411,000, or 4 cents per share, on revenue of $744,000. Excluding items, the company lost $982,000 in the latest quarter. U.S. Dataworks said it was unable to close a "major licensing transaction" in the quarter as scheduled, but that it believes this deal will be completed in the next quarter. Also, the company said its transition to a per transaction revenue model from one-time license fees should lead its quarterly revenue numbers to become more consistent. The stock last changed hands on Instinet at $2.21, down 22.5 percent, on light volume of 1,000. Entergy posts Q4 loss on severance charge (7:09 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Entergy Corp. ETR, -0.28% swung to a $39.5 million, or 17 cents per share loss in the fourth quarter against the year-ago period. It said the lower results were primarily related to severance charges recorded during fourth quarter 2003. Operating profits rose to $89.2 million, or 38 cents per share vs. $77.4 million, or 34 cents per share, in fourth quarter 2002. Analysts had been looking for operating earnings of 37 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. Radware posts in-line Q4 profit of $2.5M (7:02 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Radware RDWR, +0.95% reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 13 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $500,000, or 3 cents per share, and in line with the mean estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped 25 percent in the latest three months to $15 million from $12 million in the same period a year earlier. Shares of the Israeli maker of application switching software closed Friday at $32.17, up 6 percent. Tower Semi reports wider Q4 loss (6:59 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Tower Semiconductor TSEM, +1.09% reported a fourth-quarter net loss of $46 million, or 91 cents a share, wider than the 33 cents a share it lost in the year-earlier period, due primarily to the depreciation of expenses. Revenue rose 27 percent to $19.8 million. Looking ahead, the Israel-based chip maker expects revenue of $23 to $25 million in the first quarter. The stock closed Friday up 20 cents at $6.90. Accredo Health Q2 earns rise, top forecasts (6:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Accredo Health ACDO reported fiscal second-quarter net earnings of $19.9 million, or 41 cents a share, up from 36 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and a penny a share better than the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research. Gross margins improved by 0.4 percentage points to 20.5 percent due to more sales of higher margin products. Revenue for the quarter ending December increased 5 percent to $389.8 million, just shy of the $399.9 million expected by analysts. Looking ahead, the healthcare services firm upped its fiscal 2004 earnings forecast to $1.58 to $1.63 a share from $1.57 to $1.62, and reiterated its revenue estimate of $1.5 billion to $1.55 billion, vs. current analyst projections of $1.60 and $1.53 billion, respectively. The stock closed Friday up 36 cents at $33.70. Humana reports Q4 profit that tops expectations (6:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Humana HUM, +0.48% reported fourth-quarter net income $66.3 million, or 41 cents a share, vs. a loss of a penny a share in the year-earlier period, amid "significant" improvement in its commercial business, growth in its government business and the absence of special charges. The results topped the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of 40 cents a share. Revenue rose 10 percent to $3.15 billion, ahead of analyst forecasts of $3.11 billion. Looking ahead, the health benefits company expects to earn 40 to 42 cents a share in the first quarter and $1.60 to $1.65 a share in 2004, vs. analyst projections of 37 cents and $1.64, respectively. The stock closed Friday up 3 cents at $23.33. BAA, U.K. airports operator, 3Q profit, rev higher (3:16 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- British airports operator(UK:BAA)said Monday posted a rise in profits and revenue for its third quarter. Revenue rose 4.2 percent to 499 million pounds for the quarter and operating profit rose 8 to 149 million pounds. "Passenger numbers continued to rise, retail performance has been excellent and operating costs, including increased security and maintenance expenditure, have come in on target," BAA said. M'bishi Electric profits jump on booming factory demand (3:08 AM ET) TOKYO (CBS.MW) -- Mitsubishi Electric's MIELY, +0.24% net profits jumped almost tenfold in the third quarter on booming demand for factory equipment amid increased capital spending by Japanese companies. The company said in a statement that it earned 11 billion yen ($103.8 million) in the Oct.-Dec. quarter, up 859 percent from the same period last year. Operating profits climbed more than fourfold to 27.3 billion yen from 6.12 billion yen in the year-ago period. Sales, however, fell 5 percent to 746.8 billion yen. Shares jumped 5.3 percent to 533 yen ahead of the news. Sharp net profit rises 27% on strong LCD TV sales (2:53 AM ET) TOKYO (CBS.MW) -- Sharp Corp. SHCAF, -9.61% on Monday reported a 27-percent jump in net profits in the third quarter on strong sales of LCD color TVs and other electronics products. It earned 17.76 billion yen ($168.2 million) in the quarter while operating income rose 12.1 percent from a year earlier to 32.73 billion yen. Sales hit 580.46 billion yen, up 10.3 percent from the year-ago period. The earnings were in line with analysts' estimates. It left its full-year earnings forecast unchanged. The company cited strong sales of LCD color TVs, mobile phones and digital color copiers. Shares ended down 0.4 percent at 1,896 yen ahead of the news. Miner Rio Tinto '03 adjusted earnings dip 10% on dollar (2:27 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Miner Rio Tinto RIO, +2.65% (UK:RIO)on Monday said adjusted earnings fell 10 percent to $1.382 billion -- an in-line result -- as the U.S. dollar weakened by over 30 percent against the Australian dollar, and non-ferrous metal prices only improved markedly in the second half of the year. The failure of the acid plant at Kennecott Utah Copper in the first half and the slippage of material at the Grasberg copper mine in late 2003 also contributed to the decline. Second half adjusted earnings were $100 million higher than in the first half largely as a result of higher selling prices, it said. "As we enter 2004 we see stronger markets and improved prices for key products. We will also gain from new production capacity in iron ore, coking coal, diamonds and later alumina," said Chairman Paul Skinner. ATA Holdings cuts Q4 loss to $20 million (1:24 AM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- ATA Holdings, the parent company of ATA Airlines, said Monday it slashed fourth-quarter losses to $20.2 million, or $1.72 a share, from $57.6 million, or $4.90 a share, in the same period in 2002. Indianapolis-based ATA Holdings ATAH also said 2003 was its first profitable year since 1999, with earnings of $15.8 million, or $1.34 a share, compared with a 2002 loss of $175 million, or $14.94 a share. On Friday, ATA Holdings said that it had restructured its debt and aircraft leases, saving almost $225 million in payments in 2004. ATA Airlines operates the nation's largest charter service from hubs in Chicago and Indianapolis. The company's stock closed up 3.3 percent, at $12.84, Friday. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to be active in Tuesday's trading session is Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% The world's largest maker of networking gear was expected to post a fiscal second-quarter profit of 17 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Toothpaste and soap maker Colgate Palmolive's CL, +1.24% fourth-quarter numbers are expected to show a profit of 63 cents a share. Diversified manufacturer Emerson Electric EMR, +1.49% is anticipated to report a fiscal first-quarter profit of 57 cents a share. First Data FDC, +1.07% a credit-card processor, is seen reporting earnings of 54 cents a share for its forth quarter. Fourth-quarter numbers from Mattel MAT, +0.38% are expected to show earnings of 50 cents a share. Satellite operator PanAmSat SPOT, +0.00% is seen posting a profit of 14 cents a share. Sprint FON, +5.56% is due out with fourth-quarter numbers, for which it's expected to report a profit of 37 cents a share. Wireless unit Sprint PCS PCS is expected to post a fourth-quarter loss of 12 cents a share. Incyte INCY, -1.92% said after the closing bell that it will cut 257 jobs, or 57 percent of its workforce, when it closes its Palo Alto, Calif., facility as it leaves the genomics-research business and focuses strictly on developing new drugs. The company expects to save $50 million a year in costs and take a charge of up to $47 million this year for that and other restructuring moves. Incyte also reported fourth-quarter results, posting a loss of $40.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. a loss of $67.5 million, or $1, a year earlier. Sales fell to $10.3 million from $21.1 million. For 2004, the company said revenue will come in at $7 million to $9 million. Shares of Incyte fell 7.3 percent in late trade, to $9. Earlier, Incyte Pharmaceuticals' shares rallied to close up almost 9 percent after the stock was upgraded to "overweight" from "equal-weight" by Suntrust Robinson Humphrey. In a note to clients, Suntrust said it believes the potential restructuring of Incyte's database business, and upcoming clinical progress will provide catalysts for the stock. J2 Communications JCOM, +2.07% posted a fourth-quarter net profit of $17.6 million, or 69 cents a share, on revenue of $20.5 million. Excluding taxes, the company earned $8.6 million, or 34 cents to top the 31-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. Revenue fell just shy of analysts' $20.6 million forecast. Going forward, the messaging and communications-services provider said it expects 2004 pro forma earnings of $1.65 to $1.75 a share on revenue of $100 million and $105 million. Shares of j2 added 1.7 percent in after-hours dealings to change hands for $23.80. Stun-gun maker Taser International TASR reported fourth-quarter earnings and a 2004 forecast that blew past Wall Street's expectations after the bell. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser posted earnings of $2.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. $67,498, or 2 cents a share, the year before. Sales rose to $10.8 million from $2.8 million. Two analysts polled by Reuters Research had been looking for a profit of 31 cents a share on sales of $6.4 million. For 2004, Taser said it expects sales to come in at $49 million, double that of 2003's $24.5 million. Analysts are currently looking for sales of $30.1 million for 2004. Taser's shares added $18.11, or 13.4 percent, in late trade, to $153.13. Vulcan Materials VMC, +2.58% reported a 57 percent rise in its fourth-quarter profit late Monday as strength in its construction materials and chemical businesses lifted revenue by 13 percent. Sales for the fourth quarter climbed to $657.6 million, compared with $581.3 million a year ago. Analysts expected revenue of $601.5 million, on average. Shares closed at $47.67, down 3 The Birmingham, Ala.-based company said it made $57.3 million, or 56 cents a share. A year ago, it earned $36.6 million, or 36 cents a share. From continuing operations, Vulcan earned $61 million, or 59 cents a share -- in line with the average per-share profit estimate of analysts. On Semiconductor ONNN reported a fourth-quarter net loss of 21 cents a share on sales of $279 million. During the same quarter last year, the chipmaker lost 24 cents on sales of $268.5 million. On Semi's fourth-quarter sales were consistent with preliminary figures announced last week. Shares of On Semi lost 1.3 percent to $7.35 after the bell. Atari's ATAR, +0.00% fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 24 percent on weaker sales of games for Microsoft's Xbox, Nintendo GameCube and PC platforms. The company reported net income for its third quarter, ended Dec. 31, of $23.0 million, or 19 cents a share, down 24 percent from $30.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. See full story. Shares of Atari added 5 cents in late trade, to $3.31. Aflac AFL, +0.48% posted fourth-quarter net income fell to $73 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $186 million, or 35 cents a share, the same period last year. On an operating basis, the company said net income was $262 million, or 50 cents a share, up 19 percent from a year ago. The Thomson First Call average by the 20 brokers following the Columbus, Ga.-based insurer was 50 cents. The company took a pretax loss of $257 million on its investment in Parmalat. Aflac reported revenues of $2.8 billion, up 7 percent Aflac shares rose to $39 after the bell, up 3.1 percent. Pitney Bowes PBI, -0.73% reported a fourth-quarter profit that matched company and analyst expectations, citing strength in its main office document service business and cost cutting. The company posted a fourth-quarter profit from continuing operations of $143.6 million, or 61 cents a share, versus $18.2 million, or 8 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding charges, Pitney Bowes earned 66 cents a share, which met analyst estimates. Revenue came in ahead of Wall Street targets at $1.22 billion, up from $1.16 billion a year earlier. See full story. The office document-services company's shares ended the regular session up 25 cents at $40.84. They were unchanged in very thin evening trading. Verity VRTY, +64.50% said it would buy Cardiff Software for about $50 million in cash. Both companies make software for collecting and managing business information. "We view the ability to market Verity products into Cardiff's installed base, and Cardiff's products into Verity's, to be a tremendous opportunity to cross-sell," Verity Chief Executive Anthony Bettencourt said in a press release. Verity, which rose 55 cents to $16.54 in regular-session trading before the announcement, fell to $16.38 in extremely light aft-hours trading. Dynegy DYN, -1.46% has reached an agreement to sell its Illinois utility to St. Louis-based Ameren Corp. AEE, +1.23% for $400 million in cash and $1.8 billion in assumed debt, according to a report. The deal, to be announced Tuesday, also will consist of $100 million placed in escrow that will be released to Ameren by December 2010, The Associated Press reported late Monday, quoting two unnamed sources. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter this year, the sources told the wire service on condition of anonymity. GTX Inc. GTXI, +4.72% priced late Monday an initial public offering of 5.4 million shares at $14.50 each for proceeds of $78.3 million. The pricing came in at the high end of the expected range of $13-$15. Shares of Memphis-based GTX, a maker of drugs used to fight prostate cancer, will begin trading on the Nasdaq market on Tuesday. The underwriting is being led by Goldman Sachs. TRW Automotive Holdings TRW, -3.33% priced late Monday its initial public offering of 24.1 million shares at $28 each for proceeds of $674.8 million. The pricing was at the low end of its expected range of $28-$30. The underwriting of TRW's IPO is being led jointly by Goldman Sachs, Credit Suisse First Boston and J.P. Morgan. Shares of TRW, a car parts maker based in Livonia, Mich., will start trading on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. Monday's advancers Andrew Corp. ANDW rose almost 6 percent after the company reported first-quarter net income of $3.8 million, or 2 cents a share, down from 6 cents a share in the year-ago period. Excluding items, such as the amortization of assets and losses on asset sales, earnings were 8 cents a share. Sales for the quarter ending December rose 61 percent to $410.8 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research were looking for earnings of 7 cents a share and revenue of $406 million, on average. The company said gross margin declines were offset by cost cutting and increased sales. BearingPoint BE, +0.49% gained more than 8 percent after the company reiterated its second-quarter profit target of 4 to 6 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter will exceed the top end of the previously provided guidance range of $730 million to $760 million, the company said. A survey of analysts by Thomson First Call is forecasting earnings of 7 cents per share and revenue of $741 million. The McLean, Va., consulting services provider changed its fiscal year end from June 30 to Dec. 31. Lionbridge Technologies' LIOX shares gained nearly 8 percent after the Waltham, Mass., information technology testing and globalization services posted fourth-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 2 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $1.3 million, or 4 cents per share. Excluding restructuring expenses of $565,000, the company earned $1.7 million, or 3 cents per share, in the latest three months, in line with the mean estimate of four analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose to $36.9 million in the quarter from $30 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Lionbridge forecast adjusted earnings of $2 million to $3.5 million on revenue of between $37 million and $38.5 million for the first quarter, and reiterated its outlook for a profit of $15 million to $19 million on revenue ranging from $160 million to $170 million in fiscal 2004. Nuvelo NUVO shares jumped more than 24 percent. The Sunnyvale, Calif., firm, which is partnering with Amgen AMGN, +0.01% on a product in phase II trials to treat peripheral arterial and catheter occlusion, is scheduled to report its financial results on Wednesday. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently looking for a loss of 12 cents per share in the period, on average. SBC Communications' SBC, -0.65% shares rose more than 24 percent. Banc of America is out with a research note on the company, saying a check of SBC's Web site has confirmed changes in its pricing strategy for digital-subscriber-line services. The firm said the most significant changes are SBC's decision to raise the promotional price for its low-end packages to $29.95 per month from $26.95, and its lowering of the price of its Expert Plus enhanced high-speed DSL service to $44.99 per month from $99.95. B of A said the move suggests pricing for DSL may have bottomed because SBC has been one of the most aggressive companies with regard to pricing. "We believe SBC's decision to make its higher-speed service more price competitive with cable refutes the idea that broadband is a commodity," the firm stated, adding that it believes this may be the first sign of price stabilization in the market. ScanSoft SSFT, -5.41% advanced almost 8 percent after the company raised its fourth quarter earnings and revenue forecasts citing strength in its SpeechWorks and imaging products and new partnerships in the auto and mobile device speech markets. The company now expects to earn 4 to 6 cents a share on revenue of $45 million to $47 million, vs. prior projections of 3 to 5 cents and $42 million to $44 million, respectively. The company said it would report full results on Feb. 26. Monday's decliners Shares of Ivanhoe Mines Ltd. HUGO (IVN) lost almost 25 percent after the company issued an update on its Oyu Tolgoi project in southern Mongolia. The company said an independent scoping study "confirms the potential" of the project "to become a new, long-life copper and gold producer that could rank among the largest in the world." Ivanhoe noted, however, that roughly 78 percent of resources used in the base case for the study were classified as 'inferred,' which means they have "not yet been sufficiently drilled to have economic considerations applied to them to enable them to be categorized as reserves." LCA-Vision LCAV slid more than 8 percent after the company said its revenue for the fourth quarter would be up 56 percent from its year-ago total of $13.3 million. The Cincinnati provider of laser vision correction services said revenue from its LasikPlus centers open at least 12 months jumped 44 percent in latest period from a year earlier. "During the fourth quarter we continued to gain market share, with procedure volume up more than four-fold compared with estimated industry growth rates," said Stephen Joffe, chairman and CEO of LCA-Vision, in a press release. Mitek Systems' MITK, +2.07% shares lost nearly 26 percent after the Poway, Calif., developer of fraud protection and automated check imaging applications reported a loss for the first quarter as gross margins declined due to an unfavorable product mix, and bookings came in below expectations. The company lost $1.1 million, or 10 cents per share, in the December period, on sales of $1.7 million, down from a year-ago profit of $61,000, or a penny per share, on sales of $3 million. Mitek said it hasn't seen increased spending by its core base of regional and community banks, but it remains confident that the passage of Check 21 legislation, which gives the digital image of a check the same legal standing as the original paper check, will be a catalyst for sales growth. Oglebay Norton OGLE shares plummeted more than 63 percent. Late Friday, the Cleveland-based minerals firm said it would miss an interest payment due Monday on its 10 percent senior subordinated notes due in February of 2009. The decision follows the company's admission in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its ability to complete a financial restructuring is uncertain, and that it may not be able to accomplish its goals without filing for bankruptcy protection. Oglebay and its financial and legal advisors are currently in talks with the company's bank group, and the holders of its notes. "We continue to have sufficient liquidity to operate our business," Michael Lundin, the company's president and CEO, said in a press release. "This situation does not affect our ability to pay our employees or vendors or serve our customers." See full story. Shares of Playtex Products PYX, -5.19% slumped more than 17 percent after the company said higher-than-expected restructuring charges will hit 2003 and 2004 earnings. The personal care and consumer products firm is now targeting full-year 2003 net income of 30 cents a share, well below the Thomson First Call mean estimate of 39 cents a share. The forecast includes a 5 cent per share charge for restructurings and a 2 cent per share charge, related mainly to legal costs. Previous company guidance was for a 2 to 3 cent per share restructuring charge for 2003. The company expects additional restructuring charges of $4 million in 2004. Radware RDWR, +0.95% shares dropped more than 15 percent after the Israeli maker of application switching software posted in-line quarterly results. The company reported fourth-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 13 cents per share, up from a year-ago profit of $500,000, or 3 cents per share. The performance met the mean estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue jumped 25 percent in the latest three months to $15 million from $12 million in the same period a year earlier. Targeted Genetics' TGEN, -2.05% shares slipped nearly 6 percent after the Seattle developer of gene therapy products disclosed its public offering of 10.9 million common shares for $2.35 each. The company is selling the stock to institutional investors, and it expects net proceeds of about $25.5 million from the deal. Targeted Genetics plans to use the proceeds for working capital and general corporate purposes. Time Warner Telecom TWTC gave back almost 26 percent after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $21.3 million, or 19 cents per share, narrower than its year-ago loss of $243.7 million, or $2.12 per share. The mean estimate of six analysts polled by Thomson First Call was for a loss of 24 cents per share in the December period, on average. Revenue slid in the latest three months to $169.4 million from $175.1 million in the same period a year earlier. The company attributed the drop in revenue to a decrease in inter-carrier compensation, lower revenue from WorldCom, and a slump in business from carriers and Internet service providers. Included in the latest revenue figure is $9.2 million related to the sale of a claim related to WorldCom's rejection of certain contracts. Shares of U.S. Dataworks UDW, +3.77% plummeted nearly 9 percent after the Houston-based provider of payment processing software posted a year-over-year decline in revenue and a widening loss for the third quarter. After Friday's closing bell, the company reported a loss of $1.2 million, or 5 cents per share, on revenue of $416,000 for the latest three months. In the same period a year earlier, U.S. Dataworks lost $411,000, or 4 cents per share, on revenue of $744,000. Excluding items, the company lost $982,000 in the latest quarter. U.S. Dataworks said it was unable to close a "major licensing transaction" in the quarter as scheduled, but that it believes this deal will be completed in the next quarter. Also, the company said its transition to a per transaction revenue model from one-time license fees should lead its quarterly revenue numbers to become more consistent. Workflow Management WORK, +0.00% fell more than 7 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by Perseus LLC and The Renaissance Group LLC for $4.87 a share, which represents a 5.6 percent discount to Friday's closing price. The deal is expected to close by the end of April. The provider of printing services said the decision to sell the company came after it had explored a number of ways to address its credit needs. Zoran Corp. ZRAN shares sank almost 14 percent after the company said it would further delay the release of its financial results for the fourth quarter and full year pending conclusion of its 2003 audit procedures. The Sunnyvale, Calif., chip firm now expects the release in the second half of February. The stock closed Friday at $19.18, down 7 cents. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage S&P 500 logs longest losing streak of the year as trade-war jitters weigh What America’s gun fanatics won’t tell you My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Tuesday: CSCO, FDC, PCS, INCY, TASR

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) - Shares of Incyte Pharmaceuticals fell more than 7 percent in late trading Monday after the company announced job cuts and a restructuring charge, while shares of Taser International gained more than 13 percent after it posted better-than-expected results and raised its revenue forecast. Incyte INCY, -1.92% said after the closing bell that it will cut 257 jobs, or 57 percent of its workforce, when it closes its Palo Alto, Calif., facility as it exits the genomics-research business and focuses strictly on developing new drugs. The company expects to save $50 million a year in costs and take a charge of up to $47 million this year for this and other restructuring moves. Incyte also reported fourth-quarter results, posting a loss of $40.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. a loss of $67.5 million, or $1, a year earlier. Sales fell to $10.3 million from $21.1 million. For 2004, the company said revenue will come in at $7 million to $9 million. Shares of Incyte fell 7.3 percent in late trade, to $9. Elsewhere, j2 Communications JCOM, +2.07% posted a fourth-quarter net profit of $17.6 million, or 69 cents a share, on revenue of $20.5 million. Excluding taxes, the company earned $8.6 million, or 34 cents to top the 31-cent estimate of analysts surveyed by Reuters Research. Revenue fell just shy of analysts' $20.6 million forecast. Going forward, the messaging and communications-services provider said it expects 2004 pro forma earnings of $1.65 to $1.75 a share on revenue of $100 million and $105 million. Shares of j2 added 1.7 percent in after-hours dealings to change hands for $23.80. The stock was among the most active issues being traded on Inet ECN. Close behind on the volume leaders list were shares of Taser International TASR The stun-gun maker reported fourth-quarter earnings and a 2004 forecast that blew past Wall Street's expectations after the bell. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser posted earnings of $2.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. $67,498, or 2 cents a share, the year before. Sales rose to $10.8 million from $2.8 million. Two analysts polled by Reuters Research had been looking for a profit of 31 cents a share on sales of $6.4 million. For 2004, Taser said it expects sales to come in at $49 million, double that of 2003's $24.5 million. Analysts are currently looking for sales of $30.1 million for 2004. Taser's shares added $18.11, or 13.4 percent, in late trade, to $153.13. On Semiconductor ONNN reported a fourth-quarter net loss of 21 cents a share on sales of $279 million. During the same quarter last year, the chipmaker lost 24 cents on sales of $268.5 million. On Semi's fourth-quarter sales were consistent with preliminary figures announced last week. Shares of On Semi lost 1.3 percent to $7.35 after the bell. Atari ATAR, +0.00% fiscal third-quarter earnings fell 24 percent on weaker sales of games for Microsoft's Xbox, Nintendo GameCube and PC platforms. The company reported net income for its third quarter, ended Dec. 31, of $23.0 million, or 19 cents a share, down 24 percent from $30.1 million, or 43 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. See full story. Shares of Atari added 5 cents in late trade, to $3.31. Aflac AFL, +0.48% posted fourth-quarter net income fell to $73 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $186 million, or 35 cents a share, the same period last year. On an operating basis, the company said net income was $262 million, or 50 cents a share, up 19 percent from a year ago. The Thomson First Call average by the 20 brokers following the Columbus, Ga.-based insurer was 50 cents. The company took a pre-tax loss of $257 million on its investment in Parmalat. Aflac reported revenues of $2.8 billion, up 7 percent Aflac shares rose to $39 after the bell, up 3.1 percent. Finally, Pitney Bowes PBI, -0.73% reported a fourth-quarter profit that matched company and analyst expectations, citing strength in its main office document service business and cost cutting. The company posted a fourth-quarter profit from continuing operations of $143.6 million, or 61 cents a share, versus $18.2 million, or 8 cents a share, a year ago. Excluding charges, Pitney Bowes earned 66 cents a share, which met analyst estimates. Revenue came in ahead of Wall Street targets at $1.22 billion, up from $1.16 billion a year earlier. See full story. The office document-services company's shares ended the regular session up 25 cents at $40.84. They were unchanged in very thin evening trading. And Verity VRTY, +64.50% said it would buy Cardiff Software for about $50 million in cash. Both companies make software for collecting and managing business information. "We view the ability to market Verity products into Cardiff's installed base, and Cardiff's products into Verity's, to be a tremendous opportunity to cross-sell," Verity Chief Executive Anthony Bettencourt said in a press release. Verity, which rose 55 cents to $16.54 in regular-session trading before the announcement, fell to $16.38 in extremely light aft-hours trading. The Nasdaq-100 After Hours Indicator, a barometer of late trade in the technology sector, edged down 72 points, or 0.05 percent. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, +1.07% finished the regular session up 11.11 points, or 0.1 percent, at 10,499.18, while the Nasdaq Composite $COMPQ slipped 3 points or 0.1 percent, to end at 2,063.15. See Market Snapshot. More from MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 2 sexy ways to get paid to save Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets NY Stock Exchange NASDAQ
title: Incyte shares fall, Taser shares climb after the bell

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International tasr gained more than 12 percent in after-hours trading Monday after the stun-gun maker reported fourth-quarter earnings and a 2004 forecast that blew past Wall Street's expectations. Scottsdale, Ariz.-based Taser posted earnings of $2.8 million, or 56 cents a share, vs. $67,498, or 2 cents a share, the year before. Sales rose to $10.8 million from $2.8 million. Two analysts polled by Reuters Research had been looking for a profit of 31 cents a share on sales of $6.4 million. For 2004, Taser said it expects sales to come in at $49 million, double that of 2003's $24.5 million. Analysts are currently looking for sales of $30.1 million for 2004. Taser's shares added $16.48 in late trade, to $151.50.
title: Taser beats Wall Street's Q4 forecast, ups 2004 revs

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said its current product backlog stands at $7.4 million, as the maker of stun guns also criticized a weekend article in Barron's. Later on Monday, the Scottsdale, Ariz. company plans to release 2003 earnings of at least $1 per share, a level required under terms of a redemption of public warrants, the company said. Wall Street had been expecting 2003 earnings of 78 cents for the year, according to a survey of analysts by Thomson First Call. Taser said its market penetration in the U.S. is less than 6 percent, in contrast to a weekend Barron's article, which said the company may be reaching market saturation. Taser said Barron's never called for comment on the article, which concluded that the stock may be too pricey. Shares of Taser rose $3.64 to $133.53 on Friday.
title: Taser to beat '03 EPS target;  slams Barron's article

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Thursday's session is Bank of America BAC, +2.04% The bank is expected to post fourth-quarter earnings of $1.78 a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Regional bank Comerica CMA, +1.76% is seen reporting a profit of 88 cents a share in the fourth quarter. Fourth-quarter results from Fifth Third Bancorp FITB, +0.60% are expected to show a profit of 79 cents a share. FleetBoston Financial's FBF, -11.49% is seen posting earnings of 64 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Electronic components maker Molex MOLX is expected to report a fiscal second-quarter profit of 19 cents a share. NorthFork Bancorp NFB is anticipated to post fourth-quarter earnings of 64 cents a share. Offshore oil and natural gas driller Rowan Cos. RDC, +4.43% is seen posting a profit of 6 cents a share for the fourth quarter. SLM Corp. SLM, +1.91% also known as Sallie Mae, the No. 1 provider of student loans in the nation, is expected to report a fourth-quarter profit of 49 cents a share. Financial holding company TCF Financial TCB, +0.00% is expected to report a per-share profit of 88 cents a share for the fourth quarter. Bank holding company Union Planters Corp. UPC is seen posting fourth-quarter earnings of 52 cents a share. Wachovia's WB, +3.87% fourth-quarter results are expected to show a profit of 88 cents a share. J.P. Morgan Chase JPM, +1.82% will buy Bank One ONE, -0.46% for about $60 billion in the biggest financial deal on Wall Street in six years, creating a financial services giant second only to Citigroup C, -1.11% in total assets, the companies confirmed Wednesday. The combination will create a banking group with almost $1.1 trillion in assets, just shy of the $1.2 trillion held by Citigroup and make it one of only three banks to hold more than $500 billion in customer deposits, along with the soon-to-be-merged FleetBoston FBF, -11.49% and Bank of America BAC, +2.04% See full story. Shares of J.P. Morgan fell 5 percent, but Bank One surged more than 10 percent to $49.80 in third-market action. Intel INTC, +5.00% posted better-than-predicted fourth quarter sales and profit Wednesday as strong demand for computer chips and $420 million in unexpected tax benefits helped the world's largest chipmaker surpass Wall Street's financial targets. Additionally, Intel, whose spending serves as a bellwether for the broader tech sector, projected a capital-expenditure budget of $3.6 billion to $4 billion for 2004, compared with $3.7 billion spent last year. See full story. Shares of Intel fell 3 percent to $32.44 in extended trading Yahoo YHOO turned in its ninth consecutive profitable quarter Wednesday and announced that sales nearly doubled in the holiday quarter, but shares turned lower in after-hours trading as the online media giant's results and outlook were not as upbeat as expected. Yahoo said it earned a fourth-quarter profit of $75 million, or 11 cents a share, up from $46.2 million, or 8 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expected 11 cents per share, on average. See full story. Shares of Yahoo fell 4 percent in late dealings. Apple Computer AAPL, +0.78% beat analyst estimates with better Macintosh and iPod sales that boosted revenue by 36 percent. Apple said it earned $63 million, or 17 cents a share in its fiscal first quarter. In the same period a year earlier, Apple posted a loss of $8 million, or 2 cents a share. Sales rose to $2 billion from $1.47 billion in the same period last year. Apple said it recorded an after-tax investment gain of $3 million related to its sale of shares that boosted earnings by a penny a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call estimated Apple would earn 15 cents a share on sales of $1.93 billion. See full story. In after-hours trading, Apple shares fell $1.28, or 5.5 percent, to $22.92 after closing the regular session at $24.20. Genentech's DNA, -1.03% fourth-quarter net income rose 36 percent, driven by higher sales of anticancer drugs, the No. 2 biotechnology firm reported late Wednesday. South San Francisco, Calif.-based Genentech said fourth-quarter earnings increased to $126.7 million, or 24 cents per share including charges for litigation and special items. See full story. Shares of Genentech traded at $90.70 after-hours, up slightly from its close at $90.67. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% said that the SEC had notified it of an investigation regarding allegations that arose from a civil suit filed by former employee Matthew Whitley. The Whitley case has already been settled and the beverage giant said it will continue to fully cooperate with the SEC's investigation. The company offered no details regarding the nature of the SEC investigation. Whitley, a finance director for supply management at the fountain division, was among more than 1,000 people who lost their jobs in a sweeping reorganization last March. He claimed in a wrongful termination suit that was settled in early October that he was fired because he complained about trumped-up numbers in a frozen Coke marketing test for Burger King five years ago, among other issues. See full story. Shares of Coca-Cola closed up 9 cents at $49.80. Teradyne TER, +1.96% reported fourth-quarter sales and a bottom-line result Wednesday that beat Wall Street expectations, due to a 45-percent spike in net orders. Boston-based Teradyne, a maker of test equipment used to make computer chips, posted a net loss of $11.5 million, or 6 cents a share. The company had lost $423.8 million, or $2.31 a share, in the fourth quarter of 2002. See full story. Teradyne shares fell 13 cents to close at $26.62 in regular-session Nasdaq trading. Halliburton HAL, +1.93% defended its subsidiary's fuel pricing in Kuwait late Wednesday following media reports that said the Defense Department's top auditor requested that the Pentagon begin a formal investigation. Shares of Halliburton closed down 59 cents at $27.39. Wednesday's advancers Alaris Medical AMI, +6.00% added almost 18 percent after the company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to exceed the consensus of 17 cents a share, coming in at the top end of its own forecast of 17-to-19 cents, up from 7 cents a year ago. The maker of delivery devices for intravenous medications said sales are expected to be in line with consensus estimates of about $154 million, up 15 percent from the fourth quarter of 2002 and ahead of the company's own outlook of 13 to 14 percent growth. Shares of Applied Imaging AICX soared more than 36 percent after the maker of genetic imaging systems said the Food and Drug Administration approved its test for breast-cancer patients. The test is designed to identify women whose cancer might be treated by Genentech's DNA, -1.03% Herceptin therapy. See full story. AT&T Wireless AWE, +5.26% shares tacked on almost 17 percent following a published report that the company is in talks about a possible merger or acquisition deal with Cingular. A story in the online edition of the Wall Street Journal citing people familiar with the situation said that Cingular and AT&T Wireless are in a new round of talks, but no deal is imminent and it's not known when the current discussions began. The WSJ previously reported that Cingular is mulling an initial public offering and its interest in acquiring AT&T Wireless has increased. The two companies held merger talks more than a year ago. Cingular is 60 percent owned by SBC SBC, -0.65% whose stock closed up 23 cents. Shares of I-Flow IFLO gained almost 15 percent after First Albany upgraded the medical equipment maker to "strong buy" from "buy." Analyst William Plovanic feels the recent weakness in the stock, which resulted from concerns over competition from a former distribution partner, "is unwarranted and creates a compelling investment opportunity." Plovanic has a $17 price target on the stock. He said his current financial estimates already reflect the competitive threat. The stock fell 6.6 percent Tuesday, and had lost 17 percent since Dj Orthopedics DJO launched a new portable system to control post-operative pain earlier in the month. JoS. A. Bank Clothiers JOSB advanced more than 8 percent after the company said its board has declared a 50 percent stock dividend, giving each shareholder an additional share of common stock for every two shares they already own. The dividend will be paid on Feb. 18 to shareholders of record on Jan. 30. The move will increase the Hampstead, Md., men's apparel retailer's outstanding shares to 10.5 million from 7 million. LeCroy LCRY shares leapt more than 6 percent after the maker of digital oscilliscopes reported earnings of $1.9 million, or 18 cents per share, on revenue of $29.8 million for the fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31, reversing the prior year's loss of $1.9 million, or 18 cents, generated on revenue of $26.6 million. The profit beat by two cents the consensus estimate of three analysts surveyed by Reuters Research, after the company revised its quarterly forecast higher on Jan. 6. LeCroy cited "strong" product demand and said total orders and backlog reached their highest levels in 11 quarters. For the third quarter, management is looking for operating income of about $3 million, even with the December quarter, as well as revenue of $30 million. Orchid Biosciences' ORCH, -0.49% gained more than 8 percent. Late Tuesday, the Princeton, N.J., firm filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of up to $30 million in common stock. The company noted that it has no immediate plans to offer the shares, but said it believes the filing will give it additional financial flexibility in accessing capital markets. Shares of Orthovita VITA, +3.09% rose 5 percent after the company's bone damage repair product was granted marketing approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Orthovita will partially launch its Endoskeleton product by the end of the second quarter, with full commercial availability expected later in the year. Oxigene OXGN added more than 8 percent after the company said it received $24.2 million in proceeds from the sale of 2.76 million shares of its stock to institutional investors. The stock was sold at $8.78 each, in line with Tuesday's close. The company plans to use the proceeds to accelerate the development of its lead drug candidate for use in cancer indications and for degenerative eye diseases. Plantronics PLT, +5.08% jumped almost 16 percent after the company said it earned $17.6 million in its third quarter, an increase of 91 percent from $9.2 million in the same quarter last year. It earned 37 cents a share, more than the 20 cents it earned last year and the 28 cents expected by analysts, according to Thomson First Call. The Santa Cruz, Calif., firm said sales of its headsets, equipment for the hearing-impaired and other telephone gear rose 24 percent to $107.6 million in the period, beating analysts' average estimate of $98 million. Rayovac ROV, +0.00% shares gained 6 percent after the company said it will close plants and service centers operated by its Remington unit, resulting in the elimination of 528 jobs, as it integrates the newly acquired shaving products company's operations. Rayovac also said it will move its headquarters from Madison, Wis., to Atlanta. Rayovac, which acquired Remington in September, said the loss of 217 Remington manufacturing jobs would be partially offset by creation of 130 new jobs in Madison, some of which would be filled by Remington employees. Rayovac said it expects restructuring charges against 2004 earnings of $8 million to $10 million. Rockwell Collins COL, -0.33% rallied 8 percent after the Cedar Rapids, Iowa, maker of communications and aviation electronics products raised its earnings outlook for fiscal 2004 to reflect strong organic growth in its government systems business, continued improvement in operating efficiencies, and higher than anticipated sales in its commercial systems business. The company now sees earnings of $1.50 to $1.60 per share for the year, 10 cents above its prior projection. The current average view of 18 analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of $1.49 per share in the period ending in September 2004. Sina SINA, +4.55% shares tacked on more than 9 percent after the company and Yahoo YHOO agreed to set up an Internet-based auctions service in China. The companies said the service would be geared towards small- and medium-sized businesses and buyers and sellers in the Chinese mainland. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Shares of Yahoo, which reported quarterly results after the closing bell, closed down almost 1 percent. See full story. Spectranetics' SPNC shares gained more than 7 percent after the Colorado Springs, Colo., firm said it has submitted a 510(k) application seeking clearance for the treatment of blockages in leg arteries with its proprietary excimer laser catheters to the Food and Drug Administration. The company is specifically looking for approval of the use of the catheters to treat critical limb ischemia patients, who have few treatment options and whose condition often leads to amputation. The Sportsman's Guide SGDE shares added more than 11 percent after the St. Paul, Minn., outdoor gear seller forecast earnings of 70 to 72 cents per share in the fourth quarter on sales of between $71 million and $72 million. The current average view of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 63 cents per share in the December quarter. For the full year, the company sees earnings of $1.14 to $1.16 per share on sales of between $194 million and $195 million, ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate of $1.07 per share. Taser International TASR shares advanced more than 14 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns said its board has declared a three-for-one stock split. The split will be on Feb. 10 to shareholders of record on Jan. 26. The move will increase Taser's outstanding stock to 12.67 million shares from 4.22 million shares. "The Board of Directors has declared this 3-for-1 stock split to reduce the stock's price per share and increase its market liquidity for the purpose of enhancing the securities' appeal to both private and institutional investors," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a press release. Vans VANS surged more than 8 percent after the company raised its fiscal third-quarter and 2004 earnings outlooks due to a better-than-expected holiday sales and margin performance. The shoe and casual apparel maker now expects earnings from continuing operations to be 24 to 26 cents a share for the quarter ending February and 60 to 64 cents a share for the full fiscal year, vs. prior forecasts of 20 to 22 cents and 56 to 60 cents, respectively. The company said all of its categories performed well. WCI Communities WCI, -2.49% rose almost 10 percent after the company said fourth-quarter orders rose 152 percent over year-earlier levels to $456.5 million, amid a 186 percent rise in tower homebuilding and 116 percent increase in traditional homebuilding orders. Unit orders improved 81 percent to 668. Backlog as of Dec. 31 was $947.7 million, 32 percent more than at the end of 2002. Wednesday's decliners Adolor ADLR shares plunged 37 percent after the company said a Phase III trial for its gastrointestinal treatment Entereg, which is supposed to speed post-operative bowel recovery, failed to achieve statistical significance. Shares of Advanced Marketing Services MKT, +0.00% slumped more than 15 percent to $10.90 after the San Diego provider of book publishing services said it would restate previously reported financial results for the five-year period ending March 31, 2003, reducing earnings over the period by between $5 million and $9 million. The necessity of the restatement was revealed during an ongoing review of the company's advertising practices and related accounting. Advanced Marketing said that it has tightened internal controls and secured a forbearance of the default on its revolving credit line triggered by the restatement until Jan. 30. Also, citing a weak sales mix and the ongoing costs of probes by both the SEC and U.S. Attorney's Office, the company lowered its outlook for fiscal 2004 to earnings of between 30 and 40 cents per share on sales ranging from $1 billion to $1.1 billion. The current average view of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call is for a profit of 97 cents per share. Cleveland-Cliffs' CLF, +5.30% shares fell almost 7 percent after the iron ore pellet supplier said it plans to privately sell $100 million worth of convertible preferred stock. The company plans to use the proceeds to pay down debt and make contributions to its under-funded pension plan. Separately, the company said it expects fourth-quarter losses from operations of more than $1.30 a share. Shares of Ibasis IBAS tumbled almost 12 percent after the Burlington, Mass., provider of Web-based voice communications services received a downgrade from Kaufman Bros. The firm went to "hold" from "buy" on the stock and chopped its price target in half to $1.50 from $3. Internet Security Systems ISSX tumbled more than 9 percent after the company said that its expects to post fourth-quarter sales near or slightly above the upper end of its previously-stated forecast of $66 million, but that it may have to take charges that will result in its earnings coming in below its prior forecast of 13 cents to 17 cents a share. Shares of Photogen Technologies PHGN, +1.81% sank more than 9 percent after the ultrasound imaging products company disclosed that it was notified by the Nasdaq that it failed to comply with listing requirements by not holding an annual shareholders meeting. The company said it had delayed holding an annual shareholder meeting because it was pursuing financing, and expected to present a proposal to its shareholders related to an equity financing. The Nasdaq said the stock could remain listed on the Nasdaq SmallCap Market if the company provides documentation showing it held its planned special stockholders meeting on Feb. 5, files a regulatory statement regarding an annual shareholder meeting by Apr. 15 and submits documentation regarding an annual meeting to be held by May 14. Until requirements are met, the stock will trade under the ticker "PHGNC." Shares of The Shaw Group SGR, +0.00% lost more than 5 percent after the company said first-quarter operating results were weaker than expected, as a soft domestic power market hurt sales and profitability in its engineering, construction and maintenance division. The net loss for the quarter ending November was $49.6 million, or $1.07 a share, vs. a profit of $16.5 million, or 42 cents a share in the year-earlier period. The results include a $74.2 million charge related to higher power project costs and asset depreciation. Revenue fell 35 percent to $649.2 million, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Reuters Research of $717.3 million. Synovis Life Technologies SYNO gave back more than 20 percent after the company said it expects fiscal first-quarter earnings and revenue to come in well below the current forecast of analysts. The medical device maker said it sees first-quarter sales coming in near first-quarter 2003 results of $12.5 million, but net earnings coming in below those of first-quarter 2003 levels, when the firm posted a profit of $793,000, or 8 cents a share. Analysts are currently looking for a first-quarter profit of 13 cents a share on sales of $16 million, according to Thomson First Call. Synovis also reaffirmed its guidance for the current fiscal year ending October 31, 2004, for revenue in the range of $75 million to $79 million, and earnings 56 cents to 60 cents a share. Tropical Sportswear TSIC shares fell more than 15 percent to $1.95 after the Tampa, Fla., seller of private branded apparel products reported a loss of $96.5 million, or $8.73 per share, for the fourth quarter, well below its year-ago profit of $1.3 million, or 12 cents per share. The company said sales fell to $78.2 million in the latest three months from $117 million in the same period a year earlier, and that gross margins dropped to 15.1 percent in the quarter from 26.9 percent due to "significantly higher than normal levels of closeout sales and higher levels of returns and sales allowances." Tropical Sportswear said the results in the latest quarter were also hurt by significant increases in reserves for excess inventory, charges related to the impairment of goodwill, costs from the sale of its corporate aircraft and the closure of the Duck Head retail outlet stores, charges related to the lower value of a an administration building, and severance costs for terminated executive employees.
