content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Shares of Taser International closed at a record high Wednesday after the maker of stun guns declared a three-for-one stock split. The shares rose $14.50, or 14.3 percent, to $115.75, in their heaviest trading since Taser went public three years ago. The stock split is payable Feb. 10 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 26. The move will increase Taser's outstanding stock to 12.67 million shares from 4.22 million shares, the Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company TASR said. Amid heightened security awareness and public outcry over shooting deaths, law enforcement and security companies are increasingly opting to use high-voltage slugs that can flatten attackers without causing permanent injury. Orders have sent profits into the black, and the company's stock is up threefold since mid-October. "We've been saying for a long time that (the split) was needed," said Steven Gish, analyst at Roth Capital Partners in Newport Beach, Calif. "For investors, it's a very positive sign that liquidity is available." With members of the founding Smith family and company employees holding on to more than 1 million shares, the price of Taser's 3 million actively traded shares may have been too expensive for some small-scale investors, analysts said. And large-scale stockholders have encountered difficulty breaking up large blocks of shares to sell in smaller quantities, said Joe Blankenship, an analyst with Source One Capital in Scottsdale. Though Taser executives had broadly hinted to analysts and investors that the company's board would approve splitting the stock, neither the terms nor timing had been determined until Wednesday's announcement. The three-for-one split will provide more trading liquidity than some investors had expected, Gish and Blankenship said. Though splits typically make stocks more easily tradable, the short-term boost they provide isn't always sustained or deserved, Gish said. "In this case, it's probably deserved, because it can open up the market considerably," he said. Law enforcement fuels sales, profit Last year, the Scottsdale, Ariz., company added police departments in Cincinnati, Kansas City and Charlotte, N.C., to its client list. A $1-million allocation from Congress allowed the U.S. Defense Department to send several dozen Taser guns to Iraq. The company is now waiting to fill a $3.5-million order from the United Arab Emirates. Sales tripled to $6.1 million in the third quarter from $1.9 million a year earlier, bringing the company a $1.1 million profit. Taser probably sold $6.3 million in the quarter just ended, according to a First Call survey of analysts. Taser has mainly pushed sales to military and law enforcement, but at the Las Vegas Consumer Electronics Show last week it displayed a new stun gun it plans to introduce for individual consumers. "We're not going to do it until they see more police carrying it on their hips," Chairman Phil Smith said. "I see that as a couple of years from now." The improving results and outlook have sent the stock up 25-fold in 12 months, faster than most analysts can revise their price targets. Gish said he planned to adjust his target of $60, but wondered whether the company's projected sales and profit justify the stock's triple-digit price. "It's getting expensive," Gish said. Analysts expect the company's shares to earn a split-adjusted $1.23 apiece next year, according to Thomson First Call. The resulting price-earnings ratio of 93 is one of the highest on Wall Street. The stock has also become a darling of short sellers, investors who seek to profit by betting a stock's price will decline. Such investors sell borrowed shares, hoping to repay the lender after buying shares more cheaply. As of Dec. 8, short positions amounted to 52 percent of the stock's actively traded shares, according to Multex data, compared with 14 percent for hot biotech stock ImClone Systems IMCL, +6.11% and 2 percent for software giant Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau
title: Taser shares soar on word of three-for-one stock split

content: Stock futures saw small gains after U.S. data showed a narrower-than-expected trade gap at $38 billion in November, the lowest trade gap since October 2002. U.S. exports to China were a record $3.3 billion in November. The core December producer prices rose 0.1 percent, as expected. Merger speculation resurfaced in the U.S. wireless industry, with Reuters and the Wall Street Journal reporting that Cingular's interest in acquiring AT&T Wireless AWE, +5.26% has intensified. AWE shares surged 7 percent to $9.15 on Instinet. See Indications for full pre-open action Global Markets The dollar rallied against the European currencies, up as much as 1 percent on the euro as European authorities continued to signal discomfort with the dollar's drop in recent weeks. The euro's decline lifted German auto stocks. Modest gains for the Nikkei index overnight. See Europe Markets and London Markets and Asia Markets Broker action New York shares of Nokia NOK, +0.74% were up 1 percent to $20.80. Merrill Lynch upgraded its rating to buy from neutral, and put a 19.5 euro price target on the stock. J.P. Morgan Securities downgraded Federated Dept. Stores FD to neutral, telling clients "given average consumer spending levels that should limit sales upside, the company's earnings per share growth rate is likely to remain muted." The broker raised its rating on The May Dept. Stores MAY, +0.00% See Internet's most complete source for analyst comments Breaking News - See Market Pulse for breaking news Delta Air Lines DAL, +1.63% - in one of the bigger pre-open reports - said it had a fourth-quarter loss of $327 million, or $2.69 per share, narrower than its year-ago loss of $367 million, or $2.98 per share. Excluding a number of unusual items, the Atlanta-based airline operator lost $207 million, or $1.71 per share, wider than the average estimate of 12 analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of $1.66 per share. Yahoo and Chinese Web portal Sina SINA, +4.55% late Tuesday said they have agreed to set up a Web-based auctions service in China. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. SINA rose 12 percent to $48.20 with 324,264 shares traded for a volume of over $15 million on the ARCA ECN. Dutch banking and insurance giant Fortis set plans to raise up to $1.8 billion by offering 80 million shares of its U.S. insurance unit Assurant at $20-$22 per share. The Assurant IPO plans its debut on the New York Stock Exchange as early as next month. DaimlerChrysler DCX rose 1.3 percent, less than German peers Volkswagen and BMW, as the euro retreated. Chrysler on Tuesday recalled nearly 3 million cars. In addition, Mitsubishi Motors, 37 percent owned by DaimlerChrysler, is considering requesting a 100 billion yen ($943 million) capital increase from shareholders. The Shaw Group SGR, +0.00% said first quarter operating results were weaker than expected, as a soft domestic power market hurt sales and profitability in its engineering, construction and maintenance division Shares of Orthovita VITA, +3.09% rallied 58 cents, or 17 percent, to $4 in Instinet after the company's bone damage repair product was granted marketing approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Taser International TASR said its board has declared a three-for-one stock split. "The Board of Directors has declared this 3-for-1 stock split to reduce the stock's price per share and increase its market liquidity for the purpose of enhancing the securities' appeal to both private and institutional investors." Vans VANS raised its fiscal third-quarter and 2004 earnings outlooks due to a better-than-expected holiday sales and margin performance. The shoe and casual apparel maker now expects earnings from continuing operations to be 24 to 26 cents a share for the quarter ending February. Frito-Lay, the chips division of PepsiCo. PEP, -0.03% announced a new line extension of Doritos and Tostitos brands in May that it said would use soy proteins and fiber for half the carbohydrates of its tortilla chip brands. American interest in 'low-carb' foods has increased with the popularity of the Atkins diet. Pepsi sees sales close to $3 billion from Doritos and Tostitos in the U.S. a year Before the Bell is a daily e-mailed newsletter. You can subscribe to this free email service here. content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said its board has declared a three-for-one stock split. The split will be on Feb. 10 to shareholders of record on Jan. 26. The move will increase Taser's outstanding stock to 12.67 million shares from 4.22 million shares. "The Board of Directors has declared this 3-for-1 stock split to reduce the stock's price per share and increase its market liquidity for the purpose of enhancing the securities' appeal to both private and institutional investors," said Rick Smith, the company's CEO, in a press release. Shares of the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of advanced less-lethal weaponry closed Tuesday at $101.25, down 2.1 percent. The stock has more than tripled since the beginning of October.
title: Taser declares 3-for-1 stock split

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr said it has received orders from police departments in Kansas City and Charlotte, S.C. The $245,000 order from Kansas City involves 300 Taser x26 conducted energy weapons and accessories. The Charlotte order also involves more than 300 weapons, and it's worth an estimated $280,000. The stock closed Tuesday at $82.60, down 20 cents.
title: Taser receives orders for more than 600 weapons

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Made it -- briefly. But investment letter reaction to Dow 10,000 is very mixed. Writing early Tuesday, superbear Richard Russell of Dow Theory Letters seemed to dismiss the whole subject: "For instance, every bull and every stockholder wants the Dow to close over 10,000. Why? Well, because 10,000 means and certainly feels like progress. A Dow over 10,000 just feels bullish, and why argue with that." Russell has been treating the rally with respect. But after the close, he wrote: "TODAY'S MARKET ACTION -- Not good. The Dow gave us a key reversal -- new high and then closing lower on rising volume... It's a bit early to jump to conclusions, but I haven't liked the market action the last few days. There's been an amazing amount of complacency, along with gathering optimism. The Transport's lack of confirmation [See my Dec. 8 column] has been completely ignored, and as has been the lack of volume on the most recent rise." Peter Eliades of Stock Market Cycles put out a comment not unreasonably congratulating himselves (Eliades favors the Royal Plural): "In the Barron's issue dated March 22nd, 1999, we wrote an article which they entitled "Nasty Numbers." The subtitle was "Will the curse of Dow 100 and 1000 be revisited on 10,000?"...The first two sentences of the article proclaimed: "So the Dow finally, if briefly, touched 10,000 last week. Investors should celebrate now, because they may not get another chance to do so for a decade or more." In three more months, it will have been 4 years since that article was written and despite the ridicule that we had to face at the time the article was written, it looks more and more like the article could prove to have been quite prescient..." Eliades says his esoteric numerological "price projection technique" now makes him think the Dow will probably be unsuccessful in overcoming 10,000. Tuesday night, he noted in his hotline that his "Stock-index futures traders" should now be shorting S&P futures as of the moment the Dow breached 10,000. He added: "Exit that position tomorrow only if the Dow Jones Industrial Average moves above an intraday print of 10,040." But the bulls are not impressed by the reversal. Todd Market Forecast said: "There is currently a split market. The Nasdaq has essentially been retreating for the six sessions since the peak on Dec. 1st while the Dow has been going higher. The S&P has been sideways to down. The Nasdaq could be telling us something, but we doubt it." Todd is currently buying stocks and bonds, neutral on gold. The Cabot Market Letter interests me particularly because it is one of the "geezers" - my name for letters that were around at the last bear market climax in 1974. It has been bullish for more than a year. In Tuesday night's hotline, Cabot contrasted the jubilant atmosphere when the Dow DJIA, +1.07% first exceed 10,000 with today's restraint and wrote: "In general, we see the lack of out-and-out enthusiasm as a positive sign for the market over the longer-term. So you should remain bullish, though you shouldn't hesitate to ditch a stock if it's showing clear signs of weakness." As of last night, Cabot recommended these buys: John B. Sanfilippo & Sons JBSS, -1.23% Abaxis ABAX, +2.93% Accredited Home Lenders LEND International Game Technology IGT, +0.94% Network Engines NENG TASER TASR XM Satellite Radio XMSR Editor's note: The most recent edition of the Hulbert Financial Digest is now available by either e-mail or regular mail. Highlights this month include: Which newsletters have beaten the stock market over both the short and the long terms? content: WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Yahoo Inc. has received a second subpoena in connection with Taser Inc.'s defamation lawsuit against several Yahoo users. The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based maker of stun guns TASR said information retrieved from Yahoo YHOO through a first subpoena, pertaining to the IP addresses of certain users, was not traceable. A second subpoena was issued on July 15 asking for updated information, according to a regulatory filing Friday. Taser is attempting to sue several Yahoo message board users, who used pseudonyms and allegedly made "false and defaming statements" about the company and its officers. Taser shares gained 3.6 percent to close Friday trading at $62.29. Nextel: FCC rule may hurt financial results Nextel Partners Inc. NXTP said in a filing Friday that wireless phone number portability, required by the Federal Communications Commission as of Nov. 24, may hurt its finances. The FCC is requiring wireless carriers to allow local customers in major cities to keep the same cell phone number across service providers as of late this month. Nextel Partners, an affiliate of Nextel, said the change would create a "high rate of churn," and would increase costs. "If consumer dissatisfaction results, it could adversely impact industry growth," the firm said. Shares gained 2 cents to close at $12.05. VendingData gets $1M in financing VendingData VNDC has received $1 million in bridge financing, the firm said. The financing will be used for working capital. Shares in the firm, based in Las Vegas, NV., fell 17 cents to close at $4.08. title: Yahoo subpoenaed for user IP addresses

content: SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Still a fledgling mutual fund, Touchstone Small-Cap Growth has stepped to the front of the class with strong gains. Up 55 percent since its October 2002 launch, the $35 million portfolio TESAX ranks in the top 10 percent of small-capitalization growth stock funds over the past 12 months, reports fund data firm Lipper. Co-manager Tom Barry looks for that performance to continue. He runs 30 percent of the fund, focusing on microcap stocks, and Robert Davidson, chief investment officer of Boston's Longwood Investment Advisors, picks small-cap shares for the remaining 70 percent of the fund. "All the ingredients for a continuation of this small-cap rally are in place. This should last for some time," said Barry, who is also chief investment officer of Bjurman, Barry & Associates in Los Angeles. The Touchstone Fund carries a 5.75 percent front-end load. Barry screens for fast-growing companies with low valuations that exceed financial targets. He acknowledged that any investor can pick stocks this way, but intuition is also a factor in determining what to buy and what to avoid. That and knowing when to sell. "You have to have the attitude that you don't care if you make a mistake," Barry said. "Sell your losers and sell them quick. Many people make this mistake, particularly during an up market. It's an insurance policy against quadrupling your losses." One of Barry's favorites is Taser TASR a maker of "less-than-lethal" weapons used by police departments and correctional facilities. Taser's share price has soared this year to more than $60 from $5, but so have earnings and revenues, Barry said. Taser rose $6.83, or 12 percent, on Wednesday to close at $64.63. Barry also likes another high-flyer: OmniVision Technologies OVTI, +1.49% a maker of chips used to read images, such as those in digital cameras. This stock has quadrupled this year to around $60 and trades at 60 times projected 2004 earnings, but Barry points to expanding demand and increasing earnings. Both earnings and revenue are expected to grow 100 percent in 2004. On Wednesday, OmniVision shares rose $10.77, or 22 percent, to close at $59.14, after the company raised quarterly earnings guidance. Nam Tai Electronics NTE, +2.94% a contract manufacturer and services provider to telecom and consumer electronics companies, is another company Barry likes partly because of its involvement with digital cameras. The firm declared a 10 percent stock dividend last week at the same time it announced third-quarter earnings growth of 39 percent and sales growth of 64 percent. Shares closed Wednesday up 71 cents, or 1.8 percent, at $41.01. title: Barry likes Taser, OmniVision, Nam Tai

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to see active trading in Wednesday's session is Computer Associates CA, +1.25% The software company is seen posting a second-quarter profit of 14 cents a share for fiscal 2004, according to analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Fiber-optic company Corning GLW, +1.94% is expected to report a profit of 2 cents a share for the third quarter. Dow component DuPont DD, +2.74% is seen reporting earnings of 11 cents a share for the third quarter. Third-quarter numbers are scheduled for release from Eastman Kodak EK which is expected to show a profit of 57 cents a share. JP Morgan JPM, +1.82% will report numbers for the third quarter, for which it is expected to show a profit of 57 cents a share. Semiconductor equipment maker KLA-Tencor KLAC, +2.29% is seen posting earnings of 17 cents a share for the first quarter of fiscal 2004. Lucent LU will report fourth-quarter results for fiscal 2003, and is expected to report a loss of 4 cent a share. Fast-food giant McDonald's MCD, -1.28% is anticipated posting a third-quarter profit of 40 cents a share. And drugmaker Pfizer's PFE, +0.54% third-quarter earnings are seen coming in at 44 cents a share. Amazon.com AMZN, +1.11% posted a profit of 4 cents a share in the third quarter, versus a loss of 9 cents a share in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue came in at $1.13 billion, a shade above the $1.12 billion analysts had expected. Excluding charges, the company reported earnings of 11 cents a share, besting analysts' 10-cent per-share consensus forecast. Amazon also issued an outlook for the fourth quarter, saying it sees sales coming in between $1.76 billion and $1.91 billion. See full story. Shares of Amazon lost $1.30, or 2.2 percent, to $58.05 after the bell. Wireless chipmaker RF Micro Devices RFMD earned $11.4 million, or 6 cents a share, in the second quarter of fiscal 2004. A year earlier, the Greensboro, N.C.-based company earned $6.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Sales rose 37 percent to $163.5 million from $119.7 million in the same quarter a year ago. See full story. Shares of RF Micro rose 4 percent in late dealings, to $11.88. The stock was the most-active issue being traded on Island ECN. Amgen AMGN, +0.01% reported a third-quarter profit, reversing a year-earlier loss as revenue jumped. Amgen earned $612 million, or 46 cents per share. In the 2002 third quarter, the biotech firm had lost $2.6 billion, or $2.10 per share, because of charges related to the Immunex buyout. Amgen said profit in the latest quarter, excluding one-time items, was $714 million, or 53 cents per share. Analysts, on average, expected profit of 51 cents per share, according to Reuters Research. Total revenue increased 47 percent to $2.2 billion. Shares of Amgen shed 2.8 percent, to $61.88. Boston Scientific BSX, +2.40% said that third-quarter profit revenue jumped 21 percent, but profit slipped because of an unfavorable comparison with the year-ago quarter when a one-time gain was recorded. The medical device maker earned $124 million, or 29 cents per share, compared with $161 million, or 39 cents per share, in the 2002 third quarter. The year-ago profit was boosted by a special after-tax credit of $62 million. See full story. Boston Scientific shares rose $1.16 in late trading action, to $65. Internet Security Systems ISSX reported a third-quarter profit of $5 million, or 10 cents a share, versus $6.3 million, or 13 cents a share, the year before, as sales slipped to $60.1 million from $60.8 million. The computer security services firm also said that it expects to post earnings of between 13 cents and 17 cents a share in the fourth quarter, on sales of $61 million to $66 million. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are expecting earnings of 13 cent a share on sales of $62.9 million. For the full year, the company sees earnings of 50 cents to 54 cents a share on sales of $240 million to $245 million; analysts are forecasting earnings of 50 cents a share on sales of $240.8 million. Internet Security shares added $1.88, or 13 percent, to $16.35 after the bell. Washington Mutual WM, +1.13% reported third-quarter earnings of $1.03 billion or $1.12 a share. The results, up nearly 5 percent from $981 million or $1.02 a share reported in 2002, met expectations of analysts polled by Thomson Financial First Call, who had foreseen $1.12 a share. Loan volume jumped 73 percent to $130.6 billion for the quarter, while volume for home equity loans and lines of credit increased 167 percent to $9.65 billion, WaMu said. However, the nation's largest savings and loan also reported a $126 million loss from mortgage loans, which it said was due to volatility in interest rates. Shares added 28 cents to $40.47 after the bell. InVision Technologies INVN, -2.64% reported third-quarter profit fell 57 percent to $9.3 million, or 50 cents a share, from $21.5 million, or $1.17, a year ago. The Newark, Calif.-based maker of airport security and bomb-detection equipment beat the 47-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue came in at $86 million, down 26 percent from $117.1 million a year earlier. See full story. Shares closed Tuesday down 4 cents to $25.60 before the announcement. Schlumberger SLB, +2.48% said it lost $55 million, or a 9 cents a share, versus income $172.84 million, or 29 cents a share, in the third quarter of a year ago. Revenue improved to $3.51 billion from $3.39 billion a year ago. From operations, income in the third quarter was $242 million, or 41 cents a share. Analysts polled by Reuters Research expected, on average, per-share earnings of 39 cents and revenue of $3.64 billion. See full story. Shares closed at $51.36, up $1.52, or 3.1 percent, ahead of the announcement. Roper Industries ROP, +1.52% said late Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Neptune Technology Group Holdings in a deal valued at $475 million. The maker of machinery monitoring systems will buy Neptune from investment group Investcorp for $475 million, net of cash acquired and including the assumption of debt. Roper also announced a financing plan in connection with the deal, including loans, a credit facility and the issuance of debt and equity. Roper expects the acquisition to add between 10 cents and 15 cents a share in earnings for the full year 2004, before charges. The deal is expected to close in early 2004. Shares of Roper ended Tuesday's session down 10 cents at $46.48 Avaya AV., -0.38% a developer of corporate-phone systems, reported its second straight quarterly profit Tuesday on further cost cutting and a slight rebound in sales. The company earned $66 million, or 15 cents a share in its fiscal fourth quarter ended Sept. 30, reversing a loss of $544 million, or $1.50, a year earlier. See full story. Avaya stock added 70 cents to $14.15 in after-hours trade. LeapFrog Enterprises LF posted a 25 percent rise in its third-quarter net income but came up short of analyst targets as results were hindered by lower-than-expected domestic sales growth. The educational toy maker posted a profit of $33.4 million, or 55 cents a share, up from $26.7 million, or 50 cents a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Wall Street had pegged LeapFrog to earn 61 cents a share. See full story. At last check, shares of LeapFrog had fallen $9.58, or 20.6 percent, at $36.96. Lumenis LUME the Israel-based maker of laser eye treatments, said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration gave marketing clearance to the its Allegretto Wave laser, used to treat myopia, or nearsightedness, and hyperopia, or farsightedness. The clearance was granted to Lumenis Germany-based marketing partner, WaveLight Laser Technologie. Lumenis will be the exclusive sales agent for the laser product in the U.S. Shares of Lumenis soared 61 cents, or 34.1 percent, to $2.40 after the bell. Storage Technology STK, +1.48% posted a third-quarter net profit of $31 million, up from $23.9 million a year ago. The data-storage company earned 28 cents a share, which was in line with estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, and above the 22 cents-a-share profit in the year-ago quarter. Revenue grew to $520.3 million from $501.7 million, but missed analysts' consensus estimates of $528.3 million. Shares edged down 21 cents to $26.50. Halliburton HAL, +1.93% responded to congressional critics late Tuesday, saying the price it's charging the U.S. Army for fuel deliveries in Iraq is "fair and competitive." In a statement, Halliburton said its contract allows for only a 2 percent markup over actual costs and noted that transporting fuel in Iraq is inherently dangerous. Fuel convoys are escorted by U.S. armed forces. Halliburton's KBR unit is handling the contract. See full story. Rising costs and a tax bill increase in Illinois clipped Boyd Gaming BYD, +1.69% in the third quarter as the casino operator reported a nearly 30 percent slump in profits. Las Vegas-based Boyd reported earnings of $7.7 million, or 12 cents per share, after Tuesday's closing bell, down from $11.2 million, or 17 cents a share, a year ago. See full story. Shares fell 20 cents to $15.10 in light after-hours trading. Tuesday's advancers America West Holdings AWA, -1.82% surged more than 19 percent after the company said it earned $32.9 million, or 60 cents a share, in the third quarter, up from a loss of $49.6 million or $1.47 a share, a year ago. The parent of America West Airlines was expected to earn 28 cents, according to the average of estimates collected by Thomson First Call. The airline reported a record third quarter load factor of 79.8 percent, an increase of 4.9 percentage points from the same period last year. ATA Holdings ATAH jumped almost 18 percent after the company reported third-quarter net income of $6.57 million, or 50 cents a share, vs. a loss of $5.18 a share in the year-earlier period. Total operating revenue rose 22 percent to $387.7 million. Revenue passenger miles increased 16 percent, available seat miles rose 16 percent and costs per available seat declined 18 percent. Celera CRA, +6.25% shares rose nearly 9 percent after Robert Baird upped the stock to "outperform" vs. "neutral" and said recent positive developments at the company, including Monday's news of an alliance with Merck, are not reflected in its price. Shares of CenterPoint Energy CNP, +1.67% surged more than 5 percent after the company reported a third-quarter profit vs. a year-ago loss. In the most recent quarter, CenterPoint earned $182 million, or 59 cents a share, vs. a loss of $4.1 billion, or $13.77 a share, in the third quarter of 2002. Coach COH, +6.26% advanced almost 8 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $42.3 million, or 22 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $22.5 million, or 12 cents per share, and 4 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales jumped 34 percent in the latest three months to $258.4 million from $192.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the New York-based leather goods firm anticipates earnings of at least 44 cents per share on sales of at least $385 million for the second quarter. For the year, Coach sees earnings of at least $1.09 per share on sales of at least $1.2 billion. The current average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson First Call are for profits of 42 cents and $1.00 per share in these respective periods. EarthLink ELNK gained more than 13 percent after the company reported third-quarter net income of $3.5 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. a loss of 20 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Earnings before special acquisition-related items were 16 cents a share. Total revenue rose 2 percent to $347.4 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 6 cents a share and revenue of $347.4 million, on average. The Internet access provider said it added 71,000 net subscribers in the quarter. Looking ahead, the company expects to add 100,000 to 175,000 net subscribers in the fourth quarter and projects revenue of $1.4 billion for the full year. Everest Re Group RE, -0.58% rose 8 percent after the Barbados-based reinsurance firm reported strong third-quarter results, and boosted its outlook for the full year. The company earned $126.2 million, or $2.23 per share, on an operating basis in the third quarter. This performance sailed past Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of $2.05 per share in the period. For the year, Everest Re now sees earnings of $10 to $11 per share. Shares of scientific consulting firm Exponent EXPO, +0.51% soared more than 18 percent after Roth Capital upped the stock to "buy" from "neutral" following a strong third-quarter earnings report late Monday. Exponent reported a better-than-expected 35 percent increase in earnings and 15 percent rise in revenues. JDA Software JDAS soared nearly 23 percent after the company said its third-quarter profit rose 78 percent on stronger U.S. demand for its software for retailers. See full story. Keryx Biopharmaceuticals KERX, +1.49% jumped more than 21 percent after the company said it has initiated a multi-center phase II clinical trial of its KRX-101 treatment for diabetic nephropathy. The news was greeted by an upgrade from Ryan Beck to "outperform" from "market perform." Shares of Ligand Pharmaceuticals LGND, +1.94% rose almost 7 percent after Friedman Billings upped the stock to "market perform" from "underperform", citing improving competitive conditions for its sustained-release painkiller Avinza. Analyst Jim Reddoch said news Monday that the Food and Drugs Administration is demanding more data on Endo Pharmaceuticals' Oxymorphone is a positive as it would have been a rival to Avinza from the first quarter of 2004. Logitech LOGI, +0.30% gained nearly 20 percent after the Swiss digital communications technology firm reported second-quarter earnings of $21.2 million, or 44 cents per share, on revenue of $294 million. The company said the performance was its second-strongest ever, exceeding its own expectations for both revenue and operating income. Logitech attributed the strong earnings to a sequential improvement in gross margins. A single analyst polled by Thomson First Call was looking for a profit of 23 cents per share in the September period. Loudeye LOUD shares soared almost 19 percent on heavy volume. The company was mentioned in a recent version of The Calandra Report, a subscription service of Marketwatch.com, the publisher of this report. U.S. Dataworks UDW, +3.77% which jumped more than 15 percent, was also mentioned in the report. Monaco Coach MNC, -38.46% surged more than 15 percent after the company reported third-quarter net income of $6.3 million, or 21 cents a share, down from 40 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 3.7 percent to $303.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 9 cents a share and revenue of $268.8 million. The recreational vehicle maker said a strong retail market and a reduction in finished goods inventory led to better than expected revenue and improved production rates. Pumatech PUMA, +0.00% rose more than 6 percent after the company inked a licensing pact with Alcatel ALA, +0.59% The deal calls for a customized version of Pumatech's Intellisync software to be bundled with Alcatel's One Touch Suite line of GSM mobile phones beginning this month. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Retek RETK shares rose more than 18 percent after the Minneapolis maker of retailing software posted breakeven per share results on an operating basis for the third quarter, beating the consensus estimate of 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of a penny per share. Without items, the company was able to scrape out a scant profit of $66,000 in the latest period, much better than its year-ago equivalent loss of $9.5 million, or 18 cents per share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $43.8 million from $40.5 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said gross margins improved during the quarter due to a favorable revenue mix, and higher services utilitization. Looking ahead, Retek forecast between breakeven results and a profit of 2 cents per share on an operating basis on revenue of between $44 million and $46 million in the fourth quarter. Taser International TASR shares rose more than 13 percent, pulling back slightly after hitting a 52-week high of $51.91 earlier in the session. After Monday's closing bell, the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns reported third-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 25 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $68,896, or 2 cents per share, and well ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 14 cents per share. Revenue jumped 216 percent in the latest three months to $6.1 million from $1.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Taser added that it has already received an additional $1.7 million in orders to ship in the fourth quarter. It attributed the strong results to growing market acceptance of its products in both the U.S. and abroad. Looking ahead, the company boosted its sales outlook for 2003 to $20 million, up from its prior projection of between $13 million and $15 million in revenue. Taser is now targeting basic earnings per share of $1 per share for the year. Texas Genco Holdings TGN, +0.00% leapt more than 17 percent after the electric power company raised its full-year 2003 earnings forecast to $1.50 to $1.60 a share from $1.10 to $1.30 a share, citing higher capacity auction prices and the return to service of two generating units. For the third quarter, the company's earnings were $1.03 a share, up from 4 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Texas Genco is 81-percent owned by CenterPoint Energy CNP, +1.67% which reported third-quarter earnings of 60 cents a share, up from last year's 54 cents, and nearly double the average analyst estimate of 31 cents, according to Reuters Research. Texas Instruments TXN, +1.94% pushed more than 6 percent higher after the company reported a third-quarter profit of $447 million, or 25 cents a share, and revenue of $2.53 billion, versus $188 million, or 11 cents a share, on revenue of $2.25 billion the year before. The chipmaker's results include an expected 13 cent-a-share tax benefit. For the fourth quarter, TI predicted it would report earnings between 14 and 19 cents a share and sales of between $2.49 billion and $2.7 billion. Analysts are currently expecting earnings of 11 cents a share, on average, on sales of $2.49 billion, according to Thomson First Call. See full story. Shares of Vion Pharmaceuticals VION soared almost 41 percent after the company said it licensed its anti-cancer and anti-viral drug Triapine to Beijing Pason Pharmaceuticals for use in China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao. As part of the agreement, which is subject to governmental approval, Vion will receive an initial payment of $500,000, a potential $4.75 million in milestone payments and royalty payments of 11 percent of Triapine revenue. Beijing Pason will fund the clinical development necessary to garner regulatory approval in the territory. Xenova Group XNVA shares gained nearly 12 percent after the Slough, England-based firm reported positive findings for its OX40 technology in the treatment of flu. OX40 is a platform technology capable of generating a range of potential drugs to treat cancer, autoimmune and other diseases affecting the immune system, the company explained in a statement. Xenova said research carried out by London's Imperial College found that in pre-clinical trials, OX40 can alleviate flu symptoms without affecting the ability to clear the virus. Tuesday's decliners AT&T T, +0.25% dropped more than 5 percent after the company said net income in the third quarter rose to $418 million, or 53 cents per share up from 27 cents a share in the year-ago period. Operating income declined to $458 million vs. $525 million a year ago as margins declined on pricing pressure and weak retail demand, among other reasons cited. Revenue declined 8.1 percent to $8.6 billion, "primarily due to continued declines in long distance voice revenue, partially offset by the continued success of AT&T Consumer Services' bundled local and LD offering, as well as growth in several key markets of AT&T Business Services," the carrier said. The decline in revenue was in line with analyst expectations, according to Reuters Research. Blockbuster BBI, +4.00% lost almost 11 percent after the company reported third-quarter earnings of $63.7 million, or 35 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $51 million, or 28 cents per share, and 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of 12 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The Dallas-based movie rental firm said revenue edged lower in the latest quarter, sliding to $1.38 billion from $1.39 billion in the same period a year earlier. Brinker International EAT, +0.03% slumped nearly 13 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $44.6 million, or 45 cents per share, 2 cents short of the average estimate of 20 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 12.5 percent in the latest three months to $870.9 million from $773.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The Dallas-based operator of casual dining restaurants, including Chili's and Macaroni Grill, also forecast earnings of 44 to 45 cents per share for the second quarter, below Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 49 cents per share. Shares of Edwards Lifesciences EW, +2.01% fell almost 6 percent after the company was hit by a trio of downgrades following disappointing third quarter earnings late Monday. The medical device company reported EPS of 34 cents, a penny below consensus, and said full year sales will fall short of its goal of 7-9 percent growth. Analyst Glenn Novarro at Banc of America cut the stock to "neutral" from "buy" and lowered his 2004 EPS estimate and longer-term EPS growth forecast. Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan also cut their ratings on the stock. Fargo Electronics' FRGO shares plummeted more than 10 percent after the Minneapolis plastic card technology firm posted third-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 19 cents per share, flat with its performance in the same period a year earlier, and in line with Wall Street's consensus view. However, for the fourth quarter, the company sees earnings of 12 to 16 cents per share, well below the current average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 20 cents per share. Fargo said its earnings in last year's fourth quarter benefited from substantial shipments related to major government projects. It doesn't expect similar shipments to occur in this year's period. Nasdaq-listed shares of French drug delivery technology maker Flamel Technologies FLML dropped almost 10 percent after the company said a licensing agreement with GlaxoSmithkline GSK, -0.79% will be terminated from January 14, 2004. "GSK has informed us that they have decided to stop the augmentin sachet project for commercial reasons," said Flamel CEO Dr. Gerard Soula. "There has been no adverse performance of, or other issues with, our Micropump(R) technology and we continue to actively collaborate with GSK for the development of a once-a-day Coreg(R) formulation," Soula added in a press release. J2 Global Communications' JCOM, +2.07% shares dove nearly 24 percent after the provider of messaging and communications services reported third-quarter earnings of $7.2 million, or 28 cents a share, compared with $3.9 million, or 16 cents a share, in the same period last year. Sales soared as well, to $18.9 million from $12.5 million. J2 said it expects to report a fourth-quarter profit of 31 cents a share on sales of $20.3 million, and full-year earnings of $1.03 a share on sales of $71.4 million. Analysts are currently looking for fourth-quarter earnings of 34 cents a share, and full-year earnings of $1.05 per share. (An earlier version of this item incorrectly reported the full-year earnings estimate for J2 Global.) Trizetto Group TZIX fell more than 8 percent after the company said it expects full year earnings to come in at the low end of its target range. Trizetto, which offers software and consulting services to the health care industry, provided the outlook as it reported third quarter earnings a penny ahead of consensus. But revenues of $76 million were below the First Call consensus of $78.2 million as the company continued to refocus on its more profitable businesses. Trizetto said it expects EBITDA growth of 25-35 percent in 2004. Verisity Ltd. VRST dropped more than 9 percent after the Mountain View, Calif., developer of verification automation technology reported third-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 11 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $3.9 million, or 18 cents per share, and in-line with Wall Street's consensus view. Revenue slid 14 percent in the latest three months to $12 million from $14 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Verisity forecast earnings of 10 to 11 cents per share on revenue of between $12.1 million and $12.3 million for the fourth quarter. This is below the current average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 13 cents per share in the December period. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Wednesday: CA, AMZN, KLAC, MCD, RFMD

content: Schlumberger posts Q3 loss (6:42 PM ET) DALLAS (CBS.MW) -- Schlumberger SLB said it lost $55 million, or a 9 cents a share, vs. income $172.84 million, or 29 cents a share, in the third quarter of a year ago. Revenue improved to $3.51 billion from $3.39 billion a year ago. From operations, income in the third quarter was $242 million, or 41 cents a share. Analysts polled by Reuters Research expected, on average, per-share earnings of 39 cents and revenue of $3.64 billion. Shares closed at $51.36, up $1.52, or 3.1 percent, ahead of the announcement. WaMu profit rises (5:27 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Washington Mutual reported third-quarter earnings of $1.03 billion or $1.12 a share. The results, up nearly 5 percent from $981 million or $1.02 a share reported in 2002, met expectations of analysts polled by Thomson Financial First Call, who had foreseen $1.12 a share. Loan volume jumped 73 percent to $130.6 billion for the quarter, while volume for home equity loans and lines of credit increased 167 percent to $9.65 billion, WaMu WM said. However, the nation's largest savings and loan also reported a $126 million loss from mortgage loans, which it said was due to volatility in interest rates. Storage Technology Q3 earnings rise to $31 mln (4:31 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Storage Technology STK on Tuesday posted a third-quarter net proft of $31 million, up from $23.9 million a year ago. The data-storage company earned 28 cents a share, which was in line with estimates of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, and above the 22 cents-a-share profit in the year-ago quarter. Revenue grew to $520.3 million from $501.7 million, but missed analysts' consensus estimates of $528.3 million. InVision profit falls 57 percent, still beats estimates (4:29 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- InVision Technologies INVN reported third-quarter profit fell 57 percent to $9.3 million, or 50 cents a share, from $21.5 million, or $1.17, a year ago. The Newark, Calif.-based maker of airport security and bomb-detection equipment beat the 47-cent average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue came in at $86 million, down 26 percent from $117.1 million a year earler. Shares closed Tuesday down 4 cents to $25.60 before the announcement. Compuware swings to Q2 loss (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Software developer Compuware CPWR fell to a loss in its fiscal second quarter from a year-ago profit, on lower revenue and increased spending on marketing and sales. The Detroit-based company said it lost $8.5 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. a profit of $33.8 million, or 9 cents, in the year-ago period. The figure in the latest period matched the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue dropped to $302.75 million from $358 million; the consensus forecast was $303.9 million. RF Micro earns $11.4 million, beating expectations (4:26 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW)- RF MicroDevices RFMD a maker of chips for cell phones and other wireless devices, said late Tuesday that it earned $11.4 million, or 6 cents a share, in the second quarter of fiscal 2004. A year earlier, the Greensboro, N.C.-based company earned $6.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Sales rose 37 percent to $163.5 million from $119.7 million in the same quarter a year ago. Shares of RF Micro closed ahead of the announcement up 2.6 percent at $11.42. They rose 6.7 percent to $12.18 in after-hours trading. Avaya boosts profit on cost cuts, sales improvement (4:14 PM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Avaya, a developer of corporate-phone systems, said Tuesday it earned $66 million, or 15 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, including a onetime gain of $46 million. It was the second straight quarterly profit and reversed a loss of $544 million, or $1.50, in the year-ago period. While the net profit surpassed the 4-cent consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call, Avaya did not break out a per-share figure excluding the onetime gain. Revenue, meanwhile, was basically flat compared to the year-earlier period, but it rose 4.3 percent to $1.12 billion from the prior quarter. Results at Avaya AV also got a boost in part by continued cost cuts. Amgen swings to Q3 profit, tops expectations (4:13 PM ET) BOSTON (CBS.MW) -- Amgen AMGN late Tuesday posted a third-quarter profit, reversing a year-earlier loss as revenue jumped. Amgen earned $612 million, or 46 cents per share. In the 2002 third quarter, the biotech firm had lost $2.6 billion, or $2.10 per share, because of charges related to the Immunex buyout. Amgen said profit in the latest quarter, excluding one-time items, was $714 million, or 53 cents per share. Analysts, on average, expected profit of 51 cents per share, according to Reuters Research. Total revenue increased 47 percent to $2.2 billion. Amazon turns Q3 profit, tops rev targets (4:09 PM ET) SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Amazon.com AMZN turned a profit of 4 cents a share versus a loss of 9 cents a share a year ago. Revenue came in at $1.13 billion, a shade above the $1.12 billion analysts had expected. For the fourth quarter, Amazon predicted sales of between $1.76 billion and $1.91 billion. Shares of Amazon.com closed down 24 cents at $59.35 ahead of the announcement. Boston Scientific's Q3 profit off, tops target (4:06 PM ET) BOSTON (CBS.MW) -- Boston Scientific BSX late Tuesday said that third-quarter profit fell to $124 million, or 29 cents per share, compared with $161 million, or 39 cents per share, in the 2002 third quarter. The year-ago profit was boosted by a special after-tax credit of $62 million. The medical device maker said profit in the latest period, excluding special charges, was $137 million, or 32 cents per share. Boston Scientific had been expected to earn 29 cents per share, according to the average estimate of analysts polled by Reuters Research. Texas Genco, CenterPoint surge following Q3 reports (2:05 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Texas Genco Holdings TGN surged $3.60, or 15 percent, to $27.65 on volume of 805,000 shares - which was 13 times the full-day average - after the electric power company raised its full-year 2003 earnings forecast to $1.50 to $1.60 a share from $1.10 to $1.30 a share, citing higher capacity auction prices and the return to service of two generating units. For the third quarter, the company's earnings were $1.03 a share, up from 4 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Texas Genco is 81-percent owned by CenterPoint Energy CNP which reported third-quarter earnings of 60 cents a share, up from last year's 54 cents, and nearly double the average analyst estimate of 31 cents, according to Reuters Research. CenterPoint shares were gaining 61 cents, or 6.4 percent, to $10.08. Both stocks reached new yearly highs in intraday trading. Health Management targets FY '04 EPS of $1.35-1.37 (1:34 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Health Management Associates HMA said it expects EPS of $1.35-1.37 for fiscal 2004, compared with the Thomson First Call consensus of $1.35. In a statement outlining its goals for the year, the health care company said it expects revenues of $3.0-3.2 billion and EBITDA of $700-715 million. Same-store admissions growth is forecast at 2-5 percent, same-store surgeries growth at 1-3 percent and same-store revenue growth at 5-8 percent. HMA is targeting capex of $155-165 million and aiming to make at least 5 acquisitions. On a quarter-by-quarter basis, the company is targeting EPS of 29 cents in the first quarter, 37 cents in the second quarter, 36 cents in the third quarter and 34 cents in the fourth quarter. Mellon Q3 net slips on charges, but meets Street goal (12:59 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Pittsburgh-based financial services firm and parent of fund family Dreyfus, Mellon Financial MEL, said Tuesday its third quarter net income fell versus year-ago levels after it took about $50 million in severance and other charges. The company posted third quarter net income of $181 million, or 42 cents per share, compared to earnings of $186 million, or 43 cents share a year ago. The third quarter results were in line with analysts estimate, according to data compiled by Reuters Research. Mellon shares slipped 23 cents, or 0.7 percent to $32.22 early Tuesday afternoon. Heartland's Q3 earns rise, exceed expectations (12:23 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Heartland Express HTLD reported third-quarter net income of $14.5 million, or 29 cents per basic share, up from 22 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Operating revenue rose 15 percent to $104.5 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 26 cents a share and revenue of $102.7 million, on average. Shares of the trucking company spiked up 51 cents, or 2.1 percent, to $25.11, after being down as much as 29 cents in intraday trading. Logitech soars following Q2 report (12:16 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Logitech LOGI shares rose more than 15 percent to $38.30 after the Swiss digital communications technology firm reported second-quarter earnings of $21.2 million, or 44 cents per share, on revenue of $294 million. The company said the performance was its second-strongest ever, exceeding its own expectations for both revenue and operating income. Logitech attributed the strong earnings to a sequential improvement in gross margins. A single analyst polled by Thomson First Call was looking for a profit of 23 cents per share in the September period. Lucent leads NYSE most actives list ahead of Q4 results (12:12 PM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Lucent Technologies LU edged up 3 cents, or 1.2 percent, to $2.51, and was the NYSE's most-active issue with 36.5 million shares traded. Lucent is slated to reveal results on Wednesday, with analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call expecting a loss of 4 cents a share and revenue of $2.16 billion, on average. Sanford Bernstein analyst Paul Sagawa believes the telecommunications equipment company will report better than anticipated fiscal fourth quarter results, citing seasonal factors and the belief the company was able to recognize $200 million from a recent CDMA deployment. He believes Lucent's fiscal first quarter outlook will be "cautious." Fulcrum Global Partners' John Anthony also expects the company to exceed expectations due to stronger then anticipated sales in its wireless infrastructure and optical divisions, improved gross margins and lower operating expenses. CenterPoint shares surge after Q3 report (11:51 AM ET) DALLAS (CBS.MW) -- Shares of CenterPoint Energy CNP rose 8 percent to $10.23 after reporting a third-quarter profit vs. a year-ago loss. In the most recent quarter, CenterPoint earned $182 million, or 59 cents a share, vs. a loss of $4.1 billion, or $13.77 a share, in the third quarter of 2002. Everest Re jumps on positive Q3 performance (11:37 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Everest Re Group RE shares rose more than 6 percent to $81.55 after the Barbados-based reinsurance firm reported strong third-quarter results, and boosted its outlook for the full year. The company earned $126.2 million, or $2.23 per share, on an operating basis in the third quarter. This performance sailed past Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of $2.05 per share in the period. For the year, Everest Re now sees earnings of $10 to $11 per share. Verisity posts in-line Q3; sees Q4 below views (10:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Verisity Ltd. VRST dropped more than 12 percent to $11.18 in morning action. After Monday's closing bell, the Mountain View, Calif., developer of verification automation technology reported third-quarter earnings of $2.3 million, or 11 cents per share, down from its year-ago profit of $3.9 million, or 18 cents per share, and in-line with Wall Street's consensus view. Revenue slid 14 percent in the latest three months to $12 million from $14 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Verisity forecast earnings of 10 to 11 cents per share on revenue of between $12.1 million and $12.3 million for the fourth quarter. This is below the current average estimate of eight analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 13 cents per share in the December period. Breakeven results send Retek shares higher (10:27 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Retek RETK shares rose more than 24 percent to $10.78 after the Minneapolis maker of retailing software posted breakeven per share results on an operating basis for the third quarter, beating the consensus estimate of 13 analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a loss of a penny per share. Without items, the company was able to scrape out a scant profit of $66,000 in the latest period, much better than its year-ago equivalent loss of $9.5 million, or 18 cents per share. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $43.8 million from $40.5 million in the same period a year earlier. The company said gross margins improved during the quarter due to a favorable revenue mix, and higher services utilitization. Looking ahead, Retek forecast between breakeven results and a profit of 2 cents per share on an operating basis on revenue of between $44 million and $46 million in the fourth quarter. Taser trounces Q3 earnings expectations (9:55 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International TASR shares rose more than 11 percent to $48.78, pulling back slightly after hitting a 52-week high of $50.40 earlier in the session. After Monday's closing bell, the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns reported third-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 25 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $68,896, or 2 cents per share, and well ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 14 cents per share. Revenue jumped 216 percent in the latest three months to $6.1 million from $1.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Taser added that it has already received an additional $1.7 million in orders to ship in the fourth quarter. It attributed the strong results to growing market acceptance of its products in both the U.S. and abroad. Looking ahead, the company boosted its sales outlook for 2003 to $20 million, up from its prior projection of between $13 million and $15 million in revenue. Taser is now targeting basic earnings per share of $1 per share for the year. Fargo sees Q4 earnings well below views (9:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Fargo Electronics' FRGO shares tumbled almost 17 percent to $12.98 after the Minneapolis plastic card technology firm posted third-quarter earnings of $2.5 million, or 19 cents per share, flat with its performance in the same period a year earlier, and in line with Wall Street's consensus view. However, for the fourth quarter, the company sees earnings of 12 to 16 cents per share, well below the current average estimate of five analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 20 cents per share. Fargo said its earnings in last year's fourth quarter benefited from substantial shipments related to major government projects. It doesn't expect similar shipments to occur in this year's period. America West Q3 earns 60c, well ahead of consensus (9:17 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- America West Holdings AWA said it earned $32.9 million, or 60 cents a share, in the third quarter, up from a loss of $49.6 million or $1.47 a share, a year ago. The parent of America West Airlines was expected to earn 28 cents, according to the average of estimates collected by Thomson First Call. CEO W. Douglas Parker said "posting our second consecutive profitable quarter provides continued confirmation of America West's turnaround." The airline reported a record third quarter load factor of 79.8 percent, an increase of 4.9 percentage points from the same period last year. Passenger revenue per available seat mile during the third quarter increased 14.3 percent to 7.83 cents, while passenger yields rose 7.3 percent to 9.81 cents. The company said it intends to increase capacity by 8 to 10 percent during 2004 and will launch its first nonstop transcontinental service later this month. Alaska Air Q3 earns $1.52 vs 47c; consensus was $1.17 (8:55 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Alaska Air Group ALK said it earned $40.7 million, or $1.52 a share in the third quarter, up from $12.5 million or 47 cents a share, a year ago. The parent of Alaska Airlines was expected to earn $1.17, according to the average of estimates collected by Thomson First Call. CEO Bill Ayer said the company was "encouraged by these numbers, but (we) have considerable work to do to return to profitability on a full-year basis. Alaska Airlines passenger traffic in the third quarter increased 12.3 percent on a capacity increase of 9.3 percent. Alaska's load factor increased 2.0 percentage points to 72.5 percent compared to the same period in 2002. The company said earnings were helped by the government's temporary waiver of security fees. Excluding government compensation received in 2003 and a write-off of goodwill in 2002, the company's net loss for the first nine months of 2003 was $14.7 million versus a loss of $24.4 million for 2002. Charles Schwab beats by penny in Q3 (8:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Charles Schwab SCH reported third-quarter adjusted earnings of $147 million, or 11 cents per share, up from its year-ago equivalent profit of $99 million, or 7 cents per share, and a penny ahead of the average estimate of 16 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue at the San Francisco-based brokerage services firm rose 3 percent in the latest three months to $1.05 billion from $1.02 billion in the same period a year earlier. Including a charge related to restructuring and a gain from its European discontinued operations, Schwab earned $127 million, or 9 cents per share, in the September quarter. The company attributed the revenue growth to continued improvement in the market environment during the quarter, and it noted that it saw sequential increases in every revenue category. Schwab said it's seeing "multiple signs that clients are re-engaging with their financial affairs, including more than $10 billion of net inflows into actively managed equity and balanced mutual funds from April through September, a 21 percent increase in margin loan balances during that same period, and increased trading activity." The stock closed Monday at $13.80, up 1.6 percent. Brinker misses in Q1; sees Q2 EPS below views (8:44 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Brinker International EAT reported first-quarter earnings of $44.6 million, or 45 cents per share, 2 cents short of the average estimate of 20 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose 12.5 percent in the latest three months to $870.9 million from $773.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The Dallas-based operator of casual dining restaurants, including Chili's and Macaroni Grill, also forecast earnings of 44 to 45 cents per share for the second quarter, below Wall Street's current consensus estimate for a profit of 49 cents per share. The stock closed Monday at $33.81, down 32 cents. Boise Cascade tops Wall St. estimate by penny (8:30 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW)-- Boise Cascade BCC posted a third-quarter profit before special charges of $30.0 million, or 43 cents per diluted share, versus a profit of $8.5 million, or 9 cents per diluted share, in the same period last year. The results beat the analysts' consensus estimate of 42 cents. Sales in third quarter 2003 increased 9 percent to $2.11 billion, compared with $1.94 billion in the year-ago period. The stock closed Monday up 2 cents at $28. Wells Fargo falls a penny short in Q3 (8:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Wells Fargo WFC reported third-quarter earnings of $1.56 billion, or 92 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $1.44 billion, or 84 cents per share, but a penny short of the average estimate of 24 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue at the San Francisco-based banking services firm jumped 19 percent in the latest three months to $7.2 billion from $6.1 billion in the same period a year earlier. The company said it took "a number of strategic actions" in the period - re-positioning its bond portfolio, retiring $1.8 billion in debt, and contributing roughly 40 percent of its public stock portfolio to the Wells Fargo Foundation - that reduced earnings by $171 million, or 10 cents per share, in the latest quarter. Wells Fargo expects these moves to benefit its future financial performance. The stock closed Monday at $55.37, up 37 cents. LSI Industries Q1 earns 16c, penny ahead of consensus (8:25 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- LSI Industries Inc LYTS said it earned $2.6 million, or 16 cents a share, in the first quarter, up from a loss of $16.33 million, or $1.02 a share a year ago. The outdoor lighting company was expected to post earnings of 15 cents, according to the average of estimates collected by Thompson First Call. Sales rose 5.5 percent to $59.1 million. CEO Bob Ready said the pulse of business activity had improved in several of the company's markets. Ready said the company would introduce a new product at the company's Nov. 13 shareholders meeting that "based upon initial meetings with select customers, holds substantial promise for the future." Dominion reports Q3 net loss (8:20 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Dominion D reported a third-quarter net loss on a generally accepted accounting principles basis of $256 million, or 79 cents a share, vs. income of $430 million, or $1.54 a share. Adjusted for special items, such as Hurricane Isabel-related restoration expenses and the impairment of assets, the gas and electric holding company earned $1.30 a share, matching the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call. Operating revenue rose 12 percent to $2.86 billion. The stock closed Monday down 20 cents at $62. UPS tops in Q3; offers strong outlook for Q4 (8:13 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- United Parcel Service UPS reported a strong jump in its third-quarter earnings due to improvement in its U.S. package business, and "record" performances from its international and non-package operations. The Atlanta-based package delivery firm reported third-quarter earnings of $739 million, or 65 cents per share, on revenue of $8.31 billion, up from its year-ago profit of $578 million, or 51 cents per share, on revenue of $7.75 billion. Excluding items, UPS earned 62 cents per share, 2 cents ahead of the average estimate of 19 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Looking ahead, the company said it expects volume growth of 2 to 4 percent in the U.S., and earnings of 65 to 70 cents per share for the fourth quarter. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of 66 cents per share in the December quarter. The stock closed Monday at $68.75, up 27 cents. Bank One's Q3 EPS tops consensus by 4 cents (8:10 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Bank One ONE posted a third-quarter net profit of $883 million, or 79 cents a share, up from the $823 million, or 70 cents, earned in the same period last year. Total revenue for the Chicago-based institution increased 5 percent, topping $2.1 billion. Bank One's quarterly profit came in four cents ahead of the Wall Street consensus. Earnings per share grew faster partly as a result of the repurchase of more than 13 million common shares in the latest quarter. "We experienced momentum in many of our businesses," said Chairman and CEO Jamie Dimon. Bank One's shares ended Monday's action at $42.01, up 52 cents. SBC profit, sales decline in third quarter (8:05 AM ET) WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- SBC Communications SBC on Tuesday said it earned $1.22 billion, or 37 cents a share, in the third quarter, compared with $1.71 billion, or 51 cents, a year ago. That fell below the 39-cent consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Revenue dropped to $10.24 billion from $10.56 billion a year earlier. Carlton board: Green to go after ITV merger done (8:00 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- The Board of Carlton Communications(UK:CCM)said it was committed to Michael Green remaining chairman until the completion of its merger with Granada(UK:GAA)to form the new ITV. The deal is expected to close at the end of the year. Green and the Carlton board said they "remain committed to the completion of the merger and intend to play a full and active role in this process." The board intends to support a demand from institutional shareholders led by Fidelity to replace Green once the ITV deal is done. The board said "it will be giving an undertaking to Fidelity and other shareholders accepting their request that an independent non-executive chairman from outside Carlton and Granada should be appointed chairman designate of ITV Plc to take on that role on the completion of the merger." Carlton shares were last up close to 2 percent in London. LaBranche suspends dividend on Q3 profits decline (7:54 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- LaBranche & Co Inc. LAB the leading New York Stock Exchange specialist, said it's board was suspending dividend payments "until profitability returns to acceptable levels." Third quarter revenue decline to $70.9 vs. $118.3 million in the 2002 third quarter. Net income declined to $2.3 million, or 4 cents a share vs. $19.8 million, or 33 cents. Earnings were in line with LaBranche, which warned on profits earlier this month. Marsh & McLennan net income rises 19 percent (7:52 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - Insurer and parent to mutual fund giant Putnam Investments March & McLennan MMC said Tuesday its third quarter net rose 19 percent amid an overall pickup in business. The company posted third quarter net income of $357 million, or 65 cents per share, compared to earnings of $306 million, or 55 cents share a year ago. According to data compiled by Reuters Research, the analysts it polled expected the company to earn 65 cents per share. HCA's Q3 earns, revenue rise over year-earlier levels (7:50 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- HCA HCA reported third-quarter net income of $306 million, or 61 cents a share, up from 38 cents a share in the year-earlier. Results include a penny per share gain from the sale of a facility. Revenue rose 11 percent to $5.5 billion, as admissions increased 3.9 percent. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been forecasting earnings of 61 cents a share and revenue of $5.46 billion. Looking ahead, hospital operator lowered its long-term earnings per share growth target after 2004 to the "low double digit" percentage range from the "mid-teens," and expects to reduce 2004 capital expenditures to $1.8 billion from 2003's $2 billion. Earnings for 2004 are expected to be $2.85 to $2.95 a share, below current analyst projections of $3.06 a share. The stock closed Monday up 60 cents at $38.35. Ameritrade fiscal Q4 tops by one cent, outlook in line (7:46 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Ameritrade Corp. AMTD the Omaha-based online discount broker, said it has raised its projections for the fiscal year 2004 to earnings of 31-57 cents per share. Analysts had been estimating earnings for the year at 51 cents a share, on average. The broker posted fiscal fourth quarter net income of $55 million, or 13 cents a share. It was loss-making in the quarter a year-ago. Analysts polled by Reuters Research were expecting earnings of 12 cents, on average, for the fourth quarter. O'Charley's sees Q4 earnings ahead of views (7:45 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- O'Charley's CHUX expects fourth-quarter earnings before items of 15 to 18 cents per share, ahead of the current average estimate of 11 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The Nashville, Tenn., casual dining restaurant operator also said it has completed a $50 million sale and leaseback transaction, and authorized the repurchase of up to $25 million worth of its common stock. The shares closed Monday at $16, up 10 cents. U.S. Bancorp Q3 rises, in line with forecasts (7:38 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.S. Bancorp USB said third-quarter net income rose to $984.9 million vs. $860.3 million for the third quarter of 2002, or to 51 cents a share, up 13 cents. Earnings were in line with the consensus forecast from analysts for 51 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. The banking group said earnings improved largely due to growth in net interest income and fee based products and services, as well as controlled operating expense and lower credit costs. Blockbuster posts Q3 net of $63.7M, ahead of consensus (7:35 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Blockbuster BBI reported third-quarter earnings of $63.7 million, or 35 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $51 million, or 28 cents per share, and 3 cents ahead of the average estimate of 12 analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The Dallas-based movie rental firm said revenue edged lower in the latest quarter, sliding to $1.38 billion from $1.39 billion in the same period a year earlier. The stock closed Monday at $21.50, down 1.2 percent. ATA Holdings turns a Q3 profit (7:28 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- ATA Holdings ATAH reported third-quarter net income of $6.57 million, or 50 cents a share, vs. a loss of $5.18 a share in the year-earlier period. Total operating revenue rose 22 percent to $387.7 million. Revenue passenger miles increased 16 percent, available seat miles rose 16 percent and costs per available seat declined 18 percent. The stock closed Monday up 4 cents at $8. EarthLink reports profitable Q3 (7:22 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- EarthLink ELNK reported third-quarter net income of $3.5 million, or 2 cents a share, vs. a loss of 20 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Earnings before special acquisition-related items were 16 cents a share. Total revenue rose 2 percent to $347.4 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 6 cents a share and revenue of $347.4 million, on average. Gross margins increased 1.8 percentage points to 62.4 percent due to lower telecommunications costs per subscriber. The Internet access provider said it added 71,000 net subscribers in the quarter. Looking ahead, the company expects to add 100,000 to 175,000 net subscribers in the fourth quarter and projects revenue of $1.4 billion for the full year. The stock closed Monday up 19 cents at $7.52. DaimlerChrysler affirms 03 outlook, sales lower on euro (7:19 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Automaker DaimlerChrysler DCX (DE:710000)said affirmed its expectations for group operating profit of around 5 billion euros for 2003, but added that "significant market risks remain." It expects revenue for the year to decline to around 138 billion euro vs. 149.6 billion in 2002, citing the stronger euro against the dollar. Its outlook for Chrysler Group was maintained, with DCX detailing that Chrysler "is still striving to achieve a slightly positive operating profit on an ongoing basis. However, there are substantial risks due to the competitive environment in the U.S. The launch of nine new products next year offers more positive prospects for 2004." Shares eased 0.4 percent to 31.80 euros in home market Frankfurt. DaimlerChrysler Q3 sales down 5%, op profit lower (7:14 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Automaker DaimlerChrysler DCX (DE:710000)said third quarter operating profit declined to 1.25 billion euros vs. 1.5 billion in the third quarter of 2003 (or $1.45 billion vs. $1.8 billion). The decline was worse than the average forecast of operating profit of 1.4 billion euros, according to Reuters Research. It swung to a 1.7 billion euro loss on the quarter, reflecting a charge on its EADS holdings, as expected. Chrysler Group swung back to operating profit at 147 million euros, "primarily due to the successful implementation of further cost-reduction measures and lower increases in customer incentives than had originally been anticipated." Group revenue declined 5 percent to 34.6 billion euros, reflecting lower unit sales and the weaker dollar. Adjusted for exchange-rate effects, revenue was up 3 percent, it said. RadioShack exceeds Q3 earns estimate (7:11 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) - RadioShack RSH reported third-quarter net income of $57 million, or 34 cents a share, up from 25 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and above the average analyst estimate of 32 cents a share, according to Reuters Research. Total sales increased 2 percent to $1.06 billion, vs. analyst expectations of $1.09 billion, while comparable-store sales rose 3 percent. The consumer electronics retailer said both total sales and gross margin percentage increased in the same quarter for the first time in 19 quarters. Looking ahead, the company expects to earn 67 to 70 cents a share in the fourth quarter, surrounding analyst expectations of 69 cents. The stock closed Monday up 86 cents at $30.56. Coach tops Wall St. view for Q1 by 4c (7:08 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Coach Inc. COH reported first-quarter earnings of $42.3 million, or 22 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $22.5 million, or 12 cents per share, and 4 cents ahead of Wall Street's consensus estimate. Sales jumped 34 percent in the latest three months to $258.4 million from $192.8 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the New York-based leather goods firm anticipates earnings of at least 44 cents per share on sales of at least $385 million for the second quarter. For the year, Coach sees earnings of at least $1.09 per share on sales of at least $1.2 billion. The current average estimates of analysts polled by Thomson First Call are for profits of 42 cents and $1.00 per share in these respective periods. The stock closed Monday at $31.44, up a penny. Health Mgmt's Q4 earns rise, match expectations (7:03 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Health Management Associates HMA reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $69.8 million, 28 cents a share, up from 24 cents a share in the year-earlier period, an in line with the average analyst estimate, according to Reuters Research. Net patient revenue rose 11 percent to $657.6 million, vs. analyst expectations of $660.3 million. Total admissions increased 4.8 percent. The rural hospital operator's stock closed Monday down 8 cents at $22.52. AT&T Q3 rev drops 8%, in line with forecasts (7:01 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- AT&T T said net income in the third quarter rose to $418 million, or 53 cents per share up from 27 cents a share in the year-ago period. Operating income declined to $458 million vs. $525 million a year ago as margins declined on pricing pressure and weak retail demand, among other reasons cited. Revenue declined 8.1 percent to $8.6 billion, "primarily due to continued declines in long distance voice revenue, partially offset by the continued success of AT&T Consumer Services' bundled local and LD offering, as well as growth in several key markets of AT&T Business Services," the carrier said. The decline in revenue was in line with analyst expectations, according to Reuters Research. Quest Diagnostics' Q3 earns, revenue rise (6:54 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Quest Diagnostics DGX reported third-quarter net income of $120 million, or $1.12 a share, up from 87 cents a share in the year-earlier period, and above the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of $1.08 a share. Revenue rose 15 percent to $1.2 billion, matching expectations. Revenue per acquisition increased 38 percent, due primarily by improvement in test and payer mix. Looking ahead, the provider of diagnostic testing services for the healthcare industry expects fourth-quarter earnings of 95 cents to $1 a share, vs. analyst forecasts of $1. Revenue is expected to grow 13 to 14 percent. The stock closed Monday up 67 cents to $60.50. Regal Entertainment's Q3 earns rise, but miss estimates (6:32 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Regal Entertainment RGC reported third-quarter net income, excluding special items, of $44.2 million, or 31 cents a share, up from 29 cents a share in the year-earlier period, but a penny a share shy of the average analyst estimate, according to Reuters Research. Total revenue rose 10 percent to $629.9 million, just below analyst expectations of $631.4 million. Film rental and advertising expenses rose 9 percent to $225.8 million. The theater operator's stock closed Monday down 11 cents at $19.55.
