Monaco Coach's Q3 earns, rev. decline but top estimates (6:18 AM ET) NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Monaco Coach MNC reported third-quarter net income of $6.3 million, or 21 cents a share, down from 40 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 3.7 percent to $303.2 million. Analysts surveyed by Reuters Research had been expecting earnings of 9 cents a share and revenue of $268.8 million. The recreational vehicle maker said a strong retail market and a reduction in finished goods inventory led to better than expected revenue and improved production rates. Looking ahead, the company expects revenue of $290 million to $300 million in the fourth quarter and $1.2 billion to $1.26 billion in 2004, vs. analyst expectations of $272.5 million and $1.2 billion, respectively. The stock closed Monday down 36 cents at $19.29. Electrolux lower on Q3, may close U.S. plant (4:43 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Appliance maker Electrolux ELUX (SE:000010381)dropped 5.3 percent in Stockholm after it said third quarter net income dropped 38.1 percent to SEK767 million ($98 million), as sales eased 4.3 percent to SEK30.387 billion. The net result includes an already flagged SEK293 million charge for loan guarantees for launderettes in Germany, but still came in under expectations. Electrolux said it expect market demand for appliances in the fourth quarter to be flat or slightly up in both Europe and North America, and said it may close a U.S. plant, which would result in a charge of SEK1.2 billion U.K. chip designer ARM 'uncertain' on license rebound (2:58 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. chip designer ARM Holdings(UK:ARM) ARMHY said Tuesday that despite improving expectations emerging in the third quarter for the semiconductor industry for sales, it remains "uncertain as to how quickly an improvement in industry conditions will feed through to sustained levels of higher licensing activity for ARM." The company posted 1 percent rise in third quarter revenue over the second quarter to £31.7 million. Revenue was down 5 percent over the year-ago period. Profit before tax was £6.8 million vs. £6.6 million in the second quarter and down from £8 million in the third quarter of 2002. Eurotunnel Q3 operating revenue declined 6% (2:51 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- Eurotunnel(UK:ETL), operator of the Channel Tunnel rail link between Britain to France, said in an update Tuesday that operating revenue in the third quarter dropped 6 percent against the same quarter a year ago to £146.8 million, compared to a decline of 9 percent in the second quarter. "Weak market conditions have continued to make the third quarter difficult for the whole industry. However, we have been able to increase or maintain our market shares, and to slow the rate of revenue decline compared to the second quarter," the group said. Allied Domecq annual earnings down, sees 04 on track (2:46 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- U.K. drinks group Allied Domecq(UK:ALLD) AED Tuesday posted a 3 percent rise in annual pre-tax profit to £495 million, topping the average estimate from analysts for a 1 percent rise. Including exceptional charges and goodwill, earnings declined to £340 million from £392 million a year ago. Sales rose 2 percent -- or 6 percent on a constant currency basis -- to £3.410 billion. Looking ahead, the company said: "There are continued uncertainties in the world economy and the Eurozone remains difficult. We are confident, however, that our business is well positioned to meet the challenges. Early indications are that the 2004 financial year has started well and we are on track to meet current expectations." Schneider posts Q3 sales decline, sues EC over bid nix (2:13 AM ET) LONDON (CBS.MW) -- French electrical equipment group Schneider Electric(FR:012197)on Tuesday said third quarter sales eased 2.5 percent to 2.211 billion euros, hit by currencies and by "sluggish" economic conditions in Western Europe. Asian sales grew the fastest due to growth in China and a recovery in industrial markets in Japan. Going forward, it expects improving sales on a constant basis for the full year. Separately, it has filed a 1.5-1.6 billion euro suit against the European Commission over its thwarted bid last year for French rival Legrand, the Financial Times said. Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares rose more than 11 percent to $48.78, pulling back slightly after hitting a 52-week high of $50.40 earlier in the session. After Monday's closing bell, the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of stun guns reported third-quarter earnings of $1.1 million, or 25 cents per share, up from its year-ago loss of $68,896, or 2 cents per share, and well ahead of the average estimate of two analysts polled by Thomson First Call for a profit of 14 cents per share. Revenue jumped 216 percent in the latest three months to $6.1 million from $1.9 million in the same period a year earlier. Taser added that it has already received an additional $1.7 million in orders to ship in the fourth quarter. It attributed the strong results to growing market acceptance of its products in both the U.S. and abroad. Looking ahead, the company boosted its sales outlook for 2003 to $20 million, up from its prior projection of between $13 million and $15 million in revenue. Taser is now targeting basic earnings per share of $1 per share for the year.
title: Taser trounces Q3 earnings expectations

content: Among the companies whose shares are expected to be active in Thursday's session is consulting services provider Charles River Associates CRAI, +2.69% The company is expected to post a third-quarter profit of 33 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Entegris ENTG, +2.05% a maker of semiconductor manufacturing products, will report fiscal fourth-quarter results, with a profit seen coming in at 2 cents a share. Personal care products maker Helen of Troy HELE, +3.51% will post results for the second quarter, for which it is expected to post earnings of 36 cents a share. UTStarcom UTSI, +2.71% a maker of wireless and wireline switching equipment, raised its financial targets after Wednesday's closing bell. Only a week after repeating third-quarter financial targets, UTStarcom said it surpassed its goals and will do the same in the fourth quarter, thanks to stronger-than-expected growth in China. See full story. Shares rose $2.79, or 8.7 percent, to $34.70 on Island ECN. After Wednesday's close, Digi International DGII, -2.37% raised its fourth-quarter forecast above Wall Street's current expectations after the bell. The maker of hardware that connects computers and other devices said it now expects to report earnings of 7 cents to 8 cents a share on sales of $26 million to $26.2 million. Two analysts polled by Thomson First Call had been anticipating a profit of 6 cents a share on sales of $25.5 million. The company's prior forecast called for earnings of 4 cents to 6 cents a share on sales of $24.5 million to $25.5 million. Digi did not cite a reason for the higher forecast. Shares added 87 cents, or 12.8 percent, to change hands at $7.67 in after-hours trading. Heading in the opposite direction were shares of KVH Industries KVHI, +0.00% The satellite communications company said third-quarter per-share results will be in the range of "breakeven to a modest loss," largely due to lower-than-anticipated military revenue. KVH also said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to show only a "modest profit," with revenue growth of 30 percent to 50 percent. Shares of KVH fell $3.44 to $21.76. Management at financial software-maker Intuit INTU, +1.42% left the door open to report either a wider-than-expected fiscal first-quarter loss, or one that would slightly exceed expectations. See full story. Shares of Intuit slipped a penny, to $49.21. AK Steel Holding AKS, +5.84% said it will likely report a loss of 82 cents to 86 cents per share for its third quarter, wider than the loss-per-share estimate of 59 cents among analysts polled by Thomson First Call. The Middletown, Ohio-based steel products manufacturer cited a "less favorable product mix," as well as continued higher raw material and energy costs as factors likely to contribute to the wider loss. AK Steel also said it'll likely see a noncash charge of about $190 million on an aftertax basis, equating to $1.75 per share, for the third quarter. Online DVD rental firm Netflix NFLX, +3.35% said that its third-quarter subscriber total rose to 1.29 million, up by 74 percent from the prior year and by 13 percent from its second-quarter total. Household penetration in the San Francisco Bay Area rose to 5.4 percent, higher than 3.5 percent a year earlier and better than the 5 percent seen at the end of June. See full story. Netflix shares rose $2.19, or 6.3 percent, to $36.70 in after-hours trading. Guess Inc. GES, -0.81% said after the bell that sales at stores open longer than a year catapulted 13.5 percent for the four weeks that ended Sept. 27. Total sales surged 21.5 percent to $32.2 million from $26.5 million in the same period a year ago. For the third quarter, same-store sales climbed 13.2 percent while total sales jumped 20.5 percent to $114.2 million compared to $94.8 million last year. Shares of Guess ended the session off 8 cents at $8.82 Forest Labs FRX, -1.85% said it was dropping development of an experimental drug treatment for irritable bowel syndrome. Forest said it made the decision based on the results of two late-stage clinical trials. Shares of Forest fell $1.31, or 2.6 percent, to $48.69 in late dealings. Public Service Enterprise Group PEG, +1.78% the Newark, N.J.-based utility holding company, priced an offering of 8.25 million common shares at $41.75 each. Gross proceeds would exceed $344 million. The company said it expects to use net proceeds for repayment of short-term debt and other general corporate purposes. The stock is expected to be issued on Oct. 7, with underwriters granted overallotment options totaling an additional 1.2375 million common shares. Shares of Public Service Enterprise Group ended Wednesday's trading at $42.13, up 13 cents. Spanish-language television and radio giant Univision Communications UVN, +0.00% said it has agreed to buy WLIR-FM from Jarad Broadcasting and the Morey Organization for about $60 million in cash. The deal is expected to close in the first quarter of 2004. Shares of Univision traded unchanged from their 4 p.m. close of $32.56. IBM IBM, +0.60% cut about 700 jobs from its U.S. global services division on Wednesday, according to media reports. The company referred to the move as "skills rebalancing," a regular effort to match workers' skills with its services, according to Reuters. The world's largest computer company's services division, which provides consulting and outsourcing services, employs about 180,000 people around the world. Shares of IBM ended Wednesday's session up 2.3 percent at $90.35. Wednesday's advancers Actuant ATU, +1.97% shares rallied almost 8 percent after the Milwaukee-based diversified industrial firm reported fourth-quarter earnings of $10 million, or 82 cents per share, beating Wall Street's consensus view by 4 cents. The company also declared a two-for-one stock split. Sales rose 22 percent in the latest three months to $148.2 million from $121.4 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, Actuant forecast earnings of $3.20 to $3.50 per share on a pre-split basis with sales for between $625 million and $650 million for fiscal 2004. For the first quarter, it sees earnings of 71 to 76 cents per share on sales ranging from $155 million to $160 million. Thomson First Call's consensus estimates for these respective periods are for earnings of $3.29 and 78 cents per share. The split will be paid Oct. 21 to shareholders of record on Oct. 10. Antigenics AGEN, -0.21% shares climbed nearly 8 percent after the biotech company said results of Phase II trials of its cancer vaccine Oncophage showed a "significant" cancer-specific immune response. Antigenics said the results, published today in the Journal of Immunology, also showed the immunological mechanism of action is the same for both melanoma and colorectal cancer. Oncophage has already received fast track and orphan drug status from the Food and Drug Administration. ATI Technologies ATYT added almost 7 percent following news that the company will pay $9 million to Cirrus Logic CRUS, +3.31% this October 2003 as part of a settlement agreement. The companies said all outstanding claims and counterclaims in both lawsuits between Cirrus Logic and ATI were dismissed and that Cirrus Logic will transfer to ATI a portion of its patent portfolio relating to the former graphics products group of its PC products division. Christopher & Banks CBK, +1.90% gained nearly 10 percent after the company said September same-store sales rose 3 percent. Total sales for the four weeks ended Sept. 27 jumped 21 percent to $30.2 million from $24.9 million in the same period a year earlier. The Minneapolis-based women's clothing retailer said it was "pleased" with its performance for the month, and that it continues to plan for a low single digit increase in same-store sales for the rest of the year. Cirrus Logic CRUS, +3.31% leapt almost 11 percent after the company said it now sees fiscal second quarter revenue at the top end of its original expectations for revenue growth in a range of $45 million to $50 million, up from $41 million in the first quarter. It said it sees total cash at the end of the second quarter at $127 million, higher than the company's revised guidance of $113 million to $118 million, amid settlements and stock sales. Clear Channel Communications CCU, +2.26% rose more than 5 percent Wednesday after the company's CEO reaffrimed its earnings outlook at a meeting Tuesday. CEO Lowry Mays told attendees at the Goldman Sachs Communacopia Conference Tuesday that the company's earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) would grow in the mid-to-high single-digit range in the third quarter of 2003 versus the same period a year ago. Deckers Outdoor DECK, -0.22% shares surged more than 12 percent after the company said it expects third-quarter results to meet or beat the current Wall Street consensus estimate for a loss of 5 cents per share. The Goleta, Calif., footwear firm now anticipates revenue of $23 million to $23.5 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30, up from its prior projection of between $19 million and $20 million. Deckers attributed the better than expected performance to growth in its Ugg brand business, and continued strength in its Teva brand business. Eli Lilly LLY, +0.47% shares gained more than 6 percent after the company said additional studies would not be needed to obtain U.S. approval of its Cymbalta anti-depressant. Financial Federation FIF, +1.35% rose almost 7 percent after the leasing company topped fourth quarter estimates by 2 cents, buoyed by an improvement in repossession levels and net charge-offs. The company posted fourth quarter EPS of 38 cents against a First Call consensus of 36 cents. CEO Paul Sinsheimer said reposessions declined by 32 percent in the quarter, while past dues fell 25 percent, non-accruals by 4 percent and net charge-offs by 5 percent. However, "new business opportunities were soft due to the weak economy," he said. Immucor BLUD leapt more than 7 percent after the company reported first-quarter earnings of $3.7 million, or 27 cents per share, up from its year-ago profit of $3 million, or 23 cents per share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Revenue rose in the latest three months to $27.3 million from $23.3 million in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the Norcross, Ga., maker of blood transfusion-related products said it expects earnings of $17.1 million to $18.5 million, or $1.20 to $1.28 per share, for fiscal 2004 on revenue of between $108 million and $111 million. Wall Street's current consensus estimate is for a profit of $1.24 per share for the year. Indevus Pharmaceuticals' IDEV, +0.97% shares rose nearly 5 percent Wednesday after data published in the Journal of the American Medical Association showed the company's IP 751 painkiller, made with a synthetic cannabinoid compound, worked without causing adverse psychoactive side effects. "We believe this trial may represent a significant step forward in the evolution of an innovative pain therapy," the company said in a press release. Taser International TASR shares rose more than 10 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz., firm said the Defense Department has received $1 million for the purchase of the company's less-lethal conducted energy weapons. Taser explained the funding is part of the fiscal 2004 Defense Appropriations Bill approved by Congress and signed into law by President Bush on Tuesday. 3Com COMS gained more than 9 percent on heavy volume after the company and Chinese joint venture partner Huawei Technologies worked out an agreement to stay copyright infringement litigation filed by Cisco Systems CSCO, +2.95% against Huawei. The deal calls for Huawei to modify certain of its router and switch products then submit them to an independent review by an expert panel. VaxGen VXGN shares rallied almost 5 percent after the company said it had been awarded a contract for the advanced development of its anthrax vaccine candidate. The three-year contract, from the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, is valued at $80.3 million. VaxGen plans to manufacture the protein antigen used in the vaccine candidate, known as rPA102, in its South San Francisco facility, which the company said can produce about 100 million doses of the bulk vaccine a year. Wednesday's decliners Computer Horizons CHRZ lost more than 5 percent after the company said it expects to post a third-quarter operating loss of 1 cent to 3 cents a share on sales of between $63 million and $65 million. The company's previous forecast had called for operating income of 2 cents to 4 cent a share on revenue of between $66 million and $68 million. The company cited "a continued decline in the IT services market and softness in the overall technology market" as reason for the shortfall. Constellation Brands' STZ, +3.37% shares dipped more than 5 percent after the company reported a second-quarter profit of $34.7 million, or 34 cents a share, versus earnings of $49.6 million, or 53 cents a share, the year before. The results included a restructuring and other one-time charges of 30 cents a share. Sales soared 32 percent, to $909 million from $690 million, buoyed by its acquisition of Australian wine company Hardy. Constellation said it expects to post third-quarter results, excluding items, of 76 cents to 80 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson First Call are currently expecting a profit of 80 cents a share. Exfo Electrical Optical Engineering EXFO, +1.20% dropped almost 10 percent after the company posted a loss of $10.1 million, or 16 cents a share, versus a loss of $3 million, or 5 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Charges related to cost cuts totaled $3.8 million. Excluding items, Exfo's loss was $2.7 million, or 4 cents a share, versus a loss of $1.2 million, or 2 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2002. The results beat the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson First Call by a penny. Sales fell to $14.3 million in the quarter from $17.2 million the year before. The Canadian fiber-optics firm also said that it expects to report a net loss of between 7 cents and 10 cents a share in the first quarter on sales of between $13 million and $16 million. Hollis-Eden Pharmaceuticals' HEPH shares lost nearly 20 percent after Legg Mason initiated coverage of the company with a "sell" rating and a $10 price target. The firm said it believes the shares do not represent an attractive investment at current levels because the company's story is based on the favorable outcome of a "binary event" - the signing of a government contract for its lead product candidate, the radioprotectant Neumune. Hollis-Eden is developing Neumune for the treatment of full body radiation through collaboration with the U.S. government. The firm said it sees "numerous other opportunities" within the biotechnology sector that have a more attractive risk/reward profile. LaBranche LAB, +19.05% gave back more than 8 percent after the company warned that third-quarter earnings would be 3 to 5 cents a share, below the average analyst estimate compiled by Thomson First Call of 17 cents a share, as low equity market volatility led to a depressed trading environment. The NYSE specialist firm said principal trading volume fell 29 percent from year-earlier levels to $176 billion. Separately, the company said the activity under review by the NYSE's investigation into specialist trading practices amounts to "substantially less than one percent" of LaBranche's trading revenue. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch Thursday: CRAI, ENTG, UTSI, INTU, NFLX

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International tasr shares rose more than 10 percent to $28.95 after the Scottsdale, Ariz., firm said the Defense Department has received $1 million for the purchase of the company's less-lethal conducted energy weapons. Taser explained the funding is part of the fiscal 2004 Defense Appropriations Bill approved by Congress and signed into law by President Bush on Tuesday.
title: Taser gets lift after DoD gets funds for purchases

content: Charter issues Q3 cash flow warning (4:56 PM ET) After the market closed, Paul Allen's Charter Communications (TICKER:CHTR), one of the nation's largest cable operators, warned that third-quarter operating cash flow will fall below its previous forecast of 13.7 percent over the same period last year. The company cited basic analog customer losses. The stock closed 14 cents higher at $2, a 7.5 percent gain. PLX Tech raises revenue range; unveils buyback (2:24 PM ET) PLX Technology PLXT is rising 31 cents, or 27.3 percent, to $1.41, after the Sunnyvale, Calif., communications interconnect technology firm boosted its revenue expectations to between $7.8 million and $8.3 million in the September quarter, up from its previous projection of $6 million to $8 million. The company also said its board has authorized the buyback of an additional 2 million common shares. Target sees Sept. same-store sales "well below plan" (2:05 PM ET) Target Corp. TGT, +0.36% is slipping 56 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $28.96, in afternoon action. The Minneapolis-based general merchandise retailer has disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission and a phone message that its same-store sales for September will be "well below plan." The company had been looking for growth of 3 to 5 percent for the month at its flagship Target stores, and a slightly less of an increase in overall growth. It now sees overall same-store sales for the month at "slightly below last year's levels." The stock also received a downgrade this morning from Salomon Smith Barney earlier this morning. Vitesse reiterates revenue outlook for Q2 (1:27 PM ET) Vitesse Semiconductor VTSS is surging 16 cents, or 23.4 percent, to 83 cents after the Camarillo, Calif., chip firm reiterated its expectations for revenue of about $38 million in the fourth quarter. The company also discussed its cash position, saying that it expects end fiscal 2002 with positive 'net cash,' or cash minus convertible debt. Vitesse plans to use cash in operations "at a substantially lower rate" over the next few quarter. Supervalu slips after posting in-line Q2 (11:53 AM ET) Supervalu SVU, -1.42% is off 35 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $15.80, after the Minneapolis supermarket retailer posted second-quarter earnings of $58.8 million, or 44 cents a share, up from a year-ago profit of $50.6 million, or 38 cents a share, and in line with the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. Sales slipped in the latest three months to $4.5 billion from $4.72 billion in the same period a year earlier. Looking ahead, the company forecast earnings of $2.10 to $2.20 per share for fiscal 2003, in line with the current Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of $2.14 per share. Estee Lauder turns green after reaffirming ests. (11:04 AM ET) Estee Lauder EL, +2.53% is gaining 36 cents to $29.10 after the skin care products maker reiterated fiscal first quarter earnings and sales growth expectations. The stock was down as much as 23 cents earlier in the session. The company continues to expect earnings of 25 to 28 cents a share for the quarter ending September, versus the average analyst estimate as compiled by Thomson First Call of 26 cents. Net sales, on a constant current basis, are now expected to increase 2 percent. Q4 warning sends Advo shares lower (10:29 AM ET) Advo AD, -0.91% is losing $4.21, or 13.3 percent, to $27.54, after the Windsor, Conn., provider of direct mail marketing services warned that its fourth-quarter results would miss Wall Street expectations due to the weak economic environment and declines in advertising spending by clients in the furniture/bedding and discount categories. The company now sees earnings of roughly 57 cents per share on revenue of between $286 million and $288 million, below Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 66 cents a share. Looking ahead, Advo forecast earnings growth of 7 to 9 percent for fiscal 2003. Forest Labs' stock surges, drugmaker sees higher profit (8:56 AM ET) Shares of Forest Labs jumped 5 percent in premarket trading Tuesday after the drugmaker said it would top analysts' fiscal second-quarter profit expectations by "at least" 30 percent. Forest Labs had been expected to earn 57 cents per share, according to the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson First Call. But late Monday Forest Labs said its earnings would exceed that target because of strong sales of the company's antidepressants, Celexa and Lexapro. Shares of Forest Labs FRX, -1.85% were up $3.98 to $85.99 in recent third-market dealings. Aeropostale halved on Q3, Q4 warning (8:55 AM ET) Shares of Aeropostale ARO, +11.11% are getting pummeled for an $8.83, or 57 percent loss, to $6.57 in pre-open trading over the Redibook ECN after the casual apparel retailer warned late Monday that fiscal third and fourth quarter earnings would fall short of expectations, due to a drop-off in mall traffic and reduced customer activity beginning in mid-September. The company said it now expects to earn 31 to 33 cents a share in the quarter ending October and 30 to 34 cents a share in the January quarter, well below the average analyst forecast as compiled by Thomson First Call of 50 cents and 52 cents, respectively, on average. The company added that October same-store sales are shaping up to decline in the "mid-teens." Taser zaps Q3 forecast to loss from gain (8:48 AM ET) Stun gun maker Taser International TASR warned it'll fall short of third-quarter financial targets because of a delay of a large police department purchase order and several small orders. The Scottsdale, Az. firm said it now expects $1.8 million in revenue, versus its $2.6 million forecast. The company expects to file a loss of 2- to 4 cents per share, compared to previous guidance of a profit of 6 cents per share. Two analysts survey by Thomson First Call are forecasting a profit of 4 cents per share. Shares of Taser fell 46 cents to $5.14 on Monday. Janus Fund owner's assets fall 18 percent (8:34 AM ET) Stilwell Financial SV reported assets under management of about $139 billion, down 18 percent from $170 billion in the year-ago period and 7 percent from $150 billion in the previous month. The Kansas City-based financial management firm, which owns 92 percent of the Janus Fund, said assets under management averaged $148 billion for the third quarter, down from $198 billion last year. Shares of Stilwell Financial fell 55 cents to $12.07 on Monday. Topps' Pokemon collectibles cool off (8:17 AM ET) Topps TOPP, +0.45% said it turned in a stronger-than-expected second quarter, although sales and profit fell as the Pokemon craze cooled. Net income was $4.7 million, or 11 cents per share, compared to net income of $8.9 million, or 20 cents per share last y ear. Net sales were $70 million, compared with $81.2 million last year. Pokemon sales were $1.7 million, down from $8.7 million. The company plans to release cards featuring the upcoming film, "Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers," and sticker products featuring "Yu-Gi-Oh!" by the end of the year. Shares of Topps rose 12 cents to $8.62 on Monday. Nabors warns of Q3 earnings shortfall (7:44 AM ET) Nabors Industries NBR, +2.04% warned that third quarter earnings would fall short of expectations as projected increases in North American gas-related activity have yet to materialize. The oil driller now expects to earn 10 to 12 cents a share in the quarter ending September, while analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 19 cents a share, on average. The company said it expects "moderate" earnings improvement in the fourth quarter, versus analyst forecasts of 26 cents a share. The stock closed Monday down 11 cents at $32.75. Talk America ups Q3 EBITDA outlook (6:51 AM ET) Talk America TALK, +0.00% raised its forecast for third-quarter EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) to $15 million to $16 million from $12 million to $14 million. The provider of bundled local and long distance services reiterated its forecast for billed local lines of 270,000 to 280,000, long distance revenue of $31 million to $33 million and bundled revenue of $42 million to $44 million. The company said full results would be released on Nov. 5. The stock closed Monday up 6 cents at $2.32. JP Morgan sees S&P at 800 year-end 2003 (6:50 AM ET) JP Morgan Securities strategists are setting a year-end 2003 target of 800 for the S&P 500 stocks -- that is down 15 points from Monday's level -- on expectations for weak earnings outlooks and the potential for compression in multiples. The strategists said the target implies the market priced at multiple of 25.8 times 2002 reported earnings and 23.5 times on 2003 reported earnings. It's recommending asset allocation of 50 percent equities, 30 percent bonds and 20 percent cash. "The U.S. macro backdrop remains weak, with few signs of a sustained recovery in the making... capital expenditure recovery is likely to remain weak owning to a sluggish economy and a still-negative free cash flow position," it said. "Even after three years of bear market and some multiple contraction, we think equity valuations remain stretched." TTI Telecom warns of Q3 losses, announces job cuts (6:44 AM ET) Israel-based TTI Telecom TTIL warned that third quarter and full year results would fall short of expectations, and announced a workforce reduction of 6 percent as the company copes with a further deterioration of industry capital expenditures and lengthening sales cycles. The maker of software for operations support systems said it now expects to lose 31 to 38 cents a share in the quarter ending September and to earn 50 to 74 cents a share for the year, while analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 35 cents a share and $1.46 a share, respectively, on average. Revenue for the year is now projected to be $64.9 million to $68.9 million, below analyst forecasts of $82.1 million. TTI added that it would implement a salary reduction across all departments, effective immediately. The stock closed Monday down 22 cents at $6.78. Pepsi Bottling meets Q3 earns forecast (6:25 AM ET) Pepsi Bottling PBG, +7.14% reported third-quarter earnings that met expectations and revenue that was slightly above as "excellent" volume results in Russia helped to mitigate lower than expected volume growth in the U.S. and Spain. Net income for the quarter ending September was $178 million, or 61 cents a share, up from $162 million, or 55 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Revenue for the period increased 8 percent to $2.46 billion. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had been expecting earnings of 61 cents a share and revenue of $2.41 billion, on average. Looking ahead, the world's largest seller of Pepsi-Cola beverages lifted the lower end of its full-year earnings outlook by a penny a share. The company now expects to earn $1.42 to $1.45 a share for the year, surrounding analyst projections of $1.44 a share. The stock closed Monday down $1.19 at $23.40. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition Related Topics Earnings Markets U.S. Stocks
title: Updates, advisories and surprises

content: Stun gun maker Taser International tasr warned it'll fall short of third-quarter financial targets because of a delay of a large police department purchase order and several small orders. The Scottsdale, Az. firm said it now expects $1.8 million in revenue, versus its $2.6 million forecast. The company expects to file a loss of 2- to 4 cents per share, compared to previous guidance of a profit of 6 cents per share. Two analysts survey by Thomson First Call are forecasting a profit of 4 cents per share. Shares of Taser fell 46 cents to $5.14 on Monday.
title: Taser zaps Q3 forecast to loss from gain

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Taser International is firing on all cylinders. The maker of stun guns has seen its stock price triple over the past year, won several orders from airlines for its high-tech weaponry in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist skyjackings and is set to reap the rewards from an upcoming decision that may allow airlines to arm their pilots with stun guns. But for all the positives, is it a one-trick pony whose lofty stock price will crash once terrorism fears dissipate and it stops being the flavor of the month? Company officials and analysts don't think so. "I like the sector and I like the stock," said Steven Gish, analyst at Roth Capital Partners. "From a long-term perspective, it's relying on the law enforcement business and the consumer business, which is a sleeping giant." Even before Taser became a hot security play in the aftermath of the Sept 11 attacks, the company was on track for another quarter of record sales, thanks to booming demand from police departments for the non-lethal weapons, which emit electrical charges to disable attackers. "Obviously 9-11 adds a new dimension, bringing airlines into the picture. But they were already on an impressive growth path before that through the law enforcement side," said Richard Ryan, analyst at Dougherty & Company. "9-11 added to it, but it already was a pretty good growth story." One hundred percent growth to be exact. Spurred on by demand for its key Advanced Taser product, the company reported a doubling of revenues from year-ago levels to a record $2.4 million in the first quarter. For 2002, the company expects revenues of $12 million and earnings of 50 cents per basic share. What's the big deal? Taser TASR chairman Phillips Smith acknowledges the lift that the debate over airline security has given to the stock, but says that the issue has overshadowed growth for its more important law enforcement and consumer businesses. "We're trying to create a market on the law enforcement side and the airline sector is just icing on the cake." Taser chairman Phillips Smith "Only 2 percent of business comes from airlines, most comes from law enforcement," he said in an interview with He conceded the public debate over cockpit security is helpful. "It's (airlines) not a huge market, but it gives you visibility in the consumer market," said Smith. But it's a business that could grow dramatically if the U.S. Transportation Department gives the go-ahead for pilots to carry stun-guns to protect their planes - a decision which could come by the end of June or early July at the latest. There's a high likelihood that will happen, give the fact that the government has already turned down an idea to allow pilots to carry guns on board. "The smart money says it's going to happen but there's no guarantee," he said. If it does, the surge in orders could mean an additional $3-4 million in sales -- a nice chunk of change for a company, which came to market barely two years ago. Several major airlines have already bought the Taser, but the biggest order so far has come from United Airlines UAL, +2.30% which purchased the contraption -- which is no bigger than a cell phone -- for each of its 500 planes. "We're trying to create a market on the law enforcement side and the airline sector is just icing on the cake," he said. Ryan, who gave the stock a "buy" rating with a $23 price target, said he hasn't upgraded his financial expectations based on a possible flood of airline orders. "It's important from a PR stance, but I'm not buying the stock hoping that the government will approve the use of Tasers," said Ryan, who expects the company to make 34 cents per share this year and 77 cents the next. Instead, Ryan and other analysts are betting that demand for the non-lethal weapons will grow as more states legalize the weapons and police departments adopt them as a crucial tool to subdue suspects without deadly force. In addition, "the consumer market is opening up," said Ryan. Already, 43 states have legalized Tasers, which can be bought over the Internet though they are most widely sold through gun shops. Some controversy Use of Tasers hasn't come without controversy. Company officials firmly deny any linkage between the Taser and the recent deaths of three drug-related suspects who were zapped while in police custody. "Unfortunately, there's a tendency for people to rush to conclusions in these cases," said CEO Smith. "Every year approximately 12,000 people die as a result of drug overdoses in the U.S... If someone is in the throes of a drug overdose, the application of the Taser will not stop (or exacerbate) the ongoing chemical reactions that will lead to the eventual death of the subject." Tasers fire two probes up to 15 feet, with strong electrical charges that penetrate the nervous system immediately, knocking people out. They are considered more effective than guns because they work no matter where the probes hit one's body. Reflecting the company's hope of drumming up more law-enforcement business, Taser recently named high-profile former New York City police commissioner Bernard Kerik to its board. Kerik, with his crime-fighting credentials burnished by his performance during the terrorist attacks, will help the company with introductions and personal contacts, said Smith. "Fifteen hundred police departments already have them, and we're seeing a quarterly growth rate of 20 percent in the law enforcement market," said Smith. Analyst Gish likes Taser for other reasons as well. The company doesn't have to worry about a massive dump of its shares as its holdings come mainly from retail investors. Moreover, Taser has recently introduced a new line of products and is seeking to diversify its business. That said, Gish admits Taser may be lofty at current levels, pegging the stock at a "long-term buy" with a price target of $19.10. "The stock would look attractive if the price pulls back," he said. Taser's share price surged to over $21 in April, helped by the controversy over the pilot controversy as well as general investor enthusiasm for companies that churn out security-related products. It has fallen back since then, ending Tuesday trade at $14.86, but still up almost three-fold from a 52-week low of $5.35 set last June. Smith acknowledges the criticism that its stock is pricey relative to the market, but thinks that's not unusual given the young company's fast-growth spurt. "It's not a P/E story," he said. "We're typical of many early-stage companies that should be considered based on our revenues, except that we're also cash-flow positive," he said. "We're trying to grow 100 percent a year." More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Related Topics Markets U.S. Stocks Mutual Funds Exchange Traded Funds
title: Taser surges on airline potential

content: Is Adelphia ADLAE a bargain stock after its plunge following Nasdaq delisting and default on debt covenants? The latest Barron's notes underlying value from assets exceeding the 70 cent share price, yet pointed out that any sale of those cable TV franchises could be negated in bankruptcy court if the Adelphia story stops at Chapter 7 or 11. Applica APN, +2.27% which makes small electric consumer goods including the Black & Decker line, said after Friday's bell that it acquired pest-control device maker Weitech for $20 million to bolster its product range in that area. AOL Time Warner AOL and Viacom VIAB, +1.90% are vying for control of German music television broadcaster Viva Media AG, one of Viva's founders said Saturday in Germany's Der Spiegel magazine. The media giants are interested in shares held by EMI and French media group Vivendi Universal V, +2.25% Viacom owns a significant stake in MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report. AT&T T, +0.25% Verizon VZ, -0.37% Korea Telecom KTC, +3.02% Vodaphone VOD, +0.54% and Telmex TMX, +0.03% may get a lift from a Barron's cover story focusing on the beleaguered telecom sector. The stocks surfaced among picks by high profile fund mangers. See full story. Calytica Energy Systems CESI said late Friday that Craig Kitchen has stepped down as CEO and president but will remain on the board. Chairman Ricardo Levy will assume Kitchen's duties until a replacement is found. CBL & Associates CBL, -5.23% announced late Friday that it bought Panama City Mall in Panama City, Fla., for $46.5 million. The real estate investment trust said it expects a 10.5 percent return on the deal. Tech firms Dell DELL Intel INTC, +5.00% Cisco CSCO, +2.95% EMC EMC, +9.92% Nokia NOK, +0.74% Xilinx XLNX, +1.25% Altera ALTR, +1.98% and LSI Logic LSI, -0.35% were the subject of bearish comments from Dan Niles of Lehman Brothers as featured in the weekly "Plugged In" column in Barron's. Niles told the magazine that hope and reality are about to collide and that there's still a bit too much optimism surrounding the chip sector. Delphi Corp DPH, -33.33% confirmed plans to sell its auto instrument business, and Germany's Siemens AG may buy it. An executive at the world's No. 1 auto parts maker revealed the deal at a weekend press conference in Seoul. The Financial Times Deutschland reported last week that Siemens was close to buying the unit, which has $500 million in sales, but the German firm declined to comment. Emeritus Assisted Living ESC, -3.40% said after Friday's bell that it will lease 24 assisted-living communities for senior citizens from a private company that will buy them from Marriott International MAR, +1.55% No amount was disclosed for the 10 year lease, which carries a purchase option. FedEx FDX, +2.26% on Friday afternoon declared plans to pay a dividend for the first time. The Memphis, Tenn., package delivery firm declared a quarterly dividend of 5 cents per share on its common stock. It'll be paid on July 8 to shareholders of record on June 17. In addition, FedEx said its board also authorized the buyback of an additional five million shares of its common stock, augmenting the 1.65 million shares still available under its previous repurchase program. IBM IBM, +0.60% has cut almost 5,000 jobs after two weeks of layoff notices in more than a dozen plants around the United States, the Associated Press reported. The company has issued no overarching public statement on the extent of the layoffs, but employees have been compiling numbers. The job cuts appear to be spread among IBM's 150,000 U.S. employees in locations. A Canadian strike that began Saturday could affect truckmaker Navistar NAV, +7.43% The company said it will lift output at its Mexican plant to deal with potential shortages. Monterey Pasta PSTA, +1.90% warned late Friday that its sales for the second quarter will likely miss earlier projections of 20 percent growth over the prior year's second quarter. Instead, the food products company said growth would be closer to a 10 to 15 percent increase from year-earlier sales. A Barron's article raised doubts about recovery prospects for the semiconductor sector, with valuation concerns cited by three analysts and a venture capitalist from a recent forum. Asked to give stock picks, Dan Niles of Lehman Brothers selected On Semiconductor ONNN which was spun off from Motorola. Drew Peck of Crimson Ventures selected Zoran ZRAN Oak Technology OAKT and Cirrus Logic CRUS, +3.31% suggesting they will benefit from looming DVD sales that rely more on chips than the present videotape players. Peck also liked Agere AGRA the Lucent spinoff that holds many Bell Lab patents. He suggested shorting Nvidia NVDA, +4.63% and Broadcom BRCM saying they are overvalued and face strong competition. Peck also raised questions about the valuation of Intel INTC, +5.00% based on its revenue. Mark Edelstone of Morgan Stanley chose Silicon Laboratories SLAB, +2.39% which he sees making major gains over the next five years. Bill Tai, a venture capitalist with Charles River Ventures who moderated the forum, picked Xicor XICO for its move into chips used in mixed-signal configurations and flat-panel displays. See full story. Consumer goods titan Procter & Gamble PG, +0.56% announced late Friday that it is suing the pharaoh of fizzdom Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% alleging a patent infringement of its calcium-boosted juices by Coke unit Minute Maid. The federal suit, filed in Cincinnati, seeks an end to Coca-Cola's sales of the juices, plus unspecified monetary damages. PG&E Corp. PCG, +1.60% told the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission that it found 12 instances where its National Energy Group subsidiary was a party to the sale and purchase of electricity at the same price, deals know as "round trips" where companies can artificially puff up their revenue and trading numbers. PG&E Corp. said the deals had no material effect on its reported financial results. Calpine C.PN, +0.59% said its review found 31 of the transactions, which it said were "completed for risk management reasons." And Reliant Resources RRI, -2.04% disclosed one. See full story. A study Pharmacia PHA, +0.19% publicized to tout its arthritis pain reliever Celebrex was criticized in a British Medical Journal editorial, The New York Times reported Saturday. The editorial claimed there were major "irregularities" in the study, which said Celebrex caused fewer ulcers than other medications. Celebrex yearly sales total $3 billion. Pharmacia told The Times it stands by the study. Qualcomm QCOM, +1.30% got a positive mention in Barron's over the weekend for its plans to attack the technology market for 3rd Generation cellular service, or 3G. The company is set to unveil a new version of its BREW software. Qualcomm customers will be listening to streaming music, and even watching videos, "well ahead" of customers of rival Nokia NOK, +0.74% the magazine reported. SportsLine.com SPLN, +0.00% said late Friday that Sports.com Limited has been placed under court administration while a buyer is sought. SportsLine owns 30 percent of the digital sports information provider but says it has carried the British operation on its books on a zero cost basis and that the move will have no material effect on it. Viacom VIA holds stakes in SportsLine.com, as well as MarketWatch.com, the publisher of this report. See full story. Star Scientific STSI which is working on technology to reduce the carcinogens in cured tobacco, said late Friday that its board approved a plan to repurchase up to 1.2 million shares in the open market over the next year. The company has 60 million shares outstanding. Taro Pharmaceutical TARO, +0.09% said late Friday that it received FDA approval to market Amcinonide, a generic version of the prescription cream Cyclocort. Taser International TASR named Bernard Kerik, the former commissioner of the New York Police Department and hero of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, to its board of directors. After Friday's close, 21st Century Holding Co. TCHC, +53.83% a provider of insurance and financial services, said it expects earnings per share for its second quarter ended June 30 to hit 34 cents, up from an earlier outlook of 27 cents a share. For all of 2002, EPS was raised a dime to $1.30. United Parcel Service UPS, +1.93% and the Teamsters are getting closer to a new contract, the Wall Street Journal reported. The two sides have struck on the thorny issue of supervisors doing work that union members contend should be theirs. A union spokesman told the newspaper that recent talks led to a tentative pact "that boils down to stronger language in the contract to prevent supervisors from doing union work." UPS didn't comment. Mortgage company Vestin Group VSTN said its chairman and CEO, Mike Shustek, filed to sell 150,000 shares, about 2.7 percent of Vestin's common stock. Shustek holds 59 percent of Vestin's common shares. Williams Co. WMB, +0.32% has come out firing in response to an article in the New York Times that hints the company purposely inflated natural gas prices in California during that state's energy crisis. See full story. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: Stocks to watch Monday

content: Stocks to watch The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a preliminary investigation of the accounting method Halliburton HAL, +1.93% uses to report cost overruns on construction jobs, the company said late Tuesday. The Dallas-based oil-services provider told the SEC it would cooperate fully with the investigation. Halliburton said it believes it followed generally accepted accounting principles in accounting for the construction claims and change orders, which are negotiated with customers. Halliburton shares added 25 cents to close Tuesday at $19.35. SBC Communications SBC, -0.65% agreed to pay $3.6 million to settle charges that it provided inaccurate information to federal regulators reviewing its applications to provide long-distance service. SBC agreed to change its procedures to ensure accuracy in the future. The company also agreed to make sure its employees are educated to "provide truthful, accurate and complete information to the commission," the FCC said. Novellus Systems NVLS said late Monday it expects earnings of 8 cents a share during the current quarter, a penny more than the current Wall Street consensus estimates. The company said orders are expected to come in at $275 million compared with the company's original target of $250 million. See full story. Intel shares (INTC: news, chart, profile) stabilized in after-hours trade following a drop of 31 cents to a close of $28.35 Tuesday. Merrill Lynch trimmed its 2002 June revenue estimate for the company to $6.76 billion -- which represents flat sequential growth -- and also slightly cut full-year earnings-per-share estimates. Merrill said an improvement in Intel's second quarter could still materialize but also added that it has become more difficult to defend a sequential revenue increase, as growth has not turned up yet. Bebe Stores (BEBE: news, chart, profile) said late Tuesday that President and COO John Parros has resigned his post "to pursue other opportunities." Shares of the women's clothing retailer plunged more than 7 percent in the evening session. In regular trade, the stock dropped 12 cents to $19.33. Advancers Cognos COGN leapt almost 10 percent after the company settled its patent dispute with Business Objects BOBJ Cognos agreed to pay Business Objects a total of $24 million while making no admission about the allegation that Cognos Impromtu software infringes upon a patent held by Business Objects. Cognos said it will record a charge of $23.2 million "reflecting the present value of the agreed upon settlement payments as a year-end adjustment to its previously announced fiscal 2002 financials." In addition, Cognos reiterated its outlook for the first quarter and fiscal 2003. Cyberonics CYBX gained more than 5 percent after A.G. Edwards raised its rating on the company to "buy" from "hold" with a price target of $17.50. The firm said it believes positives at the Houston medical device firm outweigh the negatives. It added that Cyberonics' sales force continues to perform well, which should lead the company to beat the firm's top line estimate. Dot Hill Systems HIL, +0.00% rallied more than 8 percent after the data storage company said it would issue warrants to Sun Microsystems SUNW, +5.56% giving Sun the opportunity to own roughly 5 percent of the total shares outstanding, as part of a multi-year purchase agreement. As part of the agreement, Dot Hill will make private label products for Sun Micro. Gulf Indonesia Resources GRL, -1.20% surged almost 23 percent after a unit of Conoco COC, -1.36% proposed to buy the shares of the Indonesia-based oil company it didn't already own for $329 million, or $13.25 per share. Handspring HAND rose nearly 10 percent after the company unveiled the Treo 90, a version of its handheld computer that features a full-color display and a built-in keyboard. The Treo 90 is priced at $299, and it will be available within the next few weeks at retail stores in the U.S. JMAR Technologies JMAR gained almost 12 percent after the San Diego company said it has been chosen by the Pentagon to participate in research on next-generation computer chips. The company's JSAL nanolithography systems unit will work with IBM IBM, +0.60% in Vermont. The funding for the research totals $10 million, which consists of $3 million for the first year and an option for an additional $7 million in the second year. Standard Management SMAN, +0.00% rose more than 9 percent after the company agreed to sell its Premier Life international operations to Winterthur Life, a unit of Credit Suisse Group, for $27.8 million. The deal includes Premier Life (Luxembourg) S.A. and the portfolio of Premier's business in Bermuda. Tower Semiconductor TSEM, +1.09% rose more than 5 percent after the company said it expects a sequential sales increase of at least 35 percent in the second quarter, higher than previously expected. The Israel-based chipmaker added that it sees a "moderate growth rate" in the second half of 2002. Decliners A&P GAP, +2.27% fell more than 16 percent after the company disclosed late Friday that it would delay its 10K SEC filing while it reviews its accounting on vendor allowances and inventory. The company said a charge could result that would reduce the cost of goods sold after fiscal year 2001. Barra BARZ, +2.42% dropped almost 10 percent after JP Morgan H&Q is lowering its assessment of the company's stock to "long term buy" from "buy" and moved its price target to $55 from $71. The firm based the downgrade on declining volumes on Barra's alternative trading network POSIT, which pools liquidity and allows institutions to cross trades anonymously at specified times each day. JP Morgan attributed the negative trend to increased competition among market makers, and an increased focus among traders on immediate executions. Checkpoint Systems CKP, -1.02% tumbled nearly 8 percent after the company reported late Friday that it lost an antitrust suit by ID Securities Systems. A jury assessed $26 million in damages against the developer of security systems for retailers. That figure is subject to a tripling, plus lawyer fees, under antitrust law. Checkpoint plans to appeal. See full story. DiamondCluster International DTPI slid almost 15 percent after Wachovia Securities lowered its rating on shares of the Chicago-based provider of e-business and digital consulting services to "sell" from "hold." The firm cited a significant overhang from an option exchange that should dampen any recovery in earnings per share performance. Hurricane Hydrocarbons HHLF fell more than 5 percent after the Canada-based oil driller said it was forced to temporarily reduce production at its joint venture in Kazakhstan due to full inventories and export limitations. The company said if exports remain at recent rates, it expects the reduced production to remain until June 18th. JC Penney JCP, -0.98% lost nearly 5 percent after its drugstore unit Eckerd Corp. agreed late Friday to pay $9 million to settle allegations of prescription drug improprieties. The company was accused, in a 1995 cased filed by the Justice Department and 18 states, of partially filling Medicaid prescriptions yet billing for the full prescription. Numerical Technologies NMTC, +0.00% fell almost 24 percent after SG Cowen downgraded the software company to "buy" from "strong buy," citing uncertainty regarding production license timing. Analyst Raj Seth said his 2003 estimates now appear to be "aggressive" given macro pressures. Peregrine Systems PRGN fell more than 19 percent after the company said that its board of directors has terminated KPMG as its independent auditors and replaced the firm with PricewaterhouseCoopers. The software company said that as part of an investigation into revenue recognition problems totaling as much as $100 million, about $35 million of the questionable transactions were with KPMG and KPMG Consulting. Peregrine said it believed that these transactions compromise the SEC's auditor independence requirements. It said the company's decision to terminate KPMG was not as a result of any disagreement on any matter of accounting principles or practices, financial statement disclosure, or auditing scope or procedure. Seitel SEI, +0.00% slumped nearly 19 percent after the company disclosed that note holders have allowed an extra week, until May 31, for negotiations on its covenant default. Taser International TASR lost almost 10 percent after the company said that Karl Walter has stepped down as executive vice president of sales and gave up his director's seat for the maker of stun weapons. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Damn the torpedoes — what could take the S&P 500 to 3,000 Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: Novellus, Intel, Halliburton, SBC and more

content: Tenet Healthcare THC, +1.76% and two other hospital groups are looking to acquire Texas-based Baptist Health System, according to published reports. Terms of the deal weren't disclosed. Baptist Health, a nonprofit that owns five hospitals in San Antonia, Texas, posted a loss last year of $41 million on revenue of $395 million. According to Dow Jones News Service, a sale price could be in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Tenet, based in California, said it is working with Christus Santa Rosa Health Care to buy Baptist Health. Baptist Health said in response that it is in talks with Vanguard Health System, Nashville, Tenn., and that it expects a third offer from Texas-based Community Health Corp. Shares of Tenet fell 74 cents on Friday to end at $70.58. Coca-Cola KO, +0.25% will pay $8.1 million in back compensation to more than 2,000 current and former workers after a federal audit and an internal review showed the employees had been underpaid. Coke will pay $4.2 million to 980 workers under a deal with the U.S. Department of Labor. The beverage giant also said it will pay another $3.9 million to 1,100 workers in its North American operations after a separate internal review revealed other pay discrepancies. Coke stock closed at $56.20 on Friday, down 49 cents. Italy's Fiat (0268897) has worked out a deal with its major banks to reorganize $5.5 billion in debt designed to help it through a massive reorganization plan. Also, General Motors GM, +2.45% is considering a plan to offer to take control of Fiat's car unit sooner than planned, according to media reports. A report in the Wall Street Journal's online edition, citing people familiar with the situation, states GM has talked about whether Fiat should be allowed to exercise a put option ahead of schedule, now slated for between 2004 and 2009. That would allow Fiat, which sold 20 percent of its auto unit to GM in 1999, to raise cash and leave the auto business, the report said. It's unclear how serious GM is about the takeover proposal and that it's just one of several options the company has, according to the story. GM shares lost 1 cent Friday, ending at $64.99. Energy company AES AES, +1.25% said late Friday it will challenge a Brazilian regulatory decision that could retroactively affect $120 million in sales. The company said the mandated changes in wholesale market calculation violate Brazilian law. Supermarket chain A&P GAP, +2.27% disclosed late Friday that it would delay its 10K SEC filing while it reviews its accounting on vendor allowances and inventory. The company said a charge could result that would reduce the cost of goods sold after fiscal year 2001. Checkpoint Systems CKP, -1.02% reported late Friday that it lost an antitrust suit by ID Securities Systems. A jury assessed $26 million in damages against the developer of security systems for retailers. That figure is subject to a tripling, plus lawyer fees, under antitrust law. Checkpoint said it will appeal the verdict. See full story. Barron's looks at biotech companies and sees four "investment opportunities" of drug developers that have been knocked around but are cash-rich: CV Therapeutics CVTX Celera Genomics CRA, +6.25% Intermune ITMN and Medarex MEDX The article notes the likely extinction of many small-cap and mid-cap biotech companies, but suggests looking at cash-burn rates as a benchmark, as well as research and production facilities that add value beyond the bonus of successful drug development. One way to play the sector, the article suggests, is via two closed-end mutual funds that trade at a discount to assets -- H&Q Life Sciences Investors HQL, +0.68% and H&Q Healthcare Investors HQH, +0.61% Alan Abelson's column in Barron's passes along an observation from hedge fund manager Doug Kass about a Dell DELL venture, off its balance sheet, with Tyco's TYC, +74.50% CIT financial division. The Dell Financial Services partnership finances computer sales, to the tune of $2.7 billion in fiscal year 2002. According to the column, losses all accrue to CIT with profits split 70-30 in Dell's favor after any losses are made good for the Tyco unit. Shares of Deutsche Telekom DT could be a bargain, according to a Barron's article, as the German communications giant's price has fallen from triple digits to its Friday close of $10.71. An acquisition strategy that overpaid for companies such as VoiceStream and 3G licenses in Germany could bear fruit down the road for investors with long-term objectives, Barron's says. And the possible ouster of head man Ron Sommer would provide a short-term stock pop, the article says. Diebold DBD, +7.32% is the subject of a Barron's profile, noting the safe and ATM manufacturer's revenue has stagnated as banks consolidated and the U.S. market for ATMs appears saturated. To grow its revenue, Diebold managers are looking at overseas markets and made an acquisition in election equipment, hoping to cash in on the changes following the 2000 U.S. election fiasco in Florida. Telecom software developer DSET DSET late Friday named Binay Sugla as CEO. He succeeds William McHale Jr., who held the post since 1997. Dynegy DYN, -1.46% said the U.S. attorney's office in Houston late Friday subpoenaed documents relating to its transactions, including its buy and sell trades with CMS Energy CMS, +0.49% and its long-term natural gas supply transaction referred to as "Project Alpha." Computer seller Gateway GTW disclosed late Friday that it settled a class-action suit filed in 2000 for $10.25 million, but said its insurance would cover the loss and there would be no financial impact from the accord. JC Penney JCP, -0.98% drugstore unit Eckerd Corp. agreed late Friday to pay $9 million to settle allegations of prescription drug improprieties. The company was accused, in a 1995 cased filed by the Justice Department and 18 states, of partially filling Medicaid prescriptions yet billing for the full prescription. A Barron's interview with Christopher Mills, chief investment strategist at J.O. Hambro Capital Management in London, yields three story stocks of U.S. companies. Mills mentions Lincoln Electric LECO, +1.31% the world's second-largest welding company that tried at one point to buy No. 1 Charter PLC. Mills says welding has 10 percent profit margins and praises Lincoln's operations. W-H Energy Services WHES where Mills is a director, is down as the natural-gas industry battles lower prices. Mills sees an upside for W-H as one of its units has developed a well-pressure measurer that streamlines operations. He also mentions Lesco LSCO which provides lawn services to golf courses and sells lawn-care products. Mills sits on Lesco's board and Hambro is its largest shareholder. He said Lesco management could raise margins to 10 percent from the present 3 to 4 percent. New York-based Metlife MET, -0.02% said late Friday that it won the bidding for Mexico's state-owned and top insurance company, Aseguradora Hidalgo SA. Metlife is paying about $965 million for the privatization of Hidalgo. Subject to the right of first refusal by Hidalgo's employees and regulatory approvals, the transaction will close by the end of the second quarter of 2002. Microsoft MSFT, +2.10% faces more grief in Europe as the European Commission investigates privacy concerns related to the software behemoth's Passport service. See full story. The international subsidiary of Nextel Communications NXTL announced late Friday that it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and restructured its debt from $2.7 billion down to under $500 million. The division, NII Holdings, formerly known as Nextel International, has wireless operations in Mexico, Brazil, Peru, Argentina, Chile and the Philippines. Among the debt provisions, Nextel and Motorola Credit Corp. MSI, +1.29% plus other bondholders would provide $190 million in new capital, with $140 million of new notes and warrants. Nextel said it will provide $65 million for a stake of 45 percent in NII Holdings. See full story. Novellus NVLS will hold its midquarter update Tuesday, with UBS Warburg expecting the company to raise its bookings target and reaffirm revenue and earnings-per-share goals. The brokerage feels Wall Street had underestimated Novellus' potential for margin expansion and revenue growth into the capital-spending upturn. A Federal Communications Commission decision late Friday was a blow to Paxson Communications PAX, +0.57% The FCC delayed for seven months the auction of wavelength spectrum for TV channels 60 to 69. The sale of channels 52 to 59 airwaves will proceed on June 19. Paxson, which operates UHF band TV stations, wants the sales as soon as possible as it hopes to receive compensation for giving up its frequencies. The wavelengths are to be converted to wireless phone use, yet wireless companies under the aegis of the Cellular Telecommunications & Internet Association asked the FCC for an indefinite delay in the auctions. Drugmaker Perrigo PRGO, +0.90% receives an upbeat look in the latest Barron's. The company expects sales to grow in its store-brand market that takes advantage of prescription drugs that receive permission to be sold over-the-counter. It has about 40 applications pending for such switches. A downside was an FDA investigation in 2000 that faulted the company's production. Perrigo's top exec tells Barron's that 130 quality-control employees were added to deal with the problem and a troubled Michigan factory was given a "clean bill of health" last year. With the major bulge-bracket brokerage companies tainted with a reputation of untrustworthy research, Charles Schwab SC.H, +0.00% appears positioned to attract investor trust in its own research, as well as its stock, according to Barron's cover story this week. See full story. Seitel SEI, +0.00% which provides seismic services to oil companies, said after the bell Friday that note holders have allowed an extra week, until May 31, for negotiations on its covenant default. Taser International TASR said after Friday's bell that Karl Walter has stepped down as executive vice president of sales and gave up his director's seat for the maker of stun weapons. Workflow Management WORK, +0.00% said late Friday that it reached accord with lenders over covenant defaults. The graphics services company said it won extra time to seek new financing, but would enter a new 12 percent debt accord if it cannot raise funds. More from MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why every investor should be terrified by the slide in Home Depot stock Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 This emerging-market ETF continues to blow away the competition
title: Coke, Checkpoint Systems and more
