title: Stocks to watch Tuesday

content: WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- The Bush administration won't permit commercial pilots to carry handguns to deter potential hijackers, a senior administration official told lawmakers Tuesday. "I will not permit firearms in the cockpit," said John Magaw, undersecretary for the Transportation Security Administration, who is charged with making U.S. airports safe following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. "Pilots need to concentrate on flying the plane." At a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on aviation security, Magaw stressed that federal air marshals should be the only armed passengers aboard airplanes. "They will do whatever they have to -- to the point of giving up their own life -- to make sure that that cockpit stays safe," he told lawmakers. Magaw said TSA is still weighing whether pilots should arm themselves with electric stun guns. He further suggested other security measures, such as special video cameras, could help pilots. Both Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta, who also testified at Tuesday's hearing, and Homeland Security Director Tom Ridge have expressed opposition to arming pilots. A formal announcement will be made sometime this week, Magaw told lawmakers. Airline trade groups and pilots blasted the decision. "All that pilots have to prevent the plane from being turned into a cruise missile is a crash ax, a flashlight and a flight manual," said David Stempler, president of the Air Travelers Association. Capt. Duane Woerth, president of the Air Line Pilots Association, said government officials would rather send military jets to shoot down a hijacked plane rather than "give pilots a last chance to prevent such a tragedy." After terrorists used four commercial airliners as suicide bombs to crash into the World Trade Center and Pentagon, new aviation security laws were enacted last November that require secure doors on cockpits and armed sky marshals on planes to help prevent similar tragedies. And the subject of arming pilots has been the subject of much debate since the Sept 11 attacks. Legislation is pending in Senate and House panels to allow pilots to carry weapons. The House Aviation Subcommittee is scheduled to vote May 23 on a bill that would create a government program to selectively train and arm pilots. Last November, United Airlines began stocking its cockpits with stun guns from Taser International TASR The nonlethal weapons emit electronic discharges designed to temporarily disable attackers. At Tuesday's hearing, Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont., co-author of proposed legislation to let pilots brandish firearms, also urged U.S. transportation officials to reconsider their position. More from MarketWatch Samsung Galaxy S9: Putting the Camera to the Test More Coverage Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle
title: Feds rule out handguns in cockpit

content: Stocks to watch AptarGroup ATR, +1.66% expects fourth-quarter earnings to range between 26 cents and 28 cents a share, excluding charges related to the previously announced strategic initiative. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call were anticipating a profit of about 35 cents a share. The company cited softer-than-expected sales of products sold to the fragrance/cosmetic and personal care markets. "We expect softness in demand to continue going into 2002, we expect double digit earnings growth for the full year of 2002 on a comparable basis over 2001," added Carl A. Siebel, president and chief executive officer. Shares closed up 68 cents to $35.26 ahead of the news. Moody's lowered Gateway's GTW debt rating Tuesday (senior unsecured to Ba1 from Baa3) and said that the rating would be under review for possible further downgrade. Moody's said it will focus on Gateway's plans and prospect to restore and sustain profitability and market share in its PC computer operations. Gateway shares fell $2.56 to $7.69. See full story. Hutchinson Technology HTCH said Tuesday that it expects to report a profit of 16 to 21 cents a share, which includes a one-time increase to operating income totaling $2.6 million, or 8 cents a share. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had been expecting a loss. The company, which makes computer disk drive parts, also said net sales for its fiscal first quarter, which ended December 30, 2001, totaled approximately $93 million. Shares of Hutchinson closed down 17 cents to $24.24 ahead of the report. After the market closed Tuesday, specialty coatings manufacturer RPM Inc. RPM, +0.55% reported net income of $24.5 million, or 24 cents a share, beating the consensus estimate of 21 cents a share. In the year-ago period, the company earned $16.9 million, or 17 cents a share. Sales slipped 2 percent to $487.9 million for the quarter compared with the year-ago total of $499.9 million, due to business disruptions related to the Sept. 11 attacks and continued weakness in the overall economy. Factors contributing to the earnings gains in the quarter included the benefits of a restructuring program, lower interest rates and the effect of a prescribed accounting change, noted the company. Shares closed up 33 cents to $15.60 ahead of the news. Advancers Aflac AFL, +0.48% rose almost 11 percent after the insurer reassured investors that fourth-quarter earnings were expected to match the consensus analyst expectations of 34 cents a share. The company added that premium sales in the U.S. "significantly exceed upwardly revised expectations," while sales in Japan met expectations. Aflac added that it expects to achieve its target of 15 to 17 percent operating earnings growth in 2002 and 2003, before the effects of currency translation. Analyst Vanessa Wilson at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown believes the bottom in Japan sales was hit in the third quarter. He reiterated his "strong buy" rating on the stock. Bottomline Technologies EPAY, +2.40% advanced nearly 14 percent after the company agreed to supply its WebSeries software platform to Raymond James Financial RJF, +2.17% Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed. Conseco CNC, +6.50% added almost 13 percent after Mark Lubbers, the company's executive vice president of corporate affairs, took issue with a Salomon Smith Barney research report disseminated on Jan. 3. The press release, which was presented as a letter to shareholders, pointed out that many of the conclusions of analyst Colin Devine were based on the performance of GreenPoint Financial GPT, -0.87% which announced plans to exit the manufactured housing market last week due to business difficulties. Conseco, which is the leader in this sector, will not be following suit, said Lubbers in the letter. However, Conseco did warn that it would miss expectations for a profit of 72 cents in fiscal 2001. Convera CNVR surged more than 18 percent after the Vienna, Va., imaging software firm said that its Technologies International unit has added A Priori International AG, a German consulting firm, to its list of clients. The company will provide its RetrieveWare software to A Priori, enabling that company to sift through personnel records, job candidates and other documents. Financial terms weren't disclosed. Helen of Troy HELE, +3.51% climbed 22 percent after the company reported fiscal third-quarter sales of $142.6 million, an increase of 20 percent over the same period last year, and net income that rose 63 percent to $12.97 million. On a per-share basis, earnings for the quarter ending November were 44 cents, up from last year's 28 cents. Consensus analyst expectations were not available from Thomson Financial/First Call. Hollywood Entertainment HLYW rose 5 percent after the company said strength in same-store sales during the fourth-quarter would lead to earnings that at least meet the high end of previously-given expectations of 26 to 28 cents per share. The video retailer said same-store sales for the quarter ending December increased 11 percent over the same period last year, exceeding expectations of a 6 to 7 percent increase. IMAX Corp. IMAX, -1.79% soared more than 48 percent after the company purchased an additional $42 million in face value of its 5.75 percent convertible subordinated notes due April 1, 2003. The Toronto entertainment technology firm said that it has retired about $90 million worth of the original $100 million issuance. Intermagnetics General IMGC gained more than 15 percent after the company reported second-quarter net income of $10.4 million, or 60 cents per share, compared with income of $3.14 million, or 19 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Excluding a one-time gain related to the sale of a division and the write-down of investments, earnings for the quarter ending November were $3.6 million, or 21 cents a share, beating Wall Street's average analyst estimate of 19 cents a share. Sales for the period rose 20 percent over last year to $39 million. The provider of superconducting technology said results for its third quarter are expected to be below its the November quarter results, but full-year results should be in line with previous expectations. MediChem Life Sciences MCLS, +3.21% rose more than 19 percent after the company agreed to be acquired by DeCode Genetics DCGN for $83.6 million in stock, based on Monday's closing price. The deal calls for DeCode to swap 0.3099 of newly issued stock for each share of MediChem stock. This values MediChem's shares at $3.04 each based on DeCode's Monday close of $9.80. Movie Gallery MOVI jumped almost 17 percent after the company reported same-store revenue rose 2.4 percent in the fourth quarter, slightly above its expectations. In light of the strong performance, good expense controls, and the impact of an extra week of results, the Dothan, Ala., video specialty firm expects pro forma earnings of 27 to 32 cents a share in the fourth quarter, ahead of its previous outlook for a profit of 17 to 21 cents a share. For 2001, Movie Gallery forecast earnings of 68 to 73 cents a share. Looking to fiscal 2002, the company is projecting pro forma earnings of 90 cents to $1 per share on revenue of $480 million to $500 million. Nordstrom JWN, +1.06% rose almost 8 percent after the department store chain said comparable-store sales for December fell 2.3 percent, less than last year's 2.9 percent decline and better than analysts had been expecting. Analyst Laurie Breidenbach at Ragen MacKenzie reiterated her "buy" rating on the stock, saying it is valued "significantly below" its peers on a price-to-sales basis. Pharmacyclics PCYC rose nearly 7 percent after the Sunnyvale, Calif., pharmaceutical firm reported favorable results from its phase III clinical trial of Xcytrin injection. The results indicate the injection's potential utility in lung cancer patients with brain metastases. The company said ongoing analysis of the results has found that Xcytrin "improves local tumor control and neurologic function" in patients where lung cancer has spread to the brain. Rainbow Technologies RNBO climbed more than 15 percent after the Irvine, Calif., Internet security products firm said it would meet Wall Street expectations for revenue of $31 million to $32 million for the fourth quarter. The company is also projecting it will be "operationally profitable" for the quarter, bucking Wall Street's consensus estimate for a loss of 4 cents a share. RealNetworks RNWK, -4.37% gained almost 18 percent after the company formed a strategic alliance with NEC Electronics, a unit of Japan's NEC NIPNY to optimize the performance of RealNetwork's products on NEC microprocessors. The company also agreed to integrate its technologies with TiVo TIVO, +0.37% whose shares leapt more than 9 percent. Taser International TASR gained almost 12 percent after the Scottsdale, Ariz., maker of shock weapons said it expects fourth-quarter revenue of $2.8 million, topping an earlier outlook of $2 million to $2.3 million. The company expects earnings of 10 to 12 cents a share, its previous projection for a profit of 6 to 10 cents a share. For the year, Taser sees earnings of 14 to 16 cents a share on revenue of $6.9 million. Tiffany TIF, -0.38% rose nearly 6 percent after the company said fiscal fourth-quarter sales would decline approximately 3 percent from the same period last year, but that higher gross margins would lead to earnings that come in at the upper-end of the previously-given expected range of 49 to 56 cents a share. The high-end jewelry and specialty retailer added that sales for the holiday season, encompassing November and December, fell 2 percent from last year. Excluding the effects of currency translation, total sales increased 1 percent and same-store sales fell 2 percent. UAL Corp. UAL, +2.30% jumped almost 6 percent after Goldman Sachs raised its rating on shares of the airline to "market outperformer" from "market performer" and boosted its earnings estimates for 2001 and 2002. "Traffic has recovered a bit faster than expected, and declining oil prices have offset increases in insurance and security," said analyst Glenn Engel, in a note to clients. "We are narrowing estimates of 4Q losses by an average of 10 percent for most airlines." Goldman recommends investors overweight the airline sector, and that UAL's fundamentals have improved in line with the industry. Wink Communications WINK, +0.00% leapt almost 39 percent after the company and its partner NBC, a unit of General Electric GE, -1.46% announced the launch of NBC Virtual Channel, an interactive service offered to DirecTV subscribers. The service leverages the news and e-commerce capabilities of MSNBC, CNBC, and ShopNBC. Decliners ADVO AD, -0.91% tumbled nearly 10 percent after the company warned that its first-quarter earnings would be in the range of 58 cents to 60 cents a share, on revenue of between $285 million and $287 million. That includes about $2.2 million of incremental expenses related to organizational realignments and additional security costs. Analysts polled by First Call were anticipating a profit of about 77 cents a share, on revenue of $297.8 million. Full-year earnings will be roughly flat with the year-ago period in the $2.50 to $2.55 range, while the consensus stands at $2.86. Comarco CMRO, -60.00% lost 10 percent after the Irvine, Calif., provider of advanced wireless communications technology said it expects earnings of 13 to 18 cents a share on revenue of between $12 million and $13 million. This outlook is below Wall Street's consensus estimate for a profit of 24 cents a share. The company cited less than robust customer orders and customer-directed delays in performing contracted engineering services for the shortfall. Comarco also noted that it was not awarded a "significant" engineering service contract that would have started in the fourth quarter and continued through 2003. Looking ahead to 2003, the company said that it expects earnings per share excluding items and revenue to be comparable to fiscal 2002's results. Emmis Communications EMMS, -0.65% slumped 5 percent after the company reported fiscal third-quarter revenue that slightly-exceeded expectations, and said it remained confident with its previously-announced fourth-quarter targets. For the quarter ending in November, revenue at the radio broadcaster fell 4.5 percent from the same period a year ago to $137.1 million, but topped the average analyst forecast compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call of $135.6 million. Net losses for the period totaled $13.94 million, or 29 cents a share, versus income of $11.57 million, or 20 cents a share last year, and expectations of a 30-cents per share loss. After-tax cash flow for the period was $19.2 million, or 40 cents a share, down from the 62 cents a share recorded last year. First Consulting Group FCGI lost more than 5 percent after the Long Beach, Calif., firm said before the opening bell that it expects to meet its outlook for earnings of 7 cents a share excluding items. in the fourth quarter However, it forecast revenue of roughly $65 million in the period, slightly less than its previous outlook. The company attributed the revenue shortfall to lower realized billing rates and lower headcount. Gaylord Container GCR, -14.29% lost almost 55 percent after Temple-Inland TIN, +0.00% said it has terminated its merger agreement with the company since the minimum tender conditions were not satisfied as of midnight, Jan. 7. As of the deadline, only 47.2 million shares, approximately 84 percent of the total outstanding, had been tendered. Temple-Inland originally offered to buy the paper company for $1.80 per share back on Sept. 27. Flextronics FLEX, +0.12% sank nearly 5 percent after the Singapore provider of electronics manufacturing services priced a public offering of 20 million ordinary shares at $25.96 per share. The deal grants underwriters a 30-day option to purchase 3 million additional shares to cover over-allotments, if there are any. Flextronics plans to use the proceeds of the offering, which is covered under its current shelf registration, for general corporate purposes. HNC Software HNCS fell 7 percent after the company said it expects fourth-quarter earnings to be in the range of 7 cents to 8 cents a share, while the consensus is for a profit of 9 cents. Revenue will be in the range of $54 million to $55 million, lower than the current consensus estimate of about $60.2 million. Massey Energy MEE, +1.42% lost 19 percent after the coal producer said operating losses for the two-month period ending Dec. 31 are now expected to be 15 to 20 cents per share, excluding charges, below previous expectations of a loss of 5 to 10 cents a share. The company added that non-recurring charges related to losses associated with the bankruptcy of Enron ENE, +0.00% and to reserves set aside for a potential worker's compensation settlement would add an additional 15-to-17 cents-per-share loss to the period. Massey also cut 2002 earnings expectations to reflect lower coal demand as a result of mild weather, softening steel demand and the general economic recession. Simplex Solutions SPLX, +2.26% fell almost 23 percent after the Sunnyvale, Calif., integrated circuits firm forecast that it will break even on a pro forma basis in the first quarter on revenue of $11 million to $11.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call were looking for a profit of 3 cents a share in the period. "Customers were cautious about committing additional dollars for the purchase of software and services as a result of the slowdown in the semiconductor industry and the economy," said Penny Herscher, the company's chairman and CEO, in a press release. 1-800-Flowers.com FLWS, -0.42% sank nearly 16 percent after the Westbury, N.Y., firm said that Benchmark Capital has distributed roughly 5 million shares of its common stock to its limited and general partners. This distribution, which increases the market float of 1-800-Flowers.com common stock to about 19 million shares, represents Benchmark's entire investment in the company. ValiCert VLCT dropped almost 10 percent after the company warned that fourth-quarter revenue would fall short of expectations as "difficult economic conditions" led to the delay of closing several large orders, and will lead to further cost cutting initiatives. Losses for the period, however, are expected to be less than expected. For the quarter ending in December, the provider of electronic business management said sales should be $6.2 million, below previous expectations of $7.6 million. Losses however, will be $3.7 million to $3.8 million, or 16 cents a share, less than the previous forecast of $3.9 million, or 17 cents a share. ValiCert added that it would implement a 20 percent reduction of its work force and consolidate its operating facilities. Vina Technologies VINA tumbled almost 17 percent after the broadband telecom company said it expects a fourth-quarter loss of 11 cents to 13 cents a share, excluding one-time items, while analysts were polled by First Call had been expecting a 10-cent loss. Revenue will run between $10.8 million and $11 million, according to the company. The company said the revised estimates are due to a temporary suspension in the deployment of its central office product, the MBX. Western Wireless WWCA slumped nearly 23 percent after the Bellevue, Wash., communication services firm said it expects EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) of between $73 million and $75 million in the fourth quarter. Service revenue for the period is pegged between $208 million and $211 million. For the year, Western Wireless sees EBITDA of $344 million and $346 million, and service revenue of $874 million and $877 million. Net subscriber additions for the quarter totaled 19,000, with an average monthly churn rate of 2.3 percent. The company said that fourth-quarter roaming minutes from its partners came in below expectations due to a slowdown in travel nationwide. Western Wireless is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter results on Feb. 26. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call are looking for a loss of 69 cents a share on revenue of $317.7 million in the period, on average. More from MarketWatch Why It Feels Like Facebook Is Listening Through Your Mic More Coverage Jobless claims drop 4,000 to 226,000 Home sellers now use spycams to gather intel on prospective buyers Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid Related Topics U.S. Stocks Markets Investing
title: Stocks to watch: Gateway, RPM, Hutchinson and more

content: NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- While the futures markets weighed whether a planned production cut by OPEC will come to pass Jan. 1, crude futures closed under $18 a barrel Thursday for the first time in 29 months. On Wednesday, OPEC members had confirmed their agreement to cut their production quota by 1.5 million barrels per day to 21.7 million barrels in the new year. But the cartel said the cut would be conditioned on a 500,000-barrel-per-day cut by oil producers that are not members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, casting doubt on whether any price-boosting plan will be put into effect at all. See full story. Merrill's Blodget takes the money and runs NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- Merrill Lynch's dramatic cost-cutting plan, under which it offered job buyouts to virtually every employee. And those cutbacks have ended, at least for now, the Wall Street career of noted Net-stock analyst Henry Blodget. The 35-year-old Blodget, who made his name with an audacious but market-moving forecast for shares of Amazon.com AMZN, +1.11% and other Web high fliers, is leaving Merrill with a good deal of tarnish on his name. Critics fault him for remaining officially optimistic about stocks even as they spiraled southward in 2000 and 2001. Blodget told CBS.MarketWatch.com that he plans to focus his efforts on a book that's been in the works for two years. And, according to a published report, he leaves Merrill Lynch MER, -2.35% with a $2 million severance package. See full story. Cars drive October's retail sales WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Financing incentives and deep discounting led to a surge in auto purchases in October and sent overall U.S. retail sales up sharply. Retail sales rose 7.1 percent in October, the Commerce Department reported Wednesday, dramatically ahead of the 3.2 percent rise expected by economists polled by CBS.MarketWatch.com. October's was the largest monthly rise since the current data series was launched in 1992. See full story. A stunning development at UAL CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- United Airlines is striking back. Aiming to address concerns about how easily hijackers broke into cockpits to perpetrate September's terrorist attacks, United proposed Thursday to arm pilots with stun guns. Its plan also seeks to allay fears that a handgun's errant bullet could easily pierce a jet's hull and depressurize its passenger cabin. The news fueled shares of the carrier UAL, +2.30% of other airline-industry players ($XAL) and of the Taser stun gun's manufacturer, Taser International TASR See full story. Philip Morris thinks it knows what's in a name NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- You've come a long way, baby. Looking to reshape its image, Philip Morris MO, -0.21% proposed to change its corporate name to Altria Group, although its tobacco, food and beer operating units would retain their current monikers. According to Geoffrey Bible, Philip Morris' chief executive, the change results from a "need for clarity" since the corporate parent currently shares the same name as two of its tobacco units. Also, "we are not the same family of companies we were just a few years ago. The Nabisco acquisition and the Kraft initial public offering are the most recent evidence of our growth and evolution," said Bible. See full story. Frequent fliers who want airport shortcuts WASHINGTON (CBS.MW) -- Business travelers are giving a thumbs-up to Congress' airline security package, but road warriors are still asking for more. An overwhelming majority of MarketWatch.com readers who responded to a recent poll support the idea of implementing a travelers' ID system that would allow frequent fliers to bypass long security-checkpoint lines. Only 14 of more than 600 respondents to the unscientific poll opposed the concept of the voluntary pre-screening system, which was recently recommended by a Transportation Department task force. See full story. Net users adjust to dot-com shakeout SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Many Americans' Internet experiences were hurt by the dot-com shakeout, but the majority are finding replacements for defunct sites, and seeking out free alternatives. One out of every six Internet users has been asked to pay for access to a Web site that used to be free, and almost as many have seen their favorite site go under, according to a study by the Pew Internet and American Life Project. "People will want to see new services in the future, they'll want to use the Net for efficiency and more," said Lee Rainie, director of the team that issued the study. See full story. Commentary: There's something about 'Harry' NEW YORK (CBS.MW) -- In Hollywood, kids' movies are a serious business. DreamWorks' "Shrek" has racked up nearly $300 million at the box office. Walt Disney's DIS, +1.93% "Monster's Inc." drew more than $100 million in its first two weeks. With its release of "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone" this weekend, AOL Time Warner AOL chimes in with the first of what might become a seven-film franchise. Family-oriented movies are flourishing because movies that reinforce old-fashioned societal values have a higher place in pop culture than ever. See commentary by Jon Friedman Commentary: Cause for celebration SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- The U.S. response to the September terror attacks has been swift. It has been unmerciful where the Taliban is concerned. And it has been extremely successful within a remarkably short time, giving the U.S. and its allies just cause for celebration. If the economic and financial impact of Sept. 11 proves to be commensurate with the nature and speed of our response to it, as I suggested a day after the attacks (see archived Erdman's World), then as a result of what has happened this week the economic clouds caused by that attack should lift much earlier than even the most optimistic among us could have realistically hoped just a few weeks ago See commentary by Paul Erdman. Commentary: Bears are on the run SAN FRANCISCO (CBS.MW) -- Like the Taliban fleeing before U.S. and Northern Alliance forces, the bears on Wall Street are now on the run from a relentless eight-week-long stock-market rise. Market bulls, and many regular people, people are preparing for the recovery stage in the economy. But the bears aren't convinced the rally is sustainable, and they're lining up to profit from the market's next blow-off. The word among the bears is that any rally that results from more good news from Afghanistan, such as the capture of Osama bin Laden or the fall of Kandahar, will be the trigger to start selling. Both events could happen soon. But for the bears, that would be a last hurrah. See commentary by David Callaway. More from MarketWatch How to Run a Better Meeting: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage Three reasons the stock market’s fundamentals look solid
title: Week's top news stories and commentary

content: CHICAGO (CBS.MW) -- In a bold move to secure cockpits, United Airlines said Thursday it aims to arm all of its pilots with immobilizing stun guns. The news fueled shares of the carrier, of other airline-industry players and of the Taser stun gun's manufacturer, Taser International, in heavy volume. UAL Corp. UAL, +2.30% jumped nearly 7 percent, or 82 cents, to close at $12.71. The industry's main yardstick, the Amex Airline Index ($XAL), extended its three-day rally to 75.71, up 3.98 points, or 5.5 percent. But it was Taser International TASR that got the biggest bang from the news. Taser said it could generate between $700,000 and $800,000 in sales on the United deal. Its shares reached new highs while soaring nearly 23 percent, or $2.35, to $13.16 (see chart below). United said it will place the Tasers -- each is a little bigger than a cell phone -- in lock boxes on all 500 of its planes "very shortly," according to spokesman Andy Plews. Tasers fire two probes up to 15 feet, with strong electrical charges that penetrate the nervous system immediately, knocking people out. They are considered more effective than guns because they work no matter where the probes hit one's body. Taser International claims no one has ever died or suffered a long-term injury from the weapon. Surprisingly, the only maintenance required is a 9-volt battery. "Tasers will incapacitate an attacker without endangering the airplane," said UAL's chief operation officer, Andrew Studdert. An errant bullet from a handgun could pierce a jet's hull and depressurize the cabin. The Air Line Pilots Association praised the United move. "If the bad guys get on the airplanes, you want to keep them out of the cockpits," said Herb Hunter, a captain for United and an ALPA spokesman. "But if they get in the cockpits, we have to have some method of defending ourselves and the planes. "Is it a cure-all or is it perfect? No, but this is a good first step," he added. Hear Captain Hunter talk about Tasers. United is the first major airline to take such a significant step in onboard security. Last month, Mesa Air Group MESA began training its pilots to carry Tasers. "This is an important step in thwarting any potential hijacking attempt," United's Plews said. Yet the Taser plan still needs the assent of the Federal Aviation Administration or Congress. FAA rules prohibit use of a gun of any kind aboard jetliners. Sky marshals are specifically allowed to carry weapons. "We'll review the United proposal without making any commitment either way," said FAA spokesman Paul Takemoto. Approval currently looks unlikely. The FAA turned down the Mesa proposal. United also said Thursday that it is initiating fresh security training procedures for its flight attendants, who have complained about not having been given new directions since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Plews would not reveal what measures United will enact for flight attendants because, he said, terrorists would then find out as well. "Training that addresses the new world since Sept. 11 will begin shortly," he said. More from MarketWatch What Picking Up an Apple Tells You About the Future of Robotics More Coverage My husband sold his grandmother’s house and paid off our mortgage — now his family is threatening to sue Stephen Hawking’s final Reddit post is going viral over its ominous warning about robots Delta flight scare is a reminder never to put electronics in checked baggage
title: United plans to arm pilots with stun guns

content: Zamansky LLC announces that it is investigating Axon Enterprise Inc. AAXN, +3.67% (“Axon”) for potential breaches of fiduciary duties to shareholders. Axon, formerly known as Taser International, is a manufacturer of electrical weapons and body cameras which it sells to local law enforcement departments. If you are a shareholder of Axon, please contact our firm for information. On October 19, 2017, Axon disclosed that it had received a letter of inquiry from the SEC relating to the review of its annual and quarterly reports. The previous day SeekingAlpha published a negative research report by Aparecium Research which raised numerous questions about Axon’s alleged accounting and business practices. The research report raised issues over whether Axon had allegedly inflated and overstated its revenues by improperly recognizing revenue upfront while deferring associated costs. Axon’s stock was damaged by these allegations. According to Jake Zamansky, investment fraud attorney, Axon’s corporate officers and directors owe their shareholders fiduciary duties. The SEC letter and research report raised issues of potential concern for investors, Zamansky says. Our law firm is investigating whether the officers and directors breached their duties to shareholders. What Axon Shareholders Can Do If you are a current shareholder of Axon who purchased before February 2016, and who still holds stock, please contact us to review or discuss your legal rights without obligation or cost to you. Please email jake@zamansky.com or call the law firm at (212) 742-1414. About Zamansky LLC Zamansky LLC is a leading investment fraud law firm with experience handling shareholder derivative actions, and securities, hedge fund, ERISA and shareholder class action litigation. We are investment fraud attorneys who represent both individual and institutional investors. Our practice is nationally recognized for our ability to aggressively prosecute cases and recover investment losses. To learn more about Zamansky LLC, please visit our website, http://www.zamansky.com. View source version on businesswire.com: http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180302005721/en/ SOURCE: Zamansky LLC"> <Property FormalName="PrimaryTwitterHandle" Value="@zamanskylaw Zamansky LLC Jake Zamansky, 212-742-1414 jake@zamansky.com Copyright Business Wire 2018 From MarketWatch How to Get a Job: Advice From Extremely Successful People More Coverage Why tax refunds have lost their sparkle Trump boasts about making up facts about trade deficit to Trudeau Bloodbath for cryptocurrencies as Bitcoin sheds 10%, now down 40% year-to-date
title:
Zamansky LLC Investigates Axon Enterprise (NASDAQ: AAXN) for Potential 
      Breaches of Fiduciary Duties to Shareholders

content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 2, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- Axon AAXN, +3.67% the global leader in connected law enforcement technologies, today announced that the Chicago Police Department, a Major Cities Chiefs Association member, has finalized an agency-wide deployment of body-worn cameras with the recent purchase of 400 Axon Body 2 cameras . The most recent order was received in the fourth quarter of 2017 and will continue to ship through the first quarter of 2018. Chicago Police began equipping officers with Axon Body 2 cameras in 2015. The agency has now deployed around 7,000 cameras backed by Axon's digital evidence management solution, Evidence.com. "The use of body-worn cameras by our entire agency is a huge step towards increasing public safety and accountability in our city," says Chicago Police's Superintendent Eddie Johnson. "The seamless integration of body camera footage onto the Evidence.com cloud platform makes it easy for us to get to the truth of a situation quickly and efficiently." "It's great to see an agency the size of the Chicago Police Department realize the value in fully adopting our body-worn camera technology," says Axon CEO and founder Rick Smith. "By being fully integrated on the Axon network, officers have the ability to seamlessly and securely manage data, allowing them to spend less time at their desks, and more time in their communities."  About Axon Axon is a network of devices, apps, and people that helps law enforcement become smarter and safer. Our mission is to protect life. Our technologies give law enforcement the confidence, focus and time they need to keep their communities safe. Our products impact every aspect of an officer's day-to-day experience: In the field - Our Smart Weapons offer a less-lethal intermediate use of force response and our body-worn and in-car cameras collect video evidence to capture the truth of an incident; and our mobile applications enable simple evidence collection. At the station - Our secure, cloud-based digital evidence management solution allows officers and command staff to manage, review, share, and process digital evidence using forensic, redaction, transcription, and other tools. In the courtroom - Our solutions for prosecutors make collaborating across jurisdictions and agencies easy so that cases can be resolved quickly. We work hard for those who put themselves in harm's way for all of us. To date, there are more than 187,400 licensed users from around the world and more than 196,000 lives and countless dollars have been saved with the Axon Network of devices, apps, and people. Learn more at www.axon.com or by calling (800) 978-2737. Facebook is a trademark of Facebook, Inc., and Twitter is a trademark of Twitter, Inc. Axon, Axon Body 2, Axon Network, the "Axon Delta" logo, Evidence.com, "Protect Life," and Smart Weapons are trademarks of Axon Enterprise, Inc., some of which are registered in the U.S. and other countries. For more information, visit www.axon.com/legal. All rights reserved. Follow Axon here: Axon on Twitter: https://twitter.com/axon_us Axon on Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/Axon.ProtectLife/ Note to Investors Please visit http://investor.axon.com, https://www.axon.com/press, www.twitter.com/axon_us and https://www.facebook.com/Axon.ProtectLife/ where Axon discloses information about the company, its financial information, and its business. Visit our Investor Relations Safe Harbor Statement at: http://investor.axon.com/safeHarbor.cfm For investor relations information please contact Andrea James via email at IR@axon.com. CONTACT: Sydney Siegmeth VP Communications Press@Axon.com   View original content with multimedia:http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/chicago-police-department-purchases-400-axon-body-worn-cameras-now-fully-deployed-300607220.html SOURCE Axon Copyright (C) 2018 PR Newswire. content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Mar 01, 2018 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE via COMTEX) -- AMMO, Inc. POWW, +0.00% a technology leader and premier American ammunitions manufacturer, today announced it has hired Kathy Hanrahan, to serve as the Company's President of Law Enforcement and Military Services. Ms. Hanrahan will maintain her seat on the Company's Board of Directors which she joined in November 2017, and her deep experience and immediate contributions within the law enforcement and military channels make her the perfect fit for the Company's new position. Ms. Hanrahan has vast experience in both the public sector as well as in the law enforcement markets. For nearly 15 years, she held a number of key executive positions at TASER International, Inc., now Axon Enterprise, Inc. AAXN, +3.67% She was Chief Financial Officer during the company's IPO in 2001 and became Chief Operations Officer in 2003, and then President and Chief Operating Officer from 2006 until 2008. Her last position at TASER was as Chief Executive Officer and co-Chairperson for the TASER Foundation for Fallen Officers, a non-profit subsidiary dedicated to serving the families of officers killed in the line of duty. Over the course of her career, Ms. Hanrahan has also held several director positions for a number of corporations in both the profit and non-profit sectors, and currently serves on Shared Performance Systems and SentrySix Defense Group Board of Advisors in addition to serving on the Board of Directors for AMMO, Inc. Ms. Hanrahan is the founder and private management consultant for New Horizons Management Consulting which specializes in assisting small- to medium-sized companies in strategy, financial planning, personnel and infrastructure for growth phases. Among her higher profile clients was LifeLock, Inc., where she served as their interim Chief Financial Officer prior to their initial public offering. Fred W. Wagenhals, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of AMMO Inc., commented, "Kathy has made tremendous contributions to our Company since joining the Board this past November and we are extremely pleased that she is expanding her role by accepting a leadership position to facilitate our channel strategy for the law enforcement, military and international markets. Her expertise in the space is incredibly deep and will be a key component to our success in growing this segment of the business." Ms. Hanrahan commented, "I am excited to join the Team at AMMO Inc., and to be back working in an industry I love. Not since leaving TASER have I been this excited about a new technology, or the possibility to change how the law enforcement and military communities think about defense. The Company's Streak and OPS lines are defining a new era of ammunition, and offering these markets a cost effective alternative for their training and deployment needs. I believe AMMO Inc. will be a disruptive force in the world of policing both in the United States and abroad. And, I know from experience, that these channels present a major opportunity for the Company." About AMMO, Inc. With its corporate offices headquartered in Scottsdale, Arizona, and a manufacturing facility in Payson, Arizona, AMMO, Inc. (the "Company and/or AMMO") designs and manufactures products for a variety of aptitudes, including law enforcement, military, hunting, sport shooting and self-defense. The Company was founded in 2016 with a vision to change, innovate and invigorate the complacent munitions industry. AMMO promotes branded munitions, including its patented STREAK visual ammunition, the Jesse James line of munitions and accessories, /stelTH/ subsonic munitions, and OPS (One Precise Shot) a lead-free frangible tactical line of munitions for self-defense. For more information please visit: www.ammo-inc.com Investor/Media Contact: John Mills ICR, Inc. Phone: (646) 277-1254 john.mills@icrinc.com Copyright (C) 2018 GlobeNewswire, Inc. All rights reserved. From MarketWatch Can the Democrats Ride a Blue Wave to Midterm Election Wins? title: AMMO, Inc. Board Director Kathy Hanrahan Expands Role to President of Law Enforcement and Military Services

content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- ATS Armor LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Achilles Technology Solutions, LLC (ATS) and global designer and manufacturer of advanced, lightweight ballistic solutions, announces entry into the Original Equipment Manufacturer (OEM) market as a ballistic solution provider. "ATS Armor is excited to expand our ballistic offerings into the OEM market," stated Thomas Smith, CEO of ATS and Co-Founder of Axon Enterprise, Inc. AAXN, +3.67%  "We have designed a low-cost series of both standalone and in-conjunction-with hard armor plates that retain the quality and performance standards that the market has been accustomed to with our products. These new series of plates will be offered for private labeling and we have received tremendous interest in our initial talks with potential partners," concluded Mr. Smith. "This is a winning combination for the end user, our private label partners, and ATS Armor," stated Brian Beckwith, COO and Co-Founder of ATS. "In the past, we have concentrated on building the brand of ATS Armor through quality of design and performance. Now, this same quality can be leveraged by our private label partners to instantaneously grow their business by offering a low-cost solution that has exceptional performance and puts quality lifesaving products on the people who selflessly protect us. Our Director of R&D, Eric Gavelda, has designed another exceptional line of armor and we are very excited to offer it to the market," concluded Mr. Beckwith. About Achilles Technology Solutions™ LLC: Achilles Technologies Solutions (ATS) is a holding company for two subsidiaries, ATS Armor LLC and ATS MER, LLC. ATS Armor (www.ATSArmor.com), develops, assembles and markets ballistic solutions for law enforcement and military markets both in the U.S. and abroad. Their ballistic products exceed the requirements as set forth in NIJ Standards for Type threats: II, IIIA, III, and IV along with special threat testing for customized higher performance. ATS MER LLC (dba MER) is research and development focused, headquartered in Tucson, Arizona. ATS MER develops advanced materials and composites for a wide variety of industries. Today, ATS is bringing an array of new and patented ATS MER technologies to market that range from advanced ceramics for ballistic products to innovative energy solutions. ATS and ATS Armor corporate headquarters are located at 7432 East Tierra Buena Lane, Suite 101, Scottsdale Arizona, 85260. title: ATS Armor Enters The OEM Market As A Ballistic Solution Provider

content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 1, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- Axon AAXN, +3.67% the global leader in connected law enforcement technologies, today announced that Virginia Beach Police Department (VBPD), a Major Cities Chiefs Association member, has purchased 1,060 Axon body and in-car cameras on Evidence.com for agency-wide deployment. This order was received in the first quarter of 2018 and will ship in multiple phases. VBPD will roll out 250 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 500 cameras, under the TASER Assurance Plan (TAP). The agency also purchased 560 Axon Body 2 cameras on TAP on Evidence.com and 250 Axon Signal Units. The following significant orders were received from domestic agencies in the fourth quarter of 2017 and first quarter of 2018 and will ship in multiple phases: Austin Police Department (TX): 1,117 Axon Body 2 and 74 Axon Flex 2 cameras on TAP on Evidence.com and 828 Axon Signal PPMs (add-on order) Miami Police Department (FL): 650 Axon Body 2 cameras on TAP with five years on Evidence.com Fayetteville Police Department (NC): 300 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 600 cameras, on TAP on Evidence.com Omaha Police Department (NE): 460 Axon Body 2 cameras on TAP with three years on Evidence.com , 175 Axon Signal Units and 159 Axon Signal PPMs (add-on order) Stamford Police Department (CT): 225 Axon Body 2 cameras, 205 cameras on TAP, with five years of Evidence.com Jupiter Police Department (FL): 220 Axon Body 2 cameras, 110 on the Officer Safety Plan (OSP) and 110 on TAP, with five years on Evidence.com and 110 Axon Signal Units Fort Myers Police Department (FL): 120 Axon Fleet in-car video systems totaling 240 cameras with 120 Axon Signal Units Greensboro Police Department (NC): 215 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 430 cameras, on TAP on Evidence.com and 215 Axon Signal Units Topeka Police Department (KS): 212 Axon Flex 2 cameras on the OSP with five years on Evidence.com Asheville Police Department (NC): 175 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 350 cameras, on TAP on Evidence.com and Axon Signal technology Vacaville Police Department (CA): 105 Axon Body 2 cameras and 60 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 120 cameras, on Evidence.com, 105 Axon Signal PPMs and 60 Axon Signal Units Santa Cruz Police Department (CA): 110 Axon Body 2 cameras on TAP with five years on Evidence.com Lansing Police Department (MI): 62 Axon Fleet in-car video systems, totaling 124 cameras, on Evidence.com on the Unlimited Plan and 25 Axon Flex 2 cameras (add-on order) Doral Police Department (FL): 80 Axon Body 2 cameras on TAP with five years of Evidence.com  About Axon Axon is a network of devices, apps, and people that helps law enforcement become smarter and safer. Our mission is to protect life. Our technologies give law enforcement the confidence, focus and time they need to keep their communities safe. Our products impact every aspect of an officer's day-to-day experience: In the field - Our Smart Weapons offer a less-lethal intermediate use of force response and our body-worn and in-car cameras collect video evidence to capture the truth of an incident; and our mobile applications enable simple evidence collection. At the station - Our secure, cloud-based digital evidence management solution allows officers and command staff to manage, review, share, and process digital evidence using forensic, redaction, transcription, and other tools. In the courtroom - Our solutions for prosecutors make collaborating across jurisdictions and agencies easy so that cases can be resolved quickly. We work hard for those who put themselves in harm's way for all of us. To date, there are more than 187,400 licensed users from around the world and more than 196,000 lives and countless dollars have been saved with the Axon Network of devices, apps, and people. Learn more at www.axon.com or by calling (800) 978-2737. Facebook is a trademark of Facebook, Inc., and Twitter is a trademark of Twitter, Inc. Axon, Axon Body 2, Axon Fleet, Axon Flex 2, Axon Network, Axon Signal, Evidence.com, the "Axon Delta" logo, "Protect Life," and Smart Weapons are trademarks of Axon Enterprise, Inc., some of which are registered in the U.S. and other countries. For more information, visit www.axon.com/legal. All rights reserved. Follow Axon here: Axon on Twitter: https://twitter.com/axon_us Axon on Facebook : https://www.facebook.com/Axon.ProtectLife/ Note to Investors  Please visit http://investor.axon.com, https://www.axon.com/press, www.twitter.com/axon_us and https://www.facebook.com/Axon.ProtectLife/ where Axon discloses information about the company, its financial information, and its business. Visit our Investor Relations Safe Harbor Statement at: http://investor.axon.com/safeHarbor.cfm For investor relations information please contact Andrea James via email at IR@axon.com. content: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Feb. 27, 2018 /PRNewswire/ -- Axon AAXN, +3.67% the global leader in public safety technology, today announced a ten-year CEO performance award for CEO and founder Rick Smith tied entirely to achieving market cap and financial performance milestones that would make Axon one of the most valuable companies in the public safety sector. For the award to fully vest, Axon's market cap would have to grow ten-fold from recent levels to $13.5 billion, and key revenue and profitability goals would also have to be achieved. The award is modeled after the recently announced 2018 Tesla CEO compensation plan for Elon Musk, which the New York Times described as "about as friendly to shareholders as they come." Under this performance award, Rick will only be compensated if Axon generates extraordinary shareholder value. He will not receive a salary or cash bonus, nor any new equity compensation that vests automatically with the passage of time. "Today's announcement bolsters Axon's bold ten-year vision for growth, innovation, and social change with a compensation plan that inspires and motivates," said Hadi Partovi, Axon Board member and CEO of Code.org. "In every technology company I've backed, the long-term vision and drive of the founder/CEO has played a critical role. Axon's plan ensures that Rick is fully committed for the long haul, with outstanding incentives to deliver outstanding results." CEO Performance Award Details The performance award consists of a ten-year grant of stock options that vests in 12 tranches. Each of the 12 tranches vests only if a pair of milestones are both met. Market Cap Milestones: The first set of milestones are based on Axon's six-month average market cap with the first milestone at $2.5 billion, nearly double the average today. For each of the remaining eleven milestones, Axon's market cap must continue to increase in $1 billion increments. For the full award to vest, Axon's market cap must increase to $13.5 billion - more than ten times the company's market cap today using the same six-month average. Financial Performance Milestones: To meet the financial performance milestones, Axon must achieve a set of escalating revenue or adjusted EBITDA targets chosen to motivate top-line and bottom-line operational rigor. Revenue milestones start at approximately two times current levels and adjusted EBITDA milestones start at approximately three times current levels. (The revenue and EBITDA targets aren't matched to each other. This structure ensures a focus on proving the profitability of new lines of business while not becoming a constraint against investment flexibility in the long run.)   By combining market cap, revenue, and EBITDA milestones, Rick is motivated to generate long-term value for shareholders through delivering operational results, without incentives to engage in short-term measures. For each of the 12 tranches that is achieved, Rick will vest in 538,488 stock option shares (corresponding to 1% of Axon's current outstanding shares). If none of the market cap or financial performance objectives are achieved, Rick will receive no compensation. Leading Axon's Mission to Protect Life While Driving Growth and Profitability Rick has been instrumental to Axon's market leadership in less lethal weapons, body cameras, and evidence management software. Axon has an even bolder vision for the next ten years: to make the bullet obsolete, and to enhance transparency in our justice systems ensuring fair, effective justice for all. Our weapons have saved 196,000 lives and are broadly used by law enforcement worldwide. Rick's personal goal is to launch a TASER weapon that can outperform a lethal handgun within the next decade, offering a new solution to the problems of gun violence, which are painfully highlighted by recent events. Our wearable cameras and cloud services have transformed public safety, bringing the light of transparency to corners of society where brave men and women confront dangers most of us never see. We plan to revolutionize this sector further with artificial intelligence technology to help law enforcement save time and save lives. Rick remains Axon's largest individual shareholder, and today's award (which is contingent on his continued leadership) ensures his commitment and focus on delivering on a ten-year vision that can increase shareholder value. Modeled After the 2018 Tesla CEO Compensation Plan Upon reviewing the recently-announced Tesla CEO compensation plan, the Axon Board was impressed with the design of the plan to maximize alignment with shareholders while accounting for future unforeseen events. The Tesla plan stood out because it represents 100% pay-for-performance, motivates a long-term commitment, and aligns CEO compensation with value creation for all stakeholders, including employees, customers and shareholders. Consequently, the Axon Board has mindfully endeavored to mirror the Tesla plan with deviations only where it felt Axon's circumstances are different. Rick's performance award is structurally similar to the Tesla plan, with numbers adjusted for Axon's scale, business model, and objectives. Axon's Compensation Committee engaged Compensia Inc., Aon Equity Services and Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati — the same external compensation and legal experts who assisted Tesla in creating its plan, as well as the law firm of Snell & Wilmer. Readers will note this press release, and the upcoming proxy statement, are similar in format to the Tesla plan documentation. This is intentional, to help any shareholders, analysts and other parties who have invested time to understand Elon Musk's plan to more easily understand the Axon CEO award. Upcoming Shareholder Vote The Board granted this award to Rick on February 26, 2018 with Rick recusing himself, and its effectiveness is subject to the approval of Axon's shareholders, who will vote on it at the Axon Annual Stockholder meeting on May 24. Rick Smith will also recuse himself from that vote. Any shareholder of record or beneficial owner of Axon shares as of the record date (currently projected to be March 26, 2018) will be entitled to vote their shares at the 2018 Annual Meeting and the award will only become effective if a majority of the votes cast are in favor of the proposal. Axon will release its full proxy statement providing complete details of the award along with additional materials for Axon shareholders in the next few weeks. Proxy Statement Information Axon plans to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission (the "SEC"), and furnish to its shareholders a proxy statement in connection with the proposed CEO performance award. This proxy statement will contain important information about the proposed award and related matters. AXON SHAREHOLDERS ARE URGED TO READ THESE MATERIALS AND ANY OTHER RELEVANT DOCUMENTS THAT AXON WILL FILE WITH THE SEC WHEN THEY BECOME AVAILABLE BECAUSE THEY WILL CONTAIN IMPORTANT INFORMATION ABOUT AXON AND THE CEO PERFORMANCE AWARD. Shareholders will be able to obtain free copies of these documents and other documents filed with the SEC by Axon through the website maintained by the SEC at www.sec.gov. In addition, shareholders will be able to obtain free copies of these documents from Axon's Investor Relations page at http://investor.axon.com. The directors and executive officers of Axon may be deemed to be participants in the solicitation of proxies from the stockholders of Axon in connection with the CEO Performance Award. The following directors and executive officers of Axon are participants in the solicitation: Directors Michael Garnreiter, Hadi Partovi, Mark W. Kroll, Dr. Richard Carmona, Bret Taylor, Matthew McBrady, and Julie Anne Cullivan, as well as Patrick W. Smith, Director and CEO, Luke S. Larson, President, Jawad Ahsan, Chief Financial Officer, Douglas E. Klint, General Counsel, and Josh M. Isner, Chief Revenue Officer. None of such participants owns in excess of 1% of the Company's common stock except for Patrick Smith, who beneficially owns 2.4% of the Company's outstanding common stock. Additional information regarding the interests of participants in the solicitation of proxies in respect of the Annual Meeting will be included in the Proxy Statement. Forward-Looking Statements Certain statements herein, including statements regarding future development plans, are forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties. These forward-looking statements are based on management's current expectations. Various important factors could cause actual results to differ materially, including the risks identified in our SEC filings. Axon disclaims any obligation to update any forward-looking statement contained in this press release. Note to Investors Please visit http://investor.axon.com, https://www.axon.com/press, www.twitter.com/axon_us and https://www.facebook.com/Axon.ProtectLife/ where Axon discloses information about the company, its financial information, and its business. Visit our Investor Relations Safe Harbor Statement at: http://investor.axon.com/safeHarbor.cfm For investor relations information please contact Andrea James via email at IR@axon.com. CONTACT:  Investor Relations Axon  IR@axon.com   View original content with multimedia:http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/axon-ceo-rick-smith-relinquishes-salary-for-ten-year-performance-plan-300605253.html SOURCE Axon Copyright (C) 2018 PR Newswire.
